title: Artful Technology
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Land Trusts Multiplying, Study Shows
description: Land trusts, once restricted to genteel corners of New England, are now growing the fastest in the Rockies and the Southwest, according to a new national survey of this land conservation movement.

title: Clinton Putting Off Visits to India and Pakistan
description: The White House said today that President Clinton had put off a visit to India and Pakistan, whose tests of nuclear devices in May set off alarm around the world.

title: Albany to Buy 145 Staten Island Acres
description: Gov. George E. Pataki intends to announce today that New York State will pay $25 million to acquire one of the last large undeveloped shoreline tracts in New York City, a 145-acre stretch of red clay bluffs, marsh and meadows on the south shore of Staten Island.

title: Disenchanted but Packing a Punch
description: Bob Mould has a song for every kind of ending: bitter rejections, protracted breakups, suicidal thoughts, last-ditch conversions, hopes for new beginnings. So he had plenty of repertory to choose from for his sold-out shows on Friday and Saturday night at Irving Plaza, which were part of what he has said will be his final tour leading an electric rock band. His new album is called ''The Last Dog and Pony Show'' (Rykodisc), and while 37-year-old Mr. Mould isn't retiring, he wants a change of format. On Saturday night, he made fans wish that he would change his mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, DOROTHY LIFSHEY
description: KESSLER - Dorothy Lifshey. Passed away Tuesday, September 29, after a long illness. She leaves her beloved daughters Ilene Wechter, Rona Miller, sons-in-law Arnie and Buddy; six grandsons, Hugh, Andrew, Marc, Lawrence, Lee and their wives Susan, Pam, Robin, Lauren and six greatgrandchildren and sisters, Shirley & Sylvia & brother-in-law Walter. She will live on in our memories. Services Friday, Oct. 2, 10AM at Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam.

title: ABC Radio Loses Contract Lawsuit
description: The Walt Disney Company's ABC Radio Networks lost a $20 million breach of contract verdict today after a jury decided that the network misappropriated the design of a children's radio service from its onetime partner.

title: In a Town Destroyed, Dominicans Salvage Little but the Will to Go On
description: Miguel Montero and his family fled their home in this remote precinct of the town of San Juan last week after radio reports warned that a hurricane was headed their way.

title: Business Confidence Plunges in Japan
description: Japan's corporate managers are the most pessimistic they have been in four years as the economy languishes in recession. But they do not expect conditions to worsen in the months ahead, the Bank of Japan reported today in a widely watched survey of business sentiment.

title: Asylum-Seekers Are Confined To Dormitories After Protest
description: Detainees at the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center here -- the scene of a violent uprising by immigrants in 1995 -- are being confined to their dormitories in response to a hunger strike over conditions and privileges.

title: Now Playing At House Museums: The Tell-All Tour
description: THEY weren't interested in going to the beach because they don't like sand. We'd already eaten lunch and gone window shopping in East Hampton. All right then, why not take Mom and Dad on a tour of Eastern Long Island's primary art-history attraction, the Pollock-Krasner house? It's going to be a big year for Pollock, I explained, with the retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in November. Without much enthusiasm, they agreed we should check it out.

title: U.S. Charges Bin Laden Suspect in Larger Plot
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have charged an associate of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in the embassy bombings in August in Africa, with taking part in a conspiracy to attack United States military sites abroad.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's reticence on President Clinton's future referred imprecisely to the contrasting stance of New York's senior Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan. While other Democrats have used the words ''reprehensible'' or ''immoral'' to describe President Clinton's behavior with Monica S. Lewinsky, and while Senator Moynihan praised the critical speech of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, Mr. Moynihan has personally declared only that the President's apology was ''not adequate'' and that the conduct involved a ''moral issue.''

title: White House to Increase Efforts To Help Fight Software Piracy
description: Vice President Al Gore will announce today a stepped-up program intended to help combat software piracy worldwide.

title: Man Sues After Daughter Is Burned in Foster Care
description: A man whose infant daughter was severely burned while living in a foster home has filed a lawsuit charging that New York City and a nonprofit foster care agency failed in its duty to care for the child.

title: Save That Legend! Preservationists To the Rescue
description: AT a $1,000-a-plate benefit on Oct. 1 with the actor Brad Pitt as host, this city will toast the restoration of the Robert R. Blacker House, a national treasure and one of the celebrated Ultimate Bungalows designed at the turn of the century by the Arts and Crafts architects Greene & Greene.

title: In America; A Stadium For Everyone
description: The Borough President of the Bronx was up early on Tuesday. A baseball season so sweet it seemed like a child's fantasy was about to enter the crucial playoff stage. The Yankees, the sweetest of teams in this sweetest of seasons, would take the field Tuesday night against the Rangers of Texas. In Yankee Stadium. In the Bronx.

title: J.A.L. President Sees Fall in First-Half Profit
description: The Japan Airlines Company, the nation's biggest airline, said yesterday that its first-half operating profit would be lower than expected because of a decline in sales attributed to Japan's weak economy. J.A.L.'s president, Isao Kaneko, did not give an estimate of operating profit for the six months that ended yesterday. J.A.L.'s latest forecast, issued at the end of May, had operating profit at 43 billion yen ($314 million) for the year ending in March 1999.

title: Biloxi Journal; Off City on Gulf Coast, Casinos Ride Out Storm
description: The locals call it the Mississippi Miracle. But proud as they are of the glittering gambling casinos that over the last six years have turned this once-seedy Gulf Coast town into something akin to Atlantic City South, the people of Biloxi have always had in the back of their minds that, well, if the time ever comes when the chips are really down during hurricane season, Biloxi might need a more heavenly kind of miracle.

title: To Surf, Perchance To Dream
description: IF you dream that your hard drive is crashing, do you wake up just before the Fatal System Error message appears? What would be the meaning of a dream about a cursor that was frozen, not flashing, on a blank screen? And in scrutinizing nightmares about computers, are there times when a hard drive is really just a hard drive?

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Censure Isn't Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Teheran Journal; Lifting the Veil, Just a Bit, on West's Decadent Art
description: Propaganda placards around Teheran proclaim that a woman hidden by Islamic dress codes is like ''a pearl in a shell.''

title: Conagra Unit Adds Duties to Agency
description: The Hunt-Wesson unit of Conagra Inc. in Fullerton, Calif., said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago by naming that agency to handle advertising for its Wesson/ Peter Pan Foods Company, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

title: Avoiding Log-Offs
description: To the Editor:

title: REIT Takes a Partner
description: First Industrial Realty Trust Inc. has formed a partnership with the Carlyle Group L.P. to invest in industrial properties in the United States. First Industrial, a real estate investment trust, or REIT, said the partnership would buy $300 million in bulk-warehouse and light-industrial properties. Carlyle Group is a private equity investment firm in Washington. First Industrial, based in Chicago, has assets of about $2.27 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THURMAN, BARRY LEO
description: THURMAN-Barry Leo. We miss you terribly, still. Much love, AJW and friend

title: Movie Tickets, and Hats and T-Shirts
description: Movielink.com, the popular Internet film guide, is not just for hunting down what's showing at the local cineplex or buying movie tickets on line anymore.

title: Brown Promoted to Start As Giant Running Back
description: Jim Fassel today named Gary Brown the new starting running back, relegating the former starter Tiki Barber to third-down duties while keeping Tyrone Wheatley in his narrow, modest role.

title: Home Sales Down Again; Economic Indicators Flat
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell in August for the second consecutive month, a sign that the lowest mortgage rates in more than three decades might not be enough to give the housing market, and the economy, a lift in coming months. Separately, a measure of future economic activity held steady during August.

title: Pinball Still Alive in an Electronic World
description: IN an age of video games, home computers and virtual-reality snowboarding at the mall, pinball games may sound like something from the 50's, or from, at best, the glory days of the Who and its rock opera, ''Tommy.''

title: Big Board Considers Revision Of Rule on Stock-Option Plans
description: A New York Stock Exchange task force will recommend modifications today in a recent controversial ruling on certain stock-option plans that do not require shareholder approval.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Volume of New Issues Slows Sharply
description: Wall Street's core business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- slowed significantly in the third quarter after relatively smooth growth in recent years.

title: Officials Scrambling to Assess Managed Health Care in Jails
description: As investigations expand into possible problems with medical care in city jails, including several deaths, top New York City health officials have acknowledged that they have had trouble monitoring the jail system's shift to managed care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, LUCILLE
description: GLUCKMAN - Lucille. Beloved wife of Sol, devoted mother of Barrie Miller and Miles Gluckman. Cherished grandmother of Lloyd & Rona Miller. Services Thursday, 10AM at ''Riverside NassauNorth'', Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Unleashing the Power of the Pen
description: WHEN Dr. Oreste Bruni rushes around the emergency room at the Massapequa General Hospital in Seaford, N.Y., hands-on medicine is not his only occupation. Like all doctors in that fast-paced world, he's busy taking notes -- notes to guide later treatment and help insure payment for both him and the hospital. Such notes can even become vital evidence if a malpractice suit is filed.

title: MetroStars Come Apart On Defense
description: Bora Milutinovic's success as coach in the World Cup failed to rub off on the MetroStars in his first playoff game in Major League Soccer tonight. Milutinovic's newest team suffered a 5-3 loss to the Columbus Crew at Ohio Stadium to fall behind in their first playoff series in two years.

title: INSIDE
description: Gloomy I.M.F. Forecast

title: Ambitious Voice of a Pugnacious Weekly
description: AT first glance, Russ Smith does not look as if he belongs in the Chelsea offices of The New York Press, the pugnacious, profane weekly newspaper that turned 10 years old this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LOTTIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lottie. Love always. Beyond space and time. George

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Subversion of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Latest Enemy Giuliani Vows To Vanquish: The Pothole
description: Having all but declared victory in his war on crime and tackled such urban nemeses as squeegee men, jaywalkers and reckless cabdrivers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he was on the verge of eliminating one of New York City's most jarring ills: the pothole.

title: Catherine, Also Great As a Collector
description: ''Master Drawings From the Hermitage and Pushkin Museums,'' at the Pierpont Morgan Library, could not fail to be a remarkable exhibition. The collections now in the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, Russia, were initiated by Catherine the Great in ways, and on a scale, that could not be paralleled today. They were powered by greed and impatience on the one hand and by dexterous networking on the other.

title: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; Doing the Homework: Reviews of Most Models
description: AT its core, picking out a car hasn't changed. You still sit at the kitchen table and figure out what kind of car you need, how much you can spend, despair briefly at the difference and then march into a showroom, only to have your head turned by that sports car, that convertible, that sport utility vehicle, or whatever it is you really want, rather than merely need.

title: On Eve of Key Meeting, I.M.F. Paints a Gloomy Global Picture
description: In an unusually pessimistic report, the International Monetary Fund said today that it now expects the Russian economy to contract by 6 percent this year and next, and Japan to sink into its deepest recession since the end of World War II.

title: South Korea Cuts A Key Interest Rate
description: South Korea's central bank cut its key interest rate yesterday by a full percentage point in an effort to ease the credit squeeze that is hurting many South Korean companies. The Bank of Korea lowered its overnight call rate, the rate it charges commercial banks for overnight loans, to 7 percent from 8 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 3 about a woman in Chatham, Mass., who helped the police negotiate the surrender of a man who had held her daughter hostage referred incorrectly to the relationship between the woman and the man, John Nutter. The woman, Lori Urs, never lived with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTENBERG, REGINA CHARITON
description: WATTENBERG-Regina Chariton. The staff and trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are saddened by the passing of Regina Chariton Wattenberg, mother of Lily C. Kaplan and mother-in-law of JBFCS President Joseph S. Kaplan. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Kaplan family. Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Jean L. Troubh, Chairwoman, Executive Committee Alan B. Siskind, Phd, Executive Vice President

title: Fans Flock To the Web
description: EARLIER this summer Carolyn Hack got the thrill of her life. Carolyn, a 15-year-old high-school student fromOverland Park, Mo., was in line to ride the roller coaster at an amusement park in Kansas City, Mo., when she and her friends saw the actor Leonardo DiCaprio emerge from one of the cars. After the requisite hysteria, Carolyn's response fit a modern teen-age template: she rode in the same car the actor had sat in; then she went home and wrote a detailed account of the experience for her Web site.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Foreigners Don't Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Drops Currency Trigger
description: The Bank of Canada has abandoned its policy of regular, predictable intervention in currency markets in defense of the Canadian dollar in favor of a more discretionary approach, bank officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of the House & Home section last Thursday about the redesign of the Japan Society building in Manhattan referred incorrectly to a rush and bamboo fence that the society's president, William Clark Jr., found for it. The fence was from Japan, not China.

title: The Criminal Mind As a Mystery's Goal Across 5 Evenings
description: Can you justify doing evil to destroy evil? That is one of the dark questions that slowly emerge from the absorbing, unsettling five-part series that begins this season of ''Mystery.'' ''Touching Evil'' has a dashing detective hero, Dave Creegan. But this is no frothy cat-and-mouse game; it is a collection of twisted contemporary tales in which Creegan, part of a team of high-powered London detectives, comes face to face with unspeakable killers.

title: Northwest Farms and Industry Pinched by Asia's Fiscal Crisis
description: The huge piles of golden grain that rise like sand dunes along the banks of the Columbia and Snake Rivers are a beautiful sight, but to the wheat farmers of the Pacific Northwest, they are a sign of deep trouble. In a normal year, 90 percent of the region's wheat crop is exported to Asia, but this is not a normal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSZ, BETTY
description: GROSZ-Betty. With loving devotion from sons Michael and John, daughter Monique Goldwasser; grandchildren Jeffrey, Lauren, Kathy, Pamela and Rebecca, and great grandchildren Liam Haller and Talia Goldwasser. Au revoir.

title: Players and Owners Agree to Resume Their Talks
description: With the reality of canceling regular-season games a month away, National Basketball Association players and owners have decided to go back to the bargaining table for the first time in nearly two months.

title: THOMAS & BETTS TO BUY KAUFEL FOR $98 MILLION AND DEBT
description: The Thomas & Betts Corporation, a maker of electronic connectors and components, agreed to buy Kaufel Group for about $160 million in cash and debt to expand into foreign markets and add to its product line. Kaufel, an emergency lighting products maker based in Montreal, has plants in the United States, Canada, Barbados, Europe, Australia and New Zealand. Thomas & Betts, of Memphis, will offer Kaufel's shareholders $8 (Canadian) a share, worth a total of roughly $98 million (United States), and will assume the company's debt. Kaufel's board recommended that shareholders accept the offer.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about a trip to Florida by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to raise money for the Republican Party misstated the name of a local political group with which he was to meet. It was the Cuban American National Foundation, not the National Cuban Federation.

title: A Drummer, Different And Yet In the Groove
description: In 1980, when the drummer Bobby Previte first landed in New York, clubs were flowering and real estate wasn't. The downtown scene was extraordinarily fertile, with composers and musicians using the freedom that playing in little-known spots in front of friendly, art-hungry audiences gave them. Cheap rents allowed musicians to work at music and kept young musicians migrating to the city.

title: Correction
description: An Editorial Notebook on Tuesday erroneously credited Northwestern with victory in the 1996 Rose Bowl. U.S.C. won that game, 41 to 32.

title: FORD AND JARDINE MAY JOIN IN BRITISH CAR RETAILER BID
description: The Ford Motor Company and Jardine Motors Group P.L.C. said yesterday that they were in talks and had agreed in principle to set up a car retailing venture that might buy Dagenham Motors Group P.L.C., Britain's largest Ford car retailer, which is valued at about $:25 million ($41.5 million). Ford is the world's second-largest car maker behind General Motors, and Jardine is the British motor retailing unit of Jardine International Motor Holdings Ltd. The move comes as car makers increasingly seek to take control of their sales networks in key markets. A joint venture would include the Jardine-owned Ford dealerships in Britain, which include Polar Motor Group Ltd. and BPW Group Ltd.

title: This Space Available on AOL Starting for a Mere $25,000
description: For the Web surfer who has everything, the new Neiman Marcus Christmas catalogue offers an exclusive spot on the menu of America Online. The price tag: just $25,000.

title: Long Exile Is Ending at Hotel Damaged in Scaffolding Collapse
description: For 10 weeks and 2 days, Titus Wright longed for a night in his own bed and a chance to stroll the halls of the hotel he has called home for nine years.

title: Judge Backs School On Control Over Chicago Auditorium
description: In the battle for control over the historic Auditorium Theater here, a judge ruled this week that Roosevelt University, the owner of the theater, can maintain sole ownership, dismissing claims by a community group that had managed the theater for 38 years that it should have a stake in the building.

title: Airlines' Shares Drop On Analyst's Forecast
description: Shares of British Airways P.L.C. and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines dived yesterday after ABN Amro lowered its full-year profit forecasts for each of the carriers and cut its recommendations on their shares. British Airways shares fell 12 pence, to 360, on the London exchange and hit their lowest level in almost four years, while KLM shares fell 3.9 guilders, to 47.5, in Amsterdam and touched their lowest level in about 22 months.

title: Hoping to Control Spread of AIDS, China Bans the Sale of Blood
description: Reflecting a growing awareness that China's heavy reliance on paid blood donors is contributing to the rapid spread of AIDS, a new law banning the buying and selling of blood takes effect on Thursday.

title: When a Dancer's Shape Surprises the Audience
description: Dance is an accommodating art, shepherding all comers under its umbrella. This season, for instance, there are dancing horses, in the form of Zingaro, and puppet shows. The long list has also included performance art, ice and roller skating and wheelchair choreography. Still, dancegoers tend to be surprised -- even exhilarated or dismayed -- by performers who are larger, smaller, heavier or older than the norm.

title: FISCAL YEAR ENDS WITH U.S. SURPLUS, FIRST IN 3 DECADES
description: President Clinton announced today that the Government was ending the fiscal year with a budget surplus of about $70 billion, the first since 1969 and the largest on record. ''It is a landmark achievement,'' he said.

title: Soccer by Satellite
description: To the Editor:

title: Poised For Takeoff Or Standing
description: New pieces from Brueton Industries don't just sit there; they look as if they might want to move. The three-legged Gepetto occasional tables by Stanley Jay Friedman, above, seem capable of walking the hors d'oeuvres around.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Where Is Sisterhood?
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Resurrects Reddy Kilowatt
description: After 25 years in retirement, Reddy Kilowatt, the lightning-bolt character that promoted the use of electricity, is making a comeback.

title: Charlie Zito, Village Figure And Baker, Is Dead at 78
description: Charlie Zito, whose family bakery provided Greenwich Villagers with crusty, yeasty Italian bread for decades before it became fashionable, died of colon cancer on Friday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 78 -- four years older than the plain little Bleecker Street shop where he was a fixture -- and he lived in Brooklyn.

title: THE REBIRTH OF A LEGEND
description: Once pillaged for its fixtures and stained-glass doors, a 1907 Greene & Greene masterpiece in Pasadena, Calif., is restored with skillful copies. By Joseph Giovannini. (Alan Weintraub for The New York Times)

title: Despite Cut in Rates, Stocks Fall As Investors Choose U.S. Bonds
description: Worries about containing the economic crisis abroad and fears of financial problems at home prompted investors to sell stocks and buy bonds yesterday, pushing long-term Government yields below 5 percent for the first time in more than 30 years.

title: Pettitte Stymies Rangers and Stops His Slump
description: About 100 letters addressing Andy Pettitte's slump have landed in the locker of Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach. Stottlemyre reads them all and dismisses them all, believing Pettitte has always possessed his own antidote.

title: Hedge Fund's Creditors Name Investment Supervisory Group
description: Six leading members of the bank consortium that rescued the speculative hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management from collapse last week have named a full-time committee to supervise the fund's huge investment portfolio -- and promised to keep trading information secret from themselves.

title: A Primary Political Problem
description: Now that Gov. Pete Wilson of California has signed a bill moving his state's Presidential primary to March 7, the process of electing a President in the year 2000 will probably include a primary season that is too hasty and a general election campaign that is too long. Unless the nation's political leaders move to intervene, the next Presidential nominees will almost certainly be decided in the late winter, in a flurry of West and East Coast primaries that follow close on the heels of New Hampshire. That will be followed by an eight-month campaign for President, while the voters wallow in boredom and buyer's remorse.

title: Essay; October Surprise
description: President Clinton has invited Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat back to Washington about two weeks before Election Day. At that time they are expected to reach interim agreement on another transfer of West Bank land, with Palestinian reciprocity, and thereby begin final-settlement talks.

title: Worthy Of Chubby Checker
description: During a dinner party, there's nothing like a dish that bounces up and down, or a vase that wriggles like a Slinky. The Boing Dish, above, and the Mutant Vase, top, both by Giovanni Pellone, an industrial designer, were introduced by Benza at the Accent on Design show in August, where Benza won a nomination for best product line.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS AHEAD OF CENTRAL BANK REPORT. Japan's currency fell before the release of a central bank quarterly business survey that was expected to show deepening gloom. The dollar rose to 136.75 yen, from 134.45 Tuesday.

title: Classic Cartoons Take an Interactive Turn
description: EH, what's up, Doc?

title: HOECHST AND KOHLBERG KRAVIS RETHINK HERBERTS DEAL
description: Hoechst A.G., the European drug maker, said yesterday that it was still in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company on the price of the Herberts paint unit, which Kohlberg Kravis has agreed in principle to buy. Hoechst suggested that Kohlberg Kravis, the largest buyout firm in the United States, was pushing to pay less than the 3 billion marks ($1.79 billion) announced last month for Herberts, which makes paints for the European auto industry. Since then, chemical companies' shares have plunged on concern that recession in several markets will dampen worldwide growth and depress commodity prices. The continuing talks were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

title: AT&T CONFIRMS EFFORT TO BUY I.B.M.'S GLOBAL NETWORK
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the International Business Machines Corporation's Global Network, an acquisition that would bolster AT&T's services business. I.B.M. is believed to be asking $3 billion to $4 billion for the network. AT&T said that the talks were in the early stages and that it was among several companies investigating the purchase of Global Network, which provides consumer access to the Internet and is used by companies to send information worldwide. ''The discussions are so premature, it's not fruitful to say anything more,'' said Rick Roscitt, president and chief executive of AT&T Solutions, the company's services arm.

title: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; The Right Car at (Maybe) the Right Price
description: WHEN Jonathan M. Zenilman decided to trade in his five-year old Plymouth Voyager for a newer model, he looked in the paper, drove by some lots and then he got serious. He went on line.

title: Extreme Cordlessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Problem Loans at Japan's Fuji Bank
description: Fuji Bank Ltd., Japan's sixth-largest lender, said today that it had 2.56 trillion yen ($18.8 billion) in problem loans that were not covered by loan-loss reserves as of March 31.

title: Bottom Of Order Delivers Once More
description: In taking a 2-0 lead in their division series with the Texas Rangers, the Yankees seem to be using two different batting orders: their top six are hitting only .125 (5 for 40) while the bottom three, notably Scott Brosius and the rookie Shane Spencer, have a .529 average (9 for 17) with two homers, all five runs batted in and all six runs scored.

title: Dan Quisenberry, 45, Submarine-Style Pitcher
description: Dan Quisenberry, the star reliever of the Kansas City Royals who was known for his delivery of submarine-style pitches on the mound and one-line quips off the field, died yesterday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 45.

title: Come Rain or Come Shine (Expect Rain)
description: IT might seem to some (although not to anyone in the path of Hurricane Georges) that the hot, dry summer will never end. But it will. It always does. For the gray days ahead, there are doormats of teak or some modeled after 18th-century ironwork. And for umbrellas, there's a stand that's a snakes-in-the-grass combo.

title: War Crimes Panel Seeks a Way For Massacre Survivor to Testify
description: Investigators were trying today to get the lone survivor of a mass shooting in Kosovo out of Serbia to testify about the killings at a war crimes tribunal.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Check the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Haskell, 79, a Singer and TV Announcer
description: Jack Haskell, a familiar face to television viewers for some 30 years, first as the easygoing sidekick of Dave Garroway and then as a regular stand-in on Jack Paar's and Johnny Carson's shows, died on Saturday at the Actors Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 79.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Time to Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: An Easy Line to Draw
description: This is not the first time the House Judiciary Committee has been called on to determine whether actions of the President in his private life rise to the level of ''high crimes and misdemeanors.'' In 1974, we were members of the House Judiciary Committee that considered evidence that Richard Nixon committed tax fraud while President. The panel concluded that personal misconduct is not an impeachable offense.

title: Manhattan Through a Warped Window; Featured in a Film: A Homeless Tour Guide's Offbeat City View
description: Drawing notice in Greenwich Village's Washington Square Park is no easy feat, but as Timothy Levitch ambled through it Monday afternoon, eyes turned, brows furrowed and one or two jaws summarily dropped.

title: High Failure Rate for New PC's Is Found In a Magazine Survey
description: Imagine driving off the lot in a brand-new car only to find that the radio does not work, that the tires are falling off and that the steering wheel will turn only left.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want to write books or go on television or be a big star. My philosophy is come out here, do the job and get out, go home.''

title: Beyond Gray Skies and Little Lambs
description: Leave it to Julie Wilson, the most intensely theatrical of cabaret performers, to find unexpected psychological resonances in the jaunty, carefree songs of George and Ira Gershwin. Or would it be more accurate to say that the elegant 73-year-old singer infuses these songs with such powerful echoes of her own life experience that their wittily turned romantic phrases acquire a new reflective depth?

title: After Losing It Early, the Indians Win It
description: It was supposed to be a showdown between two pitchers: Dwight Gooden, the Cleveland Indians' once celebrated veteran in search of his first post-season victory, and Tim Wakefield, the soft-throwing knuckleball pitcher for the Boston Red Sox.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Dream Analysis; Meaning of the Monitor
description: Can dreams tell people something about their relationship to technology? Many people who report having such dreams say they can. Following are a computer-related dream and several interpretations of it:

title: It Was a Dark and Stormy Rewrite . . .
description: JONATHAN HARR is a homebody. His world by day and most nights -- is a book-lined study at the front of a turn-of-the-century Victorian house in this college town. In his study, Mr. Harr spent eight years writing ''A Civil Action,'' a nonfiction blockbuster that has sold a million copies since its publication in 1995. The story of an ambitious lawyer with a passion for social justice, Mr. Harr's book follows a lawsuit against two companies accused of dumping toxic wastes and causing leukemia in children in Woburn, Mass.

title: Bankers Trust Has Exposure To Funds but Sees No Losses
description: Amid continuing concerns about the troubled world of high-octane investment vehicles known as hedge funds, the Bankers Trust Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had about $1 billion in exposure to such funds.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, said it had named Christian Yates to the new position of managing director and head of international mutual fund sales.

title: Yankees to Switch From Channel 11 to Channel 5
description: Channel 5 is expected to announce today a deal to carry 50 Yankees games in 1999 and 2000, replacing Channel 11 as the team's television broadcaster, according to industry executives.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Plunges 237.90; Long Bond Yields 4.97%

title: Astros Raise Possibility Of Johnson in Game 3
description: Randy Johnson has a four-game losing streak in the playoffs after being outpitched by Kevin Brown on Tuesday in Houston's 2-1 loss to San Diego. But Johnson may get a chance to break that streak -- and possibly face Brown again -- sooner than anybody thought.

title: Dominicans Are Left With Little to Repair
description: Hurricane Georges struck hardest in the western part of the Dominican Republic, a region where most of the nation's 249 storm-related deaths occurred. A week later, residents of one village have returned to find little left to repair. Yet, with rescue workers arriving and wreckage slowly being cleared away, many are already trying to look past this ordeal.

title: How Chasing a Star Structured a Boy's Life
description: ROCKET BOYS

title: Anwar's Arrest and Injuries Shake Faith in the Country : In Malaysia, Sense of Disbelief
description: KUALA LUMPUR  When Anwar Ibrahim appeared in court here with bruises around his left eye and on his arms  injuries that he asserted had been inflicted by the police  it was a jolt for Malaysians, who just a month earlier regarded Mr. Anwar as the heir apparent to become Malaysia's next leader.

title: I.M.F. Urged By Russian Not to Give More Aid
description: Russia's former tax chief urged the West today not to provide further financial aid unless Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov takes drastic measures to develop a market economy.

title: Accounts
description: * Infinium Software, Hyannis, Mass., to Philip Johnson Associates, Boston, to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled by Harpell/Martins, Maynard, Mass. Carat Freeman, Newton, Mass., continues to handle the media portion of the account. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Big Amount Withdrawn From Equity Funds
description: Investors made net withdrawals of $11.2 billion from equity mutual funds in August, the biggest outflow on record and the first month in eight years that more money flowed out of stock funds than went in, according to industry statistics released yesterday.

title: Parents and Children Discuss Lewinsky Case, a Poll Finds
description: The crisis in the White House has caught the attention of America's young people, according to a poll released yesterday, with parents reporting that as many as 30 percent of their teen-agers had watched part of President Clinton's grand jury testimony and 21 percent had read at least part of the Starr report.

title: Connecticut To Increase Speed Limit
description: When Connecticut legislators called this session for raising the state's speed limit above 55 miles per hour, many said that, as drivers themselves, they had to go faster than 55 just to keep up with traffic.

title: High Style Along the Raritan
description: High fashion on the Raritan? Not likely, at least not until the new Boyd Park, right, opened in New Brunswick, N.J., and became the stylish background for eight pages in the fall fashion issue of Time Out magazine.

title: Stock Playing Way On to Team
description: RED WINGS 2, RANGERS 1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAROBIN, NORMA (NEE ROSEN)
description: STAROBIN-Norma (nee Rosen). Died on September 27, 1998, after a long illness of cancer. Devoted wife of the late professor Joseph R. Starobin. Loving mother of the late professor Robert S. Starobin. Cherished sister of the late Victor H. Rosen, MD. and loving wife of the late Leon Nelson. She was a life long student of modern dance, and teacher of dance and music. She was a tireless champion for social justice. Later in her life, she became a writer and poet. She was a life long devotee of the arts. She is mourned by many friends in New York, Toronto, Canada, & California. She is survived by her adoring granddaughter Rachael Starobin MacKay, of Oakland, California, and her nieces Winifred Rosen, & Barbara Rosen Garber. A memorial will be held at her country home in Hancock, Mass., on Saturday, October 3rd, at 2 PM. For inquiries: 510-923-1671.

title: Germany's Futile Look Back
description: Everyone is attributing Helmut Kohl's defeat in the German elections to one decisive factor: that, after 16 years, the people here wanted a change. In fact, the opposite is true: the voters in the world's third-largest economy essentially expressed their desire to leave things unchanged.

title: 24 Wounded As Arab Hurls Grenades In West Bank
description: Thirteen Israeli soldiers and 11 Palestinian passers-by were wounded today when a Palestinian threw grenades at an Israeli patrol post in the heart of the divided city of Hebron, a flash point for violent confrontations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IRVING
description: MANN-Irving. He was part of our extended family. We mourn with Michael, Meryl, Betsy, Adam and Marion and share the loss of a wonderful man. Lesley, Steven, Geoffrey Sanders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAMBOLD, JOHN
description: WAMBOLD - John. Aged 76. Passed away on September 29. Beloved husband to Rita. Father to John, Anne, Claire and Kristen. Grandfather to George, John, Thadeus and Elizabeth. Funeral on October 1 in Kingston, PA at the Snowdon Funeral Home. For information call 717-823-0400.

title: Slicing '98 Forecast by a Third, It Says That May Be Optimistic : IMF Turns Gloomy On Global Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund offered an unusually gloomy forecast for the world economy Wednesday, warning of a sharp slowdown in growth to just 2 percent on average this year but admitting that even this may turn out to be overly optimistic.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; How About Sympathy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ghosts of Watergate Haunt Impeachment Debate
description: Leading Democrats and Republicans here are being haunted by youthful voices of 24 years ago, during Watergate. The voices are their own.

title: Fading Indian Rock Art Saved, at Least in Database
description: SOFTWARE can sometimes be put to unexpected uses. A database system originally designed to create a variety of maps, some to aid in urban street planning, is enabling researchers and archeologists to create a permanent record of American Indian rock art.

title: New Books and Exhibitions Show New York as Walker Evans Saw It
description: Remember when developers wanted to take the glitter out of Times Square? Opponents like the Municipal Art Society had to figure out how to defend the humanistic virtues of -- O.K., let's say it -- funk. Signs speak; often, they engage people better than buildings do. The Getty Museum in Los Angeles has illustrated this truism with a show and two books on Walker Evans's photographs.

title: Data Venture By Toyota And Sony
description: Two of Japan's mightiest companies are teaming up with a relative unknown to develop a business service that provides data transmission, perhaps challenging the domain of another Japanese corporate titan.

title: Motorcycles to Be Used For Medical Emergencies
description: Combining the life-saving equipment of an ambulance with the maneuverability of a motorcycle, Saint Barnabas Medical Center today will start operating what may be the nation's first motorcycle emergency response team.

title: Needle Exchange Aides Arrested for 3d Time
description: For the third time in as many years, the operators of a New Brunswick-based needle exchange program were arrested Tuesday night and charged with giving syringes to intravenous drug users.

title: Making Books; A Bad Boy's Good Awards
description: The sometimes nasty, sometimes raunchy man whose lamentation on radio yesterday was that ''I'm not having any fun calling Jews on Yom Kippur'' is about to become the progenitor of the richest literary prizes in the United States. The very prodigiouness of that, however embarrassing for book people, should and will bring howls of joy from writers. Wrap your mind around the Imus American Book Awards. That's Don Imus, and that's four awards annually. Three are for $50,000 a pop and one for $100,000.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Dangers of Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Sing A Song or Two
description: Participatory kitsch this compelling is hard to find. Heat-N-Glo's Patio Campfire -- a portable gas blaze with fake ceramic fiber logs -- can be set up on the patio or deck and decorated with a ring of rocks. Cooking is not sanctioned on it, but the Campfire ($249) provides drama and sure beats votive candles. For information on local dealers: (612) 890-8367.

title: The Handwriting on the Wall
description: Heat leaks from houses through walls and ceilings. To help stem the flow, Chemrex has developed Radiance low-emissivity paint, which, the company says, will lower energy costs and will cover old paint in one coat. The paint reflects about 40 percent of radiant energy back into the room. The infrared photo, above, shows a wall coated with Radiance reflecting the heat of a human hand. Available in 73 colors, the paint costs $30 to $40 a gallon and can be used on walls and ceilings. Information: (800) 766-6776 or www.radiancecomfort.com.

title: Variations on Spanish
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. to Open Doors of On-Line National Showroom
description: THE burgeoning Internet has often been compared with the automobile industry in the early days of mass production. Now the big auto makers want to take more of their business on line.

title: A Fashion Dream Stays Out of Reach
description: TO a casual observer, the items inside the cardboard box I hauled to the post office the other day might have seemed mundane: a pair of jeans, a bright-colored tank top, black sneakers. But to me, the box was full of disillusionment.

title: Living Drably, Speaking Gibberish
description: Perform any 10 minutes of ''Ramdam'' and Maguy Marin's choreography might be exciting. And it would not matter if the excerpt came from the beginning, middle or end of the two-act work which Compagnie Maguy Marin presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Ms. Marin is one of France's most talented choreographers, and she comments on human folly with intelligence and compassion.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Apathy on Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire at a Lighthouse Is Ruled to Be Arson
description: Arson was the cause of a fire in July that destroyed a replica of an 1857 lighthouse keeper's quarters next to the newly restored Absecon Lighthouse, the state police said yesterday.

title: Vehicle Inspection To Be Valid for 2 Years
description: After months of delays, the State Department of Transportation will start issuing two-year motor vehicle inspection stickers today as part of its efforts to improve auto emissions testing.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT FALLS 2.7 PERCENT. Prices dropped after rains drenched fields in the southern Plains, ending a dry spell that had threatened to delay planting of winter wheat. The December contract fell 7.5 cents, to $2.6925 a bushel.

title: U.S. Again Seeks Forensic Study On Killings in Kosovo Villages
description: The United States today called once again for forensic experts to investigate massacres of Kosovo villagers, as NATO ambassadors met in Brussels and the United Nations Security Council set an emergency session for Thursday.

title: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; It Comes Down to Price
description: WHEN it comes to negotiating the price of a car, lots of us panic. After all, car salesmen are the quintessential sharp-dealers in American lore.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Premature Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Nippon Steel Posts Drop in Portfolio Value
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it expected to post a loss of 50 billion yen ($365 million) in the market value of its investment portfolio for the half year that ended yesterday. Nippon Steel had initially expected a valuation loss of 10 billion yen. The figure ballooned because of the decline in Japanese stock prices, particularly the plunge by bank shares, it said.

title: Red Ink No More; With Deficits Gone, Benefits of Surplus Are Debated
description: For the better part of two decades, economists and elected officials promised that all kinds of good things would happen if the Federal Government stopped running huge budget deficits.

title: Survey Shows Big Growth In Hedge Fund Popularity
description: A new report on hedge funds, the private investment funds aimed at wealthy individuals and institutions, shows that they have soared in popularity this decade.

title: Saudi Prince Meets Chiefs Of Big Oil; Talks Cordial
description: A quarter-century after Saudi Arabia nationalized its oil industry and put narrow limits on investment by Western oil companies, the heir to the Saudi throne, Crown Prince Abdullah, has asked top executives of seven major United States oil companies how his financially pressed country should be developing its vast oil and natural gas reserves.

title: Strawberry Stays Back To Undergo Colon Test
description: Darryl Strawberry, the Yankees' designated hitter, left the team yesterday afternoon for further testing related to pain he is suffering in his lower abdomen. While the Yankees were scheduled to fly to Texas last night for Game 3 of the American League division series tomorrow, Strawberry was preparing to take tests today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES, Greensboro, N.C., said it would sell its Madison Yarn division to Carolina Mills Inc., Maiden, N.C., to finance expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, BETSY
description: SIMONS-Betsy. Superior Printing Ink Co. extends its deepest sympathy to the Simons family on the loss of Betsy Simons, wife of Jeffrey Simons, CEO. Betsy's courageous fight with cancer was an inspiration to all of those who knew her. The well-being of the Simons family is in the thoughts and prayers of their extended family: the management and employees of Superior Printing Ink Co. Harvey R. Brice, President Stanley Hittman, Exec. V.P. Harold Rubin, CFO Michael R. Brice, V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVENS, EDITH WOLCOTT
description: DEVENS-Edith Wolcott, 90. Of Milton, MA., on Sept. 29. Beloved wife of Charles Devens & mother of Charles Devens, Jr, Essex, MA., Edith Devens Iler, Beverly, MA., & Robert S. Devens of NYC. Sister of Samuel H. Wolcott, Westwood, MA. Devoted grandmother of Charles Devens, III, Samuel W. Devens, Edith D. Iler, W. Matthew Iler, Jr, Samuel B. Iler, Alexander W. Iler, William L. Devens, Robert S. Devens, Jr. Predeceased by a son, William L. Devens and a granddaughter Sarah McK. Devens. Memorial Service to be held Monday, October 5 at 11AM at St. Michael's Church, 112 Randolph Avenue, Milton, Mass. Memorial donations may be made to Children's Hospital Medical Center, 300 Longwood Ave, Boston, MA 02115.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Democracy Reigns In the Boss's Box

title: Editorial Observer; Risking Everything on One Big Gambler
description: The more we learn about the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund run by John Meriwether, the more bizarre it becomes. Here were financial wizards -- self-proclaimed and accepted as such by virtually everyone -- who did not play by the normal rules of investing. When their reckless strategies collapsed, the Federal Reserve had to step in to arrange a rescue.

title: Extreme Cordlessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers' Bats Fall Silent for Helling
description: Only a few folks outside of Texas and his hometown of Fargo, N.D., could have matched Rick Helling's round face with his feat this season. The Rangers' uncelebrated 20-game winner did not have to be as dominant as Toronto's Roger Clemens or as fine as Atlanta's Tom Glavine or even as dramatic as the Yankees' David Cone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, CAROLYN (LYNNE) (SCHMEIDLER)
description: POPKIN - Carolyn (Lynne) (Schmeidler). Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Wonderfully special person who will be missed by all of us. No day shall pass without beautiful memories of her. Donations to the Calhoun School, 160 West 74 Street, NYC 10023.

title: With Knives and List of Names, Youth Entered Home, Police Say
description: A teen-ager from Ridgewood, N.J., has been charged with breaking into the home of a college student whose last name and address were on a list he had for 12 young women, the police said today.

title: S.E.C. Says Trader Cost AT&T Pension Fund a $150 Million Loss
description: A trader in Boston cost a pension fund for employees of the AT&T Corporation $150 million in 1996 as he made huge unauthorized bets on the direction of technology stocks, the Securities and Exchange Commission contended in a lawsuit yesterday.

title: BANC ONE IN $1.82 BILLION CONTRACTS WITH AT&T AND I.B.M.
description: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said it had awarded contracts worth $1.82 billion to AT&T and I.B.M. for networking and computing services. The three companies formed what Banc One dubbed the Technology One Alliance, to upgrade the bank company's technology infrastructure, handle year 2000 requirements and provide computer systems management. Under a six-year, $1.4 billion contract, the AT&T Solutions unit will manage Banc One's voice and data networking, creating a single Internet Protocol-based networking platform. Under a seven-year, $420 million contract, the IBM Global Services unit will manage most of Banc One's data center operations.

title: Getting the Spin in the Wedge Wars
description: Among serious golfers there is a trinity that can be called holy, for it consists of the three most important clubs in their bag -- the driver, the wedge and the putter. Nightmares in which any or all of these clubs are lost are not infrequent. It makes sense.

title: Salty Democrat Carries Ball for the G.O.P.
description: David P. Schippers, chief investigator on the House Judiciary Committee, and his boss, Representative Henry J. Hyde, bowed their heads together at a ceremony in Cleveland three years ago and left church a pair of papal knights.

title: Up From the Ruins, Red Hook Faces a Dump
description: THE sun was setting like a fat tomato behind the Statue of Liberty just as Armando Babillo hooked a 20-inch sea bass, flashing silver in the light, from the end of the new $3 million Louis Valentino Jr. Pier at the end of Coffey Street.

title: LIBRARY/CAR SITES; Leasing Deals Unveiled
description: ONCE you've settled on a price, the last question is: Who's going to finance the loan? (The well-heeled who pay cash may skip this portion and go straight to the business section to check on those hedge funds.) Dealers want to arrange financing for the same reason they want to sell you the comfort package, the roof rack and the extended warranty. The roof rack might be a good idea, but the rest are almost always better deals for the dealer than they are for you.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Use Their Home Advantage
description: ''Those fans in right field are crazy,'' said Shane Spencer, the instant idol, who whacked yet another home run in the Yankees' 3-1 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 2 last night. ''Thank God I'm doing good.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSFELD, MARILYN
description: GROSFELD-Marilyn. Dear friend, confidant, your wit, intelligence and generous spirit will live in our hearts forever. Rita and Hy Slater

title: Kosovo Killings Anger U.N.; NATO Weighs an Air Strike
description: The Security Council today scheduled an emergency meeting for Thursday to condemn the massacres of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo that witnesses attributed to Serbian forces.

title: Congress to Debate Greater Oversight of Hedge Funds
description: As the financiers who rescued Long-Term Capital Management try to salvage what is left of the hedge fund, Congress will debate whether these secretive, risky investment funds that cater to the very rich should be subject to greater scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, STANLEY
description: STRAUSS-Stanley. Our heartfelt sympathies and love to his wife Audrey, his children Wendy and Gary Pomerantz, Mark and Susan and Jill and his grandchildren Shari, Amanda and Lee. Stanley was an extraordinary man who cherished his family. His honesty, integrity, dedication and warm sense of humor will never be forgotten. We are forever blessed to have had him in our family. Phyllis and Jules Cohen and family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERLE, RICHARD
description: ERLE-Richard. 96. Died peacefully on September 29. We mourn his loss and celebrate his long life: his beloved wife Hansi and their children Joan and Henry, Lola and Walter; their grandchildren Jeffrey Erle, David Erle, Debbie Ehrentreu, Steven Erle, Wendy Larson and their families. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, October 4, 11 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Too Early to Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Marino Is Hoping Jets Are Still His Patsies
description: The statistics and films tell a story of a Miami Dolphins team that has renounced its dependence on the pass, thriving as it has opted to run the ball instead of relying on the arm of Dan Marino. Aaron Glenn has seen those statistics, studied the films, and he is not convinced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWABER, BESS
description: SCHWABER-Bess. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres., David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President,

title: A New Camera Comes With a Built-In Modem
description: Point, shoot and hit Send. That's the idea behind a digital camera that started shipping this week that includes a built-in modem. Hooked into a standard telephone line, the Fone Cam can send images directly to a PC. The camera, made by Moonlight Products and priced at $299, is the first digital camera that does not require the images to be loaded onto a PC before they are sent through cyberspace.

title: Reality Finally Catches Up With the High-Flying Blue-Chip Stocks
description: Even after many lesser stocks had faded, America's blue chips sailed into the third quarter seemingly headed for yet another year of improbably outsize gains. On July 17 the Dow Jones industrial average reached 9,337.97, with commentators still talking of the just-right ''Goldilocks economy'' and mulling over the existence of a possible ''new era.''

title: Some Stanford Students Go Deeper Into Cyberspace
description: Students entering the electrical engineering master's degree program at Stanford University last week may hold some future class reunion in an Internet chat room. That would seem about right, given that some of the students will take all their classes, turn in all their homework and hold all class discussions on line.

title: Germany's New Leader Gives France Reassurances About Ties
description: He will not become Chancellor until after the new German Parliament is sworn in and he can form a coalition Government, maybe at the end of October, Gerhard Schroder said today, but that did not stop the French from hanging on his every word for signs that he might love them less than he loves the British.

title: Los Angeles County Pays $24 Million in Arrests
description: Los Angeles County has paid nearly $24 million to 36 people who were found to have been wrongly arrested and in some cases beaten by sheriff's deputies at a bridal shower in 1989.

title: Miscellany
description: * Young & Rubicam Inc., New York, will combine its worldwide media operation, handling accounts with $9 billion in billings, in a stand-alone company operating under the Media Edge name. That is the name of the media unit Y.& R. opened last year in the United States. The worldwide Media Edge will initially operate with five major regional centers -- London, Miami, New York, Singapore and Sydney, Australia -- with its headquarters in New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: O.K., Into the Pool
description: Modern fiber optics are used to light the constellations in Grand Central Terminal's revamped ceiling. Fiber optics speed information through cables in new office buildings. To advertise its new line of fiber-optic products in trade magazines, the Lucifer Lighting Company froze its fixtures in 400-pound blocks of ice, below. The message is that fiber optics can go where most lighting cannot: into pools, fountains and concrete, for starters.

title: Big Banks Cut Prime Rate
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, Citicorp, the Nationsbank Corporation and some other big United States banks lowered the rate at which they lend money to their best customers to 8.25 percent yesterday, from 8.50 percent, a day after the Federal Reserve cut its target rate for overnight loans between banks.

title: Mortgage Debate: Wait Or Seize the Moment?
description: HOW loooooooow can they go?

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES HIRES ADVISER ON FALLEN SHARES
description: Miller Industries, the world's top provider of vehicle-towing services, said it had hired the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company to evaluate alternatives such as a possible sale of the company to bolster its lagging shares. The company, in Chattanooga, Tenn., said it was not in talks with any party about a deal. Earlier this year it reported lower profit in two quarters because a mild winter left fewer stranded automobiles, cutting demand for towing services. Miller shares rose 18.75 cents, to $4.625, giving the company a market capitalization of $215 million. The stock has fallen 56 percent this year.

title: D'Amato Makes Another Upstate Swing for Votes as 'Pothole Senator'
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato continued his campaign to win the hearts and votes of upstate New Yorkers today, visiting a string of storm-ravaged farms from Syracuse to Lake Erie and pledging to play the role of the ''pothole Senator'' by winning Federal disaster aid for the region.

title: From Lively Jigs to Chat Rooms, Web Is a Host for Irish Culture
description: IRISH culture is, of course, far more than green beer every March 17. For many, the entree into the Celtic musical traditions is ''Riverdance,'' that loud, brash Broadway-style stage show that has thumped its way back to New York for a run at Radio City Music Hall until Oct, 11. Not surprisingly, the show has its own Web site, based in Dublin (www.riverdance.com). In addition to dispensing ticket and tour information, the official site caters to fans who just can't get enough by including cast biographies, multimedia clips and rehearsal photos. The site also has message boards for fans around the world to exchange greetings and news.

title: Swatting Y2K Bug
description: Q. How can people find out if their home computers have a Year 2000, or Y2K, problem?

title: 4 Hudson Towns Agree to Unite Their Fire Departments
description: Four north Hudson County towns, some with trepidation and some without, entered the brave new world of regionalization tonight when they approved a plan to consolidate their fire departments.

title: New Web Radio Will Show Animation to Go With Music
description: Somewhere around the nexus of MTV, radio, the Internet and the late-night laser show at the Planetarium exists FlashRadio, which its marketers are calling a new concept in radio. FlashRadio (www.flashradio.com), which is scheduled to make its debut today, presents five channels of different music themes, including pop, alternative and urban. The added touch is that while the music plays, the monitor fills with a continuous animation show (the images are not tailored to the individual songs, but to the channel's ''mood'').

title: Judge Approves Bid From Tenet
description: A last-minute $345 million bid by the Tenet Healthcare Corporation for eight bankrupt Philadelphia hospitals and an associated medical school won Federal court approval on Tuesday.

title: 2 Children Killed And 5 Hurt in Accident
description: Two children died after the car they were riding in collided with a private ambulance late last night in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, ANDREW
description: GOTTESMAN-Andrew, 89. Formerly of NYC, September 30, 1998. Gifted violinist, graduate of Budapest Conservatory and Juilliard, played with major orchestras and Broadway shows till he was 84. Devoted husband and father. Will be sorely missed by daughter, Regina, and son, Steven. Donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center, L.A. CA. Interment N. Lauderdale, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, EDWARD J. JR.
description: MOHR-Edward J. Jr., 72, retired engineer, who worked on the development of the first IBM digital computer, died September 28 of cancer. He also participated in monitoring early nuclear tests in Nevada. His ballroom dance friends will miss him very much. He is survived by a brother Richard Mohr, and sister Constance Sheppard, six nephews and nieces and four grand-nephews. Burial is Thursday at the Veterans Cemetery in Calverton, Long Island

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE L.
description: McCABE-Eugene L. The Board of Governors, membership, and staff of the Greater New York Hospital Association join with the health care community of New York in mourning the passing of Eugene McCabe, President of North General Hospital. A great friend and distinguished past Board member of the Association, Gene leaves a legacy of compassionate leadership; he cared deeply about the citizens of Harlem and their health care needs. Gene personally gave life to the new North General Hospital, which is a shining beacon of hope in the community. Gene was a quiet giant whose grace and eloquence serve as a reminder of all that is good in our industry. Although Gene left us too soon, his memory and his deeds will live on. We extend our most sincere condolences to his wife, Elsie, and his children, Kevin, Eugene and Erin. Mark J. Mundy Kenneth E. Raske Greater New York Hospital Assoc.

title: Revamped Terminal Is Ready for Its Debut
description: The shiny, cavernous spaces of Grand Central Terminal yesterday resembled nothing so much as one of those dazzlingly choreographed numbers in a 40's musical with a cast of thousands.

title: Opinions Differ on Foley's Fitness to Play
description: Glenn Foley felt good, declaring himself fully healed from his torn rib cartilage that forced him to sit out the Jets' last game. The pain that he felt today came from the stinging words of his coach as a difference of opinion developed on Foley's fitness to play against the Miami Dolphins on Sunday.

title: A New Way to Kill Some Time While Web Pages Download
description: A San Francisco company wants to capitalize on two rampant conditions in modern culture: the World Wide Wait and narcissism.

title: Smaller View Is Coming For the Expanding Web
description: This just in from the World of the Incredible Shrinking Computer: a Berkeley, Calif., company is testing software that palmtop and handheld computers can use to surf the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRAGAMO, FIAMMA
description: FERRAGAMO - Fiamma. The NYU community grieves for the loss of Fiamma Ferragamo. The Ferragamo family has been true and generous friends of this University, and they have been particularly welcoming and supportive of our efforts at Villa La Pietra in Florence. Our hearts go out to her loved ones; like them, we shall miss her greatly. Laurence A. Tisch, Chairman of the Board of Trustees L. Jay Oliva, President

title: On-Line Investors Who Chase Market's Every Blip
description: LANDON RAY used to lead a fairly genteel life, selling flowers at farmers' markets in California and taking home $2,000 a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HERBERT T.
description: WEINSTEIN-Herbert T. Suddenly on September 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Wendy Schriber. Loving father of Jordan, Jonathan and Adam. Dear son of Seymour Weinstein. Services Friday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. For service time call 212-362-6600. Contributions may be made to the Greater NY Chapter of A.L.S. Association.

title: ABN Amro Is a Primary Treasuries Dealer
description: ABN Amro N.V. said today that its United States investment banking subsidiary, ABN Amro Inc., had been named a primary dealer of United States Treasury securities by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: The Insatiable Pentagon
description: The nation's top military commanders and Senate Republicans engaged in a surreal argument this week over whether the Pentagon has enough money to keep American forces and weapons ready for combat. The senators complained that the generals had soft-pedaled an erosion in readiness, while the commanders maintained that Congress had diverted money to marginal military programs that benefited the home districts of Republican leaders. Lost in the noise was any recognition that an annual Pentagon budget of $271 billion should be more than sufficient to keep American forces in fighting trim, provided it is spent in rational ways.

title: Economic Scene; Long-Term Capital didn't get a bailout and didn't warrant one.
description: JUDGING from the volume of criticism, William J. McDonough, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, made a dreadful mistake when he orchestrated a ''bailout'' of Long-Term Capital Management, the multibillion-dollar investment fund that bought most of its assets with borrowed money.

title: President Balks At $1 Million Deal
description: President Clinton conferred with his lawyers for nearly an hour today about his next move in the Paula Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit, and White House officials said he was deeply reluctant to meet her price of $1 million to settle the case.

title: Immigrants Injured by Firecrackers They Mistook for Candles
description: A family of Bukharan Jews observing their first Yom Kippur in their new apartment in Lefrak City, Queens, was injured on Tuesday night after lighting what they thought were religious candles but turned out to be powerful firecrackers, the authorities said yesterday.

title: TV commercials offer too much of a good thing all over again.
description: ADVERTISING may be at its best when it breaks conventional rules, but at least one rule is sacred: once a particular style of television commercial becomes popular, it will quickly be overused and then discarded. Good examples are the disappearance of the shaky, hand-held camera technique of the late 1980's and the reduced emphasis on computer-generated special effects, most popular in the early 1990's.

title: Eugene L. McCabe, 61, Founder Of Harlem Community Hospital
description: Eugene L. McCabe, a management consultant who founded and was president of North General Hospital, a thriving, minority-operated community hospital in Harlem, died there yesterday. He was 61.

title: Uganda AIDS Vaccine Test: Urgency Affects Ethics Rules
description: Raphael Nawiro got up extra early one steamy morning this summer. He walked a mile from his home, then took two long bus rides until he reached Uganda's principal medical complex, the aging, overburdened Old Mulago Hospital.

title: More Arrests at Stadium In Scalping Crackdown
description: They stood at Yankee Stadium last night watching every hand gesture and trying to pick up every sign. But they weren't pitchers, catchers or base coaches, and they could not have cared less who might steal third.

title: Iraq Stiffens Defiance to U.N. Demands for Spot Arms Checks
description: Iraq today hardened its defiance of Security Council demands that it allow spot arms inspections to resume. At the same time it publicly staked its hopes of ending sanctions by calling on Secretary General Kofi Annan to take over a major review of Baghdad's stalemated relations with the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMMERS, WILLIAM H.
description: LAMMERS-William H. On September 22nd, 1998. Of New York City. Father/Father-in-law of Bruce E. Lammers, Candace M. Lammers and Mark Zechel. Stepfather of Niall and Oisin O'Malley. Memorial services will be held at a later date. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Putnam Historic Model Railroad Exhibit, C/O Mike Bibbo, 93 Carolan Road East, Carmel, New York 10512.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SIMON, SYBIL K
description: SIMON-Sybil K. December 18, 1930-October 1, 1988 The world is a better place because, for a brief space, she lived in it.

title: Racist Taunts Are Cited in Shooting by Officer
description: A black New York City police officer shot a white man in Yonkers while off duty early yesterday, reportedly after the man taunted the officer with racist epithets and threatened to shoot him, the authorities said.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Ambition Before Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible I.M.F. Bailout Stirs Brazilians' Bitter Memories of 80's
description: With the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting about to start in Washington, with officials' weighing the cost and wisdom of bailing out Brazil from its deepening economic crisis, the prospect of a rescue package, however urgent, is stirring bitter memories among a cross-section of Brazilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAKER, JANET S.
description: RAKER-Janet S. Age 90. Beloved wife of the late Mendel K; loving mother of Richard K (Susan Kind) Raker; cherished grandmother of Renee Raker and Jesse Raker; dear sister in law of Marie Sturman; preceded in death by four sisters and one brother; devoted daughter of the late Charles and Anne Sturman; also survived by her loving nieces, nephews and cousins. Graveside services will be held Thursday October 1, 1998 11:30am at Oakwoods Cemetery, Chicago. In lieu of flowers, memorials in her name may be made to The Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, 132 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001. For information: The Piser Chapel 1888-67-PISER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOAN
description: MURPHY-Joan. The Martin L. Stone Obstetrical and Gynecological Society of New York Medical College expresses profound sympathy to Robert Murphy, MD, former president and esteemed member of our society, for the untimely passing of his wife Joan. Our heartfelt sympathy also extends to his daughter Rachel.

title: Starting Spencer Was Worth the Risk
description: The slightly risky decision for Joe Torre before the division series was to start Shane Spencer in left field. It might have been a little risky for the manager to place the 26-year-old in the lineup because it could have put the rookie and Torre in jeopardy if a ball was mishandled in left field. Still, despite what Chad Curtis accomplished in helping the Yankees win Game 1, it would have been the right decision.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Hollywood Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, ARNOT
description: WALKER-Arnot. Dear friend who taught us all the joy of life. We will miss you. Services today, 12 noon, Brick Church, 91st and Park Ave.

title: Metro Business; American Banana To Stay in the Bronx
description: American Banana Company will remain in the Bronx and expand its operations with assistance from the city's Industrial Development Agency, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Where Alienation Sells
description: AT one entrance to the Lab Anti Mall stands a whimsical sculpture combining a head of Buddha with a disco-style mirror ball. New Age spiritual, 1970's revival -- they sell it all here.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Congress's Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Businessman Is Indicted in 1996 Campaign Finance Case
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Miami businessman on charges of making illegal contributions to Democratic candidates, including $23,000 in supposedly fraudulent donations to President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign.

title: Malaysia's Chief Suggests Jailed Deputy Caused His Own Bruises
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad suggested today that his jailed former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, might have punched himself in the eye in order to accuse the police of beating him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGIONE, JOHN L.
description: FORGIONE-John L. On Sept. 28, 1998, at age 75, of Astoria, Queens, after a courageous battle with cancer. Accomplished painter, sculptor, film maker, photographer & swimmer. John will always be known for his generous nature, vigorous life style, and someone that ''spoke his mind.'' As a graduate of The Maryland Institute of Fine Arts, and a lifetime member of The Art Students League of New York, John shared his joy of art with many people including his loving brother and four sisters and friends. His paintings and sculptures were drawn and sculpted in New York and throughout Italy. In addition to his immediate family, he leaves behind a large number of aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, and cousins. His spirit will always be with us. Reposing at The Moore Funeral Home, 54 West Jamaica Avenue, Valley Stream, New York. Visitation Thursday from 3-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial offered Friday, October 2, 1998 at 11 A.M. at Holy Name of Mary R.C. Church, Valley Stream, New York. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYTH, HARRIET RUCKER CROWELL
description: SMYTH-Harriet Rucker Crowell, 72, of New Preston, CT died Sept. 29 in Connecticut. Mrs. Smyth taught english at Torrington High School for more than twenty years, was an avid naturalist, an antiques dealer and operated a boarding business for cats. She was born in New York City and was graduated from the Spence School. She attended Barnard College and was graduated summa cum laude from Western Connecticut State College. She received her MA from Trinity College. Mrs. Smyth was author of ''Amphibians and Their Ways''. She is survived by her daughter, Rux Martin of Marblehead, MA, a granddaughter, Hilary Martin of Burlington, VT and a brother, Caleb Crowell of Upper Montclair, NJ. Services will be held at St Andrew's Church, Washington, CT., Friday 5:00 PM.

title: A Benefit And Talks
description: Madison Avenue Against AIDS

title: It Was a Complex Hand, But It Was Worth $35,000
description: The diagramed deal may be the most complex ever to appear in this column. Readers who want to test their playing skill can cover the East-West hands and plan the play in four hearts. The bidding and opening lead indicate that West's ''unusual'' two no-trump bid was based on 1-2-5-5 distribution.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOPSTEIN, LIBA
description: GOPSTEIN-Liba. Beloved mother of Israel and Doron, adored grandmother of Etan, Avi, Leora, Emily, David and Diana, died Sept. 28. We mourn the loss of her boundless love and glowing spirit. She was one of the great Judaic teachers of her generation, leaving an extraordinary legacy to thousands of students she taught for over fifty years in New York, Israel and Poland. Services will be held at the Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, on Thursday at 11:30 AM. Interment at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: The Pop Life; An Archive Of Oddities
description: ''Here we have the beginning and end of music as we know it,'' reads a yellowed placard in the Audities Collection. The notice sits atop a 1972 synthesizer the size of a Volkswagen and is signed by Peter Zinovieff, the instrument's designer. Encapsulated in those words are the ambitions and innovations of the century's maverick inventors of electronic instruments. And the Audities Collection, one of the music world's best-kept secrets, is perhaps the only place dedicated to the preservation of such a wide variety of these instruments.

title: A Russian Bank Countersues Lehman
description: Unexim Bank, Russia's fourth-largest private bank by assets, said today that it had won a court order here to block the accounts of Lehman Brothers Holdings, arguing that Lehman defaulted on obligations to it.

title: Glittering Ode to the Days of Ziggy Stardust
description: Todd Haynes's dazzlingly surreal ''Velvet Goldmine'' offers a celestial ''Here's looking at you, kid'' to the heyday of British glitter rock in general and to the David Bowie of the early 1970's in particular. Without addressing Mr. Bowie directly, it appropriates his shimmering, protean aura in virtuoso ways that put ordinary period filmmaking or time-capsule musicology to shame.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of former Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles yesterday referred incorrectly in some copies to the landmark he attained with his election in 1973. While Los Angeles had a significantly smaller percentage of black voters than other big cities with black mayors, Mr. Bradley was not the first black mayor of a largely white major city; a majority of Cleveland's population was white when Carl B. Stokes was elected mayor in 1967.

title: For Gotti's Son, the Slow Dance of a Bail Review
description: Each day a half-dozen men, some in nylon track suits, others in pressed jeans, all in glaring white sneakers, lounge on the shadeless steps of the United States District Court here. They don't play cards. They don't read newspapers. They wait.

title: Cubs Can't Get Past First Base Against Smoltz
