description: From start to finish, Game 1 was an impressive display by the Atlanta Braves. They showed power. They got superb pitching and fielding. And when it was over, the Chicago Cubs had been pummeled.

title: Censure, Impeachment or Enough Already?; Defining Heroism
description: To the Editor:

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP TO CUT 300 JOBS AS SALES DECLINE
description: Facing continued weakness in the semiconductor business, Silicon Valley Group said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by about 11 percent, or 300 employees, in the next few months. The company, a maker of wafer processing equipment that had tried to control costs through a hiring freeze and unpaid days off for its workers, also cut 700 jobs in July. Silicon Valley Group, of San Jose, Calif., said it expected sales in its fourth quarter to fall 10 percent to 15 percent from the previous quarter and sales for the first half of the 1999 fiscal year to be 10 percent to 15 percent below those of the second half of the current fiscal year. Silicon Valley shares fell $1.0625, to $8.

title: Behold the Lowly Mouse: Clever Technology Close at Hand
description: WHILE many computer users think that the mouse was born when Apple introduced the Macintosh computer in 1984, the mouse is actually two decades older than that.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: U.S. to Ban Guardrails Linked to Pickup Truck Hazard
description: The Federal Highway Administration is banning, as of Thursday, all further installation of two common kinds of guardrail along Government-financed highways after determining that the guardrails cause full-size pickup trucks to roll over in tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, BERNARD
description: SIEGFRIED-Bernard. On September 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Robert and Jonathan. Dear grandfather of Amanda, David, Jeremy, Matthew and Rachel. Services at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street, Thursday, October 1, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers a contribution in his memory to a heart or cancer association of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAKAUER, EVELYN KORMAN
description: KRAKAUER-Evelyn Korman, 66, Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of New City, NY, died Sept. 28. Survived by her husband, Saul, her daughters, Barbara Siegel, Roberta Lensch, Sandra Krakauer; sister, Gladys Sisselman, grandchildren, Paul and Michelle. Donations to New City Jewish Center.

title: 3 Busy Weeks Of Shopping And Praying
description: FOR many Jews, the High Holy Days mean two trips to temple, one each for Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, and then the welcome suspension of alternate-side parking rules for other holy days they do not celebrate and can hardly pronounce.

title: Pettitte's Father Turns Deaf Ear to the Critics
description: Tom Pettitte punched the time clock at 6 P.M. to work a 12-hour shift at the Lubrizol chemical plant in Deer Park, Tex., last night, about two hours before his son, Andy, threw his first pitch to Mark McLemore. The elder Pettitte did not request the night off to travel to the Bronx, he did not have access to a radio, and there is no television at the plant. That is the way the father wanted it. No baseball. No problems.

title: If I Could Talk Like the Animals. . .
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Japan Business Executives Are Even Gloomier Than Expected
description: Gloom has taken hold among Japanese business, and it shows few signs of lifting any time soon.

title: Lilly Pays Big Fee Up Front To Share in Rival of Viagra
description: Eli Lilly & Company and the Icos Corporation said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to develop and sell an anti-impotency drug that some evidence suggests could be superior to Pfizer's hot-selling Viagra.

title: Antiques; Opening A Coveted Photo Album
description: Next week's major photography auctions at Sotheby's, Christie's, Phillips and Swann Galleries may change the meaning of ''photo op.'' At these sales, the opportunities are for collectors, not shooters.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new report on hedge funds misstated the report's estimated percentage of hedge fund assets that were contributed by institutional investors. It is 20 percent, not 80 percent.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Try to imagine the ideal coffee shop and I suspect you will come up with something very like Blue Star Grill.

description: KANE-Herbert S. We mourn his loss and celebrate his life. Cherished and survived by his loving wife Janice, their children Randy, Daniel and Jon, sister Elaine, grandchildren Sadya, Emily and Lily. Memorial service Sunday, October 4, 2 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Vacco Seeks Removal of 6 From Apollo Theater Board
description: The State Attorney General's Office filed a lawsuit late yesterday that seeks to remove Representative Charles B. Rangel and five other board members of the nonprofit foundation that runs the Apollo Theater, contending that the board failed to manage the theater's finances responsibly.

title: Merrill Cites $1.4 Billion Exposure To Long-Term
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had $1.4 billion of financial exposure to Long-Term Capital Management, the speculative hedge fund it helped rescue from bankruptcy last week.

title: Challenge to State Law On Welfare Can Proceed
description: A lawsuit seeking to overturn a state law that denies additional benefits to women who have children while on welfare can proceed, an judge ruled yesterday.

title: Lady of the Manor Meets Mayhem on the Moor
description: A warning for those with delicate constitutions: don't eat before seeing ''The Mystery of Irma Vep.''

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

description: Georg Baselitz

description: In percent

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: New Video Releases
description: A Perfect Murder

title: The Elaborate Fantasies of Love and Longing
description: One way to look at the films of Eric Rohmer, in which assorted combinations of attractive, cultivated Europeans rearrange their lives amid much exquisitely verbalized soul-searching, is to see them as sophisticated fairy tales. Shakespearean comedies for the modern professional class, they presuppose a highly civilized code of behavior and an advanced educational level that in a Rohmer film could be taken as universal givens. Despite what blows fate may deliver the characters, a divine plan usually emerges that overrides earlier setbacks. Rational decision-making pays off, as does trusting one's deepest intuitions. True love -- or the closest thing to it one can find in this life --is the ultimate reward, but it can't be tasted until every moral quandary has been aired and resolved.

title: The Selloff in Stocks Deepens as Markets Plunge Worldwide
description: A worsening meltdown in stock prices expanded yesterday to damage every market worldwide on growing concern about financial turmoil and the possibility of a global recession.

title: British Telecom Buys A Korean Stake
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it had acquired a 23.49 percent stake in the LG Telecom Company of South Korea, making it the second-largest shareholder in the mobile telephone company. The deal, worth around $390 million, is the largest foreign investment to date in South Korea's telecommunications industry and one of British Telecom's most significant in Asia.

title: Halloween in the Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Muscle and Bone Disorders Linked to Workplace
description: The National Academy of Sciences gave ammunition yesterday to supporters of new occupational safety standards by issuing a report stating that workplace activities, like lifting and repetitive motions, often contribute to muscle and skeleton disorders like back injuries and tendinitis.

title: UNISOURCE SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL MEXICAN OPERATION
description: Unisource Worldwide Inc., based in Berwyn, Pa., said yesterday that it planned to sell its Mexican operation and take a charge of as much as $70 million against fiscal fourth-quarter earnings as it tries to reduce costs and increase profits. Unisource, the largest United States distributor of paper and janitorial supplies, said the charge would cover writing down the value of its distribution facility. Unisource cut 300 jobs in the third quarter, and intends to cut about 1,200 more while closing 171 of its 424 facilities and eliminating 3 million square feet of warehouse space. It had expected to revamp the Mexican operation, rather than sell it, but changed its plan because of persistent problems like currency-exchange values.

title: No Place Like Home, Not Even Home
description: People talk about New York as a city of neighborhoods, and they talk about it as a city of changing neighborhoods, but it never really occurred to me that my neighborhood would change, not while I was gone. I have an apartment just off the New York University campus, and I've always thought of the few blocks north and south of Houston Street on the west side of Broadway as my home turf, a semi-fashionable, semi-shabby tract of the city that allows people like me with ambivalent self-images to think of themselves as leaning either way, not to mention as younger than we actually are.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLICHTER, ARTHUR I.
description: SCHLICHTER-Arthur I. On October 1, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Terry Reineman Schlichter. Dearest friend of Gladys Luria. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, October 2 at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Antidefamation League.

title: Milutinovic Faces Must-Win Situation
description: The MetroStars know precisely what they have to do to prevent their season from ending tomorrow night. They will need better marking by their defenders and more effective finishing by their forwards to force a third and deciding game of their playoff series against the Columbus Crew.

title: Moral Fitness Isn't Impeachable; Videotape Release
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Sept. 18 about the purchase of a power plant by the Cogeneration Corporation of America understated the size of the plant. Its capacity is 110 megawatts, not 10.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Denizens of the Front Desk, Waiting for a Kiss Goodbye
description: When Thoreau wrote, ''The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation,'' he surely had in mind people like Sonny, the night bellhop at the Hotel Stillwell in Tacoma, Wash.

title: Early Combatant Reflects on the Truce That Got Away
description: A wisp of for-want-of-a-nail retrospection wafts about the scandal now as lawyers for President Clinton rekindle settlement talks with his original nemesis in the arena of sexual misconduct charges, Paula Corbin Jones.

title: L. L. Redding, 96, Desegregation Lawyer, Dies
description: Louis L. Redding, Delaware's first black lawyer, who argued one of the cases that led to the Supreme Court's landmark 1954 decision that resulted in the desegregation of the nation's public schools, died on Monday at a hospital in Lima, Pa. He was 96 and lived in Glen Mills, Pa.

title: The Erotic As Another Sort of War
description: For her unflinching portraits of people caught in the savage ''little'' wars of the last 20 years, notably in Central America, the Magnum photographer Susan Meiselas has won many of the top prizes awarded members of her profession, including the Overseas Press Club's Robert Capa Gold Medal in 1979 (for ''best published photographic reporting from abroad requiring exceptional courage and enterprise'') and a MacArthur fellowship in 1992.

title: Baseball Failed In Not Banning Drug; First, Coordination
description: To the Editor:

title: The Killing in Kosovo
description: The United States and its European allies are rapidly approaching a decision point on whether to take military action to end Slobodan Milosevic's butchery in Kosovo. The need for outside intervention is urgent. Recent days have brought harrowing reports of massacres of women, children and the elderly by Serbian forces. With winter coming, hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo have been driven from their homes, many having to hide without shelter or food in the mountains.

title: Girl's Rape on Campus Brings Four Arrests
description: The campus police at Montclair State University have arrested four people, including a student, in connection with the rape of a 15-year-old girl after a party at a campus residence hall last month, school officials said yesterday.

title: Choice of Honoree at Dinner Angers New York Officials
description: In a couple of weeks, the Culinary Institute of America will hold its largest fund-raising event of the year, a $500-a-plate dinner that attracts New York City's premier chefs and restaurateurs. But a sudden uproar over the affair's guest of honor may have organizers choosing bicarbonate of soda as their evening's aperitif.

title: HARBINGER SAYS IT WILL REPORT A LOSS IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The Harbinger Corporation said yesterday that it expected a loss of up to 4 cents a share in the third quarter because of higher costs and lower gross margins. Analysts had expected a profit of 11 cents a share. In a bid to return to profitability, Harbinger, an Atlanta-based software company, plans to dismiss 110 people, or 10 percent of its work force, and reorganize its operations. It also said C. Tycho Howle, its founder and chairman, would reassume the position of chief executive. Harbinger's shares plunged 41 percent yesterday, falling $3 each, to $4.25. So far this year, the stock has declined 75 percent.

title: Wife Wins Right-to-Die Case; Then a Governor Challenges It
description: A Virginia judge ruled today that a woman could remove the feeding tube that has kept her comatose husband alive in a vegetative state for more than three years, but Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d ordered almost immediately that an appeal of the ruling be taken to the State Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHINELANDER, PHYLLIS M.
description: RHINELANDER-Phyllis M. On September 27, 1998. Memorial service will be held Saturday, October 3, 11 A.M. at Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88 St, NYC.

title: Fair Taxation in Cyberspace
description: The rapid growth in sales of goods over the Internet raises hard questions about how states might fairly tax those transactions. The same problem has existed for years in mail-order sales. Consumers are technically liable for sales taxes on all purchases, including out-of-state catalogue purchases, but mail-order companies are required to collect sales taxes only in states where they maintain a physical presence. This loophole costs state and local governments about $3.5 billion a year.

title: A Hovering Spirit In a Gothic Revival
description: ''The Mystery of Irma Vep,'' a revival of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's 1984 hit by Charles Ludlam, is far and away the funniest two hours unfolding on a New York stage. An outrageous spoof of about a thousand literary and movie genres, with references ranging from the Brontes to Mel Brooks, the play, which opened last night at the Westside Theater, tells the story of Lady Enid Hillcrest, installed as the second wife of Lord Edgar Hillcrest in Mandacrest, a chintz-filled English mansion. There, she is haunted by reminders of the mysterious Irma Vep, Lord Edgar's first wife. With two actors taking on eight roles between them, the show is solidly built on a lightning-fast series of costume changes and on gags that pile allusion upon allusion but never collapse under their silly weight. Everett Quinton, at left as Lady Enid, who was in the original production with Ludlam, is joined now by Stephen DeRosa; both exhibit a consummate sense of timing. William Ivey Long's hilarious costumes and John Lee Beatty's lavishly tacky sets perfectly complement the action.

title: Ambulance Driver Is Arrested After Crash Kills 3 Children
description: An ambulance driver was arrested on charges of manslaughter yesterday after the police said she sped through a red light on a nonemergency call and caused a crash that killed three children Wednesday night in Brooklyn.

title: City to Permanently Close Dilapidated Nursing Home
description: Three weeks after evacuating residents of a dilapidated nursing home at Rockaway Beach, the city informed the State Health Department yesterday that it planned to close the center permanently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPNER, LEONORE
description: KAPNER-Leonore. Beloved wife of the late Robert, devoted mother of Richard and Kevin, adored mother-in-law of Fonda, dear sister of Sheila Graziano, cherished sister-in-law of Anthony Graziano, loving grandmother of Brooke Elizabeth. Services private. For information, call Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, NJ.

title: Top U.N. Arms Inspector Tries to Quiet Ex-Iraq Team Member
description: The head of the United Nations' Iraqi disarmament commission said today that he had ordered Scott Ritter, an American inspector who quit in anger in August, to stop revealing information he gathered on the job.

title: Mizrahi, Designer Most Likely to Succeed, Doesn't
description: Isaac Mizrahi, considered the designer most likely to inherit the mantle of Donna Karan and Calvin Klein, representing the next generation of American fashion, announced yesterday that he would close his business this week. The news startled the New York fashion community, which had built Mr. Mizrahi into one of its most beloved and celebrated figures.

description: ''I can't comment on what its ultimate purpose was. We fly sugar, which can be used for cake, but that doesn't mean we're flying a cake.''

description: SCHWARTZ-Jeannette. Beloved mother of Dallas Weinberg and Herbert Schwartz. Passed away September 30, 1998, at 90 years. Her family loved her very dearly and will miss her greatly.

description: Manufacturing weakened in the United States in September for a fourth consecutive month, as exports slumped, while prices paid by industrial companies fell to the lowest level in almost half a century.

description: KAPLAN-Pearl, mother, grandmother, aunt, volunteer and friend, passed away 9/29/98. A source of inspiration, strength and compassion, Pearl worked hard in her community and for her family. She will be missed and remembered.

title: Judge Allows Girl's Confession To Be Used in Park Murder Trial
description: A confession by a 16-year-old girl in the slaying of an Upper East Side real estate broker in Central Park in May 1997 can be used as evidence in the trial of a 16-year-old boy accused of killing the man, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: On Election Eve, Doubts Cloud Brazilians' Outlook
description: When Josue da Silva stepped up to the consumer society four years ago the ground underfoot felt solid and endless.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan Remarks Before Congress
description: Following are excerpts from testimony by Alan Greenspan before the House Banking Committee:

title: AT THE MOVIES; 'Beloved' From Demme
description: Jonathan Demme said he should be nervous, even a bit panicky, about the opening of his new film, ''Beloved.'' But he's surprisingly calm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, DOROTHY LIFSHEY.
description: KESSLER - Dorothy Lifshey. Passed away Tuesday, September 29, after a long illness. She leaves her beloved daughters Ilene Wechter, Rona Miller, sons-in-law Arnie and Buddy; five grandsons, Hugh, Andrew, Marc, Lawrence, Lee and their wives Susan, Pam, Robin, Lauren and six greatgrandchildren and sisters, Shirley & Sylvia & brother-in-law Walter. She will live on in our memories. Services Friday, Oct. 2, 10AM at Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam.

title: John Gotti's Son Is Freed on Bail Of $10 Million
description: Nine months after he was jailed on a welter of racketeering charges, John A. Gotti, the son of the Gambino crime family boss, today walked out the front door of the Federal courthouse here as a theoretically free man, but one who will have to spend the months until and during his trial under strict house arrest.

title: Detained Immigrants Ending Hunger Strike
description: A hunger strike at the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Elizabeth Detention Center appeared to be winding down at the end of its third day yesterday as most of the detainees who were protesting conditions and what they considered tougher criteria for getting paroled began taking meals.

title: Help Single Mothers Before Absent Fathers
description: To the Editor:

title: Channel 5 Expecting Big Return on Yanks
description: The stock market may be gyrating madly, but the value of the Yankees as a televised product is soaring. The Yankees won 114 games this season and their television ratings are splendid. So it's not shocking that Channel 5 heavily outbid Channel 11 to carry 50 Yankee games in both 1999 and 2000.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL CABLE CORP., Highland Heights, Ky., a maker of copper, aluminum and fiber optic wire and cable products, agreed to acquire Industria Venezolana de Cables Electricos C.A., a Venezuelan wire and cable maker. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Lucky Break for the Terminally Uncool
description: Steve and Doug Butabi have been silently bobbing their heads to the music on NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' for three seasons now. Week after week, they drive to the trendy clubs, appall the women they try to dance with and deal with rejection by trying even harder to look cool. As one unimpressed young woman tells Doug, ''You and your brother are ugly, pathetic losers.''

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS -- WEEK 5
description: Game Of The Week

title: A Sibling Rivalry Can Wait No Longer
description: Tiki Barber knows that the moment will come on Sunday, a moment he has been anticipating since he was a child. He will catch a pass out of the backfield, turn and see a mirror image of himself, except that the image will be wearing a Tampa Bay Buccaneers uniform and the eyes will be tightly focused on causing damage.

title: Colorful Patchwork Tales of Black and White, Life and Death
description: In her poignantly witty, 12-part ''story quilt'' saga, ''The French Collection,'' Faith Ringgold makes her alter ego Willia Marie Simone, a 16-year-old black girl who ''escaped the cotton fields of Georgia and the side streets of Harlem'' in the 1920's. Living it up in Paris as an artist and model, Willia has a slew of improbable adventures, including dinner at Gertrude Stein's with Richard Wright, James Baldwin, Langston Hughes and Nora Zeale Hurston; a friendship with Josephine Baker, whose portrait she paints as an odalisque, a la Matisse, and the proprietorship of an artists' cafe bequeathed her by her white French husband, Pierre, an older man whom she had all but abandoned at the altar.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC IN DEAL FOR 47% OF IRELAND'S GPA GROUP
description: GPA Group P.L.C., the Irish aircraft leasing company, said yesterday that an affiliate of the privately held investment partnership Texas Pacific Group would invest $115 million in GPA for a 47.7 percent equity stake. In June, the GE Capital Corporation, the financial unit of the General Electric Company, dropped an option to buy GPA for $65 million and instead took an option to buy as much as 24.9 percent of the company, which is based in Shannon, Ireland, at any time until Oct. 29, 2001. GE Capital rescued GPA from bankruptcy in 1993 and has managed the company since then. Once one of the world's biggest plane lessors, GPA has rebounded from near-bankruptcy by paring its fleet, shedding spare engines and restructuring its debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MORTON DANIEL.
description: GOLDMAN-Morton Daniel. Beloved husband of Jeannette and devoted father of Charles. Dear brother of Helen Rachmil and the late Blanche Etra. Services Friday 12:30 PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ABRAHAM
description: GREENBERG - Abraham. The members of SCORE Chapter 1000 mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague. A counselor for over 15 years and a chairman for 2 terms, Abe Greenberg's wise counsel will be deeply missed. Ivan Szanto, Chairman

title: Needle-Exchange Project To Halt Distribution
description: Two days after two staff members for a Middlesex County needle-exchange program were arrested on charges of giving syringes to an undercover officer, the project announced yesterday that it will stop providing clean hypodermic needles to intravenous drug users.

title: Man Is Stabbed in Columbus Circle Station
description: A man trying to board a subway train at the Columbus Circle station last night was stabbed in the chest after bumping into and arguing with a passenger attempting to exit the train, the authorities said.

title: INSIDE
description: Brazil's Crisis of Confidence

title: H.M.O.'s Are Retreating From Medicare, Citing High Costs
description: Health maintenance organizations, once thought to be the hope for the future of Medicare, said today that they would drop tens of thousands of beneficiaries next year, in part because the Clinton Administration had refused to let them raise premiums or cut prescription drug coverage for the elderly.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; A Car That Could Fly, And Other Odd Gems
description: EACH year, the auto manufacturers proclaim that their new cars can do more than any they have produced in the past. But can they boast of offering a car that flies? This year, the centerpiece of the Louis Vuitton Classic at Rockefeller Center is the 1949 Airphibian, a car that 49 years ago was as at home on the highway as it was cruising 2,400 feet high in the sky.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hints of Change at GE Capital as Financial Companies Lose Favor
description: Has GE Capital, the mammoth financial services operation, become too much of a good thing for its parent, the General Electric Company? Its relentless growth over the years has made it a key source of profit for G.E. and one of the reasons that the company is famous for making its numbers. But with the tumult abroad and at home causing investors to shy away from financial service concerns, G.E. could be looking for ways to divert attention from this golden goose.

title: TJX SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK 13 PERCENT OF ITS STOCK
description: The TJX Companies said yesterday that it would repurchase $750 million of its common stock, about 46.8 million shares. The company said the buyback represented about 13 percent of its stock outstanding. The stock fell $2.0625 yesterday, to $15.75. TJX, a discount apparel retailer, said the program reflected its confidence in its ability to grow and its commitment to maximize shareholder value. The company, based in Framingham, Mass., has completed a $250 million buyback program that it began in February, with 11.2 million shares purchased. TJX's holdings include 596 T. J. Maxx stores, 467 Marshalls stores and 83 Winners Apparel Ltd. stores in Canada.

title: Grand Central, Reborn
description: New Yorkers, always on the lookout for interesting places to rendezvous, can now add the Main Concourse of Grand Central Terminal to the city's list of grand indoor spaces. The Beaux-Arts structure, of course, remains a railroad station that must accommodate nearly 500,000 people a day. But it is now full of simple pleasures that can be had free and on foot, from the sweeping new marble staircase at the east end to the celestial beauty of the restored Sky Ceiling mural 120 feet above the concourse floor. And what better place could there be to meet a friend or arriving visitor than the four-sided brass clock in the center of the concourse?

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Lynda Benglis

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: James Bohary

title: Survivor of Kosovo Massacre Describes the Killing Garden
description: A 42-year-old man who says he is the lone survivor of a massacre in which 13 ethnic Albanians were summarily shot and killed in this village in Kosovo recalled today how he was herded into a garden with other men and told to lie flat on the ground.

title: For Wilkens, It's Not the Billing That Counts
description: The statue of Larry Bird will be unveiled this afternoon, a few hours before the enshrinement dinner. Like the hotel rooms here, nearly every event surrounding his induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame is sold out.

title: Senate Approves Road Through Protected Alaska Wilderness, but a Clinton Veto Is Expected
description: Voting mainly on party lines on a question that has become a touchstone in the debate over development and preservation of wilderness, the Senate today approved a gravel road through remote wildlife habitat in Alaska.

title: Corrections
description: A letter published yesterday from Joseph Cooper on censure referred to the censure of President Andrew Jackson over the use of his power to remove officials and omitted a key word in a sentence, thus changing its meaning. The sentence, in part, should have read, ''the intent was political, though justified by contemporary interpretations of the limits on the President's removal powers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, DR. JENNIE WAUGH,
description: CALLAHAN-Dr. Jennie Waugh, an author and noted educator who pioneered the use of children in broadcasting for creative and educational purposes, died on June 27 near her home in Bronxville, New York. Dr. Callahan was the first proponent of using children to enhance the creative content of both radio and television programs. She was also a pioneer in the use of broadcasting to teach dramatic and speech skills to children, while training college students as broadcast producers and directors. Many of her students moved on to become successful with television and radio networks. Entities such as the Children's Television Workshop evolved from her early work in this field. Her first book, ''Radio Workshop for Children'', published in 1948, brought her celebrity in professional broadcasting and educational circles. She worked with CBS and NBC as a creative advisor on broadcasts that included the use of children. This book also led to the formation of what is now the Film and Media Department at Hunter College, where Dr. Callahan was a professor from 1944 until 1977. Her creation of courses at Hunter College titled TV I and TV II pioneered the inclusion of broadcast production in college curriculums, and was featured prominently in the New York Times. Her second book, published in 1954, titled ''Television in School, College & Community'' was equally well received and further pioneered the use of television for educational & community purposes. Dr. Callahan was also the first woman to be named Full Professor at any City Univerity of New York college. Dr. Callahan was 91 years old when she died at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, New York. She was born on March 22, 1907 in Tarkio, Mo. to Dr. Clifton and Anna Mamie McMaster Waugh. She received her Bachelor's degree from Tarkio College, Master's degree from Northwestern University, and PhD from the University of Berlin. She married North Callahan, a noted historian, in 1944 in New York City and lived in Bronxville, NY from 1954 until her death. She is survived by her son, North Callahan, Jr of Bronxville, NY and daughter Mary Alice Covington of Mohegan Lake, NY. Her only sibling, Dr. John M. Waugh, a noted surgeon at the Mayo Clinic, died in 1962.

title: Abortion Rights Forces Win Rare Victory on Capitol Hill
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today to require most Federal health plans to cover prescription contraceptives for women, giving an unusual victory on Capitol Hill to advocates of abortion rights.

title: SPARE TIMES: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHL, ARTHUR
description: WOHL-Arthur. His friends, family and former NYCHA colleagues will miss this extraordinary person. A memorial gathering will be held in the meeting room at 101 Clark Street, Brooklyn, on Sunday, October 4th, at 2PM.

title: Grammar Is Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Fang Lijun

title: A New Supervisor
description: The Women's National Basketball Association has named Don Rutledge supervisor of officials, replacing Dee Kantner.

title: FED CHIEF DEFENDS U.S. ROLE IN SAVING GIANT HEDGE FUND
description: Parrying a rare wave of criticism, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, defended the central bank's role in averting the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P. today, saying that it had acted out of concern for the stability of the financial markets rather than a desire to assist the investment firm's wealthy owners.

title: A new spot for Chanel No. 5 dabs on some sex and surrealism.
description: THE marketers of Chanel No. 5 will again ask consumers to ''Share the fantasy,'' with a lavish spot that tries to make a sale with a fairy tale.

title: Moral Fitness Isn't Impeachable; Turning in the Wind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, ERIK
description: KESSLER-Erik, born 1/1/24, Namsos, Norway, passed away on 9/24/ 98, Actors Fund Nursing Home of Englewood, NJ. Devoted father of Ingrid Pilley and Erika Schor. Loving grandfather of Sebastien and Apolline Pilley, David and Jason Schor. Survived by his second former wife, Diana Levy. For info, ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: In a Workers' Paradise, This Ant Feels Insignificant
description: Computer animation has advanced to the point where it can make a cute romantic couple out of Woody Allen and Sharon Stone, not to mention back-slapping buddies out of Mr. Allen and Sylvester Stallone. These and other surreal tricks are shown off in Dreamworks' funny new insect picture, the first one out of the anthill.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK JUMPS 1.4 PERCENT. Germany's currency surged against the dollar after the Bundesbank did not follow the Federal Reserve's lead in lowering interest rates. The dollar settled at 1.6467 marks, down from 1.6688.

title: Emotional Day for the Strawberrys
description: Charisse Strawberry answered the telephone on the first ring and it was obvious that she needed to talk about her husband, Darryl, and colon cancer today. She talked slowly, hopefully and extensively to a reporter she has never met. She probably figured the more that she spoke about her husband's positive prognosis, the more comfortable it would make her feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIRA, BEHIA (''BETTY'') DWECK.
description: CHIRA-Behia (''Betty'') Dweck. Age unknown; illegal, illiterate immigrant who became matriarch of large American family. Born, Aleppo, Syria, Ottoman Empire. As a girl, denied schooling. 1924: denied entry to U.S. due to recently enacted ''quota'' laws; went to Mexico, married another Aleppo emigrant there; 1928: entered U.S. on false passport as Cuban, exempt from quota laws; had eight children, six survived childbirth. 1945-1953: worked and lived on welfare to raise six children after ex-husband abandoned family. 1967: became United States citizen. Survivors: six children and six grandchildren with their spouses, plus four great-grandchildren. Only in America!

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN-Aaron. One year without you. Loved and remembered, Ruth, Bob, Michael, Lois, grandchildre

title: Strawberry to Have Surgery for Colon Cancer
description: Darryl Strawberry, the 36-year-old Yankee outfielder, was found today to have cancer of the colon and will undergo surgery, perhaps on Saturday. According to the team and Strawberry's wife, Charisse, doctors say his prognosis for recovery is excellent.

title: A Gentle Prayer That Soars Above the Din of Politics
description: For a nonbeliever, Verdi provided a fair imitation of Roman Catholic ritual in ''Aida,'' an opera of processions and prayers. Aida herself is praying in most of what she sings, and the new Aida in the Metropolitan Opera production, Maria Guleghina, prays wonderfully. She can sound pure -- breathtakingly quiet, silvery in tone, absolutely steady on the note -- and make purity sound like sensuousness: poor Radames in the third act must feel he has been ravished by a nun.

title: Restoration Liberates Grand Vistas, and Ideas
description: Lasers, acrobats, a symphony for orchestra and train whistle, flamenco dancers, a mariachi band, a 1 1/2-ton cast-iron bald eagle, vintage trains and even politicians: These were among the attractions yesterday and today in New York's celebration of the rededication of Grand Central Terminal.

title: Top House Democrats Back Finite Impeachment Inquiry
description: House Democratic leaders tonight brushed aside any possibility of a quick censure deal for President Clinton and instead for the first time endorsed a proposal that would allow party members to vote for a limited impeachment inquiry next week, party officials said.

title: In Civil Rights Ferment, A Conflicted Nostalgia
description: Kerry James Marshall, an artist based in Chicago, has described his work as history painting, and he has taken black life in America as his primary subject.

title: Protesters Shadow Tribe's Pursuit of Whales and Its History
description: Armed with a steel harpoon, a .50-caliber rifle and permission to conduct the first legal hunt for a gray whale in American waters in more than 50 years, members of a small Indian tribe gathered today on a beach on the rugged Olympic Peninsula of Washington to start an adventure intended to resurrect the glory and traditions of their whale-hunting forefathers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Katy Schimert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SAMUEL
description: SILVERMAN-Samuel. The Board of Governors and the members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemd member Samuel Silverman. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Sandra and his entire family. Leonard Shendell, President Judith Tarter, Secretary

title: Home From An Extended Trip
description: The sunsets, mountains and turning leaves of Lake Placid, N.Y., provided a welcome change of scenery for the Islanders. But after two weeks of training there, which was one more than planned, the team returned to Long Island late Monday and practiced in Syosset yesterday for the first time this preseason. For many of the players, it wasn't a moment too soon.

title: Rubin Urges More Disclosure in Global Finance and Making Investors Pay Bailout Share
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said yesterday that the United States would press for ''a new openness in international finance'' that would require private financial institutions to disclose far more information about their loans around the world and force investors to pay their share of the cost of bailing out troubled nations.

title: Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Insider-Trade Case
description: A former associate at the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton pleaded guilty yesterday to insider trading for misusing confidential information about one of the firm's clients just a month after he was hired.

title: F.A.A. Asks, Can Airliners Get Too Old To Fly Safely?
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would consider whether airliners can get too old to fly, which would be a change from its longstanding belief that jets are eternal if they are inspected often enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, SYLVIA (NEE ROSOFF).
description: NEWMAN-Sylvia (nee Rosoff). Beloved wife of the late Lawrence William Newman. Devoted mother to daughters and sons-in-law Ilyse & Dean Schuckman, Idanne and Michael Rozins, and Melissa and Jay Perlstein. Cherished grandmother of Evan, Rachel, Adam, Sari, Ryan, Larry, Jesse and Lara. Darling sister and sisterin-law to Samuel and Marilyn Ross, Annette & Joseph Resnick, Dorothy and Arthur Greenberg, Phillip Rubin and the late David Rosoff and Estelle Rubin. Her nieces, nephews and cousins share in the loss of a wonderful woman. No day shall pass without beautiful memories of her. Services will be held today at 11:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 9860 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park. Donations to Columbia University A.L.S. Gift Fund, attention: Maura Del Bene, R.N., 710 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFAND, MORRIS A.
description: GELFAND-Morris A. With the deepest sorrow The Typophiles mourn the death of our former president, Morris A. Gelfand, who brought to our organization his abilities and knowledge of printing and the graphic arts and left an enduring legacy through his contributions. Theo Rehak, President

title: A FUND OF TROUBLE: A special report.; As Economies Fail, the I.M.F. Is Rife With Recriminations
description: When the world's finance ministers and central bankers gathered last year in Hong Kong, they nervously congratulated each other for containing -- at least for the moment -- a nasty financial brush fire in Asia. In a year's time, many predicted in hallway chatter, the troubles in Thailand and Indonesia would look like a replay of Mexico in 1995 -- a rough bump in the road for a world enjoying remarkable prosperity.

title: Clinton's Spokesman Takes His Bow, Mostly to Cheers
description: Michael D. McCurry drew warm applause and on-the-record compliments from the White House press corps today even as he departed as President Clinton's spokesman with a final defense of his approach to the long mendacious months of Presidential denials in the Lewinsky sex scandal.

title: Moral Fitness Isn't Impeachable; Not People's Business
description: To the Editor:

title: An Old Shul, An Old World
description: The Jewish holidays prompted a writer to visit the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side, where the urge to preserve the old ways and the wish to throw them off are still felt. The 1887 synagogue, at left, whose sanctuary once held 1,000 worshipers, now attracts about 50 on the High Holy Days. Its once-opulent interior has endured a terrible beating, and yet it has taken on new life, encased in a scaffolding that is part of an ambitious renovation.

title: Fraud Scheme Netted More Than $200,000
description: A pair of recent graduates from New Utrecht High School in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, and 40 accomplices are suspected of defrauding area businesses of more than $200,000 over the last 18 months, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ROSE BLUM,
description: MANDEL-Rose Blum, died October 1, 1998, age 95. Beloved mother of Mimi Frishman, Susan Prusky and Samuel Mandel. Sister of Irene Silver and Sophie Kronenberg. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. An inspiration and force in all our lives. She leaves a legacy of charity and good deads. Memorial donations may be made to Hadassah and Brandeis University.

title: Moral Fitness Isn't Impeachable
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IRVING
description: MANN-Irving. The Seawane Club records with sorrow the loss of our beloved member, Irving Mann. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Marion, and their family. Robert Roman, President

title: BILLION-DOLLAR BETTOR: A special report -- The Man Behind the Curtain; Hedge Fund Wizard or Wall St. Gambler Run Amok?
description: John William Meriwether was the consummate trader. He knew when to hold, he knew when to fold. But as the chairman of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., he failed to recognize that his luck and his money were fast running out.

title: ARROW AGREES TO BUY 2 ELECTRONICS BUSINESSES
description: Arrow Electronics Inc., the No. 1 distributor of electronic components, agreed yesterday to buy Bell Industries' electronics distribution group and Richey Electronics Inc. for about $280.5 million in cash. Arrow, based in Melville, N.Y., will pay $185 million for the Bell Industries unit and $95.5 million for Richey, a component maker based in Garden Grove, Calif. Richey stockholders will receive $10.50 for each of their shares. Richey shares jumped 43 percent, gaining $3 each, to $9.75. The Bell unit had 1997 sales of $500 million. Richey has 1997 sales of $250 million. Arrow Electronics' shares fell 31.25 cents, to $12.8125, while Bell Industries dropped $2.0625, to $9.875.

title: Parcells Picks Testaverde Over Foley as Starter
description: While hoping to avoid a quarterback controversy, Jets Coach Bill Parcells named Vinny Testaverde today as the starter over Glenn Foley for the pivotal game against the Miami Dolphins on Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: Malaysia's Neighbors Break With Policy of Silence Over Internal Politics : Asians Criticize Treatment of Anwar
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Some of Malaysia's neighbors, breaking a long-standing tradition in Southeast Asia of noninterference in the internal affairs of other nations, on Thursday loudly criticized the detention and apparent beating of Anwar Ibrahim, the former deputy prime minister of Malaysia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, MILDRED
description: BERKLEY-Mildred. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, New York, and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on its loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Reviewing a Fading Life Defined by Doomed Love
description: EVENING

title: Toots Barger, 85, the Queen Of Duckpins' Wobbly World
description: Toots Barger, a perennial world champion in a decidedly regional sport, died on Monday at a retirement home in Frederick, Md. She was 85 and had long been known as the Queen of Duckpins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, ELAINE K.
description: BENSON-Elaine K. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff and volunteers mourn the loss of Elaine Benson, valued friend, benefactor and long time supporter. We are greatful for her many contributions to our success over the years. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and friends. W. Michael Pitcher, President Priscilla A. Ruffin, Director East End Hospice, Inc. Westhampton Beach, NY

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Lisa Yuskavage

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZSTEPHENS, JACK
description: FITZSTEPHENS-Jack. Beloved husband of Adela. Loving father of Stephen. On Sept. 28. Accomplished motion picture editor, WWII veteran, and courageous friend of the State of Israel at its inception. Services Tuesday, October 6, at 12:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Cone Takes a Cue From Wells and Pettitte
description: David Cone, scheduled to start for the Yankees in Game 3 of their division series against Texas here Friday night, stiffened his lower lip and said he will be ready to pitch, in spite of Darryl Strawberry's plight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, EMANUEL
description: GROSS-Emanuel. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing ofthe dear husband of our Honorary Trustee, Betty Grad-Gross. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, MEG
description: DONOVAN-Meg. 47. On Oct. 1, 1998 at her home in Washington, D.C. after a courageous battle against cancer. Deputy Assistant U.S. Secretary of State for Legislative Affairs and a top aide to Secretaries of State Madeleine Albright and Warren Christopher, Meg, a native of Long Island, NY, had a distinguished 25 year career as one of Washington's foremost experts in international human rights and legislative affairs. But her greatest love and joy was her family. Loving and beloved wife of Stephen Duffy. Devoted and adored mother of Colin, Liam and Emma Donovan Duffy. Beloved and admired sister of Paula Sherwood (Ross) of Pittsford, NY, Mary Ellen (Malcolm Chace Nolen) of New York City, Patrick (Jennifer) of New Canaan, CT, and the late Michael and Elizabeth. Cherished daughter of Daniel J. Donovan of Darien, CT and Rye, NH and the late Arline Brassil Donovan. Beloved stepdaughter of the late Kay Dunfey. Doting aunt of Ian and Duggan Sherwood, Sean, Elizabeth & Aidan Donovan & Graham Donovan Nolen. Services & burial 9:30 AM Saturday, Oct. 3, Church of The Blessed Sacrament, Chevy Chase Circle, Washington, D.C. Visiting hours Friday, Oct. 2, at DeVols Funeral Home, 2222 Wisconsin Ave. NW, Washington, D.C. 202-333-6680. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in memoriam to Lombardi Cancer Center, Georgetown University Medical Center or the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.

title: Showcase for Fillies At Belmont Park
description: Belmont Park's countdown to racing championships will continue tomorrow when six prize fillies compete in the Flower Bowl Invitational, a Grade I stake with a purse of $400,000 and stars in every stall in the starting gate.

title: Prison Term for Woman in Disputed Drug Case
description: In the latest chapter of a case that was once at the center of a pitched battle over whether judges are too protective of criminal suspects, a woman who pleaded guilty in 1996 to serving as a drug courier was sentenced yesterday to four and a half years in prison.

title: As Treasuries Keep Rallying, 30-Year's Yield Hits 4.88%
description: Treasury prices surged again yesterday for the fourth consecutive session and pushed yields down to levels not seen since 1967, reflecting a growing investor migration out of stocks and into the safety of Government securities.

title: On Eldridge Street, Yesteryear's Schul
description: Not long ago, I stood in Straus Square, a little island in the middle of East Broadway, paying my respects to the Forward building, which will soon be converted into condominiums. At 10 stories, it's still the tallest thing on the block, though imprisoned by scaffolding so that I had to cross all the way to Seward Park and peer up to see the enormous rust-red letters still spelling out the name ''FORVERTS'' in Yiddish at the top of the building. I had to come closer to make out the four faces -- Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels, Karl Liebknecht and Ferdinand Lassalle -- looking out in humorless relief above the entrance, like gargoyles meant to scare away superstition and the imprisoning past to which they now themselves belong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFALOWICZ, MIRA
description: RAFALOWICZ-Mira. Born August 11, 1941. Dramaturg and loving friend to many, and international person of the theatre, she died peacefully on September 28, 1998 in Amsterdam, Holland. An inspiration, she will be deeply missed.

title: ASHLAND TO TAKE A CHARGE OF $57 MILLION IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Ashland Inc., North America's largest chemical and plastics distributor, said yesterday that it would take after-tax charges of $57 million for previously announced severance packages, relocation of headquarters and environmental cleanup. The charge will reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by 74 cents a share. The company, which makes Valvoline motor oil, would not disclose how much it expected to earn for the quarter, which ended on Wednesday. Ashland, based in Russell, Ky., announced in July that it would dismiss up to 225 workers and move its headquarters to Covington, Ky. Ashland shares fell $3.6875, to $42.5625.

title: Rerun of '78? Close Enough to Taste
description: The Yankees have done two-thirds of their part, and with David Cone pitching tonight, they can reasonably be expected to notch the final third. The Boston Red Sox have a little more work to do. They are only a third of the way toward creating the playoff series to end all playoff series.

title: Leaks Cloud Death Inquiry On JonBenet
description: Sheets of white paper covered windows in the courtroom here where a grand jury met today to pursue its two-week-old investigation into the murder of JonBenet Ramsey.

title: Nerve-Gas Element Was in El Al Plane Lost in 1992 Crash
description: An El Al cargo plane that crashed in Amsterdam six years ago was carrying a chemical that can be used in the manufacture of the deadly nerve gas Sarin, a spokesman for the Israeli national airline acknowledged today.

title: A Klezmer Innovator Listens for Grandma's Voice
description: When David Krakauer was a clarinet student at the High School of Music and Art, and later at the Juilliard School, he envisioned a life of playing Brahms and Dvorak with chamber groups, with perhaps some orchestral work and jazz improvisation to round out his schedule. He has done all that, with considerable success, and his versatility and brilliant technique have made him a valuable player on the new-music scene as well. But the one kind of playing Mr. Krakauer never imagined doing -- klezmer, the Eastern European Jewish dance music that in its current form has a strong undercurrent of American jazz -- has won him his biggest audience.

title: A Marriage Not for Better or Worse
description: ''In a couple, one suffers and the other one's bored and vice versa.'' This bitter little epigram, spoken near the beginning of ''La Separation'' and repeated later, sets the tone of this small, exquisitely acted French film that traces the deterioration of a marriage gone stale.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Baseball Failed In Not Banning Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Cubs Play Sloppily in 10th, and Braves Clean Up
description: At one point, the Chicago Cubs were two outs from victory. But when tonight's game ended, they were one loss from elimination.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Wednesday about a New York City police officer who killed himself and his wife and children last week in Greenville, N.Y., reported assertions that she had previously reported his brutality to the police. The article quoted a woman identified as Andrea Nowack, a Greenville Town Council member, who said the wife had told her of phoning the police station to complain and getting an inadequate response.

title: Whitman Says That G.O.P. Is Ready for Woman to Run
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman says she believes that the Republican Party is ready to nominate for President or Vice President a woman who supports abortion rights. Someone, that is, like her.

title: Sports of The Times; This Darryl Is Already A Survivor
description: HEY, Skip.''

title: Poland Stands Its Ground Next to Rapidly Sinking Russia
description: When Russia went into a tailspin earlier this year, Poland's stock market crashed. Investors pulled $1 billion in short-term capital out of the country and prepared for Poland to descend into the maelstrom.

title: Education or Training?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big European Markets Fall Steeply, With Germany Worst
description: European stock markets, notably Germany's, plunged today, as investors across the Continent seemed to conclude that they are no longer insulated from crises elsewhere.

title: Nissan Says Nikkei's Tumble Has Decimated Its Portfolio
description: The destructive impact of Tokyo's tumbling stock market on corporate Japan turned apparent today when the Nissan Motor Corporation announced a severe decline in the value of its securities portfolio, which will likely erase profits for the six months that ended yesterday.

title: Lawyer Offers A Guilty Plea In Union Case
description: A Manhattan lawyer who represented Ron Carey in his 1996 re-election campaign for the teamsters' presidency pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiracy to make false statements to a court-appointed election officer.

title: Russian Premier's Calming Words: He Has No Economic Plan
description: Russia's new Prime Minister picked an unusual way to reassure the nation today. After two weeks of deliberations he announced that he still had no plan to rescue the country from its economic crisis.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: IMF Defends Its Handling of Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  A defiant Michel Camdessus denied Thursday that the International Monetary Fund, which he heads, had made any serious mistakes in its handling of the Asian and broader global financial crisis.

title: The Bonds of Friendship, Suddenly Shattered by War
description: Like scores of other television movies, ''Shot Through the Heart'' is based on real events. But unlike so many of the others, this drama feels brutally real. That is so not only because the film believably grabs its locale and plot from the news, but also because it paints a memorable portrait of ordinary people transformed by extraordinary circumstances.

title: Vallone Accuses Pataki of Avoiding Gubernatorial Debates
description: In strikingly harsh terms, Peter F. Vallone's gubernatorial campaign yesterday accused Gov. George E. Pataki of ducking debates with Mr. Vallone, echoing the charges that Mr. Pataki leveled four years ago at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Council Seeks Punishment For the Kosovo Massacre
description: The Security Council, prodded by Britain and the United States, today condemned the recent atrocities against civilians in Kosovo and demanded that those guilty be caught and punished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBAKOFF, CORINNE A. ''CORKY''
description: RIBAKOFF-Corinne A. ''Corky'' of Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Eugene J. Ribakoff; devoted mother of Betsy, wife of Richard Sheerr of Bryn Mawr, PA; and Charles Ribakoff and his wife Patricia of Boston. Beloved sister of Marie Ruth Kearns of Cleveland and cherished grandmother of Deborah J. Gordon, Benjamin H. Gordon and Jacob B. Ribakoff II. Funeral services will be held today, Friday, at 2PM in Temple Sinai, 661 Salisbury Street, Worcester, MA. Memorial contributions may be made to Cancer Patients Care Program, C/O Massachusetts General Hospital, 55 Fruit Street, Boston, MA. 02114.

description: CENTRAL OKLAHOMA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASHUTSKY, BENJAMIN
description: PASHUTSKY-Benjamin. On September 30, 1998, of Miami Beach, FL and Rivervale, NJ. Husband of the late Tillie, father of Sandra Leeds and Nina Charing. Grandfather of five; greatgrandfather of four. Funeral service at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Friday, October 2 at 11:30. Memorial contributions to Morty Fund, c/o American Cancer Society, 2600 U.S. Highway 1, North Brunswick, NJ 08902. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ

title: Hounding Lawrence Noble
description: Congressional conference committees are supposed to be the forum where lawmakers resolve differences between bills passed by the House and Senate, not reverse key policy decisions on which both chambers basically agree. Yet Republican Congressional leaders have badly abused the conference process to pursue their obsessive drive to oust Lawrence Noble, the able general counsel of the Federal Election Commission.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Defends Role Of Fed to Save Hedge Fund

title: Big Board Revises Its Trading-Halt Limits
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would take an 800-point intraday drop in the Dow Jones industrial average to halt trading in United States equity markets in the fourth quarter. The changes took effect yesterday.

title: Man Shot in Restaurant In Queens Dies of Injuries
description: A man who was shot last week after getting into an argument with other patrons at a crowded Red Lobster restaurant in Queens died of his injuries Wednesday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: 5 Teen-Agers Hospitalized After Ingesting Toxic Weed
description: As four teen-agers lay in the hospital after eating a toxic weed to try to get high, teachers at Howell Township High School in this small flatlands town found themselves giving unusual drug lectures today -- on the dangers of the wild and plentiful plant, which grows within a block of the school.

title: After Salomon, Friends Built And Lost 'Dynastic Wealth'
description: As their wealth grew rapidly, John W. Meriwether and some of his 15 partners at Long-Term Capital Management L.P. even considered buying a vineyard in France early this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE L.
description: McCABE - Eugene L. The Trustees, Faculty and staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai-NYU Medical Center and Health System, deeply mourn the passing of Eugene L. McCabe, founder and President of North General Hospital, an affiliate of Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Gene McCabe shared Mount Sinai's vision of ensuring quality health care for the broadbased needs of the Harlem community. He pursued his dream with passion and persistence, creating a hospital rooted in the community and establishing North General as the only minority-operated hospital in the state. His dedication and commitment will be sorely missed. We extend our condolences to his wife, Elsie Crum, their three children, and the entire McCabe family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President

title: Observer; Big Big Business
description: The abnormal baseball season has produced a lot of media flapdoodle about the national psyche. The theme most commonly expounded is that the spirit of America has been saved from despair and lifted into exuberance by baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSFELD, MARILYN
description: GROSFELD-Marilyn. Too soon dear friend, too soon. We were supposed to have more time to laugh and grumble together. It was you who said, ''We can't make new old friends.'' I suffer your loss deeply. Sandra Chamson

title: Global to Build New Fiber Optic Network
description: Global Crossing Ltd., which lays fiber optic cables under the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, said today that it would build a $700 million high-capacity fiber optic network linking 18 European cities to the United States, Asia and Latin America.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS 4.4 PERCENT. Prices dropped on evidence of plentiful supplies despite recent output disruptions in the Gulf of Mexico from Hurricane Georges. The November contract for oil fell 71 cents, to $15.43 a barrel.

title: A Sly Thief And All That He Plundered
description: No doubt John Boorman's canny, elegant new film, ''The General,'' about the notorious Irish thief Martin Cahill, hits unusually close to home for the filmmaker. The real Mr. Cahill actually did hit Mr. Boorman's home some years ago, and he stole the gold record that had been awarded the director for ''Dueling Banjos,'' from ''Deliverance.'' Now Mr. Boorman has his chance to return the favor, and what a chance it is. He tells this tale of an Irish underworld original with an unerring instinct for the captivating detail. And he presents this film (photographed by Seamus Deasy) in such seductively beautiful black and white that it has the visual precision of a photo essay. The black-and-white tones (shot on color stock) are so rich that the ski masks of burglars wind up looking like velvet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHECTER, ELLEN
description: SHECTER-Ellen. A true woman of valor. We mourn your loss. Our heartfelt sympathies to Barry, Leslie, Todd, Chelsea, Olivia, Heidi and Jeff. Janie and Norman Elyse, Evan, Brett and Cole

title: City Will Settle Suits on Death In Police Arrest
description: New York City has agreed to pay nearly $3 million to settle a group of lawsuits filed by the family of Anthony Baez, a Florida man whose death in 1994 after a confrontation with the police outside his family's home in the Bronx ignited a heated debate about police brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HERBERT T.
description: WEINSTEIN-Herbert T. Died Tuesday evening of a sudden heart attack. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP are united in our grief over the loss of this remarkable person. Herb possessed almost unparallelled energy and superior intellect which resulted in accomplishments rarely achieved. He approached every challenge with the same brilliance, confidence and decision making style that defined him. We have all benefited by working with and knowing such a dynamic man. In this time of heartbreaking loss, our sympathy goes out to his wife Wendy Schriber, his children Jordan, Adam and Jonathan, his father Seymour Weinstein and his sister Meryl Berstein. The funeral service will be held today at 11:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. Stanley Komaroff, Chair Proskauer Rose LLP

title: Corrections
description: A letter yesterday titled ''Defining Heroism'' was signed by Lawrence J. Jacobs, not Michelle P. Jacobs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGETT, HON. CHARLES.
description: MARGETT-Hon. Charles. October 2, 1997. Lovingly remembered always. Doris

title: Metro Business; A&P Plans Store Openings
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company of Montvale, N.J., said yesterday that it plans to open 27 stores in the next six months as it continues to upgrade to bigger supermarkets.

title: Transporting a Culture From Old World to New
description: The 1996 exhibition ''Converging Cultures: Art and Identity in Spanish America'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art broke important ground in the study of the colonial presence in the New World. It demonstrated, unforgettably, an alchemical fusion of European and Indian art and pointed to many paths of future exploration.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Rabbi Denies Playing Politics

title: Apparently, the Afterlife Is Anything but Dead
description: It wasn't so long ago that love, in Hollywood-speak, was supposed to mean ''never having to say you're sorry.'' ''What Dreams May Come,'' one of the most elaborate metaphysical love stories ever tackled by Hollywood, lays out a whole new set of irritating catch phrases to define the quest for a love that triumphs over death. These range from the blunt ''Never give up,'' which is repeated like a mantra throughout the movie, to portentous utterances about winning when you lose and losing when you win.

title: Residential Real Estate; 42-Story Apartment Tower for Battery Park City
description: Leasing began last weekend for 340 apartments at Tribeca Pointe, a rental building that is the newest addition to Battery Park City and, at 42 stories, the tallest residential structure in the area.

title: Home Video; The Long Reign Of Urban Cool
description: Noted for its successes in the so-called urban niches -- black, Latino, gay and lesbian -- New Line Cinema obviously hasn't hurt its reputation lately with ''Rush Hour,'' Brett Ratner's karate kickfest of a movie that combines not one niche, but two, with the black comedian Chris Tucker and Asian action star Jackie Chan. To date, the film has earned almost $70 million at the box office.

title: Defending Champ Says He'll Return
description: John Kagwe of Kenya, who won last year's New York City Marathon, confirmed yesterday that he would return for this year's race on Nov. 1.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the Yankees' home-field advantage, referred incorrectly in some editions to the major league team for which Scott Brosius of New York played in 1991. It was the Oakland Athletics, not the Minnesota Twins.

title: Moral Fitness Isn't Impeachable; Job for Voters

title: Exile Ends for Residents of a Times Square Hotel
description: They came on foot, by bus and in crammed taxis. One man even traveled 20 blocks in his motorized wheelchair. The men and women of the Woodstock Hotel returned home yesterday, toting their belongings in large green trash bags and tattered cardboard boxes.

title: Keeping 'Titanic' Dynamic
description: It is 12:30 P.M. on a Wednesday on West 46th Street in Manhattan. Cars with suburban license plates pull into nearby garages. Charter buses unload streams of tourists who set out trolling for pre-theater lunch deals. And inside the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, the strains of a lone clarinet float up from the orchestra pit, just one of a very different set of rituals under way in preparation for the matinee performance of ''Titanic.''

title: Sports of The Times; Uncertainty Hovering Over Jets Quarterback
description: BILL PARCELLS was deftly Presidential yesterday when he announced a fundamental change in the Jets lineup: Vinny Testaverde would be the starting quarterback against the Dolphins.

title: At Grand Central, Music by a Timetable
description: Bruce Saylor peered over the gleaming balustrade of the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal into an audience of thousands, the lone gray suit in a line of seven people in Metro-North uniforms. Beside him, Steve Hegarty, a railroad conductor trainee, gave a thumbs up.

title: Omega Has Gain Of 3% for Month
description: Omega Advisors, the hedge fund run by Leon Cooperman, rose about 3 percent in September, after losing almost a quarter of net assets in August, investors said yesterday. But the fund group is down about 12 percent for the year, they added.

title: Eight Cabbies Accused Of Meter-Tampering
description: Eight cabbies' licenses were suspended yesterday after a sting operation at Kennedy International Airport turned up three ''zappers'' -- devices attached to meters to make them run faster -- and five other yellow cabs with evidence of meter-tampering, the Taxi and Limousine Commission said.

title: Julich Decides To Withdraw
description: Bobby Julich, the 26-year-old American who surprisingly finished third in this year's Tour de France, withdrew yesterday from the world road-race championships next week in Valkenburg, the Netherlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATIN, CLARA
description: SATIN-Clara. Passed away Sunday, September 27 at age 92. She is survived by son Sheldon and his wife, Joan Throckmorton; also by grandson David and granddaughter Elizabeth and her husband Geoffrey Rockhill and great grandson Jonathan. Donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Fed's Deliberations in August Foreshadowed September Cut
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve foreshadowed this week's interest rate cut when they voted in August to drop a bias toward raising rates, minutes of the August meeting, released today, showed.

title: Corrections
description: The New York Times pro football computer rating in some copies yesterday carried an incorrect figure for Miami's average margin of victory, and the error distorted the rankings. The average margin was 12 points, not 53. Corrected rankings appear today, on page D6.

title: Giuliani Owes The General A Salute
description: ONE of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's enduring passions is to demonize people as moral or social defectives when their only sin is to dare disagree with him.

title: On Stage and Off; Technical Torture
description: Any veteran of a theatrical load-in, the installation of a production, will tell you the experience is commonly known as ''tech hell.'' But for two Broadway shows, the past week has been especially abysmal.

title: Revived Saberhagen Answers Doubters, Including Himself
description: He had conquered the major leagues as a relative youngster, winning the American League Cy Young award and leading the Kansas City Royals to a World Series championship at age 21. He had battled back from injuries time and time again to add a comeback player of the year award and a second Cy Young to his collection of honors. And now he was being signed to a minor league contract?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, GEORGE B. JR.
description: FINNEGAN-George B. Jr. One of the country's leading patent lawyers, passed away in California on September 30th at the age of 95. He was a familiar figure in Federal courtrooms throughout the United States and a member of the American College of Trial Lawyers. It was said that most of his well-known Fortune 400 clients quickly retained him after he first defeated them in court. Starting in 1934 with only three lawyers, Mr. Finnegan's firm (now Morgan & Finnegan, L.L.P.) has grown to one hundred lawyers specializing in patent and trademark litigation with offices in New York and Washington, D.C. Mr. Finnegan was a member of numerous legal organizations and was a past president of the New Jersey Patent Law Association. He was also an inventor and, together with his then-partner Hobart Durham, developed a simulator called (Drivotrainer) for testing and training automobile drivers. This device simulated driving situations with movies taken from a moving car. The driver's responses to various road situations in the movie, by use of brake, steering wheel and accelerator, were automatically recorded in a printed record. The simulator was adopted and sponsored by the Aetna Insurance Company as the ''Aetna Drivotrainer.'' It has been used widely throughout the country in driver training courses for high school students. Mr. Finnegan's maternal parents were pioneers in California, crossing the plains in 1849. They eventually settled in Nevada City, California where Mr. Finnegan was born. George Finnegan graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in June 1924. He served as 2nd Lieutenant in the Regular U.S. Army at Fort Scott, San Francisco. He attended law school at George Washington University and Fordham University. In February 1942, Mr. Finnegan was ordered to West Point where he was appointed Staff Judge Advocate and served, with the rank of Colonel, on the staff of Superintendent Lt. General Maxwell D. Taylor. He was decorated with the Legion of Merit for his wartime service. George Finnegan is survived by his wife, Fidella, his son George III, his daughter, Dana, six grandchildren and five great grandchildren. His first wife, Elizabeth, and his son, Marcus, predeceased him. There will be a requiem mass at West Point Holy Trinity Chapel on October 15 at 1:30 PM. Burial will be with military honors. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Seoul to Double Aid To Its Ailing Banks
description: The South Korean Government will double its assistance to financial institutions in a bid to revive the nation's most troubled industry. The Ministry of Finance and Economy said yesterday that it would spend 23.2 trillion won ($16.8 billion) through next June to buy bad debt from banks and finance companies.

title: The Consumer Will Prevail
description: American consumers account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Their slice of the national spending has grown steadily, from 60 percent in the early 1950's to 68 percent today. Yet what should be seen as a sign of economic strength now spawns the latest nightmare scenario: With stock markets diving and overseas economies reeling, United States households may stop spending, tipping the world into a recession.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCCABE, EUGENE L. THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS AND THE STAFF OF GREATER HARLEM NURSING HOME TOGETHER WITH MANY OTHERS IN THE HEALTHCARE COMMUNITY, ARE DEEPLY SADDENED BY THE LOSS OF AN EXCEPTIONAL HEALTHCARE LEADER AND GOOD FRIEND. UNDER GENE'S LEADERSHIP THE ENTIRE HARLEM HEALTHCARE COMMUNITY DEVELOPED COUNTLESS NEW AND CREATIVE WAYS TO PROVIDE QUALITY HEALTHCARE FOR THE RESIDENTS OF HARLEM. REITA FULLER, ADMINISTRATOR     MCCABE, EUGENE L. AS PRESIDENT OF NORTH GENERAL HOSPITAL, HE LED THE WAY IN PROVIDING QUALITY HEALTHCARE FOR THOSE WHO NEEDED IT MOST. TO OUR MEMBERS AT THAT INSTITUTION, HE WAS A FELLOW WORKER WHOSE DOOR WAS ALWAYS OPEN TO THEM. HE WAS ALWAYS AVAILABLE TO HEAR THEIR PROBLEMS. WE LOVED HIM. DENNIS RIVERA, PRESIDENT PHYLLIS HARRIS, SECRETARY
description: McCABE-Eugene L. description: Top-level executive changes were made yesterday in New York by Omnicom Group and one of its agencies, the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of TBWA Worldwide.

description: PETSCHEK-Walter. Age 99, of Scarsdale, NY on September 27. Devoted husband of the late Franziska, loving father of Alfred, Stephen and Susan Petschek. Beloved grandfather of Jennifer and Alexandra Petschek. Pursuant to his wishes, services were private.

description: LOUCKX-Taylor. The staff at Sotheby's is deeply saddened by the loss of Taylor Louckx, the only son of our dear colleague, Roberta Louckx.
