description: LEIT-Sol, 10/2/27-10/23/92. Happy Birthday. We love you and miss you. Bobbie and Family.

title: ING Groep of Netherlands to Cut 1,200 Jobs
description: ING Groep N.V., Europe's fifth-largest financial services company, said today that it would dismiss 1,200 workers as it lowers its 1998 profit expectations because of problems in its emerging-markets businesses.

title: INPUT/OUTPUT TO BUY A LAITRAM EQUIPMENT SUBSIDIARY
description: Input/Output Inc., a maker of seismic equipment used to locate oil deposits, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Digicourse, which makes offshore seismic equipment, for about $46 million in stock. Digicourse is a New Orleans-based subsidiary of the Laitram Corporation. It makes devices that control the depth of cables towed behind ships during seismic exploration. Input/Output, based in Houston, is a leading provider of land and offshore seismic equipment to the petroleum industry. Its shares fell 12.5 cents, to $7.8125.

title: Calder Works On the Move
description: The Calder Foundation is the latest suitor to make a play for 2 Columbus Circle in Manhattan, that white marble building with the slender arches and round holes that Edward Durell Stone designed to be the Gallery of Modern Art in 1965.

title: NATO May Act Against Serbs In Two Weeks
description: NATO will have both the political authorization from its members and the military forces in place to act against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia in two weeks, senior American officials said today, if he does not stop the violence against ethnic Albanian civilians.

title: Another Styron Makes Her Mark, on Film
description: THIS is a father-daughter story about a father who didn't take his children to baseball games but wrote great novels, and a daughter who saw ''Lawrence of Arabia'' at age 7 and forever after wanted to make movies. There was a lot of life and pain along the way, but things worked out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, NANCY HILL,

She is survived by her sons, Bradford A. Warner Jr. of London, Miner H. Warner of New York, five grandchildren, and her sister, Barbara H. Cano, of Mexico City. Memorial service to be held Friday, October 9 at 11 A.M., at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East 92 Street, N.Y., NY 10128.

title: Clinton Offers Jones $700,000 In Latest Bid for a Settlement
description: President Clinton raised his offer to $700,000 today to settle the sexual misconduct lawsuit filed against him by Paula Corbin Jones, who was considering whether to accept it, lawyers involved the case said.

title: Seafood
description: From casual Greek seafood tavernas to sushi bars to the fanciest gastronomical palaces, New York has no shortage of seafood restaurants. Here are a dozen. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: New Era Acquires Century
description: New Era of Networks Inc. said today that it had acquired the privately held Century Analysis Inc. for $41 million in cash and stock. The transaction includes incentives that could add another $8 million to the purchase price, New Era said. Century Analysis, Pacheco, Calif., provides information technology integration software. New Era of Networks, in Englewood, develops, markets and supports a system for automating enterprise application integration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASELL, CHESTER H.
description: LASELL-Chester H. On September 30, 1998, in Greenwich, CT. His first wife Ruth D. Lasell died in 1973. In addition to his widow, Elizabeth G. Lasell, he is survived by two children-Virginia L. Westgaard, of Denver and Chester K. Lasell, of Manchester, VT and Vero Beach, FL; a stepdaughter, Elizabeth H. Cousineau, of Seattle; six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Chester H. Lasell joined Morgan Stanley & Co. in 1935 at the Firm's inception. He was named a partner in 1951. He served as the second President of Morgan Stanley & Co. from 1971 until 1972 and continued to advise the Firm as an Advisory Director until recently. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM, Monday, October 5 at Christ Church Chapel in Greenwich. The interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be directed to Williams College, P.O. Box 231, Williamstown, MA 01267, and Greenwich Hospital, C/O Development Office, 5 Perryridge, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: How Much Does Monogamy Tell Us?
description: Those people whose sexual morality accepts the possibility of complexity and ambivalence in a marital relationship have not judged Clinton as badly as those who see marriage as a monolithic simple entity. And in Hollywood, marriage is often not seen as a monolithic simple entity. -- Marshall Herskovitz Executive producer, ''Thirtysomething''

title: New D'Amato Ad Attacks Missed Votes by Schumer
description: Signaling a new line of attack in his re-election effort, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday unveiled a television advertisement that assailed his opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer, for repeatedly missing votes in Washington because he was campaigning in New York.

title: Brule Returns To Albany
description: The Devils assigned Steve Brule to their top minor league affiliate, the Albany River Rats of the American Hockey League, yesterday.

title: On My Mind; They Will Find Out
description: Very soon millions of people persecuted, arrested and tortured for their religion will find out whether America has finally confronted persecuting governments with a permanent searchlight and the threat of penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMETANA, MARIAN
description: SMETANA-Marian. On September 26, 1998 at age 90 in Miami, FL. Beloved mother and mother-inlaw of Gerard and Beth Smetana and Dorrit and Siegfried Marks. Beloved sister of Erica Whitehead. Loving wife of Leon Smetana (deceased). Beloved grandmother of Melita and Julian Marks and Susannah Smetana (Kagan) & Peter Kagan and Frederick (Teddy) Smetana. Services Sunday, October 4, 9:45 AM, Riverside Chapels, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Astros Make a Beeline To Bats and Even Score
description: For two years, the Killer Bees had been more like Killer Zzz's in the National League division series. As their bats slept, so slept the Astros' offense. But Craig Biggio, Derek Bell and Jeff Bagwell awakened from their post-season slumber today at the Astrodome, and with the help of a game-winning hit by Bill Spiers, Houston beat San Diego, 5-4, and tied the series at one game each.

title: Metro Business; Church Buys Industrial Site
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation has sold a 60,000-square-foot industrial property in Bethpage, N.Y., for $1.8 million to the United Korean Church, which will convert the former research and development center to a church.

title: Shenanigans as Wacky As Their Perpetrators
description: More than a dozen of New York's finest actors ham it up with such unrestrained glee in Stanley Tucci's period farce ''The Impostors'' that it hardly matters if this swirl of cotton candy disappears even before it touches the tip of your tongue. Playing out-of-work actors posing as stewards on a 1930's cruise ship packed with caricatures of bogus aristocrats and hissable villains, Mr. Tucci and Oliver Platt evoke everyone from Laurel and Hardy to the Marx Brothers as they skid from one absurd scrape to the next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CAROLYN
description: SOLOMON-Carolyn. On October 1, at age 71. Her husband Irwin, daughters Marcia and Claudia, sons-in-law Roy and Joel, and grandchildren Liza, Matthew, Rachel and Nathan will miss her love and guidance, wit and intelligence, insight and compassion. In her memory, donations may be made to the Oncology Research Fund of NYU Medical Center, C/O Dr. J. Speyer at 160 East 32nd Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Baseball Failed In Not Banning Drug; And the Pitchers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Leaders Draft  Inquiry  Plan
description: To avoid being forced into the risky positon of appearing to oppose an investigation before the elections, Democratic leaders in the House have endorsed a proposal for a limited impeachment inquiry.

title: Washington Insider Is Lawyer for Panel's Democrats
description: For three weeks, Abbe D. Lowell hunched down on the thin carpeting in the hallway of the Ford Building, just outside the vault securing the Whitewater independent counsel's documents, a cellular phone in one hand and a portable file folder in the other. He was a long way from the comfortable surroundings of his downtown law office.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Don't Force Confession
description: To the Editor:

title: Tradition or Change?Japan Dithers
description: TOKYO  Asia's financial crisis may have started in Thailand, but its solution, say many, must begin in Japan.

title: Chrebet Is Leaving It Up to Parcells
description: Wayne Chrebet of the Jets has been spending six hours a day trying to make his sprained left ankle healthy enough to carry him against the Miami Dolphins.

title: House Approves Farm Bill as Budget Deadline Nears
description: The House lurched through its legislative business today, stalling for several hours, then swiftly passing the agriculture spending bill. The move gave Republicans a veneer of orderliness after a chaotic night in which they failed to bring a major spending bill up for a vote.

title: Resurfacing With Intensity
description: Great clouds of sound rose up off the stage on Sunday for Sam Rivers's big band show at Sweet Basil. Mr. Rivers, having convened some of the better players in New York, took advantage of their sound, the orchestral possibilities of all the personal textures, and had the musicians playing bright, intense and dissonant riffs. Solos didn't count so much; he let the musicians improvise in bits and pieces. What counted was the riff, the written passages that were dense with shifting contours and heavy with color.

title: Ramirez's Homers Put Boston On the Verge of Elimination
description: The Cleveland Indians' general manager, John Hart, and manager, Mike Hargrove, had been stern about the subject. Their players had been silly about it, kidding their teammate Manny Ramirez, the club's young power hitter, about going into his home run jog on balls that stayed in the park. Whatever the approach, Ramirez got the message: no more posing and sauntering up the first-base line while watching one of his well-hit balls make its way toward the outfield bleachers.

title: Players Return To Nassau Coliseum
description: The Islanders were back at Nassau Coliseum yesterday for the first time since last season.

title: Got Cause and Computer? You Can Fight City Hall
description: Bill Clinton seems to have generated the most petitions, calling for him to be impeached, to resign, to be left alone. Thirteen people have signed one demanding a ban on tigers and other exotic cats as pets. Eight favor the establishment of areas in national parks for nudists. But a petition demanding statehood for New York City attracted not a single signatory, not one, not even Donald Trump.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST SECURITY CORP., Salt Lake City, has signed a letter of intent to acquire Marine National Bank, based in Irvine, Calif., a subsidiary of Shinhan Bank of Seoul. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Freedom's Loss in Malaysia
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia has never had much tolerance for criticism or for the legal rights of those who challenge his authoritarian rule. But his high-handedness has taken a dangerous turn in recent days with his treatment of Anwar Ibrahim. Until a few weeks ago, Mr. Anwar was Deputy Prime Minister, Finance Minister and Mr. Mahathir's chosen successor. He seemed to be Malaysia's best hope for a more democratic future. Then, abruptly, he was arrested and this week appeared in court, charged mainly with sexual improprieties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFAULT, VALMORE R.
description: DUFAULT-Valmore R. (Known as Buddy). On October 1, 1998 in Great Barrington, MA. Of Forest Hills Gardens, N.Y. Musical arranger and composer for over 60 years. Past associations with Copacabana, Latin Quarter, Xavier Cugat and Musak. Member of ASCAP Local 802. Husband of the late Dorothy Jane. Devoted father of Andrea D. Moore of Vienna, VA and David A. of Sheffield, MA. Also survived by one sister, six grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Ave, Forest Hills, N.Y. 11375 Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel St, Forest Hills, N.Y. Monday, October 5, 9:45AM. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Center Moriches, N.Y. Donations to The Lighthouse Foundation, 111 E. 59 Street, NY, NY 10022 preferred.

title: Pay-TV Dispute Flares in Spain
description: Two months after Canal Plus S.A. and Telefonica S.A. proposed ending Spain's digital television dispute and agreed to merge their platforms, the two sides have drawn swords once again.

title: Bilingual Education Lives After All
description: Bilingual education in California was supposed to be in a grave by now, essentially killed when residents voted last spring to end it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEY, AUDREY C.
description: PALEY-Audrey C. Died October 1, 1998 in New York City after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. She is survived by her husband, Richard of 40 years, her daughters, Jane and Liz and son-in-law Michael. The family gratefully acknowledges the outstanding and compassionate care given by Dr. James L. Speyer and his staff at NYU Medical Center. In lieu of flowers and in support of Dr. Speyers continuing efforts the family ask that donations be made to The Gynecological Cancer Research Fund at NYU Medical Center, 550 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10016. Attention Dr. James Speyer. Family will be at home from Monday through Thursday, 2PM to 9PM.

title: Stumping in the Shadows of the Clinton Scandal
description: In other election years, Representatives David E. Price and Julia Carson would have had little in common other than that they were Democrats with relatively safe seats.

title: Cubs Put Hopes on Wood's Sore Arm
description: The Chicago Cubs will be home Saturday night, but they will also be in deep trouble.

title: Suspect in Sexual Assault Of Girl, 15, Surrenders
description: A 21-year-old man turned himself in to the campus police at Montclair State University yesterday to face charges that he took part in the sexual assault of a 15-year-old girl after a party at a campus residence hall last month.

title: This Time, at the Met, the Ayes Have It
description: When the director and designer Robert Wilson took a bow after the March 9 premiere of his production of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' last season at the Metropolitan Opera, he was greeted by a vociferous chorus of boos. The production returned to the house on Wednesday night. But this time, when Mr. Wilson, with understandable trepidation, took a curtain call, he was greeted with lusty bravos.

title: Excerpts From Conversation Recorded by Investigators for Starr
description: Following are excerpts of a conversation between Linda Tripp and Monica S. Lewinsky on Jan. 13, when Ms. Tripp wore a listening device for Federal agents working for Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel. This conversation occurred after both had been subpoenaed as witnesses in the Paula Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit, and just a few days before Mrs. Tripp lured Ms. Lewinsky to a meeting where Mr. Starr's prosecutors tried to persuade her to cooperate in an investigation into the President's conduct. Some names were omitted by the Judiciary Committee.

title: Woman Is Assaulted By a Driver in Queens
description: A 20-year-old woman was robbed and sexually assaulted last night after a man who said he was a cabdriver drove her to an empty lot in Queens, the police said.

title: Have Hedge-Fund Partners Been Punished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday about the robbery of a T.G.I. Friday's restaurant in Eatontown, N.J., misstated the role of an off-duty policeman, Reyes Quinones. He and another officer were in the restaurant when it was robbed and pursued the suspects as they fled; Mr. Quinones was not a suspect and was not charged with armed robbery.

title: Job Growth Turned Slack In September
description: Job creation fell in September to the lowest rate in more than two years, the Labor Department reported yesterday -- the most persuasive evidence yet that the financial crisis abroad is slowing the booming American economy.

title: Have Hedge-Fund Partners Been Punished?; Conflict of Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Cone Takes His Friends With Him
description: DAVID CONE is reeling, and he does not mind admitting it. His eyes are hollow-looking from the death of Dan Quisenberry and the revelation that Darryl Strawberry has colon cancer.

title: The Lewinsky-Tripp Tapes: Friends but Little Friendship
description: They talked on and on, about hair, diets, shopping and sex. But the tapes of the phone chats between Monica S. Lewinsky and Linda R. Tripp show less a real friendship than a temporary alliance between two women obsessed with Bill Clinton who often do not even seem to like each other very much.

title: Excerpts From Tripp's Recorded Conversations With Lewinsky
description: Following are excerpts from conversations between Linda R. Tripp, a Pentagon aide, and Monica S. Lewinsky, a former White House intern. The conversations were secretly recorded by Mrs. Tripp between Oct. 3, 1997, and Jan. 13, 1998. Some names were omitted by the Judiciary Committee.

title: Cairo Journal; Praising Love and War, Beneath the Pyramids
description: In a nation whose modern history has provided little cause for celebration, there is always October.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: DISNEY'S OWN MEDICI
description: * The Walt Disney Company, under Michael Eisner, is raising its sights toward high art. -- Arts & Leisure.

title: Listening Between the Lines
description: With the House of Representatives set to decide next week whether to open an impeachment inquiry, President Clinton's fate may ultimately depend on his theories of language. In his grand jury testimony, Mr. Clinton expounded on the semantics of the present tense (''It depends on what the meaning of the word 'is' is'') and of the words ''alone,'' ''cause'' and, most notoriously, ''sex.''

title: UBS Chairman Joins Casualty List From Hedge Fund's Setback : 4 Executives At Big Bank Lose Jobs Over Losses
description: FRANKFURT  The chairman of UBS AG, Europe's biggest bank, and three of his top executives abruptly quit Friday to take responsibility for damaging losses in the near-collapse of a U.S. investment fund.

title: FIAT'S MAGNETI ADDS MIDAS SHOPS IN EUROPE
description: Magneti Marelli S.p.A., a car parts maker controlled by Fiat S.p.A., the world's fifth-largest auto maker, said yesterday that it would buy Midas Inc.'s European repair shops for $100 million as part of a repair alliance that will span South America and Europe. The Chicago-based Midas, which has 2,700 service centers worldwide, will sell the 438 outlets in Europe; of them, 187 are owned outright and 251 are franchises. The repair shops will continue to use Midas technology and methods.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: MATCHUPS
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Republicans Criticize Clinton On Kosovo
description: As NATO and the United States warned again of impending military action against Serbia, several influential Republican Senators today criticized the Clinton Administration's approach toward ending the crisis in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE
description: McCABE-Eugene. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of the Program in Health Services Management and Policy in the Milano Graduate School of The New School, mourn the passing of a distinguished member of our adjunct faculty. Gene was a dedicated health leader and served as a role model and mentor for many of us. We convey our sincerest condolences to his wife and loved ones. Howard S. Berliner, Chair Jack Krauskopf, Dean

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Redefine Impeachable
description: To the Editor:

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Right-Wing Switch?
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Thief Arrives, All the Complaining Stops
description: It's hard to decide which is more annoying, the crying baby in the next apartment or the plump, middle-aged French housewife complaining about it nonstop. Well, Agrippina (Joan Shepard) is annoying to her husband (John Michalski), who barely looks up from his book to respond to her. To the audience, she's a delight, pacing and fussing in the couple's bedroom while Edward tries to ignore her and reads aloud about ego, superego and Freud's theories on humor. Still, it's very satisfying when a thief enters the room and finally shuts her up.

title: Union City Firefighters Seek Merger Referendum
description: Firefighters in Union City began a campaign last night for a referendum on whether to merge their Fire Department with those in three neighboring communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLINER, JACOB P.
description: OLINER-Jacob P. of Dobbs Ferry, New York, on Thursday, October 1. Husband of the late Malka (Rabin). Father of Carol and Mitchell Fischman & S. David and Barbara Oliner. Grandfather of Sharon, Elizabeth, Andrea and Benjamin. Services at the Mount Sinai Memorial Chapel, 454 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick, NJ (732-390-9199) on Sunday, October 4 at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. For information Levine Chapel, Brookline, Massachusetts (617-277-8300).

title: Very Bergman, With a Movie Within a Movie Made for TV
description: When great filmmakers reach old age, their work tends to grow sparer and more austere, the texture stripped away so that the core themes of a lifetime's output jut out like bones under crumbling flesh. ''In the Presence of a Clown,'' Ingmar Bergman's two-hour 1997 made-for-television movie, is such a film. A gloomy, murky, static work laced with an absurdist gallows humor, it doesn't try very hard to entertain or to look beautiful. But the movie, which the New York Film Festival is screening four times at the Walter Reade Theater today and tomorrow, is still a must-see for Bergman aficionados.

title: After Delay, Senate Approves Judge for Court in New York
description: After a delay of more than a year, the Senate today voted to elevate Judge Sonia Sotomayor of Federal District Court in New York City to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Words and Pictures as Subversive Allies
description: Blending dance with other arts, Sara Pearson/Patrik Widrig and Company offered an imagistically rich program on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church. Unfortunately, the strongest images were verbal and pictorial, rather than choreographic.

title: A Performer's Mission: Saving the Spirit of Soul
description: N'Dea Davenport has set herself a task that requires heavy muscle, and the pint-size singer is no Hercules. ''I'm trying to keep the spirit of live soul music and live instrumentation going,'' she announced during her Irving Plaza set on Wednesday night, as her band broke into ''Save Your Love for Me.'' The band, turned up too loud, threatened to overwhelm her, and Ms. Davenport pushed herself to the edge of her vocal capacity.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Admit Perjury?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Partly Recover Following Two-Day Plunge

title: Japan Banking Legislation Passes Hurdle
description: Japan's Lower House of Parliament today took a major step toward stabilizing Japan's frail banking system, passing legislation that is also expected to improve the prospects for Japanese economic recovery.

title: Economy Shift In Russia Worries U.S., Albright Says
description: The United States is disappointed by the economic confusion within the new Russian Government of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today, and she warned Russia about the dangers of an anti-Western policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSFELD, MARILYN
description: GROSFELD-Marilyn. Too soon dear friend, too soon. We were supposed to have more time to laugh and grumble together. It was you who said, ''We can't make new old friends.'' I suffer your loss deeply. Sandra Chamson

title: A Debut to Remember in the Comics
description: It has already happened to Victor Hugo, Dumas, Balzac, Flaubert and other French literary greats, so why shouldn't Marcel Proust also have his masterpiece, ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' turned into a comic strip? After all, argues its adapter and illustrator, Stephane Heuet, Proust may be considered a giant of modern French letters, but who actually reads his immense semiautobiographical novel these days?

title: Clinton's Lawyers Attack Inquiry as 'Standardless'
description: President Clinton's lawyers today accused the House Judiciary Committee of rushing toward a ''dangerous, standardless inquiry'' on impeachment and argued that under historical precedent none of the evidence put forward by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, ''is remotely sufficient to warrant an impeachment inquiry.''

title: Big Swiss Bank Is Shaken Up By Hedge Fund
description: As more fallout from the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P. cascaded over Europe today, the chairman and three high-ranking officers of UBS A.G. of Switzerland resigned -- the most visible casualties to date of dealings with the United States hedge fund.

title: Black Protest Delays Sitcom Episode
description: A protest headed by a Los Angeles-area African-American group that accused a new sitcom of making light of slavery has led the UPN television network to delay the scheduled first episode of the show. It will substitute the second episode for the series' premiere on Monday night.

title: Holding an Uneasy Line In the Long War on Heroin; Methadone Emerged in City Now Debating Its Use
description: When New York City awoke to its first heroin epidemic just after World War I, the City Health Department lured addicts into treatment with the promise of free heroin.

title: After Mutiny And Invasion, Lesotho Plans A New Vote
description: Nine days after South Africa's disastrous invasion of tiny, mountainous Lesotho, the kingdom's Government and its opposition parties finally sat down at the negotiating table today and agreed that new elections would be held within 18 months.

title: Mr. Pataki's Fiscal Record
description: With the gubernatorial race in full throttle, New Yorkers might soon wonder which of the states described by the candidates is the one they live in. Gov. George Pataki boasts that he has cut taxes, held down spending and presided over an economic renewal. His Democratic opponent, Peter Vallone, says the Governor has a poor fiscal record, saddling the state with more debt, budget deficits and a dismal credit rating. Tom Golisano, an independent candidate, is bombarding the airwaves with accusations that Mr. Pataki has generated $20 billion in new debt and actually raised taxes. Confused? In fact, these claims contain a blend of truth, distortions and misplaced blame.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: IMF and World Bank Wrestle With Panic and the Future : Shoring Up The World's Shaky Financial Pillars
description: WASHINGTON  It is very hard for policymakers to think clearly about the long term at a time of crisis, let alone to take on the monumental challenge of repairing and remaking two of the most important pillars of the global economy.

title: With IMF Advice Taken, Smugness Is Thailand's New Peril
description: BANGKOK  Little more than a year after Thailand's economic collapse triggered a global financial crisis, the country has been transformed into Asia's poster-child for International Monetary Fund reforms.

title: INTERIM SERVICES IN BID FOR COMPUTER POWER
description: Interim Services Inc., a temporary staff placement company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., made a bid of $123 million for Computer Power Group Ltd. to increase its presence in Australia's recruitment market. Computer Power's directors said they would recommend that shareholders accept the offer. The company offers computer education and training and software services. Interim placed 410,000 people last year. Interim is expected to introduce Computer Power's information technology training business, the Computer Power Training Institute colleges, to the United States, and some of Interim's recruitment services are likely to be introduced into Australia.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Giuliani Is by the Sea; Could It Be a Vacation?
description: ''I'm hanging around and checking out the city.'' That was the first -- and possibly the most accurate -- explanation that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave when reporters asked what exactly he was doing during a three-day trip to Miami, which he announced at the last minute on Tuesday night.

title: At Russian Post Office, Check Isn't in the Mail
description: In a season of crashing banks, plunging rubles, bouncing paychecks, failing crops and rotating governments, maybe it is not the ultimate insult. But the nation that bore Tolstoy and Chekhov and still regards a well-written letter as a labor of love is buckling a little this week, because it can no longer wish good health to Baba Anya in Omsk.

title: 4-Year Sentence In Graduate Test Scheme
description: A California man who pleaded guilty to charges that he organized an ingenious nationwide scheme to sell answers to graduate school admission tests was sentenced to four years in prison yesterday in Federal District Court in lower Manhattan.

title: As the Taliban Finish Off Foes, Iran Is Looming
description: With gunfire snapping in the wind and artillery blasts punctuating his sentences, the commander of the Taliban's front-line forces was in a boastful, triumphant mood today.

title: Chester Lasell, 90, Ex-Brokerage Firm Head
description: Chester H. Lasell, a former president of Morgan Stanley & Company, the Wall Street brokerage and investment banking firm, died Wednesday at Greenwich, Conn., Hospital, where he was being treated for injuries after a recent automobile accident. He was 90 and had lived in Greenwich for 68 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: New Curbs Set For Pakistan And India
description: While Congress debates a temporary waiver of sanctions imposed on India and Pakistan because of their nuclear tests in May, the Clinton Administration is getting ready to release a long list of companies and government institutions in those countries that Americans will be barred from doing business with if the sanctions stay in place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDIEU, SR. SALESIA
description: LEDIEU-Sr. Salesia, M.S.C. on Oct 1, 1998, Missionary Sister of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, esteemed educator, died in Dobbs Ferry, NY at the age of 95. Native of New orleans, LA, she was a mentor to thousands at Mother Cabrini High School, NY and Cabrini College, Radnor, PA. Friends are invited to Viewing Sunday, October 4, 4PM9PM and Monday Funeral Mass, 11AM both at Mother Cabrini High School, 701 Fort Washington Ave, Manhattan. Interment will follow at West Park, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cabrini Mission Foundation, Inc, 222 East 19th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, KALMAN J.
description: LYNCH-Kalman J. On October 1, of Andover, MA. Beloved husband of Charlotte J. (Levine). Loving father of Susan & Peter Infantine of Andover, Rachel DiFeliciantonio of Wayne, PA, and Daniel and Elizabeth Lynch of Greenwich, CT. Cherished grandfather of Katie and Joshua Infantine, Emily and Samantha DiFeliciantonio and Allison and Zachary Lynch. Beloved brother of Estelle Gould, Myron and Jonathan Lynch, all of Florida. Beloved son-in-law of Minna Levine of North Andover. Services in Andover, on Sunday, October 4th. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Temple Emanuel, 7 Haggetts Pond Road, Andover, Massachusetts 01810. For information call the Levine Chapel, Brookline, Massachusetts at 617-277-8300.

title: Honor Student Faces Gun Charge
description: A 15-year-old student at a South Belmar charter school was arrested on a weapons charge Thursday after an unloaded handgun fell from his pocket as he walked up on stage at a school assembly held to honor him as student of the month, school officials said today.

title: About New York; 'Invisible' Life Takes Shape As a City Cares
description: A LIFELESS floral wreath hangs over the doorway of Jose Soriano's tenement in El Barrio. It is the only outward sign of what befell his family inside: they held a desperate overnight vigil when he failed to come home after his shift at a Brooklyn clothing factory. He never returned because he was stabbed to death doing something he loved: walking through Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTZ, MAXWELL
description: SCHULTZ-Maxwell. 88. Survived by wife Estelle, three children, Philip, Arlene and Eva-Lynn, 5 grandchildren, 10 great-grandchildren.

title: Ranger Bats No Match For Yankees' Pitching
description: If good pitching beats good hitting and anything can happen in a short series, how is someone to know which bromide to follow in a three-of-five-game division series?

title: Harvest Home
description: The weather has been unseasonably hot in central Iowa, and farmers who are used to worrying about getting crops out of the fields before the weather turns wintry are harvesting with the air-conditioning turned up full in the cabs of their combines. The Midwest is never more beautiful than at this season, even though the air is dull with humidity. The ditches have ripened into a pale ocherous palette of colors, shades of russet intermixed, and in the fields where soybeans have already been harvested, the stubble lies slicked back like an old man's crewcut. The corn hasn't stood in shocks for 60 years and more, but even as it stands -- dry, skeletal ruins of the plant it was in mid-August -- it suggests cool weather, sharp nights and the plumage of that most autumnal bird, the pheasant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEGMAN, EDWARD
description: WEGMAN-Edward. Died at his home in Paris on September 29. He is survived by his wife Sophie Wegman, his sister Helen Ruth Freeman, his niece Elizabeth Zappala and her children, Miranda, Matthew, Christopher, Jeffrey.

title: Hong Kong Changes Its Tune Over Speculators
description: HONG KONG  A year ago, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia stood up in front of the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and said that international currency speculation should be banned. Bankers in the audience shook their heads, almost pitying a leader so out of touch with how the real world worked.

title: Moody's in a Review Of J. P. Morgan Debt
description: J. P. Morgan & Company's debt ratings were put under review yesterday for possible downgrading by Moody's Investors Service.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Kiss and Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: Against Rangers, Only Rain Stops the Yankees
description: David Cone's quivering lower jaw locked on Thursday, when someone asked him whether he would be able to pitch Game 3 after learning of Darryl Strawberry's newly discovered cancer. ''I'm going to be ready to pitch, I'll tell you that,'' Cone said, his voice instantly hardened.

title: Think Tank; Do You Know Post-Modernism? No, but if You'll Hum a Few Bars ...
description: This article was excerpted from an essay by Kevin J. H. Dettmar, an associate professor of English at Clemson University in South Carolina, in the Sept. 25 issue of The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Down and Out at the Hedge Fund? Maybe, but Don't Bet on It
description: How many lives does John W. Meriwether have?

title: Journal; Porgy And Bill
description: If truth is fungible in America these days, then let's have beauty. Beauty is Audra McDonald singing ''My Man's Gone Now'' from ''Porgy and Bess'' at Carnegie Hall, as Michael Tilson Thomas's San Francisco Symphony wraps her in a Gershwin hurricane. And it's a peculiarly American kind of beauty at that -- the boundaries of class, of race and of high and low art all fall away in ratification of the ideal that is democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENCHLEY, MARJORIE B.
description: BENCHLEY-Marjorie B. On October 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel Goddard. Mother of Peter Bradford and Nathaniel Robert. Grandmother of three and great grandmother of one. Interment is private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Nantucket Cottage Hospital, Nantucket, MA. 02554.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Sept. 25 about the English painter Jason Martin referred incorrectly to his show at the Robert Miller Gallery in Manhattan, through Oct. 10. It is not his New York gallery debut; the resume provided by his London gallery omitted a 1995 solo show at the Cristinerose Gallery, which was then in SoHo and is now in Chelsea.

title: Poetry in Prison Opens Cell Doors and Minds
description: Until very recently, the pitch for a contemporary movie celebrating the life-saving power of poetry would have been laughed out of every Hollywood studio. Hail, hail, the conquering poet? Please, you must be kidding. But the rising popularity of competitive ''slams,'' in which poetry, rap, performance art and stand-up comedy converge and ignite has redefined a literary form traditionally associated with bearded bohemians and nebbishy bookworms.

title: In Latest Documents, Little Gain for Anyone
description: More than nine months ago, on Jan. 13, 1998, as Linda R. Tripp was preparing to surreptitiously record a conversation with Monica S. Lewinsky at a hotel in the Virginia suburbs, a member of the Whitewater independent counsel's staff explained the purpose of the enterprise.

title: Indonesia Plans to Merge 4 State Banks Into One
description: Indonesia said yesterday that it would merge four state banks in the next two years and inject 1.6 trillion rupiah, or $148 million, into the bank as part of plan to fix its devastated banking industry. The four banks will operate normally during the merger, with none of the 584 branches shut and none of the 22,800 workers dismissed, said Tanri Abeng, the Minister of State Enterprises. The merged bank, to be called Bank Mandiri, may be taken private, he said.

title: Beliefs
description: Whether or not anyone has cited the story of David and Bathsheba either to defend or denounce President Clinton on Sunday morning television, plenty of people have done so in the Sunday morning pulpits. Quite a few of them have even called Walter Brueggemann, professor of Old Testament at Columbia Theological Seminary in Decatur, Ga., for advice.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Thursday, about the Audities Collection, an archive of electronic music instruments on display in Burbank, Calif., misspelled the surname of a film composer who used one instrument. He is Pat Gleeson, not Gleason.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page on Sept. 17 about Bradley McCallum, the artist in residence at the New York Civil Liberties Union, omitted the name of an artist who worked with him to create ''War Tools 2,'' a 1991 art exhibit in New Haven. She is Elise Wright.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, ARTHUR
description: RUBY-Arthur, M.D. We mourn the loss of Dr. Arthur Ruby, a most illustrous member of the Alumni of NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Ruby was the ultimate physician pediatrician who for many years served his patients and their families with utmost professionalism and compassion. He was loved, highly admired and respected by all he served and all who knew him. He was President of the Class of 1942 and led the Class for almost 60 years with extreme loyalty, dedication and devotion. He was proud of the Alumni of our school and we were always proud of him. The Alumni have lost their standard bearer. Our unique role model is gone. We express our deepest sympathy to Eleanor, his most devoted partner and spouse, and to his sons, Drs. Eric and Kenneth Ruby, and to his entire family. Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP The Frederick H. King Professor and Chairman, Department of Medicine NYU School of Medicine and Director, Medical Services Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals

title: Take Gypsies, Add the Danube And Mix Well With Jubilation
description: It must have seemed that there were two different films wrapped up in Emir Kusturica's Palme d'Or-winning ''Underground'': a tragic political allegory and a furiously Rabelaisian frolic. (The real artistry in ''Underground'' was his seamless way of weaving them together.) Now the lighter side of Mr. Kusturica's boisterous talent is let loose in his much sunnier ''Black Cat, White Cat,'' which will be shown at 8:45 tonight and 4 P.M. tomorrow as the centerpiece of this year's New York Film Festival. It's a mad scramble through the Felliniesque realm of Mr. Kusturica's imagination, and it proves nothing if not this much: give this man the Danube, gypsy musicians and a camera and you've got a party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRANGE, RANDALL S.
description: STRANGE-Randall S., 48. Of Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, formerly of New York City and Virginia, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, after a long illness. Employed as Senior Litigation Counsel for W.R. Grace and Co., and graduate of the University of Virginia Law School. Devoted companion to the late Hugh Docker. Survived by his parents, Forrest and Ruth Strange; sister, Debra Seale; nephew, Damien Seale; and his close friends, Larry Smart, Lance Shaw, and Jim Weingarten. Burial will be in Topeka, Kansas.

title: EQUITY OFFICE TO BUY WORLDWIDE PLAZA IN NEW YORK
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest owner of office properties in the United States, agreed to buy New York's Worldwide Plaza for about $310 million in cash and securities. Equity Office Properties, a Chicago-based real estate investment trust headed by the billionaire financier Sam Zell, will pay $110.6 million in cash and $199.3 million in partnership units to the seller, the investment bank Blackstone Group Inc. It will also assume $268.1 million of debt. The purchase is part of a strategy by Equity Office to expand in the New York market. Blackstone paid less than $400 million in 1996 for the 47-story condominium and office building.

title: Experts Tie Sell-off of Alcatel to Concerns About Transparency : U.S. Pension Funds Unnerve French
description: PARIS  In one of the most punishing days ever suffered by a single stock, Alcatel Alsthom, the French telecommunications giant, plummeted 38 percent on the bourse in Paris in a few hours on Sept. 17 before trading in the shares was suspended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSTON, LISA
description: HOUSTON-Lisa, age 85, died September 30, 1998 in Bristol, ME. Surviving are her husband Frederic P, children are; Douglas C Houston and Jane C McCready; two granddaughters. Burial will be in Stansted Mount Fitchet, England.

title: Serb Troops in Kosovo Seem to Halt Operations
description: For the second day, the thud of artillery and columns of smoke from burning villages were largely absent from much of Kosovo Province, leading Western officials to conclude that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia had ordered his troops to halt obvious operations against separatist rebels.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, NORMA A.
description: SCHNITZER-Norma A. On October 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Ellen Silber and the late Ronald Schnitzer. Dear mother-in-law of Alvin D. Silber. Devoted sister of Pearl Schainman and Martin Sandberg. Adoring grandmother of Kenneth Silber, Theodore and Edward Schnitzer. Service Sunday 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALSTED, KATHARINE (PATTERSON
description: HALSTED-Katharine (Patterson). Of Needham, MA., formerly of Plainfield, NJ and Dorset, VT, on September 29, 1998 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Osborne, loving mother of Margaret H. Tenney of Lyndeboro, NH, E. Bayard Halsted of NYC and Alford, MA, and David C. Halsted of the U.S. Embassy in Chad. Also survived by six loving grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, NANCY HILL
description: WARNER-Nancy Hill. The Alumnae Board, Trustees, faculty, staff and alumnae of The NightingaleBamford School mourn the loss of our beloved friend. A member of the Class of 1932, Mrs. Warner served as President of the Alumnae Board and as an Alumnae Fund Class Agent. In 1993, she received the Frances Nightingale Service Award for her extraordinary commitment to our School. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Andrea Demirjian '81 Alumnae Board President Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School

title: Trading This [up arrow] Even Up for That [down arrow]; An Exchange for the General Good Was Better for Some Than Others
description: Mount Charleston rises high above Las Vegas, just an hour's drive north of the gambling hothouses on the fabled Strip, but a world apart in spirit. At 9,000 feet, a clear mountain stream called Deer Creek tumbles between towering ponderosa pines and aspens -- Las Vegas shimmering like a mirage in the dusty valley below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss of its esteemed friend Stanley Klein. To his family and his associates at the Herman Goldman, our sincere condolences. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Melvin Salberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Gateway. Haven. Universe. Grand Central.
description: After a $200 million effort to remove 85 years' worth of wear and tear from its marble walls and vaulted ceiling, New York's Grand Central Terminal was rededicated this week. Here, several people with unique knowledge of the Beaux-Arts landmark's history offer their perspectives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SAM
description: SILVERMAN-Sam. Rest easy, Dear Friend. We shall never forget you. Rene and Len Lauren

title: With Two Symphonies, a Beethoven Cycle's Finale
description: Performing all nine Beethoven symphonies in five programs in the space of just over two weeks is a formidable challenge, even when the orchestra knows the music as well as the New York Philharmonic does and when the conductor is Kurt Masur, who has made these works a cornerstone of his repertory.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT PRICES SURGE. Wheat futures rose on speculation that frost had damaged the crop in the western part of Australia, the world's fourth-biggest exporter. December wheat rose 7 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $2.76 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFAND, MORRIS A.
description: GELFAND-Morris A. Beloved companion of Judith Follmann, died on October 1st, 1998 age 90. He seemed possessed of eternal youth, & we will miss him deeply. He leaves family, James Munn Gelfand, Lisa Jay Gelfand, Grant & Amy Ujifusa, Jeffrey and Karen Brooks, & grandchildren Andrew and Zachary Wright, Steven and Andrew Ujifusa, and Elizabeth and Emily Brooks. A memorial will be held at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, Wednesday, October 14 at 11:30 AM.

title: Hall's DeBenedictis Recaptures Title
description: Anthony DeBenedictis of Seton Hall covered the five-mile course in 24 minutes 42 seconds to regain the individual title in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Cross-Country Association championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Size of Raul Salinas Secret Funds Is Doubled
description: Even in Mexico, where people are used to hearing that politicians have fat bank accounts, the Swiss police caused a stir when they announced three years ago that Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of the former President, had about $100 million in secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: No Taste for Lobbying
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosovo and Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: Expanding Methadone Treatment
description: The Clinton Administration's decision to make methadone more accessible to heroin users is a long-needed change in national policy. Gen. Barry McCaffrey, head of the White House's Office of National Drug Control Policy, has proposed allowing physicians to administer methadone in their offices. Currently it is dispensed only in special clinics, limiting the number of people who can use this treatment. Only about 115,000 of the estimated 800,000 Americans addicted to opiates are participating in methadone maintenance programs.

title: G.E. Denies Any Plans to Shake Up Finance Unit
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had no plans to break up its star financial services subsidiary, GE Capital, and assured investors that it would report double-digit earnings growth in the third quarter.

title: SYNOPSYS TO SPIN OFF PART OF VIEWLOGIC UNIT
description: Synopsys Inc., whose technology is used to design computer chips, said yesterday that it would spin off part of its Viewlogic Systems unit to Viewlogic's management team for $58.8 million. Synopsys will retain a 14.9 stake in the unit, which makes chip-design software and sells design-related services for computer circuit boards and other electronic systems. Synopsys, based in Mountain View, Calif., bought Viewlogic in December for about $500 million. Viewlogic, based in Marlboro, Mass., will maintain the right to resell some of Synopsys products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, HERBERT T.
description: WEINSTEIN-Herbert T. We admired him, we respected him, we relied upon him, and we loved him. He was an important part of our lives. We will miss him tremendously. Our deepest condolences to his wife Wendy & his children Jonathan, Adam, and Jordan. Joseph, Michelle, David and Stephanie Jacobs

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York City's decision to close a nursing home in Queens misspelled the name. It is the Neponsit Health Center, not Naponsit.

title: Dean and Elias Turn Back Flyers
description: Third-period goals by Kevin Dean and Patrik Elias gave the Devils a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers last night at Continental Arena to improve the Devils' exhibition record to 2-1-0.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, DR. BARBARA GOODMAN
description: DALY-Dr. Barbara Goodman, age 70 of Port Washington, L.I. on October 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Stanley. Loving mother of Paul and Marian Daly. Also survived by her sister, Ruth Cohen and nieces; Helen Cohen and Lisette Bralow. A memorial visitation will be held at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington, Wednesday, October 7th from 10 A.M. to 11 A.M.

title: HALLIBURTON TAKES ACTION TO SAVE ABOUT $250 MILLION
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that it would eliminate about 5,250 jobs and close about 400 offices worldwide as part of its plan to save about $250 million a year from its acquisition of Dresser Industries and to reduce expenses as lower oil prices cut into its business. The job cuts are in addition to about 2,000 workers the company has already eliminated because of low oil prices. The cuts reduce the work force of the Dallas-based company by about 7 percent.

title: Wrenching Changes Force Jakarta to Backtrack on Reform
description: SINGAPORE  In the 14 months since Indonesia turned to the International Monetary Fund for assistance, its economy has plunged so deeply into recession that the Fund has been forced to ease the austerity and reform program it sought to impose in exchange for loans worth more than $40 billion

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHENKEN, BEE & HOWARD
description: SCHENKEN-BEE & HOWARD Lovingly remembered on your Birthdays and everyday

title: HOMESTAKE MINING TO TAKE CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: The Homestake Mining Company said yesterday that it planned to take third-quarter pretax charges of $188 million because of continued low gold prices. The San Francisco-based gold producer said it also expected to report a $17 million pretax loss in the quarter because of the continued decline of the Australian and Canadian dollars against the United States dollar. The third-quarter charges include a $76 million write-down that will reduce the carrying value of Homestake's South Dakota mine to zero; a $35 million provision for environmental and reclamation costs at the South Dakota mine, and a $38 million charge for severance and other costs that will reduce the value of its Mount Charlotte mine in Western Australia to zero.

title: Job Creation Slowed By Foreign Turmoil
description: The United States economy produced jobs at the lowest rate in more than two years during September, the Labor Department reported. Economists called it the most persuasive evidence yet that the financial crisis abroad is slowing the domestic economy.

title: Father Watches Son From Afar
description: Chuck Knoblauch, the Yankees' second baseman, expected that his father, Ray Knoblauch, would attend tonight's playoff game. Ray Knoblauch, a well-known high school baseball coach in the Houston area, was stricken by Alzheimer's last year, but he came here to watch the Yankees' series against the Rangers in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPONIYI, OYENIKE
description: KUPONIYI-Oyenike (nee Ilesanmi). We regret to announce the death on Oyenike Kuponiyi who departed from this world on September 24, 1998.

title: No Yielding To Inspectors By Baghdad
description: Iraq failed to gain any ground here this week and decided today not to resume cooperation with arms inspectors after days of hints that a change of policy could be imminent, diplomats and officials said.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; Due Process for Jones
description: To the Editor:

title: Schapiro and Others Shone At the Senior Events in Lille
description: The world championships, which ended in Lille, France, a month ago, had a full program of events for older players. The winners of the Senior Pairs were Boris Schapiro and Irving Gordon of England. Schapiro, 89, is the oldest winner of a world bridge title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, BERYL
description: OPPENHEIMER-Beryl. On October 1, 1998 of Manhattan. Funeral Services Sunday 12 noon, Bachman, Kulik & Reinsmith Funeral Home, 17th and Hamilton Streets, Allentown, PA. Contributions to Beryl Oppenheimer Cancer Fund of Sacred Heart Hospital, 421 Chew St., Allentown, Pa. 18102.

title: Exposure in Emerging Markets Is Hampering Drive for Profitability : European Banks Put in a Tight Corner
description: LONDON  When finance officials of the leading industrial countries gather in Washington this weekend to assess the impact of the crisis spreading through the world's emerging market economies, European bankers will have a particularly painful story to tell.

title: Sense of Urgency Is Dominant
description: There was a sense of urgency today at the MetroStars' practice in preparation for Game 2 of their playoff series against the Columbus Crew Saturday night at Giants Stadium.

title: Pauline Julien, 70, Chanteuse Who Inspired the Quebecois
description: Pauline Julien, who sang songs of passion and of tender love, died on Wednesday in Montreal. The chanteuse, who was 70, was most strongly identified with the songs she sang in the cause of a separate and independent Quebec.

title: 12 Indicted in Westchester Phone-Sale Stock Fraud
description: The 2 owners and 10 employees of a Westchester County securities firm were indicted today on charges of grand larceny and fraud, accused of using high-pressure telephone sales tactics to defraud 8,000 investors nationwide of $100 million, officials said.

title: Despite Rulings, Aides Refused to Answer Certain Grand Jury Questions
description: Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel, asserted lawyer-client privilege and refused to answer grand jury questions even after a Federal appeals court held that he was not entitled to such a claim, according to transcripts of his testimony.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STEADIES. The dollar pared back most of its losses against the mark after tumbling to a 20-month low as European stock markets fell. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.6458 marks, down from 1.6467 marks on Thursday.

title: When Democracy And Liberty Collide; Finding Reasons for Optimism About Authoritarian Regimes
description: The worldwide trend toward greater democracy is generally thought to be one of the clearest and most unarguable benefits of the end of the cold war. But recent developments in once hopeful nations like Russia, Peru, Algeria, Cambodia and the former Yugoslavia, among many others, have begun to give even the most devoted democrats pause.

title: Donors to McCall Campaign Got Pension Fund Contracts
description: Executives of a prominent Los Angeles investment firm took a striking interest late last year in the fortunes of a faraway public official little known nationally: H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller.

title: Three Indicted in Slaying Of Abducted Queens Man
description: A state grand jury has indicted three men on racketeering, kidnapping, murder and arson charges in the shooting of a Queens man whose remains were found in the trunk of a burning car in Harrison last year, the authorities said.

title: An Overnight Success in 9 Seasons
description: Shane Spencer was 18 years old, and the Yankee scout who watched him did not know if he would hit for power, did not know if he would become a good outfielder. But the scout was sure that Spencer loved to play baseball.

title: Tyson's Evaluation May Be Released
description: After losing a battle in a Nevada courtroom Thursday evening, Mike Tyson will have to allow members of the Nevada State Athletic Commission to publicly investigate the details of a psychological evaluation he underwent last week at Massachusetts General Hospital if he has any chance of getting his license reinstated by the commission.

title: A Bashful Larry Bird Joins Hall Of Fame
description: A crowd of more than 200 was waiting across the street, but he decided not to attend the unveiling of his bronze statue. He also escaped most of the crowds in the hotel lobby -- the kids who skipped school, standing next to their fathers wearing faded No. 33 Celtics jerseys.

title: Dow Reverses 2-Day Plunge but Ends Week With a Loss
description: After plunging the last two days, stocks rallied yesterday. But the recovery may be no more than the expected rebound after a long fall.

title: Islanders Withdraw From Talks With Nassau County on New Hockey Arena
description: The New York Islanders today withdrew from negotiations with Nassau County over the construction of a new coliseum and referred all matters concerning the team's future on Long Island to Gary Bettman, commissioner of the National Hockey League.

title: Excerpts From Letter Demanding a Definition of an Impeachable Offense
description: Following are excerpts from a letter dated today from President Clinton's lawyers and the White House counsel to the chairman and the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee demanding a definition of an impeachable offense before the committee moves forward and contending that nothing alleged against Mr. Clinton rises to that standard:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, MINETTE
description: KUSHNER-Minette (nee Permut). On October 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harvey Kushner. Loving mother and friend of Leslie and Mitchel Mitchel, Stephen Kushner, and Barrie and Matthew Kornberg. Adored nanny of Brandon and Brittany. Dear sister and sister-in-law of Michael and Connie Permut and Edward and Ann Kushner. She fought with courage and strength. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. Services Sunday 1:30 PM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: On Impeachment Hearing, Put Partisanship Aside; In Country's Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Fearing More Poisonings, Officials Seek to Curb Use of Toxic Weed
description: Eager to prevent more teen-agers from poisoning themselves by eating jimson weed seeds, Monmouth County officials plan to meet Monday to discuss removing the plants from Farmingdale and Howell Township and starting a campaign to criminalize use of the seeds.

title: Haitian Asylum Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Lion's Share of South Korean Credit Still Goes to a Favored Few
description: SEOUL  Time was when the chieftains of leading conglomerates in South Korea could demand credit from their favorite banks and get what they wanted with little if any evidence of an ability to repay.

title: Oxford to Drop Coverage for 26,000 in Medicare H.M.O.'s
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the biggest managed care companies in the Northeast, said yesterday that it was dropping coverage for more than 26,000 elderly members of its Medicare health maintenance organizations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The cancellations, mainly in five suburban counties north of New York City, take effect on Jan. 1.

title: Schumer Wins Endorsement Of City Employees' Union
description: District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City municipal employees, announced yesterday that it was endorsing Representative Charles E. Schumer over the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato, in the campaign for the United States Senate in New York.

title: Philippine Airlines' Unions Approve a Recovery Plan
description: A week after it closed with an outpouring of tears and sentimental songs, Philippine Airlines gained a new lease on life today, as its employees resoundingly approved a recovery plan.

title: Weighing In With 16 Boxes Of Evidence
description: The materials released today by the House Judiciary Committee come from the boxes of evidence that Kenneth W. Starr sent to Congress four weeks ago to support the case for impeaching President Clinton.

title: Kosovo and Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Pride In the Gains Of a Nation
description: In a cocoon of loyal and wealthy supporters, President Clinton said today that he must ''live with the consequences'' of his mistakes, as he contended that Democrats should take pride in the achievements of his Presidency and take heart from its possibilities.

title: Hernandez to Fight Mayweather Tonight
description: Genaro Hernandez (38-1-1) will defend his World Boxing Council superflyweight championship against Floyd Mayweather Jr. (17-0) tonight in Las Vegas, Nev. The fight will be televised by HBO and will be followed by a taped broadcast of the Oscar De La Hoya-Julio Cesar Chavez welterweight championship bout, which took place on Sept. 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MURRAY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Murray. The Officers and Members of the New York Joint Board, Unite express deep sense of loss at the death of Murray Goldstein, former Manager of the New York Joint Board, ACWA, ACTWU, Unite. He served as Vice President of ACTWU, Vice President of the Sidney Hillman Health Center, Director of the Amalgamated Bank of New York, and Director of the Amalgamated Life Insurance Company. He also served as Chairman of the Workmens Circle, the National Board of Histadrud, American Labor ORT and the Jewish Labor Committee. Murray retired from the New York Joint Board in 1981. His kindness and inspiration will be deeply missed. Our sympathies are extended to his wife Gladyce, his children Bruce, Donald, Stanley and Robert, their spouses, his seven grandchildren, and two sisters.

title: Congress Misbehaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio State's Germaine Looks Forward to Hits
description: His build is comparatively slight, his face boyish, his voice so soft that his linemen often wonder whether they are hearing the play correctly. The times Joe Germaine looks most like a quarterback is when he's stoically picking himself up off the turf. That's the way his Ohio State teammate and protector, Rob Murphy, an offensive guard, sees it. And yes, Murphy concedes, the pocket sometimes collapses in the Buckeye backfield.

title: Panel Releases Conversations Taped by Tripp
description: The House Judiciary Committee today released the final mass of evidence in its consideration of impeachment charges against President Clinton, offering a pungent store of furtive tapes and grand jury delvings into Mr. Clinton's intimate relationship with a White House intern.

title: TRW MAY SPLIT ITS AUTO AND SPACE BUSINESSES
description: TRW Inc. may split its automotive business from its space and military unit as a way to increase the company's ailing stock price, the company's chief executive said yesterday. ''The companies may be worth more separately than the current market value,'' TRW's chief executive, Joseph Gorman, said in an interview. The Cleveland-based TRW, the nation's largest maker of automotive air bags, is looking to ''unlock the value'' of the company, Mr. Gorman said. Profit margins from its auto-parts unit have narrowed for two quarters. TRW's stock has risen about 32 percent in the five years that ended on Wednesday, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has more than doubled. TRW's shares rose $1.8125 yesterday, to $45.625.

title: Despite Deal, Family of Man Who Died in Arrest Assails Mayor
description: The family of Anthony Baez, who died in a confrontation with a police officer in the Bronx in 1994, agreed yesterday to a record settlement in their lawsuit against the city, but family members still accused the city of failing to grapple with police brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIEN, HENRY
description: LEVIEN-Henry. On October 1, 1998. Survived by his wife of 51 years Lois, two daughters Nancy Goodman and Louise Levien, sons-in-law Richard Goodman and Robert Eby, grandchildren David & Allison Eby and Eric Goodman, two brothers Edward and Robert. He was greatly loved and will be sorely missed. Service at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Sunday, October 4, 10:45 AM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Initially, I would consider her as an intern who had been maligned improperly. Later on, I considered her a pain in the neck, more or less.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, NORMAN
description: ROBBINS-Norman. Of West Palm Beach, FL., passed away. Beloved husband of Bette, father of Andrew of Berkeley, CA., and David of Cleveland, OH. Devoted grandfather of Ruby, Miles, Jesse, and Elizabeth. Memorial contributions to be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapels, West Palm Beach, FL 561-689-8700

title: Padres Will Start Brown While Astros Rest Johnson
description: Judging by their choice of starting pitchers for Saturday night, San Diego Manager Bruce Bochy and Houston Manager Larry Dierker have differing views on the strategic importance of Game 3 of their National League division series, which is tied at one game apiece.

title: Ruminating And Roaming
description: Sunny Day Real Estate's songs keep shifting gears. When Jeremy Enigk sang ''I want to change everything'' on Monday night at the sold-out Irving Plaza, he could have been explaining the strategy behind the band's music, which keeps transforming itself. As Mr. Enigk ponders solitude, all-consuming love and questions of purpose, the tunes wander from midtempo rumination to punk overdrive, from lethargic waltzes to ethereal falsetto melodies. They hold echoes of the Beatles, Pearl Jam, Crazy Horse, Jane's Addiction, Peter Gabriel and R.E.M., without lingering on any of them. Often, the songs seem to end in mid-thought, as if they're just parts of an unfolding process: a stream of alternative rock.

title: Kosovo and Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitian Immigrant Hospitalized After He Is Taken Into Custody
description: The police said last night that they were investigating the case of a Haitian immigrant who went into a coma shortly after being taken into police custody in Brooklyn last week.

title: Global Warming, or Hot Air?
description: A coalition of business, labor and farm groups called the Global Climate Information Project has been sponsoring two television commercials for the last month opposing an agreement reached in Kyoto, Japan, last December to reduce emissions of industrial waste gases believed to cause global warming. One commercial is a 30-second spot called ''In Common.''

title: Giants Know Just How Buccaneers Feel
description: The Giants see a wounded opponent this week in the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and it is the last thing they want to see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, JESSIE LEONARD
description: HILL-Jessie Leonard. Our deepest sympathy to her son Sam, brother Charlie Leonard, sister Laura Ault, and her extended family. ''May the road rise to meet you. May the wind be always at your back. May the sunshine warm your face, the rain fall softly upon your fields, And until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of his hand. Amen.'' Fondly missed, Your Nurses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, MEG
description: DONOVAN-Meg. 47. On Oct. 1, 1998 at her home in Washington, D.C. after a courageous battle against cancer. Deputy Assistant U.S. Secretary of State for Legislative Affairs and a top aide to Secretaries of State Madeleine Albright and Warren Christopher, Meg, a native of Long Island, NY, had a distinguished 25 year career as one of Washington's foremost experts in international human rights and legislative affairs. But her greatest love and joy was her family. Loving and beloved wife of Stephen Duffy. Devoted and adored mother of Colin, Liam and Emma Donovan Duffy. Beloved and admired sister of Paula Sherwood (Ross) of Pittsford, NY, Mary Ellen (Malcolm Chace Nolen) of New York City, Patrick (Jennifer) of New Canaan, CT, and the late Michael and Elizabeth. Cherished daughter of Daniel J. Donovan of Darien, CT and Rye, NH and the late Arline Brassil Donovan. Beloved stepdaughter of the late Kay Dunfey. Doting aunt of Ian and Duggan Sherwood, Sean, Elizabeth & Aidan Donovan & Graham Donovan Nolen. Services & burial 9:30 AM Saturday, Oct. 3, Church of The Blessed Sacrament, Chevy Chase Circle, Washington, D.C. Visiting hours Friday, Oct. 2, at DeVols Funeral Home, 2222 Wisconsin Ave. NW, Washington, D.C. 202-333-6680. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in memoriam to Lombardi Cancer Center, Georgetown University Medical Center or the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYNIS, DAISY B.
description: KAYNIS-DAISY B. Today is your 91st birthday. It would be nice to celebrate it with me. Life is not the same without you. Love, Sam

title: Colon Cancer Is Not Commonly Found Among Those Strawberry's Age
description: The colon cancer for which the Yankee outfielder Darryl Strawberry will undergo surgery this afternoon is common among people over 50 but is rare for someone his age, 36.

title: SEARS TO SELL ITS PRIVATE-LABEL CREDIT CARD HOLDING
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company will sell the private-label credit card business from its Western Auto Supply car-parts chain, the company said yesterday. Sears, the nation's largest department-store chain, agreed in August to sell most of Western Auto Supply to Advance Auto Parts, as it focuses on expanding its department store business. Sears, with headquarters in Hoffman Estates, Ill., does not break out Western Auto's card receivables from its total credit card business. The company had $17.1 billion of outstanding card balances as of July 4. The card business generates half the retailer's profit.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page on Tuesday about Julian H. Robertson Jr., the chairman of Tiger Management, a hedge fund, characterized the nature of some recent losses incorrectly. The fund announced to its partners the loss of $600 million in Russia in August, although overall the fund was up 1.1 percent, or $250 million, for the month. The announcement was made on Sept. 1, not Sept. 15, the day Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts announced Mr. Robertson's gift of $25 million.

title: News Analysis; Kennelly's Star-Crossed Campaign Spurs Search for Reasons
description: For Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democratic Congresswoman trying to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland, the indignities are becoming an almost everyday event.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES I.M.F. ACT EARLIER TO PREVENT CRISES
description: President Clinton today proposed changing the strategy of the International Monetary Fund so it can act earlier to help countries ward off economic crisis, rather than waiting until disaster strikes, when bailouts are more expensive and painful.

title: Reaching For Tissues, But Smiling
description: ''About Sarah'' has been described as a story about priorities: a young woman has to decide whether to go to medical school or stay home and care for her mentally retarded mother. But that decision is almost beside the point. This CBS film, a satisfying, beautifully acted tear-jerker, is just as much about family secrets and whether anyone ever did anyone else a favor by ''protecting'' them.

title: Accounts Went From Possibly Hurtful to Hazy
description: When she appeared in January as the first witness before the grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter, Betty Currie, President Clinton's private secretary, conceded that her memory about important events was ''getting worse by the minute.''

title: Gene Autry, Singing Movie Cowboy Who Rode Champion to Fame, Dies at 91
description: Gene Autry, America's first singing cowboy of the movies and a multimillionaire businessman, died yesterday at his home in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles, said Karla Buhlman, vice president of Gene Autry Entertainment. He was 91.

title: Aide Says Mrs. Clinton Told Of 'Ministry' for Lewinsky
description: Sidney Blumenthal, a senior White House adviser, told a grand jury in June that President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, had suggested to him in separate conversations that Mr. Clinton was simply ''ministering'' to Monica S. Lewinsky in a spiritual fashion.

title: INSIDE
description: South Asia Sanctions Set

title: Countdown to Jubilee: Will Rome Be Ready?
description: ROME is a huge construction site. Actually, it has 700 construction sites, according to the city's mayor, Francesco Rutelli, and about 200 of them are in preparation for the Jubilee, the Catholic Church's celebration of the millennium.

title: Rose Kernochan And Guy Wiggins
description: Rose Alexandra Kernochan, a daughter of Adelaide and John Kernochan of Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Guy Stuart Wiggins, a son of Dorothy and Guy Wiggins of New York. The Rev. Sarah Barber-Braun, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at a private home provided for the occasion in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: A Potential New Star For an Ever-Rarer Art
description: ''COME to the cabaret,'' the famous lyric goes. But when you're in New Jersey, it makes sense to ask, ''Where is it?''

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Grand Central, at 85, Gets a Facelift
description: Built in the heyday of train travel as a lustrous palace of creamy marble walls and chandeliers, the Grand Central Terminal had deteriorated in recent decades into a grimy symbol of urban neglect. Now, at the age of 85, it has been restored to its former Beaux Arts elegance.

title: Joy Yi and Wayne Boatwright
description: Joy Gippum Yi, a daughter of Young Soon Yi of Rye, N.Y., and Dr. Shin Il Yi of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Wayne Albert Boatwright, a son of Suzanne Requa and Thomas Boatwright, both of Van Nuys, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Richard Murdoch performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about wines from Hermann and other towns in Missouri misstated the name of the Roman emperor whose armies were defeated in A.D. 9 by the German hero Hermann. He was Augustus, not Julius Caesar. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: INVESTING WITH: Wesley McCain and Kathy O'Connor; Eclipse Growth and Income Fund
description: WITH his neatly trimmed beard and his book-filled offices, Wesley McCain, co-manager of the Eclipse Growth and Income fund, looks every bit the academic. Indeed, he developed his computer-driven investment strategy as an assistant professor of finance at Columbia University's graduate business school.

title: Picasso Ceramics Touch Down in Tacoma
description: Until Jan. 10, the Tacoma Art Museum in Washington will present ''Ceramics From the Marina Picasso Collection.'' The 61 pieces on display, originally in Picasso's private collection, now belong to his granddaughter Marina and were first exhibited in Spain, by the Fundacion Bancaja in Valencia.

title: Yours, Mine And Ours
description: From beds to electronics, products that are durable enough for children but sophisticated enough for adults.

title: Ms. de Gorostiza And Mr. Rothman
description: Rowena de Gorostiza and Philip Scott Rothman are to be married today by George McKinnis, a village justice of Bronxville, N.Y., at the Bronxville Women's Club.

title: Atlantic City Neighborhood Protests Planned AIDS Hospice
description: For most of the residents of a casino-subsidized housing development here, the plan to build an AIDS hospice in their neighborhood was the last straw.

title: Kathryn Grosz, Scott Miller
description: Kathryn Amy Grosz, a psychotherapist, and Scott Harlan Miller, a public relations director, are to be married today at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs is to perform the ceremony.

title: Coliseum: It's Aging But Cozy
description: WHEN sports executives eye a hockey arena, they see revenue streams. Hockey fans just watch games. This is one subtext to the recent gloves-off court battle pitting the new owners of the New York Islanders against their landlords at Nassau Coliseum. And it may explain why a bad arena from an owner's perspective is not necessarily so awful for a spectator.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WITH ROOTS IN HEAVEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOBBE, MORRIS
description: KNOBBE-Morris (Retired Sgt., NYPD). Beloved husband of Orsola. Devoted father of Michael Max and Tona. Dear brother of Harold. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: Mayan Immigrants Without Spanish Are in Language Limbo
description: Two by two, a procession of boys in heavy pullovers, or lopils, and girls in embroidered huipil blouses dance a jaunty dance, their hands clasped behind their backs, to the tunes of a marimba band.
