They make their way up the stairs of a stage at the front of the room, where, finally, a nervous-looking young girl at the end of the procession ascends in the puffy white dress that is the traditional clothing of a Mayan bride and is crowned the year's Queen of San Miguel.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MUSEUM MILE

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the razing of older houses and their replacement by luxury homes included incorrect figures for a home being built by Ira Rennert in Southhampton, L.I. The main house in the Rennert complex is to be 59,000 square feet, according to Paul Houlihan, chief building inspector for Southampton, and the total for all five buildings that have been approved so far is to be 78,000 square feet. Permission for a 17,000-square-foot garage and a gatehouse were denied by the town, and Mr. Rennert has not yet submitted a modified application.

title: Where Walls Saved History
description: CHINA is modernizing so fast that it is sometimes hard to get a good feel for yesterday, let alone its ancient past. So, though it is a bit difficult to get to, the ancient walled city of Pingyao, about 430 miles from Beijing, is well worth a trip.

title: An Absurdist Who Savors the Poetry of Technology
description: HE conceptual sculpture of the Canadian-based artist Jana Sterbak has inspired reams of humorless, abstruse theoretical writing that leaves none of her layered metaphors unturned. Yet Ms. Sterbak's work -- seductive, intensely physical and edged with dark absurdity -- delivers a mind-body frisson unknowable by intellect alone.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: With Archibald Cox and Richard Nixon, it was a question of what the President knew, and when. With Ken Starr and Bill Clinton, it seems to be a question of whom the President knew, and how often. Interesting.

title: AIDS Continues Move Among Heterosexuals
description: AS the AIDS epidemic matures, Westchester mirrors a worldwide trend as the disease continues its spread among heterosexuals. The majority of AIDS cases in the county are now among intravenous drug users, and cases among women and adolescents have been rising steadily. Minority groups have particularly been hit hard by the disease, the County Health Commissioner said.

title: Wrongful Death Suit
description: After a grand jury exonerated the police officers who shot and killed her son, Renee Malone, the mother of Chris Malone, announced that she would file a wrongful death suit.

title: An Innocent Abroad on the L.I.R.R.
description: IT'S not like I hadn't been warned.

title: Susan Blank and Barry Gloger
description: Dr. Susan Blank and Dr. Barry Stephen Gloger are to be married today in Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi James Prosnit is to officiate at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. Victoria Blank and Lester Blank.

title: The New People
description: AMERICA THE WISE The Longevity Revolution and the True Wealth of Nations. By Theodore Roszak. 272 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $25.

title: Date That Calls For Judicious Attire
description: IT'S my first day in divorce court, and I'm waiting anxiously in the hall for my lawyer -- worried about how my life will change, whether my two children and I will have to move out of the city. And I can't believe what I am wearing.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 4, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: VANITAS

title: Miss Fairchild and Mr. Storkerson
description: SAMANTHA FAIRCHILD grew up in Manhattan, the third of four sisters whose names all begin with S. Miss Fairchild, who is nicknamed Sam, was known among her sisters -- Stephanie, Suzie and Serena -- as the wild, zany, adventurous one.

title: The World; In Mexico, Changing Times Mean Changing History
description: THIRTY years ago, soldiers and policemen crushed Mexico's first major pro-democracy movement with a massacre of demonstrators that is often likened here to the Tiananmen Square massacre in China. Ever since, successive authoritarian governments have stuck to an official history that blames the middle-class demonstrators, the principal victims, for the violence.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions with the art listings on page 47 of the Arts & Leisure section today are reversed. The upper picture shows Faith Ringgold's acrylic on canvas ''Listen to the Trees.'' The lower one shows Degas's print of ''The Hourdel Road, Near Saint-Valery-sur-Somme.''

title: Editorial Observer; The Push to 'Broaden God's Market Share'
description: Dormant churches could once fend off dismemberment because communities regarded empty houses of worship as sacred. But in the big city today, a church that stops breathing for even a moment is fair game for wrecking or secular conversion. In my own neighborhood in Brooklyn -- historically known as ''the city of churches'' -- one church has become a supermarket and several others have been refitted as apartments. With church architecture in vogue and shrinking congregations barely holding on, developers keep an eye out for houses of worship that might soon go dark.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: In his article on Ken Starr (Sept. 6), Michael Winerip writes: ''Another prosecutor, say a streetwise one who lit his cigar and had spent a career fighting serious crime, might have formed a different perspective on a President who lied about sex in a dismissed civil suit.''

title: You Call That An Interest-Rate Cut?
description: When the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee finally delivered a long-clamored-for reduction in short-term interest rates, financial markets were underwhelmed. The Fed lopped a quarter-point from the Federal funds target rate and left the discount rate unchanged, the smallest move available to it, and said the action was born of a desire to ''cushion the effects of weakness in foreign economies and less accommodating financial conditions domestically.'' Many analysts called it insufficient to relieve pressure on embattled countries like Brazil and Japan or to deter the flood of money into United States Treasuries, and predicted further cuts this year; others hailed the move as confirmation that the Fed now regards faltering growth as a more imminent threat than inflation.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MEETINGS WITH THE ARCHANGEL By Stephen Mitchell. Harper Flamingo, $24.

title: BOOKEND; 35 Years of Fireworks
description: This year marks the 35th anniversary of the founding of The New York Review of Books, the intellectual biweekly whose bricklike logo and headlines have become the Dow Jones ticker tape of highbrow culture. Inside, crowning its columns of text and footnotes, are the equally trademark drawings of David Levine -- caricatures of fang-dripping politicians and novelists with dirigible- like heads -- which are so ingrained in our imaginations that we take them for granted, like Woody Allen's output. Over the span of four decades, the magazine has maintained its identity while so many others have aged, morphed or entered the elephants' graveyard. Under the editorship of Robert B. Silvers, The New York Review has projected a steady beam. What's remarkable about the Review is that it has managed to reach middle age without ever having enjoyed the flush of youth. It was born old: it came out of the cradle cranky.

title: A South Carolina Town With Arts as Revival Focus
description: NICHOLAS SMITH, who has homes in Britain and France, now also has one in this small town of 10,000 residents.

title: Sugar-Free Design
description: It all began with a bump on the head.

title: Hearts of Darkness
description: WE WISH TO INFORM YOU THAT TOMORROW WE WILL BE KILLED

title: Outside Expert Reportedly Hired To Investigate Grand Jury Leaks
description: A Federal judge has reportedly appointed an outside expert to assist her inquiry into whether the office of the Whitewater independent counsel illegally leaked grand jury evidence about the Lewinsky investigation.

title: For the Good Book, A Good Sales Pitch
description: It was not a standard airplane banner that caught the eyes of sunbathers from Jones Beach to the Hamptons on the Labor Day weekend. Instead of hawking suntan lotion or happy hour drinks, the sign read: ''Make a Friend in a Very High Place. Marble church.org.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 6 about Kenneth W. Starr misstated a conclusion of another independent counsel, James C. McKay, in an investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in the late 1980's. While McKay did conclude that Meese had broken the law, it was not by accepting favors from a defense contractor. McKay's report stated that Meese filed a false tax return and had a conflict of interest related to stock ownership.

title: Ideas & Trends; With Prozac, the Rose Garden Has Hidden Thorns
description: FOR millions of people, Prozac and similar drugs have fulfilled the promise of freedom from depression. But for some patients, adjusting to a life without misery turns out to be far more difficult than they imagined.

title: All in the Family
description: There are many wonderful creations in this bedroom, beginning with its occupant, Sofia Rower, who will soon turn 3. Her parents, Maria Robledo, a photographer, and Holton Rower, an artist, who live in a Manhattan loft, brought the considerable talents of several generations to bear on the tiny space, which makes up in personality what it lacks in size. (It's about 9 by 11 feet.)

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: INHERITANCE

title: Democrats Appear Vulnerable in Senate Races
description: In 1992, in a good year for Democrats, Barbara Boxer won her seat in the United States Senate with 48 percent of the vote. In the six years since, she has been a reliably outspoken liberal from a state that is less so, and never managed to lift her job approval ratings above 50 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAITMAN, LEO
description: CHAITMAN-Leo. We regret to announce the passing of Leo Chaitman on Monday, September 28, 1998. He is survived by his wife Lottie, daughter Rochelle, son Barry and his grandchildren. He will always be remembered for his kindness and generosity to all.

title: Employment Notes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who has directed 20 state agencies to help disabled people find jobs, is seeking more than $1 million in Federal funds. The Governor has designated the state's Department of Labor as the lead agency, saying also that he wants the state to help the disabled find jobs ''without fear of losing their health insurance and other critical benefits.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an organization monitoring courts in New York State reversed the backgrounds of two volunteers observing the proceedings at Suffolk County Court in Riverhead. Jacqueline Gordan is a retired teacher and Jean Almazan a retired chemistry technician.

title: Sara Roosevelt, Pierre Stroh
description: Sara Delano Roosevelt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haven Clark Roosevelt of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Pierre Alexander Stroh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wetherill Stroh of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Brendan Griswold performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Episcopal Chapel in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Lisa Orange, Harry Elson
description: Lisa Shawn Orange, the daughter of Amy L. Orange of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Dr. Allan H. Orange, was married last evening to Harry Elson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Elson of Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Force in Bosnia Fails at One Task: A Pullout
description: The American troops patrolling Bosnia still run into a roadblock or an angry crowd every now and then. And even now they uncover illegal caches of weapons, as Company D, Second Battalion, Fifth Regiment, did last week when it searched an aging Serb munitions plant in Bratunac.

title: Margot Gatje And Brad Small
description: Margot Kim Gatje, a daughter of Barbara Wright Gatje and Robert F. Gatje, both of Manhattan, was married last evening to Brad Harris Small, the son of Ann J. Small and Neil B. Small of Convent Station, N.J. Judge Robert J. Ward of the United States District Court in Manhattan officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Prosecuting Bruce
description: To the Editor: With both amusement and irritation I read the ''politically correct'' but factually inaccurate article ''When the Censor Was in the Statehouse'' [Sept. 20] by the attorney Martin Garbus. Mr. Garbus's take on the 1964 Manhattan trial of Lenny Bruce for violation of the state's obscenity statute makes a number of misstatements about a handful of persons now deceased and unable to speak for themselves. Unlike Mr. Garbus, I was in a position to know firsthand. I admit, at times somewhat ruefully now, that I was the prosecutor in the Bruce case; as District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's administrative assistant, as well as chief of his Criminal Courts Bureau, I met with the D.A. regularly.

title: Christina Dutton And Paul Fucci
description: Christina Parker Dutton and Paul Thomas Fucci were married yesterday at the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Lupton P. Abshire performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: When Economic Bombs Drop, Risk Models Fail
description: ''When we examine banks, we expect them to have systems in place that take account of outsized market moves.''

title: A Mellencamp Fan: Guilty as Charged
description: I was shuffling dusty, long-unopened boxes in my basement storage room a few weeks ago when I came upon a heavy carton I had years ago simply labeled ''LAME.'' A pack rat, I had marked the box when I moved back home to Minneapolis eight years ago after living most of the 80's and my 20's in Manhattan. Ripping through the packing tape, I discovered a collection I had adjudged at the time to be the most embarrassing vinyl albums I had ever purchased.

title: Dina Nicholson, Hartley Johnson
description: Dina Marie Nicholson, the daughter of Amydee Nicholson of Dix Hills, N.Y., and William T. Nicholson of New York, was married last evening to Hartley Edward Johnson, the son of Nancy and Elliot H. Johnson of Acton, Mass. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Streetscapes / Park Avenue South and 25th Street; Turn-of-the-Century HQ of Louis Comfort Tiffany
description: THOUSANDS of people are visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art's new exhibition of works by Louis Comfort Tiffany, which is filled with the artist's striking leaded glass, lamps, vases and other decorative pieces. At the same time, thousands are walking unaware past a three-building complex that was once the headquarters of the artist's decorating firm, at 25th Street and Park Avenue South, where a few traces of 19th-century glass, woodwork and trim survive, testament to one of the most fertile minds in American design.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; After 29 Years, A Budget Surplus
description: It had been expected for months, but President Clinton held a big ceremony anyway to announce that the dog days of the deficit were over. For the first time in 29 years, the Government would end the fiscal year with a budget surplus, about $70 billion.

title: In New Jersey, a Push Is on to Teach Youngest Pupils Foreign Tongues
description: ''Rapido, escoge un color,'' Diana Alfaro told a pupil. Quickly, pick a color. ''Morado,'' the boy responded. Purple. Five other second graders holding up rectangles of different colors quickly picked out purple.

title: Doing a Number on the Boss
description: During Robert L. Crandall's 18 years as maximum leader of American Airlines, he was the most brilliant and feared executive in the airline industry, known for his predawn staff meetings and profanity-laden rebukes. But even the chain-smoking Mr. Crandall, who once likened airline competition to war, had to put his pants on one leg at a time. And when he opened his closet in the morning, he faced a rack of more than a dozen nearly identical gray suits.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Mizrahi Shutters Design Shop
description: The fashion world braced itself for a duller show season in Bryant Park tents next month as Isaac Mizrahi, the ebullient designer thought most likely to inherit the mantle of top designers like Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein, announced that he would close his business. Chanel Inc., his backer since 1992, said it was pulling out. Paradoxically, sales of Mr. Mizrahi's collection, estimated at $20 million to $30 million, had begun to pick up. CONSTANCE C. R. WHITE

title: Love Among the Ruins
description: TWO CITIES

title: Armenia Never Forgets. Maybe It Should.
description: FEW peoples in the world have had as turbulent a past, or are as passionately attached to it, as the Armenians. Many of them believe they are alive today only because of their ancestors' near-fanatical insistence on preserving the ideas of the Armenian nation, church and language.

title: At The Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: With Time the Enemy, Bellport Salvages a Tie
description: Long Island

title: Traffic Island or Money Pit?
description: It's not the biggest construction project in New York history. Indeed, skyscrapers have been built in less time. But after three years, renovation of the malls that divide eastbound and westbound traffic on West Houston Street is nowhere near completion, despite the city's having spent nearly $400,000 on the project. And no one seems able to say whether the work will ever be completed.

title: BENEFITS
description: Fostering Healthy Children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, STEPHEN
description: PEARLMAN-Stephen. Born February 26, 1935. died September 30, 1998, Yom Kippur, at home with his family after a long struggle with cancer. The tenacious optimism and courage with which he faced his illness was an inspiration to all who knew him. Beloved husband of Dr. Stefanie Solow Glennon. Devoted step-father of Leah and Hope Glennon, & father-in-law of James Gleason. Adored grandfather of Caleb and Eli Gleason. Cherished son of Judge Ruth W. Pearlman and the late Morris F. Pearlman, Esq. An extremely versatile & gifted actor whose numerous appearances in theater, film and television span more than 40 years. Even when bed-bound, he made us laugh, challenged our intellect & infused us with hope that miracles are possible. The world already feels emptier without him. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial service is planned for late October. Contributions can be made to the Kristen Ann Carr Sarcoma Research Fund, C/O Dr. Murray Brennan, 1275 York Ave, Box E, New York, New York 10021.

title: Tiptoeing Back to the Oilfields
description: IT has been just shy of a year since stocks in companies that serve the oil drilling industry began a long, grueling selloff that has left even bearish energy analysts surprised by its severity. Those who bought last fall, when these stocks peaked, have watched as the Standard & Poor's Oil and Gas Equipment Index has fallen 56 percentfrom its high on Nov. 5.

title: Before the Fast, the Lines. After the Fast, the Deluge.
description: THE SETTING: They flocked to Zabar's, the raincoated grannies, the harried East Side housewives with designer strollers, the nice Jewish boys discussing their purchases on cell phones. It was Tuesday morning, less than 10 hours before the start of Yom Kippur, the day of atonement, when practicing Jews would be fasting. It was also less than 36 hours from Wednesday night, the end of Yom Kippur, when fasting Jews everywhere would once again eat.

title: Cara Ferrin, David O'Shaughnessy
description: Cara Michelle Ferrin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Ferrin of Sharon, Mass., was married yesterday to David Tucker O'Shaughnessy, a son of Ann W. Thayer of New York and William O'Shaughnessy of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Nancy Nelson, a United Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Chanticleer restaurant in Siasconset, Mass.

title: The Nation: Congress's Maze of Choices; Impeachment: Decisions, Decisions
description: CONGRESS is beginning to climb the impeachment tree. Each time the limbs divide, the politicians must decide, this way or that. Each decision will take them closer to one of the outermost branches: impeachment, resignation or some form of Congressional sanction.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The American Way of Death

title: Strawberry's Surgery Is Termed Successful
description: Darryl Strawberry, the 36-year-old Yankees outfielder, underwent what doctors said was a successful and uncomplicated three-hour operation to remove a cancer of his colon yesterday.

title: An Ever-Changing Fleet
description: EVERYTHING old is suddenly new as most cruise lines comply with revised Safety of Life at Sea regulations. This international compact, known as Solas, requires older ships to have smoke alarms and sprinkler systems, plentiful lifeboats and life jackets, and noncombustible materials, especially in kitchens.

title: Beneath AM-FM Sounds of 'Silence'
description: BEFORE you or your grandparents were alive, before the days of Thomas Edison or Jesus Christ, even before the first human beings were around to hear it, there was radio. And it was beautiful. Sweet descending tones, wispy wavering pitches and choruses of percussive pops and hisses filled the airwaves. Only there were no radio receivers in existence to capture them.

title: Islanders' Offense Stalls Against Devils
description: The Islanders took their full complement of players (minus the holdouts Zigmund Palffy and Trevor Linden) into an exhibition game with a bare-bones Devils team last night, and they did not look like a team ready to make its first run at the playoffs in five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOBOW, BEATRICE
description: HOLLOBOW-Beatrice (Bee). The Officers and Board of Directors of Women of Reform Judaism, formerly the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, are saddened by the death of Bee Hollobow, of Chicago, cherished past President. Bee's intellect, creativity and commitment to women and Israel were exemplary. Her zest for life was contagious and so many lives were enriched by her never ending concern, dedication and deeds. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Judith Silverman, President Ellen Y. Rosenberg, Exec Director

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Sappho

title: The Silver Lining
description: Poets nearly always link silver with gold; as if to explain what silver is, they must also explain what it isn't. ''The silver apples of the moon,/The golden apples of the sun,'' sings William Butler Yeats. Silver is light from the sun reflected off the mineral face of the moon. It is colorless, ambiguous and cool. Like the poet's silver tongue, it intrigues and hypnotizes.

title: Reign of Terror
description: BAADER-MEINHOF Pictures on the Run, 67-77. Edited by Astrid Proll. Illustrated. 160 pp. New York: Scalo. $24.95.

title: No-Name for Lions May Be Best
description: The last draft was a tale of two quarterbacks -- Peyton Manning and Ryan Leaf -- and the third-best prospect was supposed to be Brian Griese. Charlie Batch was hardly mentioned. Leaf and Manning were to rise to stardom and maybe Griese would later surpass both. But Charlie Batch? He was considered a no-name quarterback with a small game from a small college, Eastern Michigan, a school 40 miles from Detroit.

title: What's Bengali for Recess? Come to P.S. 20
description: After a half hour of teaching the names of colors, Naima Begum, a kindergarten teacher at Public School 20, saw it was time to start an active, engaging game. As she began to sing, the students quickly jumped up and joined her in a conga line around the colorful classroom.

title: Forecaster Is Right On for Gulf Storms
description: After ravaging the Caribbean and Florida last weekend, Hurricane Georges raged through the Gulf of Mexico and lumbered toward New Orleans. There, local television meteorologists stood in front of computerized screens and grimly echoed the National Hurricane Center's official forecast, that New Orleans would be the hurricane's next ground zero.

title: John Cage Before He Let Go
description: THE Sonatas and Interludes are either the sins of John Cage's youth or else the last of his important music. It depends on what you think music is, and Cage had some different ideas about that. The longest of these 20 pieces is a little over four minutes, the shortest not quite two. What made them different from the other music being written in 1948 was the medium: the prepared piano, in which keyboard sound is transformed by strategic insertions of foreign objects onto or between the piano strings.

title: A Visiting Orchestra Gets a Taste of Its Future
description: THE Philadelphia Orchestra, one of the world's most venerable, won its greatest renown backing up Mickey Mouse in Walt Disney's film ''Fantasia.'' The orchestra made movie-music history when Mickey boldly approached the podium to shake hands with the formidable conductor Leopold Stokowski, admire his transcription of a Bach organ work and animate the role of the Sorcerer's Apprentice.

title: Evil's Humble Home
description: If I were to find the photograph of Kaczynski's cabin at MOMA, I would accept the photo immediately as a very striking installation. Imagine the rave reviews: ''The rare simplicity! The beautiful stark lines! Why, it could be Thoreau's!''

title: What Bothers Moralists More About Clinton; Impeach Starr
description: To the Editor:

title: Roddy McDowall, 70, Dies; Child Star and Versatile Actor
description: Roddy McDowall, who provoked tears of sadness, sympathy and joy from millions of moviegoers for his boyhood roles in ''How Green Was My Valley,'' ''Lassie Come Home'' and other film classics of the 1940's, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. Mr. McDowall, who went on to become a versatile character actor on screen and on stage, was 70.

title: Is There Room On a Republican Ticket for Another Bush?
description: I read with interest Sam Howe Verhovek's thorough article on George Walker Bush (Sept. 13). No doubt, this will be the first of many articles analyzing Governor Bush, should speculation continue on his possible run for President. However, I thought that Verhovek, at times, raised questions without providing certain obvious answers. Thus, he states, ''There are entire realms of policy -- like, say, foreign policy -- that he has simply never dealt with.'' True enough. But neither had Ronald Reagan before his own Presidency. Moreover, Bush may have available to him members of the foreign-policy A-team that served his father -- not just an older generation of well-known ''wise men'' but also their lesser-known deputies, women and men Bush's age or younger, who are ready to step up.

title: Feasting in the Land of Reindeer and Cloudberries
description: WITH a new contemporary art museum and the centennial of the birth of Alvar Aalto, the great Finnish architect, Helsinki is reminding the world of Finnish design prowess. The capital city can now happily shake off its image as Moscow's dreary stand-in in Cold War espionage movies. On a long weekend there in July, my companion, Franco, and I found the city civilized, animated, often beautiful.

title: Hummingbirds and Other Winged Messengers
description: THE hummingbirds will be leaving soon for their annual peregrination. They've been here since the lilacs bloomed in May. Possibly they arrived sooner, but lilac time is usually when I notice them.

title: Good Education Without a Profit
description: It is misleading to imply (''Magnet School, in Suburbia, and Aiming for a Profit,'' Sept. 20) that urban-suburban magnet schools in Connecticut are both new and dependent on the idea that the profit motive and good education are automatically mutually supportive.

title: When Enough Really Is Enough
description: ELTON PASEA is a mutual fund salesman's worst nightmare.

title: Autumn Leaves, Seen From a Train
description: With the countryside wearing its fall colors, Amtrak offers several scenic train trips in the Eastern United States. Here are a few examples.

title: My Mother, My Decorator
description: When children grow up, parents usually watch them move into the wide world -- and, if the setting happens to be Manhattan, into a small, cramped apartment. This was certainly true of Mariette Himes Gomez, an interior designer, whose 24-year-old daughter, Brooke, recently settled in this 800-square-foot space. But working her own magic on the one-bedroom apartment, the elder Gomez made it appear much larger. ''It's all illusion, isn't it?'' she says.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Return of the Witches

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LALL, ARTHUR S.
description: LALL-Arthur S. Former Permanent Representative of India to the UN and former Counsul General. Memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 7 at 10AM, at Church Center of the UN, 777 UN Plaza, New York City.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Surviving the Fall The Personal Journey of an AIDS Doctor. By Peter A. Selwyn. Yale University, $20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNDERSHEIM, KATHRYN M.
description: GUNDERSHEIM-Kathryn M. On October 2, 1998, of Westampton, NJ. Beloved daughter of Charles M. and Judith A. Gundersheim and the late Claire J. Moffitt Gundersheim. Loving friend of Charles L. Tiggett. Dear sister of Theresa M. Weaver, William C. and Thomas J. Cole, and the late Carolyn and Nora A. Gundersheim. Loving niece of Mrs. Paul (Mary) Haggerty. Dear cousin of Paul and James Haggerty. Dear friend of Stephanie Schwarz. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 11 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Church, Lambertville, NJ. Interment Sacred Heart Cemetery, Mt. Holly, NJ. Calling hours Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Van HornMcDonough Funeral Home, 21 York St., Lambertville, NJ, on Tuesday at the church prior to Mass. Donations to Children's Friendship Project, 9426 Forest Haven Dr, Alexandria, VA 22309-3151.

title: No Germs On the Runway: Lab Chic
description: FOR a roundup of this fall's most directional clothing, look no further than the catalogue for Red Kap Industries, a maker of industrial uniforms. There on the low-gloss pages is a compendium of some of the trendiest motifs that have been coming down high-fashion runways.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Again, a Hint of Hope For Mideast Talks
description: The Clinton Administration pressed hard for a long-elusive interim settlement between Israel and the Palestinians. President Clinton met on Monday with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu and, Yasir Arafat, and again Tuesday with Mr. Arafat, and invited them to return to Washington in mid-October to finish the deal.

title: Fun for all Ages
description: As your parents told you time and time again, sharing is good. The objects, rooms and ideas shown on the following pages are meant to be enjoyed by young and, well, older alike. Well-designed furniture, for example, is sophisticated enough for adults to love, but tough enough for children to appropriate. For the very young, little chairs offer accessible adaptations of grown-up classics. At the talented hands of three preceding generations, a toddler is given a room filled with things whose beauty will grow right along with her. At a time when conspicuous consumption is back in fashion, parents enjoy the simpler pleasures of building (rather than buying) a treehouse with their offspring. And few of us are immune to the charms of antique tableware that recalls the innocence of an earlier time. This is design that brings out the child in all of us. Pilar Viladas

title: Brooms, Rakes and Hope
description: It is a common sight in many city playgrounds: a group of children tossing a basketball as their parents set up a barbecue under a shady tree. But at Courtney Callender Playground, on Fifth Avenue between 130th and 131st Street, that these activities were taking place at all was remarkable, neighborhood residents said.

title: Poverty Spreads, and Deepens, in China's Cities
description: Ma Mingyuan lives on the underside of modern China. In a country where newfound prosperity has rewarded many urban residents with computers and cell phones, he has seen his living standard fall. Today he has neither a job nor health care, nor even a home, beyond a lean-to fashioned from blankets and a sheet of tin.

title: In the Caribbean, Support Growing for the Death Penalty
description: Like other former British colonies in the Caribbean, this is a country that has always venerated the rule of law. But the Government here is now facing widespread international condemnation following its withdrawal from both United Nations and Inter-American human rights conventions because of its dissatisfaction with restrictions they impose on use of the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKINGHAM, HERMAN L.
description: BUCKINGHAM-Herman L., Sr. On September 20, 1998 at the age of 84. Beloved husband of Thelma. Devoted father of Joseph L. Sr., Thomas P., Eugene N. and Herman L. Jr. Foster father of George Sherman. Grandfather of Joseph Jr. and Christopher and two great-grandchildren, Christopher and Ashley.

title: Susan Palmer, John Griffin
description: Susan Battelle Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Morgan Palmer Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. John Robert Griffin, the son of Mary C. Griffin of Tiburon, Calif., and Dr. Robert E. Griffin of Belvedere, Calif. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Feud Eclipses Time of Glory For Leader Of Malaysia
description: Among Asia's leaders, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was notable as a man with a bold vision: a physical and social transformation that would push this nation into the forefront of world affairs.

title: New Evidence Ties Sudanese To Bin Laden, U.S. Asserts
description: The United States has obtained new evidence to link the owner of a Sudanese factory destroyed in an American cruise missile strike last month to a terrorist group backed by Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa, according to American intelligence officials.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHALFIN, MORRIS
description: CHALFIN-Morris. Today is your birthday. Your memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Your children and grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADD, BLANCA MASTERS
description: LADD-Blanca Masters. Of Buenos Aires, London and New York. Of cancer, aged 88 years on September 16, 1998, on Cape Cod. 95 Slough Rd, Brewster, MA 02631. Loving mother of Gloria Mulhall Pullen, Cornelia Masters Goode, and William Conkling Ladd. Grandmother of Teresa Meisel, Nicola Pullen, Anthony d'Aguillo, The Hon. Robert Baillieu and William Conkling Ladd III. Sister of the late Carmen Masters Hadden.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Automobiles section on Sept. 20 about modifications for people with physical disabilities referred incorrectly to the work of Maureen Linden, an employee at Helen Hayes Hospital in West Hav erstraw, N.Y. Although she evaluates the safety of devices that secure wheelchairs in vehicles, she does not conduct evaluations of drivers.

title: Chi Chen and Keith Urban
description: Hong-Chi Chen and Keith Christopher Urban are to be married today at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. The Rev. Michael J. Cindrich is to perform the nondenominational ceremony, with Sister Annette T. Covatta, a Roman Catholic nun, taking part.

title: The Art of the Camera
description: PHOTOGRAPHS as museum treasures? And as subjects for art historians' Ph.D. dissertations? These concepts seem normal now, but Peter C. Bunnell remembers when they were almost unheard of.

title: Karlheinz Kaske, 70, Who Led Growth of Siemens
description: The former chief executive of Siemens A.G., Karlheinz Kaske, died Sept. 27 after a long illness, the company reported from Munich. He was 70.

title: When Business Gets Religion
description: IT'S no secret that a new breed of customer-oriented megachurch is using the tactics of business to win what might be called market share for Jesus.

title: Bruegger's Bagel Shops Close, Leaving a Hole
description: Two weeks ago there were two Bruegger's Bagels outlets in Manhattan. Now there are none, and the circumstances of their closing are something of a mystery.

title: Is There Room On a Republican Ticket for Another Bush?
description: When I started reading Sam Verhovek's article, I wanted to exclaim, ''Good Heavens!'' to Governor Bush and his mother, the former First Lady Barbara Bush. Throughout history, most human conflicts seem to concern the nature of heaven and the requirements for entrance. I was saddened to hear that these good people once argued whether anyone but a Christian could go to heaven.

title: Deflation Has Two Faces, And One of Them Isn't Pretty
description: HOW can lower prices possibly be bad? Who, for example, is not pleased to buy a new car today for less than the same model cost a year ago? That isn't hypothetical. Prices really have dropped for some models. But beware: The cheerful experience of paying less today for a new car, or new shoes, or anything else may become a haunting experience tomorrow.

title: Lila Katzen, 72, Sculptor of Abstract Works
description: Lila Katzen, a sculptor whose abstract works have adorned spaces from Fordham University's campus at Lincoln Center to the United States Consulate in Hamburg, Germany, died Sept. 20 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, JESSIE LEONARD
description: HILL-Jessie Leonard. On September 23, 1998. Wife of the late Ray R. Hill and mother of Samuel Ray Hill. Sister of Charles R. Leonard, Jr., Laura Leonard Ault, the late Emelyn Leonard Righter and the late W.A. Hazard Leonard. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great nephews. Memorial service to be held Nov. 16 at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York City at 11:00 AM. Donations may be sent to the Islesboro Health Center, PO Box 137, Islesboro, ME 04848 or to The American Red Cross, 150 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10023.

title: The Land of 'No' Issues a Blanket Rejection
description: IN an unusual and what some consider drastic move, the Southampton Town Board has imposed a six-month moratorium on commercial development in the heart of Hampton Bays while it conducts a study to recommend zoning changes for the hamlet.

title: Ms. Wolf, Mr. Daingerfield
description: Linda Elaine Wolf and Edward Leonard Daingerfield were married yesterday at their home in Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Jack R. Stevens, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Style; Grand Total
description: Sometimes I try to add up what I am worth. Not my stock portfolio -- that's an easy calculation, verging toward zero these days. No, it is much more interesting to figure out the cost of what I am wearing.

title: Catholic School Is Accused Of Shortchanging Athletes
description: After graduating from O'Connell High School here last May, Billy Russell planned to go to a community college and play football this fall. Instead, he is sitting at home with a diploma that is little more than a piece of paper in a nice red folder.

title: New Postal Trucks Can Run on Ethanol, but Probably Won't
description: Six years ago, with smoke from the burning oil wells of Kuwait barely cleared, Congress ordered the Federal Government to help wean America from gasoline, and decided that by 1998, half of all new Government vehicles should be able to run on an alternative fuel.

title: WORKING
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Man Charged in Death At Baptism Party
description: The police arrested a Brooklyn man yesterday in connection with a slaying outside a baptismal party on Sept. 26.

title: Sarah Gump, Thaddeus Batt
description: Sarah Alden Gump, the daughter of Elizabeth E. Gump and Dr. Frank C. Gump of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Thaddeus Wakefield Batt, the son of Mary A. Reinhardt of Ridgway, Colo., and Donald E. Batt of Denver. The Rev. Edmund M. O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Legislators Tackle Car Pools, Embryos and More
description: Both houses of the Legislature met for a voting session on Monday. Here are some highlights.

title: Gary T. Rowe Jr., 64, Who Informed on Klan In Civil Rights Killing, Is Dead
description: Gary Thomas Rowe Jr., 64, a controversial F.B.I. informer who infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan during the civil rights struggles of the 1960's, died of a heart attack four months ago in Savannah, Ga. He was buried under the name of Thomas Neal Moore, the identity that Federal authorities helped him to assume in 1965 after he testified against fellow Klansmen who were accused of killing Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a civil rights volunteer.

title: POSTINGS: Architectural Tours on Cass Gilbert, a Panel on Current Plans; Design, Then and Now
description: New York City architecture buffs will have the chance in the next few days both to tour buildings by Cass Gilbert, one of the most influential designers of the early part of the century, and to hear assessments of projects that are soon to be translated from drawing boards to steel and concrete.

title: Former President Gerald Ford Suggests a House Rebuke, Not Impeachment, for Clinton
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford broke his silence on the White House scandal today and suggested that the most fitting punishment for President Clinton would be a rebuke in the well of the House, where he would stand and listen while Republicans and Democrats denounced his conduct.

title: A Ship's Position Can Mean a Deal
description: TRAVELERS who shop for cruises carefully eventually recognize that in spring and fall, some ships break out of their usual routes. That's when the cruise lines offer ''positioning'' cruises: The ships move to new waters for the next season, and there are deals to be found.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCK, MARSHALL G.
description: FINCK-Marshall G., 78. Of West Palm Beach. Suddenly of acute leukemia. Former Chairman of Wilson Brothers, President of Enro Shirt Company. Highly decorated W.W. II Naval officer. Admired for his intellect and wit. Survived by his adoring wife Edie, loving son Robert, daughter Nancie Goldsmith & husband Stewart, brother Bud Finch, stepchildren Pat and Michael French, Jim, Tom and Jill Goodkind, and eight grandchildren. A memorial service Sunday, October 11, 2:00 PM at Breakers West Country Club.

title: Protecting Viewers
description: To the Editor: In his article ''Where Have You Gone, Standards and Practices?'' [Sept. 20], Warren Berger says that ''out there alone on the last front lines of censorship are local station owners and network affiliates.'' There is another group to be considered: viewers.

title: Living in a Disney Town, With Big Brother at Bay
description: ONE hot afternoon last month, my wife, Catherine Collins, was riding her bicycle home from the post office here when a blue car with Pennsylvania license plates pulled alongside her. One of the children in the car leaned out the window and asked, ''Can you tell me where Truman lives?''

title: Ah, for the Days When New Music Stirred the Blood
description: I HAVE a bad case of the post-avant-garde blues. Whenever I hear people praise a new piece of music for being ''accessible,'' and for nothing else, I long for the days when new music could strike terror in the soul instead of just aiming to please. Since most of the American music business has been dancing on the grave of difficult music for the last decade, I often find myself playing the role of the Ancient Mariner, spoiling the festivities with obsessive memories of an episode everyone else has forgotten. The avant-garde may no longer represent the music of the future, but now that it has been out of fashion for a generation, it is a good time to reconsider how it fits into the musical past.

title: Robyne Wright, Herbert Camp
description: Robyne Horton Wright and Herbert Latimer Camp were married yesterday in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Donald R. Cutler, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Ardsley Country Club.

title: Plums, Pears and Peaches Star in Simple Baked Desserts
description: TARTS and cobblers are wonderful in the summer but come fall, simple baked fruit comes into its own. Plums can be sprinkled with brown sugar and Marsala, dotted with a little butter and cooked in the oven until they are soft and their juices have been reduced to a thick syrupy glaze. Pears are good baked with white wine, lemon peel and vanilla; peaches can be charred lightly on a grill and then baked with amaretto, the Italian almond-flavored liqueur.

title: Go East, Not-So-Young Man
description: A big piece of the entertainment business just moved from the West Coast to the East Coast. Rupert Murdoch, 67, the media giant whose interests span the worlds of sports, newspapers and entertainment, has relocated his base of operations from Los Angeles to downtown Manhattan. With his lavish home in Beverly Hills still on the market for $19.5 million, Mr. Murdoch has moved into the trendy Mercer Hotel in SoHo. He has been dating Wendy Deng, 31, a vice president in Hong Kong of Star TV, Mr. Murdoch's Asian satellite-TV service. Ms. Deng, Chinese-born and Yale-educated, has been in New York the last few weeks.

title: A Weekend Retreat Where You Gotta Have Harp
description: This month, business executives, homemakers, computer programmers, retirees, and others will gather at a small hotel in Spring Lake to try their hands at an ancient musical instrument: the harp.

title: Sold!; New York Challenges London as the Hot Spot for Wine Auctions
description: CRACK. The hammer comes down on Lot 605, a 12-bottle case of 1987 Montrachet, a white Burgundy from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti. It sells for $5,175. Probably petty cash for the anonymous buyer. At Sotheby's first wine auction of the new season, the Saturday morning crowd consists of eager novices and savvy drinkers, collectors, speculators, consultants, brokers, restaurateurs and sommeliers.

title: Tracy Ballard, John Gorman
description: Tracy Ellen Ballard, the daughter of Dr. Bruce L. Ballard and Eleanor Cross Ballard of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Kevin Gorman, a son of Dr. Susan Black of Lowell, Mass., and Dr. Arthur Gorman of Marshfield, Mass. Rabbi Harold White officiated with the Rev. Margaret M. Graham, an Episcopal priest, at the National Press Club in Washington.

title: Ms. McCaffery, Mr. Mastroianni
description: Maura McCaffery and Francis Nicholas Mastroianni, associates at Boston law firms, were married yesterday by the Rev. Cheryl Anderson at the First Congregational Church on the Green in Washington, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERFREUND, MOE
description: LIEBERFREUND-Moe. On October 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Jessie. Loving father of Norman and daughter-in-law Brenda. Dear brother of Mollie. Adoring grandfather of Jamie and Kara. Devoted uncle. Service Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New Jersey's Roads Rated The Busiest and in Bad Shape
description: New Jersey's roads and bridges are the busiest in the nation and among those in the worst condition, according to a survey released last week by the Road Information Program, a Washington-based nonprofit organization.

title: Evil's Humble Home
description: The photograph of Kaczynski's home fooled me into believing that I was looking at a sculpture or an installa-tion by a minimalist artist displayed in a glorious gallery. As soon as I realized that it was the cabin of the Unabomber, chills ran down my spine. The cabin together with the essay by Richard Ford would make a marvelous traveling exhibition.

title: Yankees Spray Champagne And Think of Strawberry
description: Tim Raines shouted for some attention, shouted in such a shrill fashion that Manager Joe Torre thought one of his players had been injured during a clubhouse celebration. But no one was hurt. Raines simply wanted everyone to listen to him as he climbed on a wooden table and toasted a missing friend.

title: Sexual Healing
description: BY THE LIGHT

title: Outstanding Achievements in Sellavision
description: The Oscars of infomercials took place last month at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas. The ninth annual ERA Awards (ERA stands for Electronic Retailing Association, the trade group of direct-response TV) is the culmination of the industry's yearly convention. With awards in 30 categories, the event tends to run well past midnight, prompting this year's organizers to do away with acceptance speeches. Some valuable maudlin moments have been lost with this change -- like the time several years ago when Jay (The Juiceman) Kordich told the audience about the effects of fruit and vegetable juices on his young wife's libido -- but the event still has a certain something. Here's a look.

title: A Tough Family Portrait With Even Tougher Ideals
description: LAST May, for the first time in the history of the Cannes Film Festival, two Danish films were in competition. One of them, ''The Celebration,'' directed by Thomas Vinterberg, will be shown as part of the New York Film Festival tomorrow and will open commercially on Friday. The other was ''Idiots,'' by Lars von Trier (''Breaking the Waves''), which will be released next year. Both films were accompanied by the directors' heavily hyped document -- a full-blown manifesto of draconian esthetic principles, portentously entitled Dogma 95 -- that infuriated many critics and made fellow filmmakers envious over the attention it received.

title: The Bride Wore Red
description: Donna Karan and other designers have been parading a spectrum from azure to zinc down the runway this season. Michelle Roth is right in step, marching Technicolor merchandise down the aisle. Her retail shop, at 24 West 57th Street, caters to a new breed of bride, one who shuns the traditional white wedding dress in favor of a lime-green beaded sheath or lipstick-red Empire gown.

title: Global Warming Study of East End Sparks Debate on Sea Rise
description: THOSE living on the coast are in trouble,'' George Abar said after watching Southampton Beach being washed away in a hurricane.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; Virtual Youth: Computer Club Clicks on Kids
description: In a composition class that Victoria Martinez, 16, took at Murry Bergtraum High School in lower Manhattan last year, there were about 30 computers. In one class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, DAVID C.
description: BENSON-David C. Of Springfield, New Jersey, on October 1, 1998. Loving father of Kristen Benson of Brooklyn, N.Y., Eric of Berkeley Heights and Karin Benson of Springfield, brother of Daniel of Virginia, also survived by two grandchildren Ryan and Paige Benson. Family and friends are invited to visit with the family at Paul Ippolito Summit Memorial, 7 Summit Avenue, Summit, N.J. on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 6, at 11 A.M. in First Presbyterian Church, Lee's Hill Rd., New Vernon, N.J. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Diabetes Assoc., 101 Eisenhower Parkway, P.O. Box 513, Roseland, New Jersey 07068.

title: Where Has Jurevicius Gone? He May Reappear Soon
description: He was supposed to be the secret weapon to the Giants' passing attack this season, but he has been kept in hiding so well that some fans may have forgotten he was on the team.

title: Names of Next of Kin Requested for Flights
description: Passengers boarding flights to foreign countries or returning to the United States on nonstop flights from foreign countries will now be asked for a name and telephone number for next of kin. The new rule, which was created by a 1990 law but opposed by the Air Transport Association as too expensive to carry out, finally went into effect Oct. 1. The law grew out of the 1988 sabotage of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The Trans World Airlines crash in 1996 and the Swissair crash on Sept. 2 made the need more apparent.

title: Elaine Benson, 74, Writer and Gallery Owner
description: Elaine Benson, whose gallery in Bridgehampton, N.Y., was a fixture on the East End summer art scene for more than three decades, died on Monday at her home in Bridgehampton.

title: For Night-Movie Fans, The Latte, Latte Show
description: ''Monster Maker,'' a 1944 story of a mad physician who infects a concert pianist with a virus and will cure him only if the pianist agrees to marry his daughter, is probably not on sale at most video stores. But it is the type of obscure film that forms the backbone of the collection at Cinema Classics, a video store, cafe and, later this month, a movie theater.

title: In West Bank, Little Arab Control
description: To the Editor:

title: The Witnesses Recall the President And the View From Outside His Door
description: The White House that the American public sees is a place of grandeur and high purpose, the shrine where Presidents greet foreign leaders and host glittering state dinners, where leaders brandish the veto pen and solemnly announce the dispatch of military forces overseas.

title: The Young and the Wireless
description: They may be the wired generation, but when today's teen-agers and children hit the streets, they want to be as unattached as technology allows. Call them the Cordless Kids: now they're adding the latest wireless electronic gadgets to their wardrobes of cargo pants, baggy jeans and high-heeled sneakers. And just as the young want to communicate and be entertained everywhere, their parents want them tethered with electronic links that will keep them within easy reach. These twin demands have caused a boom in portable electronics designed for members of the MTV generation as well as their parents.

title: Everyday Madness
description: My Sister From the Black Lagoon

title: The Plum And Lucy Show
description: THEY'RE twins. They're thin. They're attractively employed, talented, a little vague about their past and, according to one admirer, ''hugely in demand right now.'' Oh, and one other thing: They're English.

title: Amy Roberts And Glenn Fogel
description: Amy Joy Roberts and Glenn David Fogel were married last evening at the St. Regis in New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs performed the ceremony.

title: Frustrated With the President, but a First Line of Defense
description: Not only have Representative Richard A. Gephardt and Bill Clinton never been close, but sometimes they have acted as if they belonged to separate political parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIN, SVI
description: RIN-Svi. 84. Professor Emeritus, Semitic Studies, University of Pennsylvania 1960-1982, died September 26, 1998. Books: Acts of the Gods: The Ugaritic Epic Poetry (with Shifra Rin), Biblical Aramaic, Third Column Acts of the Gods, short stories, poetry. Survived by wife, Shifra (POB 42, Narberth, PA 19072), 3 children (Ruth, Hadas, Adam), and four grandchildren.

title: Every Weird Family Is Weird in Its Own Way
description: TOMATO RED

title: The Carver Chronicles
description: Gordon Lish was my editor (D.T. Max, Aug. 9). Early on, he said to me about my work, ''Never explain or apologize in the writing.'' That is probably what accounted for the serious cuts he made in my first novel, ''The Red Truck,'' published by Knopf in 1987. He took my novel to France for a month and mowed it down from 440 pages to a final 178. He said to me when it was done, ''I wish I could put my name on it.'' I thought, ''You may as well.''

title: What Bothers Moralists More About Clinton; Thomas Comparison?
description: To Editor:

title: Two Species Of Youth
description: Two extremes of youthful fashion reveal a blue-denim generation gap. Bluejeans with a circumference of 60 inches at the hem, on teen-agers, suggest a pair of waltz skirts. In fact, the craze for ''big pants'' came out of rave dance, with its need for free movement. People in their 20's have gone in another direction, embracing 16-inch stovepipe legs with 1940's-style turned-up cuffs; before preshrunk fabric, the cuff took up the extra length factored in at purchase for shrinkage. The divide illustrates the continuing evolution of America's greatest fashion contribution: blue denim jeans.

title: Artists at an Exhibition
description: PORTRAITS

title: INSIDE
description: Brazilians Vote Today

title: But Is It Art?
description: Maria Morris Hambourg doesn't own a camera. In an age when American life has come to resemble an ongoing photo-op, with disposable Kodaks available for $10 at every drugstore counter, Hambourg prefers studying photographs to snapping her own. She holds the title of curator in charge of the department of photographs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and she did once get as far as taking a class on darkroom technique. She didn't much care for it. ''I don't like the dark,'' she says quite simply. ''You can't see anything.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELB, IRVING
description: GELB-Irving. 87. Formerly of Brooklyn. Died September 13, following a prolonged illness. He leaves a legacy of dynamic leadership in the men's hat and cap industry in New York City. Boundless energy, good humor, kindness, unbelievable family devotion and generosity, superior intelligence, confidence, athleticism, and Jewish philanthropy were his trademarks. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 59 years, Bert of Lauderhill, FL; his son and daughter-in-law Arthur and Judi of Lakewood, CA; his daughter and son-in-law Sue Ann and Arnold Grosberg of Schenectady, NY; grandchildren Michael Grosberg and wife Diana of Boston, Amy Grosberg of Schenectady; Nina, Alison and Lauren Gelb of Los Angeles. He is also survived by his sister Pearl Steindel (the late Rabbi Ben) of Queens; Estelle Gelb (wife of his late brother Murray) of New Jersey; Sistersin-law Lottie Horowitz (the late Nathan) of San Antonio; Jean Richek (the late Seymour, Milton) of Chicago. Devoted uncle to many nieces and nephews.

title: Trinidad
description: Of all the cities of the Caribbean, Port of Spain may well be the most cosmopolitan. Stroll its neatly gridded streets with their trim Victorian houses and you collide with influences from Africa and India (both Hindu and Muslim) that are marks of Trinidad and Tobago's two dominant racial groups. But you'll also see manifestations of the thriving cultures of the country's Chinese, Portuguese, British, Lebanese, Spanish and Amerindian minorities -- along with every imaginable permutation and combination of these.

title: Bit of Pier 84 Reopens and a Revival Plan Is Floated
description: Nearly lost along the Hudson River, between the bustling Circle Line tour boats and the towering gray presence of the U.S.S. Intrepid, lies Pier 84, a rotting hulk of wood and concrete that is midtown's only public access to the water. In April, the city closed the pier, citing severe deterioration of its supporting wood piles. But now a section of the pier has been restored to safety.

title: In Vitro Fertilization, Or Your Money Back
description: As a marketing ploy, it seems a bit cold at first, but straightforward. Pay $7,500 for one shot at in vitro fertilization, regardless of the outcome. Or try the money-back guarantee: Pay $15,000 up front for up to three attempts, and if none are successful, the full amount is refunded.

title: Bay Watch
description: Estuaries -- where the mouths of rivers meet the sea -- are traditionally sites of big cities. They are also home of teeming populations of fish, birds, insects and mammals, which often go unnoticed amid the buildings, factories and traffic. An organization called Baykeeper wants people to turn their attention to the Hudson-Raritan Estuary, which extends from the lower Hudson River to the tip of Sandy Hook and is named for its two biggest rivers. The organization has produced a free 12-page color booklet, ''Improving on Nature Is Impossible. Restoring It Is Imperative,'' which describes the complicated ecosystem and the threats to it; for example, readers learn that more motor oil leaked onto roads is washed by storms into the water than is spilled by oil refineries. Baykeeper, with offices in Sandy Hook, is a program of the American Littoral Society, dedicated to protecting coastal areas. The booklet is available by calling (732) 291-0176 or sending E-mail to nynjbay@keepr.org.

title: A Few Laughs With Not-So-Funny Characters
description: NO question, David Saint took the safe way to his debut at the George Street Playhouse. In choosing ''After-Play,'' the new artistic director had a pre ordained winner. Whatever needed to be proven had already been proven elsewhere.

title: A Potential New Star For an Ever-Rarer Art
description: COME to the cabaret,'' the famous lyric goes. But when you're on Long Island, it makes sense to ask, ''Where is it?''

title: Old Shirts Plant the Seed For a New Company
description: It is said that inspiration comes in many forms. For three young fashion entrepreneurs, the muse was a collection of musty old golf shirts.

title: On Language; Stop Me Before I Apologize Again
description: ' Being president,'' a wag said a generation ago, playing on a dreamy definition of love, ''means never having to say you're sorry.'' That truism no longer applies.

title: James Hooper, Marti Meyerson
description: Marti Ann Meyerson, the daughter of Marlene Nathan Meyerson of Tesuque, N.M., and Morton H. Meyerson of Dallas, was married last evening to James Coffin Hooper, the son of Nance and Michael J. Hooper of Swarthmore, Pa. Cantor Mark Malachi officiated at the Meyersons' house in Tesuque.

title: The Collectors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rude Awakening For a Goldilocks Economy
description: It's long been fashionable to compare the state of the United States economy to the blonde in the bedtime story enjoying porridge that is ''just right,'' neither too hot nor too cold. But last week's headlines brought to mind the tale's rarely mentioned denouement, wherein Miss G. is caught napping by some mightily peeved bears. The week's crop of economic reports found exports slumping, manufacturing activity deteriorating and construction spending flattening. The economy surprised analysts by creating far fewer jobs in September -- 69,000, the weakest month in years -- and the unemployment rate rose to 4.6 percent.

title: Restoration Is a Tall Order
description: WHEN the time came, raising the scaffolding around the 150-foot steeple only took a few days.

title: Poster Master
description: THE work of Paul Davis, art director for the New York Shakespeare Festival from 1984 to 1991, has become such a fixture of New York's landscape that Kurt Vonnegut Jr., the writer, declared it ''the face of the city at its best.''

title: A New Battle Plan to Fight Pollution
description: WHO is at fault? It is a question often asked after an environmental spill or another type of accident. Should a faceless corporation be required to pay a fine that it can easily afford and then pass along the cost to its customers? Or should the blame be placed elsewhere -- say on a company vice president who turned a blind eye to violations or an employee who threw the wrong switch?

title: Where to Get Information
description: ABERCROMBIE & KENT INTERNATIONAL, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60523; (800) 323-7308, fax (630) 954-3324; on the Internet, www.abercrombiekent.com.

title: Sports of The Times; Thunder Rolls, and So Do Yanks in the First Round
description: WHAT if it turned out that the Yankees were every bit as good as their 114 victories would indicate? Could they roll through the post-season the way they rolled through the regular season?

title: Large Keyhole To White House
description: Seen from Secret Service post E-6 outside the Oval Office, the White House is a place of intrigue, sometimes juvenile, about the President's private life, according to the latest testimony released by Congress. The narrow hallways of the West Wing are populated with ''rug rats'' and ''hall surfers,'' young aides with White House passes hoping to catch a glimpse of the leader of the free world on his way to the bathroom or to grab a Diet Coke. One overwhelming impression from the documents is how little privacy the President has.

title: Sources
description: A selective list of where to find the architects, designers and products featured in this issue.

title: A Wider Road Threatens Landmark In Wilton
description: WHEN his father bought the business 18 years ago, Jimmy Papanikolaou said his family took comfort in the fact that they were buying a landmark.

title: Fulfilling a Fantasy, Dancing in Queens
description: THE ostensible purpose of the trip was to visit my old ballroom dance teacher, Michele Bowles, now managing a Fred Astaire studio in Forest Hills, and while we were there brush up for Ruthie Levine's wedding. But as the evening approached, I began to think about its real significance. I would actually be dancing in Queens. I had never danced in Queens. If I had danced in Queens, back when it mattered, my life might have been different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. The Officers, Members of the Board and the Administration of OHEL, BAIS EZRA and The Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the tragic passing of Stanley Klein, compassionate, caring, and visionary leader. As President of the Herman Goldman Foundation, his efforts bettered the lives of hundreds of OHEL's children and families. May his family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman OHEL President Max Wasser OHEL Honorary President David Jacobson BAIS EZRA President Saul Wasser OHEL Member of the Board David Mandel Chief Executive Officer

title: Assaults, Protest, Vigilance
description: A swelling tide of reported anti-gay violence in the city has reached Park Slope, with three assaults in the neighborhood recently. Now some residents are urging the police to put more officers on the beat, especially at night, and gay men and lesbians say they are being more vigilant.

title: FRANK!
description: * Next month, Hofstra University will present the first academic conference on Ol' Blue Eyes: ''Frank Sinatra: The Man, the Music, the Legend.'' * Celebs are coming -- Alan King, Tina Sinatra, Skitch Henderson -- but the proceedings are basically egghead. The organizers declined appearances by a Catskills ventriloquist who uses a life-size Frank dummy. * Among the scholarly papers to be presented: ''Mammisimo: Dolly and Frankie Sinatra and the Italian-American Mother/Son Thing'' and ''Frank Sinatra and Traumatized Masculinity in 'The Manchurian Candidate.''' * Among those rejected: an astrological comparison of Frank and his ex-wife Ava Gardner. * The quantity of scholarship -- 43 panels, 120 papers, 70 discussants -- is about twice that of Hofstra's 1997 conference about the Presidency of George Bush.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SOMETIMES THE SOUL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, VIRGINIA P.
description: TAYLOR-Virginia P. Is mourned and missed by her family and friends. Survived and loved by her beloved husband, Vincent, her devoted daughter Nikki and son-inlaw Bob, her loving grandson Mark and her cherished sister Ann. We will all miss her charitable spirit. Reposing at the Kennedy Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58 Street, Woodside, New York, on Sunday 5-8PM. Service to be held at 7PM at Kennedy Roth Funeral Home. Interment on Monday 10AM at Cedar Grove cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVERANT, DINA
description: LIVERANT-Dina. We extend heartfelt condolences to Jacob Liverant on the loss of his beloved wife, Dina. To anyone who had the good fortune of knowing her, she was a source of happiness and joy. As Golden Founders of the ''Hospital with a Heart'' and supporters of the Jesselson Heart Center, their generosity has played a vital role in helping to provide comprehensive, state-of-the-art care to the people of Jerusalem. May Jacob, his son Alex, his daughter Dorothy, grandchildren Shoshana, Simona and Gabrielle, and the entire family have warm and loving memories of a very special, caring and righteous individual. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratkzer, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Quotas Are Dropped for Parking-Ticket Writers in the Capital
description: Responding to years of public complaints, District of Columbia officials have acknowledged that parking-enforcement workers often felt that they had to rely on predatory, aggressive measures to meet quotas for writing tickets.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: I enjoyed Michael Winerip's human-interest tidbits on Ken Starr, and his description of the manner in which the special prosecutor approaches his work. Although Starr has been in our lives daily via the news media, I had never heard of him prior to the investigation. I now see a man who is thorough, genuine, strong and secure. I see a man, devoted to his work, who has taken on an unpopular task.

title: Alix Goodwin, Andreas Olavarria
description: Alexandra Corbin Goodwin, a daughter of Beverley B. Goodwin of New York and Todd Goodwin of Southampton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andreas Olavarria, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcelo Olavarria of Los Angeles. The Rev. Frank Gere, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Saddlerock Ranch in Malibu, Calif.

title: Returning to the Pure and Simple Joys of Fishing
description: These days, walking any distance to go fishing is like leaping to pluck a gleaming apple off a bough and eating it on the spot. The scenario strikes a poignant, familiar chord in all of us. But few people actually do it. We buy our apples at the supermarket and when we get a chance to fish, we drive right up to the roadside pullout beside the river and jump out, ready to go.

title: Hearts and Darts
description: A sly, sophisticated marital farce, THE AWFUL TRUTH (1937), starring Cary Grant and Irene Dunne, was a sunshiny Depression hit critically and commercially. Cleverly directed by Leo McCarey and expertly played, it depicts the break-up of a worldly, loving Manhattan couple and their mock-spiteful attempts to sabotage remarriages. Much of the scenario was reportedly concocted impromptu and often piece-meal on the backs of envelopes, in waiting cars and even on the set. Ms. Dunne confirmed this to me in an interview. ''We had fun making it,'' added the actress, a garcious, relaxes woman. ''Although Cary was so apprehensive, he always worried so,'' she added. ''But the production went on like a breeze.'' - THURSDAY at midnight on TCM.

title: For a Season of Fun: Pick-Your-Own Apples
description: IN recent years, fall has become a monthlong festival. As December is to Christmas, so October seems to be to Halloween: a fun-filled holiday prelude, a time to take part in colorful, recreational rituals.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Assisted Living Proposals Are Arriving in Numbers
description: AS municipalities in Westchester County sift through a growing number of housing proposals for the elderly, many are finding their zoning codes have not kept pace with all the housing options now being offered.

title: The Medici Behind Disney's High Art
description: ON a wall facing Michael D. Eisner's desk in the sitting room outside his airy office at the Walt Disney Company headquarters hangs a single storyboard 18 feet long, 2 1/2 feet high with black and white and color pictures of events of the past 50 years and typeset story lines explaining them.

title: Columbia Makes a Little History Out West
description: When the freshman tailback Jonathan Reese crossed the goal line for Columbia's first score this afternoon against St. Mary's early in the second quarter, he displayed the jubilation to be expected of a player scoring his first collegiate touchdown.

title: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about film portrayals of writers referred incorrectly to a character in ''The Shining.'' The wife of the writer played by Jack Nicholson survives; she is not axed to death by her husband.

title: The Joys of Summer: The National Pastime Thankfully Is a Distraction
description: IT has been so long since the nation has been grateful to its pastime that some people are already pressing this past season into the record books as a gift.

title: The Fine Art of Hurricane Hype
description: IN the days before Hurricane Georges struck the Gulf Coast last week, storm forecasters faced one of their most trying responsibilities: predicting the inherently uncertain behavior of a hurricane in time to move people out of harm's way.

title: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: PULSE; Dark Stars
description: No longer are salon patrons demanding Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy's buttery chunks. Now they ask for hair the color of Bill Clinton's dog. It seems women are shaking their blond obsession. On runways from London to New York, models from Kate Moss to Audrey Marnay, a newcomer, had shiny dyed brown hair. Even Eva Herzigova, the Wonderbra poster girl, will soon appear as a brunette in a CK Calvin Klein ad. Bridget Hall browned down for her new Gucci campaign. Off the catwalk, flame-haired Gillian Anderson and pale-tressed Uma Thurman recently became brunettes, too.

title: A Lost Race: Sizing Up The Damage
description: The certification of City Councilman Anthony D. Weiner last week as the winner of the Democratic primary for Charles E. Schumer's Congressional seat brought elation to Mr. Weiner's Brooklyn supporters. But it has brought no shortage of disappointment to the Queens camp of his closest competitor in the race, Assemblywoman Melinda Katz.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: At This Club, Excess Is the Byword
description: GROUCHO MARX said that he would never join any club that would accept him as a member. But I've been searching for any club on Long Island that would accept me as a member. For years, I've had my eye on a mysterious building at Expressway Exit 64, with the tempting sign ''Sam's Club: Members Only.''

title: Ethical Review
description: In response to a controversy involving the Westchester Taxi and Limousine Commission, Alan D. Scheinkman, the County Attorney, has issued a six-page opinion stating that a commission member, Katherine Jennings, who is also the chairwoman of the Taxi and Limousine Association of Greater New York, must limit her participation on the county board.

title: Toward Defining Educational Needs
description: After reading the letter written by Jane Goldblatt (''Putting Children First in Education,'' Sept. 27) I could only come to the conclusion that someone on the editorial staff had been overly enthusiastic in the editing process. The content of the letter certainly did not express the opinion that children should be put first. In fact, the sentiment of this letter insinuated that only certain children should be put first.

title: Anxiety Is Good
description: To the Editor: As a cancer surgeon, I found Eleanor Blau's article [''Taking Arms Against Stage Fright,'' Sept. 20] particularly relevant. Musicians and surgeons both train for many unrelenting and often torturous years to be able to deliver a performance as close to perfection as possible. Certainly too much adrenaline can diminish the performance, but no anxiety can be just as bad.

title: Nancy Read, Cesar Fernandez
description: Nancy Houghton Read, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben S. Read Jr. of Manhattan, was married last evening to Cesar Manuel Fernandez, a son of Martha Eireos Ramos of Brooklyn and Cesar Modesto Fernandez of Union City, N.J. The Rev. Stephen P. Bauman performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in Manhattan.

title: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: The Air-Rage Rage; Taking a Cold-Eyed Look at a Hot Story
description: LAST month, British Airways began issuing printed warnings to abusive passengers, giving notice that continued misbehavior could result in hefty fines and even jail sentences.

title: Sculptor in Search Of Discerning Eyes
description: WILLIAM KENT, a sculptor in pine, walnut and mahogany, makes carvings of the mundane, woodblocks of the politically incorrect -- work, in short, as eccentric and original as he is.

title: How Superman Got His Groove Back
description: Gone For Good

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, STUART
description: LIEBERMAN-Stuart. With the deepest sorrow we mourn the loss of a man whose greatest love and joy was his wife, Molly, his children and grandchildren. The Klebanow Family

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Aid for the Little Guy In Securities Arbitration
description: SMALL investors who cannot find lawyers to handle their Wall Street grievances may now find counsel at a small but growing number of law school clinics.

title: A Cup Of Charm
description: You'd have to be an ogre to deny the charms of children's china. even a hard-biled chief financial officer with zero time for frivolity wouldn't be able to resist eating from a plate that depicts boys jousting and says: ''Thump away Jack -- Take care of his head./Tis all in good fun. Now hit him hard, Ned.''

title: Budget-Kindly, Flavorful Vietnamese Fare
description: ANYONE looking for dining bargains should head for Danbury, which is unusual among Fairfield County towns for its breadth of ethnic restaurants at moderate to low prices. The latest to come to our attention is Thang Long, a tiny Vietnamese establishment with authentic food priced so low you may think the figures next to the menu items are misprints. An all-you-can-eat lunch buffet, with more than half a dozen different dishes and just as many garnishes, is the best value of all.

title: Landscapes of the Earth and the Mind
description: Roy Nicholson

title: The View From/Purchase; In a Writing Class, Taking Risks Is Just Par for the Course
description: THE assignment was to describe a turning point. Take something an event, an inner revelation -- that changed your life. Then put it down in black and white, make it into a story, reveal it to, if not the world, at least a class of your peers.

title: Auntie Mame, a Horse for a Course, Wins 5th at Belmont
description: For horses that like certain courses, consider the filly Auntie Mame: She ran for the fifth time on the Belmont Park grass yesterday, and for the fifth time she outran everybody else, winning the $400,000 Flower Bowl Invitational by one length and keeping her hometown winning streak alive.

title: Jodi Caplan and Keith Getz
