description: Jodi Lauren Caplan, a daughter of Arlene and Harvey A. Caplan of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Keith Mitchell Getz, the son of Marcia and Theodore P. Getz of Glen Cove, N.Y. Rabbi Harvey Goldman officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Food; From Soup To Huts
description: Since childhood, i've used any excuse to enliven the Episcopal pomp and tradition in which I was raised. I've borrowed from seasonal pagan rites, like the winter solstice and vernal equinox, to spice up Christmas and Easter. I've staged a pilgrim pageant for Thanksgiving, and one time I went so far as to erect a maypole for some holiday marking the arrival of new wine and flowers.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about Indian and Pakistan companies and government institutions with which Americans will be barred from doing business misstated United States policy toward those countries. The ban assumes that current sanctions imposed after those countries tested nuclear devices in May remain in place. No new sanctions are planned.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH Alan Thicke; Never Too Late to Be a New Face
description: ALAN THICKE was distracted. In his basement dressing room at the Shubert Theater, minutes after his second performance in the hit musical ''Chicago'' on Thursday night (Mr. Thicke has the role of Billy Flynn, originated by Joel Grey), two Hollywood agents were congratulating him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, DOROTHY ELIZABETH
description: DONNELLY-Dorothy Elizabeth (nee Bridgham). 89. On October 2, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Edward; loving and beloved mother of Marjorie Clarke of Collinsville, CT, and Dorothy Meunier of Paradise Valley, AZ; and doting and cherished grandmother of Alison, Justin, Libby and Matthew. Born in Brooklyn on March 13, 1909, she was a public school teacher from 1945 to 1971, and left Brooklyn only in 1991 when she took her zest for life to Duncaster in Bloomfield, CT, where she enjoyed her last years. A memorial service will be held at Duncaster in December. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: A new twist on the Mississippi, and other river trips
description: As the season in Europe for river cruises -- April to October -- wanes, a new type of river experience is beginning in the United States. River Barge Excursion Lines of New Orleans, which had planned to start operating the River Explorer on July 4, finally overcame construction delays and sailed for the first time on the Mississippi River last month.

title: Long Beach Wrestles Over Library Name
description: RESIDENTS joined local officials and library trustees here last weekend to celebrate the grand opening of the newly refurbished and expanded Long Beach Public Library. But the name by the building's entrance also changed, and it is the removal of the shiny metal letters of the old name that has infuriated some residents and local officials.

title: Read It and Weep
description: You've probably heard of Y2K by now. The term is shorthand for the glitches that will occur when computers programmed to recognize two-digit numbers for years (like ''99'') roll over to ''00'' on Jan. 1, 2000. Depending on whom you ask, this techno-flummox is either a thorny but fixable problem or the First Horseman of the Apocalypse. The panickers have it that planes will fall from the sky, city lights will wink out and chaos will erupt.

title: Company Tries to Sell Golf as a Family Event
description: PHILIP HOFFMAN hit ball after ball into the bright green artificial turf at Family Golf Centers' Golden Bear Golf Center in Farmingdale recently. About an hour, and 100 balls, later he entered the clubhouse.

title: PLUS: N.H.L. -- WAIVER DRAFT
description: Among the recognizable names of the 190 players made available for tomorrow's National Hockey League waiver draft were Kirk Muller of the Florida Panthers, Ray Ferraro of the Los Angeles Kings, Ron Sutter of the San Jose Sharks and John Cullen of the Tampa Bay Lightning, who is attempting a comeback following cancer treatment.

title: So Far, 'Medicare Plus Choice' Is Minus Most of the Options
description: JOHN REGAN, a retired Bell Atlantic employee, wanted to join a health maintenance organization near his home in Centerville, Mass., on Cape Cod. But the H.M.O. said no -- he lived in the wrong zip code.

title: Liberties; Truth & Ketchup
description: Some have questioned the wisdom of Kenneth Starr's hanging the fate of the Republic on the neurotic girl talk of two dingbats.

title: A First Ripple of Tighter Credit Reaches U.S. Shores
description: THE United States is starting to feel the effects of a lending pullback.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MY NAME IS LOVE

title: Solace for Managers Of Small-Company Funds
description: September, alas, brought no relief for investors in small-company stocks.The Russell 2000 index, a barometer for such stocks, fell 20.5 percent during the month, almost twice the 10.3 percent drop in the S.& P. 500 index. And the average ''small growth'' stock mutual fund declined 22.5 percent in the third quarter and is down 16.8 percent for the year, according to Morningstar Inc.

title: Treehouses of the Hamptons
description: Ah, to be up high and have a view of the world around you. Or at least of your house, and maybe the neighbors'. When Jamie Grant set out to build a treehouse with his two sons, James, 7, and William, 5, last winter in Southampton, N.Y., it was the promise of summer that kept them going. ''We really froze out in the yard, all bundled up with hats and mittens on, but the boys loved it,'' he says. The house was built in a towering pine tree with two trunks and comes complete with a ladder that can be taken up and down. ''The boys insisted, so they could escape from the enemy,'' Grant adds, laughing.

title: Tottering Into the Spandex Era; Bankrupt, Downtown Athletic Club Tries to Hold On
description: Kevin C. Murphy counts himself as one of the Downtown Athletic Club's biggest fans, so he seemed a little embarrassed that he was the only person shooting hoops in the cavernous indoor basketball court before lunch one recent weekday.

title: Founding Fathers Are Used To Build a Case For Clinton
description: President Clinton's lawyers reached back this weekend to the travails of an American Founding Father to argue that sexual misconduct is not an impeachable offense, citing Alexander Hamilton in a memorandum released ahead of Monday's House vote on whether to begin a formal impeachment inquiry.

title: Family of Comatose Haitian Man Calls for Police Investigation
description: The family of a 53-year-old Haitian man who underwent emergency surgery hours after being taken into police custody is asking for a broader investigation to determine whether he had been beaten by the police.

title: Our Towns; Gentle Masters Breed Gentle Dogs
description: TWELVE bearded men bow their heads for grace in the dining room of a mountaintop monastery. Behind each chair rests a German shepherd, each with a placid mien to match its master's.

title: What Bothers Moralists More About Clinton; Congressional Record
description: To the Editor:

title: The Judiciary Vote
description: This week, for just the second time this century, the House of Representatives is likely to approve an impeachment inquiry into the conduct of a President. Given the serious charges leveled against Bill Clinton by Kenneth Starr -- and the need to have those charges resolved in an open, orderly way -- that decision is justified and will be supported by many Democrats. But how the inquiry is conducted is a matter that requires very careful consideration by the American people and their representatives.

title: A Real Character
description: WENDY COMER-NICHOLS will blow on dice but won't guarantee the results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIEN, HENRY
description: LEVIEN-Henry. On October 1, 1998. Survived by his wife of 51 years Lois, two daughters Nancy Goodman and Louise Levien, sons-in-law Richard Goodman and Robert Eby, grandchildren David & Allison Eby and Eric Goodman, two brothers Edward and Robert. He was greatly loved and will be sorely missed. Service at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Sunday, October 4, 10:45 AM.

title: SOAPBOX; Growing Up Grand
description: WHEN my friend Val came from London for her first visit to New York City, I put Grand Central Terminal on her list of things to see. She came back and said, ''It's a nice old station.''

title: Clinton's Woes Aren't Main Issue in This District
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast-Selling Thrillers Depict Prophetic View of Final Days
description: In an instant, millions of people disappear from the face of the earth, shedding their clothing, shoes, eyeglasses and jewelry. While terrified relatives grieve, the speculation begins. Were they snatched by aliens? Vaporized by a spontaneous chemical reaction? Kidnapped by terrorists?

title: Miss Pawelek, Mr. Benedetto
description: Rene Diane Pawelek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Pawelek of Dallas, was married there last evening to Michael Francis Benedetto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. William Benedetto of New York. Don Forbrich, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church.

title: Burlesque's Back, a Step Ahead of the Law
description: NO surgically enhanced Barbie clones. No overly attentive cocktail waitresses. No businessmen with $100 bills in their teeth. Willkommen to the Blue Angel Cabaret, where crowds line up for a different kind of erotic entertainment. The weekly show, at the House of Candles, a Lower East Side performance space, is part ''Showgirls,'' part ''Broadway Danny Rose.''

title: Doing It All Now Is Entirely In Character
description: SEATED in a tiny self-service cafe on Sullivan Street, Stanley Tucci doesn't look like a man who, at 37, has achieved the kind of career control most actors only dream about. He's gazing in consternation at the modest vegetarian sandwich displayed before him on a piece of white bakery paper.

title: Padres Want Stadium, and Ballot Will Be Like Game 7
description: It usually takes a precipitous change in the sunny weather -- something, say, the magnitude of El Nino -- to shake the relative calm of this sleepy Southern California city.

title: Waiting for a Racing Tryout

Her entree into the sport meant making sandwiches for the America True crew, handing out team water bottles to sailors and arranging tables for a promotional party. But the payoff has been handsome, a chance this weekend to try out for the group's America's Cup team.

title: Starr Said to Have Received Tip On Affair Before Call by Tripp

That makes it all the more repugnant that the Administration is trying to discredit and intimidate Scott Ritter, a former top United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq who is rightly sounding an alarm about the developments in Baghdad.

title: Whitman Wants to Push Up State's Primary to March
description: New Jerseyans could have more say in the Presidential nominating process in 2000, now that Governor Whitman has supported moving the state's primary from June to March. Governor Whitman opposed the change in 1996, but reversed herself last week, after California decided to join other large states in a March 7 primary. Mrs. Whitman supports a bill pending in the Assembly sponsored by George F. Geist, Republican of Gloucester, to move the primary, said Pete McDonough, a spokesman for the Governor.

description: THE face of the Walt Disney Company on Broadway these days has many masks. Some are daring and innovative, like those of ''The Lion King.'' Others are theme-park safe yet intimidating -- both Beauty and Beast.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Greenspan Questioned On Hedge Fund Rescue
description: Washington tells welfare mothers not to count on government handouts, so why did the Federal Reserve arrange a rescue for an investment firm run by and for some of the world's richest people? That was the question posed to Mr. Greenspan by the House Banking Committee as he recounted the central bank's role in averting the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., a hedge fund gone wrong.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Italy for the Ages
description: ''In the center of Italian cities, the presence of the past vibrates the air,'' the American photographer Linda Butler writes in ITALY: In the Shadow of Time (Rizzoli, $50), a collection of 60 photographs. Butler, who began the project in 1992, spent eight months searching for subjects by sorting through artifacts in libraries, museums and private homes. The resulting black-and-white photographs, which often look like paintings, capture a wide variety of images from all over Italy and attempt to convey the ''distilled energy of artisans long dead.'' She shows Italy as a place of tradition where wax figures cool in a tub before being realized in bronze in a Naples foundry. The stark, strong images imply the presence of humanity through the objects Italians use and through figurative sculpture and paintings. Fascinated with light, Butler's shots play with shadow, as in the photo of the cave of the Sybil of Cumae, where Virgil once consulted the oracle. Here, the pathway looks properly foreboding and eerie as Butler shows bands of light licking the keyhole-shaped openings. By photographing little-known places or sightseer traps at early hours, she offers Italy bare and beautiful before the activity of everyday life obscures its simplicity and subdues its past. Her accounts of obtaining the pictures captivate almost as much as the images themselves -- how, for instance, she bribed a guard with $15 so she could shoot a men's bathhouse in Pompeii. Sandra Mardenfeld

title: Brio Is Gone, but Brazil's Leader May Be Back

Granted, Bush has now been the Governor of Texas for nearly four years, but the passages in your article that described his thoughts about his young- to middle-adult years were shocking. On Vietnam, for example, Bush ''had trouble remembering what his position was on the war.''

Over the years I read Dr. Sacks and came to hate him -- but kept on reading.

title: The Word From Bill T. Jones: He's Moving Beyond Words
description: BILL T. JONES, famously a choreographer who uses spoken language on the stage, is tired of talking. In his 1997 piece, ''We Set Out Early . . . Visibility Was Poor,'' which has its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday, music and movement do all the work. Composed of three parts with no intermissions, the 70-minute piece ''started with the music, not from an idea I wanted to express,'' Mr. Jones said in a telephone interview from Cardiff, Wales, where he was finishing ''Nowhere But Here'' for Diversions Dance Company. The piece has a score by the same Latvian composer, Peteris Vasks, whose music closes ''We Set Out Early.''

title: MUSIC; Kurt Weill's Biblical History Of the Jews
description: IT is fair to say that a program today by the American Symphony Orchestra -- ''Kings and Prophecies: A Road to Promise,'' a concert adaptation of Acts III and IV of ''The Eternal Road'' by Kurt Weill assumes historical significance. The semistaged production, directed by Jonathan Eaton and conducted by Leon Botstein at Avery Fisher Hall, is the first modern American presentation of a work that was unprecedented in scope: dramatic, musical and scenic.

title: Cornell and Duchamp: A Fan Club of Just Two
description: FRIENDSHIPS between artists seldom receive serious attention. We assume them to be mostly trivial, a web of anecdote and gossip. They evoke visions of chummy evenings at the Cedar bar, the Cafe Deux Magots and other bohemian landmarks -- scenarios, more often than not, that involve a lot of Scotch and draw to a close when an artist either passes out or sneaks out the door with his pal's favorite model.

title: Family Style
description: The spaces that are designed for family life today are as varied as the families themselves. But whether a designer's clients are a baby-boomer couple with small children, or a daughter who has recently flown the coop to make a nest of her own, the rules of common sense apply: good design is always appropriate design. Allowing room for privacy as well as community, creating enough storage for both parents' and children's clutter and choosing materials that are both elegant and sturdy go a long way toward closing the domestic generation gap. Using such an approach allows for touches of adult sophistication or storybook whimsy without rendering a house either intimidatingly ''big'' or condescendingly kiddie-ish. And it allows rooms to grow up gracefully, too. Pilar Viladas

title: The Path Back To Dignity
description: Almost exactly 25 years have passed since Richard Nixon nominated me to replace the disgraced Spiro Agnew as Vice President. In the contentious days of autumn 1973, my confirmation was by no means assured. Indeed, a small group of House Democrats, led by Bella Abzug, risked a constitutional crisis in order to pursue their own agenda. ''We can get control and keep control,'' Ms. Abzug told the Speaker of the House, Carl Albert. The group hoped, eventually, to replace Nixon himself with Mr. Albert.

title: Spoons, Bowls And Memories
description: A FRIEND owns a spacious summer home on the island where my family rents. Sometimes when she and I are sitting on her deck looking out at the sea, she exclaims, plainly proud of her accomplishment and puzzled by my seeming lack of one, ''Look what you could have if you didn't go on all those trips!''

The chairman of the giant Swiss bank UBS and three of its senior managers resigned in embarrassment over the $696 million the bank is writing off because of its involvement with Long-Term Capital.

title: Disney: Genuinely Artificial, Really Surreal
description: As usual, Tocqueville had it nailed even before it happened. More than a century before Disneyland opened its doors, the great analyst of modern democracy grasped the spirit of hysteria that infuses the entire theme park genre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABINGTON, DAVID H.A.
description: BABINGTON-David H.A. 62, died recently in London after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife Ann and their children, Katharine and Philip. His career as an investment banker and financial consultant spanned over three decades in Frankfurt, Paris and London. A memorial services will be held on Friday, November 6 at 3:30PM at St. George Church, Campden Hill, London. Condolences may be expressed to Ann Babington, Flat 2, The Mount, 76 Bedford Gardens, London W8, England.

title: Science Fiction
description: Despite their obvious differences -- mystery stories unpack the past, science fiction addresses the future -- the two genres have one thing in common. Both often challenge the reader to solve a puzzle that is posed early and kept in view throughout the narrative: Who killed Roger Ackroyd? What is the dominant species on this planet? Since such questions can typically be answered in a few declarative sentences, the more memorable stories focus not so much on what is revealed but on the circumstances of the revelation and its meaning for the people involved.

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: When my children and I reached Los Angeles International Airport a few weeks ago, and quickly parked our car, we were not concerned about jotting down our car location. Oh, no; we were involved in our discussion of Virgin Atlantic and whether it really did have individual video games.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; It's the Potholes, Stupid
description: It's not a good time to be a pothole in New York City. For starters, it's a lot lonelier than it used to be. Back in 1994, some 200,000 potholes livened up the city's streets, but mild winters and diligent repair crews have slashed the number, officials say, to 25,000.

title: Jets Hope to Move Rivalry With Dolphins Into New Phase
description: It is a Jets-Dolphins clash with fascinating elements that can become part of their eclectic history: the mud bowl for the 1982 conference title, the faked spike that began a downward spiral for the Jets, the almost-1,000-yard passing duel between Ken O'Brien and Dan Marino.

title: Loving the Island For Its Supermarkets
description: Some recent weekly journeys to Plainview reminded this New York City resident of one of the things he loves about Long Island: Long Island supermarkets. They're enormous. Bursting with an infinite variety of goods. Staffed with competent, cordial professionals -- even the teen-agers, even at the checkout counters. Pure, exquisite bliss.

title: Takeoffs Are Main Issue For Noise Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: Look Both Ways
description: If there was ever an alternative to long, gray sportswear, this is it.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 38 of the Arts & Leisure section today with an article about Disney's high-culture aspirations misstates the role of the architect Frank Gehry in the planning of EuroDisney, the theme park in France now called Disneyland Paris. He designed its commercial area, Festival Disney, not a hotel at the park. The caption also carries an incomplete reference to the architects of hotels at the park. Antoine Predock and Antoine Grumbach also designed hotels there.

title: The Weight Of the World, On the U.S. And Europe
description: MORE than a year ago, when what is now looking very much like a global financial crisis was primarily an Asian phenomenon, the conventional wisdom was that Europe and the United States were strong enough economically to help the world ride out the problem.

title: War Baby
description: Mitchell Leisen's TO EACH HIS OWN (1946) is a perfect example of a soap opera project - a tale of sacrificing mother love - dignified and illuminated with taste and skill. At the center is a beautifully shaded performance that won Olivia de Havilland an Oscar. Her excellent supporting cast includes John Lund (above, with Ms. de Havilland) as her youthful aviator lover and also as her son. The clever scenario spans two world wars and unfolds as a London business woman (Ms. de Havilland) talks with a stranger (Roland Culver) during a Nazi air raid. A crisp edge of intelligence rules our sentimentally - one reason for the delightful, lingering flavor that comes from the final line: ''I believe this is our waltz, Mother'' - FRIDAY at 4 P.M. on American Movie Classics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUARTE, E. THOMAS
description: HUARTE-E. Thomas. 69. On Friday, October 2, 1998. Beloved husband for 46 years of Janet (Dehmer) Huarte. Loving father of Susan Casbar, Barbara Huarte, Lori Boudreau, Richard Huarte and the late Gigi Rudella. Loving grandfather of D.J., Laura, Julian, Christopher and Elisabeth. Services to be announced.

title: Another Cubs Season Ends in Disappointment
description: First Greg Maddux silenced the Cubs' bats for seven innings. Then a grand slam in the eighth inning by Eddie Perez silenced Wrigley Field.

title: A Family-Size Mouseboat
description: I HAD always thought Mickey a bit of a wimp, until I met him in Disney's private cruise terminal at Port Canaveral, Fla., sashaying arm in arm with Minnie across a terrazzo floor map of the Caribbean. With his triple-E shoes, chunky white gloves and wide-eyed plastic grin, the Disney Magic's unofficial captain managed to charm me and my 10-year-old son, Danny, a stalwart Goofy fan, into posing for a picture with him and his mate. Like so much aboard Disney's first cruise ship, and in Disney World itself, the quality costuming and elegant setting had transformed a potentially cheesy moment into a beguiling bit of silliness. Even my 16-year-old cynic, Alex, trying to be as unobtrusive as humanly possible in the glassy 70,000-square-foot expanse, admitted he had almost been ''sucked in by the cuteness.''

title: Denise Waltuch, Boris Slusarev
description: Denise Jill Waltuch, the daughter of Anita and Norton Waltuch of Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Boris Paul Slusarev, a son of Mary and Paul Slusarev of Brooklyn. Michael Coleman, a former village justice of Lynbrook, N.Y., officiated at the Mark Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BYER, PETER EDWARD
description: BYER-Peter Edward. 11/19/47 - 10/4/73. Twenty - five years lovingly remembered each and every day. The Byer, Glogower, Simmons and their extended families.

title: POSTINGS: Chancellors Hall in Southampton; Quadrangle's First Side For L.I.U.
description: The quality of light in the Hamptons, a shimmering natural treasure known to generations of artists, is paid homage in the newly dedicated Chancellors Hall at Southampton College of Long Island University, a 110-acre campus set in Southampton's Shinnecock Hills.

title: Tracking the Reclusive Sleuth of West 35th Street
description: Nero Wolfe, for those who are not familiar with the stories by Rex Stout, weighs one-seventh of a ton, washes down his meals with five quarts of beer and lives in a four-story brownstone on West 35th Street in Manhattan.

title: Miss Greenberg, Mr. Nussbaum
description: Caroline Diane Greenberg, a daughter of Marilyn and Allen Greenberg of New York, was married last evening to Mitchell Steven Nussbaum, the son of Georgette and Lucian Nussbaum of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Situation Normal
description: There may have never been a railroad as fouled up as the Union Pacific since its merger with the Southern Pacific. Snarls, delays, lost freight cars -- the mishaps became so serious last year that the Government forced the Union Pacific to hand over some business to competitors.

title: Jane King and Joseph Pantigoso
description: Jane King and Joseph Pantigoso were married yesterday by the Rev. Jose Ruiz Vera at San Sebastian Chimalistac Roman Catholic Church in Mexico City.

title: In West Bank, Little Arab Control; Oslo Timetable
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Day in Court Via the Internet
description: WHO -- Ralph Zita, lawyer and founder of Law Street, a Lawrenceville-based company that specializes in the use of computer technology and teleconferencing in the courtroom.

title: Costly Sleeper
description: To the Editor: Here's a warning to anyone who plans to take a sleeper train from Germany to Poland. Be sure you have a two-part ticket: one part for the train and one for the berth.

title: Another Round in Blind Tenants' Fight for Services
description: A controversy over services at Selis Manor, a home for the blind on West 23d Street, shows no sign of letting up. On Monday, tenants filed a lawsuit in an effort to keep social service staff members at the home. They also held a rally in front of the building, calling on Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco to investigate what they said was improper use of money raised specifically to pay for services there. Tenants chanted and held up signs saying, ''We lost our sight, let's not lose the fight.''

title: Turkey's Ties To Syria Sink To War in All But the Name
description: Tension between Turkey and Syria has risen to the point where the top Turkish military commander says the two hostile neighbors have reached ''a state of undeclared war.''

title: A Race to Remember
description: The first sign that 1998 would be the season of the slugger came early, when the Cardinals' Mark McGwire hit four home runs in his first four games. But the pursuit of Roger Maris's 37-year-old home run record was set in full motion by the Cubs' Sammy Sosa when he hit an unprecedented 20 home runs in June. By the end of August, each player had hit 55 home runs and suddenly a game that had produced only two 60 home run hitters in its history was poised to produce two in the same season. McGwire got there first, but Sosa soon joined him and they were even at 66 going into the final weekend. McGwire finally brought the chase to a conclusion with four home runs in his last two games. Babe Ruth and Roger Maris are no longer the landmarks. Now, the names that home run hitters will aspire to are Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, LON
description: CLARK-Lon. On October 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Michelle. Loving father of Lon Jr. and Stephen and step-father of Timothy and George Morse. Grandfather of Lon III. Dear brother of Gerald and Eduard. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Interment private. Memorial services to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Episcopal Actors' Guild, 1 East 29 St, NY NY 10016.

title: It Wasn't Like This At Good Old P.S. 28
description: Ah, school days. In these fast-changing times, additional education often seems a necessity in business. And job-related instruction -- in-house or through extension courses -- is a rapidly growing field. But in many instances, the experience is a far cry from those halcyon days of crayons and show-and-tell.

title: Sports of The Times; A Player Who Was Truly Exceptional
description: HE was the classic small-town prodigy, with the creativity of a big-city profiteer. When there was no shot to take, he invented a new one. When there was no one to pass to, he reconfigured the play until a teammate was open.

title: IN MY. . . SUITCASE: Betty Beene
description: Betty Beene, president of United Way of America, spends 150 nights a year on the road pitching the organization's good works and brand name. And as befits her previous stint as the head of the Girl Scouts in Houston, she goes prepared with food for both body and soul.

title: Revving Up His Retirement
description: Robert A. Lutz, who retired as vice chairman of Chrysler in July, likes to boast that his daughter married a top motorcycle racer who, by the way, is also a particle-physics researcher. Now Mr. Lutz plans to pursue his own passion for high-speed driving by helping to revive a legendary name in two-wheel motor racing, the Indian motorcycle.

title: Let It Rain On Parades, Residents Say
description: For many groups, a march down Fifth Avenue is a parade to end all parades. But some residents of the Upper East Side, where many Fifth Avenue parades end, say they are under siege. Huge crowds press up against apartment buildings and young people, some of them drinking alcohol, linger for hours after a parade is over.

title: Classical Brief
description: BACH: KEYBOARD TOCCATAS

title: Kids' Stuff
description: Fresh shapes, materials, colors and designs take the basics for children's rooms well beyond the ordinary.

title: Why Say 'Manned' When 'Staffed' Will Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wooten's Problems Continue With Death Threat and Tighter Security
description: Giants safety Tito Wooten has had more to worry about of late than the possibility of losing his starting job because of poor play. Wooten, who has had a series of personal problems, has received at least one death threat within the past six weeks, according to high-ranking National Football League executives.

title: Nightclub Maven Auditions for His Latest Adventure
description: The phone call was not the most dramatic thing ever to happen to Jean-Claude Baker: singer in France, nightclub owner in the former West Berlin, restaurant owner in New York and biographer of his adoptive mother, Josephine Baker, the American performer who captivated 1920's Paris.

title: Miss Cameron And Mr. Taylor
description: Elizabeth Whitaker Cameron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard G. Cameron 2d of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Nikolai Taylor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Taylor of Fort Worth. The Rev. Dr. James L. Kowalski performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: The Swoon of The Swoosh
description: Timothy Egan's portrait of Nike's efforts to stop its recent ''swoon'' reveals that the Nike machine cares little about corporate responsibility (Sept. 13). While every corporation has profit as its raison d'etre, why does the quest for dollars have to come at the expense of treating human beings with dignity? Phil Knight and Michael Jordan are correct to address the shameful conditions of Nike's factories in Asia. I wonder, however, if anyone at Nike is concerned about human-rights violations because people -- children -- are suffering needlessly, or if the concern is only for the suffering of Nike's image and bottom line. And no one at Nike seems to care that here at home, by design, poor children, teen-agers and young adults spend scarce dollars on absurdly overpriced sneakers.

title: Pop Classicists Leave the Crowd Behind
description: WHAT life lessons, if any, has rock handed down to future generations from its boundary-smashing heyday? In ''That Says It All,'' a catchy Bob Dylan-style ballad on his exquisite second album, ''Humming,'' the 28-year-old singer-songwriter Duncan Sheik offers a short list of resonant catch phrases slung by 1960's rock gods who are now either graying or dead.

title: Moynihan Calls a Schumer Victory Crucial
description: Warning that Democrats in the United States Senate were ''perilously close'' to losing even minimal influence over that body's deliberations, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday urged the election of Representative Charles E. Schumer, saying he would help block the passage of ''radical, reactionary legislation'' in Washington.

title: Henrik Ibsen's 'Ghosts' by Fleetwood Stage
description: THE repressed, hypocritical Pastor Manders is an emissary of the fanatic religious right. He is business manager, spiritual adviser and longtime confidant -- all dubious -- to Mrs. Alving, who has sacrificed her own thoughts for what thoughtless people will think. Duty always came first. The Fleetwood Stage production of ''Ghosts'' makes sure you get that.

title: Phoebe Farber and Craig Levine
description: Phoebe Farber, a psychiatric social worker, and Craig Randall Levine, a children's rights advocate, were married last evening by Rabbi Avi Winokur at the Down Town Association, a private club in New York.

title: Greetings From Earth! ?##%zx* +=
description: IF you wanted to send a message to a bunch of aliens in outer space, how could you be sure they would understand it? Would you make the message rich in the opaque minutia of modern science and write it in code? Would you assume that beings from other planets are more intelligent -- much more intelligent?

title: MEDICAL HARVEST
description: To the list of famous Texas exports, add cadavers. Last year, Texas officials sent nearly 20 percent of the 1,480 bodies donated to the state to medical institutions in other locales. Texas has a surplus, in part, because its Anatomical Board has built up trust during 91 years of existence. One beneficiary is New York City, where medical schools have experienced body shortages for two decades. Why is such a populous area experiencing a shortage? Frank Jones, executive director of the Associated Medical Schools of New York, says some of the city's ethnic groups ''have superstitions about making body donations.'' Whatever the cause, Texas has pitched in: over the past five years, New York-area medical schools have received some 50 bodies from the Lone Star State.

title: A Civilian Who Earned Her Wings in War
description: IN November 1939, shortly after Adolf Hitler touched off World War II, a British writer commented about the two World Wars: ''The last one was a soldier's war. This one is everybody's.''

title: Habitats / Brooklyn Heights; Finding His Sanctuary In a Former Church
description: SOME people might find it vaguely unsettling, perhaps even blasphemous. They wouldn't even consider living in a building that used to be a church, as if God might be looking down at them, watching and judging as they engage in their very human and earthly pursuits.

title: Show Will Go On: Yiddish Theater Finds New Space
description: When the city's only Yiddish theater group lost its performance space after an Aug. 28 fire at the Central Synagogue at Lexington Avenue and 55th Street, the troupe and its fans worried that for the first time in its history, it would fail to put on one of its yearly shows. But now it looks like the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater will maintain its streak of 83 annual productions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FIELDS, CARL A.
description: FIELDS-Carl A. Sunday, October 25 at 2PM, Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, New Jersey. Information: 609-258-3049

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Fed Cuts Interest Rate
description: For nearly a month, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had hinted that the global financial crisis might force the central bank to put aside its concern about inflation and cut interest rates. On Tuesday he acted, leading the Fed to cut its key interest rate by a quarter point, to 5.25 percent.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: The Coins Go In, and the Worms Come Out
description: At a sleepy rural intersection here in the Hudson Valley, the quintessential ''going fishing'' scene was unfolding. A creaky old pickup truck drove by, with grandparents squeezed into the cab around two boys with eager faces who had the day off from school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, ANDREW M.
description: HUNT-Andrew M. on October 1, 1998. Husband of Carol (Meehan) Hunt. Father of Kevin M., Peter M. and James G. Hunt, Martha H. Sexton, Andrea C. Denby, Margaret A. Szymkowicz and Sarah H. Faggard. Brother of Ellen McIsaac, Martha Barnes and the late Howard Hunt, Jr. Residence: Cooke St., Providence. The funeral and burial will be held Monday in Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Andrew H. & Carol Hunt Scholarship for Medical Education at Brown University, Box G-A2, Providence, RI 02912 or the Carol and Andrew Hunt Scholarship Fund at Portsmouth Abby School, 285 Cory's Lane, Portsmouth, R.I. 02871.

title: His Debut As a Woman
description: Thank you for Andrew Jacobs's portrait of Sara Davis Buechner (Sept. 13). Stories of transgendered people frequently veer toward the sensational, and his was level and complete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBACH, LOUIS
description: FISHBACH-Louis. On Friday, October 2, 1998, of Cranford, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Ray (nee Bernheim). Devoted father of the late Joyce Abrams. Dear father-in-law of Herman Abrams. Loving grandfather of Lowell and Clark Abrams; great-grandfather of Justin and Ramin Abrams. Mr. Fishbach was associated with Fishbach and Fishbach Attorney at Law, NY, NY, for over 60 years. Graveside services conducted from Beth David Memorial Park, Kenilworth, NJ, on Sunday, October 4, 1998, at 11:30 AM. For further information contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ.

title: 'One Fictional Thing' Starring Maplewood
description: Making movies is a little like making sausage. Just ask Susan Rinaldi, the general manager of the Maplewood Theater, where the film ''One True Thing'' has, in a sense, come home.

title: Demythologizing Hollywood, Star by Star
description: IN ''Celebrity,'' the first installment of a documentary series titled ''The Entertainment Business,'' beginning on Bravo tonight at 8, there is a moment that illuminates the assembly-line process by which movie stars are made and then made all over again. The viewer gets a glimpse inside a Hollywood casting call, where a young, dark-haired actress is responding to a film studio's search for a ''new Winona Ryder.'' Then the camera cuts to an interview with Ms. Ryder herself, who seems plainly uncomfortable when told about the casting call. ''I didn't know they were looking for the new me already,'' said the 20-something actress. ''Now I'm nervous.''

title: What Bothers Moralists More About Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / Long Island; Lowest Rates in 30 Years Fuel Higher Home Prices
description: AS both a seller and a buyer, Didi Farrell has an interesting perspective on house prices.

title: A Long, Emotional Day Has Yanks Breathless
description: The Yankees gathered in the hotel lobby here this morning, ready to travel, with Manager Joe Torre and the others looking surprisingly refreshed considering the ordeal they went through to finish their division series sweep of the Texas Rangers.

title: End to School Segregation, Voluntary Or Mandated?
description: WHETHER Connecticut should continue its plan of voluntary school desegregation or institute one with mandated timetables and goals and some kind of punishment for school districts that don't comply was debated in a court hearing last month.

title: Moon Sets on Luna Park. Sun Rises on Coffee Emporium.
description: Toddlers toddled as moms watched them behind steaming mugs. On an autumn afternoon at Luna Park Cafe, on Fifth Avenue at Garfield Place, there was a note of melancholy in the air. The cafe is scheduled to close this afternoon and be replaced by a coffee boutique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, DR. ARTHUR
description: RUBY-Dr. Arthur. Of Manhattan and Cold Spring, New York, died October 2, after a lengthy illness. During Dr. Ruby's 44 years in practice he was President of the Brooklyn Pediatric Society and Founding President and Medical Director of The Brooklyn Center for Families in Crisis. He was also an advisor & medical consultant to the Wyndham Childrens Services, a foster care placement agency & for twenty-six years served as a pediatrician for the Early Childhood Center at Brooklyn College, lecturing in child developement. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Eleanor, and sons Dr. Eric Ruby of Taunton, Massachusetts, Dr. Kenneth Ruby of Yehud, Israel, a brother, Dr. Nathan Ruby, a sister Beatrice Friedman and two grandchildren, Ethan and Abigail. Services are private. The date of a memorial service at NYU Medical School will be announced.

title: Sweetening a Bitter Pill at Upjohn
description: IT'S hard not to feel a little sorry for Fred Hassan, the chief executive of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORR, RUTH MILLER
description: DORR-Ruth Miller, 91. Of Fort Myers, FL. Homemaker, artist, died September 21, 1998. Studied at The Art Students League of New York, graduated from The Boston Museum School of Fine Arts and La Sorbonne, Paris, France with awards. Taught at The Nightingale Bamford School, NYC. Exhibited paintings in Paris, France, Ankara, Turkey, and the United States. Married Russell H. Dorr, lawyer, diplomat and international banker. While living in Turkey, she founded the Turkish-American Woman's Society, a nursing school, & was active in The Red Crescent Society. Survivors: son Goldthwaite H. Dorr 3rd, daughter Virginia D. Maxwell, sister Charlotte M. Luippold, eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial services to be announced. Contributions to The National Alzheimer Foundation or The Church at Point O'Woods, Fire Island, New York.

title: The Financial Bogeyman Could Strike at Any Moment
description: Don't sweat the small stuff. Sure, but what about the big stuff? If you lost your job, would you have enough savings to live on for six months? Or say you had a medical emergency or your car had a major breakdown? Do you have enough money to handle the expense without borrowing?

title: From the Breakfast of Champions, 'Cerealectibles'
description: IN the days when Roy Rogers cantered down happy trails and Howdy Doody was the national timekeeper for the 10-and-under set, what commanded attention around the breakfast table was what was in the brightly colored cardboard box: sugary, crunchy cereal that could be drowned in milk, crowned with fruit or aimed in the direction of an annoying brother or sister.

title: Of Human Bondage
description: MANY THOUSANDS GONE The First Two Centuries of Slavery in North America. By Ira Berlin. Illustrated. 497 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Pope Beatifies Croat Prelate, Fanning Ire Among Serbs
description: Hailing the World War II Archbishop of Zagreb as a martyr to ''the atrocities of the Communist system,'' Pope John Paul II beatified him today.

title: Rooms of Their Own
description: There is nothing like a baby boom to wreak change on a sophisticated life style. Fortunately, the two aren't mutually exclusive. As this five-story, Greenwich Village town house demonstrates, it is possible to live in contemporary, comfortable elegance with children who are meant to be seen and heard -- in this case, three under age 5. The design team is almost a family affair as well: the architect, Karen Jacobson, and the project designer, Stephen Brockman, have collaborated on other commissions with the interior designer, Lucien Rees-Roberts.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: What drives Kenneth Starr? Ambition and power. Starr clearly wanted to make his mark and he did. With no crime committed, individuals were interrogated under oath about the most intimate details of their private lives. In the aftermath of his investigation, we as a nation have to strive to provide stronger safeguards for our right to privacy, since it was so easily trampled by an ambitious prosecutor.

title: Inviting or Not, What Do Beds Mean?
description: IN the 17th century, Samuel Pepys could end his diary entries with, ''And so to bed.'' In those days it meant recovery and respite from the day's business. But in the late 20th century, it isn't so easy. Concerns and anxieties follow a person to bed and can remain vivid. This is abundantly illustrated in ''Embedded Metaphor,'' at the Zilkha Gallery, at Wesleyan University in Middletown.

title: A Director With an Evolving Classical Lexicon
description: JAMES KUDELKA walked through the corridors of American Ballet Theater's headquarters on lower Broadway as if he belonged there. Although he became artistic director of the National Ballet of Canada in 1996, his many years as a freelance choreographer make him feel at home with troupes all over the world. Last month, he came down from Toronto to coach Ballet Theater's second ensemble, the Studio Company, and to make final arrangements for his troupe's one-week engagement at City Center, which begins Tuesday.

title: The Hissing of a Living Legend
description: Slices of afternoon sun cut through the blinds of a darkened second-floor room in the Hollywood Athletic Club as Joni Mitchell, cigarette hanging limply from her thick lips, bends over a pool table and meticulously lines up a shot to sink the solid yellow ball.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: RIVIERA OFF SEASON: The French Experience, a New York-based company specializing in independent travel to France, is offering a six-night package to the French Riviera for $518 a person, double occupancy, from Nov. 1 through March 31. The package includes hotel accommodations in a deluxe room with a balcony at the Hotel Croisette Beach in Cannes; daily buffet breakfast; a minimum-category (standard shift) rental car for seven days with unlimited mileage, taxes and insurance; a half-day excursion to the Lerins Islands south of Cannes; an evening at the Casino Croisette with dinner or dinner at Le Festival restaurant on the main beachside street; a tour of the Galimard perfume factory in Grasse, and a pass providing entrance to 58 museums on the Riviera. Air fare is extra. Information or reservations: (212) 986-1115.

title: Lives; VW Day
description: Why would any Jew buy a BMW, Mercedes or Volkswagen? It was my mantra, repeated frequently to friends, especially those with Jewish surnames and a German car. Before anybody could answer, I'd cite the wartime slave labor used by all three firms and the fact that their factories fueled the Nazi effort. My worst vitriol was reserved for lowly Volkswagen. The ''people's car'' was conceived by Hitler, who reportedly helped with the original design.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 4, 1998
description: Weeks

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Lexus LX 470 and 1999 Toyota Land Cruiser; One Ready for the Woods; The Other, the Country Club
description: DID conspicuous consumption disappear with the 1980's? Not where large, expensive sport utilities are concerned. It seems that the bigger and more expensive the luxury sport utility, the better it sells.

title: The Schoolhouse As Just One Room
description: IT could be a country and western song, the kind Roger Miller used to sing, but, in fact, ''Slate Boards and Dunce Caps'' is an exhibition about the one-room schoolhouse of yore. It is on view at the Scarsdale Historical Society here.

title: Cory Wickwire, Nicholas Halaby
description: Corrigan Breene Wickwire, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Geoffrey R. Wickwire of Wellesley, Mass., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Alexander Halaby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rurik B. Halaby of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Gwen L. Buehrens performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Families Evacuated After Building Collapse
description: Four families were evacuated and one person was injured after a building partially collapsed in Brooklyn last night, city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHENBAUM, BETTY
description: KIRSCHENBAUM-Betty, of West Palm Beach, FL on September 30. Beloved wife of Manny, adored mother of Janet & Israel Horowitz; Larry and Martha Kirschenbaum; admired grandmother of Tami, Elana and Jonathan.

title: Big Attraction
description: To the Editor: We agonized over the fact that our 9-year-old California grandson, Tom, would have a long layover in Minneapolis on his way to visit us. By the time he arrived at our house in Connecticut, he was tired.

title: Making a Cellblock An Unlikely Garden Of Free Expression
description: MARC LEVIN'S feature film ''Slam'' is a vivid marriage of ideas usually seen as contradictions: documentary and fiction, action and poetry, black and white. ''Slam,'' which opens here on Friday after being shown at the New York Film Festival, is the story of a young black performance poet, Raymond Joshua (Saul Williams), who is imprisoned on a petty drug charge but who manages to establish his identity and his voice within the maelstrom of a Washington jail.

title: His Debut As a Woman
description: I am a mother of six adult children, and a grandmother of three. I also founded a support group for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgendered teen-agers and young adults. I started this group five years ago because these kids were killing themselves at a rate three times that of their ''straight'' peers. Sara's courage, determination and, I suspect, humor set a standard for young people who are struggling to be true to themselves.

title: R.O.T.C. Arrives at Mt. Vernon High School
description: SERGEANT HYMES, please come to the main office.'' That boomed over the intercom system throughout the sprawling building of Mount Vernon High School just before the start of the new school year. Along with this simple request came a new science elective course and lofty expectations that the sky will be the only limit to the opportunities available to the 2,400 students here.

title: His Debut As a Woman
description: As a gender therapist, I have heard hundreds of similar stories of the emotional pain and remarkable resolve of these individuals. Extraordinary musical talents aside, Sara Buechner, as described in your article, seems representative of the majority of transgendered clients I have seen over the years. The article gives a more genuine profile of the male-to-female transsexual than do the exploitive daytime talk shows that seem to be the source of most people's knowledge (or lack thereof) about transsexualism.

title: Not Even Trying to Appeal to the Masses
description: THREE years ago, a successful comedy writer named Dan O'Shannon (''Newhart,'' ''Cheers,'' ''It's a Living'') sat down to write the pilot of a new sitcom. His central character, Maggie Day, was a 40-year-old woman going through a midlife crisis. He sprinkled laughs on every page as Maggie coped with an inattentive husband, a couple of self-centered teen-agers and an unrequited crush on her boss, the local veterinarian.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; California Sets Early Primary
description: With 54 electoral votes, California has long been the 800-pound gorilla of American politics, except when it comes to Presidential candidates. In an era of increasingly early primaries, the state's June date made it an afterthought.

title: The Nation; Forget Prisons. Americans Cry Out For the Pillory.
description: I AM ashamed,'' wrote Fanny Burney, the English novelist, in 1778, ''of confessing that I have nothing to confess.''

title: It's All in How You Look at It
description: THE UNVEILING OF THE NATIONAL ICONS A Plea for Patriotic Iconoclasm in a Nationalist Era. By Albert Boime. Illustrated. 427 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $59.95.

title: SOAPBOX; One Tough Cookie
description: I WORK for a large New Jersey corporation, a Fortune 500 company. One of the things that this company does well, besides make money, is recognize diversity. Each month as part of this recognition, a minority group is showcased. There's Black History Month, Asian and Pacific Islanders Month, and there are months to celebrate the roles of Hispanic people , gays and lesbians and women. In March for Women's History Month, E-mail was sent to all employees. It was titled Women's History Month Bake-Off. You can imagine the hue and cry. ''Cookie baking contest? Who do they think we are? Are they living in the dark ages?'' No woman, especially no corporate woman, wants to be thought of as a cookie baker. We are too powerful, too intelligent, too competent -- and too insecure.

title: Pedaling Down The Net
description: For gym buffs

title: Evil's Humble Home
description: Richard Barnes's photograph of Theodore Kaczynski's cabin, isolated in a cavernous warehouse, is arresting, but Richard Ford ducks the point in his essay (Sept. 13). To me, the cabin says nothing about ''evil's humble beginnings,'' nor does it appear ''a mean little place, evocative of our darker selves.'' It looks like a snug, well-built little house that might be somewhat familiar to much of the world's population who live in small dwellings. Set in a natural landscape, where one steps out into the beauty of trees, plains or mountains and sunshine or clouds, it would need no ornamentation.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; A Blast From Space
description: Observing repeating bursts of gamma rays from four distant places in the galaxy, astronomers came up with an explanation, in theory. When a star explodes, all that remains is a dense object known as a neutron star. In rare cases, these objects must generate extremely powerful magnetic fields. Scientists reported they have compelling evidence of the existence of such stars, called magnetars.

title: The Big City; All's Well That Ends
description: This is my last column for the magazine, an occasion on which it is legally mandatory to contemplate what I've learned and how I've changed the world for the better. Unfortunately, the one great lesson I've learned is that people pay no attention to columnists, which has made it difficult to accomplish a significant amount of world-changing. Looking back over nearly five years of work, I can discern only two tangible results.

title: Yes, Blood Stains the Balkans. No, It's Not Just Fate.
description: COULD it be that the latest images of slaughtered ethnic Albanians from Kosovo -- slashed abdomens, spilled brains, slit throats, severed limbs -- comfort the West in a deeply held notion of incorrigible Balkan violence even as they spur renewed talk of NATO air strikes against the Serbs?

title: Babe Ruth, Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills referred to it erroneously. In fact the oldest congregation in New Jersey is Congregation B'nai Jeshurun of Franklin Lakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENCHLEY, MARJORIE B.
description: BENCHLEY-Marjorie B. On October 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel Goddard. Mother of Peter Bradford and Nathaniel Robert. Grandmother of three and great grandmother of one. Interment is private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Nantucket Cottage Hospital, Nantucket, MA. 02554.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENSINGTON; Sell Ice and They Will Come
description: Rick and John Luigi may not have seen any bright side when they learned that the rents on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope were too expensive for their new Italian ice and ice cream shop.

title: In America; A War on Women
description: Jay Leno does not see himself as a political or human rights activist. And his wife, Mavis, generally has, as she describes it, ''less than no interest'' in drawing public attention to herself.

title: Italian Spot on a Thoroughfare in Yonkers
description: DINERS looking for a meal in the vicinity of Central Park Avenue will find this busy thoroughfare lined with possibilities, most of them Italian. Thus it is not surprising that, when Cafe Morelli closed, Assaggio slipped in without missing a beat. Assaggio means taste, and most diners will be glad they did.

title: In SoHo, Art of Cooking
description: AQUAGRILL *

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ADALINE HAVEMEYER PERKINS
description: RAND-Adaline Havemeyer Perkins. Of Needham, MA, on October 2, age 85, of cancer. Born in New York City & a resident there until recently. She had been married to Richard S. Perkins and the late Laurance Rand. She had been a trustee of the Union Theological Seminary, a volunteer archivist at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Colony Club of New York. She leaves two sons, Richard S. Perkins, Jr. of Topsfield, MA, Thomas Perkins of Santa Barbara, California, two daughters Sarah & Judy Perkins, both of Concord, Massachusetts, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 22, at 10AM at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, New York. Instead of flowers contributions may be sent to the New Bedford Whaling Museum, Old Darmouth Historical Society, 18 Johnny Cake Hill, New Bedford, Massachusetts 02740. A memorial service will also be held in August in S. Dartmouth, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLONTZ, FRANZ
description: CLONTZ-Franz. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Franz Clontz, associated with The Times from 1966, until retiring in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGE, MARGARET D.
description: GEORGE-Margaret D. Born Elmhurst, L.I., NY 1903, died Sept 29, 1998. Resident Highland Beach, Fla., formerly Great Neck, NY and Darien, Ct. Widow of Allan C. George. Survived by daughters Phyllis Pitzer and Doris Williams.

title: Tinseltown Archaeology
description: To shoot his 1923 silent epic, ''The Ten Commandments,'' Cecil B. De Mille created a wood-and-plaster City of the Pharaohs in the Guadalupe Dunes, an 18-mile stretch of coastal sand 170 miles north of L.A. A crew of 2,500 people and 3,500 animals recreated Egyptian life among towering statues of the Pharaoh Ramses, five-ton Sphinxes and city walls more than 120 feet high. When the monthlong shoot wrapped, De Mille buried it all in the sand, creating a sort of ancient city of the desert. Funny thing is, it's still there. Though some small pieces have been uncovered and carted off by looters, a 1990 ground-penetrating radar survey showed that most of the set (pictured above) remains entombed by sand.

title: The Nation; Shedding New Light On a Scandalous Episode
description: OF all the episodes shaping public opinion about prosecutorial conduct in the White House scandal, few seemed so wrenching as when the mother of Monica S. Lewinsky broke down on her second day of questioning before the grand jury last February.

title: The Romance of the Seas
description: THROUGH most of the first eight months of this year, almost everything seemed to be coming up roses for the cruise industry. The year-end passenger count is likely to surpass last year's 5.05 million total, and the industry forecast of 7 million passengers by the year 2000 seemed well on target. Even the arrival in Florida two days ago of the Grand Princess, the world's biggest cruise liner, which departs on its initial Caribbean cruise today, did not give rise to the usual laments that the industry cannot absorb so many berths.

title: Room to Grow
description: Somewhere in my family's photograph collection is a picture of the first room I remember in any detail. My father painted it in the late 1950's for my sister and me, based on a design he saw in a magazine. (He showed us the article.) The walls were French blue with a broad band of soft red, across which zigzagged a line-drawing frieze of toy trains, painted in white. The effect was charming without appearing too childish, probably because the colors were more sophisticated than schoolroom primaries or nursery pastels. Baby talk, even in decorating, was not my parents' style.

title: The Story of O.
description: Sweet Water By Kathryn Kramer. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Tracey Tietjen, Mark Mahoney
description: Tracey Lynn Tietjen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Tietjen of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Edward Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mahoney of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. David Lothrop, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club.

title: Correction
description: The New York on Line column on Sept. 6, about The New York Welsh Home Page, misstated the name of a Welsh-language publication based in Basking Ridge, N.J. It is Ninnau (translated as We or Us), not The North American Welsh Newspaper.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down:

title: Her Old Hoboken Home Was Across From Foster's
description: To the Editor:

title: Kristi Fries, David Avram
description: Kristi Fries, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Fries of Phoenix, was married yesterday to Dr. David K. Avram, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morrell Avram of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Glazer officiated at the house of the bridegroom's parents in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; Schroder Ousts Kohl In German Election
description: Gerhard Schroder, a Social Democrat, defeated Helmut Kohl to become Chancellor of Germany, ending an era in Germany and opening a new one in Europe, where center-left governments now dominate the continent's politics.

title: Freshman's Foot Helps New Coach To Victory
description: At breakfast yesterday morning, the Fordham freshman Brian Colsant, of Vacaville, Calif., who had been on the campus for only a month, told his roommate, Dan Gress, that yes, he could see himself kicking the winning field goal against Princeton later in the day.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERRARA, RONALD A.
description: FERRARA-Ronald A. October 6, 1938. In loving memory of you on your birthday. You are missed every day. Love always, Jane

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Straightish
description: Jonathan Ames's second novel, THE EXTRA MAN (Scribner, $23), is both a sure-footed exploration of sexual confusion and a loopily elegant, surprisingly moving urban comedy of manners. Its hero, Louis Ives, is a private-school teacher in Princeton, N.J., who goes to great lengths to mold himself into the kind of ''young gentleman-about-town'' that Maugham, Fitzgerald and Wilde once wrote about. After losing his job because of an embarrassing incident involving a co-worker's brassiere, Louis slinks off to Manhattan in shame. There he builds a prickly friendship with his new roommate, Henry Harrison, a sloppy yet debonair elderly playwright with his own bundle of eccentricities. (Henry's ''sleeping costume'' consists of a black eye mask, a blue bathing suit and a tuxedo shirt.) Louis is fascinated and charmed by the sexually ambiguous Henry, who squires a series of rich widows around town as a means of scoring free meals and theater tickets. Louis has enough trouble figuring out his own preferences. Hopelessly attracted to women, he also shows a predilection for cross-dressing and transvestites, one of whom tells him, ''You're not really straight, but you're not really gay. You're straightish.'' Without resolving Louis's confusion, Ames makes it clear that his protagonist's sexual tentativeness and anxiety are really just flimsy covers for his passion and warmth. That's what makes ''The Extra Man'' work so well. Louis may feel as awkward as Milton Berle in drag, but inside he's really Fred Astaire -- he just doesn't know it yet. Stephanie Zacharek

title: The Nuclear Family
description: GEONS, BLACK HOLES,

title: No Trespassing?
description: Like innocence, a clear conscience and exquisite skin, privacy is something we all want but children have a special knack for getting. I learned this recently. For years, my fraternal twin sons had been sleeping in a room without any door. (Space limitations and furniture configurations being what they were, we had removed it when they were infants.) A recent renovation allowed the boys, now 9, to have their own rooms, and we tried to redress this lack of personal space. One of my sons was immediately grateful, catching on in no time to the notion of spatial privacy; the first time he slammed that door shut, banning entry by other family members, it was clear that he appreciated the full value of nursing his grievances in solitude. My other son, however, occupied the original room the boys had shared, and when I suggested we rehang the door there, he wanted nothing to do with it. He didn't need a door, he told us, and, in fact, didn't want one.

title: Susan Fried, Shawn Williams
description: Susan Deborah Fried, an editor, was married yesterday to Dr. Shawn Paul Williams, a research chemist. Joanne M. Sullivan, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated at Fort Sewall in Marblehead, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, HAROLD
description: WEINER-Harold, Dr., 84. Of Laguna Hills, California, formerly of Brooklyn Heights, New York, died suddenly on September 30, 1998. Husband of the late Mildred Olesh. Devoted father of Lois Prensky of Stamford, CT and the late Joanne Drutz. Caring father-in-law to David Prensky and Martin and Susan Drutz. Loving grandfather of Michelle Prensky, Judith and Lori Drutz. Devoted brother to Bea Meyer. Loving uncle and greatuncle to many. Friend to Elizabeth Gorden. A Podiatrist in Brooklyn for over 50 years, Harold headed the Podiatry Clinic at Long Island College Hospital. He enjoyed every moment of his eighty-four years. His one of a kind spirit will live on in us forever.

title: Miss Lewinsky: Are You Ready for Your Makeover Now?
description: As we all now know, the Monica Lewinsky paper doll should be wearing thong underwear.

title: Next: Yankees-Indians
description: The Yankees returned to New York yesterday to prepare for the American League Championship Series, which begins Tuesday, and received news of their teammate Darryl Strawberry, who had what doctors called successful surgery to remove a cancerous tumor from his colon. The Yankees' next opponent will be the Cleveland Indians, who defeated the Boston Red Sox, 2-1.

title: Settlement May Be Near In 8 States' Tobacco Suits
description: In a sign that a new tobacco settlement deal may be near, state attorneys general nationwide will be told this week about the details of a plan intended to resolve their lawsuits against the industry, lawyers familiar with those discussions said.

title: Robert Lewis Taylor Is Dead, Novelist and Biographer, 88
description: Robert Lewis Taylor, a prolific and witty writer of a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, a respected biography of W. C. Fields and New Yorker articles that a magazine colleague and memoirist called ''some of the funniest profiles we ever published,'' died on Wednesday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 88.

title: East Hampton Pulls Out Stops for 350th Gala
description: VISITORS to East Hampton often come in search of contemporary glitter and glitz. Next weekend, however, throngs of tourists are expected to join the town in celebrating its 350th anniversary by taking a trip into its past. And those wary of overpriced restaurants and boutique shops that sell $1,000 scarves will be buoyed by an official slogan for the weekend: ''When's the last time you got anything for free in East Hampton?''

title: Kevin Warwick
description: Warwick is a professor in the cybernetics department at Reading University in England. In a recent experiment, he had a computer chip temporarily implanted in his arm.

title: J. P. Morgan to the Rescue?
description: In October 1907, New York's Knickerbocker Trust Company failed, setting off a banking panic throughout the United States. Earlier that year stock prices had suffered two severe declines.

title: Toying With Science
description: A curious hybrid of math professor and poet, Chuck Hoberman considers himself an accidental toy maker. ''I didn't set out to make toys,'' says Hoberman, a lanky 42-year-old known in the play business as the erudite inventor of the Hoberman Sphere, a collapsible, skeletal ball made of brightly colored plastic. ''But it's been a revelation to see the huge variety of relationships that people have with toys. The world of toys is a place where people share whatever is neat and exciting to them.''

title: Marlene Laro, Andrew Joel
description: Marlene Ellen Laro, a daughter of Judge David Laro and Mrs. Laro of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Burns Joel, a son of Penny Joel of Andover, Mass., and the late Helmuth W. Joel Jr. The bride's father, who is a judge of the Federal Tax Court in Washington, officiated at Selma Plantation in Leesburg, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ROBERT KNIGHT
description: HARRIS-Robert Knight. We mourn the passing of our dad and grandfather, Bob Harris, his thoughtfulness, patience, style, dignity and sense of humor will be missed. He has made a lasting impression on all of us and he will be in our hearts forever. Jenny, Kate, Gail Walter and Bette Ann

title: Getting the Big Picture; The Film Industry Started Here and Left. Now It's Back, and the State Says the Sequel Is Huge.
description: MERYL STREEP came to Maplewood for ''One True Thing.'' Scott Rudin brought Kevin Kline to Montclair for ''In and Out.'' Harrison Ford stalked through Newark City Hall in ''Presumed Innocent.'' Nicolas Cage and Matt Damon stormed Atlantic City for ''Snake Eyes'' and ''Rounders,'' respectively. Jim Jarmusch is in Jersey City now, for ''Ghost Day.'' Woody Allen worked at the Jersey City Armory for ''Deconstructing Harry'' and in Atlantic City for ''Celebrity''; he is planning to cross the George Washington Bridge again this month for his next project. Norman Jewison will be here, too, to recreate the story of the boxer Hurricane Carter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBACH, IRVING
description: STEINBACH-Irving. Age 85. Of Glen Rock, NJ. Husband of Dorothy. Father of Jean Demmer, Judy Brown. Brother of Teresa Wieselberg. Beloved grandfather of Michael, Matthew, Jason and Jordan. Services are 12:30 PM, today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus.

title: Sept. 27-Oct. 3; H.M.O.'s Shun Medicare
description: More than 200,000 Medicare beneficiaries will have to find new health insurance next year because they are in health maintenance organizations that are cutting back their Medicare operations.

title: Shakespeare, And the Wilds Found Indoors
description: ONE can picture a room like this on the glassy upper floors of a corporate compound or, for that matter, on board next century's executive spacecraft. The proportions and color, a sleek all-over red, render it both intimate and stately. The furnishings, a table and a set of padded chairs, are at once sumptuous and stark: any recriminations will be muffled by the heavy drapes.

title: In West Bank, Little Arab Control; Arafat's Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: Sox Fans See Disaster If Mo Vaughn Leaves
description: His departure would be a disaster in every way. From the standpoint of performance, it would cost the rejuvenated Boston Red Sox their best hitter for average and power. From the standpoint of morale, it would remove one of the team's most respected and authoritative voices from the clubhouse. And from the standpoint of public relations, it would infuriate the fans and take away the most beloved black superstar baseball player this city -- one long regarded as racially divided -- has had.

title: A Composer Defying Categories
description: DURING one of the first performances of Astor Piazzolla's self-described ''little opera,'' ''Maria de Buenos Aires,'' in 1968, a voice rose from the audience, repeatedly emitting profane exclamations. Backstage after the show, the culprit was discovered: it was the Brazilian poet Vinicius de Moraes, paying homage in his paradoxical way to the composer's astonishing achievement.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on Sept. 20 for a costume ball in Chadds Ford, Pa., misstated the telephone number of the Brandywine River Museum, where the ball will be held. It is (610) 388-2700.

title: Europe Dominates Survey's Top 10 Least-Corrupt-Countries List
description: Transparency International, a small independent organization that has been tracking for four years how the public and international businesses view corruption worldwide, has published its largest survey to date, looking at 85 countries and ranking only one completely clean: Denmark.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you told me two years ago that I'd be making a great living selling worms from machines, I'd have told you you were crazy.''

title: No Room To Breathe For Banks
description: During a rough patch for stocks in general last week, financial shares in particular took a beating. Though bank and brokerage stocks rallied Friday with the overall market, most of these shares remain near their lows for the year.

title: Tackling Wooden Siding Problems
description: METAPHORICALLY speaking, siding is the skin of a house. It serves two functions: it protects the house from the elements,insects and rodents and adds style and beauty to the exterior of the house.

title: The 'F-Troop' Version Of Agarn's Hometown
description: Regarding Alvin Klein's ''A Season With Star Power'' article on Sept. 13: It seems fitting that Larry Storch should be coming to the Garden State to perform in a play. After all, Storch's best-known character, Corporal Agarn on the 1960's television western spoof ''F-Troop,'' spoke often and fondly of his hometown of Passaic. As one born in Passaic and raised in neighboring Clifton, I was amused by Storch/Agarn's grandiloquent pronunciation of ''Pa-SAY-ik,'' given that my family and I used the more prosaic-sounding ''Pu-SAKE.''

title: The Power of Music, the Glory of the Chorus
description: ''OPERA is my wife.''

title: Law to Track Foreigners Entering U.S. Is Postponed
description: A new law that tightens America's borders by tracking every foreigner who enters the United States has been postponed because immigration officials say they are not ready to handle the job and Congress is not sure it really wants the measure enforced.

title: Smuggler's Child
description: AHMED'S REVENGE By Richard Wiley. 320 pp. New York: Random House. $23.95.

title: 55 Suffolk Officers Avert Dismissal Over Tests
description: ENDING an investigation in which 32 Suffolk County police officers faced dismissal for suspected cheating on hiring exams, the county has agreed that all will remain on the force.

title: Psychoanalyst's Harm
description: To the Editor: I strongly support Katharine Weber's portrait of Dr. Gregory Zilboorg [''In a Painting, Gershwin Packed the House,'' Aug. 30]. For Maurice Adelman [Letters to the Editor, Sept. 20] to refer to a 1957 obituary of the psychoanalyst to refute it makes no sense. At that time, such notices rarely spoke ill of the dead.

title: Ohio State Turns Game on Turnovers
description: One minute 25 seconds before the Ohio State band marched onto the field at halftime, and 2 minutes 16 seconds after they left was all it took for the Buckeyes to turn a tense, well-played football game into a 28-9 drubbing of Penn State today. It was a game made even more dreary by an afternoon of driving rain.

title: Amanda Moss, David Totaro
description: Amanda Stacy Moss and David Jonathan Totaro were married on Friday at the St. Regis in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Once Again, the Red Sox Come Up Short in the Post-Season
description: The latest addition to Boston's painful baseball narrative was supposed to be Pete Schourek, the lightly regarded pitcher who Manager Jimy Williams decided to start over the sensational Pedro Martinez today in Game 4.

title: PULSE; The Great Unwashed
description: When only the stiffest, darkest jeans will do, the problem becomes, how to wash them? Cold water and dry cleaning merely postpone the inevitable. And replacing a pair by Helmut Lang ($135, far left) or by A.P.C. ($110) when they start to fade will burn a hole in your pocket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, WALTER C.
description: TAYLOR-Walter C. 77. Retired assistant general counsel at Eli Lilly & Co. Died on October 2, 1998, Martinsville, IN. Served in the U.S. Navy on the battleship U.S.S. Massachusetts during WW II. Received his L.L.B. degree from Columbia University Law School. He practiced law in NYC with Simpson, Thatcher & Bartlett, and Clark, Carr & Ellis, and served as special counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives subcommittee. Joined Eli Lilly & Co in 1964. Retird in 1986. He was benefactor and volunteer for mental health organizations, with a deep commitment to helping children, including roles as: the Beverly Farm Foundation in St. Louis, MO; as Chairman of the Indiana State Childhood Mental Illness Committee; as a founding member and President of the Association for Mentally Ill Children in Westchester County, NY. Above all, he was a generous friend. Beloved husband of D. Joan Taylor; father of Christopher Taylor of Huntersville, NC; Walter Taylor III, Susan Taylor of St. Louis, MO; and, loved by his five step-children, twelve grandchildren and by his many relatives and friends. We all will miss him dearly. Contributions can be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Out of Space? Get Rid Of Clutter
description: ORGANIZING a household almost always involves one crucial word: clutter. ''Most people I deal with have too much stuff,'' said Linda Rothschild, head of Cross It Off Your List, a professional organizer and moving consultant in Manhattan. ''And most people with too much stuff have their stuff in all the wrong places.''

title: Season Ends for MetroStars in a Shootout
description: The soccer season came to an end for the MetroStars tonight when they experienced their first loss in four shootout games this season, while the Columbus Crew posted its first shootout victory in six attempts.

title: County Won't Take Part in a Sales Tax Waiver
description: CONVINCED that property taxes would have to be increased substantially if it did otherwise, Westchester County has decided not to take part in a state plan to waive all sales tax on some apparel for a fourth trial week in January.

title: Robin Yunis, Robert Easton
