description: Robin Dale Yunis, the daughter of Marilyn L. Yunis of Toronto and Jeffrey R. Yunis of Coconut Grove, Fla., was married last evening to Robert Hale Easton, the son of Joan and Peter Easton of New Hyde Park, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Where's the Bottom? It May Not Be Here Yet
description: For investors who hope the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index won't revisit its Aug. 31 low, last week's 4.0 percent selloff seemed to be the market's surly way of saying: ''Don't be so sure.''

title: In Time of Need, Unity Pulses to a Latin Beat
description: They came from all over Latin New York, looking to glimpse a star, to dance, to help.

title: Spectacular Scenery and Exciting Food
description: THE trumpets for which a new Eastport restaurant is named are those that call race horses to the starting gate. Diners should also be off and running to this new spot. It's worth the ride.

title: Sex Advice for the Clinton Age
description: It may not feel like it now, but some day America may look back on the Starr report as a publishing event as significant as the Kinsey report was in its day. True, it is a crudely sketched morality play, but it has given the American public and the descendants of Kinsey -- the sex-advice columnists, the researchers and the therapists whose job it is to explain us to ourselves -- an unprecedented opportunity to examine our attitudes about sex.

title: School Busing, City and Suburban
description: EVEN as Superior Court Judge Julia L. Aurigemma ponders whether the state has failed to meet a 1996 Supreme Court mandate on the Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation case, a $3 million voluntary busing program was begun last month in the state's three largest cities.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THREE films that swiftly attained legendary status and a flinty, atmospheric whodunit lend luster to the lineup of movies on television this week.

title: The View From/The Freedom Trail; A Giant Quilt Pays Tribute to People United in the Cause of Justice
description: THE history of African-Americans in Connecticut can be traced in the Freedom Trail -- 77 sites connected with the heritage and civil rights struggles of black citizens. Now those sites have been illustrated in the Freedom Trail quilt, an unusual collaboration of preservationists, artists, historians, human rights advocates and bicyclists.

title: Federal Grants Help Gown to Aid Town
description: The gap between universities and their adjoining neighborhoods is often wide, especially in cities. But as urban problems have intensified over the years, intruding at times on campus life, more and more schools have been rethinking their relationship to the greater society.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Valhalla, N.Y.; Tree-Lined Hamlet With Dramatic Views
description: ACCORDING to Norse mythology, the name of this small Westchester hamlet means burial ground for slain heroes, which is fitting since it is home to Westchester's two largest cemeteries, Kensico and Gate of Heaven.

title: Attached To an Attache
description: WOMEN are losing their grip on status bags. Or so it seems, judging by the logo-laden bags clenched by well-heeled businessmen around town. There are now briefcases emblazoned with double G's from Gucci, double F's from Fendi, L V's from Louis Vuitton and paisley swirls from Etro -- all a man could want and more. Can it be long before Oprah Winfrey devotes a show to shop-aholic executives, ''Today, the man who went out for one new briefcase and came home with 80''?

title: The Nation; For Senators, That Was Real Brass
description: GEN. HENRY H. SHELTON is a good soldier. But smart salutes and muddy boots don't always take the hill, especially when it's Capitol Hill.

title: Is the Time Right for Market Timing?
description: WHAT a difference two months can make.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on page 10 of the Travel section today with the What's Doing column, about Trinidad, misstates hotel and taxi charges. The average hotel room for one night is $100, not $200. A taxi ride from St. James to Port of Spain is 33 cents, not $33.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Cleanup of Tainted Industrial Sites Gains Momentum
description: VACANT for six years, the single-story building at 4 Henderson Drive within a corporate park in West Caldwell is an industrial wreck, a victim of time and environmental concerns.

title: Merchants Offer Discounts To St. John's Students
description: The Union Turnpike Merchants Association has teamed up with the area's businesses, St. John's University and The Queens Courier Newspaper to distribute coupon books for use by St. John's students. Copies were also placed on the association's Web site (www.utma.org).

title: She's Not Even Pushy, So Break Out the Brandy
description: A good woman is hard to find, members of the exclusive, all-male chief executive's club known as the Business Council will tell you. But when the 65-year-old group convenes its semiannual meeting in Williamsburg, Va., on Thursday, there will at last be a woman among its 100 active members: Crandall Close Bowles, 50, who became chief executive of Springs Industries, the textile giant founded by her great-grandfather, on Jan. 1, will join such macho members of the corporate elite as John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. of I.B.M. and Walter V. Shipley of Chase Manhattan.

title: MAKING IT WORK; A Pilgrim in the City
description: THE most vivid passages of ''The Seven-Storey Mountain,'' the autobiography of the Trappist monk Thomas Merton, published 50 years ago today, describe the author's early 20's and his efforts to liberate his soul from the snares of a New York City illuminated by the fires of hell. Most of the physical way stations along Merton's spiritual journey remain standing, in neighborhoods from Greenwich Village to Harlem, forming for Merton pilgrims a dramatic panorama of the city he loved to hate. No one was more surprised than Merton when ''The Seven-Storey Mountain'' became a best seller for Harcourt Brace and a spiritual classic. He went on to become a major voice in struggles for racial integration, ecumenism and civil rights. During a brief return visit in 1964, he was enchanted by New York and wrote, ''It isn't a soulless city at all.''

title: Serbs Display a Death Site; Identity of Remains Not Known
description: The Serbian authorities took foreign reporters to a rocky crevice on this mountain today to show four skulls and the remains of people buried near a former hideout of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

title: Yank Pitchers Allowed a Run, and Sent a Message
description: The Yankees had their way with the Texas Rangers and turned them into one-hit wonders. Next.

title: Tomorrow Is Deadline For Voter Registration
description: The deadline for registering to vote in the Nov. 5 general election is tomorrow.

title: Police and Firefighters At Odds in Shelton
description: MANY firefighters in Shelton are angry about what they believe to be targeting of their vehicles for tickets by a few disgruntled police officers. But the conflict goes back several years, say officials, and involves not only the two departments but also the mayor's office.

title: West Celebrates Mining's Past, but Not Its Future
description: A massive, illuminated ''M'' burns nightly on a hillside here, a reminder that this town was founded by gold miners and is home to the Colorado School of Mines. For tourists, Golden celebrates its mining heritage with a geology museum and welcoming banners featuring a broad-hatted miner panning for gold.

title: Fugitive in Bombing of Clinic May Be Charged With 3 More
description: Eric Robert Rudolph, the North Carolina fugitive already wanted in the deadly bombing of an Alabama abortion clinic, may soon be charged with carrying out three bombings in the Atlanta area, including the 1996 explosion during the Olympics, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Shame On You!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Picture of Good Nature Balanced With Fond Thoughts of Bad Times
description: Ah, debauchery. It really doesn't make for a sustainable life style, but those who gave themselves over to it sure came up with some fine rock-and-roll.

title: Essay
description: Here are seven questions overlooked in the torrent of testimony.

title: Poughkeepsie, in a Long Tailspin, Now Copes With a Clouded Image
description: Although they may laugh along when outsiders poke fun at their hometown, people here feel a deep affection for this neighborly, unpretentious Hudson River city, once home to companies as prosaically American as Smith Brothers cough drops.

title: Yanks Relieved, Relaxed And Ready for Revenge
description: George Steinbrenner elicited smiles easily from Derek Jeter and Tino Martinez as they chatted behind the batting cage. Tim Raines and Jorge Posada, who are normally nowhere near second base during real games, turned fancy double plays. Teammates teased Hideki Irabu and Orlando Hernandez whenever one of their offerings was torched during rare batting practice sessions for both restless pitchers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSENBERG, PETER
description: WEISSENBERG-Peter. (10/5/96) Remembered with love, today and everyday. Laura, Ariel, Adam, Robbie, Sophie, Ally, Paula and Mother

title: Small Network Consultant Prospers on Backs of Technology Giants
description: Bell Atlantic had a problem.

title: Reality of the H.M.O. System Doesn't Live Up to the Dream
description: At the start of the 90's, when employers' health insurance costs were surging 15 percent a year, the giant Sprint Corporation was quick to shift to health maintenance organizations and their businesslike management of medical care.

title: Yankee House-Hunting Options
description: The New York Yankees would no doubt prefer to have all eyes trained on their quest for another World Series title. But their inspiring on-field performance cannot shut out that other fall classic -- the struggle over the future of their storied stadium. Recent developments fortify the case for keeping this ball club in its historic home in the Bronx. Gov. George Pataki has affirmed his support for this location. The possibilities for upgrading the structure and enhancing the surrounding neighborhood were laid out in a new $535 million renovation plan, drafted by a respected architectural firm at the behest of Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer. That plan and others like it should whet everyone's appetite for a competition to design a stadium, a museum and surrounding amenities worthy of baseball's premier franchise.

title: Hecklers Try to Goad Pataki Into Debate With Vallone
description: In a bit of guerrilla theater, Peter F. Vallone's campaign yesterday stepped up the pressure on Gov. George E. Pataki to debate, sending people dressed as duck hunters to the annual Pulaski Day Parade to heckle the Governor and accuse him of ducking debates.

title: High School Senior Rides to Victory
description: Cullen Latimer of Pound Ridge, N.Y., rode S&L Apparel to win the United States team equitation championship, the first leg of equitation's triple crown, at the team's training center in Gladstone, N.J., yesterday.

title: At Least for One Day, It's Easy Being Green
description: He floated to the Jets in 1993 as a free agent from the University of Akron Zips. Who knew zip about safety Victor Green? He landed in training camp that season among 15 Jets defensive backs, a bunch that included Ronnie Lott, Lonnie Young, Dennis Price, Brian Washington and James Hasty. All bigger names. Supposedly, better players, too.

title: Woman Slain in Lobby Of Queens Building
description: Detectives were searching yesterday for a gunman who shot a 20-year-old woman to death in the lobby of her Queens apartment building on Saturday night, the police said.

title: Room at Top? Nos. 1 and 2 Not Dominant
description: The two college football coaches on top believe they know something about staying there. Ohio State's John Cooper said that piling up ''solid wins'' makes his team immune to the whims of poll voters and the computer-ranking calculations. Nebraska's Frank Solich said that achieving consistent excellence is about winning the games you are supposed to win.

title: Accounts
description: * Allied Domecq Spirits USA, Old Greenwich, Conn., to Zenith Media, New York, a joint venture of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., to handle its consolidated media planning and buying account, which had been handled by various agencies, including Zenith. Billings were estimated at more than $30 million.

title: From Romantic-Comedy Sidelines to Glaring Spotlight
description: The thing about the people in ''Unmade Beds,'' Nicholas Barker's docu-narrative about four New Yorkers searching for love and marriage, sex and companionship, or the money that sex and companionship can secure, is that they are the kind of people that movies about romance have always relegated to the sidelines. They don't have the physical glamour or charisma that makes us eager to believe that the leading man and woman will find each other (and therefore happiness) against all narrative odds.

title: Gooden Back Where It Began
description: With the celebratory rhythm and blues blaring and his Cleveland Indians teammates rejoicing, Dwight Gooden felt so good Saturday night that he forgot about his nightmarish experience three days earlier in Game 2 of the division series. His feud with Umpire Joe Brinkman behind him, Gooden looked forward to returning to New York City, the birthplace of his stardom, where the Indians will face the Yankees in the American League Championship Series.

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, DR. SYDNEY J.
description: ROSE-Dr. Sydney J. 82. Died on October 3, 1998, in Winchester, MA. Beloved husband for 55 years of Hester. Dear father of Linda Portnay and Jeffrey Rose. Devoted grandfather of Rebecca and Ted Portnay, and Jennifer and Joshua Rose. He practiced family medicine in Flushing, Queens. His kindness and generous spirit will be missed by many. Memorial donations may be made to Camp Sussex, Inc., 110-11 Queens Blvd., Apt. 1BB, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLESNICK, RUTH
description: KOLESNICK-Ruth. Passed away on October 2, 1998. Loving wife of Leon Kolesnick and the late Samuel Bederson. She is survived by her children Dale and George Rotner, and Cathy and Robert Schlecter, her loving grandchildren Stacey and Robert Gendelman, Dorit and Glenn Rotner and Justin Schlecter, plus her six beautiful great-grandchildren. Friends are invited to pay their repects on Monday or Tuesday evening at 21 Cornell St., Scarsdale, NY. Service will be held on Tuesday, October 6, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, at 9:45 AM. Ruth's family wish to thank all of the people who helped and cared for her during her stay at the Sound Shore Medical Center for their caring, dedication and professionalism.

title: Management Tips, From the 'Literature' Shelves
description: Bristling with suspicion, I picked up Robert A. Brawer's ''Fictions of Business: Insights on Management From Great Literature.'' First, the very juxtaposition of the human imagination and business management seemed somehow contradictory. The dust jacket of Mr. Brawer's book, a detail of Edward Hopper's painting ''Office at Night,'' said it all: the possibility of any spontaneous interchange between the young woman at the file cabinet and the young man at the desk seems deadened by something unseen, perhaps the threat of bankruptcy looming in the next room.

title: Cullman Journal; Hold Back the Barrel, It's (Dry) Oktoberfest Time
description: Five thousand miles away, at the real Oktoberfest, the Mayor of Munich kicked things off this year, as is the solemn tradition, by pounding a bent bronze spout into a keg of golden brew and declaring ''O'zapft is,'' or ''It has been tapped.'' So began the two-week quest to see whether this year's revelers would exceed last year's consumption of 5.6 million liters of beer, which is, after all, the whole point.

title: Politics Again Leaves U.S. Financial Overhaul in Limbo
description: World financial markets are in turmoil. Hedge funds are bleeding billions. But with consumers confused and investors scared, a measure that supporters say would modernize the nation's financial system and make it more globally competitive is stuck in Congress, caught in the crosscurrents of several political fights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFER, MIRIAM
description: HOFFER-Miriam. Age 96. On October 3, 1998. We mourn the loss of a person of great vitality, warmth, hospitality and zest for living. Beloved wife of the late Harry Ralston and the late Fred Hoffer. Loving mother of Donald Ralston and the late Dr. Bruce Ralston. Devoted mother-in-law to Carole and Shirley Ralston. Adoring grandmother of Beth, Lowell, Diana, Jim, Harry and Ilene. Great-grandmother of six. Cherished sister to the late Lester and Herbert Levy. Services will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, New York.

title: Treasury's Schedule This Week Offers Two Bills and a Note
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a 10-year inflation index note on Wednesday.

title: Protests Set for Moscow, but Over What?
description: If the Commu nist Party has its way and it has been planning for months -- millions of Russians will take to the streets on Wednesday for some of the biggest demonstrations in years.

title: Compressed Data; Scientist Sees a Power Drain In Switched-Off Appliances
description: Alan Meier would like people to mean ''off'' when they say ''off.''

title: Sports of The Times; Still Looking for the Answers
description: JIM FASSEL has a problem. In his brief tenure as Giants head coach, he has gone through a number of philosophic evolutions before the season in an attempt to restore the Giants to their previous glory.

title: Problems With Diamonds Kept Swedes in the Race
description: Swedish teams did extremely well in the world championships, which ended in Lille, France, a month ago. One came close to reaching the final of the Vivendi Rosenblum Open Teams, and another had the satisfaction of eliminating the top-seeded American team led by Nick Nickell of Manhattan. The diagramed deal, with a series of problems in the diamond suit, contributed to this result.

title: Sports of The Times; Byars, Like the Old Pro He Is, Knew No. 13's Mind-Set
description: WHEN they were Dolphins teammates for four seasons, Keith Byars often saw that look in Dan Marino's eyes. And when he saw that look again yesterday on Marino's 2-yard touchdown pass to Troy Drayton with more than five minutes remaining, he warned his Jets teammates about the 37-year-old quarterback who still throws lasers.

title: Pressure On Marino
description: The Jets had been the only National Football League team without a defensive lineman producing a sack. That changed yesterday as ends Anthony Pleasant and Ernie Logan got to Dan Marino. Linebacker Chad Cascadden snared him in the first quarter.

title: JAPANESE TELL U.S. THAT THEIR BANKS ARE IN BIG TROUBLE
description: Japan's top financial officials told their American counterparts this weekend that their country's banking system was acutely short of capital, with the top 19 banks in deeper trouble than Tokyo has ever before admitted, according to officials familiar with the discussions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANDERSON, ROSAMOND MARIE
description: ANDERSON - Rosamond Marie ''Andy''. Died Oct 4, 1997. Sweet be thy rest and peaceful thy sleeping, God's way is best, Thou art in his keeping. Mother, loved ones & friends

title: Young & Rubicam Gets Sony Business
description: The Sony Electronics unit of the Sony Corporation of America in Park Ridge, N.J., has named Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York to handle advertising for its consumer products marketing group. Billings had been estimated at $35 million to $50 million but are now expected to rise to $60 million.

title: Joseph C. McCarthy, Pilot in '43 Dam Buster Raid, Dies at 79
description: It was considered quite a show at the time: a brazen British bombing raid in 1943 on a trio of strategic German dams carried out with such high-spirited elan, employing such delightfully preposterous techniques and producing such spectacular success that it gave an immediate boost to battered British morale in World War II.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Choreographer Unafraid, And So Even Caligula Lives
description: ''Dances Old and New'' was the name of the program presented by the Mary Anthony Dance Theater on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. The six pieces did span three decades. But it was the ''old'' that distinguished this satisfying evening, from a choreographic emphasis on solid craft to big, emotionally committed, weighted dancing.

title: Marino, Jets' Arch-Nemesis, Is Battered, Beaten, Banished
description: It was another step forward, and perhaps a wave goodbye to a negative history that is fading fast.

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Faces Old and New Issues
description: The Supreme Court term that opens today has the potential to produce significant rulings on civil rights and Federal regulation, with a mix of constitutional and statutory cases on a docket that is still very much a work in progress.

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Petersburg Orchestra Evokes the Pall Of Politburo Censors
description: Fear is not the best motivation for musical composition, but all three pieces on the St. Petersburg Philharmonic's program at Carnegie Hall on Friday night were touched by it. The music was Shostakovich and Prokofiev, the two most talented composers of the Soviet school and therefore the two to suffer most at its hands.

title: Bitter Roots of a Banana Republic
description: Rambling across four centuries and turning a bleak eye on the Roman Catholic Church and United States imperialism in Central America, Arthur Grion's ambitious new play, ''A Dream of Wealth,'' may not be subtle, but it provides plenty of history and food for thought.

title: Patents; Software that tracks the amount of time browsers spend on Web sites and how they use them.
description: Fall the unknowns about the Internet, the greatest questions may revolve around whether or not it will ever become a reliable money maker. Granted, some companies do earn money through World Wide Web sites, but for the majority the promise of E-commerce with vast new markets, customers and profits remains unfulfilled.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about a woman who is suing Lenox Hill Hospital over the results of an amniocentesis test misstated the date that the woman, Janet Shei khan, and her husband, Mohammad, were photographed. It was Sept. 16, not last Tuesday.

title: Twirling Skirts on a Bridge to the Divine
description: The form looks simple. Imbuing it with depth and meaning is something else. This lesson came through clearly in a return appearance at City Center on Friday night by the group that has toured nationally in recent years as the Whirling Dervishes of Turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ADALINE HAVEMEYER PERKINS
description: RAND-Adaline Havemeyer Perkins. Of Needham, MA, on October 2, age 85, of cancer. Born in New York City & a resident there until recently. She had been married to Richard S. Perkins and the late Laurance Rand. She had been a trustee of the Union Theological Seminary, a volunteer archivist at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Colony Club of New York. She leaves two sons, Richard S. Perkins, Jr. of Topsfield, MA, Thomas Perkins of Santa Barbara, California, two daughters Sarah & Judy Perkins, both of Concord, Massachusetts, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 22, at 10AM at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, New York. Instead of flowers contributions may be sent to the New Bedford Whaling Museum, Old Darmouth Historical Society, 18 Johnny Cake Hill, New Bedford, Massachusetts 02740. A memorial service will also be held in August in S. Dartmouth, MA.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Thursday about performances by Bob Mould at Irving Plaza misstated the surname of the accompanying guitarist. He was Michael Cerveris, not Cerberis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, WILLARD
description: FREEDMAN-Willard. Age 80, of Southbury, CT. On October 4, 1998. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Eric, Andrew and Ellen. Graveside services Tuesday, October 6, 11:30 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, LI.

title: Equity Offerings Expected
description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Cardoso Seems to Be Re-elected in Brazil, Averting Runoff
description: Brazilian voters gave President Fernando Henrique Cardoso a comfortable lead in the first round of balloting today, apparently maintaining the leadership of a country struggling against economic crisis.

title: Starr's Efforts to Expand Inquiry Raise Doubts, White House Says
description: The White House said today that ''troubling questions'' had been raised about the actions of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, and his office in seeking to expand its original inquiry to include accusations of a relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastor Chides Candidates For 'Dirty' Senate Campaign
description: With Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato clapping in the pews, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake stood before an exuberant congregation in his Queens church yesterday and urged Mr. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer to halt their ''dirty campaign'' for the United States Senate.

title: World Bank Worried by Pressure for Quick-Fix Fiscal Action
description: As the global economic crisis spreads, the World Bank fears that it will be made to transform itself from a slow-moving development agency into a financial fire truck, programmed to squirt streams of cash at countries under speculative attack as part of a plan to head off such crises.

title: INSIDE
description: Pressure on World Bank

title: Media Talk; In the Battle for Advertisers, Parties, Parties Everywhere
description: One of the great perks of working in the media department of a New York advertising agency is the wining and dining you're treated to. Even a lowly media planner has enormous discretion over where an advertiser spends its money. But such largesse usually stops at the banks of the Hudson River.

title: Padres Defeat Johnson; Next Up Are the Braves
description: Even though they knew they might not be able to afford him when he became a free agent at the end of the season, the Houston Astros traded for Randy Johnson minutes before the July 31 deadline in the hopes that he could lead them to a World Series.

title: Speaking for the President, With Knowing Humor
description: Joe Lockhart is realistic about his new job as President Clinton's press secretary. ''I'm sure something horrible will happen'' right away, he said, in this his first full week on the job.

title: Cubs Go Back to Land That Time Forgot; Braves Roll On
description: Asked to explain how the Atlanta Braves swept the Chicago Cubs, Sammy Sosa was succinct.

title: Supreme Court Docket Mixes Old and New
description: The Supreme Court term that opens Monday has the potential to produce significant rulings in such areas as civil rights and Federal regulation, with a mix of constitutional and statutory cases on a docket that is still very much a work in progress.

title: Haru M. Reischauer, 83; Eased Tensions With Japan
description: Haru Matsukata Reischauer, a journalist and author who was influential in diplomatic affairs in the 1960's as the wife of the United States Ambassador to Japan, died on Sept. 23 in La Jolla, Calif. She was 83.

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENCHLEY, MARJORIE B.
description: BENCHLEY-Marjorie B. On October 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel Goddard. Mother of Peter Bradford and Nathaniel Robert. Grandmother of three and great grandmother of one. Interment is private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Nantucket Cottage Hospital, Nantucket, MA. 02554.

title: WITH LINES DRAWN, HOUSE PANEL NEARS IMPEACHMENT VOTE
description: With Congress poised to open the first Presidential impeachment inquiry since the national agony of Watergate, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that it was his ''hope and prayer'' to complete the investigation of President Clinton by the end of the year.

title: The association of ad agencies is welcoming some not-too-distant cousins into the family fold.
description: THE American Association of Advertising Agencies, in a significant step, is opening membership for the first time to independently owned agencies that specialize in services outside the realm of traditional advertising, like media planning and buying, public relations and corporate identity consulting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILBERT, IDA
description: DILBERT-Ida. Died October 3, 1998, in Great Neck, NY. Beloved mother of Phyllis Turin and Ann Sandler and dear mother-in-law of Michael Turin and the late Melvin Sandler. Devoted sister of Esther Bernstein and the late Rose Schatner. She was a loving grandmother and great-grandmother. We will remember her as a true lady. Graveside services will be held Tuesday, October 6, at 11:30, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Howard to Carry Out Tax Reform; Anti-Immigrant Party's Bid Fails : Australian Chief's Mandate Shrinks
description: Prime Minister John Howard of Australia said Sunday that he would press ahead with a tax reform plan despite being returned to power with a sharply reduced majority Saturday in the general election.

title: Media Talk; Anti-Drug Group Sues Writer Who Made Up Some Sources
description: Stories about journalistic invention have been distressingly common these last few months, with their impact upon the credibility of the news media well dissected. But what of the legal consequences of questionable attributions and fictitious ''facts''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPATI, ANNE MARIE F.
description: CAPATI-Anne Marie F. Of Huntington, NY, on October 1, 1998. Beloved wife of Douglas Hanson. Loving mother of Olivia and Maxwell. Cherished daughter of Nazario and Ana Capati. Dear sister of Carmel Capati. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:45 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Huntington. For information call A. L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 516423-2185. Burial to follow at Huntington Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Olivia and Maxwell Hanson.

title: Leftist Fringe Is Imperiling Italy Coalition Over Budget
description: It is autumn in Italy, the birds are going south, and so it seems could the Italian Government, as the bonds of compromise and political opportunism that bind a small leftist party to the Government came undone today.

title: Compressed Data; Meditation in a Wired World: Stare at the Screen and Relax
description: It is easy for Mark Abouzeid to preach inner harmony and balance for today's highly stressed business people. He lives in a house in Castelmuzio, Italy, population 250, where the view from his window -- a hundred olive trees and the church featured in the movie ''The English Patient'' -- is a picture of tranquillity. But with the help of two high-speed phone lines and nine employees scattered in Europe and the United States, Mr. Abouzeid, a transplanted American, keeps in touch with angst, 90's style.

title: Pensive and Sensual In the Face of Mortality
description: Though the subject of mortality is at the heart of ''Late August, Early September,'' this latest film by Olivier Assayas studiously avoids an air of life-or-death urgency. Mr. Assayas, a filmmaker capable of both subtle intensity (''Wild Reeds'') and sneaky wit (''Irma Vep''), this time takes a tastefully oblique approach to his material. Though his film centers on the death of a middle-aged man and its effect on the friends around him, Mr. Assayas concentrates on myopic egos and changing relationships rather than morbidity or pain. The film shows at least as much interest in texture -- smoking, eating, shrugging, kissing -- as in fully grasping its characters' malaise.

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?; Serbian Caprice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SYLVIA
description: LEVINE-Sylvia. On October 3, 1998, of Rockville Centre, LI. Beloved wife of the late Leo; devoted mother of Steven Levine, Phyllis Tunick and Marvin Levine; loving grandmother of Lesa, Lauri and Robyn Levine, Debbie Loeb, Sandi Kroll, Lindsay and Alexander Levine; cherished great-grandmother of Tori and Dani Kroll, and Brett Loeb. Sevices Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: To Buy Some Time, Russia to Sell U.S. Some Time in Space
description: In a concession born of crisis, Russia has agreed to sell the United States up to all its allotted research time aboard the first phase of the International Space Station for $60 million, NASA officials say.

title: Citibank Sets New On-Line Bank System
description: Citibank, a pioneer of consumer electronic banking, has decided to abandon many of the computer systems it has built at a huge cost in the last decade and create a new retail banking and investment service on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERRY, STUART M.
description: SPERRY-Stuart M. On September 25, 1998, Professor Emeritus of English at Indiana University, died peacefully at his home in London, England. He was the son of the late Stuart M. Sperry and Doris Laidlaw Sperry and husband of Sophie, and brother of Suzanne Sperry Klay of N.H. Educated at Hall School, Princeton '51 Harvard Ph.D '59. Served in the Korean War in the 47th Artillery Division. Wounded in action he received the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star with ''Leaves.''

title: Truth in Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor,

title: Fear Greets Cut in H.M.O. For the Elderly
description: In a tense ritual like that being played out around the country, counselors and politicians in the New York City suburbs scrambled today to calm thousands of elderly people who learned second-hand over the weekend that their health insurer would drop them on Jan. 1.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have a New Year's resolution and that is we finish by New Year's, and you know how New Year's resolutions sometimes get broken, but it's my hope and prayer that we could finish by New Year's.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, LON
description: CLARK-Lon. On October 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Michelle. Loving father of Lon Jr. and Stephen and step-father of Timothy and George Morse. Grandfather of Lon III. Dear brother of Gerald and Eduard. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Interment private. Memorial services to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Episcopal Actors' Guild, 1 East 29 St, NY NY 10016.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS Double Take

title: Skip Away Stays Loose at Belmont
description: As Breeders' Cup preview week dawned at Belmont Park, with five Grade I stakes scheduled for Saturday, several of the stars aiming for championships worked out yesterday, led by Skip Away, the No. 1 race horse in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLELLAN, THOMAS F.
description: McCLELLAN-Thomas F. On October 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann (nee Moran). Loving father of Thomas, James, Edward and Theresa Johnston. Dear brother of Joseph, Ann and the late Helen Monahan, John and Harry. Proud grandfather of nine grandchildren. Visitng Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Ephrem's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ROBERT KNIGHT
description: HARRIS-Robert Knight. We mourn the passing of our dad and grandfather, Bob Harris, his thoughtfulness, patience, style, dignity and sense of humor will be missed. He has made a lasting impression on all of us and he will be in our hearts forever. Jenny, Kate, Gail Walter and Bette Ann

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Revenues Decline at Some Newspapers
description: Advertising revenue has fallen off sharply at Dow Jones & Company's two major newspapers, The Wall Street Journal and Barron's, a sign of newspapers' vulnerability to industry-by-industry and region-by-region economic storms.

title: Neuwirth Is Cast in a Kander and Ebb Show
description: Bebe Neuwirth, who starred on Broadway for two years as Velma Kelly in ''Chicago,'' the musical by John Kander and Fred Ebb, has been signed to star in the world premiere of their new effort, ''Over and Over.'' In this adaptation of Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''The Skin of Our Teeth,'' Ms. Neuwirth is to play Sabina, the Antrobus family's maid. Performances of the new musical begin on Jan. 6 at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., and will run through Feb. 14.

title: Heartbreak and Wordplay
description: Robbie Fulks has a knack for writing clever country songs: honky-tonkers, ballads and waltzes with the correct balance of heartbreak and wordplay. At Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., on Thursday night, he sang one of his best two-beats, ''You Shouldn't Have,'' about a girl who ''partied all night, picking up everything but the tab.'' Then he exulted: ''All right! Country music!'' and as the crowd applauded, he added, ''I hate it!''

title: Viacom's Weak Link Grows a Bit Stronger; Blockbuster Shows Gains as Parent Proceeds With a Strategy to Shed It
description: After years of trying to turn around the company's Blockbuster video-rental unit, the chairman of Viacom Inc., Sumner M. Redstone, seemed finally to be on the right track. Viacom's shares had been weathering the recent stock market turbulence, largely on word that Blockbuster was bringing customers back into its stores in record numbers.

title: Preseason Ends With Loss to Bruins
description: The Rangers ended their exhibition season last night with a 3-2 loss to the Boston Bruins in Hartford, concluding the preseason with a 4-4-1 record. But the Ranger goal scorers, Esa Tikkanen and Harry York, represented two stories of redemption in training camp.

title: Amnesty Finds 'Widespread Pattern' of U.S. Rights Violations
description: Amnesty International, in its first campaign directed at any Western nation, intends to publish a harsh report on the United States on Tuesday, saying American police forces and criminal and legal systems have ''a persistent and widespread pattern of human rights violations.''

title: Swipes by Candidates Highlight Attorney General Race
description: Dennis C. Vacco, New York's Attorney General, did not have a primary challenge to worry about this year. Neither has he had to fret about money -- his campaign war chest is bulging. And he has picked up good publicity lately on issues like cracking down on unscrupulous health insurers and arresting child pornographers.

title: The Certainty of Reform
description: In the final days of a dismal session, Trent Lott appears to have buried the best chance in years to clean up the nation's corrupt election fund-raising system. The Senate majority leader's last pirouette of hypocrisy included his recent description of President Clinton as ''fund-raiser in chief'' for the Democrats, offered even as Mr. Lott was raising bundles of money for Republicans and serving as executioner in chief for the McCain-Feingold campaign reform bill. But the cause of restoring integrity to the American election process is not dead permanently. With majorities in both the Senate and the House favoring change, it can only gain momentum next year.

title: Serb Pullback May Forestall NATO Attack
description: Under NATO threat to end his punishing offensive against ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has ordered most units of his army back to their barracks and may well avoid an attack by the alliance, military observers and diplomats say.

title: Compressed Data; Archives Wins a Reprieve In Storing Electronic Records
description: As technology marches forward, so do the paper handlers in the nation's capital.

title: The Islanders Are Back, But Many Fans Are Not
description: One week after they were ordered back into Nassau Coliseum by a judge, the Islanders played there for the first time since last season.

title: OBITUARY : Russell Smith, 71, Composer Of Opera and Symphonies
description: Russell Smith, 71, an American composer whose music won a wide audience in Europe, died Sept. 25 in Munich of cancer.

title: Milutinovic Is Asked To Remain as Coach
description: After meeting for more than three hours with Bora Milutinovic yesterday, Charlie Stillitano, the vice president and general manager of the MetroStars, said he was optimistic that Milutinovic would agree to a two-year contract to remain as coach.

title: Sounds of Comfort for the Collegiate Set
description: Elliott Smith has been performing for the last few years alone with his acoustic guitar, singing in a quiet, wispy voice. But he is no folk singer; he is, instead, a pop craftsman who rethinks structure with every song. Now he has hooked up with a band, Quasi, who played its own set and backed him up at Tramps on Saturday night. (Quasi's guitarist and keyboardist, Sam Coomes, used to be with Mr. Smith in Heatmiser, their late-1980's band in Portland, Ore.) The merger pushes Mr. Smith's songs toward their true roots, even as it trades away some subtlety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, GRACE S.
description: MILLS-Grace S. Wife of Ralph J. Mills of Baton Rouge, LA and formerly of Chappaqua, NY, passed away on September 29. She leaves a daughter, Amy Levert of Baton Rouge, a son, Philip Rodger of Charlotte, NC, a step-daughter, Leslie Ann Santos of Randolph, NJ, and four grandchildren. A memorial service for family and friends will be held 1:00 Saturday, October 10th in the Chapel at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Humane Society of Broward County, FL. or The Salvation Army.

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?; Third-World Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAB, ELEONORA
description: SCHWAB-Eleonora. The Jewish Survivors of Latvia mourn the loss of Eleonora Schwab, loving wife of our Vice President, Professor George Schwab, and loving mother of Clarence, Claude and Solon. Steven Springfield, President

title: First of Many Casts in Met's 'Tosca'
description: The 13-year-old, sumptuously extravagant Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera is hugely popular with audiences. So the company, naturally, keeps bringing it back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANKO, MELANIE
description: MANKO-Melanie. Loving mother to Harry and Phyllis. Beloved grandmother of Elizabeth, Clifford and Patricia. Great grandmother to Katharine, and Margaret and Melanie. Services private.

title: Media Talk; WWUS in Key West Is a Voice in the Storm
description: The voice that haunts Bill Becker is a woman's, filled with fear, who dialed in the dark Sept. 25 as Hurricane Georges reached its 100 m.p.h. peak over the Florida Keys. She was huddled in a closet, her house shaking, a phone in one ear and a portable radio tuned to WWUS-FM, said Mr. Becker, news director of the station.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WESTERMAN, NELLIE
description: WESTERMAN-Nellie, October 5. With all our love, Barney and Jackie

title: Whitman Proposes $5.3 Billion To Build or Refurbish Schools
description: In what could result in the largest building program in New Jersey's history, the Whitman administration is proposing to spend $5.3 billion to build or repair hundreds of schools in New Jersey over the next 10 years.

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?; Misplaced Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Are Arrested In Village Protest
description: Thirteen people were arrested, including 11 on disorderly conduct charges, during a protest in Greenwich Village yesterday of the policies of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the police said.

title: Control of Domain Names Draws Alternative Proposal
description: The Clinton Administration this week enters the final phase of what has been a highly contentious effort by the Government to hand administration of the Internet over to an international nonprofit corporation.

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?; Western Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: In Balkans, Time to Intervene?; Appeasment's History
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Pay Reassuring Visit To an Upbeat Strawberry
description: David Cone carried a Yankee cap with him to Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday for Darryl Strawberry, a cap with Strawberry's No. 39 embroidered on it. Cone knew that Strawberry had seen the caps on television, but he wanted to give him one remind his teammate just how much he meant to the Yankees.

title: Media Talk; California Law Will Allow Celebrities to Sue Paparazzi
description: Granting the wishes of an industry that at once promotes and protects its famed charges, Gov. Pete Wilson of California signed lesiglation last week intended to allow celebrities to sue paparazzi for invasion of privacy.

title: Schumer vs. D'Amato: Not So Opposite
description: Anyone following the United States Senate race in New York this year could be forgiven for concluding that this is one of the epic ideological battles of the 1990's: the right-wing extremist, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, versus the ultraliberal Brooklyn Congressman, Charles E. Schumer.

title: Barber Still In a Big Rut
description: Tiki Barber, the Giants' starting running back for the first four weeks of the season, had a dreadful game yesterday, with two carries that netted minus-2 yards. He had 3 receptions for 10 yards.

title: A Financial Limbo
description: A measure that supporters say would modernize the nation's financial system and make it more globally competitive is stuck in Congress, caught in the crosscurrents of several political fights, including the D'Amato-Schumer Senate race.

title: For Once, the Frustration Is Marino's
description: In the closing minutes today, as the Jets were running the clock down to almost nothing and putting the game out of reach, Dan Marino stood near midfield, away from his Miami Dolphins teammates, one foot on the field. He was anxiously waiting for another chance that never came.

title: Pope Asks World Effort for Balkan Victims
description: At a seaside Mass here, Pope John Paul II called for reconciliation throughout the former Yugoslavia and urged the world to do more for the victims of the Balkan war that ended not long ago in Croatia and that has most recently raged in Kosovo.

title: Meeting the Threshold?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Swiss Telephone Company Prices Its Initial Offering

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the high number of hardware failures among new computers misattributed a statement that recommended that people consider buying iMacs. The person who said ''It's a good solution for a lot of people, especially novices,'' was Mike Elgan, editor of Windows magazine, not Larry Sennett, a spokesman for Hewlett-Packard.

title: Disappearing Rubles, Omnipresent Rust Belt
description: Yevgeny Primakov, Russia's new Prime Minister, would seem to have little choice but to pony up back wages owed to millions of Russian workers, some of whom haven't been paid in more than two years. But Mr. Primakov's solution -- printing a mass of new rubles -- has an air of unreality about it.

title: Polio's Sentence of Death or Disability
description: For a while in the 1940's, movie fans could count not only on a double feature, a newsreel and a cartoon at their local movie house, but also on a plea from a star for a contribution to fight polio. The clink of coins in cans was the music for what must be the most successful publicity campaign in a worthy cause ever to capture America.

title: A Changed World for the I.M.F.
description: The world has changed greatly in the past year, since the last annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund. Then, although policy makers were slow to realize it, the world was seeing the first clear problems caused by excessive investments in emerging markets. Now the investment world has turned on its head. Banks and investors that once acted as if there were no risks see nothing but risks. An international credit crunch, in which many will not be able to borrow, is looming.

title: Daring Lincoln To Spin In His Grave
description: Art and entertainment can satirize any forbidden subject if the treatment is witty and thoughtful enough; that's what satire is. But let's not confuse ''The Secret Diary of Desmond Pfeiffer'' with art, entertainment or satire. This is a jaw-droppingly witless series about an aristocratic black Englishman who flees from his gambling debts and finds work at the White House as Abe Lincoln's butler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, LOUIS
description: FINKELSTEIN-Louis, 82, on Saturday, October 3. Devoted husband for 55 years of Lillian (Reiser). Cherished father and father-in-law of Miriam and Ira Strassberg, and Ira and Madelyn Finkelstein. Adored grandfather of Gordon, Sarah and Rachel. Services at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, Tuesday, October 6, at 12 noon.

title: Prospectus; Small technology-based companies constantly face the problem of getting big customers to pay their bills on time.
description: WHEN Jeff Stewart started Square Earth, a New York City-based company developing World Wide Web applications for Fortune 500 companies, he knew that managing cash flow would be almost as important as getting business. As a former consultant with Ernst & Young's financial services division, he knew both how large companies operated and that collections, and thus cash flow, would be a problem.

title: Chat Room Opens Door To Torture And Pursuit
description: There are just two good lines in the film ''Dee Snider's Strangeland.'' One is when Robert Englund, best known as Freddy Krueger, appears in a crowd of reporters and protesters outside a supposedly rehabilitated mass murderer's house and mutters, ''Somebody's got to take that boy out.'' The other is the mass murderer's own comment after having been hanged (well, nearly) by a lynch mob: ''What a rush!'' They don't sound like much, but the delivery and the context help.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 24 about a bond hearing for a Texan who was a close aide to the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden misstated the year in which another man, El Sayyid A. Nosair, was convicted on Federal charges. The convictions, for murder in aid of racketeering and for seditious conspiracy, both occurred in 1995, not 1995 and 1996.

title: Private Conduct Is Linked to Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUARTE, E. THOMAS
description: HUARTE-E. Thomas. Died on Friday, October 2, 1998, at the age of 69. Beloved husband of more than 46 years to Janet (nee Dehmer). Loving father of Susan Casbar, Barbara Huarte, Lori Boudreau, Richard Huarte and the late Gigi Rudella. Loving grandfather of D.J., Laura, Julian, Christopher and Elisabeth. Reposing Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Andreson Ave., Cliffside Park, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 AM, at Our Lady of Libera Church. Interment Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Montclair, NJ.

title: S.E.C. Guidelines to Yield Data on Year 2000 Risks
description: As awareness of the Year 2000 problem has spread, a wide gulf has opened between computer consultants, who say many companies are dangerously vulnerable, and Wall Street analysts, most of whom have been telling investors there is little to worry about.

title: Tales of Sex On the Brain, All Over London
description: ''The obsession that taunts us all, Sex.'' So speaks the doomed, noble Phedre of her illicit, ruinous passion for her stepson in the stark new West End production of Racine's tragedy, which -- Oops. Scratch that. That's not Phedre talking. That's a headline that appeared in a tabloid here the day after the videotapes of President Clinton's testimony about his illicit, ruinous passion for a White House intern were made public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE L.
description: McCABE-Eugene L. The Board of Managers and staff of State Communities Aid Association (SCAA) join with others in offering a final tribute to our board member and friend, Gene McCabe. Gene brought to all of his efforts, a passion and concern for the poor, a wealth of knowledge and a vision for helping people. All of our deliberations about improving health and human services for New Yorkers were enhanced as a result. We will miss him greatly and extend our thoughts and prayers to his family. Anne Mead, President SCAA's Board of Managers Karen Schimke, Exec. Director

title: Interpublic Agencies Reorganize Top Staff
description: Changes in top executives are being made at three agencies owned by Interpublic Group.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Buccaneers' Defense Makes the Difference
description: When Warren Sapp watched a teammate return a Giants pass for an early Tampa Bay touchdown today, the defensive tackle started yelling.

title: Read Your Own Chart
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Giants' Dismal Day: Nothing Works
description: It was in the second quarter today, when 15 Giants plays netted 1 yard, that the suspicion grew on the Giants' bench that something drastic would have to be done to try to resurrect the team's offense.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: It's October, So Expect The Second-Guessers
description: The Yankees were only four outs from advancing to the American League Championship Series for the second straight season last year when Sandy Alomar Jr. swatted a stunning, game-tying home run off Mariano Rivera. The Cleveland Indians scored the winning run the next inning, won the next day as well and went on to win the American League pennant.

title: How to Make the Financial Giants Behave
description: The collapse and rescue of Long-Term Capital Management has raised concerns about secretive, unregulated and enormously leveraged pools of hot money that threaten the world financial order.

title: Bombay Journal; 50 Years Later, Gandhi's Killer Is Gagged in India
description: The melodrama was irresistible to the playwright Pradeep Dalvi: an eloquent, idealistic thinker who had studied the teachings of history fires three bullets into the bony chest of this century's greatest apostle of nonviolence, Mohandas K. Gandhi, then puts down his gun and shouts for the police to arrest him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMERT, WILLIAM A.
description: BAUMERT-William A. Age 75, of Spring Lake, formerly of Pelham Manor, NY. Husband of Marjorie (Kelleher) Baumert. Funeral services Monday, 10:15 AM, from O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy. 35, Wall, NJ, followed by an 11:15 AM Mass of Christian Burial in St. Elizabeths R.C. Church, Avon, NJ. Interment private. Contributions in his memory can be made to the VNA of Manasquan, NJ, or Garden State Hospice. No prior visitation.

title: Ethics of AIDS Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Switzerland's Phone Giant Sets Offering
description: Swisscom A.G., Switzerland's state-owned, dominant telephone company, set the price today for shares that will begin trading on Monday in the eighth-largest initial stock offering of all time and the biggest in Europe this year. Swisscom hopes to raise $5.5 billion

title: When the Astrology Zone Aligns With the Internet
description: Cynics will wonder why, if Susan Miller can really peek into the future, she did not predict years ago that something called the Internet would make her fortunes rise as an astrologer. But then, Ms. Miller -- whose Astrology Zone is one of the most popular of its kind on the Web, spawning a number of media spinoffs -- is accustomed to wisecracks from those who doubt that the stars and planets guide personal fates.

title: Uphill Racers of New York City Politics; For a Variety of Reasons, Underdogs Persevere in the Face of Almost Sure Defeat
description: With the smell of simmering collard greens in the air, Thomas W. Bayley Jr. sat at the counter of a soul food diner in the South Bronx on a recent morning and launched into a nonstop recitation of the history of black candidates in the Republican Party.

title: Philip Grushkin, 77; Designed Fine Books for More Than 5 Decades
description: Philip Grushkin, a book designer whose work made him the standard-bearer throughout the publishing industry, died on Sept. 25 at Hackensack University Medical Center in Hackensack, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: Mubarak Visits Syria in Effort To Defuse Crisis With Turkey
description: In a sign of Arab concern over growing tensions between Turkey and Syria, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt flew on short notice to Syria today in an effort to defuse what is being portrayed in the Middle East as an unsettling crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, JOHN N.
description: BROOKS-John N., The Right Reverend Monsignor. 77, a retired Roman Catholic priest of the Archdiocese of New York, died October 1, 1998. Reposing at Simpson-Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston (914331-0631) on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Kingston, on Wednesday at 11 AM. Burial in St. Mary's Cemetery, Kingston. Memorial contributions may be made to Catholic Youth Organization, 1011 1st Ave., New York, NY 10022.

title: Boycott Confuses Elections in Mexican State
description: Local elections that the Government was counting on to bring stability to the turbulent state of Chiapas were thrown into unexpected turmoil today when some of the Government's staunchest supporters boycotted the balloting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINDER, ROSE DIVAK
description: BINDER-Rose Divak. On September 30, 1998, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Binder. Devoted mother of Janet and Irwin Robinson, and Dr. Henry and Joan Binder. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth and Steven Schubiner, Jonathan and Heidi Robinson, Eve and Joshua Wiener, Stephen and Kris Binder, Sarah Binder and Forest Maltzman. Great-grandmother of Andrea, Julie, Jasmine, Maia, Nathaniel and Noa. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Sarah Neuman Nursing Home, 845 Palmer Ave., Mamaroneck, NY 10548.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, NANCY HILL
description: WARNER-Nancy Hill, 84. On September 30 in New York after a brief illness. Daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Miner C. Hill of New York and Oyster Bay. Wife of the late Bradford A. Warner. She is survived by her sons, Bradford A. Warner Jr. of London, Miner H. Warner of New York, five grandchildren, and her sister, Barbara H. Cano, of Mexico City. Memorial service to be held Friday, October 9 at 11 A.M., at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East 92 Street, N.Y., NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBY, DR. ARTHUR
description: RUBY-Dr. Arthur. Dr. Ruby honored the Brooklyn Center for Famliies in Crisis by serving as our President from our inception in 1983. A pediatrician with a true understanding of the importance of mental health's place in a child's well being, he will be greatly missed by us all. Our deepest sympathy to Eleanor, Eric and Kenneth. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Brooklyn Center for Families in Crisis

title: An All-World Runner, When Not Recovering
description: That smile on Robert Smith's face? It's a grin of peace. Not contentment, but happiness knowing that maybe -- just maybe -- the most explosive running back you've hardly heard of has put his injury-riddled past behind him.

title: Tilmans Ecosystem Survival Kit
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOMQUIST, ARNOLD R.
description: BLOMQUIST-Arnold R. January 3, 1930-September 25, 1998. Of New York City. Survived by stepdaughter Karin Naess of Norway, two grandchildren, sisters Alice Blomquist and Margaret Christiansen of FL. He was pre-deceased by his wife Judith & two brothers, William and Alfred. Cremation was private. Memorial service Tuesday, October 13, Norwegian Seaman's Church, 317 E. 52 St, NY.

title: Devils Trim Roster To 32 Players
description: The Devils did not lose anyone or claim anyone in yesterday's waiver draft, but they made four other moves that reduced their roster to 32 players in camp. They assigned defensemen Vlastimil Kroupa, Colin White and Sergei Vyshedkevich to Albany, and returned goaltender Jean-Francois Damphousse to his junior team, the Moncton Wildcats.

title: Sports of The Times; Life's Twists And Turns For 2 Athletes
description: THEIR seasons turn. Their teams change. Their roles reverse. But in the middle of another New York October baseball parable, two inescapable names, Doc and Darryl, continue to run deep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, MOLLIE G.
description: POLLACK-Mollie G., Z''L, 83, of Tamarac, FL, died in Hartford on October 3, 1998, the 14th day of Tishrei, 5759, in the middle of the high holiday season. Beloved wife, for 44 years, of the late Samuel B. Pollack who predeceased her in 1983. Survived by Ann and Edward Meyer of New York and Elliott and Eileen Pollack of Hartford and grandchildren Jill Pollack and Jessica and Mark Mindich, all of New York. She also leaves a sister Selma Katz of Delray, Florida, and brother Jack C. Groter of Boca Raton, FL. Graveside services will be at New Montefiore Cemetery on Wellwood Ave., Farmingdale, New York on Tuesday, October 6, 1998 at 2 P.M. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Moscow Journal; Ruble Is on 'Tilt,' but Russians Keep Their Balance
description: It's drive time, and Muscovites are heading home after another day of crisis. After the news, all of it bad, an ad comes on the radio.

title: Making Intelligent Use of Scouts
description: Each Yankee position player arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday to find a sheet of paper dropped in his locker -- a scouting report on Jaret Wright, Cleveland's starting pitcher in the first game of the American League Championship Series tonight at the Stadium.

title: Playing for the World Series, and for History
description: The Yankees worked out in near silence last Thursday after learning that Darryl Strawberry had been found to have colon cancer. But their mood had changed dramatically yesterday as they prepared for the start of the American League Championship Series.

title: It Was All Too Familiar, Like a 'Nightline' Rerun
description: Who needs Congress when there's ''Crossfire''? During the House Judiciary Committee's televised debate about an impeachment inquiry yesterday, Representative Robert Wexler of Florida, a vehement opponent of impeaching the President, said he was scheduled to appear on ''Crossfire'' later that night with Representative Bob Barr of Georgia, one of the President's fiercest critics.

title: Most Valuable Injury
description: Scott Seabol is an 88th-round draft pick who played in Class A this year and probably will never make it into pinstripes at Yankee Stadium. But he is doing his part to help the Yankees in the playoffs. Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, used Seabol to create a loophole and give the team maximum roster flexibility in the post-season.

title: The Light Fantastic
description: About 10 P.M. my fishing companions and I were roused by a slapping on tent canvas and a rush of English from our French-Canadian guide: ''Quickly! Come, it's starting.'' Nobody around our campfire, nor the rest of the world for that matter, knew what was about to appear in the night sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEDULD, SYLVIA
description: GEDULD-Sylvia. A woman of charm, dignity and love of family and friends. We were blessed to have her in our extended family. Our hearts go out to Victoria, Buzzy, Amanda, Nancy and Bram, who were lucky to have her in their immediate family. We'll all miss her. With Love, Gloria and Paul Asnes

title: Driverless Trains Have Paris Debut
description: In a subway tunnel far below the Place de la Madeleine on the Right Bank, an empty automated ghost train glides up to the platform. No driver is at the controls, and no conductor at the doors, which slide open as a recorded human voice announces ''Madeleine.'' They close again, and the train whooshes off toward the next stop in the five-mile-long tunnel.

title: INSIDE
description: Portrait of Terror Suspect

title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Who Transplanted Hand Ponder Their Surprising Patient
description: THE hand and forearm transplant performed on an Australian man in France nearly two weeks ago ranks among the most extraordinary cases in the annals of surgery, one full of sudden plot twists, colorful characters and international controversy.

title: To Computer Novices, the Advice Is Constant: Learn the Language and Buy Enough Memory
description: IN June 1982, the I.B.M. personal computer, only a few months on the market, offered a maximum of 256 kilobytes of memory, a choice of one or two floppy disk drives and an optional color monitor. Fully configured, it cost close to $7,000.

title: Settlement Said to Be Near in Suit Against Child Welfare Agency
description: Advocates for foster children said yesterday that they were ''very close'' to a settlement agreement that would resolve the class-action lawsuit they filed in an effort to replace the leadership of New York City's troubled child welfare agency.

title: Serbs Continue Kosovo Terror, Annan Asserts
description: In a tough report that was welcomed by the United States, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that Serbian security forces were continuing to carry out punitive operations against ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo as part of a campaign of ''terror and violence.''

title: As Stocks Drop, Bond Prices Leap
description: Fears of further losses gripped financial markets around the world yesterday, driving down stock prices and driving many investors into the relative safety of United States Treasury securities, which surged for the biggest one-day gain in more than a year. An extended rally in bonds has pushed yields down to 31-year lows.

title: Save Whales or Culture?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are not here to pass judgment on anyone. We are here to ask and answer this one single question: based on what we now know, do we have a duty to look further, or to look away?''

title: A new eye-catching ad for Absolut vodka involves a lot of window dressing.
description: WILL an unusual ad for Absolut vodka carry the headline ''How much is that bottle in the window?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, JOSEPH
description: BAUM-Joseph. On October 5 at age 78. Beloved husband of Ruth and father of Hilary, Charles and Edward. Grandfather of Anna, Alexander, Alexandra, Trevor, Graham and Kiva. Great grandfather of Anaia. Funeral services will be private. A memorial celebration will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to CityMeals-on-Wheels. Smile, Joe. The Baum Family

title: Schumer Says Clinton's Acts Were Wrong but Not Impeachable
description: In his first detailed remarks on the Lewinsky matter, Representative Charles E. Schumer said today that President Clinton's lies about his extramarital affair were wrong and possibly illegal but did not warrant impeachment. He called instead for some lesser form of punishment, perhaps censure or a rebuke.

title: Big Plays, Big Victory For Vikings
description: It is time to start talking about how the offense of the Minnesota Vikings may be one of the best of all time.

title: Starr Accused Of Misleading Appeals Court
description: Opening two new legal fronts, President Clinton's lawyers accused the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, today of misleading a Federal appeals panel in a battle over lawyer-client privilege and asked the Justice Department to release the information he had provided for approval to begin the Lewinsky investigation.

title: Carlson and Thomas Cook to Merge Leisure Travel in Britain
description: The Carlson Companies, the Minneapolis-based owner and franchiser of a worldwide network of hotels, restaurants and cruise ships, plans to merge its leisure travel business in Britain with the worldwide travel operations of Thomas Cook, one of the oldest and best known names in travel. The intended transaction, to be formally announced today, is valued at more than $1 billion.

title: Cable News Covers Complete Hearings
description: The impeachment debate in the House Judiciary Committee received gavel to gavel coverage on cable news channels yesterday, and a few minutes of live coverage on the ABC network. Neither NBC nor CBS had any live coverage of the debate, though the two networks did provide a form of live coverage last night for the vote by the committee.

title: Bell Atlantic Sets Fast Web Access
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it had begun offering high-speed Internet access in Washington and Pittsburgh, supported by marketing alliances with computer companies, to meet the demand for faster connections to computer networks.

title: 2 Sides Fight Over a Budget, Leaving Some In the Middle
description: The amount of money represents less than one-half of 1 percent of the $34 billion city budget, yet it continues to provoke a dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council over who holds claim to the title of Most Fiscally Responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, LON
description: CLARK-Lon. We mourn the loss of our dear and highly respected member. A Player since 1945, Lon was a true man of the theatre as well as radio. His feistiness and tenacity for what he thought right will be remembered by generations of our members. His contributions to his beloved profession will be appreciated by generations of actors. Our deepest sympathies to Michele and his family. The Players

title: Joseph Baum, American Dining's High Stylist, Dies at 78
description: Joseph H. Baum, the tirelessly innovative restaurateur who created a new American style in dining with theme restaurants like the Four Seasons, the Forum of the Twelve Caesars and La Fonda del Sol, and who gave new meaning to high style in skyscraper restaurants like Windows on the World and the renovated Rainbow Room, died yesterday at his home. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan and North Salem, N.Y.

title: Bill Would Require Notification of AIDS
description: A bill approved yesterday by the Assembly Health Committee would require the state to try to notify people who have had sex or shared needles with people infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Strawberry in a Joking Mood
description: Darryl Strawberry, who had surgery for colon cancer last Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, complained good-naturedly yesterday that he was overcome with hunger.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAPITAL SENIOR LIVING CORP., Dallas, an operator of senior living communities, said it would buy four communities from NHP Retirement Housing Partners I Ltd. for $40.6 million in cash.

title: In Wright, Yankees See Wolf in Sheep's Clothing
description: The boyish Jaret Wright digs surfing and hip sideburns and stands before you with the kind of pudgy cheeks that grandmothers would take a number to pinch. This is where the innocence ends.

title: As Spending Bills Lag, Democrats Attack
description: With just five days until money for Federal operations runs out, President Clinton and Congressional Democrats escalated their criticism of Republican leaders today for not moving faster on the 13 spending bills needed to keep the Government running.

title: Veritas Software to Acquire Seagate Unit in Stock Swap
description: The Veritas Software Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire a unit of Seagate Software Inc., a majority-owned subsidiary of Seagate Technology Inc., in a stock swap valued at $1.6 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENTHAL, MARI
description: FREUDENTHAL-Mari, 95. Beloved wife of the late Josef. Loving mother of the late Jonathan and survived by loving nieces and nephews died Oct. 4 in Cincinnati, OH. Mari and Josef founded Transcontinental Music,Publishers of Hebrew Liturgical Music. Funeral service Thurs., October 8, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial, 5044 Broadway, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERG, BEATRICE
description: KLEINBERG-Beatrice. Age 84. Of Stony Brook, New York. Wife of the late Max. Survived by her loving family, Lenore, Ira, Amy, Amanda Cernitz, son Paul, sister Edith Lieberman. Graveside service 1 PM, Tuesday, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Ellis Island Official Says No to Development
description: The newly appointed chairman of a panel that will recommend uses for Ellis Island yesterday ruled out a theme park or any other commercial ventures for New Jersey's newest territory.

title: Latin Americans Say Russian Bailout Leaves Too Little for Them
description: Increasingly angry at what they consider the lenient treatment that Russia received in its $4.5 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund, Latin American officials and economists warned today that the programs being offered to protect their own countries were too paltry.

title: Holbrooke Meets Milosevic on Pullback
description: An American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, met President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia tonight, and American diplomats said Mr. Holbrooke had told Mr. Milosevec that he had to take further steps to pull back his military in Kosovo Province or face a NATO attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIVILINO, JOSEPH PAUL
description: TRIVILINO-Joseph Paul ''Jo Jo'' on October 4, 1998. Beloved son of Anna and Alfred B. Brother to Alfred C., Dessy, Rosanna, Cristina and Loretta. Brother-in-law to Robert, Jennifer, Mark and Jeff. Uncle to Caraline, Victoria, Emma and Jake. Buddy to Bert, Gus and Greta. Friend to all who knew and loved him! Reposing at Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard, corner of 193 Street. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30 AM, Immaculate Conception R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donation to Ronald McDonald House of Long Island.

title: New Light On Nureyev's Grand Leap To the West
description: When Rudolf Nureyev defected to the West on June 16, 1961, at the height of the cold war, the event was seen as a leap to freedom, a triumph for democracy. Nureyev was a transformative figure, the greatest male ballet dancer of his time. He was sinuous, hollow-cheeked, with Tartar eyes and a Dionysian sexual presence. He was one of the first major cultural figures to defect from the Soviet Union. His singular act of defiance set the stage for the ensuing defections of Natalia Makarova in 1970 and Mikhail Baryshnikov in 1974.

title: Former Prime Minister Sues French Newspaper
description: BRUSSELS  Edith Cresson, a European commissioner and former French prime minister, has sued a French newspaper for libel after it alleged that she was involved in irregularities in the awarding of European Union contracts.

title: Top Teams Continue Strong Play
description: The most effective teams in Major League Soccer's regular season have been true to form in the playoffs. The two-time defending champion, D.C. United, eliminated Miami in two games to reach the Eastern Conference finals, and Los Angeles swept Dallas to reach the Western Conference finals.

title: Intramural Feuding and Shifting May Save Italy's Government
description: Italian politics have long been enlivened by baroque feuds and shifting alliances. And that time-honored tradition may have won the embattled Government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi a momentary reprieve.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about followers of the late Italian priest Padre Pio referred incorrectly to his order, the Capuchins. They are friars, not monks. The article also referred incorrectly to St. Francis of Assisi. He was not a priest.

title: Abroad at Home; The Light and the Dark
description: We have before us today, in dramatic opposition, two views of what it means to be a conservative and a Republican.

title: Lawyers Battle Over Sentence for Convicted Police Officer
description: When Anthony Baez died after a confrontation with the police outside his family home in the Bronx in 1994, the case ignited what has become a continuing debate about police brutality in New York City.

title: Testaverde or Foley? Don't Even Ask Parcells
description: Bill Parcells was sitting in traffic Sunday night after the Jets' game -- an important 20-9 victory over the Dolphins -- and trying to think what his best bet was for getting to the Triborough Bridge.

title: National Healing: Is It Too Soon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Comments by Members of the Judiciary Committee
description: Following are excerpts from comments today by members of the House Judiciary Committee during its consideration of initiating an impeachment inquiry against President Clinton, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, DR. RACHAEL
description: WYMAN-Dr. Rachael. October 3, 1998. Beloved mother of Michael Magdleno and mother-in-law of Bonnie Magdleno. Dear sister of Miriam Weingarten. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 7 at 7 pm. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health, 124 E. 28 St., NY NY 10016.

title: Swisscom Shares Rise In Big Europe Offering
description: Shares in Swisscom A.G., Switzerland's dominant telephone company, rose yesterday on their first trading day after the company sold 22 million shares in an initial public offering.
