Swisscom's shares traded as high as 395 Swiss francs ($293) each after being priced on Sunday at 340. They closed at 376.5 francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINNUCAN, WILLIAM A.H.
description: KINNUCAN-William A.H. On October 4, 1998. Beloved son of Alfred & Mary. Loving brother of Nancy Doty and Jane Page. Dear friend of Trish Moylan Torruella. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 7, 2-5 and 79PM. Memorial mass at Church of Christ The King, Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, N.J. Thursday 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, New York, New York 10013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ROBERT KNIGHT
description: HARRIS-Robert Knight. The Board of Directors and the staff of the National Conference for Community and Justice, Greater N.Y. Region, founded as the National Conference of Christians and Jews join with others in offering a final tribute to our Board Chair and longtime friend. His commitment and passion to the fight against bias, bigotry and racism is much admired. His vision and leadership will long be remembered. Hon. Martin Minkowitz, Chairman of the Board Sheldon Friedberg, Acting Executive Director

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: By Design; For Tote Bags, a Slim Fit
description: To complement this fall's easy, unstructured clothing, tote bags should be sleek and slim. With flat heels all the rage, there is no need to carry extra shoes; there should be room just for papers and reading material -- that's the ideal, anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFFENKRANTZ, RUTH
description: OFFENKRANTZ-Ruth. On October 5, 1998 at Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Beloved wife of the late William Offenkrantz, M.D. Devoted mother of Ronald, Gary (1943-1949) and Jill. Loving grandmother of Paul and Jonathan and great grandmother of Alex, Emily, Eli and Noah. Funeral services Wednesday, October 7th at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City at 1 PM.

title: Los Angeles Honors Legacy of Tom Bradley
description: Vice President Al Gore arrived here today for the funeral of the former five-term Mayor of Los Angeles, Tom Bradley, in a long motorcade, helicopters hovering overhead. Mr. Gore told the mourners that he had come to celebrate the life of a great American, ''in many ways the Jackie Robinson of public service.''

title: Dow Retreats 58 Points and Other Gauges Also Decline
description: Technology shares fell sharply yesterday, leading markets lower as the troubled world economy seemed to undermine investor sentiment.

title: Manly Giant vs. Zealots And Scheming Women
description: I MARRIED A COMMUNIST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, HERMAN
description: SCHNECK-Herman, MD. On Oct. 5 at home. Survived by his loving wife of 55 years Muriel, devoted sister Margaret, brothers Jerome and Stuart, nephews Ronald and Mark Rogart, grand nephew Jason and grand niece Stephanie. Services Wednesday, Oct. 6, at Park West Riverside Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue at 76 Street.

title: A Swedish Dilemma: The Immigrant Ghetto
description: No Bjorns, Alfs or Stefans appear on the Rinkeby community bulletin board. The names instead are Juan Fonseca, Moissis Nikolaidis and Rebwar Hassan.

title: ICN TO ACQUIRE RIGHTS TO 4 HOFFMAN-LAROCHE PRODUCTS
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $179 million in cash and ICN stock to acquire rights worldwide, except in India, to four products of Hoffman-LaRoche Ltd. The products, which have annual sales of $67 million, are Dalmadorm, a sleep-disorder drug; Fluoro-Uracil, an oncology product; Librax, a gastrointestinal treatment, and Mogadon, a sleep-disorder drug used to treat epilepsy. Roche will hold the shares until Dec. 31, 2000, at a 6 percent annual return. If the stock price rises above $31 a share before then, Hoffman-LaRoche, a unit of Roche Holding A.G., which is based in Basel, Switzerland, can sell the stock and share the gain equally with ICN. Shares of ICN, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., closed yesterday at $15.375, down $1.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about Olivier Assayas's ''Late August, Early September,'' part of the New York Film Festival, misidentified a previous film he directed. It was ''Cold Waters''; the director of ''Wild Reeds'' was Andre Techine.

title: How Green Can Germany Get?
description: Imagine it is January 2001, and President-elect Al Gore is about to be sworn in along with his running mate: an antitechnology crusader from Earth First! Such a pairing is roughly analogous to what the next German Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, is expected to make in aligning his Social Democrats with the country's Greens.

title: Poland's Consumer-Credit Industry Grows Quickly
description: Given the mess Communism left in Eastern Europe, Lenin's motto might have been, ''Buy now, pay later.'' Yet consumer credit hardly existed in the old Communist bloc, and so Mariusz Lukasiewicz faced virgin territory when he set out to introduce the idea to post-Communist Poland.

title: In First Debate, Kennelly Faults Rowland on Child Care
description: United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly used the opening debate of the Connecticut gubernatorial race to go after Gov. John G. Rowland with a stick rather than a sword today, setting a dignified tone for the closing month of a campaign in which polls show the Governor holding a huge lead.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Tilting but Standing As a Big Domino Falls; Ex-Communist Poland Holds Up Well Next to Russia's Staggering Economy
description: Scott R. Mackie doesn't envy his old boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBARTH, VICTORIA
description: WEISBARTH-Victoria on October 3rd. Adored wife of the late Morris Weisbarth, and twin sister of the late Lillian Boshnack. Our wholehearted sympathy to her cherished and devoted daughters and sons-in-law, Berissa and Jack Frame, Ellen and Michael Azaria, and her precious grandchildren, John Frame and Mathew Azaria. We could always count on her unflagging loyalty and sunny disposition to brighten our days. Her love lives on. Dorothy Lang, Murray and Adele Kleiman and Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, ROBERT
description: WELLS-Robert. The Board of Directors and members of the National Academy of Popular Music regret the passing of Robert Wells, a recent inductee into the Songwriters' Hall of Fame. His ''Christmas Song'', co-written with Mel Torme, will live in the hearts of music lovers forever. Bobby Weinstein, President

title: Ethnic Assimilation Isn't Europe's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSHNACK, LILLIAN
description: BOSHNACK-Lillian. On September 28th. Devoted wife of Leo and twin sister of the late Victoria Weisbarth. With hearts full of love, we send our deepest condolences to her loving twin sons, Harvey and Arthur, dear and caring daughters-in-law, Suzanne and Arlene, and beloved grandchildren, Joshua, Jeremy, Alissa and Michael. We all will miss her intrepid larger-than-life spirit. Her love lives on. Dorothy Lang, Murray and Adele Kleiman and Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVILLE, SHERIDAN
description: PREVILLE - Sheridan, passed away on October 3, 1998. Survived by children Penny and Jay, Patsy and Hershel, sister Elinore Topping, six adoring grandchildren, and loving companion Emma Mars, and family.

title: A Potpourri From Composers Whose Styles Clash Compatibly
description: David Starobin has expanded the contemporary guitar repertory with the same voraciousness that the Kronos Quartet has brought to the chamber literature, but he started earlier and is less concerned with trendiness and theatricality. Still, his latest recording, ''Newdance'' (on Bridge), is a decidedly Kronosesque project: Mr. Starobin commissioned composers of various nationalities and virtually every stylistic stripe to provide short dance pieces, which he arranged into an extended suite.

title: Bond Prices Surge as Investors Push Yields to 31-Year Low
description: Another big loss in stocks and fears of a further deterioration in nearly all types of financial assets drove investors worldwide into the relative safety of Treasury securities yesterday for the fifth consecutive day. Bond prices surged for the biggest one-day gain in more than a year, pushing yields to another in a series of 31-year lows.

title: New Leader for a New Germany
description: Although only a week has gone by since Germany's voters ended Helmut Kohl's 16-year tenure as Germany's leader, some things are already apparent. The voting reflected Germany's metamorphosis into a more self-confident, tolerant and liberal state. The government of the next Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, will have a new tone, one fitting a country that seems increasingly comfortable with the new political and cultural diversity brought by unification and immigration.

title: Vote on Investigation
description: Following is the 21-to-16 roll-call vote by which the House Judiciary Committee voted today for an open-ended impeachment inquiry of President Clinton. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to proceed with the inquiry. Voting ''yes'' were 21 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 16 Democrats.

title: AT&T Buying Vanguard to Extend Reach
description: Expanding its wireless network in the Northeast from big cities into smaller markets, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc. for about $900 million in stock and cash.

title: A Debate on Allowable Lies
description: The Associated Press summary of the House Judiciary Committee hearing yesterday was admirable for its simple, concentrated statement of Washington's political mood and the constitutional quandary presented by a chief executive who has squandered public respect. ''No one -- no Republican, no Democrat -- defended Clinton's conduct with Ms. Lewinsky or his testimony while under oath,'' The A.P. said. ''The issue was whether the President's behavior constituted events worthy of impeachment.''

title: Let the Process Go Forward
description: The House Judiciary Committee did the right thing yesterday in voting for an investigation of President Clinton that could lead to impeachment hearings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENHEIN, BEVERLY.
description: ROSENHEIN-Beverly. Gone one year; remembered always. Eli

title: Family Seeks Inquiry on Death Of Woman in Police Custody
description: Relatives of a woman who died last Wednesday while in police custody demanded an investigation into her death yesterday, and their lawyers said their own preliminary inquiry suggested she had been beaten by two detectives and a police officer in a Brooklyn station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, SALLY
description: KRIEGER-Sally. Sutton Place Synagogue records with deep sorrow the loss of our longtime member. Our sympathies to her devoted husband, Joseph, adoring children and grandchildren. Memorial Service Wednesday, October 7, 3:00 P.M. Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 Street, NY, NY. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Assets of a Bombing Suspect: Keen Wit, Religious Soul, Angry Temper
description: The man accused of directing the bomb attack on the American Embassy in Kenya came of age in this impoverished Indian Ocean archipelago, a land where gifted teen-agers leave home to enroll in the radical Islamic academies of Libya, Sudan and Pakistan.

title: Ion Propulsion of Science Fiction Comes to Life on New Spacecraft
description: COMBINING technology with fantasy, the United States is about to send an experimental probe into space to test some of the favorite concepts of science fiction. The robot craft not only will be driven by an advanced ion propulsion engine, it will also take care of itself, navigating through space on its own and occasionally calling home to let people on Earth know how it is doing.

title: Goodyear to Shift Unit
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it would transfer its Kelly-Springfield operations from Cumberland, Md., to Goodyear's headquarters in Akron. The tire and rubber-products maker, which employs more than 92,000 workers, said the transfer of Kelly-Springfield's sales, marketing and financial systems operations will be completed by Sept. 30, 1999.

title: U.S. Suit Charges Fraud by 2 Big Hospital Chains
description: The Government announced yesterday that it had sued two of the nation's biggest hospital companies, contending that they had defrauded Federal health programs over more than 14 years through a huge scheme involving bogus expense claims.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARIS, SAMUEL L.
description: PARIS-Samuel L. In everlasting remembrance of a cherished husband, father and poppa. One year and your in our thoughts with every passing day. Shirley and family.

title: 'Over the Hill' 7 Ran Theft Ring For 15 Years Authorities Say
description: The annals of crime in metropolitan New York -- a long registry of mayhem, thievery and skulduggery -- is replete with tales of clever rogues, acts of mindless savagery and other headline-grabbing sensations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDER, IRVING
description: SCHINDER-Irving. Beloved husband of Betty Abramowitz. Loving father of Dr. Harry and Erik Schinder. Beloved brother of Bella Geller and the late Anne Wrubel. Dear friend of Bernard Romano. Services Wednesday, 10AM, Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Bklyn.

title: The Supreme Court's Docket
description: As the nine justices of the Supreme Court prepared to ascend the bench yesterday, protesters outside the building were calling attention to a collective embarrassment. Of the 34 law clerks currently serving the justices, they complained, 22 are white men, 11 are white women and one is a Hispanic woman. There are no blacks among the group. It was a jarring, if fitting, beginning for a new and potentially important Supreme Court term in which issues of race, discrimination and political power will loom large, challenging the conservative-leaning Court to reach for a new level of wisdom and sensitivity.

title: So Nice to See You Again -- Scouting report on the American League Championship series.
description: NEW YORK

title: Singing About an America That Existed Only in Song
description: Jay Farrar of Son Volt, who performed on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom, helped shape a moody version of country rock that defined a thriving subculture. Called No Depression, after his former band, Uncle Tupelo's first album (itself named after a song by the Carter Family), the movement sought points of origin like Appalachian mountain music and honky-tonk. Its young acolytes, purists and modernizers alike, salvaged a bohemian dream of America from twice-told tales of dirt-stained workers, shady bootleggers and truck-driving highwaymen. Their music mustered a sense of traditionalism while avoiding the family values of contemporary Middle America.

title: Unit of Burnham Acquires 5 Malls
description: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. said today that its affiliate BPP Retail L.L.C. had acquired five retail properties for $80.1 million in the first transaction in a joint venture with the California Public Employees' Retirement System.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night misstated the nationality of the soprano Karita Mattila, who sang Elsa. She is Finnish, not Swedish.

title: As Incumbents, Republicans Hold Advantage in 18 Races for Governor
description: With elections next month in 36 states, including the 8 most populous, this year's campaigns for governor will determine whether the Republicans maintain their remarkable hegemony in the nation's statehouses or the Democrats rebound from their catastrophic losses of the last four years.

title: Using Biting Humor to Attack Pataki's Record on State Finances
description: Here are two 30-second advertisements for B. Thomas Golisano that went on the air on Monday.

title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: ROUNDUP
description: COLORADO

title: From Beach to Bullpen Leader
description: Trevor Hoffman wanted to be a surfer when he was growing up in southern California, but he could not find a regular ride to the beach, so he concentrated on baseball.

title: Holding AIDS at Bay, Only to Face 'Lazarus Syndrome'
description: JOHN LESNICK spent much of the time from Thanksgiving 1995 to Valentine's Day 1996 lying flat on his bony back at Roosevelt Hospital in New York, confronting a royal flush of AIDS ailments -- lymphoma, mycobacterium avium complex, microsporidiosis and esophageal thrush. He had few visitors, his closest friends were already gone, and zero T-cells.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Two Opinions On a Street Name

title: ALZA PLANS TO ACQUIRE SEQUUS PHARMACEUTICALS
description: The Alza Corporation, making a move to strengthen its portfolio of commercial products, agreed yesterday to acquire Sequus Pharmaceuticals Inc. in a stock swap valued about $580 million. Alza's chairman and chief executive, Dr. Ernest Mario, said his company's strategy was to grow into a business with products focused on oncology and urology. The merger will also enhance Alza's research and development capability; the company will continue the clinical development programs that Sequus currently has in place, Dr. Mario said. Alza, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., is offering four-tenths of a share for each share of Sequus, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif. Sequus's stock jumped 29 percent yesterday, gaining $3.1875 a share, to $14.0625. Alza fell $2.50 a share, to $39.9375.

title: Accounts
description: * Versaware Technologies, New York and Los Altos, Calif., to Katsin/ Loeb Advertising, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: More Fallout From Long-Term Capital's Crash
description: The near-collapse of the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management L.P. continued to reverberate yesterday as Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. disclosed its exposure to hedge funds and emerging markets and Moody's Investors Service downgraded the rating outlooks of five of Europe's largest banks.

title: Q&A / Pamela Gordon, Prime Minister of Bermuda : 'Citizens of Nowhere,' Bermudans Resist Britain's Limits
description: Pamela Gordon is prime minister of Bermuda and a member of the United Bermuda Party, which has held power since 1968. As Britain prepares a white paper on relations, she faces elections in the next few months amid suggestions that Bermuda will hold another referendum over independence; the last, in 1995, saw 75 percent of the voters support ties with Britain even though its 1981 citizenship law stripped citizens of dependent territories of the right of abode in Britain. She talked with Justin Keay for the International Herald Tribune.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Dinosaurs: No Butting

title: Nuttiness Turns Up, And So Does Quietude
description: The dances at either end of a wide spectrum stood out in the program presented by the dance department of the New York University School of Education on Friday night at the Loewe Theater. Sheer nuttiness was well represented in this evening of faculty choreography, beginning with the program's opening number, Renata Celichowska's ''Bones Part III: Professor Zsa Zsa and Her Greatest Expedition.''

title: CLINTON APPEALS FOR JOINT ATTACK IN ECONOMIC CRISIS
description: President Clinton today urged a select group of the world's top financial officials to develop a unified attack on the global economic crisis, after nearly three days of debate here have produced a near stalemate over immediate cures.

title: Excerpts From Minority Counsel Presentation to House Judiciary Committee
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation given today to the House Judiciary Committee by the minority counsel, Abbe D. Lowell, outlining the matters that could be grounds for impeachment of President Clinton, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Ethnic Assimilation Isn't Europe's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Sends In the Foreign Police in Bosnia
description: When an angry crowd of Bosnian Croats put up a roadblock on the main road south of Mostar the other day, commanders of NATO's peacekeeping force here refrained from flooding the area with their troops, as they might have not long ago.

title: Earnings Verdict Is Upheld
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday upheld a $67 million verdict against the National Collegiate Athletic Association for restricting the earnings of some assistant coaches.

title: A Prize-Winning Violinist In a Crazy-Quilt Program
description: Hardly had the International Violin Competition of Indianapolis announced its 1998 winner, Judith Ingolfsson of Iceland, a week or so ago, than the Queen Elisabeth International Music Competition of Belgium, also one of the world's most distinguished, presented another young Scandinavian violinist on Friday evening. Nikolaj Znaider, a 23-year-old from Denmark who won the 1997 contest in Brussels, played a crazy-quilt program with Sophie Rachlin, a Lithuanian pianist, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Motorola Says Its Earnings Beat Forecasts
description: Motorola Inc., the wireless communications and semiconductor company that has been stumbling for about two years, said late today that its third-quarter earnings were better than expected, largely because of an aggressive restructuring and cost-cutting effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBEL, FRED
description: GRUBEL-Fred, 90. On October 4. Beloved husband for 63 years of Lisa, devoted father of Henry, Eva and Lucille, father-in-law of Robert & Dick, loving grandfather of Roslyn, Audrey and Joe, David and Amy, Eliane and Carl, Howie and Rachel, and great-grandfather of Jaclyn, Jonathan, Eric, Samuel and Jeremy. His intellect, dignity and sense of humor have made a lasting impression on all of us and he will be in our hearts forever. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, October 6, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE JUMPS 4.6 PERCENT. Prices rose on expectations of a smaller crop from Florida because of extreme cold in the top orange-growing state. The November contract rose 4.45 cents, to $1.019 a pound.

title: ARTS ABROAD; As Latin American Art Prices Rise, So Do Forgeries
description: Ramon Cernuda, a Miami-based publisher and passionate collector of modern Cuban painting, recalls his first encounter with the shadowy world of art forgery. But there was nothing murky about the setting: it was the mid-80's, in an elegant Miami home whose owner was a private dealer from one of Cuba's most patrician expatriate families. Therefore, he had no reason to doubt that the painting by Wilfredo Lam (1902-82) being offered to him for $200,000 was anything but an original by the acclaimed Cuban artist.

title: 3d-Party Candidate Mocks Pataki's Record in TV Ads
description: With a humorous bite that had been absent from the gubernatorial campaign, a flurry of advertisements attacking Gov. George E. Pataki went on the air yesterday, courtesy of B. Thomas Golisano, the wealthy third-party candidate who is trying to shake up a contest that is shaping up as an easy stroll to re-election for the Governor.

title: Parcells Lifts the Bar As Defense Does Job
description: You, too? Were you thinking that Bill Parcells took two years away from football after winning Super Bowl XXV with the Giants in 1991 with grit and defense and a running game and then watched too much television? Heck, he was on TV. As a football analyst. Watching the 49ers and the Bills and the West Coast offense and the no-huddle offense. It was as if the guy discovered something in football during that two-year television stint -- the passing game and lots of points -- and decided, hey, I'm going to try that stuff.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Josephthal of 'Malicious' Harassment
description: Steve Williams, a former broker at Josephthal & Company's Washington office who is black, said when he arrived at work in 1996 he often found 3-by-5 index cards with crude racist cartoons on his desk. Harolyn Duerr, the receptionist and the only woman among 25 people in the office, said that in late 1995 her computer screen saver was changed to a picture of two women having sex.

title: Democrats Now Waging Battles That the Republicans Fought and Lost in '74
description: On Jan. 31, 1974, at the end of a session similar to the one today, the House Judiciary Committee voted unanimously to recommend to the full House that an impeachment inquiry against President Richard M. Nixon be authorized.

title: Bacardi-Martini Selects McKinney
description: Bacardi-Martini U.S.A. Inc. in Miami has named McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., to handle advertising and marketing for the Disaronno Amaretto brand of liqueur, which the company recently acquired from Diageo P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million. McKinney & Silver was awarded the account after a two-month review that also included three agencies in New York: Ammirati Puris Lintas, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; DeVito/Verdi, and Warwick Baker O'Neill. McKinney & Silver is owned by CKS Group, which is being acquired by the USWeb Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALET, DOROTHY
description: CALET-Dorothy, age 91. Loving wife of the late Joseph. Beloved mother of Carole Geller and Neil. Grandmother of Lois, Harlan and David. Great grandmother of Sararose and Jennamae.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUILDEN, TAMARA
description: GUILDEN-Tamara. On October 5, 1998. Wife of the late Ira. Mother of Pat and Richard Adler. Grandmother of Jessica Bartlett, Melanie Adler, Joanna Adler and Great-grandmother of Molly Bartlett. Services and interment private. Mrs. Guilden was an active patron of the arts including The Metropolitan Opera, The New York Philharmonic, The Sante Fe Opera, Paris Opera and Ballet, The National Actor's Theatre, The Roundabout Theatre and The Artists' Colony YADDO. She was also on the Board of Directors of the Foreign Policy Association and the National Committee for American Foreign Policy.

title: Rangel Sees a Political Motive in Vacco's Apollo Lawsuit
description: United States Representative Charles E. Rangel lashed out at State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco yesterday, accusing him of concocting a lawsuit against the Apollo Theater Foundation to gain support in his campaign for re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, J. GARY
description: MENDELSON-J. Gary. Devoted husband of Linda; loving father of Meredith (Jeb) Mendelson Bryan and Amy Mendelson. Born April 11, 1939, a graduate of Long Island University and Brooklyn Law School. Services were held in Los Angeles following his death on September 21, 1998.

title: Trimmed Tobacco Plan Takes Center Stage
description: As state attorneys general start today to review the outlines of a new national tobacco settlement proposal, even supporters of the plan acknowledge that it represents a new phase in the nation's debate over smoking: one of lowered expectations.

title: PEP BOYS PLANS TO SELL 100 EXPRESS STORES TO AUTOZONE
description: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack said yesterday that it would sell 100 of its Express auto parts stores to a larger rival, Autozone Inc., for $108 million and would close nine others as it focuses more on supercenters that offer services and tires. Pep Boys expects to post a pretax charge of about $34 million related to the sale and closing of the Express stores, formerly called Parts USA, which offer parts and accessories. Excluding the 109 stores that will be sold or closed, Pep Boys, which is based in Philadelphia, operates 624 stores. Autozone is based in Memphis and operates about 2,000 stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, FRANCINE
description: GRUBER-Francine. On October 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sy. Mother of Vikki Rivlin and Scott. Sister of Suzanne Srour. Also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral service at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, N.J. Wednesday, October 7, 10:15AM. Memorial donations to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, New York Chapter or Valley HospiceJourneys, 15 Essex Rd, Paramus, N.J. 07652 would be appreciated.

title: Unlikely Ally for Officer Accused of Racism
description: The case of the New York Police Department vs. Officer Joseph Locurto, which has had a through-the-looking-glass quality from its very beginning, drew to an end yesterday with the Rev. Al Sharpton appearing as a defense witness for the officer, who wore blackface on a parade float that parodied a brutal racial killing in Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUTRY, GENE
description: AUTRY-Gene. The Board of Directors and members of the National Academy of Popular Music and the Songwriters' Hall of Fame regret the passing of Gene Autry, past recipient of the Sammy Cahn Lifetime Achievement Award. He will be greatly missed. Bobby Weinstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, HARRY
description: FEIN-Harry. Thursday, September 17. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of Merryl and Alan and their spouses Bernard and Lucy. Adoring grandfather of Dr. Corey Greenwald and wife Dr. Megan Missette and Vicki Greenwald Auerbach and husband Jonathan. Great grandfather to Taran Greenwald. Devoted companion of Esther Altabet and her children and grandchildren. A man of indominable spirit, great humor and intelligence and raconteur par excellence, he devoted himself to his family, his music and the pursuit of knowledge. We miss him already.

title: Demanding Parole, Immigrants Held in Queens Stage Protest
description: Five days after asylum-seekers at an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in New Jersey went on a hunger strike to demand better conditions, immigrants at a center in Queens protested yesterday to pressure immigration authorities into granting them parole.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: PENSKE AUTO CENTERS INC., Troy, Mich., an automotive service provider, named James M. Wheat president and chief executive. He replaces Roger S. Penske Jr. as chief executive and Timothy Findlay as president. Mr. Penske will assume other management responsibilities, and Mr. Findlay will provide consulting services to Penske Auto while pursuing other interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT J.
description: BROWN-Robert J. On October 3rd, 1998 of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Branford, Connecticut. Husband of Mary Jane Brown. Father of Robert J. Brown, Jr., Tracy Hanson, Kerri Beckert, Dorothy Duncan and Stephanie White. Brother of Carole Fischer. Son of the late Irving J. and Alice Brown. Mass of christian burial St. Therese, Stoney Creek, Branford, CT. Tuesday morning 10AM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Robert J. Brown Memorial Fund, C/O Cheshire Academy, Cheshire, CT. 06410.

title: Legal Journal; Scandal Is Grist for Law School Grind
description: The students' pens in the classroom at the University of Maryland School of Law were poised the way law students' pens often are.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's visit to Miami misidentified an official of the Cuban American National Foundation, a lobbying group of Cuban exiles. He was Jorge Mas. Jorge Mas Canosa was his father and the group's founder. The elder Mr. Mas died last November.

title: 3 Women Honored For Careers In the Arts
description: To commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Women's Rights Convention at Seneca Falls, N.Y., Judith Jamison, the artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater; Tania Leon, the composer and conductor, and Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, were presented with lifetime achievement awards at the ceremony for the 1998 Governor's Arts Awards last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Manhattan.

title: N.F.L.
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Save Whales or Culture?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBENSTEIN, HENRY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Henry. Henry dearest, six years of missing and loving you. Always, Your Beatric

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Exiting Medicare is not a sure solution for H.M.O. woes.
description: THE managed care companies that unloaded 250,000 elderly Medicare customers last week will have healthier financial statements to show for it, starting in the first half of 1999. But many Wall Street analysts said that dropping Medicare units in dozens of unprofitable markets would not be enough to pull the health maintenance organizations out of a three-year earnings slump.

title: A Glow in the Dark, and a Lesson in Scientific Peril
description: THIS year is the 100th anniversary of the Nobel-prize-winning experiments by Marie and Pierre Curie into the origins of radioactivity, and their discovery of the radioactive elements polonium and radium. Marie Curie herself coined the term ''radioactivity,'' and a century ago, the word conveyed promise and evoked excitement. As the spontaneous release of energy from certain substances, radioactivity was regarded as a newly identified force of nature, something that would surely lead to insights into the structure of matter, and to practical applications in medicine and science.

title: Kariya Is Haunted by Next Big Hit
description: After Paul Kariya sustained another concussion last Feb. 1, the Anaheim Mighty Ducks medical staff expected him to be back in the lineup in a few days. The Canadian Olympic team was counting on him to join it in Japan later that month. Young, talented and charismatic, Kariya is important to the National Hockey League on several levels.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS AGAINST MARK. The dollar declined for a sixth day on expectations the Federal Reserve may lower interest rates again. The dollar settled at 1.6295 marks in New York, down from 1.6463 marks Friday.

title: Yankees Try to Forget a '97 Homer
description: The voice came from a nearby locker, but its tone and meaning were clear.

title: Labor Standoff Knocks Out N.B.A.'s Exhibition Season
description: In a decision that will almost certainly lead to the first regular-season work stoppage in National Basketball Association history, the league announced yesterday that all preseason games were canceled. Citing stalled negotiations with the players union over a new collective bargaining agreement, league officials said they would decide next week whether to cancel the first week of regular-season games.

title: Operator? Give Me the World Wide Web and Make It Snappy
description: A group of communications, software and financial services companies plans to announce an alliance today aimed at creating standards for speech recognition that will push electronic commerce and the Internet beyond the boundaries of the personal computer, potentially making it accessible to anyone with a telephone.

title: National Healing: Is It Too Soon?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Healing: Is It Too Soon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Whither Faith?
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter of the Law, but the Spirit Is Weak
description: Bill Moyers and ''Frontline'' return tonight to what they call ''Washington's Other Scandal.'' You remember: that's the one about campaign financing, when the President entertained rich contributors instead of interns. This report focuses on how the 1996 Clinton campaigners sold ''access'' to those who could afford it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINUCCI, LUCIANO
description: MARTINUCCI-Luciano, M.D. On October 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia nee Murray. Loving father of Suzanne, Kenneth, Mary, Matthew, Andrea, Licia and Bernadette. Also survived by five grandchildren. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Wednesday at 11 AM, in Holy Innocents R.C. Church. Interment will follow at St. John's Cemetery.

title: A Jazz Triumph After Decades of Bad Breaks
description: TERI THORNTON began hemorrhaging at the Bern Jazz Festival, becoming so weak that her manager had to spoon-feed her, and when she got back to the United States from Switzerland, the doctors decided that the bladder cancer they had been treating with chemotherapy and radiation required surgery. This was in June.

title: Methadone Is Just Another Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: A Lawmaker Asks: Watergate or Peyton Place?
description: The question rang forth from the committee room as a succinct outcry at what the nation is being put through: ''Is this Watergate or Peyton Place?''

title: Assembly Panel Seeks To Ease Welfare Rules
description: The Assembly Senior Issues and Community Services Committee has approved a bill that would ease welfare restrictions on some convicted drug offenders by allowing them to collect benefits while enrolled in drug treatment programs.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Since he came to Washington in 1981 to shoot President Ronald Reagan in a bid to impress an actress, John Hinckley Jr. has resided at the city's St. Elizabeths psychiatric hospital. Chun Callen has lived there since being detained in 1989, after coming from Washington State intent on talking to the president about her divorce.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: This is the final Personal Computers column in Science Times. Starting on Oct. 15, the Circuits section, on Thursdays, will introduce a column by Peter H. Lewis, who will write about new products and other computer industry developments of interest to consumers.

title: Review/Fashion; In London, Method To the Madness
description: Despite evidence to the contrary, London fashion isn't all about fun and games. There are also some real, wearable clothes coming from designers here.

title: Haunting Melodies for a People Torn Between Faith and Despair
description: Whatever Leon Botstein's merits as a conductor, he has used his post as music director of the American Symphony Orchestra to bring to performance some fascinating works that have been completely overlooked by conductors with better baton technique but far less intellectual curiosity.

title: Ethnic Assimilation Isn't Europe's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Reached on Bill For More Rent Subsidies
description: Senate and House negotiators reached agreement today on a bill that would make rent subsidies available to more poor families and allow more home buyers to qualify for federally backed mortgages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAB, ELEONORA
description: SCHWAB-Eleonora. All of us at the National Committee on American Foreign Policy extend our heartfelt sympathy to our esteemed President, George D. Schwab, on the loss of his beloved wife, Eleonora. Our thoughts and prayers are with him and his sons, Clarence, Claude and Solon. William J. Flynn, Chairman

title: Close Election Complicates Brazilian Economic Reform
description: Through the anxious weeks leading up to the national elections here on Sunday, as some $30 billion fled Brazil despite a doubling of domestic interest rates, international financial officials watched for the Government to tackle cost-cutting reforms as soon as the voting ended.

title: Political Memo; Union Lauds D'Amato But Backs Schumer
description: It was a surprising scene three months ago when Dennis Rivera, one of New York City's most left-leaning labor leaders, was singing the praises of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Clarify the Law on Leniency for Refugees Seeking Asylum
description: Adding an immigration case and five other new cases to the term that opened today, the Supreme Court agreed to clarify the law on leniency for refugees who seek to remain in the United States despite having committed crimes in their home countries.

title: A First Step With No End in Sight
description: Almost every member of the House Judiciary Committee paid some tribute to the Constitution and the Founding Fathers today. Many said portentously that their debates and votes would be remembered for generations. The muse of history was obviously working overtime.

title: Butterflies' Energy
description: Q. With its small body mass, how does a monarch butterfly obtain enough energy to migrate 1,800 miles?

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR TO CUT BACK AT SCOTTISH PLANT
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation will close part of a plant in Scotland and dismiss 600 of the 1,000 workers there because of slumping demand for computer chips. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said that it would take a $25 million charge in its second quarter, ending Nov. 29, for the cutback in Greenock, near Glasgow and that it was interested in selling its remaining operations in Greenock. National Semiconductor shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $9, on the New York Stock Exchange. They have plunged almost 70 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARKEY, ANNE J.
description: SHARKEY-Anne J. Age 86, died on October 2nd, 1998. She was a beloved and loyal friend to many. Her career included work with Henry Sell, the U.S. State Department and the American Federation of Arts. Please send donations in her memory to Operation Smile, 250 Broadway, Suite 1704, New York, New York 10007.

title: Philippine Airlines To Give Up 8 Jets
description: Philippine Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to surrender eight Airbus Industrie jets to its creditors as the airline, the national flag carrier, prepares to resume operations tomorrow with a smaller fleet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, NANCY
description: WARNER-Nancy. The Board of Directors of the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames note with sadness the death of Nancy Warner, a cherished member of the Society and the Board. She was a guiding light and will be greatly missed. Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor, Directress General

title: Officer in Murder-Suicide Had Sought Counseling
description: A New York City police officer who killed his family and himself last month had sought help from Police Department counselors four years ago, but the counseling did not appear to be related to marital problems, officials said yesterday.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: G. David Tilman; Ecologist Measures Nature's Mosaic, One Plot at a Time
description: IT is a warm, luminous day, and the prairies and woodlands of the Cedar Creek Natural History Area, 30 miles north of the Twin Cities, are buzzing with life. Crickets chirp. Bees and butterflies float from bloom to bloom amid scores of species of grassland plants carpeting the flatlands that run between groves of trees presided over by stately bur oaks two centuries old.

title: Anxiety Creeps Along Hedge Row; A Crisis Over a Local Investment Fund Has All of Greenwich Talking
description: For the epicenter of a financial earthquake that is roiling stock and bond markets around the globe, Greenwich is looking remarkably tranquil these days. At first glance, even the headquarters of John W. Meriwether's Long-Term Capital Management, the giant investment pool that threatened to go bust and take billions of dollars with it, was typically lush and leafy and well-landscaped.

title: World News Briefs; PRI Retains Domination In Elections in Chiapas
description: The governing party has again retained overwhelming control over mayors' offices and the legislature in Chiapas State, according to results announced today.

title: People Who Skip Breakfast Pay a High Price
description: IT'S that no-time-in-the-morning time of year again. The kids are back in school, parents are back to work and breakfast in many households has become a catch-as-catch-can affair, if it is eaten at all. This decade has seen a steady decline in the proportion of Americans who regularly eat breakfast, long considered ''the most important meal of the day.''

title: A Place to Put Money If You Can Afford a Risk
description: To the extent that the term ''hedge fund'' conjures up any image in the public's mind these days, it is likely to be a picture of financial calamity created by Long-Term Capital Management, the Greenwich, Conn., investment pool that nearly went belly up.

title: Man Charged in Sex Abuse of Toddler
description: The police arrested a 45-year-old Queens man late last night on charges that he sexually abused a 3-year-old girl in the unlicensed day care center that he and his wife ran out of their home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, GRACE S.
description: MILLS-Grace S. Wife of Ralph J. Mills of Baton Rouge, LA and formerly of Chappaqua, NY, passed away on September 29. She leaves a daughter, Amy Levert of Baton Rouge, a son, Philip Rodger of Charlotte, NC, a step-daughter, Leslie Ann Santos of Randolph, NJ, and four grandchildren. A memorial service for family and friends will be held 1:00 Saturday, October 10th in the Chapel at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Humane Society of Broward County, FL. or The Salvation Army.

title: Robert Wells, 75, Composer and Lyricist
description: Robert Wells, a lyricist and composer who also wrote and produced programs for television, died on Sept. 23 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 75.

title: Executive Is Named At New York Times
description: Michael G. Williams has been appointed vice president and chief information officer of The New York Times. His appointment was announced yesterday by Janet L. Robinson, the newspaper's president and general manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, PATRICK J.
description: PATTERSON-Patrick J. October 3, 1998 of Forest Hills, New York. Son of the late Myrtle M. (Handel) and Patrick C. Husband of the late MaryAnn (Bellamacina). Father of Judith N. McBride, brother of Nancy L. Polash of Macungie, PA. Grandfather of Donald T. McBride III. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Executive chef Plaza Hotel, Cornell Club, Garden City Country Club & Catholic Charities Food Service. He became ill in 1995 leading to a heart transplant on May 26, 1998. Reposing Fox Funeral Home Inc., 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, New York, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9. Funeral mass Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, N.Y. on Friday, October 9 at 9:45 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions to Gift of Life Foundation, C/O Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, Milstein Building, 622 W. 168 St, N.Y. 10032-3784 would be appreciated.

title: Possible Counts Presented By Republican Counsel
description: Following are 15 counts of possible impeachment outlined today by David P. Schippers, the Republicans' chief investigator on the House Judiciary Committee. Mr. Schippers found that there was substantial and credible evidence that President Clinton:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, BERTHA
description: GOLDEN-Bertha. Beloved wife of the late Nathaniel. Cherished mother of Richard. Dear grandmother of John, Allison, Adam, Nancy and Cynthia. Services today 10AM at ''Guttermans'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Supreme Court Lets Ruling on Bus Ads Stand
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's fight for the right to refuse to run advertisements on its buses that poked fun at the Mayor ended yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear the agency's final appeal.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz Parent Gets Sweeetened Bid
description: Vendex N.V., a Dutch retail company, raised its bid yesterday to acquire a Dutch retailing competitor, Koninklijke Bijenkork Beheer, in an effort to ward off a rival offer from WE International B.V. Vendex, which operates more than 2,300 stores in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany, increased its bid for K.B.B. to 167.50 guilders a share ($91) in cash and stock, from the initial bid of 145 guilders it made in February.

title: G.M. Reportedly to Combine U.S. and Foreign Operations
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to combine its domestic and international automotive operations in a shakeup to be announced on Tuesday morning, Wall Street analysts and other people close to the plan said this evening.

title: Dirty Looks and Raised Pinkies
description: The art of glowering, as opposed to that of merely glaring, is being practiced with exemplary skill on the stage of Playwrights Horizons at the moment. Portraying a landlady and her tenant at rancorous odds with each other in ''The Uneasy Chair,'' an anemic comedy by the young dramatist Evan Smith, Dana Ivey and Roger Rees turn their eyes into simmering bogs of unspeakable hostility and discontent. Yes, the word is definitely glower, unless you prefer the term ''baleful glances.''

title: The Warm-Up Act Was Hot
description: Sandy Alomar Jr., the Cleveland catcher, was asked how the Indians planned to deal with Shane Spencer, whom Will Clark of the Texas Rangers dubbed ''the reincarnation of Babe Ruth.''

title: Transit Repairs Hurried, Unions Warn
description: In the latest sign that a surge in ridership may be straining the New York City transit system, union officials warned yesterday that maintenance work on buses and subway cars was being hurried and perhaps shortchanged as the system tries to get them back into operation.

title: Researcher Proves Scientists Are Funny. Some of Them.
description: THE award ceremony to be held on Thursday at Harvard University will draw more than 1,100 scientists and their students. But the occasion will be something less than solemn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, MELVIN
description: JACOBS - Melvin. August 26, 1926-October 6, 1993. You live on in our hearts and thoughts and continue to inspire our lives and those who were privileged to know you. All our love. Roz and Peggy

title: JUDICIARY PANEL, IN PARTY VOTE, URGES IMPEACHMENT HEARINGS
description: After a long day that veered from sober constitutional discourse to bitter partisan scrapping, the House Judiciary Committee voted along party lines tonight to recommend that Congress open a formal impeachment investigation into a President for only the third time in the nation's history.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 2 Hospital Companies Sued On Charges of False Claims

title: Sales for G.M. Last Month Were Better Than Expected
description: The General Motors Corporation is rebounding faster than expected from the strike that shut down virtually all of its North American factories during the summer, according to sales figures reported today.

title: Economics and People
description: To the Editor:

title: Save Whales or Culture?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLITZ, JANICE DRUCKER
description: GORLITZ-Janice Drucker, of Bay Harbor Islands, Florida, passed away on October 4, 1998. She was predeceased by her loving husband Jules Gorlitz and daughter Barbara Paula Adams. She was the loving, devoted grandmother of Adam Hammel. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ADALINE HAVEMEYER PERKINS
description: RAND-Adaline Havemeyer Perkins. Of Needham, MA, on October 2, age 85, of cancer. Born in New York City & a resident there until recently. She had been married to Richard S. Perkins and the late Laurance Rand. She had been a trustee of the Union Theological Seminary, a volunteer archivist at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a member of the Colony Club of New York. She leaves two sons, Richard S. Perkins, Jr. of Topsfield, MA, Thomas Perkins of Santa Barbara, California, two daughters Sarah & Judy Perkins, both of Concord, Massachusetts, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 22, at 10AM at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, New York. Instead of flowers contributions may be sent to the New Bedford Whaling Museum, Old Darmouth Historical Society, 18 Johnny Cake Hill, New Bedford, Massachusetts 02740. A memorial service will also be held in August in S. Dartmouth, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, TERESA
description: REILLY-Teresa. 83 years. Of Singer Island, Florida. Died October 3, 1998. Formerly of New York. Sister of the late Hugh, Peter and Elizabeth Grey. Survived by many nieces and nephews.

title: Witness to a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Pre-game Show on CBS Settles for Field Goals
description: After five weeks, CBS's revived ''The N.F.L. Today'' is a decent show but not a memorable one. The former domain of Brent Musburger and Greg Gumbel boasts a dandy set, zippy graphics, the old theme song and a miniature gridiron. It is informative but not compelling. Jim Nantz, the host, and the analysts, George Seifert, Marcus Allen and Brent Jones, are amiable but predictable.

title: Deaths Linked to Sex After Childbirth
description: DOCTORS routinely advise women to refrain from sexual activity for several weeks after childbirth, and for most women postpartum pain and exhaustion are incentives enough to comply. But for those who do not follow doctors' orders, the consequences can be serious and, in rare cases, even fatal.

title: Johnson's Exit Proves Cashman Right
description: When the San Diego Padres defeated Randy Johnson and the Houston Astros on Sunday night to race into the National League Championship Series, Brian Cashman was finally able to exhale. No more Johnson in the post-season meant there was little reason for the general manager to wonder whether he should have pushed harder to acquire the left-hander from Seattle at the July 31 trading deadline. Johnson is gone, and he cannot hurt the Yankees.

title: Review/Fashion; Springtime Plot Openers in Milan
description: The first weekend of the spring 1999 showings in Milan was like the opening act in a rock concert, with lesser lights warming up the audience for the stars who will perform later. With the exception of Romeo Gigli and Lawrence Steele, who showed their signature lines, it was mainly designers' secondary collections that set the stage for what will follow.

title: Steadily Weaving Toward Her Goal; Petah Coyne's Art Strategy Has Its Scary Moments
description: Petah Coyne, a small woman clad in an oversize T-shirt, stood in the center of Galerie Lelong on West 57th Street one recent day and started to explain her latest artistic odyssey. ''Two years ago, I had the hair and the animals,'' she said.

title: Reveling in the Possibilities Of the Improvisational Art
description: ''Ah, that was yummy,'' a member of the audience sighed at the end of ''Relativity,'' a program presented by four improvisational dancers and musicians at Dance Theater Workshop. It was easy to understand what the woman, an actress herself, meant. When it is well done, improvisation can be the most excitingly immediate approach to theater. And Kirstie Simson and Chris Aiken, performing with Philip Hamilton and Peter Jones on percussion, gongs, bells and piano Thursday night, were as satisfyingly sweet and creamy as a high-calorie treat.

title: Giants Are Bewildered By a Poor Performance
description: Pick your favorite failed Giants drive in Sunday's 20-3 drubbing by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: HINT OF TAKEOVER PUSHES UP STOCK OF GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL
description: Shares of Global Industrial Technologies Inc. jumped 20 percent yesterday after investors learned the company could be a takeover target for the WHX Corporation. WHX, the parent of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation, a steel manufacturer, disclosed yesterday that it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in Global and might seek to buy the remaining shares. That would cost about $175 million at current share prices. Global, which is based in Dallas, responded in a statement that the company was not for sale. Global makes refractories that line steel furnaces, along with other industrial products. Global's shares rose $1.50, to $8.875. Shares of WHX, which is based in New York, slipped 18.75 cents, to $11.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBANE, PAUL L.
description: KILBANE-Paul L. Holland Lodge #

title: Doubts About Gambits Are Often Unresolved
description: It is amazing how a gambit can go on and on, with now the attacker and next the defender winning the games, but without a clear resolution of who was right. Chalk it up to stubbornness -- and inventiveness.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES ANNOUNCES A BIG STOCK BUYBACK
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the maker of Otis elevators, Carrier heating and air-conditioning systems, and Pratt & Whitney commercial aircraft parts, will buy back up to $1 billion of its stock. The company, which is based in Hartford, said yesterday that it would buy up to 15 million shares, or about 6.5 percent of its 228 million outstanding shares. It had revenue of $24.7 billion last year. United Technologies said it had repurchased 39.3 million shares for $2.3 billion since April 1994. Its stock fell $2 yesterday to close at $74.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Grit and Hard Winters in Rediscovered Ives
description: Charles Ives's ''Emerson'' Concerto is less buried treasure than Poe's purloined letter. Rediscovered pieces may indeed emerge intact from the back of a composer's sock drawer, but others have been there all along, lying inscrutable among a welter of sketches and notes.

title: After Two Years of Service, Having Fun With 'Phantom'
description: Having spent more than two years performing in the Melbourne production of ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' the members of the Australian cabaret trio Combo Fiasco understandably have a love-hate relationship with that bombastic Andrew Lloyd Webber operetta. And in their polished, lighthearted act, which plays Thursdays through Saturdays this month at Eighty-Eight's (228 West 10th Street in Greenwich Village), they take cheerful comic revenge by performing an condensed eight-minute travesty that shreds ''Phantom's'' plot and songs into childish nonsense.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALM, MICHAEL D.
description: PALM-Michael D. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 11th at 4:00PM at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Michael Palm Foundation, P.O. Box 20189, New York, New York 10014.

title: In Their Own Words
description: From the candidates' closing statements at their first debate in Stamford yesterday:

title: People
description: * Robert J. Perkins was named to the new position of president and chief executive of Chamber Communications Inc., Washington, a new company owned by the United States Chamber of Commerce that will oversee operations including Nation's Business magazine. He had been executive vice president, chief marketing officer and head of strategic development at Playboy Enterprises Inc., Chicago.

title: Patterns
description: More Makeup at Barneys

title: Excerpts From Majority Counsel Presentation to House Judiciary Committee
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation given today to the House Judiciary Committee by the majority counsel, David P. Schippers, outlining the matters that could be grounds for impeachment of President Clinton, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Cambridge Lab Keeps Britain Ahead in Genome Stakes
description: THIS ancient university town, with its winding streets and medieval grandeur, has contrived to earn its place on maps of the contemporary world, too. Ever since the structure of DNA was discovered here in 1953, Cambridge has been a leading world center for molecular biology. And with the help of a recent bonanza from a long dead American pharmacist, Cambridge scientists have become leading players in the effort to decipher the human genome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEER, JAMES O.
description: SPEER-James O. At age 80. On October 3, 1998. Beloved friend and patron of the arts. Interment private.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Marius Goring, a British Actor, Is Dead at 86
description: Marius Goring, a British actor who played Shakespearean villains and Nazi officers and stole Moira Shearer's heart in the classic ballet film, ''The Red Shoes,'' died on Wednesday at his home in the West Sussex county of England. He was 86 and had cancer, the BBC reported.

title: CENDANT CANCELS PLANS TO BUY INSURER OWNED BY AEGON
description: The Cendant Corporation, a marketer and franchiser, is ending plans to buy the Providian Auto and Home Insurance Company, an American unit of Aegon N.V., a Netherlands-based insurer that sells auto insurance by mail and telephone. A spokesman for Cendant, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., said the performance of Providian had ''deteriorated substantially'' since Cendant's predecessor, HFS Inc., agreed in December to make the purchase for $219 million in cash. Cendant's shares fell $1.25 yesterday, to $9.50. Cendant said it had filed a lawsuit against Providian because ''several representations and covenants in the acquisition agreement had not been fulfilled.''

title: Crisis in Kosovo
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Memories of Marrow
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: A Chickpea Wafer

title: The Face on the Stock Exchange Floor
description: MARKET DUDE, a New York Stock Exchange floor broker whose real name is Allan E. Gershowitz, was on the phone and skeptical.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARIS, SAMUEL L.
description: PARIS-Samuel L. In everlasting remembrance of a cherished husband, father and poppa. One year and you're in our thoughts with every passing day. Shirley and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSON, ROSE
description: EDELSON-Rose. Formerly of Yonkers. Beloved wife of the late Isaac Max Edelson. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Charles and Susan Edelson, Simon and Linda Edelson. Devoted grandmother of Deborah, Jonathan, Jacob, Sharon and Jessica. Funeral Wednesday 10 A.M. the Chapel at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings.

title: Making the Most of Least
description: NEW YORKERS like to brag that you can get absolutely any ingredient in the city. I think this is probably true. I've tracked down fresh curry leaves, a tropical fruit called a genep and soft wheat berries with almost no effort. What they don't tell you is that these ingredients are never all in one place. In a year's time, not once have I been able to buy everything for a recipe-testing session in one store. Instead, I run all over the city and am usually exhausted before I even begin cooking.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Family Making Orphanhood Look Good
description: Though it dedicates itself to avoiding directorial egotism, in accordance with strict rules of the Danish filmmakers' collective known as Dogma 95, Thomas Vinterberg's ''Celebration'' is still a virtuoso feat. Five years out of film school and colossally assured, Mr. Vinterberg strips away the conventions of ordinary filmmaking (as per the group's manifesto) and furiously devises new, unfettered ways of telling a story. If the style of this group, which also includes the formidable trend-setter Lars von Trier, should ever become widely imitated, it risks looking as fresh as the Macarena. But at a time when filmmaking so often falls back on the familiar, its effect indeed manages to be excitingly inventive and pure.

title: On First Day, Cabby Held in 3 Accidents
description: Many New Yorkers would not be surprised to hear that a taxi ran into a car, hit a pedestrian or fled from the scene of an accident. But Mohammad Rahman gained some renown yesterday morning when, according to the police, he did all three on his very first day as a cabby.

title: Wildcats: 2 Quarterbacks, 0 Losses
description: Alternating quarterbacks can be a two-headed curse for many teams, but the Wildcats are making it a blessing. Keith Smith and Ortege Jenkins have led Arizona to a 5-0 record and No. 10 ranking (No. 25 in The New York Times computer) heading into its Pac-10 confrontation at home against No. 3 U.C.L.A. (3-0, 1-0) on Saturday.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: BASF Says Sales Grew 11% at Its Drug Unit
description: BASF A.G., Europe's largest chemicals maker, said that sales at its pharmaceuticals unit increased 11 percent, to 2.9 billion marks ($1.8 billion), in the first eight months of 1998 and that it expected full-year sales to show a similar percentage rise. The company said sales were bolstered by demand for its thyroid and pain medicines. Drug sales for the whole of 1997 were 4.1 billion marks, or 7.4 percent of BASF's total sales of 55.78 billion marks.

title: With Parcells, Little Errors Can Make a Big Difference
description: In the moments after the Jets' impressive 20-9 victory on Sunday over the previously-unbeaten Miami Dolphins, Bill Parcells sounded less than impressed. While his team celebrated, Parcells was focusing instead on what he called ''awfully dumb things'' that the Jets continue to do even in victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, JOHN BURR
description: JENKINS-John Burr, age 86. Of Chatham, MA., September 30, 1998. Husband of Margaret B., also survived by two sisters, several nieces and nephews. Memorial services in St. Christophers Church Chatham, MA., Friday, October 9, at 11 A.M. Nickerson Funeral Home Chatham, Massachusetts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JOHN LUDLOW
description: LEE-John Ludlow. John Ludlow Lee, a one time account executive with Hill, Holliday, Ogilvy & Mather, and Wells, Rich, Greene, died on September 13 at his home in West Hollywood, California. He was fifty-one years old and had lived in Los Angeles since 1988. Born in Bernardsville, New Jersey in 1947, Mr. Lee was raised in the New York area. His grandfather founded Red Devil Tool company in Union, New Jersey, & his father, John Landon Lee, served as President and CEO. Mr. Lee attended Choate Hall, St. Andrews School, and American University. He worked as a District Sales Mgr for Red Devil from 1976-1979 before beginning his advertising career. Mr. Lee served as Board President of Cri-Help, a communitybased drug and alcohol recovery program, on the boards of the Mountains AIDS Project in Santa Monica and Being Alive in Los Angeles. Mr. Lee is survived by his mother, Binx, his brothers Bruce and Gregory, his sister, Dulcinea, and three nephews. A family memorial was held in Bernardsville, New Jersey, on October 5. A memorial is planned in Los Angeles on Sunday, October 11. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John Lee Fund of the Tides Foundation in San Francisco.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Revamping Structure
description: Wieden & Kennedy is overhauling its structure by creating a top echelon of worldwide managers in its headquarters in Portland, Ore., and separate management teams for its regional offices.

title: Raised by Smotherers And Ne'er-Do-Wells
description: They may not be wonderful role models, but they are wonderful roles. Consider how many great American plays revolve around spirit-crushing mothers and fathers: Amanda Wingfield, the smothering succubus of ''The Glass Menagerie''; Willy Loman, the wholesale disappointment of ''Death of a Salesman''; Mary and James Tyrone, the blighted egoists of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, MILTON
description: MORSE-Milton. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Died Monday in his home. He was 85. Mr Morse founded APM HEXSEAL Corporation of Englewood, N.J. in 1946 and remained active as its President and CEO until his death. Holder of more than 100 patents worldwide, he was recently inducted into the N.J. Inventors Hall of Fame. Survived by his son David and daughter-in-law Carol, his sister Selma Eisler and three grandchildren, Sara, Susanna and Michael. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, N.J. today, 2PM.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Onward Into the Past On Cablevision Calls
description: If retro chic can be applied to technology, a Long Island-based communications giant is attempting to have the last word in answering the phone.

title: France Detects Iraqi Nerve Gas, Experts Assert
description: French tests appear to have found traces of chemicals linked to the nerve gas VX on Iraqi warheads, according to several weapons experts who said this would confirm earlier American test results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSHETZ, ANN
description: KOSHETZ-Ann. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Nina Spiro, Judith Bases and the late Charles Koshetz. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Service today 12 noon at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: When Wealth Promotes Love of Music; Los Angeles School Gets a New Home and a National Goal
description: Eighty years ago, when Richard D. Colburn was growing up on a farm in what was then still the sleepy seaside town of San Diego, his mother surprised him on his seventh birthday with a violin case and a bow and took him to have his first lesson. It was given by a neighbor who advertised ''instruction in violin, piano, banjo, guitar, mandolin and something else.''

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS SEEK PARTY UNITY ON IMPEACHMENT
description: As the House prepares to vote on Thursday on beginning an impeachment inquiry, Democratic leaders labored today to keep as many beleaguered Democrats as possible from voting for the Republican proposal to conduct an open-ended investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, CELE
description: GOLDSMITH-Cele. In her 97th year, wife of the late Edward, mother of Judith Bergoffen and the late Thelma Berger. Motherin-law of Charles Bergoffen and Charles Berger. Grandmother of Susan, Philip, Peter (Nathan) and Sue, John and Demi, Ruth and Barry. Great grandmother of Milan, Melissa, Hannah and John Charles. Survived also by sisters, Kay Press and Norma Meresco. Service on Friday 10:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For the holidays, a big campaign for an electronic, interactive bit of fur. Sound familiar?
description: IN this season of pre-holiday hype, every toy maker likes to promote its newest plaything as the next Tickle Me Elmo or Beanie Baby.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Let's Not Make a Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIJKERK, INGE
description: NIJKERK-Inge. We mourn the passing of Inge Nijkerk and extend condolences to her husband, Alfred, and her two sons, Ernst and Richard, her daughter-in-law, Lauren Nijkerk-Bogen, and her granddaughter, Margaux. Stanley and Roberta Bogen Joy Bogen Edmund Bogen Alexandra Bogen

title: Man in the News: G. Richard Wagoner Jr.; New G.M. President Knows the Profitable Car and the Ugly
description: The naming of G. Richard Wagoner Jr. today as the president and chief operating officer of the General Motors Corporation shows how the world's largest corporation is changing -- and how it is not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA E.
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila E. Died of cancer on October 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother of Roy (Nell) and Neil (Dee). Proud grandmother of Matt (Keri) and Garth. Dear sister of Ruth, Julia (Jack) and the late Dave (Evelyn). She will be missed by her family and many devoted friends who knew her kindness, generosity and spirit. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The People's Light & Theatre Company in Malvern, Pennsylvania.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Is This a Cultural Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Benefit to Support Life After Dance
description: A worthy cause gathers no floss and all was silky smooth at ''The Next Step,'' the fourth annual benefit for Career Transition for Dancers on Monday night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Gene Autry on Saturday misstated the history of singing cowboys in the movies. He was not the first; Ken Maynard was, singing in the 1929 western ''The Wagon Master.'' Mr. Autry first sang in Maynard's 1934 film ''In Old Santa Fe.''

title: Mourning a Departed Mainstay
description: The old General Motors assembly plant here is being torn down. And, as if paying their last respects, dozens of former auto workers have been stopping by regularly to watch as construction crews dismantle the factory where some of them spent their entire working lives.

title: Journal; Capital Shrink Rap
description: Mark McGwire's other legacy -- not that anyone who hits 70 home runs needs another one -- could be his casual aside to sportswriters: ''Hey, everybody needs therapy!'' He was exaggerating, of course, but the message was clear. The guy the nation grew to worship -- the man who fought his way to the top from a messy divorce and career setbacks, the devoted single father, the surrogate brother to Sammy Sosa and the Maris family -- is someone who conquered his demons with the help of four years of psychiatry. In a culture where therapists and their patients alike are always good for a laugh, a heroic jock's openness about his own history may well encourage others who need help to seek it out.

title: Political Briefing; Michigan Polls Hint At Democrat's Defeat
description: Few candidates have been more outrageously outspoken this year than Geoffrey Fieger, who aspires to be Michigan's governor after building a reputation as a lawyer for Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the advocate and practitioner of physician-assisted suicide.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Counsel's Misstep
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Is Fined $11,000 in Death of Boy
description: Monmouth Medical Center has been fined $11,000 by the state for the death of a 10-month-old boy who was given 10 times the proper drug dose because his doctor omitted a decimal point.

title: New TV Ads Stress Issues, Not Scandal
description: Republican Party organizations and a liberal advocacy group today unveiled television advertising campaigns that seek to energize voters by emphasizing issues and not the White House scandal.

title: Budget Showdown in Washington
description: In an atmosphere already bitter over impeachment proceedings, President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders are heading toward another nasty confrontation on the budget that threatens to shut down the Government. In this dispute, however, the White House has a strong hand. Despite his political problems, Mr. Clinton is right to insist on legislation free of objectionable attachments to keep government operations going past Friday. The most offensive riders under consideration would damage natural resources, cut programs for schools and the poor and impose mischievous new curbs on abortion and contraception.

title: Inside an Artist's Mind In a World of Torment
description: Anyone who subscribes to the sentimental fallacy that great artists are nicer people than the rest of us (the reasoning goes that because they supposedly feel more than ordinary mortals, they must be nobler and more caring) hasn't met many great artists. If anything, the reverse tends to be true: the obsessive pursuit of an artistic idea more often than not involves a ruthless tunnel vision that screens out anything that isn't useful to the work or to the career.

title: In No Time, The Yankees Take Charge
description: Scoring lots of runs early would be nice, Joe Torre, the manager of the Yankees, mused before last night's playoff game with Cleveland, as if he were considering a room service menu. And the Yankees delivered.

title: House Party Lures 200 And Police, Who Arrest 6
description: The flier for ''Shakedown '98'' attracted up to 200 people mostly men -- with the promise of an off-campus house party featuring a deejay, lap dancers and alcohol, the authorities said.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Take the Yankees, Jersey; Dom's Has Moved to SoHo

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A poor showing by Chrysler illustrates the pitfalls of all-stock merger deals with foreign companies.
description: THE financial bane of Detroit auto makers has been the laggard shares of their stocks; those have tended to sell for only seven to nine times their earnings per share, less than half the market average for big companies.

title: THE CHEF
description: UNLIKE most of today's outdoorsmen, my dad hunted and fished for sustenance rather than sport. As soon as we were old enough, my brothers and I joined him in the fields and forests of upstate New York, bringing home deer, rabbit, pheasant, partridge and a host of other game birds.

title: Fans Cheer Strawberry, The Absent Outfielder
description: Charisse Strawberry, the wife of Darryl Strawberry, threw out the first ball before last night's game.

title: Discreetly Veiled Brothels of Old Shanghai
description: The Taiwanese film ''Flowers of Shanghai'' arrived late for its critics' screening at the New York Film Festival. It wasn't particularly worth the wait.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS MORE THAN 3 YEN. The dollar tumbled to 130.85 yen from 134.25 in New York, on speculation that Japan may be planning to take aggressive steps to stimulate its economy.

title: Rikers Doctor Says She Quit Over Worsening Medical Care
description: The doctor responsible for monitoring the quality of medical care in city jails said in an interview yesterday that she resigned recently because the medical care for prisoners has eroded under a new managed care contract, and she accused city officials of refusing to address the problem.

title: Would-Be Image of Lincoln Fails to Sell
description: The much debated Hay Wadsworth daguerreotype, dated 1843 and thought by some to be the first image of Abraham Lincoln, failed to sell at Christie's yesterday. The auctioneer started the bidding at $110,000 and, after two bids, stopped at $150,000, below the secret reserve price and the estimate of $200,000 to $300,000.

title: Maraschino's Historic Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: Jean Crockett, 79, First Woman To Lead the Philadelphia Fed
description: Jean Andrus Crockett, the first chairwoman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and first chairwoman of the finance department at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, died on Saturday at her home in Media, Pa. She was 79.

title: Lopez Gains in His Bid for Title Bout
description: Main Events, the promoter for Jose Luis Lopez, has got an injunction to keep the World Boxing Association from sanctioning the bout between Andrei Pestriaev and Greg Page in Paris this Saturday as a welterweight championship match.

title: N.Y.U. Sees Profits in Virtual Classes
description: Moving to become a major player in the emerging market for education on the Internet, New York University plans to create a for-profit subsidiary that will develop and sell specialized on-line courses to other colleges, corporate training centers, as well as students who simply prefer to attend class at home.

title: Just 2 Miles Separate 2 Bill Clintons
