description: President Clinton's parallel universes have been separated by a mere two miles the past several days, as international financial leaders assemble in downtown Washington hotels to address the spreading global economic crisis while Capitol Hill is consumed by debate over whether to impeach the President.

title: Owner of N.F.L. Team Ties Ex-Governor to Extortion
description: After striking a deal to provide evidence against former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana, Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., the co-owner of the San Francisco 49ers, pleaded guilty today to concealing an alleged extortion plot by Mr. Edwards that involved the licensing of a riverboat casino.

title: INSIDE
description: Russian Appeal for Calm

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIX, ROBERT HELLER
description: DIX-Robert Heller. Professor emeritus of political science at Rice University, died October 3 from complications arising from multiple sclerosis and cancer. Born in Elizabeth, N.J., in 1930, he received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Harvard University. He served at the American embassy in Bogota, Colombia, 1957-60; his first book, ''Colombia: The Political Dimensions of Change'', considered a classic in its field, drew on his experiences there. Dr. Dix taught at Yale, 196266, and spent a research year in Santiago, Chile, before becoming an associate at the Harvard Center for International affairs. He joined the Rice faculty in 1968; from 1987 until his retirement in 1994 he was the Lena Gohlman Fox Professor of Political Science. When his health limited travel to Latin America, he expanded his research to revolutionary movements & transitions to democracy, publishing a number of highly acclaimed articles on these subjects. He is survived by his wife Mary Seaton Dix, his brother Willard M. Dix of Noblesville, Indiana, nephews Andrew C. Dix, Robert M. Dix, Willard M. Dix, Robert C. Platzoeder, William S. Platzoeder, nieces Inge Dix Joseph and Sally P. Reed, and cousins Althea A. Clark and Elizabeth A. Edwards.

title: A G.O.P. Fund-Raising Device Angers Some Voters
description: It was not a voice mail message that Dr. Marilyn M. Rymer, a neurologist in Kansas City, Mo., would routinely delete, even as a registered Democrat. ''Speaker Newt Gingrich's office,'' it said, was calling to discuss a ''national leadership award.''

title: Jerome Weidman Dies at 85; Author of Novels and Plays
description: Jerome Weidman, the prolific and popular novelist who wrote ''I Can Get It for You Wholesale'' and also won a Pulitzer Prize as the author (with George Abbott) of the Broadway musical ''Fiorello!,'' died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Incentive Program Raises Immunization Rates
description: A Chicago program has significantly improved the dangerously low immunization rates among the city's poor children through incentives that require parents to report to the authorities monthly, instead of quarterly, to receive Federal food vouchers.

title: Dissension Erupts at Talks On World Financial Crisis
description: As President Clinton argued anew today that ''we must find a way to temper the volatile swings of the international marketplace,'' the president of the World Bank publicly broke with the approach that the United States and the International Monetary Fund have taken in managing the global crisis.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Conspiracy Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIVILINO, JOSEPH PAUL ''JO JO''
description: TRIVILINO-Joseph Paul ''Jo Jo'' on October 4, 1998. Beloved son of Anna and Alfred B. Brother to Alfred C., Dessy, Rosanna, Cristina and Loretta. Brother-in-law to Robert, Jennifer, Mark and Jeff. Uncle to Caraline, Victoria, Emma and Jake. Buddy to Bert, Gus and Greta. Friend to all who knew and loved him! Reposing at Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard, corner of 193 Street. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30 AM, Immaculate Conception R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donation to Ronald McDonald House of Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, FLORENCE PEARL
description: EHRLICH-Florence Pearl. On October 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Daniel and the late Andrew. Loving sister of Edna Palecek of Margate, FL and William Berman of Hamden, CT. Services Thursday 10am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Pros and Cons Of a Scandal
description: If you're doing a show called ''Politically Incorrect,'' it has to help when a political scandal is dominating the news, right?

title: Sailing for the Masses: Wind, Water, Plastic; Easy to Learn and Easy to Afford, New Tiny Boats Are Proving Popular
description: There is something familiar about the slogan used by the Escape Sailboat Company: The Sailboat for the Rest of Us. If the phrase calls to mind Apple Computer's famous 1980's pitch for the Macintosh, ''a computer for the rest of us,'' well, that's fine with Peter Johnstone, Escape's president and co-founder.

title: Agassi Cruises to Victory
description: Fourth-seeded Andre Agassi gave Roger Federer a lesson, brushing aside the Wimbledon junior champion from Switzerland, 6-3, 6-2, in the first round of the Swiss Indoors in Basel. Third-seeded Petr Korda was the only seeded casualty of the opening day, losing by 6-2, 6-4 to Nicolas Kiefer.

title: NFL: NOTEBOOK -- WASHINGTON
description: The Redskins, who lost the only fullback on their roster when Larry Bowie broke his left leg in Sunday's game against Dallas, filled the vacancy yesterday with Jim Kitts.

title: 2 Book Giants In Global Deal To Sell Titles Via Internet
description: Two giants in the business of books struck a $200 million deal today to become partners in a global network to sell titles in all major languages on line, posing a powerful competitive threat to the electronic commerce pioneer Amazon.com.

title: The Minimalist; The Essence Of Thai Cooking
description: ON one level, it is absurd, even insulting, to try to reduce an entire cuisine to a few ingredients. But in fact, so many of the world's exciting cuisines do have signature combinations and flavors. For instance, any cook presented with olive oil, lemon, parsley, garlic and tomatoes and a few directions could well be on the way toward a terrific Western European dish. And it will have about it a sense of reassuring familiarity.

title: Political Briefing; Polls in Nebraska Go Against the Grain
description: Senator Bob Kerrey's hopes for running for President in 2000 got a nice lift a few days ago when a poll in his home state, Nebraska, found that 3 of 5 voters thought he should go for it. Often, such polls find that voters want their elected officials to stay put and govern rather than take up the chase after that most elusive of political goals.

title: Holbrooke Is Unable to Wrest Concessions From Milosevic
description: The American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke held a second round of talks here early today with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, but failed to extract any concessions on a troop pullback from Kosovo Province or a return of refugees, an American diplomat said.

title: United Ethnically, and by an Assault; Two Groups of East Indians Are Brought Closer, for Now
description: By age 5, Rishi Maharaj was waving an American flag. By the time he was a teen-ager, he was haranguing his family to register to vote. Years before he cast his first vote, he was volunteering for political campaigns and manning the local polls.

title: A Challenge for Carl McCall
description: New York State's Comptroller, Carl McCall, is not the only Albany politician whose campaign treasury is bulging with donations from companies and executives doing business with the state. Mr. McCall has called for campaign finance reform in the past, and his current fund-raising is within the law. Still, as described by Clifford J. Levy in The Times, he has harvested a sizable amount of money from lawyers, investment officials and others awarded contracts involving the state's $100 billion pension fund.

title: 4 Men Charged With Selling Faulty Uniforms to Pentagon
description: A Brooklyn-based clothing company and four of its top officials have been charged with defrauding the Pentagon of millions of dollars by using defective cloth in coveralls and combat uniforms, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: 6 at City Hall Are Shot; Ex-Worker Is Accused
description: A man armed with a pistol and years of anger about his dismissal as a part-time city parks employee burst into a meeting room at City Hall here this morning and opened fire, wounding the Mayor and two members of the City Council, the police said.

title: Hold Those Blueprints
description: President Clinton was right to call for ''urgent steps'' to stem the global financial meltdown when he addressed a meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank yesterday. But he went on to echo the call of Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain for a new global ''financial architecture,'' a mantra that has been repeated too often in recent days.

title: Western Resources Plants
description: Western Resources Inc., a holding company that owns two Midwestern electric utilities with 614,000 customers, said it would build three power plants near Wichita, Kan., at a cost of $120 million. The plants will add 300 megawatts, or about 5 percent, to the company's power-generating capacity. The natural-gas-fired turbines will be designed to help the company meet electricity demand during periods of peak consumption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, NANCY
description: WARNER-Nancy. The Board of Directors of the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames note with sadness the death of Nancy Warner, a cherished member of the Society and the Board. She was a guiding light and will be greatly missed. Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor, Directress General

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; What Framers Meant
description: To the Editor:

title: Sowing A New Order In Rocky Soil
description: ''Were you always a peasant?'' one handsome young man asks another in the Austrian film ''The Inheritors,'' prompting the suspicion that a strain of tongue-in-cheek mischief may be alive and well here. In the midst of Stefan Ruzowitzky's somber rural allegory, which owes much of its visual inspiration to the palette and compositional sense of the Dutch masters, that would indeed be a ray of light. Mr. Ruzowitzky's film, which will be shown tonight and tomorrow night as part of the New York Film Festival, does show off a knowingness that reaches beyond its stylized simplicity, but its tone often remains uncertain. What starts out as an arrestingly sharp film with strong political undercurrents winds up increasingly unfocused as it goes along.

title: Trial Testimony in Case Of Firefighters and Float
description: As the administrative trial began in the case of two New York City firefighters who wore blackface on a float at a Labor Day parade in Queens, one of the float's organizers testified yesterday that his intention was not to offend African-Americans but rather to mock the attitudes of his virtually all-white neighborhood.

title: Brosius's Ankle Mends
description: Scott Brosius had an X-ray taken on his sprained left ankle Sunday and a CAT scan Monday. But he appeared to be moving very well in the Yankees' pre-game workout yesterday, beginning his drill by running from first base to third, where he then fielded ground balls. Brosius later took batting practice and was hitting line drives from line to line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, JOE
description: BAUM-Joe. The Citymeals-onWheels family is sadly diminished by the loss of one of its own, Joe Baum, our Board member and long-time friend. Joe's heart was as expansive as his vision. His loving generosity to New York's homebound elderly was abundant and ceaseless. His Rainbow Room has been a gift to our Women's Power Lunch for over a decade and some of our most glittering and fruitful dinners took place at one or another of his magnificent restaurants. Our thoughts are with Ruth, Hillary, Charles, Edward, and his many devoted colleagues and staff. We will miss Joe very much. His spirit of fun, mischief and incomparable hospitality will be with us forever. Gael Greene, Chairman Preston Robert Tisch, President Marcia Stein, Executive Director

title: From Brazil's Perspective, a Bailout Shouldn't Have to Hurt
description: In gatherings with financial officials and international investors in Washington, Brazilian officials have been pledging drastic, if unspecified, measures to cut spending by $25 billion over the next three years.

title: To Be, or Whatever, in a Shakespearean Fracas
description: The aim of the new theater company Public Domain in its first production, ''The Circle Hamlet,'' is to sharply focus the attention of the actors, and thus of the audience, on the words of the play, a slightly trimmed version of Shakespeare's ''Hamlet,'' with occasional variations of familiar lines and speeches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, FRANCINE (NEE LITT)
description: BROWN-Francine (nee Litt) of Ft. Lee, New Jersey, on October 5, 1998. Beloved mother of Martin Brown & Bonnie Stambaugh. Dear sister of Bruce Litt. Loving grandmother of Robert and Zachariah. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood, N.J., Wednesday 12:30 PM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKERMAN, BERNARD
description: BECKERMAN-Bernard. Died fourteen years ago. Missed and loved.

title: In the Stands, Optimism and Prayers
description: When the Yankees were being introduced before last night's opener with the Indians to deafening cheers and No. 39 was called, E. Daniel Fearon, deep in the left-field bleachers, stopped clapping and shut his mouth. He made a sign kind of like the one a third base coach might use -- head, stomach, shoulder, shoulder -- put his index fingers together and spoke softly inside his head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTKIN, PHYLLIS
description: WERTKIN-Phyllis. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Passed away 10/5/98. She was the beloved wife of Ben, loving mother of Martin (Sandi), and Craig. Cherished grandmother of Scott, Jeffrey, Brian, Logan, and Stephanie. Adored sister of Doris (Fred) Saffer. Service Fri.,10/9/98, 10 A.M. at Temple Beth El, Great Neck. Riverside Gordon 1-800-884-0979.

title: LUCENT BUYS NETWORK SOFTWARE MAKER FOR $50 MILLION
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Quadritek Systems Inc., a closely held maker of network-management software, for about $50 million in cash, as it continues its thrust into data networking. Lucent, the phone maker based in Murray Hill, N.J., said the acquisition's impact on earnings would be immaterial, though it will result in a charge in the first quarter, ending on Dec. 31. An explosion in data transmission has Lucent and its rivals scrambling to get into networking, a business dominated by Cisco Systems Inc. Since last year, Lucent has acquired six related companies. Lucent's shares fell $1.3125 each, to $57.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHAIR, KATHLEEN C.
description: PHAIR-Kathleen C. Beloved wife of the late James Seward Phair. Loving mother of Evelyn Finn, James Stephen Phair & Elizabeth Fredericks. Adored grandmother of 12 grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection, Fri., 11 AM, Church of the Assumption, Brooklyn Heights, NY. Visiting Wednesday 7-9, Thursday 2-9 at Jere J. Cronin Funeral Home Inc, 115 Atlantic Ave, Brooklyn Heights, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, EVELYN
description: ETTINGER-Evelyn. In Walnut Creek, CA on October 4th at 85 years of age. Native of New York, moved to California in 1990. Wife of the late Charles Ettinger, mother of William (Sheryl) Ettinger and the late John (Karen) Ettinger, grandmother of Nicole Ettinger. Active in the March of Dimes, Hadassah and the National Council of Jewish Women. She read for the Literacy Volunteers of America. Services, Wednesday, October 7 at Menorah Chapel, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd, Union, NJ. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, CARL DUNKLE, JR.
description: SHEPPARD-Carl Dunkle, Jr. Age 82, died Saturday, October 3, 1998 in Santa Fe, NM. Mr. Sheppard retired to Santa Fe in 1983 as Emeritus Professor and Chair of the Department of Art History, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis. He served as President of the International Center of Medieval Art, on the Boards of the College Art Assocation, the Center Opera Company, the James J. Hill Library, St. Paul; the Santa Fe Symphony Orchestra and the New Mexico Historical Society. He received his doctorate in Fine Arts at Harvard University in 1947.

title: 2 Big On-Line Music Stores Said to Be Discussing Merger
description: In the first big combination of Internet retailers, the two biggest online music stores are in the final stages of negotiating a merger.

title: UEFA Shuffles Cup Competitions
description: The executive committee of European soccer's ruling body UEFA decided yesterday in Lisbon to merge the Cup Winners Cup with the UEFA Cup and enlarge the Champions League to 32 teams from 24 as of the 2000/2001 season.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; End the Proceeding
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Has a Million Rebate Checks, in Mid-Campaign
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is taking advantage of one of the most powerful and time-honored perks of political incumbency -- the ability to dole out the largess of government. Instead of the usual library grant here, road project there, though, the Governor is going tradition one better, with two programs that are sending refund checks to more than a million New Yorkers in the middle of his campaign for a second term.

title: Republicans Yield On Spending Matters
description: Seeking to keep the spotlight on the impeachment investigation from being dimmed by any potential Government shutdown, House Republican leaders showed a new willingness to resolve disputes that could push the nation toward such a shutdown.

title: Hold That Bottle, Bring Out the Glass
description: I'LL have a glass of chardonnay,'' the lady says. Her male companion adds, ''Make it a glass of merlot for me.''

title: Schumer Sees Opportunism In D'Amato Acid Rain Talk
description: Seeking to seize an issue from his Democratic opponent's quiver, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato testified at a Senate hearing today in support of legislation intended to reduce acid rain, which he called ''airborne terrorism'' that is defoliating New York's forests and destroying its lakes.

title: Mark Belanger, 54, a Shortstop On Orioles Known for Fielding
description: Mark Belanger, the smooth-fielding Baltimore Oriole shortstop of the 1970's who won eight Gold Glove awards, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Belanger, who lived in New York, was 54.

title: New York Bracing for Medicaid Managed Care
description: After years of policy debates, hand-wringing and foiled attempts, the managed care revolution is finally coming to New York City's 1.2 million Medicaid recipients. And the details indicate just how hard the transition will be.

title: NU SKIN IN DEAL TO EXPAND FOOD-SUPPLEMENTS BUSINESS
description: Nu Skin Enterprises Inc., a skin care and nutritional products company with $890.6 million in sales in 1997, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Generation Health Holdings Inc. to expand its food-supplements business. Nu Skin will pay 4.1 million in stock, valued at $45.1 million at Monday's price. It may also make additional payments of as much as $33 million, depending on market conditions and its stock's performance in the year after closing. It will also assume about $30 million in debt. Nu Skin's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $10.375.

title: White House Farce
description: A group that included the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson gathered as planned on Monday for a protest rally urging the cancellation of UPN's new sitcom ''The Secret Diary of Desmond Pfeiffer,'' but the more effective protest was a silent one. Viewers stayed away in droves.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Election Day Coup
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Costs of Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: France Telecom Plans Update for Minitel
description: France Telecom, which pioneered the quirky Minitel on-line information service years before anyone ever heard of the World Wide Web, announced plans today to bring its aging child into the modern world.

title: Too Much Bullpen Rest?
description: The Yankees were thrilled when David Wells, Andy Pettitte and David Cone pitched deep into their games in the series against Texas. But Joe Torre, the Yankee manager, expressed some concern about pitchers who haven't been able to work in a game for so long.

title: ALLEGIANCE IN CASH DEAL FOR MEDICAL PRODUCTS SUPPLIER
description: The Allegiance Corporation, one of the largest United States suppliers of medical products, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held International Medical Products Group B.V. of the Netherlands to expand its product lines and presence in Europe. Financial terms were not disclosed, although Allegiance said it would pay cash. Allegiance, which had 1997 revenue of $4.4 billion, said the acquisition would not dilute its 1999 earnings. International Medical Products, which will have $40 million in sales this year, makes surgical supplies. Shares of Allegiance, based in McGaw Park, Ill., fell $2.4375, to $27.

title: Political Briefing; 'Uncle Joe' Exhorts Democrats on Polls
description: In the all-in-the-family brand of politics . . .

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Dangerous Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Economic Troubles
description: Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, has little time to savor his apparent first-round re-election victory on Sunday. He must take rapid and unpopular steps to save the economy.

title: Russia Vows to Block the U.N. From Backing Attack on Serbs
description: Russia vowed today to veto any attempt by the United Nations to authorize air strikes against Yugoslavia and warned of ''serious international consequences'' if NATO proceeds with force to halt the ethnic conflict in Kosovo Province.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HASKELL, JACK
description: HASKELL-Jack. Memorial service, 10:30 AM, Oct. 15 at Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien, 2011 Post Road, Darien. Memorial donations to the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: About New York; Fans Cheer For Recovery, Day at a Time
description: ''YOU Gotta Believe'' is emblazoned next to a picture of Darryl Strawberry on the front page of a tabloid that someone has tossed onto a table in a conference room. Since the Yankee left fielder successfully underwent surgery Saturday to remove a tumor from his colon, that phrase has meaning beyond mere games for several baseball fans sitting around the table.

title: Fund Spinoff May Be Delayed
description: Kansas City Southern Industries may delay the spinoff of its mutual funds unit until next year because of a delay in getting a tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section yesterday about the National Heritage Fellowship awards ceremony at the White House misstated the date. The event was yesterday, not Monday.

title: Simple French Fare Graced by North African Touches
description: FINDING a little French restaurant in Greenwich Village is as easy as finding a squirrel in the park and usually about as rewarding. They're common, inoffensive and unremarkable -- the restaurants, I mean -- but despite their mediocrity, they seem to have little trouble attracting crowds.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Let System Operate
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS AUTHORITY EXPECTS WIDER LOSS FOR THE QUARTER
description: Sports Authority Inc., the largest United States sporting-goods chain, said yesterday that it would have a loss in the third quarter that was wider than expected because of weak sales and that it would close 18 unprofitable stores. The retailer expects a loss before a charge of 27 cents to 32 cents a share for the quarter ending on Oct. 25. Analysts forecast a loss of 3 cents, according to a survey by the First Call Corporation. A charge of $55 million, or $1.72 a share, is related to store closings. It is Sports Authority's third-consecutive quarterly profit warning this year, as it marks down athletic gear that has not sold well. Shares of Sports Authority fell $1.0625, to $5.6875.

title: Documents Cast New Light On Ickes's Tie to Teamsters
description: A House panel investigating the teamsters union today disclosed internal White House documents that shed a fuller and harsher light on an effort by Harold M. Ickes, the former deputy chief of staff, to resolve an agricultural labor dispute in California in behalf of the union.

title: Europe Sharpening Its Challenge To the U.S. Over Economic Crisis
description: After more than a year on the sidelines, European governments are challenging the United States over how to address the world financial crisis, suggesting that new ideas and leadership are needed as the turmoil persists and Congress continues to block new funding for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAKIS, PETER
description: TRAKIS-Peter. October 7, 1965June 24, 1998. On your birthday and every day we will always miss you. Love, Mom and Da

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, CEIL
description: GORDON-Ceil. On October 6th. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Helen and Jerry Spielman. Cherished grandmother to Joseph and Steven. Services Thursday 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Wednesday 6-8PM.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; A Poor Example
description: To the Editor:

title: A Complacent Attitude Is Not in Braves' Plans
description: The usual guideline for a team that has grown accustomed to winning all the time is to act in tune with having been there before. The usual danger for such a team is becoming blase about its achievements.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Not Fit Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Grace & Rothschild, New York, was named as the first agency to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $3 million: Medcast Networks, Atlanta, a unit of Greenberg News Networks, which offers in-office computerized news service for physicians, and the Orpheus chamber orchestra, New York.

title: A Slump? The Hitters In Question Respond
description: The Yankees' first five batters were not exactly the fabulous five during the first three games of the post-season. Not even close. Bernie Williams had vanished, Chuck Knoblauch and Derek Jeter looked like impostors, and Tino Martinez had turned into a singles hitter, while Paul O'Neill had been pretty productive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, GLORIA
description: KLINGER-Gloria. On October 5, 1998. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Alan and Susan, Robyn & Jeffrey. Adoring grandmother of Zachary, Sara, Jesse, Joshua and Emily. Contributions to Cancer Care or American Lung Association. Services 11:30AM Wednesday at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Dining Car

title: Turning a Computer Problem Into a Campaign Issue in Connecticut
description: Candidates who thought they had their fall rap down pat smaller class sizes (good), health insurers (bad), new taxes (really bad) -- suddenly find themselves fielding a new issue: the millennium bug.

title: FOX ENTERTAINMENT TO RAISE $1.5 BILLION TO $2 BILLION
description: The News Corporation's Fox Entertainment Group Inc. plans to sell 13.4 percent of its common stock to investors, providing the first indication of the size of its initial public offering since it was announced in June. The stock offering will consist of 85 million class A common shares in the company, which produced the movie ''Titanic'' and the television show ''The Simpsons.'' The News Corporation, the world's fifth-largest media company, will hold 98.5 percent of Fox Entertainment's voting rights and an equity stake of 86.6 percent. The stock offering could raise between $1.5 billion and $2 billion, said Larry Petrella, an analyst for Lehman Brothers Inc. The company will assume about $4.5 billion in debt.

title: Business School At Arkansas U. Is Getting Gift Of $50 Million
description: The largest single gift to an American business school -- $50 million to the College of Business Administration of the University of Arkansas -- was announced yesterday by the Walton Family Charitable Support Foundation at a ceremony at the university's Fayetteville campus.

title: China's Central Bank Closes Guangdong Investment Firm
description: China shut the investment company of its richest province because the firm was unable to pay its debts. The closing is a sign of the growing strain in China's financial industry.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; The Truly Impeachable
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Aide Details Tactics on Clinton
description: The Republicans' chief investigative counsel held open the possibility today that Congress could still consider whether President Clinton abused the power of his office by asserting legal privileges in the investigation by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFFENKRANTZ, RUTH
description: OFFENKRANTZ-Ruth. On October 5, 1998 at Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Beloved wife of the late William Offenkrantz, M.D. Devoted mother of Ronald, Gary (1943-1949) and Jill. Loving grandmother of Paul and Jonathan and great grandmother of Alex, Emily, Eli and Noah. Funeral services Wednesday, October 7th at Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, LON
description: CLARK-Lon. On radio, ''Nick Carter-Master Detective.'' In life, master diplomat. Friend and beloved of countless through The Episcopal Actors' Guild. He was a stellar figure at The Players. And depending on the circustances, father or brother to me. David Wren, Philadelphia, PA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEWES, PAMELA
description: TEWES-Pamela, 37. On September 21, 1998. Beloved daughter of James & Rhondda, sister of Daniel H. & Robert B. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 10, 1998 at 3 PM in the Chapel of the West Park Presbyterian Church, 86 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Leave the Law Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Falling Elevator Hurts A Construction Worker
description: A construction worker was injured yesterday after being hit by a falling elevator at a work site in lower Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Neuberger Withdraws Plans to Go Public
description: Neuberger & Berman L.L.C. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its plans to sell shares to the public. The decision was driven by ''the volatility of the equity markets and its impact on the financial services sector in particular,'' the company said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is difficult to act as a great power when you constantly beg for aid.''

title: Raines Honors Boy Who Died
description: Tim Raines has ''TRA'' written across the front left side of his Yankee cap as a tribute to Tra Lemon, a 7-year-old from Sanford, Fla., who died of brain cancer on Monday. The Lemon family is friendly with the Raineses, so the Yankee told Tra's father that he would put the boy's name on his cap in honor of him. JACK CURRY

title: Le Pen May Be Charged for a Remark About the Holocaust
description: The European Parliament today lifted the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of France's far-right National Front, allowing a German prosecutor to open a criminal investigation against him on a charge of belittling the Holocaust.

title: Reinventing the Bear Claw With a Light, Airy Touch
description: MOST bear claws deserve their fierce designation. Dense, shellacked and prune-filled, they lurk under rectangular plastic covers on the counter tops of diners, each a leaden experience-in-waiting.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday about the Sanger Center, a leading gene research laboratory in Cambridge, England, reversed the identities of two scientists. Dr. John E. Sulston, the director, was on the left and Dr. Alan Coulson, a colleague, on the right.

title: Trade Group Forming For Internet Issues
description: A group of Internet marketing and promotion executives have formed the Internet Direct Marketing Bureau in New York, a trade organization that will address such issues as E-mail advertising and on-line privacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINDMAN, STANLEY
description: BINDMAN-Stanley. October 5, 1998 in Cincinnati, Ohio, formerly of Roslyn Heights, New York. Devoted husband of Miriam (nee Brodman); dear father of Regina and Lawrence Westerfeld and the late Jonathan; loving grandfather of Jill & Emily. Services Thursday 10AM, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Inquiry's Choice: Is the Law a Tool or Weapon?; Hillary Is My Sister
description: To the Editor:

title: The Formerly Staid Ma Bell Hatches a Secret Offspring
description: After more than 100 years, the AT&T brand is one of the most recognized in the world, a hallmark of corporate stability and might.

title: New Age Anthropology in Old Mexico
description: BY THE LIGHT OF MY FATHER'S SMILE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, LEONARD
description: LEVINSON-Leonard. Of Teaneck, NJ. Husband, father, brother, uncle, friend. He will be remembered as the kindest man anyone knew. He personified the word ''good''. He always smiled, even in his sleep. Our lives are forever enriched because this loving man was our husband and father. Julie, Kenneth & Mia

title: Advanced Micro in Surprise Gain as Chip Industry Recovers
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported an unexpected return to profitability in its third quarter today, helped by strong sales of the company's K6-2 microprocessor.

title: Smith Still Trying to Sign Top Pick
description: The Rangers were busy today trying to make their roster final for the season opener Friday night against the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden. As they continued to try to sign their first-round draft pick, Manny Malhotra, by Wednesday's midnight deadline they demoted five players to the minors, including Bill Berg.

title: N.H.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: ISLANDERS 1, DEVILS 0

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Isles Again Start Amid Confusion
description: This past summer began, as so many have for the Islanders, with talk of getting every player under contract by the start of training camp. The new owners -- Steven Gluckstern and Howard Milstein -- even considered adding a big-name free agent, a player who might help the Islanders reach the playoffs for the first time in five years.

title: Malaysia's Leader Betrays the Future
description: In the Vietnam War era, Anwar Ibrahim was a student leader in Malaysia, admired for his magnetism, Islamic faith and intense nationalism. He spent 22 months in jail under a Draconian law left over from the British period. After he gained his freedom, he entered politics, rising to become Deputy Prime Minister, building a reputation for tolerance and civility along the way. By the mid-1990's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was grooming him to be his heir.

title: Man Is Guilty in the Killing, For Sport, of a Firefighter
description: A 22-year-old Long Island man was convicted yesterday of murdering a total stranger -- an off-duty New York City firefighter out for a jog -- for no reason other than pure, random sport in January 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTIN, SYLVIA
description: KASTIN-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Jack (Jacob). Devoted mother of Howard, Malcolm and Steven. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister of Madison Weiss & Mitzi Friedman. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island today 11:30 AM.

title: Speckkuchen: Pizza Addendum
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Expected to Pass Bill To Shift Debt to Railroads
description: A bill that is likely to lead to a showdown between the Japanese Government and foreign investors has passed the Lower House of Parliament and is expected to win Upper House approval by the time the current legislative session ends later this month.

title: Istanbul Journal; Mayor Guilty of Godliness: What Next for Turkey?
description: Smiling broadly beneath her headscarf, Nafize Cayer leaned over a table in front of Istanbul's City Hall on a recent afternoon and signed a petition of support for her embattled Mayor.

title: BECKMAN COULTER TO CLOSE PLANTS AFTER ACQUISITIONS
description: Beckman Coulter Inc. said yesterday that it planned to close manufacturing operations in San Diego and Puerto Rico and cut 100 jobs. The closings, scheduled to be completed by the end of next year, represent an effort to adjust for excess capacity resulting from multiple acquisitions, the company said. Manufacturing operations in San Diego will relocate to Carlsbad, Calif., and Chaska, Minn., while Puerto Rico manufacturing operations will move to Carlsbad. Beckman, based in Fullerton, Calif., provides instrument systems for blood and other cell analysis. It has about 11,000 employees.

title: Tomatoes: The Long Goodbye
description: WHEN it comes to garden-fresh tomatoes, it's annual separation-anxiety time. Next week, maybe even this weekend, the last of the summer's sun-ripened beauties will be gone, and we'll be back to imports and hothouse tomatoes. Or no tomatoes: purists would argue, particularly after this summer's lush crop, that anything other than local, seasonal tomatoes isn't worth the bother.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Posman Books Is the New Tenant in the New School's Store
description: When New School University was seeking a tenant for a 2,000-square-foot retail store it owned at Fifth Avenue and 13th Street, it could have leased the space to a coffee bar or a hair salon at an annual rent of up to $95 a square foot, or $190,000. Instead, it chose a bookstore, a branch of Posman Books, for $66 a square foot, or $132,000.

title: State Appeals Ruling On Sexual Material
description: The State Attorney General yesterday appealed a court decision that overturned a ban on sexually explicit material for repeat sex offenders in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODLEY, MARY (NEE MCGRATH)
description: GODLEY-Mary (nee McGrath). Born Wilkes Barre, PA. Beloved wife of the late Thomas of Ballyronan-Ballyheigh, Tralee, County Kerry, Ireland. Loving mother of Rev. Robert J. Godley, MaryFrances Egan and Thomas Godley. Mass of the Resurrection on Thursday 9:30AM Church of the Sacred Heart, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Wednesday 7-9PM EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Interment Wilkes Barre, PA. Memorials to St. Barnabas Church Memorial Fund, Revolutionary Road, Ardsley, New York 10502 appreciated.

title: U.S., Citing Security, Shuts Saudi Embassy Briefly
description: Having received information that the United States Embassy in Saudi Arabia may be the target of a terrorist attack, the State Department said today that the embassy and two other diplomatic buildings will close on Wednesday, so security can be tightened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKEL, MORTIMER L.
description: MERKEL-Mortimer L. Age 84. Of Pembroke Pines, Fla., formerly of New York. On October 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth, cherished father of Howard and Jeffrey. Dear father-in-law of Suzanne and Jo-Ann. Loving grandfather of Allison, Andrew, Judd and Jessica. Devoted brother of Adrienne Berenbaum. A gentle man of uncommon grace and dignity, he was admired and respected by all who knew him.

title: Jones Deal May Be Down to a Final Haggle
description: Negotiations to settle the Paula Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton as described by both sides this week are increasingly coming to resemble the haggling in a new-car showroom.

title: House Votes $100 Million To Aid Foes of Baghdad
description: A bill that would allow the Clinton Administration to spend nearly $100 million to aid Iraqi opposition groups seeking the ouster of President Saddam Hussein is moving rapidly through Congress, with final approval virtually certain.

title: Law Would Require Taxi Riders to Wear Seat Belts
description: A taxi industry group has proposed a state law requiring cab passengers to wear seat belts, calling it a potential solution to the persistent problem of cab riders slamming their heads into the bullet-resistant partitions that separate the front seat from the back.

title: A Hard Job to Accept: A Slain Buddy's Show
description: To Jon Lovitz, Phil Hartman was more than a longtime comedy partner on ''Saturday Night Live'' in the 1980's, more even than a friend so close they often spent Thanksgiving and other holidays together.

title: Hoffa Says He Will Not Debate Candidates in Teamsters Race
description: James P. Hoffa, widely considered the front-runner in the race for the teamsters presidency, does not intend to participate in the Oct. 19 candidates' debate scheduled by the court-appointed officer overseeing the election, the Hoffa campaign announced yesterday.

title: Federico Zeri, Italian Art Historian, 77
description: Federico Zeri, an Italian art historian whose expertise was sought by many American museums and private collectors, died on Monday of a heart attack in his villa outside Rome, the news agency ANSA reported. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENTHAL, MARI
description: FREUDENTHAL-Mari, 95. Beloved wife of the late Josef. Loving mother of the late Jonathan and survived by loving nieces and nephews died Oct. 4 in Cincinnati, OH. Mari and Josef founded Transcontinental Music,Publishers of Hebrew Liturgical Music. Funeral service Thurs., October 8, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial, 5044 Broadway, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN ANDA, ALLEN D., SR.
description: VAN ANDA-Allen D., Sr. of Rumson, NJ formerly of Glen Ridge, NJ on October 5, 1998. Husband of Roberta H, Van Anda. Father of Paul A., James P., Allen D. Van Anda, Jr. and Lynn V.A. Garwood. Brother of Dorothy Dennison. Grandfather of six. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Central New Jersey 141 Bodman Place, Red Bank, NJ 07701 or to the Rumson First Aid Squad, c/o Rumson Boro Hall, 80 East River Road, Rumson, NJ 07760. Just as appreciated would be a kind gesture to the family at a later date.

title: The Youngest Team Has Youthful Lapses
description: The Giants are the youngest team in the National Football League, as they were a season ago, a fact usually delivered as compliment or commendation, as in:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZANOFF, PAUL E.
description: KAZANOFF-Paul E. A man of wit, dignity, high intelligence and commitment, with a passion for music and theater, on October 6, 1998. Son of Theodore and Lee and brother of Mark. Memorial service Thursday, October 8th, 7PM at The Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St, NYC. His family, friends and colleagues will miss him greatly.

title: Father-and-Son Officials Indicted in Betting Ring
description: A father who worked as a sheriff's officer in Essex County and his son, an assistant prosecutor there, were among 20 people indicted yesterday on charges of running a multimillion-dollar sports betting ring in Northern Jersey and New York, the State Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, HERMAN
description: BERGER-Herman. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Leonard & Joel and father-inlaw of Barbara and Hinda. Adored grandfather of Betsy and Michael Moreno, Amy and Lee Certilman, Dina and David Bortnichak and Lauren. Loving great grandfather of Andrew, Reid & Alex. Services Wednesday 11AM at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 Street & Mad Ave.

title: Albright Gives New Warning On Urgency In Mideast
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright issued a new warning today that the time for negotiating peace was running out, with both sides haggling over an interim agreement while a far more difficult subject, the permanent status of their relationship, had barely been broached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIT, MORRIS
description: LEWIT-Morris, 95. Passed away September 28 at home. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia Lewit. An intellectual, long time social activist, movement leader. We mourn the passing of this cherished comrade & family member.

title: CALENDAR
description: Art and Food for a Cause

title: Shares Are Mixed: Dow Is Up as Nasdaq Retreats Again
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday in a volatile session as the technology-heavy Nasdaq declined for a second consecutive day. Traders and analysts said investors remained nervous about a number of outstanding issues threatening the global and domestic economy, and were using brief rallies as an opportunity to sell shares.

title: N.B.A. Players Take Their Case to the Public
description: Patrick Ewing did not want to sound like a striking longshoreman demanding health benefits. ''I'm not going to try and put it in dollars and cents,'' he said. But Ewing, the president of the National Basketball Association Players Association, played the public-relations game today by expounding on the themes of labor unrest: strong-willed unity and shortsighted proposals.

title: Easter Seals Presents Awards
description: Easter Seals has named the recipients of its ninth annual E.D.I. Awards, for Equality, Dignity and Independence, which honor communications judged to enhance the independence of people with disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUDDEN, MARIE A.
description: TRUDDEN-Marie A. Of Farmingdale, on October 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eugene P. title: House G.O.P. May Soften on Spending to Clear Decks for Clinton Inquiry
description: With four days until temporary financing for the Government runs out, House Republican leaders today demonstrated a new willingness to resolve several of the spending issues that had pointed toward a Government shutdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOWALL, RODDY
description: McDOWALL-Roddy. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Bay Street Theater are deeply saddened by the loss of a dear friend, Mr. Roddy McDowall. His generosity of spirit, loyalty, humor and talent will be sorely missed. He will always be remembered for his contributions to the world of film and theater, and especially to this theater and this community.

title: The Woman Who Stalked Letterman Is a Suicide
description: The woman who was repeatedly jailed for stalking David Letterman over the last decade committed suicide on Monday by kneeling in front of a speeding train in western Colorado, the police said.

title: Racist E-Mail Is Sent to 13 at Boston College
description: It took minutes for a racist E-mail message to land in the mailboxes of 13 minority students at Boston College last Thursday. It took a few hours more before the whole campus knew about it.

description: HE chose this uniform as his symbol of the establishment, the mark of excellence. He was the outsider, and he loved the New York Yankees, the classic insiders.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON RISES 1.6 PERCENT. Prices rose to a six-week high as rains delayed the harvest of a crop already battered by bad weather. The December contract rose 1.17 cents, to 75.17 cents a pound.

title: Chef, Darling, Peel Me a Grape
description: WHEN Michael Eisner, the chairman of Disney, goes to La Grenouille, he doesn't look at the menu. Doesn't have to. The chef, Daniel Orr, designs a meal for him that is, unlike almost everything else on the menu, fat free.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, the savings and loan company, said it would close 161 branches in California next year to combine outlets too close to each other after its purchase of Home Savings of America.

title: Another Question in Thrillers: Where Did the Logic Go?
description: Alfred Hitchcock, as is well known, gave the playful name McGuffin to the element in a movie's plot that propels the action. A McGuffin can be one of two types, an event that unleashes a series of subsequent events (as in ''Strangers on a Train'') or (as in, say, ''Frenzy'' or ''Psycho'') a secret, a mystery, that must be revealed by the end. Either way, the unfolding of the intrigue must follow logically from the McGuffin, as it always did in Hitchcock. Things made sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, PEGGY KEASBEY
description: WHITE-Peggy Keasbey. 76. On 30 September in New York City. Beloved wife of King, mother of Kevin Frank and stepmother of David and Julie. Grandmother of Meghan Frank, Steven White and Thayer White. Her sense of humor and perseverance will be missed. Contributions in her memory can be made to the American Lung Association.

title: G.O.P. Says Democrats Should Return $1.7 Million More in Campaign Money
description: A House committee investigating campaign finance abuses has concluded in a report that the Democratic Party should have returned up to $1.7 million more in potentially tainted contributions than the $3.2 million the party gave back after President Clinton's re-election.

description: A humbled Jaret Wright shuffled off the field as the crowd hurled insults and taunts at him high and tight. All he could do was duck.

description: Making banking services available to citizens who need them has long been a worthy goal, but it will become even more important in January, when new rules require that most recipients of Federal benefits -- including Social Security -- have the money transferred to them electronically. Paper checks will no longer be available.

title: Action Deepens Regional Split Over Malaysia's Detention of Anwar : Habibie Cancels Visit to Kuala Lumpur
description: SINGAPORE  President B.J. Habibie has canceled a planned visit this month to Malaysia, the Indonesian foreign minister said Tuesday, in another blow to regional unity in Southeast Asia already strained by political and economic differences arising from the financial crisis.

title: After Beating Packers, Vikings Are Talking Super Bowl
description: While the Green Bay Packers spent this morning recovering from the hangover of one of the worst losses in the history of their franchise, the Minnesota Vikings were looking ahead. They are not content with beating the Packers. They will not be happy with winning the National Football Conference Central crown.

description: The Yankees can be compared to some of the greatest teams in history if they win the World Series. But it is unlikely the team that won 114 games in the regular season will remain intact.

title: Rents More Affordable, But Still High for Many
description: Rising wages meant that rent was affordable to more New Jerseyans last year, but, as a percentage of income, rents remained the second highest in the nation after Hawaii's, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Asea Brown Boveri Facing Antitrust Fine
description: Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., the world's largest electrical engineering company, will be fined by European Union antitrust regulators at the end of the month for fixing prices of insulated steel heating pipes, the European Competition Commissioner, Karel van Miert, said yesterday. Mr. van Miert would not comment on the amount of the fine, which he said had not been decided.

title: Witches as Bubbly Babes Toiling Away at Good Deeds
description: Nobody is calling the stars of ''Charmed'' lightweight, but when three red-blooded young witches stand inside a circle of fire, chanting to destroy an enemy, surely they should look and sound a little fiercer than college girls playing ''Charlie's Angels.''

title: The Lighthearted Approach
description: The starting pitchers for today's second game of the American League Championship Series took the lighthearted approach in some of their comments before last night's game. They tried their brand of humor in answers to questions at pre-game news conferences.

title: Reeves Is Returning With Resurgent Team
description: Here he comes. Here comes Dan Reeves, the former Giants head coach, back into Giants Stadium as the Atlanta Falcons head coach. The guy one of his former Giants players (Mike Sherrard) said ran a Big Ten offense. The guy one of his former Giants quarterbacks (Dave Brown) said offered an offense that was too cumbersome and too archaic to flourish.

title: Bank of Spain Cuts Short-Term Interest Rate
description: The Bank of Spain cut its benchmark short-term interest rate by half a percentage point yesterday, bringing Spanish interest rates closer to those of the other European nations that will adopt the euro, a single European currency, on Jan. 1. The reduction to 3.75 percent, from 4.25 percent, in the intervention rate, at which the bank supplies funds to the banking system, was the largest since December 1996. The cut reflects the global stock market slump, which has affected Spain along with the rest of Europe, and it brings Spain closer to the short-term rate average in France, Germany and the Netherlands, now at 3.3 percent. That average is expected to be the benchmark when the euro goes into effect.

title: Linden Ends His Holdout
description: Having already missed three weeks of training camp, and with no new offers coming from the Islanders, Trevor Linden, the team's captain, yesterday agreed to the team's offer of a one-year contract worth $2.5 million, plus incentives. His signing leaves Zigmund Palffy, the Islanders' leading scorer, as the only player yet to report to camp. After a month of stalled talks, the Islanders on Monday resumed negotiations with Palffy's agent, Paul Kraus, but the sides report they are far from reaching a new deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSNER, FRED
description: KASSNER-Fred. Passed away October 6, 1998 after a long illness. Mr. Kassner was Co-Founder of Liberty Travel and Go-Go Worldwide Vacations. He was a pioneer in the leisure travel business, and is recognized as revolutionizing the business by making package vacations available to the general public. Mr. Kassner was also an owner and operator of various steamship cruise lines, hotels, golf and country clubs and restaurants. He is survived by Gerda, his loving wife of 44 years, his daughters Ellen Teitelbaum and Michelle Kassner, his sister Trudy Carlyle, his brother Ernest Kassner, sons-inlaw David Teitelbaum and Christopher Gallagher, and three grandchildren. A funeral service will be held October 8th. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: White Captain Settles Suit With Promotion To Police Chief
description: Settling a discrimination lawsuit in United States District Court here, the city of East Orange agreed today to the forced retirement of its first black police chief and to the immediate promotion to chief of a white police captain who had accused the city of illegal discrimination eight years ago.

title: '60 Minutes' More
description: Because ''60 Minutes'' is the grand old monarch of all network news magazines, the growing pains of its offspring have been matters of great curiosity in the press. Just about any serious television news correspondent not already locked into a dream job has seen his or her name tossed out as a candidate for a correspondent's job on ''60 Minutes II,'' which is to take a midweek time slot on CBS early next year.

title: Senate Temporarily Blocks New Rules on Derivative Securities
description: The Senate temporarily blocked the Commodities Futures Trading Commission from regulating over-the-counter derivative securities today. The moratorium, contained in an agricultural spending bill that the Senate approved by a 55-to-43 vote, is effective until March 30 next year.

title: LYCOS PLANS $83 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR WIRED DIGITAL
description: Lycos Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Wired Digital Inc., a privately held Internet company, for $83 million in stock. In the deal, Lycos will issue additional stock equal to any Wired Digital cash on hand at the time of closing. Wired Digital, based in San Francisco, provides Internet-based products and services, including Hotbot, a so-called spider search engine. Lycos, based in Waltham, Mass., provides Web navigation as well as business and consumer electronic commerce products. Lycos said its Angelfire home pages and Mailcity E-mail applications were now offered to all Hotbot and Wired Digital users. Lycos's stock fell $1.8125 a share, to $30.125.

title: U.S. IS STEPPING UP MILITARY THREATS AGAINST THE SERBS
description: The Administration today intensified its threat to use force against the Yugoslav military and the police, as Washington continued diplomatic efforts to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to end the crackdown in Kosovo.

title: A Taste of San Francisco; Culinary Lights: North Beach Shines Again
description: NORTH BEACH is a gentle old Italian neighborhood that ambles up the hill from San Francisco Bay, in the shade of Telegraph Hill. Only 30 years ago, the small streets were lined with butchers who made their own sausages, and with bakeries that supplied every Italian restaurant in town. Old men played boccie in the park in front of the Church of Saints Peter and Paul, and argued over espresso in the sidewalk cafes along Columbus Avenue. The neighborhood was sprinkled with modest restaurants -- Columbus, U.S., Little Joe's -- where bachelors gathered nightly to talk politics and eat good, solid meals at low prices.

title: Suit Dismissed Against Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company won dismissal today of a lawsuit over the severance package for its former president, Michael Ovitz, estimated at $140 million. The decision came after unhappy shareholders failed to prove it was a waste of corporate assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, BERYL
description: OPPENHEIMER - Beryl. The members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute, and the professional staff and directors of the Treatment Center, past and present, express profound sorrow at the loss of our colleague and co-worker, Beryl Oppenheimer, ACSW, who served the Treatment Center as a social worker from 1968-1994 in which capacity she was devoted to patients, students and members alike. Lester Schwartz, MD President/Society Eslee Samberg, MD President/Institute

title: FLUOR CALLS OFF SALE OF ITS AMERICAN EQUIPMENT UNIT
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had discontinued efforts to sell its American Equipment unit after the leading bidder changed the terms of its offer, citing market circumstances. American Equipment is one of the nation's five largest suppliers of construction and mining equipment. Fluor had said in March that it wanted to sell the unit, which then had 55 offices in 13 countries and generated annual sales of $700 million. Fluor, in Irvine, Calif., is a global engineering, construction and coal-mining company. Its shares rose 81.25 cents, to $35.4375.

title: Behind Schumer Ads, 'a Long Island Thing'
description: UNDER the rules, Hank Morris is not allowed to say that the Senate race in New York is the campaign of a lifetime, the culmination of everything he has learned in politics, the potential breakthrough moment that could cement his reputation as a giant killer. Naturally, he does have other clients besides Charles E. Schumer, and it would be amateurish to stake one's reputation on a statistical dead heat, even if he is ahead by a few points.

title: Citizen Line Item Veto?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrangling Over I.M.F. Bill at Fever Pitch
description: Alarmed that their foot-dragging could drive international financial markets into still deeper turmoil, the Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans said they were working frantically today to agree on legislation to provide $18 billion in new funding to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Charles Delafield, 93, Utility Executive
description: Charles B. Delafield, a former executive for Consolidated Edison, died on Sept. 22 at Glengariff Health Care Center in Glen Cove, N.Y. Mr. Delafield, a resident of East Norwich, N.Y., was 93.

title: Wheeling Around In a Slipper Chair
description: Billy Baldwin favored slipper chairs -- low-legged, armless up-holstered chairs -- because they were less bulky than armchairs. A descendant is the Zondra chair, a slipper chair on wheels designed by Bob Williams for Mitchell Gold, a furniture maker. ''The inspiration was British colonial furniture in the Caribbean with bulky, turned wood legs,'' Mr. Williams said. The brown and black cushions are stitched to the chair. It's $665 at Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, 117 Mercer Street (near Spring Street.)

title: Metro Business; Cityscape Chapter 11 Plan
description: Cityscape Financial Corporation and its Cityscape Corporation unit filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.

title: A New Electronic Paperback To Read on Planes and Trains
description: The maker of a new electronic book is hoping it will become the dog-eared paperback of the digital age. Weighing in at less than a pound and costing under $200, the grandly named Millenium Reader, scheduled for release this fall by Librius Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., will be lighter and less expensive than its current competitors. Users will be able to go to the Librius storefront on the Internet, browse the virtual shelves and download encrypted texts to the Reader. The company estimates that each title will cost about 30 percent less than bound copies of the same text. The Reader can hold up to 4,000 pages, and other purchases can be stored by the user on the Librius server.

title: Sports of The Times; Braves Need Yankees To Affirm Greatness
description: TONY GWYNN stood outside a batting cage discussing the story line of this National League Championship Series between his San Diego Padres and the Atlanta. The story line is pitching: in John Smoltz, Tom Glavine and Greg Maddux, Atlanta has one of the greatest rotations of all time.

title: Meeting of World Finance Leaders Ends, With No Grand Strategy but Many Ideas
description: The world's finance ministers and central bankers ended five days of debate today with nothing approaching a strategy to lift the global markets out of their downward spiral, but a with a plethora of new ideas that some officials insisted would ultimately bear fruit.

title: Digital Magic: From Teen-Age Witch to Barbie
description: I WAS far too young to appreciate the stir that the Beatles caused when they landed in America, so I missed out on the early training that might have better prepared me for celebrity worship. By the time I glimpsed someone famous nearby -- Warren Beatty in a restaurant -- I was already an adult and felt no urge to (1) scream hysterically, (2) run up to him and sob, ''I love you,'' or (3) rip out my own hair.

description: Members of Congress expressed doubts today about Russia's continued role in the international space station as NASA officials defended plans to help Russia finish important components of the program and reduce future dependence on the cash-strapped nation in completing the orbiting outpost.

title: Clintons Delicately Lobby Democrats for Support
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton today undertook the delicate job of persuading wavering Democrats to support the President on the vote set for Thursday to authorize a broad impeachment inquiry without actually pleading for their votes.

title: Hands on Hips, the Yankees Give One Away
description: Bill Buckner is doomed to infamy for letting a grounder go through his legs in the 1986 World Series. Because of a mental blunder Chuck Knoblauch committed in the Yankees' playoff game early last night, he is destined for a similar fate if the Yankees go on to lose the American League Championship Series to Cleveland.

title: Economic Turmoil's Latest Turns Raise the Level of Anxiety in U.S.
description: The world economic crisis spread a nervousness in America yesterday that played out in odd ways.

title: A Fund-Raising Frankenstein
description: Campaign fund-raising techniques seem to be getting worse by the day. Unannounced Presidential hopefuls for the year 2000 are setting up political action groups that dodge through loopholes in the law to solicit large donations from a small number of wealthy supporters. Coupled with a new schedule of rapid-fire late winter primaries, these new gambits are creating a perpetual Presidential campaign financed by political insiders, while the voting public's role gets smaller and smaller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, JEROME, DR.
description: HURWITZ-Jerome, Dr. The Jewish Braille Institute of America, rocords with sorrow the loss of a much loved honorary Life Trustee and former officer. His devotion over many years helped to create new opportunities for the blind and visually impaired worldwide. His essential involvement in the establishment of the JBI Low Vision Clinic at the Sourasky TelAviv Medical Center, brought a higher quality of low vision care to Israel. To his devoted wife Hortense, a trustee of our agency, and his family, we extend profound sympathy sure in the knowledge that his memory will serve as a blessing. Barbara B. Friedman, Acting Pres. Dr. Jane Evans, Honorary Pres. Gerald M. Kass, Exec Vice Pres.

title: Dollar Drops 8% in Day Against Yen
description: The dollar plunged 8.1 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday, its biggest one-day decline in 25 years.

description: Roger Vivier, a leading shoe designer whose innovations in heel and toe shapes changed the silhouette of women's shoes, died on Friday at his home in Toulouse, France. He was 90.

Now, Mr. Stewart, who at 46 appears no less the determined musician of his younger days, is once again teasing at the creative edges of yet another emerging mass medium: the Internet.

title: Democrat Loses Ground In Illinois Senate Race
description: She says he is ''duplicitous,'' a ''wolf in sheep's clothing'' who has resorted to ''scuzzball'' campaign tactics in the past. He has described her as ''shrill,'' contending that she has ''nothing positive to say about her own record'' and saying her career has been ''obscured by numerous scandals and controversies.''

title: Music Made Easier; It's All In the Mix
description: FOR years Josh Gabriel, a musician and computer programmer, had looked for a way to make composing and recording music as simple for the average person as desktop publishing had made producing newsletters.

title: Interpublic Combines 2 Media Service Units
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that as expected it would combine two big media services units -- Western International Media in Los Angeles and Initiative Media Worldwide in Paris -- to form an agency that would be the world's largest in terms of total media billings handled.

title: Detained Immigrants Still Not Eating in Protest
description: On the third day of a protest to pressure immigration authorities into granting them parole, about 35 asylum seekers at an Immigration and Naturalization Service in Jamaica, Queens, continued to refuse to eat yesterday.

title: I.M.F. Needs Reform, Not Money; Russia's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: APOLLO TAKES 20% STAKE IN BERLITZ FOR $100 MILLION
description: Berlitz International Inc., the world's biggest language-services company, said yesterday that a Leon Black buyout fund would invest $100 million for a 20 percent stake and that its largest shareholder, Benesse Holdings International Inc., would invest $55 million to help the company expand. Under the agreement, Berlitz, which is based in Princeton, N.J., will issue $100 million of convertible debentures to Apollo Management IV L.P., a closely held New York investment firm. Benesse will buy $55 million of convertible debentures under similar terms. If the debentures were fully converted into stock, Apollo would own about 20 percent of Berlitz's shares, while the Benesse Holdings stake would fall to about 60 percent from 73 percent. Berlitz shares closed unchanged at $26.

title: With New Disk Drive, Inventor Of Floppy Competes With Itself
description: The inventor of the 3.5-inch floppy disk, Sony, is joining the already crowded battle to dislodge that floppy as the removable computer storage device of choice. This week, Sony and Fujifilm officially unveiled HiFD, a floppy disk on steroids that holds about 140 times as much information as a conventional disk, and the HiFD disk drive.

title: Metro Business; An ESPN Sports Bar Is Set for Times Sq.
description: Disney and its subsidiary, ESPN, the cable sports network, announced plans yesterday to open an upscale sports bar called ESPN Zone in Times Square next summer.

title: Top Pick Is Signed In Last-Minute Deal
description: The Rangers signed Manny Malhotra, their top draft pick, to a three-year contract just before last night's midnight deadline, insuring that the 18-year-old center would play in tomorrow night's season opener against the Philadelphia Flyers at the Garden.

title: A Contemporary Bookstore
description: WWW.MOSAICBOOKS.COM

title: Firefighters Who Wore Blackface Defend Their Actions
description: A New York City firefighter who is facing dismissal for wearing blackface at a Labor Day parade in Queens testified yesterday that he did not mean to offend anyone when he grabbed the back of a pickup truck and dangled in an apparent parody of the killing of a black man in Jasper, Tex., who was dragged to his death from a pickup truck.

title: G.M. is beginning a $135 million campaign to ballyhoo the redesigned Chevrolet Silverado.
description: THE General Motors Corporation plans to begin one of the largest advertising campaigns ever in the auto industry this evening, a $135 million effort to promote a complete redesign of the company's best-selling vehicle, the full-sized Chevrolet Silverado pickup truck.

title: Who You Gonna Call? Graffitibusters!
description: Graffiti artists, watch out: On Sept. 26, in Elmhurst, Queens, Sanitation Commissioner John Doherty showed off a new weapon in the war against graffiti -- the anti-graffiti unit (inset), a veritable paint store on wheels. Mr. Doherty, left, showed how an electronic sensor, which determines the color of the under-lying paint on a wall, can order up the right color from the truck, which has a computer, paint mixer, paints, brushes, cans and a sink. ''The computer reads the wall color, and spits out a recipe of the formula,'' said Paula Young, assistant commissioner of public affairs for the Sanitation Department. More than 200 volunteers showed up to start painting a 50-block area that Ms. Young said was ''vibrant with graffiti.'' The truck is available to community groups through the Mayor's office. Information: (212) 788-7418.

title: Ballot Battle in New York
description: So here we are again, edging toward Election Day with no firm idea of what the ballots in New York City will look like. In particular, the referendum section, often tucked down at the lumbago level of the ballot, is still very much in doubt. The cause for this confusion is a highly vocal and political battle between Council Speaker Peter Vallone and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.

title: German Federation Suspends Pippig After She Fails a Random Drug Test
description: Uta Pippig, the German runner who won the 1993 New York City Marathon and three Boston Marathons, was suspended yesterday by the German track and field federation after failing a random out-of-competition drug test.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROY, RABBI ALBERT.
description: TROY-Rabbi Albert. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague who served Temple B'nai Abraham in Meriden, CT from 1951-1977 after his army chaplaincy during World War II where he dedicated himself to helping Displaced Persons. After his retirement, he was instrumental in the establishment of a number of synagogues in the South Florida area. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Deborah, Naomi and Melanie and to his sister Rosalyn. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Boston's Smart-Card Meters Don't Need Quarters
description: Students at Boston University can save their quarters for video games. The City of Boston and Fleet Financial Group recently unveiled 200 new smart-card parking meters near the university. The cards incorporate a microchip that allows users to store up to $100 electronically.

title: AMP Shares Rise on Optimism Bill Could Help Allied's Bid
description: Shares of AMP Inc. rose as much as 6.3 percent yesterday as investors expressed optimism that legislation passed by the Pennsylvania House of Representatives late Tuesday could help Allied Signal in its $9.7 billion hostile takeover bid for the company.

title: Blowing in the Wind: Post-Modern 'Huts' in New Caledonia
description: Where do the trees end and the buildings begin? Renzo Piano, the Italian architect who won this year's Pritzker Prize, has designed the Tjibaou Cultural Center (above) in Noumea, New Caledonia. The center's 10 semitransparent structures (made of wood, glass, concrete and steel) are so airy the wind literally blows through their fragmented tops. The houses, as he calls them, are inspired by Kanak Indian culture and the nearby pine trees.

title: Celebrating a Sculptor of the City
description: To the north towered the United Nations. Traffic whooshed by on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, to the east. Directly overhead was the ventilating tower of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Back to the Store

title: Fred Kassner, 71, Who Made Travel Affordable for Many
description: Fred Kassner, the co-founder of Liberty Travel and a pioneer in bringing many of the world's exotic vacation spots within reach of people of modest means, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Leave Impeachment Inquiry to the House; Lying Under Oath
description: To the Editor:

title: To Devils, Net Looks Very Small
description: Robbie Ftorek, who took over as coach of the Devils from Jacques Lemaire, has promised more scoring, but he has inherited a team that is geared for defense. It will take more than a few weeks before Ftorek establishes his game.

title: Citizen Line Item Veto?
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgrade Bars U.N. War-Crimes Investigators
description: Belgrade has told the war crimes tribunal here that United Nations investigators will not be allowed to look into reported war crimes in Kosovo, and it has refused to grant the visas that the court has requested, tribunal officials said today.

title: Buying a Lemon
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is great news. But I have a 23-year-old son, and I'm periodically shocked when he says things, like, 'It's not a problem anymore, right Mom?' ''

title: PRESIDENT URGES 'CONSCIENCE' VOTE ON HOUSE INQUIRY
description: President Clinton today gave House members public leeway to ''cast a vote of principle and conscience'' on a Republican-drafted impeachment inquiry Thursday. But White House advisers and Democratic House leaders worked hard to draw as many party members as possible to vote instead for a more limited investigation.

title: Finding a Way Out of Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, JOSEPH P.
description: KEARNEY-Joseph P. Of Tiburon, CA on October 3rd in Washington, D.C. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Michele Kearney (nee Trutanic). Loving son of Mary Agnes & the late John E. Kearney. Devoted father of Michael Joseph Kearney. Loving brother of John T., James V. and Kevin M. Kearney. Dear uncle of Rosemarie, Maureen, Cathey, Jennifer, James, Megan, Kate, Christine, Elisa & Sean. Mass of Christian burial will take place in Washington, DC, Thursday, October 8. Funeral Services, Saturday, October 10th, at 10 AM, from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Interment to follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. Visiting Fri, October 9 only from 7-9 PM.

title: Netanyahu and Arafat Break Bread for First Time
description: Signaling an unexpected thaw in a long frosty relationship, Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat broke bread together for the first time today, after Mr. Netanyahu became the first Israeli Prime Minister to cross over to the Palestinian side of the Erez checkpoint for a meeting.

title: The Urgent Agenda in Kosovo
description: With confusion and division growing over what to do about the Serbian assault on the people of Kosovo, it is essential not to lose sight of the most urgent issue, which is saving lives. Tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians have been driven from their homes in Kosovo by Serbian forces, and many will soon perish in the cold forests if the Serbs do not withdraw. Making it possible for the refugees to return home, and getting international assistance to them, should be the overriding objectives of Western diplomacy and potential military action.

title: Now Appearing on the Strip: Czarist Treasures!; On a Night Out in Vegas, Don't Miss the Romanovs or Miro
description: At the Orleans Hotel and Casino, a blocky behemoth a mile or so off the famous Strip and a notch or two down the luxury ladder, the first Las Vegas Film Festival concluded on a recent weekend with a fitting bit of self-celebration. The honoree at the closing night banquet was the director George Sidney, a local resident whose signature film was ''Viva Las Vegas,'' a 1964 vehicle for Elvis Presley and Ann-Margret.

title: Liar's Poker Contest
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Firm Denied Construction Permit
description: The State Casino Control Commission denied a license yesterday for casino construction services sought by a Brooklyn drywall company, asserting that it has ties to organized crime.

title: Leave Impeachment Inquiry to the House
description: To the Editor:

title: Why March? 'People Are Fed Up With This Business'
description: With his long hair and dark blue beret, Vladimir Tyuterev, 31, didn't look like most of the other demonstrators at today's mass protest in Moscow.

title: Unwell, Clinging, Drifting and Bingeing
description: ''Holding On'' is a determined exercise in nonjudgmental documentary making. In what he calls ''A Love Story From the Street,'' John Baynard, the producer and director, delivers scenes from five years of the hazy driftings of Donna Mercier and Luis Santiago, from a tent on a Boston street to briefly occupied apartments to campgrounds; the two hold on to each other except when Mr. Santiago is doing time for shoplifting.

title: California's Tobacco Initiative
