description: The demise of national tobacco control legislation puts the burden on states to find new strategies to reduce smoking and its harmful consequences. The California Children and Families Initiative, which will be on the November ballot as Proposition 10, provides a model that other states could emulate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKHEIMER, FRANK H.
description: LOCKHEIMER-Frank H. October 5th, 1998 of Teaneck, N.J. Prior to retiring in 1972, he was in charge of Gulden's Mustard Division of American Home Foods. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Wiecoreck). Devoted father of Gary and F. Roy Lockheimer. Loving grandfather of F. Hiroshi Lockheimer. Religious services Saturday, 11 A.M., at the Tower Chapel in George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visitiation Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, N.J.

title: Far Becomes Much Nearer As Web Touches an Island
description: THE on-line equivalent of Mount Everest has been climbed. Tristan da Cunha, where people live farther away from anywhere else than anywhere else, is on the Internet.

title: Orfeo Gets Euridice; Audience Gets Nudes
description: Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, is determined to make his company an up-to-date center for opera as theater. So he did not flinch over the director Martha Clarke's ideas for staging Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice,'' including one extended scene involving fully nude dancers. A co-production with the English National Opera, it was first presented in London last year, and introduced at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night. Ms. Clarke's controversial direction, and the production in general, will be the most fruitful subjects for discussion because the musical performance, despite some lovely singing by the soprano Amy Burton as Euridice, was disappointingly lackluster.

title: Cyberagencies Match Families With Modern Mary Poppinses
description: TERESA JOHNSON never wanted to be a nanny. After graduating from Oral Roberts University, she spent four years teaching band at a Christian school in Madison, Wis. When she wanted a new teaching job, possibly one that would take her overseas, she began her job hunt on the Internet.

title: Caminiti's Home Run In the 10th Lifts Padres
description: The Atlanta Braves staged an improbable rally for a ninth-inning run off San Diego's usually implacable closer, Trevor Hoffman, to send Game 1 of the National League Championship Series into extra innings. But with one swing in the top of the 10th this morning, Ken Caminiti made sure that the Padres would keep intact their two-and-a-half-year streak of never losing a game in which they carried the lead into the ninth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMMEL, DR. ROBERT C., MD.
description: EMMEL-Dr. Robert C., MD. In Bloomfield, CT, October 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Sarah Noyes Emmel. Father of Barbara Wolinsky, Dr. David Emmel, Dr. Alfred Emmel II, Richard Emmel. Memorial service Saturday, Oct. 24th, 1 P.M., Westminster Presbyterian Church, West Hartford, CT.

title: Aiming for a design That Doesn't Scream 'Asia'
description: Bop, a new Korean restaurant, looks Asian but by indirection. Brad Kelley, the owner, left, did not want Bop to look like his two other restaurants, Khin Khao (Thai) and Kelley & Ping (Chinese). ''They screamed 'Asia,' '' Mr. Kelley said. At Bop, the Asian design is by allusion. ''I didn't want to knock people in the head that it was Asian,'' Mr. Kelley said, ''but a Korean person could come here and see elements that were familiar.''

title: Tyson Appeals Evaluation's Release
description: Mike Tyson's lawyers filed an appeal with the Nevada Supreme Court in Carson City yesterday, seeking to set aside a lower court ruling that ordered the former heavyweight champion's psychiatric evaluation to be made public in advance of a hearing on the reinstatement of his boxing license before the Nevada State Athletic Commission.

title: THE DOCTOR IS IN
description: Think of it as a doctor's office with the world's largest waiting room. America's Doctor Online is a new service provided to members of America Online. Found on AOL's Health channel, America's Doctor Online (keyword: amdoc) will provide AOL users with free access to certified primary-care doctors, either through E-mail correspondence or through real-time conversations in chat rooms.

title: Bad Play Exposes Missed Chances
description: For six months, baseball lived -- thrived -- on home runs. The Mark and Sammy show epitomized the theme of the season and captivated the country. Home runs, however, were not the deciding factor in the latest game. That was the one played yesterday at Yankee Stadium, and the outcome turned on bunts and lack thereof.

title: Myron E. Scott, 91, Ohioan Who Created Soap Box Derby
description: Myron E. Scott, an Ohio-born photographer who had such an uneventful career he probably wouldn't have attracted much attention if there hadn't been a couple of inspired blips in an otherwise satisfyingly humdrum life, died on Sunday at his home in Kettering, Ohio. He was 91.

title: For Buppies With a Capital 'P'
description: WWW.BUPPIE.COM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWEY, ROSL IROM.
description: LOWEY-Rosl Irom. On October 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Hans. Devoted mother of Sue and Peter Gutlon and Janet and Andrew Edelman. Loving (Mimi) of Michael and Tommy Fankhauser, Daniel and Valerie Edelman. Cherished sister of Robert and Eve Irom. We will miss her strength and wisdom. Services Thursday, October 8, 10 A.M. at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, N.Y. For further information call the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144.

title: Needle Exchange Plan To Fight AIDS Advances
description: In defiance of the Governor who appointed him, the chairman of a state advisory panel vowed yesterday to continue supporting needle exchange programs to curb the spread of AIDS.

title: Judge Blocks Giuliani Move Over Stadium
description: On a day when he had hoped to revel in the playoff exploits of the Yankees, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was instead rebuked yesterday by a state judge, who ruled that the Mayor's maneuvers to block a referendum on the future of Yankee Stadium were improper, and said the issue should go to the voters next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSSON, ELIZABETH C.
description: CROSSON-Elizabeth C., 77. Of Wilton, Connecticut. Formerly of Staten Island. Wife of the late Francis J. Crosson, Sr. Died Wednesday. Mother of Francis J. Crosson, Jr. MD and Matthew T. Crosson, Esq. Sister of Thomas F. Curley and Ann C. Brown. Grandmother of two. Mass Saturday 9:00 AM Our Lady of Fatima, Wilton. Visiting hours Friday 4:00-8:00 PM at Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave, Norwalk, CT. (I-95 Exit 16).

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Tomatoes Rampant

title: Making Books; Serial Sleuths, Spreading Glee
description: Few things bring a merry heart to a fiction publisher quicker than the coming of a character who will endure in novel after novel and, if truly lucky, in movie after movie. Most such characters are in murder inventions or other thrillers, usually noir. But sometimes they perpetuate and flourish in adventure make-believes.

title: Leave Impeachment Inquiry to the House; No Privacy Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki's Economic Adviser Is Subpoenaed in Contract Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed Gov. George E. Pataki's senior economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, in their inquiry into the awarding of a $97 million state contract to a Long Island company owned by a major Republican political contributor, officials said yesterday.

title: Nikkei Soars After Japan Edges Closer to a Bank Bailout
description: The governing party edged closer today to injecting massive amounts of money into the Japanese banking system, and that prospect sent investors rushing into markets with greater hopes of an economic recovery.

title: Essay; Reno's John Huang
description: Remember John Huang?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFON, FLORENCE, AKA FLORENCE REIMAN.
description: GEFFON-Florence, aka Florence Reiman. On Oct. 7, 1998. Survived by her husband Sam Geffon, wife of the late Irving M. Reiman. Mother of, and to, Leslie and Jim Quest, Jim and Sherrill Reiman, Billy and Cheryl Geffon. Grandmother to Annie & Matt, Daniel & Ellen, Ben and Jean. Great-grandmother to Kora, Aidan, Trevor & Dylan. We will all miss her as long as we live. Services Friday, October 9, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Isles' Arena In Talk Stage
description: National Hockey League and Nassau County officials will meet again next week to formulate the financing for a new arena for the Islanders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZMAN, CAROLYN
description: SCHWARTZMAN-Carolyn. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Carolyn Schwartzman, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Some Concern About Quarterback
description: Quarterbacks have long been a strength at Virginia Tech, but the team's latest starter was reclaimed from the defense and pressed into emergency duty tonight against Boston College.

title: Federal Anti-Bias Spending Is Inadequate, Groups Say
description: With President Clinton and his advisory board on race recommending sharp increases in programs to enforce anti-discrimination laws, civil rights groups are expressing disappointment that Congress has approved only modest increases for agencies like the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONTANA, FLORA
description: FONTANA-Flora. Adored wife of Joseph, died in Florida October 6, 1998. Lost her courageous battle to cancer. Distinguished career as Public Relations Director and Special Assistant to Regine's. Viewing October 9th, 9-11AM at Hillebrand Funeral Home, 63-17 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. Interment St. John's Cloister, Queens.

title: A Grand Grand Central
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Inquiry Focuses On 8 Chicken Heads
description: Police in Union City are investigating whether eight severed chicken heads and an unlighted candle that were placed beneath the bench of a municipal court judge this week were part of a Santeria ritual or simply a prank.

title: I.M.F. Needs Reform, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Dreaming of Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Half a Nation, Condemned
description: Even as we overdose on the coverage of the frenzied, sex-based madness in Washington, the tragic subjugation of nearly the entire female population of Afghanistan goes scarcely noticed.

title: U.S.-Iraq Talks Fail to End Stalemate on Arms
description: After 10 days of talks, Iraq and the United Nations said today that they had failed to break a two-month impasse that prevented spot searches for weapons of mass destruction.

title: Finding a Way Out of Depression; Stolen Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Shows on Architects, Tribal Antiques Sale
description: Spotlight on Gilbert

title: Clinton's Aides and G.O.P. Try to Resolve Budget Issues
description: With temporary financing of the Government due to expire at midnight on Friday, Republican leaders met tonight with White House officials in their first high-level effort to resolve a dozen crucial spending issues and avoid a Government shutdown.

title: Raytheon Widens Layoffs; Lower Earnings Foreseen
description: Continuing to struggle in its construction operation and in its attempts to build a lean, integrated military electronics business, the Raytheon Company said yesterday that it would expand layoffs and would not meet Wall Street's expectations for third-quarter earnings.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT JUMPS 3.8 PERCENT. Prices rose on speculation that the U.S. might donate food to Russia, which could help reduce abundant supplies. The December contract rose 11.75 cents, to $2.955 a bushel.

title: Finding a Way Out of Depression; In Wake of Disability
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, THE REVEREND MONSIGNOR JOHN A.
description: CARLIN-The Reverend Monsignor John A., on October 6, 1998. Dear brother of Susan Carlin and the late Sr. Mary Grace R.D.C., Sr. Mary Germaine, R.D.C. & Bernard Carlin, Jr. Reposing Thursday 2-5 P.M. at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of the Eucharist Thursday 7:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Church (Riverdale Ave., Yonkers) & Mass of Christian Burial Friday at 10 A.M. at St. Peter's Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Quartey Is Not Intimidated
description: Ike Quartey was at ringside when Julio Cesar Chavez called it quits from his corner stool during his fight with Oscar De La Hoya on Sept. 18 in Las Vegas, Nev. It was a good showing by De La Hoya, but Quartey was not overly impressed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDY, VICTORIA
description: HANDY-Victoria. Suddenly, on October 1st, 1998, in Minnesota. Survived by her husband, Martin Clough. Devoted daughter of Dorothy Handy. Cherished sister of Barbara Matonis, Cathy Handy and Jennifer Handy. Also survived by niece, Melinda and nephew, Eric Matonis. She was a devoted and loving school teacher in Farmington, Minnesota. Visitation Thursday, 2-5 & 7-9PM at Joseph Farenga & Sons, Inc. (queens chapel), 38-08 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria. Funeral Mass 10:15 AM, at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: A Quick Turnaround; In Only 4 Months, Greenspan Changes Economic Tune
description: Testifying before Congress in June, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called the American economy the best he had ever seen. Less than four months later he is trying to avert a slowdown that some economists now fear could easily turn into a recession.

title: U.S. Closer to Tying Bin Laden to Embassy Bombings
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday that one of the men accused of conspiring to bomb the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August had met in 1996 with Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the attacks, and ''asked him for a mission.''

title: Players and Owners Finally Meet Again
description: Like two schoolchildren forced to reconcile in the principal's office, the players and owners of the National Basketball Association will try to bridge their differences today. In a bargaining session at a Manhattan hotel, they will meet for the first time since Aug. 6.

title: An Aggressive Defense Can Be the Only Defense
description: It has long been recognized that British bridge books are very attractive in quality but very unattractive in cost. An American publisher has circumvented this problem by assembling some of the best British bridge books of recent years in one massive hardcover. It is simply called ''Bridge,'' and its 647 large pages include writing by such authorities as Tony Sowter, Freddie North, Brian Senior, Sally Brock, Alan Mould, Robert Berthe, Norbert Lebely, Raymond Brock and Barry Rigal.

title: Restless Energy in a Topsy-Turvy World
description: ''Dancing for Bessie'' was the overall title of the program that the Randy James Dance Works offered on Sunday afternoon at Clark Studio Theater. The matinee honored Bessie Schonberg, a teacher of dance composition who died last year and who served as artistic adviser to this group from Highland Park, N.J.

title: 16 Are Charged in Bribery Scheme at Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn
description: Saying that he had found corruption in his own backyard, the chief Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn charged yesterday that six Federal employees had taken bribes from contractors on renovation and repair jobs in Federal buildings, including some payoffs received in the halls of the courthouse where the case will be tried.

title: In Close Race, D'Amato Seems The Main Issue
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer are locked in an extraordinarily tight race for the United States Senate. The outcome apparently rests with a small group of undecided voters, many of whom are not yet paying attention to the contest, a statewide New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Review/Fashion; Evoking Glamour a la Cher
description: No one seems to be in the business of subsidizing creative genius anymore, a situation brought home by the demise last week of Isaac Mizrahi's business, a tale that is being mourned and dissected here by designers, editors and retailers alike.

title: Top 2 Seeds Eliminated
description: Pete Sampras and Patrick Rafter, the top two players in men's tennis, were upset yesterday in the opening round of the $1 million Swiss Indoors tournament in Basel.

title: Martin Was Unbrakable, Even With Thigh Injury
description: It turns out that Curtis Martin carried 34 times against the Miami Dolphins last Sunday after injuring his right thigh on the second play of the game.

title: The Global Village Goes Pop Baroque
description: ''JON JERDE,'' Steve Wynn declared grandly, ''is the Bernini of our time.'' He continued: ''These are the cathedrals of our time. This is the future of architecture.''

title: A Festival, Exhibitions And Talks
description: Art and Architecture

title: Tigers Interview Davey Johnson
description: The Tigers said yesterday that Davey Johnson was a finalist for their vacant managerial position.

title: Hockey Publication Sold
description: GTC Transcontinental Group Ltd. said today that its Transcontinental Publications Inc. unit had acquired Hockey Business News, a trade publication covering the ice, in-line and street hockey industries. Terms were not disclosed. The seller was Straight Line Communications of Los Angeles, which started the magazine in 1994. Eight times a year, Hockey Business News provides news of the business of hockey to 10,000 owners, managers, retailers and others.

title: Oil Merger Raises European Concerns
description: The British Petroleum Company's $60 billion planned purchase of the Amoco Corporation is raising European Union worries that the combined company could control an excessive share of the European petrochemicals market, an European Union official said yesterday. The merged company's potential dominance of that market is the main focus of the antitrust investigation, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: Sports of The Times; A No-Brainer Of His Own Creation
description: ALONG with the anxiety of a series taken for granted that has suddenly turned scary comes the time-honored tradition of the second-guess. As in: try to guess what Chuck Knoblauch could have possibly been thinking as he staked the outcome of a 4-hour-28-minute marathon on the assumption that an umpire's call would go his way.

title: Emergency Preparedness
description: Q. How do I make an emergency boot floppy?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: A Voyage Through Time, Undertaken With a Grand Vision
description: Much has been made of Bill T. Jones's recent turn toward abstraction after a series of full-evening dramatic dances, parables for our time that explored a variety of social themes. But those who have seen his shorter pieces could not have been surprised by Mr. Jones's latest work, ''We Set Out Early . . . Visibility Was Poor,'' performed by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next Wave Festival.

title: CONSTRUCTION COMPANIES REACH $122.5 MILLION DEAL
description: Cornerstone Construction and Materials Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the United States unit of the British builder Alfred McAlpine P.L.C. for $122.5 million. Cornerstone, in Neptune, N.J., is a unit of Hanson P.L.C., the British building materials company. It is one of the largest producers of sand and gravel for construction in the United States. McAlpine's United States subsidiary is divided into two units: Becker Minerals, an aggregates producer, and Blythe Construction, a construction company. On completion of the acquisition, Cornerstone will sell Blythe for $40 million to Hubbard Group Inc.

title: Nagy Puts His Past Failures Behind
description: The Indians' ragtag pitching staff looks as if it were composed of scraps that could be used for a quilt when compared with the seamless group the Yankees have on call.

title: Out of Prison, Priest Reopens Homeless Shelter
description: To Federal agents and prosecutors, the Rev. Patrick Moloney is a rogue priest who was linked to an audacious robbery that pumped $5 million into the coffers of Irish Republican Army terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONOMO, MARGARET, 95 YEARS OLD, (NEE GUERRIERI).
description: BONOMO-Margaret, 95 years old, (nee Guerrieri). Beloved wife of the late Salvator. Devoted mother of Dr. Thomas and Carol Albright. Loving grandmother of Mary Ann Donovan, Thomas Jr, Edward Ahearn, Kathryn O'Brien, Sally Effman, Michael and Stephen. Cherished great-grandmother of Kathryn & John Donovan, Alexandra, Margo & Thomas III Bonomo, Bennett & Max Ahearn, Michael, Matthew, Daniel & Claire O'Brien, and Zackary Effman. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC Thursday 79:30PM, Friday 2-5 & 7-9:30PM. Funeral mass Saturday 9:30AM St. Anthony's R.C. Church. Interment in Calvary Cemetery.

title: Amazon Ponders Effects Of Rivals' Planned Mergers
description: If the stock market is to be believed -- and that's rarely a good bet -- the prospect of mergers among on-line merchants in both books and music is dire news for Amazon.com Inc., the most popular store on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSNER, FRED
description: KASSNER-Fred. Passed away on October 6, 1998 after a long illness. Mr. Kassner was Co-Founder of Liberty Travel and Go-Go Worldwide Vacations. He was a pioneer in the leisure travel business, and is recognized as revolutionizing the business by making package vacations available to the general public. Mr. Kassner was also an owner and operator of various steamship cruise lines, hotels, golf and country clubs & restaurants. He is survived by Gerda, his loving wife of forty-four years, his daughters Ellen Teitelbaum & Michelle Kassner, his sister Trudy Carlyle, his brother Ernest Kassner, sonsin-law David Teitelbaum and Christopher Gallagher, and three grandchildren. A funeral service will be held October 8th. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: Board Tells Englewood School To Form Own Integration Plan
description: Rejecting a proposal that would have created an integrated regional school district in eastern Bergen County, New Jersey's Board of Education today ordered the city of Englewood to prepare its own plan for integrating its high school.

title: AIDS Deaths in U.S. Drop by Nearly Half As Infections Go On
description: The number of Americans who died from AIDS fell to 16,865 last year, almost half the number of the year before and well below the 43,000 deaths in the peak year of 1995, Government figures released today show.

title: Milosevic Releases Villager Who Reportedly Saw Mass Execution
description: In what could be an important move for the prosecution of suspected war crimes in Kosovo, the man who says he is the sole survivor of a mass execution in his village was moved from Serbia today by international monitors.

title: A Webliography of Chuckles That Wears a Cap and Gown
description: HOW many conservative economists does it take to change a light bulb? Heard any good anecdotes about Canadian actors lately? Know any good songs about Socrates?

title: Adopt a Palm Tree (Needs Light)
description: DINERS at the Brasserie Centrale may be tempted to wrap sweaters around the palm trees shivering in the outdoor dining area on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 53d Street in Manhattan. No fear. Come the end of October, when the restaurant pulls in its chairs and tables, those trees, some 14 feet tall, will be sold off like exotic pets to adoptive homes.

title: Virtual Community for African-Americans
description: FOR information on everything from black-owned businesses to hip-hop, Internet users can choose from a growing number of Web sites aimed at African-Americans. Derrick Brown, a graduate student at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, has been visiting these sites for several years, mainly for news on topics of particular interest to African-Americans.

title: 2 Are Given Up to 30 Years In Murder of a Millionaire
description: Two of the young men who pleaded guilty in the kidnapping and murder of Nelson Gross, a New Jersey millionaire, were given the maximum sentence of 30 years in prison today. A third accomplice, who entered into a plea agreement to testify had there been a trial, was sentenced to 17 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, KEITH P.
description: BROWN-Keith P. On October 5, 1998, aged 81. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor. Devoted brother of Jane Brown. Interment private in Orange, CT.

title: Starr May Have New Material for Committee
description: On the eve of a House vote on a formal impeachment inquiry against President Clinton, the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, told leaders of the Judiciary Committee tonight that he might be preparing to refer to Congress matters that could become additional grounds for impeachment.

title: China Grows Impatient With Its Ailing Banks
description: The Government shutdown of a prominent state-run investment company, the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation, shows that China may finally be getting tough with insolvent financial institutions.

title: Italy's Premier Seeks Backing For Coalition From the Left
description: Arguing that Italy cannot afford a return to political instability, Prime Minister Romano Prodi pleaded with Parliament today to keep his splintering center-left majority intact.

title: Fame Forcing Cancer to Go Public; Strawberry and Other Celebrities Break Taboos, Saving Lives
description: Last Friday, after Darryl Strawberry's doctors confirmed that the pains in his stomach were a result of a cancerous tumor in his colon, the phones starting ringing at Dr. Alice Furman's office.

title: The Upcoming National Nightmare
description: Should the House of Representatives vote today to proceed with an inquiry to consider the impeachment of the President? It's a question that has come before the House only three times in the history of this country. It is a vote that should be approached with a deep and abiding respect for Congress, the Constitution and the Presidency.

title: Clinton Plans To Intervene As H.M.O's Exit Medicare
description: President Clinton plans to announce several steps this week to help Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations and is determined to halt the exodus of H.M.O.'s from the program, White House officials said today.

title: Looking for the Inner Janet Jackson and Finding More Than One
description: We might think we know her; after all, she kept telling us on Tuesday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., that she loved us. But mostly all we know of Janet Jackson is the family photos, the love for children and animals. And the numbers: No. 2 in most Top 10 hits of all female artists; No. 7 in most Top 10 hits of all artists; most gold singles by a female artist. The statistics go on and on.

title: Human Guides in Jungle of the World Wide Web
description: RETRIEVING information from an increasingly tangled World Wide Web is one of the most common on-line activities. Retrieving information that's actually useful is far more rare. While search engines mostly use roving software robots to scour the Web, the Mining Company (www.miningco.com), a relatively new vehicle on the information superhighway, is trying to prove that it has found a higher technology: the human brain.

title: Volunteer Firefighters Left in Limbo
description: The gritty streets of this 4-by-12-block sliver of a town in densely populated and urbanized northern Hudson County might be the last place to expect to find a largely volunteer fire department.

title: Republicans Agree to New Limits On Consumer Bankruptcy Filings
description: House and Senate Republicans agreed today on a vast overhaul of the bankruptcy system, making it more difficult for consumers to walk away from their debts and handing the banking and credit-card industries a major victory.

title: Mac Program Generates Effortless Prose
description: THESE days, a freshly created word-processing file on a computer screen takes the place of the blank page as an object of terror for most writers, but The Fear remains. Now, if only there was a computer program that would actually do the writing for you. . . .

title: In Paris, Even Junk Has a Class System
description: I ARRIVED in Paris with two suitcases and soon learned how to live among other people's things, in a rented room decorated with Japanese white paper lanterns and nondescript plasterboard shelves. By the time I graduated to my own studio, I had the requisite bed, desk and couch from Ikea, but I needed everything else. Determined to fill the apartment with Parisian treasures, I ruled out the notoriously overpriced Left Bank antique stores and Parisian flea markets like the Marche aux Puces at Porte de Clignancourt -- where it's possible to pick up an armchair for $200,000.

title: Zone Wars: Umpire Slices It Lower and Wider
description: Ted Hendry, the plate umpire, interpreted the strike zone consistently, which is exactly what players say they prefer. But Hendry's strike zone, as always, was larger than most, perhaps a couple of inches beyond the black border on either side of the plate, perhaps an inch lower than most strike zones. These parameters changed the way yesterday's Yankees-Indians game was played, both benefiting and hurting both sides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERMER, ABRAHAM
description: DERMER-Abraham, 85. Of Port Charlotte, Florida. Died October 3, 1998. Born New York City October 9, 1912, moved to Florida from NYC in 1974. Retired electrician and member of Temple Shalom of Port Charlotte. Survived by a niece, Iris Sokoloff of Oceanside, New York, and a nephew, Samuel Herman of East Brunswick, N.J. Private interment in Port Charlotte. Roberson Funeral Home and Crematory, Port Charlotte.

title: Buying a Lemon
description: To the Editor:

title: Potential of the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACCONCI, JESSIE CARNEVALE.
description: ACCONCI-Jessie Carnevale. On October 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Professor Themistocles F. Acconci. Devoted mother of Marcia C. Fazzari and Cynthia S. Schwanderla. Cherished grandmother of Cynthia Fazzari-Wimer, Andrea L. Fazzari, Edward J. Schwanderla, and James J. Schwanderla. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:30 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations in her memory can be made to the American Diabetes Association-New York Affiliate, 149 Madison Ave, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, BERTHA
description: SCHAEFER-Bertha. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Batya Levin on the loss of her mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: At Last, a Logo That Communicates
description: Rare is the logo that everyone can understand. But when -- and if -- the Airtrain line, which will whisk people from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport in less than an hour, is completed, the logo is perfect. ''We needed a pictogram that was memorable,'' said Michael Gericke, a partner at Pentagram, the New York design company that created it. On Sept. 16, Gov. George E. Pataki broke ground for the train at Kennedy. Stay tuned.

title: Skip Away Pursues the Gold Cup and the Ghost of Kelso
description: The backstretch at Belmont Park was bristling yesterday with horses preparing to run in the five Grade I stakes scheduled for Breeders' Cup Preview Day on Saturday. And the star of the show, reigning in Barn 1, remained Skip Away, who can make history three ways if he wins the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: Using Linux; Linux Pioneers Find the Differences Are Subtle
description: THE laptop in front of me looked as if it was running Wordperfect, the mouse felt as if it was interacting with a copy of Wordperfect, and for all intents and purposes, it was Wordperfect.

title: WESTERN BANCORP IN $77 MILLION DEAL FOR PNB FINANCIAL
description: Western Bancorp said yesterday that it planned to buy PNB Financial Group Inc. for about $76.9 million in stock. Both are based in Newport Beach, Calif. Under the offer, each share of PNB will be exchanged for one share of Western. Western said it planned to combine PNB's Pacific National Bank subsidiary with Southern California Bank, a Western unit. Matthew P. Wagner, chief executive of Western, said PNB's mortgage business would expand Western's product line. PNB has assets of $267 million and originated about $1.1 billion of mortgage loans in the first nine months of the year. Western shares fell $2.75, to $26.875, and PNB dropped $3, to $24.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, MARION
description: OPPENHEIM-Marion, 96. On October 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack N. Oppenheim Sr. Devoted mother of Jack N. Oppenheim Jr. and cherished grandmother of Jennie and Daniel Oppenheim. Her family and friends shall miss her love, strength and wise counsel. Private service. Donations in her memory may be made to Fountain House, 424 W. 47 St., NYC 10036.

title: Taliban Said to Weigh Trial for Bin Laden
description: The Taliban movement in Afghanistan might consider putting Osama bin Laden on trial for a 1996 bomb attack that killed 19 American airmen in Saudi Arabia, a leading Saudi-owned newspaper reported today.

title: For a Judge, Yankee Call Just Another In a Blizzard
description: The Mayor was deriding him as a Democratic Party hack. His admirers were praising his judicial acumen and savoring the familiar populist tone in his latest decision.

title: Brooklyn Academy's Chief Is Stepping Down
description: Harvey Lichtenstein, who took the Brooklyn Academy of Music from an imperiled relic three decades ago to one of the world's beacons of avant-garde music, theater, opera and dance, will step down this summer as president and executive producer , officials are to announce today.

title: Explosion Damages Roof Of Yonkers Apartments
description: An explosion in a Yonkers apartment building last night left three people hospitalized with minor injuries and eight families homeless, the authorities said.

title: Price Plunge On Nasdaq Hits 15-Month Low
description: Prices on the Nasdaq stock market declined to their lowest level in 15 months yesterday and have fallen 17.25 percent in just the last eight days of trading. Other market gauges also continued to slump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, PROFESSOR JOSEPH J.
description: SANDLER-Professor Joseph J. The officers and members of the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine and the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourn the passing of our beloved and esteemed colleague. He will be sorely missed. Burton A. Lerner, M.D., President Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine Robert A. Glick, M.D., Director Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Republicans in Agreement On Bankruptcy Overhaul

title: Martinez Stuck in Autumnal Swoon
description: Tino Martinez admitted that the fateful and forgettable sequence in the 12th inning of yesterday's game felt as if it were unraveling in slow motion. Dreary plays that help lose games can feel that way because players replay them in their minds. Every time Martinez replayed the bunt that doomed the Yankees, he wished that he could punch rewind, pause or delete to do something about Cleveland's 4-1 victory.

title: Longtime Editor To Leave Forbes Post
description: For years, Forbes magazine staff members have murmured that James W. Michaels -- the magazine's legendary, cantankerous and perfectionist editor since 1961 -- would like to expire at his desk.

title: Communists and Workers March to Denounce Yeltsin
description: Red banners flapping in the breeze, Communists and trade unionists led a nationwide strike today to protest President Boris N. Yeltsin's rule.

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST TO SELL STATIONS WORTH $500 MILLION
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell radio and television stations with a value of about $500 million in the fourth quarter and early next year to finance pending acquisitions and to pay down debt. As of June 30, Sinclair, which is based in Baltimore, had almost $1.5 billion in outstanding long-term debt. It owns 56 television stations and 54 radio stations. Without saying which, or how many, stations would be sold, Sinclair said it would sell those that are not central to its strategy and that after the sales were completed, it would own or program 64 TV stations and 51 radio stations.

title: Clinton Ally Is Refusing To Be Quiet
description: A week after the White House and Congressional Democrats disavowed his ''war'' on Speaker Newt Gingrich, James Carville, President Clinton's former campaign strategist and chief outside defender, put forth a new battle cry today: he will not be muzzled.

title: Toddlers' Tools Without the Ring of Truth
description: THERE is virtual. And then there is fake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ESTHER
description: DAVIDSON-Esther. On October 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Michael Davidson; dear mother of Mia Andersen; adored grandmother of Thea Andersen Bonomo and Eric Andersen; great grandmother of Vincent Michael Bonomo. Survived by her sister, Sonya Hamlin. Services Friday, October 9, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: I.M.F. Needs Reform, Not Money; Polish Example
description: To the Editor:

title: The Heavens Came Tumbling to Earth
description: SEEING AND BELIEVING

title: Economic Scene; Keeping tabs on the levels of risk at the nation's banks.
description: ROBERT C. MERTON and Myron S. Scholes are smarter than smart. They know better than anyone else how to think about financial risk. The proof lies in their Nobel award, which they shared for figuring out the complex math by which to assign precise price tags to options and other risky investments.

title: Internet Heroine Takes Aim at TV
description: It's a bird. It's a plane. No, it's a television development deal for a caped Internet heroine who flies to the rescue of broken hearts and fractured relationships.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on Aug. 23 about a huge house being built in the Hamptons by Ira Rennert, an investor, misstated its size ranking. (The error also occurred on Sept. 19 in an article about Mr. Rennert's plans and on Sept. 27 in a Real Estate section article about trends in luxury home construction.) The house will not be the largest private home in America. That distinction belongs to the Biltmore Estate in Asheville, N.C. Biltmore, built in the 1890's by George Washington Vanderbilt and now owned by his grandson, has 174,000 square feet, more than twice the space of Mr. Rennert's planned home.

title: Minority Medical Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong's Chief Offers No Economic Initiatives
description: Hong Kong's chief executive, in his second annual policy address, offered little to immediately lift the beleaguered domestic economy. The executive, Tung Chee-hwa, covered familiar ground in his address, reiterating that the government remained committed to free-market principles and to maintaining the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the United States currency.

title: U.S. to Back NATO Military Action Against Serbs in Kosovo
description: President Clinton decided today that the United States would vote to give NATO's supreme commander the authority to carry out military strikes against Yugoslav military and police forces in response to their crackdown in Kosovo Province.

title: An Evening Russian in Spirit and Sound
description: The program that the Chamber Orchestra Kremlin played at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening combined distinctively Russian coloration and spirit with a kind of internationalism that kept Moscow at its heart. Included were works by Miecyslaw Vainberg, a Pole who spent most of his life in Moscow; Salim Krymski, a composer from Azerbaijan who was represented by a collection of Jewish dances, and Steven Gerber, an American who lives in New York City but whose Serenade (1990) was filled with the wintry imagery that generations of Russian composers have made their country's musical vernacular. Tchaikovsky's Serenade for Strings, which closed the main program (there were also several encores), seemed chosen as a definitive assertion of the Russian style in its most classical form.

title: Mortgages Are Much in Demand
description: Applications for United States mortgages jumped last week to an all-time high, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today. Applications to refinance mortgages also surged to a record, as mortgage rates continued to decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, SIMON
description: REICH-Simon, age 92. Cherished husband of the late Anna. Beloved father of Drs. Walter & Raymond. Devoted father-in-law of Tova and Sue. Adored grandfather of Daniel, David and Rebecca, and of Yael (and David Hillel), Shlomo (and Adina), Yitzchak, Yosef and Avigail. Survivor of the Holocaust. His dignity, modesty and quiet strength has always been, and will forever be, a blessing for us all. Shiva will be begin Tuesday night, October 13, and end Monday morning October 19, at the home of Dr. Raymond Reich, 131 Dover Street, Brooklyn, New York. Phone (718-646-2642).

title: The Burger Industry Takes a Big Helping of Technology
description: AH, the joys of youth. What baby boomer can't remember the drive with a date to the local Big Boy, A & W or Dairy Queen, where a young woman cheerfully took orders from people in parked cars, then delivered shakes and cheeseburgers she might have even helped to prepare?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, JACQUES S.
description: BOEHM-Jacques S. Died October 7th. Husband of Dorothy for 56 years. Father of Beth and Paul. Father-in-law of Ellen and Gene. Grandfather of Jesse, Adrienne, Meredith, Jonathan, Emilie and Heather. Brother of Irwin and brother-in-law of Beatrice. Rest in peace with all our love. Services Thursday 2PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, RACHAEL
description: WYMAN-Rachael. The members of the Postgraduate Psychoanalytic Society mourn the death of their long time fellow member and esteemed colleauge, Rachael Wyman, and extend condolences to her son and his family

title: The Strong Pound Weakens Britain's Export Economy
description: When the Bank of England's secretive Monetary Policy Committee decides on Thursday whether to lower interest rates, its members may not be thinking too much about Hugh Morgan Williams. But he will most certainly be thinking about them.

title: Antitrust Suit Filed Against Visa and Mastercard
description: The Government filed an antitrust lawsuit against Visa USA and Mastercard International yesterday, contending the nation's two biggest credit card networks restrain competition and limit consumers' choices.

title: A Computer Anti-Theft Alarm That Squeals Like a Stuck Pig
description: Car alarms have become an annoying, if necessary, part of the American soundscape, and a company wants computer alarms to join the racket.

title: Public Eye; On the Proving Grounds Of Soft Projectiles
description: THE strange red mark that kept showing up on the arms and bellies of wide receivers was quickly named ''the Elway cross.'' As soon as the quarterback John Elway came into the National Football League, he became known for his rifle arm and rope-straight spiral. Today, with a Super Bowl victory at last, Elway holds another record, widely publicized by the Oddzon toy company. He has thrown the finned Koosh Vortex Mach 110 more than 110 yards.

title: A Library Card for Techies From Macmillan's Web Site
description: More than 200,000 people are taking advantage of full-text computer books offered on line by the Macmillan Personal Bookshelf (www.mcp.com/personal) to coach themselves through glitches or explore new digital worlds, the company announced last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIMAN, FLORENCE, AKA FLORENCE GEFFON.
description: REIMAN-Florence, aka Florence Geffon. On October 7, 1998. Survived by her husband Sam Geffon, wife of the late Irving M. Reiman. Mother of, and to, Leslie and Jim Quest, Jim and Sherrill Reiman, Billy and Cheryl Geffon. Grandmother to Annie and Matt, Daniel and Ellen, Ben and Jean. Greatgrandmother to Kora, Aidan, Trevor and Dylan. We will all miss her as long as we live. Services are on Friday, October 9th, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: TAKEOVER OFFER ERASES GAIN IN RESOURCE AMERICA SHARES
description: Shares of Resource America Inc., a finance company, rose as much as 65 percent and then lost all of the gain after the investment firm Radcliffe, Mitchell & Weiss said it had offered to buy the company for $15 a share. The shares closed at $8.3125, down 6.25 cents, after hitting a high of $13.6875. Resource America, in Philadelphia, buys distressed commercial mortgages and restructures them into performing loans. Radcliffe, Mitchell, based in Monroe, N.Y., said its offer valued the Resource America stock outstanding at $302.9 million. Resource America said it was ''endeavoring to learn more about this offer.'' Its shares climbed as high as $37.50 on July 31 before plunging amid concerns about the company's accounting methods for real estate loans.

title: Part Home, Part Rooster
description: When people in Fredericksburg, Va., encounter the boathouse on the Aquia Creek, they come up to the owners and ask, ''Do you sell hot dogs?'' At least that's what Jeff J. Vandeberg, the New York City architect who designed the little house, says.

title: General Consumers Are Similar To Those Plugged Into Web
description: It sometimes seems there are two parallel universes, one with tech-savvy Netizens on the front lines of the digital revolution, and one with plain old folks who think calculators, in-person conversation and paper-based organizers work just fine. One new study finds those universes are not as far apart as they appear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNTERBERG, AARON
description: UNTERBERG-Aaron. All of us at the East Midwood Jewish Center profoundly mourn the passing of this paragon of religiosity. He was a learned Jew who loved to pray and fulfill the commandments of our faith. He was also the consummate gentleman and a friend to all. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Marsha Shlefstein, President

title: College Tuition Rises 4%, Outpacing Inflation
description: The cost of a college education rose by about 4 percent this year, two and a half times the current rate of inflation, 1.6 percent, maintaining a pattern of the last few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOTCHKISS, JUDITH (NEE FRADKIN).
description: HOTCHKISS-Judith (nee Fradkin). On October 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Edward. Dearest daughter of Ruth Fradkin. Devoted mother of Jon and Jill, Wendy and Hilary. Loving sister of Stephen. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: THOMAS & BETTS CORP., Memphis, a producer of connectors and components for the electronics market worldwide, said it planned to buy Ocal Inc., Van Nuys, Calif., for $20.3 million in stock.

title: NFL: NOTEBOOK
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Pace of U.S. Consumer Borrowing Slows
description: Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a slower pace in August, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Classical Yet Looser, A Troupe Renewed
description: Choreography, genuine and unusual, is on view this week at City Center, where the National Ballet of Canada opened on Tuesday night for its first visit to New York in a decade.

title: Washington Talk; Congress Leaves Its Promises From Spring Largely Unfulfilled
description: Last spring, Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders in the House promised representatives from the Christian Coalition that Congress would end what the conservatives call partial-birth abortion, eliminate financing for the National Endowment for the Arts and work for a constitutional amendment to permit prayer in public schools.

title: U.S. Discloses New Charges Against Mexican Involved in Drugs
description: American officials announced today that drug and money-laundering charges had been filed against Vicente Carrillo Fuentes, the brother of a Mexican trafficker who died last year, and they said Mr. Carrillo had assumed control of the drug-smuggling cartel once led by his brother.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG TO TAKE $91 MILLION IN CHARGES
description: The Bergen Brunswig Corporation, the big drug wholesaler based in Orange, Calif., said that it would take fourth-quarter charges of $91 million, or $1.78 a share, after taxes. It will take a charge of $87 million against earnings for acquisitions its medical-supplies unit made before September 1995, mostly involving the purchase of Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc. in 1992. Bergen Brunswig will also take a $3 million pretax charge to pay for changes in its sales force and the consolidation of four divisions. It will also take two $5 million pretax charges, one for the abandonment of computer software and one for merger costs. Bergen Brunswig shares fell $4.1875, to $46.4375.

title: Chicago Theater and Opera To Collaborate on 2 Works
description: In an unusual arrangement meant to encourage the blurring of the distinction between genres, the Goodman Theater and the Lyric Opera will collaborate on the development and production of two new musical theater works, the two institutions announced today. Both William Mason, general director of Lyric, and Roche Schulfer, executive director of the Goodman, said they believed that such a partnership between an opera company and a theater company was unprecedented.

title: MICROSOFT'S WORLD: A special report.; How Software's Giant Played Hardball Game
description: In the summer of 1995, a whiff of revolution was in the air in Silicon Valley. The Internet offered a new deal in computing, a fresh opportunity for entrepreneurs to try to break the Microsoft Corporation's firm grip on the personal computer software business. Leading the challenge was the Netscape Communications Corporation, whose software for browsing the World Wide Web had ignited the Internet boom.

title: Mouse Manipulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Mac, Windows And Now, Linux
description: SINCE it was first developed in 1991 by Linus Torvalds, a student at the University of Helsinki, the operating system called Linux has engendered strong -- some might say fanatical -- loyalty among a growing community of users. To be a Linux devotee today is a bit like being one of the early users of the Internet, when using it required a solid technical grounding.

title: Brazil Chief to Offer Spending-Cut Plan
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, trying to calm investors while placating voters, said today that he would announce in two weeks a plan to cut spending to reverse a growing budget deficit and shore up investor confidence.

title: For Whom the Sell Tolls? It Tolls For Thee
description: PAPA'S got a brand new bag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, STEPHEN DOW.
description: FULLER-Stephen Dow. Age 90, passed away after a short illness Oct. 6, 1998 at St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, New York. Survived by his beloved wife, Emily Hurry Fuller. He is also survived by daughters, Emily Fuller Kingston of New York City and Ann B. Fuller of Big Horn, Wyoming & a son, Stephen W. Fuller of Joplin, Missouri. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Samuel S.R. Kingston, Sage Daly, Aeron Daly, Cary R. Fuller, Jane B. Fuller and Emily A. Fuller. The funeral service will be on Friday, Oct. 9, at 11AM at Christ Episcopal Church, East Main St., Oyster Bay, NY. Friends may call at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, New York, Thursday 5-7 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in memory of Mr. Fuller may be sent to Christ Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: It's a Year for Marking Centennials
description: What is the oldest golf club in the United States? In what is a record year for clubs marking their centennials -- 60 in all, according to the United States Golf Association, including a dozen in the New York metropolitan area -- that seems to depend on whether you're referring to a golf club or a golf course.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; It's still early, but chip makers may be turning things around.
description: ANALYSTS who cover the semiconductor industry have for months been casting about for some sign that the beleaguered sector had reached a bottom. So today, with three or four bits of positive data in hand, many seized on the opportunity to declare a turnaround.

title: Milosevic Says He Has Met NATO Demands on Kosovo
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia insisted in talks with the American envoy Richard C. Holbrooke that he had ordered enough forces out of Kosovo in the last few days to avert a threatened NATO attack, an American official said here tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKOFER, JOHN
description: BIRKOFER-John. On October 7, 1998. Loving father of Catherine Johnson, Karin Sturtevant, Carole Rynn and Anne Ellis, dear brother of Richard and William Birkofer and devoted grandfather of seven. Services will be Sat., 9:00am from Gleason Funeral Home, 1360 Hamilton St., Somerset, NJ., followed by a 9:15AM funeral mass at St. Matthias R.C. Church in Somerset. Cremation will follow at Franklin Memorial Park in No. Brunswick. Relatives and friends may call Friday 2-4; 7-9PM at Funeral Home.

title: Giants Come In From Cold Amid Some Talk About Spies
description: Dan Reeves isn't the Giants coach anymore, but as he prepares to bring his Atlanta Falcons to Giants Stadium this weekend, he's still having an impact on Giants practices.

title: Democrats Must Weigh The Personal and Political
description: Representative Louise M. Slaughter has not been a big fan of her fellow Democrat Bill Clinton. She thinks that he was a major reason the Democrats lost control of Congress in 1994, that he has struck one too many deals with the Republicans, that his behavior has been reckless and abhorrent. Two months ago, she was on the verge of urging him to resign.

title: Hospital Is Ruled Liable For Girl's Birth Injuries
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Queens awarded a Manhattan appellate judge and his wife $49 million yesterday in a medical malpractice verdict against Lenox Hill Hospital for what the couple contend was the botched birth of their daughter in 1989.

title: Bipartisan House Rejects Public Lands Measure
description: By an overwhelming bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives today bowed to the objections of environmentalists and the threat of a veto and rejected wide-ranging legislation on parks and public lands in dozens of states.

title: Gore Tries to Bolster Vallone's Candidacy
description: Hoping to borrow a little star power from the White House, Peter F. Vallone campaigned with Vice President Al Gore in western New York today, giving Mr. Gore a chance to take a few pokes at a possible opponent in the 2000 Presidential race, Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: The Nobelest People
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: G.E. Profit Rise Meets Estimates
description: The General Electric Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 13 percent, matching expectations, even as delayed shipments of power-generating equipment were partly responsible for disappointing sales growth.

title: Republicans List Terms for I.M.F. Payout
description: Republican Congressional leaders presented the Clinton Administration today with a list of lending conditions that they want imposed on the International Monetary Fund in order for Congress to approve $18 billion in new money for the I.M.F.

title: Metro Business; Merrill Lynch Incentives
description: Merrill Lynch & Co. will get almost $20 million in economic incentives from New Jersey in return for a commitment to build new offices and keep thousands of jobs in the state.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Laurie Anderson

title: HOUSE, IN A PARTISAN 258-176 VOTE, APPROVES A BROAD, OPEN-ENDED IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY
description: After a civil if sometimes harshly phrased debate that lasted more than three hours, the House of Representatives voted largely along party lines this afternoon to begin a full-scale, open-ended inquiry into possible grounds for the impeachment of President Clinton.

title: A Poll Finds Pataki With Broad Support
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who won office four years ago as the candidate of conservatives upstate and on Long Island, now enjoys robust support across regional and party boundaries and commands a 2-to-1 lead for re-election over his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, a statewide New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Investigator Says Pupil Missed Most of 3d Grade, Yet Passed
description: A 9-year-old boy who was absent from his third-grade class in a Brooklyn school for 165 days -- and who did not take mandatory reading and math exams -- was promoted to the fourth grade during the 1996-1997 school year anyway, school officials said. The case prompted a call for the New York City Board of Education to develop minimum attendance standards and for disciplinary action against the school's principal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, JEROME
description: HURWITZ-Jerome O.D. Beloved husband of Hortense, devoted father of Sanford and Robert, father-in-law of Rhona, loving grandfather of Jade. Services at 11 A.M. on Sunday at Union Temple of Brooklyn, 17 Eastern Parkway. Memorial contributions to Union Temple of Brooklyn, or the Jewish Braille Institute would be deeply appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; So Far, the Passion Belongs to the Padres
description: EARLIER this week, John Schuerholz, the Atlanta Braves' vice president and general manager, responded curtly to suggestions that the organization, from the executive office to the playing field, had become a bit too ho-hum about its success in the 90's. It had begun to take the victories for granted. It had replaced the unchecked exuberance of the early 90's with a more laid-back, businesslike attitude.

title: Decorating A Home Office For Louis XIV
description: The home office may seem like a new idea, but it has existed for at least 300 years in the West. In fact, ''From Paris to St. Petersburg: Important French and Russian Furniture and Works of Art,'' an exhibition that opened this week at the Chinese Porcelain Company, shows three ''home offices'' from three centuries.

title: This Week, in the Role Of the Starter . . . Foley
description: Glenn Foley passed his audition. Again.

title: Police Suspect Women Were in Sexual Servitude
description: The police in Atlantic City have arrested 11 women on prostitution charges but said they may have been forced into sexual servitude after being smuggled into the United States from Southeast Asia.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Beck and Al Hansen

title: Dollar Hits 111.73 Yen Before Staging Comeback
description: Foreign-exchange traders battered the dollar into what looked like a second consecutive free fall yesterday before the currency abruptly reversed course, ending only slightly lower against the Japanese yen in extraordinarily volatile dealings.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cass Gilbert And the City Eclectic
description: You, too, can stand where Leona Helmsley stood: on the steps of the only palace in the world where the Queen stood trial. Or, you can go off in quest of your own personal Elvis sighting, at the Army depot where the newly drafted King shipped out. The United States Courthouse on Foley Square and the Brooklyn Army Terminal, the settings for these momentous civic occasions, are just two of the seven buildings included in the third annual Open House, a self-guided tour on Sunday sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York. This year, the event celebrates the architecture of Cass Gilbert, a pivotal figure in defining the public face of New York in the early years of this century.

title: Georgetown Guard Ruled Ineligible
description: Georgetown guard Shernard Long has been ruled academically ineligible through the first semester, leaving the Hoyas without their leading scorer for at least the first nine games of the season.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York City metropolitan region.

title: Talents to Make Buddies: Walking and Wisecracking
description: The young-adult novel ''Freak the Mighty'' by Rodman Philbrick has been renamed ''The Mighty'' for a more inspirational effect on screen. Still, it's mostly a story for the age group that would find ''Freak'' the most enticing word in the title. In this fanciful but tragic tale, the outsider status of two boys is what creates their sense of specialness, helps them defeat obstacles and gives them a proudly medieval way of dealing with the world. Only when that world looks bleak does the story earn its hankies for adults in the crowd.

title: Campaign Reform: None Too Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTKIN, PHYLLIS
description: WERTKIN-Phyllis. She lightened my life in my dark days. I will never forget. To Ben, Doris, Fred and their families my deepest condolences and love. Dolores

title: On Stage and Off; From Sophocles, Slimmed Down
description: The dialogue is continuing , but it looks likely that Sophocles is heading for Broadway.

title: Parole Official Accused of Perjury in Pataki Campaign Case
description: A member of the State Parole Board has been charged with repeatedly lying when questioned about whether the board gave preferential treatment to an inmate whose family contributed to Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign.

title: Study Says Emissions Cut Will Raise Fuel Costs
description: The Energy Department's official forecasting arm has produced an extraordinarily pessimistic forecast of steeply rising energy prices if the United States fights global warming by clamping down on emissions of heat-trapping gases that come from burning fossil fuels.

title: With Brown in Charge, Padres Take Command
description: Before this National League Championship Series began, John Smoltz had warned that no matter what happened to the Braves this year, when Atlanta fans looked back on the 1990's they would finally realize how good they had it during an era when their team played in seven league championship series in a row.

title: U.S. May Ask Death Penalty in Embassy Bombings
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday that the Government was seriously considering asking for the death penalty for two of the suspects arrested after the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGARMAN, JUNE
description: SUGARMAN-June. Died October 5th, 1998. Beloved wife of Tracy Sugarman and mother of Laurie Sugarman-Whittier, son Richard Sugarman and granddaughters Casey Sugarman, Amy Whittier and Abby Whittier. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Those desiring to make contributions in her memory, contact XCEL Inc., 16 Brookfield Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06854.

title: Attention Internet Shoppers: No New Taxes
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to make cyberspace a tax-free zone for most transactions for the next three years, following the House in trying to help incubate a new engine of commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ESTHER
description: DAVIDSON - Esther. Wonderful piano teacher, storyteller, highspirited woman, friend. May her memory be for a blessing. Nancy Schwartz

title: With 31 Exceptions, a Partisan Vote
description: Opening nearly three hours of debate over whether the House should initiate impeachment proceedings, Representative Henry J. Hyde, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, warned Republicans and Democrats alike today that ''too much hangs in the balance for us not to rise above partisan politics.''

title: Arena Is Top Choice To Replace Sampson
description: With Bora Milutinovic strongly indicating a preference to coach the MetroStars and Carlos Queiroz having withdrawn from consideration, Bruce Arena has become the leading candidate to replace Steve Sampson as coach of the United States national team.

title: Poll Finds Broad Statewide Support for Pataki's Re-election
description: After four years as Governor, George E. Pataki has forged a strikingly broad appeal, propelling him to a 2-to-1 lead for re-election over his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, who has barely registered in voters' minds, a statewide New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Sideline Illuminates Matisse's Main Line
description: Though he is celebrated as one of the 20th century's great painters, Henri Matisse (1869-1954) was also a sculptor of no small talent. True, he turned out vastly more paintings than sculptures, once declaring to an interviewer that for him sculpture was ''a break from painting.'' And with a few exceptions, the bronzes he made were small. But despite his statement that he made sculpture ''as a painter,'' some of Matisse's works in this medium rank among the 20th century's greatest.

title: A Woman Stalks the Self In the Land of Safaris
description: RULES OF THE WILD

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Miguel Calderon

title: Most Likely to Succeed? Or Annoy?
description: This guy looks awfully familiar. Don't we know him from somewhere? Is it the yearbook pictures, the ones that show him with the Piper Cub Club or leading the beekeepers's society? Is it the way he wrote and directed the school's most unbearable plays? Isn't he the crossing guard who used his job to hit on friends' mothers? Remember how he gave the orders and outsmarted the teachers? Probably he has grown up to be a captain of industry and loves reminiscing about his hard climb to the top.

title: TV Weekend; A Spare 'Lear' Influenced By Beckett and Brecht
description: When Lear and his daughters make their entrance, they walk into a room whose walls are the color of dried blood. In Richard Eyre's stunning, minimalist production, the only furniture in that room is a long table and chairs, swathed in fabric of the same blood red. Fiery torches provide light, and the men wear medieval-looking tunics. Yet the women's long, high-collared dresses seem modern, even futuristic, and their hairstyles are conspicuously contemporary.

title: A Laugh, Perhaps A Tear
description: Like all recent modern-dress versions of the ballet classics, Matthew Bourne's ''Swan Lake'' can give one pause. Beware of those who stir the waters to suggest they are deep, as the Chinese saying goes.

title: Authorities Arrest 13 In Drug Ring Raid
description: Federal and local law enforcement officials said yesterday that they broke up a drug ring operating at a public housing project in Orange, just blocks from Interstate 280, that mainly served suburban commuters.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO BUY SHIPBUILDER FOR $415 MILLION
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest military contractor, said yesterday that it would buy Nassco Holdings Inc. to strengthen its ship-repair business and to compete better for future commercial and Navy contracts. General Dynamics will pay $370 million in cash and assume $45 million in debt for Nassco, an employee-owned company based in San Diego that is the parent of the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company. General Dynamics already owns the Bath Iron Works in Maine, a destroyer builder for the Navy, and Electric Boat, in Groton, Conn., a submarine builder. Nassco specializes in smaller Navy vessels, like support ships, and also builds commercial ships.

title: A Champagne Evening Awash in Gloom
description: To the casual observer, the meeting of international finance ministers and central bankers that ended here today had all the elements of a glittery affair of the type often portrayed in movies: a mix of big money and bright thoughts as the world's rich and powerful gather in one spot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMSON, BRUCE
description: WILLIAMSON-Bruce, age 71. On Oct. 6, 1998. ''The Noel Coward of Film Critics'', Playboy magazines movie critic for thirty-one years. Living on in his daughter Stephanie, son-in-law Joseph, grandsons Henry & Ethan; his sisters Alberta and Janette and many nieces and nephews. Forever loved by his partner Shirley. Private memorial Saturday, October 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ROBERT KNIGHT
description: HARRIS-Robert Knight. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Robert Knight Harris, devoted husband, father and grandfather. Our sympathies are extended to his wife, Myrna, and his children, Betty Ann; Walter and his wife, Gail; Michelle; Caren and her husband, Peter; and his grandchildren, Kate and Jenny. Mr. Harris was a loyal supporter of UJA-Federation as a past chairman of the General Insurance Division. His son, Walter, currently serves on the General Insurance Committee. Our most sincere sympathies are with his entire family and we know that his presence will be missed by many. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Two-Time Survivor Has No Use for Self-Pity
description: TWO years ago, a story swept like a bad fire through the breast cancer community:

title: A Volatile Day Turns Wall St. To Uneasy St.
description: Over the last six weeks, investors have held onto the hope that the United States might be able to avoid the full effect of the economic downturn that has struck so many far-flung parts of the world. And while the financial markets remain in turmoil, many investors thought that the prices of stocks, bonds and other financial assets had largely taken the bad news into account.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Where Talk Is Golden
description: In noisy, bustling New York, a restaurant where you can hold a peaceful conversation is a treasure. Here are 11 places where you don't have to strain to listen or be heard. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Medicare health maintenance organizations dropping elderly members in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey misstated the plans of Aetna Inc. It is closing Medicare H.M.O.'s with 930 members in two Connecticut counties, Windham and Tolland, not in New York State.

title: Hargrove on His Pitching
description: Cleveland Manager Mike Hargrove was thrilled with the effort his bullpen gave him in Game 2 against the Yankees. Six relievers allowed just two hits over the final six and one-third innings of a 12-inning victory. But do they now have anything left for Game 3?

title: Iran's Forces Said to Clash With Afghans Along Border
description: Iran said today that its troops had clashed with Taliban forces along the Afghan border and inflicted heavy casualties there in a skirmish between neighbors who have been in a tense standoff.

title: An Optimistic Doctors' Report On Strawberry
description: All but 1 of 36 lymph nodes taken from Darryl Strawberry are free of cancer, his doctors at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center reported yesterday, and they said the Yankee outfielder could be released from the hospital on Sunday.

title: N.H.L. Preview; A Season Of Change On and Off The Ice
description: The National Hockey League begins its season tonight, and with the addition of the expansion Nashville Predators, it now has 27 franchises. The Stanley Cup playoffs could end as soon as June 19, about the time Mark McGwire hits his 30th home run.

title: Brodeur Expected To Play in Opener
description: Martin Brodeur missed practice yesterday because of what the Devils called a slight groin pull, but Coach Robbie Ftorek said he expected Brodeur to play in tomorrow's National Hockey League season opener in Chicago against the Blackhawks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISSIM, KHADOURI, CHACHAM
description: NISSIM-Khadouri, Chacham. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Simha Margalit on the loss of her brother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: 'When the Cat's Away'
description: Kinky Friedman, a songwriter and performer turned novelist, brings to crime fiction something that no other writer can offer: himself. The hero of ''When the Cat's Away,'' as was the case in the two previous entries in this series, is none other than Kinky Friedman. For that matter, an extraordinary number of the characters who people these pages have real-life counterparts, from the book editor whose missing cat first involves Kinky in the novel's convoluted goings-on to the hero's trusty sidekick, Ratso. When a friend's beloved feline disappears from its cage during a Madison Square Garden cat show, Kinky agrees to take the case. Soon he's involved with dead bodies, a menacing figure in a cat's mask, warring Colombian drug families and a mysterious half-Palestinian, half-Colombian beauty. None of this makes much sense, of course, but that's not the point. Humor is. Mr. Friedman, who once named his backup band ''the Texas Jewboys,'' applies the same craziness to novel writing. Unfortunately, what works within the limited span of a popular song is less successful over the course of 200 pages. Kinky the character does just fine. Kinky the author would benefit from some literary discipline.

title: Patience Pays Off, Yet Again, For Indians
description: There is a mellow streak in the Cleveland Indians. The Indians are so laid back and patient they will wait for anything: paint to dry, a pot to boil or a crack to develop in a landmark.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 5.8 PERCENT. Prices slumped on news of a large gain in inventories last week, showing little disruption from Hurricane Georges. The November contract fell 13.9 cents, to $2.254 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Contest Account To McCann Seattle
description: American Family Enterprises in Jersey City said yesterday that it had named McCann-Erickson Seattle to handle advertising for its American Family Publishers Sweepstakes, which had previously been handled in-house and farmed out on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Restoration Plan Ordered For Potter's Field in Newark
description: A judge has ordered the city of Newark to devise a plan to restore a potter's field that had been used to bury the city's poor from 1869 to 1953 but since the late 1960's has been used as a garbage dump, where thousands of once-tidy graves are now hidden under mounds of debris.

title: 225 of Clinton's Nominees Wait, and Some of Them Will Wait Forever
description: The United States Institute of Peace may have to fight war with a few board members missing in action. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund and the Museum Services Board may have to educate and archive without a full roster of top officials.

title: Airtouch Names Mediacom as Buyer
description: The Airtouch Cellular subsidiary of Airtouch Communications named Mediacom in New York, the media services company owned by Grey Advertising, to handle its national media buying account, which had been divided among various agencies. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: Early Tibetan Paintings in Living Color
description: Alternating scholarly erudition with drop-dead beauty, ''Sacred Visions: Early Paintings From Central Tibet'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a silver cloud with a tragic lining.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Not a Photo For the Court Wall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSSER, ROBERT JOHN
description: MUSSER-Robert John, age 77. Formerly of Greenwich, Conn., died Tuesday, October 6, 1998. Born in New York City, son of the late Dr. John and Grace Musser. He graduated Yale in 1942 and M.I.T. with a M.S. in 1947. He was a former Director of Planning for Union Carbide, Europe. He had served as an officer in the Navy during World War II & was on the Ethics Committee of the Veteran's Home and Hospital in Rocky Hill, CT. He is survived by his three children: Charles John Musser of New York, Nancy Musser Sutton of Los Angeles, and Jame Musser Nelson of Chicago, a sister Nancy Klebold of Toms River, N.J., five grandchildren and his former wife Marilyn Musser Bernart of South Carolina. His determination in the face of a debilitating stroke of twenty-two years moved all who knew him. Please make memorial donations to the Hospice Unit, Rocky Hill Veteran's Hospital, West Street, Rocky Hill, CT. 06067.

title: Japanese Index Falls 800 Points
description: Japan's key stock index took its steepest tumble in more than seven years today, led by electronics companies and auto makers on worries that their profit growth would be stunted by a stronger yen and weaker overseas markets.

title: Reno Says She'll Look at the Origins of Starr's Lewinsky Inquiry
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she would review accusations by President Clinton's lawyer that Kenneth W. Starr might have misled the Justice Department in January when he sought permission to begin an investigation into Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Mexico Gets Green Light to Charge Interest on Interest
description: The Supreme Court ruled late Wednesday that it was legal for Mexico's ailing banks to charge interest on interest. The decision upheld a practice that is bread-and-butter basic to banking worldwide and showed just how obsolete many of Mexico's business laws are.

title: On My Mind; Talk in a Crowded Cab
