description: I got into the cab at the airport and there they were -- 20-odd of my good friends. About 60 other people also were waiting in the cab.

title: In Area Around New York, Only 2 Break Party Ranks
description: After much wringing of hands, reading of the Constitution and consulting of priests and pollsters, almost every member of the House of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut did what party leaders asked today on the vote to begin an impeachment inquiry.

title: New Kosovo Refugees, Many Ailing, Scramble to Survive
description: Three days after the United Nations Security Council called on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to halt his shelling against civilians in Kosovo, Nakije Halili remembers hearing the sound of artillery across the valley.

title: 2-Month Flood Breeds Havoc and Spreads Disease in Bangladesh
description: Monsoon floods that lasted three times longer than any other in Bangladesh's history have finally receded and millions of people have begun cleaning the muck from their homes.

title: Fuel That Doesn't Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MARGOT
description: GREENE-Margot on October 3 at 106. Beloved wife of the late Irving J., loving mother of Joan Lazrus, cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Funeral was held. She will always be loved.

title: Chilean Chief of U.N. Team Linked to Abuses Under Pinochet
description: A Chilean military officer linked to unlawful executions and torture during the era of the dictator Augusto Pinochet is serving as the chief military observer of a United Nations mission on the India-Pakistan border, a human rights group says.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: U.S. Said to Face Brunt of Economic Crisis
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank wound up their annual meetings today saying that the United States will bear most of the burden of helping Asia and the rest of the developing world get out of a recession.

title: German Green Evolves From Revolutionary to Pragmatist
description: It is some distance from the leftist revolutionary struggles of Frankfurt in the 1970's to the corridors of power in Washington, but Joschka Fischer of Germany completes that long march on Friday, with unpredictable consequences for the Atlantic alliance and for Kosovo.

title: Disney Offers an 'Aida,' With a Morphing Pyramid
description: The Disney Company's latest venture into musical theater, ''Elaborate Lives: The Legend of Aida,'' by Tim Rice and Elton John, opened at the Alliance Theater here on Wednesday night before a glittery audience that was equal parts native Atlantans and Disney movers and shakers, including Michael D. Eisner, the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 4 about the origins of Kenneth W. Starr's investigation into President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky misstated Mr. Starr's role in Paula Jones's lawsuit against the President. Although Mr. Starr offered to help the Independent Women's Forum in filing a friend-of-the-court brief in the lawsuit before becoming independent counsel in 1994, he did not write such a brief and none was filed.

title: $23 Million Expansion Planned for Staten Island Freight Center
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced a $23 million expansion project yesterday for the Howland Hook Marine Terminal, a 187-acre Staten Island freight-handling complex that was reopened two years ago by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: CBS News Division Cuts About 7% of Work Force
description: As part of a broader corporate cost-cutting effort at CBS Inc., the network's news division yesterday laid off about 7 percent of its staff, but closed no bureaus and dismissed no correspondents.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: AMERICANS REBUKE YUGOSLAV LEADER
description: In a delicate dance of diplomacy and threats, the Clinton Administration today accused President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia of ''cosmetic gestures'' that would not be enough to head off NATO air strikes in Kosovo. But at the same time the United States embarked on yet another round of negotiations with him.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: They'll Take Him in Cleveland
description: Mike Hargrove did not agree with the vilification of Chuck Knoblauch for his obvious lapse in Game 2, when the Yankees' second baseman argued for a call while the Indians scored a go-ahead run in the 12th inning.

title: Proposed Cigarette Deal Doesn't Force Rise in Price
description: Under a national settlement being negotiated by the tobacco industry, cigarette makers would not be required to pass along to consumers the cost of the deal, a price increase that many anti-smoking advocates have said is critical to reducing under-age tobacco use.

title: Japan Apologizes Forcefully for Its Occupation of Korea
description: Seeking to forge a new relationship with the Korean people, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi offered an unusually forthright apology today for Japanese colonial occupation of the Korean peninsula early in this century.

title: At the Movies; On Revealing A Hidden Talent
description: Mari Hoff is quite disagreeable, with an overheated sexual appetite, an appallingly salty tongue and an over-the-hill figure. Ray Say, her boyfriend in this working class English town, isn't much better: he books strippers at a local club and cruises the streets in a hulking, red Oldsmobile convertible. And then there's L. V., for Little Voice, Mari's grown-up but waiflike daughter, who is so crushed by her mother's demands and the death of her father that she has retreated to her bedroom to stew, squeak out an occasional word and sing the show tunes her father loved, like a diva.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Daring to Seduce by Covering Up
description: The abandonment of nudity in fashion, no matter how fleeting it may be, has sent designers on a quest for other kinds of titillation. They have found it in new fabrics and in fresh ways of manipulating them.

title: Op-Art; Still More Reasons For Impeachment
Corrections
description: A cabaret review on Tuesday about Combo Fiasco misstated its performance schedule this month at Eighty-Eight's, at 228 West 10th Street in Manhattan. The group is performing Thursdays and Fridays, but not Saturdays.

title: Health Care Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Menashe Zemro, 92, Dies; Led Ethiopian Jews
description: Menashe Zemro, the last remaining ques, or traditional spiritual leader of Ethiopian Jews, died on Wednesday in Qiryat Gat, the town where he settled after arriving in Israel in 1991. He was 92.

title: Ex-Official of Gtech Is Sentenced to 5 Years
description: The former national sales manager of Gtech Holdings Corporation, which has run New Jersey's state lottery since 1984, was sentenced to five years and 3 months in prison yesterday for taking nearly $170,000 in kickbacks from an Atlantic County consulting firm.

title: Campaign Reform: None Too Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharp Appetites and Penitent Hearts? Sounds Familiar
description: In the privacy of his office, a powerful officeholder asks an attractive young woman for sex.

title: Lon Clark, 86, Radio Voice of a Detective
description: Lon Clark, who began his career in radio drama and went on to a theatrical career on and Off Broadway, died on Friday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Uncertainty of 'This Excursion'
description: For all the talk of duty and Constitution, it was not all that difficult for the House to open a formal impeachment inquiry into President Clinton today. The more troublesome question is how Congress will bring to a conclusion the process that Representative Henry J. Hyde called ''this venture, this excursion, this journey.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Growling, but for How Long?; Assessing the Fallout From a Season of Lower Earnings
description: Is it time for investors to sober up?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALHEIM, BETH
description: THALHEIM-Beth. We all mourn the passing of a most very special person. Beth was a remarkable lady. She was truly a one-of-a-kind individual. She had a way about her that generated a spark of life wherever she went. Beth was the devoted wife of 48 years to her husband Jay. They were always a team, and worked alongside one another for over forty years to build one of the largest trade show and exposition management companies in the U.S. Beth will always be remembered as one of the true pioneers in the exposition industry. She will be deeply missed by her three children, David Thalheim, Amy Handwerker, and Neil Thalheim. They will always remember the fond moments spent together with their Mom. Her nine grandchildren, Lindsay, Adam, Michael, Marc, Benjamim, Shira, Rena, Eliana and Raphael will also miss the wonderful times spent with their grandmother. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 9, at 12:30 pm at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', located at: 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck (located North of Great Neck railroad station--516-487-9600). Shiva will be at the home of Jay Thalheim, 264 Sparrow Drive, Manhasset (located in The Estates I on Searingtown Road) from Saturday evening thru Tuesday evening. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Asthma-dedicated Clinical Research Center at The North Shore University HospitalLong Island Jewish Medical Center in Manhasset, NY.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Carmen Cicero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIWEL, MARIA
description: FEIWEL-Maria. On October 8, 1998. Favorite teacher of many students. Loving wife of Henry. Beloved mother of Patricia, Jean and Larry. Cherished grandmother of Sarah and Emma. Dear aunt of Lawrence, Robert, Toni and Raymond. She was greatly loved and we will miss her. Services are private.

title: Yield for 30-Year Rises to 4.99% In a Mixed Session for Treasuries
description: Treasury securities ended sharply mixed yesterday, with selling by hedge funds battering the long end of the market even as shorter maturities were bolstered by weakness in equities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSTAEDT, DAVID
description: KARSTAEDT-David. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its member, Marc Karstaedt. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWYON, PATRICK MICHAEL
description: TWYON-Patrick Michael, at 56. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Hanff) and loving father of Ashley Branwen; brother of Sandy & Jon Twyon. Resident of New York City and Sag Harbor. Publisher of the Multicultural Target Source Directory and recently named president of the Multicultural Advertising Association. Died suddenly of a heart attack on October 7th. Memorial service at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, Saturday, October 10 at 1 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Evans Golf Scholarship Fund. Gone Golfing...

title: Criimi Mae Court Filings List Millions in Unsecured Loans
description: Criimi Mae Inc., whose shares plunged 80 percent this week after the company filed for bankruptcy, named Prudential Securities Inc. and the First Union Corporation among its largest unsecured creditors in court filings.

title: Judge Deals Allied a Blow In AMP Bid
description: A Federal judge in Pennsylvania dealt a blow yesterday to Allied Signal Inc.'s $9.7 billion hostile takeover bid for AMP Inc., ruling against Allied's current effort to seek AMP shareholders' written consent for its purchase offer.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The photograph on the postcard sent to announce the opening of the restaurant is nearly 100 years old. It depicts a group of well-fed people gathered around an outdoor table playing cards. The men smoke pipes, the women wear starched white aprons, and bottles of wine are scattered about the table. Above them a huge sign reads, ''Cafe Boulud.''

title: Home Video; 83-Year-Old Evil In a Grim Paris
description: Artistically, the film is a masterpiece. Commercially, however, there's a bit of risk. ''People have to decide to commit seven hours,'' said David Shepard, the preservation expert who restored it. ''That's the roll of the dice.''

title: How does a media company get its message across at an advertising conference? Pay for it.
description: REMEMBER the golden age of radio and the early days of television, when dulcet-voiced announcers like Don Wilson, Harry Von Zell and Ed Herlihy let listeners and viewers know that programs were being ''brought to you by'' sponsors like Lucky Strike cigarettes, Carnation milk and Kraft cheese? If only those smooth-talking pitchmen could be on hand for the 89th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, to let attendees know that programs will be brought to them by sponsors like ESPN, Time Inc. and USA Today.

title: Taking Aim at the Red Wings
description: The N.H.L. regular season starts tonight. Here is a scouting report, with teams listed in projected order of finish.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Saying System Is Unsound, Grand Jurors Urge Changes
description: In a rare glimpse into a secretive process, 11 New York City residents who recently served on grand juries in the state court system offered scathing testimony before a state panel yesterday. They complained that being a grand juror in New York can be ''degrading and disillusioning'' and a ''kind of torture'' and called for a sweeping overhaul of the system.

title: Rhode Island's Autumn Cool Spot
description: We stood at the edge of Wickford Harbor, blinking and sleepy, in baseball caps, bathing suits and old sneakers. It was 9:15 A.M., a reasonable hour for a workday, but early for four people on vacation who had never kayaked before, and were now face to face with a large body of water, two slips of boats shaped like bananas and a mellow guide named Craig.

title: Palestinian Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: The X-Files

title: Fears of a Spreading Recession Send Markets Tumbling
description: Sparing only a couple of major markets, stock prices tumbled around the world yesterday in emotional and often panicky trading, reflecting investor fear that recession might be spreading from the Far East to Europe and might eventually grip the United States. But then Wall Street suddenly reversed course and produced a late-session comeback in the third-heaviest trading session on record.

title: Pragmatism May Explain Some Crossover Voting
description: For the 31 Democrats who voted for the Republican proposal today, political pragmatism might have had as much to do with their decision as anything else.

title: Romance Spiked Generously With Exuberance
description: If there is one ballet not to miss this season it is James Kudelka's ''Desir,'' a flamboyant but lyrical surge of passionate dancing that the National Ballet of Canada is to perform again tonight at City Center.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK 25 MILLION SHARES
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would repurchase 25 million of its common shares, or about $1 billion in stock. The buyback represents about 4.5 percent of the company's 547.4 million shares outstanding. Kimberly-Clark, the Dallas-based maker of personal-care and paper products, had 1997 revenues of $12.55 billion. Its stock rose 93.75 cents, to $43.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOTCHKISS, JUDITH
description: HOTCHKISS-Judith (nee Fradkin). On October 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Edward. Dearest daughter of Ruth Fradkin. Devoted mother of Jon and Jill, Wendy and Hilary. Loving sister of Stephen. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Matt Collishaw

title: At 2d for Yankees, Goat of the Day; Sympathy Is Scarce for Knoblauch and His Costly Error
description: So much for that heralded new civility.

title: New Leader Tells Tories They Have to Be Tough Against Labor
description: Seeking to end damaging party quarrels and bolster his own unproven leadership, William Hague told Conservatives today that they had to be tough with the Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: Political Memo; A Game Plan From Giuliani For Stadium?
description: As the Yankees soar and stumble in their quest for the World Series championship, the team's best-known fan continues to do what he can to insure victory. He provides pitching analyses, sizes up opponents, even wears a team warm-up jacket to games. You half expect to see him in the dugout come game time, spitting out sunflower seeds and gesturing to the center fielder, Bernie Williams, to shade a little to the left.

title: A Sampler of Excerpts From Saramago's Work
description: From ''Baltasar and Blimunda'' 1982 (translation, Harcourt Brace, 1987).

title: New Citigroup Is Getting Off To Rocky Start
description: Citigroup Inc., the financial services giant formed by the newly combined Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., said yesterday that it would report an estimated $700 million of net income for the three months ended on Sept. 30 after being hit by about $1 billion in losses from the recent turmoil in financial markets.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Routine Business, but No Routine Day
description: President Clinton maintained an ordinary schedule and an air of absorption today in routine public business as the House approved an impeachment investigation that may shorten his term in office and will certainly affect his place in history.

title: SAKS SAYS IT EXPECTS TO MEET PROFIT FORECASTS THIS YEAR
description: Saks Inc. said yesterday that it would meet earnings estimates this year and next year as the company focused on cutting costs from the newly combined businesses of Saks Holdings Inc. and Proffitt's Inc. Saks, which owns the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, also said it had completed the purchase of 14 Dillard's Inc. stores last week. Saks said it expected earnings for its third quarter, ending Oct. 31, to be 37 cents or 38 cents a share, in line with analysts' average estimate, according to the First Call Corporation. The reassurance about profits came after Saks said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1 percent, its second monthly decline.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Claudia Fitch

title: Jury Finds Psychiatrist Was Negligent in Pedophile Case
description: A Federal jury in Bridgeport, Conn., has found a Manhattan psychiatrist negligent for failing to warn anyone that a doctor undergoing psychoanalysis with him had confessed to being a pedophile. Four months after that confession, the patient molested a 10-year-old boy at Danbury Hospital.

title: Hare Krishna Movement Details Past Abuse at Its Boarding Schools
description: In its own official journal, the Hare Krishna movement has published an unusually candid expose detailing widespread physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children who were sent to live in the group's boarding schools in the United States and India in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: PENNZOIL TO TAKE $115.6 MILLION CHARGE IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it would take $115.6 million of charges for debt refinancing, foreign projects, low oil and natural-gas prices and weather problems in the Gulf of Mexico, giving it a loss for the third quarter. The charges will total $2.43 a share. Pennzoil, whose motor oil is the top-selling brand, warned that results before the charges would also be hurt by the low oil and gas prices and severe gulf weather. The company had been expected to earn 30 cents a share, the average estimate of eight analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. A year earlier, Pennzoil, based in Houston, had net income of $35.2 million, or 75 cents a share, after taking a $2.9 million charge. Pennzoil shares fell $3.625, to $28.5625.

title: Faulty Families: Music Is Easy Listening and Dessert Is Hard to Take
description: ''Don't worry,'' coos the famous, successful, beautiful sister. ''I'm not laughing at you, I'm laughing with you.''

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Made 3 Mistakes On One Play
description: WHAT is wrong with Coach George? At the very time the Yankees needed a football-style, two-a-day drill on the fine art of throwing the baseball to first base, Coach George was fighting a grudge match with the baseball establishment.

title: Nobel in Literature Goes to Jose Saramago
description: Jose Saramago, a 75-year-old Portuguese writer who took up literature relatively late in life and whose richly imaginative novels soon won him a following of loyal readers across Europe and vocal admirers in the United States, was awarded this year's Nobel Prize in Literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: Joseph Merlino, 76, Trenton Political Figure
description: Joseph P. Merlino, a rough-hewn Democrat who was a powerful figure in New Jersey politics for years, serving two terms as State Senate president and helping enact key legislation, died on Wednesday at the Forrestal Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Princeton, N.J., where he had been for a week. He was 76 and a lifelong resident of Trenton.

title: Health Care Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: In Partisan Debate, the Sublime and the Surreal
description: Only in America could the House debate authorizing an impeachment investigation of President Clinton juxtapose quotations of the founding fathers with those of the wayward daughter Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Pictures Give Hints Of Universe At Its Dawn
description: Peering farther back in space and time than ever before, the Hubble Space Telescope has taken infrared pictures of what may be the most distant objects ever detected, early light from the galactic dawn of the universe.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Candid and Correct, Palermo Makes Call
description: Sometimes planning is overrated, and good TV benefits from serendipity.

title: A Day Later, Knoblauch Picks Up the Ball
description: After a nearly sleepless night that included watching replays of himself ignoring a baseball just a few feet away from him, Chuck Knoblauch acknowledged today what thousands of others had seen at Yankee Stadium and on television: that he made a mistake in not retrieving the ball on the play that led to a Yankee playoff loss on Wednesday.

title: INSIDE ART
description: An Invasion Of de Koonings

title: Memories, Not Hopes, as Rangers Open
description: At training camp last month, Rangers players and staffers wore optimistic T-shirts. Along with the team's four championship banners, the garment displayed the words: ''New Beginning. New Attitude. Same Dream.''

title: Excerpts From Debate on Plan to Begin an Impeachment Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from comments by members of the House today during its debate on a resolution to begin an impeachment inquiry against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service, and The New York Times:

title: Deals Near on Manhattan Sites for 3 Stock Markets
description: Working against deadlines imposed by New York's financial markets, city and state officials are scrambling to complete a series of complex deals in the coming weeks that would create new headquarters for the New York, American and Nasdaq Stock Exchanges in Manhattan.

title: A Mid-Concert Birthday Surprise of Elgar and Mozart
description: Ambushing a performing artist with a birthday ''surprise'' in the middle of a concert is a time-honored tradition in the straight-laced classical music world. It happened again on Monday night when the conductor and violinist Pinchas Zukerman, having embarked on his 50th birthday tour of North America with the English Chamber Orchestra, performed at Carnegie Hall.

title: Bonds That Flourish in the Heart
description: This year's New York Film Festival concludes on a note of uncommon grace. ''The Dreamlife of Angels,'' to be shown on Sunday night at 8:30, begins simply and becomes a glimpse into an unexpected world. Though its two main characters, young Frenchwomen adrift and living hand to mouth, are rough-edged and scrappy, they wind up forming a bond of enormous delicacy. As that bond frays, this impassioned first feature by Erick Zonca reveals a soulful, moving vision of our shared responsibility for one another's lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMITA, KIKU
description: TOMITA-Kiku, 75, died October 5 after a brief illness. She worked many years for the NYS Department of Labor, retiring in 1989. Her passions were world travel and volunteer work. She is survived by two brothers, Jun and Joe and sister Kay Hashimoto, all of Seattle, Washington. Family services will be held in Seattle.

title: A Grim but Historic Day
description: By becoming the third President to face an impeachment inquiry, Bill Clinton has secured an unfortunate historic distinction that he provoked with reckless personal actions and self-defeating political and legal tactics. But he was able to forestall the wave of defections that the White House had feared. In the end, only 31 Democrats crossed over to vote for the Republican resolution that passed 258 to 176. The debate was harsh, but at last the road ahead is clear. While the Democrats favored a shorter, less expansive inquiry, they in effect conceded that the nation deserves a formal conclusion to the charges of lying under oath, witness-tampering and obstruction of justice.

title: Starr's Legal Tactics Raise Troubling Questions; Starr Misled
description: To the Editor:

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT SAYS FUTURE EARNINGS ARE ON TRACK
description: A day after its shares fell 17 percent, Waste Management Inc. said yesterday that its earnings for the second half and next year would meet its expectations. Waste Management, the largest United States trash-disposal company, said it expected earnings to be $1.05 to $1.10 a share for the second half of the year and $3 to $3.05 for 1999. The company is expected to make $3.03 a share next year, according to a survey of analysts by the First Call Corporation. Waste Management shares closed yesterday at $38.625, down 37.5 cents. The share price fell 17 percent on Wednesday after an analyst reduced earnings expectations for the company because of concern that a recently completed merger would not increase growth overseas.

title: France Seeks Talks on Iraqi Chemical Tests
description: France asked today for a meeting of technical experts at the United Nations to ''clarify'' the results of tests its scientists carried out on Iraqi warheads. Earlier American tests had found traces of chemicals linked to VX, a deadly nerve gas .

title: Campaign Reform: None Too Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Cable Franchises Renewed
description: After months of intense negotiations, New York City and Cablevision Systems Corporation yesterday announced an agreement to renew the cable company's franchises in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Clear Channel to Buy Jacor For $2.8 Billion in Stock
description: Clear Channel Communications agreed yesterday to pay $2.8 billion in stock for Jacor Communications, the broadcaster that brings Rush Limbaugh, Dr. Laura Schlessinger and other radio personalities to the nation.

title: Gee, What a Night for Romance: You, Me and the Moonlight (Ribet)
description: Marcia has some serious boy problems. She's gaga for Mike, the handsome new crooner over at that slick dive, Noam Pearlstein's Pearl Onion. Although he's taken a shine to Marcia, too, Mike is the weak, silent type, and here's where it all gets, well, a little slimy. Mike's weakness isn't vodka or cocaine, fast cars or easy money. It's frogs.

title: Bank of England Lowers Rate a Quarter-Point
description: The Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point today, reflecting concern about global financial turmoil and fears of recession among British exporters and manufacturers.

title: NATO Plans to Intensify Its Pressure on Milosevic in Stages
description: The NATO effort to persuade the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to back down is following a clear track, senior American and NATO officials said today. It is designed to ratchet up the political and military pressure, while providing him various opportunities to change his mind.

title: Residential Real Estate; From an Abandoned Summer Camp Site to Waterside Estates
description: Sales began last month for the first houses at what eventually will be the largest single-family detached-home subdivision in Whitestone, Queens, in more than three decades, with prices ranging from $500,000 to nearly $1 million.

title: The Beauty of Closed Doors
description: The House has taken the giant step, kicking off the first formal impeachment inquiry of a President since Richard Nixon. This has led some to draw parallels between the House Judiciary Committee's deliberations and the deliberations made by the same committee in 1974. Indeed there are similarities -- but the contrasts are more striking. The Nixon era committee and the Clinton era committee reflect sharply different approaches.

title: Service for Michael Palm
description: A memorial service for Michael D. Palm, who contributed millions of dollars he earned in the reinsurance industry to benefit the arts, gay rights and AIDS treatment, will be held at 4 P.M Sunday at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center. He died Aug. 7. Rolf Huppi, chairman of Zurich Financial Services, will be among the speakers. Earl Wild, the pianist, and Camillia Johnson, the soprano, will perform. The service is public.

title: Politicians Seek Wider Role In European Central Bank
description: As financial gloom grew across Europe today, political leaders were running into deepening conflicts with European central banks over the best way to respond.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is not in my hands. It is in the hands of Congress and the people of this country, ultimately in the hands of God. There is nothing I can do.''

title: Raising Consciousness, Lightening Wallets
description: Widening the dewiest eyes this side of Bambi, Eddie Murphy turns up bald and beatific in ''Holy Man.'' Is he or isn't he the purest of beings, a sacred and unselfish soul? And what is his mission in this movie? If he is mostly here to provide much-needed wisdom to the crass television executive played by Jeff Goldblum, who has crassness down to a science, then ''Holy Man'' needs some spiritual enlightenment of its own.

title: Senate Rivals Try to Juggle Duties and Denunciations
description: At the Republican National Committee on Second Street, allies of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato held a news conference today to chide Representative Charles E. Schumer, Mr. D'Amato's Democratic challenger, for missing 90 percent of the House Judiciary Committee's votes this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, STANLEY
description: ROSENBLATT-Stanley ''Rosie''. Age 77, beloved husband and friend of Janice (Levine). Devoted father of Melvin (Maralyn) and Helene (Ken). Adored son of the late Estelle and Benjamin. Feisty World War II Coast Guard Veteran LST 787-Coxswain LCVP D-Day Iwo Jima, Okinawa and the Occupation of Japan. Retired NYPD, Farmer and US Postal Service. Services today, 11:30AM, at Beth Shalom Chapels Inc, 760 Smithtown By-Pass, Smithtown, NY.

title: Acid-Washed Family
description: It has taken only two films, ''Welcome to the Dollhouse'' and now ''Happiness,'' for Todd Solondz (below) to establish one of the most lacerating, funny and distinctive voices in American films.

title: Knoblauch's Knuckleheaded Play
description: If the New York Yankees needed any further incentive to beat the Cleveland Indians in the American League playoff series and move on to the World Series, Chuck Knoblauch has given it to them. Only a victory will allow forgiveness of Knoblauch's blunder that gave the Indians the winning run on Wednesday night. If the Yankees lose, Knoblauch will forever be remembered in the same company as Fred (Bonehead) Merkle, who failed to touch second base in a critical game in 1908.

title: Metro Business; WFMU Finds New Offices
description: WFMU, the alternative radio station marooned on the deserted East Orange campus of bankrupt Upsala College, has moved to a 10,000-square-foot building in Jersey City, the station manager said yesterday.

title: Little Progress for G.O.P. and White House on Spending Bills
description: With their deadline just hours away, Congressional Republicans and the White House made little progress today toward resolving their differences over the must-pass spending bills needed to keep the Government open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE L.
description: McCABE-Eugene L. The Board of Directors and Staff of Weston United Community Renewal, Inc. deeply mourn the untimely death of our Board President and distinguished leader, Eugene L. McCabe. His compassion and profound commitment to all of those in medical need assured that the least fortunate are entitled to receive services with dignity and respect. His leadership created a new vision, beacon of hope, and inspiration to those whom we serve. Mr. McCabe will be deeply missed, but his inspirational presence will be constant and secure as we move forward in making his dream a reality. The work done by Mr. McCabe will forever speak for him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and to The North General Hospital community. M. Moran Weston, Founder and Pres. Emeritus Sharon Lockhart-Carter

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Global Turmoil May Slow Nation's Buoyant Economy

title: Afghan Women Are U.S. Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KONKOY, WILLIAM J.
description: KONKOY-William J. Forever in my heart

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Nancy Davidson

title: Makes a Vipers' Nest Look Downright Cozy
description: ''I don't allow smoking in my house, and I don't appreciate having an antique incense burner used as an ashtray,'' snaps Wes Westlund (David Strathairn), an embittered, prissy academic, to Kim Matthews (Caroleen Feeney), his seductive chain-smoking house guest, in Jonathan Kaufer's pitch-black comedy ''Bad Manners.''

title: Revolution Player Fined for Remarks
description: Doug Logan, the commissioner of Major League Soccer, fined Edwin Gorter of the New England Revolution $20,000 yesterday and suspended him for the first two games of next season for racial remarks Gorter made against a teammate, David Nakhid. The fine is the largest in the three-year history of the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGANE, DOROTHEA MILLER
description: COGANE-Dorothea Miller. On Oct. 6, 1998. Long time resident of Massapequa. Beloved wife of the late songwriter Nelson Cogane. Loving mother of Karen Cherie Cogane. Dearest sister of Zondal Miller, M.D. Religious service on Friday at 7:15 P.M. at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (2 traffic lights east of Rt. 135). Cremation private. Hours on Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Hunt Slonem

title: Federal Judge Deals Microsoft A Setback on Antitrust Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge dealt the Microsoft Corporation a setback in its pretrial antitrust suit preparations yesterday by denying the company access to the interview tapes and transcripts for a new book written by two business school professors.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: N.B.A. and Players Getting Nowhere
description: The first substantive talks in more than two months between opposing sides of the National Basketball Association's labor dispute came and went yesterday without a hint of a settlement.

title: Umpires Taking A Bigger Role
description: In earlier eras in baseball, umpires felt they were doing a good job if no one noticed them or talked about them. In this year's playoffs, people everywhere have noticed the umpires and, oh, are they talking about them.

title: Starr's Legal Tactics Raise Troubling Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUGER, MARY SALES
description: CRUGER-Mary Sales. On Wednesday, October 7, died at the Ramapo Manor Nursing Home after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of the late Bertram de Nully Cruger, KBE. Beloved mother of Maryvan Pendl and mother-in-law of Ulrich Pendl. A memorial service will be held at Saint Mary's in Tuxedo on Saturday, October 10 at 12Noon. She was greatly loved.

title: Metro Business; Saks Plans a Store At Shopping Mall
description: Saks Fifth Avenue will announce today the fate of its Garden City branch in light of its plans to open a new site at the nearby Roosevelt Field shopping mall, store officials said today.

title: Armenia's Present
description: To the Editor:

title: Officers Are Accused Of Misusing Computers
description: Nearly half of the Oakland Police Department in Bergen County could be suspended and even demoted after being accused of using the mobile computers in their patrol cars to send each other inappropriate electronic messages.

title: Republican Leads Race for Glenn's Senate Seat
description: The last time George V. Voinovich ran for office, he won re-election as Ohio's Governor with 72 percent of the vote, stunning even his most optimistic supporters and setting a 20th-century record for victory margins in Ohio politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLSTEIN, BENJAMIN
description: WOLSTEIN-Benjamin, Ph.D. On October 7, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Irma Holland. Loving uncle of Carlos Wolstein. Dear great-uncle of Patricia & Claudia. Service on Friday, at 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BARBARA M.
description: BROWN-Barbara M. PhD. Of New Hyde Park, N.Y. on Oct. 8, 1998. Life partner of Cara Donaldson, PhD. Beloved mother of Jodi Lehrman & Stacey Brown. Loving Bubbe of Rebecca & Robin Lehrman. Memorial Service Saturday 1PM-3PM, Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Av, Williston Park, New York. In lieu of flowers donations in Barbara's memory to Parker Comprehensive Hospice Services, Coalition Against Domestic Violence or the Coalition Against Child Abuse and Neglect would be greatly appreciated.

title: INSIDE
description: Padres Beat Braves Again For 2-0 Playoff Lead

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Peter Saul

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY / Buying and Leasing; G.M. Runs the Shows To Spread Its Message
description: PEOPLE used to go to auto shows to see new car models from all companies and then to a particular dealer to test-drive the one they liked. Now General Motors, eager to regain market share, is trying a new way to sell cars; it is putting on its own one-company auto shows, where visitors can take test drives, to raise the chance that when the customer goes to a dealer, it will belong to G.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, STEPHEN DOW
description: FULLER-Stephen Dow. Age 90, passed away after a short illness Oct. 6, 1998 at St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, New York. Survived by his beloved wife, Emily Hurry Fuller. He is also survived by daughters, Emily Fuller Kingston of New York City and Ann B. Fuller of Big Horn, Wyoming & a son, Stephen W. Fuller of Joplin, Missouri. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Samuel S.R. Kingston, Sage Daly, Aeron Daly, Cary R. Fuller, Jane B. Fuller and Emily A. Fuller. The funeral service will be on Friday, Oct. 9, at 11AM at Christ Episcopal Church, East Main St., Oyster Bay, NY. Friends may call at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, New York, Thursday 5-7 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in memory of Mr. Fuller may be sent to Christ Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Taken Off the Case, a Cop Disobeys Orders, and Pays
description: When it comes to staying on the cutting edge of urban realism, police movies have increasingly fallen behind television drama in evoking the texture of urban life. And Bruno Barreto's film ''One Tough Cop,'' although strongly acted and pungently written (by Jeremy Iacone), is no exception. Despite a hearty two-fisted performance by Stephen Baldwin as the tattooed lug of a main character, the movie feels faintly old hat as well as mechanically contrived.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALM, MICHAEL D.
description: PALM-Michael D. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 11th at 4:00PM at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Michael Palm Foundation, P.O. Box 20189, New York, New York 10014.

title: Excerpts From President's Remarks at Meeting on Budget Matters
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks today before a meeting with his economic team, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Mr. Clinton was asked a question by reporters.

title: Kanell Hopes to Fix Mistakes
description: Last Sunday, after the worst game of his 25-game National Football League career, Danny Kanell went around apologizing to members of the defense for his poor performance in a 20-3 loss to the Buccaneers. Kanell threw three interceptions and completed 10 of 27 passes for only 83 yards.

title: Former Officer Gets 7 1/2 Years In Man's Death
description: In a case that galvanized a bitter debate about police brutality in New York City, a Federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a former police officer, Francis X. Livoti, to seven and a half years in prison yesterday for violating the Federal civil rights of Anthony Baez, who died after a 1994 confrontation with police officers outside his family's home in the Bronx.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: An Appetite For Language

title: The Play's the Thing, but to Yankees, It's Forgotten
description: The Yankees were hesitant to open the doors to the visiting clubhouse before their optional workout at Jacobs Field this afternoon. Just wait for some more players to arrive, they requested. It was a curious decision because Chuck Knoblauch, the Yankee virtually everyone wanted to interview, had already strolled in.

title: Partly Tango, Partly Classical, Partly Four-Alarm Fire
description: Popular music is taking dead aim at its upscale neighbors this season. A convergence of Kurt Weill events and the Gershwin centennial tell us that low culture can no longer be treated as a vulgar nemesis to concert and opera life. Astor Piazzolla's ''Maria de Buenos Aires'' at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn on Wednesday night offered a further suggestion: the music of the streets is not raw material ready for the classical composer's refining touch but a legitimate art in itself.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: GATEWAY INC., North Sioux City, S.D., the maker of personal computers, named John Todd senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding David McKittrick, who retired earlier this year. Mr. Todd had been chief financial officer at Allied Signal Engines in Phoenix.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKOFER, JOHN R.
description: BIRKOFER-John R. The Members of The Board of Trustees of The Catholic Charities of The Archdiocese of New York record with heartfelt sympathy the death of John R. Birkofer. He served as a Member of our Board of Trustees for many years. We treasure greatly the inspiration of his leadership and the wisdom of his counsel. His loving service and his generous giving of himself and his talents have been an outstanding example of faith and love in action and have given new hope to families, children, the aged, the sick, the handicapped and all served by Catholic Charities. We thank God for his life with us and we express our sincere condolences to his family. John Cardinal O'Connor, President Rev. Msgr. James J. Murray, Secretary

title: Gunpowder Markers Not Feasible, Panel Says
description: There are no proven ways to tag or mark gunpowder to make it more easily detectable or to deter its use in bombings, a National Research Council panel said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AGRIBIOTECH INC., Las Vegas, Nev., a turf and forage seed company, said it had hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to explore ways of maximizing shareholder value.

title: Hedge Fund Protectors
description: To the Editor:

title: Competition for Credit Cards
description: Americans are bombarded constantly by telephone and mail solicitations for credit cards, offering all sorts of incentives to apply. So it may be hard for many to believe that Visa and Mastercard, which dominate the field, are guilty of restricting the choices for consumers, as the Justice Department charged in an antitrust suit filed this week. But the department has marshaled impressive evidence that these two credit card companies have conspired to stifle competition between themselves and keep other competitors out.

title: Defense Helps Virginia Tech Make Bigger Splash in Rain
description: When the special teams are truly special and the defense lives up to its national rankings, it does not matter that you are down to your third-string quarterback -- a converted safety -- and monsoon conditions are squirting the ball every which way but safely into your team's hands. Or so Virginia Tech proved tonight in beating Boston College, 17-0, in a game only meteorologists could enjoy.

title: Honda Is Joining Roadster Competition With S2000
description: FIRST it was the BMW Z3. Then the Mercedes-Benz SLK230 Kompressor followed. On its heels came the Porsche Boxster. This spring the Audi TT arrives.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Back in the Saddle Again: Equestrian Dreams
description: Spice and Poison waited patiently for the light as cars whizzed through the chaotic traffic circle below Prospect Park. Spice was a smallish mare, but on her back I was nearly eye-level with the distant ''Don't Walk'' sign. The light changed and Walker Blankinship, my instructor and the owner of Kensington Stables, moved Poison into the street. Spice lagged behind, and the light changed again before we were across. Blankinship called over his shoulder, ''Horses have right of way in New York City.''

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 6
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Hong Kong Journal; McDonald's Is in the Doghouse (Snoopy Did It)
description: In this status-obsessed city, where Rolls-Royces and Rolexes seem to outnumber Toyotas and Timexes, the most prized of all possessions these days is a 75-cent plastic beagle.

title: Starr's Legal Tactics Raise Troubling Questions; Hamilton's Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Lyman Ford, 89, Who Headed A Precursor to the United Way
description: Lyman S. Ford, who in the 1960's was president of what became United Way of America and who pushed the old Community Chests to become a financing channel for President Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty, died Monday of pneumonia at a hospice in Hillsborough, N.C., United Way of America said. He was 89.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Kapp

title: 5 Teen-Agers Behind Bars in Gang Attacks
description: For the past year, as the police and neighbors tell it, a dozen or so teen-agers in Morris Heights in the Bronx tried to build a name for themselves by shoplifting from local stores, threatening passers-by, and slashing a few of those they didn't like. Their goal, police investigators said, was to become known as the Bloods, emulating their Los Angeles-based namesake, whose violent exploits have been popularized through rap and movies.

title: Dazzling and Devout Voodoo Energy
description: The 1990's have been watershed years for art. Building on the multicultural thinking of the previous decade, traditional esthetic categories and hierarchies have been radically revised; cultural geographies have been remapped.

title: A Lawmaker From Arkansas Takes a Solitary Stand
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich urged him not to do it. So did an angry Representative Tom DeLay, the House Republican whip. But Representative Jay Dickey of Arkansas did not listen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWITKO, IRVING D.
description: KWITKO-Irving D., age 87, born in Russia and resided for many years in Brooklyn and North Miami Beach, Florida with his late beloved wife Sally. Survived by daughter Gloria Bell and son-inlaw Donald of Palm Beach Garden, Florida and son Edward and daughter-in-law Carla of Melville, Long Island. Loving grandfather of Amy, Brian, David and Seth and four great grandchildren. He was a founding director of Jenapo Federal Credit Union in Brooklyn. He will be missed by all for his kindness and charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAILING, LEWIS IRA
description: RAILING-Lewis Ira, age 76, of New York City, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, at Newport Hospital, Newport, RI, after a long illness. He was the husband of the late Trudy Kalbfleisch Railing of Wheeling, W.V. Born in Baltimore, on September 23, 1923, he was the son of the late Lewis Ira and Edna Creighton Railing. Mr. Railing lived and worked in NYC most of his career. He graduated in 1940, from Baltimore City College High School and did post-graduate work at Baltimore Polytechnic Institute. He attended the Colorado School of Mines in Golden, CO., until 1944, when he joined the U.S. Corps of Engineers, Third Army, under General George Patton. He was awarded a Battlefield Promotion and discharged with the rank of Major. He received his BS from Colorado School of Mines in Geological Mining Engineering in 1947. He subsequently attended Harvard Business School. He was associated with Ford, Bacon and Davis, Co., for 20 years, as an independent engineering consultant; he spent nine months in Bolivia as a consultant for construction and operation of underground installations. He also acted as a consultant to Guggenheim, Bros, Asbestos Corp, Ltd., South American Gold and Platinum Co. For the last ten years, he was Research Consultant for the investment firm of Ruane, Cunniff, the Sequoia Fund, in NYC. He received a MS degree in Transportation Management from State University of NY in 1965. He most recently was a Doctoral Candidate at Pace University, majoring in management, economics and finance. He leaves a sister, Dorrie R. Richardson, of Newport, RI, and Vero Beach, FL: three sons, Chip Railing and Bill Railing of Wheeling, WV; Andrew Railing of Charlottesville, VA, and eight grandchildren. Memorial Service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the Colorado School of Mines Alumna Association, 1600 Arapaho Street, Golden, CO. 80401.

title: Theater Review: 'Swan Lake' On Broadway; Drama Without the Words
description: His royal highness, the Prince, is face down on the sidewalk, and if there were a gutter in sight he would no doubt crawl right into it. It hasn't been a good day. His mother, a Dior-style version of the Evil Queen in Disney's ''Snow White,'' has made her dissatisfaction with him even clearer than usual by slapping him; an especially galling moment of public humiliation at the ballet has already hit the tabloids, and now he has been tossed out of the louche bar where he sought to forget it all.

title: Securities Association Seeks Change in Arbitration Rules
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers proposed changes today to its arbitration process for employment discrimination claims.

title: HICKS, MUSE TO BUY BOOKER SEED UNIT FOR $48.9 MILLION
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate and & Furst Inc. said yesterday that it would buy a Danish horticultural seed business for about $48.9 million from the British food wholesaler Booker P.L.C., expanding the leveraged buyout firm's interests in Europe. The Danish concern, L. Daehnfeldt A/S, which produces vegetable and flower seeds, had sales of about $47.3 million in 1997. Hicks, Muse, based in Dallas, and which has nine partners, is best known for its acquisitions in the media industry. It also has interests in the food industry.

title: Starr's Legal Tactics Raise Troubling Questions; What the Framers Said
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIFF-DAVIS TO SHUT 3 MAGAZINES AND CUT 350 JOBS
description: Ziff-Davis Inc., a major publisher of computing magazines, said yesterday that it would discontinue three publications and cut 350 jobs, or 10 percent of its United States work force. The New York-based company will stop publishing Internet Business, Equip and Windows Pro. Instead it will focus on stronger products like PC Magazine, PC Week, the Comdex trade show and its ZDNet technology Web site. Costs associated with the restructuring will lower fourth-quarter earnings by $50 million to $60 million, before taxes, the company said. Shares of Ziff-Davis fell 28 percent, falling $1.6875 each, to $4.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 Oil Giants To Combine Gas Stations
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation agreed yesterday to combine their gas station chains and refineries into a joint-venture company called Diamond 66.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about 10 statues recently installed above the main entrance of Westminster Abbey in London misattributed the design of the 18th-century towers flanking the facade. Although Christopher Wren did indeed supervise the upkeep of the abbey and propose building twin towers, the architect was Nicholas Hawksmoor.

title: Observer; Fire, Ice and Farce
description: Some say the end will come by fire, and some by ice, but I say farce is just as likely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, JOSEPH L.
description: WADE-Joseph L. On October 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Margaret. Devoted father of Mark Wade and Catherine Ware. Dear brother of James and Robert. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. John the Evangelist R.C. Church Saturday, 10AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: European Insurer Posts Strong First Half
description: AXA-UAP, Europe's second-largest insurance company, said yesterday that its profit rose by 42 percent in the first half as it benefited from strong life insurance income and a buoyant investment environment. AXA said its first-half profit rose to 6.04 billion francs ($1.12 billion), from 4.24 billion francs a year earlier. Revenue rose 6.3 percent, to 197.14 billion francs.

title: It's New York, New York, Boos in the 12th and All
description: The intensity of the boos aimed at Chuck Knoblauch on Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium took some Yankees by surprise, including right fielder Paul O'Neill.

title: Skip Away 2-5 in Gold Cup
description: Small but highly select fields totaling 33 horses were entered yesterday in the five Grade I stakes on Belmont Park's Breeders' Cup Preview tomorrow, with Skip Away installed as the runaway favorite at 2-5 to win the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: Detective Buddies and Racial Boundaries
description: Twenty-five years after it was first released, ''Detroit 9000'' -- with its tale of a womanizing Washington politician, campaign finance shenanigans, urban crime, suspicion and hostility between blacks and whites, and the moral question mark that hangs over its conclusion -- has attained the status of a valuable cultural gauge. Even the reason it is being reviewed now says something about life and attitudes toward race and film in these United States.

title: Huge Gains, and Huge Worries, on AIDS
description: The medical accomplishment has been astonishing. Not many years ago infection with the virus that causes AIDS was considered a death sentence. Virtually everyone infected, except for rare individuals with a peculiar natural resistance, would inexorably develop symptoms, become progressively sicker, and die. It might take 10 years or more for the virus to destroy the body's immune system, leaving it vulnerable to attack by a host of opportunistic infections, but the end was invariably the same -- premature death for individuals who were mostly in the prime of life.

title: The Bunt That Wasn't
description: There were questions about why Manager Joe Torre did not ask Shane Spencer to bunt with the score tied, 1-1, Homer Bush on first base and no one out in the bottom of the ninth inning on Wednesday. Initially, Torre did signal for a bunt. Spencer said he received the sign, but a timeout was called on the field and then the bunt was removed. Bush proceeded to steal second and Spencer expected to see a bunt sign again to get the winning run to third with one out. But Torre let the rookie hit and he struck out against Paul Shuey. The lost chance was significant because Bush never budged off second.

title: Afghan Women Are U.S. Concern; Zero Tolerance on Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Officials Tell of Talks On a Deal With Lewinsky
description: Executives from the Fox Broadcasting Company said yesterday that they had been negotiating with representatives of Monica S. Lewinsky to buy rights to her account of her affair with President Clinton.

title: Slight Drop Found in North America's Pollution
description: One of the first detailed studies of environmental pollution across North America shows a slight decrease in the amount of hazardous substances being released into the air, water and soil, but the improving record of American industry was largely offset by hefty increases in pollution by Canadian companies.

title: Vintage Prints, Superior, Eh? Not Always
description: For anyone interested in exploring the pros and cons of vintage prints -- those made within a few years after a negative is created -- exhibitions of work by Ansel Adams, Brett Weston and Gordon Parks, now at three Manhattan galleries, make intriguing, sometimes contradictory arguments.

title: Taking the Children; With Karate Kicks And Jabs Aplenty
description: Rush Hour

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGNOS, AMALIA
description: LIGNOS-Amalia. On October 8, 1998. Beloved wife of Nicholas. Devoted sister of John Falangas. Loving aunt. Reposing Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave, NYC. Services at Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral 319 E. 74th St Saturday 9:45 AM.

title: Cardinal Health Is Acquiring Allegiance Hospital Supply
description: Skirting antitrust concerns that derailed its attempt to acquire a competing drug wholesaler in July, Cardinal Health Inc. announced yesterday that it would buy the Allegiance Corporation, a hospital supply company, for $4.5 billion in stock and assume $890 million of its debt.

title: Atop Rocket, Glenn Is the Center of Attention Again
description: The space shuttle Discovery's engines shut down seconds before liftoff on Thursday, prompting Senator John Glenn to scramble out of the cockpit and run for his life -- knowing all the while that it was just a drill.

title: New Team Doesn't Know It's Supposed to Lose
description: Bryant College of Smithfield, R.I., playing its first season of football in the school's 135 years, has skipped the growing pains and gone straight to the growing. The Bulldogs are 2-0, having beaten Dean College, 20-19, and Assumption, 30-14. The latter is a more significant victory because Assumption belongs to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II Eastern Football Conference that Bryant will join next year.

title: Congress Works on a Tax-Cut Package That Could Win Bipartisan Support
description: With the Republican plan for a big tax cut having died without coming to a vote in the Senate, Congress scrambled today to put together a far smaller tax package that could win bipartisan support.

title: A U.S. Message to Milosevic Turns Into Full-Dress Talks
description: What was initially described as a mission of Richard C. Holbrooke delivering a message to Slobodan Milosevic --comply or else on Kosovo -- has turned into negotiations that are being dubbed a ''mini-Dayton,'' American officials said today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLUMPS. The dollar dropped further against the yen for a weekly decline of 13.8 percent, its biggest fall since major currencies went off the gold standard in 1971. The dollar fell to 116.95 yen, from 119.05 Thursday.

title: Making the Farm Worker's Life Even Harder
description: Congress is working out a plan that, if adopted, could make conditions for American farm workers worse than they have been since 1965.

title: Another Indignity for Islanders: Opener Isn't on Local TV
description: The Islanders will open their season against the Penguins tonight, but the game will not be shown to cable television viewers by Fox Sports New York.

title: Op-Art; 'E.R.' It Ain't
Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNN, PETER HARWOOD
description: GUNN-Peter Harwood. Age 72. An Englishman living in New York for 26 years. Father of Jeremy and James. Countless friends, lover of nature, music, history and the arts. Passed away unexpectedly on October 5, 1998. To be remembered at Dimiceli & Sons, 182 Lexington Avenue from 5PM to 7PM on Tuesday, October 13. In lieu of flowers, donations to Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Maddux Is Hoping To Quiet The Crowd
description: The San Diego Padres are expecting more than 60,000 fans at Qualcomm Stadium this weekend, a far cry from the turnouts at Turner Field in Atlanta, where there were at least 7,000 empty seats each for Game 1 and Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Economic Slump Bypasses Kazakhstan
description: Richard Morningstar, the White House special adviser on Caspian Sea affairs, had just fulfilled one of his principal missions -- defending the United States law restraining investment in Iran. Then he got an earful.

title: Where's the Romance of the Open Road?; In the Past, Homeless Meant Footloose; Today, It's Just Misery
description: Stuck in the streets of high-rent downtowns and depressed inner cities like abandoned wreckage at the rim of the highway, today's homeless seem to be the least mobile of Americans.

title: 102 Indicted in Crack Sales to White-Collar Workers
description: Law enforcement officials announced the indictment yesterday of 102 members of three drug operations that discreetly sold millions of dollars' worth of crack cocaine to white-collar workers in midtown Manhattan over the last decade.

title: Village Tilts at the Megamall That Lured Its Shoppers Away; Former Long Island Retail Mecca Tries Comeback
description: This wealthy village has long fancied its main thoroughfare, Franklin Avenue, as the Fifth Avenue of Long Island.

title: At a Wal-Mart, a Rush to Win Turns Into a Crush
description: One minute before 8 on Thursday evening, 9-year-old Melissa Morgan was sitting on the floor of a Wal-Mart in Brick, N.J., crowded together with 200 other keyed-up children, waiting to scramble for balloons with prizes inside.

title: Schroder Tells Clinton He Backs Action by NATO in Kosovo
description: The German Chancellor-elect, Gerhard Schroder, told President Clinton today that he would support a decision by the caretaker German Government to authorize NATO to use force over Kosovo if necessary.

title: Chang Chong-Jen, 93, Model for Character in Tintin Comic
description: Chang Chong-Jen, a Chinese painter and sculptor who inspired the comic strip artist known as Herge to create Chang, one of the most loved characters in the renowned Tintin books, died on Thursday at an artists' retirement home outside Paris. He was 93.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph F. Speyer, 72, Geneticist Who Advanced Study of Mutation
description: Dr. Joseph F. Speyer, a molecular geneticist at the University of Connecticut whose early work on mutant genes helped build the foundation for modern molecular genetics and biotechnology, died on Oct. 2 at his home in Willington, Conn. He was 72.

title: Judge Allows Detainees to Sue I.N.S. Officials
description: In a decision that could change the way asylum seekers are treated in immigration detention centers, a Federal judge in New Jersey has ruled that immigration officials can be sued for violating the human rights of detainees at a center in Elizabeth.

title: Killer Blames His Therapist, and Jury Agrees
description: The last time Wendell Williamson drew national attention, it was one January day in 1995. He seemed to come out of nowhere, firing an M-1 rifle on a busy street near the campus of the University of North Carolina, where he was a law student, and killing two men he had never met.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Fairness, Not Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: An Impertinent Bid Pays Off In an Annual Charity Game
description: One of the biggest charity games in the New York metropolitan area was played Thursday night at Temple Emmanuel in Kings Point, N.Y. It was the annual AIDS Awareness game of the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association, and it raised more than $31,000 for the North Shore Hospital AIDS Research Center.

title: Shin-Etsu to Buy Vinyl Businesses
description: The Shin-Etsu Chemical Company agreed late on Thursday to buy most of the vinyl businesses of Royal Dutch/ Shell Group and the Dutch chemical maker Akzo Nobel N.V. for an estimated $200 million, making it the world's No. 1 maker of polyvinyl chloride plastic, or PVC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKOFER, JOHN R.
description: BIRKOFER-John R. The Members of The Board of Trustees of The Catholic Charities of The Archdiocese of New York record with heartfelt sympathy the death of John R. Birkofer. He served as a Member of our Board of Trustees for many years. We treasure greatly the inspiration of his leadership and the wisdom of his counsel. His loving service and his generous giving of himself and his talents have been an outstanding example of faith and love in action and have given new hope to families, children, the aged, the sick, the handicapped and all served by Catholic Charities. We thank God for his life with us and we express our sincere condolences to his family. John Cardinal O'Connor, President Rev. Msgr. James J. Murray, Secretary

title: Nabokov Son Files Suit To Block a Retold 'Lolita'
description: What if Lolita didn't die at the end? What if she kept a diary and had her own story to tell?

title: Italy's Center-Left Government Is Toppled by One Vote
description: By only one vote, the center-left Prime Minister of Italy, Romano Prodi, lost a confidence vote in Parliament today and was toppled from power.

title: Medicare H.M.O.'s
description: The move by several big health maintenance organizations to end their Medicare coverage in counties where they are losing money should come as no surprise. In their headlong rush to capture part of the huge Medicare market of 38 million Americans, many H.M.O.'s have made inaccurate financial projections and now realize they cannot provide comprehensive care at the cost they expected. Some 400,000 Medicare beneficiaries whose insurers are therefore cutting them loose will now have to find another H.M.O. or go into the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; No More Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Journal; A New Epic With a History of Its Own
description: As the crowd of mostly young Beijingers filed in from the misty night off Tiananmen Square, it was obvious this was not your everyday world film premiere. Sure, there were cameras flashing, huge movie posters and a high proportion of men with ponytails.

title: Bill to Punish Nations Limiting Religious Beliefs Passes Senate
description: The Senate today unanimously approved a compromise bill that would require the Government to deal with countries that persecute citizens for religious beliefs by using measures ranging from the mildest private rebuke to tough economic sanctions.

title: Gay Man Beaten and Left for Dead; 2 Are Charged
description: At first, the passing bicyclist thought the crumpled form lashed to a ranch fence was a scarecrow. But when he stopped, he found the burned, battered and nearly lifeless body of Matthew Shepard, an openly gay college student who had been tied to the fence 18 hours earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBIN, WILLIAM
description: TAUBIN-William. On October 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Jeanette. Loving father of the late Richard, Helene and Jane. Dear husband of the late Doris. Devoted brother of Adele and Annette. Adoring grandfather of Wendy, Lara and Katja. Cherished fatherin-law of Peter Marsman. Bill was a highly decorated and awarded Art Director in the advertising industry. Bill was a distinguished member and former president of the Advertising Art Directors Club. Bill will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Service on Tuesday, 12:30 P.M., at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Yen's Rise Against Dollar Is Threatening Japanese Exports
description: The yen's sudden jump against the dollar this past week threatens to take the momentum out of Japan's exports by making it more costly for America and other foreign markets to buy Japanese products.

title: Drop Seen in Orange Crop
description: Florida's new orange crop will be 22 percent smaller than last year's record harvest, the Government said today. Orange juice futures prices soared 26 percent after the Department of Agriculture estimated the 1998-99 Florida crop at 190 million boxes, each weighing 90 pounds, down from last year's record harvest of 244 million boxes and considerably below the 219 million boxes expected by analysts. The Florida crop, the nation's largest, has suffered from extreme weather.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Stops Rangers in a Lively Opener
description: Low-scoring hockey games need not be boring. The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers demonstrated this last night at Madison Square Garden in their energetic season opener. The pace was brisk, the hitting hard, the chances plentiful around the nets. Although the show was entertaining for the loud capacity crowd, the result was unsatisfying for the home fans as the orange-and-black-clad visitors headed home with a 1-0 victory.

title: Staten Island Rail Link Is Said to Be Imperiled
description: Union County's top administrator said yesterday that efforts to build a rail link in the county connecting to a Staten Island freight terminal were dead despite the announcement this week by officials in New York that the project would proceed.

title: INACOM SET TO BEGIN ACQUISITION OF VANSTAR
description: The Inacom Corporation will acquire the Vanstar Corporation for $480 million in stock, creating the world's largest distributor of I.B.M., Compaq and Hewlett-Packard computers to corporate customers. Vanstar shareholders will receive 0.64 Inacom share for each of the 44.6 million Vanstar shares outstanding. Based on Thursday's closing price, the deal values each Vanstar share at $10.76. The share prices of both companies fell yesterday. Shares of Inacom tumbled $1.5625, to $15.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, where shares of Vanstar fell 87.5 cents, to $7.50. Vanstar, with headquarters in Atlanta, builds and manages corporate computer networks. Inacom, based in Omaha, provides technology management services.

title: A Wild Card in the Mideast
description: Just days before heading to the United States for critical negotiations with Palestinian leaders, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has jolted the Middle East peace effort with the appointment of Ariel Sharon as Israeli Foreign Minister. The most optimistic reading is that Mr. Sharon, long an implacable foe of the Palestinians, is prepared to make peace with them and then sell it to the Israelis who are most opposed. Unfortunately, he is also capable of wrecking the entire peace effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELKOWITZ, MORTIMER, M.D.
description: WELKOWITZ - Mortimer, M.D. Services Sunday 11 A.M., Mount Sinai Memorial Park. Mount Sinai Mortuary, Los Angeles, California

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; One-Sided Argument
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Grows Into Spending By City Unions
description: The Manhattan District Attorney yesterday broadened his investigation into possible corruption in the municipal labor unions, demanding financial documents from 40 locals of District Council 37, the umbrella group that represents 120,000 city workers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZARUCKI, CHARLES S.
description: ZARUCKI-Charles S. Dear Charlie, this would have been your 75th birthday. We love and miss you every day. Rose, Betsy and Jud

title: When Playgoers Take Up the Gauntlet
description: Why is that man on the stage? He's not even an actor, for heaven's sake, only a playwright, and everyone knows how exciting they are these days. And it's not as if he's talking about anything really juicy, like personal problems with substance abuse or gender identity, or firing off zippy one-liners. His subject, if you please, is the irreconcilable differences in the Middle East, something you can read about in almost any newspaper any day of the year. Why bother to go the to theater?

title: The Roar of the Accountants; The Strange Last Days of a Theater Impresario's Reign
description: As Garth H. Drabinsky watched the world premiere of ''Fosse: A Celebration in Song and Dance'' in August, he knew the stakes were high. The entertainment company he had founded -- Livent Inc., based in Toronto -- had struggled for months to pay its bills. Its credit was so poor that its bonds were considered junk.

title: Dow and Nasdaq Rally to End Turbulent Week on Wall Street
description: The stock market rallied yesterday, with the technology-heavy Nasdaq index jumping 5.2 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 2.2 percent.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Schippers's Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Skip Away Is Victory From Being Richest
description: On the day before his attempt to become the leading money-winner in racing, Skip Away galloped a mile and three-quarters at Belmont Park yesterday, and his trainer expressed full confidence in his star horse regardless of whether the track came up wet or dry.

title: 2 Suicides and an Attempt Raise Concern at Columbia
description: A senior on the dean's list leapt to her death from a 20th-floor window. A troubled engineering student, taking a semester off, hanged himself in his home on Long Island. A student at a popular fraternity stabbed himself twice in the chest and barely survived.

title: INSIDE
description: Wall Street's Wild Week

title: Gordon Is Winston Cup Leader But Not a Lock for His 3d Title
description: To win his second straight Winston Cup championship and his third in six years, Jeff Gordon doesn't need to win a race, he just needs to finish fifth or better in each of the season's final five races.

title: TRAMMELL CROW CALLS OFF PLANS FOR SALE OF STOCK
description: The Trammell Crow Company, one of the largest real estate service companies in the United States, said yesterday that it had called off plans to sell five million common shares because of poor market conditions. The Dallas-based company, which went public in November, registered with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in July to sell the shares in a secondary offering. Since then the shares have fallen more than 50 percent. The company cited ''the deterioration in market conditions'' for its decision. Trammel Crow's stock rose $1.50 a share, to $17. Trammell Crow, which provides property management and brokerage services, manages more than 400 million square feet of space throughout the country.

title: ISRAELI HAWK GETS FOREIGN MINISTRY
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appointed Ariel Sharon, the hawkish former Defense Minister, to be Israel's Foreign Minister today in an effort to placate the far right as he moves closer to turning over more West Bank land to the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE KAY, ORMONDE
description: De KAY-Ormonde. Writer, historian, poet, editor. Beloved husband of Barbara, father of Thomas, brother of George and James Tertius, stepfather of Lenore and Philip Roosevelt, step-grandfather of three, friend of hundreds, maybe thousands. Wrote books, film scripts, light verse and articles over a 50 year career. Served on destroyer escorts in WW II and Korean War. Born in New York City on December 17, 1923. He died there after a brief illness on October 9, 1998. Interment will be private at St. George's Church in Hempstead, New York. A memorial service will be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Authors League Fund for writers in financial distress.

title: Cuba's Folkloric Severity
description: It's the rigor that's immediately obvious, the strict adherence to the rule of its particular musical law. When Grupo Afro Cuba, a folkloric group from the town of Matanzas in Cuba, opened its first set at S.O.B.'s on Monday night, the precision in the placement of notes, the accuracy of the singing and the quick formal changes all argued for what the group was playing as some of the most complicated popular music in the world.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Filegate Forgotten?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; To Spare the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Bankruptcy Legislation
description: The number of people abusing the bankruptcy law to stiff their creditors is probably not very large, but the fact that there are some who do it brings the law into disrepute. Just this week, the actor Burt Reynolds had his bankruptcy plan approved. Creditors will lose millions, but Mr. Reynolds will remain a millionaire, as did Bowie Kuhn, the former baseball commissioner, some years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Citigroup's third-quarter results misstated the two chief executives' plans for their work force. While they still plan to eliminate several thousand jobs, as was announced on Sept. 17, they said yesterday that they planned no further job cuts beyond that.

title: GE CAPITAL AGREES TO ADD EAGLE STAR REINSURANCE
description: GE Capital agreed yesterday to acquire the Eagle Star Reinsurance Company from Zurich Financial Services. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The companies said the sale does not include business written by Eagle Star before 1993. Eagle Star, based in London, provides reinsurance around the world in the property, casualty and marine markets. It will become a part of GE Capital's Employers Reinsurance Corporation, a reinsurance company in Overland Park, Kan.
