Zurich Financial Services, based in Zurich, is the operating unit of Zurich Allied A.G. and Allied Zurich P.L.C. GE Capital, based in Stamford, Conn., is the global financial services arm of the General Electric Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about black-oriented Web sites omitted the caption for a picture showing a sculpture of a woman with her left hand on her chin. The sculpture was ''Phillis Wheatley'' by Elizabeth Catlett, from the Neuberger Museum of Art.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; A Basis for Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Offense at a Premium In the Post-Season
description: Circumstances could be worse for the Yankees' hitters. They could be facing the San Diego Padres' pitchers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Taliban are too religious for me, but they have stopped the thefts and the killings. Maybe someday they will also figure out how to supply some food.''

title: There's Not Much to Say After a Stunning Defeat
description: George Steinbrenner sat on a table in the trainer's room tonight, looking exhausted and exasperated after the Yankees skidded to a 6-1 loss to the Indians and into their most perilous position of this glorious season. Steinbrenner dangled his legs over the table, sometimes kicking them back and forth like a child on a swing.

title: A Three-Homer Inning Pushes Indians Ahead
description: The Yankees offered odes to confidence after their season of staggering achievement fell into jeopardy tonight. David Cone, Joe Girardi and others insisted that everything would be O.K., that the Yankees would ultimately prevail against Cleveland in the American League Championship Series.

title: Think Tank; So, You Care About History? Get Out of the Classroom and Onto TV
description: Simon Schama, a humanities professor at Columbia University, is to deliver the New York Council for the Humanities Scholar of the Year address on Wednesday at the Donnell Library Center in Manhattan (reservations: 212-233-1131, ext. 43). Following are excerpts from the lecture, ''Visualizing History'':

title: Microsoft Suit Pushed Back Until Oct. 19
description: A Federal judge today pushed back the starting date of the antitrust trial against the Microsoft Corporation by four days, to Oct. 19, while also ordering the company to comply with the Justice Department's request to examine Microsoft's financial records.

title: STATE OF MISERY: A special report.; Afghans Ruled by Taliban: Poor, Isolated, but Secure
description: Kabul's largest children's hospital, like Afghanistan itself, is a study in want.

title: William E. Griffith, 78, Expert on Communism
description: William E. Griffith, a historian and political scientist who was an authority on Communism, the cold war and Central and Eastern Europe, died on Sept. 28 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 78 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: The Cyber Donald
description: No trophy wives. No gaudy Rolexes, Julian Schnabel paintings or custom-made Armani suits. No Gordon Gekkos, Sherman McCoys, Donald Trumps. The 1990's model of high-flying self-made zillionaire, we've been repeatedly told, is as different from his 1980's predecessor as a fully loaded Jeep is from a Porsche. Instead of vulgar Reagan-era barbarians at the gate, we're getting dressed-down microgeeks who don't know or care how much money they have and are so busy dispensing utopia to the entire globe through technology that they don't have time to lord their good fortune over us peons who can't install a printer without crashing Windows.

title: Unapologetic Scrapper Enters Diplomatic Ring
description: Ariel Sharon has a law degree, and fancies himself a farmer. But for more than three decades his role in Israeli public life has been that of an unapologetic warrior, first on the battlefield and later in the bare-knuckled combat of domestic partisan politics.

title: Starr Faults Clinton Aide On Charge to High Court
description: The war of words between the independent counsel and the White House escalated again today when Kenneth W. Starr accused one of President Clinton's lawyers of deceiving the Supreme Court and wrongly accusing prosecutors of misconduct.

title: Sonic Boom Starts Quietly, With Talk
description: On Tuesday night Miller Theater instituted its New Works October series with a concert by the New York New Music Ensemble that also opened, or detonated, this year's Sonic Boom. More such events are to follow at the theater throughout the month, roughly every two or three days. There will be a strong emphasis on senior American composers: George Crumb, Ned Rorem, Ursula Mamlok and, most senior of all, Elliott Carter, to whom Speculum Musicae will devote a 90th-birthday celebration on the 27th, including two new pieces unheard in New York and the classic Double Concerto.

title: Hillary Clinton Heading to East Europe
description: This Sunday, on the 23d anniversary of her marriage to Bill Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton will be in Bulgaria, making a visit that morning to the Faith, Hope and Love Center, a shelter for homeless children in Sofia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cardinal Health Acquiring Allegiance for $4.5 Billion

title: SENATORS REJECT BILL TO REGULATE CARE BY H.M.O.'S
description: Legislation to give patients more power in dealing with health insurance companies died today, a casualty of heavy lobbying by the insurance industry and of the sex scandal that has enveloped President Clinton.

title: Judge Orders Brawley to Pay $185,000 for Defamation
description: The judge who presided over nine months of often contentious testimony in the Tawana Brawley slander suit issued his final decision in the case today, ruling that Ms. Brawley herself, the central, elusive character in this drawn-out melodrama, must pay $185,000 in damages for defaming Steven A. Pagones.

title: Dostoyevskian Fireworks, With Raving and Writhing
description: ''You cannot imagine what I have done!'' Rodion Raskolnikov shouts angrily at his best friend, Dmitri.

title: Martin's Injury May Give Anderson an Opportunity
description: The Jets prepared today for life without running back Curtis Martin, whose thigh injury will probably sideline him for Sunday's game against the St. Louis Rams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, JEROME O.D.
description: HURWITZ-Jerome O.D. Beloved husband of Hortense, devoted father of Sanford and Robert, father-in-law of Rhona, loving grandfather of Jade. Services at 11 A.M. on Sunday at Union Temple of Brooklyn, 17 Eastern Parkway. Memorial contributions to Union Temple of Brooklyn, or the Jewish Braille Institute would be deeply appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALHEIM, BETH
description: THALHEIM-Beth. An extraordinary person and devoted friend. We will miss her greatly. Morris and Doris Sobin and Family

title: Losses Are Said to Continue At Troubled Hedge Fund
description: Long-Term Capital, the troubled hedge fund, has suffered losses of $200 million to $300 million in the two weeks since it was saved by a Wall Street consortium, a financier involved with the fund said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the sentencing in a kick-back scheme of J. David Smith, a former national sales director for the Gtech Holdings Corporation, which runs New Jersey's state lottery, misstated the length of his sentence in some copies. It was 5 years and 3 months, not 50 years and 3 months.

title: Stephen Pearlman, 63, Actor In Movies, TV and Theater
description: Stephen Pearlman, a versatile character actor in theater, film and television, died on Sept. 30 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Profiting From Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOR, NAOMI
description: TOR-Naomi. An urban Planner, former Director of Planning in Yorktown on Oct. 8, 1998. Wife of Abba, Mother of Shuli and the late Daniel. Sister of Esse Blumenthal. Funeral on Sunday at 10AM, Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings on Hudson, NY 10706. Memorials in her name may be sent to the Temple.

title: Republicans Play to the Folks at Home
description: Nearly 60 years behind the times, the House voted today to condemn the Nazi-Soviet nonaggression pact of 1939.

title: Finally, It's Nixon's Revenge
description: I voted for Ronald Reagan. I voted for George Bush. And next month I am going to do the unthinkable: vote 100 percent straight Democratic. And I don't care who's running.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Who Among Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLISH, ALFRED
description: MARGOLISH-Alfred. On October 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Lois and Joan & loving grandfather of Michelle, Wendy, Eric and Craig. Services Sunday, October 11, 10:30 A.M., ''Gutterman's'', Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, THOMAS A., JR.
description: BRADLEY-Thomas A., Jr. Of Upper Brookville, Long Island, NY. Son of the late Irene Talley Bradley & the late Thomas A. Bradley, died peacefully on October 8, 1998, after a short illness. Devoted husband of Elise Cavanagh Bradley, beloved father of Elise B. Mackay, Belle C. Bradley, Renee B. Bradley, cherished grandfather of Christopher Bradley Merz & Wendy Allen Merz. Loving brother of Kate Dooley, Rosemary Corroon, Jeanne Kelly and the late Irene Parker. Funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, October 13, 1998 at 11:00 AM at St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Route 107, Brookville, NY. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove, N.Y. 11542.

title: Judge Urges Firing of Police Officer Who Rode on Racist Parade Float
description: A Police Department judge has ruled that a New York City police officer who admitted riding on a racist float during a Labor Day parade in Queens should be fired, according to a copy of the decision, which has not been made public. Police Commissioner Howard Safir, who would not confirm the details of the judge's ruling, said he would weigh the recommendation, officials said yesterday.

title: Goal for Hernandez: Stop the Indians Cold
description: Armed with a video camera he recently purchased, Orlando Hernandez walked through the Tower City Mall here today, taping sights and sounds within a symbol of capitalism, for the benefit of his two young daughters living in Cuba.

title: Justices to Hear Second Case On Census Use of Sampling
description: The Supreme Court today added a second census case to its calendar for argument next month, an action that could substantially increase the odds of producing a definitive and relatively quick ruling on whether the Clinton Administration can proceed with its plan to use statistical sampling to correct an expected undercount in the next census.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Starr's Temptation
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Step on Impeachment Path: Arguing About the Witness List
description: A day after the House authorized an impeachment inquiry against President Clinton, Judiciary Committee members appear to be at odds over what kind of investigation to conduct, with Democrats pushing to summon a parade of players in the scandal and Republicans suggesting narrowing the witness list.

title: Religion Journal; Defining Moral Failings, Both Private and Public
description: Just as the White House scandal involving Monica S. Lewinsky has left many Americans divided and angry, so it is becoming an increasingly public matter of contention among the nation's religious leaders.

title: Japan Life Insurers May See Ratings Cut
description: Japan's life insurers may see their credit ratings cut by Moody's Investors Service in the near to intermediate term amid the nation's worsening economy and stock market. ''Unrealized gains on equity portfolios have become unrealized losses for more and more life insurers,'' said Moody's, the credit rating agency. The continued decline is ''likely to place significant pressure on life insurers' solvency margins.''

title: OFFICEMAX NAMES ITS TAKEOVER SUITOR AS STAPLES
description: Officemax Inc., the third-largest United States office-supply retailer, confirmed late Thursday that the takeover bid it received late in the summer was from Staples Inc. Officemax said last month that it had ended talks with an unnamed suitor on Sept. 14. It is now confirming a report on the ''Nightly Business Report'' on public television that Staples, the No. 2 office-supply retailer, was the prospective buyer. It also said the offer was ''substantially above'' its share price at the time of about $13. Officemax's shares have since fallen sharply. They closed yesterday at $7.3125, down 62.5 cents. The takeover bid came about a year after Staples abandoned a proposed $4 billion purchase of Office Depot Inc., the largest retailer of office supplies, because of opposition from the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, MINDY (NEE HYMOWITZ)
description: CELLA-Mindy (nee Hymowitz). Age 43, on October 8, 1998. Mindy died peacefully at home surrounded by those who loved her. Adoring husband John Cella. Devoted parents Bernard and Shirley Hymowitz. Loving sister Rita Ashton, beloved family and friends. Mindy succumbed to cancer after a prolonged battle that began at age 24. Undaunted, Mindy became the named plaintiff in the class action suit Hymowitz v. Eli Lilly, representing DES victims. After years as a nurse, she graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1991. Her battle with this relentless disease began again three years ago. Mindy, we will never forget the force of your personality, the sparkle of your eyes, the sweetness of your smile. We will always remember your strength, sense of humour and incredible courage. Services, Tuesday, October 13, Sherman Weinstein Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn 9:30 AM.

title: Allied Signal Will Pursue AMP Despite Adverse Ruling by Judge
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it would proceed with its offer of $44.50 a share to buy 9 percent of the outstanding stock of AMP Inc., indicating confidence that Allied's $9.7 billion hostile takeover bid will be successful despite a Federal judge's ruling that part of its purchase plan was unlawful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HARRY
description: KRAMER-Harry. On October 8, 1998, in Pompano Beach, FL. Loving husband of Phoebe Kramer, father of Norman Kramer of Westport, CT., & Ellen Rachlis of West Springfield, VA. Services Sunday 11:30 AM, at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY.

title: Thome's Slump Ends With a Couple of Blasts
description: Several hours before the American League Championship Series began on Tuesday, all the Cleveland Indians were corralled in their clubhouse before batting practice. All but one. Jim Thome kept pacing the corridor beneath Yankee Stadium.

title: Man Sentenced to Prison For Death of a Friend
description: A New Gretna man has been sentenced to five years in prison for driving while intoxicated and causing an accident that killed one of his friends, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: CITADEL COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY SIX RADIO STATIONS
description: The Citadel Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would buy six radio stations around Saginaw-Bay City, Mich., for $35 million from 62d Street Broadcasting, to enter the nation's 115th- largest radio market. The radio broadcasting company said it would buy WKQZ-FM (Midland), WMJK-FM (Pinconning), WIOG-FM (Bay City), WMJA-FM (Saginaw), WSGW-AM (Saginaw) and WGER-FM (Saginaw). After the transaction, Citadel will own or operate 80 FM and 36 AM radio stations in 22 mid-sized cities.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Clinton Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Extends Deadline On Stalled Spending Talks
description: Budget negotiations faltered today, prompting Congress to delay until midnight Monday its deadline for passing a spending bill to keep the Government open.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Rushed Proceedings
description: To the Editor:

title: Open to All Music and Unafraid to Serve a Smorgasbord
description: It was genre-splicing night when D.J. Spooky and Plastilina Mosh performed at Irving Plaza on Monday night. D.J. Spooky lives in New York City; Plastilina Mosh got started in Monterrey, Mexico. But they'd rather be known as information-age world citizens, with access to all kinds of music and the nerve to mix them at whim.

title: Sports of The Times; The Moment Of Truth Has Arrived
description: SUDDENLY, what is supposed to be the greatest team in American League history is drifting on a raft, like the one Orlando Hernandez rode out of Cuba. Suddenly, it is the Cleveland Indians, not the Yankees, who look like the 114-game winner holding a reservation for a World Series dugout.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Majority Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: MATCHUPS
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Doctors Using Hybrid Egg to Tackle Infertility in Older Women
description: Doctors in New York have become the first to try to make an infertile woman pregnant by plucking the genes out of one of her eggs and inserting them into a younger woman's egg that has had its own genes removed. The resulting hybrid egg is then fertilized and placed into the older woman's womb.

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: C.I.A. Reportedly Ignored Charges of Contra Drug Dealing in '80's
description: Despite requests for information from Congress, the Central Intelligence Agency repeatedly ignored or failed to investigate allegations of drug trafficking by the anti-Sandinista rebels of Nicaragua in the 1980's, according to a newly declassified report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELNIK, SAUL
description: CELNIK-Saul. October 8, 1998. Survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto. Beloved husband of Ann (nee Kalina), father of Olga and Steve Weitzman & Joyce & Paul Levine, grandfather of Nili Richards, Aron Weitzman, Caralyn and Marissa Levine, great-grandfather of Jessica & Matthew Richards. Services Sunday, October 11, at 1 PM at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: MEN'S WEARHOUSE ENDS OFFER FOR MOORES RETAIL
description: Citing stock market conditions, Men's Wearhouse Inc. said yesterday that it had terminated negotiations to acquire Moores Retail Group Inc. Since Men's Wearhouse announced its intent to acquire Moores on Aug. 4, its shares have lost more than half their value, falling to $15 from $30.75. The company had agreed to buy Moores for 2.4 million shares and the assumption of $56 million in debt. Men's Wearhouse, based in Fremont, Calif., is an off-price specialty retailer of men's business clothing. Moores is a privately held Canadian operator of more than 100 men's apparel stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, LEONARD
description: HOLLAND-Leonard. We mourn the death of our colleague and extend our condolences to his family. Wohl Loewe Stettner Fabricant & Deitz P.C.

title: The Avant-Garde Lens, Heavenly and Harrowing
description: Is there a more beautiful cinematic image than a plastic shopping bag gently blown by the wind across a stretch of pavement? Strangely enough, no. One of dozens of images of light, shadow and passive movement in Nathaniel Dorsky's silent film ''Variations,'' the shopping bag rustled by a light breeze is a transfixingly lovely evocation of randomness and evanescence in the everyday. In Mr. Dorsky's film, the second in a trilogy, the camera also catches reflections of trees on water, dissolving colors on rainy streets reflected in store windows, tree shadows dappling a chessboard and dozens of other exquisite visions of transient beauty in the everyday world.

title: Democrat on the Offensive In Florida Governor's Race
description: With polls showing the Republican Jeb Bush still a commanding front-runner in the election for Florida governor, the underdog Democratic candidate, Lieut. Gov. Kenneth H. MacKay, wasted no time on niceties this week in the first of three scheduled debates.

title: The Millennium in Fable and Reality
description: It is the morning of Dec. 31, 1999, and who should breeze into John F. Kennedy International Airport just in time for the apocalypse but a bland, dapper Jesus (Martin Donovan). Accompanying him is his assistant and gal Friday, Magdalena (P.J. Harvey), a witchy-looking vixen wearing knee-high black boots and toting a backpack. The pair head straight for Manhattan, where they check into a hotel, consult with their lawyers and make final plans for the millennium.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; The People Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article about toys in the Public Eye column of the House & Home section on Thursday misidentified the inventor of the Vortex football. He is David Fuhrer, not John Hunter.

title: Devils Have Holes to Fill
description: The Devils begin the future tonight by immediately confronting the past. They will be in Chicago to open the 1998-99 season against the Blackhawks, who hope to get a big year out of Doug Gilmour, a key player for the Devils until he switched sides in the off season after getting an $18 million offer from Chicago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Linking Endangered Species Act to Spending
description: The Senate authors of a bill to overhaul Endangered Species Act are trying to persuade House leaders to attach the measure to a catch-all spending bill, a step that would fundamentally rewrite one of the nation's most important environmental laws without a separate vote on it by the full Senate or the House.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Democratic Rhetoric
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Legal Power Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Passion, Betrayal and Death, With a Gypsy Full of Secrets
description: Mixing the mystical and the literal as it relates its tale of guilt, lust and betrayal, the Portuguese film ''The River of Gold'' ends by hurling itself over the rapids of reason into an overheated, quasi-operatic frenzy of blood and union in death.

title: Corrections
description: A caption and a subheading with an article Tuesday about Abdallah Mohammed Fazul, who has been accused of directing the bomb attack on the United States Embassy in Kenya, imprecisely described a result of the search of the Fazul home in the Comoros by the F.B.I. and the Comoros police. As the article noted, although Mr. Fazul's father-in-law did die the evening of the search, the F.B.I. did not play a role in his death. Mr. Fazul's wife, Halima, said, ''The F.B.I. behaved correctly.''

title: Foreign Affairs; Oh, By the Way ...
description: Ah, excuse me. I don't mean to interrupt the fun Congress is having with its impeachment hearings and all. But, well, there's just this little problem going on in the rest of the world. It has to do with economics. You see, the world's first truly global economy is going through its first truly serious global crisis. If you follow the global credit crunch and market declines as they are displayed on graphs on a Bloomberg machine, they each look like an EKG tracking a massive heart attack. So, you know, we might want to talk about it. I mean, not all the time. Maybe just in between the impeachment hearings and the release of the next Tripp tapes. Like I said, I don't mean to interrupt ...

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day

title: With Little to Lose, Faltering Vallone Embraces Clinton
description: With his campaign in demonstrable trouble, Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic candidate for governor of New York, has adopted the novel strategy of embracing President Clinton, even as most other Democrats are keeping the battered but still popular President at arm's length.

title: 2 Former Winners to Compete
description: The first Swiss runner and the first South African runner to win the New York City Marathon will both be competing in the event again Nov. 1.

title: South Africa Strikes Down Laws on Gay Sex
description: Citing a provision in the new Constitution, South Africa's highest court struck down the country's sodomy laws today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pulse column of Sunday Styles on Sept. 27 about matching dresses that women on the design staff of Ian Schrager, the hotel developer, wore to a party he gave misspelled the surname of the designer of the dresses. He is Phillipe Starck, not Starcke.

title: Is Impeachment Inquiry What the People Want?; Context Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman, 19, Is Killed By Lover, Police Say
description: A 19-year-old woman was shot and killed yesterday when a man described by investigators as her jealous lover pulled alongside the car she was riding in and shot at her through an open window, the police in Newark said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, CHARLOTTE
description: WEINSTEIN - Charlotte. Loving mother of Susan and Laura. Devoted grandmother of Adam, Amanda and Michal. Died as she lived on October 8, 1998, in dignity and surrounded by the care and support of all who knew her. Her integrity, intelligence and wisdom have left a mark which will last through the years. For funeral information, please call Hellman Memorial Chapels at 914-356-8600.

title: Cornerback Is a Concern For Giants
description: Entering the season, Jason Sehorn and Phillippi Sparks figured to make cornerback a position of strength for the Giants. It is now a position in flux.

title: Ford Shaking Up Senior Executives
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that 27 senior executives would retire or change jobs at the end of the year, as William Clay Ford Jr. and Jacques A. Nasser began putting their stamp on the company as they move toward becoming chairman and chief executive, respectively, on Jan. 1.

title: 2d Set of Bones Found At House Are Identified
description: The second set of bones found by a Northfield man in the basement of his recently acquired home three months ago have been identified as the remains of a 14-year-old girl, county prosecutors said.

title: No One Lets Knoblauch Forget About That Play
description: Chuck Knoblauch placed two bats in a rack in the corner of the dugout, stopped to speak with a familiar reporter and suddenly felt like Tom Hanks entering a theater for one of his own movie premieres. A group of photographers scooted toward Knoblauch, clicking away from close range while he casually chatted.

title: About New York; Heavens, No, This Group of Protesting Priests Won't Go
description: THE REV. DONALD MOORE and his brethren gather nightly for meals in the dining room of the West Side Jesuit Community. Under the steady gaze of icons depicting saints and martyrs, they also share camaraderie and conversation about the ups and downs of their days as professors, counselors, chaplains and writers. The routine has endured for 29 years with bonds as intense as any family's.

title: Van Eyck and Bruegel at the Met
description: In the blue distance life goes on as usual, though the foreground swells with scenes of excruciating woe and mild acceptance. The postures are stylized, but the faces are uniquely individual. The weight of the sacred world is balanced, sometimes toppled, by the weight of the secular world, by the sight of gardens and city markets, peasants and hunters, seen through the windows of a room where an angel interrupts a handmaiden sitting in a plain but exquisitely detailed interior.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS RENEGOTIATING OFFER IN EUROPE
description: CHS Electronics Inc., the largest personal-computer distributor in Europe and Latin America, is renegotiating its offer for Vobis Microcomputer A.G., Europe's largest computer retailer, and may abandon the bid. The Miami-based CHS and Metro A.G., Vobis's parent, are considering three options. Metro may partly finance the acquisition, the companies may extend the deadline for payment or the agreement may be scrapped, said Craig Toll, CHS's chief financial officer. In July, CHS agreed to pay $320 million in cash and stock. It also said it would assume $350 million in debt.

title: GLOBAL TELESYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY NETSOURCE EUROPE
description: Global Telesystems Group Inc., a telecommunications services company, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Netsource Europe for as much as $155 million in cash and stock. G.T.S. will swap one share for each share of Netsource and pay an additional $30.7 million, or $7.61 a share, in cash. The stock and cash are valued at $120 million, or $29.70 a share. Netsource, based in Kristiansand, Norway, provides long-distance phone service to business and residential customers in Germany and the Netherlands. G.T.S. is based in McLean, Va.

title: Congress Inching To End of Session
description: RELIGION -- The Senate unanimously endorsed a bill to require the Government to react when countries act against citizens for their religious beliefs. Page A3.

title: Gramm Seems To Doom Vote For the Passage Of Banking Bill
description: With a lone Senator standing in the way, a bill to overturn Depression-era restrictions on the financial services industry was put into a legislative deep freeze today, its prospects for passage reduced to almost nothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILMAN, ANNA
description: SILMAN-Anna. On October 8, 1998. Beloved wife of George, mother of Trudie and Jeffrey, mother-in-law of Lewis. Lifelong, devoted member of Hadassah and holder of many local and regional offices. New York City teacher and guidance counselor, she provided inspiration and love for all whose lives she touched. Services will be held 10AM Sunday at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: DOWN, AND IN
description: As stocks fell from grace in the third quarter, mutual fund investors might have felt as if they were descending into the inferno. And bonds were far from a source of salvation. Mutual Funds Report, Money & Business, part 2.

title: Fordham's O'Keefe Takes Nurturing Approach
description: A visitor to a Fordham football practice would never know that Ken O'Keefe is the head coach. He does not yell. He blends in during drills and occasionally claps his hands encouragingly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACCONCI, JESSIE CARNEVALE
description: ACCONCI-Jessie Carnevale. On October 6, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Professor Themistocles F. Acconci. Devoted mother of Marcia C. Fazzari and Cynthia S. Schwanderla. Cherished grandmother of Cynthia Fazzari-Wimer, Andrea L. Fazzari, Edward J. Schwanderla, and James J. Schwanderla. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:30 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations in her memory can be made to the American Diabetes Association-New York Affiliate, 149 Madison Ave, NY, NY 10016.

title: Farm Labor Opposes Bill On Importing More Workers
description: As part of the last-minute lobbying battle before Congress recesses, farm worker groups and Hispanic organizations are fighting a bill that would let American farmers bring in tens of thousands of foreign workers, a move that opponents say would hurt farm worker wages and housing conditions.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Steinbrenner's Rantings Earn Him a Fine
description: The American League announced shortly before the start of Game 3 tonight that it had fined George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, $25,000 for ''inappropriate comments'' about the umpiring in Game 2 of the league championship series.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS RISE 4.4 PERCENT. Prices surged after the Government cut its crop forecast by more than 100 million bushels, to 2.77 billion. The November contract rose 23.5 cents, to $5.64 a bushel.

title: Colon Gets Form Back Just in Time
description: Early this season, Bartolo Colon was cruising along when the fizz on his fastball went as flat as day-old Champagne.

title: Newsday to Start Publishing A Spanish-Language Paper
description: The Long Island newspaper Newsday and the owners of a small weekly paper published in New Jersey for a regional Hispanic audience are planning to start a new Spanish-language newspaper late this year that would appear five days a week, Mondays through Fridays, throughout the New York City region.

title: Armed With a Lead, Padre Fans Believe
description: A strong sign that this city is going bonkers for the Padres came this morning when 680 fans agreed to shave their heads for a radio promotion raffle in return for a 1-in-680 chance at skybox tickets for post-season play.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., said it would build a new semiconductor plant in Allentown, Pa., for $165 million, consolidating smaller facilities it has in the area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINARICK, GLADYS
description: WINARICK-Gladys. On October 5, 1998. Beloved mother of Nancy and Ken, loving grandmother of Aura and Daniel, mother in-law-of Richard and Wendy. Psychotherapist for many years; beloved by her patients.

title: New Details on When Starr Was Told of Clinton Affair
description: Sometime in early January, Paul S. Rosenzweig, a lawyer working for Kenneth W. Starr, received a tip from a law school classmate that President Clinton was having an affair with a White House intern, lawyers familiar with the matter say.

title: Facing Severe Shortage of Food, Russia Seeks Foreign Relief Aid
description: Rocked by its worst harvest in 45 years and a plummeting ruble, Russia appealed today for relief aid from the European Union. It has also approached the United States and Canada for help.

title: Hoke Simpson, 83, Former Dean At Columbia's Business School
description: Hoke S. Simpson, a former associate dean at the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, died on Sept. 26 at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. Mr. Simpson, a resident of Rye, N.Y., was 83.

title: Richard M. Cyert Dies at 77; President of Carnegie Mellon
description: Richard M. Cyert, a management professor and former president of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, whose half century at the university encompassed its growth from a small regional institute to a national center of higher learning with a global reputation in computer technology and education research, died on Wednesday night at his home in Fox Chapel, Pa. He was 77.

title: The Surge in Teen Smoking
description: New data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that teen smoking rates are soaring. In 1988, 700,000 teen-agers under 18 became daily smokers. Less than a decade later, in 1996, the number of teens who became daily smokers had risen to 1.2 million. Two-thirds of the people who took up daily smoking that year were under the age of 18. These grim numbers show just how successful the tobacco industry has been in making its products attractive to the high school set.

title: What Viewers Want

title: A Multiplicity of Languages on AM Radio
description: Some listeners who tuned into WGBB (1240 AM) Monday morning expecting the usual local news and music from this Freeport, N.Y., station whose signal reaches western Long Island, Brooklyn and Queens, were in for a case of culture shock. The news was read in Mandarin Chinese.

title: A Relaxed Grip On the Panhandle
description: THERE is, for my money, no more telling window on a town's soul than low-power FM radio. Take, for example, WOYS-FM -- a k a Oyster Radio -- in Apalachicola, Fla. For a week in June a tireless disk jockey named Billy D. accompanied me and my wife, Shelley, our two sons and our two dogs as we lay around our rented beachfront home or ventured out to seafood shops and ramshackle restaurants overlooking the Gulf of Mexico.

description: More than 20 families were left homeless on Sept. 28 by a fire that Yonkers firefighters now say was set by three youngsters playing with matches near a garbage can.

title: What? No Polkas in Poland?
description: WHEN Jan Lewan arrived in the United States 18 years ago, he had never once heard a polka. In Poland, Mr. Lewan sang opera. ''I wasn't any Pavarotti,'' he said of his career there. ''I wanted to be the Polish Englebert.''

title: Prominent Harlem Minister Says He Will Back Pataki
description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, the prominent Harlem minister and a Democrat who has forged close ties to Gov. George E. Pataki during the last four years, said yesterday that he would endorse the Republican Governor's steamrolling drive for re-election today.

title: Welder Is Killed in Explosion At the Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: An explosion in the hull of an oil barge in the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday killed a welder and injured his assistant, the authorities said.

description: A few weeks ago, out of the blue, I got a phone call from a guy I dated in college.

description: Who was that bearded man trading quips with his fellow basses in the Dallas Symphony Chorus last month at the Morton H. Meyerson Family Weekend of Concerts in the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center in Dallas? Why, none other than Morton H. Meyerson.

title: Our Towns; Cool Weather, Hot Rentals In Westport
description: DARKNESS comes early these days. Each rainfall strips more leaves from trees, soon to be bare. But despite omens of winter, Michelle Genovesi has summer on her mind.

title: 'Appalachian Spring' Finds Renewal in the Rockies
description: AS he waited for curtain calls at the gala closing of the old Metropolitan Opera House in 1966, Martin Fredmann, then a 23-year-old dancer with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet, felt a pinch on his bottom. He turned to discover Martha Graham. She gave him a big wink. It was the only time Mr. Fredmann met Graham. Now artistic director of Colorado Ballet in Denver, he could probably use another pinch and wink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWELL, ALLEYNE

We will deeply miss this remarkable man and extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and friends. We will always remember his work and his kind and generous spirit. Mary Ryan Gallery

description: Skip Away's nine-race winning streak and his march on racing's money record were both broken yesterday when he and Gentlemen were run down in the muddy homestretch by the 34-1 long shot Wagon Limit, who streaked past them to win the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup by 5 1/2 lengths.

title: How I Came To Love Tennis
description: I love sports. How can I then not respond to ''Bad Tennis Players at the Top of Their Game'' [Sept. 27]?

title: Fans Carry Torch
description: Brian Snyder started collecting Statue of Liberty memorabilia in 1984 after learning that his grandfather saw the statue when he emigrated from Italy. Now Mr. Snyder, 35, a pharmaceutical salesman, owns more than 400 representations of the statue that occupy two bedrooms in his three-bedroom house in Fresno, Calif.

title: Show That Highlights Dreams and Magic
description: ON view in the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle here, ''The Waking Dream'' makes a case for psychological realism, a term that resists precise definition but here seems to mean Surrealism manque.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Did Jewelry or Dice Game Lead to a Man's Slaying?
description: It is an eye-catching piece of jewelry -- a gold chain and a pendant shaped like a bulldog's head, with rubies for eyes -- and it cost Marvin McIntosh his life, say prosecutors in New York City's second death penalty trial since capital punishment was revived in the state three years ago.

title: What Is a Brand-New Music Quiz Show?
description: There are game shows with spinning wheels and oversize dice, and then there is ''Jeopardy,'' where everything comes down to the correct questions.

title: Recalling Betty Carter, Mentor to a Generation
description: Jazz singer, composer, arranger nonpareil -- Betty Carter, who died on Sept. 26 at the age of 69, was all these things. But along with her own music, she leaves another significant legacy with the musicians she nurtured, the careers she helped shape. Over the last two decades, her band was an incubator for jazz talent, and many young musicians who honed their skills with Ms. Carter are now making their mark as leaders. With the death of the drummer Art Blakey in 1990, Ms. Carter became the dean of what insiders considered jazz's finest university. Here, eight almuni recall the lessons they learned from a beloved teacher and inspiring taskmaster. (Their ages and time spent with Ms. Carter are noted below their names.) FLETCHER ROBERTS

title: So Who's the Starter If It Goes a Full Seven?
description: Cleveland Manager Mike Hargrove lost his confidence in Jaret Wright, after the pitcher gave up five runs in two-thirds of an inning in Game 1, and replaced Wright in the Indians' rotation with Chad Ogea, who will start Game 5 on Sunday.

title: Ross Accuses His Lethargic Lions (1-4) of Playing Only for Their Paychecks
description: The Detroit Lions have Barry Sanders, a future Hall of Famer. They have Herman Moore, one of the top three receivers in football. They have all that talent, and just one victory, and Coach Bobby Ross has had enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMSON, LESTER
description: ABRAHAMSON-Lester. Suddenly, October 7, 1998, Martha's Vinyard. Beloved husband of Rose. Dear father of Johanna and the late Shelley. Cherished grandfather of Whitney, Joshua and Jake. Esteemed brother of Florence, Roy and Estelle. A man of charm, wit and intelligence.

title: Juliette Zener, David Fairman
description: Juliette Baur Zener and David Fairman were married on Friday by Kathleen Scully Hodges, a justice of the peace, on the Weeks Footbridge over the Charles River in Cambridge, Mass. Today, Mrs. Hodges is to lead a spiritual ceremony written by the couple at the Red Hill Inn in Centre Harbor, N.H.

title: Gibson Told Not to Count On Democrats in Executive Race
description: In a county where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by 3-to-1, you don't have to be a mathematician to conclude that the party's nominee for county executive should have an edge, even against an incumbent.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Having grown up before the days of television, I never found turning it off to be a problem (Culture Zone: ''Deep Impact,'' by Caryn James). So when my set died several years ago, I didn't replace it. If this curious fact emerges in conversation (I don't make much of it because I'd rather not be saddled with more of a reputation for oddity than I already have), the other person invariably says, ''Good for you; I wish I had the guts to throw it out.'' No wonder the medium's ''power'' can be frightening. Isn't this the definition of addiction?

title: Su-Lin Cheng, William Nichols
description: Su-Lin Cheng and William Dean Nichols were married yesterday at the East Ruskin Place Cottage in Seaside, Fla. The Rev. Harry Houseman, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Culture Zone; Cheap Thrills, Seriously
description: Early on in Jonathan Demme's movie ''Beloved,'' a character named Paul D (Danny Glover) literally walks a gantlet of memories, moving slowly down a hallway while bloody images of the past are flashed before him, the work of an invisible and extremely hostile young ghost. He shields his eyes -- who wouldn't? -- trying not to look but having to as he moves toward a room free of these visions. It's an unsettling sequence, certainly, but one that evokes the familiar: he could just as easily be a viewer cringing from any one of a number of recent and soon-to-be released movies and television shows that traffic in graphic violence, difficult sex and plain old nastiness.

title: Condensing The Essence Of a Show Into a Poster
description: IN late-19th-century Paris, Alphonse Mucha created the lasting public image of Sarah Bernhardt in a series of iconic Art Nouveau posters that have come to symbolize the actress and her plays.

title: Cars, Very New and Very Old; Freeport Test Drives Electric Car
description: THE Toyota RAV-4 parked at the curb of Freeport Village Hall looks like an ordinary sport utility vehicle. But under its hood, there is no transmission, carburetor or pistons, but two dozen 12-volt batteries.

title: On the Rebound, 3 Birds Escape Endangered List
description: For the first time since the state started designating threatened and endangered animals in 1974, three birds -- the great blue heron, the little blue heron and the cliff swallow -- are being removed from the threatened list, the department announced last week.

title: Bond Act Grants
description: Governor Pataki last week announced $6.2 million in grants from the Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act and the State Environmental Protection Fund for projects in Westchester, including $3.3 million to improve the water quality of Long Island Sound and to improve local parks and waterfronts. ''Long Island Sound is one of this nation's great water resources,'' the Governor said. ''Unfortunately, it was neglected for many years, endangering its aquatic resources, its fisheries and its economic value to communities on its shores.''

title: Correction
description: The Long Island Journal column on Sept. 27, about a tennis team competing for a national championship at the beginner level, misstated the name of the club in Blue Point where the team's coach is tennis director. It is the Eastern Athletic Club, not the Eastern Tennis Academy. The column also misstated the number of players in adult tennis leagues on the Island. It is 2,459, not 22,459.

title: Reservationist Reservations
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Nights in the Gulag L.A.
description: John Ridley's crime-noir first novel, ''Stray Dogs,'' was made into the Oliver Stone movie ''U-Turn.'' This may explain why Ridley's second novel, LOVE IS A RACKET (Knopf, $24), blends elements of the noir novel with the Hollywood novel. True to the first genre, the book's hero, a hard-drinking con man named Jeffty Kittridge, owes money to Dumas, a bad guy with a deceptively soft voice who just might kill him. True to the second, Jeffty is also a hard-drinking, burned-out screenwriter already being slowly killed by ''the gulag L.A.'' Enter Mona, a street urchin with a striking resemblance to the actress Pier Angeli -- who, Jeffty reminds us, killed herself with an overdose of pills. The first thing Mona says to Jeffty is ''Change?'' She's begging for money, but the double meaning is soon clear. Jeffty recruits her for a scam that could turn his life around. The plotting is routine, but the writing is smart and edgy and even moving; if Richard Ford wrote genre fiction, it might read something like this. The only weaknesses result from unfortunate conformities to the noir formula and a digressive first act. Once Mona appears, however, Ridley has us hooked on his game. Mark Lindquist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, ROBERT J.
description: NADLER-Robert J. Of Glen Head, NY, on October 7, 1998. Beloved son of Seymour and Lois. Loving brother of Paul and Michael. Also survived by two nieces, one nephew and a million friends. Funeral service Sunday, 11 AM, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Interment Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Market Turmoil Doesn't Kill Companies' Urge to Merge
description: Mergers and acquisitions are crawling tentatively out of the bomb shelters to test the wind again. Clear Channel Communications said it would buy Jacor Communications for $2.8 billion in stock; the combination would be the second-biggest radio station owner in the country. Cardinal Health, a drug wholesaler, agreed to buy Allegiance, which sells medical supplies, for $5.4 billion in stock and debt.

title: Lucy Coudert, Douglas Conrod
description: Lucy Anita Coudert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor R. Coudert Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Douglas Franklin Conrod 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Conrod of Chappaqua, N.Y. Msgr. Frank C. Wissel performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church.

title: Leaky School Moves to Top Of Repair List
description: A Brooklyn elementary school that was abruptly closed last week because of severe water damage and fears of asbestos and lead contamination had been patched up intermittently since last spring but now will move to the top of the list of buildings scheduled for extensive renovations, a school official said yesterday.

title: Ferry to the Past
description: Most ferries in Puget Sound are expected to run on schedule, but an exception will be made in the case of the Kalakala, an Art Deco ferry that operated out of Seattle from the 1930's to 60's. The passenger vessel, which is expected to arrive from Alaska this week, will be moored for 30 days at the Bell Street Pier on the Seattle waterfront for visitors to see before it goes in for restoration. Meanwhile, the Museum of History and Industry, 2700 24th Avenue East, will have an exhibit on the Kalakala through February entitled ''A Ferry Tale: The Kalakala Comes Home.'' Information: (206) 324-1126.

DeBartolo Jr., the opulent co-owner of the San Francisco 49ers, was reportedly about to be indicted last December by a Federal grand jury in Louisiana investigating riverboat casino licensing and other business arrangements, he suddenly resigned as the 49ers' chairman. title: A Dandy Who Makes Dated Seem Cutting-Edge
description: WHEN Stephen Calloway opened the front door of his seedy Georgian terrace house in the Camberwell section of south London not long ago, it was easy to imagine one was being greeted by the original owner. Wearing a Vandyke beard with twirled, waxed mustache and a dashingly cut 19th-century-style suit that would have made the foppish Benjamin Disraeli swoon, Mr. Calloway, a 47-year-old art historian and design consultant, smiled apologetically at the imposing but ramshackle structure into which he had moved a few months earlier. ''Somewhere under all the horrors are two 1790's houses struggling to get out,'' he said.

title: In Berlin, a Reshuffling of the Artistic Deck
description: ALMOST 40 years ago, when I was a young journalist working at NBC News, I bought a woodcut of a church from the print dealer Sylvan Cole. It showed a church tower, viewed as through a disturbing prism. I recognized it as the work of Lyonel Feininger, for whose art I had developed a no doubt superficial appreciation while at college. The fact that it was an artist's proof and that Feininger had inscribed it in pencil to his wife gave it added appeal.

title: Tiny, Twisted and Beautiful
description: THEY originated in China more than 2,500 years ago, then arrived in Japan in the ninth century. This week, they'll go to the Bronx. They are bonsai and more than 80 of them, from different varieties, will be displayed in the conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden as part of its Chrysanthemum and Bonsai Festival. The diminutive stature of the bonsai (which means ''tree in a pot'' in Chinese) may make them appear young, but one is more than 225 years old. Visitors will be able to learn the secrets to bonsai longevity at clinics and demonstrations to be held over the weekend. On Saturday, member organizations of the Bronx Council on the Arts have scheduled free performances, like the one of Garces Puppets pictured above. And children can pick pumpkins, take a hayride or wander through a variety of mazes.

title: After a 7-Year Summer, Economic Leaves Turn
description: The outlook for the United States economy has ''weakened measurably,'' Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a group of economists last week. Though current indicators remain fairly healthy, he said, ''we are clearly facing a set of forces that should be dampening demand going forward to an unknown extent,'' including a ''scary psychology'' in financial markets and fears that gloomy market news will undermine consumer confidence and chill spending. Fed watchers found in Mr. Greenspan's remarks strong hints that further interest-rate cuts were in the offing.

title: Lives; Silent Bond
description: There is nothing like a crisis to galvanize a family, to set its silent wheels in motion. Two years ago I found out I had PNH, a rare disease that decimates the bone marrow. I was 31, the oldest of four and the only son, about to join my father's dermatology practice. The doctors told me my only hope was a bone-marrow transplant; they would fill my languishing marrow with healthy stem cells from a suitable donor.

title: Crime
description: When women write suspense stories, the heroines are often too good to be true and the psychopaths too creepy for words. When men write suspense stories, the psychos are often too clever to be true and the heroines too dumb for words. Peter Abrahams, however, gets the human dimensions just right in A PERFECT CRIME (Ballantine, $24.95).

title: Hernandez, a Survivor, Calmly Pulls the Yankees Even
description: The Yankees spent recent years carefully piecing together the juggernaut that won 114 games this summer, but the player responsible for winning their most important game to date washed up on a sliver of island aboard a leaky boat last winter.

title: Hilton Puts Down Another Marker
description: For gamblers arriving on the Black Horse Pike, the sprawling Gothic structure with its boarded-up windows and broken clock worthy of Miss Haversham is just one more decaying building from a bygone era.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the front page of the Arts & Leisure section today about the mission and impact of the Aga Khan Awards for Architecture misspells the surname of the founder of the program at several points. He is Prince Karim Aga Khan, not Kahn. The name of the architect who directs the awards program from Geneva is also misspelled. He is Suha Ozkan, not Suhah Ascan.

title: HIP-HOP HOOPS
description: This fall, Fleer/Skybox -- the venerable company that makes collector cards for sports fans -- is giving its line of basketball cards (''N.B.A. Hoops'') an overhaul designed to appeal to inner-city kids and the suburban youth who love to emulate their style. What this means is that in addition to the traditional stats and gutsy team history, the players are presented in hip-hop style. Patrick Ewing of the New York Knicks is transformed into ''Ew the Man.'' (''This Beast of the East has more heart than 20 brothers in a Land Cruiser.'') Shaquille O'Neal is ''Shaq Fu, large and in charge.'' Even the whitebread Keith Van Horn gets funked up. Sort of. ''You're from the W.A.C.,'' his card informs, ''but your game's anything but.''

title: Familiar Voice Crying About the Wilderness
description: ALTHOUGH Jackie Mason's fame has nothing to do with cantorial chants, he summons that gift from his past to end the first act of his latest stand-up routine at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here. It may not be widely known that he is an ordained rabbi as well. But the real revelation of ''Much Ado About Everything'' is that the ostensible comic is a bona fide prophet.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; State Adds to Subsidies to Spur Home Ownership
description: TWO state initiatives aimed at increasing home ownership in New Jersey, especially in cities, received new infusions of money last week. One program helps developers build houses, while the other helps people buy them.

title: Kay Taylor, Stephen Hightower
description: Kawardra Albrina Taylor and Stephen Philip Hightower, both New York State assistant attorneys general in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Manhattan. D. Ward Nichols, a retired senior bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, who is the bride's maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony with Bishop Philip R. Cousin, the prelate of the first district of the A.M.E. church.

title: ANGRY AT OPRAH
description: * Disgruntled fans writing on AOL's ''Oprah Online'' message board are calling Oprah Winfrey ''a preacher bent on having people think the way you do'' and ''a female Pat Robertson.'' * Behind the gripes is ''Change Your Life TV,'' a periodic series of New Agey theme shows aimed at empowering viewers to spiritualize and refocus their lives. * Oprah generally loses nearly a million homes each time a ''Change'' show is broadcast. * ''She is on a different path than I now, and we are parting, which feels sad to me,'' one watcher wrote. * Still, Oprah can change people's behavior: Oprah-philes lost 534,336 pounds (or 86 elephants, says the show) thanks to her weight-loss broadcasts in 1995. * For now, Oprah is keeping the faith. ''I don't want to throw the baby out with the bath water because a few people post negative stuff,'' she says.

title: Beyond Books, but Sticking to the Basics
description: Is Amazon.com changing from the darling of the Internet to a nascent evil empire?

title: OPINION; It's My Adopted Home but I Love It
description: I DIDN'T grow up on Long Island, but I've ended up here. As a transplant, with my ''R's'' and ''T's'' intact, I can wax enthusiastically in favor of a place that gets far too little respect. Here are a few things I love about my adopted home:

title: Ms. Flanagan and Mr. O'Malley
description: Wendy Ronan Flanagan and Christopher Brian O'Malley were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. William Watson performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Alomar's Status in Doubt
description: Cleveland catcher Sandy Alomar left Game 4 in the sixth inning because of lower-back spasms. Although Alomar has struggled this year with injuries, he is still an important part of the team, particularly in a leadership role.

title: The View From/Yonkers; Where the Troubled Can Find Counseling in Adventure
description: A 15-YEAR-OLD resident of Leake and Watts Services, a child-care agency here for troubled young people, was talking about his life before he came to live on the agency's campus.

title: Managed Care Plans Shirk Their Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/Peter Kanze; Interest in Radio Fuels Hobby and Career
description: IT was a different era. Children and their parents huddled around large radios to hear the news or the latest installment of the adventure of one superhero or another, or to be entertained with music that was broadcast live.

title: Cars, Very New and Very Old; Auto Rally Seeks the Spirit of Vintage Races
description: IT is not the speed that counts in the sixth annual Bridgehampton Sportscar Road Rallye, it's precision timing. And although most entrants in the Oct. 17 event claim not to take the 111-mile race seriously, one gets the feeling they do.

title: Kara Harris, David Fleming
description: Kara Marie Harris, a daughter of Marilyn Brown of Miami and James Harris of Singapore, was married yesterday to David McAdam Fleming, a son of Nancy and Samuel Fleming of Weston, Mass. The Rev. James P. Adams performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Sunapee, N.H.

title: FILM; Picking Up the Story Where 'Casablanca' Left Off
description: ''AS TIME GOES BY'' started with a simple question. ''What would you think about writing a novel based on ''Casablanca?'' Maureen Egen, the president of Warner Books, asked me over lunch one fine spring afternoon in 1996.

title: A Booming Field Goal Short-Circuits Columbia
description: Columbia was within a couple of kicks of upsetting undefeated Lehigh yesterday at Wien Stadium, but the Mountain Hawks won the match, 20-19, near the end with a long field goal of 47 yards by Jaron Taafe, who had never tried a boot of such a distance.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Next Big Thing
description: THE GIANT, O'BRIEN By Hilary Mantel. 192 pp. New York: A Marian Wood Book/ Henry Holt & Company. $22.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Saving by Buying a House From the Blueprints Only
description: MANY buyers of new houses are taking advantage of a builders' marketing strategy of selling houses from blueprints or scale models at so-called preconstruction prices before model houses are built.

title: The Electronic Dilettante
description: THE INVISIBLE COMPUTER

title: Helen Updike, Asa Rountree
description: Helen Hill Updike and Asa Rountree were married yesterday at the River Club in Manhattan. Judge John G. Koeltl of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUFIAN, GLORIA
description: SUFIAN-Gloria. EMUNAH of America mourns the untimely death of Gloria Sufian, beloved mother of our member Bruce Sufian and mother-in-law of EMUNAH's Director of Growth and Development, Carol Sufian. Our condolences to Gloria's husband Aaron and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld National President

title: POSTINGS: Panel Discussion at New-York Historical Society; The Cityscape Of the Future
description: ''Design at the Millennium: New York City and Beyond,'' a discussion on the cityscape by a panel of architects, designers and writers, is to be held at the New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, on Tuesday at 6 P.M.

title: Revisiting Today's Man
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, MICHAEL
description: PALM-Michael. We mourn the passing of a dear friend. Michael was a man of rare intelligence and generosity. We will always miss him. Tom Healy and Fred Hochberg, Chuck Holmes, Terry Bean and David Mixner

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAUM, MAXINE R.
description: TRAUM-Maxine R. October 12, 1997. We love you and think of you every day. Your children, grandchildren and brother

title: A Fan Primer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NATO Nears Final Order To Approve Kosovo Strike
description: NATO is ready to approve an ''activation order'' on Monday, opening the way for its military commanders to order air strikes against Serbian targets in Kosovo and perhaps in the Serbian heartland itself, senior Western officials said today.

title: Congress Gets Break in Season Of Sex Scandal
description: Congress savored the sheer comfort of asexual political skirmishing this weekend as lawmakers struggled with lost legislative causes and artificial doomsday deadlines in their attempt to quit and go home to face the voters.

title: Growing Numbers of Coyotes Lead to Traps and Fear for Pets
description: LIKE many others who live in well-kept developments at the edge of a wooded area, Jane Moross and her husband, Jeff, have made peace with the wild animals that forage in their garden and trash cans. ''Over the years, we'd grown used to the raccoons, the deer and woodchucks,'' Mrs. Moross said.

title: The Way New York Tawks; Speech Classes Took Natives Only So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: A Concrete Company That Serves the Fun
description: FOR 40 years, William E. Hoffman has been working in the concrete business his father started in Scituate, Mass., south of Boston. It makes reinforced concrete pipe, curbing and precast pieces like manholes, septic tanks and catch basins. His job is designing underground utilities, he said.

title: Marlowe's Beliefs
description: To the Editor:

title: In Vienna, Finally a Suitable Job for a Woman
description: ONLY in the last couple of years did it even enter Agnes Grossmann's mind that she could -- in fact, would -- become music director of the Vienna Choir Boys. She is certainly qualified to take charge of the prestigious choir, continuing its traditions, its tours and its recording projects, which date back to Arturo Toscanini, Bruno Walter and numerous other conductors of that rank. But its 500 years under solely male leadership just wouldn't make it a likely career dream for a woman.

title: Alicia Parla, 84, Dies; Showed the World How to Rumba
description: Alicia Parla, a sinuous Cuban-born beauty who had a brief but incandescent run as the international Queen of the Rumba, died of cancer on Tuesday at her home in Miami. She was 84 and was recalled as the teen-age sensation who became the toast of New York and Paris, captivated crowned heads of Europe and taught the rumba to the Prince of Wales, Josephine Baker and a generation of Depression-weary revelers.

title: The View From/Waterford; Shimmers of Old Glory In Harkness State Park
description: VISITORS to the 42-room mansion at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford eyed a little button on one wall. ''To call the servants,'' explained a docent, Gail Hollingsworth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, VIRGINIA BERGEN
description: BLACK-Virginia Bergen. Of New York City and Shelter Island, New York. On September 12, 1998. Daughter of the late Douglas McCrae Black and Maude Bergen Black. Direct descendant of Sarah Rapalje, the first child of European parents born in New Amsterdam. She was a graduate of The Nightingale Bamford School, New York, New York and St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York and was a member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, associate member of the Amateur Comedy Club of New York and a member of the former St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Auxiliary. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Red Cross-Shelter Island Chapter, P.O. Box 830, Shelter Island, New York, 11964; the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church, Shelter Island, New York 11964 or St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York 13617, would be appreciated. Memorial service in the Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, NY at 11:00 a.m., on Friday, October 23, 1998.

title: Ceiling Tiles Looking Up at Last
description: Almost 40 years ago, Robert Makla took a tour of Central Park with Henry Hope Reed, the architectural historian, and caught his first glimpse of the 19th-century tiles that adorned the ceiling of the Bethesda Terrace Arcade at 72d Street. ''I was overwhelmed that anything could be so splendid,'' he said.

title: October 4-10; Dispute Over Nerve Gas
description: French experts detected traces of the nerve gas VX on Iraqi warheads they examined but withheld their findings because they did not want to damage Baghdad's efforts to have United Nations economic sanctions lifted, according to several international weapons specialists.

title: In Parks, a People's Gallery
description: Savona Bailey-McClain rises before dawn every Sunday to care for three gardens. She tends the petunias and impatiens in her courtyard on 143d Street, then walks to Johnny Hartman Plaza at 143d and Amsterdam Avenue to prune the bushes, then goes to Alexander Hamilton Playground on Hamilton Place and 141st Street to water the nicotianas.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Skewering the Human Race

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Don Hewitt is on target when he says that ''television is an entertainment medium. And because they can't find entertainment, they've come to the news divisions to fill the time slots.'' That's because sports, news, talk and even religious programming can pass for entertainment today.

title: Fred Grubel, 89, Who Headed A Jewish Research Institute
description: Fred Grubel, who as executive director of the Leo Baeck Institute expanded the organization into a respected historical research center for the study of German-speaking Jewry, died Oct. 4 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was three weeks shy of 90 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Sports of The Times; Boss and O'Neill Navigate Game of Follow the Leader
description: TWO emotional men one known for flinging helmets, the other for throwing tantrums -- roused the slumbering Yankees here last night. First George Steinbrenner made the clubhouse rounds. Then Paul O'Neill came up in the first inning and rounded the bases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, BYRDIE
description: GERBER-Byrdie. On October 10, 1998. In her 96th year. Beloved daughter of the late Charles and Bessie Gerber. Cherished sister of Libby Hillman and the late Philip, Julius and Irving Gerber. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Services today, 1 PM, October 11, at Menorah Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

title: Kosovo War Crimes Cannot Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Possibly J.D. Salinger was ''infatuated'' with ''The Andy Griffith Show'' (which Frank Rich calls ''schlock'' in ''What the Tube Is For'') because the characters who live in Mayberry are as well crafted as Salinger's own delicious bunch, the Glass family. Rich owes the Griffith show an apology.

title: A Time to Burn, a Time to Learn
description: AFTER seven fat years, the mutual fund industry has suffered a drought. A community of sainted portfolio managers has fallen from grace. And mutual fund investors may be thinking they have descended into the inferno.

title: Two Parts Farm, One Part City
description: The dress code is down-home comfort with New York flair on Saturdays at the Union Square Greenmarket, where the colors and fragrances of autumn fill the air. A suede shirt is worn over sweat pants, with accessories of bedroom slippers, curlers covered with a scarf, and chic wire baskets holding fresh milk, eggs and plants. A stylish black trench coat, below, can cover anything. A young man coordinated fall colorings, right. The Koos van den Akker patchwork jacket, left, blends perfectly with the produce. Leather coats, tweed jackets, 1940's flower-patterned tote bags, a profusion of city dogs, children and families -- it's just marketing the old-fashioned way.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I wish they'd take the whole bunch -- Clinton, that woman, Ken Starr, the Republicans in Congress, the media -- I wish they'd take the bunch, put them on the Queen Mary, tow it away and sink the whole thing at sea. But no, I can't really tell you who I blame the most for how out of control this thing has gotten.''

title: A Classical Beauty Emerges Cleansed
description: FOR a while on the morning of Grand Central Terminal's rededication ceremony, an unfamiliar feeling seemed to pass through the thousands of people who had gathered to watch the festivities.

title: For Lucky Few, a Ferry to Connecticut Jobs
description: SIPPING hot coffee at a table in the lounge or juggling a tepid cup on your lap in the train. A stroll along the upper deck, feeling the sea breeze, or stuck behind the wheel snorting 18-wheeler exhaust. A leisurely evening drink at the bar watching the sunset or a hurried guzzle in a cavern-tavern in the bowels of Penn Station. For a few Long Island commuters, life is beautiful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTY, RAYMOND A.
description: CHRISTY-Raymond A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Raymond A. Christy, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1983.

title: Too Tough To Take A Spill
description: Even the Teflon Don would need to stick a napkin in his shirt before sitting down to a plate of spaghetti Bolognese -- unless he had a Teflon shirt.

title: October 4-10; A Shorter Season
description: For 51 years and 35,001 games, the National Basketball Association avoided losing regular-season games to labor strife. But with the cancellation of the entire preseason and talks going nowhere, Patrick Ewing and friends will be off the court awhile.

title: Animal Rights Advocates Have Permits, Won't Trap
description: As Bill Mannetti strides through a swampy piece of state land near the Quinnipiac River, he points out spots where a trapper might place a beaver trap or a coyote trap -- there at the bottom of that small hill, here in this shallow of the river.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FETISH LIVES

title: Aid for Sudan's Hungry Keeps War Well Fed
description: Faced with the prospect of pictures of emaciated, malnourished children as well as thousands of deaths in southern Sudan, the world's governments launched Operation Lifeline Sudan and appealed for funds to meet the ''emergency.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANKSTEEN, ANNA W.
description: BLANKSTEEN-Anna W. In her 99th year. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of David Blanksteen, Norma Braver and Rita Miller. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services are private.

title: Wee Wheeling
description: ''People have said I look like a circus clown on my little red bike,'' Lucas Bennett said, describing his Shuttle bicycle. The folding Daewoo bicycle has 16-inch alloy wheels, normally used on children's bikes.

title: October 4-10; A Bit of Lucre From Lucky Dog
description: What do Larry Hagman from ''Dallas,'' Isabel Sanford from ''The Jeffersons'' and Joe Lynn Turner from the rock group Deep Purple have in common?

title: BENEFITS

description: LOVE UNDETECTABLE

title: Sosa's Chances
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FILM; The Enduring Art of a Poet of All That Is Fleeting
description: THE great German director Georg Wilhelm Pabst relished smoke and fog, mist and steam: the vapors that drift through his movies remind us of impermanence, hinting that much of experience is ephemeral. Sometimes the smoke means destruction, as it billows from a bombed house or over a battlefield. Or it can express dissipation, when it beclouds a nightclub or rises from thick cigar butts abandoned in choked ashtrays. The haze may be romantic, as two lovers -- soon to be separated by a political crisis -- embrace in swirling mist and smoke. Many of Pabst's characters live in the moment: in love (which can evaporate), in war (in the midst of sudden death).

title: The Way New York Tawks; Speech Classes Took Natives Only So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Theater Produces Sartre

title: And the Winner Is . . . The Money Market?
description: MANY investors give more thought to breakfast than to their money market funds, which they have used mainly as a place to park their cash between stock trades.

title: IN MY... BAG: BOBBI BROWN
description: Bobbi Brown is a makeup artist to supermodels and has her own line of cosmetics. But she is also a mom, and her bag mirrors all of her roles. She might need to change the diaper of her 12-week-old son, Duke, only moments after whipping together a makeover for a guest on NBC's ''Today.'' While dotting eye shadow on a runway model, she might want to grab her Audible headset to listen to a recording of ''The Color of Water,'' by James McBride.

title: From Botanist, Spores For Ferns at Home
description: CONSIDER the fern spore.

title: Ruling May Hurt Campaign Finance Cases
description: In a decision that could seriously undercut the Justice Department's campaign finance prosecutions, a Federal judge has ruled that the department misinterpreted election laws that restrict contributions by foreign nationals.

title: ART REVIEWS; Surrealism, Traditionalism and Re-Visionism
description: '22/21 Vision'

title: The World: What Asian Crisis?; What Asian Crisis? Beijing Feels Bullish As It Plays Catch-Up
description: ACROSS the river from this city's majestic waterfront, in an area that was swampland not long ago, a gleaming collection of skyscrapers is emerging. The most impressive, ambitiously named the World Financial Center, is scheduled to become the tallest building in the world when it is completed in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUSTER, IRA
description: SCHUSTER-Ira. Dearest Dad, missing you on this day and your birthday. Wally is now with you and Mother. Rest with honor. We all love you now and forever. Phoebe Lewin and family

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the View column, about a writing class at Purchase College, misidentified the home of the teacher, Howard Enders. He lives in New Rochelle, not Larchmont.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.
