description: To the Editor:

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Bittersweet Road To Home Sweet Home
description: THE real estate broker glanced nervously at her watch. ''Remember, you've only got until 5,'' she said.

title: Sharing a History As Well as a Play
description: IF Holly Hunter and Beth Henley had not been stuck in an elevator together 16 years ago on their way to an audition for Ms. Henley's play ''The Wake of Jamey Foster,'' the two would have found each other eventually.

title: County Workers' Raise Approved
description: THE County Board of Legislators has approved a raise for the county government's largest employee union but has deferred a decision on a proposal to raise the pay of some Legislators.

title: A Coca-Trade Jungle Town Trapped by Colombia's Strife
description: The bloody struggle over the future of Colombia, raging between shadowy groups of men and women with masks and false names, is closing in on Calamar, a main transit point in the coca trade scratched out of the jungle 20 years ago by the refugees of earlier conflicts in this stricken country.

title: Another Take On 'Streetcar'
description: The review of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' (Theater, ''The Music of Words. Sex and Violence, Too,'' Oct. 4), the play now at the Hartford Stage, was cruel and unusual. This attendee was electrified from the torch singing that rewarded early arrivals to the earth-shattering collapse of Blanche DuBois at the end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, LEONARD
description: HOLLAND-Leonard. Who practiced law for 50 years in NYC, died October 8, 1998, from complications of myasthenia gravis, diabetes and heart disease. Surviving him are his wife Taffy (Ruth Robins), his daughters Claudia and Louisa, their husbands Richard Crane and Stephen Rinehart, his grandchildren Angelica, Francesca, Sally and Nicholas, and his brother Irwin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCIOSCIA, ROBERTA LEE
description: SCIOSCIA-Roberta Lee, 43. Loving wife of Anthony Scioscia, beloved daughter of Allan Passin and Lola Laub, adored sister of Monica Passin, loved niece of Mary Levine, Sara Haskell & Joe Szmuller, cherished stepparents Odile Passin & Jack Laub. Loved by her stepdaughters, Doreen and Jill, their husbands, children and the entire Scioscia family. To know her was to love her, a blue ribbon equestrian with a heart of gold, who will be deeply missed forever by family and hundreds of friends. An organ donor who saved six lives. Services today at her beloved home in Charlotte, N.C. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Boca Raton, FL., at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to Misty Meadows Mitey Riders, 455 Providence Road South, Weddington, North Carolina 28173.

title: Stomp
description: Harvests of Joy

title: Steal a Bit of Spring for the Coming Cold
description: For a preview of next spring's flowers, put aside some bulbs you're planting outdoors to force into bloom indoors.

title: Eisner's Tell-Little Tale Of His Magic Kingdom
description: I'VE always found that experiences from everyday life made the best drama,'' writes Michael D. Eisner in ''Work in Progress'' (Random House, $27.95), a first-person account of his years at ABC, Paramount Pictures and, of course, the Walt Disney Company, where he has run things since 1984.

title: Melanie Lemkau, William Campbell
description: Melanie Ann Lemkau, a daughter of Carol Ann Lemkau and Arthur Lemkau of Port Washington, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Richard Campbell, a son of Eleanor and Peter Campbell of Loudonville, N.Y., and Phoenix. The Rev. Maurice Fetty performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Manhasset, N.Y. Msgr. John J. McCann took part in the service.

title: A Downtown Troupe Revels in a New Sci-Fi Opera
description: THE RIDGE THEATER is an avant-garde company with the unbuttoned charm of ex-hippies who have made a name in experimental theater for staging multimedia spectacles with tidy, Swiss-watch precision. ''Looking at us, you'd think we're aging slackers,'' says Bob McGrath, the group's 43-year-old artistic director. ''But I take great pains to get things perfect.''

title: Giants and Falcons Do Least With First-Round Picks
description: A first-round pick in the National Football League's annual college draft is a prized commodity, the cornerstone of a franchise's talent base. Players chosen in the first round who become stars for the franchise that selected them highlight the roster of most N.F.L. teams.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Nice job, as usual. Lots of good stuff. Still, I am baffled that you ignored commercials. No matter how good the program, come the first commercial break, I'll click away.

title: The Nation; Partisan Rancor: Not Always So Bad for the National Soul
description: THE tidy, fateful day of partisan struggle was winding down as Representative Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, forwarded the recommended impeachment inquiry of President Clinton to certain approval by the House.

title: October 4-10; Unconvicted
description: Imelda Marcos will not be cooling her well-shod heels in jail -- not yet, anyway -- now that the Supreme Court of the Philippines has overturned a corruption conviction against her. Is she off the hook? Not exactly. Other criminal and civil matters loom, involving the billions that she and her husband, Ferdinand, who died in 1989, are accused of stealing. And the United States wants to discuss the small matter of $5 million in unpaid income taxes from the Marcoses' days in Hawaii. She may be barefoot yet. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Weird Science
description: DANCING NAKED

title: Famous in Tokyo If Not Here
description: IF you came to New York to be famous but haven't made it yet, take heart. You already have 100 million fans.

title: F.Y.I
description: Storage in Splendor

title: Edgar Pew, Christiane Mahoney
description: Christiane Marie Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Mahoney of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to James Edgar Pew, a son of Sally Chinn Pew and George L. Pew Jr. of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. Giles Spoonhour performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Soaring Teen-Agers at the Skate Park
description: THREE years ago, Ridgefield, a town that takes pride in the low brick walls, Colonial-style homes, and tasteful shops that line Main Street, found its charm challenged -- by teen-agers on skateboards.

title: Angry Voters Aren't Sure Where to Place the Blame
description: There is no question that voters are upset here in Washington, a state that has been a particularly accurate electoral bellwether in recent years. It broadly backed Bill Clinton and Congressional Democrats in 1992, turned to Republicans with spectacular vengeance in 1994, then returned to Mr. Clinton in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDY, ELOISE I.
description: HANDY-Eloise I. Devoted mother of Michael J. and Veronica Handy. Dear mother-in-law of Edna Wells Handy and Hugh (Buddy) Smith, Jr. Cherished grandmother of Dawn, Kenya, Jannah, Jacqueline Handy and Nicole Joie Smith. Loving great-grandmother of three. Viewing Mon. 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Franklin Funeral Home, 42 New Hyde Park Rd, Franklin Sq. Mass of Christian burial 10am Tues., St. Catherine of Sienna Church, Baisley Blvd., St Albans, Queens.

title: No, Angela, Life Isn't Fair, Even Your So-Called Kind
description: NO one said as much, but ''My So-Called Life'' was probably done for from the beginning. ''The first sign of trouble was the reception the network gave the pilot when we turned it in,'' recalled Marshall Herskovitz, one of its producers. ''Very mixed.''

title: A Happy (or Not So Sad) Group
description: AFTER years of lagging behind pure equity funds, balanced mutual funds are suddenly looking a lot more attractive.

title: For 5 Retirement Portfolios, It Was a Quarter to Forget
description: THE battering of the financial markets left few money managers unscathed in the third quarter. Just ask the ones whose hypothetical retirement portfolios have been tracked by The New York Times for the last five years.

title: PULSE; Independent Labels
description: Chasing someone down the street to find out what designer she's wearing is not beneath Anna Kim and Tracy Meyer. That's one reason their store, Hedra Prue, which opened two weeks ago at 281 Mott Street (Houston Street), is quickly becoming a showcase for downtown fashion talent.

title: Jessica Aldrich and Mark Strassman
description: Jessica Lee Aldrich, a daughter of Linda and Henry Aldrich of East Haddam, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Finn Strassman, the son of Kirsten and Roger Strassman of Chevy Chase, Md. Joan Nelson of the American Humanist Association officiated at the Lark Creek Inn in Larkspur, Calif.

title: Car Racers Fight for Gravel on Pikes Peak Road
description: Hiking below the spectacular Pikes Peak Highway, Gail Snyder points out the behind-the-scenes damage to the mountain. For decades, rain water has drained unchecked off the gravel road leading to the 14,110-foot summit, carving gullies deep enough to swallow ponderosa pines whole.

title: Tips on Vinyl and Aluminum Siding
description: MOST manufacturers recommend washing vinyl or aluminum siding twice a year to remove dirt, grime and mildew. Generally a forceful spray from a garden hose is enough. Areas with thick accumulations of grime may have to scrubbed with a brush and cleaning agent. Use a non-abrasive household detergent mixed with water for this.

title: PLAYING THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT PARK

title: Hawaii's Tourism Slump: Short or Long Term?
description: WHILE most of the United States appears headed for a second consecutive year with a record number of tourists in 1998 -- or was before the recent stock market gyrations raised questions about rosy tourism projections for this fall -- Hawaii's tourist industry continues to struggle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROELICH, MARTHA T.
description: FROELICH-Martha T. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Martha T. Froelich. To her family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: A Model Will Call The Shots
description: Why can't a supermodel edit a magazine? John F. Kennedy Jr. does. And Gwyneth Paltrow edited an issue of Marie Claire. The model Helena Christensen is the latest celebrity to attach her name to a masthead. She will be editor at large of Nylon, a women's magazine that will come out every other month starting in March.

title: Racist Logos
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: To my mind, ''schlock'' is cynical, exploitative, uninspiring and forgettable. ''The Andy Griffith Show,'' at its best, represents what television ought to be: effective entertainment with conscience, emotional resonance and unique insight into the human condition.

title: Queens Man Arrested After Firing Toy Cannon
description: A Queens man who wounded himself while firing a toy cannon in his apartment was arrested yesterday after neighbors called the police, the authorities said.

title: Listen to Shaw
description: To the Editor:

title: Battling It Out on the Links Is All in a Day's, uh, Work
description: General Electric's official line is that while John F. Welch loves to talk about the company's success, he keeps his golf game private. A similar message comes from Sun Microsystems about its chairman, Scott G. McNealy. But put your ear to the fairway, and you will hear more than the thwack of golf balls. The two chief executives apparently learned from Golf Digest last May that they were among the nation's top golfing C.E.O.'s -- Mr. Welch has a 3.8 handicap index and Mr. McNealy a slightly better 3.2. They agreed to play in Nantucket, and Golf World reported that Mr. Welch emerged victorious.

title: Democrats Try to Talk Gay Group Out of Backing D'Amato
description: White House officials and gay Democrats, concerned that the nation's largest gay and lesbian political organization is about to endorse Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for re-election, are intensely lobbying the group to try to shift its support to the Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Basics or More, It's Off to Cooking Class!
description: MORE and more people, men and women, working and non-working, are tackling cooking classes to expand entertaining skills, to exercise creativity and simply to relax.

title: Medical Team Ready If Disaster Strikes
description: THEY were preparing for the worst. Hurricane Georges had already taken more than 300 lives in the Caribbean, forced 30,000 people to evacuate the Florida keys and was heading straight for New Orleans. As the local population was fleeing, emergency crews were beginning to converge around the area. Among those the Federal Government called for help was a disaster medical assistance team from Westchester.

title: Impeachment Inquiry Won't Help Us Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JACQUES ANDRE, NE SELIGMANN
description: ROBBINS-Jacques Andre, ne Seligmann, of Greenwich, CT, on Wednesday, October 7, 1998. Son of the noted late art dealer of Paris and New York, Andre Jean Seligmann and the late Claude Simone Barrou Robbins of New York. He is survived by his loving wife J. Suzanne Geiss Robbins, Greenwich, CT. Loving father of Jacques Mel Robbins, New Rochelle, NY. Loving brother of Claude Seligmann Delibes of NYC and Water Mill, NY. Mr. Robbins was an investment analyst with Lazard Freres in Paris and New York and also an Executive Vice President at the Banque Nationale de Paris in New York City. Since his retirement in 1985 he has achieved acceptance and success as a figurative, portrait and landscape artist. He recently had his first one-man show in Roxbury, CT. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, October 13, 1998 at 11 AM at the First Presbyterian Church, 18 Lafayette Pl., Greenwich, CT. Calling hours 69 PM Monday, October 12, at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to the Bruce Museum Inc., 1 Museum Dr., Greenwich, CT 06830 for the Jacques A. Robbins Memorial Fund.

title: Keeping the Faith, Sort Of
description: BESIDE STILL WATERS Searching for Meaning in an Age of Doubt. By Gregg Easterbrook. 381 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: October 4-10; Tales From the White House
description: The investigations into officials of the Clinton Administration continued to yield startling tidbits.

title: Q&A; Extending Assistance To Abused
description: WHO -- Anna M. Diaz-White, 40, who gave up her job as a bank executive in New York 15 years ago to become executive director of the Women's Center of Monmouth County in Hazlet Township.

title: All These Hard Feelings!
description: Seth Flam's golden parachute isn't so golden after all. Mr. Flam got a $4.8 million severance deal when he resigned in March from FPA Medical Management Inc., which he founded and which filed for bankruptcy protection last year. That seemed enough to allow him to enjoy the suburban San Diego mansion he had just bought for $3 million. But the company now says it terminated the package in July after paying only $255,000. And doctors left with unpaid bills are going after even that pittance. . . . Sylvester Stallone has come under a lot of heat from nearby residents -- including Madonna -- for agreeing to sell his 12-acre estate in Miami's Coconut Grove section to a hotel chain for $24.7 million. But the deal is contingent on rezoning of the neighborhood for commercial use -- and Miami Mayor Joe Carollo says the chances for that are ''slim to none.'' Mr. Stallone, who bought the estate for $8.4 million in 1993, retorts that Mr. Carollo ''has been getting reports tinged with neighborhood hysteria.''

title: Impeachment Inquiry Won't Help Us Abroad; No Time Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Masterly Novice, A Triumph Over Time
description: HAD Erick Zonca's first feature film been autobiographical, as so many French first movies seem to be, it might well have been set in New York: a young illegal immigrant, who washes dishes in a Little Italy restaurant and sleeps in Washington Square, falls in love with a dancer and discovers a different America. Or it could have been set on the Paris Left Bank where the same Frenchman, now in his late 20's, wangles his way into the Sorbonne only to find he understands nothing of the course he has chosen.

title: Pataki Rated
description: According to a report from Environmental Advocates, a statewide lobbying group, Gov. George E. Pataki may be strong on preservation but he has not got tough with polluters.

title: Emily Mindel, William Gottlieb
description: Emily Beth Mindel, a daughter of Susan Mindel and Dr. Joel Mindel of New York, was married last evening to William Gottlieb, the son of Rena Blumberg of Kihei, Hawaii, and the late Dr. Louis Gottlieb. Rabbi Judith Lewis officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Stars, Above And Below
description: The renovated Grand Central Terminal was celebrated at a dinner and dance on Oct. 5.

title: Hurricanes' Mediocrity Can't Topple Seminoles
description: Demonstrating superior depth, Florida State wore down Miami in the second half today en route to a 26-14 victory. The Seminoles, who have finished in the nation's top 5 for the last 11 seasons, improved to 5-1. Miami fell to 3-2.

title: The Drifters
description: When cargo pants and turtlenecks washed up on shore, fashion took a new direction.

title: Hartford
description: Under an eight-foot-tall Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington, an actor dressed in a slave trader's gold vest sinks to his knees and tells a judge, ''The Negroes had gathered with sabers around my head, and they just started singing my death chant.'' The trader, Don Pedro Montez, pleads for the return of his slaves every Tuesday at the Old State House in Hartford, part of a re-enactment of a trial -- held in that very room -- after the 1839 slave mutiny on the schooner Amistad.

title: Gooden Decries Being Fine, Not Aggressive
description: It seemed as if Dwight Gooden delicately tried to sculpt a masterpiece for everyone back in New York to remember tonight, attempting to add just one more page of lore to the history between himself and the city.

title: Out of the Wild
description: WALTZING THE CAT

title: October 4-10; HMO's Accused of Fraud
description: Probably few executives at the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation or Quorum Health Group ever gave much thought to tiny North Valley Hospital in Whitefish, Mont. But now few will be likely to forget it. The Government said it had joined a lawsuit filed by a former North Valley officer, who accused the two hospital companies of defrauding Medicare through bogus expense claims. The suit, filed under seal almost six years ago, has already led to Federal investigations. Analysts expect that before it's all over settlements might top $1 billion. KURT EICHENWALD

title: Janet O'Brien and Joao Garcia
description: FRIENDS call Janet O'Brien ''Janet the Planet,'' mainly because she has more energy, friends and telephones than most earthlings.

title: Experts Discuss How Arts Can Aid Network
description: The arts saved Cleveland and Pittsburgh and they can save Newark, too, participants in a conference at Rutgers University were told today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALTA, ROMEO C.
description: SALTA-Romeo C. A memorial service will be held Sat., Oct. 17, 3 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Back to the Heady Days When a Hat Was a Hat
description: ''You can find a great hat for anybody,'' Lisa Shaub said confidently. ''It's just a matter of proportion.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDEMAN, EDITH (NEE GOULD)
description: LINDEMAN-Edith (nee Gould). Of Allendale, NJ, formerly of NYC, on October 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Adela Biggio and Alfred Lindeman. Loving grandmother of David, Eric and Christopher. Services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ, Sunday, 1 PM. Should friends desire contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation. For information please call ''Gutterman - Musicant'' 1 - 800 522-0588.

title: Can 1 Suburban Paper Do the Work of 10?
description: Gannett Suburban Newspapers of White Plains, N.Y., is merging several local papers in Westchester and parts of Rockland and Putnam Counties into one. Some residents wonder whether the new regional paper, The Journal News, will be as committed to small-scale hometown stories as its predicessors were.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLER, BERNICE
description: MEHLER-Bernice. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved sister of their devoted member, Dr. Lawrence Steinberg and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Offices Spread in Shore Towns Near New Haven
description: ECHOES of the commercial development that swept through suburban Fairfield County in the 1970's are reverberating eastward along the midshore suburbs of New Haven County. In quiet, upscale, residential towns like Guilford, Madison and Killingworth -- where antique homes abound, a few farms still exist and village greens remain pristine -- office building and applications for new construction are accelerating despite local concerns for preserving the New England character.

title: Amy Scheibe And Brian Flynn
description: Amy Lyn Scheibe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claire Scheibe of La Moure, N.D., was married yesterday to Brian Paul Flynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Flynn of Montville, N.J. The Rev. Philip Bohan, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in New York.

title: How We Fell, Then And Now
description: The sense of shock is different this time around. The stretch limos, the hubristic shoulder pads and the junk bonds of the 80's were bound to excite the anger of the gods, but hey, we've been riding around in Jeeps and dowdy gray Town Cars for the last 11 years.

title: The Museum Show Has An Ego Disorder
description: This week, the Library of Congress will open the doors of its Thomas Jefferson Building for the largest exhibit ever assembled on the life and work of Sigmund Freud. If the Library's estimates are correct, by the time the show closes on Jan. 16, more than a quarter million people will have inspected Freud's handwritten case notes on immortal patients like the Rat Man, the famous letter to his friend Wilhelm Fliess in which Freud renounces the so-called seduction theory and dozens of other manuscripts and first editions from the library's vast collection of Freudiana. Visitors will see the actual chair Dr. Freud used in his examining room, the actual kilim rug that draped the iconic couch, his actual spectacles and a phalanx of the antiquities Freud collected and arrayed with fetishistic precision on his desk.

title: The Way New York Tawks; Sunshine Hotel Dwellers Are New Yorkers Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Costs, as Well as the Sports, Are Extreme
description: AND you thought that new Big Bertha driver or Prince racket was a bit too much champagne for your beer pocketbook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROELICH, MARTHA TUCHMAN
description: FROELICH-Martha Tuchman. On October 9, 1998. Wife of the late James D. Froelich. Beloved mother of Edward (Joanne) and Robert (Denise). Devoted sister of Lucille Jaffe and the late Dr. Lester R. Tuchman. Loving grandmother of Laura, Cecilia, James, Emma and Helen Froelich. Friends may call Monday 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to the Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, SYLVIA
description: DONOHUE-Sylvia. Interment October 8, 1998 Arlington National Cemetery. Rabbi Bosch officiated. Jewish War Veterans, Post 58 were represented. She is survived by her husband Thomas, grandchildren, Rochele and Thomas Brockelman of Syracuse, Mira Brockelman of Oregon and great granddaughter Sophia. Mrs. Donahue assisted her husband in writing his book of his war experiences, ''Born Lucky or Unlucky'', which was published as a memorial for Mrs. Donohue.

Catron of Wytheville, Va. The Rev. David Goode performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: A Bankruptcy Rush, Just in Case
description: BY all accounts, President Clinton plans to veto the bankruptcy bill now in the final stages of approval in the Republican Congress. But many debtors aren't taking any chances.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dirk DeLaCour, Kerri Richardson
description: Kerri Lynnette Richardson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Richardson of Washington, is to be married there today to Dirk Jordan DeLaCour, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis S. DeLaCour Jr. of Brooklyn. Judge Harold L. Cushenberry Jr. of District of Columbia Superior Court, is to officiate at the Meridian House.

title: Spiritual Retreat That's No Monastery
description: WILLIAM PFEIFFER, counselor and married priest, likes to tell a well-known folk tale. ''When a young man prayed, he asked God to give him wisdom to change the world. In middle age, he sought guidance with his wife, children and friends. Upon growing old, he asked for help in changing himself. 'If I'd done that in the beginning,' the man concludes, 'I wouldn't have wasted my life.' ''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Campaign's Threat: Shakeup of L.I. Town Politics
description: AFTER more than 30 years of arguing that at-large elections for town board members favor party bosses and alienate residents from the level of government closest to them, Long Island proponents of town council districts believe their hour has come.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Some surprising back-grounds bolster a group of feature films on television this week.

title: Coping With Economic Crisis
description: The world's economic situation is perilous, and there is little doubt that there will be pain and suffering in many countries during the next few years. But the problems need not lead to world recession, let alone depression. With time and wisdom, the problems can be overcome.

title: Champions Converge On Arkansas's Waters
description: To the half-million people who live within 30 minutes of Lake Maumelle in Little Rock, Ark., access to clear water and undeveloped hillsides is part of the metropolitan landscape. But the area, which is staging a national sailing championship this week, is not your average port of call for yachting's elite.

title: Battle on 2 Fronts Over Planned Shelter for Children
description: A plan for an emergency children's shelter in the R & S building, on Bellevue Hospital Center's grounds at First Avenue and 31st Street, has existed since last year. And for just as long, it has fueled controversy in Kips Bay, where local officials worry about its proximity to a men's shelter on First Avenue and 29th Street and claim that the city is illegally circumventing its Uniform Land Use Review Procedure (Ulurp), which requires community input into ''site selection for capital projects.''

description: SHERMAN-Paula (Schwartz), nee Rubin. Of Forest Hills, NY. On October 7, 1998. With great bravery and dignity after a short illness. Beloved mother, sister, aunt. Dear friend to many. We will not see her like again. Cremation private.

title: No Bones About It, Cooked Fresh Tuna Adds to Favorite Dishes
description: FRESH tuna is best cooked rare or medium rare so it remains moist and juicy inside.

title: Sharing a Name but Little Else
description: SEND someone out for a bottle of Chablis and you run the risk of getting two wildly different wines. The confusion rests on nomenclature. Chablis from the Chablis region of France is a fine, flinty white Burgundy. Chablis from California will be white, but after that, all bets are off. How can two wines share a common name and little else?

title: Taking the Kids
description: To the Editor: Enjoy your children while you can. You can plan activities that interest them. There will be time enough for museums and concerts when they are older.

description: FRIEDENREICH-Lillian. beloved daughter of Goldie and Abraham O.B.M. Son David, Loving sister Helen and her children Julie and Gordon are grief stricken. Lilly succumbed after valient struggle. Rest in eternal peace. Amen.

description: No matter how much he denied it afterward, Greg Maddux looked very much like someone trying to deliver a message to Jim Leyritz and the San Diego Padres today when he hit Leyritz on the left shoulder with a pitch in the fourth inning.

title: U.S. BID TO BUILD CASPIAN PIPELINE APPEARS TO FAIL
description: A two-year campaign by the Clinton Administration to persuade major oil companies that they should quickly build a multi-billion-dollar pipeline in the Caucasus, a campaign that has become a centerpiece of American foreign policy, appears to be on the brink of failure.

description: EVEN Michaelangelo had off days.

title: Election Day, Deadline for Tulip Plantings
description: BULBS are easy to plant. These ready-made floral displays have the most simple needs: warm soil, a few gentle rains and several nice sunny spring days. The rewards: bloom.

title: A Guitarist's Travels Through Time
description: The guitar, when played with confidence, skill and commitment, makes anything sound good. Listening to David Starobin's recent recital at the Manhattan School of Music, I wondered who, on a different solo instrument, would dare slide back and forth between Baroque and new music as if it didn't matter which era was which.

title: Under the Surface In Chelsea
description: BRIGHT FOOD SHOP +

description: IT is tempting on meeting Ted and Sherry Scofield to slot them into a New York stereotype of the Young Southerners: innocent and naive, just arrived in the big city, ready and waiting to be marked by fate.

description: WHERE SHE WENT

title: Wanda Grant, Ricardo Knight
description: Dr. Wanda Felicia Grant and Dr. Ricardo Alfonzo Knight were married on Friday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. Edward Chinn, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Dr. Lemuel Taylor, an uncle of the bride and a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Taking the Kids
description: To the Editor: As to the benefits of taking grade-schoolers along, I offer just a sampling of the travel experiences that I owe completely to my young companions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURA, ANTHONY
description: LAURA-Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony Laura, associated with The Times from 1985, until retiring in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGMORE, JOHN W.
description: LONGMORE-John W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John W. Longmore, associated with The Times from 1975, until retiring in 1992.

title: Ruling Eases Threat To Gold Coast Estate
description: IT is the point of Kings Point, the tip of the Great Neck peninsula. Atop its 20-foot cliff looming over Long Island Sound, Manhattan's skyline, the Connecticut shore and the mansions of Sands Point unfold in a majestic panorama.

title: A Pessimism As Irrational As That Old Exuberance
description: SO, whatever happened to the new economy?

title: In St. Petersburg, the Sacred and Profane
description: BY midmorning, on a typical summer day, the parking lot of the Hermitage is filled with tour buses disgorging hordes of passengers who, led by guides holding aloft bright scarves or umbrellas, are already drifting or sprinting toward the doors of St. Petersburg's most famous museum. Of course, the elaborate former palace of the Romanov Czars houses one of the world's great collections, well worth enduring the long lines, the crush to get inside. But if one happens to visit at the most popular times, the experience of walking through its gilded and mirrored halls is roughly akin to riding, at the height of the rush hour, a subway lined with the canvases of Matisse and Van Gogh, Raphael and Rubens.

title: Film Festival at 6: Mature yet Growing
description: ''THERE'S always room for a savvy newcomer,'' Denise Kasell was saying of the Hamptons International Film Festival, which opens its sixth season on Wednesday.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: In the conversation moderated by Lynn Hirschberg (''What's a Network to Do?''), Fred Silverman, arguably the best television programmer of the last 50 years, said, ''We always tested, but we paid very little attention.'' In James Sterngold's article ''How Cable Captured the Mini-Series -- and the High Ground,'' Lindy DeKoven, an executive vice president at NBC, is quoted as saying, ''We have to wait and see the results of the testing'' (before deciding whether to identify William Shakespeare as the author of ''The Tempest,'' in advertising the upcoming production). Now, are there any more questions about why network television is going down the drain?

title: Municipals: Prime Time for the Other Haven
description: TURMOIL in global equity markets has sent investors scurrying for the safety of United States Treasury bonds. But investors willing to forgo the ironclad Government guarantees of Treasuries may be able to garner significant extra income after taxes -- and still maintain relative safety -- by investing in a municipal bond fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HORNSTEIN, CHARLES STUART (CHAIM HARAN)
description: HORNSTEIN - Charles Stuart (Chaim Haran). 7/30/50-10/12/73. Sweet Chuckie. 25 years. Forever loved, missed, remembered. ''And the rest will be told in the books of the chronicles of Israel''. Mother, Bennett, namesake Chaim

title: New Mall: Anticipation for Some People; Dread for Others
description: Nahyzla Glavan says the seven-acre fenced-in field up the block from her family's 72d Street home is a waste of land. In her mind, nothing could be better than the three-story shopping center, with national retailers, a large supermarket and a cineplex, that is planned for the site.

title: Sara Diamond, Jonathan Banner
description: Sara Helen Diamond and Jonathan Samuel Banner are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: A Larger, Truer Vision Of a Passionate Modern
description: BY the time William Kapell died in a plane crash in October 1953, at 31, he had already come to be recognized as the finest pianist America had produced. The popular pianists at the time were foreign-born: Horowitz, Rubinstein, Brailowsky, Hofmann. Then Kapell appeared, out of nowhere, it seemed, the son of a couple who owned a bookstore on Lexington Avenue.

title: Elizabeth Shreve, Russell Greiff
description: Elizabeth Steward Shreve, a daughter of Prof. Susan Richards Shreve of Washington and Porter Shreve of Houston, is to be married this evening to Russell David Greiff, a son of Carole Greiff and Dr. Barrie Greiff of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Harold White is to officiate with the Rev. Paula Kettlewell, an Episcopal priest, at Galemont Farm in Broad Run, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, LEONARD G.
description: DRISCOLL-Leonard G. On October 7, 1998, age 84, in Washington, D.C., from complications following surgery for cancer. A former resident of Stamford, CT, retired from The New York Times and a resident of Jupiter, FL, he is survived by his son, Brian Driscoll, and two grandsons, Daniel and David Driscoll, all of Washington, D.C., by a brother, James Driscoll, of Danvers, MA., and by three sisters, Mary Morris of Augusta, ME, Rita McCormack of Needham, MA, and Florence Ramsay of Wakefield, MA. A memorial Mass will be held at 1:00pm on Monday, October 12, in the student chapel at Gonzaga College High School, 19 I Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Tribe Seeks A Hastened Federal Status
description: THE Schaghtichoke Indians, a state-recognized tribe, are seeking accelerated Federal recognition and 1,900 acres in Kent including land being sought by the National Park Service for the Appalachian Trail. If they succeed, in New Haven Federal District Court, the Schaghtichoke could soon be building a casino in the western part of the state.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: I enjoyed the articles on television. But could you not have had a more attractive cover? Are pajamas passe? I did not appreciate the recumbent figure, complete with exposed armpit. Paradoxically, the only reassuring object in the photograph was the cigarette, a reminder of a gentler era, before vulgarity became the order of the day.

title: No TV, or Replays, or Victory
description: The sky didn't fall, and neither did their 10-ton scoreboard. But the Islanders, the Chicken Little franchise whose threat to boycott their home games due to unsavory conditions at Nassau Coliseum landed them in state and Federal court last month, fell into immediate arrears on the 1998-99 season tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSER, SIDNEY
description: GENSER-Sidney. Of Boca Raton, formerly of Jersey City. Beloved husband of Ruth. Cherished father of Barbara Zinn Moore (Jay). Adored son of the late Martin and Lena and brother of Alvin and the late Norman and Henry. Services at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 2 PM, Wednesday.

title: What Do a Town's Origins Mean to Its Future?
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; Tracking an Index, With Room to Wiggle
description: INVESTORS torn between choosing an actively managed mutual fund and an index fund often overlook a third, lower-profile option: a so-called sector-neutral fund. Such funds try to offer some of the virtues of indexing, with the hope that a manager's stock-picking skill will lead to index-beating results.

title: Editorial Observer; Presenting President Clinton's New Best Friend
description: Early in this election season, a consultant for New York City Council Speaker Peter Vallone used a focus group to test Mr. Vallone's potential as a gubernatorial candidate. Kevin McCabe, Mr. Vallone's top aide, reported that the focus group initially felt the Speaker was ''a nice guy who'd been around too long.'' But, Mr. McCabe added triumphantly, once shown extensive information on Mr. Vallone's accomplishments, the group saw the error of its ways and announced that he was an excellent public official who just needed more publicity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLER, CHARLES KOPEL
description: GABLER-Charles Kopel. We mourn the passing of our dad and grandfather, Charles Kopel Gabler, age 83, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Woodside and the Bronx, on October 2, 1998. Linotype operator with the New York Times for 30 years. Husband of the late Mary (Malakoff) Gabler for 54 years and recently of Marlene Gabler. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association. We will miss him. Rita, Ted and Elena Rover

title: Nature Center Plans
description: The Weinberg Nature Center in Scarsdale, one of the few recreational centers in the mid-Westchester area that offers early childhood programs on nature and wildlife, is expanding. Walter Terrell, the village's naturalist and the executive director of the 10-acre preserve, said the center is planning to add office space, new areas for animals and access for the handicapped. The center is home to Snowball, a sulfur-crested cockatoo; Karen, an albino dove; Delilah, a tarantula; Monty, a python, and several other animals. It also houses a butterfly garden, an apiary and an Indian village.

title: Complaints About H.M.O.'s Rise as Awareness Grows
description: State health insurance regulators are reporting surging numbers of formal complaints from patients and doctors against health insurers, primarily health maintenance organizations.

title: Understanding Arm Candy
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: BOOKEND; Thomas Merton's Durable Mountain
description: ''The SEVEN STOREY MOUNTAIN'' was first published 50 years ago this month. As Thomas Merton revealed in his journals, he had begun to write his famous autobiography four years earlier, at the Trappist monastery in Kentucky to which he had journeyed in December 1941, at the age of 26, after resigning as a teacher of English literature at St. Bonaventure College in Olean, N.Y. ''In a certain sense,'' Merton wrote, ''one man was more responsible for 'The Seven Storey Mountain' than I was, even as he was the cause of all my other writing.'' This was Dom Frederic Dunne, the abbot who had received Merton as a postulant and accepted him, in March 1942, as a Trappist novice.

title: Rangers Go North, But Effort Goes South
description: In his original travel plan, Coach John Muckler wanted his Rangers to stay after the game and spend an extra night here in Quebec. Instead of hurrying for a charter flight home, they could have enjoyed the bonding process that sometimes occurs at night on the road.

title: Girl Talk: What It Is, And Isn't
description: WHEN Monica S. Lewinsky poured her heart out to Linda Tripp, she was clearly looking for girl talk.

title: Champion of the New
description: To the Editor:

title: Overlooked
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNDERT, HYMAN
description: HUNDERT-Hyman. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Haspel). Cherished father of Vickie and Bruce Gorlick, and Amy and Michael Hundert. Adored grandfather of Robyn Gorlick and Steven Duberstein, Jennifer Gorlick, Julie and Joshua Hundert. A survivor of the Holocaust who was a dedicated member of the Jewish community. His integrity and spirit will live with us always.

title: Israel Is Advertising for Clues to a Sub Lost in 60's
description: Seeking to solve a mysterious maritime tragedy, Israel has appealed to the public in Turkey and elsewhere to help it find the wreck of a submarine that disappeared 30 years ago.

title: Those Quaint Apple Cider Stands Meet Up With the Long Arm of the Law
description: IF Johnny Appleseed only knew.

title: Legislative Priorities
description: The county has adopted its 1998-99 Joint Federal Legislative Program, which sets forth Westchester's priorities for the next 18 months. Among highlights of the program: Water Pollution Control and Estuary Restoration Financing Act to increase funds for the Federal Clean Water Act State Revolving Loan Fund Program through 2004, and funds for the Summer Youth Employment and Training Program, which serves about 650 young people a year.

title: Refinishing Hardwood Floors
description: HARDWOOD floors, often the most visible and vulnerable blend of form and function in a house, inevitably take a beating over time. And when that happens, flooring experts say, homeowners usually have two basic options: refinish what's there or cover it with something else.

title: Two-Fisted Philanthropy
description: THEY needed a good eater, quick with a fork, but steady, one who could stay the courses. Retired fat boys are the best. If the cause is just, we will dig deep into our checkered (tableclothes, that is) pasts for the know-how to suck it down. When the going gets full, we get going. This is how I happened to be in a back room at La Bodega de la Familia's storefront on Third Street off Avenue C last week, sampling entries in a bilingual cookbook that should make the little drug crisis center rich and famous.

title: Sinn Fein Head Praises Clinton's Role in Peace
description: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, praised President Clinton's role in the Irish peace process at a news conference at Kennedy International Airport yesterday at the beginning of an eight-day fund-raising tour.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: It was disheartening to see your entire issue devoted to television. Even more disappointing was a comment by Lesley Stahl in the article on newsmagazines (''3,000 Minutes,'' moderated by Diane Sawyer). Stahl states: ''War, inflation, hard news. We don't live in a time where there is any at the moment.'' Perhaps not on network news, but important events are taking place in Kosovo, in the Asian economic crisis and in Congressional votes that are ignored by most of the news media.

title: As U.S. Presses Talks on Kosovo, Hope of Averting Air Strikes Rises
description: The continuation of negotiations on Saturday by the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, with both the ethnic Albanian leadership in Kosovo and the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, suggested that enough common ground was being found to avert NATO air strikes, Western diplomats said.

title: Just One School Too Many?
description: Most communities would welcome a new school in their backyard. But in the northern section of Belmont, some residents are dreading the opening of a 650-seat intermediate school that they say will oversaturate an area that already has five schools and more than 8,000 students.

title: Contraceptive Care
description: To the Editor:

title: What's It All About? Simply Burt.
description: IT was 10 o'clock on a Saturday night, and several hundred people were standing around in a record store having a religious experience: Burt Bacharach was giving a miniconcert in a megastore. They were mostly hip 30-somethings, not candidates for hip replacement. This wasn't the Westbury Music Fair; the stage was not revolving.

title: Nancy Snell and Andrew Weislogel
description: Nancy Carol Snell, the daughter of Susan M. Snell and Dr. Glen D. Snell of Watertown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Carl Weislogel, a son of Judith B. Weislogel and Dr. Paul O. Weislogel of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Russell Clark, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Anabel Chapel at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: October 4-10; A Hefty Charge Against Visa And Mastercard
description: People who feel deprived of access to what now seems to be an American right to buy on credit have a friend at the Justice Department.

title: Problems a la Carte for a Popular Restaurant's Neighbors
description: When Cafeteria opened during the summer on Seventh Avenue it became an instant palace of cool, drawing supermodels and celebrities for martinis and macaroni and cheese. But some neighbors, armed with a menu of complaints about noise and smells, are resolutely unimpressed.

title: POSTINGS: At Livingston Ridge in Dobbs Ferry; 6 Homes, 1 Floor Each, With Elevator
description: On a precipitous 100-foot hill overlooking the Hudson River in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., ground is being cleared for Livingston Ridge, a 24-home development that will include six 3,200-square-foot ''maisonette elevator homes'' in two buildings. Martin Ginsburg, president of Ginsburg Development of Hawthorne, N.Y., which is developing the project, said that each building would have three of the homes, and each home would occupy an entire floor, with an elevator opening directly into the foyer. Selling prices for the 3,200-square-foot flats will be $800,000 and up.

title: Taking the Kids
description: To the Editor: I could not disagree more with the letter from Jean Shriver (Sept. 6) about Seth Margolis's article ''On Your Mark, Get Set, Duomo!'' in which she suggests that children under 10 could not enjoy or remember a trip to Europe. Our son, Michael, now 10, accompanied us to Scandinavia at age 6, to London and Paris at 8, and to northern Italy at 9. I asked him now what he remembered and out poured happy memories about these places:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FABBRI, LOU, JR.
description: FABBRI-Lou, Jr. Vice President, Tommy Hilfiger. Memorial Wednesday, October 14, 6 PM, Epiphany Church, 2nd Ave and 22nd St. Contributions may be made to St. Michael's School Fund, 28 East Main St., Frostburg, MD 21532.

title: Positive Ways To Move On
description: Q. I am a computer consultant at a major international bank. Recently, my boss and one member of the staff have made anti-Semitic remarks that are at best insensitive, at worst fighting words. The agency that hired me for the job has acknowledged the problem but says I am overstating it. The agency, however, has to defend its client, so its sympathies lie with her.

title: ON THE WATER WITH -- PERCY HEATH; A Love of Bass (Fiddle) and (Striped) Bass
description: THE wind had already turned against the tide, slowing the 22-foot Boston Whaler as it drifted above the rocky bottom where the fluke feed. The boat's skipper, Percy Heath, explained that the fish bite better when the bait bounces by at a livelier speed.

title: Closing In on 2000: Will Computers or Government Blink?
description: With less than 15 months remaining before the turn of the century, state lawmakers are finally starting to get worried. It is the year 2000 problem, the computer glitch that could bring down everything from elevators to sewage pumping stations.

title: The Byways Not Taken On Old Beethoven Road
description: PLAYING Beethoven is one of the two most important things a symphony orchestra has to do, along with performing new works. We need to keep going back to Beethoven. And we need to keep thinking about why we need to keep going back. Opportunities to go back, but not so much to think about why, were recently offered by the New York Philharmonic and its music director, Kurt Masur. Their season-opening Beethoven cycle was, remarkably, the Philharmonic's first compact presentation of the Beethoven symphonies since Toscanini conducted the works in the orchestra's centenary year, 1942.

title: Mark Twain's Ghost
description: To the Editor:

title: Cri de Coeur Over Baker's Lost Lease
description: For 24 years, Maurice Bonte, 63, and his wife, Suzannne, 61, have owned and operated Patisserie Bonte on Third Avenue near 75th Street. Now, the Bontes say, they may soon have to close their shop. They say that their landlord has refused to renew their lease, which expires Oct. 31, and that the Ann Taylor store next door has signed on to take over the space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, BERNARD A.
description: FUCHS-Bernard A. Age 86, died Saturday in Tallahassee, FL, after an extended illness. Mr. Fuchs had been President of USV Pharmaceutical Corporation. He is survived by sons, Larry Fuchs, Director of the Florida Department of Revenue, and Dennis Fuchs, District Court Judge in Salt Lake City, UT; brothers Dr. Bertram Fuchs in Northport, NY, Morton Foxe in Silver Spring, MD; and sister Susan Pearlstein in Port Jefferson, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Big Bend Hospice, Tallahassee.

title: Devils Lose Momentum and First Game
description: In Robbie Ftorek's debut tonight as Devils coach, his players did something they never accomplished under Jacques Lemaire: prevent the opposition from an official shot on goal for an entire period.

title: Roller-Coaster Fan in Line for Clinton Staff Chief
description: John David Podesta, the lean, wry roller-coaster enthusiast who senior White House aides say is likely to become their next chief of staff, keeps an unusual photograph of President Clinton on his office wall.

title: Career Criminal Is Suspect in Three Rapes
description: Brooklyn detectives have identified a career criminal as the suspected rapist accused of attacking at least three women as they waited at transit stops in different parts of the borough. A ''Wanted'' poster with a photo of the suspect, identified by the police as Bart Roman, is taped to token booths in subway stations throughout Brooklyn.

title: No Face Lift, No Cover-Up
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Woman in Handcuffs Says She Was Captive
description: An 18-year-old woman who was found on a Manhattan street in handcuffs yesterday told the police she had been held against her will for 10 months by her boyfriend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATZ, BEVERLY C.
description: SPATZ-Beverly C. Died peacefully on October 9, 1998, with her beloved husband Theodore Spatz by her side. Beloved and devoted mother of Gail Spatz Krischer and dear mother-in-law of Kenneth Krischer, M.D., of Fort Lauderdale, FL. Services will be held Sunday, at 11 AM, at Temple Sholom, Pompano Beach, FL. Donations in her memory may be made to Hadassah or Temple Sholom.

title: Las Vegas Headliners: Monet and Van Gogh
description: In most Las Vegas casinos, the only truly valuable artwork is a royal flush. But on Thursday the 3,000-room Bellagio hotel and casino will open with, among other attractions, a fine-arts gallery containing original works by Monet, Van Gogh, Renoir, Cezanne and Gauguin.

title: On Language; Alone With 'Alone,' or What 'Is' Is
description: 'It depends on how you define alone,'' President Clinton told the grand jury. At another point, he said, ''It depends on what the meaning of the word is is.''

title: Ivy Epstein, Joshua Levine
description: Ivy Beth Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Epstein of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Joshua Adam Levine, the son of Alice S. Levine of Brookline, Mass., and the late Dr. Sol Levine. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Backtalk; Extreme Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: ''I get excited by the journey,'' says Shawn Ray, a leading contender for the Mr. Olympia title, the most prestigious in professional bodybuilding. ''I see a little change in a muscle, I go, 'Oh, boy, look at that.' I mean you don't get excited eating chicken and egg whites, working out, then tanning for an hour, then feeling so depleted you've got to work out all over again.''

title: That Year's Model
description: LENOIR

title: BMW's Hotline: Dial M for Muscle
description: For the truly driven among driving enthusiasts, more is always better. For BMW, the question is how to improve on what are some of the best-driving cars on the planet. To find the answer, BMW established its M division -- ''M'' for Motorsport -- 20 years ago. Its mission: produce high-performance variants of BMW products.

title: A Toyshop That Doesn't Forget to Play
description: THE chief executive of Mattel Inc. likes to wake up every morning to CNN Headline News. And she can be certain the television set will be on in the morning. After all, it's on when she falls asleep. Yes, her husband does mind, but it's a habit she finds hard to break.

title: The Way New York Tawks; Like Bryant Park, Bronx Garden Is a Jewel
description: To the Editor:

title: Stehanie Horan, Cyrus Sepahbody
description: Stephanie Peters Horan, the daughter of Arlene and Gary Horan of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Cyrus J. Sepahbody, the son of Angela Sepahbody and Farhad Sepahbody of Sedona, Ariz. Msgr. Anthony Dalla Villa, the rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, performed the ceremony there.

title: New Set of Wheels For My Suburban Life
description: For most of my life, I have lived in the outer boroughs of New York City. So when my husband and I agreed to move to Long Island in a quest for more space, less congestion and better public schools, I viewed our decision with a bit of trepidation. I was reluctant to leave behind the bus, subway and rail lines that, while far from perfect, had been my chief mode of transportation for many years. I felt that exchanging the negative aspects of urban living for the positive aspects of suburbia meant I would have to spend more time traveling by automobile. I was not particularly pleased about this. Unlike many Americans, I have never maintained a love affair with my car.

title: Correspondence/At Work In Johannesburg; To Me It's Blatant Sexism; To South Africans It's Not a Problem
description: THE first clue was right there on the day our furniture arrived from New York. Though I had spent the whole day directing traffic -- the couch goes there, the Chinese piece here -- along about 5 P.M. the foreman approached me with his clipboard and said, ''Where's the boss?''

title: Just How Low Can Fees Go?
description: WITH equity markets on the skids, investors may soon notice the bite that fees take from their mutual-fund returns. But a new fund family with big-name outside advisers hopes to attract investors by reining in these costs.

title: Parcells Happy With Jets' Choices That Gave Rams Pace
description: In a sense, the Jets will confront their recent past when they face the Rams here on Sunday. And they will get to see how their present is evolving.

title: The World: Boom; A Panic Can Be Stopped, Until It Starts
description: AS the world's finance ministers and bankers argued and strategized here last week about the most virulent outbreak of economic turmoil in half a century, it often seemed as if they were watching a spectacular fire, viewed from the safety of a well-catered picnic just across the river.

title: In Port Chester, Goan Indian Cuisine
description: THE ambiance at Miramar (''The Home of Goan Indian Cuisine'') reminds us how vast the Indian subcontinent is. Diners accustomed to Indian restaurants cozy with patchwork canopies, guarded by icons and soothed by the sitar's strains will be unprepared for Miramar's Southwestern touch, where murals of palm trees on tropical beaches and pop music extolling the ''Goan paradise'' sung by a Jimmy Buffett sound-alike reaffirm the extent to which Goa has been invaded by the West.

title: Fear of Math in the Workplace = Business Opportunity
description: DAVID Frieder and Mark Weinfeld have a simple market niche: fear.

title: BRAT CAM
description: Starting this year, school-bus drivers in Spokane, Wash., have a new tool in the war against back-seat rowdies: Bus-Cam. Hanging silently above the driver, the device videotapes without prejudice up to five hours of noogies, spit wads and wedgies. ''Kids will do all kinds of things, hop around the bus, hang out windows, jump out emergency exits at stoplights,'' says Pat Doten, a veteran Spokane driver, ''and it's much harder to keep the bus on the road if you're trying to catch them.'' During test runs last year, drivers found that the mere presence of the camera, manufactured by Robotics Technologies of Joliet, Ill., deterred misbehavior. And the tapes help control more than just the students. ''Parents are often in denial when we try to suspend a student's bus privileges,'' says Joe Madsen, a school-district transportation coordinator. ''Now it's pretty tough for Johnny's mom to support Johnny when he's on tape.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRER, REINALDO A., M.D.
description: FERRER-Reinaldo A., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our longtime friend and former colleague, Reinaldo A. Ferrer, M.D., who served with distinction as the hospital's Associate Director for Academic Affairs prior to his tenure as Commissioner of Health for New York City. To his wife, Elba, his children and grandchildren, the entire Ferrer family and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, CHP and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D., President and CEO, CHP Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO, BIMC Ray E. Trussell, M.D., General Director Emeritus, BIMC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JACK
description: LEE-Jack, 91. Of North Miami Beach went to heaven to meet his wife, Edith & daughter Judy Ann. Jack ''The Great Lee'' ''The Professor'' is survived by his daughter, Nancy Ericksen and his grandson, Lars Ericksen. Jack arranged Lionel Hampton's Band and managed Louis Armstrong & Eddie Haywood. He was an avid golfer with Perry Como, Dean Martin & Eddie Fisher. He was ''The Music Man.'' We love you.

title: Leslie Lewis, Gavin Sword
description: Leslie Nicolas Lewis, a daughter of Loida Nicolas Lewis of New York and the late Reginald F. Lewis, is to be married this afternoon to Gavin Rodney Sword, a son of Delana and Rodney D. Sword of Nanaimo, British Columbia. The Rev. John Bucki is to perform the ceremony at Sacred Hearts Roman Catholic Church in Lanai City, Hawaii.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLASSER, ISRAEL
description: GLASSER-Israel. 8/5/20-10/11/93. Lovingly remembered. You live on in all of us. Julia, Susan, Steven, Marc, Donna, Noah, Coren and Ethan

title: World Markets Keep Roiling; World Leaders Keep Squabbling
description: A five-day conference of finance ministers and central bankers in Washington ended without agreement on any coordinated steps to bolster the world economy, despite a direct appeal for a unified plan from President Clinton. European leaders and the president of the World Bank broke with the United States and the International Monetary Fund over strategies for restoring stability in global financial markets. Latin American governments, envious of what they consider lenient treatment of Russia, called for more generous financial aid for themselves.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Deepak Chopra on ''The X-Files''? Robert Pinsky on ''The Simpsons''? And all those unfunny ideas for the ''fantasy fall season.'' Sorry, but you only reinforced my belief that TV is junk. Life was better when there were three networks, PBS and no remote control, because then people scanned the offerings and if they didn't see something they liked, they turned the damn thing off, got off their behinds and did something else. And for the record, I'm not a senior citizen with myopic nostalgia; I'm 31 years old.

title: Jennifer Friedman, Daniel Sklarew
description: Jennifer Beth Friedman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barton Friedman of Cherry Hill, N.J., is to be married today to Daniel Marin Sklarew, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Sklarew of Reston, Va. Rabbi Gary Mazo is to officiate at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del.

title: Tips on Repairing Vinyl and Aluminum Siding
description: MOST manufacturers recommend washing vinyl or aluminum siding twice a year to remove dirt, grime and mildew. Generally, a forceful spray from a garden hose is enough. Areas with thick accumulations of grime may have to scrubbed with a brush and a cleaning agent, like a non-abrasive household detergent mixed with water.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 56 of The Times Magazine today, about a new Freud exhibition at the Library of Congress, omits credits for the photographs and documents used in the illustrations. The photographs should be attributed to the Library of Congress, courtesy of A.W. Freud et al., and the documents to Mark Paterson & Associates/Collection of the Library of Congress.

title: Links to Hull
description: To the Editor: A paragraph in the L. J. Davis article ''Salt Air Still Lingers in Hull'' (Sept. 6) really made me smile. I mean the assertion that underneath the statue of Queen Victoria the territory was -- and still is -- devoted to public restrooms.

title: Cool and Collected
description: Classic modern design is the style today, in everything from living rooms to television commercials. But for Michael and Gabrielle Boyd, who have spent the last two decades amassing thousands of pieces of 20th-century furniture, objects and abstract art, modernism is -- as its inventors intended -- ''a philosophy, not a trend.''

title: Rhyming and Reasoning
description: Bet your 10th-grade English teacher never called poetry ''a process framework which enables individuals and groups to recognize and act on opportunities.'' But then, your teacher probably never met Barbara J. Babij.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBIN, WILLIAM
description: TAUBIN-William. On October 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Jeanette. Loving father of the late Richard, Helene and Jane. Dear husband of the late Doris. Devoted brother of Adele and Annette. Adoring grandfather of Wendy, Lara and Katja. Cherished fatherin-law of Peter Marsman. Bill was a highly decorated and awarded Art Director in the advertising industry. Bill was a distinguished member and former president of the Advertising Art Directors Club. Bill will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Service on Tuesday, 12:30 P.M., at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Why Does Washington Need Wise Men?
description: At a moment when Washington is obsessed with a constitutional crisis of farcical proportions, it is perhaps understandable that a whiff of nostalgia is felt for the old Establishment.

title: Put Zoning to Work For Central-City Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paula Gillen, Shawn Martin
description: Paula Anne Gillen, a daughter of Rita G. Sewell of Aiken, S.C., and James R. Gillen of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Shawn Patrick Martin, a son of Kathleen and Robert J. Martin of Lititz, Pa. The Rev. William L. Winston, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Morristown.

title: Highly Intoxicating Wit, Served Straight Up
description: '' CAIRO!... Cairo!... '' cries the bewildered Egyptian princess to Lord Edgar Hillcrest, the dim archeologist who has invaded her tomb and brought her back to life after 3,500 years. A small world, you might think, recalling ''To Moscow, to Moscow, to Moscow!'' and those three weepy sisters from another, far later time and less exotic place. Yet the princess isn't longing for the intellectual stimulus of a city that didn't even exist when she was mummified; she is struggling to remember the word -- and it's right on the tip of her tongue -- for the type of doctor who treats bad backs. She finally locates the two missing syllables: ''. . . practor!''

title: When Breast Cancer Invigorates a New Life
description: LORETTA COLON took three cruises this year. She frequented Broadway shows. With two sons out of college, she and her husband savored every moment.

title: GURU: Dr. Pat Wexler; Soothing Celebrities and Smoothing Away Their Skin Woes
description: ON a late autumn afternoon, the sun was pouring through the broad windows in Dr. Pat Wexler's office, the decor of which can best be described as French provincial meets the Museum of Modern Art's design store. Dr. Wexler, the dermatologist, was sitting behind an antique desk, wearing a brown dress, jacket, and sling-backs from Bergdorf Goodman. ''They're so Blahnik, aren't they?'' she said, holding one of her pale feet aloft. She is a well-tended 47-year-old woman with skin like creme fraiche and a personality as soothing as buttermilk.

title: The World; If Hedgehogs Could Talk, This Is What They'd Say
description: NOBODY likes to say, ''I goofed'' -- particularly when the mistake helped cause the meltdown of stock and bond markets around the globe. Which is part of the reason the public pronouncements about the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management and the billion-dollar bailout of the hedge fund organized by the Federal Reserve have been couched in language as arcane as the military lingo in a Tom Clancy novel. (Another reason is that Wall Street loves jargon, which makes its business sound mysterious and important and serves as a sort of secret handshake.)

title: Fright, Misery and Anger Fuel Serb's Plan
description: To many Serbs in this frightened capital, the threats of air strikes against the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, are producing one result that Washington says that it does not want: strengthening rather than weakening the control of Mr. Milosevic.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Talk About Baseball!
description: It is getting pretty hard to find much new in baseball oral history. THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF BASEBALL: The Inside Story From the Stars Who Played the Game (Abrams, $35) does not add to the mountain of verbiage. Rather, one might fairly say that the book draws on the words of more than 150 ballplayers past and present in ways that try to whittle it down some. Written as ''an extended conversation'' by Joseph Wallace, the book is a sort of meta-commentary on the major-league game as career, craft and love. Wallace, the general editor of ''The Baseball Anthology,'' tries to take readers from the beginnings of a ballplayer's career to the day he retires. Along the way, there are ruminations on the art of pitching, the best way to defend against the double steal and how to cope with every possible setback, from racial taunting to batting slumps. As a result, the book is an uneasy mix of too many things and not enough of anything. If you are going to include a lengthy section on defense, why omit any discussion of turning the double play? Only one page on the pain of being traded? Nor is the text improved any by Wallace's own rather lifeless prose. Still, there are some wonderful moments provided by the ballplayers themselves, and Wallace offers one genuinely real insight, an observation that seems to have been lost to so many baseball fans and writers: ''Baseball is a hard game to play.'' The black-and-white photographs are beautifully reproduced. The two-page spread of Roberto Clemente leaping for a fly ball, a white blur flashing down as he is rising, two vectors about to intersect with geometric certainty, alone is worth the price of the book. George Robinson

title: October 4-10; Another Guilty Plea
description: Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., the co-owner of the San Francisco 49ers, had bigger worries than his team's recent loss to the Buffalo Bills. Mr. DeBartolo pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Baton Rouge, La., to failing to report an alleged extortion plot concocted by Edwin W. Edwards, the roguish former Governor of Louisiana. As part of a plea bargain, Mr. DeBartolo agreed to provide evidence that Mr. Edwards had demanded $400,000 in cash in exchange for using his influence to shepherd a DeBartolo riverboat casino project through the local Gaming Board. He was ordered to pay $1 million in fines and penalties. Prosecutors have their eye on Mr. Edwards. KEVIN SACK

title: Jackie Mason Takes Act to Nyack
description: ALTHOUGH Jackie Mason's fame has nothing to do with cantorial chants, he summons that gift from his past to end the first act of his latest stand-up routine at the Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center here. It may not be widely known that he is a rabbi, but the real revelation of ''Much Ado About Everything'' is that the comic is a bona fide prophet.

title: Erin Knight, John Bautz
description: Erin Leslie Knight, the daughter of Janet Battaile and Jerry Knight of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to John Joseph Bautz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Bautz of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph D. Casaclang performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUVELIN, GERTRUDE
description: SUVELIN-Gertrude. On October 2, 1998. She will always be remembered by her friends and family. May she rest in everlasting peace.

title: Why It Takes 400 Pages to Tell You What's On
description: IF, as Emily Dickinson says, hope is the thing with feathers that perches in the soul, then maybe boredom is the thing in a bathrobe that just sits around the house. It is, in any case, my only excuse for the amazing statistical discoveries that follow.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HASKELL, JACK
description: HASKELL-Jack. Memorial service, 10:30 AM, Oct. 15 at Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien, 2011 Post Road, Darien. Memorial donations to the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Duncan Sheik; A Laid-Back Buddhist-Semiotic Life
description: ON a rainy Thursday evening two days after the release of Duncan Sheik's second album, he was padding barefoot around his guitar-strewn TriBeCa loft, muttering, ''This is insane.''

title: A Fund's Letters Can Cool Love's Fire
description: IT remains one of the most memorable letters I've ever received, up there with my acceptance to college and the emotive notification from my mother that my childhood pet cat, Noodle, was dead.

title: College Admissions, the Consultant's Way
description: COLLEGE planning. The very thought of it raises the blood pressure of most parents. And just when they thought that good S.A.T. scores, challenging coursework, athletic or musical skills, leadership and community service would practically guarantee their child's admittance to a prestigious school, there's evidence that one more investment might be helpful: hiring a consultant to package youngsters and match them with the best college.

title: For a Child Who Can't Do Math But Has the Shot Clock Aced
description: Score, which operates 50 after-school educational centers throughout the United States, recently opened two in the city. The first, at 412 Columbus Avenue (at 79th Street), opened last month, and two weeks ago a learning center opened in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, at 1360 Fulton Street, Building B (between New York and Brooklyn Avenues).

title: South Jersey Expected To Get New Area Code
description: Northern and central New Jersey residents went through the process of getting two new area codes last year, and now people in southern New Jersey should expect their turn.

title: Streetscapes / Grand Central Terminal; The 23-Story, Beaux-Arts 1913 Tower That Wasn't
description: WHILE the city is celebrating the completed restoration of Grand Central Terminal, one large element of the original design is still missing -- a 23-story Beaux-Arts-style office tower directly above the concourse. The tower was never built, but it casts a shadow over the 1913 rail terminal and the surrounding area.

title: Finding 'Happiness': A Good Career Move
description: THE star of Todd Solondz's ''Happiness'' is wide-eyed, soft-edged and good at rolling with the punches. ''That's when my Juilliard training comes in handy,'' said the star in question, Jane Adams. One day she arrived on the ''Happiness'' set and was informed by Mr. Solondz that a scene scripted as a verbal showdown between her character and her boyfriend's other girlfriend now resembled something out of ''Caged Heat.'' ''Todd said, 'O.K., she's going to come in, spit on you, grab you and then the two of you will fight on the floor.' And I said, 'O.K.!' Then I went back in the Rolodex of my mind to: 'Down on the Ground -- With or Without Kneepads' and started to figure how to do it. It was kind of exciting.''

title: Kosovo War Crimes Cannot Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Precious Cargo
description: Gucci's got 'em for fall. Yohji and Helmut, too. Ralph is doing them in white cashmere, and of course, Old Navy has been pushing them since last winter. Yeah, the kids started it. But to get the back story on why a military-style staple of antifashion has become the chic signifier of the moment, you have to look beyond the trendy tribalism of extreme sports to the real deal: the cargo cults of Papua New Guinea.

title: Philadelphia Packages For Delacroix Show
description: Several Philadelphia hotels are offering packages that include passes to the exhibit ''Delacroix: The Late Work'' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The show, which runs through Jan. 3, includes about 70 paintings and 40 works on paper produced by Eugene Delacroix in the 15 years before his death in 1863.

title: Commercial Property / The Jersey Riverfront; On the Hudson's West Bank, Optimistic Developers
description: EVEN as its steel skeleton for a 420,000-square-foot office building at 90 Hudson Street on the Jersey City waterfront is starting to rise, Hartz Mountain Industries has purchased another acre of Colgate Center where it plans to erect an identical 12-story building at a location designated as 70 Hudson Street.

title: A Country-Eastern Night Out
description: THE sound of fiddles pierces the silence on Avenue W in Gravesend, Brooklyn, on Wednesday evenings, and Don Coy's amplified Kentucky drawl echoes down the street. In the basement of Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church, at East Fourth Street, Mr. Coy leads about 100 people through the basic square-dance steps: ''Do-si-do, allemande left, ladies chain, dive on through.''

title: Into the Woods, for Answers
description: He calls them the Cat Rock Gang, in honor of a boulder near his country home in Dutchess County. That's where Mike Harris, 76, a child psychologist who lives in SoHo, goes hiking every six weeks or so with a group of about 15 boys and young men, 11 to 21 years old.

title: Miss Caldwell, Mr. Jackson
description: Jane Barron Caldwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Caldwell of Dallas, was married yesterday to Alexander Edward Jackson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Jackson of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Ideas & Trends; Privacy Matters: When Bigger Banks Aren't Better
description: IMAGINE you are being treated for breast cancer, a fact known to your Travelers' insurance agent from your medical tests and insurance forms. Imagine also that you are applying for a mortgage from, say, Citibank, where you've banked for years and which has just merged with Travelers Group. Despite your excellent credit rating, your mortgage is denied by Citibank for reasons that are unclear.

title: Making Art That Lasts Of Theater That Doesn't
description: IN Paul Davis's theater posters, one can see the essence of the original performance: the arrogant charm of Raul Julia's Mack the Knife in ''Threepenny Opera,'' Sam Waterston crying out his rage in ''Hamlet,'' the Orientalized elegance of Irene Worth in ''The Cherry Orchard'' and the full range of Kevin Kline's virtuosity as Hamlet, Richard 3d and the Pirate King in ''The Pirates of Penzance.

title: Yorkshire Library
description: To the Editor: A Yorkshirewoman who lives in New York City, I was enchanted to read ''The Robust Charms of a Yorkshire Port'' (Sept. 6). Whitby is one of my favorite places, and I usually visit each summer.

title: Cynthia McKane, Christian Stewart
description: Cynthia McKane, the daughter of Beatrix and Robert B. McKane of Centerport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian Joseph Stewart, a son of Patricia G. Stewart of Convent Station, N.J., and Peter G. Stewart of Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Bruno Ugliano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Sybaritic Soothing At Two Spas
description: CALL me a glutton for pampering. We'd been in Tampa to visit a favorite uncle, but now my husband, Bill, and I yearned for the sybaritic life. Why not a spa hop? The Don CeSar Beach Resort and Spa on St. Pete Beach was better known for its luxe appointments than go-for-the-burn workouts, but there'd be enough in the way of wraps and scrubs to keep us purring. Half an hour away, Safety Harbor Resort and Spa along Tampa Bay had a solid reputation on the spa circuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ROBERT
description: ALLEN-Robert. One of the original Hollywood screen cowboys, Robert Allen, age 92, a.k.a. born I.E. Theodore Baehr, died peacefully from cancer in Oyster Bay, NY on October 9, 1998. Funeral services will be announced.
