Mr. Allen/Baehr was the beloved husband of the late Evelyn Peirce and beloved father of Katherine Meyer (Charles) and Theodore Baehr (Liliana), and loving grandfather of Katherine Merritt, Charles and Robert (Ted) Meyer, and Peirce, James, Robert and Evelyn Baehr. A graduate of Dartmouth College in 1929, Mr. Allen/ Baehr played the juvenile lead and starred in over 40 films in the 1930s, including ''Crime and Punishment'' (1935). Mr. Allen won the Box Office Award for ''Love Me Forever'' (1935). Mr Allen starred in the ''Bob 'Tex' Allen Ranger'' series for Columbia Pictures. After WW II Mr. Allen starred in Broadway in such classics as ''Showboat''; ''Auntie Mame''; and ''Whoopie.'' Mr. Allen starred in numerous television programs and many commercials. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Christian Film and TV Commission, 2510-G Las Posas Rd., Camarillo, CA 93010.

title: Playhouse Baroque
description: Like so many things these days, children's playhouses are getting awfully fancy. ''The thinking is, If you can afford it, nothing is too good for your children,'' says Wendy Holden, whose company, Signe's Little Houses, sells fully constructed Victorian playhouses off a Web site. Handmade by Amish carpenters in Pennsylvania, the cottages offer, as basics, touches that many grown-up homeowners mortgage their future to obtain: cedar shingles, wood shutters, tongue-and-groove construction and a custom paint job. The standard model (10 feet high) runs $4,450. Holden says that ''a third to half'' of her customers pay for extra niceties like bookshelves ($60), electrical wiring ($390) or a hand-painted interior ($150).

title: Newspaper Truck Hits Building in Brooklyn
description: A New York Post delivery truck crashed into a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday morning, knocking out one of the building's support columns and causing 76 people to be evacuated, the authorities said.

title: A Travel Agency Keeps Its Ties to Ireland
description: WHAT type of travelers were your forebears? If they emigrated from Ireland to New York in the 1920's, they were steamship passengers who might well have bought their tickets from Patrick J. Grimes, the owner of Grimes Travel in Manhattan.

title: An Islamic Reminder of the Sacred in Design
description: AGA KHAN: the name shimmers with glamour. Fabulous wealth. Palatial houses. Racehorses. Yachts. Jewels. Royal prerogative. As if that weren't enough, the Aga Khan is also the most important figure in the world of architecture today. In a ceremony at the Alhambra in Spain last Friday, Prince Karim Aga Khan honored seven buildings and urban plans, winners of the 1998 Aga Khan Awards for Architecture.

title: A Moneyed Young America, With Great Expectations
description: The robust economy may have everyone feeling a bit flush, but a survey of young Americans suggests that the money culture is building some strongly materialistic desires.

title: V.A.T. Refunds: Vexations Added
description: GETTING refunds on the value added tax, or V.A.T., in Europe is getting harder. It's not knottier mathematics. That's the same old challenge to those of us who hated eighth-grade arithmetic. But new problems are being created by the softening of borders within the European Union. It's more difficult for travelers to do the paperwork for tax refunds on major items being taken home because the tax chits are supposed to be validated at the last stop in the Union, no matter where the purchases were made.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DANCE WRITINGS AND POETRY By Edwin Denby. Edited by Robert Cornfield. Yale University, cloth, $40; paper, $18.

title: I Should Have Flown
description: Employees can come up with the darnedest excuses for returning to work a day or two late from vacations and long weekends: A car breakdown. An ill great-aunt. Believable? Maybe. But what about that mysterious allergy to the pineapple at Waikiki? What particularly imaginative tales have you heard -- or told? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Teaching the Elderly to Spot Fraud
description: A RESIDENT of New Rochelle became aware of the economic waste in the Medicare system when his mother needed a special bed from a medical equipment company. Medicare paid for the bed and continued to pay for it for three months longer than it was needed, despite repeated phone calls to have it removed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 13 with an article about NBC's coming production of ''Crime and Punishment'' misidentified the actress pictured with George Hamilton in the 1959 film ''Crime and Punishment U.S.A.'' She is Marian Seldes, not Mary Murphy.

title: Riders Are Still Critical of the French Police and Courts for Their Role in Drug Affair
description: Stephane Barthe is one of the many fine French riders who will not be competing today in the world championship bicycle road race in Valkenburg, the Netherlands. While most of the others are ineligible because they have been accused of doping, Barthe is staying away in protest.

title: October 4-10; Sold, Time in Space
description: Desperate for cash, Russia has agreed to sell the United States most of its allotted research time aboard the International Space Station for $60 million. The deal reduces Russia's role to mostly that of a builder but not a user of the outpost during its five or six years of orbital construction.

title: Long-Term Capital: A Case Of Markets Over Minds
description: BOND traders nicknamed Long-Term Capital Management ''Salomon North,'' a reference to the many partners in the Greenwich, Conn., hedge fund who were veterans of Salomon Brothers. But a more apt choice might have been ''M.I.T. South.''

title: Serving Well-Executed Italian Classics
description: ITALIAN restaurants rule Long Island. Nearly every town boasts two or three good ones. But Glen Cove is king, with at least twice that many.

title: Deborah Tillman, Louis Stone
description: Deborah Lynn Tillman and Louis Mark Stone are to be married in New York today by Rabbi Peter Rubenstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, JEROME O.D.
description: HURWITZ-Jerome O.D. With profound sorrow, Union Temple of Brooklyn mourns its long time member and Trustee, Dr. Jerome Hurwitz. For over half a century, he devoted his time, energy and love to our congregation, having served as Chairman of Ushers and Chairman of The School of Religion. He was deeply committed to the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the National Federation of Temple Brotherhoods. Our entire congregation extends its heartfelt sympathy to Hortense, his adoring wife of 54 years, and Honorary President of Union Temple. Our thoughts are also with his children, Sanford and Robert, his daughter-in-law Rhona, and his grand daughter, Jade. Funeral services Sunday, October 11th at 11 A.M. at Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, at the Grand Army Plaza. Rabbi Linda Henry Goodman, Rabbi Dr. A. Stanley Dreyfus, Rabbi Emeritus Mike Baron, President

title: Kosovo War Crimes Cannot Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officer Is Dismissed Over Float
description: Following through on a pledge, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has dismissed an officer who wore blackface and an Afro wig on a float in a Labor Day parade in Queens, saying he had disgraced the Police Department.

title: Leslie Castay, Bryan Burkey
description: Leslie Ellen Castay, an actress, and Bryan James Burkey, a painter, were married at the New Orleans Museum of Art last evening by Judge Sterling Snowdy of State District Court in Edgard, La.

title: In Closed-End Funds, a Fire Sale
description: WITH the embers still smoldering from the financial-market firebombings of the third quarter, prospective investors in closed-end funds might want to borrow a few lessons from junkyard dogs and other naturally skilled scavengers: Venture forth, sniff around and, perhaps, bite.

title: Vox Populi
description: WHO SPEAKS FOR AMERICA? Why Democracy Matters in Foreign Policy. By Eric Alterman. 244 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $25.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Slate for Gingrich
description: The House ethics committee today dismissed the three remaining ethics charges against Speaker Newt Gingrich, although it found that he repeatedly violated a rule against using outside consultants to conduct official House business when he was the Republican minority whip nearly a decade ago.

title: High School Trainers Hope to Boost Their Status
description: It's the Friday night opener of the North Bergen Bruins football season, and the team's veteran trainer, Ira Wolfe, stands on the sidelines with his young protege, Martin Mokrzecki, taking in the scene. An intense, almost giddy crowd cheers the first plays as color washes over the field: the maroon and yellow uniforms of the Bruins and the blue and white of visiting Irvington.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: What your round table reveals, in disturbing ways, is that there is no one left at the corporate level who's interested in maintaining even a semblance of news standards. It's all about ratings and entertainment.

title: The Nation: Playing the Impeachment Card; In Senate Races, a Tough New Issue
description: SENATOR ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, the New York Republican who is running for re-election, went to Grand Central Terminal the other morning to accept an award from mass transit advocates. But the reporters who had gathered there showed little interest in the shiny train car at the Senator's back. Instead, they repeatedly asked him how he would vote on an impeachment of President Clinton.

title: The Way New York Tawks; Sunshine Hotel Dwellers Are New Yorkers Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Adios South Beach, Hola Budget Miami
description: ON those occasions when my body whispers that it needs to get out of New York for a few days, but my bank account hollers ''No way!'' my answer is Miami. Miami is my cut-rate escape hatch from urban stress, the place I slip off to for a long weekend of recuperation on the cheap. I even love to go there in summer -- with discount roundtrip air fares nearly always available for around $200 (sometimes less), and an abundance of hotel rooms at off-season rates within walking distance of a sandy strand, a Miami break can work out to be less expensive than a weekend in the Hamptons.

title: A Tugboat That Needs One
description: Built at the Brooklyn Navy Yard in 1898, she stayed afloat for a century, serving a busy harbor. But time and tide finally got the better of the Pennacock on Aug. 19, when the historic tugboat -- it once ushered Titanic survivors aboard the Carpathia into New York -- sank off its moorings at Pier 25 in TriBeCa, despite rescue efforts by the Coast Guard and the city's Fire Department.

title: Ramapo Rolls Along Behind Its Two Stars
description: New Jersey

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: I turned first, but hesitantly, to Richard Ford's essay on his favorite television show, ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood.'' I thought Ford might satirize Mister Rogers. But I hoped I'd be wrong, and that he and I would agree that the show provides consistent kindness, calm and reason. And we do!

title: When Dylan's Genius Burned Brightest
description: THINGS got ugly when Bob Dylan performed on May 17, 1966 at the Free Trade Hall in Manchester, England. A good part of the audience was actively hostile to Dylan's non-protest songs and his bluesy electric band: catcalling, shouting insults, clapping in an attempt to drown out the music. During a pause while the band tuned up, one heckler shouted ''Judas!,'' as if Dylan was both apostle and traitor to his true disciples. Dylan declared, ''I don't believe you,'' told the band to play loud and turned ''Like a Rolling Stone'' into both an exultant accusation and a disillusioned anthem.

title: Panel Calls for Limit on Airport Expansion
description: FURTHER expansion of the County Airport should be severely curtailed or halted altogether because of quality-of-life and environmental issues affecting residents, airport neighbors and especially the adjacent Kensico Reservoir.

title: To the Beat of the Business Meeting
description: MIDWAY through the business meeting, an executive gathered his courage and stood up. Facing his colleagues across a blue conference table, he spoke briefly about an idea, opened his briefcase and began distributing a report that laid it all out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE KAY, ORMONDE
description: De KAY-Ormonde. Writer, historian, poet, editor. Beloved husband of Barbara, father of Thomas, brother of George and James Tertius, stepfather of Lenore and Philip Roosevelt, step-grandfather of three, friend of hundreds, maybe thousands. Wrote books, film scripts, light verse and articles over a 50 year career. Served on destroyer escorts in WW II and Korean War. Born in New York City on December 17, 1923. He died there after a brief illness on October 9, 1998. Interment will be private at St. George's Church in Hempstead, New York. A memorial service will be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Authors League Fund for writers in financial distress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EISENSTEIN, ALVIN GORDON
description: EISENSTEIN-Alvin Gordon. Remembered always by his loving family and friends. 10/12/15-10/26/87.

title: Wyoming School Wins Girls' Title
description: In a race that determined the No. 1 high school girls cross-country team in the nation, Campbell County High of Wyoming won the girls' Eastern championship yesterday in the Manhattan College invitational at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx.

title: Mom and Pop Jolt Music Publishing
description: HISTORICALLY, getting a musical composition published was more than a practical way of putting a new score into circulation. It was a tangible sign that a composer had arrived on the scene and was to be taken seriously.

title: Jessica Bennett, Eric Wilkinson
description: Jessica Anne Bennett, the daughter of Audrey Egger of Princeton, N.J., and Arthur Bennett of New York, was married last evening to Eric Richard Wilkinson, the son of Ellen Prakken of Delmar, N.Y., and Dr. Richard G. Wilkinson of Burnt Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Rachel Cowen officiated at the Grounds for Sculpture, a museum in Hamilton Township, N.J.

title: Lusting After Prozac; Drug Makers in Hot Race For a New Market Leader
description: IT began one morning 12 years ago, when Matthew, then 24, could barely crawl out of bed. He persevered at podiatry school in Chicago for six months while becoming increasingly nervous and agitated. Finally, he saw a psychiatrist. The diagnosis was chronic depression, and the doctor wrote a prescription for an antidepressant.

title: Serious About Barbecue, and Clean, Too
description: THE Cookhouse, a big red barn along Route 7 in New Milford, is doubly pleasing. Not only are the ribs slow-smoked and as tasty as can be, but the premises are meticulously clean, neat and tidy. Even the gritty school enthusiasts in our group, who feel the best barbecue can only be found in grungy, down-and-dirty joints. agreed that in this case cleanliness did not preclude tastiness.

title: George Washington Sleeps Here
description: ''You can tell a lot about a leader by his final resting spot,'' says Manus Hand of Englewood, Colo., a 34-year-old computer programmer and history buff who is closing in on his quest to visit the grave of every U.S. President. Hand has been to 34 of the 37 available sites so far. Based on his travels, he says that the surviving Commanders in Chief should start thinking now about the eternal messages they hope to send. For instance, he says that President Gerald Ford ought to consider a monument with approaches from east and west, to symbolize ''the spirit of bipartisanship'' he brought to post-Nixon America. ''Presidents have spent anywhere from a little to a whole lot of time on these efforts after leaving office,'' he says. ''It's not fun to think about, but they do have kind of an obligation to history.'' Here are some favorite places.

title: World Bank Emphasizes Role of Free Media in Fighting Graft
description: After surveying the Asian financial crisis, the World Bank has concluded that a strong and independent news media could be an important protection against economic mismanagement and government malfeasance in developing nations.

title: A Show as Light as the Air That Propels It
description: SO, what does an inflatable man do when the chips are down on Wall Street?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON ROSENBERG, ANGELIQUE ''GISELA'' (BARONESS)
description: von ROSENBERG - Angelique ''Gisela'' (Baroness) on September 28, died suddenly at home after a prolonged illness. She was the cherished wife of David Miller of Chicago. She had been a visiting lecturer in German Literature at the Graduate School, University of Illionois at Chicago and a scholar in European history and teaching English as a foreign language. For information call 773-784-5765.

title: Kosovo War Crimes Cannot Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: I used to watch ''Hardball,'' before Chris Matthews became a hysterical commentator with absolutely no control over his mouth. Now I watch the more even-handed Keith Olbermann, on MSNBC. I can take only so much moralizing in any 60-minute period.

title: Ms. Paszek, Mr. Rosenberg
description: Martha-Anne Paszek and Bruce Richard Rosenberg are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Donald J. Pollock at the Airplane House, a historic house in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Managed Care Plans Shirk Their Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: To Hike In Heels
description: Marathon runners were the target for Hydropel foot ointment when it went on the market six months ago. But another urban athlete is finding the ointment useful: the woman in high heels.

title: Q&A;/Frank Harris 3d; Talking About Race, Out Loud and Often
description: WHETHER knowingly or not, journalists deal with the subject of race all the time. They may be subconsciously avoiding it, or consciously struggling with it. So says Frank Harris 3d, an assistant professor of journalism at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven and columnist for the New Haven Register.

title: In Search of a Record and a U.S. Uniform
description: For today's Chicago Marathon, where he has a chance for a repeat victory and a world record, Khalid Khannouchi will follow a familiar ritual.

title: Pitino Wins at Track Though Idle on Court
description: Rick Pitino, the Boston Celtics' coach and president, calls himself a small-time player in horse racing. But in yesterday's Breeders' Cup Preview Day at Belmont Park, he found himself a winner in a big way.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 27 about women and domestic violence misstated the telephone number for Rape Crisis and Incest, a phone service that offers help to victims. It is 345-9111.

title: Seeking Safety In Bonds? Good Luck
description: LAST quarter, mutual fund investors learned just how wrong they can be when they do the right thing.

title: October 4-10; A Guilty Plea
description: A few weeks before Christmas a 15-year-old fired at teen-agers praying in the hallway of Heath High School in West Paducah, Ky., killing three and injuring five others.

title: A La Carte; Cars, Very New and Very Old
description: MY mother would have loved the new Black Forest Brew Haus in Farmingdale. In her youth she adored eating, drinking and singing in the beer halls of Munich, and this German enclave at 2015 New Highway (391-9500), owned by Privatbrauerei Hoepfner Brewery in Karlsruhe and its American partners, recreates the gemutlichkeit of its European counterpart. On weekends the sprawling, dome-ceilinged main dining room moves at a frenetic, madcap pace. It is an exciting, rollicking spot full of happy laughter, serving trays piled high with sausages, schnitzels, sauerbraten and beer, beer, beer made with German ingredients from 200-year-old recipes and served in mugs and slim Pilsner glasses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRNA, JOSEPHINE P.
description: SIRNA-Josephine P. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph B. Sirna. Devoted mother of Joseph, Angela Curran, Maria Archer, Anthony and Paul. Dear grandmother of nine grandchildren and sister of Dr. Domenic Palazzo. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 245 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Visiting Sunday and Monday 4 PM through 9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday 10:15AM, Our Lady of Grace Church, 430 Avenue W Brooklyn.

title: Tales and Meditations
description: THE ODD LAST THING SHE DID

title: Travel Ban Burdens Students From Gaza
description: As his classmates filed into lecture halls last month to start the fall semester at Bir Zeit University in the West Bank, Jamal Safi found himself stranded at home in a bleak refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.

title: Man Dies in Brooklyn After Fall Under Bus
description: A 72-year-old man died in Brooklyn early yesterday morning after falling under a city bus that he was trying to catch, the police said.

title: Holiday Tomorrow  Columbus Day    NEW YORK    PARADE: The Columbus Day Parade will begin tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. on Fifth Avenue at 44th Street and proceed north to 86th Street and east to Third Avenue.
description: GOVERNMENT OFFICES: Closed.

title: Letting Reality Settle In
description: Plenty of sound and fury emanated from the stock market this week. What does it signify? In one of the more tumultuous weeks on record, the Dow Jones industrial average ended at 7,899.52, up just 1.3 percent.

title: Reaching the High-End Market in Senior Housing
description: AT a storefront marketing office on Cutter Mill Road in downtown Great Neck, L.I., last month Suzette A. Gray, an investment banker whose parents are healthy octogenarians, sat through a slide show and briefing about the Mayfair at Great Neck, a senior housing development nearing completion down the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ELLA
description: FINKELSTEIN-Ella. Age 94. Beloved wife of the late David Finkelstein of blessed memory; loving mother of Sidney and the late Florence, Irving and Shirley, Doris and Norman and Allen and Shelley. Grandmother of Joy and Barry, Andrew, Nancy and Karen, Steven, Ricky and Joni, Jill, Jennifer and Amanda. Great grandmother to 12 wonderful great grandchildren. Sister of Samuel and Abe and the late Morris, David and Dorothy. Passed away peacefully at her home in Lawrence, LI. She will be sorrowly missed for the unique individual that she was. Her spirit will live on with her family and friends and the untold numbers of people she helped both in New York and Israel through her charity.

title: On the I.R.S. Calendar, It's April in October
description: The annual income-tax deadline -- the real one -- is at hand. On Thursday, a few million citizens will have to file 1997 returns, their six-month free ride at an end.

title: SOAPBOX; Bad Seed
description: EVERY fall, dozens of adolescents in New Jersey experiment with jimson weed, hoping to experience a hallucinogenic effect and avoid its toxic effects. Some teen-agers who ingest the seeds of this poisonous weed, however, become severely ill and require hospitalization, and in rare cases, some do not survive.

title: The Nation; For Halloween, It Was Inevitable
description: IT'S not easy being Monica -- even for one night. The nation's major mask makers have taken a pass on Monica S. Lewinsky this Halloween, worried about possible lawsuits over the use of her likeness. So revelers will have to improvise with wigs and berets, and many plan to do so.

title: Remains of the Day
description: EVENING

title: Parked On a Train To Florida
description: I SWORE I'd never do it again, but when my parents asked my husband and me to drive a car from New York City to Florida and another car back for them last winter, I gritted my teeth, called Amtrak, and bought tickets for the Auto Train.

title: A Pleasure Dome Worthy of Xanadu
description: FOR a while on the morning of Grand Central Terminal's rededication ceremony, an unfamiliar feeling seemed to pass through the thousands who gathered to watch the festivities.

title: Councilman Accuses Bar Owner of Racism
description: City Councilman Philip Reed has filed a discrimination complaint against the Eagle Bar, a gay watering hole on 11th Avenue and 22d Street, where he and a friend were harassed, he said, because of their race.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about living in Valhalla, N.Y., misspelled the given name of a real estate sales agent. She is Jeanne Beckley, not Jayne.

title: For Brown, Sky Is the Limit (and Preferably It's Over an N.L. Field)
description: Kevin Brown, who has been the most dominant pitcher in the post-season, will be a free agent in a couple of weeks. Baseball executives only shake their heads when they are asked what they think he will get. Pedro Martinez, at $12.5 million a year, is the highest-paid player at the moment. Start somewhere north of that figure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONOVER, ROBERT F.
description: CONOVER-Robert F. A distinguished New York artist and teacher died on October 5, 1998 of natural causes. Mr. Conover was born in Trenton, New Jersey in 1920. His career in the arts began in the 1940's, following his service in World War II and continued throughout his life. His work is represented in many collections, including the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art & the Metropolitan Museum. He taught painting, drawing and printmaking at the New School for Social Research since 1958, and received many honors throughout his career. He is survived by his daughter, Chris Conover of New York City, his sister Mrs. Nancy Anderson of Holland, PA, his brother David Conover of Oshkosh, WI., and Jaqueline Heaslip, his longtime companion. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: Awash in the baptism of born-again punditry, Chris Matthews's ''Hardball'' is a cable-televised crusade. Though James Traub's ''Inyourface the Nation'' suggests that ''if you want depth, you can read a book,'' why bother when nightly you can spin past the land mines of rhetoric to salvation via Matthews's ministry?

title: Executive-Class Jail Cells
description: Like most nations in the Arab world, Dubai has a grouchy penal code. Steal a peach and your friends may soon be calling you ''Lefty.'' In 1997, two people were actually sentenced to death by crucifixion. But a new multimillion-dollar jail promises to change some of that -- at least for elite white-collar criminals.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE ANGEL OF GALILEA

title: Impeachment Inquiry Won't Help Us Abroad; Plain-Citizen Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Duty Always Comes First?
description: THE repressed, hypocritical Pastor Manders is an emissary of the fanatic religious right. He is business manager, spiritual adviser and longtime confidant -- all dubious -- to Mrs. Alving, who has sacrificed her own thoughts for what thoughtless people will think. Duty always came first. The Fleetwood Stage production of ''Ghosts'' in New Rochelle, N.Y., makes sure you get that.

title: Recognition Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Urges More Money For Educational Programs
description: In a campaign-style effort to regain their political footing after this week's impeachment vote, President Clinton and Congressional Democrats challenged Republicans today to enact broad education initiatives in the new budget.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING
description: Same Song, 2d Verse: A Re-election Battle

title: Penn Exploits the Weaknesses of Fordham
description: Through the season's first four games, Fordham had compensated for its suspect defense and rushing game with an aggressive passing attack. Yesterday, Steve O'Hare and his receivers provided a spectacular comeback, but no victory.

title: 2 Projects, 2 Methods, 2 Reactions
description: The two development projects are large, imminent and within four blocks of each other. But they are being received very differently by local groups.

title: The Art Of Getting Response From a Pet
description: ON the whole, people like response: children who clean their rooms the first time they are asked, partners who share daily responsibilities without constant reminding, animals that come when called.

title: Family, Faith, Food and Fun
description: FOR 29 years, Nick Cristano tells the Off Broadway audience at the John Houseman Theater, traipsing to Hoboken for Sunday dinner with his grandparents, Nunzio and Emma Cristano (on his father's side) and Frank and Aida Gianelli (on his mother's). Now, he means to break the news that he is breaking away, moving to Seattle to accept a promotion as a marketing executive -- and getting a life. To Nunzio and Emma and Frank, and especially to Aida, marketing means going to Foodtown. Pathmark or Shop Rite. And Seattle? Isn't that in ''the far-away Washington''?

title: Adrienne Schwartz And Erik Becker
description: Adrienne Gail Schwartz and Erik John Randall Becker were married last evening by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman in Bryant Park in New York.

title: Managed Care Plans Shirk Their Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Seven Artists Apply Craft to Fine Art
description: THE differences between art and crafts are topics of endless debate. To clear matters up a bit, an epigrammatic remark by the painter Ad Reinhardt might be useful: he said that art was anything that was useless. Crafts, to be sure, are eminently useful -- glassware, pottery, rugs and so on.

title: DATABANK: October 5-9; On Friday, the Bear Took a Holiday
description: After mauling the markets all week, especially technology, financial and small-capitalization issues, the bear took Friday off, allowing investors to go on a bargain-hunting spree amid optimism that interest rates would be cut further.

title: Hiring Your Own Painter
description: Q. As a senior citizen living in a rent-stabilized apartment, I wish to hire my own painter rather than have the landlord use his building painter to paint my apartment. I have delayed requesting that the apartment be painted because I could not undergo what it would entail during the one or two days it would take to do it. I wish to spread the work out over a period of time. Is the landlord required to compensate me in any way if I use my own painter rather than his? . . . Gerald Heineman, Manhattan.

title: October 4-10; AIDS Deaths Drop
description: The Federal Government announced that 16,685 people died of AIDS last year, less than half the number who succumbed in 1996, and a stunning drop from the more than 43,000 in the peak year of 1995.

title: Taking the Kids
description: To the Editor: I hope the Jean Shriver letter won't discourage parents from taking children under 10 abroad. When our two daughters were young, we went regularly to Europe for family vacations. We all retain rich memories, from viewing the stained glass of the great cathedral at Amiens (which reminded our 4-year-old of a Christmas tree) to looking at the long rows of graves in the hilly World War I cemeteries in France.

title: When Bad News Is Good News
description: BASICALLY, two winning themes emerged in a quarter so dismal that gains of less than 2 percent could catapult a mutual fund into the top 10 among domestic diversified stock funds: plays on falling interest rates, and an overall search for safety.

title: Atwater Appetizers And Philco Vinaigrette
description: Radio Perfecto is a restaurant with a streamlined, decorative twist. The place, which opened yesterday at 190 Avenue B (between 11th and 12th Streets), is filled with 80 antique radios -- the luminous, colorful kind from the 1930's, 40's and early 50's. The display is only part of a 300-plus collection amassed by one of the restaurant's owners, Peter Du Pre.

title: Backtalk; Drivers Try to Put Threat of 'Big Wreck' Out of Mind
description: Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama and Daytona International Speedway in Florida do not discriminate.

title: QNA
description: Layover at Narita

title: Food
description: The hudson river has always been both a callous roar and a bittersweet meander. You almost need a ritual, like a Dutch colonial tea, to live on the edge of something so beautiful and timeless, so enthralling and, ultimately, so heartbreaking.

title: Santa's Lapland
description: To bypass department-store Santas and go to the source, there's Santapark, opening Nov. 28 on the Arctic Circle in Finland. The park, on Syvasenvaara Mountain, will be about a mile from Santa's Workshop Village, an established attraction, and three miles from Rovaniemi, capital of Finnish Lapland. Santapark, to be open year round, will contain a Disney-like ride past different seasonal displays, a reindeer ride, a carousel and a multimedia theater. Call (358-16) 333-0000; www.santapark.com on the Web.

title: Child's Close Call Aided Nun's Way To Sainthood
description: The miracle that qualified Edith Stein for sainthood began with the kind of thoroughly avoidable childhood accident that haunts the imagination of every conscientious parent.

title: Rescued by the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; F.O.B.'s: Femmes of Bill
description: Bill Clinton's Presidency crystallized with one courtesan. It shattered with another.

title: Survival of the Fittest
description: THE EVOLUTION OF JANE By Cathleen Schine. 210 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: Managed Care Plans Shirk Their Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officers Put Abrupt End To Rumba Beat
description: For years, people have gathered on Sunday afternoons at a lakeside corner of Central Park for drumming, dancing and singing to the driving beat of rumba, the rhythmic music born on the slave plantations of Cuba. Now, after a recent police action, the drums are silent.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of community board meetings last Sunday misidentified the manager of District 4 in Manhattan. The post is held by William Kelley, not Jessica Greer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALHEIM, BETH
description: THALHEIM-Beth. From Dorado Beach to Trade Shows to Seder's, you so graciously commanded that we not celebrate alone-your every demand filled our every wish. Your glow will light our hearts forever. You are deeply, deeply missed, but will never be forgotten. Dee Dee and Jeff Siegel

title: Contraceptive Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Ardsley Fights to Halt More Traffic on Road
description: THE cars come and go on Route 9A in Ardsley, a two-lane road that goes through the village's commercial area and feeds traffic to southbound Interstate 87 and both ways onto the Saw Mill River Parkway from Ashford Avenue. Mayor Samuel J. Abate Jr. said that it is already too congested there, and that when Stew Leonard's, the Home Depot, Costco and a new multiplex theater open near the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway exit in Yonkers, the local road will be a nightmare.

title: The Footloose Worker: Why Employers Aren't Dancing
description: Yet another indicator of the strength of the economy: Employee turnover and retention have become significant problems for American businesses.

title: The Funniest Italian You've Probably Never Heard Of
description: The funniest man in Italy appeared to be talking, quite solemnly, about American dentistry. ''Mandelbaum,'' Roberto Benigni said, breathing the name reverently. ''Some of the best dentists in the world are American.'' Few would argue the point, but it seemed an odd topic for an Italian comic whose knowledge of the United States is limited. His teeth, moreover, are even and unblemished.

title: As Local Papers Merge, Some Ask: Will One Size Fit All?
description: Many residents of Westchester County can remember when every city and several towns had their own hometown daily newspapers.

title: The Town Crier for the Year 2000
description: PETER DE JAGER enjoys kidding about his unlikely emergence as the Paul Revere for the year-2000 computer crisis.

title: Links to Hull
description: To the Editor: You omitted mention of a connection to the poet Philip Larkin, who lived in Hull from 1955 until his death, in 1985. Probably he is more widely read now than Hull's other noted poet, Andrew Marvell.

title: Two Worthy Operas
description: To the Editor:

title: A Season of Color Not So Vibrant
description: THE cumulative effect of three years of extreme, abnormal weather is having a very destructive and visible impact on the autumn foliage this year. Throughout Connecticut leaves are prematurely wilting, and falling, portending a less than splendid show of color.

title: M Coupe: As Thrilling as a Thriller
description: IN a ''B'' movie, BMW would stitch together the M Coupe on a dark and menacing night as lightning crackled against a castle in deepest Bavaria. Slightly mad scientists would scurry among test tubes and shelves of body parts. Grave robbers would rush in with a fearsome heart -- a 3.2-liter straight six purloined from the M works down the road. A bulbous top would be planted on the curvaceous body of a Z3 roadster.

title: Bang the Drum Slowly
description: THE MAIDEN KING

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Blue as the Lake A Personal Geography. By Robert B. Stepto. Beacon, $23.

title: Kely Nascimento, Arthur DeLuca
description: Kely Christina Nascimento, a daughter of Rosemeri C. Nascimento and Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the Brazilian soccer player known as Pele, was married yesterday to Dr. Arthur DeLuca, the son of the late Anna Marie and Arthur A. DeLuca. Nicholas L. Pitaro, a retired Justice of State Supreme Court in Queens, officiated at Day for Night, a photography studio in Manhattan.

title: Other Alums May Take the Hint
description: Never one to shirk the limelight, Michael R. Bloomberg has rounded off his gift-giving to Johns Hopkins University at an even $100 million. Mr. Bloomberg, the colorful -- some say egotistical -- founder of Bloomberg L.P., says he will add $45 million to the $55 million he contributed three years ago. That makes him the ''largest single donor by double'' to the Baltimore school, a spokesman for Johns Hopkins said, adding that Mr. Bloomberg, head of its $1.2 billion fund-raising drive, is ''putting his money where his mouth is.''

title: Looking for Art in Unexpected (but Welcome) Places
description: ART seems destined to become one of the major industries in the Jersey City of the future. An enterprising museum has long been in place, and several galleries have proven themselves to be more than one-season wonders. Now, art can be seen trickling into spaces not normally associated with art, including a church and a bar.

title: A Cathay Pacific Deal For Fall Travel to Asia
description: With Asian economies struggling, Cathay Pacific is offering a break on a single-rate pass for travel to Hong Kong and 17 other cities in Asia.

title: A Handful of Guyana
description: THE VENTRILOQUIST'S TALE

title: Fresh Tuna Adds Flavor to Favorites
description: FRESH tuna is best cooked rare or medium-rare so it remains moist and juicy inside. If leftover tuna is cooked again, the rosy interior blush will fade. But in recipes that incorporate strong seasonings as well as ingredients that contribute their moistness, cooked fresh tuna can be used successfully.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Operation Dud

title: A Vote for Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttered Clubs, Scrambled Lives
description: LIZABETH JAY stepped onto the stage in a pair of patent leather stilettos, swayed her hips a few times and coyly began removing her sheer black negligee. Two Italian tourists sat expectantly at her feet as Ms. Jay, backlit by the kinds of flashing bulbs that adorn bodega awnings and used-car dealerships, gyrated to a Led Zeppelin song.

title: Wanted: One Very Large Toaster
description: THE SETTING -- The 10,500 Pop-Tarts gave off a strong factory-made strawberry scent as they were laid side by side on tables in the marble and neon entrance to the Theater at Madison Square Garden Tuesday morning.

title: Joseph J. Sandler Dies at 71; Leading British Psychoanalyst
description: Dr. Joseph J. Sandler, a psychoanalyst known internationally for his major theoretical contributions and a leader of what a colleague called a ''quiet revolution'' in psychoanalytic thought, died Tuesday at his home in London. He was 71.

title: Send the Gondolas: 'Save Venice' Is Sinking
description: CAN anyone save Save Venice?

title: Going Down Screaming
description: I can't remember now at which point during the Starr report I stopped reading. Maybe it was the sudden prim reminder that ''the President's wife'' was out of the country during one of President Clinton's hallway trysts. Or the superfluously wounding inference that the President was considering leaving his wife after his second term. Or the inclusion of the date for one of the President's liaisons: Easter Sunday. Or any one of the points when it simply became obvious that the narrative, compelling and lucid as it was, seemed to be building a case not so much for the President's public, legal impropriety but for a private, moral iniquity. And I stopped reading not because I sympathize with President Clinton's repeated public lies, or his abuse of power and of his office. (I still think he should resign.) Nor because I am instinctively a liberal. I stopped reading at some point because it became depressingly clear that the Starr report and its aftermath represents not simply a case study in what has gone wrong with an American Presidency, but also a case study in what has gone wrong with American conservatism.

title: Clark Clifford, a Major Adviser To Four Presidents, Is Dead at 91
description: Clark M. Clifford, the silver-haired Brahmin of the nation's political establishment who advised Presidents across half a century of American history, died yesterday morning at the age of 91 at his home in Bethesda, Md.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 11, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: I was shocked to see that Jerry Seinfeld was not only smoking, but smoking in bed on the cover of your issue on television (Sept. 20). What kind of a message is that?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HENDERSON, JIMMY
description: HENDERSON-Jimmy. October 11, 1942. 20,456 days since I saw your smiling face. Always in my thoughts and heart. Love, Roberta

title: Shopping Around
description: Some make a side trip from their travels t do a bit of shopping. Others make a side trip from shopping to do a bit more shopping. For the latter, the New Jersey guidebook is thenewly published ''New Jersey's Best Shopping,'' by Liz Fuerst. Each entry includes driving directions, strategies (mainly where to park) and a selection of stores, and a restaurant or two. Then there is ''Worth a Detour,'' which covers shops in nearby towns. For example, the section on Westfield describes 11 stores from chocolates to shoes to children's books and toys and recommends 4 restaurants. Detours are Mountainside for a florist and Scotch Plains for an antique and a linen shop. ''There are communities in the Garden State as engaging as any Provencal village,'' says the introduction. But do they have as many outlet stores as Secacus? The book, $12, is available at bookstores or from its publisher (an additional $3 for shipping), Golden Sun Books, Post Office Box 715, Princeton, N.J.

title: Keyboard, Strings And Brass in Recital
description: CHAMBER music, symphonies, choral singing -- including a happy diversity of performances this afternoon -- can all be heard this week. Recital options at 3 today include artists of brass, strings and keyboard: the Columbia Brass Quintet will explore music from Renaissance to modern during its visit to the Keeler Tavern Museum in Ridgefield; the St. Lawrence String Quartet has chosen Haydn, Schumann and Beethoven to open season No. 21 for Newtown Friends of Music at the Edmond Town Hall, and Boris Berezovsky plays works by Rachmaninoff and Ravel in a Millard Auditorium concert sponsored by the Hartford Piano Society.

title: Umpiring's on the Other Foot
description: Twenty-four hours after George Steinbrenner was fined $25,000 for disparaging comments about umpires, the Cleveland Indians had reason to criticize them. More precisely, Jim McKean, umpiring at second base in tonight's Game 4.

title: Nervous? Yanks Play Relaxed
description: Whether it was real or contrived, the Yankees were a relaxed bunch before last night's game with the Indians. It was a game they desperately needed to win, but the Yankees were not biting their cuticles, sweating in anticipation or shivering with fear. They appeared resolute and prepared.

title: The Lost Heads of Balbura
description: A YEAR ago I spent three months traveling in western and southern Turkey. It was an immense pleasure to do so, but this was travel with a purpose. For some time I had been toying with the idea of writing an alternative guide to Turkey. My priorities were simple: I was looking for places that weren't overwhelmed by visitors or disfigured by development, and I wanted to evaluate the impact of mass tourism on archeological sites. If, as I strongly suspected, the impact was largely negative, I had sworn to abandon the project. There seemed no point in adding to the problem.

title: Snub at Stadium
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Novel As Indictment
description: Barbara Kingsolver has been hospitable beyond the call of duty ever since I accidentally arrived early at her house in Tucson and surprised her padding barefoot in a sundress and sipping a beer. She's been solicitous about jet lag. She has gone out into her woolly desert garden, plucked giant cucumbers and bright purple eggplants and cooked up a delicious meal. But when I ask about her childhood, she says, ''I'm not crazy about myself,'' and emits a low, edgy chuckle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELNIK, SAUL
description: CELNIK-Saul. October 8, 1998. Survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto. Beloved husband of Ann (nee Kalina), father of Olga and Steve Weitzman & Joyce & Paul Levine, grandfather of Nili Richards, Aron Weitzman, Caralyn and Marissa Levine, great-grandfather of Jessica & Matthew Richards. Services Sunday, October 11, at 1 PM at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Cradle of Democracy
description: ATHENS A Portrait of the City in Its Golden Age. By Christian Meier. Translated by Robert Kimber and Rita Kimber. Illustrated. 628 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $37.50.

title: Now What? A TV Special Issue
description: 'A Fantasy Fall Season'' was fun, and Reed E. Hundt may actually have something with his idea for a children's educational show called ''Like, Duh.''

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about a reception on Oct. 13 for the New York City chapter of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill misstated the role of Byron Janis, the pianist, who is a host of the event. He will not perform.

title: Security Experts Say Cult Is Back in Japan
description: The cult that planted nerve gas in the Tokyo subway three years ago, killing 12 people and injuring thousands more, has returned.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Girl in the Photograph

title: Joy Cappelli and Philip Spiegel
description: Joy Anne Cappelli, the daughter of Jane and Roch R. Cappelli of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Philip Charles Spiegel, the son of E. Teresa Spiegel and Charles J. Spiegel Jr., both of Scarsdale, N.Y. Msgr. George A. Cocuzzi performed the ceremony at St. Raymond Church in the Bronx.

title: Sex, Abortion and Moral Values
description: JEN, a 17-year-old, is pregnant. Terry, the 25-year-old father of the child she does not want, is a pro-lifer. Ken, Jen's father, mouths off about moral values, but he is manager of a pharmaceutical company that is under pressure to ban a controversial abortion pill. The company is sponsoring an international conference on health, with an emphasis on population control.

title: Camden Celebrates the Poet Who Celebrated Himself
description: ''The messages of great poets to each man and woman are, Come to us on equal terms, Only then can you understand us,'' wrote Walt Whitman. ''What we enjoy you may enjoy.'' To this end, a conference exploring Whitman's life and work is to be held in Camden, to which he moved in 1873 and where he spent the last 19 years of his life.

title: Pensions Battle: Modern-Day Separate but Equal
description: In 1966, Willie Bies Jr. became a police officer in this university city, assigned to the poor black neighborhood on the west side where patrol cars were often pelted with rocks. He did such a good job that the police chief made him the training officer who taught rookies the ropes.

title: The World; In the Cradle of Revolution, You Hear Mostly Snores
description: THE world watched tens of thousands of Communists and their allies march on the Kremlin last week, demanding the removal of Boris N. Yeltsin and his lackeys, and a telegenic protest it was. What it wasn't was a good gauge of Russian discontent. For that, you had to go 5,300 miles and six time zones east, to the Siberian city of Yakutsk.

title: The World: Taboos, Globally Speaking; Like Politics, All Political Correctness Is Local
description: IF there is a worldwide canard about political correctness, it is that it's an American disease. Geopolitically speaking, though, that is wildly incorrect. Every country has its own strain.

title: Undefeated Tennessee's Two Quick Strikes Stop Georgia
description: It has been a long time since Georgia was a national powerhouse in college football. The school last earned a national championship in 1980, with a freshman named Herschel Walker in the backfield. Behind a heady freshman quarterback, Quincy Carter, the Bulldogs were again getting that prominent feeling this season.

title: In America; G.O.P. Cover Story
description: Throughout Thursday's impeachment debate in the House you could hear the uncharacteristically low-keyed voice of the G.O.P.'s chief inquisitor.

title: Tina Li, Julian Kleindorfer
description: Dr. Tina Grace Li, the daughter of Dr. Su-Chen Li and Dr. Yu-Teh Li of Metairie, La., was married in New Orleans yesterday to Julian Thomas Herbert Kleindorfer, a son of Ann Downs Kleindorfer of Dorchester, Mass., and Dr. George B. Kleindorfer of State College, Pa. The Rev. Glen Cannon, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the New Orleans Women's Opera Guild Home.

title: Co-op Admissions: Doing the Numbers
description: IN the thicket of assessing the finances of prospective co-op purchasers -- with its tangle of documents, murky requirements, competing interests and board-member egos -- a would-be buyer's application can be impaled on a thorn.

title: Dawn Upshaw in Recital at Sarah Lawrence
description: DAWN UPSHAW is that most remarkable of artists: a singer equally at home in grand opera, art songs, theater music and folk tunes, who conveys, as Time Magazine put it, ''the sense that a song springs directly from mysterious promptings within her.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Braves' Bugle Boy Starts Sounding Taps
description: THE Braves weren't quite hanging by their fingernails from the edge of a cliff. It wasn't exactly like being tied on a track with a train snorting down. Or swimming toward shore just ahead of a mouthful of sharp teeth attached to a gluttonous shark.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Berkeley Heights, N.J.; Quiet Streets Near River and Mountain
description: ALTHOUGH bisected by several major arteries, including Springfield, Plainfield and Mountain Avenues, the Township of Berkeley Heights in Union County retains its rustic ambiance.

title: Correction
description: A cartoon last Sunday about an imaginary exchange between President Clinton and Senator Orrin G. Hatch carried an erroneous credit. The cartoonist was Drew Sheneman, not Dan Shefelman.

title: Revisiting a World War II Refuge; 7 Sent From Britain as Children Return to Their Haven
description: One of the English Children, Peggy Robinson Gibson, stood today in the backyard that once was as familiar to her as any place on earth and gazed at the placid vista of Tuxedo Lake and the wooded hills turning color above it.

title: Ms. McAtee And Mr. Kenny
description: Elizabeth Pearson McAtee, the daughter of Alice Cooley McAtee and John J. McAtee Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Francis Kenny 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenny 3d of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred A. Riendeau performed the ceremony at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, GERALDINE POWELL
description: BALSAM-Geraldine Powell. Died September 23, 1998, after a long illness. She was a fine artist and an inspiring art teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute. She had a gift for friendship and will be greatly missed by her many friends in Brooklyn Heights, Block Island and elsewhere.

title: Presidential Morals
description: To the Editor:

title: A Model's Life for Me
description: I DIDN'T always throw air kisses at other men, or carry around photos of myself in different outfits in my backpack, or cleanse my face with blue herbal astringent. But then, I didn't always aspire to be a male model. I graduated from Stanford University and earned a master's degree in English at Oxford University. Through the years of my higher education, I assumed that hunting for a job would entail submitting a resume and donning a suit and tie for interviews.

title: You're Asked To Cheat. What to Do?
description: THE cynical cliche has it that ''business ethics'' is an oxymoron and that getting ahead requires locking one's conscience in a desk drawer. But three-quarters of working American adults say they have never been asked or told to do something they thought was unethical on the job, according to a survey by Yankelovich Partners released last week.

title: Biltmore Inn
description: Staying in the Vanderbilts' neighborhood will be a real possibility by the summer of 2000, the target for completion of a 224-room hotel on the Biltmore Estate, the national historic landmark in Asheville, N.C., that was George Vanderbilt's summer retreat. The hotel, to be called the Inn on the Biltmore Estate, will overlook the estate winery. Information: The Biltmore Company, 1 North Pack Square, Asheville, N.C. 28801; (800) 543-2961. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Virginia Hackett And Denis Burns
description: Virginia Marie Hackett and Denis Hugh Burns were married yesterday at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York. The Rev. Daniel G. O'Hare performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: They're Not Dead Yet: Braves Rebound
description: The heart of the Atlanta Braves order finally shook free of its National League Championship Series funk. The question now is whether the awakening came three games too late.

title: Step Back on Arms Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Memo Offers A Glimpse Of Gates 2.0
description: The Federal Government and the Microsoft Corporation may be nearing a historic antitrust showdown. But William H. Gates, the man who co-founded Microsoft, has largely disengaged himself from the company's legal defense to concentrate on new ways to extend the world's largest independent software company's influence into the next century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILKESON, ELIZABETH C.
description: GILKESON-Elizabeth C. Age 95, on October 7, 1998. Founder of the Poughkeepsie Day School; Founding Director of the Bank Street School for Children and senior faculty member at Bank Street College. Beloved grandmother of Robert C. Gilkeson, M.D., Nancy O'Connor-Reedy, Elizabeth C. O'Connor, Martha G. Todd and Sarah G. Melcher. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, October 14, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Bank Street College of Education, 610 W. 112 St, NYC 10025.

title: Microsoft Is Busy on Several Legal Fronts
description: Microsoft's legal department could keep a travel agent fully occupied these days. In addition to dispatching lawyers from Redmond, Wash., to Federal court in Washington, D.C., the company is currently defending itself against lawsuits filed by software companies in San Jose, Calif., Salt Lake City and Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLOSOFF, JEANETTE
description: WOLOSOFF-Jeanette. As always, we love and miss you. Joy, Jessica and Eva

title: Everything Goes The Patriots' Way
description: CHIEFS 10

title: A Hand That Would Call For a Really Big Table
description: Bridge is one competitive activity in which four people on four continents can be engaged simultaneously. The diagramed deal on the OKBridge network was reported by Martin Seligman of Philadelphia, who sat East. His electronic partner was ''Val22'' in Buenos Aires, while North and South were Bilmur of Turkey and Fukwan of Hong Kong. (Turkey is counted as part of Europe for bridge purposes.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBLOOM, ZELDA G.
description: ROSENBLOOM - Zelda G., 1926-1998. The family & friends of Zelda will gather for a celebration of her life, Wednesday, October 14, 1998 at 4:00 P.M., at The New York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, NY, NY. Please join us.

title: Rivera's Redemption
description: The closer Mariano Rivera has pitched four and two-thirds scoreless innings in the series, including scoreless appearances here in Games 4 and 5. Rivera surrendered an unforgettable homer to Sandy Alomar in Game 4 of the division series last season, when the Yankees were four outs away from advancing to the World Series, so the last two games have probably helped him exorcise some demons.

title: A Knack for Meeting the Famous and Marrying Well
description: Things have reached a sad state when two hours with Ann-Margret isn't sexy. This is no reflection on the actress, who has been exuding sensuality since ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' when she was 22. Now, at 57, she seems the perfect choice to play Pamela Harriman, America's Ambassador to France who was better known for the powerful men she had loved and/or married. But the resulting film, which has its premiere tonight on Lifetime, is deadly.

title: Islanders' Chess Game: Pawns Only
description: The fans are furious, the players are humiliated and management is hostile: this is not exactly a textbook package for National Hockey League success. But this is reality inside the Islander crucible, where the X-rated rants, raves and chants from the paying customers in Nassau Coliseum during Saturday's season opener urged mayhem against the team's new owners and characterized the players as martyrs and the fans as dupes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, NEWTON
description: WILSON-Newton. Age 90, of Port Washington, LI, on October 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted father of Bruce. Also survived by a brother, Scott Wilson of Sacramento, CA, and many nephews. Former founder and president of Sky Chef. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc, Funeral Home, 128 Main St, Pt. Washington. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Monday, 8 PM. Interment is private.

title: Jarrett Outruns Crashes and Gordon
description: At the biggest, fastest track on the Winston Cup circuit, avoiding the big wreck can be the determining factor. And there is always a big wreck at Talladega Superspeedway.

title: Putting Aside Activism, Students In Korea Focus on Hunt for Jobs : Campus Life:Work, No Fray
description: SEOUL  On the third floor of the student center at Korea University, Lee Han Byul, deputy chief of a student union affiliated with a national student organization noted for sometimes radical activism, talks earnestly about his country's problems.

title: Accounts
description: * Computer Literacy Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the provider of online information resource for computer professionals. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODCOCK, FRANCES BENNETT
description: WOODCOCK-Frances Bennett, 82, of Hope Valley, RI. Died Tuesday, October 6, 1998, in Westerly, RI. She was the widow of Robert B. Woodcock. Born in Chicago, IL, a daughter of the late Clinton Alexander Bennett and Frances Forshew Bennett. She is survived by two daughters, Mary W. Johnson of Hope Valley, RI, and Frances W. MeVay and Adriane Bennett MeVay, and a nephew, Carl David Elliges of Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 24, at 2 PM, in St. Andrews By the Sea Episcopal Church, 182 Willow Ave, Little Compton, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sakonnet Preservation Society, Box 945, Little Compton, RI 02837.

title: After Beating of Gay Man, Town Looks at Its Attitudes
description: As a gay college student lay hospitalized in critical condition after a severe beating here, this small city, which bills itself as ''Wyoming's hometown,'' wrestled with its attitudes toward gay men.

title: Yankees Take 3-2 Lead; Braves Avoid a Sweep
description: VICTORY SALUTE -- David Wells acknowledging Bronx cheers from Cleveland fans after he was removed in the eighth inning of a 5-3 victory by New York. The Yankees will advance to the World Series if they win tomorrow or Wednesday at Yankee Stadium.

title: A Wounded Tribe
description: Injuries played a big role in what Hargrove had to work with in Game 5. With catcher Sandy Alomar out with back spasms and David Justice unable to start with a sore elbow, the bottom of the Indians' lineup was pretty thin. Hargrove had Alomar's inexperienced backup, Einar Diaz, batting eighth behind the slumping Richie Sexson, who was put in to play first base while Jim Thome took over Justice's role as designated hitter. Diaz, Sexson and second baseman Enrique Wilson, who batted ninth, are all rookies.

title: When Friends Break Up, Darwin May Know Why
description: THE EVOLUTION OF JANE

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PIKE, SEYMOUR J.
description: PIKE-Seymour J. 9/17/05-10/12/97. A true Renaissance man remembered by everyone who knew him. We will love you always. Annette, your dear family and many, many friends

title: Confidence Buckling as Markets Plunge
description: The global financial crisis and the plunging stock market are beginning to unnerve the nation's more affluent families and make them more cautious in their spending.

title: Translating a British Paper for the U.S.
description: Almost every weekday morning, Jerri Wildrick pulls her gray van up to the headquarters of Berkshire Hathaway, and delivers a salmon-pink copy of The Financial Times destined for Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire's founder and the nation's best-known and richest investor.

title: Deep-Sea Clues to an Ancient Culture Discovered
description: The Phoenicians were the master seafarers of antiquity, the first to knit the Mediterranean into a trading state. Contemporaries knew them well. Homer derided them as ''greedy rogues,'' and the Bible praised their ships of oak and cedar as works that ''did sing.''

title: New Recorded Film Format Draws Criticism From Rivals
description: Despite test marketing in two cities that did not appear to be a runaway success, the national rollout is under way for Divx, a disk-based recorded movie format intended to compete with rental videocassettes and the emerging DVD digital disk format.

title: Joseph Cates, 74, a Producer Of Innovative Specials for TV
description: Joseph Cates, a pioneering television impresario and Broadway producer with an eye for quality, an ear for a good country twang and a weakness for trapeze acts, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Policies: Testing Time
description: With President Clinton distracted and besieged and his moral authority questioned after an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, there is much room for America's allies, its Congress and even its energy companies to ignore, deflect or defy his will.

title: G.E.'s Plan to Build a Hangar For Corporate Jets Hits a Snag
description: In December, the Westchester County Legislature approved a plan by General Electric to build a 75,000-square-foot hangar at the county airport to house two company jets the size of Boeing 737's. But after a lawsuit by critics with environmental concerns, and a change in county leadership, the plan could be in jeopardy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, BERNARD A.
description: FUCHS-Bernard A. A man to admire and love. Dear companion of Dorothy Winkelman. Peggy and Marty Winkelman Janice and George Gewirtz

title: Reluctant Competitor Makes Stunning Debut in Chicago
description: The Chicago Marathon demonstrated emphatically today that the marathon is really two races, with the first 20 miles bearing little resemblance to the final 6.2 miles, when aching bodies grow exhausted and resolve can sag as the temperature rises.

title: Lock Up the Holocaust Deniers?
description: Last Tuesday, the European Parliament voted to lift the legal immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, one of its members, so that a German prosecutor can begin a criminal investigation of remarks Mr. Le Pen made belittling the Holocaust. The European Parliament has few serious duties, and last week's vote may have seemed like a way of justifying its existence. That does not mean that the vote was wise.

title: Media Talk; When an Editor Takes A Political Stance
description: Last Thursday, The New York Post pointed out with no small measure of delight that Harold Evans -- editorial director and vice chairman of The Daily News of New York, U.S. News & World Report, The Atlantic Monthly and Fast Company, a business magazine -- had added his name to a full-page advertisement in The New York Times, calling for censure, not impeachment, of the President.

title: Human Rights at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: An Uneasy Meeting in China

title: Sports of The Times; No Time for Parcells To Play Favorites Now
description: THE Jets' season took an unexpected turn for the worse here yesterday. This game against the reeling Rams was cast as a winnable challenge.

title: No Headline
2 Charged in Attempt To Poison Parents
description: Two teen-age siblings in New Jersey have been accused of trying to poison their parents, apparently in retaliation for being disciplined last week, the authorities said.

title: Politician Now, 'Grandpa' Forever; Star of 'Munsters' Makes a Colorful Bid for Governor
description: A few days before Election Day, one of the candidates for governor of New York will defy basic political strategy by going to New Jersey. There, he will don a vampire's cape, apply enough makeup for a ghoulish cast, and help the Fairfield Garden Center promote its sale of Halloween costumes and lawn ornaments.

title: Pope Canonizes Jew Who Became Nun and Died at Auschwitz
description: Describing her as ''an eminent daughter of Israel and a faithful daughter of the church,'' Pope John Paul II today canonized Edith Stein, a Jewish intellectual who became a Carmelite nun and died at Auschwitz.

title: Experts Are Cautious On Strawberry's Odds
description: Since Darryl Strawberry, the 36-year-old Yankees outfielder, had surgery to remove a cancer from his colon on Oct. 3, his doctors and the Yankees have painted an optimistic picture of his chances for a long-term cure.

title: For the Jets and Foley, It's Turnovers and Out
description: The Jets' worst turnover performance in the Bill Parcells regime sent Glenn Foley to the bench and handed the Rams a 30-10 victory today.

title: Affluent Buyers Show Signs Of Caution About Spending; Wall Street's Gloom Has New York Tense
description: Was it really only three months ago that the economic sky was blue? That life was lush? That everything was coming up roses, even in the asphalt jungle of New York?

title: The New $20 Bill Says More Than Its Weight in Gold
description: I don't really have anything against new money. I haven't been around enough old money to get snotty about its patina of tradition, its noble character and its good breeding.

title: Our Towns; 500 People Gather in Sad Farewell to a Friend Who Bowed Out on Her Own Terms
description: UNTIL the last days of her life, Elaine Benson told only a chosen few that she was dying. Even when the effects of chemotherapy forced her to wear a wig, and friends noticed, she brushed them off with a joke or a fib.

title: Decline Is Reported In Orders for Tools
description: Orders for machine tools fell in August from a month earlier as demand in all regions of the country declined, an industry survey showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, LEONARD
description: HOLLAND-Leonard. Goodbye, Grandpa. As you always carried a picture of us, we will always carry memories of you. Love, Annie, Francesca, Sally and Nicky

title: D'Amato Assails Rival Over Votes in Congress
description: Senator D'Amato attacked Charles E. Schumer for missing votes in Congress, as Mr. Schumer campaigned on his plan to make college tuition tax-deductible. In Manhattan, Mayr Giuliani questioned Governor Pataki's decision to accept the endorsement of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAEDER, ROBERT R.
description: BRAEDER-Robert R., husband of Janice, formerly of Upper Montclair, NJ, died in Jupiter, FL. A memorial will be held in New Jersey at a later date.

title: India's Hottest Political Issue: The Price of Onions
description: Five months ago, people here triumphantly celebrated in the streets when the Hindu nationalist-led Government conducted nuclear tests. In recent days, thousands of Delhiites have again poured into the streets, but this time they are cursing the very same political party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELMAN, SAM
description: FOGELMAN-Sam (Simcha). In his 86th year. Loving husband of Leah. Brother of Malka and Bella. Father of Eva and Gila. Adoring grandfather of Adam. Father-inlaw of Jerome Chanes. Simcha was a partisan during World War II, a soldier in the Israel Defense Forces, and active in Holocaust remembrance in America. In New York, he was Vice President of GUF Knitting Mill. Shiva at 60 Riverside Dr, Apt. 11G, Wednesday, October 14 through Tuesday, AM, October 20. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: Patents; Using sophisticated laser light as an alternative to potentially hazardous X-ray mammography.
description: DURING Victorian times, physicians tried to detect breast tumors by illuminating the breast with candlelight. The candlelight technique turned out to be less than successful. But now, more than a century later, researchers are turning to light once again -- this time in the form of sophisticated lasers -- as they search for more precise, less potentially hazardous alternatives to X-ray mammography.

title: Skip Away's Injury Not Serious, Hine Says
description: On the morning after he ran third in the Jockey Club Gold Cup and lost for the first time in 10 races, Skip Away was nursing a swollen right front ankle yesterday. But his trainer, Sonny Hine, said he was ''95 percent sure'' that Skip Away would run in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic and pursue his goal to become racing's richest horse.

title: Media Talk; Vanity Fair Won't Run Story on Representative
description: When Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, the Republican chairman of the Government Reform and Oversight Committee, found out that Vanity Fair magazine was planning to run a story revealing that he was the father of an illegitimate child, he decided to beat the magazine to the punch. On Aug. 31, he announced at news conferences in Indiana that Vanity Fair would soon be producing a ''scandal story'' about his sexual life.

title: Silicon Valley Journal; Preserving Birthplaces Of an Idea
description: For a piece of history, the building is not much to look at: a glass-sided ergonomics furniture showroom with a stucco facade. It sits along a fast road crowded with shopping plazas, office parks and condo developments, commanding as much attention as a 7-Eleven.

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; Bureaucratic Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Big 3 Networks Forced to Revise News-Gathering Methods
description: Such was the paranoia at CBS News last week, before some 120 employees were laid off, that several high-level CBS journalists passed along an ominous rumor: Mel Karmazin, the president and chief operating officer of CBS Inc., had told Andrew Heyward, the president of CBS News, that the network should get out of the news-gathering business because it cannot compete with the 24-hour news channels.

title: Executives Take New Positions
description: Two executives in New York are respectively taking jobs in North Carolina and Connecticut.

title: No Headline
Risks for the New Team At the Brooklyn Academy
description: In his 31 years as president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Harvey Lichtenstein infused an institution founded during the Civil War with so much of his own vision that it was almost as if he created the place. So one question lingered after last week's announcement that he would step down next summer from an organization he transformed from an artistic wreck to an international showcase: how do you replace a legend?

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks' Rotation Has Certain Symmetry
description: IF you wait long enough, even in a short series, it becomes abundantly clear why one team won 114 regular-season games and other 89. In the swing game of the American League Championship Series here yesterday, Game 5, the Yankees trotted out the author of a perfect game, while the Indians responded with the defendant in what became a crime against Mike Hargrove's choice of starting pitchers.

title: Friction Seen in Future Talks On City Labor
description: Unhappy about the two-year pay freeze in their contracts, New York City's municipal unions are warning that they will not accept such a freeze again, while several labor leaders are demanding an end to pattern bargaining, in which every union receives the same percentage raise.

title: Mayor Faults Pataki Approval Of Harlem Minister's Support
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani publicly questioned Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to accept the endorsement of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d yesterday, saying the prominent black minister ''plays the worst kind of race politics.''

title: No Headline
Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, LAWRENCE V.
description: MURPHY-Lawrence V. On October 10, 1998. Loving husband of the late Georgette and devoted father of the late Georgette. Beloved son of Anna Murphy. Dear brother of Constance Gridley, Alice Patterson, and Robert Murphy. Also survived by his nieces Maryanne Gridley, Anne Eichinger, and his nephew Philip Patterson. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 8225 Third Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Anselm Church.

title: Snyder Acquires Response Marketing
description: Snyder Communications in Bethesda, Md., acquired Response Marketing Group, an interactive marketing and analytical services company in Richmond, for stock valued at $52 million.

title: Political Memo; Democrats Find Campaign Trail in the Capital
description: Three weeks before the midterm elections, with the vote on an impeachment inquiry finally behind them, Congressional Democrats acted this weekend as if the best place to campaign were right here in the nation's capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FRANCES RESSNER BENDER
description: ROSENTHAL-Frances Ressner Bender. Age 80. Of Miami Beach. On October 10, 1998. Devoted wife of Richard. Cherished mother of Susan Bender-Scheer (Perry Scheer), Robert (Ann) Bender and Ron (Kay) Rosenthal. Beloved grandmother of Casey and Dylan. A special person who will be forever missed.

title: David Evans, Pioneer in Computer Graphics, Dies at 74
description: David C. Evans, a pioneer in the field of computer graphics and a noted computer scientist who oversaw the education of some of the computer industry's most influential figures, died on Oct. 3 after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease, his family said. He was 74 years old.

title: With Wells Taking Control, the Yankees Breathe Easier
description: Forty-eight hours changed everything for the Yankees, 48 hours and two victories. Plummeting toward elimination Friday, the Yankees rediscovered their path of greatness: Edging the Cleveland Indians by 5-3 in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series today, they took a lead of 3 games to 2 in the four-of-seven-game series.

title: Welcome Wagon to Make Its Visits Via Post Office
description: The Welcome Wagon is rolling up the welcome mat.

title: Technology Bills Languish As Congress Races for Exit
description: A long-sought compromise to let high-technology companies hire more foreign workers has been derailed in the Senate, and infighting in the final hours of the 105th Congress is threatening final passage of two other cornerstones of the information-technology industry's legislative agenda.

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: No Headline
The Ball Remains In Play To Vizquel
description: The unflinching Omar Vizquel used every inch of his talent -- right to the tips of his bare hands -- to stop the Yankees from barging into town and swiping the feel-good atmosphere that was swirling around the Indians' clubhouse as the weekend began.

title: Legionnaires' Disease Suspected in Deaths
description: In what health officials say is probably an outbreak of Legionnaires' disease, five elderly people have died and more than 30 have contracted pneumonia in and around Ellenville, N.Y. since mid-September.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Davis Produces as Designated Hitter
description: The Yankees, always on the prowl for productive free agents, had this terrific idea last winter. They would sign Chili Davis and make him their everyday designated hitter. Davis, a switch-hitter, would be 38 years old at the start of the year, but he had lost none of his ability to hit home runs (he clubbed a career-high 30 last year) and drive in runs (90 runs batted in last year, the sixth time he had knocked in 90 or more). So the Yankees gave Davis a three-year contract worth $13.6 million, a nice package for a man approaching the age of 40.

title: Derivatives Aren't Always Risky Investments
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
Sports of The Times; Now the Field Seems Nearly Level to Braves
description: LOOK at the body language,'' someone was saying in the press box as the Atlanta Braves took the field for the bottom of the eighth inning Saturday afternoon. ''Looks like their best friend died.''

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; Hollywood's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: In Small Town, U.S.A., AIDS Presents New Set of Hardships
