description: Ronda Elliott's 6-year-old daughter often comes home in tears after fending off taunts on the school bus. Her 10-year-old son got so fed up with being picked on that he got into a brawl. And the man who owned the trailer Ms. Elliott was living in abruptly told her to find a new home.

title: No Headline
Paid Notice: Deaths  HOTCHKISS, JUDY
description: HOTCHKISS-Judy. The Staff Society of the Long Island Jewish Hospital and Medical Center expresses its condolences on the untimely passing of Judy Hotchkiss, wife of Dr. Edward Hotchkiss, past President of the Society, and their children, on October 7, 1998. William Doscher, M.D. President Ira Kalfus, M.D. Vice President Michael Frogel, M.D. Treasurer Eugene Friedman, M.D. Secretary

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, LEON W.
description: HARRIS-Leon W. Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook mourns the death of our beloved Honorary Chairman of the Board, who served our Temple lovingly for more than half a century as a teacher and leader. Services Tuesday, 12:30, at Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook. Rabbi Stuart M. Geller Rabbi Emeritus Harold I. Saperstein Barbara Stern, President Cantor Rica Julie Timman

title: No Headline
Mining Industry Shortchanges Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine Pitching by Wells Is the Best Revenge
description: David Wells tugged at the left sleeve of his gray Yankee jersey, tugged at the right sleeve and adjusted his pants. Wells had just started to pitch in the most important game of his career, but he looked more like a frustrated hitchhiker than a post-season stalwart. He looked uncomfortable.

title: Questions Arise About Swiss Report on Raul Salinas's Millions
description: Almost from the moment that detectives in Switzerland found a huge hidden fortune belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of Mexico's former President, Mr. Salinas has said the money was from an investment fund that he had assembled with big Mexican entrepreneurs.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Another Look at Bacon; Newfound Canvases Shed More Light on a Master
description: For several weeks, the basement of Tony Shafrazi's SoHo gallery has been transformed into a makeshift photography studio where scores of high-wattage lights and large-format cameras mingle with paintings of mostly distorted, screaming figures.

title: Showcase Peek at Russians Of the Stanislavsky Troupe
description: There is more to ballet in Russia than its best-known companies, the Bolshoi and the Kirov. The second major troupe in Moscow, after the Bolshoi, is the Stanislavsky and Nemirovich-Danchenko Ballet, to make its United States debut on Dec. 19 at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: No Headline
Gone Are Political Wise Men and the Culture That Bred Them
description: For many weeks now, as the storm clouds of impeachment have gathered on Bill Clinton's horizon, those who value his Presidency or fear the political trauma of removing him from office have been looking for an honest broker who could cut a deal between the White House and Republicans in Congress.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are starting to see consumers who feel nervous about the stock market and are becoming more cautious in their spending behavior.''

title: Who Pitches Game 7? Only Talk Is Necessary
description: Andy Pettitte is scheduled to start on Wednesday if a Game 7 is necessary. But Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, would not say who would actually pitch Game 7, indicating that he was at least thinking about starting somebody other than Pettitte.

title: Spain Joins the March to Peace
description: The visit of the Irish republican leader Gerry Adams to Spain's Basque country last week suggests that peace can be contagious. Mr. Adams's visit came three weeks after the Basque nationalist terror group, E.T.A., for the first time announced an unconditional and indefinite cease-fire. The E.T.A.'s apparent decision to pursue its goal of independence for the Basque country through politics alone, after a 30-year conflict that has killed 800 people, seems in part inspired by Northern Ireland's peace effort. Now the Spanish Government should respond with conciliatory gestures to create lasting peace.

title: Media Talk; Defendant in CNN Suit Hires Her Own Lawyer
description: Talk about strange bedfellows.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORDER, RAYMOND
description: CORDER-Raymond. Dear Daddy, Gone 2 years-always in our hearts and minds. Love, Val, Andi and Meredith

title: Godfrey P. Schmidt, 95; Helped Hoffa Opponents
description: Godfrey P. Schmidt, a labor lawyer who was retained in the late 1950's by teamsters opposed to the union's newly elected president, James R. Hoffa, died on Sept. 27 at Marian Manor, a nursing home in Boston. He was 95 and had lived for the last eight years with a daughter in Virginia, after spending most of his life in the New York City area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROELICH, MARTHA TUCHMAN
description: FROELICH-Martha Tuchman. On October 9, 1998. Wife of the late James D. Froelich. Beloved mother of Edward (Joanne) and Robert (Denise). Devoted sister of Lucille Jaffe and the late Dr. Lester R. Tuchman. Loving grandmother of Laura, Cecilia, James, Emma and Helen Froelich. Friends may call Monday 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to the Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund.

title: Essay; Shattering Shibboleths
description: Let's cut to impeachment's chase.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEWART, EDWARD S.
description: STEWART-Edward S. Jr. (Ned). You were simply the best. You always will be. Gary

title: Voskresensk Journal; Russia's Factories, Prey of Bankers, Rust Away
description: Slender birch trees, their leaves turning gold and orange in the early autumn air, line roads leading to this humble, fraying town about 50 miles southeast of Moscow.

title: Serbian Priest in Ancient Monastery Is a Thorn in Milosevic's Side
description: The black robes and black toque cap unmistakably signify that the Rev. Sava Janjic is a monk of the ancient Serbian Orthodox Church. But his language and his study in southern Kosovo, with three computers, a scanner and the latest Internet connection, are unquestionably of the modern world.

title: For the Islanders' Opener, Picture Was Truly Dark
description: Howie Rose and Joe Micheletti sat together Saturday night in their Fox Sports New York aerie at Nassau Coliseum. Rose was to start his fourth season with the Islanders; Micheletti, his first. But they had nothing to do.

title: No Headline
Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, BARBARA K.
description: EDELMAN-Barbara K. (nee Kulka). Of New Rochelle, NY, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, died peacefully at home Sunday, October 11, 1998. Cherished wife of Elliott, loved and devoted mother of Susan and Matthew. Adoring grandmother of Sean, Adam and Julia, and dear mother-in-law of Jan. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, Tuesday, October 13, at 10 AM.

title: Brazil's Economy Doesn't Need Shock Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Brian T. Turner was named to the new post of president at Sherwood Outdoor, New York, part of Sherwood Equities. He had been general sales manager at WABC-AM Radio, New York, owned by Walt Disney Co.

title: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: 'World Briefing'
description: Starting tomorrow, The New York Times adds an important feature to its foreign news coverage -- ''World Briefing,'' a compilation of news, organized by region, that will run five days a week, Tuesday through Saturday.

title: A Woman's Perspective And a Man's Prerogative
description: Liz Phair loves to hear a crowd roar for her. ''I wish I could tape- record everything you guys are saying out there,'' she said, grinning hugely, at Roseland on Thursday night. Then she lifted her slender arms in a come-on gesture to get her fans to yell more. She adores that sound, not because it signals solidarity or whatever else women in rock are supposed to champion, but just because it turns her on.

title: Hong Kong Leader Tries To Cope With the Crisis
description: After a year of economic despair, relentless criticism and growing doubts about his leadership, Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, finally got a break last week.

title: No Headline
Holt's Ex-Chief Savors the Bite of Politics
description: To put it bluntly, Michael Naumann swims with the sharks instead of the carps since he abandoned the rarefied world of New York publishing for a a rank as German Culture Minister and a political career that can so far be counted by the months.

title: Reeves, the Insider, Loves Every Minute
description: It didn't take long for Atlanta's Dan Reeves, the former Giants coach, to show just how well he still knows his old team. In the first quarter last night, Falcons wide receiver Tony Martin took a slow seven steps or so off the line of scrimmage, then bolted in the direction of safety Tito Wooten. The reason for Martin's delay was obvious: Reeves, who drafted Wooten, knows Wooten's biggest liability is that his attention span is about as long as the life of a fruit fly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, FRANK X.
description: FARRELL-Frank X. Formerly of Freehold, NJ. On October 9, 1998. Retired from Thurston Motor Lines. Father of Nancy, Mary, Anne, Mark and the late Michael. For information, contact O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, NJ. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL, appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIRNA, JOSEPHINE P.
description: SIRNA-Josephine P. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph B. Sirna. Devoted mother of Joseph, Angela Curran, Maria Archer, Anthony and Paul. Dear grandmother of nine grandchildren and sister of Dr. Domenic Palazzo. Reposing at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 245 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Visiting Sunday and Monday 4 PM through 9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday 10:15AM, Our Lady of Grace Church, 430 Avenue W Brooklyn.

title: European Chief For Credit Suisse
description: Credit Suisse First Boston, the investment banking arm of Credit Suisse Group, said it had hired John Nelson, vice chairman of London-based Lazard Brothers & Company, to become chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Europe.

title: Derivatives Aren't Always Risky Investments; Affordable Checking
description: To the Editor:

description: Technology Bills Held Up With Time Running Out

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZULBERTI, GLORIA
description: ZULBERTI-Gloria. Loving daughter of the late Colombo and Angelina, nee Moriglio. Devoted sister of Florence and the late Walter. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei R.C. Church. Burial Calvary Cemetery.

title: Giants Turn Back Clock And Turn Over the Ball
description: Dan Reeves returned to Giants Stadium tonight, turning back the clock in more ways than one.

title: Evading the Obvious
description: In the long speculative splurge in the late 1920's and thereafter in the Great Depression, the record of official Washington was far from compelling. So it is remembered in history: the amiable indifference of Calvin Coolidge; the repeated assurances by Herbert Hoover, as the Depression deepened, that it was really over; the many statements that the ''fundamentals are sound.''

title: Joseph P. Kearney, Power Company Executive, 52
description: Joseph P. Kearney, a senior vice president for the PG & E Corporation who built it into one of the largest independent power producing companies in the nation, died Oct. 3 of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived in Tiburon, Calif.

title: Miscellany
description: * The comedian Don Rickles will appear in a new campaign focusing on retirement planning for Fidelity Investments, which is owned by the FMR Corporation, along with the company's vice chairman, Peter Lynch. The campaign, created by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, a unit of the Interpublic Group, is an extension of current advertisements that feature the comedienne and actress Lily Tomlin.

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; New York's Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Teen-Ager Rises to First
description: Kent Farrington of Chicago, riding Toronto, rose from 15th place after the first round to win the American Horse Shows Association Medal Championship at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show in Harrisburg, Pa.

title: U.S. Seeks Input on New Rules for the I.M.F.
description: The Administration has begun to consult foreign governments about changes that will be demanded of the International Monetary Fund under a deal with Congress to provide the fund with $18 billion, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Doner Is Named As Agency for May
description: May Department Stores Company in St. Louis, which is the nation's second largest retailer, has named W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., to handle the creative, strategic planning and research duties for 10 of its chains like Filene's, Foley's, Hecht's and Robinsons-May. Billings for those duties, previously handled in-house, were estimated at $65 million.

title: Huddle Diplomacy
description: Once again, no one seemed quite certain who the Jets' quarterback would be. Although Bill Parcells contended all week that Glenn Foley was his man if he was healthy, he would not give him that vote of confidence after yesterday's 5-for-15 performance that included two interceptions and a lost fumble. Foley was lifted late in the third quarter with the Jets trailing, 23-3.

title: Brazil's Economy Doesn't Need Shock Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSAM, GERALDINE POWELL
description: BALSAM-Geraldine Powell. Died September 23, 1998, after a long illness. She was a fine artist and an inspiring art teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute. She had a gift for friendship and will be greatly missed by her many friends in Brooklyn Heights, Block Island and elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLESTEROS, REMEDIOS
description: BALLESTEROS-Remedios. October 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Avelino Ballesteros. Devoted mother of Michael A. Ballesteros and Mary Ballesteros Heinemann. Cherished grandmother of Mary D. Stevens, Anita Vanderbeek and Marla Duffy. Also survived by three great-grandchildren and loving sister Maria Fernandez. Funeral Mass Tuesday, October 13, 1998, 9:30 AM, at Holy Innocents Church, East 17th St and Beverly Rd, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite charity preferred.

title: Sports of The Times; Was or Wasn't There A Spy Up on High?
description: YOU can call it espionage, or you can call it surveillance. But in pro football, a spy by any other name would smell as sour.

title: Regional Retreat on Car Pooling
description: New Jersey may soon be positioned to convert its car-pool lanes on Interstate 287 into regular lanes, thanks to the footwork of some members of its Congressional delegation. They crafted legislative language that would relieve New Jersey of the obligation to repay Washington $140 million in Federal money spent building the lanes. This maneuver is the latest expression of growing opposition in New Jersey and Long Island to special lanes for car pools -- an unfortunate attitude in a region of congested roads and poor air quality. Instead, officials ought to be emulating cities elsewhere that have found ways to get more out of underutilized car-pool lanes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALFAS, STEPHEN
description: KALFAS-Stephen. October 10, 1998. Age 71. Beloved brother, uncle and great-uncle. Visitation Antonopoulos Funeral Home, 3808 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Catherine's and George.

title: Learning Gemology on the Web
description: CARLSBAD, California  As Gregory Harrison put it, he needed a school to fit a rather unusual lifestyle. Mr. Harrison spends half of each year in Antarctica as an air traffic controller.

title: D'Amato Again Criticizes Schumer for Missing Votes
description: Signaling that he had settled on a new line of attack in his re-election effort, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato assailed Representative Charles E. Schumer again yesterday for missing votes in Congress this year, as Mr. Schumer campaigned across Long Island on his proposal to make college tuition tax deductible.

title: Daimler-Benz Rejects $1.22 Billion Bid for Its Debitel Division
description: ''We understand that there is a great deal of interest for this pearl in our company,'' said Rainer Knubben, a spokesman for Debis, referring to Debitel. ''It would be absurd to sell.''

title: A Win-Win on Housing
description: Ever since the Republicans took control of Congress, the new majority has struggled with the Clinton Administration over the issue of low-income housing. Last week the two sides came together and passed a measure that blends conservative and liberal concerns. It is a major achievement for both the Administration and Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCIPE, ANNA
description: PRINCIPE-Anna. On October 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eugene S., Sr. Devoted mother of Mary Rose Catanzaro, Frank, Renee Bilotti, Claudia Faller, Victor, Eugene S., Jr., and the late Viviana Bilotti. Also survived by grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Reposing Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway (207th St), Monday, 2-5 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Elizabeth's Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Entombment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Biologists Gain a Toehold Against a Pesky Mussel
description: Zebra mussels do not generate much good news. A decade ago, the mussels, thumbnail-size bivalve mollusks, were accidentally carried from Eastern Europe to the Great Lakes by shipping traffic and have since spread across North America, clogging the cooling systems of power plants, crowding out native species and cloaking docks and rocky areas with bristling mats of sharp, striped shells.

title: Budget Talks End Round With Amity but No Deal
description: Top-level budget negotiators for Congressional Republicans and the White House concluded yet another bargaining session late this afternoon with plans to resume talks on Monday morning and probably to extend their midnight Monday deadline for another day or two.

title: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of 3- and 6-month bills and a 52-week bill. Trading in Treasury securities and on futures on the Chicago Board of Trade is closed today because of Columbus Day.

title: Rankings Take Left Turn in Wake of Nebraska Loss
description: Bob Toledo and Cade McNown doth protest too much.

title: The Rural Life; Prairie Monday
description: I found myself one recent Monday on a stretch of rural highway in eastern Colorado at the time of morning when round bales lying in the hayfields look like cattle grazing, and vice versa. I was driving toward the sunrise, still only a premonition in the distance. The horizon in that direction was a long, low ridgeline dotted either with trees that resembled a band of clouds or clouds that had affixed themselves with stems to earth or possibly very large sheep moving single file with a grim and stately purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONE, MARGARET WALSH
description: SIMONE-Margaret Walsh. On October 10, 1998, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Loving mother of Robert James of Houston, Texas, John Cameron of Manhattan, NY, Victor Robert, Jr., of Manhattan, NY, Carolyn Mary of Manorville, NY, and Christine Marie of Garden City, NY. Cherished grandmother of nine. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Monday. Funeral Mass 10:45 AM, Tuesday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: A Delayed Honeymoon And Feminist Advance
description: In music, as in politics, while some lame ducks are merely hanging on, others are thriving. Claudio Abbado, who is 65 and has announced that he will give up the podium of the Berlin Philharmonic in 2002, seems to be luxuriating in a particularly mellow relationship with the orchestra, perhaps partly in compensation for the honeymoon the initially recalcitrant band denied him when he arrived in 1989.

title: Man Threatens Child In Attempt to Rob Family
description: For the second time in less than a month, a man grabbed a small child in Central Park on Saturday evening, held a sharp object against his throat and threatened to hurt the boy unless family members handed over their money.

title: National Association of Advertisers startles agencies by offering to admit them as members.
description: THE annual conferences and meetings of the advertising industry trade associations are almost always like Kabuki or No theater -- highly stylized, ritualized events carefully choreographed on the theory that, to quote the old ad slogan, the best surprise is no surprise.

title: Exploiting A Weakness
description: Three players in the Giants defensive backfield did not dress for last night's game with the Atlanta Falcons: safeties Sam Garnes and Shaun Williams and cornerback Phillippi Sparks.

title: A Politician Stands Accused as Villain in South Korea's Economic Disaster
description: Kang Kyong Shik used to have this nation at his fingertips, and as Deputy Prime Minister and a renowned economic planner he enjoyed influence and glory that seemed able to take him anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTASERSE, HON. PETER P.
description: ARTASERSE-Hon. Peter P. Age 98. One of New Jersey's oldest living former legislators and retired Superior Court Judge Peter P. Artaserse died this morning after a brief illness. Raised in and a longtime resident of Jersey City, he devoted his life to the law and public service. He represented Jersey City in the Assembly for seventeen years, rising to Minority Leader. He served another seventeen years on the Superior Court, with eight years as Assignment Judge in Hudson County. His wife of fifty-three years, Muriel Dodd, died in January, 1997. He was a member of the New Jersey Bar Association for over fifty years, past President of the Hudson County Bar Association, past President of the Dante Alighieri Society, and a director of Statewide Savings Bank. He was included in the State of New Jersey Oral History Program in Trenton. He was a member of Upper Montclair Country Club, and, while in his eighties, de facto Club Champion. He was a lifelong Yankee fan. He is survived by his son, Peter. Funeral services Thursday, 9:30 AM, Bizub Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton, NJ, and 10 AM, at St. Philip the Apostle R.C. Church, Valley Road, Clifton, NJ. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the funeral home. The Dante Alighieri Society service will be Wednesday, at 8 PM.

title: Beijing-Taiwan Talks: Intimate Rivals to Meet
description: From the bluffs along the edge of this booming Chinese city, you can easily peer into Taiwan's western frontier, a small island only half a mile away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZKA, THELMA
description: HERZKA-Thelma. On October 10, at age 90. Devoted wife of the late Lloyd I. Herzka. Cherished mother of Rita McIntyre, Marilyn Stanley, and Dorothy Lichtenstein. Also survived by six grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, two sisters, three brothers and numerous nieces and nephews. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 11 AM, Tuesday, October 13.

title: Best Little Election-Year Brawl In Texas Is for Control of Schools
description: Now, Texas is a state that likes a good political brawl almost as much as a slice of mesquite-smoked brisket smothered in sauce. Yet here it is, a month before the election, Gov. George W. Bush is about 50 points ahead in the polls and seems set for a big wet kiss from voters on his way to a possible Presidential run in 2000. So where's the rumpus?

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, RITA
description: ALPERT-Rita (Ossip). October 11, in Miami. Loving mother of Lewis (Phyllis), Mindy (Menachem) Givon and son-in-law, Ross Hoffman; husband, the late Aaron and daughter, the late Jo Ann Hoffman. Grandmother of seven.

title: 20 Years in the Making, Rail Freight Link Opens in Bronx
description: Sometime this morning, the daily freight train from Albany to New York City will take a new route, ending its journey on a never used track that skirts the southernmost tip of the Bronx along the Harlem River.

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; The Poor Will Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Raises Its Pressure On the Serbs
description: As United States bombers landed in Britain for a buildup of NATO forces ready to strike against Slobodan Milosevic, Richard C. Holbrooke, the American envoy, pressed the Yugoslav leader for a sixth day to back down in his confrontation with the West over Kosovo.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: F.B.I. SET TO OPEN ITS DNA DATABASE FOR FIGHTING CRIME
description: In a computer at a secret location, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will open a national DNA database tomorrow that advocates say could significantly reduce the incidence of rape and other crimes by helping to catch repeat offenders earlier.

title: Talk of Impeachment Is Not on the Menu At the Gore Family Barbecue in Tennessee
description: This is the kind of place where they just call him Al.

title: Changing of the Guard, and Coverage, at Forbes
description: James W. Michaels has never been known for his mild-mannered demeanor. Office folklore has it that the 77-year-old editor of Forbes magazine even fired one of his employees -- whose wife was pregnant -- on Christmas Day, back in the 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, THOMAS A.
description: BRADLEY-Thomas A., Jr. Of Upper Brookville, Long Island, NY. Son of the late Irene Talley Bradley & the late Thomas A. Bradley, died peacefully on October 8, 1998, after a short illness. Devoted husband of Elise Cavanagh Bradley, beloved father of Elise B. Mackay, Belle C. Bradley, Renee B. Bradley, cherished grandfather of Christopher Bradley Merz & Wendy Allen Merz. Loving brother of Kate Dooley, Rosemary Corroon, Jeanne Kelly and the late Irene Parker. Funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, October 13, 1998 at 11:00 AM at St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Route 107, Brookville, NY. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove, N.Y. 11542.

title: No Headline
The Making Of an 'It' Girl; WB Network Hyped 'Felicity' But Still Seeks the Right Viewers
description: The star's angelic face was everywhere. The reviews were mostly glowing. The show was being called the next ''Dawson's Creek'' or the next ''Ally McBeal.''

title: Cigarette Tax Only Sounds Like a Good Idea; Public Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; 3 Producers See Potential In a Hollywood Tale
description: ''Indecent Exposure,'' David McClintick's 1982 best-selling saga of greed and glory in Hollywood, may finally make it onto the screen. The tale, which started with a check forged by David Begelman, then president of Columbia Pictures, and ended with Mr. Begelman's ouster, was perhaps the first book in which the daily history of a business crisis was re-created by an author. Noted books of this genre that followed included ''Barbarians at the Gate,'' which recounted the takeover battle for R. J. Reynolds.

title: Destiny's Child Doesn't Quite Get the Message
description: ''You simpleton! You missed the point.''

title: Space: NASAs Frontier
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Research Honor Goes to the Brooklyn Side
description: The State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn has always been a bit of an underdog among the city's medically elite institutions. In spite of its groundbreaking work in the study of AIDS, alcoholism and other illnesses, kudos most often went to hospitals and research centers on the other side of the Brooklyn Bridge, like Mount Sinai and New York University.

title: Missing Man, 67, Found Beaten To Death in a Bronx Social Club
description: The body of a 67-year-old Bronx man who had been bludgeoned to death was found yesterday morning by his son inside a social club the victim frequented in the Wakefield section, the police said.

title: Met Players Arise From the Anonymity of the Pit
description: If chamber music by orchestra members begins as therapy against the anonymity and potential frustrations of corporate life, James Levine has made the idea into something more. We are, indeed, permitted to see, hear and appreciate specifically all the invisible virtues that rise nightly from the pit of the Metropolitan Opera. But Mr. Levine creates from these concerts finely played adventures for audiences and opportunities for him to explore the 20th century, something his work at the Met allows him only sporadically to do.

title: Skip Away Ready To Resume Training
description: Sonny Hine said yesterday that he expected to resume training with Skip Away as early as tomorrow, and was still counting on a trip to Louisville, Ky., two weeks later to run in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic and one final shot at Cigar's career earnings record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, LAWRENCE A., M.D.
description: LERNER-Lawrence A., M.D. How I love you let me count the ways. A wonderful husband for 53 years to Elaine; Loving Father of Michael, Jimmy, Lisa and Fran. Grandchildren-David, Bryan, Alana, Lauren and Rachel. For information Robert Greaver Funeral Home, Hallandale, FL.

title: Good Riddance, 105th
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, CHARLES PERRY
description: KAPLAN-Charles Perry. 82. On October 9th, 1998. Loving husband to Esther, father to Marilyn, Donald (deceased) and Linda, fatherin-law to Peter and John, grandfather to Daniel and Rachel. Proudly served in WWII. He was our hero to the end. Shiva Tuesday evening, October 13th.

title: Train Kills 6 Mexicans As They Slept on Tracks
description: Six people believed to be illegal immigrants from Mexico were fatally hit early today by a freight train as they slept on a desolate stretch of tracks in southern Texas. Officials said they believed the immigrants might have been victims of a superstition that the rails would keep them safe from snakes.

title: INSIDE
description: Fiscal Change in the Air

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERIDAN, NANCY
description: SHERIDAN-Nancy. Actress. 95. Died of natural causes Oct. 3, 1998, at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington. Ms. Sheridan's career spanned four decades including vaudville and the Palace. She started on Broadway as an ingenue in ''Sure Fire'' and later appeared in ''Celebrity,'' ''10 Per Cent,'' ''Come Easy,'' ''The Eldest,'' ''Penny Wise,'' ''Schoolhouse on the Lot,'' ''Farm of Three Echoes'' with Ethel Barrymore, AJ Cronin's Last Broadway play, ''Jupitar Laughs'' with Jessica Tandy and Alexander Knox, & J.B. Priestley's four character play, ''Dragon's Mouth.'' She toured in ''Cynara'' opposite Philip Merivale, and ''The Shining Hour'' with Conrad Nagel and performed in summer tours with Eva LeGallienne, Groucho Marx, Leon Ames and Grace George. She was also featured in numerous television and radio dramatic productions and commercials. Ms. Sheridan had been a member of The Screen Actors Guild, Actors Equity Association and American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. Ms. Sheridan was born Sarah Rose Penn in Wheeling, W.VA. in February 1903, and adopted the name Nancy Sheridan for the theatre, and continued to use it until her death. She grew up in the Pacific Northwest and attended The University of Washington and a dramatic school in Chicago, Ilinois. Ms. Sheridan left no survivors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN KOERT, JOHN O.
description: VAN KOERT-John O. Age 86,formerly of New York City, died of a massive stroke. on Oct 11, 1998 at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He leaves no immediate survivors.

title: Abroad at Home; 'A Tawdry Honey Trap'
description: In President Reagan's second term, top officials used the power of the White House covertly to sell arms to Iran with the aim of freeing hostages, and to pass the proceeds to the Nicaraguan contras in violation of a Congressional statute. The conspirators, conscious of their lawlessness, tried to conceal their scheme with cold-blooded lies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MARGOT
description: GREENE-Margot. On October 3 at 106. Beloved wife of the late Irving J., loving mother of Joan Lazarus, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral was held. She will always be loved.

title: Nagy Carries Indians' Hopes
description: It is largely up to Cleveland pitcher Charles Nagy to prevent the Indians from being eliminated from the American League Championship Series as the starter for tonight's Game 6.

title: Gay Man Dies From Attack, Fanning Outrage and Debate
description: Matthew Shepard, the gay college student who was kidnapped, robbed and pistol-whipped, died here today, five days after he was rescued from a Wyoming ranch where he had been left tied to a fence for 18 hours in near-freezing temperatures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMEISTER, THEODORE H.C.
description: HOFFMEISTER-Theodore H.C., 90, formerly of New York City, died October 12, in Lebanon, NH. The husband of Anne (Schaetzel) Hoffmeister. The brother of Margaret Hess. Also survived by nieces and nephews. There are no services. Memorial donations may be made to the Pemi-Baker Home Health, Highland St. Plymouth, NH 03264.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a newly declassified report that says the Central Intelligence Agency repeatedly ignored allegations of drug trafficking by the anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua in the 1980's, or failed to investigate, referred incorrectly in some editions to the Acting Director of Central Intelligence in April 1987. He was Robert M. Gates, not William.

title: When Singer and Space Are a Perfect Match
description: Bryn Terfel's swift rise in the singing world, and the adoring following that has come with it, is not difficult to explain. Mr. Terfel's bass-baritone is effortlessly big and commands the large opera and concert spaces from which fame and fortune most easily come. He has an outgoing presence onstage, and he pays attention both to music and to text. The voice lover has the thrill of unusual resonance and refinement; the music lover finds little to argue about.

title: Chicago Wants to Crash Party
description: The league's dream matchup in the championship game on Oct. 25 in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., -- the two-time defending champion D.C. United against the Los Angeles Galaxy -- is in jeopardy after Chicago's 1-0 victory over Los Angeles on Saturday in the opening game of the Western Conference finals.

title: Bold Assault on El Nino's Mysteries
description: ''Nova'' ventures tonight on the track of El Nino, the mysterious phenomenon that every few years rages out of the Pacific Ocean to wreak havoc around the world. Its impact in 1997 and 1998 is fresh in memory.

title: Lawsuits by Rivals Accuse Textile Maker of Corporate Espionage
description: John Hickey became suspicious as he reviewed the 16 detailed questions faxed by a graduate student.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: SANDLER-Joseph, M.D. It is with great sorrow and respect that we extend our condolences to the family and colleagues of Dr. Sandler, psychoanalytic scholar and former president of the International Psychoanalytic Association. He was a great friend, not only to psychoanalysis, but also to us as we made our way into membership in the IPA. Barbara Stimmel, Ph.D., Pres. New York Freudian Society

title: West Nkosi, 58, a Producer Of South African Musicians
description: West Nkosi, a saxophonist, songwriter and producer who helped bring South African music to the outside world, died on Thursday in Johannesburg from injuries he had received in a car crash, said an executive of Gallo Records, where Mr. Nkosi had made hits since the 1960's. He was 58.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICCOBONO, PAUL X.
description: RICCOBONO-Paul X. Age 59. Of Bedminster. On Sunday, October 11th, 1998. Husband of Frances (nee Saccomanno) Riccobono. Stepfather of Celine Doran of Riverdale and Edmond Doran of Hawthorne. Funeral service will be held at 4PM today at the Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 176 Main Street, Peapack, New Jersey. Visiting hours will be at the funeral home today 1-4 PM. Memorial gifts may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Clinton Seeks Votes for Schumer, Who Is Away, Casting Some
description: President Clinton flew into New York last night to raise $1 million in one of the most fiercely contested Senate races in the nation -- Charles E. Schumer's challenge to Alfonse M. D'Amato -- and to draw emotional sustenance from a place where Mr. Clinton has been admired, even during his worst of times.

title: No Gain in Backward Exercise, Experts Say
description: On a recent Monday night at the New York Sports Club on Wall Street, a woman was turned around on the stair climber and stepping backward. Nearby, several exercisers were striding on elliptical motion trainers, switching the direction of their leg movements from forward to reverse and back again every couple of minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, ALLAN ALEXANDER ARTHUR
description: FLYNN-Allan Alexander Arthur, of Plandome, Long Island, a retired partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell, passed away Saturday, October 10. He was 67 and died as a result of a stroke suffered the prior Tuesday. Mr. Flynn grew up in Port Washington and graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1949 and Yale University in 1953. Commissioned as an Ensign in the Navy that year, he was released as a Lieutenant (j.g.) in 1956. Mr. Flynn joined Davis Polk in the fall of 1959 after graduating from Columbia University Law School. He had a distiguished career at the firm as a real estate finance attorney, serving on the boards of Ticor Title Guarantee Company and Ashlee Publishing Company, Inc. A member of The Racquet and Tennis Club and The Creek Club, he was also a director of The Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities (SPLIA). He had actively pursued his interest in preservation with his wife of 29 years Judy Flynn at Willets Farmhouse, their 1810 residence on Manhasset Bay which they had lovingly restored. Mr. Flynn kept his treasured Bertram 31' Sportfisherman ''Adios'' moored in front of their house. In addition to his devoted wife Judy, he leaves behind a son, Michael L. of Charlotte, NC, stepchildren Lee R. Carlson of Tulsa, OK and Ellen L. Snodgrass of Port Washington, and three grandchildren, Arthur G. Carlson, Lee L. Snodgrass, and D'Arcy L. Snodgrass. He will be missed by many others. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 14, at 12 noon at the Congregational Church in Manhasset. Donations may be made in his memory to SPLIA, P.O. Box 148, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

title: Country Journal; For a Couple, An Idyllic Life Turns to Ruins
description: Is there a New Yorker who does not yearn occasionally to escape the city and its grinding annoyances? Jeff Mehler and his wife, Mary Russell, know well the impulse to flee and, unlike most of us, acted on it. After more than two decades in New York City, they left in 1995 in search of a simpler life in the bucolic hills of eastern Connecticut. Theirs is a cautionary tale for those seeking the alleged placidity of the country. Emphasis on the alleged.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, a State of Unease on the Runway
description: With the current political and financial turmoil in the world and with the millennium fast approaching, society is being affected in countless ways. And fashion, being a reflection of the times, is in its own state of unease, searching for a new way of dressing post-minimalism.

title: New Earnings Criteria
description: The listing of corporate earnings in Business Day covers companies that have at least $100 million in quarterly revenues. Banking and insurance companies, which do not usually report revenues, will be covered in the listing if their total assets exceed $2 billion.

title: Richard Denning, 84, an Actor On TV's 'Hawaii Five-0' Series
description: Richard Denning, a character actor who was perhaps best known for his roles in the television series ''Mr. and Mrs. North'' and ''Hawaii Five-O,'' died on Sunday at the Palomar Medical Center in Escondido, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

title: A Nightclub Bottles Cuba, Before the Revolution
description: On the dance floor, Jose Cancela, a radio executive who left Cuba as a child, is shaking a pair of maracas, trying to keep up with the rhythm of a song that praises the hot tamales of a cook named Olga. Lily Renteria, a Cuban actress who arrived in Miami just over a year ago, is dancing next to him with a man who crossed the Florida Strait in a raft four years ago.

title: New Chief for Times Magazine Group
description: Leonard P. Forman has been named president and chief executive officer of The New York Times Company's magazine group, the company announced yesterday.

title: From Fathers to Children, a Twice-Told Tale
description: THE best place to start is with the fish that were staring up from the clear mountain lake and had the faces of people from the traveler's childhood. It was 1954, and the traveler, a very tired Czech filmmaker lost for 14 months in Tibet, had put his feet in the water to cool off. Suddenly, there was Mr. Novak, a neighbor from the street of his childhood, swimming in on the right. There was Mr. Bitnar floating on the left. When Mr. Novak and Mr. Bitnar started to nibble at the filmmaker's toes, he quickly pulled his feet from the water -- and then later, back home in Prague, told the story to his wide-eyed 5-year-old son.

title: Stocks in Broad, Sharp Rallies as Bank Bill Passes in Japan
description: Stock prices rose yesterday after Japan's parliament approved legislation to revive its moribund banking system, setting off rallies in Asian and European markets.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Special Envoy To the World's Fair

title: Silva, Winner in '94 And '95, Will Run
description: The two-time winner German Silva of Mexico will run in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 1, race organizers said yesterday. Silva, 30, finished fifth in the race last year, registering a personal-best time of 2 hours 10 minutes 19 seconds. He was sixth in the Boston Marathon in April. Silva won his first New York City Marathon in 1994, even though he mistakenly ran off the course into Central Park. He was directed back onto the course and beat his countryman Benjamin Paredes by two seconds, the closest finish in race history. Silva came back and won the race in 1995, holding off Paul Evans of Britain to win by five seconds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, DOROTHY
description: HONIG-Dorothy. Of Middletown, New Jersey. Formerly of Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Jack, loving mother Henry and Jill, Alan & Celia, devoted sister of Evelyn Milhender, loving grandmother of Adam, Douglas, Noel and Amy. Services Wednesday, 11:30 A.M. at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels of Ocean, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar closed higher against the yen for the first time in nearly two weeks on hopes that Japan was closer to reviving its ailing banking system. The dollar rose to 118.10 yen, from 116.95 Friday.

title: White House Seeks to Block Care Ruling
description: The Clinton Administration is asking a full appeals court to overturn an August ruling that gave new rights and consumer protections to six million Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations.

title: JAPAN PARLIAMENT PASSES RELIEF BILL FOR AILING BANKS
description: Japan's Parliament approved landmark banking legislation today that will allow the Government to nationalize failing banks, and political parties announced that they had reached a new accord to provide several hundred billion dollars in new money to try to revive the banking system and set the country on a path toward economic health.

title: Calcium Takes Its Place as a Superstar of Nutrients
description: Calcium is fast emerging as the nutrient of the decade, a substance with such diverse roles in the body that virtually no major organ system escapes its influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLSTROM, HELENE
description: HILLSTROM-Helene, on Oct. 11, 1998. Devoted daughter of Lottie Siegel. Beloved mother of Howard Hillstrom, Martha Mack and Linda Reid. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Seth, Danny, Michael, Lisa and Joey. Dear sister of Cynthia Mandel. Cherished aunt of Susan and Andrew Mandel. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam. Visiting Tuesday, 7:30-9 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the West Side Jewish Center, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACK, JUDY
description: MACK-Judy. Of Verona, NJ on October 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Martin Mack. Devoted mother of Joan Gelman and Carole Meyers and loving mother-inlaw of Donald E. Aronson, all of New York City. Adored grandmother of Josh, Gregg, Adam and Kelly. Private funeral services were held Sunday, October 11, 1998. Contributions may be made to Center for Hospice Care, 3 High St., Glen Ridge, NJ 07028.

title: Spottswood W. Robinson 3d, Civil Rights Lawyer, Dies at 82
description: Spottswood W. Robinson 3d, a Virginia civil rights lawyer who argued one of the five cases that led to the Supreme Court's 1954 desegregation ruling in Brown v. Board of Education, died on Sunday at his home in Richmond. He was 82.

title: Russia Sees NATO Raids as Imperiling Cooperation With West
description: Russia mounted a last-ditch campaign today to avert NATO air strikes against Yugoslavia, warning that such strikes could bring an end to cooperation with the Western alliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAER, BURTON LOUIS
description: PAER-Burton Louis. On October 11, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Mary Stevens Paer. Devoted father of Susan. Dear brother of Frances Levy and Herbert Paer. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, IRVING
description: WEISS-Irving. On October 11, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Loving father of Barbara and Perry Tirschwell and Marsha Tobias. Devoted grandfather of Mark, Cathy, David, Carolyn, Jonathan, Anne, Eric, Emily and David. Adoring great grandfather to Jessica, Max, Ellie and Ilana. We willlove you and miss you eternally. Services Wednesday 9:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: I.B.M. and Realnetworks in Joint Venture
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Realnetworks Inc. announced a venture to integrate audio and video into E-mail and other Internet software as I.B.M. tries to gain an edge on the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Sports of The Times; A Cry in Panic? Pass the Button
description: THERE had been a strange sense in the air. The San Diego Padres, the team that had gone up by three games to none and then by three games to one in the National League Championship Series, might have some cause for alarm.

title: Tucker Makes The Padres Pay Dearly
description: Game 5 of the National League Championship Series tonight had more twists and turns than the Coney Island Cyclone.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Passes Law to Permit Nationalizing Failing Banks

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jets on Roller-Coaster Ride at Quarterback
description: Something has happened to Glenn Foley since he sustained a rib injury in Game 2, and from the way Jets Coach Bill Parcells spoke today, he was prepared to name Vinny Testaverde the starting quarterback.

title: NATO OPENS WAY TO START BOMBING IN SERB PROVINCE
description: The United States and its allies early today approved an order opening the way for NATO to begin a bombing campaign in the Serbian province of Kosovo in four days' time. But White House officials said an agreement to end the crisis with the Serbs appeared imminent.

title: A Rough Trip for Yeltsin Adds to Worries About Health
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly cut short a three-day visit to Central Asia today after the his doctor announced that Mr. Yeltsin was suffering from bronchitis and a slight fever.

title: A Computer Diagnosis Of Prejudice
description: Ask people if they have negative attitudes toward blacks, women or the elderly, and you are likely to hear a chorus of denials. But give those same individuals a simple test to tap unconscious beliefs, two psychologists say, and the results often tell a different story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, MINDY
description: CELLA-Mindy. In memory of our friend and colleague, Mindy Cella. Mindy will be remembered by all as a very special and courageous lady. She had the unique ability to make those around her laugh and to laugh at herself. She will be deeply missed. From her colleagues at Aaronson Rappaport Feinstein & Deutsch

title: Bech's Back, Brooding Grimly On Updike
description: BECH AT BAY

title: Evidence to Deny 6 Iraqis Asylum May Be Weak, Files Show
description: Newly declassified Government documents show that the United States has relied on weak and unsubstantiated evidence that has never been fully investigated to detain six Iraqi dissidents who worked with the Central Intelligence Agency against President Saddam Hussein.

title: U.S. Catholic Seminarians Turning to Orthodoxy
description: Young American men entering the priesthood today are far more conservative and tradition-bound than many of their elders and most American Roman Catholics, according to bishops, priests and church surveys.

title: Edith Stein's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Ariel Sharon, Peacemaker?; Arafat the Reckless
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Attacks Republicans on Impeachment Steps
description: Emboldened by recent polls that suggest a backlash against Republicans for initiating impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore today made his strongest comments to date on the subject in speeches criticizing Congress for not passing significant legislation.

title: People
description: * Erin Clark was named to the new position of senior vice president and client services director at Grant/ Jacoby Inc., Chicago. She was previously managing director at Leap Partnership, Chicago, part of Leap Group.

title: Still Living With AIDS, and Endless Jokes About Bananas
description: When one first meets Jeff Getty, 41, at his Japanese-style loft in Oakland, Calif., it is hard to think of him as a man who has lived with H.I.V. and AIDS for 18 years. Mr. Getty gives off an air of vitality. His eyes gleam; he is muscular, articulate and energetic. The only sign of AIDS is an infusion tube filled with antibiotics sticking out of his right arm -- an emergency measure he needs to fend off a nasty lung infection. But Mr. Getty has learned to live with AIDS, even defeating death.

title: Federal Aid Improved Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GERTRUDE KLEIN
description: KAPLAN-Gertrude Klein. Of NYC on October 11, 1998. Beloved wife of Jules; also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and nephews. Funeral service Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. in Bernheim-Apter-Goldstick Suburban Funeral Chapels, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ.

title: Metro Business; Mall Builder Says 60% of Space Taken
description: Glimcher Realty Trust has signed leases or obtained letters of intent to lease 60 percent of a 1.3 million-square-foot mall it is building on a former landfill in Elizabeth, N.J., the developer said yesterday.

title: Taiwan and China, Talking Again
description: This week's meetings between mainland China and Taiwan mark a welcome return to negotiations in a sometimes dangerously tense relationship. Only two and a half years ago, China test-fired missiles across the Taiwan Strait to protest Taipei's assertions of greater diplomatic independence. That astonishingly reckless move led the United States to respond with a show of naval might. Talks, not force, are the way to resolve deep differences between China and Taiwan over the issue of eventual reunification.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Still Another Hedge Fund Seems to Be in Financial Peril
description: Turbulence in the bond markets continues to wreak havoc among some of the most sophisticated investors. Ellington Capital Management, an Old Greenwich, Conn., investment firm created by a star mortgage bond trader, has unloaded hundreds of millions of dollars of mortgage-related securities in the last two days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORKEN, FRAN
description: SORKEN-Fran. Age 57. Died at her home in Yorktown Heights, NY, on Saturday, October 10. She was the loving wife of Edward, beloved mother of Elizabeth and Jonathan, dear sister of Natalie Hannon, Margaret Rodkin, and Ronald Rodkin. Funeral Services were held on Sunday, October 11, at the Yorktown Jewish Center, Yorktown Heights, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Phelps Hospice at Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY, The Yorktown Volunteer Ambulance Corp, and The American Cancer Society.

title: In Many Guises, a Plea for Peace
description: Fragile and magical as it often is, fine theater can be a problematical traveler. So it is a pleasure to report that ''A Night in November,'' the multi-character one-man play that proved so rewarding in a brief run last winter at the Irish Arts Center, has survived its departure, return and transfer to the stage of the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on Theater Row.

title: Justice Storms In And Takes The Floor
description: An agitated David Justice popped into the interview room at Yankee Stadium yesterday as an unexpected arrival on the Cleveland Indians' day off. Almost instantly, he created a scene that had all the feel and flavor of open-mike night at group therapy.

title: Japan's Hollow Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Officers Quit Marisa Christina
description: Marisa Christina Inc., said yesterday that its chairwoman, Adrienne Vittadini, and vice chairman, Gianluigi Vittadini, her husband, had resigned.

title: Chaos in Congress
description: President Clinton, who has been searching for firm ground in the swampy budget negotiations with Congress, may finally have found a solid issue -- schoolchildren. Twice over the weekend, Mr. Clinton challenged the Republican majority to enact the main element of his 1998 education initiative, $1.1 billion to hire 100,000 new teachers to reduce classroom sizes in inner cities and rural areas.

title: Pul-i-Charki Journal; Afghan Beard Code: Like Castro Si, Pavarotti No
description: The commandant himself summoned them, so the inmates walked briskly across the dusty prison yard, these 75 men jailed here because they had illegally trimmed their beards.

title: The Leonids: a Viewer's Guide
description: Unfortunately for residents of the United States, the Leonid storm on Nov. 17 is expected to begin at 2:43 P.M. Eastern standard time and is likely to last for only an hour or so. For the United States, therefore, the entire show will be during daylight hours and will be invisible, unless unusually bright bolides, or exploding fireballs, flash through the sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONELLA, ANNETTE
description: GONELLA-Annette. On October 12, 1998. Age 55. Beloved wife of Ronald. Devoted mother of Erica. Memorial service will be held at St. Agnes High School, College Point on October 31 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Campaign for Tobacco-free Kids.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARVIN, ANTHONY (TONY)
description: MARVIN-Anthony (Tony). Veteran radio and television artist and MC, on October 10, in Boynton Beach, Florida, age 86. Beloved husband of Dorothea & cherished father of Lynda. He was known for his many kindnesses to fellow performers & numerous charities. Funeral service Wednesday 2 PM, Beth Moses cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island.

title: A Personal Touch In Small Paris Shops
description: PARIS  While the boutique scene here has recently been dominated by mega international names opening mega stores, four new stores have bucked the trend by embracing smaller spaces and an individual approach to fashion.

title: Hoechst Says Profit Will Slide for 1998
description: Hoechst A.G., Europe's fourth-largest chemical company, warned yesterday that its earnings would drop in 1998 as business in Asia, Latin America and Russia slumps. Its shares closed at 61.3 marks, down 2.9 marks, after falling as low as 57.5. Hoechst said several units, including the flagship drug division Hoechst Marion Roussel, would earn less than forecast in August.

title: By Design; Strap Packs
description: The most surprising accessory seen so far on the spring runways is the reinvented fanny pack. The trend started in New York with Helmut Lang, who slung a holster-style bag around models' waists and attached it to the thigh.

title: In New York's Hubbub, Moody Vibes for Sheryl Crow
description: Sheryl Crow is, she said, ''conducting an experiment.'' It's a simple one, she explained recently at the SoHo Grand Hotel, where she has been staying sporadically while her new loft in NoHo is renovated. ''I'm staying home for the next two months,'' she said. ''I'm going to see how that feels.''

title: Company Investigated by Vacco Is Tied to Funds for His Campaign
description: The first complaints streamed in a decade ago: a large car-leasing company on Long Island called Oxford Resources was habitually overcharging customers. Robert Abrams, then the New York Attorney General, accused Oxford of deceptive practices, and the company settled in 1990 by issuing refunds, paying a $10,000 fine and pledging to change its ways.

title: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?; A Remote Prospect
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Injured as Airport Van Climbs Sidewalk
description: An airport shuttle van lurched onto the crowded sidewalk outside Bloomingdale's in Manhattan yesterday afternoon, bumping its way along the side of the store, shattering display windows and injuring two tourists, a vendor and the driver.

title: Not Just Another Opening For Disputed McNally Play
description: More than the usual opening-night anticipation surrounds this evening's performance of ''Corpus Christi,'' Terrence McNally's play about a gay Christ-like character and his gay apostles. Dueling protesters have announced plans to demonstrate in front of the City Center: those who oppose the production on religious grounds and those who support it based on free expression.

title: SOLUTIA SAYS IT PLANS TO PUT A THIRD UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: Solutia Inc., a specialty chemical and fiber maker with annual sales of $2.97 billion, said yesterday that it planned to shed another business soon as part of its effort to trim costs and focus on its more profitable products. Earlier, Solutia said it planned to sell its phosphorus unit, which contributed about $370 million from sales of chemicals used in fire retardants, detergents and other products. The company has also said it will sell its Scripsets paper-coatings business. The St. Louis-based company will put a third business up for sale ''within the next few months,'' said Chip Merritt, Solutia's director of investor relations, though he declined to specify which business Solutia might shed. The company's shares rose 93.75 cents, to $24.6875.

title: NEW TODAY: An Expanded Science Times
description: Science Times today observes its 20th anniversary by adding new pages for health, behavior and fitness. Along with Jane Brody's Personal Health column, the section will offer additional news reports and regular features like The Novice, a periodic column on the personal experience of learning new fitness activities.

title: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?; Starr's Tactics Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE FINANCIAL CANCELS DEAL WITH FIRSTPLUS FINANCIAL
description: The Life Financial Corporation, a bank holding company, has canceled an agreement to be acquired by Firstplus Financial Group Inc., a struggling subprime lender, for $138 million. Shares of Firstplus jumped 43.75 cents, to to $3.75. Shares of Life Financial rose 37.5 cents, to $4. Life Financial, based in Riverside, Calif., purchases and originates nonconventional mortgage loans through its Life Bank unit. The company said on Monday that its directors had decided the agreement was not in the best interest of shareholders because of recent developments concerning Firstplus.

title: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Women Pace During Labor?
description: Does walking during labor's early stages ease pain and hasten delivery?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, HELEN B.
description: LEVY-Helen B. On Oct. 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Caring mother of Louise Cooperstein & the late Jim Linden. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Judith, Steven and Richard. Adored great-grandmother of Eva, Paula and Gregory. Devoted mother-inlaw of Miriam Goldman. She loved us all. Her family were her riches. She was our jewel. A sweet, soft lady, reached her 100th year with dignity and beauty. All who knew her will never forget her. Graveside services, Wednesday 1 P.M., at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Glendale, NY.

title: A Life Reflected in a House Transformed
description: As he waits for the last votes of his 34-year Congressional career, Representative Lee Hamilton runs one hand through his crew cut and thinks out loud, in his right-down-the-middle way, about why the House is both meaner and cleaner, more hard-working and less thoughtful, than when he arrived here from Columbus, Ind., in 1965.

title: Federal Aid Improved Education
description: To the Editor:

title: In Peer Review, Experts Often Skip Over Directions
description: How well do doctors follow directions?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGALL, VIOLET R. (NEE TOLK)
description: SIEGALL-Violet R. (nee Tolk). Beloved wife of the late Herman, adored mother of Laurie Berger, loving grandmother of Jaimie and Adam. Dear sister of Lloyd Tolk and the late Buddy Tolk. We all love you and will miss you. Services Tuesday 11:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Brisby Is Out With Broken Finger
description: The Patriots wide receiver Vincent Brisby will miss the next four games because of a broken finger sustained during Sunday's 40-10 victory over the Chiefs. Brisby, 27, broke the index finger on his right hand while making a catch during the second quarter. He has caught 6 passes for 89 yards this season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEARLMAN, STEPHEN
description: PEARLMAN-Stephen. Memorial service Sunday, October 25, 1998 12 Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Harvest of Gold

title: AMERITECH BUYS CLOVER, A NETWORK SERVICES PROVIDER
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the fifth-largest United States local phone company, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Clover Technologies for an undisclosed price, expanding the size of its data operations by 15 percent. Clover will become part of the Chicago-based Ameritech, which has 3,000 employees who support data services and expects 1998 sales of more than $100 million. Clover will help Ameritech provide more data services to companies.

title: What upheaval in the world's financial markets? National advertisers are upbeat on the economy.
description: A LUXURY hotel on the Gulf of Mexico has little in common with a home on the range. But the 89th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, held at the Ritz-Carlton here, shared with that little house on the prairie the absence of discouraging words.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZULBERTI, GLORIA
description: ZULBERTI-Gloria. Loving daughter of the late Colombo and Angelina, nee Moriglio. Devoted sister of Florence and the late Walter. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei R.C. Church. Burial Calvary Cemetery.

title: FRED MEYER ADDING 98 STORES IN SERIES OF DEALS
description: In three separate transactions, Fred Meyer Inc. will sell 38 food stores outside its western market area and will acquire a total of 136 food and jewelry stores. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed. Meyer's Ralph's Grocery Company unit plans to sell five Falley's and 33 Food 4 Less stores in the Midwest to Associated Wholesale Grocers. Meyer's Smith's Food and Drug Centers unit acquired 13 food stores in Wyoming and Montana, while its Fred Meyer Jewelers unit acquired 123 jewelry stores in 10 eastern states. The 13 food stores previously were Albertson's and Buttrey stores. The jewelry stores were operated as Littman's and Barclays.

title: Where Have All the Launch Pads Gone?
description: As the National Aeronautics and Space Administration marks the 40th anniversary of its founding on Oct. 1, 1958, aspects of the occasion are more archeological than astronautical. So it sometimes seems on the back roads and in the weeds along the shore of Cape Canaveral, Fla., where the ruins evoke memories of all those rockets in the early morning and the eerie twilight after the cheering stopped.

title: Fashion's Crossover Moments : Playing to the Galleries:Wannabe Art
description: LONDON  To the right, a plastic maternity dress with a porthole window at the front. That's a fashion item? No! It's art  Mimi Smith's feminist statement from the 1960s.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CANCELS DEAL FOR PACIFICAMERICA
description: The Fremont General Corporation has canceled negotiations to acquire PacificAmerica Money Center Inc. PacificAmerica said yesterday that Fremont had cited turmoil in the securities markets and the subprime lending industry. PacificAmerica said it planned to look at all options, including the sale of the company, a sale or refinancing of receivable assets or the raising of additional capital. PacificAmerica, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said recent turmoil in the subprime lending industry makes it difficult to predict whether any transactions will be completed. Last month, Fremont General, based in Santa Monica, Calif., agreed to purchase PacificAmerica for $10 a share, or about $55 million in cash and stock.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Matthew Shepard's horrible suffering and death cannot be dismissed simply as the fault of deranged, isolated individuals. His attackers are among millions of Americans who constantly hear the message that gay people are not worthy of the most basic equal treatment.''

title: A Stitch in Your Side
description: Q. What is a stitch in your side? What can you do to relieve the pain?

title: High Chlamydia Rates Found in Teen-Agers
description: It is a finding sure to dismay parents everywhere: The sexually transmitted disease chlamydia has become so common among teen-age girls in some parts of the United States that doctors have begun to recommend that sexually active girls be tested for the disease twice a year, instead of once a year, as called for by current medical guidelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNOW, JAY HOWARD
description: CHERNOW-Jay Howard. 62. On Monday October 12, 1998 at Old Bridge, NJ. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee Messing) loving father of Michael Chernow and Laurie Kolbasowski, also by nine grandchildren, friend of many and will be sorely missed. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral service Wednesday October 14, 1998 at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ at 10:30 A.M. For information Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels Inc. Manalapan, New Jersey.

title: Chrysler Net Rises 54%, Beating Forecasts
description: The Chrysler Corporation posted a much-better-than-expected 54.6 percent increase in third-quarter net profits today as the turmoil in global financial markets seemed to be having surprisingly little effect on the Big Three auto makers' domestic sales and profits.

title: Accounts
description: * Eaton Truck Components Operations, Kalamazoo, Mich., a unit of Eaton Corp., to Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle its marketing communications, which had been handled by Euro RSCG Tatham, Chicago, part of Havas Advertising. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Bruce Williamson, 71, Film Critic at Playboy
description: Bruce Williamson, a longtime film critic and contributing editor at Playboy magazine, died on Oct. 6 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71.

title: Costly Fight Rages in California Over Indian Gambling Measure
description: More than a century after Indian wars roiled the West, another battle is raging here over a ballot measure that would expand the state's $1.4 billion Indian gambling industry. It pits California's gaming tribes against an unlikely coalition of Nevada casinos, unions, church groups and other businesses in what may become the most expensive fight in California political history.

title: Placebos Prove So Powerful Even Experts Are Surprised; New Studies Explore the Brain's Triumph Over Reality
description: Many doctors know the story of ''Mr. Wright,'' who was found to have cancer and in 1957 was given only days to live. Hospitalized in Long Beach, Calif., with tumors the size of oranges, he heard that scientists had discovered a horse serum, Krebiozen, that appeared to be effective against cancer. He begged to receive it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARFZAWSKI, ARON
description: WARFZAWSKI - Aron. Passed away peacefully after a prolonged illness on October 12, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Vivienne, his sister, Sarah, his four sons, and his five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. October 10, 1998. Faithful husband of Joan BrandtCates. Loving father of Phillip, Valerie, Phoebe and Alexandra Cates and stepfather of Wilson Brandt. Adoring grandfather of Owen Joseph and Greta Simone Kline. Devoted brother of Gil Cates and Kit Adler. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 15, 6-9PM with service Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Friars Foundation, Inc., 57 E. 55 St, NY, NY 10022.

title: With Life Support Off, Rutgers Student Dies
description: A Rutgers University student who suffered head injuries last week in a fall at his fraternity house after a night of drinking died early today after being taken off life support.

title: THE NOVICE; Learning How to Get a Grip, at 7,500 Feet
description: There may be more appropriate venues to first learn the art of rock climbing than an enormous granite escarpment known as Suicide Rocks. The formation is the size of several football fields, albeit vertical ones, and emerges out of the San Jacinto Mountains of Southern California at an altitude of 7,500 feet. This means climbers must deal with the thin air as well as the rocks, which are sufficiently intimidating on their own.

title: Predictions, Good and Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 4.7 PERCENT. Prices slumped on expectations that exports from a bumper crop in Brazil would swell United States inventories. The December contract fell 5.1 cents, to $1.034 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, EDNA BACKUS
description: TOBIN-Edna Backus. 95. Formerly of Lord & Taylor Furniture Galleries, 5th Avenue, N.Y. Survived by son, David, daughter-in-law Maureen, six grandchildren, seven great grandchildren. Graveside service Wednesday, 1 PM, Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y.

title: New Blow to Royal Opera
description: In another blow to the struggling Royal Opera House, its music director, Bernard Haitink, has handed in his resignation to protest the opera house's decision to cancel its 1999 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIALLONARDO, CONCETTO DINO
description: DiGIALLONARDO-Concetto Dino. Beloved son of Clotilde and the late Onorino. Cherished husband of Mariateresa, devoted father of Daniela, Nadia and Christine. Loving brother of Romeo and Rita. Loving uncle of Sandra. Fond brother-in-law of Maria and Ben. A man of wit, charm and intelligence. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo, 2005 West 6th Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:30AM at St. Simon & Jude R.C. Church. Interment Moravian cemetery.

title: Ariel Sharon, Peacemaker?; Appeasing Extremists
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid New Calls for Pain Relief, New Calls for Caution
description: William Bergman knew how he wanted to die. ''He wanted to be free of pain,'' said his daughter, Beverly, ''and die at home with us.'' But when Mr. Bergman, an 85-year-old retired railroad detective from Hayward, Calif., contracted lung cancer last February, he got only half his wish. He died at home, his daughter said, but in miserable pain.

title: As Meteors Near, Satellites Avert Eyes
description: Periodically for at least the last 1,000 years, a spectacular rain of meteors spawned by a passing comet has lighted up the sky, inspiring fear, wonder and admiration. The meteor storm, which shot hundreds of thousands of blazing streaks across the heavens 33 years ago, is soon due to hit Earth again, and this time space scientists are concerned about its effects.

title: Media Metrix Plans Merger With Relevant Knowledge
description: In another sign that even cyberspace may not be big enough for all of the companies that have sprouted up hoping to profit from the Internet, the two largest companies that measure the audience size of World Wide Web sites have agreed to merge.

title: Aerospace Combination Plan Confirmed
description: Daimler-Benz Aerospace and British Aerospace P.L.C. aim to combine early next year into a military contractor that could include other European arms suppliers, a spokesman for the German company said today.

title: Giuliani, After Chiding Pataki On Endorsement, Praises Him
description: A day after he disparaged Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to accept the endorsement of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani heaped praise on his fellow Republican yesterday, saying Mr. Pataki deserved to be re-elected ''by a very, very large number.''

title: Forecast Is Mostly Cloudy at a Hedge Fund Conference
description: Julian H. Robertson Jr., who runs Tiger Management L.L.C., one of the largest hedge funds in the world, said today that the global financial markets remained precarious and that he did not expect things to get much better anytime soon.

title: And Then There Will Be Two; Set to Split Its Last Units, Tenneco Tries to Please Wall St.
description: Just how focused must a company be? And how much does it have to cut before Wall Street is happy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, JESSICA
description: FIELDS-Jessica. Age 96. On October 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Michael Dana. Cherished mother of Stanley and Nancy. We mourn the passing of our adorable Jessica, through all her days, in so many ways, a perfect blending of sweetness and strength. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, October 13, from 7-9PM. Services private. In lieu of flowers, send something nice to someone you love.

title: City Plans 13% Raise for Child Agency, but Union Fears Favoritism
description: Moving to fulfill a longstanding promise to improve the pay and professionalism of New York City's beleaguered child welfare workers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to offer a 13 percent salary increase to the employees who monitor abused and neglected children, their largest single raise in more than a decade.

title: INTERNATIONAL NETWORK BUYING VITALSIGNS IN STOCK DEAL
description: International Network Services agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Vitalsigns Software Inc. for $127 million in stock. International Network Services will exchange 4.2 million shares of common stock for all outstanding shares and options of Vitalsigns, based in Santa Clara, Calif. International Network Services, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will take an undisclosed charge in its second quarter, ending in December, to pay for the purchase. It said it would provide details when it reports first-quarter earnings on Oct. 25. International Network Services makes software that lets computer network managers track the users and devices connected to the network.

title: Viagra and the Older Woman
description: Viagra, which has revved up the sex lives of many men, may have another down side, this one among the female partners of the men taking it.

title: ALLIANCE CAPITAL TO BUY BRITISH ASSET MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: Alliance Capital Management L.P. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Whittingdale Holdings Ltd., a London fixed-income fund manager, for undisclosed terms. Alliance has money-management partnerships everywhere from Brazil to Hong Kong and recently oversaw a total of more than $260 billion of assets. Alliance is expected to complete the acquisition of Whittingdale, a 21-year-old firm that manages about $:850 million ($1.44 billion) of assets, by the end of the year.

title: Gadgets, But None To Put Out A Big Fire
description: The proper young British widow has a rocket in her purse. The handsome, aging patent clerk is in pain because he showed up for military duty in his dancing shoes. The French Ambassador's wife is lonely and convinced that she's dying. The Secretary of Patents is worried about his gadgets. The big, burly sailor just wants to stay alive. And they all end up together in the United States Patent Office one day in 1814 when British soldiers decide to burn America's capital.

title: Ariel Sharon, Peacemaker?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS
description: The Devils sent defenseman Bryan Muir to the minor leagues yesterday, even though Muir was one of their better players in their 2-1 season-opening loss at Chicago last Saturday night.

title: Political Parties Opposed to Bosnia Peace Get Millions in Rent From NATO
description: NATO forces in Bosnia and Croatia are needlessly paying millions of dollars in rent that is winding up in the coffers of the governing political parties, say financial experts who have studied the two governments. And diplomats say those parties are often the principal obstacles to peace.

title: Today: an Expanded Science Times
description: Starting today, Science Times is adding health and fitness coverage. Jane Brody's Personal Health column will be joined by new features including The Novice, a column that will periodically detail the experience of learning a new fitness activity. Pages 7-12.

title: An Older, Taller No. 1
