description: A work in progress for the past 22 years, and an exception to the unwritten tennis rule that favors female stars who are ultramarketable teen-age novelties in the Sweet 16 range, Lindsay Davenport stepped yesterday into the first week of her reign as the world's No. 1 player.

title: Are Giants Desperate? Game 7 Is a Must Game
description: Six weeks into a season that once held much promise, the bewildered Giants today were soberly trying to pull their season together before it was too late.

title: 'Beloved' Tests Racial Themes At Box Office; Will This Winfrey Film Appeal to White Audiences?
description: The opening of the film ''Beloved'' this week has drawn extraordinary attention in Hollywood -- and not just because the movie was adapted from a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Toni Morrison, was directed by an Academy Award-winning director, Jonathan Demme, and stars the queen of daytime television, Oprah Winfrey, who also produced it.

title: M.G.M. QUITS TALKS ON ACQUIRING SEAGRAM UNIT
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks with the Seagram Company about buying Polygram Filmed Entertainment's film library after the companies failed to agree on a price. A spokesman for M.G.M., the struggling film studio controlled by the Las Vegas financier Kirk Kerkorian, said it offered about $400 million for the 1,500-title library, which includes films like ''Four Weddings and Funeral.'' Seagram has been trying to sell Polygram Filmed Entertainment since May to help offset the $10.4 billion cost of acquiring its parent, Polygram N.V. Originally, Seagram sought $1 billion for the entire film unit, including production and distribution.

title: In China, 35+ and Female = Unemployable
description: Every afternoon, in the small courtyard outside the Machang Street Re-employment Center, small groups of laid-off workers anxiously scan the day's help-wanted listings. There is a sad sameness about this army of job hopefuls, each one dressed up, ready for an interview at any time: they are all women, all over 35 and all unskilled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVOK, RUTH J. (NEE FIEGMEISTER)
description: NOVOK-Ruth J. (nee Fiegmeister). Of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of New York, beloved wife of the late Daniel A., adored mother of Barbara J. Klein, and Gail-ellen Goldberg. Precious mother to Marc Goldberg and the late Robert J. Klein, cherished grandmother of Karen, Gary, Bruce, and Allison, loving great grandmother. Her energy, intellect, elegance, grace, and beauty will forever inspire us. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Fox Acquires 50 Met Games
description: Fox Sports New York announced yesterday that it had acquired the rights to 50 Mets games, which will presumably be offered to Channel 9 or Channel 11.

title: A Change in the Air
description: The centerpiece of the Clinton Administration's economic policy this year has been a demand that the Republican-controlled Congress forgo tax cuts and set aside the projected Federal budget surplus until the nation shores up the Social Security system.

title: One Man's Endorsement Is Another's . . .
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has been unseasonably quiet this autumn, which may explain why he suddenly succumbed to one of his political tics, this one disrupting an endorsement for a fellow Republican, Gov. George Pataki. The New York Governor, who is running far ahead of his Democratic opponent, Peter Vallone, in next month's election, was about to receive the nod from a prominent Harlem minister, the Rev. Calvin Butts 3d, when the Mayor erupted. ''I think Reverend Butts plays the worst kind of racial politics,'' Mr. Giuliani told reporters as he marched in the Hispanic Day Parade on Fifth Avenue. ''If I were in Governor Pataki's position, I would refuse to take the endorsement. . . .''

title: Agreement Close on Holyfield-Lewis Bout
description: A heavyweight unification bout between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis is closer than ever, after Don King and Panos Eliades, two of the promoters for the fighters, agreed to terms last night in London.

title: That Team. That Time of Year.
description: Once again, the Yankees are in post-season play, and once again they're not having an easy time of it. And once again, like every fan who loathes the Yankees but loves baseball, I am, as baseball people put it, in a pickle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORROW, STEVE
description: MORROW-Steve. We deeply regret the passing of our dear friend, founder of our Florida Chapter, former president of the New Cracow Society. Our sincere condolences to his brother, our friend and supporter Zigmund Morrow and his family. Friends of Israel Disabled Veterans Susan Aberbach, National Chairperson Michael Stoler, Executive Director

title: High Cost of Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman Resigns At ING Barings
description: Marinus Minderhoud stepped down yesterday as chairman of ING Barings and accepted responsibility for its poor financial performance. ING Groep N.V. recently cut 1,200 jobs at its ING Barings unit.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about David C. Evans, a pioneer in computer graphics, misstated his position in the computer science department at the University of California at Berkeley in the 1960's. He was a member of the department, not chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, BARBARA
description: EDELMAN-Barbara. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of Barbara Edelman, wife of our fellow member, Elliott Edelman, and extend sincere condolences to him and his family. Roy R. Raizen, President

title: Candidates Risk Little With Harsh Ads
description: At a Sunday morning service recently, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake went to the pulpit of his church in Queens and urged the candidates for the United States Senate, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer, to cease their ''dirty campaign.'' They were doing themselves a disservice and would ultimately turn voters away from an important political contest, Mr. Flake told the congregation, which included Mr. D'Amato that morning.

title: In an Irish Village, Faith, Love, Death And the Gift of Gab
description: No one can accuse the new crop of Irish playwrights of shying away from the big issues. Take, for example, ''Moonshine,'' a new play by Jim Nolan at the Irish Arts Center that is at heart a romantic comedy about death, burial and the Resurrection, taking place on Easter weekend in a small Irish village.

title: Baan Shares Tumble After It Forecasts Loss
description: The stock of the Baan Company N.V. fell more than 27 percent yesterday after the company, a Dutch maker of business software, unexpectedly predicted a loss for the quarter. Analysts had forecast profit of 14 cents a share. Baan said the quarter would probably end with a loss of 13 to 16 cents a share.

title: Risk of Lyme Disease May Increase in Winter
description: A bumper crop of acorns this year is likely to cause a spike in the population of white-footed mice this winter, which could result in an increased risk of Lyme disease, scientists said yesterday.

title: What Do Blue Jays Like to Eat? Ask a Virtual Moth
description: The scene has been played out again and again over the millennia: a hungry bird spies a bug and pounces, driving its beak into its hearty insect meal. Now, in a twist on this ancient story, scientists are training birds to aim at virtual insects, computer-generated fakes at the heart of a growing field of ecology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, JESSIE
description: FIELDS-Jessie. Farewell, special friend and dear mother of our special friend, admired and loved by all of us. Rest well. The Blochs, Millers and Rosenblatts

title: The Ugly Handwriting Award
description: Everybody knows it, but now researchers in Wales have proved it: Doctors have rotten handwriting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLIGHTLY, BONNIE
description: GOLIGHTLY - Bonnie. Colorful New York writer, thought to be the original of ''Breakfast At Tiffanys'' died in New Haven, October 10, leaving two daughters, LeAnn Samuels, and Molly Allender. Seymour Hacker

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the acquisition of the Allegiance Corporation by Cardinal Health Inc. misstated the year in which the lower value of the Malaysian currency, the ringgit, contributed to Allegiance's profits. It was this year, not 1997.

title: Music as Ultimate Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoblauch's Miscue: Forgotten, Not Gone
description: The last time Chuck Knoblauch was on the field at Yankee Stadium, he made an awful mistake. He forgot to chase after a loose ball. It was the sort of reaction that could get a 10-year-old second baseman benched, even if his father was the coach. It is the sort of lapse that should never happen in a major league game, but it did.

title: Congress Passes Anti-Piracy Bill
description: Legislation intended to protect books, music, computer software and other works from Internet pirates cleared its last congressional hurdle today, winning unanimous approval by the House of Representatives.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the music column of the Westchester section on Sunday about a planned recital by the soprano Dawn Upshaw at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers has become outdated. After the section went to press, the performance, scheduled for this Thursday, was canceled.

title: With Big Name, a Taft Seeks to Win Classic Race for Governor in Ohio
description: There are few names that evoke as much political resonance in Ohio as Taft. From William Howard Taft, the nation's 27th President and a Chief Justice, to his son, Robert A. Taft, a Senator and Presidential contender, the family name is one that helped define Republican politics for more than a century.

title: Small Towns, Tarnished Badges; In New Jersey, Corruption Feeds on Silence and Dashed Hopes
description: In his six years on the police force, Sgt. Michael Anderson had investigated dozens of break-ins, but this was the first one he had committed. He was nervous.

title: Ad Asserts a Democrat Took a Stand for Money
description: The Republican incumbent in a special election for a Camden area Assembly seat has accused his Democratic predecessor of accepting campaign money in exchange for allowing the battleship New Jersey to be berthed in Bayonne.

title: Plane Strikes Trees At End of Runway
description: A single-engine plane was hit by a tail wind and crashed into trees at the end of a runway yesterday morning, the State Police said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a film review of Todd Solondz's ''Happiness'' misidentified the child shown with Dylan Baker, who plays Dr. Bill Maplewood. The boy was Evan Silverberg in the role of Johnny, not Justin Elvin as Timmy.

title: Kava May Soothe Jagged Nerves, but Is It Safe?
description: A pill that calms you down without making you dull, sleepy or addicted? It may seem too good to be true, but the prospect of inner peace with no strings attached is tempting more and more Americans to try kava, an herbal product derived from the roots of a pepper plant grown in Fiji, Vanuatu and other Pacific islands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZKA, THELMA
description: HERZKA-Thelma. On October 10, at age 90. Devoted wife of the late Lloyd I. Herzka. Cherished mother of Rita McIntyre, Marilyn Stanley, and Dorothy Lichtenstein. Also survived by six grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, two sisters, three brothers and numerous nieces and nephews. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 11 AM, Tuesday, October 13.

title: Yankees Keeping One Eye on Padres and Brown
description: Last night's fifth game of the National League Championship Series was critical for three teams: the Atlanta Braves, the San Diego Padres and the Yankees.

title: Murdered for Who He Was
description: In the United States, for all its consecration of equal rights, the members of minority groups have often had to pay a terrible price just for being who they are. It is a history that African-Americans, Asians, Jews, Italians, Irish and others know too well, and its most compelling image, the symbol of a dangerous knot in the American spirit, has always been the black figure at the end of a lynch rope, hanging from a tree. But other groups have been the victims of that murderous impulse too, and homosexuals have always been among them. Gradually, crimes motivated by hate have come to be seen as a category of their own.

title: 2 Top Executives of Triarc Seek to Take the Company Private
description: In a move that surprised many on Wall Street, two top executives of the Triarc Companies, which owns the Snapple and Mistic beverage lines as well as several restaurant franchises, have made a bid to take Triarc private.

title: It's a Party, With Rumbas and Cha-Cha-Chas
description: It was the pianist's night on Wednesday at S.O.B.'s. Nachito Herrera, working with the group Cubanismo, was having a good time. On a cha-cha-cha he tore up the music, dropping a series of quotes -- melodies from other cha-cha-chas -- into his solo; the chorus picked up one and sang it. He worked over the dissonance of a whole tone scale, and flatted the fifth degree of a chord, ending a phrase on its bitterness. Left and right hands sprayed contrasting rhythms, and the intensity of the band soared in reaction.

title: Sports of The Times; Boomer Asks Yankee Fans To Cool It
description: DAVID WELLS's idol, the esteemed George Herman Ruth, once tried to fight a couple of opposing players. Asked about it later, the Babe said he didn't mind being called a blankety-blank or a bleepety-bleep; he just didn't like it when they got personal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, MARY (NEE BOYLE)
description: EGAN-Mary (Nee Boyle). On October 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Michael T. Devoted mother of Mary Garvey and Theresa Egan, dear grandmother of Sean. After graduating, The College of Mount St. Vincent, she went on to serve as a 1st Lt. in the United States Women's Army Corp. She will be missed and loved by all. Reposing at Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funderal Home, 4955 Broadway (207 Street), on Tuesday from 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of the Christian burial Wednesday 10 A.M., at the Good Shepherd Church.

title: Bass May Seek CD Radio Stake
description: Prime 66 Partners L.P., a Texas limited partnership linked to the billionaire Sid R. Bass, is expected to announce soon that it is investing $100 million to acquire 5 million shares, or about 20 percent, of CD Radio Inc., a satellite-to-car radio broadcaster, according to people involved in the proposed transaction.

title: F.C.C. Likely to Halt BellSouth Long Distance Bid
description: The Federal Communications Commission will reject the BellSouth Corporation's latest application to offer long-distance service in Louisiana, people close to the process said yesterday.

title: N.B.A. Set to Start Canceling Games
description: Russ Granik, the National Basketball Association's deputy commissioner, has termed tomorrow the drop-dead date before the league decides to begin canceling regular-season games. The N.B.A. Players Association has worked all weekend preparing a counterproposal.

title: Three Americans Awarded Nobel for Discoveries of How a Gas Affects the Body
description: Three American pharmacologists were awarded the Nobel Prize yesterday for their surprising discoveries of how natural production of a gas, nitric oxide, can mediate a wide variety of bodily actions. Those include widening blood vessels, helping to regulate blood pressure, initiating erections, battling infections, preventing formation of blood clots and acting as a signal molecule in the nervous system.

title: Back Home, a Democrat Defends Clinton Inquiry Vote
description: He is big on back pats, and he was patting hard at home this holiday weekend. Facing a nip-and-tuck re-election race and a Republican opponent who has been fanning resentment toward President Clinton, United States Representative James H. Maloney split with his party last Thursday and became one of just 31 Democrats to vote for impeachment hearings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ANDREW BREEN PH.D.
description: MYERS-Andrew Breen Ph.D. On October 12, 1998. Professor emeritus Fordham University. Beloved husband of Margaret Lohrmann Myers, MD. Devoted father of Cathleen, Christopher and Andrew L. Grandfather of Christopher M. Christina, and Julia. Wake at Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Tuesday and Wednesday, October 13 & 14, 2-5pm and 7-10pm. Funeral mass Thursday at St. Michael's R.C. Church, Flushing at 11am. Burial at Mt. St. Mary cemetery.

title: Education Initiatives Still a Sticking Point in Budget Talks
description: Republican leaders in Congress and White House negotiators ended their talks tonight on the Federal budget without reaching agreement but pushed back their deadline to midnight Wednesday to work out their differences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WING, SUSAN MCINTOSH
description: WING-Susan McIntosh, 72. Of Chatham, NJ, on October 10, 1998. Daughter of the late Andrew J. McIntosh and Harriet C. McIntosh, M.D. Graduated Smith College 1947. Beloved wife of Charles M. Wing, mother of Charles & Susan, sister of Andrew J. McIntosh, Jr. Cherished grandmother. Memorial service on Sunday, November 1, 2 P.M., Stanley Congregational Church, Chatham, New Jersey.

title: Islanders Still Struggle To Fill In the Blanks
description: Had the Islanders played at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum today, Mike Milbury's remark might have been construed differently.

title: Pettitte Left Wondering If He Is Game 7 Choice
description: Andy Pettitte realizes there is a strong chance that Manager Joe Torre could pass him by and start Orlando Hernandez in a possible Game 7 on three days' rest for the Yankees, a depressing thought for a pitcher who has won 55 games over the last three seasons.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLSTATE LIFE INSURANCE CO., a unit of Allstate Corp., Northbrook, Ill., agreed to reinsure and administer about 21,000 variable annunity contracts worth a total of $1.3 billion managed by Lincoln National Corp., a financial services company based in Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: Camenzind Wins; Armstrong Fourth
description: Switzerland's Oscar Camenzind broke away in the final lap to win a wet and windswept men's road race Sunday at the World Cycling Championships in Valkenburg, the Netherlands, the last major event of a season overshadowed by doping scandals.

title: THE NOVICE; Learning How to Get a Grip, at 7,500 Feet
description: There may be more appropriate venues to first learn the art of rock climbing than an enormous granite escarpment known as Suicide Rocks. The formation is the size of several football fields, albeit vertical ones, and emerges out of the San Jacinto Mountains of Southern California at an altitude of 7,500 feet. This means climbers must deal with the thin air as well as the rocks, which are sufficiently intimidating on their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEMAN, REV. DR. LYNN L.
description: HAGEMAN-Rev. Dr. Lynn L. On October 4, 1998. Husband of Leola. Father of Erika, Hans and Ivan. Grandfather of Jamila and Kiana. Brother of Gwendolyn. Rev. Hageman was a civil rights activist and the Founder/Director of the Drug Addict Treatment Center, Exodus House. Memorial service Thursday, October 15, at 11AM at Saint Mary's Episcopal Church, 126 Street and Old Broadway, NYC.

title: Miami Loses Momentum At the End
description: Miami and Jacksonville had never played a regular-season game before tonight, so who knew what to expect in their Floridian fling? Plenty of spurts, almost like a basketball game, was the way it unfolded. And Jacksonville produced the final fast break, the one that broke things open and gave it a 28-21 victory before 74,051 fans at Alltell Stadium.

title: Enthusiasm Of Doctor Can Give Pill Extra Kick
description: Though some people respond more strongly to placebos than others do, it seems that everyone responds at some time or other. And doctors seem to play a large role in the degree of that response.

title: In World of 'Antz,' It's the Females Who Should Be Wearing the Pantz
description: Woody Allen has played many implausible characters in his career: a human sperm, a failed writer, an aging nebbish who remains irresistibly attractive to gorgeous Barnard students. Yet none is as preposterous as the one that he assumes, by voice and persona, in the new and critically acclaimed animated feature, ''Antz.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: World Briefing
description: This column, appearing Tuesday through Saturday, summarizes diplomatic, political and economic news. It will track continuing stories and note events that may move markets and governments but are not reported elsewhere in The Times.

title: HOCKEY: By Popular Demand?; Isles Reluctantly Return, as Have a Few Fans
description: The Islanders, a proud team that won the Stanley Cup four times from 1980 to 1983, find themselves in a sports opera bouffe, a landlord-tenant dispute gone wacky. Last month, the team abandoned Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, declaring it unsafe for fans, beer men or goalies, but returned by court order after National Hockey League inspectors had declared that conditions at the arena posed no danger.

title: Asian Markets, With Japan Leading, Continue Rally
description: Buoyed by a stronger Japanese yen and expectations of interest rate cuts at home and abroad, stock markets rose throughout Asia today in what has become a surprisingly vigorous and sustained rally, although there is no guarantee that it will last.

title: The Icarus Complex
description: We've seen ''Taxes for Dummies'' and ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to DOS.'' This year many leading intellects seem to need a simplifying book or two of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, LAWRENCE
description: WEINSTEIN-Lawrence. Attorney. On October 11, 1998. Cherished husband of Joy. Adored father of Mark, Gail and Jay. Beloved grandfather of Zachary, Brooke, David, Amanda and Scott. He was the kindest and gentlest of men. Services Wednesday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Federal Aid Improved Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurers Get 2d Bid On U.S. Contract
description: Humana Inc. and Foundation Health Systems Inc. said last week that they would get a second chance to bid on a $2 billion Defense Department contract that they lost to Anthem Insurance Companies Inc. last year.

title: I.M.F. Deal Is Reported To Be Near
description: The White House and Republican Congressional leaders are close to an agreement to provide $18 billion to the International Monetary Fund in exchange for new conditions on the fund's loans to foreign governments, Clinton Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Where to Find Chess and the Computer Column
description: Starting this week, the Chess column has a new home. It will appear on Sundays, in the main news section. The page number will be shown in the index on page 2 of that section.

title: Patterns
description: Chanel to Start a Line: Beige

title: A Truce in I.M.F. War
description: The White House and Republican Congressional leaders are close to an agreement to provide $18 billion to the International Monetary Fund in exchange for new conditions on the fund's loans to foreign governments, Clinton Administration and Congressional officials say.

title: Beating Deadline, Normal Service Returns for the Nos. 2 and 3 Subway Lines
description: Relishing the rare chance to finish a major subway project on budget and ahead of schedule, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reopened the No. 2 and No. 3 lines north of 96th Street yesterday, ending seven months of disruption that inconvenienced more than a million riders each day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILKESON, ELIZABETH C.
description: GILKESON-Elizabeth C. Age 95, on October 7, 1998. Founder of the Poughkeepsie Day School; Founding Director of the Bank Street School for Children and senior faculty member at Bank Street College. Beloved grandmother of Robert C. Gilkeson, M.D., Nancy O'Connor-Reedy, Elizabeth C. O'Connor, Martha G. Todd and Sarah G. Melcher. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 14, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Bank Street College of Education, 610 West 112 Street, New York City 10025.

title: Starbucks Is Parting From BBDO West
description: The Starbucks Coffee Company said yesterday that after only 13 months, it had ended its relationship with BBDO West in Los Angeles. Billings on its account are estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Men on Infamous Float Cite Prize-Winning Past Spoofs
description: To hear the police officer and the two firefighters tell it, the float that got them in so much trouble this year when they wore blackface at the annual Labor Day parade in Broad Channel, Queens, was just a spoof, like the floats they had created for the last nine years.

title: A Determined Cone Welcomes His 'Defining Moment'
description: The pitcher who will try to guide the Yankees into the World Series tonight sat in an empty clubhouse with a cup of coffee yesterday afternoon and basically invited a mass of reporters over for a baseball discussion. He was determined, nostalgic and relaxed. David Cone sounded ready.

title: Upcoming Book to Provide Grist at the Microsoft Trial
description: The Microsoft Corporation has said that material in an unpublished book by two business school professors will be a crucial part of its defense in the antitrust trial scheduled to begin next week. But judging from an advance copy of the book's manuscript, the Justice Department and 20 states that are suing the software giant will find support for their arguments as well.

title: Rangers Leave the Fans Cheering for the Yanks
description: It was not as if New York fans had nothing to cheer and chant about last night at Madison Square Garden. They made a joyous noise late in the first period when the scoreboard screen showed the image of David Wells, the Yankee pitcher, sitting in the hockey crowd on an off night during the American League Championship Series.

title: Telegroup to Cut 231 Jobs
description: Telegroup Inc., a provider of long-distance telecommunications services based here, said today that it would cut 15 percent of its work force, or about 231 jobs worldwide, to reduce costs. The company said it expected to report third-quarter revenues of about $105 million, up from the comparable period a year earlier but lower than had been expected. It also said it would report a negative third-quarter cash flow of $11 million to $12 million.

title: Gentle Memories of a Savage War
description: Small miracles can occur amid monstrous disasters. As evidence, one could cite ''In Their Shoes,'' which Kristin Jackson and Keiko Fujiie offered on Wednesday night at Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College.

title: Federal Aid Improved Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: GOLDSTEIN - Sidney. Beloved husband of the late Adele. Devoted father of Mark and Marcia, Eliot and Rochelle. Dear brother of Mac and Saul. Loving grandfather of Jacob, Michael and Alison. Services Wednesday, 10:15 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVISSON, WILLIAM HENRY PORTER
description: DAVISSON-William Henry Porter, 73, died peacefully at home in Marlboro, Vermont on October 9, 1998. Loving husband to Marion Eyre Davisson, father to Harry, stepfather to Ainslie Eyre Robertson, David Brian Robertson and Julia Anne Robertson-Davisson, grandfather to Catherine and Ariane Davisson-Boult all who mourn him. Service October 12 at St. Michaels Episcopal Church in Brattleboro, VT. Memorials to Marlboro College, Vermont Land Trust or World War II Memorial in Washington, DC in care of Covey & Allen Funeral Home, P.O. Box 215, Wilmington, VT. 05363.

title: BANKERS TRUST SHARES FALL AFTER RATINGS ARE CUT
description: The shares of the Bankers Trust Corporation fell after Fitch IBCA lowered its rating on the company's debt, citing concerns about earnings prospects. Bankers Trust's shares fell $4.625, to $54.25. Bankers Trust's ''medium-term business prospects are weaker than many of its peers,'' the agency said in its downgrade. Bankers Trust said it would report a loss for the third quarter, during which it lost $350 million in trading. The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its ratings on Bankers Trust late last month. Fitch IBCA lowered the long-term rating for Bankers Trust to A from A+.

title: Federal Aid Improved Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring Luster to a Dark Melodrama
description: The Lyric Opera of Chicago, which has been notably committed to performing contemporary operas, has come to the rescue of a nearly forgotten work, Martin David Levy's ''Mourning Becomes Electra.'' Commissioned and given its premiere by the Metropolitan Opera in 1967, it was produced two years later in Germany and then disappeared until the Lyric Opera's current production, which I attended on Friday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBBS, HAROLD
description: DOBBS-Harold. Devoted husband of the late Lila. Beloved father of Jonathan and Sharon Dobbs and Joanne and Richard Arfin. Dear brother of Jack Dobbs and Mary Ascher. Cherished grandfather of Katharine, Lesley, Jacob, Lila and Joshua. Services Wednesday, 9:30AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Give and Take
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: U.S. Balks at Cleanup of Hazardous Canal Zone Sites
description: For nearly a century, the United States military has used the jungle terrain surrounding the Panama Canal as a testing ground for explosives and chemical weapons. Now, a little more than a year before those ranges must be handed back to Panama, Washington is balking at cleaning up some of the most hazardous of the ordnance its troops are leaving behind.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Before Expanding, Sprucing Up Old Penn Station
description: A vast new concourse, crowned by a skylight and evoking the long-lost grandeur of rail travel, may be coming when Pennsylvania Station expands into the General Post Office across Eighth Avenue.

title: Mr. Vacco's Questionable Investigation
description: It is a familiar story under New York's flaccid campaign finance laws. Attorney General Dennis Vacco accepted campaign contributions from a company's executives and subsidiaries suspiciously close to the time of his settlement of complaints against the company. The settlement was far more favorable than a similar investigation of the same company eight years earlier under a previous Attorney General.

title: Pepsico Has Less-Than-Expected Income Gain of 1.8% in Quarter
description: Pepsico reported yesterday a less-than-expected 1.8 percent earnings rise in the third quarter, when it raised spending on marketing its snacks and revamped its beverage business.

title: Sharon and the P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: American Home Products' Deal With Monsanto Collapses
description: The American Home Products Corporation and the Monsanto Company scrapped their $34.4 billion merger yesterday, the third big combination in the pharmaceutical industry to fail this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ELIZABETH WATSON
description: MYERS-Elizabeth Watson. Died on October 9, 1998 in Menlo Park, California at 68 years of age. Educator, Counselor, Administrator at American University, Georgetown University & Syracuse University. Graduate of the University of Chicago. After residing in Washington, D.C. and New York City for many years, she moved with her husband to California in 1995. She is survived by her husband Robert J. Myers of Menlo Park, three children Timothy, Holly and Lauchlin, sons-in-law Kirk Neely and Mark Liebman, seven grandchildren, and a brother James D. Watson of Long Island. Contributions to her memory may be made to Citymeals-on-Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017, or other social service organizations reflecting her spirit of compassion and responsibility to those in need.

title: New York Team Moves to Hartford
description: After two losing seasons and poor attendance at Madison Square Garden, the New York CityHawks of the Arena Football League are moving to Hartford.

title: Bottles by Mail, From Brooks Brothers
description: BROOKS BROTHERS is getting into the wine business. But please, hold the jokes about buttoned-down merlot and pinstriped chardonnay.

title: We Could Be Wrong, but Isn't This October?
description: IT'S autumn in New York. A chill is nudging through the last trace of summer's warmth, and the leaves hint of turning. The signs can't be missed -- except, maybe, if you're a chef.

title: Reverberations of a Fading Boom
description: There are great advantages for New York in being the financial capital of the world. But there is a downside. When financial markets are roiled, and investors grow hesitant, Wall Street inevitably cuts back. Those cuts are likely to have a larger impact on the New York region than on other areas. It would be wise for city and state officials to start planning now for reduced tax revenues.

title: Kennelly, in Debate, Sees Two States, One Struggling
description: United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, who throughout her campaign for Connecticut governor has touched on many issues but never found a theme, tonight unified her concerns about the state's future by asserting that the prosperity trumpeted by Gov. John G. Rowland amounts to only half of ''a tale of two states.''

title: An Elusive Flavor of Greece
description: OF the eight Greek dessert choices on the menu at the midtown Manhattan restaurant Molyvos, the one ordered least is mastic ice cream with Commandaria and fig sauce.

title: Former Head of Manhattan H.M.O. Charged With Medicaid Fraud
description: The head of a Manhattan health maintenance organization hired by the city to provide medical care for the needy was arraigned yesterday on charges of defrauding the city and state out of $300,000 in Medicaid funds in 1996.

title: But Will It Play in Manhattan?
description: WHEN Eatzi's Market and Bakery opens its huge carryout food emporium in Macy's basement on Friday, it will inevitably be compared to places like Balducci's and Zabar's, those mythic cornucopias of culinary magnificence whose cramped but sprawling displays signify that New Yorkers are not only canny enough to demand the best but also willing to endure whatever it takes to get it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, JACK WILLIAM
description: PRINCE-Jack William, 52. Of Granby, CT. Beloved husband of Cathi-Lynne Ames. Died Saturday, Oct. 10, 1998 at his home. Along with his wife, he leaves his mother Margaret (Lloyd) Prince of Brighton, MA, two sisters Eileen Prince Lou of Newton, MA., Francine and Gonzalez of Queens NY. A service in his memory will be Sunday, October 18, 1998 at 3PM at the First Congregational Church in Granby, 219 North Granby Road, Granby. Memorial donations to the McLean Hospice, 75 Great Pond Road, Simsbury, CT. 06070.

title: Death Penalty Possible In Serial Killing Case
description: A man suspected in the serial killings of eight women was indicted by a grand jury yesterday on eight counts of first-degree murder, making the suspect eligible for the death penalty.

title: No Need for World Rate Cut, European Bank Chief Says
description: Despite growing anxiety that global financial problems might soon affect Europe, the president of the new European Central Bank rejected demands today to relax monetary policy in an effort to spur economic growth.

title: A Restaurant's Past Comes Back to Delight the Diner
description: RESTAURANTS come and restaurants go, but sometimes if you are lucky, the chefs and owners stay the same. Such is the case with Siena, an Italian restaurant that opened a month ago at the address where Luma used to be.

title: Ramirez: Big Bat, Blunders
description: The Indians' Manny Ramirez has become the answer to the old Sesame Street brain teaser: one of these things doesn't belong.

title: The Mashed Potato, With Attitude
description: COMFORT food -- that buzz phrase embracing all the bland, soft satisfactions of childhood eating -- doesn't quite have the cachet now that it did a few years ago, when restaurants everywhere were trying to outdo each other in the evocation of home and hearth.

title: WORLD ACCESS DROPS PRICE IT WILL PAY FOR TELCO SYSTEMS
description: World Access Inc., a maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it had lowered the price it would pay for Telco Systems Inc. to at least $12 a share in cash and stock, from $17 a share, all in stock, under the agreement announced June 4. The total price was listed as about $187 million in June; at $12 a share, it is about $133 million. World Access shares have dropped 54 percent since the agreement was announced. They rose $1.6875 yesterday, to $15.3125, in Nasdaq trading. World Access, based in Atlanta, said it must pay a minimum of 45 percent of the purchase price in stock to guarantee tax-free status for the acquisition. Shares of Telco Systems, which is based in Norwood, Mass., jumped $3.50 yesterday, to $9.875.

title: Prototype of Peace via Trade in Gaza
description: The grandly named Gaza Industrial Estate, an unprepossessing 120-acre collection of vacant factory sheds and water towers rising from the ragged flatlands east of Gaza City, is an unlikely focus for the highly charged, high-stakes Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELMAN, SAM
description: FOGELMAN-Sam. The International Network of Children of Jewish Holocaust Survivors mourns the death of the beloved father of Eva and Gila. May his legacy of resistance and remembrance and love for his family be an inspiration and blessing.

title: O Canada, Land of Few Banks; The Industry Seeks Mergers, but Consumers Are Wary
description: John E. Cleg horn showed what a formidable competitor he can be when he played center on the McGill University football team that won the intercollegiate championship in 1960. Now that he is chairman of the Royal Bank of Canada, the country's largest, and campaigning vigorously for Government approval to make it a lot larger by merging with the Bank of Montreal, he is acting as though he still thinks no one can get past him.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RALLIES TO A 10-WEEK HIGH. Prices rose after the Agriculture Secretary, Dan Glickman, talked about a food aid package for Russia. The December contract increased 8 cents, to $2.28 a bushel.

title: DAYTON HUDSON MAY SELL OR SPIN OFF MERVYN'S STORES
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation may get rid of its Mervyn's unit, a chain of 269 department stores selling midpriced merchandise, unless Mervyn's improves sales in 12 to 18 months. Dayton Hudson, the fifth-largest United States retailer, declined to say if it would sell or spin off Mervyn's, which accounts for about 15 percent of annual sales. Sales at Mervyn's stores open at least a year have fallen from totals at the same time last year. Analysts have been calling on Dayton Hudson to sell Mervyn's so that it can focus on expanding its highly profitable Target discount stores. Shares of Dayton Hudson, which is based in Minneapolis, rose $1.375 each, to $38.75.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARKIN, MILTON
description: BARKIN-Milton. After twenty years, we still revere and cherish our father's and grandfather's memory. Love remains. Your Children and Grandchildren

title: When a Killer Blames His Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: When Money Is Everything, Except Hers
description: Watching classmates strut past in designer clothes, Wendy Williams sat silently on the yellow school bus, wearing a cheap belt and rummage-sale slacks.

title: Legislator Says Mayor Tried to Run Him Down
description: State Senator Bernard Kenny yesterday accused Mayor Anthony Russo, a neighbor and fellow Democrat, of trying to run him over with his sport utility truck on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, MAUD (NEE KEISTER)
description: JENSEN-Maud (nee Keister). Of Madison, NJ, on Monday, October 12, 1998. Wife of the late Anders Kristian Jensen. Mother of Philip Jensen and his wife Cathy. She is also survived by three grandsons, Kris, Scott and Randy Jensen. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Interment will take place in Korea. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in her name be made to the United Methodist Church, 24 Madison Avenue, Madison, N.J. 07940.

title: Unloved Car-Pool Lanes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEHR, I.E. THEODORE (AKA ROBERT ALLEN)
description: BAEHR - I.E. Theodore (aka Robert Allen). On Oct. 9th, 1998, age 92. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn Pierce, dearly loved father of Katherine (Charles) Meyer, and Theodore (Liliana) Baehr. Beloved grandfather of seven and great grandfather of six. Funeral service will held Friday, Oct. 16, 1998 at 2 P.M. at The First Presbyterian Church, Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Christian Film and TV Commission, 2510-6 Los Pasos Road, Camarillo, CA. 93010.

title: About New York; Old King Pong May Be Down, But Not Out
description: MARTY REISMAN hunkered down and inspected the table tennis net. Wearing a purple shirt, red pants and a Panama hat, he looked like a retiree going to the deli for a nosh. But the $100 bill he held in his hand made it clear he wasn't about to retire anywhere. He folded the bill and held it against the net to check its height. It had to be exact.

title: For World's Women, Progress and Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Lower House Clears $508 Billion Bank Rescue
description: The lower house of the Japanese Parliament passed a bill today that would allow the Government to inject huge amounts of money into the nation's weakened banks, moving Japan closer to the start of repairs on its banking system after months of political wrangling.

title: Schumer Assails D'Amato Over High Speaking Fees
description: In one of his sharpest attacks yet on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's ethics, Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic candidate for Senate, accused his opponent yesterday of ''lining his pockets'' with $390,000 in speaking fees from large corporations and other special-interest groups that had legislation pending before Congress between 1981 and 1991.

title: Bank of Japan to Stay With Monetary Policy
description: Japan's central bank will maintain its current monetary policy, the bank said yesterday, countering expectations of steps to expand the money supply. Bank of Japan policy makers voted to keep the bank's discount rate at a record low five-tenths of 1 percent and its target for the interbank overnight loan rate at an all-time low of a quarter of 1 percent.

title: Giants' Problems Predictable, Just Slow in Coming
description: The Giants' offensive line lacks depth and cohesion, the young starting quarterback has little pro experience to fall back on, the head coach is still trying to establish himself, and there are serious injuries threatening the team's long-term production.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ST. JOE CORP., -- Jacksonville. Fla., a real estate developer, agreed to acquire the assets of Prudential Network Realty, a real estate services company also based in Jacksonville. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: U.N. Tries to Cajole Iraq Into Cooperating on Arms Inspections
description: The Security Council called on Iraq today to resume cooperation with United Nations weapon inspectors, alluding to prospects for faster progress on easing economic sanctions against Baghdad if it heeds the call.

title: A Bankruptcy Crisis?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells's Jets Slipping Up In Stepping-Stone Games
description: Bill Parcells can still vividly recall the games when the teams that he had previously coached reached a turning point -- when the Giants and the New England Patriots suddenly believed that they could be contenders and replaced rhetoric with performance.

title: To Weaken Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef
description: WHEN I opened my own pastry shop last year, I wanted the selection of pastries, cakes and chocolates to be so dazzling that people would not only have trouble deciding what to taste first, but also wonder how everything was made. Most of what we do at the shop is pretty complicated, and after all, if everyone could make these sweets at home, who'd need us?

title: Calendar
description: Far From the Pumpkin Patch

title: London Journal; Has England Lost Its Identity? Or Just Its Cliches?
description: The English, past masters at turning the raised eyebrow and the cold shoulder on others, are suddenly feeling looked down upon and left out in their own land.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hurt by Market Swoon, Merrill Lynch to Cut Jobs

title: Justice Apologizes To TV Commentator
description: On Monday, David Justice of Cleveland blasted ESPN's Peter Gammons for post-game remarks that Justice said the baseball analyst made about his absence from the Indians' lineup for Game 5. Justice said he never asked out of the lineup. Justice then demanded an apology from Gammons.

title: Alcatel of France To Buy Packet Engines
description: Alcatel S.A., one of the world's largest makers of telephone equipment, agreed late on Monday to buy the closely held Packet Engines Inc. for $315 million to broaden its line of computer networking products and attract American customers. Packet Engines, based in Spokane, Wash., makes powerful switches for corporate networks and has its European headquarters in France.

title: Cruel and Unusual
description: Executing a mentally impaired person for a crime committed while still a juvenile does not serve the interests of justice. Gov. James Gilmore of Virginia should recognize that as he weighs the clemency application of Dwayne Allen Wright, who is scheduled to be executed this evening by lethal injection.

title: Unlikely Star Sparks Aggies
description: His mother escaped a bombing raid on her Vietnamese village when she was pregnant with him. He was born in an Arkansas refugee camp. An now Dat Nguyen is a star linebacker. Nguyen added another unlikely chapter to his story last Saturday when he helped the Aggies upset Nebraska, then ranked No. 2.

title: Robert Allen, 92, Texas Ranger in Westerns
description: Robert Allen, a Dartmouth-trained actor whose youthful experience playing polo, hunting foxes and riding in the cavalry at a military academy helped him land the role of the original Texas Ranger in 1930's westerns, died on Friday in Oyster Bay, N.Y. He was 92.

title: Report Finds Girls Lagging Behind Boys In Technology
description: Although high school girls have been catching up to boys in math and science achievement over the last six years, there is a serious gender gap in technology, according to the latest report on girls' education by the American Association of University Women Educational Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILKESON, ELIZABETH C.
description: GILKESON-Elizabeth C. The Trustees, administration, faculty, staff, students and alumni of Bank Street College of Education mourn the passing of Elizabeth C. Gilkeson. For more than forty years, she played a significant role in developing many of the major programs that characterize the College. As Founding Director of the Bank Street School for Children, an innovative, progressive school serving children from two to thirteen, she developed an approach that is still in action. In the 1960's, she and her colleagues sponsored and administered the Polly Miller Day Care Center, and she directed a National Headstart Demonstration Program at the Early Childhood Family Resources Center. As the Director of the Bank Street component of the then Office of Education's National Follow Through Programs, Mrs. Gilkeson traveled the country to develop & implement the Bank Street approach in fourteen coummunities. After her official retirement in the 1970's, she remained active in both Follow Through and Bank Street College. An innovative leader, her work manifests itself in the educational practices of the students, teachers and administrators with whom she worked. The entire Bank Street community joins together in offering condolences to Mrs. Gilkeson's grandchildren and great grandchildren. Augusta Souza Kappner, President Elizabeth S. Pforzheimer, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 12 about recently discovered paintings by Francis Bacon included a client erroneously among those represented by John Eastman, lawyer for the Bacon estate. Though he is a co-executor of the estate of the artist Willem de Kooning, Mr. Eastman does not represent it; John Silberman does.

title: McCall and Opponent Urge New Restrictions on Political Gifts
description: The New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and his Republican opponent, Bruce A. Blakeman, announced competing plans yesterday that each said would improve the perception of state government by placing new restrictions on political giving.

title: General Motors Posts Loss of $809 Million
description: The General Motors Corporation lost $809 million in the third quarter, mainly because of a nearly eight-week-long strike that ended on July 29 and crippled G.M.'s production in North America, the auto maker announced today.

title: For World's Women, Progress and Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: HELLER AGREES TO BUY DANA EQUIPMENT-LEASING BUSINESS
description: Heller Financial Inc., a commercial lender, agreed yesterday to buy a $700 million loan portfolio from a unit of the Dana Corporation, an auto-parts maker, to expand its equipment-leasing business. Dana, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, is selling the part of its Dana Commercial Credit Corporation unit that finances leases on certain computers and office equipment. Terms were not disclosed. Heller, with assets of $13 billion, is based in Chicago and specializes in providing financing for small and midsize businesses. The acquisition will expand its business in Europe and Canada.

title: 5 Quantum Theorists Share 2 Nobel Prizes in Sciences
description: Quantum theory, in its most arcane and practical guises, was the focus of the Nobel Prizes in Physics and Chemistry announced yesterday by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. The three winners of the physics prize and the two winners of the chemistry award are all university professors in the United States.

title: Investor Seeks Seat on Loewen's Board
description: An investment group led by Thomas Taylor has formally requested a board seat at Loewen Group Inc., the struggling Canadian funeral services company.

title: Potato Play: Getting It Perfect
description: THERE are those who love their mashed potatoes lumpy, and those who prefer them ultra silky. I'm a classicist: to me, the perfect mashed potatoes are smooth and thickly creamy, but not overly buttered, with a definite potato flavor.

title: New Radio Network Set for Fox News
description: Fox News said yesterday that it would join Westwood One Inc. to create a new radio network as its parent, the News Corporation, prepares to take its entertainment holdings public.

title: Microsoft Rebuttal Reinterprets Old E-Mail
description: In its latest pretrial salvo, the Microsoft Corporation issued a 40-page document yesterday that attempts to refute the Government's antitrust case -- a case that Microsoft asserts is based on ''a handful of snippets'' quoted ''misleadingly'' from among the 3.3 million pages of E-mail and memos the company handed over to the Justice Department.

title: L.I.R.R. Commuters' Top Gripes: Noisy Laptops and Cell Phones
description: Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road have long complained about litter in the trains and people who take up more than one seat. But a recent poll has found a new complaint to top the list: the noisy gadgets of the information age.

title: Diagnoses and the Autopsies Are Found to Differ Greatly
description: A new study has found a substantial discrepancy between the number of cancers detected during life and those found in autopsies. Despite advances in medical technology, the disparity between the diagnosis of cancer before and after death was 44 percent, similar to that found in studies conducted in earlier decades, said the authors.

title: Review/Fashion; Galliano's Dance for Dior
description: The only vision more disturbing than the Goth panorama that Olivier Theyskens displayed in his spectacular show yesterday was the suggestion of the return of wasp waists and full skirts a la Dior. And where else were backward-looking fashions like these shown? In the Dior salon on the Avenue Montaigne, of course, in blazing yellow suits with skirts held girlishly aloft by horsehair linings.

title: Moviefone Licensing Deal
description: Moviefone Inc., a seller of movie tickets over the telephone and the Internet, signed a long-term licensing and service agreement yesterday with United Artists Theater Circuit for its Mars ticket-sale system. Moviefone, based in New York, said the deal would bring the system, which can sell tickets through Moviefone and Movielink.com, as well as at automatic-ticketing machines in theater lobbies, to more than 275 United Artists theaters within the next 18 months. United Artists, based in Denver, is owned by the Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst investment firm.

title: Veterinarian Accused of Assisting In Suicide of Friend With Cancer
description: An Upper East Side veterinarian was arrested yesterday and charged with helping a friend and former receptionist commit suicide last year as she lay in the hospital gravely ill with breast cancer.

title: Saving Lives in Kosovo
description: Peace and reconciliation are not coming to Kosovo, but at least the displacement and killing of civilians may abate under an agreement reached with Slobodan Milosevic. The deal, arranged by Richard Holbrooke, the American envoy, can save lives if it is vigorously enforced by the United States and its European allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVOK, RUTH J. (NEE SIEGMEISTER)
description: NOVOK-Ruth J. (nee Siegmeister). Of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of New York, beloved wife of the late Daniel A., adored mother of Barbara J. Klein, and Gail-ellen Goldberg. Precious mother to Marc Goldberg and the late Robert J. Klein, cherished grandmother of Karen, Gary, Bruce, and Allison, loving great grandmother. Her energy, intellect, elegance, grace, and beauty will forever inspire us. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Church Urged To Do More For Women In Leadership
description: A committee of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops declared yesterday that the church authorities ought to do more to promote qualified women to positions of lay leadership in the church, thereby increasing the ranks of those who serve in such jobs as hospital administrators, school superintendents and even chancellors of dioceses.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: They Look Like Olives And Taste Like Big Kiwis

title: U.S. Unveils Plan to Revamp South Florida Water Supply and Save Everglades
description: The Army Corps of Engineers today released a plan to transform South Florida's fresh water supply and restore some of the flow of the Everglades -- ''the River of Grass'' -- to the course it followed for centuries.

title: When a Killer Blames His Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vocals, Strings and Aspects of Rock
description: In the right context, with a solid band, David Byrne's uncomfortable jerkiness of movement and voice can provide a pleasurable tension of opposites. But on Thursday night at the Knitting Factory, as he presented a new band that combines his vocals and guitar with the singer Christina Wheeler, a rock rhythm section and Alexander Balanescu's chamber-music string quartet, his voice seemed only a trembly symbol for the instability of the performance.

title: For World's Women, Progress and Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGNER, ROSE (NEE GRENADIER)
description: BERGNER-Rose (nee Grenadier). Died September 18, 1998 in La Jolla, Ca. Widow of Harold A. Bergner, M.D. Devoted mother of Elaine Schneider. Grandmother of Danielle and Jane Schneider. Great-grandmother of Rachel Eaton. Cherished sister of George and Simon Grenadier. Her family including many loving nieces and nephews will remember her kindness, generosity and humor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORROW, STEVE
description: MORROW-Steve. We are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of dear friend, Founder and Honorary President of the New Cracow Friendship Society. Our heartfelt sympathy to his sons Alex and Stanley, brothers Zigmund and Roman and their families. New Cracow Friendship Society

title: Young Offender Faces Death, And State Is Urged to Halt It
description: Virginia plans on Wednesday to execute a man who was 17 when he fatally shot a woman in 1989, in a case that has drawn wide criticism of the use of capital punishment for juvenile offenders.

title: Bilingual for Its Own Sake; School Teaches Chinese Not as Step to English, but as Equal
description: Michelle Leung's kindergarten classroom at Public School 184 on the Lower East Side looks much like any other, with a few hard-to-miss exceptions.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Merger Falls Apart

title: Rating Up a Bit For Game 5
description: The Atlanta Braves' 7-6 victory over the Padres in San Diego on Monday night in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series produced a 9.5 Nielsen rating for Fox, up 1 percent from a 9.4 for Game 5 of last season's A.L.C.S., which it carried.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about a merger plan by Daimler-Benz Aerospace and British Aerospace misstated the proposed completion date, and the headline referred incorrectly to the status of the plan. The companies said they intended to merge as soon as possible, not necessarily early next year. The plan remains under discussion; it has not been confirmed.

title: Oil-Dumping Charge For Royal Caribbean
description: One month after Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. pleaded guilty to felony charges in the dumping of oil near Miami and near San Juan, P.R., and agreed to pay $9 million in fines and penalties, one of its ships dumped oil in July, Federal prosecutors say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, LEONARD ISRAEL, MD.
description: KLEINMAN-Leonard Israel, MD. 63. On October 8, 1998. Loving son of Lillian and Abraham, MD (Z''); husband to Yorkette; father to Jonathan, David, MD and Miriam; father-in-law to Deborah, MD and Iris; grandfather to Liron and Daniel; brother to Sylvia Grossfeld. Physician, scientist, teacher, Professor of Pediatrics at U. of Cincinnati (1967-1983), Director of Neonatology at SUNY-Stonybrook (1983-1997). Shiva starting Tuesday evening, October 13. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Leonard I. Kleinman, MD, Pediatric Research Library or the Neonatal ICU Development Fund at SUNYSB Medical School.

title: High Schools Tackle Marital Skills, Igniting a Debate
description: As conservatives and liberals alike have come to agree on the importance of marriage and the need to strengthen families, a growing number of high schools across the country are requiring students to undergo marriage education.

title: Republicans Meet Aides To Clinton On I.M.F.
description: The Clinton Administration and Congressional Republican leaders met today to hammer out the final details of compromise legislation that would provide the International Monetary Fund with $18 billion in exchange for new restrictions on its loans to foreign governments.

title: Echoes of Bosnia
description: The agreement on Kosovo seems fraught with the dangers that have long bedeviled the West in Bosnia. News Analysis, page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: GOLDSTEIN - Sidney. Beloved husband of the late Adele. Devoted father of Mark and Marcia, Eliot and Rochelle. Dear brother of Mac and Saul. Loving grandfather of Jacob, Michael and Alison. Services Wednesday, 10:15 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: When a Killer Blames His Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pickets, Pro and Con, for Play Premiere
description: Chanting prayers and waving placards with messages like ''Blasphemous filth is not art,'' an estimated 2,000 people gathered outside City Center last night to protest the opening performance of ''Corpus Christi,'' the Terrence McNally play about a gay Christ-like figure.

title: People Determined To Have Their Say
description: ''Binlids'' has a job to do and attempts to get it done with the fervor and singleness of purpose of a political campaign. In two somber hours, the play, written and performed by residents of West Belfast, tells the story of three decades of bloodshed and anguish in which the conflict in Northern Ireland, known as the troubles, has engulfed their hardscrabble community.

title: Quantum Experts Win Nobel Prizes
description: Research on the interaction of atoms and molecules won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry yesterday and the physics prize was awarded for work involving a bizarre form of electrons.

title: Ford to Produce Gearless Car Transmission
description: The Ford Motor Company announced plans today for mass production of a new, gearless car transmission to be produced in a joint venture that could also become a new model for labor relations in the auto industry.

title: Merrill Lynch to Cut 3,400 Jobs In Big Setback for New York City
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 3,400 jobs, or just more than 5 percent of its work force, because of global economic turmoil.

title: AVONDALE AND COAL CITY BANKING COMPANIES TO MERGE
description: The Avondale Financial Corporation has agreed to merge with the Coal City Corporation, creating a banking company with assets of $1.4 billion. Shares of Avondale surged $1.50 each, to $10.50, in Nasdaq trading. Avondale Financial, the holding company for Avondale Federal Savings Bank, has five banking offices and assets of $520.1 million. Coal City is the closely held parent of Manufacturer's Bank and Trust, with eight offices and assets of $800 million. Avondale will be the surviving entity and will be renamed MB Financial Inc. Avondale shareholders will own 41.5 percent of the new holding company. Both companies are based in Chicago.

title: Eating Well; Success for New Federal Standards on Meat and Poultry
description: THE Federal Government's new system for reducing contamination in meat and poultry appears to be having positive results. Two weeks ago, the Agriculture Department announced that the system has almost cut in half the number of broiler chickens contaminated with salmonella in the plants where it is in use. It has also greatly reduced the amount of salmonella-infected pork.

title: Thatcher's Handbag for the Ages?
description: Margaret Thatcher's handbag, an often-noted symbol of her swaggering power when she was Prime Minister, may be enshrined in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHONHORN, ANNA (NEE STOLZBERG)
description: SHONHORN-Anna (nee Stolzberg). At age 94, on October 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Devoted mother of Rita Levik. Cherished grandmother of Carol and Elliot DeBear and Richard Levik. Loving great grandmother of Jesse and Hannah. Services Wednesday 11:30AM, at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: Political Memo; Day of Adulation in Life of a Dues-Paying Mayor
description: He began yesterday by reading a children's book about his homeric mayoral stamina to a cluster of adoring schoolchildren in Manhattan, then ended it by attending the New York Yankees playoff game in the Bronx. But in between, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani managed to make a 90-mile side trip -- not to one of the city's other three boroughs, but to Bethlehem, Pa., a tired steel city in the Lehigh Valley.

title: Devils and Niedermayer Inch Closer
description: The Devils will play their home opener against Pittsburgh Wednesday night without Scott Niedermayer, but the talented defenseman could be playing with the team by the end of the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, JOSEPH J.
description: SANDLER-Joseph J. International Universities Press mourns the death of our esteemed author, Joseph J. Sandler, and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife, Anne-Marie Sandler and his family. He was a noted psychoanalyst with an extensive international following and a prolific writer in the field of psychoanalysis. Among his 11 books he published with International Universities Press are ''Freud's Models of the Mind, Analysis of Defense'', and ''The Patient and the Analyst''. He will be deeply missed by all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. October 10, 1998. Faithful husband of Joan BrandtCates. Loving father of Phillip, Valerie, Phoebe and Alexandra Cates and stepfather of Wilson Brandt. Adoring grandfather of Owen Joseph and Greta Simone Kline. Devoted brother of Gil Cates and Kit Adler. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 15, 6-9PM with service Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Friars Foundation, Inc., 57 E. 55 St, NY, NY 10022.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Do you know what it's like to have your daughter come home and say, 'Mom, the kids say my clothes are tacky,' and then walk off with her head hanging low?''

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Uncle Miltie Is 90

title: An Estranged Williams Gets Comfortable at Bat
description: Bernie Williams has been extremely aloof during the post-season, so distant that Manager Joe Torre had a private meeting with him and so distant that General Manager Brian Cashman and other Yankee officials have been repeatedly quizzed about it. Torre acknowledged that Williams, who is usually quiet and introspective, has not been himself. Even Williams basically conceded it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINBERG, MILTON (MICKEY)
description: SCHEINBERG-Milton (Mickey). Beloved husband of Sylvia, father of Linda and Tina. Grandfather of five. Great-grandfather of six. Lover of music, legendary manager of Manhattan's Park East Lounge. He'll be missed by all.

title: New Laws Won't Stop Hate
description: I don't know what ''the answer'' is to stopping horrific crimes like the murder of Matthew Shepard, the gay University of Wyoming student, or whether there is an answer. But I am certain that the State of Wyoming did not invite or contribute to the crime by having an inadequate criminal code. The alleged perpetrators face capital murder charges and the death penalty. Yet politicians (including President Clinton) and gay activists say that the tragedy demonstrates a need for more state and Federal ''hate crime'' laws. Such calls are well-meaning but misguided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, LORNA CHRISTENSEN,
description: BLACK-Lorna Christensen, 53. Of St. Louis, Missouri, formerly of Bronxville, New York. Daughter of Gladys and Harold Christensen. 1967 graduate of Sweet Briar College. She is survived by Dameron Black and their children Emily and Ned of St. Louis, her father, Harold Christensen, of Boynton Beach, Florida, and her sister, Linda Graham of White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Unity Health Hospice Memorial Fund, 13645 Shoreline Drive, St. Louis, MO. 63045.

title: Earthbound or Skyborne In a Dance of Playfulness
description: The choreographer James Kudelka is to be envied. As director of the National Ballet of Canada, Mr. Kudelka has at his disposal a troupe of vital, beautifully schooled, personable young dancers, several of whom took on new roles on Friday night at City Center.

title: In Balkans Again, Promises, Promises
description: Through forceful if belated diplomacy, the Clinton Administration has won enormous concessions from the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic. But the agreement announced today on Kosovo, the embattled province in southern Serbia, seems fraught with the dangers that have long bedevilled the West in Bosnia.

title: U.S. Postpones American Airlines Hearing
description: The United States Government said last week that it would postpone a long-awaited hearing on a proposed alliance between American Airlines, which is a unit of the AMR Corporation, and British Airways, citing a lack of progress during air treaty talks between the United States and Britain.

title: Clinton Presses Yugoslavs As NATO's Role Is Hailed
description: In an effort to keep up pressure on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, President Clinton today demanded he make serious progress in complying with an agreement to end the crackdown in Kosovo.

title: ISLANDERS
description: Fox Sports New York will not carry tonight's Islanders-Tampa Bay game because it is being played at the same time as the Devils-Pittsburgh game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, GLORIA (NEE MUSSENDEN)
description: JACKSON-Gloria (nee Mussenden) of Gloria Jackson Dance Studio, Jamaica, NY on October 11, 1998. Wake service: Thursday, October 15, 1998, 6-9 P.M. Funeral service: Friday, October 16, 1998, 10A.M. Both services will be held at St. Albans Congregational Church, 172-17 Linden Blvd., St. Albans, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers to National Cancer Society. For information J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, Inc. (718) 526-5656.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERTLER, RUTH
description: GERTLER-Ruth. Cherished wife of the late Sheldon, devoted mother of Robert (Jessie), Diane Kaye (Kenney), Jo-Ann (Bill McDermott) and Brian (Jane). Dear sister of Joyce. Special grandma of Ian (Jenny), Shawn, Darren, DJ, Brad, Ryan, Steven, Tracy, Sherie and Glenn. Services today, 10AM, Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGEMAN, REV. DR. LYNN L.
description: HAGEMAN-Rev. Dr. Lynn L. Forty years ago, Dan Wakefield, in his striking challenge to the conscience of this Town, issued his poignant narrative of crushing poverty and abandonment on just one City Block, 101st Street off First Avenue. It was his 'Island in the Sun.' One figure stood almost alone in the dust of that Block's agony, Rev. Lynn Hageman. And Exodus House, the by-product of that Block's agony, stands so proudly as a monument to Lynn's indomitable spirit in holding out the branch of safety when droves of the abandoned, addicted young were being swept downstream. Will we ever see his like again? Alexander Pope in his 'Essay on Man' wrote: ''Who sees with equal eye, as God of all, a hero perish or a sparrow fall?'' A New York Hero, indeed! May Heaven welcome him home! And may his beloved Leola and his Family feel our prayerful support! (Msgr) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc

title: Ousted Italian Prime Minister Announces He Will Try Again
description: Acting Prime Minister Romano Prodi said tonight that he would try to form a government, four days after he was ousted after narrowly losing a confidence vote.

title: Journal; The Road to Laramie
description: On the same day Americans learned last week that Matthew Shepard, a 5-foot-2, 105-pound gay college student, had been tortured, strung up like an animal and left to die on a fence outside Laramie, Wyo., the Family Research Council was co-hosting a press conference in Washington. It was the latest salvo in a six-month campaign by the religious right, with the tacit, even explicit, approval of Republican leaders, to demonize gay people for political gain in this election year.

title: Padres to Save Brown, Start Hitchcock Today
description: If he had it to do again, Bruce Bochy wouldn't change a thing. Other than the result, that is.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Beyond Living by Beer Alone
description: I'VE never quite understood the term ''beer drinker.'' Does it mean someone who drinks only beer, or can you qualify if you also drink water, wine, coffee, tea and milk? And more, is there another, new category, the boutique-only beer drinker?

title: Mental Tests Ordered In Parent Poisoning Case
description: A brother and sister who were arrested Saturday for trying to poison their parents by putting a household cleaner into iced tea were ordered by a judge to undergo psychological testing yesterday, the Burlington County Prosecutor's Office said.

title: To Save Money, Miami Herald Will Close Its Sunday Magazine
description: In the most painful of a series of recent belt-tightening moves, The Miami Herald's top editors said yesterday that the newspaper's Sunday feature magazine, Tropic, would close before year's end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBBS, HAROLD
description: DOBBS-Harold. The Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Harold Dobbs and extend our deepest sympathy to his son Jonathan and daughter Joanne Arfin and their families. Joel M. Simon, President

title: Ethics Inquiry Delays a Career
description: The diplomatic career of Richard C. Holbrooke, who brokered the Kosovo accord, remains in the hands of Justice Department lawyers who are investigating whether he violated Federal ethics rules.

title: Nice Young Man and Disciples Appeal for Tolerance
description: The excitement stops right after the metal detectors.

title: For 35th Time, Yankees Reach the World Series
description: Ghosts have hung over Yankee Stadium all season, David Cone once remarked, as the Yankees pursued their place among the greatest baseball teams in history. But other ghosts haunted them, ghosts of the very recent past, until the Yankees won the American League championship last night with a 9-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians in Game 6.

title: Next Stop: Brazil
description: The financial crisis that swept through Asia and Russia has turned its gale-force winds on Brazil. Reports from Washington indicate that an emergency bailout of $30 billion or more is being cobbled together to help fend off the storm. Unfortunately, the policies that will likely form the core of the package -- shoring up Brazil's overvalued currency through International Monetary Fund loans, tight credit and budget cuts -- could condemn Brazil to follow Asia and Russia into deep recession.

title: Bell Atlantic Expects $1.1 Billion in Charges
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it expected to take third-quarter charges of $1.1 billion, or 70 cents a share, for an early retirement plan and for a write-off of some assets.

title: Fraud Scheme Involving 91 Is Broken Up, Officials Say
description: An insurance fraud ring that involved 91 people and scores of fictitious injury claims from eight van accidents has been broken up, the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office said today.

title: Gunmen Kill Israeli; Peace Deal in Doubt
description: Two days before an Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting near Washington, gunmen believed to be Palestinian militants shot and killed an Israeli and seriously wounded another today as they bathed in a hillside spring outside Jerusalem.

title: The Coen brothers spoof TV programming in new spots selling Honda's redesigned minivan.
description: VIEWERS of television shows like ''The Practice'' and ''Law and Order'' may be momentarily confused next month when the American Honda Motor Company starts a $50 million advertising campaign for its new Odyssey minivan.

title: Intel Beats Expectations On Strong Demand for Chips
description: Buoyed by vibrant demand for microprocessors, the Intel Corporation reported unexpectedly strong third-quarter results today.

title: Man With a History, in a House With a Past
description: IT was the construction workers, sitting around half-filled glasses at the Ear Inn tavern on the river-soaked western fringes of SoHo, who first noticed that there might be a problem with the old building. The state was planning to lay a new water main beneath Spring Street, they said, and with the vibrations of the backhoes and the jackhammers, and the clang of steel plates, the ancient timbers would be lucky to remain standing.

title: Spy Agencies' Ex-Analyst Charged With Selling Secrets to Soviets
description: A former code-breaking analyst at the top-secret National Security Agency was charged today with spying for Moscow for the last three years of the Soviet Union's existence.

title: NABISCO MARGARINE BRANDS COST CONAGRA $400 MILLION
description: Conagra Inc. paid $400 million to buy several brands of margarine from the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, according to a regulatory filing. The price was not disclosed when the sale was announced in July. Conagra bought Fleischmann's, Parkay, Blue Bonnet, Touch of Butter, Chiffon and Move Over Butter margarines as well as Egg Beaters egg substitutes. The purchase made Conagra, based in Omaha, one of the largest makers of table spreads in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, FRANCIS M.
description: WALSH-Francis M. 74. Of Boca Raton, FL and Jericho, NY died on October 10, 1998 in Boca Raton. W.W. II veteran served in the 20th Air Force in Saipan. Received B.S. degree from Fordham University and graduate of Columbia School of Law J.D. in 1950. Retired as General Claims Attorney for Long Island Lighting in Mineola. Survived by wife, Frances Garvey Walsh; daughter, Marianne and son, Patrick. Visiting hours at Dalton Funeral Home in Hicksville. Funeral Mass is on Saturday, October 17th at St. Paul The Apostle at 9:45 A.M. Burial at Cemetery of the Holy Cross in Brooklyn.

title: When a Killer Blames His Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Are Irked at Industry Group's Hiring of Democrat
description: In an aggressive push to enforce greater Republican loyalty among Washington lobbying groups, Representative Tom DeLay, the majority whip, has urged the Electronic Industries Alliance to reconsider its hiring of a Democrat to serve as president.

title: DEAL BETWEEN DUKE ENERGY AND DYNEGY INC. IS CANCELED
description: Duke Energy Corporation said yesterday that it would not buy Texas and Oklahoma oil pipeline and sales operations from Dynegy Inc. because the companies were unable to agree on contract terms. Duke Energy, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., and is a leading seller of electricity and natural gas in the Southeastern United States, had agreed in July to pay about $55 million for the Dynegy assets. The assets include an 1,850-mile pipeline system as well as 700,000 barrels of oil-storage capacity in Cushing, Okla. Dynegy, a Houston-based seller of natural gas and electricity, may still try to sell the unit.
