Shares in Duke Energy rose $2, to $66.4375, and Dynegy's stock rose 12.5 cents, to $12.5625, both on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Takeout, Puccini and Chutzpah: Eatzi's Takes On Manhattan
description: IT'S not a restaurant. It's not a grocery store. It's Eatzi's Market and Bakery, the food store that ate Dallas. Now, in the boldest out-of-town incursion since George Steinbrenner bought the Yankees, it has planted its cowboy boots right in Macy's basement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 12 about recently discovered paintings by Francis Bacon included a client erroneously among those represented by John Eastman, lawyer for the Bacon estate. Though he is a co-executor of the estate of the artist Willem de Kooning, Mr. Eastman does not represent it; John Silberman does.

title: Judge Rebuffs Bid to Intervene In Yankee Vote
description: With the election three weeks away, a Federal judge declined last night to intervene in the politically charged battle over whether a referendum aimed at keeping the Yankees in the Bronx will be submitted to New York City voters.

title: Doing Penance After a Flop
description: NBC got some punishing news for its first big movie project of the season, an adaptation of the Dostoyevsky classic ''Crime and Punishment,'' which drew ratings so frigid that the network may send several of the other literary works on its development list to Siberia.

title: A Humbled Cendant Calls Off $3.1 Billion American Bankers Deal
description: Seven months and a lot of accounting problems after the Cendant Corporation beat out the big insurer American International Group in a bruising battle to buy the American Bankers Insurance Group, Cendant announced yesterday that the $3.1 billion deal was off.

title: BankAmerica Hedge Fund Loss Expected
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest bank, is expected to announce a big hedge fund loss today in the latest example of the dangers posed to financial companies from the risky, sometimes high-flying investment pools.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar gained for a second day against the Japanese yen as skepticism increased that officials in Tokyo would quickly carry out a relief plan for ailing banks. The dollar rose to 119.15 yen, from 118.10 on Monday.

title: Ogilvy Atlanta Wins William Carter Account
description: The William Carter Company, the children's apparel maker in Morrow, Ga., said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather Atlanta to handle its account, which had been handled since 1993 by Sietsma Engel in Minneapolis, now closed. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, EDMOND A.
description: LEVY-Edmond A. Beloved husband of Denise died Sat., October 10, 1998. Loving father of Jonathan and Jeremy; loving stepfather of Stephen, William & Peter Judson; dear brother of Kay Michaels; and cherished grandfather of Sierra, Akash & Ishan. Memorial celebration to be announced. Donations in memory of Ed to: Visiting Nurse Service of NY-Hospice Program; American Cancer Society; Prasad Project, South Fallsburg, NY, and The Museum of Jewish Heritage of New York City.

title: The Swagger Appears Dull For Alomar and the Indians
description: Sandy Alomar's body language told the story of how this playoff brush with the Yankees unfolded so differently for the Cleveland Indians this time around.

title: Sumitomo Trust to Sell Aviation Leasing Unit
description: The Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Boullioun Aviation Services, its wholly owned aviation lease and financing company, for $120 million to Deutsche Bank A.G. Boullioun, based in Bellevue, Wash., leases passenger aircraft. It owns 35 planes and has assets of $989 million.

title: A Bunch of Men Getting Bashed
description: Every man in the audience at the Worth Street Theater Company's ''Snapshots '98'' should get down on his knees and thank John Patrick Shanley. Of the six one-act plays that make up this quirky but thoughtful collection, only Mr. Shanley's avoids making the human male look like the most horrible monster in the universe.

title: Report Says Tyson Has Mental Woes, but Is Fit
description: A series of psychological evaluations of Mike Tyson conducted three weeks ago at Massachusetts General Hospital reports that the former heavyweight boxing champion suffers from depression, anger, low self-esteem, irritability, and that he has trouble controlling his impulses. But it also concludes that he is mentally fit to return to the ring.

title: A Dusky Voice and Steamy Heat From a Strong-Willed Heroine
description: In terms of background, culture and appearance, Beatrice Uria-Monzon has what it takes to be an exceptional Carmen. Though her family roots are partly Spanish, she is French-born and French-trained. What better mix to play the iconic Spanish Gypsy of Bizet's great French opera? Moreover, Ms. Uria-Monzon, making her Metropolitan Opera debut in the first ''Carmen'' of the season, is an exceptionally beautiful woman who gave us a lithe, small-framed and unabashedly seductive Carmen.

title: Monica Who? Say Candidates In Close Races
description: While the election in three weeks has been portrayed in Washington as a referendum on whether President Clinton should be impeached, the Lewinsky scandal has not been a central part of the discourse -- or the candidates' strategies -- in the closest House and Senate contests in the country.

title: Rangers' Problems Cover the Ice
description: Even if the Rangers signed Zigmund Palffy from the Islanders and Scott Niedermayer from the Devils today, they would still be three or four players short of a good team. And they aren't about to sign either restricted free agent and risk the wrath of other National Hockey League teams.

title: B-Movie Wise-Guy Talk Along With the Songs
description: ''This song's about a bum date,'' announced Eddie Nichols, the singer for Royal Crown Revue. He was stalking around the stage at Roseland on Friday night, safely guarded against the fashion indignities of the present in his 1940's high-drape pants and short, wide necktie. ''Y'know what a bum date is? Nothin' from the neck down, pal.'' He counted off the song, and the band steamed into ''The Walkin' Blues,'' a shouted uptempo number.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, JOHN E.D.
description: IRVING-John E.D., 78. Longtime resident of Unionville, PA., on October 10, 1998. In addition to his wife Louise he is survived by five children John Jr. of Princeton, NJ, Henry of Cambridge, MA, Douglas of Unionville, PA, David and Carol of New York City and five grandchildren. Memorial services to be held Saturday, October 24, 3 PM at the Unionville Presbyterian Church. Memorial contributions may be sent to the US Committee for UNICEF, 1330 Beacon St. Suite 355, Brookline, MA. 02446.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Know El Duque Saved Them
description: THERE is a time for loyalty and convention in baseball. It is called the regular season. When they start hanging the bunting from the facades, a baseball manager must sometimes be blatantly expedient.

title: Panel Says Village Halloween Parade Can Roll, With Changes
description: After a boisterous public hearing, the committee that supervises the Halloween parade in Greenwich Village voted last night to recommend that the annual extravaganza continue, with a few changes to make it less riotous.

title: Abortion Rights in Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth Jernigan, Advocate For the Blind, Is Dead at 71
description: Kenneth Jernigan, who was a forceful advocate for the blind in gaining access to jobs and to public places during his longtime leadership of the National Federation of the Blind, died on Monday at his home in Baltimore. He was 71.

title: WB Network to Show Anti-Drug Spot Tonight
description: The WB television network in Burbank, Calif., part of the Warner Brothers unit of Time Warner Inc., is introducing its first public service announcement.

title: People
description: * Pat Baskin, vice president and public relations director at the public relations division of W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield, Mich., was promoted to the new position of senior vice president for corporate communications as part of a revamping that creates a communications division. Also, David Kiley was named to the new position of senior vice president for marketing communications; he had been a senior editor and columnist at the Adweek Magazines unit of VNU N.V., New York.

title: N.B.A. IS CANCELING ITS FIRST 2 WEEKS
description: The National Basketball Association, embroiled in a labor dispute with its players, yesterday canceled the first two weeks of the 1998-99 season. It is the first time in the league's 51-year history that it will lose regular-season games.

title: Mobster on Trial Testifies He Spied on Terror Suspects
description: An admitted Mafia member testified at his murder trial yesterday that while in jail he spied for the Government on four other inmates -- the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing and three others eventually convicted of terrorist acts -- and reported their plans to the authorities.

title: Accounts
description: * Cable and Wireless West Indies P.L.C., Grand Cayman, part of Cable and Wireless P.L.C., to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, to handle advertising in the Caribbean for its Cable and Wireless Caribbean and Atlantic and Cable and Wireless Caribbean Cellular divisions, which had previously been handled by various agencies. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Broadway Angels In a Different Role; 'Pimpernel' Tries Reincarnation
description: From the towering bubble-gum-pink wigs in the new opening number to the three-way sword fight in the new finale, Broadway's troubled musical, ''The Scarlet Pimpernel,'' has undergone a major overhaul, noteworthy not only for its breadth but also for who is behind it.

title: W. Allen Wallis, 85, Economist And President of U. of Rochester
description: W. Allen Wallis, an economist who became president of the University of Rochester and held a variety of Government posts in Washington, died on Monday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 85 and lived in Washington.

title: States on Twisted Path To Weaker Tobacco Pact
description: Last Tuesday, the attorneys general of Arizona, Connecticut and Iowa and officials from seven other states filed into a windowless conference room in a Manhattan hotel to review the latest proposal for a national tobacco settlement.

title: Nothing Strange About a Yankee Pennant
description: Finally imitating themselves instead of a weak-hitting team struggling for runs, the Yankees forged ahead to the World Series last night in a game that was filled with plays that could only be described as inexplicable.

title: Liberties; Last Tango in D.C.
description: I've always loved stories about parallel universes.

title: Knoblauch's Mistake Forgotten
description: The moment of truth for Chuck Knoblauch came in the bottom of the first inning when his name was announced at Yankee Stadium for the first time since he neglected to chase down that memorable loose ball last Wednesday. There were no boos. It was a very warm ovation. They liked him. They really liked him. Knoblauch exhaled.

title: A Dance Book Award
description: Roland John Wiley received the de la Torre Bueno Prize, awarded annually since 1973 by the Dance Perspectives Foundation for original books of dance scholarship. The award, which carries a cash prize of $1,000 and a crystal paperweight, was given in a ceremony on Monday night at the French Institute. Mr. Wiley won for ''The Life and Ballets of Lev Ivanov: Choreographer of 'The Nutcracker' and 'Swan Lake,' '' published this year by Oxford University Press. Receiving citations were Ellen Graff, for ''Stepping Left: Dance and Politics in New York City,'' (1997, Duke University Press) and Karl Toepfer, for ''Empire of Ecstasy: Nudity and Movement in German Body Culture, 1910-1935'' (1997, University of California Press). The dance historian Selma Jeanne Cohen was also honored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIALLONARDO, CONCETTO
description: DiGIALLONARDO-Concetto Dino. Beloved son of Clotilde and the late Onorino. Cherished husband of Mariateresa, devoted father of Daniela, Nadia and Christine. Loving brother of Romeo and Rita. Loving uncle of Sandra. Fond brother-in-law of Maria and Ben. A man of wit, charm and intelligence. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo, 2005 West 6th Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:30AM at St. Simon & Jude R.C. Church. Interment Moravian cemetery.

title: Officer Pleads Guilty To Sex Charge
description: A Camden County Sheriff's officer pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he had a 14-year-old girl perform a sex act on him while in his custody, the Camden County Prosecutor's Office said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: G.O.P. May Consolidate Impeachment Counts
description: Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee are considering folding most of the 15 counts outlined as impeachable offenses against President Clinton into 2 broader accusations: lying under oath and obstruction of justice, a Republican official said tonight.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Even with good earnings news, Kodak finds out just how unforgiving investors can be these days.
description: A BULL market might have taken it as good news. The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported third-quarter earnings of $398 million, up nearly 72 percent from the quarter last year, and a penny a share ahead of analyst forecasts. It was way ahead of schedule on its cost-cutting campaign. It had stopped the cash hemmorrhage from its portfolio of digital products.

title: For Cone, It Was Not A Start to Remember
description: Without much provocation, David Cone had called last night's start against the Cleveland Indians the ''defining moment in my career as a Yankee.'' Cone talked about enhancing his legacy with the Yankees and how he wanted to win Game 6 so the Yankees would not have to worry about a Game 7. It all sounded brave.

title: The Line Between Loving and Cursing
description: LIKE NEVER BEFORE

title: Art So Bad A Museum In Boston Relishes It
description: ''Gak!'' is one expression likely to burst from a visitor. Also ''Agh!' and ''Yew!'' Or here and there, a more articulate ''Hoo boy! Is that bad!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, BERTHA G.
description: SCHAEFER-Bertha G. Peacefully in her 91st year on the the first night of Sukkot. Devoted wife of the late David. Dear mother of Batya (Ezra) Levin and Marsha (Dr. Martin) Rubinowitz. Beloved grandmother of Zachary, Ayala, Rachel and Sarah. She leaves her parents' good name enhanced as a legacy. Shiva until morning October 19th. Donations may be made to Amit Women or Program for Memory Impaired at Riverdale-Y.

title: Car and Bus Collide, Killing a Man
description: A Union man was killed and a woman was critically injured after their car collided with a New Jersey Transit bus yesterday morning.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: ABC Ascending
description: At least one network had something to smile about in the weekly ratings: ABC saw some promise is its improvement in many areas from a week earlier and the network has moved into a solid second place behind NBC in the category of viewers between ages 18 and 49 that ABC considers its measuring stick.

title: Co-op Inquiry Into Kickbacks Is Broadened
description: Four years after investigators uncovered corruption in the management of hundreds of luxury co-ops and condominiums in Manhattan, prosecutors are looking into whether contractors and managing agents took part in kickback schemes that routinely inflated the cost of repairs at thousands of middle-class apartment houses throughout the city.

title: The Minimalist; Fish With a Crisp Crust, And No Frying or Breading
description: I'VE sat at lunch with friends and heard them wonder when presented with a nicely crisped piece of fish, ''How do they get such a fabulous crust on there?'' The fish isn't fried, nor is it breaded: it's just perfectly browned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUER, ELEANOR G.
description: SAUER-Eleanor G. On October 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Paul K. Sauer. Devoted mother of G. Russell Sauer. Adored grandmother of Steven, James and Thomas. Funeral service private.

title: Business Travel; Those flying to Milan from another European city may soon have to pay for a pricey taxi ride.
description: TRAVELERS flying into Milan from other European cities after Oct. 25 may want to double-check their destination before they leave. According to a compromise worked out last week by the European Commission and the Italian Government, most major European airlines are scheduled to move about two-thirds of their flights on that date from Linate Airport, which is only five miles from the center of the city, to Malpensa International Airport, which is 33 miles out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBARI, ANNA NEE PAONE
description: DiBARI-Anna nee Paone Beloved wife of the late Michael. Devoted mother of Betty Incatasciato, Rachel Ferrante, Ralph, John and Michael. Also survived by 9 grandchildren. Reposing Dahill Funeral Home, 2525 65th St, Brooklyn until Friday, 8:30AM. Mass of the Resurrection Our Lady of Grace R.C. Church, 9:30AM. Visiting hours Wednes. and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9:30

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the high-capacity HiFD floppy disk misstated the year that Sony introduced the first 3.5-inch floppy disk. It was 1981, not 1986.

title: White House Is Facing Democratic Opposition Over Proposed Deal on Census
description: A sticking point for White House and Congressional budget negotiators has been the issue of how the 2000 census will be conducted, and the White House finds itself negotiating on the issue as much with House Democrats as with the House Republican leaders.

title: You Don't Need a Map To Pinpoint Perfection
description: Tony Boselli is the Jacksonville Jaguars' supreme offensive tackle, and he is intelligent, animated and talkative. He grew up in Boulder, Colo., and earned a degree in business administration from Southern California. He was the Jaguars' first-ever draft pick and was the second player chosen over all in the 1995 draft.

title: A Call for Decency
description: Is television leading children down a moral sewer? Steve Allen thinks so, and his name and photograph have appeared in full-page newspaper advertisements -- one ran yesterday in The New York Times -- asking people to send money to a conservative media advocacy group that is urging advertisers ''to stop sponsoring sex, filth, violence and sleaze.''

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Colombe d'Or Is Sold

title: In a Steak Palace, a Timely Turn to Pasta
description: CAN a restaurant predict the future?

title: To Weaken Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, HELEN ELIZABETH PEIRCE
description: PRINCE-Helen Elizabeth Peirce. 76, of New York City, died on Saturday, October 10, 1998, after a brief illness. She is survived by her daughter, Elizabeth Prince de Ramel; her son, Frederick Henry Prince, and five grandchildren, Diana Elizabeth Oehrli, Guillaume and Regis de Ramel, Cynthia Elizabeth and Frederick Octavius Prince. Funeral service at 11:30AM, Friday, October 16, at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue between 71st & 72 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bryn Mawr Book Store, 502 East 79th Street, New York City or The Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, HAROLD
description: ROBBINS-Harold. 5/21/16-10/14/96. The chapter ended-the story continues. Always a friend. Ed Golli

title: Homophobia Often Found In Schools, Data Show
description: Last Saturday morning, while Matthew Shepard lay comatose from a beating, a college homecoming parade passed a few blocks from his hospital bed in Fort Collins, Colo. Propped on a fraternity float was a straw-haired scarecrow labeled in black spray paint, ''I'm Gay.''

title: Robert Gill, 87, Collector of American Antiques
description: Robert Lee Gill, a longtime member of the New York Stock Exchange and a prominent collector of American antiques, died on Sept. 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFELD, IRWIN
description: HELFELD-Irwin. Ohr Torah Stone Colleges and Graduate Programs mourn with sorrow the passing, on Erev Sukkot, of our beloved friend, devoted husband, loving son-in-law, faithful congregant and noble benefactor, Irwin Helfeld. Irwin was a proud son of his People who was deeply committed to the State of Israel, Jewish future and our noble heritage. May his wife Ilse, a most loving and caring life's partner, find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Israel. Shlomo Riskin Chancellor and Dean

title: MILOSEVIC ACCEPTS KOSOVO MONITORS, AVERTING ATTACK
description: The American special envoy Richard C. Holbrooke announced an agreement here today that averted the immediate threat of NATO air strikes against Serbia and could lead to a form of autonomy in Kosovo Province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIVINEY, THOMAS J.
description: DIVINEY-Thomas J. Of Southbury, CT. Died October 13, 1998. He was the husband of the late Alma Haley Diviney. Survived by three sons Thomas H. Diviney of Chesterfield, MO, Richard J. Diviney of Westport, CT & Joseph A. Diviney of Charlotte, NC; and two daughter Paula M. Burke of Charlotte, NC, and Susan A. Diviney of Cincinatti, OH; a brother Monsignor Charles E. Diviney of Brooklyn, NY; thirteen grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. Services will be held in Woodbury, CT.

title: And Now to the Hardware: A Ricer, of Course, but Which?
description: THE potato ricer has survived into the age of the food processor. And it has the starch content of the potato to thank. The food processor's blade slices open too many of its starchy cells, and what you end up with is not a silky potato puree, but a sticky, gluey, unpleasant mess.

title: Fractured Funny Bone
description: Nobody is laughing at the Fox network -- both on the air and in its office suites. Four of the five live-action comedies on Fox's schedule drew anemic ratings and Fox's patience ran out quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, PEGGY LEE
description: STEIN-Peggy Lee, age 78. Died on October 12, 1998. Loving wife of Bernard Stein, devoted mother of Lynn Igel and Robert Stein, like a mother to daughter-in-law Jacqueline Stein and son-in-law Anthony Igel, sister-in-law to Ruth Stein, and beloved nanie to Brian Stein, Leon Igel, Craig Stein and Bradley Igel. Your love will remain with us forever. No flowers. Donations to: The Foundation Fighting Blindness, 122 E. 42 St., Suite 1700, NY, NY 10168. Services at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St., New York City Friday at 11:30 AM.

title: BUDGET TALKS TRIP OVER SCHOOL AID AND OTHER ISSUES
description: Struggling to meet their fourth deadline over the Federal budget, Congressional Republicans and White House officials wrestled today with their differences over education, the most politically high-stakes element of the budget battle.

title: Rival Bid Dropped For Dutch Retailer
description: WE International dropped its bid late on Monday for Koninkelijke Bijenkorf Beheer, a Dutch retailer also known as K.B.B., after being outbid by Vendex N.V. Until last week, WE International said it was interested in making a counterbid for K.B.B., saying that it was willing to pay more than Vendex's offer of 167.50 guilders a share.

title: The Unheralded Brosius Becomes His Team's Not-So-Secret Weapon
description: When the Yankees obtained third baseman Scott Brosius from the Oakland Athletics in a trade for Kenny Rogers and cash late last year, many Yankee fans didn't know who he was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRANAHAN, MARION, M.D.
description: STRANAHAN-Marion, M.D. Age 98, on October 11. Dedicated psychiatrist who practiced in Manhattan for 70 years, specializing in children and adolescents. Her compassion and intelligence brought help to so many. Graduated from Indiana U. School of Medicine 1925. Former psychiatric Director of Mental Hygiene Clinic of Brooklyn Bureau of Charities and the Women's House of Detention. Psychiatrist at the Payne Whitney Clinic and the Vanderbilt Clinic of Columbia U. Medical Center. Beloved aunt of Beverly and seven grand-nieces and nephews in Rome, N.Y. Will be deeply missed by friends, patients and those who cared for her in her failing years. Contributions in her memory may be made to Habitat for Humanity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIEBOUT, ALICE MARGARETTA
description: TIEBOUT-Alice Margaretta. At age 96, died peacefully on Sunday, October 11, in Huntington, L.I. A talented interior decorator-the Air Force Academy Chapel was one of her projects-she was also an accomplished amateur musician in the Tiebout family tradition. During World War II, she served with distinction with the American Red Cross in the ChinaBurma-India theater. Alice is survived by seventeen nieces and nephews. Interment was at Cypress Hill Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Shift in Septic-Tank Rules at Reservoirs Draws Suit
description: New York City officials last month began allowing developers around the city's upstate reservoirs to install septic systems on steeply sloping hills, drawing the concern of Federal officials and environmentalists, who fear that the practice could pollute the city's water supply.

title: Task Force to Investigate Killing of Woman
description: The killing of a woman whose body was found in Newark on Sunday will be investigated by a task force convened to look into 14 other unsolved murders in Essex County, the county prosecutor's office said.

title: Justices Leave Intact Anti-Gay Measure
description: Two years after overturning an anti-gay rights amendment to the Colorado Constitution, the Supreme Court today left intact a similar measure barring protective legislation for homosexuals in Cincinnati.

title: STAPLES TO BUY OFFICE-PRODUCTS ASSETS OF IVAN ALLEN
description: Staples Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the office-products assets of the Ivan Allen Company for an undisclosed price. Staples, which is based in Westborough, Mass., and is the second-largest office-supply superstore chain in the United States, is expanding its operations in the Southeast and building its catalogue business. It said it would buy the closely held Ivan Allen's supplies assets in Atlanta and 14 divisional sales offices in the South. Ivan Allen will continue to operate its office-furniture business.

title: Big German Union Will Seek 6.5% Raises
description: IG Metall, Germany's largest union, said today that it would seek the biggest pay increase in years, as it enters job-creation negotiations with the new Social Democratic-led Government.

title: Waving Her Cultural Magic Wand
description: In her wheelchair, facing a roomful of work by the likes of Donald Judd and Barnett Newman, her back to the magnificent view of San Francisco Bay afforded by her apartment in the Pacific Heights section, Phyllis C. Wattis seemed braced by what she loves: modern art and this city. At 93, her hearing is poor and a recent leg infection has curtailed her mobility, but she wears her hair jauntily in a silver pageboy and she has an unmistakably mischievous smile. In deference to company, she wasn't listening to Stravinsky, turned up loud. ''I play 'The Rite of Spring' all the time,'' she said.

title: PUTNAM INVESTMENTS TO BUY 10 PERCENT STAKE IN NISSAY
description: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, Japan's largest life insurer, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 10 percent stake in its asset management unit, the Nissay Asset Management Corporation, to the Boston-based Putnam Investments for an undisclosed sum. Nippon said the equity stake was part of a broader agreement under which Putnam and Nissay would cooperate to develop a line of yen-denominated investment trust products. Putnam, a unit of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, which is based in New York, has had a working alliance with Nissay since mid-1997, and the two companies jointly manage nearly $1 billion in Japanese pension fund assets.

title: Dow Off 63 Points as Eastman Kodak Revenue Declines
description: Stock prices fell as the flow of third-quarter corporate earnings reports began to intensify.

title: Bill to Increase Work Visas for Foreigners Gets New Lease on Life
description: Congressional leaders revived legislation today that would nearly double the number of employment visas available for skilled foreign workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSZAWSKI, ARON
description: WARSZAWSKI - Aron. Passed away peacefully after a prolonged illness on October 12, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Vivienne, his sister, Sarah, his four sons, and his five grandchildren.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: For World's Women, Progress and Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROVATO, VINCENT W.
description: TROVATO-Vincent W. Sunday, October 4, 1998. Of Maywood, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Caroline (Nee Fico). Devoted father of Carol Trovato. Funeral Thursday, October 15 at 8:30AM from The Trinka Faustini Funeral Home, 439 Maywood Ave., Maywood, NJ. Funeral mass at Our Lady Queen of Peace R.C. Church, Maywood at 9 A.M. Interment in George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Visiting Wednesday 3-5PM & 7-9PM. Donations to the Little Sisters of the Poor, Totowa Boro, NJ, The Tomorrows Children's Fund, Hackensack, New Jersey or to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: When a Killer Blames His Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Blazing Laptops
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On the Train to West Chelsea
description: Silas Seandel was a pioneer 30 years ago, and he may be one again. In 1967, the designer and metal smith, below left in his workshop, was one of the original tenants at the D.& D. Building in Manhattan, where he sold his handmade sculptural metal furniture to architects and designers. Recently, he relocated his showroom, left, to 551-3 West 22d Street in Chelsea, where he now sells to the public. To create the all-white showroom, he carved a space at the front of his existing workshop. If Mr. Seandel is right again, there will soon be other furniture designers moving to West Chelsea. Metal tables start at $1,100; (212) 645-5286. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Albany to Make Trucks and Buses Pass Emission Tests, as Cars Do
description: Concerned about truck emissions that pollute the air more than its 10 million cars, New York State plans to require the 160,000 trucks and buses in the state to begin undergoing the emission tests that have long been required of automobiles.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinbrenner Better Than Alternative
description: DEAR GEORGE: Don't sell.

title: Cathay Pacific Close To Philippine Air Deal
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. of Hong Kong is close to acquiring a 40 percent stake in Philippine Airlines, the country's struggling national flag carrier, the Philippine President, Joseph Estrada, said yesterday. A spokesman for Cathay Pacific, based in Hong Kong, said that negotiations were continuing but that no agreement had been reached.

title: G.O.P. Agrees on Scaled-Back Tax Package
description: Their hopes for a big tax cut this year having been blocked by President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, Republican leaders tentatively agreed tonight on a sharply scaled-back package that kept alive several politically popular tax breaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, JOE STEPHENS
description: SNYDER-Joe Stephens. 82. Of Tenafly, N.J. Died Oct. 12, 1998. He is survived by his wife, of 52 years, Evelyn and his three children Judith Hallock, Joe Jr. and George. Four grandchildren and four stepgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 17, at the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly, N.J., at 11A.M. Donations may be made to SEED of Englewood Hospital and/or The Presbyterian Church at Tenafly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUBEN, BERNARD
description: REUBEN-Bernard of White Plains, N.Y. on October 12, 1998. Husband of Carla Reuben, father of Berne Reuben & Carla ReubenCarbone. Father-in-law of Walter Reuben-Carbone and Janet Coleman. Brother of Marion Kern and the late Sylvia Newman. Grandfather of Sage Reuben-Carbone, Danielle and Melissa Reuben. Funeral service Sunday, November 1, 11 AM, at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Elsag Bailey Gets $1.5 Billion ABB Bid
description: The Swiss-Swedish engineering company ABB A.B. is making a $1.5 billion cash tender offer for Elsag Bailey Process Automation N.V., a Dutch industrial automation company.

title: Set All of England's Mink Free! Oops. That's Killing Them.
description: Everywhere Len Kelsall looked, he saw mink. They were thick on the road, running like lemmings looking for a cliff. They were congregating in the barn. They were moving in an unbroken black carpet across his fields.

title: Congress Adds 20 Years To Copyright Terms
description: Congress has voted to extend the current copyright term by 20 years. The move offers a reprieve to creators and corporations holding the rights to such cultural icons as Mickey Mouse and the songs of George and Ira Gershwin, products of the 1920's that under the current law would begin entering the public domain in the year 2,000.

title: AT&T Is Awarded Network Contract by Microsoft
description: The AT&T Corporation has won an 18-month contract from the Microsoft Corporation to provide a high-capacity network to link the software company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash., to nearly 70 sites in the United States and Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECHTSCHAFFEN, DR. RUDOLF
description: RECHTSCHAFFEN-Dr. Rudolf. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Ronnie; father of Dr. Thomas and Candice; and brother of Rabbi Manfred M. Rechtschaffen, member of the Board of Directors of our Sy Syms School of Business and, with his wife Pamela, a YU Guardian and Fellow of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Virginia Executes Man Who Killed in 1989 When He Was 17
description: Despite pleas from groups who said that those who kill when they are juveniles should not be executed, Virginia put Dwayne Allen Wright to death tonight for a 1989 murder committed when he was 17.

title: A Man With a Garden That's a Medicine Cabinet
description: ABOUT a month ago, I stopped by Dr. Jim Duke's garden to check out the little six-acre spread he calls Herbal Village. Fulton is one of those little burgs off the interstate, where the farms have given over to ranch houses, with guys out on their power mowers every Saturday, riding herd on their lawns.

title: Taking a Monkish Delight In the Serious and Spare
description: Like the most formalized wings of punk or hip-hop, the key mandate of the tenor saxophonist David S. Ware's band -- which operates within the context of what may or may not be called free jazz, out jazz, avant-garde jazz or forward-looking jazz (most of these terms are up for disputation) -- is keeping it real. And the way the Ware quartet keeps it real is by an ascetic commitment to a single mood.

title: Schools Are Talk of California, But Not of the Candidates There
description: Throughout this election year, every public opinion poll in California has ranked education as the No. 1 concern among voters in a state whose once-golden public schools have slipped badly.

title: Shaw, Self-Styled Cautious Operator, Reveals It Has a Big Appetite for Risk
description: D. E. Shaw & Company, the hedge fund on which BankAmerica lost $100 million, has long presented itself as a cautious operator that only uses small amounts of debt, or leverage in Wall Street parlance.

title: Even Lamps Need Clothes
description: A LAMPSHADE is a fashion item that changes with the times,'' said the Manhattan designer Noel Jeffrey. ''In the 1970's, no one used lamps with shades, but in the 1990's, even though interiors are simple again, people want warmer, cozier spaces, and they're using lampshades.''

title: Ailing 6-Year-Old Disappears, and Sitter Is Sought
description: She did not have any children of her own, but Theresa Giannola Goldberg had 6-year-old Chaim Weill. Chaim, who uses a wheelchair and leg braces, has cerebral palsy and communicates mostly with a smile or an awkward nod. His parents knew that Mrs. Goldberg, his regular baby sitter, loved Chaim, so they did not worry when she took him for a stroll on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Col. Gaston de Bonneval, 86, De Gaulle's Closest Confidant
description: Col. Gaston de Bonneval, a French Resistance fighter who spent two decades as Charles de Gaulle's right hand, left hand and half-a-step-behind man, died on Oct. 2 at his home in St.-Mande, France. He was 86.

title: Mets Close to Signing Leiter
description: With a month to go before potential free agents can sign with other teams, the Mets are, in the words of the co-owner Nelson Doubleday, close to signing Al Leiter to a long-term deal.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about The Miami Herald's decision to close its Sunday feature magazine, Tropic, referred incorrectly to plans for the newspaper's international edition. The existing version will be replaced by a shortened version of the Miami edition; the international edition is not closing. The article also misstated the change at The Herald's bureaus in Israel and Brazil. The Herald recently turned control of them over to the Washington bureau of its parent company, Knight Ridder. The bureaus were not closed.

title: The Computer as Wedding Consultant
description: DELIRIOUSLY happy but a bit overwhelmed? Jumping for joy and compulsively biting your nails? You must be a bride-to-be.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; A Right to Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Hoboken Waterfront Plan
description: Hoboken and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that they had selected two developers to build the residential complex within a larger plan to redevelop Hoboken's waterfront.

title: Ex-Jones Lawyer Says Starr Advised Him on Civil Case
description: Not long before he was appointed independent counsel in August 1994, Kenneth W. Starr assisted a lawyer representing Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton, the lawyer said today.

title: Yes, Brown Is Ready For Yanks in Game 1
description: Bruce Bochy got away with the biggest baseball gamble of 1998, and now the Yankees will pay for his good fortune.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAN, SIDNEY PHILIP
description: LEVITAN-Sidney Philip. Our Flicker. Devoted husband of Arlene, beloved father of Henry and Robin, Mark and Melissa and Marge and Gary. Brother of Mort Levitan, cherished grandfather of six grandchildren. We are grateful for his good years and kindness to all. Services Friday, 10AM, Gutterman's in Woodbury.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, MARSHA
description: FORMAN-Marsha. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation are deeply saddened by the death of Marsha Forman, beloved mother of Amy Rubenstein, our 1999 Lion of Judah chair, and mother-in-law of Howard J. Rubenstein, co-chair of UJA-Federation's Business Leaders Forum and 1997 recipient of the Real Estate Division's Jack D. Weiler Award. Mrs. Forman established an admirable example of devotion to the Jewish community which has been embraced by her entire family. We shall long remember her many deeds of compassion as we honor her memory. ''A woman of valor, who can find? Her price is far above rubies.'' We extend our most sincere condolences to her husband, Sol; her children, Amy and Howard Rubenstein, Marilyn and Harry Spiera, and Ellie and Edgar Cullman; her grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and all the members of the family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Susan K. Stern, Women's Campaign Chair Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; Inequity of Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; Art, and the Usual Adornment
description: On one side of the fashion picture stand the traditionalists. On the other, the experimentalists. And nowhere is that more apparent than in Paris, the home of traditional houses like Givenchy, Ungaro, Chloe and Saint Laurent, and the mecca for adventurous designers from Asia like Rae Kawakubo of Comme des Garcons and Junya Watanabe.

title: In Protest, Clinton Downgrades Visit to Malaysia : U.S. 'Horrified' About Anwar
description: SINGAPORE  The United States intensified its criticism of Malaysia on Wednesday over the treatment of the dismissed deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Up in Modest Rally, Led by Advances in Nasdaq

title: Doctor Is Arraigned in Assisted Suicide
description: An Upper East Side veterinarian has confessed to helping a close friend and receptionist at his office to commit suicide by giving her a lethal dose of a sedative commonly used to euthanize pets as she lay in a hospital last year, withered and terminally ill with breast cancer, according to a criminal complaint filed by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Teaching the Computer to Recognize a Friendly Face
description: ARE you tired of remembering so many passwords? Would you like to get rid of your PIN for the cash machines and those annoying passwords you use to log on to different Web sites and the office computer? Maybe you will be able to trade them soon for a simple smile.

title: Genentech Earnings Double for Quarter
description: Helped by strong sales of new genetically engineered drugs for cancer, Genentech Inc. reported today that its third-quarter earnings nearly doubled.

title: A Sense Of Romance
description: WEDDING WORKSHOP

title: Wood of the Moment, of a Minute Ago
description: NAOMI, Kate, Shalom, Claudia, wenge? It came down the runway three seasons ago in Milan. Now wenge (pronounced WEN-geh) is the deep, rich darling of the furniture-design moment, the bittersweet chocolate-brown muse of the new minimalists -- from reigning sultans like Christian Liaigre to young turks like Spencer Fung. If ever there was a wood that was, it's wenge. It's so there, it could be over.

title: Weaker-Than-Expected Retail Sales Push Bond Prices Higher
description: Treasury bond prices rose for a second day as a report showing weaker-than-expected retail sales suggested the economy was losing steam, reinforcing expectations for another Federal Reserve interest rate cut.

title: Frank Yankovic, Long-Reigning Polka King, Is Dead at 83
description: Frank Yankovic, the hard-working singer and accordionist who was crowned the Polka King at a polka contest in Milwaukee in 1948 and was known by that title through five subsequent decades of performing and recording, died yesterday at his home in New Port Richey, Fla. He was 83.

title: Yanks Get One Day To Revel And Rest
description: The Yankee players knew that George Steinbrenner was off limits to Champagne showers: when they clinched the American League East in Boston on Sept. 9, and when they swept Texas in the division series this month, Steinbrenner was nowhere to be found.

title: STARWOOD TO SELL 35% STAKE IN TRADE SCHOOL OPERATOR
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts said yesterday that it was exploring ways to sell its 35 percent stake in the trade school operator ITT Educational Services Inc., worth about $258 million, to focus on hotels and casinos. Starwood acquired the stake with its $14.6 billion purchase in February of the ITT Corporation and its Sheraton hotels and Caesars World casinos. The Indianapolis-based ITT Educational operates 64 schools and had revenue of $261.7 million last year. ITT Educational's stock fell $1.9375, to $25.375, and Starwood was down 43.75 cents at $19.50. Starwood, a real estate investment trust based in White Plains, said it might sell all or part of its remaining 9.5 million ITT Educational shares or sell securities tied to the shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNARO, VITO A.
description: GENNARO-Vito A. On October 14, 1998. Former Principal NYC Board of Education and active member of Helpers of God's Precious Infants and the Life Center of New York. Beloved husband of Marian (nee Astuti). Loving father of Margaret Buckley, M.D., Rocco, Ph.D. and Maria. Dear brother of Joseph. Proud grandfather of Olivia Anne Gennaro. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Sat., 9:30AM Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: Lightning Again Offers What the Islanders Need
description: Whenever the Islanders were in desperate need of a victory last season, they could always count on getting one against the hapless Tampa Bay Lightning. It was a 7-1 victory in Tampa last January that ended the Islanders' wretched 11-game streak without a victory.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES TO CUT 10% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc., a bank holding company, will cut 1,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, in an effort to increase profits. The company said yesterday that it would close or sell 39 banking offices and hire third parties for operations like the administration of employee benefits. The cuts, which will occur in the next six to nine months, are intended to increase annual pretax profits by $125 million, Huntington said. Costs associated with the moves will lower pretax fourth-quarter earnings by $90 million, the company said. Shares of Huntington, based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 18.75 cents, to $25.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIES, SARAH YOUNGS
description: SPIES-Sarah Youngs. Of Old Brookville, NY on October 12, 1998. Loving mother of Barbara Jensen, Bruce Spies and Betsy Gustafson. Dear grandmother of Geoffrey and Russell Spies and the late Chris Keoughan. Dear sister of John H. Youngs. A member of the Syosset Garden Club. Visiting Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service Friday morning at the funeral home. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the Preservation of Coe Hall, Planting Fields, Planting Fields Rd., Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

title: Returning to Tour, Couples Finds Less Is Better
description: Fred Couples has mastered the art of playing well without playing often. Although Couples has played only 15 events on the PGA Tour this season, he ranks sixth on this year's money list ($1,591,437), averaging $105,000 every time he enters a tournament. Only David Duval, No. 1 on the money list with $2,553,865 in 22 events, has earned more per start than Couples.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; For a 'Shepard Bill'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, LEO A., M.D.
description: SPIEGEL-Leo A., M.D. on October 12, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Tow Spiegel, beloved father of Wendy Kesselman. A memorial gathering will be announced.

title: Panel Urges H.I.V. Tests For All Pregnant Women
description: Every pregnant woman in the country should be checked for the AIDS virus as part of routine prenatal care, an expert panel said today in recommending a policy change that could further reduce cases of babies' being infected at birth.

title: 'Do the Math?' Sure, With Help on Line
description: DO your homework first!'' Prof. Ellen Freedman of Camden County College in New Jersey implores students from a rolling banner across her virtual classroom, a Web site designed to provide ''information about basic math and algebra.''

title: Well, Someone Had to Do It
description: ''This safely falls into the 'not glamorous' category,'' said Warren Gran, an architect, referring to his plan to renovate the East River Bridge Repair Facility on Kent Avenue, under the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEBRAK, MARY
description: ZEBRAK-Mary. Passed away October 13, 1998. She is survived by her devoted son Ira and daughter Mildred. Her beloved sister Beatrice Tobias, and her brother Samuel Orzitzer. In loving memory.

title: INSIDE
description: Prenatal H.I.V. Test Urged

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Tense Times, Crowd Is Kept Far From City Hall
description: For years, the front steps of City Hall have served as the backdrop to all sorts of ceremonies, concerts and news conferences, often drawing crowds of hundreds of people.

title: To the Bookshelf Born, With Noblesse Oblige
description: EX LIBRIS

title: Vallone Assails Debt Under Pataki and Offers Reduction Plan
description: Seeking to revitalize his gubernatorial campaign, Peter F. Vallone criticized Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday over ''borrow and spend policies'' and his failure to contain New York State's debt, and he proposed several measures, including a two-year moratorium on some new debts, to help remedy the problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEHR, I.E. THEODORE (AKA ROBERT ALLEN)
description: BAEHR - I.E. Theodore (aka Robert Allen). On Oct. 9th, 1998, age 92. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn Pierce, dearly loved father of Katherine (Charles) Meyer, and Theodore (Liliana) Baehr. Beloved grandfather of seven and great grandfather of six. Funeral service will held Friday, Oct. 16, 1998 at 2 P.M. at The First Presbyterian Church, Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Christian Film and TV Commission, 2510-6 Los Pasos Road, Camarillo, CA. 93010.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a ceremony honoring Robert Moses at a playground that bears his name misstated the teaching position held by David Smiley, who attended the ceremony and discussed Mr. Moses. He teaches in the architecture department at Barnard College, in the urban studies program at Columbia University and in the urban design program at Columbia's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. He is not a history professor at Columbia.

title: J. Peterman, Archeologist of the Retail Trade
description: HE has bounced across the desert on camels and hobnobbed with potentates and palace-bound pashas. But there are things that John Henry Peterman, creator of the mail-order clothing business that the comic strip ''Doonesbury'' once parodied as ''J. Pretensions,'' is not. A westerner is one of them.

title: A Question of Empathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Architect and Artist Plant an Air Kiss on the Middlebrow
description: OVER the last decades, work has increasingly invaded the home and changed the way Americans view the domestic landscape. Wing chairs, mantelpieces and newel posts make little sense for houses that double as offices: cozy images send unprofessional cues to clients, and cocoon people into thinking their workday never starts.

title: The Summit by the Bay
description: The Wye Plantation on Maryland's Eastern Shore does not have the same ring as Camp David, but events there over the next few days may affect the Middle East as much as the Camp David accords did two decades ago. Israeli and Palestinian leaders meeting at the Chesapeake retreat can put the Middle East back on a course toward peace. It is an opportunity they must not misplay.

title: 2,000 Monitors to Go to Kosovo, but Their Power Is Unclear
description: Since the end of the cold war, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe has been a sort of crossing guard for Eastern Europe's gradual transition from Communism to democracy. It has championed civil society, promoted arms control and overseen elections from Armenia to Bosnia to Russia.

title: Schneider's Wish Is Granted: A Trade to the Rangers
description: When Mathieu Schneider completed his first practice with the Rangers this morning, the defenseman spoke of how a dream had come true.

title: State Gets High Score On the Environment
description: The League of Conservation Voters yesterday ranked New Jersey's Congressional delegation third in the country for its environmental record, behind Connecticut and Massachusetts.

title: High Court Hears Case on States' Power in Referendum Process
description: With voter referendums gaining an ever more prominent role as adjuncts to ordinary lawmaking, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on how far states may go in regulating the process of getting such measures on the ballot.

title: If You Weren't Born With . . .
description: People like to eat, of course, and they often want to do it with porcelain and sterling. For those who aspire to finer dining, Sotheby's is holding a dinnerware auction.

title: A Century of New York City Life in Pictures
description: Collected Images

title: Case of Malaria Reported In a College Student
description: A 19-year-old college student has been found to have had malaria, the first case of the disease in New Jersey since 1991, officials said yesterday.

title: CONGRESS'S RATING CONTINUES TO SLIP IN INQUIRY'S WAKE
description: With the midterm elections less than three weeks away, support for the Republican-controlled Congress has eroded significantly in the aftermath of the House vote to open a formal impeachment inquiry into President Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Residents' Views on City Life Improve, and Giuliani Gets Credit
description: For the first time since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani won election in 1993, more than half of New York City residents say that life in the city has improved, a New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Political Briefing; For Colorado G.O.P., The Enemy Is Itself
description: At a time when it normally would be concentrating all its guns on Democrats, the Colorado Republican Party is at war with itself. Its hard-right conservative chairman is battling almost daily with the moderates who ran the party until a few years ago.

title: Finalists of the National Book Awards
description: The novelists Tom Wolfe and Robert Stone and the literary critic Harold Bloom are among the finalists for the 1998 National Book Awards, the National Book Foundation announced yesterday.

title: Little Reward in Sight, Yankee Fans Camp Out for Tickets
description: Some people just cannot be stopped from sleeping on the sidewalk.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOFMANN, REGINA
description: HOFMANN - Regina. 10/15/97. Gene, We miss you-your humor, your wisdom and your loyalty. Jane and Mark

title: Tasting Boogie-Woogie and Glam Rock, Ingredients in an Eccentric Formula
description: On Tuesday night, as thousands protested the Off Broadway opening of ''Corpus Christi,'' Terrence McNally's play about a homosexual Christ figure, and people nationwide mourned the homophobia-fueled murder of 21-year-old Matthew Shepard in Wyoming, an openly gay man who writes music for Disney movies and has been knighted by the Queen of England sat behind his piano at Madison Square Garden and led a wholesome evening of fun. The spectacle raised an inevitable question: Why does Elton John get so much love while others fight back revulsion and hate?

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Danger: Diet!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MINNIE
description: HIRSCH-Minnie. On October 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late David Hirsch. Loving mother of Rita and Irving Wahl, and Terri and Martin Hirsch. Dear grandmother of Susan Wahl and Lisa Rosenstock. Great-grandmother of Debra Rosenstock. Graveside service today at 2:30PM, Beth-El Cemetery, Westwood, New Jersey.

title: Fighting Fire With Technology as Computers Help Out
description: DAN GOSNELL, a fire management planner in California for the United States Forest Service, wishes he had had his service's new technology two years ago. It was nearly Thanksgiving when a wildfire flared in Waterman Canyon, in the San Bernardino National Forest. Flames jumped the crest of the canyon and ripped down the foothills, fueled by 30-m.p.h. Santa Ana winds. The fire stalked to within a mile of the campus of California State University at San Bernardino.

title: Crossing Racial Boundaries, Rap Gains Ground
description: ''Glam rock is back!'' proclaimed The Guardian of London recently. And the newspaper wasn't alone in its excitement. For months, record label executives and other culture watchers have been making similar pronouncements, and the evidence to back them up is legion: movies like ''Velvet Goldmine,'' musicals like ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch,'' acts like Marilyn Manson and Kiss, topping the pop charts, the signing of half a dozen 80's glam-metal bands at Columbia Records. Even theoretically it makes sense: pop musicians have been gloating that people are tired of alternative rock and its reaction against pomp and stardom, and that audiences want to be entertained by flashy anthemic rock spectacles.

title: A Spanish-Flavored 'Quixote'
description: Victor Ullate's ballet company from Spain, which made its New York debut in 1996 billed as Ballet Ullate of Madrid, returned to City Center on Tuesday night with ''Don Quixote.''

title: Making Books; Finding Stories Boys Will Read
description: It's a maxim of book publishers and teachers and librarians that boys don't go home and read after school. So the slipperiest groups for book publishers to lay hold of are pre-teen and teen-age boys, and trying to gather them in is about as easy as grabbing hold of a freshly caught trout. Girls read. They're interested in feelings, publishers say. Boys require muscle and guts.

title: Reinaldo Ferrer, 82, Educator and Ex-New York City Health Chief
description: Reinaldo Antonio Ferrer, a former medical educator and administrator who, as New York City's Health Commissioner, was one of the highest-ranking Hispanic officials in the Koch administration, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Altamonte Springs, Fla. He was 82.

title: Kournikova Ready For Garden Debut
description: With the notable exception of being able to count a professional tennis title among her laurels, Anna Kournikova, the latest player to qualify for the year-ending Chase Championships next month at Madison Square Garden, seems to have everything going her way: in just three years she has soared from 281st to 12th in the rankings, reached the 1997 Wimbledon semifinals, and she has managed not to lose a match to anybody ranked beneath the Top 15 since January 1997.

title: Passing On a Clean Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Man Charged In Restaurant Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday on charges of fatally shooting a man after an argument at a Red Lobster restaurant in Queens last month.

title: Planning an Apt Tribute To Sosa, Home Run Hero
description: New York City in general -- and the Washington Heights section of Manhattan in particular -- is planning to honor Sammy Sosa when he visits the city this weekend. But beyond presenting him with a key to the city, city officials are still trying to figure out how best to celebrate the Dominican-born baseball star.

title: Elusive Fugitive Is Charged With Bombing at Olympics
description: With the trail of Eric Robert Rudolph turning cold in the mountainous wilds of North Carolina, Federal law-enforcement officials announced today that he had been formally charged with the Centennial Olympic Park bombing and two other bomb attacks in Atlanta in 1996.

title: Salem Revisited
description: A number of commentators have seen a resemblance between the extravaganza around President Clinton and the witchcraft hysteria in Salem 300 years ago. There are some similarities and some important differences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAENEMAN, LEWIS G. JR.
description: SCHAENEMAN-Lewis G. Jr. Age 67 of 30 Aylesbury Circle, Madison. Died Saturday October 10, 1998 at Middlesex Medical Center in Essex. He was the husband of Priscilla Snider Schaeneman. He was born in Springfield, MA, April 4, 1931. He was the son of the late Lewis G. and Mary Wargo Schaeneman Sr. Mr. Schaeneman was formerly of East Longmeadow, MA. and spent his winters in Oldsmar, FL. He retired in 1995 as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Stop and Shop Companies, Inc. Besides his wife he is survived by two sons Lewis G. Schaeneman, III of Columbia, S.C. and Andrew Schaeneman of Guilford, CT., three daughters Laura Burrows of Dunedin, FL., Margaret Schaeneman of New York City, and Mary Anne Schaeneman of Guilford, CT., one brother Walter P. Schaeneman of West Springfield, MA. Also survived by two grandchildren. He was predeceased by a brother William F. Schaeneman. Funeral services will be held at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Durham Rd., Madison, CT. Saturday 11 A.M. Burial will be in Resurrection Cemetery Westbrook. Friends may call at the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Rd., Madison, CT. Friday 6-8 P.M.

title: F.A.A. RECOMMENDS AIRLINES REPLACE INSULATION IN JETS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is recommending that insulation on most of the world's 12,000 passenger jets be replaced in regularly scheduled maintenance, because the insulation now in use catches fire too quickly when exposed to heat.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; Fuel for Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Almost as Lighthearted As a Tropical Breeze
description: Gaetano Pesce, an Italian architect who lives in Manhattan, has designed an anthropomorphic and richly colored house, above, for himself in Salvador, Brazil. Part of the main building, now under construction, holds a living room and, above that, a bedroom. The exterior is clad in colorful, overlapping leaf-shaped tiles that form profiles that resemble two people peering at each other on either side of the windows. A separate building, which holds the bathroom, will be yellow stucco with broken bits of glass; the kitchen building will be blue stucco with mixed pieces of pots and pans, jugs and bowls.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Not Quite Figs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABLER, CHARLES K.
description: GABLER-Charles K. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles K. Gabler, associated with The Times from 1941 until retiring in 1975.

title: Topics of The Times; Double Drinking Standard
description: The University of New Hampshire is cracking down on student drinking, and rightly so. Drunken behavior at the annual homecoming football game had gotten so out of hand in past years that administrators decided to ban alcohol at tailgate parties before the big game this year.

title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ELLA
description: FINKELSTEIN-Ella. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Ella Finkelstein. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain

title: Bombay Journal; India Relishes the Novels She Sprinkles With Spice
description: It could have been a Manhattan dinner party of the media elite. The women wore cocktail dresses and high heels. The men, in business suits, had downed a few too many scotches. The banter was bawdy, gossipy, sometimes cruel. And beneath it all, business was being done.

title: CISCO AGREES TO BUY SELSIUS SYSTEMS FOR $145 MILLION
description: The networking giant Cisco Systems Inc. has agreed to acquire Selsius Systems Inc., a maker of switches that route phone calls over company intranets, for $145 million in cash and stock. Costs associated with the deal will lower second-quarter earnings by 3 to 6 cents a share, Cisco said. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., has annual revenue of $8.46 billion. Selsius, a privately held company based in Dallas, was sold by the Intecom Inc. unit of Lagardere S.C.A. of France.

title: Essay; Globaloney Crisis
description: Every economic seer, sage and pundit has an incentive to predict what Jimmy Durante used to call a ''catastrostroke.''

title: Parties Seem To Have Deal On Education
description: Delivering $1.1 billion for education just in time for the Nov. 3 elections, Democrats and Republicans appeared to strike a compromise today on a spending bill that would earmark the money for more teachers.

title: Prices Turn Upward, With the Dow Climbing by 30.64
description: After early hesitation, stock prices moved ahead yesterday, resuming a rebound that began last Thursday just as it appeared that the main gauges would drop 20 percent below their July peaks and qualify the trend as a bear market.

title: Using Internet Polls To Predict Election Results
description: It remains to be seen whether the Internet, as a grass roots medium, will revolutionize politics, but political pollsters hope it will at least help them predict the outcome of elections.

title: Bank of Tokyo Reports Its Recent Write-Offs
description: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Ltd., Japan's top commercial bank, said yesterday that it had written off 319 billion yen ($2.67 billion) in appraisal losses on its securities holdings as of the end of September. Despite the write-offs, the bank's projection for a profit during the fiscal half-year remained largely unchanged. As of the end of September, the bank still had a paper profit on its stock holdings of 375.1 billion yen.

title: Fiat Announces Big Production Cut
description: Fiat S.p.A., the world's fifth-largest car company and Italy's largest private employer, said yesterday that it would trim production by about 28,000 units in November and December, amid signs of slower economic growth in Italy. The cuts, equal to 41 percent of Fiat's new car registrations in September, come as demand dries up after the end of a Government subsidy program in July.

title: Judge Makes Courtroom Of Chairs and Park Bench
description: Squeezed by a space crunch in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, the judges have been sentenced in recent months to sharing courtrooms or using jury rooms or their chambers for court proceedings.

title: Compromise for I.M.F.
description: The deal taking shape provides the full $18 billion that the White House said was needed to stem the global financial crisis. Page A16.

title: Undercover Officer Hurt Pursuing Drug Suspects
description: An undercover narcotics officer was injured last night when he was pushed down a flight of stairs in a Brooklyn apartment building while trying to arrests two suspects conducting a drug deal, the police said.

title: Political Briefing; Campaign Fund Issue Dogs Alaska Aspirant
description: Running for governor in Alaska is iffy business for a Republican in any circumstance, given that no Republican candidate has won the office in 20 years. And with each passing day -- more specifically, with each passing brouhaha -- the chances that this year's Republican candidate, John Lindauer, a conservative, might defeat Gov. Tony Knowles, a moderate Democrat, seem more remote.

title: Keeping Track of Every Detail
description: THE ESSENTIAL WEDDING PLANNER

title: Group's Letter To Cardinals Offers Advice On Next Pope
description: In an early sign of the maneuvering for influence that may accompany the next papal election, a coalition of more than 140 liberal Roman Catholic groups, which have forged links through the Internet, has sent a statement to each of the church's cardinals, asking that the next Pope be a ''collaborative'' leader who would allow bishops, priests and lay people a share in church decision-making.

title: The Medium as Message, as Well as the Punch Line
description: ACCORDING to A. C. Nielsen, kids are watching less television. That could be because they're playing video games that laugh at television. Witness Gex: Enter the Gecko, a ''Simpsons''-style send-up of Hollywood played out by a wisecracking lizard with encyclopedic knowledge of 1970's sitcoms.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CLOSE TWO FIBERBOARD PLANTS
description: The International Paper Company will close fiberboard plants in South Carolina and North Carolina and dismiss 336 workers after the company failed to find buyers for the sites. The layoffs come on top of 1,500 job cuts that were announced on Tuesday. International Paper said yesterday that it would shutter a plant in Spring Hope, N.C., cutting 191 jobs, and a plant in Sellers, S.C., eliminating 145. Both make medium-density fiberboard, used in countertops and cabinets. The company put the fiberboard plants up for sale in August 1997. In addition, the company plans to cut 50 jobs from its chemical unit, Arizona Chemical. Shares of International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., fell $1.25 a share, to $44.8125.

title: The Mystery Of the Dongle
description: Q. I keep getting the screen message ''no dongle found'' when I try to open a certain software program. What is a dongle?

title: Man Arrested in 1997 Killing of a Newark Prostitute
description: An Irvington, N.J., man described by investigators as the brother of Larry Hogue, a mental patient who was accused of menacing people on the Upper West Side of Manhattan for more than a decade, has been arrested in the death last year of a 37-year-old Newark prostitute.

title: Car Alarms And Lovers Can Be Funny
description: Headlong Dance Theater, a troupe from Philadelphia, brought rowdy tomfoolery to Dance Theater Workshop with a program jointly choreographed by its directors and leading dancers, David Brick, Andrew Simonet and Amy Smith.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALTMAN, JACK
description: KALTMAN-Jack. Of Great Neck, N.Y. On October 13, 1998, age 73. Loving husband to Selma. Father to Hannah, Ilya, Naomi and Alice. Dear brother to Helen. Adoring grandfather to Caleb, Anna, Abraham, Nicholas and Noa. Funeral services will be held today, Temple Beth El, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- The Unmaking of the 'Uncola'; After Years of Decline, New Owner Plots Revival at 7-Up
description: Hundreds of the nation's 7-Up bottlers met here last month, and it was not the cozy, self-congratulatory affair such gatherings often are.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Hebron is a city without normal days. If it's quiet, it's only on the surface. Quiet is a fiction because the hatred and violence continue to sizzle just beneath. It takes a nothing, a tiny provocation, and boom, blood is shed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, HONORA
description: ZIMMERMAN-Honora. On October 10, 1998. Beloved mother of Daniel and Matthew. Cherished grandmother to Natalie. Loving daughter of Mildred and the late Edwin Coane. Dear sister of Linda Copeland and Ethan Coane. Services Thursday, 5 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. The warmth, wit, wisdom and generosity that Honey brought to our lives will be forever cherished and honored in the memories of her family and friends.

title: Political Briefing; Senate Race Turns Nasty in Wisconsin
description: This fall's United States Senate race in Wisconsin started out on a positive, even lighted-hearted note, with the Democratic incumbent, Russell D. Feingold, running a television advertisement that urged a much-overweight Uncle Sam to ''reduce'' the budget deficit, and the Republican challenger, Representative Mark W. Neumann, poking fun at the Senator for once supporting a government study of cow flatulence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, IRENE
description: NATHANSON-Irene. The Shelter Rock Jewish Center deeply mourns the passing of our longtime member and dearest friend and offers sincere condolences to her family. Shelter Rock will miss Irene and Jerry. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Stanley Shanies, President

title: Security: A Growth Industry in Mexico
description: Dale O. Bulkley, who works for the Kroll-O'Gara Company, the investigation and security concern, found just how common kidnappings have become here while investigating the abduction of a high school student along a boulevard winding through an affluent Mexico City suburb. Nine other victims, he learned, had been taken hostage in recent months along the same leafy road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, JR., REV. JOHN THOMAS
description: MASON-Jr., Rev. John Thomas 89 minister and writer husband of Elizabeth (Branch) Mason died September 29 in Kent, Ct. All services are private. Memorial contributions to Christ Episcopal Church, Sharon CT 06069.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest column yesterday about drug company financial results misstated the third-quarter earnings per diluted share of Pfizer Inc. in some editions. The earnings were 51 cents, not 6 cents.

title: World Series Pits Padres Vs. Yankees
description: The San Diego Padres defeated the Atlanta Braves today and advanced to the World Series for the first time since 1984. And they didn't need Kevin Brown to do it.

title: State of the Art
description: A column by Peter H. Lewis called State of the Art will begin next week. He will write each week about new products and developments in the electronics industry of interest to consumers.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; No News at All
description: To the Editor:

title: Coup de Theatre in East Village
description: ''We wanted to expose new materials to people,'' Manuel Fernandez-Casteleiro said. That's why he and his partner, Jeffrey Parsons, used rubber, plastic, fiberglass and phenol, a synthetic resin, to design Coup, above, a restaurant at 509 East Sixth Street in the East Village.

title: White House Memo; Clinton's Rose Garden Campaign and Its Calculations
description: Most Democratic candidates gush over his leadership and glue themselves to his side. Millionaires, shouldering each other like enraptured Hanson fans, stretch to catch his eye and shake his hand.

title: Balancing Act: Finding the Right On-Line Service
description: MY friend Liz DeGennaro called the other day to say she was thinking about going on line for the first time. She figured that she would liberate her Macintosh Power PC from the closet, where it has resided in the months since she left graduate school, set up a family computer station in the corner of an almost-renovated bedroom and then ''do a little E-mail, some Web surfing, some research.'' At least that's what I think she said, because her baby, Emma, was cooing into the phone receiver and on my end of the line, my baby was rhythmically hitting my leg with an unplugged surge protector.

title: BankAmerica Names Finalists in Review
description: The BankAmerica Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it had selected finalists to compete for its account, with billings estimated at $90 million to $100 million.

title: It's Testaverde's Job As the Plot Thickens
description: Facing a pivotal stretch of games that could salvage, or ruin, the Jets' season, Bill Parcells today made the difficult decision every football coach dreads: changing quarterbacks.

title: Swiss Conservatives Sue Critic Who Testified on Jewish Accounts
description: GENEVA  Jean Ziegler, a relentless critic of Swiss banks and their dealings with Hitler's Germany, is the target of a lawsuit that seeks a treason charge against him, and the federal prosecutor has asked Parliament to decide whether to lift his immunity as a member of Parliament.

title: Library Grapples With Internet Freedom
description: JUST inside the entrance of the public library here hangs a photograph of the building's namesake, John Henry Faulk, a radio performer and humorist famous for his uncompromising defense of free speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZGODNY, WILLIAM
description: ZGODNY-William. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its member, Melvin Zgodny. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, JUNE (NEE ABELSON)
description: HERMAN-June (nee Abelson). On October 14, 1998 of Cedar Grove, N.J. Devoted mother of Alan and Daniel Herman. Adored sister of Florence Goldfarb and Elaine Stalford. Loving grandmother of five grandchildren. She was the Vice President of Jabel Inc of Irvington, NJ. Funeral Services conducted from Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, NJ on Friday October 16, 1998 at 1 P.M. For information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J.

title: The High Art Of Dressing For Battle
description: If you were a rich, style-conscious noble of the 16th century with a yen for a signature suit of armor, you would more than likely turn to Filippo Negroli of Milan. And who was Negroli? Why, the Michelangelo, the Cellini and the Giorgio Armani of this highly specialized profession, the most innovative and celebrated Italian armorer of the era.

title: ENTERGY IS BUYING TWO-THIRDS STAKE IN BULGARIAN UTILITY
description: The Entergy Corporation, the third-largest United States power producer, is buying two-thirds of a Bulgarian utility for $375 million in its first step into Eastern Europe's energy market. Entergy's 66 percent stake in a joint venture with the National Electricity Company of Bulgaria will give it control over the Maritza Iztok 3 thermal power station, which provides 10 percent to 12 percent of Bulgaria's electricity. The New Orleans-based Entergy will invest the money over four years to upgrade and modernize the station. After four years, Entergy will assume total ownership of the plant and sell the power to National Electricity.

title: Death Penalty Is Challenged In State Court
description: In the first test of New York's death penalty law before the state's highest court, lawyers challenging the law contended today that its plea-bargaining provisions were unconstitutional because they coerced defendants into pleading guilty rather than risking a death sentence.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Tuesday about the resignation of the fashion industry executives Adrienne Vittadini and Gianluigi Vittadini misstated their titles. Mrs. Vittadini was chairwoman of Adrienne Vittadini Enterprises Inc. and Mr. Vittadini was vice chairman; they did not hold those titles at the parent company, Marisa Christina Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, DAVID HOWARD
description: GRAY-David Howard of Wilmington, NC, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died Monday, October 12, 1998. He was born on November 9, 1907 in Brooklyn, N.Y. Surviving are his wife, Florence E. Gray; four children, eleven grandchildren, and ten great grandchildren. Interment will be held at a later date in Bellport, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Bridge; An 'Impossible' Contract Worth a Best-Play Award
description: Duplicate bridge players around the world probably play more than two billion deals in a year, so the task of selecting the best play is clearly impossible. The International Bridge Press Association attempts the task by limiting the scope to deals played on major occasions and published in its monthly Bulletin.

title: N.B.A. Owners Cool To Players' Proposal
