description: Players searched for a good pickup game, owners digested a new proposal and each side anxiously awaited an arbitration decision. The day after canceling regular-season games because of a labor dispute for the first time in its 51-year history, the National Basketball Association was marking time yesterday.

title: A Big and Familiarly Irish New York City Family
description: When Jill Clayburgh walks down a Manhattan street -- even now, 20 years after ''An Unmarried Woman'' -- she emanates an energetic hope and love of life that's contagious. But walking down the street, carrying groceries, is just about the most interesting thing her character is given to do in the first two episodes of ''Trinity,'' an NBC drama series that has its premiere tomorrow night. ''Trinity'' is about her five grown children.

title: Catholic Orthodoxy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits at New York Times Co. Rose 18.9% in Third Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 18.9 percent in the third quarter, as cost-control measures helped compensate for a slight weakness in advertising revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIALLONARDO, CONCETTO
description: DiGiallonardo-Concetto. The Seavey Organization mourns the great loss of its friend and Associate, Dino. He was a shining, bright light to us all, and leaves us with the fondest of memories. Dino will never be forgotten.

title: Chic Cuisine for a Parisian?Just Like Mother Used to Make
description: PARIS  When Ramdane Touhami threw a party to celebrate the opening of his new fashion store L'Epicerie, he wanted to create a cool and underground vibe. So he invited a select young crowd, organized a sit-down dinner and asked his mom to cook 190 plates of couscous.

title: Serbia Shuts 2 More Papers, Saying They Created Panic
description: Less than 24 hours after the American special envoy Richard C. Holbrooke swept out of here with a peace plan for Kosovo province, the man he negotiated with for nine days shut down two newspapers and renewed a decree against the freedom of the press.

title: Hunting, Wool, Allergy Pills: Pet Projects Are Promoted
description: Senator Trent Lott set his sights on extending Mississippi's duck-hunting season. Representative James T. Walsh wanted to cut the cost of imported Italian wool to tailors in Syracuse. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg sought to rewrite rules to prolong a big New Jersey drug-maker's monopoly on a popular allergy pill.

title: ABC Shelves Report on Parent Disney
description: ABC News has rejected a report by its leading investigative correspondent raising questions about hiring and safety policies at Disney World, the Florida theme parkowned by ABC's corporate parent, the Walt Disney Company.

title: Banks More Exposed Abroad, Fed Says
description: Overall American bank exposure to global markets rose substantially in the second quarter, according to a Federal Reserve survey released yesterday.

title: For the Padres, Hitchcock Becomes a Lifeboat
description: It wasn't quite the Titanic, but, for the Padres, it was akin to running into an iceberg in the neighborhood. And when things looked particularly leaky, Sterling Hitchcock offered himself as a lifeboat. And today, in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series, he came grim-lipped to the rescue.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; Role of the Pulpit
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Says Earnings Rose According to Expectations
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that its earnings from continuing operations rose roughly in line with expectations during the third quarter, as cost reductions and record sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in the United States offset losses overseas.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Green Bay (4-1) at Detroit (1-4)

title: A Tale Of Two Main Streets; The towns that inspired Disney are searching for a little magic of their own.
description: THE flapping American flags on lampposts and the pages of a paperback flipped by a shop owner on a bench outside her antiques store were the only things moving on a recent afternoon in downtown Marceline, Mo. There was one customer and one waitress down at Mom's Coffee Shop. Both were smoking. It was a landscape out of ''The Last Picture Show,'' except for the new street sign. It read ''Main Street USA,'' beneath a halo of mouse ears.

title: Woman Is Assaulted In Central Park
description: A woman was assaulted at knifepoint in Central Park last night by a man who tried to rape and rob her, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JOSEPH V.
description: MARCUS-Joseph V. On October 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Vivian, father to David and Linda, father-in-law to David Brawerman and Babs Marcus and loving grandfather of Melissa and Jaime Brawerman and Matthew and Erica Marcus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, ROBERT JOSEPH
description: O'CONNELL-Robert Joseph. Of Hilton Head Island, SC, formerly of Darien, CT died Monday, October 12. Survived by two daughters, Barbara O'Connell of Westport, CT and Nancy O'Connell Wiacek of Potomac, MD; a sister, Dorothy Grogan Lefstin of Lincolnwood, IL. and four beloved grandchildren, Katie, John, Billy and Michael Wiacek. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Luke's Church, Westport, CT on Sat, October 17, at 10A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Grandma, happy 5th birthday in heaven. Always in my thoughts. Love, Michael

title: Finding Linux Bargains
description: To the Editor:

title: Unemployment Rate Gets Closer to Nation's
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate inched closer to the nation's in September, when the state rate held at 4.8 percent compared with a slight rise nationwide, to 4.6 percent from 4.5 percent, the Federal Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: European Shipbuilder Ousts Chief Executive
description: Kvaerner A.S.A., Europe's largest shipbuilder, ousted its chief executive, Erik Toenseth, yesterday and said it would speed up the sale of noncore businesses to reduce debt. Kvaerner, which also has interests in oil and gas and in construction, said its chairman, Christian Bjelland, would act as interim chief executive.

title: Giving Birth to a Web Business
description: OLGA TERESHKO became an on-line entrepreneur because of a fussy baby.

title: Boss Stays Collected With Title In Hand
description: George Steinbrenner complained loudly about the umpiring after the Yankees lost Game 2 of the American League Championship Series on a controversial play, suggesting that baseball needed to figure out a way to get the best umpires in the most important games. Steinbrenner said nothing about the umpiring in Game 6, won by the Yankees -- but he could have.

title: Teen-Age Pregnancy Rate Drops in U.S., Report Says
description: The rate of teen-age pregnancies in the United States has dropped to its lowest rate in two decades, according to a new report by the Alan Guttmacher Institute.

title: THE TESTING GROUND: A special report; In Hebron, Peace Accord's Bitter Fruit
description: At one entrance to divided Hebron, before the dusty descent into the hellish heart of the old city, there is a carefully tended shrine to Dr. Baruch Goldstein, the Jewish settler who killed 29 Muslim worshipers before he was set upon and beaten to death by other Muslims.

title: Testimony Is Sought In 23-Year-Old Murder
description: State prosecutors will try again this week to force the father of two suspects in the 1975 murder of a Greenwich teen-ager to testify about his sons' involvement in the case, despite pleas by his lawyer that he is mentally incompetent.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 2 PERCENT. Prices dropped as moderate weather weakened demand for heating fuel and left ample supplies in storage. The November contract fell 4.3 cents, to $2.041 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Knee Surgery Scheduled for Guard
description: Tomora Young, who was second in scoring, assists and steals for the Rutgers women's team last season, will undergo surgery on her patellar tendon to relieve tendinitis in her left knee and will be sidelined six to eight weeks, the school announced yesterday.

title: U.N. Votes, 157-2, in Referendum to End U.S. Embargo of Cuba
description: In a General Assembly vote a record 157 countries today favored an end to the United States economic embargo of Cuba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, FRANK C., M.D.
description: MURPHY-Frank C., M.D. On October 13, 1998 at Concord, MA formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved brother of the late Kathleen N. Johnson, devoted uncle of John B. Johnson and his wife Andrea of Wellesley, MA. Frank C. Johnson of Vienna, VA and Gerard M. Johnson and his wife Donna Milmore of Melrose, MA. Also survived by eight grandnephews and nieces. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of St. Saviour, Friday, 12 noon. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Saviour Church, 611 8th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11215. For further information call Henry Mc Caddin & Son 718789-2222.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday appeared under an incorrect subheading. The first Family Concert by the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall will be on Saturday at 2 P.M., with a pre-concert program of storytelling at 1 P.M. The orchestra did not perform yesterday.

title: Top Fugitive's Arrest Revives Turkish Corruption Inquiry
description: The arrest of Turkey's most-wanted fugitive has shaken the Government and opened an additional chapter in a long-running investigation of ties among politicians, gangsters and police officers.

title: Black F.B.I. Agents Renew Bias Complaint
description: Five years after the Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed to a ground-breaking settlement with black agents who had complained of racial discrimination in promotions, the agents' lawyers went back to court today and accused the F.B.I. of failing repeatedly to change the personnel system.

title: Final Details On the Budget Taking Shape
description: Congressional Republicans and White House officials appeared near a budget agreement tonight, providing substantial new aid to schools and farmers in a total budget package of $1.7 trillion.

title: Canadian Phone Companies Discuss Merger
description: BC Telecom Inc. and the Telus Corporation said today that they were in talks to merge. Such a combination would join Canada's second- and third-largest phone companies to create a stronger competitor to Bell Canada.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rights Report Blames Paramilitary Forces in Colombia Violence
description: Gruesome and dependent on the connivance of army officers as it was, the ravaging of the town of Mapiripan was singular just in the size of the operation and the logistics involved, a report by a human rights group says.

title: Indian Wins Nobel Award In Economics
description: Amartya Sen won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work on human rights, poverty and inequality that has changed the way governments deal with famines and for what the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said had ''restored an ethical dimension to the discussion of vital economics problems.''

title: Bear Stearns Net Falls 60% Amid the Market's Downturn
description: The Bear Stearns Companies became the latest United States brokerage firm to post sharply lower earnings as the sudden reversal in stock and bond markets worldwide cut into the firm's trading and investment banking profits.

title: Devils Manage a Goal, but Still Lose One to the Penguins
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins franchise may have declared bankruptcy, but the team prospered on the ice tonight, thanks mainly to the Devils' generosity in turning the puck over and their philosophy of letting Jaromir Jagr roam Continental Arena's ice at will.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, THOMAS B., JR.
description: CAMPBELL-Thomas B., Jr. , 87, formerly of Brooklyn, died October 11, 1998, Worcester, MA. Former middle school teacher, PS 27, Brooklyn. Husband of the late Kathryn (Hannon). Survived by son, Roger C. of Ridgewood, NJ, daughter, Nancy K. Horan, Princeton, MA, six grandchildren. Funeral was held in St. John's Church, Worcester. Interment L.I. National Cemetery. Donations to Arthritis Foundation, Mass. Chapter, 29 Craft St., Newton, MA 02160.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dressing for Success: Check These Salaries
description: Many shoppers know that when they are buying a designer shirt, they are paying for a bit of glamour associated with the name. Investors in apparel companies may not know that glamorous names in executive suites can come with a high price, too.

title: Daiwa Securities Seeks Buyer for Europe Unit
description: The Daiwa Securities Company said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for its British banking unit, Daiwa Europe Bank P.L.C., as Japanese financial institutions continue to scale back in the face of Japan's worst recession since World War II. Daiwa, the second-largest Japanese brokerage firm, said the bank had $:1.35 billion ($2.3 billion) in assets and shareholders' capital of about $:160 million. A price in the range of $:160 million to $:240 million is considered likely.

title: Schumer Says D'Amato Puts 'Ideology Ahead of People'
description: Trying to link Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to the conservative Republican leadership in Congress, Representative Charles E. Schumer, his Democratic challenger, attacked the incumbent yesterday for supporting cuts in Federal education spending and for failing to fight House Speaker Newt Gingrich's Contract With America.

title: Cabbies' Gambling Is Stopped at Kennedy
description: Until last week, the six wooden picnic tables in the taxi holding lot at Kennedy International Airport formed a little oasis where a cabby could step outside his yellow cell and stretch his legs or enjoy a meal while waiting to be summoned to pick up a fare.

title: HDTV's Mixed Signals
description: WHD-TV, the broadcast industry's experimental high-definition television station, doesn't have many regular viewers. In fact, the actual number is one.

title: Compaq's Earnings Slightly Top Forecasts
description: The clouds seem to be clearing a little faster than expected at the Compaq Computer Corporation, the world's largest maker of personal computers.

title: Economic Scene; Economists raise questions about educational priorities.
description: President Clinton has fought hard this week, in the final stage of budget negotiations, to protect his proposal to spend $1 billion as the first step in hiring 100,000 additional teachers to reduce class size in early grades. Mr. Clinton linked his proposal to the grand ambition of preparing the economy for the 21st century.

title: From Roots of Lilt and Punk
description: If clothes made the man, Elvis Costello's tuxedo would have turned him into a suavely heartsick pop balladeer when he and Burt Bacharach started their tour together at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night. A small orchestra accompanied them as they performed the new songs they wrote together for the album ''Painted From Memory'' (Mercury) along with medleys of Mr. Bacharach's hits and new orchestral arrangements of Costello songs like ''Accidents Will Happen'' and ''Alison.''

title: For Bottom Fishers, Nary a Nibble
description: AS the stock market lurches like an elevator out of control, a growing number of would-be apartment buyers are seeking to take advantage of the current uncertainty by making ''take it or leave it'' bargain-basement offers on co-ops and condominiums -- and getting nowhere, brokers say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JERNIGAN, KENNETH
description: JERNIGAN-Kenneth. We mourn the passsing of Kenneth Jernigan the longtime president of the National Federation of the Blind. Mr. Jernigan worked tirelessly to ensure equal access to employment and public accomodations for people who are blind. He dedicated his life's work to dispelling stereotypes and inspiring people with impaired vision to lead independent and productive lives. We have lost a true ally and friend. Barbara Silverstone, President Staff of Lighthouse International

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Sidney. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center sadly mourn the untimely passing of Sidney Goldstein, beloved father of our long-standing and esteemed Board Member and President of Metropolitan Jewish Health Systems, Mark L. Goldstein. All of us join in grieving for this distinquished and honorable individual. We share in the family's sorrow at this difficult time. May his legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom he touched. We extend sincere condolences and deepest sympathies to his dear family. John H. Wolff, President Eli S. Feldman, Chief Executive Officer

title: Apple's First Annual Profit Since 1995
description: Sounding a confident note of personal vindication, Steven P. Jobs, the interim chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., announced today that the company earned $106 million in its fourth quarter and was reporting its first profitable year since 1995.

title: Budget Deal in Congress to Give Clinton the Full $18 Billion Sought for the I.M.F.
description: The budget deal being worked out tonight on Capitol Hill provides the full $18 billion requested by the Clinton Administration for the International Monetary Fund, apparently ending a months-long struggle by the Administration to persuade Congress that the money is vital to the fund's efforts to stem a global financial crisis.

title: Account Decisions From Media Companies
description: Two entertainment media companies made decisions yesterday involving their accounts.

title: Vogue for Neutrals Reflects Shift in Approach to Color : Redefining the Spectrum
description: PARIS  At the end of the 20th century, fashion seems to have entered a twilight zone. Designers are talking up color for the new season. But the reality in Western capitals is a color spectrum that ranges from black to colorless neutrals, while bright colors have been relegated to street signs, cars and household appliances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HATTIE
description: SCHWARTZ-Hattie. Beloved wife of the late William Schwartz; dear mother of the late Penny Binn Binstock; devoted son-in-law, Moreton Binn; loving grandmother of Jeffrey/Asako, Jonathan & Jason Binn. Died peacefully in Florida on Monday, October 12. Graveside services will be held on Friday, October 16, at 10:50 A.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery, 134-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, New York 11352.

title: Time Warner Has a Return To Profitability in Quarter
description: Time Warner Inc. reported a $39 million third-quarter profit yesterday, reversing a $35 million loss the year before, on a rebound in the company's music division and gains in its cable networks, publishing and television operations.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; Seize the Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: On Your Left, 2 Guys With Pocket Protectors
description: WE must have been the only high-tech sightseers within miles. ''Driving down the Central Expressway now, and soon we're going to see, uh, Applied Materials and National Semiconductor,'' said Ed Pansullo on a Thursday morning in Silicon Valley. Mr. Pansullo is the only tour guide here specializing in technology tours for the public. ''Mitsubishi will come up on the left-hand side, and on the right is the new headquarters of Yahoo.'' He valiantly tried to sound excited, but through a smoggy haze, we stared at darkish office buildings and motionless parking lots. In a slapstick effort to stay awake, Mr. Pansullo, 49, slapped his face with his tie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ANDREW B.
description: MYERS-Andrew B. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and friend, Andrew B. Myers, and send condolences to his family.

title: Choosing a Nanny
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; A National Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Business Giant Begins Transition to Sons
description: Carlos Slim Helu, the billionaire Mexican businessman, has handed two of his sons the leadership of Grupo Carso S.A. de C.V., the company where he began the climb that made him the richest man in Latin America.

title: Deeper Failures in the Livoti Case
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir want to put the 1994 choking death of Anthony Baez behind them. But their continued attempts to paint the case as the aberrant act of one rogue cop, Francis Livoti, shows they are not facing up to the New York City Police Department's systemic failure to crack down on brutality and cover-ups of brutality. The recent sentencing of Mr. Livoti and the city's decision to pay Mr. Baez's family nearly $3 million to settle a wrongful-death lawsuit by no means answer all the key questions.

title: PEPSICO'S CHAIRMAN WARNS OF A TOUGH FOURTH QUARTER
description: The chairman of Pepsico Inc., Roger A. Enrico, said yesterday that the company faced a tough fourth quarter as increased investment spending and the impact from the recent turmoil overseas finally hit the bottom line. Mr. Enrico made the comment in the company's quarterly earnings conference call. The company expects operating income for the fourth quarter to be flat with a year earlier, even with the recently acquired Tropicana Beverages Inc. under its umbrella. Pepsi's fourth quarter began in early September. The company has also sharply increased its marketing spending behind new products. Shares of Pepsico fell $1.25 a share yesterday, to $30.75.

title: Audit Shows Flaws With Metrocard System
description: In the first comprehensive audit of New York City's Metrocard system, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall warned yesterday that there are flaws in the way the transit agency keeps track of the cards, leaving them vulnerable to employee theft or abuse.

title: Casino Ship Operator Rolls the Dice; Plan Would Turn a Brooklyn Marina Into a Gambling Hub
description: When Michael Kornblum, founder of Bay Casino, presented his plans for a ''destination attraction'' in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, the neighborhood's community board meeting erupted into a Jerry Springer-like debate. Hecklers called Mr. Kornblum a liar. One man unbuttoned his shirt and challenged another man to a fight.

title: From Outsider to Starter, Young Savors Return to Giants
description: In September, Rodney Young watched on television as the Giants opened their season against the Washington Redskins.

title: Murder of a Gay Man: It Can't Happen Here?; Close State Gaps
description: To the Editor:

title: From 1 Device, 2 Kinds of Images
description: Vacationers, doting parents and business people who cannot decide whether to ''capture the moment'' with still photographs or videotape may no longer have to decide which camera to pack. A new digital camera from Hitachi records still and video digital images and audio tracks -- but it is not cheap.

title: Fan Is Deluged With Offers For Home Run Ball No. 70
description: Michael Freedland, a local lawyer who is fielding offers on behalf of the man who retrieved Mark McGwire's historic 70th home run, thought he had heard about everything in the nearly three weeks he has been on the job.

title: A Question of Empathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Holding Their Breath As the Curtain Rises
description: Underwater, 17 feet down, on the bottom of the pool that serves as the stage at the theater of the new Bellagio Hotel here, the divers were shooting craps. Ordinarily, even though they're mostly unseen by the audience (they're never offstage, just under it), these are the busiest performers in the new Cirque du Soleil extravaganza ''O,'' which opens here on Oct. 19.

title: Krishna Sect Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKMAN, IRENE, NEE SAIDMAN
description: STECKMAN-Irene, nee Saidman, age 86, on October 14 in Tamarac FL, formerly of Staten Island. Beloved wife of Maurice, devoted mother of Walter (Joyce) and Donna Powell. Cherished G-ma to Billy, Bobby, Robert and Vanessa.

title: Growing Up and Freshening Up at Givenchy and Chloe
description: PARIS  Young Turks growing up and established designers freshening up  that was the story at the spring/summer shows Wednesday. But nobody has yet stamped the season with an indelible fashion moment  even if designers are generally spreading a little prettiness.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: SPECIALTY FOODS TO PAY $100 MILLION FOR TWO COMPANIES
description: The Specialty Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Archway Cookies Inc. and the San Diego Bread Company for more than $100 million as Specialty, a closely held food maker, concentrates on its baking business. The acquisitions will make Specialty Foods the third-largest United States cookie maker, said Lawrence S. Benjamin, chief executive. Specialty, based in Deerfield, Ill., produces Mother's cookies and other food products distributed in the Midwest and West. Archway, based in Battle Creek, Mich., makes more than a billion cookies a year.

title: Henry Hyde's Next Letter
description: As chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Henry Hyde has primary authority for setting the speed and scope of the impeachment inquiry. In recent days he has used that authority in responsible ways. The latest example is his proposal to consolidate the charges about President Clinton's conduct in the Monica Lewinsky scandal into three core categories -- lying under oath, obstruction of justice and witness-tampering.

title: One Man's Long Love Affair With Gadgets Plain and Fancy
description: AFTER the Little Bighorn, according to the writer Evan S. Connell, ''one Cheyenne pulled a flat, round object out of a trooper's pocket.'' ''This thing was made of white metal and glass, with black marks under the glass,'' he went on, ''and was thought to be alive because of the noise it made. The Cheyennes decided this must be the soldiers' medicine, so the warrior kept it. But the next day it died. He threw it away -- as far as possible.''

title: African-American Improvisation
description: If quilters are musicians, Frank Maresca said, then the Amish are classicists who reinterpret the same designs, generation after generation, and African-Americans are jazz artists, who improvise on the spot. Mr. Maresca and Roger Ricco are presenting ''Rhythms: The African-American Textile Esthetic,'' a show of 14 quilts by African-American women, at their gallery, 529 West 20th Street.

title: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty in the Killings of 8 Women
description: Kendall L. Francois, in a soft-spoken and polite manner, pleaded not guilty today to the serial killings of eight women, but once the women's families began taunting him from their seats here in Dutchess County Court, he threw back his head and laughed softly.

title: Lynn L. Hageman, 67, Founder Of Center for Addicts in Harlem
description: The Rev. Lynn L. Hageman, a pioneer in drug counseling and the founder of Exodus House, a nationally known drug treatment center in East Harlem, died in his apartment at the center on Oct. 3. He was 67.

title: Cartoon Characters Give Web Sites Their Master's Voice
description: New software called Agent 7 can help personalize a Web site with an animated character that speaks in one's own voice.

title: Scents of the Everyday Locked in a Bottle
description: TECHNO fragrances are the coming thing,'' said Christopher Brosius of Demeter, the company whose line of fragrances won the best of show award last week at Extracts, the trade show at the Javits Center. Demeter offers little bottles of real-world fragrances like Rubber, Dirt and Vinyl. The company is working hard on Gasoline, a fragrance that will offer less the raw smell of petrol than ''the idea of gasoline,'' Mr. Brosius said.

title: Mounting a Defense Against Millennium Bug
description: The news that 10 percent of the nation's top executives are stockpiling canned goods, buying generators and even purchasing handguns cannot be all that good. Are they worried about the Russians coming, the collapse of the Dow, a wayward asteroid?

title: Topics of The Times; Nobel Oblige
description: This year's Nobel Prize in economics is going to Amartya Sen, whose work has focused on helping the poor and on analyzing how government policies can cause starvation even when food is available.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CML GROUP INC., Acton, Mass., said it would cut 300 jobs, or about 25 percent of the work force, at its Nordictrack fitness equipment subsidiary, to reduce costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, PEGGY
description: STEIN - Peggy. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the passing of our beloved member, Peggy Stein. We will always remember her love of family, and abiding Jewish commitment. We send deepest condolences to her husband Bernard, their children, Robert Stein and Lynn Igel, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: New Hardware Offers Cheaper Long-Distance
description: While AT&T and MCI bash each other's brains out in an effort to attract long-distance callers, a Silicon Valley startup hopes to offer an alternative that relies not on telephone connections but on Internet ones.

title: How Farmers Get Lemonade From Apples
description: TWO weeks of spring rain kept the bees from pollinating the apple trees, cutting the normal crop by one-third. The same wet weather swelled and then cracked the cherries, while the dull skies stunted the hothouse tomatoes.

title: Iran-Contra, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue in Iran Democracy Debate: Clerics' Power
description: In a country lurching between old oppression and new freedoms, Heshmatollah Tabarzadi has kept his bloodstained shirt as a kind of two-edged reminder -- of the peril in outspokenness and the pleasure of speaking out.

title: In America; Learning What Normal Is
description: The two women, Gayle Walcott and Kelly Hawkins, were upbeat, clear-eyed, well dressed, engaging, intelligent and drug-addicted. Both have had their lives ruined by crack, the bargain-basement innovation that brought cocaine to the poor and a nightmare to the nation's cities.

title: REPTRON AND ALL AMERICAN TERMINATE $40 MILLION DEAL
description: Reptron Electronics Inc. and All American Semiconductor Inc. have terminated negotiations to merge the two companies' distribution businesses. No further details were disclosed. Under the $40 million deal first announced in June and amended in September, Reptron was to combine All American's operations into its electronics distribution business. All American stockholders were to exchange each of their shares for a minimum of $2 in cash and Reptron stock. In the three weeks after the announcement of the amended deal, however, the price of Reptron shares fell to $4.25 from $6.25, reducing the value of the stock portion of the deal. All American Semiconductor, based in Miami, and Reptron, based in Tampa, Fla., distribute electronic components.

title: Primestar Drops Plan to Buy Satellite Venture
description: Primestar Inc., the satellite television service owned by a group of cable operators, has abandoned a $1.1 billion plan to buy the direct-broadcast satellite venture of the News Corporation and MCI Worldcom Inc.

title: The Experts On Elegance
description: EMILY POST'S COMPLETE GUIDE TO WEDDINGS

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The dollar rose against the German currency after two Bundesbank council members suggested that the central bank might cut interest rates. The dollar settled at 1.6426 marks, up from 1.6342.

title: Harlem Rally's Leader Turns Up at Hearing
description: Heads turned at an otherwise routine public hearing in City Hall yesterday when an unexpected visitor walked through the doors: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the minister who has not been seen much in the city since he led a rally in Harlem last month that ended in brief violence.

title: Kosovo's Albanians Give Truce Pact Poor Reviews
description: With their suffering seeming to have forced Western Governments to face down Yugoslavia's President, the man regarded as their tormentor, many ethnic Albanians in Kosovo today were nonetheless not optimistic that the agreement announced Tuesday would achieve even the West's limited objectives.

title: Hyde Promises a Streamlined Clinton Inquiry
description: Sensing public hostility to the impeachment inquiry, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee today promised a streamlined investigation and said that if it was not completed by Dec. 31, Democratic obstruction would be the reason.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about a licensing agreement between Moviefone Inc. and United Artists Theater Circuit misstated the ownership of the chain. It is a closely held company controlled by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners and management; it is not owned by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst.

title: Saving Kosovo Lives, Or U.S. Skins?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. Tells Toys 'R' Us to End Anticompetitive Measures
description: The Federal Trade Commission unanimously upheld today an earlier ruling by an administrative law judge that Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, had colluded with manufacturers to prevent competing retailers from offering toys at lower prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. October 10, 1998. Faithful husband of Joan BrandtCates. Loving father of Phillip, Valerie, Phoebe and Alexandra Cates and stepfather of Wilson Brandt. Adoring grandfather of Owen Joseph and Greta Simone Kline. Devoted brother of Gil Cates and Kit Adler. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, October 15, 6-9PM with service Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Friars Foundation, Inc., 57 E. 55 St, NY, NY 10022.

title: Operating Income Plunges at BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation surprised analysts and investors yesterday by reporting that operating earnings fell 50 percent in the third quarter to $893 million, or 50 cents a share -- well below the 90 cents a share expected by analysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKENS, KATHLEEN
description: LUKENS-Kathleen. The College of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of Kathleen Lukens, compassionate champion of the developmentally disabled, 1984 recipient of the Doctor of Humane Letters degree, and beloved wife of Dr. John Lukens of the psychology department. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU, Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D, President

title: Facing the Ghosts of Our Past
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about calcium misidentified Dr. Susan Thys-Jacobs, a researcher at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York who links chronic calcium deficiency to the disruptive symptoms of premenstrual syndrome. She is an endocrinologist, not a gynecologist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAG, DR. SAMUEL M.
description: HAAG-Dr. Samuel M., 89. Of W. Nyack, NY. On October 15, 1998. Survived by wife, Jeannette Browdy; daughter, Frances; son, Arthur, Aline and their family; and grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Funeral Sunday, 2 P.M. Congregation Sons of Israel, Upper Nyack, N.Y. For information, call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 914-356-8600.

title: Well, It's Not Exactly Your Father's Piano Trio
description: If good intentions and a willing audience could have done anything, the Ahn Trio's concert at the Miller Theater would have been an exciting occasion. The three sisters in the group have evidently decided to give their aged medium, the piano trio, a kick into the late 20th century, in terms both of repertory and presentation. Under the sobriquet ''Ahn-Plugged,'' they have started a project to commission, perform and record new works, and on Tuesday they delivered the results for the first time. Perhaps this was the first piano trio recital since the 1770's at which almost everything on the program had not been heard before.

title: Stadiums Inspected
description: Officials of the organizing committee for the 1999 Women's World Cup, which will be played in the United States from June 19 to July 10, began an inspection yesterday of the eight stadiums that will stage the games. Their first stop was Giants Stadium, which will play host to the opening ceremonies and a doubleheader involving the United States on June 19.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: James Welling

title: Fox Comes to the Series With an All-Star Team
description: Ask Tim McCarver about his World Series experiences and he goes numb.

title: Deal to Pay Back American U.N. Dues Collapses Over Abortion
description: A deal that would have allowed the United States to pay $200 million in back dues to the United Nations as part of the overall Federal budget agreement collapsed after the issue became entangled once again in the politics of abortion, Clinton Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZBERG, FLORENCE
description: HERZBERG-Florence. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Checketts Creates a Stir On a Day of Some Progress
description: In what could be construed as minor progress, National Basketball Association owners will deliver a response today to the players' latest proposal. But the chance for a speedy resolution to the league's labor morass appears to be fading with most other new developments.

title: Before the Yankees Take the Field...
description: Enter the front door of the rectangular-shaped clubhouse at Yankee Stadium, and Bernie Williams's locker is located to your right, in the corner. This used to be Don Mattingly's locker, and as the team's elder statesman, Williams had first dibs when Mattingly retired. Every other locker is about five feet deep, but Williams's space has enough room to envelop the center fielder, his chair, the guitar Williams likes to play and a small amplifier. Stop by early in the afternoon and sometimes Williams peacefully strums out familiar songs like ''Purple Rain,'' wearing his own purple sunglasses.

title: Zap, a Nervy Internet Venture, Is Zapped
description: A brazen plan by the Zapata Corporation to weave a World Wide Web of gold from Internet straw through a financial maneuver known as a roll-up has unrolled.

title: Congress Staggers Home
description: After three weeks of partisan bickering and four emergency budget extensions to keep the Government running, Congress reached final agreement yesterday on a $500 billion spending package. The awkward and furtive way in which it crawled to the finish line will do nothing to improve its image with the voters, who already hold Congress in much lower esteem than they do the President. Indeed, if there was any winner at all in this inglorious endgame, it was Bill Clinton, who demonstrated that even an embattled President can wield considerable power, especially when his poll numbers are climbing while Congress's sag.

title: 4 Young Women Watch the Clock
description: For a challenging little movie with good reviews but without a lot of promotion, ''Clockwatchers'' has done quite well for itself in theaters, where it has played for five months in about 80 cities and earned more than $500,000 at the box office. Now it is time for video.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, MORRIS
description: BLASER-Morris. October 16, 1966. Cherished father, grandfather. We never forget you. Love, Blaser family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECHTSCHAFFEN, RUDOLPH
description: RECHTSCHAFFEN-Rudolph. Our heartfelt condolences to our dear friends the Rechtschaffens on their loss of their dear brother. Marilyn and Stanley Barry

title: Search for Truth Is Not a Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleveland Amory Dies at 81; Writer and Animal Advocate
description: Cleveland Amory, social historian, novelist, television critic and animal rights advocate, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Jet Dumps Fuel Over Homes in Queens
description: An American Airlines jet dumped fuel yesterday onto some Queens homes while returning to Kennedy International Airport shortly after takeoff when a bird apparently flew into an engine.

title: For Yankees, 70's Flashback Fitting for 90's
description: The last time the Yankees played in World Series so close together, they lost one (1976) and won two (1977 and 1978). There was a direct correlation between the one failure and the two successes.

title: A Cruel Pecking Order Among Flighty Peacocks
description: A-gays look good in the shower, so ''All the Rage'' opens with close-ups of soaping up and rinsing, with beads of water thrilled to be on such perfect gym-toned skin. A-gays have fabulous kitchens, work out religiously (''Today I do chest and arms''), have windowed offices on high floors and sneer when someone sends roses after the first date (and to the office! with a note! that he signed!). A-gays know who they are.

title: D'Amato Cites Storm Aid And Schumer Gun Control
description: In a day of dueling news conferences 500 miles apart, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato campaigned upstate yesterday, emphasizing his efforts to help storm victims, while Representative Charles E. Schumer, his Democratic rival, appeared in Washington with the mother of an 11-year-old girl killed by gunfire, to attack the Senator's opposition to gun control.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: EUROPEAN CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Do Not Disturb: Ace in Thought
description: The Padres, who were not expected to beat the Houston Astros in the first round of this year's National League playoffs, beat Houston. The Padres, who were not expected to beat the Atlanta Braves in the National League Championship Series, beat Atlanta. The Padres are not expected to beat the Yankees in the World Series. But they give the Yankees considerable food for thought. Particularly in the lanky person of Kevin Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, OLGA
description: GLUCKMAN-Olga. On October 15, 1998. Beloved music teacher and friend to many. Her vitality and her gift for making life more interesting for those around her will be missed by many of those she knew.

title: In a Tour Boat's Net, A City and Its Past
description: No man is an island, nor woman either. Manhattan, however, certainly is, and on occasion it's refreshing to look at it from the surrounding waters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. in his 81st year. The officers, directors, staff and volunteers the world over mourn the sudden death of our founder, President, and guiding intellect and spirit. Mr. Amory founded the Fund for Animals in 1967 and has led it every inch of the way while tirelessly continuing his career as a best-selling author. We will of course continue to serve animals, large and small, all of whom he loved, but without him it won't be the same. We will not see his like again. Memorial service to be announced. The Fund for Animals

title: In a Super-Cute Coven, A Witches' Brew for Men
description: ''Practical Magic'' has a new look for Halloween: super-cute. It's Barbie Joins a Coven time as Sandra Bullock and Nicole Kidman shake their long flossy hair and play witch sisters with otherworldly decorative qualities. In a bouncy, bubble-brained movie with the look of a shelter magazine, they flounce through a domesticated story in which magic is for dealing with menfolk and brooms look all too comfortably at home. ''C'mon, ladies, let's clean house!'' is the battle cry in the big broom scene at the end.

title: Fight Over Statistical Sampling in 2000 Is Postponed
description: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today to postpone their fight over the use of statistical sampling in the 2000 Census until the Supreme Court decides whether the method is a legal way to conduct the nation's official headcount.

title: Decorum Is Not on Agenda At Gubernatorial Debate
description: The civility of the Connecticut governor's race, in which even the television commercials have been tame, evaporated tonight as Gov. John G. Rowland and his Democratic challenger, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, scrapped during a debate over issues as large as the state's school system and as trivial as how they should refer to each other.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Modern Acquires New Sculptures

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Hope Floats

title: Sun Microsystems Net Up 5%, Exceeding Analysts' Estimates
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. reported earnings today for its first fiscal quarter that modestly exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. Sun officials said sales growth was strong across all product lines and geographic regions with the exception of Asia.

title: Clinton Officials Say I.M.F. Deal Expands Strategies to Halt Crisis
description: With the final agreement struck today in Congress to inject $18 billion into the depleted coffers of the International Monetary Fund, Clinton Administration officials said they now have more political leeway to attempt new strategies in fighting the continuing global financial turmoil.

title: Cargo Handlers Guilty Of Mail Theft at Airport
description: Two former employees of a cargo-handling company that works with the United States Postal Service admitted yesterday to stealing merchandise worth more than $26,000 from parcels of mail being loaded and unloaded from airplanes at Newark International Airport, Federal prosecutors said.

title: YUGOSLAV LEADER IS NOT COMPLYING WITH KOSOVO PACT
description: About a dozen Serbian policemen armed with AK-47 automatic rifles sauntered today around the same brick house where they were camped a week ago, in sight of ethnic Albanian villages on a ridge.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON DROPS 3.3 PERCENT. Prices slumped on concern demand will weaken because of global economic turmoil, despite one of the smallest crops in years. The December contract fell 2.35 cents, to 69.1 cents a pound.

title: Indonesia's Anguish
description: Eighteen months ago, Indonesia was one of the developing world's most confident and successful nations. Today it has a President, B. J. Habibie, without political legitimacy who is trying to save tens of millions of people from hunger, calm ethnic tensions and right an economy in which perhaps half the citizens are now poor and half the companies bankrupt. But Indonesia cannot recover until it becomes a stable and democratic nation, with political institutions for fighting corruption and addressing dissatisfaction before it turns into riots and ethnic unrest.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mike Bidlo

title: Australian Patient's Transplanted Hand Is Doing Well in France
description: The world's only person with somebody else's fingerprints is expected to leave a French hospital today with the transplanted hand and forearm he received there three weeks ago, his doctors said yesterday.

title: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: Opulence at the Armory, With a Slight Hedge
description: Over the last decade, exhibitors at the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show have seen it all. They remember the flush days of the late 1980's when collectors elbowed one another to be the first through the heavy carved oak doors of the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, dropping several million dollars on a chic little table or a pair of unusual chairs. But they also remember the bleak years of the early 90's when the crowds came but almost nobody spent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPHIR, ROBERT
description: SAPHIR-Robert. The Executive Board, Board of Governors and Members of The New York State Camp Directors Association mourn the death of their esteemed past President and founding father. Bob served as President NYSCDA for over 20 years and will always be remembered for his efforts and energy on our behalf. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Shirley, children Marc, Marge and Bob and grandchildren Douglas and Kate. David Fleischner, President

title: Observer; Marlowe Goes to Market
description: It was grisly in Manhattan. People were riding around in those ridiculous-looking three-bedroom limousines sobbing.

title: Brazilian Troupe Kicks Up Its Heels at Tradition
description: ''Cisne negro'' means ''black swan.'' But the Cisne Negro Dance Company has nothing to do with ''Swan Lake'' or any other balletic classic. Rather, this is a high-powered Brazilian contemporary dance troupe from Sao Paulo, which gave a stimulating program on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. All four works were unfamiliar to New York. And the dancers, under Hulda Bittencourt's direction, performed with an admirable combination of discipline and vitality.

title: Men Held in Beating Lived on the Fringes
description: Within two hours one night last week, Poudre Valley Hospital in Fort Collins, Colo., admitted two young men from different sides of a social and sexual chasm in the small city of Laramie, Wyo.

title: A Soft, Voluminous Look Is Edging Out Skinny Silhouette : Loosening Up on Slim Chic
description: PARIS  Look down any chilly street this fall in Paris and what will you see: beautiful young girls with Mona Lisa smiles in crunchy knit tunics and A-line floor-sweeping skirts preferably in boiled wool. The fashion faithful these days is sliding into a new silhouette, one that makes top to bottom skinny chic and stilettos look like old hash.

title: A Wild Season's Perfect Hero
description: DAVID WELLS was one of the last players in the sticky clubhouse after the Yankees danced into the World Series on Tuesday night, still jabbering and finding out where the team was going to celebrate. The glossy trophy that Wells received as the most valuable player of the American League Championship Series was sitting on the carpet like a pair of soiled socks, next to a stack of fan mail and some cleats.

title: Agency Chief Says Prisoners Still Receive Deficient Care
description: The chairman of a city watchdog agency said yesterday that some prisoners in city jails are continuing to receive deficient care under a managed-care contract instituted by the Giuliani administration in January.

title: End Insanity Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Monsanto's Profits Are Hurt By Product Development Costs
description: The Monsanto Company, one of the world's largest agricultural biotechnology companies, reported a 15.5 percent decline in third-quarter earnings today, in part because of higher costs associated with developing new products and absorbing acquired seed businesses.

title: No Peace From A Brutal Legacy
description: The pivotal event in ''Beloved'' is the arrival of a breathtaking apparition. A beautiful young woman dressed in mourning is washed up on a riverbank, caught in a trancelike state on the verge of drowning. In the most exquisitely strange moments of Jonathan Demme's transfixing, deeply felt adaptation of Toni Morrison's novel, this creature seems poised at the crossroads where the supernatural and natural worlds meet. Bugs and butterflies mysteriously herald her arrival into the lives of the story's other characters, who have their own kind of strangeness; they know what it means to be haunted. They take the otherworldly in stride. Ghostly spirits already dominate their lives.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN MEDICAL SECURITY GROUP INC., Green Bay, Wis., a health benefits provider, agreed to buy most of the group health insurance business of CNA Financial Corp., a property and causualty insurer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Delta Results Set a Record For Quarter
description: Confounding investors worried about a weakening economy, Delta Air Lines reported record quarterly earnings yesterday, easily surpassing Wall Street's estimates.

title: After a Loss, Merrill Replaces Risk Manager
description: Merrill Lynch & Company demoted the executive in charge of managing the firm's financial risk taking yesterday, two days after Merrill announced a steep loss in the latest quarter related to turmoil in stock and bond markets.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: Tenement Museum Bill Approved by the Senate
description: The United States Senate has approved a bill to designate the Lower East Side Tenement Museum a ''national historic area,'' and the bill has been sent to President Clinton.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Rules to Speed Stock and Bond Offerings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules today to let public companies sell their stocks and bonds more quickly and cheaply as part of a comprehensive move to simplify corporate finance disclosure.

title: A Robbery in Central Park May be Linked to Earlier One
description: A pedestrian was robbed at knifepoint in Central Park last night, the second such incident in two days, the police said. And based on descriptions given by the victims, investigators say they believe that the crimes were committed by the same man.

title: Sumitomo Bank to Cut 2,000 Jobs in 5 Years
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd., one of Japan's largest lenders, said yesterday that it will slash its retail staff by 2,000, or 40 percent, in the next five years, as it reorganizes its branches to cut costs. The Osaka-based bank, which has 280 branches that handle a mix of corporate and individual clients, will separate its retail operations from its corporate business, a spokesman said. It will handle corporate customers at 110 sites nationwide, he said.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration on Wednesday showing plans for the renovation of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan omitted a credit. The rendering was by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum/New York.

title: Clinton Down, Not Out
description: President Clinton only looked powerless.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMBRIA, BARBARA SCHMIDT
description: CAMBRIA-Barbara Schmidt. 1/8/53-10/16/97. Forever in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFAIL, AZMY
description: RAFAIL-Azmy. age 68. Of Port Washington, L.I., on October 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Ida. Devoted brother of Hayat and Sofie Rafail. Brother-in-law of Drs. Maher and Mokhtar Estafan and Dr. Laila Basta. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Friday 7-9PM. Funeral service Saturday 9:30AM, St. Mark's Coptic Orthodox Church, Woodbury. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington.

title: Trade Group Faults U.S. on Shrimp Rules
description: The World Trade Organization has ruled that the United States is not evenhandedly applying a law that bans certain shrimp imports, while saying that the law itself does not violate trade rules.

title: Trump Starts A New Tower Near the U.N.
description: Donald J. Trump, who has already left his sizable imprint on New York City's skyline, is starting work on what he says will be the tallest residential building in the world, a $360 million slender glass monolith across the street from the United Nations complex.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Producer Prices Edge Upward; Analysts Call Increase a Fluke
description: Higher costs for new cars and trucks pushed up the prices paid to producers in September at the fastest rate in a year, a statistical fluke that analysts said did not portend a lasting acceleration of inflation.

title: A Hybrid Riffcom-Sitcom-Fatcom
description: It's revealing that the set for ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy'' is a vast, cluttered garage, because the production that unfolds around it is a big fat mess.

title: INSIDE
description: Violent Protests in Paris

title: Opposing Teams Have Enough Connections to Bridge a Continent
description: Hideki Irabu's head fell back slightly and he laughed aloud yesterday, after being asked about how San Diego fans might boo him generously during the World Series because of how he essentially forced the Padres to trade him to the Yankees in 1997. Through an interpreter, Irabu said, ''That was then and this is now.''

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Still Counting

title: Fairies Adrift in Love's Garden
description: Bertie Wooster, the dimwitted swell of P. G. Wodehouse's ''Jeeves'' novels, didn't get many things right. But he did show unusual wisdom in his perception that a certain kind of woman was dangerous. It wasn't so much hardhearted vamps that gave Bertie the shivers as what he called ''soupy'' girls, with an overdeveloped sense of whimsy: the type, as he described one of them, to say that ''rabbits were gnomes in attendance on the Fairy Queen and that the stars were God's daisy chain.''

title: Bistros
description: Definitions of what constitutes a bistro can vary enormously, but in France, generally, it is an informal and unpretentious neighborhood place with a welcoming atmosphere, moderate prices and traditional, gutsy cuisine. In New York nowadays, prices aren't always so moderate, and Italian, American and Indian restaurants are among those that call themselves bistros. Here are a dozen restaurants that hark back in some way to the original French ideal. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: On My Mind; The Fuse Between
description: At a conference center in Maryland, the U.S. works with Israelis and Palestinians in negotiations toward the peace and safety neither people has known. In New York City 200 miles away, members of the U.N. Security Council and top U.N. bureaucrats work in closed meetings to speed the political and military rebirth of the nation aching to destroy any Israel-Palestine peace -- the Iraq of Saddam Hussein.

title: National News Briefs; $260 Million Spent On Issue Advertisements
description: Dozens of organizations are spending a total of at least $260 million in this year's election campaign on television and radio advertisements to advance their political agendas or to support or oppose particular candidates, a study released on Wednesday said.

title: KEARNY FEDERAL TO BUY FIRST BERGEN FOR $62.4 MILLION
description: Shares of First Bergen Bancorp jumped more than 21 percent yesterday after Kearny Federal Savings Bank said it had agreed to acquire First Bergen for $24 a share, or about $62.4 million total. First Bergen, based in Woodridge, N.J., is the parent company of South Bergen Savings Bank, a savings and loan association with assets of $300 million and branches in four northern New Jersey towns. Kearny Federal, based in Kearny, N.J., is a Federal mutual savings bank with assets of $794 million and five northern New Jersey banking offices. Shares of First Bergen were up $3.9375 at $22.0625 in Nasdaq trading.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Antiques Get Ever Younger

title: New Jersey Transit Plans Penn Station Expansion
description: Forecasting a 50 percent increase in rail passengers commuting from New Jersey to New York next year, New Jersey Transit is planning a $55.7 million expansion at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, the agency said yesterday.

title: Stocks Surge In Final Hour On Rate Cut
description: With stocks already rallying yesterday, a surprise interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve touched off a huge final-hour surge that drove prices up more than 4 percent on all three major market gauges.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, HYMAN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Hyman R. You are with me every momentin my heart and in my thoughts. Your Ruth

title: Pope Calls on World to Reunite Faith and Reason
description: Denouncing the ''fateful separation'' of faith and reason in modern times, Pope John Paul II today set out a Christian alternative to the dominant philosophies of the 20th century -- post-Enlightenment rationalism, Marxism and ''postmodern'' nihilism.

title: No More Policy Changes, Japan Bank Chief Says
description: Masaru Hayami, the governor of Japan's central bank, said yesterday that no further changes in monetary policy would be made until it judged the effects of recent measures to pull the nation out of recession. The agency, the Bank of Japan, cut rates last month, is gauging the effect of the Government's plan to help banks dispose of bad loans and will keep an eye on fluctuating foreign exchange rates and the United States economy before it takes further steps, Mr. Hayami said at his monthly news conference. The central bank chief also urged top banks in Japan to accept capital injections of taxpayer funds quickly, as provided for in a 60-trillion-yen package that is expected to win final passage in Parliament today.

title: Camping Adventure With a Toddler
description: Dinner was done and our fire blazed on the banks of the Raquette River, deep in the High Peaks region of Adirondack Park. We sat back, sipping hot chocolate and watching the narrow waterway recede into the grainy gray light. The sky slowly brightened with a canopy of stars.

title: Seeking growth, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano changes its name and adds nine partners.
description: A CREATIVELY focused New York agency is reorganizing as the principals seek to spark new growth.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS RATES AGAIN; WALL ST. SURGES
description: The Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates today, warning that a growing wave of fear among investors and lenders was threatening to derail the nation's long economic expansion.

title: Leyritz Has Hugs for Steinbrenner
description: Jim Leyritz is coming back to Yankee Stadium to hug George Steinbrenner.

title: 44% Rise in First Half For Suez Lyonnais
description: Suez Lyonnais des Eaux S.A., the diversified French water company, said yesterday that its first-half net earnings rose by 43.5 percent as it benefited from solid results in its public utilities services businesses and its lack of exposure to emerging markets. Its first-half profit climbed to 3.1 billion francs ($568 million) as sales increased by 9.5 percent, to 99.8 billion francs.

title: Labonte Wins Pole For the Pepsi 400
description: Bobby Labonte continued to dominate carburetor restrictor plate qualifying last night, putting his Pontiac on the pole for tomorrow night's Pepsi 400 Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway. Labonte, who started from the pole in the Daytona 500 in February, has qualified on the front row in all four restrictor plate races this year and has started from the pole in three races.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Mixed Signals From the Fed; If the Water's Fine, Why Are Those Sharks Still Circling?
description: The Federal Reserve Board's late-afternoon decision yesterday to cut two key interest rates by one-quarter of a point caught traders and investors in all the United States financial markets completely flat-footed. And even though the Dow Jones industrial average soared 330.58 points on the news, the fact that the move came between regularly scheduled meetings at the Fed only served to make already-battered bond investors more nervous than ever. If the Fed was aiming to increase the confidence of financial market participants, the cut did only half the job.

title: Democrats Fill the Breach With a Session on Impeachment History
description: A day after the Republican-controlled House Judiciary Committee indefinitely delayed a hearing planned for next week on the history of impeachment, Democrats held a rump forum of their own on the subject.

title: A Century of Pinstriped Success
description: The Yankees will be making their 35th World Series appearance tomorrow with a distinction that 12 previous Yankee teams carried into a Series: 100 or more victories in the regular season. This year's team outdid itself with 114 victories, the most in American League history and the most since the 154-game schedule was expanded to 162 games in 1961. And if history is a guide, the 1998 Yankees should capture the Series in six games or fewer, for that's what 10 of those 12 Yankee teams that reached the century mark and the Series accomplished. The only 100-victory Yankee teams that failed to taste World Series Champagne were the 1942 and 1963 clubs, which lost in the Series, and the 1954 and 1980 clubs, which never reached it. RAY CORIO

title: Capitalism for Cowards
description: In the closing days of the 20th century, new financial rules are being written that will undermine the principles of capitalism and lay the foundation for a new economic order of not-so-free free markets.

title: Elusive Gestures in a New Age Paean to Greek Myth and Personal Hygiene
description: About 20 minutes into ''The Mysteries of Eleusis'' the thought occurs that this shapeless, shiftless spectacle, filled with buff men and women writhing to a recording of Irene Worth's voice as it is being drowned out by electronic music, might be an elaborate hoax.

title: Toshiba Sells Most Time Warner Shares
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that the Toshiba Corporation had sold 9.5 million of its shares. Time Warner itself bought back 1.9 million shares of the stake, with the remainder going to other investors.

title: City Set to Pay $9.5 Million To Settle Federal Billing Suit
description: New York City has agreed to pay the Federal Government $9.5 million to settle charges that the city had billed Medicare for providing ambulance service to patients who did not need it.

title: Coca-Cola's Earnings Down By 12.2% in Third Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that were in line with what the company previewed earlier this month, when senior executives warned that Coke's business had suffered from economic crises around the world.

title: McNown Goes Deep With His Thinking
description: On his nightstand are books by C. S. Lewis and devotional tomes by spiritual thinkers. In his heart is an ardor for football so deep he has forsaken dating, his beloved golf game and anything else that would distract him from pursuing that higher plane of X's and O's.

title: COVENTRY HEALTH WILL SELL FLORIDA UNIT FOR $95 MILLION
description: Coventry Health Care Inc., a managed care company, has agreed to sell its Principal Health Care of Florida unit to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida for $95 million. Coventry, based in Bethesda, Md., provides health care benefits and services to employers and government-financed groups in six states. With revenue of $1.23 billion last year, it has 1.6 million members in 21 markets in the Midwest, the Mid-Atlantic states and the Southeast. Its stock rose 93.75 cents, to $7.125, in Nasdaq trading. Principal Health Care of Florida has more than 138,000 commercial customers and annual revenue of $225 million.

title: Luxury Fiber Shows Lots of Versatility : Cashmere Shakes Off Its Stuffy Image
description: PARIS  Today's fashionable woman lives her life in a cashmere cocoon, preferably four-ply. In the morning she throws off her Malo cashmere-covered hot water bottle, slips on a Lucien Pellat-Finet cashmere tank with a pair of Fake London cashmere bondage pants, eases her feet into her Manolo Blahnik cashmere stilettos and kisses the baby  wrapped in cashmere swaddling  good-bye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, MINNA
description: MICHAEL-Minna. On October 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Ephraim and the late Olga Gladstone. Adoring grandmother of Candi Sue Scott, Robin Wilson and the late Carol Arava, and greatgrandmother of Adam Chait, Jeffrey Chait and Zaran Arava. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, October 19th, 11:30 A.M. Burial to follow at Beth-El Cemetery, Queens. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Brotherhood Synagogue or Cabrini Medical Center.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Oh, to Be Loud, Red and Shiny

title: 10 To Be Inducted Into Ad Hall of Fame
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has for the first time named new members to the Advertising Hall of Fame who had been passed over for nomination during their careers.

title: 24 City Sanitation Workers Are Accused of Scheme to Steal Hundreds of Cars
description: The program was intended to get rid of the abandoned hulks of cars that litter New York City's side streets: sanitation workers would find the old wrecks, tag them for removal and wait for a private company to tow them away, chop them up and sell their parts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSES, JULIAN MORTON
description: MOSES-Julian Morton. October 28, 1911-October 16, 1997. Music and opera critic, record historian and consultant, teacher, writer, lecturer. Author: ''COLLECTORS' GUIDE TO AMERICAN RECORDINGS 1895-1925'' and other works and articles. A brilliant intelligence and a witty kind man always anxious to help others, he is revered and missed by friends, record collectors, music lovers, colleagues, students; and by: CHRISTOPHER BRUNO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTA, ROMEO C.
description: SALTA-Romeo C. A memorial service will be held Sat., Oct. 17, 3 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Search for Truth Is Not a Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Sosa to Toss Out First Pitch
description: Sammy Sosa, half of the dynamic duo that lighted up the baseball season with their scintillating home run derby, will throw out the ceremonial first ball tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium before the first game of the World Series.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Oct. 8 about an Internet search service called the Mining Company included an erroneous figure supplied by Media Metrix, which measures Internet traffic, to indicate the Mining Company's popularity. The site was 35th in August among the sites visited from home and work, not 43d.

title: Problems Only a Night in Jail Will Cure
description: What's a young man like Robin to do? His old girlfriend, the beautiful daughter of the richest man in town, is leaving the next day for a new life in New York. Robin (Alessandro Nivola), it seems, is stuck in this small Illinois town, where he grew up. Now he finds himself, late at night, standing in the unnatural, deserted quiet of the town's main street. Calmly he pulls down the American flag and uses the flagpole to break the window of the hardware store.

title: Salomon Cuts 100 Bond Jobs
description: Salomon Smith Barney Inc. said yesterday that it had cut 100 jobs in United States bond trading, research and sales in New York to reduce costs as a result of trading losses in global markets.

title: Padres' Manager Is Finally Stepping From the Shadows
description: Most managers would have second-guessed themselves -- if not publicly, then most certainly in private.

title: Enact Hate-Crimes Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Stationmaster's Life: Central, but Not Grand
description: YOU don't meet many people who have been Pullman porters on the fabled 20th Century Limited, carrying Champagne to movie stars making the night run between New York and Chicago, smitten with the romance of the rails. So when you receive a tip that such a fellow is working in the newly restored Grand Central Terminal, a fellow who remembers when they literally unrolled a red carpet for first-class travelers, a visit is required.

title: Zen and the Art of Creating a New Purism
description: MILAN  If you don't know your "New Age" from your "Next Age," relax, for the ultimate in pre-millennium escapism is coming from Milan, where a new wave of designers headed by Sancita Ajumpur, Gugliemo Capone and Emi Kurebayashi are transforming the ancient philosophy of Zen into soul-searching womenswear.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Revisiting Oz 6 Decades Later

title: Lords Leap To Defend Old Powers
description: The bishops, magisterial in flowing black and white, sat upon their appointed benches. The Lord Chancellor, an Alice-in-Wonderland creature in shiny slippers and a tightly curled wig, perched in place on the woolsack, his ceremonial banquette filled with British wool.

title: Designers Struggling to Find a Voice
description: PARIS  The great big breath of fresh design gulped down by Paris houses is fast turning into a long sigh of disappointment. Although some pretty clothes are hitting the runways, none of the new designers taking on establishment names has the stamp of major talent or the authority to forge a clear image.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: A Swank Antiques Fair
description: How this year's International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show, which opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, will be affected by the worldwide financial crisis is anyone's guess. But the offerings are broad and the booths glamorous. A walk around the show provides a look at everything from a $3 million Cezanne still life to a $50,000 Calder, ''The Card Players'' (above), to a $100 delft tile and a $40 18th-century silver mustard spoon.

title: Residential Real Estate; Ruling Broadens Protection for Renter in a Co-op
description: In a decision that could affect the status of unsold co-op and condominium apartments throughout New York State, a housing court judge in Brooklyn has ruled that a tenant who rented an apartment from a sponsor after a conversion was entitled to the same protection against eviction as tenants who were living there at the time of the conversion.

title: FIRSTPLUS SELLING BUSINESSES AND CUTTING HALF ITS STAFF
description: The Firstplus Financial Group, a struggling home-equity lender that failed to find a buyer after putting itself up for sale in August, said yesterday that it was selling its businesses in parts and would dismiss 3,000 people, or 50 percent of its staff. Firstplus, a Dallas-based company that specializes in loans of up to 125 percent of a home's value, said it was selling its loan servicing business to Superior Bank F.S.B. and that it had accepted an offer for its British-based business. It said the two transactions were worth $130 million. Firstplus said Aug. 31 that it wanted to be acquired, but at least two potential buyers reportedly abandoned purchase plans after preliminary talks.

title: RACING: NOTEBOOK
description: N.Y.R.A.

title: Bettman Seeks Financing for Arena
description: National Hockey League Commissioner Gary Bettman met for about two hours yesterday with Nassau County officials in a continuing effort to create a financing plan for a new Islanders arena to replace Nassau Coliseum.

title: On the Streets of Paris, School Protests Turn Violent
description: High school students flooded the streets of France again today to campaign for more teachers and better schools, but the march in Paris turned violent when troublemakers looted stores, burned cars and clashed with riot police.

title: Philosophy as Hotblooded Adventure
description: ''Destiny'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4, 1997. The film, in Arabic with English subtitles, runs today through next Friday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. It moves to the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, on Oct. 30.

title: Congress Provides $1.2 Billion For Hiring Teachers Nationwide
description: School officials across the country hailed the additional $1.2 billion that Congress is allocating for the hiring and training of new teachers in grades one through three, saying that reducing class sizes, especially in lower grades, was one of their highest priorities.

title: BUDGET ACCORD IS REACHED; BOTH SIDES CLAIM A VICTORY AS A SHUTDOWN IS AVERTED
description: President Clinton and Congress reached agreement today on the final portion of the nation's $1.7-trillion budget, the first in three decades brought forth with a surplus and one that offers the biggest peacetime increase in military spending since Ronald Reagan was President in 1985.

title: So Many Fans, So Few Tickets; A Long Line, but Most Series Seats Go to the Connected
description: Whether you were one of the true die-hards who could recite the batting averages of even the Yankees' minor league players or someone still unaware that there is a position known as designated hitter, there was passionate unity yesterday in trying to achieve a nearly impossible goal: getting tickets to the World Series.

title: A Sardonic Stand-Up Comic In Pursuit of Real Romance
description: Anyone who can get past the title pun and the opening shot of misogyny in ''The Souler Opposite'' is liable to like Bill Kalmenson's almost film in spite of itself. Its hero, like Mr. Kalmenson, is a stand-up comic, and his mean-spirited wisecracks earn him a well-deserved sock in the nose early in the story. The rest of the film is about his struggle to get involved in a real romance and be less of a jerk. Once the sardonic character of Barry Singer (Christopher Meloni) worms his way into your affections, you may just wish him success.

title: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: No Ice Cream Cones In a Heart of Darkness
description: THE POISONWOOD BIBLE

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLIN, SONDRA
description: GITLIN-Sondra. On October 14, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Raymond. Dearest caring mother of Judith Dweck, Geraldine & Stanley Wiener. Adored grammy of Hilary and Scott, Joanne and Frank, Alyssa and Evan, Stuart & Hilary, H.P. Sean and Lenore. Loving great-grandma of Alison, Rachel, Kyle, Zane, Jace and Zoe. Your gentle kindness and wonderful spirit has set an example for all generations to come. We love you. Privates graveside services.

title: 3 Days for New York to Celebrate Sammy Sosa
description: Sammy Sosa will be getting a hero's welcome in Washington Heights after all.

title: Off the Boat and Into a Century of Women's Struggles
description: No one is yet declaring that the women's movement has achieved all its goals, but you know it has been largely successful in winning over mainstream America when a major network will devote a five-hour mini-series to the cause.
