NBC, it's safe to say, would be unlikely to give over two lucrative prime-time evenings to political advocacy unless the views expressed were no longer getting any serious argument.

title: White House Secures $476 Million for Projects
description: After vowing for weeks to block spending provisions it said would be bad for the environment, the Clinton Administration won many concessions in the final budget agreement but gave ground on other disputed policies.

title: Fed Action on Interest Rates Sends Treasury Prices Higher
description: Treasury bond prices surged yesterday, and two-year notes posted the biggest rally in more than three years, after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates to avert a credit crunch and calm financial markets.

title: McCann-Erickson Opens New Agency
description: The McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies has opened another health care advertising agency, McCann-Erickson Consumer Health, in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSTO, ANTHONY
description: MUSTO-Anthony. Age 55, of Nashville, TN. He was Vice President of Celebrity Cruises of Miami, died at home of brain cancer. The family will receive friends on Friday, October 16 from 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at The Broadway Chapel, TN. Funeral mass will be held Saturday, October 17 at 10:00 AM at Saint Edwards Catholic Church. He is survived by his mother, Ernestina Musto, Halliswood, NY; son Andrew, Syracuse, NY; daughter Alexandra, Norfolk, VA., and good friend Dennis DiTraglia, Nashville, TN. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plains, IL, 60018. For information call Roesch Patton Austin Bracey & Charlton, 615-244-6480.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Rummana Hussain

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ANNY NEE ARNSTEIN
description: ROSENTHAL-Anny nee Arnstein., age 77 of Bayside, New York passed away early morning October 15 at Calvary Hospital. She is survived by husband Ernest of 49 years, son Dr. Allan Rosenthal and wife Cheryl and granddaughters Dana and Erica of Ridgefield, Connecticut and son Jeff Rosenthal of Forest Hills, Queens. As a Holocaust survivor from Seelbach, Germany contributions in her memory should be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center, 9760 West Pico Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90035. Services today at Sinai Chapel in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Offer to Piazza Reportedly Ready
description: As is his policy, General Manager Steve Phillips of the Mets would not articulate how he planned to approach an attempt to sign Mike Piazza. But a person with knowledge of Phillips's strategy confirmed yesterday that Phillips would fly to Southern California early next week to make an offer to the All-Star catcher and his representatives.

title: Accounts
description: * Hearst Magazines, New York, part of Hearst Corp., to Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, which is majority owned by MDC Communications Corp., to handle corporate advertising. Billings on the account, which had been inactive, were estimated at $7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, AARON
description: GOLDBERG-Aaron. On October 14, 1998. after a long illness. Beloved husband of Edith, loving brother of the late Arthur and Albert. Devoted uncle and grand uncle. Services Sunday, October 18th, 1998 at 11 A.M., Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jeffrey Vallance

title: Psychiatric Tests Ordered For Accused Killer
description: An Irvington man accused of killing a Newark prostitute last year was declared incompetent yesterday to make an initial court appearance and was ordered to undergo a 30-day psychiatric evaluation, county prosecutors said.

title: AXA IS HOLDING TALKS WITH BARR ROSENBERG INVESTMENT
description: AXA S.A. said yesterday that it was holding discussions with Barr Rosenberg Investment Management Group, a California fund manager, about an alliance as AXA, Europe's biggest insurer, expands its asset management in the United States. In disclosing the talks, AXA was confirming a report yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. The company's chief executive, Claude Bebear, has said AXA will expand in asset management, a business that insurance companies know from managing their own funds backing customers' policies. With about $600 billion under management, AXA is already the world's third-largest fund manager.

title: For Yankees, Love or Respect?; Loving New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBEL, FRED
description: GRUBEL-Fred. We mourn the loss of a great scholar, leader, and friend of the German-Jewish Community. American Federation of Jews from Central Europe

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In a Surprise Move, Fed Reduces Interest Rates

title: Striving for Recovery From Grip of Alcohol
description: Seeking discipline and direction after four dizzying years of gold-medal heights and alcoholic depths, Oksana Baiul of Ukraine has begun training seriously again with a goal of competing in the 2002 Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGER, HAMILTON RIGGS
description: WAGER-Hamilton Riggs. Age 81. October 13, 1998. Beloved husband of June Millett. Devoted father of Marcia Finger and Ellen Wachterhauser. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth Pugh, Alexandra Finger, Scott and Katie Wachterhauser, and great-grandfather of Nathaniel and Ashley Pugh. Loving brother of Charlotte Perkins. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Tony Questions Get Early Start

title: For Yankees, Love or Respect?; Yankees-Hating Contest
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tunga

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARGROVE, JOHN E.
description: HARGROVE-John E. On October 14, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Madeleine. Loving father of Patricia, John, Paul and Michael. Also survived by four grandchildren. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM McLaughlin & Sons, 3rd Avenue at 97 Street, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30AM, Our Lady of Angels Church.

title: The German 'Volk' Seem Set to Let Outsiders In
description: On the facade of the refurbished Reichstag, which will once again become Germany's Parliament building next year, the words engraved in 1916 are still dominant: ''Dem Deutschen Volke'' -- ''To the German People.''

title: Money Effort In Jones Suit Falls Apart
description: A delicately constructed financial package devised to settle Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton was slowly crushed today in raucous feuding among her lawyers and a would-be benefactor, Abe Hirschfeld.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For Yankees, Love or Respect?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday tracing the dispute between the Islanders hockey team and the company managing the Nassau Coliseum misstated the year John Pickett bought the team. It was 1978, not 1988.

title: Clinton Urges Netanyahu And Arafat to Take Risks
description: President Clinton, promising his own intense involvement to secure agreement, today urged the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to ''break the logjam'' and take the risks required to provide new hope to their peoples.

title: Student Life As a Mirror Of Division In Europe
description: ''La Sentinelle'' was shown as part of the New York Film Festival in 1992. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 5, 1992. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: Norwest and Keycorp Report 3d-Quarter Gains
description: The Norwest Corporation and Keycorp reported higher third-quarter profits yesterday, while the BankBoston Corporation said its earnings fell on trading losses.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAYS / Collecting; History From a Rearview Mirror
description: FOR Walter Miller, the history of the automobile is about much more than just motor vehicles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, DR. RENEE K.
description: MARGOLIS-Dr. Renee K. The administration, faculty, staff and students of SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourn the passing of our colleague, Dr. Renee K. Margolis, professor of pharmacology. Dr. Margolis was an esteemed scientist whose pioneering studies on the structure and function of brain glycoconjugates won international acclaim. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her husband, Dr. Richard Margolis, with whom she worked in close collaboration, her family, and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, MD Interim President and Dean, College of Medicine

title: German Trade Surplus Narrows to $5.26 Billion
description: Germany's merchandise trade surplus narrowed to 8.6 billion marks ($5.26 billion) in August from a 10-year record high of 14.2 billion marks in July, the Federal Statistics Office said yesterday. An informal poll of analysts had forecast a larger surplus, 10.2 billion marks. In the first eight months of the year, the surplus was 89.2 billion marks, up from 69.6 billion marks.

title: Quarterly Profit Down at Gillette
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said today that its third-quarter profit fell -- the first quarterly decline in eight years -- because of weak sales in Asia, slowing economies in Latin America and the rising dollar.

title: Missing Brooklyn Boy Found in Virginia
description: A 6-year-old Brooklyn boy with cerebral palsy was found unharmed yesterday, sitting in a car in a motel parking lot on Interstate 95 near Richmond, with the former baby sitter who left for a stroll with the boy two days before and never returned.

title: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: Absentee Balloting Threatened By Delays Over Stadium Vote
description: Thousands of New York City voters could lose the chance to vote in the Nov. 3 election because the court battle over a referendum on Yankee Stadium has delayed the printing of absentee ballots, the president of the Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: Metro Business; St. Luke's-Roosevelt Chief
description: After a four-month search, the board of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center announced this week that it had appointed a new president and chief executive.

title: Young Out 2-3 Months With Injury To Back
description: Rodney Young had a day to think about possibly starting a National Football League game for the first time, to ponder the strange road that his career had taken. But before he could realize that dream, the doctors shattered it with a diagnosis that will probably sideline him for the remainder of the season.

title: Sports of The Times; Frank Torre Talks of Life And the Game
description: HE is 66 years old, but his heart is only 30. Two years ago, as the Yankees were about to win the World Series, Frank Torre, the older brother of the team's manager, Joe Torre, received a heart transplant at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center from a 28-year-old man who had died of a brain tumor.

title: Rangers Seek Ice Time And Their First Victory
description: Still trying to fit the members of his cast into changing roles, Coach John Muckler of the Rangers will shuffle his lineup again Friday night when his 0-3 club meets the 0-2 Devils at Madison Square Garden.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/4010/20/90. Cherished Mother, your namesake has arrived. Alliso

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Rendezvous At the End Of a Century
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum may be the country's leader in exhibition spectaculars. In a few short years it has mounted sprawling overviews of the visual culture of the Russian Revolution, 20th-century Italy, Africa and China, not to mention Robert Rauschenberg, a continent unto himself.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jan Lukas

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIMMINO, VINCENT J., MD.
description: CIMMINO-Vincent J., MD., of Mt. Vernon, New York, on October 14, 1998. Husband of Theresa. Father of Valerie Farah & Michele Stone. Grandfather of Jesse, Michael and Timothy. Brother of Angelina Tuccillo, Victoria Castaldi, Silvia Hughes. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 79 P.M. Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM Friday. Services are at Woodlawn Cemetery Chapel, Bronx, NY, on Saturday, October 17, at 1 PM.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Annette Lemieux

title: Foley Defends Comments As Parcells Gives a Shrug
description: A day after Glenn Foley contended that ''behind-the-scenes'' events played a role in his being demoted, the Jets' quarterback mystery continued today with Coach Bill Parcells dismissing the subject and Foley saying his remarks were taken out of context.

title: TRION SAYS PROPOSED TAKEOVER BY MCLEOD RUSSEL IS OFF
description: A $55 million merger agreement between Trion Inc. of Sanford, N.C., and McLeod Russel Holdings P.L.C. has been terminated by mutual agreement. No further information was disclosed. McLeod Russel agreed in August to acquire Trion for $7.27 a share. In early September, McLeod Russel postponed a shareholder meeting to consider the Trion purchase. At that time, it noted that Trion's July results were substantially below forecasts. Trion makes air-cleaning and filtration products. McLeod Russel also makes clean-air filtration systems and surface- coating products.

title: South African Industrial Giant Moving to London
description: South Africa's largest and best-known company, the Anglo American Corporation, announced today that it would reorganize and switch its stock exchange listing and headquarters to London from Johannesburg.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Political Memo; Campaign Jolt: D'Amato Plays The Lazy Card
description: WHEN Alfonse M. D'Amato flew across the North Country yesterday, attacking Charles E. Schumer for being absent when Congress approved financial assistance for storm-damaged upstate communities, it was the 15th day in a row that the Senator had assailed Mr. Schumer's 1998 Congressional attendance record. Mr. D'Amato is raising the issue of his opponent's missed votes at every opening now -- and, his aides say, intends to do so every day between now and the election.

title: Holdover From Solid South Tries to Defy G.O.P.'s Tide
description: He is, quite simply, the last of his kind.

title: A Street Sign: Public Service or Private Campaign?
description: It is hard for motorists on River Street to miss the sign that men in orange jumpsuits are painting near Mercer Street, warning drivers in big blue letters to ''Buckle Up.'' But it is even harder to miss the much larger red letters above the warning, spelling out the name of Sheriff Jay Alpert.

title: AIDS-Related Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan for Park on Hudson River Hits Snag in City Council
description: The embattled plan for a 4.5-mile park along the Hudson River has encountered a new and unexpected obstacle -- City Council members interested in modifying the plan that Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law last month.

title: Diplomacy on the Hoof / From Court of St. James to Highlands : U.S. Envoy Wears Down His Soles Meeting Britons
description: MEY, Scotland  The approach of four walkers, the only people in sight for miles across the barren fields at the northern tip of Scotland, prompts a teenage girl to come running out of a solitary house.

title: Theatricality by an All-Australian Boy
description: In a cabaret world where careers tend to build slowly over many years, occasionally a meteor appears. David Campbell, an affable 25-year-old Australian singer, breezed to the top last year with a sellout engagement at Rainbow and Stars, where he became the youngest performer ever to be given a solo stint. On Tuesday evening he returned to the club for a three-week engagement that finds him moving away from pop standards toward an assimilative 1970's style of soft rock.

title: When Words' Meaning Is in Their Look
description: In certain non-Western cultures, the written word is the emperor of art forms. The shape of individual characters, the way they interact, can embody the personality of a writer, the essence of a text, the moral timbre of a society.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about The Miami Herald's decision to close its Sunday magazine, Tropic, misspelled the surname of a Herald feature writer in some editions and misidentified the new job of Tom Shroder, the magazine's current executive editor. The writer is Elinor Brecher, not Blecher. Mr. Shroder will become editor of the Sunday Style section of The Washington Post, not The Post's Style editor.

title: Jewish Group Occupies House in Arab Area
description: As peace talks began in Maryland, a group of ultra-nationalist Jews established a beachhead for new conflict in East Jerusalem today, occupying a vacant house in the heart of a Palestinian neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. Dad, you're in our thoughts every day. We miss you. Love always, The Kids

title: New Freedom Confuses Devils
description: Coach Robbie Ftorek has given the Devils the freedom to go on the attack whenever possible, but the defensive philosophy of his predecessor, Jacques Lemaire, has been so ingrained in the players that they seem confused about choosing the right time to venture into the attacking zone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about news gathering by the major television networks misstated the title of Bill Wheatley at NBC. He is a vice president, not executive vice president.

title: Peddling Home Security by Hook and Crook
description: Let's hope that Evan Dunsky's gleefully paranoid comedy ''The Alarmist'' doesn't give some unscrupulous salesman of the kind found in a David Mamet play any ideas for devilish new scams.

title: Dr. Andrew Breen Myers, 78, Washington Irving Scholar
description: Dr. Andrew B. Myers, a long-time Fordham University English professor who pursued a lifelong scholarly obsession into virtual oblivion, died on Monday at Flushing Hospital in Queens. He was 78.

title: In Philippines, Ethnic Attire Comes Back Into Own
description: MANILA  Luisa Estrada wore a white terno as she stood next to her husband, Joseph, as he was sworn in as the new president of the Philippines last June. Some people saw it as an unsettling omen. The last woman in a similar position was Imelda Marcos. And the terno was her signature dress.

title: Seattle Journal; 60 Years After Spain, Lincoln Brigade Is Honored
description: More than 60 years after they took up arms against the fascists in Spain, for which Hemingway romanticized them and F.B.I. files blacklisted them, members of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade have finally been given an official monument in this country.

title: A Top-of-the-Heap Rally And a Free Lunch, Too
description: Just as baseball has its rituals, so too does New York City in how it roots for the Yankees. And enough of those idiosyncratic traditions were on display yesterday at a pep rally in City Hall Park to keep urban anthropologists busy for years.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR TUMBLES. The dollar fell against the Japanese yen after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly lowered interest rates and as hedge funds continued to sell dollars to repay yen loans. The dollar fell to 116.75 yen from 118.98.

title: It's Not All Relative
description: Whoever thought it would come to this? Most secular philosophers today, proudly calling themselves postmodernist, have given up on the Enlightenment and reason in favor of an easygoing moral relativism. In discussing everything from ''Paradise Lost'' to law to biology, today's ''critical thinkers'' strip away ''patriarchal'' objectivity to expose what they think is really real: power and interest. Today, the strongest and most unabashed defender of reason in the world appears to be the Pope. Voltaire, where art thou at this hour?

title: Court Relaxes Care Standard That Carriers Must Meet
description: New York State's highest court struck down a century-old standard in state negligence law today, a ruling that could make it more difficult for passengers to win negligence suits against public and private transportation carriers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Arthur B. Davies

title: Columbia Sues Ex-Executive And Vendors
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation sued one of its former top financial officers and several vendors yesterday, accusing them of engaging in a conspiracy over seven years that defrauded the company of millions of dollars.

title: Giuliani to Stump in 4 States in 4 Days
description: The 1998 Giuliani Road Show reaches full throttle next week, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani scheduled to make political appearances on four consecutive days in four states: New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Tennessee and North Carolina.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You try to make your mark in this game somewhere, and to do it where you wanted to play is awesome.''

title: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: For Yankees, Love or Respect?; Rescuing the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Trying to get a reservation at Nobu is among the world's more irritating tasks. The phone is always busy. If you are lucky enough to finally reach the restaurant, you inevitably discover that the night you want is already fully booked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKENS, KATHLEEN
description: LUKENS-Kathleen. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Kathleen Lukens, compassionate champion of the developmentally disabled, 1984 recipient of the Doctor of Humane Letters degree, and beloved wife of Dr. John Lukens of the psychology department. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU, Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D., President

title: Ballot Madness
description: The solution for printing New York City's ballots seemed simple. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone have been dueling for months over whose referendum belongs on the Nov. 3 ballot. The Speaker wants a line that asks whether city money should be used to move Yankee Stadium to Manhattan. The Mayor has come up with a hastily concocted charter reform item that would bump off any other referendum. The debate is now in the courts.

title: Usinor Offer: $1 Billion For 75% of Cockerill
description: Usinor S.A. of France, Europe's fourth-largest steel company, said yesterday that it planned to buy private investors' shares in the Belgian steel company Cockerill Sambre S.A. on top of the majority stake in Cockerill that it agreed to buy on Wednesday from the government of Wallonia, a region of Belgium.

title: Gardner Is Leaving Ammirati Puris Lintas
description: Stephen H. Gardner, president of the New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, is leaving to open a consulting company in New York.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Josef Sudek

title: John Paul's Words: '2 Modes of Knowledge Lead to Truth in All Its Fullness'
description: Following are excerpts from the encyclical ''Fides et Ratio'' (''Faith and Reason''), issued at the Vatican yesterday by Pope John Paul II:

title: Different but Determined to Beat the Christmas Rush
description: The message that the late Gene Autry conveyed in 3 minutes, 13 seconds of perennially popular song takes 90 minutes to transmit in the pedestrian animated film that goes by the tortured title ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Movie.''

title: Assailing H.M.O.'s, Vallone Offers Broad Plan for State Role in Health Care
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic candidate for governor, yesterday proposed a radical revamping of health care coverage in New York to guarantee that everyone is insured, mainly by making the state, rather than private health insurers, the primary provider of coverage.

title: Finding a Balance in the Dollar's Slide
description: Many Americans love a strong dollar. After all, a rising currency means lower prices for imports and more bang for the buck when traveling abroad.

title: Enact Hate-Crimes Law; Punishment Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Gains in Deal; Haitians Do So, Too
description: In a significant shift of United States policy toward immigrants, Congressional Republicans and the White House agreed yesterday on a budget proposal that could benefit thousands of immigrants and the Federal agency that serves them.

title: $9 Billion to Pentagon, With Missile Defense
description: The White House agreed with Congressional negotiators today to add about $9 billion to the military budget, including about $2 billion for intelligence programs and about $1 billion for a defense against a missile attack, Congressional staff members said.

title: Proposed Farm Aid Signals A Shift in Economic Winds
description: The agreement to spend $6 billion on the nation's farmers marks a departure, at least in spirit, from a landmark 1996 measure intended to move agriculture into a free market economy.

title: ARCO LAYING OFF 900 AND CUTTING COSTS BY $500 MILLION
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the seventh-largest oil company in the United States, said yesterday that it would cut 900 jobs, or 4.5 percent of its work force, and reduce costs by $500 million. Costs will be reduced over two years, with most of the savings, $350 million, expected in 1999, the Los Angeles-based company said. Facing the lowest oil prices in 12 years as well as slumping earnings, ARCO is seen by many analysts as a target for takeover by another oil company. ARCO's chief executive, Michael R. Bowlin, warned employees last month that spending would have to be reduced ''to insure that ARCO remains a strong and successful independent company.'' ARCO said the 900 layoffs would come mainly from technical and administrative positions at its Los Angeles headquarters and in Plano, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, LEO A., M.D.
description: SPIEGEL-Leo A., M.D.. The Officers and Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the death of their respected and beloved colleague, Dr. Leo Spiegel. In his nearly five decades as a member, Dr. Spiegel served as President of both the Institute and Society, was a training and supervising analyst in child and adult psychoanalysis and actively involved in the affairs of the Institute and Society. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his daughter, Wendy Kesselman. Eslee Samberg, MD President/Institute Lester Schwartz, MD President/Society SPIEGEL-Leo A. M.D.. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our professor emeritus, an esteemed psychiatrist and renowned teacher who was associated with our medical school since its inception in 1955. A distinguished psychoanalytic scholar, he made major contributions to the understanding of the psychology of adolescents. We extend our deepest condolences to his daughter, Wendy Kesselman. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D., Dean

title: Search for Truth Is Not a Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Tony Marvin, 86, Announcer For Radio
description: Tony Marvin, the mellifluous radio and television announcer who proclaimed ''It's Arthur Godfrey time!'' over the airwaves in the 1940's and 50's, died on Saturday at the Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 86 and lived in Boynton Beach.

title: Williams, in Distant Mood, Is Guarding His Privacy
description: Bernie Williams had conceded on Tuesday that his recent aloofness had made it seem as if he ''was not there,'' a distance that caused Joe Torre to meet with him one on one. While Williams also said there was nothing personally wrong with him, a Yankee official said that the center fielder was grappling with a personal matter and that is why he has been so estranged recently.

title: Wells Predicts Yanks in 5, er, 4
description: David Wells was a guest on Howard Stern's radio program yesterday and did not seem to mind giving the San Diego Padres some potential motivation when he predicted that the Yankees would win the World Series in five games.

title: Jet Insulation Urged by F.A.A. Is Not Ready Yet, Maker Says
description: One type of flame-resistant insulation that the Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday that it wanted the airlines to start using as soon as possible is still ''under development,'' its manufacturer said today, and may not be available for a year or more.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 7
description: Game of the Week

title: Spaniards Walk on Wild Side
description: MADRID  Spanish shoemakers have let their imaginations run wild lately, one producing unisex black leather boots with steel-coated heels, another toying with nonidentical "twin" shoes, a third adding distinctive dark stains on imported leather from India.

title: Mostly Bits and Pieces, From Bach to Copland
description: To celebrate the opening of its 30th season, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered a panoramic overview of its repertory on Wednesday evening. In just under two hours -- a Live from Lincoln Center broadcast imposed a strict time constraint -- the society traversed just over 200 years of music. A dozen composers, from Bach to Copland, were glanced upon, with connecting commentary by the pianist Andre Watts, who was also among the 37 musicians -- artist members of the society and guest players -- who combined and recombined as the scores required.

title: Degas's Eye for the Unseen World
description: It's not exactly a revelation that Degas made photographs -- his work has been exhibited so often lately that nothing about him remains a mystery -- but I would guess that the only picture by him familiar to many people is his double portrait of Renoir and Mallarme.

title: The Fed Acts
description: By suddenly cutting interest rates yesterday, the Federal Reserve sent a strong message that it is worried about the world economy and determined to prevent a world recession. It was the latest encouraging signal that officials around the world are no longer complacent about the financial storm.

title: Clinton Plea Opens Mideast Peace Talks
description: President Clinton, promising his intense personal involvement, welcomed the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and asked them to ''break the logjam'' by taking risks needed to reach an interim peace accord.

title: Sports of The Times; Flutie Offers N.F.L. Prism for Foley
description: SOMEWHERE in Doug Flutie's career lies a lesson for Glenn Foley, the Jets' beleaguered quarterback. On Nov. 22, 1984, Flutie achieved college football immortality when he heaved a 48-yard touchdown pass into rain and gusty winds with no time left and led Boston College to a 47-45 victory over Miami.

title: 'Fat Comedy' Opens a Season
description: ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy,'' which opened last night at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, makes a very tiny impression. The play (if you can call it that), the first of the new Broadway season, was written by and stars Rob Bartlett, above, best known for his work on Don Imus's radio show. Though some moments of Mr. Bartlett's standup comedy are not bad, they are small consolation.

title: For Barenboim, an A-Liszt and B-Liszt
description: There are few good Liszt players. So much is expected of them. Brains and brawn are not everyday partners in any enterprise, and this is music needing a pianist with both a mighty technique and a discerning heart. Cool organizational skills and impulsiveness must find a way to live together.

title: Rhythms of Disorder, in Science and Music
description: Nebulae and flames, clouds and crystal networks flash across scrims; operatic voices declaim above ratcheting polyrhythms and notes frayed by static and distortion. ''Chaos,'' which the Kitchen is presenting through Oct. 24, finds all sorts of visual and sonic analogues to the chaos theory being pursued by its hero and heroine, in a technology-happy opera that romanticizes science as successfully as any work since ''Einstein on the Beach.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Search for Truth Is Not a Witch Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGARA, ALLYS DWYER
description: VERGARA-Allys Dwyer. On October 15th, 1998. Loving sister of Rosamond McDonough and Virginia Pierce. Visiting on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10AM Holy Family Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, MARSHA
description: FORMAN-Marsha. Congregation Talmud Torah of Flatbush mourns the passing of Marsha Forman. Marsha possessed keen intellect, ready wit and a sweet character. She will be lovingly remembered. Our condolences to her devoted husband Sol and daughters Marilyn, Amy and Ellie. Dr. Leo Landman, Rabbi Rabbi Isaac Tuchman, Pres.

title: REPRIEVE BY NATO ALLOWS MILOSEVIC ANOTHER 10 DAYS
description: NATO granted President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia a reprieve today, extending by 10 days its deadline for him to withdraw military and police forces cracking down on ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo.

title: RADCLIFFE, MITCHELL WITHDRAWS RESOURCE AMERICA BID
description: Radcliffe, Mitchell & Weiss, based on Monroe, N.Y., said it was ''withdrawing its offer'' to buy the finance company Resource America Inc. for more than $300 million. Radcliffe, Mitchell & Weiss offered $15 a share, or $302.9 million, for Resource America. The Philadelphia-based Resource, which buys distressed commercial mortgages to restructure into performing loans, surged by 65 percent on Oct. 7, the day the takeover bid was made, but quickly retreated.

title: Friends and Strangers Mourn Gay Student in Wyoming
description: Matthew Wayne Shepard, the gay student who was beaten in the dead of night, tied to a fence at a Wyoming ranch and left to die alone, was mourned at his funeral today by 1,000 people, including many who had never met him.

title: Catholic Scholars Call Message a Timely Critique
description: When the Vatican released Pope John Paul II's latest encyclical on Thursday, it published a document by a trained philosopher who explores and amplifies a historic church position that faith and reason cannot be separated. He does so in a style that some Roman Catholic scholars say might even make it a useful text for undergraduate courses.

title: MERCK PROFIT INCREASED BY 14% IN THIRD QUARTER
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that its profit rose 14 percent in the third quarter as sales of new drugs, including the asthma treatment Singulair, helped offset slowing demand for its top seller, the cholesterol reducer Zocor. Merck is seeking to fuel growth by developing new products and creating alliances with smaller companies instead of seeking mergers. It also needs new products because although Zocor sales continue to rise, they are being threatened by a rival product, the Warner-Lambert Company's Lipitor. In the latest quarter, Merck said, net income increased to $1.37 billion, or $1.12 a diluted share, from $1.2 billion, or 97 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected a result of $1.11 a share, and Merck rose $2.75, to $136.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We know that while we have the makings of peace, it is not wholly secure yet. I hope it does not turn out to be premature.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGARA, DR. ALLYS DWYER
description: VERGARA-Dr. Allys Dwyer. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Dr. Allys Dwyer Vergara, Class of 1924, Professor Emeritus of Speech and English. A caring, concerned, loyal friend and advocate for almost 80 years, she lovingly and unselfishly shared her long, rich life with others. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D President

title: New U.S. Disclosures on Tanzania Bombing
description: In a rare public statement about the August bombings of two American embassies in Africa, the F.B.I. said today that two vehicles had been used in the attack on the Embassy here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSPAN, ESTHER
description: GREENSPAN-Esther. On Oct. 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Mother of Natalie Anderson and Madge Rosenberg. Mother-inlaw of Barry Rosenberg. Sister of Miriam Horn, Alice & Eli Nemeth. Grandmother of Peter, Lili and Joanna Rosenberg.

title: The Whispering of Brass
description: It takes a lot to tame out-of-towners talking through music at a jazz club, but the drummer Max Roach, playing at the Blue Note on Tuesday, did it with near silence. He called the tune ''God Bless the Child,'' and had it performed by the tuba player Antonio Underwood and the trumpeter Eddie Henderson, using a muted trumpet. It was quiet, and exquisite, and even the drunks took notice that something special was happening.

title: Software Glitch Disrupts Cash Machine Service
description: The largest network of automated teller machines in the Northeast, NYCE, reported last night that a software glitch in its network disrupted an undetermined number of machines for at least six hours yesterday.

title: Was It Mercy or Murder?; Veterinarian's Arrest Puts Focus on Pacts To Help the Terminally Ill Commit Suicide
description: He was a man with an advanced case of AIDS. His pain was unbearable and constant, lucidity a luxury that floated into each day with less and less frequency. His life finally ended at home when he succumbed to large doses of painkillers and tranquilizers prescribed by his doctor, who knew what their effect would be.

title: Showing a Modern Facet, With a Touch of Insolence
description: After presenting its version of the 19th-century classic ''Don Quixote,'' Ballet Ullate of Madrid found its true center in the contemporary style of its second program. This mixed bill, which is to be repeated tomorrow at 2 and 7 P.M., when the company closes its run at City Center, shows off the dancers' strong points. There is a formidable stage presence with a touch of insolence, all combined with a polish in dancing that fuses ballet and nonacademic idioms.

title: Nostalgic, John Paul II Celebrates 20-Year Reign
description: John Paul II celebrated his 20th anniversary as Pope today by revisiting his past.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: BIZBALL
description: As a murderers row of media barons steps up to the plate, sports is becoming a hot entertainment product, changing the rules of the game. An all-sports issue of the Times Magazine.

title: DUKE ENERGY IN NATURAL GAS PIPELINE DEAL WITH TEPPCO
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said yesterday that it was folding its oil and natural gas liquids pipeline unit into its Teppco Partners L.P. affiliate in a transaction valued at $100 million, and it plans to use Teppco to acquire other pipeline businesses. Teppco, a publicly traded partnership, is one of the largest United States operators of pipelines that move gasoline and other fuels refined from oil. The Houston-based Duke Energy owns almost 11 percent of Teppco. After the transaction, it will own about 20 percent. The Duke pipeline unit, the Oklahoma City-based Duke Energy Trading and Transport, gathers crude oil from wells in Oklahoma and Texas and ships it via pipeline.

title: Citing Low Inflation, Government Makes Only Small Increase in Social Security
description: Social Security benefits will rise 1.3 percent next year, the Government announced today. That is the smallest cost-of-living increase since 1987.

title: Healthy Turn of Events for Vaughn
description: It was the middle of last summer when Greg Vaughn was flown into New York only to have Yankee team doctors inspect his right shoulder as carefully as fine print. Something was up.

title: Peter Paul Artaserse, 98, Judge And Lawmaker in New Jersey
description: Peter Paul Artaserse, a retired Jersey City lawyer, Superior Court judge and former state legislator, died Sunday at General Hospital Center in Passaic. He was 98 and lived in Clifton, N.J.

title: Leftist Leader to Try to Assemble a New Government in Italy
description: Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist and leader of the largest leftist party in Italy, was selected today to try to form a new government.

title: In France, Creating The Look That Lasts
description: PARIS  Longchamp, the classic leather goods maker that started out making pipe bowls wrapped in leather, celebrates its 50th anniversary this year.

title: Holyfield and Lewis Ponder Signing Up for Title Bout
description: The parties negotiating a proposed undisputed heavyweight championship bout between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis are inching closer to an agreement that will have both boxers in the ring early next year. But after five days of talks on two continents, it is still not officially done.

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: Taming Cardinals' Rush Is Giants' Onerous Task
description: The Giants have an offensive line under siege and a defensive backfield under repair.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, THOMAS F.
description: CASEY-Thomas F. on 10/16/98. Supervisor REA Express and Hallman Downtown Association. Beloved husband of Audrey E., nee Flack, devoted father of Robert, Paul, John and the late Peter Gordon. Brother of Vincent and James. Cherished grandfather of Audrey, Margaret, Andrew and Taylor Gordon. Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, Inc. 35-20 Broadway, LIC, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45AM Corpus Christi RC Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. Memorial service will be planned for a later date.

title: A. I. Bloomfield, 84, Economist and Author
description: Arthur I. Bloomfield, an economist, author and educator, died on Oct. 6 at the Maplewood Park Place Nursing Center in Bethesda, Md., from degenerative neurologic disease, his wife, Dorothy, said. He was 84 and lived in Bethesda.

title: William & Mary Junior Takes Race
description: Matt Lane, a 21-year-old junior at William & Mary, never trailed in winning the IC4A Cross-Country Association championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

title: THE GRAPES OF WRATH '98
description: Fade in: A deserted, dust-blown street on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Twilight. Tom Joad, a former mutual fund manager just released from Federal prison, stands in front of the Joad family's six-bedroom town house. The building is in ruins; the double-paned French doors are smashed, and the tattered Ralph Lauren window treatments flutter ghostlike in the howling wind.

title: NATIONWIDE FINANCIAL ENDS BID FOR PILGRIM BAXTER
description: Nationwide Financial Services Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks to acquire the fund management company Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Ltd. because it could not agree on terms. The Boston-based United Asset Management Company was said to be seeking as much as $600 million for its Pilgrim Baxter unit. United Asset and Nationwide, the fifth-largest United States life insurer, and Pilgrim Baxter had been talking for months. Executives of Pilgrim Baxter, based in Wayne, Pa., wanted to own a stake in the firm if any sale occurred, they said.

title: Scandals, Then and Now; Equal Legal Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Elliott Carter, Playful or Crusty, Much Feted at 90
description: At the age of 90, Elliott Carter goes on, vital as ever, and it is good to find so many celebratory concerts coming along in his home city as he approaches his 10th decade. It is especially good that a lot of his most recent music will be heard in the next few weeks. The Quintet for Piano and Strings, his latest big instrumental piece, will arrive on Dec. 4. The Clarinet Concerto will get two New York performances, the first by Charles Neidich and Orpheus at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 31. And a couple of smaller new items are to be included in the concert of Mr. Carter's music at Miller Theater on Oct. 27.

title: Schumer's New Ad Assails D'Amato's Abortion Stance
description: With an attack on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's position on abortion rights, Representative Charles E. Schumer began a new phase in his television advertising campaign last night, releasing the first of a series of rapid-fire commercials intended to highlight how the two candidates differ on key issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECHTSCHAFFEN, RUDOLPH
description: RECHTSCHAFFEN - Rudolph, PhD. The Young Israel of Scarsdale regretfully records the passing of its member. Our heartfelt condolences to Ronnie and the entire family. Jacob Rubenstein, Rabbi Joshua Klapper, President

title: Ocean Township Police Giving Away Gun Locks
description: As state lawmakers considered a bill this week that would require all handguns sold in New Jersey to be fitted with a childproof fingerprint sensor, the police in Ocean Township began offering a simpler way to keep weapons out of the hands of children.

title: All Nippon Airways May Join Star Alliance
description: The All Nippon Airways Company, Japan's second-largest airline, is set to become the next member of the Star Alliance, the world's biggest airline grouping, as the alliance pushes to expand its reach in Asia. The chief executives and chairmen of the alliance will meet in Rio de Janeiro early next week with an agenda that includes the addition of new partners. A partnership with All Nippon would strengthen the Star members' foothold in Asia, where it is the second-biggest carrier.

title: State Sues 2 Brokers Accused of Scalping Yankees Tickets
description: State officials, saying they are intensifying efforts to crack down on ticket scalping as the World Series gets under way, filed a lawsuit yesterday against two brokers for selling tickets to the playoff games between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians at about twice their face value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B. Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. Services, followed by a reception, will be held at the Chevy Chase Club, 6100 Connecticut Ave., N.W., Chevy Chase, MD 20815, on Sunday, October 18, at 4 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: Maynard Parker, the Editor Of Newsweek, Is Dead at 58
description: Maynard Parker, who as editor of Newsweek helped transform the weekly newsmagazine from a digest of foreign and political events into a publication that put greater emphasis on science, religion, social issues and technology, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the television producer Joseph Cates on Monday gave his marital history incompletely and omitted two survivors. Mr. Cates was married four times, not three. His survivors include his estranged wife, Joan Brandt-Cates of Little Rock, Ark., and a stepson, Wilson Brandt, of Colorado Springs.

title: K.J.'s Appeal Is Long-Shot Winner
description: The success of the Yankees did not rub off on the track last night for their principal owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cut in U.S. Interest Rates Helps Markets Rally Abroad

title: Foley's Toughest Test Continues on the Bench
description: Vinny Testaverde has come through the trial by fire, and so far Glenn Foley has not. That was the gist today of Coach Bill Parcells's analysis of Foley, the younger, less experienced and more vulnerable of the two quarterbacks, who has now been relegated to the Jets' bench.

title: Inquiry Is Planned Into Telecom Italia
description: Italian prosecutors plan an investigation into possible insider trading at Telecom Italia S.p.A., according to Adusbef, an Italian consumer association that lodged a criminal complaint against the former telephone monopoly. The inquiry centers on Telecom Italia's share price fluctuations last week, when the concern, the world's eighth-largest telephone company, first denied and then confirmed a forecast of declining profit in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. The staff of Parade Publications, where he was a senior contributing editor to PARADE Magazine for more than 15 years, mourns the sudden death of our beloved friend and colleague. Cleveland's journalistic talents were as legendary as his love for animals. Although he claimed to be a curmudgeon, Cleveland was a deeply sensitive and caring man, who charmed everyone he met. His gracious style, wit and compassion will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: At Penn Station: Rider Egression
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Writer, 32, Passed for 19; Bloom Is Off Her Contract
description: A 32-year-old woman who pretended to be a teen-ager to get work faces the possible loss of a lucrative writing contract with Touchstone Television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOPE, RICHARD A.
description: SCOPE-Richard A. Age 66, of Boca Raton, FL passed away October 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Audrey Scope. Loving father of Cindy Scope, Michael & Erin Scope. Adored son of Estelle Davies. Dear brother of Sherry & Alan Salzman. Son-in-law of Leo & Shirley Goodfriend. Brother-in-law of Marvin & Tina, Irwin & Phyllis Goodfriend. Vice President of Prudential Securities. Past Master of Dunwoodie Lodge Masons. Graduate Yale Class of 1953. Services Sunday 12 noon at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton Beach, FL 561-272-0098.

title: Ill Boy Taken From Home Returns to Williamsburg
description: Once again wearing his yarmulke but shorn of his side curls, a 6-year-old Hasidic boy returned home yesterday to a celebratory welcome in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as the couple alleged to have kidnapped him faced Federal abduction charges.

title: Adrian Spies, TV Writer, 78; Won Acclaim For 'Climax'
description: Adrian Spies, an award-winning television writer who turned out dozens of acclaimed scripts for the live drama series ''Climax'' in the 1950's and wrote one of the first ''Star Trek'' episodes in 1966, died on Oct. 2 at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Galliano Soars While Chanel Is Spaced Out : The Faustian Syndrome
description: PARIS  An exquisite show of seraglio sensuality from John Galliano, and a weird, futuristic collection from Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel underlines what is bedeviling fashion in the 1990s: the Faust syndrome.

title: When Experts Do the Shopping
description: NEW YORK  Many people associate shopping with frantically searching for a salesperson who, when he or she finally ambles over, seems to know little or nothing about the merchandise and to have even less interest in being helpful, much less making a sale.

title: Sports of The Times; Honoring His Father's Instructions
description: ONCE upon a time, baseball was full of players like Tony Gwynn. A player spent his career with one team, no jumping around, no chasing after the money, putting down roots. There was a covenant: play hard, play well, and chances are you'll have a home for a while.

title: INSIDE
description: Home for the Series

title: Shares Rise for Second Day on Euphoria Over a Rate Cut
description: Confidence stemming from the Federal Reserve Board's second interest rate cut in three weeks spread further through financial markets yesterday, as stock prices registered strong gains in heavy trading and bond yields fell.

title: Sly Dissident Or Soviet Tool? A Musical War; New Evidence on Memoirs Splits Shostakovich Scholars
description: During the 40 years before his death in 1975, the composer Dmitri Shostakovich was no stranger to life-and-death controversy. In 1936 Stalin attacked his opera ''Lady Macbeth,'' as ''crude, primitive, vulgar''; the composer feared for his life. Then, in 1948, an even larger attack was mounted on his musical style; Shostakovich lost his teaching job and again expected brutal knocks on the door.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, WILLIAM J., MONSIGNOR
description: HIGGINS-William J., Monsignor, October 16, 1998. Beloved brother of George Higgins and Grace Higgins Gazda. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Saturday 2-5 and 7-9PM, Sunday 79PM. Service Monday, 10 AM, St. Monica's R.C. Church, 79th Street, between York & 1st Avenue, NYC.

title: HOECHST AND KOHLBERG KRAVIS HALT TALKS
description: Hoechst A.G., Europe's No. 4 chemical maker, and the United States buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company ended talks on Kohlberg Kravis's purchase of Hoechst's paint unit. The Frankfurt-based Hoechst said Kohlberg Kravis had reduced the price it was prepared to pay for the Herberts paint unit below what Hoechst would accept. In August, Kohlberg Kravis agreed in principle to pay 3 billion marks ($1.86 billion) for Herberts, Europe's leading coatings supplier. The news comes at the end of a week in which Hoechst warned that its 1998 earnings will fall from last year's level, as business in Asia, Latin America and Russia slumps. Hoechst said yesterday that it was in talks with other companies that have shown interest in buying Herberts.

title: Journal; 'Corpus Christi' D.O.A.
description: Culture wars may come and go, but some things don't change: Culture wars are almost never about culture, and are almost always more dramatic, more entertaining and more farcical than the supposedly incendiary art works that ignite them.

title: 2 Developers Settle Suit Over Gambling Complex
description: Ending a nine-month court feud, two Las Vegas-based casino operators have agreed to drop legal actions against each other over a proposed gambling complex they were to build together in Atlantic City.

title: N.H.L.: ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders traded an unhappy Tom Chorske and a 1999 eighth-round pick yesterday to the Washington Capitals for a sixth round pick in next year's draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, LEO A., M.D.
description: SPIEGEL-Leo A., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the loss of their longtime colleague and friend. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Owners Would Expand Union's Luxury Tax Idea
description: Three days after the players union proposed a luxury tax on very high-salaried players as a way of breaking a three-month labor impasse, the National Basketball Association responded yesterday with a luxury tax proposal of its own that would include the salaries of many more players.

title: Fed-Generated Optimism Sends Asian Stocks Soaring
description: Stock market euphoria swept from the United States and Europe to Asia today, as share prices across the region surged in response to Thursday's cut in interest rates in the United States.

title: TWO BIG DENTAL GROUPS PLANNING A COMBINATION
description: The Gentle Dental Services Corporation and Dental Care Associates Inc. have agreed to combine, creating one of largest dental-management companies. Dental Care holders, who will own about 46.5 percent of a new holding company, will exchange each of their shares for 1.67 shares in the new company. Gentle Dental holders will own 53.5 percent and exchange their shares 1 for 1. Gentle Dental had 1997 revenue of $43.4 million, while Dental Care had 1997 revenue of $7.88 million. The new company will be based in El Segundo, Calif., where Gentle Dental is based.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, AARON
description: GOLDBERG-Aaron. On October 14, 1998. after a long illness. Beloved husband of Edith, loving brother of the late Arthur and Albert. Devoted uncle and grand uncle. Services Sunday, October 18th, 1998 at 11 A.M., Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York.

title: Mrs. Hume's 'You Got It!' Confirms Prize
description: On the morning he won the Nobel Peace Prize, John Hume got out of bed, as usual at 8:30, made himself some Alpen and bananas for breakfast and prepared to spend another day in his life's work: trying to permanently end sectarian violence in this predominantly Protestant British province.

title: Two in Ireland Share Nobel Prize for Peace
description: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to John Hume and David Trimble, leaders of the largest Catholic and Protestant political parties in Northern Ireland, for their efforts to bring peace to the British province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLISEY, JAMES VINCENT
description: HALLISEY-James Vincent. October 16, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Hallisey. Loving father of James V. Hallisey, Jr. and Tamara Hallisey-Hatfield. Cherished grandfather of Sasha A. Hatfield and James V. Hallisey, III. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81st Street, Sunday, October 18, 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday, 10 A.M., at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th Street at Lexington Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Carrying a Torch for a Malevolent Doll
description: A handful of jokes about Martha Stewart, a dig at Barbie and an excursion into the sex life of toys cannot rescue the comic Grand Guignol that is ''Bride of Chucky'' from the graveyard of horror sequels that lose the heartbeat of inspiration long before they die of box office anemia.

title: Baseball Bragging Rights
description: It is fitting that this most memorable of baseball seasons should conclude with a World Series that opens tonight in Yankee Stadium, the aging but still grand cathedral of the sport. Bedecked in bunting and banners, the revered ball park always elevates the game with its aura of history and accomplishment. That makes it the perfect venue for part of a championship series that will determine whether the 1998 Yankees are one of the greatest teams of the modern era, or just a talented squad that owned the regular season but folded in the World Series.

title: ENTERPRISE SOFTWARE STOCK UP ON POSSIBLE SALE
description: The stock of Enterprise Software Inc. soared 34 percent yesterday after the company said it would hire an investment bank to explore a sale or merger. The company said it would name its financial adviser in a few weeks. Enterprise, based in Detroit, provides management software and systems to television and radio broadcasters, advertisers, cable-TV operators and TV programmers. It has 1998 revenue of $24.1 million. Enterprise Software made the announcement on Thursday after stock markets had closed. Its shares jumped $1.50 yesterday, to $5.875, on the Nasdaq stock market. At that price the company's market capitalization is $26.5 million.

title: Father's Surgery a Strain on Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte left his Yankee teammates on Thursday to be with his father, Tom, who had triple-bypass heart surgery that day. Pettitte, who is scheduled to pitch Game 4 of the World Series, may not rejoin the team until it flies to San Diego next week. Andy Pettitte, said Manager Joe Torre, ''is under a lot of stress and strain right now.''

title: Mob Linked to Adult Entertainment Thefts
description: In a case of oldest profession meets newest technology, a Federal indictment handed up last Friday suggests that the mob is muscling its way into cyberspace.

title: At Penn Station: Rider Egression
description: To the Editor:

title: Together Or Apart, A Oneness
description: Marta Renzi, an American choreographer, has been working with Anna Sedlackova, a dancer from Slovakia, since 1994. They celebrated their collaboration in ''Long Distance Dialogues/Rozhovory na dial'ku,'' the program that Ms. Renzi and the Project Company presented on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, MINNA
description: MICHAEL-Minna. The Brotherhood Synagogue mourns the passing of our long-time member and Trustee. In her 100 plus years of life, Minna was a loyal mother, an ardent supporter of Israel, and a devoted Jew.

title: End the Insanity Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lesson of Matthew Shepard
description: It was a painful and soul-searching moment for the nation when Matthew Shepard was buried in Casper, Wyo., yesterday. The details of his murder have been a public horror -- he was singled out, apparently, because he was gay, tied to a fence, beaten and left in a coma in the chill of night. His death at the tender age of 21 has brought home to the American public as nothing else ever has the menace and hatred that homosexuals still face in being honest in the United States.

title: Right Now, Future Can Wait for Williams
description: As Bernie Williams starts what could be his final series with the Yankees in Game 1 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium tonight, he wants to do it with a free mind. Free of worrying about his extremely uncertain future and an undisclosed personal matter that has made this post-season as perplexing as it has been pleasing.

title: Washington Talk; Even in the Best of Times, Reaching a Budget Accord Is a Sometime Thing
description: For the first time in decades, Congress and the White House negotiated tax and spending legislation this year with the budget in surplus. The result was chaos.

title: DNA for the Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about computer security programs misspelled the surname of the director of public relations at the Mr. Payroll Corporation, which uses facial recognition technology to identify people cashing checks at A.T.M.'s. He is David E. Doremus, not Duremus.

title: 2 Ulster Peacemakers Win the Nobel Prize
description: The 1998 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to John Hume and David Trimble, leaders of the largest Roman Catholic and Protestant political parties in Northern Ireland, for their efforts to bring peace to the long-polarized British province.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM RISES 2.2 PERCENT. Prices climbed in reaction to the Federal Reserve's rate cut, which raised expectations of stronger growth and higher demand. The December contract increased $5.95 an ounce, to $280.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday, with an art review of ''Heroic Armor of the Italian Renaissance: Filippo Negroli and His Contemporaries,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the Roman-style equestrian armor at the upper right. It is believed to have been made in the workshop of Giovan Paolo Negroli for Archduke Ferdinand II of Tyrol -- not by Bartolomeo Campi for the Duke of Urbino.

title: Brazil Plans $20 Billion In Tax Hikes, Budget Cuts
description: As a three-man economic team headed for Washington, and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso flew off to Portugal, Brazilian Government officials put the finishing touches today on an ambitious package to raise $20 billion in revenues through spending cuts and tax increases next year.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Locked Together, Mideast Negotiators Chafe
description: The theory behind the current Middle East meetings is that if you lock feuding leaders together in a pretty spot, chase away the press, strip off their pinstripes or military tunics and put the American President between them, they will surely see the light.

title: At Penn Station: Rider Egression
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 23 about protests over the construction of a mansion in Sagaponack, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the dispute over an archeological tunnel in Jerusalem that prompted a wave of violent clashes in 1996. (Magazine articles have described the Sagaponack property owner as a financial supporter of the Jerusalem dig.) The tunnel does not run under Muslim religious sites, and the dispute was over the opening of a new entrance, not the construction of the tunnel. The error was pointed out in a letter from a reader on Aug. 25. This correction was delayed by errors in the checking process.

title: Trimble, Visiting U.S., Hopes for Lasting Peace
description: Shortly before sunup in Denver today, one of the new Nobel Peace Prize winners, David Trimble, held an impromptu news conference outside the Brown Palace Hotel as he hurried to meetings on the final day of a trade mission here.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about NATO's threat to bomb Serbia misstated the number of countries in the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is to deploy monitors in Kosovo. It is 54, not 29.

title: Bank Rescue Plan Becomes Law in Japan
description: Japan's Parliament completed passage of a plan today that commits more than $500 billion of taxpayer funds to rescue the nation's teetering banking system in an attempt to get money flowing through a crippled economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINZHEIMER, RONALD H.
description: SINZHEIMER-Ronald H. At rest October 9, 1998. Prominent Albany Attorney expert in the fields of environmental and business law, bankruptcy and real estate. Husband of Marsha Stern, father of Andrew. Son of Hans and Shula Sinzheimer of NY City. Nephew of Traute Mainzer. Services at the Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, New York on Sunday at 1:00 PM.

title: Oregon Gets Its Big Shot At U.C.L.A.
description: They are clearly the supporting stars of this Hollywood showdown, but Oregon is certainly bringing enough A-list credits to the Rose Bowl to make U.C.L.A. worry about its national close-up on Saturday.

title: Brandeis at 50 Is Still Searching, Still Jewish and Still Not Harvard
description: Half a century ago, when a group of uneducated immigrant Jews scraped together enough money to buy a bankrupt medical and veterinary school in Waltham, Mass., west of Boston, they named it Brandeis University and set out to found the Harvard of the Jews.

title: Pataki Calls Political Financing 'Dreadful,' but Has No Solution
description: New York State's campaign finance system is ''dreadful'' and ought to be overhauled, Gov. George E. Pataki said in an interview this week, but he suggested that any real reform would be difficult to achieve and refused to detail what changes he might want to make.

title: Hate-Crime Law Is an Easy Political Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Necessity Bridges Gulf Between Gore and Gephardt
description: The possibility that impeachment proceedings against President Clinton could weaken the Democrats this year, and again in the Presidential election in 2000, has helped bring together the two leading potential candidates for that race, Vice President Al Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.

title: WORLD SERIES PREVIEW: YANKEES VS. PADRES -- The Series Goes Coastal; Scouting report on the World Series.
description: NEW YORK

title: Political Memo; In About-Face, Democrats Give Clinton Praise
description: Here's a quiz to see if you are keeping up with the head-snapping political swerves in Washington.

title: An Alert Double of a Cue-Bid Spells Doom for a Bold Slam
description: A major charitable effort that began on a small scale 15 years ago was played Thursday night at the Parker-Meridien Hotel, 118 West 57th Street in Manhattan. It raised almost $30,000 for the Israel Cancer Relief Fund, and the winners, ahead of many national champions, were Bob Fishman and Elaine Immerman of Manhattan, with a fine score of 70 percent. Runners-up with 64 percent were Pauline Harrison and Barbara Mosbacher of Manhattan.

title: New Stock Exchange Site Under Discussion
description: City and state officials told the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that they were on the verge of securing a site for a new headquarters and trading complex for the market directly across the street from its historic home on Wall Street, according to people involved in the discussions.

title: Newark Park Restoration Begins Along the Passaic
description: Essex County officials began the restoration of Riverbank Park in Newark yesterday.

title: Editorial Observer; A Clean, Germ-Free Candidate
description: The Bill-and-Monica jokes may die down by 2000, but only then will we see President Clinton's legacy to the next Presidential campaign. In shaping what voters look for and how candidates present themselves, his impact could be as striking as President Nixon's on the election of 1976.

title: Beliefs
description: In a decade when frantic and information-sodden people must rely on handy aids like ''Wittgenstein in 90 Minutes'' and ''Dating for Dummies,'' can't someone do the same for the Pope, who at the age of 78 keeps producing long and idea-packed encyclicals? ''Wojtyla in 90 Minutes''? ''John Paul II for Dummies''?

title: COLLEGES: SMALL COLLEGE REPORT -- PENNSYLVANIA
description: When Jim Finn was the Quakers' strong safety last season, he would watch his team's offense struggle and feel like a caged running back.

title: Famous Lighthouse Gets Money for Move
description: The Federal budget agreement reached on Thursday includes a grant of $9.8 million to the National Park Service for moving the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse from the shoreline of North Carolina's Outer Banks to a point 1,600 feet from the sea, Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina announced yesterday.

title: End Isolation Of Bosnian Serbs
description: To the Editor;

title: Caught Up, Eye and Ear, In a Tale Of Disaster
description: ''Hindenburg'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night marked a significant advance in the collaboration between Steve Reich and Beryl Korot. ''Music for 18 Musicians'' on the same program reminded us that Mr. Reich at his best has managed to rearrange our thoughts of what beauty and purpose in music really are.

title: Tony Blair, Thatcherite
description: In the past month, the European chattering classes have been going on about Third Way this and New Middle that. For the first time, 14 of the 15 European Union member states have left-of-center governments -- a sign, we are told, of Blairism run riot across Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSLER, DR. IRVING
description: RESSLER-Dr. Irving. On October 15, 1998. Dearly beloved husband of Ida (Fried). Loving father of Lauren and Joel Rublin, Marcy and John Harris, Mark Ressler and Ilissa Rothschild. Devoted ''Poppy'' of Michael, David, Andrew, Jennifer, Justin, William and Sage. Practiced dentistry in Waterbury, Conn. for forty-four years. His life was a wonderful example to all who knew him.

title: When the Clothes Dare to Grow Up : A New Attitude About Getting Old
description: WASHINGTON  The first indication that a change is afoot in the fashion industry has been largely symbolic. But that is a start. Fashion has gone gray. The clothes that now dominate the department and specialty stores come in a narrow palette of cool, sophisticated shades of gray.

title: DiMaggio Is in Hospital With Pneumonia
description: Joe DiMaggio is being treated for pneumonia in a hospital near his home in Florida.

title: End Isolation Of Bosnian Serbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Australia Exploits Cultural Diversity
description: HONG KONG  Australian fashion has catapulted into the international fashion arena, receiving rave reviews from buyers around the world. At a time when many European and American designers seem to have lost their creative edge, Australia's designers are moving in to provide a fresh alternative.

title: In Kosovo Village, Sounds of Problems for the Monitors
description: At lunchtime today, as Shkurte Ismajli was kneading dough in a tin pan on the floor of her makeshift kitchen here, she heard the thud of a mortar.

title: California Prepares for Faster Execution Pace
description: The largest death row in the United States is not in Florida or Texas, where executions have become almost routine rituals of last meals, unanswered prayers, lethal injections and hearses driving slowly through a prison gate.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Tuesday about ''Plague War,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary shown Tuesday night on PBS stations, referred incorrectly to two of three diseases mentioned as possible biological weapons. Plague and anthrax are caused by bacteria; only smallpox is a virus.

title: Nissan Expects Loss To Total $284 Million
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, said yesterday that it expected to post a net loss of 33 billion yen ($284 million) for the first half of the current business year because of huge losses on its securities holdings. Nissan had previously said it expected to break even in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, but it announced two weeks ago that it had incurred appraised losses of 76 billion yen on its securities holdings because of the sharp drop in Tokyo stock prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRACHMAN, HAROLD
description: DRACHMAN-Harold, age 71, of Monroe Twp., NJ, formerly of Oyster Bay, NY, October 16, 1998. Retired Vice Pres. of Andover, Inc., Manhattan. Husband of Eve, father of Harold (Cindy) & David (Janet). Grandfather of David, Jaclyn, Daniel, D.J., Jillian and the late Harold George. Service 12 noon Sunday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd, at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick, NJ. Memorials to Harold Drachman Oncology Fund, C/O Medical Center at Princeton, 253 Witherspoon St., Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: For Umps, It's Not a Perfect World
description: The last time they were seen on the field at Yankee Stadium, they were inadvertently influencing the outcome of the game that sent the Cleveland Indians home and the Yankees to the World Series. That's not to say the umpires will mess up in the World Series, but they have shown they are eminently capable of interfering with the natural progression of post-season games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UMLAS, HARRY
description: UMLAS-Harry. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving dad of Marilyn Wachtel & Robert Umlas. Devoted grandfather of Stefanie and Jared Umlas. Loving fatherin-law of Allan Wachtel and Judy Umlas. Died Thursday morning in his sleep after a long illness. New York services will be held at the Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Union Port Road, Bronx, New York, this Sunday, October 18th. at 11AM. Call for directions: 718-892-9400. Burial will be in the Stockbridge Town Cemetery, Massachusetts, approximately at 3 PM. The family will be sitting Shiva on Sunday and Monday in Stockbridge at the home of Marilyn and Allan Wachtel, and back in New Jersey, from Tuesday evening through Friday afternoon. The family request that in lieu of flowers, donations in Harry's memory be made to: The Jewish Home & Rehabilitation Center, of River Vale, New Jersey. 201-666-2370

title: Rizo de Oro Journal; Under Siege, Zapatistas Keep Their Profile Low
description: Everywhere in this village in the verdant canyons of Chiapas State there are subtle signs of the presence of the Zapatista rebel army.

title: G.O.P.'s Bad Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Demotes Debt Chief in Latest Shake-Up
description: The shake-up in the executive suite at Merrill Lynch & Company continued yesterday as the brokerage firm announced that it had replaced the head of its global debt business.

title: A Personal Take on Walking in Clinton's Shoes
description: When the American cultural historian Ann Douglas was deep into the 13th century for her doctoral dissertation at Harvard, she discovered what she calls predecessors of the modern media: the handmade books created by Roman Catholic priests in England and France to record the religious visions of illiterate peasants. As Ms. Douglas tells it, the peasants described their visions, and the priests compiled them into books used to promote their orders. ''It was that fundamental process,'' she said, ''by which the private becomes public.''

title: At Rochester Catholic Church, Anger Over 2d Dismissal
description: After church officials removed a popular pastor from a Roman Catholic parish in Rochester six weeks ago, many of its 3,000 members looked to his longtime assistant for comfort and continuity. So when the assistant, a female theologian, was dismissed on Thursday for taking too prominent a role during the liturgy, they were left floundering for ways to express their loss and anger.

title: At Penn Station: Rider Egression
description: To the Editor:

title: Hate-Crime Law Is an Easy Political Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Timing a Rate Cut: The Fed Acts Quickly
description: He is revered in the financial markets these days as omnipotent and omniscient, but Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has not always gotten it right.

title: CONGRESS DELAYS VOTING ON BUDGET UNTIL NEXT WEEK
description: A day after celebrating a much-delayed agreement on a final Federal budget package, Congress did not have a budget bill in place to vote on today and postponed planned action on the $500 billion deal until next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHBAUM, BLANCHE
description: KIRSCHBAUM-Blanche. Beloved wife of Herman. Devoted mother of Robert & Jacquie Kirschbaum and the late Michael. Adored grandmother of Jake. Services on Sunday, at 1 P.M., at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Boulevard and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Yankees' Biggest Task: Neutralize Brown
description: Joe Torre carried a thick red binder through the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday, holding it against his hip, like mother and child. The binder, as thick as any Yellow Pages, contained the Yankees' scouting report of the San Diego Padres, intelligence to be used in the World Series that begins tonight at Yankee Stadium.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar declined further against the Japanese yen, in the wake of the Federal Reserve's cuts in interest rates. The dollar fell to 115.25 yen from 116.75, finishing the week down against the yen by 1.4 percent.
