title: Judge Reluctantly Recommends Dismissal of 2 Firefighters Who Rode on Racist Float
description: A city administrative judge recommended yesterday that two firefighters who wore blackface as they rode on a racist float during a Labor Day parade be fired from their jobs. But the judge added that she reached her decision in part because she could not consider a less severe but perhaps more appropriate punishment.

title: With Prod From U.S., Mideast Talks Are Moving, Slowly
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders, under the prodding hand of American officials, are making some progress toward an interim accord, officials said today, but they described the going as slow and the mistrust as still deep.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RALCORP HOLDINGS INC., St. Louis, a maker of private-label crackers and cereal, announced it would buy back as many as 5 million shares at a price of $14 to $16 in a Dutch tender offer.

title: Caterpillar Profit Is Down 12.7%
description: Caterpillar Inc., the largest manufacturer of construction and earth-moving equipment, said today that third-quarter profits fell 12.7 percent because of weaker sales in Asia and global competition that forced the company to lower prices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARIPIDES, WILLIAM, GABRIELLA
description: CARIPIDES-William, Gabriella, Peter. Victims of Swiss Air Flight 111. A memorial service in celebration of the lives of William, Garbriella, and Peter will take place today at St. Dimitru Church, 50 West 89th St at 3 PM. All of the family and friends they have left behind are saddened and deeply grieving their loss. We all know, however, that we have been blessed to have had such wonderful people touch our lives, and we know that we have three angels watching over us. May they rest in peace. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Dimitru Church 212-874-4490. Always in our hearts, The Catar, Caripides, Metianu and Rybakoff Families

title: Vallone Criticizes Pataki for Vetoing Bills to Finance Child Care
description: Surrounded by child care advocates, parents and children assembled for his news conference, Peter F. Vallone criticized Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday for vetoing funds in the budget for child care, and said his record showed that he would do a better job of serving the interests of young children and working parents.

title: 'Fat Comedy' to Close
description: ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy,'' a play by Rob Bartlett, is to close after this evening's performance at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Jack O'Brien, will have run for 17 previews and four regular performances.

title: Output Slows and Consumer Prices Are Steady
description: Industrial production unexpectedly declined during September and consumer prices were unchanged, signs the Federal Reserve has room to reduce interest rates still further to combat faltering consumer confidence.

title: Man Is Convicted in City's 2d Recent Death Penalty Trial
description: In New York City's second death penalty trial since the state reinstated capital punishment three years ago, a Brooklyn man was convicted of first-degree murder yesterday by a jury that will now decide whether to sentence him to death for killing another man while robbing him of his jewelry.

title: U.S. May Fight Northwest Deal For Continental
description: The Clinton Administration has raised objections to Northwest Airlines's bid to buy a controlling stake in Continental Airlines and may file suit to block the deal as early as Monday, a person briefed on the Government's plans said yesterday.

title: Think Tank; Down and Dirty in the Ivory Tower
description: The financial stakes cannot compare with Monopoly. There is no chance for global domination as in Risk. It may feel like a life-or-death matter, but there's almost never a murder, as in Clue.

title: About New York; A Family Bond As Thick As Blood
description: SYLVIA RODRIGUEZ and her son Andrew recently went shopping at the Kmart near Co-op City in the Bronx. The place is huge and Andrew is young, so it was only a matter of time before the 8-year-old wandered off to explore the aisles that beckoned with toys. His mother cried as she scoured the store.

title: Rangers Accentuate Positive in Loss
description: For Rangers Coach John Muckler, it was time to pass out praise and stress the positive. He spoke of how young Todd Harvey was the ''heartbeat of the team'' with almost 17 energetic minutes at center. Then there was the impressive play of the rookie goalie, Dan Cloutier, who stopped 28 Devils shots last night in Madison Square Garden.

title: Court Upholds Giuliani's Bid To Bar Yankees Referendum
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gained a crucial victory yesterday in his battle to keep a referendum on the future of Yankee Stadium off the Nov. 3 ballot, as a state appellate court upheld his right to replace that referendum with one on campaign finance.

title: Scandals, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Jarvis Ready To Begin Season
description: It has been more than four months since Mike Jarvis was hired as the coach at St. John's. But filling up the shelves and walls of his office, watching film and learning his way around Queens are not the sort of things that brought him here. And even with the hoopla of Midnight Madness taking hold of Alumni Hall last night, it still was not quite enough to make it all real for Jarvis.

title: Budget Item Would Curb Internet Smut
description: Tucked into the $1.7 trillion budget agreement is a new measure that would restrict children's access to pornography on the Internet. The measure was sponsored by Republicans who said they had written it to overcome free-speech objections that the Supreme Court used to overturn a previous ban.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUENTES, JOSE
description: FUENTES-Jose, age 62. Died on October 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Janelle and Damaris. Predeceased by daughter Adina. He had a life-long commitment to human and community services. Memorial celebration to be scheduled at a later date. Visiting hours are Saturday from 2:30 PM through 8:30 PM at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, DENIS J.
description: CASEY-Denis J. on October 15, 1998 formerly of Bronxville, New York. Loving father of Caroline and Michael. Adored grandfather of Alexandra. Beloved brother of Patrick, Mary Geary & Eleanor O'Byrne. Reposing Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square Tuckahoe, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 A.M. St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bronxville. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Sunday & Monday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations to the Denis J. Casey Memorial College Fund for Alexandra Casey at the United Nations.

title: Jacques Abram, 83, a Pianist Of Crisp Modernist Precision
description: Jacques Abram, a pianist who performed regularly as a recitalist and concerto soloist in New York in the 1940's and 50's, died in Tampa, Fla., on Oct. 5. He was 83.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: New York Escape:A Day in the Spa
description: NEW YORK  After decades of the "sweat and starve" mentality, New Yorkers are turning to day spas as a gentler, more hedonistic way to relieve stress.

title: Mannequins vs. Top Models?No Contest : The Changing Face Of Shop Dummies
description: PARIS  Who can compete with top models? Not the dummies in the windows, those material girls and boys who never make the catwalks because they are made of wax, wood, plaster, cloth or fiberglass.

title: Hope Fades for Uptown Rally for Sosa
description: The on-again-off-again hero's welcome for Sammy Sosa in upper Manhattan that was supposed to take place tomorrow appears to be off again, if it ever was on.

title: In an Interview, the Governor Stresses Crime, Welfare and Tax Cuts
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Gov. George E. Pataki on Thursday with editors, reporters and executives of The New York Times:

title: Gadgets to Go Gentle Into Age; A Market Grows and Modernizes as Demand Increases
description: They spent 40 years building a life that produced six children, a thriving business and the security for what was to be a carefree retirement. But David and Ann Lambert's plans crumbled when he suffered a stroke five years ago that left him partly paralyzed and unable to speak more than a few words.

title: Strawberry Goes Home to Begin Recovery
description: Hours after Darryl Strawberry was released from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday, he spoke happily about being able to play with his two young children, joked about eating a small amount of chicken and potatoes, and sounded relieved to be at home in Fort Lee, N.J., instead of in a hospital.

title: G.O.P.'s Bad Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Hate-Crime Law Is an Easy Political Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEMPLE, NATHAN
description: TEMPLE-Nathan. 10/17/53. Remembered with love always. France

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIEDRICK, ARTHUR HILL, M.D.
description: DIEDRICK-Arthur Hill, M.D. On October 16, 1998 of Rye, N.Y. Devoted husband of the late Ann. Father of Arthur Hill Diedrick, Jr. of Litchfield, CT; Dinah Beverly of Brandywine, WV; Lawrence Gilyard Diedrick of Rocky Mount, N.C.; and William Brice Diedrick of Rye, N.Y. Grandfather of 11 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends Sunday, 5-7 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. A memorial service will be held Monday, October 19, 1998 at 11 A.M. at Rye Presbyterian Church. Interment service private. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospital, Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: October 11-17; N.B.A. Cancels Games
description: The first two weeks of the National Basketball Association season were canceled as labor talks slowed to a crawl. The players' union and the league lobbed verbal grenades at each other in the dispute, which involves the distribution of about $2 billion in league income.

title: Coattails And More In the Races For Congress
description: WHEN Mark Nielsen campaigns, he often introduces himself as the Republican running for John G. Rowland's old Congressional seat. No matter that Mr. Rowland, now the Governor, hasn't been in Congress since 1990, and that there have been two Congressmen in the seat since then.

title: When a Return Is Sweet Sorrow
description: EVERYONE knows you can't go home again, but what of travelers and their earlier destinations? Can you -- should you -- ever return? Or like Heraclitus's river, can these places never be stepped into twice? Such questions I'd never been forced to confront, much less pondered, until I was about to go to Prague again.

title: When Mass Transit Was an Amiable Beast
description: THE era of the electric streetcar, or trolley as it was commonly known, was relatively brief, lasting only from the fading years of the last century to the middle of this century.

title: Eric Weintz and Joy Gustafson
description: Joy Ellen Gustafson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Gustafson of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric Cortelyou Weintz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob F. Weintz Jr. of Riverside, Conn.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'Love Letters' in Katonah

title: East Hampton Graduates Show High Cancer Rates
description: AN unusual number of cancer cases have been found, state health officials say, in young people who have at least one thing in common: they have all graduated from East Hampton High School since 1990.

title: Miss Mirchandani, Mr. Trauber
description: Priya Gitanjali Mirchandani, the daughter of Veena and Sunder Mirchandani of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Jay Trauber, a son of Dianne Trauber of Midlothian, Va., and Ami Trauber of Brookline, Mass.

title: The World: Europe's New Policeman; NATO Shatters Old Limits in the Name of Preventing Evil
description: HALF a century after it was founded, NATO expanded its mandate last week, taking upon itself a mission to extend freedom, human rights, civility and the rule of law in Europe.

title: Katherine Elwyn, Georg Budenbender
description: Dr. Katherine Elizabeth Elwyn and Georg O. Budenbender are to be married today at the James House, a historic house in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. Judge John E. Sprizzo of the Federal District Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

title: A Little Pain Is Worth It
description: When you stop playing the game, it's like dying. You spend your life struggling and striving to attain this dream of playing in the N.F.L., and then you're out and it's jarring. People ask me, Do you like broadcasting games? And I say: Yeah, but it's not as good as playing. It's like methadone to a heroin addict.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Financier to the Garage Start-Up
description: AT 6 A.M. on Wednesdays, some of Silicon Valley's most prominent financiers gather at a basketball court of the Pacific Athletic Club in Redwood Shores, Calif., to rub -- and throw -- elbows. In that weekly pickup game, Guy Kawasaki, 5 feet 9 inches tall, has established himself as career leader in assists. Now he wants to become the leader at assisting off the court as well -- and get rich doing it.

title: Dressed to Party
description: Costume balls and other festivities have a positive effect on the worlds of art, dance and charity.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Flights of Angels

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHBAUM, BLANCHE
description: KIRSCHBAUM-Blanche. Beloved wife of Herman. Devoted mother of Robert & Jacquie Kirschbaum and the late Michael. Adored grandmother of Jake. Services on Sunday, at 1 P.M., at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Boulevard and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: Sighing, a French Sound Endures
description: IN this country, the very idea of the French popular song usually triggers the most primitive faux snapshots of French culture: Maurice Chevalier waving his boater, or Edith Piaf -- the Little Sparrow -- alone on a dark stage, holding a note interminably while one or two melodies are dashed off on the accordion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, EILEEN LANOUETTE
description: HUGHES-Eileen Lanouette. 73. Died suddenly on October 8, 1998 in Florence, Italy while vacationing with dear friends. Born June 11, 1925, Mrs. Hughes was a former international correspondent for Life Magazine. In 1951, she married Emmet John Hughes, Life Editor. After their separation, Mrs. Hughes resumed her journalistic career in Rome. More recently she worked as Director of Public Relations at both New York and Fordham Universities and as a writer at Reader's Digest Recorded Music. Mrs. Hughes is survived by her two daughters Mary Larkin Hughes and Kathleen Murphy, both of Los Angeles; her brother Henry of Southbury, CT and by her four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Most Holy Trinity Church on Buell Lane in East Hampton, NY on Saturday, November 14 at 11 AM.

title: Chefs Who Prize Canada's Bounty
description: IN British Columbia, without looking very hard, I always stumble upon ingredients that would catch the eye and impress the palate of even the fussiest chef.

title: Will Our Bluff Be Called in Kosovo?; Ask More of Milosevic
description: To the Editor:

title: Victory in October Is a First for Gordon
description: On a day of firsts for Nascar, Jeff Gordon also did something for the first time.

title: Ronnie Paccione, Murray Barnes
description: Veronica Paccione and Murray Barnes were married yesterday by the Rev. William Dearman at St. John's-in-the-Wilderness Episcopal Church in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: The Good Eating column on Oct. 4 carried an erroneous rating for the restaurant Aquagrill. It received two stars from The New York Times on May 10, 1996, not one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, BEATRICE
description: ALEXANDER-Beatrice. Died October 15. Services will be at the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY, at noon today. Survived by her two brothers Norman Alexander and Alex Alexander. She was a loyal sister and we mourn her loss.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 18, 1998
description: Weeks

title: . . . and Signs at a Hot Dog Stand That Try to Shed It
description: As the House Judiciary Committee debated last month over whether to release President Clinton's videotaped grand-jury testimony about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, Nicholas A. B. Gray, the owner of Gray's Papaya takeout, was getting steamed. He decided to turn his hot-dog stands into soapboxes.

title: Preaching to the Converted
description: . . . And the Horse He Rode In On

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGARA, DR. ALLYS DWYER
description: VERGARA-Dr. Allys Dwyer. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Dr. Allys Dwyer Vergara, Class of 1924, Professor Emeritus of Speech and English. A caring, concerned, loyal friend and advocate for almost 80 years, she lovingly and unselfishly shared her long, rich life with others. We mourn her loss and celebrate her life. Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D President

title: Jewish Holiday Stories With Puppets and Shtick
description: As part of a series of weekend performances for children at Asphalt Green, Jennifer Levine and her sidekick, Aaron Task, will present two performances of ''Madame Matzah Ball's Holiday Celebration'' today.

title: Morning TV, Evening Recital: Just Another Day
description: ON ''CBS News Sunday Morning,'' the celebrated flutist and elegant correspondent Eugenia Zukerman is doing her weekly segment, this one about the pianist Yves Thibaudet. She says audiences love him and he's popular with his peers; she praises his technique, his way of conjuring colors. ''He brings out the hidden magic,'' she adds.

title: In Their Own Words
description: CHARLES E. SCHUMER

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Garden City, L.I.; A Village Planned by a Merchant Prince
description: FOUNDED in 1869 by Alexander T. Stewart, an authentic 19th century merchant prince, the Village of Garden City has from the outset been one of Nassau County's most prized addresses.

title: Bizball
description: Once every spring, I get a telephone call from my friend Michelle, who informs me she has received her invoice for Knicks season tickets and will be faxing news of the latest increase in the price of her two seats in the front row, directly behind the team's bench. This year, despite the lockout that threatens to delay the start of the National Basketball Association's season, the markup is $20 per ticket. That's the lowest since Pat Riley began modeling Armani at Madison Square Garden in 1991, at the expense of Michelle's once-perfect sight lines. The other good news is that Jeff Van Gundy -- considerably shorter than his predecessor, with much less hair and given to the occasional midgame squat -- remains the coach.

title: Elysa Koplovitz, John Goldstone
description: Elysa Koplovitz, the daughter of Rose and Joshua Koplovitz of Woodstock, N.Y., was married last evening to John Tigran Goldstone, the son of Maro Newman and Dr. Jonas Goldstone, both of New York. Judge Charles Rubin of the Beverly Hills Municipal Court officiated at the home of the couple in Los Angeles.

title: SOAPBOX; The Garden in Autumn
description: THOSE lazy, hazy Jersey summer days are long over, and in the garden, I've switched to life in the slow lane. The cooler temperatures signal the roses to put on their last flush of bloom. Asters, mums and sedum fill the border. Fall is the season when I take the time to wander around my garden and muse.

title: As Congress Session Ends, a Question of Legacy
description: The 105th Congress, which is to wrap up its final legislative business next week, rejoiced a year ago over a landmark bipartisan balanced-budget agreement that provided the biggest tax cut since the Reagan years. But the question today is whether the 105th will be remembered instead for something else: the bitter, protracted preoccupation with President Clinton's personal life and his lies about it.

title: Artists as Pariahs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SANTIS, JOSEPH W.
description: De SANTIS-Joseph W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph W. De Santis, associated with The Times from 1952, until retiring in 1992.

title: Streetscapes / East 80th Street Between Park and Lexington Avenues; 4 Mansions That Made Up a Multimillionaires' Row
description: SINCE August, the Junior League's clubhouse at 130 East 80th Street has gleamed -- a gentle cleaning has brought out all the sophistication of its Regency-style facade.

title: Where Art Often Mourns, Memorials to Life
description: A small crowd gathered at an abandoned church at West 127th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard recently and scrutinized three giant multicolored portraits mounted in the boarded-up windows. A man said of one picture, ''Doesn't that look like Bill Cosby to you?''

title: State Issues a Health Warning on Mosquitoes
description: SINCE the death of a Rhode Island man from Eastern equine encephalitis in June, scientists and public health officials in Connecticut have been watching for the presence of the rare but often fatal mosquito-borne disease. And a mosquito with the equine encephalitis was indeed found in Stonington in late September, meaning Connecticut as well as Massachusetts and Rhode Island have a problem. Spraying of pesticides has begun and officials warn that risk from mosquito-borne disease will persist until first frosts, and that people, particularly residents of the southeastern corner of the state, should take care, especially at dawn and dusk, when the species of mosquitoes known to be carrying the equine encephalitis are most active.

title: Muscleman, or 98-Pound Weakling?
description: AS America awakened from a recession in 1991, the economy had a lot of work to do.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Opens the Door For Buying Opportunities
description: The Federal Reserve's move last week to shave a quarter of a point from interest rates may not be the only thing going for the stock market for the remainder of the year. While the 10.3 percent fall in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the third quarter was the seventh-worst for all the third quarters since World War II, that may actually portend some good news. Looking at the six comparable quarters with greater declines in the index, The Outlook, an S.& P. newsletter, reported in its Oct. 7 issue that five of them were followed by fourth-quarter gains.

title: A Bipartisan Team Grounds Bill Allowing More Flights
description: The roar of jumbo jets in the sky recently made for strange bedfellows on Capitol Hill. As Republicans and Democrats debated impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, Democratic members of Congress from Queens teamed up with a Republican colleague, Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, to defeat a bill that would have allowed more airplanes to fly in and out of La Guardia and John F. Kennedy Airports.

title: Liftoff in Coalwood
description: ROCKET BOYS

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Our Towns; Human Touch On the Way To Daily Grind
description: LAUGHTER rippled from one railroad car to the next, followed by waves of applause. These are sounds not normally associated with the early morning commute. But this was the 7:44 from New Haven to Grand Central Terminal, Travis Ford's train.

title: Penn's One-Man Show Upends Columbia
description: Jim Finn, a halfback at the University of Pennsylvania, carries a burden with him. It is not one that debilitates him or hounds him or even stays on his mind for long periods of time. Nor is it what inspires him during the off season to work harder in the weight room or run longer on the track.

title: On Language; The 1998 Bloopie Awards
description: We begin the award of this year's coveted Bloopie Awards -- for outstandingly sloppy solecisms in advertising copy -- by holding our noses.

title: A Cultural Standoff Over Guns
description: WHEN Wal-Mart opened a store here Margaret Nadramia was so excited that she came to the grand opening. Mrs. Nadramia, a Peekskill resident, had been browsing in the home fashions department for sheets and curtains when she decided to look at the lawn and garden supplies. On her way down the aisle she stumbled across something that shocked her -- Wal-Mart's gun display.

title: San Francisco Treat: A Quicksilver Tour
description: THE august San Francisco Ballet, at 65 America's oldest classical company, takes audiences on a guided tour through ballet of the century's second half in an ambitious weeklong season at City Center, opening Tuesday. The theme is embodied by ''Criss-Cross,'' a recent work by Helgi Tomasson, the company's visionary director. The two-part piece opens with a classical section set to Charles Avison's reworking of 12 Scarlatti sonatas for harpsichord, then moves on to modern classicism danced to a Handel-influenced Schoenberg concerto. ''Criss-Cross'' promises, too, to show off the San Franciscans' distinctive clarity and quicksilver dancing. The program will also include three modern ballet classics: George Balanchine's edgy ''Agon,'' Jerome Robbins's neurotic insect-ridden ''Cage'' and Harald Lander's ''Etudes,'' an irrepressible galumph through classical pedagogy. William Forsythe, one of the most influential ballet choreographers of the time, will be represented, as will Christopher Bruce, an import from modern dance, and Flemming Flindt, whose seldom-seen ''Lesson,'' a 1963 work inspired by the Ionesco play, is an eerie portrait of a homicidal ballet teacher. The beloved warhorses of 19th-century ballet will also be seen in excerpt in an opening night gala as wide-ranging as the season. JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Elizabeth Pryor, Gerrit Bradley
description: H. Elizabeth Pryor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Millard H. Pryor Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Gerrit G. Bradley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Bradley of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. William J. Hilliard performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: ART REVIEWS; A Most Appropriate Place to Celebrate the Sea
description: 'Sea Change'

title: Devils' Woes Continue as Guerin Scores Twice
description: The last thing the punchless Devils need now is for Martin Brodeur to allow soft goals.

title: Martha Hagen, Michael Black
description: Martha Anne Hagen and Michael Ian Black were married yesterday by the Rev. Edmond Nixon at the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany in New York.

title: INVESTING WITH: Gary M. Lewis; Van Kempen Emerging Growth
description: I've got a calm personality, so I don't get too excited when we go way up, and I don't get too down when we go way down,'' Gary M. Lewis, the manager of the Van Kampen Emerging Growth fund, said from his 45th-floor office in Houston.

title: Backtalk; Secret Love for Yanks Pour Out
description: Because it was for so long a love that dared not speak its name, the current outpouring of adoration for the Yankees is almost poignant. Finally, Yankee fans are feeling secure enough to come out. People who over the years sneered at the Yankees in public or at least allowed those who slobbered over the Mets, the Red Sox, the Cubs, the memory of the Brooklyn Dodgers, to prattle on about the arrogant, smug, rich, elitism of the Yankees are willing to identify themselves and flash pinstripes.

title: Schumer and D'Amato Look for an Edge
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato charged across upstate New York yesterday, mocking Representative Charles E. Schumer as ''the Phantom'' for missing votes in Congress this year. Mr. Schumer campaigned by marking the six-year anniversary of Mr. D'Amato's pledge, later abandoned, not to run again if voters rewarded him with a third term.

title: Meat On the Hoof
description: In the N.B.A., you're a piece of meat. That's it, bottom line. When it's contract time and you're negotiating, even when you're reading articles in the paper, it's always about people evaluating your talent. But what's the difference between that and 10 lawyers going for the same job at a big firm? I tried to keep it in perspective by telling myself: Well, if I'm a piece of meat, I want to be the best piece. I don't want to be hamburger.

title: A Blazing Tank, a Rescue in World War II
description: HIS tank afire after being hit by an armor-piercing German artillery shell, which killed one of the five crewmen inside, a badly wounded Arthur Slote thought his chances of survival were slim indeed as he lay on the snow-covered ground in France with machine-gun bullets whizzing around him on Jan. 9, 1945.

title: Budget With a Surplus: Late, but No Shutdown
description: President Clinton and Congress reached agreement, only 16 days late and without a Government shutdown, on a $1.7 trillion budget for fiscal 1999 that is the first since the late 1960's not to include deficit spending. The deal included an industry-backed increase in visa quotas for foreign workers with technology skills, a sharp increase in military spending, aid for farmers and new money for the International Monetary Fund, but no general tax cuts. Projects to combat global warming and farm runoff won financing; so did plans to step up logging on public lands in the West and Alaska. A bankruptcy overhaul passed by Congress but disliked by the White House was omitted from the deal.

title: Karin Eig, Steven Swain
description: Karin Eig and Steven Joseph Swain were married last evening by Cantor Theodore Aronson at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Having It: Desire Bides Its Time
description: RAISED working-class, I've often experienced pangs of hot guilt over my desires -- not the sexual ones, the retail ones. Whenever I buy something expensive and wholly unnecessary, I make a vow to do more for the struggling classes, to donate the clothes in the back of my closet to the Salvation Army and to clean my apartment thoroughly.

title: Kerry Hatton, Marc Cozzolino
description: Kerry Christine Hatton, a daughter of Deirdre Hatton of Flanders, N.J., and the late Harold K. Hatton, was married yesterday to Marc Christopher Cozzolino, a son of Joanne and Vincent Cozzolino of West Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. John T. Mulligan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Boys: The Untold Story

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARFING, JANIS
description: SCHARFING-Janis. Beloved wife of Leon ''Ruby.'' Loving mother of Sheryl and Alan. Dear sister of Lorraine. Cherished grandmother of Lance, Jennifer and Lauren. Devoted aunt to her nieces and nephews.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Monument Is Closed for Renovation
description: The Washington Monument has been closed to the public until December to erect scaffolding so that workers can inspect, repoint and clean its marble skin. At the same time, the red lights that warn aircraft away from the 555-foot obelisk will be resealed and its eight observation windows will be reglazed.

title: Ms. Petermann And Mr. Pollin
description: Kirsten Anne Petermann, the daughter of Christina Zacharia of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Fred H. Petermann of Easton, Md., was married last evening to David Brian Pollin, a son of Jacqueline Davis and Harold Pollin, both of Portland, Ore. Rabbi Emanuel Rose performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Earnings Smiles and Scowls
description: Companies reporting happy surprises in a heavy week for quarterly earnings reports included Apple Computer, back from the dead thanks to its red-hot iMac computer, as well as Chrysler, Delta Air Lines, Intel and Johnson & Johnson. Disappointers included General Motors, whose results were savaged by an eight-week strike, along with Caterpillar, Eastman Kodak, Pfizer and several brokerage firms, including Bear Stearns, Paine Webber and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: Political Feuds Rack Haiti: So Much for Its High Hopes
description: Four years ago this month, Haiti's future seemed so promising that people here were dancing in the streets. American troops had just overthrown a brutal dictatorship, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was on his way back from exile, and a procession of foreign aid donors and investors was following in his wake.

title: Using Farce to Break the Dark Spell of Fascism
description: FASCIST humor may be an oxymoron. Fascism, after all, is a serious matter. It submerges the whims and freedoms of the individual to the uniform demands of the state. It treats its authority as natural law and any opposition as mortal sin.

title: Witching Hour; Rethinking McCarthyism, if Not McCarthy
description: 'I have here in my hand a list of 205 -- a list of names that were made known to the Secretary of State as being members of the Communist party and who nevertheless are still working and shaping policy in the State Department.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINS, PIERRE ROBERT
description: WILKINS-Pierre Robert. Died on October 6, 1998 in Brooklyn, N.Y. Born Oct. 14, 1932 in St. Louis, Mo. Son of the late John J. & Roma E. (nee Abernathy) Wilkins. Brother of the late John (Jack) Wilkins, Clearwater, FL. Pierre was graduated from Missouri University School of Journalism in 1953, did his military service in Verdun, France between 1954 and 1956. Former Director of Eastern Public Relations, N.Y. office, Monsanto, St. Louis. Beloved father of Carole A. Wilkins of Montclair, NJ, Nancy E. Wilkins of Portland, OR., and Keith W. Wilkins of New York, N.Y. Renowned for his charm, eloquence, wit and humor-his joie de vivre to the end. Pierre's religion: The New York Times. Ceremony was privately held on October 9th, 1998, Fire Island, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Kingsbrooke Jewish Medical Center, Brooklyn, N.Y. Pie-air-ee, au revoir.

title: Embattled Sex Shops Find A Survival Tactic Works
description: Three months after a spate of highly publicized padlockings heralded the arrival of the Giuliani administration's crackdown on New York City's sex shops, a string of legal victories by adult business owners has turned what looked like a speedy rout into a war of attrition.

title: October 11-17; New Insulation for Airlines
description: First it was airliner seats, then carpeting and other cabin components. Now the Federal Aviation Administration says it's airplane insulation that burns too easily and should be changed. The agency said it would devise a new flammability test within six months and then require new and old planes to meet it, although it asked airlines to start work immediately. But they are wary of spending money to meet a standard that hasn't been written yet. MATTHEW L. WALD

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: Let me see if I have this right. George Steinbrenner, a military school brat who has never held a real job, inherited a business from his daddy and proceeded to manage it into bankruptcy. Along the way, he received two major suspensions from the commissioner of baseball. This guy claims to have a low tolerance for failure and cannot abide those who are unable to meet his high standards! You do not have to be a Red Sox fan to see the irony in that situation.

title: Tea Is Sold Once Again At Teatown
description: AS a promotion, it seems a natural: Teatown Tea. At least that is what Dolores Jean (D. J.) Chain thought when she came up with the idea of selling tea to benefit the Teatown Lake Reservation, a 730-acre nonprofit nature preserve here. Ms. Chain, a Teatown trustee, was looking for new fund-raising possibilities when it hit her: sell the substance that gave the place its name.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's unprecedented in my experience how unsettled the national environment is two weeks from a national election. This thing could tip either way.''

title: Charge!
description: THE LION'S PRIDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: DRAKE-Joseph William, 76, died October 15, 1998 at his home in Greenwich, CT. Father of Barbara Drake Glass of Old Greenwich, CT., J. William Drake of Riverside, CT., Geoffrey J. Drake of Aptos, CA., and Thomas P. Drake of Wayne, PA. Also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral Mass Monday, Oct. 19th at 11AM in St. Michael the Archangel on North St. in Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Greenwich World Hunger Assoc., PO Box 7444, Greenwich, CT 06836.

title: Hospital Gowns Get a Life
description: For charity, clothing designers have created cars, dinner plates, even birdhouses. On Oct. 24, in a benefit fashion show for the Hackensack (N.J.) University Medical Center, solutions to the intractable problem of how to look good in a hospital gown will be offered by Jill Stuart, Nicole Miller, Cynthia Rowley, Kevin Hall for Halston and an Anne Klein team.

title: Beth Brodsky and Amir Shaviv
description: Dr. Beth Sharon Brodsky and Amir Shaviv are to be married today by Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon at the Columbia University Faculty House in New York.

title: The Nation: A Poll-Watcher's Guide; Stalking the Elusive Likely Voter
description: WITH midterm elections just around the corner and the impeachment inquiry of President Clinton set to start shortly afterward, public opinion polls are more numerous, more important and possibly more confusing than usual.

title: A Commotion in the Brain
description: MY YEAR OFF

title: October 11-17; American Spy Arrested
description: A 46-year-old retired enlisted man who had worked in both Army intelligence and at the super-secret National Security Agency was arrested by the F.B.I. on charges that he spied for Moscow during the last days of the Soviet Union.

title: Backtalk; So Much to Sell, Except the Game Itself
description: The gleaming NBA Store opened a month ago on Fifth Avenue and 52d Street with little fanfare and no advertising but with logos on everything from bibs and $210 cashmere sweaters to $8,000 Waterford vases and $25,000 Breitling watches.

title: Still Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Hopes In Baghdad For Ending U.N. Embargo
description: With Washington sapped by scandal and the United Nations arms inspectors weakened by infighting, Iraqi officials are expressing confidence that they are closer than ever to having some sanctions against their country eased and that they can avert a military strike even if they stonewall against inspections.

title: Dancing Away the Havana Blues
description: A tropical rain cleanses the crumbling structures of old Havana as a motley group of dancers repairs to an underground sanctuary. Carrying donated costumes and worn audiotapes, they filter into an empty cabaret and begin to structure the afternoon lineup. A powerhouse modern dancer will present a new solo, a group of grade-school children will show a reconfigured mambo, a virtuosic teen-ager will accept a choreography prize and an ecstatic deejay wields a bootleg copy of last year's London techno hit. Two North American dancers will perform contemporary solos, making for truly exotic entertainment. Welcome to an Afternoon of Dance at the Cafe Cantante, where for a few hours the daily struggle is forgotten with the distinctly Cuban antidote to black-market blues: dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDMANN, ANDREE
description: FREUDMANN-Andree. On October 15, 1998. Beloved wife of Marcel, adored mother of Gladys Wilson, Axel Freudmann and Nora Warshauer. Dearest mother-inlaw of Lee Wilson, Lauren Freudmann and Bruce Warshauer. Adoring grandmother of Dana, Emily, Lizy, Laura and Sammy. Spirited, funloving and deeply loved, she will be profoundly missed. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Look Back at a Legislative Term
description: Following is some of the major legislation that the 105th Congress approved or failed to approve.

title: On the Kibbutz, Dirty Hands at Last
description: It is with a sense of sadness that I read Ze'ev Chafets's article -- sadness for the thousands of volunteers who will miss out on an experience that is life-changing (Sept. 27). In 1980, I had the opportunity to live on Kibbutz Yifat, which is situated on the main road between Haifa and Afula. I lived with other volunteers, Jewish and non-Jewish, from the States, England, Australia and Germany. For a kid from the suburbs, it was an eye-opening experience. I worked closely with Israelis, picking grapefruits, raising chickens, cooking and working in the factory. I really got to understand the Israeli pioneering spirit. I heard stories about the birth of a nation.

title: Producer, Host, Prince And Basic Working Guy
description: ''ONE is caught in a horrendous Catch-22 situation,'' is the way Prince Edward, the youngest of Queen Elizabeth's three sons, once described the overwrought burst of attention that greeted him here in 1993 when he announced that in a distinctly unroyal move he was starting his own film production company, Ardent Productions.

title: Goodbye Chatter, Hello N.J. Diary
description: Have you heard an amusing story lately? Overheard a strange or humorous conversation? Beginning Nov. 1, the New Jersey section will feature a new column, New Jersey Diary, that will help define who New Jerseyans are, how they talk and what they talk about, what they think and what they like. (The diary will replace the Chatter column.)

title: Habitats / Broome Street Near the Bowery; Stretching the Loft Scene Onto Streets Called BoHo
description: JAN SASSON'S divorce was so nasty and so prolonged that when it was finally over, he was, in a sense, homeless -- in an affluent sort of way. He had an apartment, after the property was divided up, but it was rented out and he needed the income.

title: Home Delivery, Off the Internet
description: New Yorkers are used to picking up the phone and having whatever they fancy wrapped up and hot-footed to their doorstep. Now they need just pick up their fingers with the debut last month of the Homedelivery Web site.

title: Clinton Returns to Mideast Summit in Maryland
description: Trying to force the pace of a Middle East agreement, President Clinton returned to Maryland's Eastern Shore today, meeting in turns with the Palestinian and Israeli delegations sequestered here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLEY, ROBERT
description: HARLEY-Robert Livingston, age 93. Beloved brother of Ruth and his twin sister Jeannette Huber. Loving uncle of Frank H. Huber. He attended Columbia University, was a member of Alpha Chi Rho and graduated from New York University. He was associated with The Old Print Shop, in Manhattan, for over 50 years. Private graveside services only.

title: Investor, Can You Spare a Dime? Fund Managers Take Pay Cuts
description: Has your actively managed stock mutual fund lagged behind its benchmark? This may make you feel better: Fund managers are starting to feel the pinch as they fail to keep pace with market indexes.

title: By Phone, and on TV, She Feels Your Vibes
description: THE phones start ringing even before Grace Grella goes on the air.

title: Pamela Weiers, Michael Medvecky
description: Pamela Sue Weiers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald M. Weiers of Indiana, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael John Medvecky, the son of Joan Medvecky of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Michael N. Medvecky. The Rev. John T. Mulligan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan.

title: Amy Beim, J. W. Sarbinowski
description: Amy Marie Beim, the daughter of Elizabeth and David Beim of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Joseph W. Sarbinowski, the son of Florence and Michael Sarbinowski of Nokomis, Fla. The Rev. Josephine Cameron performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Daniel G. O'Hare, a Roman Catholic Priest, took part in the service.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Will a Land-Leasing Plan Fly for Gyrodyne?
description: THE conference room walls at the headquarters of the Gyrodyne Company of America, in Building 7 of the Flowerfield business campus here, are decorated with illustrations and photographs of several generations of helicopters that the company designed and manufactured since its founding in 1946.

title: Children's Books; Gimme Rewrite
description: They're the last words any writer wants to hear: ''May I make a suggestion?'' But you'll hear them a lot if you want to write, because revision is part of the game, as Benjamin Franklin knew. The Hatmaker's Sign: A Story by Benjamin Franklin (Orchard, $15.95; ages 5 to 9) is a true tale of writerly frustration, written by Candace Fleming and illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. As the story-within-a-story begins, it's July 1776, and Thomas Jefferson is writhing in pain as the Continental Congress debates changes (he calls them ''mutilations'') in his draft of the Declaration of Independence, which he believes to be perfect as it is. The delegates noisily argue over every treasured syllable, striking out, adding, inserting, toning down, beefing up, rewording, rephrasing and reordering. On the sidelines, meanwhile, the distraught Jefferson is consoled by his friend Ben Franklin. ''Tom,'' he says, ''this puts me in mind of a story.'' The story he tells (one that Jefferson later recalled in his memoirs) is about a Boston hatmaker who's on his way to the sign shop with a plan for a new sign. On his parchment are the words ''John Thompson, Hatmaker. Fashionable Hats Sold Inside for Ready Money,'' and below them a drawing of a hat. Along the way, he meets a few people who have suggestions to offer. Each one seems to have a good idea: The hatmaker's name is irrelevant, isn't it? And why say ''inside''? Where else would the hats be sold? One by one and two by two, the carefully chosen words are struck out, and finally even the picture of the hat disappears (after all, there are hats in the shop window, aren't there?). By the time he arrives at the sign shop, his parchment is empty. But the sign maker has an idea too. ''May I make a suggestion?'' he says. ''How about: 'John Thompson, Hatmaker. Fashionable Hats Sold Inside for Ready Money.' '' Under them, he'll draw a hat. ''It's perfect!'' says the hatmaker. Fleming's retelling captures the humor of Franklin's tale and adds charming period detail, while Parker's richly colored ink-and-watercolor paintings are the perfect accompaniment. I wouldn't change a thing. Patricia T. O'Conner

title: Shades of Horowitz, Yes, but an Individual Still in the Making
description: WHEN you next go hiking in the hills outside Madrid, you might come across a stocky young man with thick, wavy hair, very Russian-looking, very polite, and never know that inside his head he was considering how to phrase and shade the melody in a piece by Schumann; how to render the shape of a Schubert sonata, or how to bestow counterpoints on something by Glinka to create a fantastical variation.

title: The Surrogate Court Race: Hot Politicking, Cool Civility
description: It is a position to which few voters devote much attention. But in a borough marked by several competitive races this fall, the campaign for surrogate on Staten Island has become what may be the hottest contest.

title: Pssst. . .We Have No Problems At This Hedge Fund. Really.
description: Hedge funds, those notoriously secretive beasts, are being flushed out into the open. Fearful of another Long-Term Capital Management, investors are starting to insist that the tight-lipped managers of these private partnerships do more talking.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Call It B'Agostino

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTOLENGHI, PAOLO, M.D.
description: OTTOLENGHI-Paolo, M.D. February 9, 1914-October 11, 1998. Rest in Peace. Anne and Donna Ottolenghi

title: Kelly Macaluso, Richard Coles
description: Kelly Burns Macaluso, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Macaluso of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard A. C. Coles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Coles of Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Christine Petersen, Robert Wells
description: Christine Elaine Petersen and Robert Craig Wells were married yesterday by the Rev. Calvin Genzel, a Congregational minister, at the Old South Church in Boston.

title: The Player; The Woman Can Swing
description: Among the events on the P.G.A. tour, the pro golf circuit for men, are tournaments named for, and sponsored by, Mercedes, Buick, Nissan and Honda, AT&T, Sprint, Bell South and M.C.I. By contrast, the L.P.G.A., or women's, tour includes events named for, and sponsored by, Weetabix, Nabisco, Welch's and Sara Lee, Giant Eagle, Safeway, ShopRite and Kroger -- testament to the fact that women's golf hasn't left the kitchen, unless it's to go to the grocery store. And the disparities don't stop there. David Duval, the P.G.A.'s leading money winner this year, has earned more than $2 million; Annika Sorenstam, at the top of the women's money list, has won less than half that. Nike and Titleist pay Tiger Woods some $60 million for endorsing their products; last year, Nike paid Kelli Kuehne, a promising debutante, a mere $1.5 million, a record at the time. Woods, Greg Norman and Jack Nicklaus are among the many P.G.A. players who have attained popular stardom, and names like Arnold Palmer and Ben Hogan have become household words; meanwhile, Sorenstam, Karrie Webb and even Nancy Lopez rack up their victories in relative obscurity.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: In Combining Apartments, 1 + 1 = 2+
description: SHORT of space and eager to expand, apartment-dwellers these days are viewing adjoining apartments the way Caesar might have regarded Gaul: territory that with a little effort might be pleasingly annexed.

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; Admiration, Not Pity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEVINS, ANNE
description: BLEVINS-Anne. We are saddened by the death of our longtime colleague Anne Blevins on October 5, 1998. Anne was first a nurse, then a microbiologist and finally, a hospital epidemiologist in a long and distinguished career at New York University, Columbia University, and the last 44 years at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was an active member and an awardee of the American Society of Microbiology and its New York City branch and a Fellow of the New York Academy of Sciences and the American Board of Microbiology. She was a life member of the American Public Health Association and the Soroptimist International Club of New York. She will be remembered by scores of nurses, microbiologists, epidemiologists, and the residents in medicine, surgery and pediatrics whom she helped train. Her dedication to patient care, education and research was an example for us all. Ms. Blevins is survived by cousins, Jacelyn Perrigo of Wisconsin, and DeeJay Weger and Todd Negel of New York. A memorial mass is scheduled for Thursday, October 22, 1998 at 3 P.M. to be held at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121 Street. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Morningside Garden Retirement, 1 La Salle Street, New York, N.Y. 10027 or a charity of your choice. Dr. George Bosl, Chairman, Department of Medicine Dr. Donald Armstrong, Chief, Infectious Disease Service Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: October 11-17; Plan to Save the Everglades
description: The Army Corps of Engineers unveiled a vast plan to fix the natural plumbing of southern Florida, restoring a more natural flow of fresh water through the imperiled Everglades.

title: Hyde Quickly Feels the Harsh Heat of the Limelight
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Republican presiding over House impeachment proceedings, is discovering the price of fame: Every word he speaks counts.

title: He Works Really Hard on Tuesdays
description: Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, got off some zingers this month about the work habits of Bernard Mendik, the real-estate mogul whose company Vornado acquired last year. In a speech to 500 developers, investment bankers, brokers and corporate executives, Mr. Roth raised eyebrows by declaring that Mr. Mendik, then Vornado's co-chairman, had given him a lengthy vacation schedule and informed him he leaves for the Hamptons on Wednesday afternoons in the summer and returns the following Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, VIRGINIA
description: BLACK-Virginia Bergen. Of New York City and Shelter Island, New York. On September 23, 1998. Daughter of the late Douglas McCrae Black and Maude Bergen Black. Direct descendant of Sarah Rapalje, the first child of European parents born in New Amsterdam. She was a graduate of The Nightingale Bamford School, New York, New York and St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York and was a member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, associate member of the Amateur Comedy Club of New York and a member of the former St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Auxiliary. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Red Cross-Shelter Island Chapter, P.O. Box 830, Shelter Island, New York, 11964; the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church, Shelter Island, New York 11964 or St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York 13617, would be appreciated. Memorial service in the Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, NY at 11:00 a.m., on Friday, October 23, 1998.

title: Tortoise Heads Into Queens
description: AFTER more than 25 years of construction, will the 63d Street subway line be completed on schedule in 2001? New Yorkers can judge for themselves on Wednesday when they tour the construction site (shown here looking east toward Northern Boulevard from 29th Street) and view a slide presentation on the project's history, titled ''2001: A Subway Odyssey.'' The presentation and tour, presented by the 92d Street Y, will be led by Richard Mitchell, a technical director for New York City Transit.

title: Going Native
description: THE POISONWOOD BIBLE

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; Parallel Tracks
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday in the Diary column of the Personal Business page about extensions that allow taxpayers to file Federal income tax returns in October referred incorrectly to the interest consequences. Unpaid balances accrue interest effective with the April deadline at rates adjusted quarterly; they are not interest-free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MARJORIE (NEE SPIER)
description: FREEMAN-Marjorie (nee Spier). Age 77, died October 15, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Charles for 52 years. Loving mother of David, James (Judith), & Jean (Morton) Hertz. Dear sister of Daniel and the late Amy Pryor. Proud grandmother of Beth Freeman. Services today 10 A.M., at Temple Beth Sholom, 171-39 Northern Blvd. (corner 172nd Street).

title: Lives; A Sticky Wicket
description: I bought my first newspaper when I was 6, in Bombay. It was a provincial ''afternooner,'' sold to me by a hawker no older than I was. His sooty face pressed against our car window, he bawled these words as we waited at a red light: ''Six sixes in one over, Sobers hits six sixes in one over.'' He waved the paper avidly, flaunting the picture of Gary Sobers -- a man from Barbados, the greatest player in cricket's history -- swinging his bat as lustily as a West Indian cane-cutter might swing a cutlass.

title: Local and County Ballot Proposals
description: VOTERS in New Rochelle will be asked on Election Day whether to replace the existing city manager form of government with a strong mayor system.

title: Celebrating a Dream Come True; Salute to Sammy Sosa, Dominican and American Hero
description: Elena Tejada, a retired seamstress who lives in Washington Heights, prefers quiet weekends at home. But yesterday, she got her 5-year-old grandson up early and headed to City Hall.

title: ECHOES OF SIN CITY
description: FROM times of antiquity, travel has been associated with trade and commerce. Now it's become a business in its own right -- the tourist industry -- and as cities have evolved into products, certain destinations have a short shelf life. Eventually they pass their ''sell by'' date and people begin to object: ''But nobody goes there anymore.''

title: Bias Law Would Amount to Piece of Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Exhibition Displays A Fascination for Bridges
description: PHOTOGRAPHS of bridges, paintings, drawings, prints and models of bridges -- all of them at the Hudson River Museum here. Called ''Getting From Here to There,'' this documentary begins with High Bridge, a 150-year-old relic fenced off from the public, which used to carry water from the Croton Reservoir to Manhattan.

title: Greater Good, and Whitman, Are Served by Early Primary
description: For more than 20 years, New Jersey's presidential primary has been held so late in the political season that the state has been relegated to the thankless status of some wealthy out-of-town uncle.

title: Words, Words, Words, Their Heady Power
description: THE most important component of a relationship, any relationship, is trust. In just one season, the new artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Doug Hughes, has somehow imparted and invited a mutuality of trust. He has made clear a convincing respect for the vitality and the viability of a world-class repertory and for the capacity of the audience to get it, without condescension, without concessions to self-conscious trends, only an embracing regard for the power of theater.

title: Finally, for Martinez, His October Moment
description: Mark Langston's 2-2 pitch sliced across the middle of the plate at the knees and Tino Martinez froze. It looked like a strike, but Martinez did not swing. With the bases loaded and the score tied, 5-5, in the seventh inning, it was a dangerous decision.

title: Sarah Veale, Jerome Taylor
description: Sarah Ellen Veale and Jerome Cogburn Taylor were married yesterday in Exeter, N.H. The Rev. Robert H. Thompson, the minister of the church at Phillips Exeter Academy, performed the ceremony there.

title: His Father Mending: Pettitte Comes Back
description: Andy Pettitte returned to the Yankees yesterday after his father, Tom, underwent what doctors described as successful double-bypass heart surgery Thursday. Pettitte said that he felt comfortable rejoining the team for Game 1 of the World Series once his father was moved from intensive care to a regular room at St. Luke's Hospital in Houston.

title: Is This Guy A Threat to The Rules, Or the Fish?
description: IT evokes images of freedom and self-reliance, of putting dinner on the table in one of the most elementary ways known to humans. But in late-20th-century America, fishing, whether for a living or for sport, is an intensely regulated activity.

title: Pay Was Up in 'Gilded' Year For University Leaders
description: University presidents still do not come close to basketball players or venture capitalists in earnings, but a growing number have compensation packages in the half-million-dollar range once thought of as the preserve of corporate executives.

title: Shopping List Says Diapers; Saving List Says Cap and Gown
description: Conventional wisdom holds that boomers are not doing enough to save for their children's college costs. A recent poll by Louis Harris & Associates shows at least some parents bucking that tide.

title: The State in Celluloid
description: What are your favorite movies made or set in New Jersey?

title: Rangers Blow a 2-Goal Lead but Earn a Point
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins may be bankrupt, but you've got to give them a little credit. They are undefeated in three games, the latest being a 3-3 tie with the Rangers tonight in the Igloo.

title: A Blizzard in Florida
description: Employees can come up with the darnedest excuses for returning to work a day or two late from vacations and long weekends: A car breakdown. An ill great-aunt. Believable? Maybe. But what about that mysterious allergy to the pineapple at Waikiki? What particularly imaginative tales have you heard -- or told? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: New Worlds an Ocean Apart, Seen Side by Side
description: THE exhibition begins with a group of elegantly dressed settlers at the base of Niagara Falls in an 1823 painting by Alvan Fisher, and with a group of English explorers and their aborigine guides clawing to the top of Wentworth Falls in New South Wales in an 1830 canvas by Augustus Earle. It ends with five desperate cowboys in Frederic Remington's 1903 ''Fight for the Water Hole,'' and with an equally desperate Australian cowboy trying to brake a sheep stampede in Tom Roberts's 1891 ''A Break Away!'' In between the open and the close lies a compelling illustration of how Americans and Australians viewed, construed and subdued their lands.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: Anthony J. Van Patten's letter (Sept. 27) suggests that, based on his experience, Ken Starr's draft deferment (for psoriasis) seems like funny business and should be investigated (Michael Winerip, Sept. 6). I've had psoriasis for 68 years and I'd like an investigation. Not of Starr's deferment record, but to find out how Van Patten got into the service. In 1942, I tried to enlist in the Army Air Corps. Their doctor told me that I was rejected because the Army didn't need people like me making service-connected insurance claims and, to add insult to injury, because my appearance might not be good for the morale of others.

title: October 11-17; Uniting Faith and Reason
description: In an encyclical marking his 20th anniversary as Pope, John Paul II made a spirited defense of clear, rational thought, criticizing those who

title: A Grand River Widens Its Circle of Friends
description: THE 410-mile Connecticut River was recently designated an American Heritage River under a Clinton Administration initiative. The designation should give a boost to as many as 29 projects in natural resource and environmental protection as well as in economic revitalization, historic and cultural preservation.

title: Just Saying 'No' Is Not Enough
description: THE FIX

title: The Network; The Straw That Stirs the Shtick
description: It's two hours before show time in the newsroom at ESPN's Bristol, Conn., headquarters, but preparations for the 6:30 P.M. edition of ''SportsCenter'' have accelerated into the broadcast version of the two-minute drill. Production assistants scurry about monitoring the late August afternoon's baseball games, checking on the latest developments in the home-run quest of Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa. Reporters and anchors bang out the copy they'll soon read on the air. Producers work the phones and keep tabs on the news coming over the wire: which basketball star missed his court hearing, which gridiron hero finally ended his holdout, which greedy owner is packing up his team for a sweetheart deal in northern Virginia/North Carolina/New Jersey. Meanwhile, apparently oblivious to the frenzy surrounding them, the ''SportsCenter'' anchors Kenny Mayne and Steve Levy are battling Alexi Lalas and Tab Ramos, two U.S. World Cup soccer players, in a friendly game of Foosball.

title: Sailor Looks for Home-Water Advantage in Bermuda
description: Having grown up in Bermuda, Paula Lewin has learned the idiosyncrasies of wind along her island-nation's waterfront sailing arena at Hamilton Harbor. With buildings on one side, and a hill on the other, the breeze gets fluky. But when it comes to yacht racing, the irregularity can pay off in a favorable lift that bodes well for the sailor smart enough to see it coming.

title: Poetic Justice
description: The several, almost charming intrusions of ''Leaves of Grass'' into the Starr Report mark the second time that Whitman's book has figured in a Washington scandal, which is rather a lot for a book of poetry. You might have thought that Kenneth Starr, having spent his $40 million in research, would point to the earlier time, if only to cite a precedent and lend majesty to his enterprise. But on the topic of ''Leaves of Grass'' and scandalous Federal precedents, the Starr Report says not a word. The report merely records that President Clinton, in a romantic mood, gave a copy of the book to Monica Lewinsky, and that Lewinsky was keenly appreciative -- criminal details, in Starr's judgment, that help to demonstrate why the President ought to be removed from office.

title: Themed Old West Spot in Mamaroneck
description: NOTHING is delicate about this huge Mamaroneck hangout, which seems more like a theme park than a proper restaurant. The look is Western reimagined for Westchester -- an over-the-top stage set for an old oater, in which cowboys were quick on the draw and quicker to prove it. Everything here -- from the restaurant's name to the decor to the menus to the food itself -- keeps tongue decidedly in cheek. It is hokey; it is hogwash, and we loved it.

title: The Nation; Tailoring the S.&L. Crisis To Save Japan's Banks
description: AGOOD portion of the financial system was buried under a mountain of bad debts that was growing bigger with each passing day. Yet politicians, pressed by powerful interests and afraid of committing huge sums of taxpayer money to the problem, were dithering about how to respond. Other nations looked on with concern and disdain.

title: Mourning 3 'Cherubs' Killed by Ambulance
description: There were silent tears when friends rose to read homespun recollections of the sweetness and merriment of three children who had died. There were sniffles and whispered prayers when the minister exhorted the mourners to have faith in God.

title: Rumors and Secrecy Cloud Issue: Is Qaddafi O.K.?
description: If every rumor swirling around this seaport capital is true, someone tries to assassinate the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi -- oh, about every couple of months.

title: Tribes to Revive Language
description: IN 1908, the Mohegan elder Fidelia Fielding -- the last speaker of the Eastern Algonquin language spoken by the Pequots as well as the Mohegans -- died. Ninety years latter leaders of both the Mohegan and Mashantucket Pequot tribes say reviving their dead language is their most important long-term cultural goal.

title: 47 Are Arrested in Drug Raids at Sports Bars on Staten Island
description: Three firefighters and a city sanitation worker were among 47 people arrested yesterday during early morning narcotics raids at a cluster of sports bars on Staten Island, the police said. All four men face drug possession charges, the authorities said.

title: Glorifying Actors
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Says A Candidate Was Insulting
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani denounced the Democratic candidate for New York attorney general yesterday for what he called an ethnically insulting campaign incident. The candidate, Eliot L. Spitzer, disputed the Mayor's interpretation, adding that he abhorred prejudice and was sorry if the Mayor had been hurt.

title: In Lots Of Hostas, A Success
description: RANSOM LYDELL guessed right 17 years ago when he thought there would be a booming market for the lilylike perennials called hostas. But spotting an opportunity is one thing and exploiting it is another, as millions of failed entrepreneurs have discovered. Today, Mr. Lydell, 59, runs one of the most successful hosta businesses in the country, mostly because he has figured out how to differentiate himself from his rivals in flower-selling.

title: Pirro Under Microscope
description: Blair Horner, legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonpartisan government watchdog group, wants to know why the campaign of District Attorney Jeanine Pirro paid almost $12,000 to Weil, Goteshal & Manges, a Manhattan law firm, but the District Attorney will not say what legal issue the firm was involved in.

title: Library Contract Voided, And Board Is Faulted
description: A contract with a private consulting firm to manage the public library was voided Friday by a judge who declared that the library's board of trustees had failed to take proper steps in awarding the contract.

title: October 11-17; Charges in Olympic Bombing
description: Two years after a pipe bomb exploded at Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta, Federal authorities charged Eric Robert Rudolph with the attack, which killed one woman and injured hundreds. Mr. Rudolph, already wanted for his role in a fatal January bombing at an abortion clinic in Birmingham, Ala., was also accused of two other Atlanta bombings in 1996.

title: Double Happiness Reinterpreted
description: ''Double Happiness,'' the Chinese character representing harmony between bride and bridegroom, has traditionally appeared on the walls of Cantonese banquet halls on the Bowery. Now the symbol has become popular among hip entrepreneurs of all ethnicities -- and it's gaining new meanings in the translation.

title: The (17,106) Pipes Called Him
description: HALF of the organ at Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove, Calif. with its 17,016 pipes, is a transplant from the East Coast. It was originally built for Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, and brought here in 1981.

title: A Role for Theater In Fighting Terror
description: Despite last year's attacks by Islamic militants outside the Egyptian Museum and at Luxor, which decimated Egypt's lucrative tourist trade, the goverment has continued, as it has every year for the last decade, to welcome a wide variety of challenging theatrical performances at its Cairo International Festival for Experimental Theater. In fact, it could be said that the government is fighting the militants with theater.

title: Taiwan's Old Soldiers, Forsaken in New York
description: They have been together for five bitter decades, and they will stay together, it seems, for the foreseeable future.

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; Slogans Won't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; My Honorable Opponent, the Ax Murderer...
description: Back in 1828, when President John Quincy Adams was running for re-election, supporters of Andrew Jackson felt compelled to find some way to undermine the incumbent's reputation as a terrific diplomat. They settled on spreading a story that Adams, who had served as Ambassador to Russia, had gotten on the czar's good side by offering up his children's nanny as a royal mistress. It was not a very convincing story -- anyone who looks at Adams's portrait will instantly perceive that this was no good-time Charlie. But the President was called ''the Pimp of the Coalition'' throughout the campaign, and when Jackson won, he made the editor who invented the slander part of his kitchen cabinet.

title: New England Tries to Adapt to Sound of Skateboards
description: Thousands of tourists go every year to the Trinity Church in Copley Square for its renowned choir, Tiffany stained-glass windows and 120-year-old spires.

title: As Elections Near, Both Parties Reassess Prospects
description: Just over two weeks from Election Day, Republicans are retreating from their hope that the White House scandal will drive huge gains for their party, while some newly confident Democrats are daring to predict that they will even pick up Congressional seats this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFACH, ROSE
description: ZWEIFACH-Rose. On October 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, adored mother of Rita Drusin and Ellen Zweifach. Sister of Ann, Bertha and the late Bernard Jassen. Mother-in-law of Hy Drusin; grandmother of Joanna and Greg. Services today Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 11:30 AM. Shiva at Drusin residence beginning tonight.

title: Taking Precautions With Garage Doors
description: OVERHEAD garage doors have more components than any other door in the house, and periodic maintenance is necessary to keep them functioning smoothly and to eliminate potential problems.

title: Pronouncing 'Porshe' Correctly
description: When Chrysler and Daimler-Benz merge next month, the auto giant's official language will be English. But Chrysler's president, Thomas T. Stallkamp, is struggling to learn German anyway. So far, he jokes, he has learned to count to 12. Maybe that is because his wife didn't let him listen to German-language tapes on a drive last weekend and banished him to their den. ''Talk to me in about six months -- I can count to maybe 30 by then,'' he quipped. Why all this effort? ''I'd like to know how to go to the bathroom in Germany without embarrassing myself.'' KEITH BRADSHER

title: Ms. Cogswell, Mr. Hastings
description: Sarah Hamlin Cogswell was married yesterday to Matthew Brian Hastings at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Richard I. Belser performed the ceremony.

title: A Nobel for Peace-in-Progress
description: John Hume, a moderate Catholic politician from Northern Ireland, has been working for peace there for three decades. David Trimble, the pro-British Protestant who is now First Minister of Northern Ireland, is a more recent convert. Together they helped mold the Good Friday Agreement that has brought the beginning of reconciliation to Northern Ireland, and together they were justly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday. But peace is by no means assured, and Mr. Trimble is right to hope the prize is not premature.

title: A Billion, A Trillion, Whatever
description: THE concept of a trillion has shifted in recent weeks from a fuzzy, imprecise and somewhat abstract notion into a hard-edged number like, say, 47 or 254 or 7,453.

title: The Cuisine Challenges the Hot Spots
description: CAN this be Oakdale? The dishes coming out of the kitchen at the Oakdale House resemble the towering creations found at trendy Manhattan restaurants and Hamptons hot spots. Paper-thin fans of fried potato slices, long, curved spears of fried plantain; skewers of fresh rosemary and clumps of frizzled sweet potato threads all point to serious efforts by the chef. The food here is especially noteworthy when compared to the fare at nearby fish houses, casual cafes and pubs.

title: Greyhound Is Adding More Buses With Lifts
description: Greyhound Lines has announced a plan that it says a year from now will allow the disabled to catch a lift-equipped bus at any of its 4,000 stops nationwide, provided the traveler calls 48 hours ahead. To do this, it will raise to 80, from 26, the number of lift-equipped buses in its fleet of 2,100.

title: Lightning Strikes Late And Lifts Garden City
description: Long Island

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday in the quarterly Mutual Funds Report, part 2 of this section, about the performance of funds in the third quarter referred incompletely to the Janus Twenty fund, a top performer the last 12 months. While Morningstar Inc. lists it as a diversified stock fund, the Securities and Exchange Commission classifies it as nondiversified.

title: When the Son Becomes the Parent
description: THE case is complicated, common but not particularly interesting as a case: female, six weeks shy of her 90th birthday, a diabetic with osteoarthritis, high blood pressure, hiatal hernia, thyroid imbalance, congestive heart failure and carpal tunnel syndrome, for which she has been operated on twice.

title: Golden Years 2: Is Glam's Return Real or Fantasy?
description: GABE DOPPELT was scrambling. As VH-1's creative director of fashion, Ms. Doppelt is a producer of the cable music channel's annual Fashion Awards, and each year she commissions designers to create outfits around a rock-related theme for the show's opening. But she admits, ''Every year I look for the appropriate collision of fashion and music, and I never really find it.''

title: It Ain't Over Till Berra Calls
description: Joe Torre received a call yesterday from Yogi Berra, the Hall of Fame catcher and former Yankees manager who has insisted he will not appear at Yankee Stadium because of his distaste for George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/ 1999 Honda Odyssey; The New Life of the Minivan Party
description: CHRYSLER threw a party here recently to mark the 15th anniversary of the minivan -- a vehicle it invented.

title: Board Dedicates Rooms
description: The County Board of Legislators had dedicated three of its rooms in the County Office Building in White Plains to former lawmakers. Last week, the 17-member Board named its library in honor of Herman S. Geist, the first chairman of the Board, who served for four years beginning in 1970. Mr. Geist, a Republican originally from Mount Vernon, is a lawyer and certified public accountant. He left the board at the end of his second term in 1973, but had served on the Board of Supervisors from 1966 to 1970, when it became the Board of Legislators.

title: New Mutual Series Lineup Imparting Less Mutuality
description: THE roster of value players at Franklin Mutual Advisers will remain the same after the chief executive officer, Michael F. Price, gives up his management duties next month, but they will be getting new positions. Specifically, the senior analysts who have long executed the Mutual Series team-based investing have been named as managers and co-managers of the individual funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DONALD
description: LEWIS-Donald. Of Sarasota, FL, formerly of New Rochelle and Somers, NY. On October 15. Beloved husband of Gloria. Cherished father of Linda Grigg, Cathy Dreilinger and James Lewis. Adored grandfather of Danielle, Lindsay and Chris. Admired father-in-law of David Dreilinger and Alan Grigg. Services October 18, 10 AM, at Toale Brothers, Sarasota, FL.

title: A New Threat in Blood Doping
description: Just as researchers are closing in on a method to detect abuse of the artificial hormone EPO among athletes, a dangerous new drug, which is also believed to substantially increase endurance, has aroused the active concern of the International Olympic Committee. According to Dr. Laurent Rivier, the head of the I.O.C.-accredited laboratory in Lausanne, Switzerland, the lab is prepared to test blood samples for the presence of perfluorocarbon metabolites, or PFC.

title: IN MY... CARD HOLDER: John S. Reed
description: He is one of the financial world's most powerful men, yet he doesn't carry a wallet. ''Really, I never have,'' said John S. Reed, co-chairman of Citigroup, the largest financial company in the world.

title: The World; Israeli Business Flies Like a Dove
