description: A FEW hours before boarding the plane that would take him to Washington for the peace talks that started last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stood on a stage here and handed out etched glass trophies to 53 foreign businessmen whose companies had each sunk $50 million or more into the Israeli economy.

title: Arab-Israel Talks: Wary Dance on a Narrow Ledge
description: The branches of the Wye River that embrace the sprawling conference center where high-powered Israeli, Palestinian and American delegations are cooped up for the weekend define their challenge in elemental terms -- either figure out a way across now, or tumble into muddy waters in six months' time.

title: Stewart's Primary Lesson Is to Teach Ashby to Think
description: The looming Dave Stewart has been like a hypnotic audiotape for Padres pitcher Andy Ashby, providing a constant flow of information that eventually seeped in during the season.

title: Naval Gazing
description: THE HUNDRED DAYS

title: In America; A Special Senator
description: Quietly in this season of scandal the Clinton Administration has managed a significant advance in the most unlikely of areas: low-income housing.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Freeport officials' testing of a Toyota electric vehicle misstated the number of New York Power Authority fleet customers involved. It is 18, not 130. The article also misstated the extent to which the vehicle is being tested. The Toyotas are being tested at New York Power Authority plants and offices around the state, not just by Freeport and New York City.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SURVEYOR By G. W. Hawkes. MacMurray & Beck, $20.

title: Rochester Wins Title
description: Darren Tilley scored all three goals last night to lead the Rochester Rhinos to a 3-1 victory over the Minnesota Thunder in the A-League soccer championship in Rochester.

title: Joyce Mermini, J. J. McCarren 4th
description: Joyce Marie Mermini and James Joseph McCarren 4th were married yesterday by the Rev. Orion Davis at St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELMONT, BEVERLY (NEE SIMP,
description: BELMONT-Beverly (nee Simp- son). On October 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Ronald. Loving mother of Ron, Jr., Lynne Aversa and Matthew. Adoring grandmother of Ron, Drew, John and Matthew. Dear sister of Matthew and John. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 7-9 PM, and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at Epiphany Church, 2nd Ave. at 22 St., Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Florida Rider Wins Jumpoff
description: Schuyler Riley of Wellington, Fla., and her mount, Ilian, cashed in on the experience they received last summer riding for the developing riders squad of the United States Equestrian Team when they won a seven-horse jumpoff to capture the top prize in the $50,000 Budweiser Grand Prix de Penn National World Cup qualifying event in Harrisburg, Pa., last night.

title: Tenants as Developer's Partner in a Loft Venture
description: UNPLEASANT as it is, a handful of tenants are living through the reconstruction of their building at 285 Lafayette Street, a block south of East Houston Street at the eastern fringe of SoHo. Once it was the Hawley & Hoops candy factory. Now it is an unusual example of an owner-tenant business partnership.

title: Wendy DeBow, Brian Carswell
description: Wendy Elizabeth DeBow, the daughter of Lynn DeBow of New York and Thomas C. DeBow of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Brian Alexander Carswell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Carswell of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. Christine B. Grimbol performed the ceremony at the Old Whalers' First Presbyterian Church in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: How Do We Measure The Virtue of Charity?
description: To the Editor:

title: 19 Years After the Killing of a Kansas Woman, a Man Confesses
description: This time of year is difficult for the family of Tracy Fresquez -- it is both her birthday and the anniversary of her death.

title: Stiff Dose Of Starch
description: A reader writes:

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Good to the Last Drop

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Bertram Fields; Taking On The Case of Richard III
description: ON Wednesday night, a double-A list of the friends and clients of Bertram Fields gathered at the ''21'' Club to offer congratulations. Another legal victory for the swashbuckling Hollywood attorney?

title: Carolyn Rubin, David Leitner
description: Carolyn Judith Rubin, a daughter of Rochelle and Morton Rubin of New York, is to be married this evening to David Kevin Leitner, a son of Sheila and Art Leitner of Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the St. Regis in New York.

title: 'Tiny Bistro' With a French Pedigree
description: Lucien Bahaj characterizes Lucien, his new East Village restaurant, as ''a tiny bistro that offers some good food.'' More precisely, the 38-seat space at 14 First Avenue (between First and Second Streets), which opened yesterday, serves classic French fare including pate ($5), escargot ($6) and oysters ($1 each) as appetizers; duck with figs ($16); roasted squab with foie gras ($22); and steak frites ($16) as entrees.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Horrors in Bristol . . .

title: Inspiration From Past Times and Distant Places
description: THE shadow of the modernist masters hangs heavy over the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts here.

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; Being Different Hurts
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Goldfish Tactics Help Campbell's Soups?
description: NOT so long ago, Pepperidge Farm Goldfish were swimming nowhere fast. The salty little crackers were popular among preschoolers and the bar-stool set, but they drew scant interest from other demographic groups. Sales were flattish year after year.

title: Can Intel Stock Get Off Its Back?
description: ONE school of technology investing hews to a simple strategy: follow the leadership. The shares of so-called leadership companies may not look cheap by conventional measures, say price-to-earnings or price-to-book ratios. But because the leaders define standards the rest of the industry must follow, they will always command a disproportionate share of earnings and growth. Therefore the leaders will always bounce back from setbacks to deliver market-beating returns, or so the school teaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIEDRICK, ARTHUR HILL, M.D.
description: DIEDRICK-Arthur Hill, M.D. On October 16, 1998 of Rye, N.Y. Devoted husband of the late Ann. Father of Arthur Hill Diedrick, Jr. of Litchfield, CT; Dinah Beverly of Brandywine, WV; Lawrence Gilyard Diedrick of Rocky Mount, N.C.; and William Brice Diedrick of Rye, N.Y. Grandfather of 11 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends Sunday, 5-7 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. A memorial service will be held Monday, October 19, 1998 at 11 A.M. at Rye Presbyterian Church. Interment service private. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospital, Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Hack Work
description: TRIP SHEETS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLISEY, JAMES VINCENT
description: HALLISEY-James Vincent. October 16, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Hallisey. Loving father of James V. Hallisey, Jr. and Tamara Hallisey-Hatfield. Cherished grandfather of Sasha A. Hatfield and James V. Hallisey III and Mark O. Hatfield III. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81st Street, Sunday, October 18, 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th Street at Lexington Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Beating the Rush
description: In the mail comes an alarming-looking card featuring a tight close-up of a clock reading two minutes to midnight. Black stripes slash across the garish yellow clock face, asking in computerish type, ''Concerned about the millennium bug?'' and listing a Web site to contact. A fire-red stripe says ''Every minute counts.''

title: Jennifer Dann, Jonathan Phillips
description: Jennifer Allison Dann is to be married today to Jonathan Michael Phillips at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum is to officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, DANIEL JAMES
description: CALLAHAN-Daniel James. On October 15, 1998. Beloved brother of Jean F. Callahan and Frances F. Lavelle and the late Rosalie Hayden. Reposing Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Ave., Flushing, NY. Visitation Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 9:30 AM, St. John Vianney R.C. Church.

title: Anti-Tax Campaign Delayed, Not Defeated
description: Up in the northwest corner of Arkansas earlier this year, some affluent landowners, many empty-nest retirees, grew weary of paying the state's property tax, the main source of money for public schools. So they passed around a petition that called for abolishing the levy and replacing it with an increase in the sales tax.

title: Behind McNown, U.C.L.A. Escapes in Overtime
description: U.C.L.A. 41, OREGON 38

title: The Agent; The Most Hated Man in Baseball
description: The only rule of the rude and sprawling sports-entertainment culture that spans the morning drive-time radio hours to the late-night highlights on ESPN is that every fan has a right to his opinion. The second baseman can't hit left-handed pitching? Bench him! Ride the bum out of town! All that is required in exchange is that you back up your opinions with facts, the way the six stone-cold baseball fanatics seated at the conference table are doing this morning in a gray-carpeted office just off the freeway in Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Nobelist Put Focus On Population, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: Since winning and the approbation of fans are of paramount importance to George Steinbrenner, he might give some thought to being a winner with the entire Bronx. If he is about ''bigger and better and more and winning,'' how about bigger and better parking lots and more security? How about sprucing up the neighborhood, all of which he could do in a New York minute with his wealth?

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; The Great Leveler
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigarette Tax Supported by Unlikely Coalition
description: A lifelong Democrat, the film director Rob Reiner does not have a lot in common politically with people like the millionaire Michael Huffington, a Republican, or the actor Charlton Heston, a conservative icon.

title: For the Love of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Holding On to Hopes for Mart 125
description: Merchants say that the roof leaks when it rains, that there is no heat in winter and no air-conditioning in summer, but for the last 12 years they have persevered at Mart 125, the indoor market on 125th Street. They hold out the hope that one day they may run the place themselves, as the original agreement with the city envisioned.

title: Kosovo's Battles Appear Headed Into the Chill of Winter
description: As the arrival of significant numbers of international monitors appeared weeks away, and the withdrawal of Serbian forces remained very unclear, the tensions of Kosovo province seemed to be heading today for the deep freeze of winter -- ready to reopen in spring.

title: In a 'Virtual' Race, Politics Without Kissing Babies
description: Judged by its blizzard of shrill press releases, the campaign for attorney general in New York is an intense, hard-fought contest, much like the one four years ago.

title: Concert Amid Flowers at Botanical Garden
description: THE flowers that bloom in the fall -- especially chrysanthemums -- are on full display at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, and today at 3 P.M. those who attend the concert of the Bronx Arts Ensemble in Ross Lecture Hall will be able to see the floral exhibition as well as hear works by Mozart, Ravel and Beethoven. A more rarefied part of the program offers the soprano Elizabeth Farnum in a performance of ''Gusan,'' a song cycle based on ninth-century Persian poems by the Iranian-born composer Ramin Heydarbeygi. For travel directions, call (718) 601-7399.

title: Riding High as Election Nears, Rowland Promises Opponent a Job
description: Lots of candidates promise more jobs if elected, but Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut is going them one better: he is promising one to his opponent.

title: Beautiful Objects Fitting for the Garden
description: THE curtain will not come down on the garden, not with ''The Glory of the Garden'' as the theme of the 22d Annual Antiques Show at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk.

title: Broken Records
description: Jack Rosenthal's On Language column was great fun (Sept. 20). My favorite ''fossil of technoterminology is ''This is where I came in.'' It harks back to when you would go to the movies at any time that was convenient. You'd enter, usually in the middle of the movie, sit through the film (and often a second film, if a double feature was playing). When the movie began to look familiar, you would say, ''This is where I came in.''

title: Peru and Ecuador Agree to Put Border Dispute in Outsiders' Hands
description: After emotional debates, the Congresses of Peru and Ecuador have agreed to give the United States, Brazil and two other nations the power to impose a solution on South America's longest-running border dispute.

title: Battered and Broken, So That She May Rise
description: VIVIAN BEARING, at age 50 a professor of 17th-century poetry, has devoted her life to the ''Holy Sonnets'' of John Donne. She holds the sort of Ph.D. that restores some sense of academic majesty to the honorific of doctor, now most frequently used by radio and television people who tell us whether the sun is in or out.

title: McNabb and Syracuse Give B.C. the Slip
description: Doug Flutie? Glenn Foley? How about Donovan McNabb?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ANNE R.
description: WRIGHT-Anne R., 91. Of New York City. Wife of the late George L. Wright, Jr. Beloved mother of George, Peter and Fredrica. Grandmother of eight and greatgrandmother of three. Mass Monday 10 A.M. St. Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT. For information, contact the Collins Funeral Home, 203-866-0747.

title: All That You-Know-What
description: VISIONS OF JAZZ

title: Altered Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: They're the People
description: With unhurried confidence and an author's wisdom, John Steinbeck's GRAPES OF WRATH (1940) inches across the screen like a classic juggernaut, testing the power of a perfect outlet. An experienced moviemaker, John Ford knows exactly what to do with the camera. The picture, which became an instant classic, patiently and trenchantly follows the fortunes of the Joads as newly displaced Okies, whose troubles are mutliplied when the eldest son, Tom, is charged with murder involving an itinerant preacher. In the powerful final scene, Tom (Henry Fonda, above with John Carradine) bids his mother (Jane Darwell) farewell. Fonda and the picture were nominated for Oscars. Darwell and Ford won them - THURSDAY at 8 P.M. on AMERICAN MOVIE CLASSICS.

title: Seconds of Freedom
description: GOD OF THE RODEO

title: Cabaret Has a New Lease but Can't Pay the Rent
description: FROM the 1980's into the mid-90's, cabaret seemed to be breaking out everywhere. Singers of all generations, from the veteran Julie Wilson to the baby boomer Karen Akers, had combined with musicians, songwriters and promoters to create a giddy scene. Tony Bennett was a hit with the MTV set, and clubs offering the magic of an intimate evening of music, dinner and candlelight were springing up in New York and elsewhere. The Algonquin, the Russian Tea Room, Tavern on the Green and the Cafe Carlyle were pillars of the new circuit. But if the cabaret renaissance had a flagship, it was the shiny Rainbow and Stars, where, 65 floors above Rockefeller Center, star performers like Rosemary Clooney and Vic Damone vied with the view for the attention of the tourists, well-heeled New Yorkers and celebrities who frequented the place.

title: Hate Laws Don't Matter, Except When They Do
description: THE crime was horrific enough; cunningly cruel, brutal and utterly senseless. But it was the way the victim was chosen -- singled out because he was part of a despised minority -- that aroused the nation.

title: Susanne Kent, Neil Miller
description: Dr. Susanne Margaret Kent was married last evening to Neil Lance Miller at the Hotel Intercontinental in New York. Rabbi Jeffrey M. Wert officiated.

title: Union Made Little Effort To Police Itself
description: As prosecutors investigate allegations that millions of dollars were stolen from New York City's largest union of municipal workers, months of disclosures paint a picture of rampant corruption, in which money flowed freely and there was a startling lack of financial controls.

title: Q&A/William Hosley; A Passion for Lively Regional History
description: THE Antiquarian and Landmarks Society, established in 1936, is Connecticut's only statewide museum-based preservation organization. The 1,000-member society owns or operates 13 historic properties and William Hosley, just gathering steam in his first year as its director, is brimming with ideas about how to make the properties more accessible and interesting, how to draw more interest in tours and how to increase the strength and vitality of the group.

title: A Bundle of Emotion From 'Miss Show Business'
description: ''JUDY.'' Pure feeling. Judy Garland didn't just deliver it when she sang, she embodied it, no matter how ragged her voice or how histrionic her delivery. The sound of that much emotion so densely concentrated wasn't always easy to take. Like no other American singer, Garland erased the line between laughter and tears, suggesting a barely suppressed hysteria with each gasp and choked-up cry.

title: The Fans; Making the World Safe for Miller Lite
description: The sports bar -- that quintessential American nexus of TV screens, memorabilia, alcohol, loud music and louder people -- has taken over the world, a process that started in the early 90's when American pro sports started to become available worldwide on satellite. ''In the past, internationally, you always had some sporting events on TV, like soccer,'' says Jon Taffer, an American sports-bar owner and industry consultant. ''But sports really wasn't available on this scale before satellite broadcasts, which have driven the whole sports-bar expansion.''

title: Ms. Shedrick And Mr. Brew
description: Elisabeth Farrell Shedrick, a daughter of Elizabeth M. Guittar of New York and Daniel C. Shedrick of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy Joseph Brew, a son of Frances and Richard Brew of Amagansett, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick J. Callan performed the ceremony at the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Bridgehampton.

title: MUSIC; The Chanson Under Attack
description: JUST under two years ago, the French song legend Johnny Hallyday traveled to Las Vegas to perform before an overwhelmingly French public, flown in from France by charter to applaud their countryman. French newspaper, television and radio journalists battled to outdo one another in covering the event.

title: Underdogs of the Kitchen
description: STUDENT chefs with white paper columns on their heads whirled like dervishes. Lunch hour was fast approaching at New York City Technical College on Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn, and the students in the Hospitality Management program were preparing the midday meal. They would soon be serving it to an assemblage of teachers and guests in the school's dining room.

title: Black Belt in Market Share Becomes the Goal at Toyota
description: IN the three years he has been president of the Toyota Motor Corporation, Hiroshi Okuda has become known as much for his black belt in judo as for his outspoken views and aggressive moves to revitalize the once very conservative automobile maker that the stock market values as Japan's largest publicly traded company.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Caroline Babbitt, Stephen Eustace
description: Caroline Welsh Babbitt and Stephen Michael Eustace were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Foster Wilson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated with the Rev. Donald O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, EDWARD
description: LANDES-Edward, New Rochelle, October 16, wife Evelyn, daughters Llyana, Vikki, son Alan. Loved by family and friends.

title: In Metal and in Miniature, Creating Objects of Desire
description: FOR 30 years Daniel Brush has led a double life as a painter and an object maker. His monumental abstract paintings were exhibited in one-man shows here during the 1970's, at the Phillips Collection (1974) and at the Corcoran Gallery of Art (1976 and 1977).

title: Children's Books
description: I DID IT, I'M SORRY

title: Arm-Wrestler Returns to Sport
description: THERE are 19 muscles in the human forearm, but it was another muscle entirely that derailed Glenn Terracciano of Pleasantville on the way to the world arm-wrestling championship.

title: Backtalk; Search for Values Finds Gold in Pro Basketball
description: No one has guaranteed Michael Jordan's return, just as no one can safely say when the season will start. If it's not young knuckleheads failing to mature, it's old sages saying goodbye. And all the while, these grown men who make their living off a Y.M.C.A. recreation cannot seem to divvy up $2 billion.

title: The Capitalist; A Miami Fish Story
description: How could a baseball team in a major media market win the World Series and lose $34 million? The owner of the Florida Marlins, H. Wayne Huizenga, claims that's just what his team did last year. He hoped that his proclamation of penury would shame Broward and Miami-Dade Counties into building him a new, retractable-roof ball park. When it didn't, he went ballistic. Putatively to stop the team's financial bleeding, he conducted the most radical fire sale of players in baseball history, lowering the Marlins' payroll from $53 million in 1997 to $13 million in mid-July 1998 and leaving many baseball fans wondering exactly what Bud Selig was doing in the commissioner's office. At the same time, Huizenga tried to arrange a sale of the Marlins to his longstanding associate and team president, Don Smiley, for $169 million.

title: Sanford Rosenberg, Jennifer Dorne
description: Jennifer Lindsay Dorne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dorne of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married last evening to Sanford Paul Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Rosenberg of New York. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: October 11-17; F.B.I. Opens DNA Data Base
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a national computer data base that holds identifying information from the DNA of convicted felons. The new system, which consists of smaller state-run data bases that are linked by common test procedures

title: The Downside Of Being Like Mike
description: When you stop playing the game, it's like dying. You spend your life struggling and striving to attain this dream of playing in the N.F.L., and then you're out and it's jarring. People ask me, Do you like broadcasting games? And I say: Yeah, but it's not as good as playing. It's like methadone to a heroin addict.

title: Op-Art
October 11-17; The Unbearable Badness of Being
description: Sometimes, bad is good.

title: A New Alliance to Help Westbury Schools
description: WHEN she became principal of the Park Avenue Elementary School at the beginning of last school year, Gloria P. Dingwall began an ambitious reading program for her 600 first- and second-graders. By the end of the year, the students had read 40,000 books.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBY, DR. ARTHUR
description: RUBY-Dr. Arthur. Memorial service for Dr. Arthur Ruby, Sunday, December 6, 12 Noon, 550 1st Avenue, Farkas Auditorium, NYU School of Medicine. Contributions may be made to the Saul J. Farber Scholarship Fund. Eleanor Ruby

title: November in Paris: Photography's the Thing
description: A flurry of photography shows is scheduled in Paris throughout November. For its 10th edition, the Mois de la Photo a Paris is orchestrating 79 photography exhibitions in the city's museums and galleries under a triple theme, ''Seclusion, Intimacy, Event.'' There will also be an international photo fair.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LAMPSHADES

title: The Mogul; Sly as Fox
description: They could have prolonged their Super Bowl junkets and stayed in San Diego, but many of the top buyers in the advertising community had to rush back to the wintry cold of Manhattan for a luxe cocktail party at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. For this tribe, accustomed to fancy schmoozefests, it wasn't just another party: it was a pivotal event that heralded the future of sports under the new dominance of media conglomerates. In Gatsby-esque fashion, the host was mysterious and fabulously wealthy, and he wasn't even there. Rupert Murdoch was in London on other business, as if to show, ever haughtily, that his takeover of big-time sports in America wasn't sufficient cause to merit his actual presence. He wasn't there, but in a way he was -- his live image was projected on a giant screen as if he were Big Brother. Framing his ominous mug shot were a proliferation of smaller screens, each showing a different sports contest that was being telecast live by Murdoch's empire. Murdoch already had the American rights to broadcast the National Football Conference and Major League Baseball and the National Hockey League. Now, at this event, he was about to further his hegemony.

title: Rome's Glory Is Now Tunisia's
description: THE Romans named it Africa. Not the continent, just one small corner of it jutting into the Mediterranean, the country we know today as Tunisia.

title: No Role Models Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Class-Action Lawsuit
description: Unless a regional advocacy group, called Grow, sees evidence of Gov. George E. Pataki's commitment to build housing for the disabled, it will continue with its plans to file a class-action lawsuit forcing the state to develop such housing.

title: An Ideological Secret? That Is the Question
description: Colorado's Second Congressional District has long been in Democratic hands, centered as it is on the university town of Boulder, northwest of Denver. But when the seat opened up this year with the retirement of Representative David E. Skaggs and Republicans nominated former Mayor Bob Greenlee, the conventional political wisdom was that Democrats could no longer take their lock on the district for granted.

title: Braves Lack the Finish Of a Great Champion
description: The Atlanta Braves are not playing in New York this weekend, which means they are not playing in the World Series for the third time in their seven-season run as a division champion and therefore will not win the World Series for the sixth time in those seven seasons.

title: Be Careful What You Ask For; What the Democrats Have in Mind for Ken Starr, Maybe
description: DEMOCRATS are salivating over the prospect of making Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, their star witness in next month's Congressional impeachment hearings.

title: In Vienna, a Suitable Job for a Woman at Last
description: ONLY in the last couple of years did it even enter Agnes Grossmann's mind that she could -- in fact, would -- become music director of the Vienna Choir Boys. She is certainly qualified to take charge of the prestigious choir, continuing its traditions, its tours and its recording projects, which date back to Arturo Toscanini, Bruno Walter and numerous other conductors of that rank. But its 500 years under solely male leadership just wouldn't make it a likely career dream for a woman.

title: Art, Cars, TV's: If It's Asian, It's Cheaper
description: ASIAN stocks, bonds and real estate are not all that have been marked down for immediate clearance. From Hyundai's humble econoboxes to Honolulu's choicest penthouses, merchandise made, owned or offered by Asians is also priced to sell.

title: Food; Batter Up!
description: Mint pesto was tickling his nose, like dust behind home plate, and Yogi Berra began to twitch. Seated at Sharon and Barry Halper's long marble dining table, he tucked a napkin into his waistband and said that eating is the best way to have dinner.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides; A Clevelander Looks For Advice on Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Robbing Graves In Odd Search For the 'New'
description: AS musicologists and record labels look ever harder for something new -- some novelty to justify their jobs or prod their affairs forward -- the line between scholarly inquiry and grave-robbing blurs.

title: For Vaughn, 2 Homers Weren't Enough
description: For someone who had just slammed two home runs, driven in three runs and scored three more, it was strange to hear San Diego left fielder Greg Vaughn say he felt he could have contributed more.

title: What This Season's Acorns Are Saying
description: JUDGING from the number of acorns that have dropped from the big oak tree onto the driveway, this could be a banner year for squirrels. There should be more-than-ample supplies of these protein-rich seeds, which form a major part of a squirrel's diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIGER, LYNN EARHART
description: SCHWEIGER-Lynn Earhart. The staff and Board of Directors of the Purchase Community House send their condolences to the family and friends of Mr. Lynn Earhart Schweiger of Hawthorne, NY. Mr. Schweiger passed away on October 15, 1998 after an all too short battle with a malignant brain tumor. He is survived by his wife, Joyce, son, Keith and daughter, Kerry Lynn and son in law Al Crosby. Mr. Schweiger grew up in Elkhart, Indiana and received his Undergraduate Degree at Purdue University. After being hired as the Director of the Purchase Community House in Purchase, New York in 1967, he completed his Master's Degree at Columbia University Teacher's College. Affectionately known as ''The Boss,'' his integrity, fairness and high standards are lasting legacies to all those who knew him. The safe and caring atmosphere he created for our children made the Community House ''a home away from home.'' Lynn, we love you, we miss you and in our hearts, the Community House will always be ''Lynn's House.'' Services will be held on Monday, October 19th at 11:00am at White Plains United Methodist Church, 252 Bryant Avenue, White Plains, NY. Reception to follow at the Purchase Community House, 3095 Purchase Street, Purchase, NY. In lieu of flowers, for contribution information please contact James Kelly at 914-949-2636.

title: Follow That Scent!
description: Private dressing rooms for preferred clients are a staple of upscale stores. But this week Creed, the official fragrance house of the British royal family, takes V.I.P. shopping to the next level of decadence: chauffeur service.

title: Bialystok Guide Recalls A Center of Polish Jewry
description: INCREASINGLY, American Jews are traveling to Poland to unearth family histories or to revisit a past that is painfully known. These are often moving and solemn trips taken for emotional and personal reasons. Now a carefully researched guidebook has come along that concentrates on Jewish history, people and places in eastern Poland and its main border city, Bialystok.

title: Rebecca Levey, Corey Podolsky
description: Rebecca Sara Levey, a daughter of Debra R. Levey of Manhattan and Dr. Robert L. Levey of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Corey Jon Podolsky, the son of Meryl Podolsky and Dr. Terry A. Podolsky of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Rabbi Irwin Groner officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Themselves Raise Stakes
description: TALK about high expectations. It's not just the man from Tampa who has them anymore. Knowing their baseball as well as they do, everybody in the Joe Torre family passed up tickets for the division series and the League Championship Series as just so much parsley on the plate of life.

title: Trotting Record Set At Yonkers Raceway
description: FROM the beginning of the season, he had been chasing one of his sport's hallowed records, often adding to his numbers in multiple bursts. Then, as September wound down, he broke the record and kept going . . . kept going, setting fresh record after fresh record.

title: A Farewell to Art
description: It could be even better than shopping at Neiman Marcus. Stanley Marcus, the retired chairman and his wife, Linda, an anthropologist, are selling their prime collection of Southwestern art at Sotheby's on Dec. 2. Mr. Marcus, 93, has sold the home in Santa Fe, N.M. that contained his trove. The 180 or so lots, including early New Mexican carvings of patron saints, textiles and furniture, are expected to bring $800,000 to $1 million. When he began collecting 50 years ago, he wondered about paying $75 for primitive wooden statues that sell today for tens of thousands of dollars. He has already donated parts of his Dallas collection to local museums, including a famed series of Japanese prints by Hiroshige that Frank Lloyd Wright had put up as collateral for a loan. ALLEN R. MYERSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITMAN, LORRAINE F., 94. PREDE
description: PITMAN-Lorraine F., 94. Predeceased by his devoted wife of 68 years, Marian Coggeshall Pitman. Died peacefully October 8, 1998 at Duncaster, Bloomfield, Connecticut. Survived by daughter Sandy Pitman, POB 21564, El Cajon, CA. 92021; & two nephews John Brand Pitman, West St. Paul, MN & Lockett C. Pitman, Austin, TX; & brother-in-law & sister-in-law Dr. Bayard & Mary Coggeshall & family.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Big Moments for the Padres to Forget
description: FOR the Yankees, it's as if the San Diego Padres were a new theatrical troupe on the other side of the World Series stage. And two of the new actors are already assured of enduring in the Yankees' Series lore.

title: Beth Cohen, Robert Kirsch
description: Beth Penny Cohen, a film company executive, and Robert Andrew Kirsch, an assistant United States attorney, are to be married today at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the congregation's senior rabbi, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Abridged 'Carmen,' Victor Borge, Too.
description: THOUGH it is often lost in the hilarious shuffle of his one-man shows, Victor Borge is both a masterful pianist and a conductor of equally high achievement.

title: The Hate Epidemic
description: When I read the account of Matthew Shepard's murder, the words that I could not forget were those reportedly used by one of his killers after he and a companion had lured Mr. Shepard out of a Laramie, Wyo., tavern and into the pickup truck in which they would drive him to his place of execution: ''Guess what? I'm not gay -- and you just got jacked.''

title: Precautionary Care of Garage Door
description: OVERHEAD garage doors have more components than any other door in the house, and periodic maintenance is necessary to keep them functioning smoothly and to eliminate potential problems before they become major headaches.

title: Jennifer Witrock, Matthew Fenster
description: Jennifer Anne Witrock, a medical student, and Matthew Scott Fenster, a lawyer, are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Barry Dov Katz at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton.

title: Commercial Property; Vornado's Chairman on Why Its Gusts Have Abated
description: STEVEN ROTH, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, hit New York's office market like a whirlwind last year, buying Bernard Mendik's portfolio of 4 million square feet of Manhattan properties for $650 million as the Mendik Company was preparing to become the city's first real estate investment trust.

title: Hopes Dim in Haiti
description: Four years after American troops landed in Haiti to restore democracy, a government impasse there has evaporated hopes for an era of prosperity and stability.

title: Who Needs Oils? Skill and Beauty on Paper
description: BY the end of the 19th century, watercolor painting enjoyed considerable popularity among both artists and collectors. The medium had attained a level of respectability, and the market had significantly increased. Influenced by the establishment of professional organizations like the American Watercolor Society in 1866 and the all-male Boston Water Color Society in 1885, the Philadelphia Water Color Club was founded by painters in 1900 to promote the use of aqueous media for finished works of art.

title: First-Year Comparison of Kanell and Brown Shows Much in Common
description: At Giants Stadium today, the starting quarterback for the Giants and the backup quarterback across the field for the Arizona Cardinals will share an uncommon history.

title: Spare a Dime?
description: SWEET CHARITY? Emergency Food and the End of Entitlement. By Janet Poppendieck. 354 pp. New York: Viking. $26.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, ALBERT CALDWELL JOHN
description: JOHNSTON-Albert Caldwell Johnston, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., and until recently, of Darien, CT, died Monday, October 12, 1998. He was born Dec. 7, 1909 in Chattanooga, TN and grew up there and in Fort Thomas, KY. In 1930, he was graduated from Miami Univ., Oxford, Ohio where he joined the Sigma Chi Fraternity. Later, he served as legal counsel to Sigma Chi, and was appointed to its Order of Constantine. He received his LLD in 1934 from George Washington Univ. with honors, a member of its Order of the Coif, while working full-time for the U.S. Patent Office. He began his patent law practice in New York City in 1939. He became a member of the District of Columbia Bar, the New York State Bar, the Connecticut Bar, the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. He was admitted to practice in the U.S. Supreme Court and various U.S. Courts of Appeals and District Courts, and was elected President of the New York Patent Law Association. He was instrumental in drafting and promoting landmark Design Protection Legislation, and was honored by the American Bar Association in 1987 for his 50 years of exemplary membership. After 35 years of commuting, he moved his practice to Stamford, CT., where he was senior partner with the firm of St. Onge, Steward, Johnston & Reens until his retirement in 1995. In Darien, he was elected to the Board of Education, on which he served over 10 years during the critical growth period of the town, and was Chairman for several years, promoting education excellence. He was then elected to the Board of Selectmen, serving on the Budget committee and chairing the Long Range Planning Committee. He was a member of Wee Burn Country Club since 1942, the Landmark Club, and was active in the First Congregational Church during the '40's and '50's. Survivors include his beloved Jane Rose, his daughters Bonnie Jane Hamilton of Bradenton, FL., and Virginia of Oslo, Norway, and a son, Robert M. of Leesburg, VA; seven grandchildren, and one great granddaughter

title: Culture Zone; Life Is a Camel Race
description: The curtain for ''Cabaret'' was a half-hour away, but Manoel Felciano, actor and sports fanatic, had his priorities straight. On his way back to the theater, where he is an understudy and a member of the ensemble, he wandered past the All-Star Cafe and its bank of TV's. Sammy Sosa was at bat, smack in the middle of the home-run race to end all home-run races. ''It was getting really close to the time I had to be back, but he kept prolonging the at-bat,'' Felciano recalls. ''But sports history in the making needs to be watched.''

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Last-Ditch Effort to Block a Garbage Flow
description: With East Williamsburg scheduled to become a hub for much of Brooklyn's residential garbage in two weeks, local politicians, environmentalists and neighborhood groups are preparing last-ditch efforts to keep the garbage out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINENBERG, WARREN
description: RINENBERG-Warren, 92. Died October 15. Newspaper man formerly of the NY Post, NY Herald Tribune, Daily News, Mirror and Sun, and business consultant. Loving husband of the late Lillian S. Rinenberg. Survived by two daughters Alice Brickner of New York City and Curry Sawyer of Santa Barbara; five grandchildren, Jed & Maude Brickner, Nell Brickner Eakin, Eric & Brian Sawyer; & five great grandchildren: Daniel, Nora, Lily, Grace and Ariel.

title: Interviewers Glimpse More With Their Ears Than Their Eyes
description: Body language, facial expressions, sweating patterns -- all essential information for evaluating a would-be employee? Guess again. Susan G. Straus, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University's Graduate School of Industrial Administration, says that a job interviewer can tell a lot more from a disembodied voice than from a live-and-in-person applicant.

title: At Least 3 Die as Rains Swamp Central Texas
description: Heavy rains sent rivers and creeks surging over their banks in the Central Texas hill country today, killing at least three people in San Antonio and closing dozens of highways.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about Berkeley Heights, N.J., misidentified the town house development. It is Berkeley Village, not Berkeley Meadows.

title: Can Bikes and Birders Mix?
description: Among the trails that snake through the hilly forest of Alley Pond Park is a crumbling asphalt bike lane built in the 1930's. Much of the trail is now a narrow, overgrown dirt or gravel footpath, and that is just how many bird watchers and conservationists want it.

title: Barbara Thorpe And John Emery
description: Barbara Elisabeth Thorpe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Thorpe Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to John Amir Emery, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Emery of Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Robert D. Edmunds performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

title: Virginia Lee, Andrew Wright
description: Virginia Woollen Lee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lee of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church there to Andrew Fearon Wright, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Wright of Baltimore. The Rev. Vernon D. Miller, a Presbyterian minister, officiated with the Rev. Richard D. Thompson, a cousin of the bride and a United Methodist minister.

title: Word for Word/1400 B.C.; At Harvard, a Political Sex Scandal That's Not News, but Ancient History
description: HEY, does this ring a bell? Dogged by an aggressive prosecution, a political leader denies an illicit affair -- ''I did not have sex with her!'' -- although one of his own associates swears to it. In addition, the leader is accused of hitting up constituents for illicit contributions, of using government employees and resources for his own purposes and even of sending operatives out to threaten people.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 98 of The Times Magazine today about the tennis player Lindsay Davenport misstates her ranking on the Women's Tennis Association tour. She is ranked No. 1, not No. 2. The ranking changed after the magazine went to press.

title: Norman M. Clapp, 83, Leader In Electrifying of Rural Areas
description: Norman Moses Clapp, a Government official from Wisconsin who led the Rural Electrification Administration under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and who directed New York State's investigation of the disastrous power blackout of July 1977, died on Oct. 7 at his home in Clearwater, Fla., where he was living in retirement. He was 83.

title: New Delhi
description: If Bombay is India's New York City, then New Delhi is its Washington, a capital city with a staid provincial air that boasts broad, stately boulevards, grand vistas of awe-inspiring monuments, and an abundance of bureaucrats and politicians. It is a place where the history of India -- from the time of the Mughal emperors, through the British Raj, and into the post-independence era -- is visible everywhere, like the layers of an archeological dig.

title: Wells to Be Tested After Mercury Is Found
description: Bids for testing private wells in Gloucester County are being solicited after unsafe levels of mercury were found in 15 wells in Monroe Township.

title: Elizabeth Gilkeson, 95, Educator and Founder of Children's School
description: Elizabeth Chapman Gilkeson, an educator associated with the Bank Street College of Education for more than four decades and the founding director of its School for Children, died on Oct. 7 at her home in lower Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Nanette Stahl, William Hallo
description: Dr. Nanette Stahl and Dr. William W. Hallo, curators at the Yale University Library in New Haven, are to be married this afternoon. Rabbi Herbert N. Brockman is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn.

title: Despite Fed's Rate Cuts, Dangers Remain
description: O.K, the Federal Reserve may have been stingy when it cut its short-term interest rate target by only a quarter of a percentage point at its last policy meeting Sept. 29. But on Thursday, just 16 days later, it more than made up for that, slicing off another quarter point. As if to add emphasis to the central bank's message that it is alert to the world's financial problems -- especially that of its banks -- this cut came in between the regularly scheduled meetings of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Richelle Sasz and William Neumann
description: TWELVE years ago, Richelle Doris Sasz had just started her junior year in high school in Holbrook, N.Y., and spent most of her free time practicing break-dancing moves. ''Oh, my God, she could do head spins forever,'' remembered Denise Macnamara-Bandl, a friend.

title: What If He Had Waited And the Crisis Had Ended?
description: So what does a global financier do to rush out his global economic warning? In George Soros's case, he abandons his global publisher for a fledgling house that agrees to get his book out before Christmas. Random House had edited Mr. Soros's ''Crisis of Global Capitalism'' and, under his prodding, was willing to move up publication to January from the spring. That wasn't soon enough, so Mr. Soros enlisted Public Affairs, founded this year by a Random House refugee, Peter Osnos.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / Westchester; Office Vacancy Rate Is Continuing to Inch Up
description: AFTER a mid-decade high of 25 percent, office vacancy rates in the county have, for the most part, been declining, hitting a low of 16.8 percent at the end of last year. Since then, however, rates have been inching back up again, leading some brokers to speculate that global economic strains may finally have caught up with Westchester's market.

title: Put the Surplus to Good Use, Like Bulldozers for Tollbooths
description: SOMEWHERE in Trenton sits a huge pile of cash that represents our chance to live a blissful, annoyance-free life.

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: I've been a Yankees' season-ticket holder for three years and was excited to read your article. I was particularly interested in Steinbrenner's reaction to the pretzel he was served. If he thinks the pretzels are lousy, he should try the hot dogs.

title: Behind a Desk, but Maybe Not for Long
description: DR. HENRY C. LEE has endured the tabloid glare of the JonBenet Ramsey and Nicole Brown Simpson murders, inspected mass graves in Bosnia and Rwanda, and picked through the ashes of David Koresh's empire in Waco, Texas. As one of the country's top forensic scientists, he has been in demand worldwide for the last two decades to help with crime investigations. Dr. Lee's turns probing and testifying in the O. J. Simpson and William Kennedy Smith trials, among many others, have put him in the sometimes uncomfortable role of scientist turned celebrity.

title: Intimidation By Resume
description: I started a management-consulting practice eight years ago. It has been a successful venture, and I have worked with organizations like I.B.M., Fidelity Investments and Andrew Jergens. While being my own boss has been great, I'm feeling burned out and would like to work with a larger team. I have been applying for positions in public relations, public affairs, government relations and foundations -- jobs for which I have the background but not the titles. Yet, I can't even get an interview. What should I do?

title: Life as It Was in the Projects
description: For Pamela Weintraub, life in the Linden Houses, a working-class housing project in the East New York section of Brooklyn, was intimate. ''You could hear what everyone was talking about through the walls,'' Ms. Weintraub, 44, said. ''You could smell what everyone was having for dinner, especially if it was stuffed cabbage.''

title: Between the Lines of the Yellow Pages
description: IF you want to know which New York businesses are going where, you can find out fast in the Yellow Pages. The new editions landing on doorsteps in parts of the city this month are not much thicker than those of five years ago, but some categories have expanded greatly, while others have shrunk.

title: World War II Veterans Could Use Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: The Microsoft Trial Begins
description: When the Justice Department filed its antitrust suit against Microsoft last May, both sides were hoping for a quick resolution. But with the trial set to begin tomorrow, those hopes are gone. The case against Microsoft has broadened in scope, encompassing new charges of predatory conduct against big-name rivals. If these allegations are proved, the courts may well be asked to consider drastic remedies, including increased regulation or even a breakup of Microsoft. Many experts worry that such steps could stifle innovation and enterprise in the nation's most dynamic business sector.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Chang Chuckified
description: Susan Choi's first novel, THE FOREIGN STUDENT (Harper Flamingo, $23), is a richly detailed exploration of a young man's escape from the nightmare of a country torn by war. During a stint as a translator for the American information services in Seoul, a young Korean named Chang Ahn is caught up in the political turmoil and forced into a life on the run. By August 1955, two years after the cease-fire has ended the war, Chang has managed to emigrate to the United States, where he attempts to settle into the life of a scholarship student in the university town of Sewanee, Tenn. Yet he is unprepared for the smallest shocks of a vastly different world: even the realization that people in Sewanee go to sleep at night without locking their doors is unnerving. Choi (herself the daughter of a Korean immigrant father) catches such moments under a very clear glass, wisely resisting the urge to embellish. Instead, she allows the story to blossom slowly after Chang (renamed Chuck) makes his first real friend in America: Katherine Monroe, his 28-year-old neighbor. Caught in a poisonous relationship with a popular professor, begun while she was only 14, Katherine is nearly as wounded as Chuck. Together they begin to heal, not with the dreamy pleasure of romantic young lovers but tentatively and painfully, mindful of all that has gone wrong in their lives -- and all that might still go wrong. Moving from the present to the past, from America to Korea, Choi brings hundreds of small scenes to life, then uses them to construct an intricate portrait of lovers who must also prove (to themselves and others) that they are survivors. Kimberly B. Marlowe

title: Backed by U.S., Saudis Seek Afghan Ouster of Bin Laden
description: Urged on by the Clinton Administration, Saudi Arabia's top intelligence official met privately with the leader of the Taliban in late September to try to persuade Afghanistan to deport Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected of masterminding the August bombings of two American embassies in East Africa, according to United States and Arab officials.

title: EASY MONEY: A special report.; For Russia and Its U.S. Bankers, Match Wasn't Made in Heaven
description: The House of Unions, like so many buildings in Russia, has served many different masters. In the 18th century, a Crimean prince commissioned its construction in Moscow. Russian nobles later converted it to a private club. Lenin, Stalin and Brezhnev lay in state behind its bright green facade.

title: Correction
description: The Correspondence column last Sunday, about the experience of The Times's Johannesburg bureau chief with sexism, misstated the name of a leading South African educator who contends that sexism is a bigger problem in Africa than racism. She is Mamphela Ramphele, not Ramphela Mamphele.

title: No Fear For Ledee, Just Desire
description: Ricky Ledee's eyes were dancing and his voice was excitable as he sat in a seafood restaurant in Salinas, P.R., last December and spoke about the possibility of someday playing for the Yankees in the World Series. He leaned closer to the table and listened intently as a reporter told Ledee stories and anecdotes about what happened when the Yankees won the title in 1996. At one point, Ledee simply shook his head and stared at the floor in disbelief.

title: How Do We Measure The Virtue of Charity?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN ARRESTS PINOCHET TO FACE CHARGES BY SPAIN
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who reigned over Chile as a dictator for 17 years and came to symbolize the excesses of military rule in Latin America, has been arrested in London after Spain asked that he be extradited for the presumed murders of hundreds of Chilean and Spanish citizens, the British authorities announced yesterday.

title: Staying Stubbornly True to a Writer's Vision
description: TONI MORRISON'S novels have never been easy reading. Much like the work of William Faulkner, another Nobel laureate, they tell large, graphic, emotionally charged stories but do so with a level of poetic language that fights against being understood too quickly. They are full of vision about race and dominion in America, but that vision is cumulative, even oblique, emerging only in a slowly prevailing rhythm of words.

title: OPINION; Hands-On Transportation Planning
description: EFFECTIVE and meaningful public participation is a critical component in developing any successful transportation program. But in most cases public involvement has been the weakest link in planning. Public participation has been a perfunctory process involving limited discussion and interaction between planners, engineers and the public. Many government agencies responsible for projects have determined their course of action before the public has had a chance to respond. In many instances there has been no effective forum for presenting information, soliciting the public's views and candidly exchanging ideas.

title: Laurie Mintzer, Michael Edberg
description: Laurie Sue Mintzer, the daughter of Warren Mintzer of Commack, N.Y., and the late Arlene Jayne Mintzer, is to be married today to Michael Alan Edberg, the son of Miriam Edberg and Dr. Stephen Edberg of Orange, Conn. Rabbi William Berman is to officiate at the Congregation Adas Israel in Washington.

title: Aznavour, The Last Chanteur
description: CHARLES AZNAVOUR may well be the only person who remembers his first visit to New York, in 1948. He was 24, poor, and spoke no English, but he was eager for adventure. Edith Piaf had invited him to accompany her to the United States -- as a friend, not a lover, he insists -- and the ''little sparrow'' helped him find a few gigs of his own. More important, this short, wiry Frenchman entered a world of music in which he felt immediately at home. He already knew the work of Cole Porter, George Gershwin and Jerome Kern, and now he discovered Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington and Dizzy Gillespie.

title: Taking a Bus Tour of Their Own Backyard
description: ''MY name is Carol Lucca and I'm a Long Islander,'' the tour guide announced to 38 passengers, primarily senior citizens from Huntington, who had taken seats in the tour bus on a recent Sunday morning. ''Do we have any visitors?''

title: October 11-17; The Spoils of the Budget War
description: Schoolteachers, immigrants and the Pentagon emerged as big winners after Congress and President Clinton reached agreement on the $1.7 trillion Federal budget. Weighty issues aside, some lawmakers were quietly enjoying their success in slipping into the huge spending bill several favors to constituents.

title: Weld Thing
description: Not much of an accomplishment (Frank Bruni, Sept. 27)? Driving home to Harvard Square from Kenmore Square after a Red Sox game ''in a flash'' is an accomplishment to anyone who has ever tried to do it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, DENIS J.
description: CASEY-Denis J. on October 15, 1998 formerly of Bronxville, New York. Loving father of Caroline and Michael. Adored grandfather of Alexandra. Beloved brother of Patrick, Mary Geary & Eleanor O'Byrne. Reposing Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square Tuckahoe, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 A.M. St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bronxville. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Sunday & Monday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. At Denis's request, donations in lieu of flowers may be made for his granddaughter's college fund at Alexandra A. Casey at the United Nations Federal Credit Union in NYC.

title: Billboards That Block the Light ...
description: Three weeks ago, the middle window on the south side of the sprawling loft at 620 Broadway looked down on the bustle of Houston Street. Now, it affords only a close-up view of a huge I-beam and the back of a new 52-foot-wide billboard, both painted black. It lets in no light, which angers the loft's owners, Marri Davis and David Moffly, almost as much as the six lamps that shine on the still-blank billboard at night, filling their apartment with a bluish glow. Their left-hand window on the south side now looks into a V-shaped formation of catwalks, steel beams and wood formed by the billboard and its twin.

title: October 11-17; Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates Again
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, unexpectedly cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, taking the unusual step of moving on his own authority in between the central bank's regularly scheduled policy-setting meetings.

title: For Padres, Glory of '84 Is Distant
description: Bruce Bochy was a seldom-used catcher, Tim Flannery a utility infielder, Greg Booker a relief pitcher. They were not the stars of the team, but they, along with Tony Gwynn, are the links to the only other time the San Diego Padres played in the World Series.

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Kibbutz, Dirty Hands at Last
description: It was difficult to discern what Ze'ev Chafets's true point was in his article on Israel's kibbutzim. Was it merely to note how kibbutzim are being transformed from a socialistic practice to a more capitalistic approach? Or was it just an attack on the orthodox religious movement?

title: 10 Are Injured at Hotel After Elevator Collapses
description: Ten people suffered minor injuries yesterday morning when an elevator that had recently undergone repairs collapsed at the Park Central Hotel in midtown.

title: Patriots Seem to Have Real Leader in Bledsoe
description: When New England trampled Kansas City by 40-10 last week, the Patriots gained the bonus of an orderly setting for the undesirable Jets tomorrow night. Although many in New England still admire Coach Bill Parcells, that is how plenty of others there feel about Parcells and his Jets. Undesirables. The Patriots would like to smack both by a score of, oh, 80-10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland in his 81st year. The officers, directors, staff and volunteers the world over mourn the sudden death of our founder, President, and guiding intellect and spirit. Mr. Amory founded the Fund for Animals in 1967 and has led it every inch of the way while tirelessly continuing his career as a best-selling author. We will of course continue to serve animals, large and small, all of whom he loved, but without him it won't be the same. We will not see his like again. Memorial service to be announced. The Fund for Animals

title: Once Again, Drug Giants Can't Get Along
description: Any doctor or pharmacist knows the importance of checking for harmful cross-reactions before putting together two drugs, but the idea appears to be lost on drug-company bosses. For the third time this year, an announced merger of pharmaceutical giants fell apart, largely because the chief executives of the two companies could not agree on sharing power. Last week it was American Home Products and Monsanto calling the whole thing off, following bust-ups between SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome in February and SmithKline and American Home in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTS, FLORENCE
description: WATTS-Florence. On October 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late William. Dearly loved Aunt of Lisa Burge, Robyn Jacobs and Gary Coe. Cherished and devoted friend to the many whose lives she touched and enriched. A graduate of Stanford University, she had a distinguished career in the service of non-profit institutions including Albert Einstein College of Medicine and New York University.

title: Government Give-backs Or Government Gimmicks?
description: The refund checks to electric ratepayers have arrived and include a letter from the LIPA Chairman, Richard Kessel. Mr. Kessel gives Governor Pataki credit for getting the checks out and for the 20 percent reduction in rates on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, MARSHA
description: FORMAN-Marsha. AMIT Aviva Chapter is saddened by the passing of our charter member and devoted supporter, Marsha Forman. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. AMIT Aviva Chapter

title: Another Eli as the Hero Of the Industrial Revolution
description: CLOCKS are taken for granted nowadays. People wake up to the summons of an alarm, keep an eye on the kitchen clock while making breakfast, check the time at work and in the car on the way home.

title: One Bar, Three Environments
description: Revelers can choose their ambiance at Cream, an Upper West Side club that opened last month. At 246 Columbus Avenue (between 71st and 72d Streets), Cream is owned by Rick Oscher, Shawn Kolodny and Keany Squire. The three also own Venue, a bar at 505 Columbus Avenue (between 84th and 85th Streets).

title: A Passport to Dreams
description: Men, naked but for diapers, writhing sensually like Nijinsky on a bed of pink rose petals, are not what a fashion-show audience comes to see. But few would be telling the truth if they claimed that they minded this backdrop to the bounty of airy, magical dresses and redoubtable slithery suits that were the John Galliano collection.

title: Deadheading Prolongs the Season
description: Don't stop deadheading pansies, long-blooming perennials like fragrant cottage pinks (Dianthus x alwoodii) and indispensable fall bloomers like asters and the unfortunately named sneezeweeds (Helenium Coppelia, which has masses of mahogany-red flowers that fade to burnt orange and are great for cutting). Many plants will continue to thrive and bloom prolifically into late fall if regularly deadheaded to redirect the plant's energy from forming seed into forming flowers. Pull up spent annuals, but remember to leave some seed heads for winter interest.

title: Where Bombing Maneuvers, and Training, Could Be Deadly
description: At the height of World War II, the Naval Air Station Wildwood, at the southern tip of Cape May County, served as the training ground for 3,000 Navy personnel at a time. Some were trained as dive bombers, and the training cost 36 men their lives.

title: Lunge Wear
description: You don't have to be a volleyball star like Gabrielle Reece to participate in fashion's great leap forward. It's all in the mix: the juxtaposition of the athletic and purely functional with the chic and extravagant.

title: Beethoven's Mysteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Oxford's Pullout
description: Calling Oxford Health Care's decision to stop providing health insurance to the elderly in Westchester cruel and inhumane, County Legislator Bernice Spreckman, a Republican of Yonkers, is trying to help those left out of Oxford's coverage. Legislator Spreckman, who leads the Board of Legislators' Task Force on Senior Citizens, said, ''Oxford enticed seniors to join its plan, then pulled the rug out from under them.''

title: How Do We Measure The Virtue of Charity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Warming Up to the Foods of El Salvador
description: PUPUSAS are the national dish of El Salvador and one of the Island's best versions is being served at the new Pupuseria Melissa Restaurant, at 1419 New York Avenue (Route 110), in Huntington Station (425-4125).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MAYNARD
description: PARKER-Maynard. Age 58, died of complications of leukemia on October 16. As reporter, editor, friend, father and husband, he was the best of the best. Funeral services will be announced later. In lieu of flowers please make contributions in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: Elizabeth Hochberg, Michael Schloff
description: Elizabeth Joy Hochberg, the daughter of Marcia A. Hochberg and Dr. Fred N. Hochberg of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Benjamin Schloff, a son of Dr. Linda M. Schloff and Dr. Leonard D. Schloff of St. Paul. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at the Cipriani Wall Street Hotel in New York.

title: October 11-17; Prenatal AIDS Tests Sought
description: Testing for the AIDS virus should be a routine part of every pregnant woman's prenatal care, a panel of experts from the Institute of Medicine recommended. Checking for H.I.V. infection need not be accompanied by extensive AIDS counseling, as now recommended by Federal officials, which some doctors find so burdensome that they forgo offering tests.Treating infected women with anti-H.I.V. drugs cuts the risk of transmission to newborns by two-thirds. WARREN E. LEARY

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: I have long been a Steinbrenner admirer, even during his tempestuous earlier years, when it wasn't fashionable to be one. He is a throwback to baseball's better days, when an owner or field manager could motivate players by challenging their personal and professional pride. That invariably involved an excellent motivator: fear, whether of a trip to the minors, of a trade to a poor ball club or of no job at all.

title: A Ruling On Rentals By Sponsors
description: WHEN Barry Paikoff, the sponsor of the conversion of a six-unit rental building in Park Slope into a co-op, rented out a vacant, unsold apartment after the conversion, he did so in the belief that when the tenant's lease expired he could decline to renew it.

title: First Malaria Caught Locally Since 1991 Is Diagnosed
description: The discovery of the first locally contracted case of malaria since 1991 has raised concerns about access to health services in the state.

title: Far From 'the Troubles,' Agitprop for Both Camps
description: IN 1973, Danny Deveny, a member of the Irish Republican Army, was arrested for bank robbery after being shot and wounded by security forces in Northern Ireland. Sentenced to eight years at Long Kesh, a British prison outside Belfast, Mr. Deveny lived in one of several hundred Nissen huts surrounded by barbed wire like a World War II internment camp. Housing 30 men together, the huts were rundown, cold and occasionally rat infested. A change of bedsheets was rare, and outbreaks of scabies were common. Prison guards routinely brutalized the inmates, strip searching them and setting police dogs on them.

title: Pros Have Feelings, Too
description: You see a lot of prima donnas in this sport. Like, I'm not saying who, but there are players who expect people to do everything for them. They're the ones who are going to have problems later on, when they're out of tennis and they're no longer the center of attention. I suppose I could call my agent and say, Arrange for somebody to pick me up at the airport, but I'd rather do it myself. The only thing I can't do is reserve the rental car, because I'm under 25. My coach does that.

title: Will Plan Fix Japan Banks? The Devil Is In the Details
description: UNTIL the Federal Reserve Board cut interest rates again and Congress agreed to more than $90 billion in financing for the International Monetary Fund, the biggest development last week in the effort to stave off global recession seemed to be made in Japan.

title: Children's Books
description: FRANKENSTEIN

title: Penn State Cuts Off Purdue at The Pass
description: Penn State did not require anything fancy to stop Purdue's Drew Brees and his band of receivers today. Sticky man-to-man coverage and a persistent rush were all the Nittany Lions needed. With occasional bursts from its offense, Penn State rolled over the Boilermakers, 31-13, before 97,034 at Beaver Stadium.

title: PULSE; Saving Face The Morning After
Nearly 6,000 Competing in the Head-of-Charles Regatta
description: The 34th annual Head of the Charles regatta, the autumn rowing festival in Boston with an entry of close to 6,000 North American and international collegiate, club and veteran rowers, began competition today over a three-mile stretch of the Charles River.

title: Judith Wilson and Dan Greenburg
description: Judith C. Wilson and Dan Greenburg, writers who live in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., were married yesterday afternoon in New York. Justice Stanley L. Sklar of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the home of Mildred Newman and Dr. Bernard Berkowitz, friends of the couple.

title: Out of the Shell In the Village
description: BABBO ***

title: October 11-17; U.N. Gangs Up on Embargo
description: A year ago, in a United Nations General Assembly vote, 143 nations favored an end to the American embargo on Cuba. Only the United States, Israel and Uzbekistan said nay. This year, Uzbekistan defected -- and some abstaining nations came around -- in a record 157-to-2 vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODER, ALICE
description: BRODER-Alice, on October 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Maurice L. Broder, adored mother of Cali and Larry Tamarkin and Janice and Tom Burne. Cherished grandmother of Eric and Jed Tamarkin and Jessica and Andrew Burne. Loving sister of Helen Dreeben and devoted friend.

title: Liberties; It Was Ever Thus
description: Best news of the week: Soccer moms may be history. The election of 1998 may be decided by waitress moms.

title: Soccer's Din Threatens Poet's Rest In Spain
description: For the 100th anniversary of the birth of the poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca this year, his relatives helped plan dozens of conferences and concerts. Arguably Spain's greatest literary figure this century, he was executed in the Spanish Civil War by fascists loyal to Franco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, GENE J.
description: FLANAGAN-Gene J. On October 16, 1998 (Dean of Kingsborough Community College). Devoted husband of Kay (nee Leary). Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 12:15 PM, at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. Visitation Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin's & Sons, Third Ave. at 97th St., Brooklyn. Interment St. Catherine's Cemetery, Spring Lake, NJ.

title: Votes Are Lure as San Antonio Angles for G.O.P.
description: If the Republican National Committee's site selection team picks San Antonio for the party's Presidential nominating convention in 2000, as the backers of the city's drive predict, the nation will be treated to a lovefest of diversity aimed at drawing Hispanic-Americans into the Republican tent, backers say.

title: Colette Post, Neal Oldford
description: Colette Mary Post was married on Monday to Neal Robert Oldford. Pascal Braun, a civil officer, officiated at the civil registry office in Geneva.

title: Children's Books
description: THE GINGERBREAD MAN

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the films of Georg Wilhelm Pabst misidentified the actress in ''The Love of Jeanne Ney.'' She is Brigitte Helm, not Edith Jehanne.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A thriller set in occupied Paris in World War II, a fine swashbuckler, a twisted tale of revenge and a lavish green and gold version of the Sherwood Forest legend promise the viewer an adventursome week in television.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: I certainly now have a soft spot for George Steinbrenner after reading Buster Olney's terrific article (Sept. 27). The relationship between the Boss and Darryl Strawberry is particularly touching. Steinbrenner's commitment to stand by a person is admirable. You couldn't ask for a better mentor and friend.

title: Bias Law Would Amount to Piece of Paper; State Law Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: A Case of Too Little Math And Too Many Winners
description: There were only 47 participants in the Atlantic Open Tourney, held in Washington in late July, but seven of them tied for first place. That happened because this Swiss-system competition had only five rounds, and that proved insufficient to separate out a clear winner or even to prevent such a comparatively large horde from crossing the finish line together. The old rule of thumb that the number of rounds should at least equal the square root of the number of players was not observed; it seldom is in events that must be fitted into a weekend. (In this case, the square root of 47 is 6.85, so seven rounds were called for.)

title: Tickets Sold Today For Games 6 and 7
description: There are a good many people in New York, David Wells of the Yankees most vocal among them, who do not believe that the World Series will last more than five games. Nonetheless, tickets will go on sale at 11 A.M. today for Games 6 and 7.

title: In Dismissals, Silence Has Its Perils
description: YOU walk into the office, and as the day goes on you realize that the guy who sat in the cubicle next to you for years isn't there. It's not just that he hasn't come in to work. There is no trace of him. The family pictures, the plants, the cartoons he liked to clip and post are simply gone. Office scuttlebutt has it that he has been dismissed. But there is no official word: no memo, no department E-mail.

title: Landlubber Sets Sail On Sound
description: ''I'VE never seen a less promising crew,'' said the captain. Nobody disagreed. Several dozen ill-assorted mariners, many of us well past our prime, were slouching on the main deck of the Rose while the captain addressed us from the eminence of his quarterdeck. We had signed on for a day of voluntary bondage on this splendid tall ship, and many of us were having second thoughts.

title: An Inning of Power Puts the Yankees on Top
description: The Yankees stalked San Diego's Kevin Brown in Game 1 of the World Series last night, their pack of hitters relentlessly pressing and wearing him down, wearing him out. When Brown was finally driven from the mound, Chuck Knoblauch and Tino Martinez moved in for the kill.

title: Miss Fingleton, Mr. Sheerin
description: Priscilla Fingleton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Fingleton of New York, was married on Friday to James Laurence Sheerin Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheerin of San Antonio. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Putting Boces Money To Better Use
description: It is misleading if not inaccurate to imply that Boces services allow local school districts to save money [''Boces Becomes a Technology Services Force,'' Sept. 27].

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, JAMES PATRICK
description: McFADDEN-James Patrick. On October 17, 1998. Editor of The Human Life Review. Beloved husband of Faith (nee Abbott). Loving father of Maria Maffucci, Patrick, Regina and Christina McFadden and the late Robert Arthur McFadden II. Adoring grandfather of James Anthony and Anna Clare. Dear brother of Thomas and Edward McFadden, Rita Ward, Louise Boelger, Jean Jenkins and the late Robert Arthur McFadden. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Agnes Church, 143 E. 43 St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Loyalty Can Be Measured
description: Back when I came up, baseball was about establishing yourself. You wanted to get in position to break the records of the players you grew up watching. I'm just now getting to the point where guys like Rod Carew, Pete Rose and George Brett were, and it's exciting to me. But now you've got young guys who don't even think about the history of the game or putting their names in the record books. The money they're making, if they get one long deal, they don't have to keep playing. They don't ask a lot of questions like I did either. Man, I was a pest. If Cincinnati was here, I'd be sitting on the bench watching Rose take batting practice, then asking him about hitting. Guys today, they're scared to approach you, scared to say hello. I did have this one guy, though, a catcher for the Marlins, who sent me a note this season. Do you have five minutes to talk? I sent back a note: Sure -- on the last day of the series. You don't want him going on a tear against you. After we talked, he went on a tear. That feels good. You think: maybe you made a difference.

title: Classical Briefs
description: FRENCH AND SPANISH SONGS

title: Yale, Clinton's Alma Mater, Is Little Moved by Drama
description: During the Vietnam War and the Watergate crisis, the campus of Yale University, like many others, was politically energized if not radicalized. The university chaplain, the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., took a prominent role in opposing the war, and many undergraduates viewed the resignation of Richard M. Nixon as a triumph over the forces of evil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSS, ROBERT E.
description: SCHLOSS-Robert E. On Sept. 16, 1998. Beloved, adoring husband, caring father, stepfather, brother, grandfather. Because of his empathy and generosity of self, he will be missed by so very many.

title: Jonathan B. Postel, Who Helped to Create and Administer the Internet, Is Dead at 55
description: Jonathan B. Postel, who played a pivotal role in creating and administering the Internet, died of complications after undergoing heart surgery on Friday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, his brother Thomas Postel said yesterday. He was 55 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: BENEFITS
description: 112 Years of Helping

title: What This Season's Acorns Are Saying
