description: JUDGING from the number of acorns that have dropped from the big oak tree onto the driveway, this could be a banner year for squirrels. There should be more than ample supplies of these protein-rich seeds, which form a major part of a squirrel's diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C. Of Redding, CT. Died September 16. There will be a memorial service Saturday, October 24, 1 P.M., St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: HOME RUN: The Story of Babe Ruth. By Robert Burleigh. Illustrated by Mike Wimmer. Silver Whistle/Harcourt Brace. $16. (Ages 6 to 10) Before the glow of this year's slugfest completely fades, or perhaps to burnish it during the off-season, here, told in lushly romantic full-page paintings, mostly of the subject himself, and in data-filled old-style bubble-gum baseball cards, is the story of the Babe. His record of 60 home runs stood for 34 years.

title: Negotiations In Jones Case Don't Produce A Settlement
description: Paula Corbin Jones today demanded that President Clinton pay her $1 million as part of a $2 million package she would receive to drop her sexual misconduct lawsuit against him, but White House advisers quickly described the proposal as riddled with insurmountable problems.

title: A Provider of Programs For Exchange Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters Are Still Sitting on Fence In the D'Amato-Schumer Contest
description: The contest between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer remains close, according to five polls of New York State voters conducted this month, while Gov. George E. Pataki continues to lead his Democratic challenger, Peter F. Vallone, by a large margin.

title: The Wanderer
description: THE WHEREABOUTS OF ENEAS McNULTY

title: Battle of Phone Giants Has a Long Day in Court
description: As the Microsoft antitrust lawsuit lurched toward trial, another important technology case, consolidating eight suits about local phone service, had a hearing before the Supreme Court last week.

title: An Announcement: Candidate Has Baby
description: Jane Swift, the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor in Massachusetts, gave birth on Friday in Boston to a 7-pound 6-ounce girl, Elizabeth Ruth Hunt.

title: Barbie, Chess Queen
description: Like most chess clubs, the one at Public School 29 is composed of nearly all boys. Marlene Hochman, the coach, wants to change that and in a most unusual way: with dolls.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: AFRICANS IN AMERICA

title: In San Jose, a New Home for the Cutting Edge
description: If you've ever had an urge to design a roller coaster or have a 3-D map of your head made by a rotating laser scanner, the new permanent home of the Tech Museum of Innovation, which opens in San Jose, Calif., on Oct. 31, may be the place for you.

title: Lawyer's Challenge
description: For the second time in three years, the Supreme Court of the United States has turned down a request from a White Plains lawyer, Doris L. Sassower, to hear a legal challenge of her professional disciplining. Without comment, the court denied a petition from Mrs. Sassower, who said that judges and other officials have denied her civil rights by continuing to suspend her license.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBASH, ROSLYN
description: BARBASH-Roslyn. 1/5/11-10/18/85. Wise physician, loving wife and mother, loyal friend. 13 years after leaving us, you are vividly remembered with affection by all whose lives you touched.

title: The Ties That Bind: Thinking Globally At the Local Level
description: DOES Margate, England, have an elephant?

title: Life in the Fast Lane (Thanks, Dad)
description: Sequent Computer Systems is spending $450,000 this year to help sponsor a drag-racing team. The driver of the car, who pulls down a salary of $65,000, is none other than Cristen Powell, the 19-year-old daughter of Sequent's chairman, Karl C. Powell Jr.

title: The Owner; Every Fan's Fantasy
description: Peter Angelos, the Baltimore lawyer, led a group of investors that bought the Baltimore Orioles baseball team for $173 million in 1993, and instantly made his presence felt. After he poured millions of dollars into the club's payroll, the Orioles emerged from an era of mediocrity to make the playoffs in 1996 and 1997. This year, however, was a different story: despite amassing the highest payroll in baseball history, the Orioles finished fourth in a five-team division.

title: INSIDE
description: Few Checks on Union

title: Week for Wishful Thinkers
description: Has the stock market bear lumbered back into its cave? That is the way it looked this week as stocks roared following the Federal Reserve Board's surprise rate cut on Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 6.5 percent at 8,416.76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTIMER S., ESQ.
description: ROSENTHAL-Mortimer S., Esq. On October 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Frances S. Rosenthal. Dear father of John, Richard and Susan. Adored grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Andrew and Sandra. Loving brother of Mildred Shapiro and the late Wilma Musher. Services Monday, October 19, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Back to the Future With Belgian Endive
description: THERE is something very 60's about Belgian endive. Perhaps it is those canapes made with salmon caviar or blue cheese spooned onto the leaves and served at cocktail parties. In those days it was also the main winter salad vegetable, when other greens were out of season. But now I often find it a welcome antidote to those dubious piles of so-called mesclun, of which one can easily get very tired.

title: Splendid Digs
description: THE LOST TOMB By Kent R. Weeks. Illustrated. 330 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $27.50.

title: Colleagues as Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFELD, IRWIN
description: HELFELD-Irwin. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of one of our founding members, Mr. Irwin Helfeld, beloved husband of our esteemed member and benefactor, Mrs. Ilse Helfeld. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Richard Kestenbaum, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEN, MORRIS R., M.D., F.A.C.S.
description: KEEN-Morris R., M.D., F.A.C.S. Age 98. Died at home in Tempe, AZ, Friday October 15, 1998. Formerly of Huntington, NY where he practiced for 40 years. He was Chief of Urology at Huntington Hospital. He is a former President of the Suffolk County Medical Society and founded and was Editor in Chief of the Society's Bulletin and its medical museum. He is survived by his second wife Estelle; two children Elizabeth Keen and Linda Scharer; son-in-law Lawrence; grandchildren Melissa Alwang and Scott Scharer, as well as his step-children Carl Scheinman, Lynn Green and Karen Greenfield; their children Lisa and Brian Greenfield, Elissa and Erica Green, Carrie and Jonathan Scheinman and four great-grandchildren. His first wife, Golda, died in 1972. When asked how he wished to be remembered, he replied, ''I love my family and I love my country.'' He will be buried Sunday, October 18, 2 PM at Old Montifiore Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Stylish Decor, Abundance of Asian Fare
description: AS a university town, New Haven has long had a concentration of ethnic restaurants, but we can't think of any as stylish as Bentara. The space is warehouse large, with high ceilings and well-spaced tables in several dining areas. A cavernous look is avoided by extremely sophisticated decorating: shadow puppets projected onto three screens in the rear, Malaysian baskets stacked in a corner near the large front windows, a bamboo screen separating the bar area, niches displaying subtle, well-chosen handcrafts.

title: He Blew the Whistle, And Health Giants Quaked
description: JAMES F. ALDERSON maneuvered his 9-year-old Ford Tempo through the snow, parking beside the Federal courthouse in Butte, Mont. Mr. Alderson, a small-town hospital accountant, left the heat on, telling his wife, Connie, to wait in the car. He was sure it would only take a moment to file his lawsuit on behalf of the United States, charging four giant hospital companies with fraud.

title: Lynn Green, Marc Rosenthal
description: Dr. Lynn Danielle Green, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Green of Woodsburgh, N.Y., was married last evening to Marc Stuart Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Rosenthal of Muttontown, N.Y. Rabbi Mordekai Shapiro officiated at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Bergen's Facing a Vote on an Open-Space Tax
description: BRUCE R. MAREK grows more than 100 different kinds of organic vegetables on a patch of farmland along Old Hook Road in Emerson Township in Bergen County, which with 851,344 residents is the most populated of New Jersey's 21 counties.

title: Again, the Talk Around Bush Turns to 2000
description: Gov. George W. Bush, ahead by as much as 50 points in statewide polls in his bid for a second term, met his Democratic challenger, Garry Mauro, for their first and only debate tonight and it did not take long for the talk to turn to Mr. Bush's possible run for the Presidency in 2000.

title: Clinton's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 37 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about political murals on Theater Row misidentifies the artist pictured with a mural at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. He is Danny Deveny, not Marty Lyons.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 4 about filmmaking in New Jersey misidentified a movie being shot in Jersey City. It is ''Ghost Dog,'' not Ghost Day.''

title: Win, Lose or Draw
description: To the Editor:

title: Yet Another Ride On That Sinking Ship
description: BEFORE last year's Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, before the Oscar-winning movie, before the best-selling book from the movie, there was Jeffrey Hatcher's play about the Titanic. Titled ''Scotland Road,'' after the name given to a passageway on the ship's steerage level, the play made the rounds of small regional theaters before it was briefly seen Off Broadway early this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 4 about a new recording by Elvis Costello and Burt Bacharach misstated the title of a song on the album. It is ''God Give Me Strength,'' not ''God Give Me Grace.''

title: Immigrants' Beliefs Figure In Cancer Treatment and Care
description: THE woman was extremely proud and private, speaking only in three- or four-word sentences, said Dr. Anthony Cahan, a breast cancer surgeon at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, part of Our Lady of Mercy Healthcare System in the Bronx. ''You knew she had much to say but wouldn't.''

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: I enjoyed your article on George Steinbrenner but was disappointed that an aspect of sports to which he gave so much of his life went unnoted. For 12 years George served as a member of the United States Olympic Committee. Moreover, he helped to support financially scores of athletes who dreamed of making the Olympics. He did this with no public visibility, and it is only now that, as an Olympics officer, I have come to learn how generously he gave. He was a soft touch.

title: Girl Power
description: Any adult who has dispensed advice to the young knows how much weight children give such guidance. But when a girl has some advice for another girl, all ears are open. In fact, ''Ask Any Girl,'' a book of girl-to-girl advice published last year was so well received that the publisher, Beyond Words, of Hillsboro, Ore., has just issued ''Ask Any Girl 2'' ($8.95). One of the 47 contributors, aged 7 to 16, is Keeley Stalnaker, a 12-year-old from High Bridge who is in the seventh grade at Gill St. Bernard's School in Gladstone. Her tips for girls who want to start a business were chosen from 600 submissions. Other topics in the book include how to tell if you are right- or left-brained, what to do when your best friend ditches you, overcoming shyness and having fun while you're grounded. If there's a third volume, Keeley, who appeared at her first book signing yesterday at the Clinton Bookshop in Clinton, might tell other girls how to handle fame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, LAWRENCE V.
description: MURPHY-Lawrence V. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Lawrence V. Murphy, associated with The Times from 1946 until retiring in 1989.

title: Tourism, Seen From Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Patient Arrested in Molestation at Hospital
description: A 57-year-old patient at a city hospital on Roosevelt Island was arrested Friday night and accused of sexually molesting two comatose women in their beds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPKOWITZ, IRVING
description: LIPKOWITZ-Irving. October 18, 1898, our Grandpa, on the Centennial of his birth, we remember him with love and celebrate his life. Gerald, Arthur and Elliot Levy

title: POSTINGS: At 453 Broome Street, With Lofts at $11,000 a Month; Spiffing Up an 1873 Cast-Iron Building in SoHo
description: Giel Millner has a strong attachment to 453 Broome Street in SoHo, a six-story cast-iron building that is being renovated to include two penthouse duplex lofts, each renting for $11,000 a month.

title: Kathleen Lukens, a Mother First and Foremost, Dies at 67
description: Kathleen Lukens, a more or less ordinary woman whose life had such an ordinary focus on her children it is a wonder how much people made of what she saw as routine maternal devotion, died on Tuesday at her home in Tappan, N.Y. She was 67 and had been executive director of Camp Venture, a Rockland County service organization for the developmentally disabled that she founded in 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSKOPF, NATALIE
description: GROSSKOPF-Natalie. On October 16, 1998. Beloved wife of Neil. Devoted daughter of Naomi and the late Judge Saul Moskoff. Adored mother of Marnie Bernstein and Meredith Lieberman. Loving mother-in-law of Jeff Bernstein and grandmother of Josh Bernstein. Cherished stepmother of Jennifer, Jonathan and Melissa Grosskopf. Service Sunday, 11 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Almost, But Not Quite, Deja Blue All Over Again
description: NO, it's not your imagination. New York really does seem to be living through 1987 all over again. Just look at the calendar: Tomorrow is Oct. 19, the very date that will live in financial infamy as Black Monday, when the stock market plunged 23 percent.

title: With Gift Ban, Prisoners Get Time but Little Else
description: Anyone wanting to help an inmate break out of prison will have to tear up the recipe for hacksaw in a cake. As of tomorrow, the 29,000 residents of the state's prisons will no longer be allowed accept any gifts other than some religious, educational and legal material. The policy change, announced last week by Corrections Commissioner Jack Terhune, is intended to keep drugs more than hacksaws out of prisons.

title: Mystery Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Schindler, Chip Wallach
description: Rabbi Judith Rachel Schindler and Charles F. Wallach are to be married this afternoon at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., where the bride was until recently the associate rabbi. Rabbi Alexander Schindler, the bride's father and the emeritus president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, is to perform the ceremony. Rabbi Richard Jacobs, the chief rabbi of the Westchester Reform Temple, is to take part in the service.

title: From China, Guides to the Next Life
description: RIGHT now the Bruce Museum in Greenwich has two major exhibitions and they are worlds apart. ''Spinning Spheres and Whirling Wheels'' is about play. Just outside its doors is ''Seeking Immortality,'' which concerns death, but paradoxically it is zestful, too.

title: Designing Woman
description: Mommy Dressing

title: Michelin Offers Guide To 3 Northeast States
description: Michelin has just published its first green guide for New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The 376-page tourist guide discusses such sights as the Adirondacks, Niagara Falls, the Hudson River Valley, New York City, Atlantic City, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Lancaster County, Pa.

title: They Do Windows
description: The Microsoft File

title: The Money's Great -- And I'm Worth It
description: People will tell me to my face that I'm overpaid, but they're always drunk. Nobody ever has the guts to do it when they're not. You walk away, because that's a no-winner, and because they're probably right. I am overpaid, and I'm thankful for that. I was born with the God-given talent to play hockey better than most people, and I went with it.

title: Ms. Wahlers, Mr. Connors
description: Elisabeth Roche Wahlers, the daughter of Sheila Whalen Wahlers of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Galvin Connors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Connors of Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Kevin McGrath performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Susannah R. Smith, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Out for a Spin
description: The marriage of fashion and exotic cars goes back to the early years of the century, when Paris couture designers often showed their innovative designs at the automobile shows, amongst the Bugattis, the Rolls-Royces and Duesenberg's ''flights of imagination'' -- the theme of the third annual Louis Vuitton Classic car show and competition. The three-day exhibit included 50 rare cars set on the streets and in the Channel Gardens of Rockefeller Center, and ended with a parade and awards ceremony on Oct. 4. Guests in the grandstand wore traditional, classic clothes. The best of show went to the 1907 Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost, center far right, driven by its owner, Terry Cohen. His wife, Anne, bottom right, accepted the trophy and a jeroboam of Champagne. The exhibit included many vintage racing cars, like the 1934 Bugatti Type 54, top right, which needed a push to start the engine.

title: Shakespearean Soaps For Complicated Times
description: ''HILL STREET BLUES'' was the first cop show that ever made me cry. If it had been a film instead of a television series, Hollywood wouldn't have known whether to call it a crime picture or a relationship movie.

title: Few Signs Of Advances For Women On Boards
description: A RECENT survey by a women's research group found that the boards of directors of 71 companies among the Fortune 500 were made up entirely of men.

title: Ms. Sweeney And Mr. Singer
description: Catherine Ellen Sweeney, the director of the Winter Antiques Show in New York, was married yesterday to William Merritt Singer, an architect. Canon Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York. The Rev. Peter Murray, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Unearthing the Roots of a Repressed Past
description: Race is quite possibly the most pernicious four-letter word in American history. From race riots to race cards, the Civil War to civil rights, it has been a source of discord almost since a Dutch ship unloaded a cargo of some 20 Africans in Jamestown harbor in 1619. Where blacks have seen years of bigotry and hatred, whites have as often seen a history marked by accommodation and mistrust. The goal of racial harmony has been elusive, and as a result America largely remains, in the words of the social historian Andrew Hacker, ''two nations,'' one white, one black.

title: The Difference Between Night and Day
description: There was one thing missing from Tuesday night's public meeting of the Hunterdon County Board of Freeholders: the public.

title: What Have You Done For Me Lately?
description: Losing is the hardest pill to swallow. So many people use you as an outlet from their everyday lives. If we have a bad game, their day or their week is ruined. It's an unfortunate situation, but that's the nature of the beast.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CERRUTI, LEO E.
description: CERRUTI-Leo E. October 21, 1997. Handsome, brilliant and brave. Loved by Deb, Nina, Wade, Ryan, Rachel and Sarah.

title: Pace Securities Clinic Aids Small Investors
description: SO, you feel that you have been victimized and betrayed by your broker. The problem is you have not lost enough to make it worthwhile for a lawyer to handle your case.

title: Bridging High Mass and High Melodrama
description: SEPTEMBER is filled with the plaintive melodies of Jews asking God to forgive their sins and enter them in the Book of Life. October is spent preparing 50 voices to blend in the musical drama of Mozart's Requiem on All Saints Day.

title: Deco Site Escapes Wrecker
description: The Tunnel Garage, a well-known example of Art Deco architecture on Broome Street just east of the Holland Tunnel, was spared demolition on Wednesday, when the owners withdrew an application for a permit to build a larger garage at the site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, JOSEPH
description: CHASE-Joseph. Beloved husband of Georgine. Devoted father of Bari and Daniel Kalin. Adored grandfather of Skylar. Services were held on Friday.

title: N.Y.R.A. Cuts Signal To OTB Outlets
description: The New York Racing Association stopped sending its television signal of races at Belmont Park to Off-Track Betting shops in New York City yesterday as the two sides approached one year in their struggle over fees.

title: The Beast; Bizbrawl
description: Rupert Murdoch made headlines last month with his $1 billion offer for England's Manchester United soccer club, but he's hardly alone among his fellow media barons. Disney and Time Warner are gobbling up teams and television rights, with relative upstarts like Cablevision close behind. In today's brave new world of sports, when you own the team, the network that carries the games, the print media that analyze the scores and the airwaves from San Diego to Sao Paulo to Singapore, the term ''corporate synergy'' simply doesn't do justice to the power at your command. And for fans who don't think any of this will affect them: Ever heard of pay-per-view?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BELONG TO ME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDENREICH, LILLIAN. CHER
description: FRIEDENREICH - Lillian. Cher ished daughter of Goldie and Abraham. Beloved son David, faithful companion Wilfredo will forever miss you. Rest in eternal peace.

title: Shifting Its Plan, Synagogue Chooses Steakhouse Site
description: Four months after starting controversy with its plan to convert a house on a landmark block into a temple, a Conservative synagogue has changed tack and bought a defunct Sizzler restaurant for the purpose.

title: Miss Broadhead, Mr. Schirm
description: Carolyn Mary Broadhead, a daughter of Sharon and James L. Broadhead of North Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Kurt Alexander Schirm, the son of Lydia Mueller of Davidsonville, Md. The Rev. George Andrews 2d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Lost Tree Chapel.

title: If Money Is All, Then Something's Wrong; Is Something Missing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoblauch Gives the Fans Something to Cheer About
description: Chuck Knoblauch delivered a thank-you note of sorts last night the moment he sent a pitch arching like a rainbow just over the glove of San Diego's Greg Vaughn, who was scaling the left-field wall like a skateboarder.

title: 'Common Folk' Pledging Their Homes to Free Gotti's Son
description: In a modest corner of the Marine Park section of Brooklyn is a modest home where a modest couple string Christmas lights in the winter and plant tomatoes in the spring.

title: The Eyes Have It
description: ''MYSELF, My Camera, My World,'' an exhibition of photographs by Mercer County children who were once homeless, opened last week at the First Union National Bank in Trenton.

title: Pulling Strings? Not With These Puppets
description: A little over a year ago, a strange videotape arrived at the offices of MTV: on it, two sock puppets, adorned with the remnants of a plastic sunflower, discussed popular music and sang original songs about llamas, the fake blood used in vampire movies and their fervent desire to be rock stars. The video's creators, two childhood friends, Matt Crocco and Liam Lynch, both 27, were accomplished musicians but novices in the world of filmmaking. Now their puppet alter egos -- two pals named Sifl and Olly -- have become MTV's newest stars, as hosts of a half-hour late-night variety show featuring music, interviews, comic sketches, and nearly 150 supporting characters, all of them puppets.

title: PULSE; TO DIAL FOR
description: My Twinn: (800) 469-8946 or www.mytwinn.com

title: Giants May Turn to Cardinals' Moore for a Big-Play Receiver
description: One possible answer to the Giants' offensive problems will be playing at Giants Stadium today. A Giants assistant coach said last week his team would love to steal Rob Moore from the Cardinals when the wide receiver becomes an unrestricted free agent at the end of this season.

title: Go Hollywood? Sir Ian Rather Likes the Idea
description: THERE is something rather touching about Ian McKellen's new enthusiasm for cinema. During a long stage career, he has won all the honors (including a knighthood) that are the due of great English actors. His interpretations of such roles as Macbeth, Iago, Richard III and Uncle Vanya are considered generational benchmarks. Yet now, at 59, he has acquired an appetite to work in movies, to do what for the best part of four decades he found unappealing.

title: How Long Is a Marathon?
description: NOT once in 16 years of measuring footraces, including today's Atlantic City Marathon, has Gene Newman ever used a ruler, yardstick or tape measure. And he would never trust his van's odometer.

title: POSTINGS: 127 Apartments at 108th Street; Assisted Living On Fifth Ave.
description: Construction is to start this month on the first rental apartment building in Manhattan with meals and support services for low- and moderate-income elderly residents. The $23 million de Sales Assisted Living project will rise on what is now a parking lot at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 108th Street. When it is completed, in 2000, there will be 127 apartments in a 14-story building overlooking Central Park.

title: For Fledging L.I. Entrepreneurs, A Modest Boost to Independence
description: MARY LATINI, a classically trained pianist from Cold Spring Harbor, always worked hard, but always struggled financially. Last year, she nearly lost that struggle.

title: October 11-17; Big Layoffs at Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, sent a shudder through Wall Street -- and New York City -- when it said it would get rid of 3,400 jobs, or a little more than 5 percent of its work force.

title: The View From/Yorktown; When a Dog Is Not a Pet But a Partner in Life
description: STACY BLAIR remembers the first time he was alone in a room with Guthrie. ''I knew from the very first how it would be,'' he recalled. ''I said to him, 'Guthrie, you're my dog and I love you. You're going to be mine.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAUGHAN, MADELINE P.
description: VAUGHAN-Madeline P. (Gartland), 86, died October 14, 1998 at the home of her daughter, Nancy Van Deusen in Watertown, Conn. Devoted wife of the late Robert B. Vaughan, Executive Vice-President of The Emigrant Savings Bank. Mrs. Vaughan was born on December 10, 1911 in New York City, daughter of the late William & Briget (Boyle) Gartland. She formerly lived in Roslyn and Shelter Island, New York before moving back to CT. She worked for the American Red Cross at their New York City headquarters & later in the Roslyn school system. She leaves 3 daughters, Nancy Van Deusen of Watertown; Judith Mendlinger of New York City; Jane Aronowsky of Clinton, NY, a sister, Anna McCallum of Southold, NY & two granddaughters, Leah & Ellen. Funeral Mass 10AM Monday, Oct. 19 at St. John's Church, Watertown. Calling hours, 7-9PM Sunday at Hickcox Funeral Home, 195 Main St., Watertown. Burial Shelter Island, NY Tuesday.

title: Wisconsin Welfare Experiment: Easy to Say, Not So Easy to Do
description: In building a bridge from welfare to work, Wisconsin, perhaps more than any other state, has prided itself on doing things right. It has spent heavily and pledged lavishly to give poor families the tools they need, from baby sitters and bus passes to case managers and community service jobs. On paper, no state has done more to replace welfare checks with workers' supports.

title: Children's Books
description: YOU NEVER KNOW

title: One Big Inning Gives the Yankees a 1-0 Lead
description: Letting no pitcher or deficit deter them in their quest for irrevocable greatness, the Yankees struck for seven runs on two home runs in the seventh inning last night and overpowered the San Diego Padres, 9-6, in the first game of the World Series at Yankee Stadium.

title: Banned in Lima
description: TORN FROM THE NEST By Clorinda Matto de Turner. Translated by John H. R. Polt. 174 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONHEIM, DAVID
description: BRONHEIM-David. Not a day goes by that we don't think of you, miss you-your wisdom, wit and insight, and wish with all our hearts that you were still here. Jeff and Liz

title: Two-Way Street
description: THE 8 A.M. Sunday service at St. Anthony's Church has just let out, but Sullivan Street is nearly empty. SoHo has yet to fill with its weekend crush of shoppers and tourists, and the neighborhood hipsters are still sleeping off last night's adventures. As Anna Maggio, 91, heads home to her fourth-floor walkup, a light drizzle falls.

title: Finding a Mate to Build a Portfolio
description: FOR a year, Edward Lecomte listened to an incessant stream of talk about ''the market.'' Friends boasted about booming stock portfolios, his sister made a bundle in a mutual fund and colleagues badgered him to jump on the bandwagon. So last winter, Mr. Lecomte, 37, decided it was time to become a player.

title: Police Search for Robbers Posing as Utility Workers
description: Brooklyn detectives are searching for a ring of men suspected of posing as utility employees to gain entry to the homes of elderly residents and rob them, the police said.

title: When Ironing Is Not an Option
description: THE ''indispensable'' travel dress is headlined in one catalogue. Another highlights clothes ''designed specifically for the rigors of world travel.'' ''Pack with less bulk,'' says the redoubtable L. L. Bean, never one to squander syllables.

title: The Cost of Hanging In There
description: I'm from Faribault, Minn., a town of about 15,000, and the other night I went to a football game at my old high school and a guy asked me, What do you make, $40,000, $50,000 a year playing minor-league ball? I told him it's more like $9,000 or $10,000 a year. He's like: No you don't. I had no idea. A lot of people have no idea. When you figure out the hours we work, we make less than the minimum wage.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CATCH

title: Just Call Them Glads and Move On From There
description: SOME worthy plants are victims of gardeners' prejudice, among them marigolds, because of their scent; goldenrod, because it resembles ragweed, and gladioluses, because they are so often the flower of choice at funerals.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 18, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Challengers Buck History In Elections
description: ONLY three times in the last three decades have Westchester voters failed to return an incumbent Congressman to office, and in two of those instances extraordinary circumstances were involved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, SARA (SHIRLEY)
description: RUDIN-Sara (Shirley). Age 95. On October 17, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nat. Loving mother of Janet Anzelowitz, Charlotte and Sheldon Brodie, and Susan and Ira Rudin. Devoted grandmother of Lois, Steven, Martha, Barnett, Elizabeth and Eric. Great-grandmother of Aubree, Daniel and Max. Services Monday, October 19, at 1:30 PM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

description: To the Editor:

title: As Bochy Knows, There Is Little Relief in Sight for the Padres
description: Now everyone knows why Bruce Bochy, the San Diego manager, summoned Kevin Brown to make a rare relief appearance in the fifth game of the National League Championship Series against Atlanta.

description: CYRIL CONNOLLY

title: Peace Laurels Refresh Ulster Protestant's Optimism on Progress
description: One day after he won the Nobel Peace Prize, David Trimble, the most powerful Protestant leader in Northern Ireland, said today that he was distinctly optimistic about prospects for advancing the peace effort in this predominantly Protestant British province.

title: Is P.S. 166's Principal Going?
description: Jack Regan, the principal of Public School 166, on 89th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, elicits strong feelings from parents of children who attend his elementary school. And when word went around recently that he might retire, emotions ran high among his supporters and his opponents. Was he really going to step down?

title: To Students, Having a Beeper Isn't a Close Call Despite Law
description: Stephanie Redfern, a student at Ocean Township High School, was running to class one day when a beeper fell out of her pocket.

title: DataBank: October 12-16; The Fed Breathes Life Into the Markets
description: The Federal Reserve unexpectedly trimmed interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point late on Thursday, and it was like a 1998 version of the shot heard round the world. Investors everywhere went on a buying spree.

title: A Detour in the Theater That No One Predicted
description: IF you love the theater, or are part of it, or even writing about it, then everything's a drama.

title: 'Never at War'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice as Rare in Type as in Beauty
description: EWA PODLES does not want to be compared with other contraltos. ''I do not like talk of all contraltos,'' she said. ''I am me, Ewa Podles. I do not like when people say, 'She sings like Marilyn Horne, but Marilyn Horne did this passage this way.' If you want to hear Marilyn Horne, go listen to Marilyn Horne.''

title: A Town That Big Dreams Built
description: IN 1887 in the booming settlement of Port Townsend, Washington Territory, a prosperous Maine-born contractor and occasional rum-runner named George Starrett married Ann Van Boklen, a hometown girl. At the time of the wedding, local Indian uprisings were a none-too-distant memory and Washington statehood was another two years away, but Port Townsend -- on the northeast corner of the Olympic Peninsula -- already seemed destined for prominence.

title: Q&A/Sarwar A. Kashmeri; Helping Businesses Prepare for the Euro
description: AS many focus on the coming of the millennium and the expected havoc it could play with computers, Sarwar A. Kashmeri is reminding people that a date perhaps even more significant is coming up sooner: Jan. 1, 1999. That is when 11 European countries will replace their currencies with one joint currency, the euro. And the effect will be a shot heard around the world, said Mr. Kashmeri, a resident of Mount Kisco and president of Niche Systems, a Manhattan-based consulting company, which has been offering seminars to help businesses prepare for the euro. He also has a Web site (www.nsinc.com).

description: A SEASON IN HELL

description: 'No Pet' Rules in a Conversion

title: Troubled Times Arise at Southampton Hospital
description: IN his four-and-a-half years as president and chief executive of Southampton Hospital, Dr. John J. Ferry Jr. had seemed to be everything that the top administrator of a private hospital in the Hamptons should be.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Blasphemy? Again? Somebody's Praying for a Hit.
description: IT'S been a good month for blasphemy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPIR, FANNIE
description: SAPIR-Fannie. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of the beloved mother of our dedicated Board of Directors member, Harriet Seif, who together with her devoted husband Heshi, are magnanimous benefactors of our AMIT children in Israel. A righteous woman of valor, Fannie Sapir epitimized courage, compassion, family and Torah values. May her memory be a blessing to her children, grandchildren and Klal Yisrael. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Dir.

title: The Product; Ryan's Song
description: If Ryan Leaf, the rookie quarterback of the San Diego Chargers, wants to have big-media, Michael Jordan-style marketing fame, he can pretty much forget it. It doesn't matter that last January he led Washington State to its first Rose Bowl appearance since 1931 or that he went No. 2 in the draft and received an $11 million signing bonus. It doesn't even matter that he has a winning smile and a colorful, bad-boy image. (He supposedly hit on the wife of a prominent quarterback and recently aimed a football at the head of a local reporter.)

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: VACATION PLANNING

title: Return of the Stay Morons
description: WHEN ANGELS REST By Donald Harington. 250 pp. Washington: Counterpoint. $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELGADO DETORRES, MERCEDES SALVADOR
description: DELGADO deTorres-Mercedes Salvador. Born December 28, 1907, Madrid, Spain. Died July 2, 1998, at Beth Israel Hospital, New York. Widow of Demetrio Delgado deTorres. Pre-deceased by her eldest son Juan. She is survived by her three children, Ines, Pablo, and Miguel, and five grandchildren, Maud Kozodoy, Fergus Kinnell, Lena Delgado deTorres, Christian and Andreas Delgado deTorres. In lieu of flowers, donations by friends may be made in her memory to: Spanish Refugee Aid, A Division of International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42 Street, New York, New York 10168-1289.

title: The Quarter-Acre Universe
description: Geraldine Brooks's Lives essay demonstrates a fond nostalgia for her childhood (Sept. 27). It's fun to play with our children the games we played when we were young. But it's important to realize that coaching young children is not the way to unlock their imaginations. Parents can provide the tools -- a few toys with good ''play value,'' books, the great outdoors and lots of unstructured playtime (with the TV off) -- but they should let the child decide what to do with them. Showing children that you can make a hat out of a leaf is just another way to entertain them. When they can figure out for themselves that a leaf can become a hat, a doll blanket or a boat, that's imagination.

title: October 11-17; 5 Theorists Win Nobels
description: In a clean sweep of the 1998 Nobel prizes in chemistry and physics, five professors at American universities garnered a total of $1.96 million for their masterly applications of the arcane rules of quantum mechanics.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHY SINATRA MATTERS

title: Headache, Thy Name Is 'Hedge Fund'
description: BankAmerica said it would eat $372 million of a $1.3 billion unsecured loan to D. E. Shaw & Company, a hedge-fund manager, and would take over and liquidate Shaw's entire $20 billion bond portfolio in hopes of recouping the rest. The bank's bum hedge-fund loan, rotten trading results, write-downs on a mortgage-servicing portfolio and merger-related charges hammered third-quarter earnings down 80 percent from a year earlier. . . . Another hedge fund, Ellington Capital Management, dumped a huge position in mortgage-backed securities to cover margin calls from its lenders and stave off insolvency. . . . Merrill Lynch demoted the executive in charge of managing the firm's financial risk-taking, two days after reporting a steep quarterly loss related to market turmoil and saying it would lay off 5 percent of its staff.

title: Halloween Arrives Early as Fairies Alight at Frick
description: THE SETTING -- Think sylph. Dryad. Nymph. Naiad. Elf. A mob of fanciful creatures roaming twilight Victorian bowers in, of all places, the Henry Clay Frick Mansion.

title: Albanian Student Looks Past Asylum
description: AFTER months of fighting for political asylum, Edmond Coku, 18, is breathing easily again. Fearful that if he returned to Albania, the country of his childhood, he would share the fate of his grandfather, Mr. Coku waged a hard-fought battle with the United States Government this summer -- and won.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, MINNA.
description: MICHAEL-Minna. On October 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Ephraim and the late Olga Gladstone. Adoring grandmother of Candi Sue Scott, Robin Wilson and the late Carol Arava, and greatgrandmother of Adam Chait, Jeffrey Chait and Zaran Arava. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, October 19th, 11:30 A.M. Burial to follow at Beth-El Cemetery, Queens. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Brotherhood Synagogue or Cabrini Medical Center.

title: Greening A School's Reputation
description: For 17-year-old Anastasia Bakakoulis, describing the 4,600 students who attend John F. Kennedy High School is easy. ''Kennedy has hooligans and other kids,'' she said.

title: The View From/Stratford; Jazz, With Walk-Ons, As It Once Was Played
description: PATRONS sitting at the bar at Pepin's in Stratford can look over the top of the musicians' heads and see a sliver of traffic whizzing by on Interstate 95, a sort of Arthur Milleresque view, symbolic of the fast-paced life outside this restaurant and club.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; It's Not Over Till Everybody Sings
description: Opera is an art form that has always required the collaboration of many different kinds of people, all of them, to judge by THE STORY OF OPERA (Abrams, $49.50), at least a little neurotic. About Mlle. de Maupin (1673?-1707), a famous French contralto, for example, Richard Somerset-Ward, a former head of music and arts programming for BBC Television, writes, ''She made her debut as a 22-year-old in one of Lully's operas at the Academie, but by then she had (in no particular order) married, run away with a fencing master, taken vows as a nun in order to get into a nunnery to seduce a girl with whom she had fallen in love, and been condemned by a court in Avignon to be burned alive.'' This book, with a fascinating and handsome picture or two on every page, is a serious and lively history. The story begins in the late 16th century and continues up to the present, tracing the swervings toward and away from drama that are the form's essence. Plenty of mediocre operas have been composed for famous castrati and prima donnas, but the most important opera composers have always sought to involve the audience in a human drama by creating music that powerfully expresses the text. ''What changed in the 20th century was that opera finally became a genuine branch of theater,'' Somerset-Ward writes. ''The drama got on equal terms with the music.'' This book persuasively describes opera as a thriving, complex art that has never been more appealing than it is right now. Rick Whitaker

title: The League; David Stern's Full-Court Press
description: Many of the National Basketball Association's best-known players gathered at Madison Square Garden in September for a charity exhibition game straight from the Last Days of Disco. Because of a labor dispute between the N.B.A. and the N.B.A. Players Association -- a dispute jeopardizing the coming season, which was set to begin Nov. 3 -- the game was held without the league's involvement, and it felt like 1978 all over again. Scoring was rampant and defense nonexistent. Low-tech music echoed off the walls, and there were none of the slick videos that fill dead time in today's N.B.A. arenas. The players' generic uniforms were unadorned by those cartoonish logos that drive souvenir sales. Most important, the Garden was only one-third full, a turnout more typical of N.B.A. games during the Carter Administration. The whole affair was a stark reminder of what pro basketball might have been without David Stern, the commissioner who has established a new paradigm for the marketing of sports.

title: FLASHING BACK WITH: Grace Slick; Still a Rock 'n' Roll Mama
description: SOMEHOW the Palm Court at the Plaza Hotel, with its harpist and doilied dessert plates, seems like the last place where Grace Slick would want to meet. But here she comes, dressed mostly in black, looking startlingly like herself even though the Feed Your Head Queen of Jefferson Airplane, the voice that launched a thousand trips with her 1960's anthem ''White Rabbit,'' turns 60 next year. Judging from how good she looks, either she took far fewer drugs than anyone imagined, or the cosmetics industry should start marketing an LSD eye cream.

title: Hate-Crimes and Punishment
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sports of The Times; Sense of Inevitability Pervades This Series
description: SOMETIMES, these stories just seem preordained, and it is up to someone -- Kirk Gibson comes to mind -- to step up and dramatically alter destiny's plans. But no one has limped heroically to the plate in the 1998 World Series for the San Diego Padres, the way Gibson did for the Dodgers against Oakland a decade ago. No one has fought off the flu bug or the assembly line of Yankee bats. The Padres seem caught in the viselike grip of inevitability, looking last night like the dot under the exclamation point to a record Yankees season.

title: It's Big Fun Deluxe On the West Coast
description: In the Midwest or South, 79 points and 985 yards of total offense usually mean that Ohio State or Florida has rolled over some hapless nonconference opponent. Out West, it gets you U.C.L.A. out-high-wiring Oregon in overtime Saturday night, 41-38, in the most thrilling game of the season.

title: Vergennes Prevails At Belmont Park
description: Vergennes, a model of consistency at the age of 3, ran in the money for the ninth time in 12 starts this year when he won the 50th Jamaica Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday by two lengths over Tangazi.

title: 'Beloved' Appeals Mainly in Big Cities
description: Movie audiences over the weekend responded tentatively to ''Beloved,'' despite lavish promotion by its studio, the Walt Disney Company, and its star and producer, Oprah Winfrey.

title: Johnson Talks, Stalking the Limelight
description: All Keyshawn Johnson has ever wanted is to be the star.

title: In One East Texas Town, the Bloom Is Off the Rose
description: When this year's Rose Queen walked onto the stage on Thursday night in her jeweled gown with a 16-foot train, she became part of a tradition dating to 1933, when this East Texas town may have actually deserved its nickname, ''Rose Capital of the Nation.''

title: A Peace Agreement That's Bound to Fail
description: The Clinton Administration claims that it has made progress toward bringing peace to Kosovo. Don't believe it. The deal arranged by Richard Holbrooke is likely to fail sooner rather than later.

title: Officials Accused of Atrocities Losing Places to Hide, Scholars Say
description: The arrest of Gen. Augusto Pinochet shows the growing significance of international human rights law, suggesting that officials accused of atrocities have fewer places to hide these days, even if they are carrying diplomatic passports, legal scholars say.

title: Arrest Raises New Issues On Tracking Rights Crimes
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator arrested here at the request of a Spanish judge, remained sequestered under police guard today, awaiting a potentially devastating court hearing to weigh his extradition on charges of genocide, terrorism and murder.

title: Religious Circumcision In a Changing World
description: Like any other group of professional colleagues meeting for a conference, the members of the national organization of men and women certified by the Reform Jewish movement to perform ritual circumcisions had but one focus of conversation this weekend: shop talk.

title: For Better Land Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASEY, ELIZABETH F.
description: CASEY-Elizabeth F. October 19, 1960-January 30, 1998. Lizzie you're loved forever and missed so much. Always in our minds and hearts, especially on your birthday. Your bright light shines over us and warms us. The Casey Family

title: MIDEAST  MEETING WILL BE CONTINUED INTO ANOTHER DAY
description: Despite more than 20 hours of personal engagement by President Clinton, talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders on an interim peace accord will continue past their original deadline and into Monday, American officials announced this evening.

title: The Underdog Hitchcock Ready for His Day
description: Never mind that Sterling Hitchcock has already outpitched Randy Johnson, Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine this post-season.

title: Piazza Puts Off Met Talks
description: Mike Piazza's representatives have apparently postponed a meeting scheduled for today in Los Angeles with Mets General Manager Steve Phillips, a person familiar with discussions between the team and its All-Star catcher said yesterday.

title: Legal 'Fetters,' For Clinton and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamptons Festival Focuses On Comedy
description: Since its beginning, the Hamptons International Film Festival here has been searching for an identity, and perhaps it has found one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIEDRICK, ARTHUR HILL, M.D.
description: DIEDRICK-Arthur Hill, M.D. On October 16, 1998 of Rye, N.Y. Devoted husband of the late Ann. Father of Arthur Hill Diedrick, Jr. of Litchfield, CT; Dinah Beverly of Brandywine, WV; Lawrence Gilyard Diedrick of Rocky Mount, N.C.; and William Brice Diedrick of Rye, N.Y. Grandfather of 11 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends Sunday, 5-7 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y. A memorial service will be held Monday, October 19, 1998 at 11 A.M. at Rye Presbyterian Church. Interment service private. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospital, Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Challenger Presses Dodd In Lopsided Senate Race
description: A man with little to lose makes a dangerous debate opponent. So in mock debates, aides to Senator Christopher J. Dodd have been trying to rattle him in preparation for going lectern-to-lectern this week with his Republican challenger, Gary A. Franks, a former Congressman with low poll ratings.

title: Serb Forces Leaving Kosovo, But at a Slow Pace, U.S. Says
description: Yugoslavia has begun to withdraw two army and police battalions from Kosovo in what NATO and Clinton Administration officials described today as a significant step by President Slobodan Milosevic toward complying with demands to end his campaign against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians.

title: In England, It's North vs. South
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Goes to Court
description: Shortly before the Government filed its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation in May, Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in change of the Justice Department's antitrust division, met with a Silicon Valley executive. The executive recalls telling Mr. Klein that unless a case went beyond the Internet browser market, it would have little effect on Microsoft's power to stifle competition across the computer industry.

title: Posada Bound to Hernandez by Trust
description: Jorge Posada has been 60 feet 6 inches away from the incredibly unfolding story of Orlando Hernandez all season. Virtually every time Hernandez has hiked his left knee up around his ear in his funky motion, Posada has been behind the plate waiting to see what will transpire. Usually, Hernandez has produced positive developments.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Possible Kroger Merger Draws Traders' Interest

title: Mourning Became Frick as an Art Collector
description: In the month before Henry Clay Frick died in 1919, he would descend at night from his second-floor, wood-paneled bedroom to the ground floor of his Fifth Avenue mansion, which is today the Frick Collection. He would sit in the dark, ashes accumulating on his cigar, and stare at one of his many paintings, which would be lit by only a small spotlight. After a time, he would move to another masterpiece.

title: Legal 'Fetters,' For Clinton and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: An ABC News Reporter Tests the Boundaries of Investigating Disney and Finds Them
description: With 20 years' experience as an investigative reporter, Brian Ross of ABC News knows a good story when he hears one. He is also not stupid. He knew the story he heard last spring might raise difficulties because it involved ABC's parent, the Walt Disney Company, but he thought he had enough solid information to pursue it.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Barney, Mob Suspect, Says He's the Wrong Barney
description: They are cousins with the same name, Liborio Bellomo, the same nickname, Barney, and, law enforcement authorities say, the same occupation: mobster.

title: Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Advice About Clothing And a Snug Fit for the Ads
description: For anyone who has wondered who invented dry cleaning or how to care for mohair, Martha Stewart has come to the rescue. This month, Martha Stewart Living published a special issue titled ''Clotheskeeping,'' devoted to the maintenance of -- and how to choose -- classic clothing.

title: Dysfunctional, to Say the Least
description: A lot of beer, a little reefer, a whole lot of television: as a steady diet, these ingredients don't exactly sharpen the powers of concentration. And for the mush-minded Smiths, the homicidal, trashy Texas family in ''Killer Joe,'' Tracy Letts's terrifically tasty potboiler at the SoHo Playhouse, focus mostly means getting a better picture on the tube.

title: U.S.-Microsoft Trial Is Set to Open Today
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the Government are scheduled to go to trial today in an antitrust case that extends well beyond the original charges that Microsoft attempted to monopolize the market for so-called browser software used for navigating the Internet. Since the suit was filed in May, the case has come to embrace what the Justice Department described in a recent Federal court filing as ''a broad pattern of anticompetitive conduct'' by Microsoft to stifle competition across the computer industry.

title: Media Talk; The Los Angeles Times Assembles a 'Latino Team'
description: In its effort to broaden coverage of minority communities and meet its ambitious circulation goals, The Los Angeles Times is establishing an 11-member ''Latino team'' that will include reporters in the business, cultural, sports and general news departments. It will meet daily and plan coverage of Latino issues throughout the newspaper.

title: Quick Change in San Diego
description: The Padres are scheduled to work out in San Diego at 4 P.M. today Pacific time, with the Yankees following at 5:30.

title: Hampel/Stefanides To Be Acquired
description: The agency world is getting smaller again as another independent shop is being acquired.

title: Who Leads the Flock?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, JAMES PATRICK
description: McFADDEN-James Patrick. On October 17, 1998. Editor of The Human Life Review. Beloved husband of Faith (nee Abbott). Loving father of Maria Maffucci, Patrick, Regina and Christina McFadden and the late Robert Arthur McFadden II. Adoring grandfather of James Anthony and Anna Clare. Dear brother of Thomas and Edward McFadden, Rita Ward, Louise Boelger, Jean Jenkins and the late Robert Arthur McFadden. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Agnes Church, 143 E. 43 St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Mr. Sherman's 1890 Nod to Populism Has Often Been Broadly Interpreted
description: The legal tool that the Government is using in its assault on the Microsoft Corporation -- the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 -- is brief, vague and malleable. The combination has meant that this bedrock statute of antitrust policy has been at turns toothless and powerful over the years, depending on the politics and economics of the day as interpreted by the courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLEDGE, M. PAULINE
description: RUTLEDGE-M. Pauline, 103, long-time Principal, Brooklyn Ethical Culture School (1936-1963), former resident of NYC, at Dowden Retirement Home, Newtown Square, PA, on October 14th. Inquiries: call 610-356-8348.

title: Hernandez Leaves the Padres Both Impressed and Frustrated
description: Almost everyone in a somber San Diego Padres clubhouse seemed impressed with Orlando Hernandez last night. Almost everyone except Wally Joyner, that is.

title: Penguins Go From Cup Chapters to Chapter 11
description: A bankrupt franchise in a healthy sports league is like a neglected house on a pleasant and prosperous street. The decaying dwelling may be surrounded by neat homes with trim lawns, painted gutters and clean picture windows. But it is difficult to ignore the eyesore next door with the overgrown shrubs, the plywood over the broken glass and the police car in the driveway to break up the fight between the dysfunctional spouses.

title: Former Student Faces Trial in '97 Slaying
description: Opening arguments are to begin today in the trial of Corey Arthur, a 20-year-old accused of torturing and killing his former English teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, for his banking card.

title: Hyundai Wins Auction to Take Over Kia Motors
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's biggest auto maker, today won an auction for the insolvent Kia Motors Corporation, offering the highest bid among four candidates, Kia said.

title: Martinez's Bat Booms for Teammate
description: Chuck Knoblauch and Tino Martinez have more in common than heroics in Game 1 of the World Series. Knoblauch began using Martinez's bats during the American League Championship Series and was swinging a Martinez model when he hit his game-tying three-run home run in the seventh-inning comeback Saturday night.

title: Another Trophy For U.S. Eight
description: The 34th annual Head of the Charles race in Cambridge, Mass., turned into a victory parade for the world champion United States national team eight yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, COURTNEY
description: STEEL-Courtney. The soul takes flight to the world that is invisible and there arriving she is sure of bliss and forever dwells in paradise. M.A

title: Time Out, at 30, Plots for Further Expansion
description: Looking for the latest anti-apartheid protest or Jethro Tull gig? Thirty years ago -- before history claimed such events as its grist -- the place to look was Time Out, then a start-up listings magazine produced by a 21-year-old British college graduate.

title: Too Late on Health
description: To the Editor:

title: An Upstart Talent Agency Blossoms Quickly
description: Marty Adelstein, a partner at the Endeavor talent agency in Beverly Hills, vividly recalled his first day at the upstart company three years ago when he walked into his cramped office located then above a hamburger restaurant. He picked up the phone to dial one of his top clients, David E. Kelley, the writer-producer of hit shows like ''Ally McBeal'' and ''The Practice.''

title: On Baseball; No Field, No Hit, No Pitch, No Hope
description: In the opening game of the World Series, the San Diego Padres' relief corps failed them. In the second game last night, everything else went -- starting pitching, hitting and fielding. But when all else fails, a team's defense, especially the defense of a team in the World Series, should hold together. That made the Yankees' 9-3 victory so much more painful for the Padres.

title: El Duque Fever
description: Pedro Bello felt he had to do something to celebrate the improbable rise of his fellow Cuba native, Orlando (El Duque) Hernandez, from mere balsero -- which means rafter in Spanish -- to World Series starter in less than eight months.

title: Batting Ninth, a Newly Minted Hero
description: Ricky Ledee was tired yesterday after half a day of feeling more like a telephone operator than the left fielder for the Yankees. From the time he wandered into his hotel room in Manhattan at 3 A.M. until the moment he left for Yankee Stadium near 3 P.M., Ledee said his phone rang 30 times. His bleary brown eyes and droopy shoulders were evidence of his weariness.

title: Ruling Today by Arbitrator On Guaranteed Contracts
description: More than 220 National Basketball Association players with guaranteed contracts will find out today whether they are to be paid during the management lockout, a long-awaited arbitrator's decision that may affect leverage in the league's dispute with the players and have major ramifications on American sports-labor law.

title: Boehringer vs. Knoblauch
description: In the eighth inning of Game 1, Chuck Knoblauch stepped out of the batter's box twice in succession against the San Diego right-hander Brian Boehringer -- Knoblauch said yesterday that he was bothered by flashing lights on the scoreboard -- and Boehringer began screaming at Knoblauch.

title: Why Wye?
description: Newly confident after a meeting with Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov in Moscow (at which that longtime K.G.B. Arabist offered ''unconditional support for Palestinian peace efforts''), Yasir Arafat took much of the zip out of President Clinton's pre-election October surprise.

title: Heart of Gold: Young's Annual Rite of Passage
description: In its 12 years, the Bridge School Benefit, an annual concert put on by Neil Young at the Shoreline Amphitheater just outside the city, has become a rite of passage for rock bands. It is a chance to spend a weekend in the world Mr. Young has created for himself, a rigidly defined yet easygoing system in which music, family, nature and personal obsessions (toy trains, in Mr. Young's case) exist in eternal balance.

title: Tyson Shifts His Strategy In Nevada
description: For the second time in 30 days, Mike Tyson will appear before the Nevada State Athletic Commission here Monday and try to convince its five members that he should be given back his boxing license.

title: India and Pakistan Agree Only to Future Talks
description: On the third and final day of talks between Indian and Pakistani diplomats, the world's two newest nuclear powers announced today that they had agreed only to keep talking to each other about ways to reduce the risk of nuclear conflict between them.

title: Older Brother Is Accused Of Killing the Younger
description: A 39-year-old man was stabbed to death by his older brother early yesterday morning in the apartment they shared in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMLER, JUDGE JOSEPH H.
description: STAMLER-Judge Joseph H. At his home in Stony Creek, CT. Formerly of Summit, NJ. Leaves his wife Lillian Spitzer Stamler, son Joseph H. Stamler, Jr., and wife Ann of Fairfield, CT, and son S. Paul Stamler and wife Amy of Stony Creek, CT, grandchildren Abigail Hopkins Stamler, S. Reed Stamler, Theodore Joseph Stamler, and stepgrandson Forrest Page. Funeral arrangements are private. Memorial contributions may be made to: Willoughby Wallace Memorial Library, 146 Thimble Islands Rd., Stony Creek, CT 06405; Rescue Company #

title: Yankees Crush Padres by 9-3 And Go West With 2-0 Lead
description: The San Diego Padres are the National League champions, conquerors of their domain. Facing the Yankees in the World Series, the Padres look an awful lot like doormats. But then, so does every other team the Yankees play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MAYNARD
description: PARKER-Maynard. Age 58, died of complications of leukemia on October 16. As reporter, editor, friend, father and husband, he was the best of the best. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, October 22, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. In lieu of flowers please make contributions in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. CHAI, Concern for Helping Animals in Israel (POB 3341, Alexandria, VA 22302) mourns the loss of a devoted Advisory Board member who strongly supported our Humane Ed. Center and Spay/Neuter Clinic projects. Nina Natelson, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREMER, SAMUEL, ESQ.
description: FREMER-Samuel, Esq. On October 17, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Florence Hans. Loving father of Judith Kotick Hans, Dr. Susan Hans and Michael Fremer. Grandfather of Robert Kotick, Debbie Kotick Gruber, Jonathan Hansburg, David Hansburg, and great-grandfather of Jordan, Morgan and Grace. Graduate of St. John's University Law School, founder of New York Abstract Co., V.P. First American Title Co., expert in the field of real estate law. A private service wil be held Tuesday, October 20.

title: 2 States Consider Boldly Revamping Campaign Finance
description: Around the packed back room of a suburban Boston bar one recent evening, dozens of rain-sodden campaigners summoned the energy for one last refrain. To the tune of the pop chestnut ''King of the Road,'' they sang:

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; Whose Rock Is It? And, Yes, the Haitians Care
description: Columbus stumbled across it in 1504 but never bothered to come back, and later explorers scorned it as a worthless outcropping of rock and bird dung.

title: Brooklyn Couple Held in Tenant's Kidnapping
description: An unusual landlord-tenant dispute ended in a kidnapping and two arrests late Saturday night after a 26-year-old woman from Russia was abducted by a couple who had rented her a Brooklyn apartment, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: In D'Amato Country, Schumer Attacks Him on Environment
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer brought his campaign for the United States Senate to the edge of Long Island Sound today, accepting endorsements from several environmental groups and saying that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had done nothing to protect the waters surrounding his home base of Long Island.

title: Legal 'Fetters,' For Clinton and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Revitalized Giants End Weeks of Misadventure
description: It all looked so familiar at Giants Stadium today -- eight Giants sacks, three long Giants scoring drives, 141 yards rushing, no turnovers and three turnovers forced.

title: Kroger Said to Seek Deal for Fred Meyer
description: Wall Street is speculating that the Kroger Company, the nation's largest supermarket chain, will buy Fred Meyer Inc., the owner of the Ralphs Grocery chain in Southern California and other stores, in a move that would create the first grocery chain spanning most of the nation.

title: Bells and GTE Hope to Win by Losing at Supreme Court
description: There tend to be two sorts of regulatory disputes in the communications industry: the wildly Byzantine and the merely arcane.

title: Big Drug Wholesaler in a $14 Billion Deal
description: The McKesson Corporation, the nation's largest drug distributor, and HBO & Company, the largest supplier of computerized patient-monitoring systems, said yesterday that they would merge in a stock swap valued at about $14 billion.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Girls and Computers
description: A new report by the American Association of University Women shows that a troubling gender gap in computer use exists in high schools. Girls make up only a small percentage of students who take high-level computer courses that might lead to technology careers. Yet they are more likely than boys to take data-entry classes, the high-tech equivalent of typing.

title: Justice May Need Two Trials; Motive Is Important
description: To the Editor:

title: The Seas of Adventure Still Beckon a Storyteller; At 83, Patrick O'Brian Journeys Into History
description: Our meeting was set for noon, but it was after 1 and I was lost. I knew he lived in this little seaside village, but I couldn't find him. So I called from a gas station. ''I'll come along to fetch you,'' he said. ''I'll be in a Deux Chevaux. You can follow me back.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONHEIM, DAVID
description: BRONHEIM-David. Not a day goes by that we don't think of you, miss you-your wisdom, wit and insight, and wish with all our hearts that you were still here. Jeff and Liz

title: Sports of The Times; El Duque's Great Calm Eases the Adjustments
description: ORLANDO HERNANDEZ turned to watch Paul O'Neill soar against the right-field wall for a one-handed catch of Wally Joyner's drive to end the Padres' threat in the first inning last night, just as he had turned to watch O'Neill camp under Jim Thome's deep drive to end the Indians' threat in the first inning a week ago Saturday in Cleveland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, FRIEDA
description: LEVINSON-Frieda. On October 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Philip. Also survived by two loving brothers-in-law, Leo and Fred, sistersin-law Kay and Joan, and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Retired member of the Queens College Choral Group. Memorial services Wednesday, 2 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Memorial Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Censorship or Common Sense?
description: A 5-year-old is not ready to confront the world. This should be obvious, but it doesn't seem that way to many free-speech advocates, who are angry that some libraries around the country have installed software on their computers to block out Internet material that's unsuitable for children.

title: Media Talk; Scandals Don't Much Harm An Already Bad Reputation
description: Has the recent spate of journalistic scandals damaged the media's credibility? There's a good news/bad news answer.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Passers Have Roller-Coaster Week
description: DANNY KANELL was elated yesterday. The Giants had just beaten Arizona, and he had enjoyed the best day of his career: completing 22 of 36 passes for 259 yards and 3 touchdowns.

title: Last Hurrah at the Stadium? Williams Isn't Dwelling on It
description: It was late, just past 11 P.M., and there were parents trying to corral sugar-charged children in one aisle. And there was a guy trying to balance an empty beer cup on his head just a section away at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Samuel Messick, 67, Leader In Educational Testing Field
description: Dr. Samuel J. Messick, a leader in educational testing who argued for restraint in the use of student test scores, died on Oct. 6 at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center in Philadelphia. He was 67 and lived in Pennington, N.J.

title: Treasury Bills Set to Be Offered This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C. Of Redding, CT. Died September 16. There will be a memorial service Saturday, October 24, 1 P.M., St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Oil Pipeline Blast and Fire in Colombia Kill 45, Mostly Villagers; Rebels Are Blamed
description: As the Colombian Government prepared for peace talks with rebels to try to end three decades of civil violence, an explosion believed to be the work of rebels hit the country's most important oil pipeline early today, killing at least 45 people and wounding scores more.

title: Joseph Machlis, 92, Music Textbook Author
description: Joseph Machlis, an author and opera translator whose 1955 textbook ''The Enjoyment of Music'' is one of the most popular music appreciation books published in English, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Slaying and Suicide Leave a Couple Dead
description: An elderly man shot and killed his wife in her wheelchair in their Queens apartment yesterday afternoon, walked out onto their balcony and committed suicide by shooting himself and falling 11 stories, the police said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jonathan B. Postel, a Pioneer Of the Internet, Is Dead at 55
description: Jonathan B. Postel, who played a pivotal role in creating and administering the Internet, died of complications after undergoing heart surgery on Friday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., his brother Thomas Postel said on Saturday. He was 55 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Death-Row Juveniles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHER, TOBIE B.
description: OHER-Tobie B. On October 17. Of Skokie, IL. Mother of Jim (Susan), Kathy and Joe. Grandmother of Sam, Jake and Andrea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, IRWIN S., M.D.
description: LOWENTHAL-Irwin S., M.D. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted, loving father of Lisa, Stacey and Leslie. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: In Their Own Words
description: ALFONSE M. D'AMATO

title: Correction
description: An article on Friday about the New York Senate race misstated the Congressional voting record of the Democratic candidate, Charles E. Schumer. He was present for about 77 percent of the votes this campaign year; he did not miss 77 percent of the votes.

title: H.M.O.'s Cut Off Medicare, Leaving Many in Quandary
description: Tens of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations have suddenly found themselves in a confusing predicament, with no reliable information about their options and no guarantee of coverage for costly prescription drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, HAROLD S.
description: LEWIS-Harold S. October 18, 1998, in his 82nd year. Beloved husband of Marianne, father of Harold and Dale, Leslie and Debra, grandfather of Katherine and Ethan. A distinguished engineer, he was a partner in the New York firm of Jaros, Baum & Bolles. His love of family, home and nature, and his wisdom, illuminated the lives of an adoring family and devoted friends. Private service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Alzheimer's Support Network, 660 Ninth St. N., Naples, FL 34102.

title: China and Taiwan Agree to Keep Their Discussion Going
description: As a senior official from Taiwan ended a landmark visit here, China and Taiwan promised to continue talking but also reiterated their profoundly different visions about the island's political status.

title: Previous Antitrust Cases Leave Room for Both Sides to Cite Them Now
description: The case of United States v. Microsoft Corporation, the Government's most aggressive move against a monopolist in almost 25 years, is playing out against a century of antitrust laws so broadly worded and court rulings so ambiguous that both sides are citing the same rulings to support their opposing arguments.

title: Media Talk; Newsweek May Find New Editor on Its Staff
description: The editor at Newsweek magazine needs the management skills of an eagle-eyed chief executive, the energy of a distance runner and the composure of the Mona Lisa. Maynard Parker, the editor from 1982 until his death on Friday, had all of those qualities, those who worked with him say.

title: Slavery Echoes in the Prism of a Film
description: While film executives raise their eyebrows and ponder the fate of ''Beloved'' as a high-profile ''race movie,'' let us consider other more interesting and honest ways in which it can be seen.

title: Too Late on Health
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS
description: Lack of discipline is starting to surface as a problem for the Devils, who were whistled for eight penalties in their 4-2 loss to Edmonton on Saturday night.

title: Push to Buy Palm Shows Aggression Is Consistent
description: In a recent move that indicated he has no intention of backing away from his company's aggressive business tactics, the Microsoft Corporation's chairman, William H. Gates, has proposed acquiring the software business behind the 3Com Corporation's popular Palm Pilot hand-held computer, according to people who have been briefed on the discussions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, DOROTHY F.
description: WOOD-Dorothy F. Age 85, formerly of Manhattan, died October 16, 1998, in Middletown, NY, after a long illness. Born in Middletown, NY, November 3, 1912. She is survived by her sister Elizabeth Pippin of Old Greenwich, CT, her niece Elizabeth Leahey of Southport, CT, her nephew Curtis Pippin of Norwalk, CT, and her grandnephew Cosden Leahey. Graveside services will be held on October 23 at 11 AM at Hillside Cemetery, Middletown, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Wellesley Collge, Wellesley, MA 02181, or one's own selection.

title: U.S. Still Unsure on Northwest-Continental Deal
description: Talks between the Clinton Administration and Northwest Airlines ended inconclusively yesterday, with lawyers for the airline unable to overcome the Administration's objections to Northwest's bid to buy a controlling stake in Continental Airlines, participants said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTIMER S.
description: ROSENTHAL-Mortimer S. A finer gentleman and attorney we have never known. We will miss your wise counsel dearly. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Frances, children, Richard, John and Susan, and grandchildren. Herb Nass, family and associates

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, CORWIN E.
description: ACKERMAN-Corwin E. It's been 16 years but seems like yesterday. We will always miss and love you. Mother, Father and Brothers

title: A Magazine for Your 'Inner Guy'
description: In 1996, Mark Golin was living in Allentown, Pa., editing a Web site for Prevention magazine and addressing elderly readers' health questions when a call came from Bonnie Fuller, the editor of Cosmopolitan.

title: Debate Flares Over Count of Women in Newsroom
description: In the months after the issue of ethnic diversity in newsrooms exploded at the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in April, the development of an overarching statement of principles, goals and strategies for increasing the numbers of black, Asian, Hispanic and Native American journalists was one of the group's top priorities.

title: Justice May Need Two Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Bitter Fight for Senate Is Just Politics Upstate
description: This is the time of year in Cortland, N.Y., when leaves turn red and gold and signs sprout on front lawns with the names of favored candidates.
