This year's crop offer an instructive guide to the neck-and-neck Senate race between the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato, and his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Patents; Congress has extended its protection for Goofy, Gershwin and some moguls of the Internet.
description: CONGRESS moved to rewrite American copyright law earlier this month when it passed two hotly contested pieces of legislation. The first lengthens protections by 20 years for an array of 20th century cultural icons, including Mickey Mouse. The second guarantees on-line providers of artistic material that their responsibility for copyright infringement will be limited as the digital age progresses.

title: Poverty Amid Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: Strahan and Armstead Made Most of Meeting
description: The Giants' season may have been saved more than a week before the team beat up on the Arizona Cardinals yesterday at the Meadowlands. That was when defensive end Michael Strahan and linebacker Jessie Armstead walked into an offensive team meeting and basically told them, in the words of Armstead, ''to stop playing like a bunch of punks.''

title: INSIDE
description: Signs of Serb Pullback

title: More Enduring Than Politics
description: The Government's antitrust scrutiny of Microsoft, the world's largest independent software company, has spanned Republican and Democratic Administrations and involved hundreds of Government lawyers and investigators. But it has by no means been an example of consistent, coordinated public policy. Nor, by all accounts, of politics.

title: New South Africa Shuts the Door on Its Neighbors
description: The anonymous caller to the police claimed that there were many illegal immigrants working at the Galaxy clothing shop downtown.

title: Heinz Chooses Burnett For Ketchup Account
description: The H. J. Heinz Company, as part of a renewed commitment to advertise its grocery products, has selected the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago to handle the consolidated worldwide brand duties for Heinz ketchup and other condiments and sauces. Though billings on the account, which had been divided among a dozen shops, were not disclosed, they were estimated at $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURZI, GLORIA M., PH.D. (NEE VOLPE)
description: BURZI-Gloria M., Ph.D. (nee Volpe). On October 18, 1998. Principal and educator for over 35 years at P.S. 291 in the Bronx. Beloved daughter of the late Felix and Antonietta Volpe. Dear wife of A. Vincent J. Burzi for 50 years. Devoted mother of Anthony and Stephen Burzi and Grace A. Hayes. Cherished grandmother of Thomas, Michael and Wilson. Loving sister of Antonietta Sbano and Sabina Pecoraro and the late Helen, Frank and Edmund Volpe. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 1 PM, at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Scarsdale. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The family will be present Monday, 7-9, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to a charity of your choice.

title: A Trivial, Not Triumphant, Homecoming
description: When Dave Brown trotted onto the field at Giants Stadium with 6 minutes 12 seconds left in the game today, he got roughly the same reaction from the fans that he had received in his final year as a Giant; he was booed heartily. A hometown boy who never quite made good enough, the only cheers for Brown came when the referee announced a roughing the passer call that had crushed him to the turf.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; The Roots of Bosnian Horror Lie Not So Deep
description: HEARTS GROWN BRUTALSagas of SarajevoBy Roger Cohen523 pages. Random House. $27.95.

title: Book Publishers Seek Global Reach And Grand Scale
description: Borders are as flimsy as bookmarks in the global realm where Thomas Middelhoff is preparing to take power as the new chief executive of the Bertelsmann media and publishing conglomerate.

title: What the Sherman Act Actually Says
description: Following is the text of the first two sections of the Sherman Act, as passed by Congress in 1890. As the foundation on which Federal antitrust law has been built, the act has been amended several times -- elevating the crime to a felony, increasing the fines and prison terms for individuals and setting fines for corporations convicted of violating it. In the case of Microsoft, the Government has invoked the Sherman Act to file a civil suit that seeks to change the company's business practices, not a criminal suit that seeks financial penalties.

title: Homecomings Dethrone Kings and Queens
description: The boast has been enough to bring tears to the eyes of University of Illinois alumni, who can be recognized by the louder-than-a-boom-box orange attire they customarily don for the Big Ten football games here at Zupke Field.

title: John O. Van Koert, 86, Designer And Promoter of Danish Modern
description: John O. Van Koert, a prominent New York designer who helped promote the fascination with Danish modern furnishings in the 1950's, died last Sunday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 86.

title: How a 'Peculiar Institution' Shaped a Nation's History
description: If there is still any doubt about the central and profound place in American history of the black Africans who were carried here as slaves, it should be laid to rest by ''Africans in America.'' Subtitled ''America's Journey Through Slavery,'' the forceful four-part series that begins tonight on PBS combines recent scholarship with famous slave narratives to explore the resounding clash between the young nation's ideals of freedom and the realities of bondage.

title: In England, It's North vs. South
description: To the Editor:

title: Finishing Unfinished Business
description: From Internet taxes and Internet pornography to digital copyrights and visas for technology workers, Congress last week finished work on a number of bills affecting the information technology industry. Over all, the industry gave high marks to the legislative record of the 105th Congress, even though it failed to act on bills that would have lifted export controls on data-scrambling technology and displayed a growing trend toward regulation of the Internet.

title: Strawberry Visit Possible
description: There is a chance that Darryl Strawberry can visit Yankee Stadium for Game 6 or Game 7 next weekend, if those games are played. But Strawberry has lost a lot of weight, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, and is still trying to regain his strength.

title: Next Year in Congress, It's Back to the Surplus
description: Faced with the first Federal budget surplus in a generation, the Clinton Administration and the Republican-controlled Congress squabbled throughout this year's tax-and-spending negotiations. In the end, they spent more than they had agreed to a year earlier but deferred until next year any of the big decisions about how to take advantage of the nation's newfound fiscal health.

title: Gordon Lights Up Daytona And Nears Another Title
description: The Champagne is not on ice just yet, but it certainly looks as if Jeff Gordon will soon be celebrating another Nascar Winston Cup championship, his second straight and third in four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELMONT, BEVERLY (NEE SIMPSON)
description: BELMONT-Beverly (nee Simpson). On October 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Ronald. Loving mother of Ron, Jr., Lynne Aversa and Matthew. Adoring grandmother of Ron, Drew, John and Matthew. Dear sister of Matthew and John. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 7-9 PM, and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at Epiphany Church, 2nd Ave. at 22 St., Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Something to Think About: Magazine's Section on Logic
description: Here is a trick question for bridge historians. What is the world's oldest bridge magazine?

title: Adolf Althoff, 85, Circus Chief Who Hid People From Nazis
description: Adolf Althoff, a courageous German circus executive who saved several people in the Nazi era by having them work and travel with his circus, died in his sleep on Wednesday in a hospital in Stolberg near Aachen. He was 85 and lived in Stolberg.

title: In England, It's North vs. South
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Minorities at 6.1 Percent On Major Magazine Staffs
description: How well are minority groups represented is the magazine industry?

title: Editorial Notebook; Looking Eastward From the Rural West
description: Traveling across the Western plains in late summer and early fall, I seemed to be traveling across the landscape of a national moment -- the protracted moment between President Clinton's apologia in mid-August and the House of Representatives' early-October vote to authorize an impeachment inquiry. I tried hard to let the news in general and that news, specifically, slip away behind me like the rough red pavement on the interstate. But no matter how far I went, and no matter where I stopped -- at a small ranch in Colorado's Bijou Basin or a large ranch along the East Rosebud River in Montana -- the question, sooner or later, arose, ''What do you think of this mess?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIGER, LYNN EARHART
description: SCHWEIGER-Lynn Earhart. The staff and Board of Directors of the Purchase Community House send their condolences to the family and friends of Mr. Lynn Earhart Schweiger of Hawthorne, NY. Mr. Schweiger passed away on October 15, 1998 after an all too short battle with a malignant brain tumor. He is survived by his wife, Joyce, son, Keith and daughter, Kerry Lynn and son in law Al Crosby. Mr. Schweiger grew up in Elkhart, Indiana and received his Undergraduate Degree at Purdue University. After being hired as the Director of the Purchase Community House in Purchase, New York in 1967, he completed his Master's Degree at Columbia University Teacher's College. Affectionately known as ''The Boss,'' his integrity, fairness and high standards are lasting legacies to all those who knew him. The safe and caring atmosphere he created for our children made the Community House ''a home away from home.'' Lynn, we love you, we miss you and in our hearts, the Community House will always be ''Lynn's House.'' Services will be held on Monday, October 19th at 11:00am at White Plains United Methodist Church, 252 Bryant Avenue, White Plains, NY. Reception to follow at the Purchase Community House, 3095 Purchase Street, Purchase, NY. In lieu of flowers, for contribution information please contact James Kelly at 914-949-2636.

title: A Rescue Plan for the Everglades
description: It has always been clear that the Clinton Administration's ambitious plan to save the Everglades would not succeed unless ways could be found to guarantee this wondrous ecosystem a reliable flow of fresh water. Last week, the Army Corps of Engineers unveiled a breathtaking plan to do exactly that. The plan has already won the support of environmentalists. It also needs support from less reliable but nevertheless indispensable stakeholders -- Congress, Florida's political establishment and the state's powerful and often obstructive sugar interests.

title: Expensive Fantasies on Iraq
description: Congress's desire to hasten the removal of Saddam Hussein from power in Baghdad is understandable. But throwing money and weapons at Iraq's feeble and fractious opposition will not achieve the intended results.

title: Pinochet's Spanish Pursuer: Magistrate of Explosive Cases
description: A stubbornly independent judge who more than once has challenged the Spanish Government, Baltasar Garzon was ridiculed when he first set out to pursue the most notorious right-wing generals in South America for human rights crimes committed in the 1970's and 80's, offenses for which they had already been granted amnesty at home.

title: Party Boss Has Firm Grip On Judgeships
description: The uninitiated might imagine that judges in New York City ascend to the bench by destiny, the only sound the swishing of their black robes. But the selection of judges may be one of the few areas of local politics where back-room deals are still the rule, and where the county political leaders exercise the greatest control.

title: Columbus Forces A Deciding Game
description: Brian McBride scored two goals and the host Columbus Crew kept their championship hopes alive with a 4-2 victory over the two-time Major League Soccer champions D.C. United on Sunday in Game 2 of the Eastern Division finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, PAULINE
description: SILVERSTONE-Pauline. Beloved mother of Brenda Meltzer and Barbara Brill. Proud grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Most Chileans React Moderately to Arrest
description: Perhaps as a sign of how much Chileans wish to forget their years of polarized politics and repression under Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the immediate popular response here to the sensational news of his arrest in London has been remarkable for its moderation.

title: THE TECHNOLOGY TRADE: A special report; Chinese Said to Reap Gains In U.S. Export Policy Shift
description: Shortly after he took office in 1993, President Clinton traveled to Silicon Valley to lay out his vision of a robust American economy buoyed by high-technology companies that could compete anywhere in the world.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a serious effort being made, and the meetings today and our overall mood and the atmosphere justifies almost certainly continuing these meetings tomorrow.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, DAVID
description: RAPOPORT-David. Loving husband of Rose. Devoted father of Dr. Samuel Rapoport and Nancy Goldstein, and father-in-law of Sandra Rapoport and Dr. Steven Goldstein. Doting grandfather of Benjamin, Matthew, Ezra, Rebecca, Sarah and Jordana. Steadfast brother of Morris Rapport and Rose Gelber, both of Miami Beach. Shiva at the Goldstein residence, 31 Sunset Rd. South, Searington, NY, through Friday. Contributions in his memory may be made to the David Rapoport Torah Fund of the Drisha Institute, 131 West 86 St., NY 10024 or to the David Rapoport Torah Fund of the Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY 11576.

title: Missed Pass Costs Kanell
description: Wide receiver Chris Calloway had 6 catches for 97 yards, including a touchdown. But on the Giants' first possession he dropped a Danny Kanell pass in the open field that would have been a touchdown.

title: Levi Strauss begins a far-reaching marketing campaign to reach gay men and lesbians.
description: INTENSIFYING its efforts to reach younger, more fashion-conscious consumers, Levi Strauss & Company is embarking on its most ambitious marketing campaign aimed at gay men and lesbians.

title: Jewish Vote Becomes Battleground in Tight Race for Senate
description: With two survivors of the Holocaust at his side, and a rabbi leading his rally, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato stood solemnly at the Holocaust Memorial Wall in Manhattan yesterday, promoting his efforts on behalf of Jewish voters and joining Jewish supporters in assailing his opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer, over issues of concern to Israel and to Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLISEY, JAMES VINCENT
description: HALLISEY-James Vincent. October 16, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Nancy Hallisey. Loving father of James V. Hallisey, Jr. and Tamara Hallisey-Hatfield. Cherished grandfather of Sasha A. Hatfield and James V. Hallisey III and Mark O. Hatfield III. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81st Street, Sunday, October 18, 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th Street at Lexington Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Speaking Out For the Indigent Dead; A Woman's Search for Her Father's Remains Is Forcing Newark to Restore a Potter's Field
description: In death as in life, the people buried in City Cemetery were Newark's unknown and unclaimed, a forlorn caste of varied race, religion and ethnicity whose brief appearances in the urban swirl of the late 19th and early 20th centuries all ended in destitution.

title: Space-Age Experiments
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Simon in Alliance With JCDecaux
description: Simon Brand Ventures in Indianapolis, a strategic business unit of the real estate investment trust Simon Property Group Inc., and JCDecaux in Paris, which specializes in outdoor advertising media like bus shelters and kiosks, have formed a 15-year, multimillion-dollar strategic alliance to produce new ad media in malls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, GENE J.
description: FLANAGAN-Gene J. Dean of Continuing Education and Professor of Behavioral Sciences at Kingsboro Community College, The City University of New York. The administration, faculty, staff and students of Kingsboro Community College mourn the passing of a most valued colleague and friend on Friday, October 16. Dean Flanagan joined Kingsboro in 1977, directing the Continuing Education Program, where he introduced a number of programs including College for Kids, GED Preparation, English as a Second Language and Diploma Now. Before coming to Kingsboro, Dr. Flanagan was principal of the Sheepshead Bay Adult School. He was also active in a number of regional and national professional organizations in Adult and Continuing Education. His dedicated professionalism, skills and creativity were an inspiration to many members of the Kingsboro community. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Kay and his family.

title: DANCE
description: Emphasis on Correctness

title: Martinez: Power, Pride and a Keeper
description: Tino Martinez had heard the speculation about his future with the Yankees, how it was in peril if he continued to have a dismal post-season. He heard the speculation about how the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, would trade him if the Yankees did not win the World Series, and then sign Mo Vaughn as Martinez's replacement. He heard the same old story and he cringed.

title: Executive Changes At Three Agencies
description: Three agencies have made executive changes.

title: 3 Fatal Shootings Jar Quiet California City
description: Drive-by shootings and shootings of tourists in the street are not supposed to happen in this small city, where the average house is valued at more than $500,000 and the views of the ocean are priceless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMM, LILI
description: LAMM-Lili. On October 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Hugo Lamm. Loving mother of Werner and Gaby, Frank and Susan. Cherished grandmother of Vivian, Todd, Michael, Rosalia, Stephanie, Eric and Josh, and great grandmother of Jeffrey, Jason, Andrea and Alexandra. Dear sister of Kurt Strauss. Funeral services are on Wednesday at 11:30 A.M., from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Interment Beth El Cemetery (New Jersey).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, HERMAN
description: WALKER-Herman, 89. Formerly of Waldwick, NJ, September 24, 1998. Preceded in death by his wife Virginia Decker Walker, survived by son, Roger W. Walker, daughter Beverly Walker Gelbert, and grandchildren Michael & Jennifer Walker, Sara & Katherine Gelbert. Walker graduated from Columbia University in 1931, served as Lieutenant in U.S. Army and was employed at ITT Marlow. His family founded the Fairview Cemetery where he served as consultant until his death. An avid reader, artist, lover of wildlife and supporter of various library, law enforcement and youth programs. Memorial service at Waldwick United Methodist Church, October 23, 12PM. Contributions to Friends of the Library, Waldwick Library, 19 East Prospect St., Waldwick, NJ 07463

title: From Mexican Soil to Museum Sanctum; San Antonio Enshrines Nelson Rockefeller's Hobby
description: When Nelson A. Rockefeller made his final trip to Mexico in 1978, several months before his death, his eye was drawn to a small hacienda surrounded by a picket fence along a rural road in Oaxaca. Atop each picket was a tall, strangely striking figurine made of rough pottery.

title: Peering Back in Time, Astronomers Glimpse Galaxies Aborning
description: In the beginning, there was light, the bursting dawn of cosmic creation. As the fireball of the Big Bang expanded and cooled, though, the light faded away and darkness fell on the young universe, by then little more than a formless sea of dark matter flecked with traces of primordial hydrogen and helium and broken only by scattered but fateful ripples.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Making Books column on Thursday misidentified the literary prize won three times by Gary Paulsen. He received the Newbery Honor, not the Newbery Medal, which is higher ranking.

title: Giuliani Is Welcomed in New Hampshire, Even by Red Sox Fans
description: If his experiences today are any indication, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani learned that whenever he feels unappreciated in the harsh environs of New York City, he can always come to New Hampshire to breathe in the restorative New England air and bask in the admiration of others.

title: INTEL TO BUY MAKER OF COMPUTER NETWORKING PRODUCTS
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's leading maker of computer chips, agreed yesterday to buy the Shiva Corporation for $6 a share, or about $185 million in cash, as it expands its line of networking products. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is pushing into the business of linking computers as sales growth in its main chip operations slows. The technology it will acquire with Shiva, based in Bedford, Mass., provides secure connections between computers based in far-flung offices using the Internet. Shares in Shiva rose $1.25, to $5.50. Intel shares rose $1.25, to $85.

title: Internet Filter Makes Bad Censor
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; The Starr Questions
description: When Kenneth Starr is criticized, those who want President Clinton out of office tend to respond with two sorts of questions. What exactly has Mr. Starr done that was wrong? And in any event, since the charges against the President are on the table now, why should we care what Mr. Starr did?

title: Antitrust Case Relies Heavily on Events at a 1995 Meeting
description: The Government's case against Microsoft is a narrative that revolves around the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Government's leading witness, James L. Barksdale, Netscape's 55-year-old president and chief executive.

title: Surrogate Mothers Report Few Regrets
description: More than 10 years after giving birth, women who acted as surrogate mothers for infertile couples said they did not regret the role they played. But some felt sad and disappointed over the loss of contact with the children they bore, who were biologically their own. And many imagined that one day their children would find them, even though in some cases the children had no idea that they came into the world in any other than the usual way.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Sees Genetic Crop Effort
description: Rhone-Poulenc Agro, the world's seventh-largest crop-protection company, said today that it planned to become a leading developer of genetically enhanced crops and did not need to make high-priced acquisitions to succeed.

title: Testaverde Shreds Pats, Putting Jets Back in the Race
description: The Jets may have found themselves a quarterback while finding themselves tonight.

title: Review/Fashion; Creativity Meets Reality
description: Call them the realists, the ones who acknowledge that the clothes they design are destined actually to be worn by women in real life, not just by models on the runway or in magazines. Their challenge is in a way stiffer than that faced by the dreamers who envision a fantasy world where clothes exist merely to be and not to serve a particular function.

title: Sports of The Times; Learning Patience, Quietly, From Bernie
description: IN the aftermath of Ricky Ledee's weekend World Series ascent, a soda can was hanging from the fingertips of his left hand, the chain holding his crucifix was drooping out one side of his shirt, and a most interesting hypothetical was dangling in front of his face.

title: Private Survey on Street Quality Conflicts With Mayor's
description: A study described as the first comprehensive survey of the conditions of New York City's streets confirms what drivers may have suspected: Many of the city's streets are in pretty bad shape.

title: A Really Different Drummer
description: Rare is the ethnic arts showcase that is as enriching and enjoyable as ''Music and Dance of Nepal,'' the program presented by the Raj Kapoor Ensemble at Symphony Space on Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAREK, ADELE (NEE GRUNBAUM)
description: KANAREK-Adele (nee Grunbaum). On Oct. 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Irwin. Mother of Rivi Katz & Esthy Hersch, mother-in-law of Avi & Eli. Grandmother of Dena, Josh, Tamar, Adam, Yehoshua, Rachel and Aliza. Funeral service today, Tuesday, October 20th, 11:30 AM, Boulevard Park West Funeral Chapel, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Fires Erupt Across Vail As It Begins An Expansion
description: Two days after Vail cleared trees on a disputed ski area expansion, fires erupted today along a nearby milelong mountain ridge, destroying three major buildings and damaging four chair lifts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, HENRY
description: CANTOR-Henry, 81 years. Son of the late Samuel and Ida Cantor. Husband of the late Sylvia Pepper Cantor. Beloved father of Richard, Linda S., & Linda. Devoted grandfather of Daniel, Amanda, Andrew, & Laura. Great-grandfather of Lily. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Pakistani Premier Prevails in Clash With General
description: In the welter of events unfolding here, one remarkable episode stands out: after the chief of the powerful Pakistani Army got in hot water for publicly criticizing the Prime Minister and proposing a stronger military role in making policy, it was the general who lost his job, not the Prime Minister.

title: Tense Times at the Mideast Summit
description: The Middle East peace talks in Maryland are in overtime, and may yet fail. But they were saved from extinction yesterday by some intense American diplomacy and the decision of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, not to let a new terrorist attack in Israel abort the negotiations.

title: To Stay Sharp, Niedermayer Signs With Minor League Team
description: Frustrated by the failure to reach a contract agreement with the Devils and eager to play hockey, the talented defenseman Scott Niedermayer signed a 25-game contract yesterday with the Utah Grizzlies of the International Hockey League.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Metro Business; Public Service Earnings Up
description: The Public Service Enterprise Group, a New Jersey electric utility holding company, said its third-quarter profit rose 2.3 percent on stronger electricity sales.

title: After 24 Years, a Foundation Finds a Lot to Celebrate
description: It was a snapshot for the ages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAREK, ADELE
description: KANAREK-Adele. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: In the Park With Humperdinck
description: When Humperdinck turned the Grimm Brothers' version of ''Hansel and Gretel'' into an opera, he considerably lightened the bleakness of the story and lessened the meanness of the parents, who, in the opera, do not intentionally desert their children in the forest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINMAN, SADIE
description: ZINMAN-Sadie. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the mother of Alice Amelar and extends to her and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: John E. Fagg, 81, Historian of Latin America
description: John E. Fagg, a retired history professor at New York University and an author of books on Latin American and Spanish history, died on Oct. 3 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSCH, GULNAR KHEIRALLAH
description: BOSCH-Gulnar Kheirallah died October 9, 1998 in Tallahassee, Florida. Memorial Lemoyne, October 24, 5:30 PM.

title: G.E. Saves in Turbine Deal
description: Stewart & Stevenson Services agreed today to return $84 million to the General Electric Company after lowering by 14 percent, to $516 million, the price G.E. is paying for a gas-turbine business. It said that to do so, it would take a charge of $20 million, or 71 cents a share, in its fiscal quarter ending on Oct. 31 and that part of the reason for the adjustment was weak demand from Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, JOAN
description: CLARKE-Joan. Formerly of Glen Head, NY. Active in the Glen Cove Women's Club and St. Mary's, Roslyn. Beloved wife of the late John. Loving mother of John S., Robert A. and Joan Sefton. Dear grandmother of six and great grandmother of three. Dear sister of Marea and Robert. Visiting on Tuesday, from 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM, Whitting Funeral Home. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, 10 A.M., St. Mary's R.C. Church, Roslyn, New York. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, New York. Contributions may be made to North Shore University Hospital, Glen Cove, New York.

title: Warner-Lambert Profit Soars 49%
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 49 percent as sales of Lipitor, a cholesterol drug introduced last year, more than doubled to $569 million.

title: Wrinkles
description: Q. Why do we wrinkle as we age? What can be done about it?

title: Back Schumer, Hillary Clinton Tells Women Voters
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned with Representative Charles E. Schumer for the second time in a month today, assailing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for deluging Mr. Schumer with a ''blizzard of negative advertising,'' and she explicitly urged women to support the Democratic challenger in November.

title: Revived and Relieved, Giants Take a Break
description: The Giants' locker room was almost empty today, the playing and practice fields quiet. The bye week began, and everywhere at Giants Stadium, there was a sense of relief befitting a hiatus.

title: The Mystery of Cranberry Juice Unfolds
description: The mystery of the medicinal power of cranberry juice may have been solved at last.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES TO SELL UNIT TO CONDOR SYSTEMS
description: Litton Industries, an aerospace, military and commercial electronics company based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Applied Technology division to Condor Systems Inc., based in San Jose, Calif., for about $120 million in cash. The division, which supplies warning systems for military markets around the world, had about $130 million in revenue for the fiscal year ended July 31, Litton said. Applied Technology employs 600 people, most of whom will be offered positions by closely held Condor, Litton said.

title: New Cheerleader for the World's End
description: The hunger is obvious from the very first cry of ''Hello, darlings!,'' the signature salutation she hurls at the audience in her nightclub act. There's a new stridency in the voice: a loud, raw, anxious quality that suggests that the speaker would very much like you to like her, but knows that isn't going to happen.

title: Continental Airlines Posts Record Net Before Charge
description: Continental Airlines reported record third-quarter earnings yesterday, excluding a previously announced one-time charge, and acknowledged publicly for the first time that the Clinton Administration might file suit to block Northwest Airlines from buying a controlling stake in Continental.

title: The Pill at 40: Renewed, Improved and in Its Prime
description: The birth control pill is pushing 40, and like many another veteran of the 1960's, it never looked so good. It is the Volkswagen Bug of drugs -- a sleekly remodeled version of the 1960 prototype, housed in a box full of old associations, but completely reconfigured inside and intended for a brand-new market.

title: Seeing the Vacuum Roar
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGA, MARK
description: SELIGA-Mark. The Chairman, Board of Trustees, Director, and Staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of our good friend and colleague, Mark Seliga and extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Josefina and their son Mark. Controller of the BMA since 1990, Mark was dedicated and tireless in his responsibility for the operation of the Museum's Financial Department. Before joining the Museum, he service as Fiscal Administrator at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, prior to which he held financial positions at PepsiCo, Inc., Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, and Price Waterhouse & Company. Visiting hours John J. Healey Funeral Home, 2977 Ocean Ave at Avenue Z, Brooklyn, October 20-21 2-5 PM and 7-9:30 PM. Service October 22 St. Mark's Church, Ocean Ave & Ave Z Brooklyn 10:15 AM.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADAPTEC INC., Milpitas, Calif., a maker of computer connectors cards and storage devices, said it would buy back as much as $200 million of its common stock, or about 15 percent of its outstanding stock, to increase returns to shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, BEN
description: PACE-Ben. Of Boynton Beach. Beloved husband of Ilse, loving father of Dr. Richard Pace (Mary Pat), James Mann (Jacqueline), and the late Neil Pace. Adored grandfather of Matthew, Marcy, Stacy, and Alison. In loving memory.

title: Plundering a Municipal Union
description: A wave of indictments is expected when Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau finishes investigating charges of embezzlement and kickbacks from those doing business with at least a half-dozen locals of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union. But the urgent business of cleaning up the union should not await the filing of criminal charges.

title: Suspect Says Second Man Killed Teacher
description: A 20-year-old man accused in the torture and killing of his former high school English teacher was in the victim's apartment the day of the crime, his lawyers said yesterday, but they argued that the killing was committed by a second defendant and that others involved in the case might still be free.

title: In Their Fourth and Final Debate, Kennelly and Rowland Reiterate Party Themes
description: Squaring off in their fourth and final debate, Gov. John G. Rowland and his opponent, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, each took a strong party stance tonight, with the Governor charging Mrs. Kennelly with recycling tired Democratic themes while she continued to charge that he was ignoring the state's neediest citizens.

title: Yankees Hope They Hit Pay Dirt in San Diego
description: The home-field advantage in Yankee Stadium is loud fans chanting colorful phrases and occasionally dropping objects in the vicinity of opposing players. At Qualcomm Stadium, the advantage might be knowing the difference between the foul lines and the yard lines.

title: With Change in Habit, Beetles Shake Up Corn Country
description: In the endless battle between farmers and insects, the bugs have won another round. A big change in the behavior of the western corn rootworm beetle is threatening one of the great success stories in American agriculture, the use of crop rotation instead of pesticides on millions of acres of Midwestern corn.

title: Prosecutor Letter Is Offered In Louima Cover-Up Case
description: A police sergeant charged with trying to cover up the reported brutalizing of Abner Louima by four police officers told an investigator about another officer with ''pertinent information'' about the case, a prosecutor has said in a court document.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNELLY, PATRICK
description: KENNELLY-Patrick. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Patrick Kennelly, associated with The Times from 1964, until retiring in 1988.

title: Sharon's Muscle Evokes Hopes and Some Fears
description: The key figure at the Middle East talks on Maryland's Eastern Shore is probably not the President, nor the Prime Minister, nor even the Chairman, but a veteran of the Arab-Israeli frays who only recently became Israel's Foreign Minister and showed up at the talks two days late.

title: Whitman Seeks More Open Land, but Decay Is Seen in State's Parks
description: New Jersey's voters will soon be asked to pass judgment on a plan to preserve a million acres of open land. But critics say the state is not taking care of the parkland it already has.

title: A Grass-Roots Message on Reform
description: In the weeks since campaign finance reform was killed in Washington, it has been fashionable to say that the issue never had much popular support. But that cynical view is belied by the momentum behind two important initiatives this fall, in Massachusetts and Arizona, where voters are being asked to create publicly financed campaign systems that would free politicians of their dependence on money from special interests. Approval of these measures would provide a model for how to clean up local political races and send a strong signal to Washington to enact reform legislation next year.

title: In Boost for Left Wing, Stollmann Won't Take Economics Portfolio : Free-Marketeer Quits Schroeder's Team
description: FRANKFURT  Germany's new government lost its most outspoken advocate of economic change when Jost Stollmann abruptly withdrew as the next economics minister on Monday.

title: The 'Rummaging' Got Rough and Nasty
description: The supposedly defunct Paula Jones lawsuit produced another burst of documentation today detailing the visceral nature of a confrontation that the President said allowed Ms. Jones to ''rummage'' through the intimate life of the nation's chief executive.

title: Prodi Takes a Swipe At D'Alema for Way Majority Was Formed : Italy Gives Mandate To Former Communist
description: ROME  Massimo D'Alema became the first former Communist to lead a Western European government on Monday when he succeeded in obtaining the support he needed to form Italy's 56th postwar government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ADOLPH
description: ROSS-Adolph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Adolph Ross, associated with The Times from 1973, until retiring in 1982.

title: PACIFIC DUNLOP TO SELL BATTERY-MAKING UNIT TO QUEXCO
description: Pacific Dunlop Ltd., an Australian maker of rubber, clothing and auto parts, said that it had cut the price for its GNB Technologies battery-making unit after United States regulators had delayed approving the sale and market conditions subsequently worsened. The business will now be sold to closely held Quexco Inc. of Dallas, for $500 million, $50 million less than originally agreed. Pacific Dunlop said that despite the setback, profit had grown 10 percent or more in the first quarter of the company's new financial year.

title: Ex-Communist at Italy's Helm May, or May Not, Vex the Church
description: At first glance, it looked as if the Vatican was not thrilled when Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist who leads the largest leftist party in Italy, was asked to form a majority that would allow him to become Prime Minister.

title: Schroder Acts To Explore Compensating Slave Workers
description: In a sign that Germany's new Government may be willing to set up a fund to compensate people forced into slave labor under Hitler, Gerhard Schroder, the Chancellor-elect, plans to meet with top industrial executives to discuss options for resolving a growing number of lawsuits.

title: CLINTON STRUGGLES TO ACHIEVE GAINS IN MIDEAST TALKS
description: President Clinton struggled tonight to salvage stalled Middle East peace talks after a Palestinian grenade attack on Israeli civilians made success seem less likely, senior officials representing all parties said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GENDAL, KEITH BARRY
description: GENDAL-Keith Barry 4/27/53-10/20/94 To forget would be unthinkable.

title: Joan Hickson, Miss Marple on TV, Dies at 92
description: Joan Hickson, a stage, screen and television actress who became an international celebrity when she played Miss Marple, Agatha Christie's sharp-witted elderly detective, in a BBC television series from 1984 to 1992, died over the weekend at a hospital in Colchester, Essex, said her son, Nicholas Butler. She was 92.

title: Organized Crime Link Is Investigated in Slaying
description: Investigators are looking into possible links to organized crime in the slaying of a man found in a remote section of Jersey City, the Hudson County Prosecutor's Office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, SIDNEY
description: BURGER-Sidney. October 18, 1998, age 90. Beloved father of Richard and Berry. Grandfather of Gareth, Claudia, Cory and Abigail. Services Tuesday, 1:00 at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard; Shiva at 21-15 34 Ave L.I.C.

title: Two Torahs, Adorned With Gold and Silver, Are Stolen
description: Two Torahs, the sacred Jewish scrolls containing the five Books of Moses, and the handmade silver breastplates and crowns that adorned them were stolen early Sunday from Temple Emanu-El, a prominent synagogue here that was led for nearly 30 years by Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, the eminent Jewish historian, the police and temple officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, REVEREND EDWIN J.
description: DUFFY-Reverend Edwin J. On October 19, 1998 at United Hospital Medical Center, Port Chester, New York. Son of the late Florence and Stephen Duffy. Brother of Miriam D. Scavullo of New York City, Rev. Stephen V. Duffy, S.J. of New York City, Sr. Helen Marie, S.S.N.D. of Towson, MD, Florence D. Doherty of Scranton, PA, Jane D. Burt of Fort Lauderdale, FL and Constance D. Corroon of Rye, NY. Also survived by 21 nieces and nephews and 48 grandnieces and nephews. Visiting hours are Wednesday from 2 to 4 P.M., and 7 to 9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye. A Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, October 22 at 10:00 A.M., at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to the United Hospital Skilled Nursing Pavilion, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573 or the National Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 366 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10001.

title: Argentine Coin Sales
description: Argentina's central bank will sell 1.54 million gold coins, the last of its gold reserves since it sold off all of its bullion to insulate assets from falling metal prices. The coins will be sold directly to the public and through local and international auctions, the central bank said today in a statement. No value has been placed on the coins, and no date for the sale was announced.

title: A Dictator's Arrest
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Giant Taylor Is Arrested On Drug Charges in Florida
description: Lawrence Taylor has not tackled anyone in five years, but one thing has stayed the same for the former Giants All-Pro linebacker: he hasn't avoided drug charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ESTHER L.
description: SINGER-Esther L., 85. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt of many nephews and nieces and cherished friend of many. She was a dedicated teacher for over 25 years in the junior and senior high schools of New York. She ended her career at Sheepshead Bay High School where she touched the lives of hundreds of students. Graveside service on Tuesday, October 20th, 1998, at 1:00 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Old as Society, Social Anxiety Is Yielding Its Secrets
description: ''Man seeketh in society comfort,'' Francis Bacon asserted, but you could have fooled Robert Suhoza. Gatherings of his fellow humans have rarely inspired in Mr. Suhoza a sense of consolation and well being. Usually, it has been more like sweating, heart-pounding dread.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS 5.6 PERCENT. Prices slumped after Venezuela's oil minister said his country, a leading oil exporter, planned to return to maximum daily output in mid-1999. The November contract fell 80 cents, to $13.35 a barrel.

title: GTE Reports 8.7% Increase in Earnings
description: The GTE Corporation, which has agreed to be bought by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said today that third-quarter profits rose 8.7 percent as the phone company had strong growth in revenue, mainly from services like caller identification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, JUDITH
description: BERKOWITZ-Judith. On October 18th, 1998. Beloved daughter of Clara and the late Jack Berkowitz. Cherished sister of Susan and Robert Koweek. Loving aunt of Sharon, Jeffrey and Andrea. Adored niece of Honnie Marcus. Judy was a truly special person who touched the lives of everyone she knew. Contributions in her memory may be made to United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau County-Bayville Residential Fund, 380 Washington Ave., Roosevelt, NY 11575.

title: Two Exempt Army Battalions Are Deployed by Milosevic
description: Reflecting the unstable situation in Kosovo, the Yugoslav Army deployed two battalions of soldiers, tanks and artillery in the province in the last 24 hours, Western diplomats said today.

title: Internet Filter Makes Bad Censor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Drummer Shows His Goal
description: Who exactly Lewis Nash is as a drummer has always been in question. Mr. Nash, perhaps the drummer most in demand in jazz circles in New York, plays with all sorts of people, from the pianist Tommy Flanagan to jazz orchestras. He has been consistently excellent and selfless as a sideman, and what he wanted from music was never apparent. But after last week's stay at the Village Vanguard, he has cleared up his allegiances; he's after adventurous music.

title: The Forecast: A Battle to Survive; Homeless and Their Advocates Plan for a Bitter Winter
description: By all accounts, Baye Lorde is tough -- a stocky, quick-tempered former drug dealer who likes to use his fists. But after six months of being homeless, there is one thought that frightens even him: having to battle a winter living on the streets.

title: Culture of Kava
description: To the Editor:

title: Measure Won by D'Amato For Donor Faces a Repeal
description: When officials with the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, better known as Freddie Mac, were looking for someone in Congress to push one of their most important bills this year, they looked no further than an old ally and recipient of their campaign largess: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: 96 Arrested During Rally Protesting Gay Man's Killing in Wyoming
description: What began as a rally down Fifth Avenue to mourn and protest the killing of a gay college student in Wyoming ended chaotically last night, with nearly 100 arrests and several injuries after demonstrators faced off against police officers in riot gear and on horseback.

title: As Microsoft Trial Gets Started, Gates's Credibility Is Questioned
description: After months of noisy prelude, the antitrust trial against the Microsoft Corporation opened in Federal court this morning with a pointed personal attack on the credibility and integrity of William H. Gates, the company's chairman.

title: CABARET
description: Complicated Mixture Of Laughter and Longing

title: Islander Fans Get Short End of Cablevision's Stick
description: When the Islanders play Edmonton tomorrow night, it should be televised on Cablevision-controlled Fox Sports New York. But you never know. Cablevision has refused to show three of four Islanders game this season on F.S.N.Y. because . . . we actually don't know why. Executives of Cablevision and its subsidiary, Madison Square Garden, have balked at answering any questions.

title: Green Tea Without the Taste of Old Socks
description: In recent years, several studies have pointed to the health benefits of green tea. Regular drinkers have less lung, stomach and esophageal cancer, lower rates of cardiovascular disease and fewer strokes.

title: U.S. May Seek to Change Medals Won by East Germans
description: The United States Olympic Committee is preparing for a controversial process that seeks to upgrade medals for American athletes who lost to East Germans in cases where the use of performance-enhancing drugs can be documented.

title: Sports of The Times; Parcells Is Pressing Psychological Buttons
description: WALKING off through the silence of Foxboro Stadium and under the scoreboard that had the Jets' 24-14 upset victory over the Patriots in lights, Bill Parcells turned toward a familiar face last night on his way to the Jets' locker room.

title: 2 Views of Initiative on Hiring Practices
description: Following are the texts of two broadcast advertisements dealing with a Washington state ballot initiative to ban state affirmative action programs. The former was prepared for radio by the American Civil Rights Institute, which supports the initiative; the latter for television by No! 200, which opposes the ban.

title: McKesson Stock Drops Sharply
description: Shares of the McKesson Corporation and HBO & Company tumbled today after McKesson's proposed $14 billion acquisition of HBO left investors wondering how the combined company's sales forces could package products as different as drugs and computer services.

title: AFFILIATED COMPUTER TO PURCHASE BRC HOLDINGS
description: Affiliated Computer Services Inc., the nation's second-largest nonbank operator of automated teller machines, said yesterday that it would acquire BRC Holdings Inc. for about $261 million in cash. Affiliated Computer will begin a cash tender offer within five business days for about 51 percent of BRC's fully diluted shares at $19 each. BRC has about 13.7 million common shares outstanding. After regulatory and shareholder approval, Affiliated Computer will pay $19 a share in cash for the remaining shares. Affiliated Computer provides information technology and staffing services, and BRC develops computer and management systems for health-care organizations. Shares in Affiliated Computer rose $2.0625, to $30.9375. BRC's stock rose $2.0938, to $18.3438. Both companies are based in Dallas.

title: St. John Terrell, 81, a Re-Enactor of History
description: St. John Terrell, a flamboyant Chicago-born actor and impresario who pronounced his name Sinjin and led a campaign to clear Richard III's blackened name, died on Oct. 9 at his home outside Trenton. He was 81, and in a tricorn and cape had crossed the Delaware River as George Washington 25 times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFADDEN, JAMES PATRICK
description: McFADDEN-James Patrick. On October 17, 1998. Editor of The Human Life Review. Beloved husband of Faith (nee Abbott). Loving father of Maria Maffucci, Patrick, Regina and Christina McFadden and the late Robert Arthur McFadden II. Adoring grandfather of James Anthony and Anna Clare. Dear brother of Thomas and Edward McFadden, Rita Ward, Louise Boelger, Jean Jenkins and the late Robert Arthur McFadden. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Agnes Church, 143 E. 43 St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERRY, LEAH
description: SHERRY-Leah. Beloved mother of Ruth Dollinger. Loving grandmother of Michael and Jeffrey and great-grandmother of Eric. Graveside services were held.

title: Parcells and the Jets Go for It
description: In a tribute to both Vinny Testaverde and Drew Bledsoe, Bill Parcells last night gave the go-ahead on a Testaverde bomb that led to the crushing touchdown pass to Dedric Ward in the Jets' 24-14 victory over the New England Patriots. Fewer than five minutes remained and the Jets were nursing a 3-point lead, yet threw the ball. I didn't want to give the ball back to Bledsoe, Parcells said.

title: Pope's Encyclical Noted Peril of Our Age; Faith as a Wedge
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 5 on the mood in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., after the Tawana Brawley trial and the arrest of a man charged with killing eight women, reversed geographic descriptions of the city. It is the north side that is ragged and partly industrial and the south side that is genteel, not the other way around.

title: Can't Decide if That Centerfold Is Really a Perfect 10? Just Do the Math
description: Good news from England: Statistical criteria may make it easier for a man with stunted perceptual ability to decide whether a woman is sexually attractive, unattractive or just so-so.

title: Researchers Find Signs of Warming in Arctic Air, Ice and Water
description: Having endured arctic storms, dangerous fissures in the ice pack, polar bear intrusions and a year of crushing pressure while frozen into a drifting floe, the Canadian icebreaker Des Groseilliers reached Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, over the weekend. Aboard the vessel was a rich cargo of data expected to reveal subtle mechanisms that drive changes in the world's climate.

title: Auto Makers Experiment With New Fuels
description: Struggling to comply with Federal fuel-economy and emissions regulations even as Americans buy ever-bigger family vehicles, auto makers have quietly begun experiments with oil companies to develop new and potentially cleaner fuels.

description: McSWEENEY-John P. On October 16, 1998 in Broad Run, VA. Husband of Kit, father of Michael K. and James G. McSweeney all of Virginia, brother of Jean Dillon, Massapequa. Mass of Christian Burial on October 20th, at 10 A.M. in Warrenton, VA. Memorials contributions may be made to the Hospice of Northern Virginia, 13168 Centrepointe Way, #

title: 2 Canada Providers Plan Phone Merger
description: The Telus Corporation and BC Telecom agreed to merge today, creating a western Canadian telephone company that can compete nationally with Bell Canada, the nation's biggest phone provider.

title: Remedies For Hair Loss
description: Now that a more potent version of Rogaine has joined Propecia on drugstore shelves, some 33 million American men who have been anxiously counting the hairs in their combs have more options. Here is how they measure up:

title: Choice for Economics Post Spurns Offer by Schroder
description: Throughout his campaign for Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder portrayed himself as a pragmatic ''new'' Social Democrat who would promote economic growth while strengthening Germany's generous social welfare system.

title: Odd Rules on Testimony, Strict Rules on Seating
description: The judge who is hearing the Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation without a jury has imposed unusual procedures that make this trial different from most civil lawsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DONALD
description: LEWIS-Donald. The Board Of Directors of the Usdan Center For The Arts expresses its deep sympathy to the family of our Executive Director, Dale Lewis on the passing of his father, Donald. Dale's devotion to his father is equaled by his dedication to the Usdan Center for which we are extremely grateful. Jerrold Ross, President

title: Gay Philanthropist's Nomination to Become Ambassador to Luxembourg Dies in the Senate
description: The Senate has effectively killed the nomination of James C. Hormel to be Ambassador to Luxembourg, an appointment that would have made him the first openly gay American ambassador, Congressional officials said today.

title: NETSCAPE TO BUNDLE REALNETWORKS PRODUCT IN BROWSER
description: Stock prices for both Realnetworks Inc. and the Netscape Communications Corporation rose yesterday after Realnetworks said it would bundle its Realplayer software with a new version of Netscape's Web browser and its Web site. Realnetworks already distributes the software through the Microsoft Corporation's Web browser, which competes with Netscape. Shares of Realnetworks, based in Seattle, rose $2.50, or 7 percent, to $37.375, and shares of Netscape, based in Mountain View, Calif., rose $3.50, or 17 percent, to $23.75.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Government Attacks Gates As Microsoft Trial Opens

title: Budget Deal Deprives Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Battle Over Preferences, Race and Gender Are at Odds
description: Two years after California voters abolished most affirmative action programs and a year after Houston's residents chose to retain them, the fight has shifted to the Northwest, where voters in Washington State are facing the only ballot initiative on the issue in the country this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MAYNARD
description: PARKER-Maynard. Age 58, died of complications of leukemia on October 16. As reporter, editor, friend, father and husband, he was the best of the best. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, October 22, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. In lieu of flowers please make contributions in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: Corrections
description: A review on the fashion page Thursday about the spring 1999 collections in Paris misspelled the given name of the designer for Comme des Garcons. She is Rei Kawakubo, not Rae.

title: Wax Museum Sold to British Buyout Firm
description: The Tussauds Group, the wax-museum operator that plans to open exhibits in New York and Las Vegas over the next two years, has a new owner.

title: When Body Piercing Causes Body Rash
description: They arrive at Dr. David Cohen's office decked out in metal, wearing rings and studs in their ears, eyebrows, noses, navels, nipples and nether parts. Often, they arrive scratching.

description: Serious, Yes,

description: NEWS

title: Japanese Steelmakers Downgraded by Moody's
description: The credit ratings of the Nippon Steel Corporation, the world's largest steelmaker, and five other Japanese steel companies were cut nearly to junk-bond levels yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited concern that earnings would remain sluggish because of Japan's recession. Japan's steel industry has been hurt by a slump in orders from auto makers and construction companies. Moody's also cited the companies' ''highly leveraged financial profile.''

title: With a Warning, Nevada Lets Tyson Return to Boxing
description: The Nevada State Athletic Commission voted today to restore Mike Tyson's boxing license, 15 months after it was revoked because he bit both of Evander Holyfield's ears in a heavyweight title fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRICK, REV. FREDERICK
description: FRICK-Rev. Frederick. Funeral services Wednesday 10:30AM at Saint Mark's Lutheran Church, 248 Broadway, Norwich, CT. Burial will be private. Calling hours Tuesday, Saint Mark's Church, 12-8PM. Inquiries Church and Allen Funeral Home, 136 Sachem St, Norwich.

title: Human or Chimp? 50 Genes Are the Key
description: Theologians may ponder the difference between God and the creature made in His image, but biologists have always asked a humbler question: How do humans differ from other animals? A proposal now under active discussion promises to provide an answer of possibly disconcerting precision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACKENSON, JOEL J.
description: NACKENSON-Joel J. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Jody P., Bonnie R. and the late Mitchell C. Loving grandfather of Julia Nackenson and Avery Stern. Survived also by brother Lester. Mr. Nackenson was a veteran of World War II.

title: S.E.C. Chairman Is Cautious About Social Security Plans
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that plans to help shore up Social Security by seeking higher returns in the financial markets risked leaving inexperienced investors vulnerable to fraud.

title: 400 Doctors in Dallas Break Contracts With Aetna's H.M.O.
description: In the biggest rebellion yet against a health insurance company, more than 400 doctors in Dallas have terminated their contracts with Aetna Inc.'s health maintenance organization, and Aetna has retaliated by cutting off their access to all its Dallas patients.

title: U.S. Expected to Support Shift in Administration of the Internet
description: Clearing the way for the global Internet to be governed without governments, the Clinton Administration is expected today to commit itself to hand over the administration of the computer network to a nonprofit corporation under a proposal that has won broad support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINMAN, SADIE (NEE KRELLENSTEIN)
description: ZINMAN-Sadie (nee Krellenstein). 94. Died in Palm Beach, FL. Widow of Samuel. She leaves her son Walter, her daughter-in-law Carol Zinman, her daughter Alice, her son-in-law Richard Amelar, her daughter Ann and her son-in-law H. David Leventhal, nine grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. Shiva to be observed at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Amelar, 32 Washington Square West, New York City. Memorial contributions to the Orange County Cerebral Palsey Center, 2 Fletcher Street, Goshen, New York 10924.

title: Stronger U.S. Sales Lift McDonald's Profit
description: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest restaurant company, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 7.4 percent as the company bolstered sales in the United States and weathered economic slumps overseas.

title: BUDGET MAKERS WEIGH LAST ISSUES
description: Lawmakers tonight hurriedly hammered out policy issues ranging from banning poison gas to financing more home care for the elderly, putting the final punctuation in the $500 billion spending bill needed to keep the Government open.

title: The Lewinsky Scandal as Presidential Decoder
description: THE CLINTON ENIGMA:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZULFER, ANTHONY G.
description: ZULFER-Anthony G., age 70, of Chicago, IL. Husband of the late Gail Peterson and the late Joan Ryan. Father of Andrea Marion (Jerry) Gibbs. Cousin of Sister Patricia DaCosta and Patricia (Roy) Bishop. An employee of Stien Roe and Farnham for over 40 years. A memorial service will be held 1PM Saturday, Nov. 7th, St. Chrysostom Episcopal Church, 1434 North Dearborn Parkway, Chicago. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Shattuck-St. Mary School, P.O. 218, Faribault, Minn. 55021. Blake-Lamb Funeral Home, Directors, 312-944-5594.

title: Patterns
description: Europeans to Go Second

title: Plotting the Center Of the New Europe
description: For more than 15 months, Mitchell Shivers, a managing director at Merrill Lynch, and 105 of his associates here have been readying themselves for a single date: Jan. 4, 1999. On that day, after the year-end revelries and a feverish final weekend of preparations, markets across Europe will reawaken to a financial landscape the like of which has never been seen before.

title: Taxicab Kills Traffic Officer, Prompting Calls for New Rules
description: In a crash that immediately provoked calls for tougher regulation of New York City taxi drivers, a traffic enforcement agent was fatally injured yesterday when his three-wheeled Police Department scooter was struck by a yellow cab on the Upper West Side.

title: Pataki Gets Precise on Second-Term Goals
description: With the election just over two weeks away, Gov. George E. Pataki, who has largely avoided laying out a detailed agenda for a second term, offered a few more specifics about his goals yesterday, citing a further push to reduce crime and to move welfare recipients off the rolls.

title: Metro Business; Studios Planned for 42d St.
description: Design plans were unveiled yesterday for The New 42d Street Studios, a 10-story building on West 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues that will provide rehearsal and office space for nonprofit performing arts companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SAMUEL
description: WEINER-Samuel. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Samuel Weiner, associated with The Times from 1958, until retiring in 1985.

title: A Dividend Of Conflict In 'Tosca'
description: When the New York-born soprano Aprile Millo made her Metropolitan Opera debut in 1984 as Amelia in Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra,'' there was talk among critics and opera buffs that the next important Verdi soprano had arrived. She seemed to be a true spinto soprano, combining lyric and dramatic vocal qualities, a singer in the tradition of Zinka Milanov and Leontyne Price.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOBER, HARRY A.
description: STOBER-Harry A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harry A. Stober, associated with The Times from 1973, until retiring in 1982.

title: Kanell Has a Lump Removed
description: Giants quarterback Danny Kanell had a peanut-size lump removed from the left side of his chest today, a lump that appeared to be benign and posed no serious health risk, according to the team.

title: Artists Who Challenge Sedate Chamber Image
description: Carnegie Hall, common wisdom holds, is no fit place for small-scale chamber works. But the performances there on Thursday evening by the cellist Mischa Maisky and the pianist Martha Argerich were not items with which you would want to be trapped in a small room. They were wild in their amplitude and intensity: not chamber performances in any conventional sense but something created, it seemed, specifically for the space.

title: Publicis in Deals With Asian Agencies
description: Publicis S.A. in Paris has acquired stakes in and formed affiliations with agencies in Asia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, DAVID
description: RAPOPORT-David. Shelter Rock Jewish Center mourns the passing of David Rapoport, devoted father of our devoted board members Nancy and Dr. Steven Goldstein. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Myron Fenster Dr. Stanley Shanies, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTMAN, EPHRAIM M.
description: LICHTMAN-Ephraim M. Of Fort Lee. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Debra, Gabel, and Karen Dugan. Loving grandfather of Daniel, Jared, and Lauren. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack, New Jersey, Tuesday at 10:00 AM. 1-800-522-0588

title: A Dictator's Arrest
description: To the Editor:

title: Fears of Sorcerers Spur Killings in Java
description: Shrieking triumphantly and waving bloody sickles and knives, about 30 motorcyclists drove slowly through town in a victory celebration. Onlookers cheered and the atmosphere was half-exultant, like that of a carnival.

title: Finding Calcium Sources Outside the Dairy Case
description: Photos of famous men and women sporting mustaches of milk have become familiar advertisements for a calcium-rich food that has fallen on hard times. Milk consumption has been dropping for the last three decades, and calcium nutrition among both young and old has collapsed with it. Some experts predict an epidemic of osteoporosis because today's children and teen-agers, who guzzle sodas and juice drinks instead of milk, are consuming about half the amount of calcium from foods that youngsters did in 1950.

title: On the Eve of Glenn's Shuttle Flight, Concerns Over a Lull in Launchings
description: Behind the excitement of the coming spaceflight of Senator John Glenn is quiet apprehension about hidden dangers.

title: Brown Seen As Likely To Start In Game 4
description: His team trailing, two games to none, San Diego Padres Manager Bruce Bochy wrestled today with who his starting pitcher would be in Game 4 of the World Series.

title: A Secret of Health in Old Age: Muscles
description: Fred Kovaleski, a former State Department official, stares across the net at Jason Morton in the thick of their fight for the title of No. 1 tennis player in the world. Mr. Kovaleski is losing, something he has not had much experience with during the past 60 years, and he is not delighted. But in a corner of his brain is lodged a thought that is becoming more and more common in a rapidly expanding segment of the American population: ''I can't wait to get older.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHER, TOBIE B.
description: OHER-Tobie B. On October 17. Of Skokie, IL. Mother of Jim (Susan), Kathy and Joe. Grandmother of Sam, Jake and Andrea. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Jim Oher Tuesday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/4010/20/90. Cherished Mother...I'll never forget. Alliso

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREMER, SAMUEL, ESQ.
description: FREMER-Samuel, Esq. On October 17, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Florence Hans. Loving father of Judith Kotick Hans, Dr. Susan Hans and Michael Fremer. Grandfather of Robert Kotick, Debbie Kotick Gruber, Jonathan Hansburg, David Hansburg, and great-grandfather of Jordan, Morgan and Grace. Graduate of St. John's University Law School, founder of New York Abstract Co., V.P. First American Title Co., expert in the field of real estate law. A private service wil be held on Tuesday, October 20.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. We deeply mourn the tragic passing of a dear friend and counselor. We shall always cherish the memory of our long and rewarding relationship with him. May his dear wife and children be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Max Wasser, Michael Lipstein, Charles Steinman, Ira Wasser, and Shaul Wasser

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Clorox acquires First Brands, and Wall Street cheers. Apparently there's money in cat litter.
description: YOU might wonder why anyone would want to be the nation's No. 1 maker of kitty litter. But for G. Craig Sullivan, chief executive of the Clorox Company, such a distinction is part of where he wants the company to go.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Individual Instruments

title: Name of the Game Is Jury, Not Barney, a Judge Decides
description: Because his nickname is Barney, Liborio Salvatore Bellomo, a reputedly powerful New York Mafia leader, got disappointing news yesterday: he has to stay in New Jersey.

title: By Design; Styles in Bloom
description: In the spring styles on European runways, it's all in the details. Although most designers used a light hand, they left almost nothing totally unadorned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, IRWIN
description: LOWENTHAL-Irwin. The Staff Society of Long Island Jewish Medical Center deeply mourns the passing of a dedicated colleague Dr. Irwin Lowenthal. His thirty years of devoted service will not be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Linda and family. Staff Society of LIJ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, MANUEL L.
description: BLOCK-Manuel L. The Officers, Board of Trustees and members of Temple Sinai of Bergen County, Tenafly, N.J. deeply mourns the passing of Manuel L. Block beloved father of our Rabbi, Bruce S. Block. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Lillian and daughter-in-law Terrie and his grandsons Jeremy and Joshua and to the entire family. The funeral was held Monday, October 19th in Newport Beach, CA. Richard Simon, President Nitza Amit, Cantor

title: Federal Housing Investigator Broadens Inquiry
description: Responding to charges that she was driven by racial and political considerations, the nation's chief housing investigator has broadened an inquiry into possible fraud in housing-assistance programs to include Long Island and other locales.

title: Pope's Encyclical Noted Peril of Our Age; Skepticism Is Critical
description: To the Editor:

title: WPP Group Reports Higher 3d-Quarter Sales
description: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's second-largest advertising company, said yesterday that its third-quarter sales had risen 11 percent as acquisitions and new business helped revenue grow faster than it had in the first half of 1998. Revenue in the three months to September rose to $:471 million ($801 million) from $:423.9 million in the period a year earlier, with about a third of the growth from acquisitions.

title: Guitar Fireworks On a Rare Visit
description: One might have thought that a guitar recital on the night of the first game of the World Series would be a difficult sell in Yankee-mad New York, but the 92d Street Y was well packed for the Saturday evening concert by the Australian guitarist John Williams. One reason, no doubt, is that Mr. Williams, an extraordinary player with a large and enthusiastic following, tours the United States infrequently. It could be, too, that concertgoers hoped they could have it both ways: intermission came just as the Padres were rallying in the third inning, and even staying for encores, one could make it home in time for the Yankees' seventh-inning fireworks.

title: Rejection of Arthritis Therapy Hurts Stock
description: Anika Therapeutics Inc.'s shares plunged today after the Food and Drug Administration rejected its Orthovisc treatment for osteoarthritis of the knee.

title: INSIDE
description: Fire at Disputed Ski Area

title: Two Satellites to Study Sun During Discovery Mission
description: In spite of past problems, NASA engineers say they are optimistic about plans to have two satellites make joint observations of the Sun during the next space shuttle mission.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't know if I'm prepared to fight by the end of the year. I've been going through a lot psychologically.''

title: N.B.A. Owners Needn't Pay Locked-Out Players
description: An arbitrator ruled against the National Basketball Players Association yesterday, deciding that players with guaranteed contracts need not be paid during the current lockout. The decision, on a grievance filed by the union, represented an important victory for the owners in a labor dispute that has already brought cancellation of the first two weeks of the regular season.

title: Panel Backs Drug Tests For High School Athletes
description: The State Senate Education Committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday allowing school districts to conduct random drug tests of high school athletes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMATOU, SONIA, M.D.
description: DIMATOU-Sonia, M.D. On Oct. 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Alexandros Eleftheriadis, devoted sister of Andreas Dimatos. Service and interment in Greece. Contributions in her memory may be made to breast cancer research.

title: A Dictator's Arrest
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN ENTERPRISES TO PURCHASE COLONIAL GAS
description: Eastern Enterprises said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Colonial Gas Company for $332 million in stock and cash, plus assumed debt of $163 million. Colonial Gas, based in Lowell, Mass., is a regulated natural gas utility serving more than 150,000 customers northwest of Boston and on Cape Cod. It had revenue of $187.1 million in 1997. Eastern Enterprises, based in Weston, Mass., is the holding company for the Boston Gas Company, a supplier of natural gas in Boston and elsewhere in the state. It had revenue of $970.2 million in 1997. Shares of Colonial Gas rose 14 percent, or $4.1875, to $33.75.

title: Neil T. Shayne, 66, a Founder of Law Firm
description: Neil T. Shayne, a founder and senior partner of the law firm of Shayne, Dachs, Stanisci, Corker & Sauer in Mineola, N.Y., died Sept. 24 at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens. He was 66 years old.

title: Earnings at J. P. Morgan Tumble by 60%
description: J. P. Morgan & Company's third-quarter earnings plunged a greater-than-expected 60 percent as slumping worldwide markets hurt trading revenue. Its stock, already battered in anticipation of bad results, rose 3.77 percent yesterday on optimism that the worst was over at the nation's No. 4 bank.

title: Defensive Players Lead Fire
description: Two defensive players for the Chicago Fire, the expansion team that has reached Sunday's championship game, won major awards yesterday. The two, Zack Thornton and Lubos Kubik, were voted goalkeeper and defender of the year, respectively, by Major League Soccer's coaches and general managers.

title: A Brother's Death Helps Bring a Performance to Life
description: Somewhere between the production of ''Wit'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven last November and the production of ''Wit'' that reopened at the MCC Theater in Manhattan this month, Kathleen Chalfant says, her performance got better.

title: CABARET
description: Sly Minimalism

title: Adjusting House and Body Clocks
description: When Americans go off daylight time at 2 A.M. on Sunday, they will need to set their clocks -- and their bodies -- back an hour.

title: 3 Children Missing In Texas Flooding
description: Stymied by persistent rain, the authorities in Texas searched in vain for three children swept away by floods during weekend storms that killed 14 people.

title: IPC INFORMATION SYSTEMS TO BUY REUTERS VOICE SYSTEMS
description: IPC Information Systems Inc., the leading American provider of voice trading systems to financial companies, said yesterday that it would buy Reuters Voice Systems, a unit of Reuters Group P.L.C., the world's largest financial information provider, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The unit supplies dealer boards, also known as turrets, to about 10,000 end users within such financial institutions as investment banks and brokerage companies. IPC, which sells the Tradenet electronic trading system, is hoping the acquisition will help expand its business in Europe. IPC, based in New York, said it would finance the purchase through a combination of cash from operations and borrowing and expected to complete it by the end of the year.

title: 3 Children Still Missing As Texas Floods Worsen
description: Stymied by persistent rain, authorities searched in vain today for three children swept away by flood waters during storms that have killed 15 people since the weekend in Texas.

title: New Criteria
description: The listing of corporate earnings in Business Day covers companies that have at least $100 million in quarterly revenue. Banking and insurance companies, which do not usually report revenue, will be covered in the listing if their total assets exceed $2 billion.

title: October Fans Join Summer Fanatics on Yankee Bandwagon
description: Nothing else matters. Nothing else, it seems, is permitted to matter: only the nine-inning tallies and intervening dramas of a handful of baseball games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, BERNARD
description: SHERMAN-Bernard. October 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Marlene. Loving father of David, Esther, Shalom, Tova, and Eli. Brother of Joe and Phil. He will be greatly missed by family, friends, and community.

title: Kia Motors' Suitor Must Now Face Reluctant Bankers
description: Now that the Hyundai Motor Company has won the auction to take a controlling stake in the bankrupt Kia Motors Corporation and its Asia Motors subsidiary, it remains to be seen whether Kia's creditors will agree to the bid.

title: Officer Is Relieved of Command After Sex Misconduct Complaint
description: The captain of a Navy destroyer has been temporarily relieved of his command amid an investigation into accusations of inappropriate sexual behavior involving an enlisted sailor aboard his ship, Navy officials said today.
