title: NABORS TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF DRILLING EQUIPMENT
description: Nabors Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bayard Drilling Technologies, based in Oklahoma City, for about $225.5 million in stock, cash and assumed debt. The acquisition will add Bayard's 87 United States drilling rigs to Nabors's 400 onshore rigs and 33 offshore rigs worldwide. Bayard, a maker of drilling equipment and provider of oilfield services, also has a large inventory of drilling components. Shares in Nabors, based in Houston, fell $1.1875, to $16.4375. Shares in Bayard rose $1, to $5.9375.

title: Kroger to Buy Fred Meyer, Creating Country's Biggest Grocer
description: The Kroger Company said yesterday that it would acquire Fred Meyer Inc. in a deal that would create a supermarket giant with $43 billion in annual revenue and 2,200 stores in 31 states.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: What's Good for Microsoft . . .
description: The Justice Department is suing Microsoft for the antitrust offenses of ''tying'' and ''predatory pricing.'' It claims that Microsoft illegally tied its Internet browser to its Windows software because the company sells them only as a package, and that it was selling the package below cost because it didn't raise the price of Windows when it added the browser.

title: Kurds Are Players
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, O. NILE
description: BELL-O. Nile. On Monday, October 19th, 1998. O. Nile Bell of Potomac, Maryland, beloved husband of Joanne Mackey Bell, devoted father of Anne Ashley Bell, brother of Margaret Bell Smith. He is also survived by several brothersin-law, sisters-in-law & numerous nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street, N.W. on Wednesday from 6-8 P.M. Services will be held at the National Presbyterian Church, 4101 Nebraska Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20016, Thursday at 11 A.M. Interment will be held in Clarksville, Missouri. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the National Center for Leadership, C/O The National Presbyterian Church or the charity of your choice.

title: Budget Deal Deprives Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Widens Charges for Pinochet; He Signals He'll Fight Extradition
description: As a Spanish judge broadened genocide charges against him, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator detained here for extradition hearings, indicated today that he would resolutely oppose any attempt to try him in Madrid.

title: Internet Filter Makes Bad Censor
description: To the Editor:

title: Promise of Spring Is Unfulfilled For Fox This Fall
description: At the end of the last television season, Fox was hot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMLER, JUDGE JOSEPH H.
description: STAMLER-Judge Joseph H. At his home in Stony Creek, Conn. Formerly of Summit, NJ. Leaves his wife Lillian Spitzer Stamler, son Joseph H. Stamler, Jr., and wife Ann of Fairfield, CT, and son S. Paul Stamler and wife Amy of Stony Creek, CT, grandchildren Abigail Hopkins Stamler, S. Reed Stamler, Theodore Joseph Stamler, and stepgrandson Forrest Page. Funeral arrangements are private. Memorial contributions may be made to: The Willoughby Wallace Memorial Library, 146 Thimble Islands Rd., Stony Creek, CT. 06405; Rescue Company #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAYZE, PHYLLIS SMITH
description: SWAYZE-Phyllis Smith, 92, Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, died at home Friday, October 16, 1998. Survivors are children, Joan Williams and John, Townsend and Henry Swayze; sister, Kathleen E. Smith; 11 grandchildren; 1 greatgrandchild. Memorial service, 2PM, October 31, Church of the Good Shepherd, Wantage, NJ. For information, Glackin/Saul Funeral Home, 136 Morrison Avenue, Hightstown, New Jersey 08520.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHLIS, JOSEPH
description: MACHLIS-Joseph. The entire Queens College community mourns the death of our beloved professor of the joys of music, Joseph Machlis, who gave thousands a lifelong appreciation of the art of beautiful listening during his thirtyfive years as a teacher at the College. His generous heart and brilliance in creative expression enthralled all who met him or read his words in textbooks or novels. He remained a member of the College family after his retirement. It was a thrilling moment in our history when we were able to award him an honorary degree as a special convocation on the occasion of his ninetieth birthday, with so many of those he befriended present and able to shower their love on him. He was an irreplaceable human being, unique in his wit and warmth and ability to share his feelings and his devotion to the great art of music. We will never forget him. Allen Lee Sessoms, President Queens College

title: Review/Fashion; Wedding Clothes for Everyday
description: At different points in relationships, ''Je T'Aime, Moi Non Plus'' and ''Here Comes the Bride'' are the songs against which women play out their love lives, and it was fitting that Yohji Yamamoto used both in his wry, magnificent show.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DECLINES. The dollar fell against the yen for a fourth consecutive session on expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates a third time this year. The dollar dropped to 114.28 yen, from 115.25 Friday.

title: In Their Own Words
description: ALFONSE M. D'AMATO

title: C. David Marsden, 60, Expert In Certain Movement Disorders
description: C. David Marsden, a British neurologist who was one of the world's leading authorities on movement disorders like Parkinson's disease, died on Sept. 29 at his American residence in Columbia, Md. A resident of Ash, in Kent, England, he was 60 and had just begun a one-year sabbatical, his first, at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.

title: POP
description: Bending Notes,

title: Democrat Gains as Ad Attacks Vote for Impeachment Inquiry
description: In a finding that could prompt other Democrats to make voter distaste for an impeachment inquiry an issue in their campaigns, a poll made public yesterday found that former Representative Jay Inslee, a Democrat running for the House in Washington State, has gained ground since he began running a commercial about impeachment.

title: Testaverde the Answer For the Time Being
description: While walking onto the practice field one day late last week, Jets Coach Bill Parcells, in that loud, raspy voice of his, said something to quarterback Vinny Testaverde that shocked a small group of players accustomed to shocking Parcells statements. ''Vinny,'' several of the players recalled the coach saying, ''you're my quarterback for the rest of the season.''

title: Ellis Island May Receive $2 Million for Repairs
description: Ellis Island would get $2 million toward the stabilization of 29 buildings on its so-called ''sad side,'' under an appropriations bill that Congress may vote on as early as today, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An Advertising column on Oct. 7 about Tiger Electronics Inc.'s new Furby toy misidentified the agency that created the first ads for Cabbage Patch dolls. It was Richard & Edwards, not Posner & Kolker.

title: Where to Find Chess and the Computer Column
description: The Chess column has a new home. It now appears on Sundays in the main news section. The page number is shown in the index on page 2 of that section.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLISEY, JAMES V.
description: HALLISEY-James V. The Board of Trustees of Marymount School and the entire School community mourn the death of our dear friend and former Trustee. A man of integrity, he shared his legal expertise, strong leadership and wisdom with the School. He will be fondly remembered for his love of Marymount and for his generous support. Our deepest sympathies to alumna Tamara Hallisey-Hatfield '76, James V. Hallisey, Jr. and his entire family.

title: The Next-Best Thing? Padres May Relive '84
description: Talk about poor timing. The San Diego Padres get to the World Series twice in their 30-year history, and they play the 1984 Detroit Tigers and the 1998 Yankees.

title: Grenades Wound 67 in Israeli Bus Station
description: As the peace talks in Maryland entered their fifth day, a grenade attack on a busy bus terminal in this modern desert town today left 67 people wounded, one gravely, and cast a shadow over the fragile negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, BERNARD J.
description: EDELMAN-Bernard J. On October 17th, 1998, of Boca Raton, Florida. Loving husband of Carol. Adored father of Dr. Reed and Cathy Edelman, Dr. Judi and David Shor, Meredith, Jarrod and Jordan. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Matthew, Carolyn, Jaclyn and Michael.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Irish Eyes Smiled, And Others, Too

title: Change accounts here and accounts there, and pretty soon they add up to $230 million worth.
description: MADISON AVENUE bustled in recent days as a variety of marketers made changes on advertising assignments that had total billings estimated at more than $230 million.

title: The Arrest of General Pinochet
description: In a development sure to bring shivers to the world's dictators, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is under arrest in a London clinic where he went for surgery. He is held at the request of a Spanish court, accused of genocide and the murder and torture of dozens of Spanish and other citizens in Chile after his 1973 military coup. His detention and possible prosecution are warranted under international law.

title: Motto for a Movie Tough Guy: Semper Fi
description: SOMEHOW it is not a surprise that Harvey Keitel is a former Marine. Or that he longs to go to war with the Marines every time there is action. Or that every Marine he meets is an instant brother. ''There's been this journey, this rite of passage, of feeling like a man,'' Mr. Keitel said last week. Ask anybody who knows him: Harvey just loves the Marines.

title: Stock Prices Rise Again; Dow Up 49
description: Stock prices moved higher again yesterday, the sixth advance in the last seven sessions, as investors remained optimistic about the economic benefits of recent interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: F. Story Musgrave; Watching From Sidelines as NASA Regains Spotlight
description: It was a sweltering recent autumn afternoon and F. Story Musgrave, 63, physician, poet, sky diver and now former astronaut, was sitting in a Florida hotel room and fiddling with a recalcitrant air-conditioner. ''I'll get this going in a flash,'' declared Dr. Musgrave, the former space walker. ''I'm real good at fixing things.''

title: In Terms of Jobs, A One-Street Town
description: Middle Eastern oil emirates are the classic one-commodity economies. When oil prices boom, the sheiks build hospitals and air-conditioned palaces, buy fighter jets and import tens of thousands of service workers. When oil prices sink, the hospitals crumble, the service workers are sent home and wrecks of Mercedes rust in the sand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEEHANDELAAR, FREDERIK J.
description: ZEEHANDELAAR - Frederik J. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Devoted father of Eric, Randi, David, and Mona. Loving grandfather of Dara, Rachel, Daniel, and Travis. Services today 1:30 pm at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Pope's Encyclical Noted Peril of Our Age; Secular Philosophers
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting Holy Cows
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Three Parts Make a Whole Soup
description: I ALWAYS love it when I can apply a simple formula to a broad range of dishes. And it seldom works as well as it does with creamy vegetable soups.

title: Getting Rid of That Heap, While Saving a Heap of Trouble
description: THERE comes a time in every car owner's life when a crucial, anxiety-producing decision must be made: how to get rid of the old car to make way for the new one.

title: Suspicious Fires Shed a Light On Dark Grumblings in Vail
description: The suspicious fires that erupted across a snowy mountain ridge high above here on Monday were still unsolved today, but they have shed light on the dark grumblings in the town below about a corporate ski giant that is seen by many residents as aggressively acquiring water, business, real estate and Forest Service land.

title: Shoney's Will Sell or Close 84 Restaurants
description: Shoney's Inc. said today that it would sell 34 restaurants to Elias Brothers by early next year and close 50 locations by the end of January to focus on its restaurants in the Southeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIN, PAUL
description: ROCHLIN-Paul. On Oct. 19, 1998, devoted husband to Marjorie, superb father to Jonathan, loving brother and uncle to Miriam and Michael. He will be dearly missed. Services Thursday, Oct. 22, 11:00 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory to Gilda's Club.

title: Intel Consolidates Consumer Accounts
description: The Intel Corporation has consolidated consumer advertising, with American billings estimated at $100 million, at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, which began sharing the account with the longtime Intel agency, Euro RSCG DSW Partners in San Francisco, only eight months ago.

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret review yesterday about the singer and pianist Blossom Dearie misstated the address of Danny's Skylight Room. It is at 346 West 46th Street in Manhattan, not 56th Street.

title: New Delhi Journal; Sacred Cows Are Wily Too; Just Try Catching One
description: It takes eight men to capture a street-smart cow, so the municipal cow catchers of New Delhi must squeeze together tightly in the cab of their cattle truck. There are two parts to their important job and only one is easy: finding the cows. Getting the beasts into the truck is where these workers really earn their $119 a month.

title: How Do You Add Up Sales Figures? Let Us Count the Ways
description: WHAT is America's most popular car? It depends on what you mean -- the car bought by the most people or the car that sells the most over all?

title: TRANSACTION NETWORK IN TALKS WITH POTENTIAL BUYER
description: Transaction Network Services Inc., a large handler of credit card transactions, said yesterday that it had been approached by a potential acquirer. Transaction Network, based in Reston, Va., said no agreement had been reached and that issues such as financing remained unresolved. It did not identify the prospective buyer. The shares fell $3.9375, to $26.50, as the company reported earnings that were slightly below analysts' expectations. Third-quarter net income fell to $2.1 million, or 16 cents a diluted share, from $2.3 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier. It was expected to earn 17 cents a share.

title: About New York; Happy to Be In the Bronx, The Boss Says
description: HERBERT and Walter Glaser don't want to leave the South Bronx, even if their neighbor has bad-mouthed the block and been tempted by New Jersey. Suitors send them letters trying to lure them from the city. They toss them into the garbage. They like their location, especially the nearby highways and subways.

title: Winter of Discontent For Fans of the N.B.A.
description: As the owners and the players of the National Basketball Association try to negotiate how to divide $2 billion worth of revenue, fans across the country are growing disenchanted. They view the labor dispute as a battle between rich vs. rich at the expense of people who buy high-priced tickets and team merchandise that has made the league flourish for the last two decades.

title: Beersheba Suspect Confesses to Other Terrorist Attacks, Israeli Army Aides Say
description: The Palestinian arrested in the grenade assault on Monday that wounded 67 Israelis, including 24 soldiers, has confessed to several recent terrorist incidents, Israeli Army officials said today.

title: The Top Quarterbacks Are Aging to Perfection
description: Pro football teams in recent years have been enamored of youth. Youth usually means speed, quickness and an open mind that can be easily molded. Youth has often meant a cheaper player, one who fits more easily under the salary cap. Youth has meant freshness, a bushel of players less prone to injury who often heal more quickly.

title: You Can See Murrow Now, Again
description: The most satisfying moment in ''A Question of Loyalty'' comes in the second act when Senator Joseph McCarthy, seen in black-and-white close-up on a large screen, questions a demure black woman who has been brought before his committee on accusations of being a Communist. The woman, seated onstage just below the screen and played by Kimberly (Q) Purnell, insists politely that she's not the person they're looking for. Come now, says McCarthy (Don Creech), does she expect him to believe there's another Annie Lee Moss of Washington? ''Three, sir,'' she answers. ''There are three Annie Lee Mosses, sir.'' And she points out that all three are in the phone book.

title: From Luxury Good to Expensive Wrapper
description: The announcement of cutbacks in reporters and producers at CBS News continues a discouraging trend for nightly network news. Not that the old favorites, presided over by Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather, have altogether lost their punch. Millions of viewers still tune in; the network trademarks are still potent, and the anchors remain among the most famous and trusted television personalities.

title: Struggling in the Wind Tunnel to Keep Its Sound Out
description: EVEN drivers who love to feel the road don't want to hear it.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; The Man Who Keeps Mercedes Up to Date
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

title: Who Is Served by More Concrete?
description: ADDISON, VT., which lies on a fertile ridge near Lake Champlain, has long defined itself by two seemingly unchangeable resources: green pastures that feed hundreds of dairy cattle and old state Route 22A, the region's main highway that runs through the center of town.

title: How a Fall Ritual Became a Year-Round Circus
description: A PRODIGIOUS pothole has turned one of the A-arms in your car's suspension into an M. The rear-wheel bearing sounds like a nest of hungry sparrows. Sparky the dog has spent far too much time in the back seat. You need a new car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, VIRGINIA BERGEN
description: BLACK-Virginia Bergen. Of New York City and Shelter Island, New York. On September 23, 1998. Daughter of the late Douglas McCrae Black and Maude Bergen Black. Direct descendant of Sarah Rapalje, the first child of European parents born in New Amsterdam. She was a graduate of The Nightingale Bamford School, New York, New York and St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York and was a member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, associate member of the Amateur Comedy Club of New York and a member of the former St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Auxiliary. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Red Cross-Shelter Island Chapter, P.O. Box 830, Shelter Island, New York, 11964; the Shelter Island Presbyterian Church, Shelter Island, New York 11964 or St. Lawrence University, Canton, New York 13617, would be appreciated. Memorial service in the Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, NY at 11:00 a.m., on Friday, October 23, 1998.

title: Bankruptcy Unit Is Bought
description: Trumbull Services, a subsidiary of the Hartford Financial Services Group, bought the bankruptcy services company W. R. Gruber to expand its own newly formed bankruptcy unit.

title: Hot Chocolate of Kings
description: WHEN chilly nights call for steamy, foamy mugs of hot chocolate, consider that it was once the drink of Aztec kings.

title: When Worlds Collide: Bugattis for Cancer Research
description: THERE is the world of high-tech medical research, with its gleaming laboratories, world-renowned scientists and low-key fund-raising aimed at inducing the well-to-do to dedicate a part of their wealth in the pursuit of cures for diseases.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; A Dash Of Flash For BMW
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 7 of Robert Allen, an actor who played the original Texas Ranger in 1930's westerns, misstated several aspects of his career. Mr. Allen was never nominated for an Academy Award. He appeared in supporting and not principal roles in Broadway productions of ''Show Boat,'' ''Auntie Mame'' and ''Kiss Them for Me.'' He appeared in a revival of ''Show Boat,'' not the original production. And neither the Walt Disney Company nor the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences could confirm the existence of a film called ''Brimstone, the Amish Horse,'' in which Mr. Allen's family said he appeared.

title: New York, a Nice Place to Visit; Thanks a Lot, Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Civil Rhode Island Governor's Race Seeks Spice if Not Mud
description: The somewhat wistful word on the street here is that this year's governor's race is a bore, a plodding match between two candidates who are so decent and civil that they cannot summon the almost mandatory vitriol that has traditionally made Rhode Island politics a full-contact sport. Heck, people say, there isn't even a good scandal brewing.

title: Put Down the Coffee, Hang Up the Phone, and Pull Over
description: A FUNDAMENTAL problem with the debate about speed limits is that it started when people did nothing but drive when they were driving.

title: The Car as a Canvas: Adventures in Accessorizing
description: For most people, buying a car means choosing a vehicle ad options package. The car is delivered, end of story. You drive it the way they made it.

title: Recalling the Pickup, 20 Years B.C. (Before Cup Holders)
description: AN Idahoan once told me that here and there in the mountain West you would come across a dirt airstrip, usually not far from a trout stream, and usually with an unowned or at least unclaimed battered old pickup truck parked alongside. The keys would be in it.

title: Pact Reached on Shape of German Coalition
description: Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder reached a final agreement today on the shape of a new left-of-center government that has pledged itself to redistribute taxes, shut down nuclear power plants and restrengthen Germany's generous social welfare programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, ADALINE HAVEMEYER PERKINS
description: RAND-Adaline Havemeyer Perkins. On October 2, in Needham, Mass. Memorial service at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, on Thursday, October 22, at 10 A.M.

title: BankAmerica President Says He Will Quit
description: David Coulter, the president of the newly merged BankAmerica Corporation, resigned yesterday, days after the company stunned investors when it announced huge losses because of a loan to a hedge fund.

title: No Way to Handle a Protest
description: Outrage and fear brought thousands of marchers into midtown Manhattan Monday night to protest the brutal murder of a gay college student in Wyoming last week. The death of 21-year-old Matthew Shepard, who had been beaten and lashed to a fence near Laramie, was worthy of what was billed as a ''political funeral'' in a major center of gay life.

title: In the Debate Over Speed, There Are Few Facts, No Limits
description: WHEN Congress imposed a national speed limit of 55 miles per hour after the oil embargo of 1973, it said the move would save billions of gallons of gas. But little did Congress know just how much ink would be spilled debating whether such a speed limit would be good for the nation.

title: Environmental Infomercial to Run
description: The Advertising Council in New York has teamed up with the Environmental Protection Agency and Earth Share, both of Washington, to introduce what is called the first national public service campaign in a long format -- in other words, a kind of pro bono infomercial.

title: Press Paid Too Much Heed To Speculation, Critics Say
description: Major news organizations, long under fire for their coverage of the investigation into President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, showed reasonable care with facts but sometimes placed unreasonable credence in investigators' speculation, according to a new study by a watchdog group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, LEONARD H.
description: BARON-Leonard H. On October 19, 1998. Retired Executive of Joseph H. Cohen & Sons Mens Clothing and Biltex International Textiles. Husband of Cynthia, father of Marc, Sandy and Michael. Father-in-law of Gail, Janet and Paulette. Brother of Stanley. Grandfather of Jay, Scott, Rebecca, Emily, Hannah and Zachary. Graveside service on Thursday 11:30 AM at Riversville Cemetery, Glenville, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions to Connor Moran Children's Cancer Care, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Brosius' Homers Put Yanks Within One Victory of a Title
description: The day before the playoffs began, David Cone was asked to pick one Yankee who might shine in the post-season.

title: Why America's Left Foot Has Less and Less to Do
description: BARBARA CROOK has been driving since she was 14, but she was afraid to get behind the wheel of my Honda Prelude. There was nothing wrong with the little black coupe -- indeed, Mrs. Crook had just bought it to use as her family's second car -- but she was just scared. She is one of a large and growing population of motorists who have never stirred a manual gearbox.

title: Jitters on Wall Street, Caution on the Menu
description: WALL STREET'S seismic tremors have barely rattled the glassware in most New York restaurants. The question is whether there will be aftershocks.

title: Why Scary Highways Can Be the Safer Choice
description: IMPROVING the car and the driver -- installing air bags, for example, and cracking down on drunkenness -- have been celebrated in the fight against auto fatalities that has steadily lowered the highway death toll over the years.

title: Agencies Selected For 2 Drug Accounts
description: Two drug companies named agencies yesterday to handle the introductions of new products.

title: Telecom Italia Buys 25% Of Telekom Austria
description: Telecom Italia S.p.A. gained a foothold north of the Alps yesterday, winning a 25 percent stake in Telekom Austria A.G., but analysts said it had paid a high price. The former Italian telephone monopoly paid 27.226 billion schillings ($2.4 billion) for the stake in the Austrian telephone company after raising its initial offer by an estimated 4 billion schillings to overcome competition from the Chicago-based Ameritech Corporation.

title: Raw, Then Desperate: A Life Destroyed
description: Lenny Bruce's last laugh echoes throughout ''Lenny Bruce: Swear to Tell the Truth,'' a cleverly titled documentary recalling his life, work and punishing legal travails. In this intimate and affectingly nostalgic portrait, the lacerating comic emerges as someone whose talent and long shadow have unequivocally withstood the test of time.

title: New York, a Nice Place to Visit; More Exciting Skyline
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, CHRISTOPHER J.
description: GEORGES-Christopher J. On October 20th, 1998. Beloved son of Jerry and Mary. Loving brother of Stephanie Comfort and Gigi. Reposing at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 Street. Funeral service at the Greek Cathedral or the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St., N.Y.C. 12 noon. Mr. Georges will lie in state from 10 A.M. to 12 noon Thursday at The Greek Cathedral.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Basketball On the Menu

title: New York, a Nice Place to Visit; Ask the Women
description: To the Editor:

title: The Holocaust as a Teaching Tool; Survivors and Spielberg Move Difficult Students
description: The two dozen high school students had been asked to define the word ''struggle,'' and as the conversation bounced around the classroom like a rubber ball, they told how the word had visited their lives.

title: A Look Ahead: Nylon in the Engine, Plastic for the Body
description: NOT too long ago, cars meant steel -- thousands of pounds of sheet steel, shaped steel and steel fasteners. Not too long from now, it's going to be anybody's guess as to what cars will be made of: precolored plastic for the roofs, foam for the headliner, even engines with more nylon than iron. But behind these transformations is the material most basic to car design -- paper, as in money.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about Navassa, an uninhabited Caribbean island claimed by the United States and Haiti, omitted the credit. The photograph was supplied by the Center for Marine Conservation, an environmental group based in Washington.

title: Siberia as Winter Comes: Hungry, Cold and Broke
description: To the Russians crazy enough to live there, summer in the Siberian Arctic is merely a deep breath before the next winter, a few weeks of melted ice and midnight sun in which to gird for the next deep freeze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRISH, JAMES PETER
description: GERRISH-James Peter. Beloved friend of so many, died Sunday, October 18 at New York Hospital. Memorial services will be held on October 29 at 6:00 PM at The Holy Name Church, 207 W. 96 St., NYC.

title: Duval Tries To Secure Money Title
description: If David Duval gets his wish, he will clinch the PGA Tour money title this weekend.

title: A Southern Italian Renaissance; After red sauce, America is discovering the real thing.
description: SALVATORE ANZALONE, the chef at Caffe Bondi in Manhattan, had a banged-up pan heating on the stove and just six ingredients in front of him. He reached for one of them -- a few brown grains that smelled powerfully salty and pungent.

title: Deutsche Bank Is Reportedly Seeking U.S. Acquisition
description: Deutsche Bank, eager to buy a concern that will enhance its international investment banking business, has been scouting out prospects, including the Bankers Trust Corporation, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and J. P. Morgan & Company, bankers and analysts said yesterday.

title: Magical Year, Immortal Game
description: It's World Series time and yet people are still buzzing about the regular season. How fabulous is baseball? So fabulous that you can't kill it with a stick.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; Bold American Style With a Hot-Rod Heart
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

title: Friendly Music And Style
description: Making acoustic jazz into popular music again -- in the literal sense of the term -- while respecting its dignity is an extraordinarily difficult navigation, and most musicians shrink from the task entirely. The saxophonist Joshua Redman will be remembered, among other reasons, for brusquely assuming that straight-ahead jazz can have the drive and appeal of popular music, and his campaign has gotten sharper with each successive album.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZLER, LUCILLE H.
description: SCHNITZLER-Lucille H. Died on October 20, 1998 at the age of 92. Beloved daughter of the late Harry and Bertha Wilkus. Wife of the late Laurence Schnitzler who she married on October 20, 1929. She was the dear sister of the late Doris Miller, Ruth Rosenweig, Teddy and William Wilkus. Survived by her daughter Barbara Goldman (Mark), two grandchildren, 4 great grandchildren. Services will be 12:30 Wednesday, October 21st, Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAJIBOULLAH, YOUSOF
description: NAJIBOULLAH-Yousof, suddenly, October 16th. Survived by mother, Mrs. Sharifa Ullah, other family, many friends. Burial on Oct. 23, service Oct. 25, Arlington, Va. (703) 522-1441. Information N.Y. service (914) 664-5930.

title: Israel Has Kept Its Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Watchdogs
description: To the Editor:

title: BY THE BOOK; Casting Chocolate as Sophisticate
description: IS it possible that there can be too much of something as perfect as chocolate? Countless writers from cooks to psychologists have tried to offer the final word on this divine substance. And even the stodgiest restaurants attempt to outdo each other with versions of ''death by chocolate,'' which usually turns out to mean mud cake sludge. Awash in this excess, it can be impossible to truly appreciate chocolate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, SUSAN
description: WHITE-Susan. The officers of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the passing of Susan White, wife of Alan, mother of our beloved Senior Rabbi Michael and Rebecca, Lisa and Jeffrey Frankel and Carl, grandmother of David, Talia, Jayson and Justin. Our sincere condolences to the family. Daniel S. Reich, President Michael Paul, Exec Vice-President Adrienne Chernick, Vice-President Carol Weinstock, Vice-President Toni Wiener, Vice-President

title: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY 4% OF CONCENTRIC NETWORK
description: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy 4 percent of the Concentric Network Corporation for about $21.9 million as part of a deal to sell Concentric's Internet-based data services to SBC's business customers. SBC, the No. 2 United States local phone company, will buy 906,000 shares for $24.15 each from Concentric, or will buy the shares on the open market. Concentric, of Cupertino, Calif., closed at $20.8125, down 31.25 cents, while SBC, of San Antonio, rose 68.75 cents, to $42.875. SBC also asked the Supreme Court to hear an appeal of a Federal court ruling that would make entry into the long-distance market for it and the other Bells conditional on convincing Federal regulators that their networks were open to competition.

title: Israel Has Kept Its Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, EVELYN (NEE MOSTOWITZ)
description: EHRLICH-Evelyn (nee Mostowitz) of Fort Lee, N.J., on October 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Albert. Devoted mother of Jane and son-in-law Jim. Loving grandmother of Jesse. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Soaring Endowments and Big Spending
description: If there is a commonly followed barometer of the wealth of universities, it is surely Harvard's endowment, which, thanks to generous donors and the long stock market boom of the 1990's, stood close to $13 billion at the end of June, more than the gross national product of most developing countries.

title: New York, a Nice Place to Visit; Who Loves a Parade?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOLN, ASHE
description: LINCOLN-Ashe, in London, England on Monday, October 19, 1998. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of Ashe Lincoln, Q.C., loving father of our esteemed Senior Rabbi David H. Lincoln, beloved husband of Sybil, highly respected representative of and for the Jewish and legal community, devout Jew and ardent supporter of the State of Israel. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Feels Effect Of Global Financial Turmoil
description: The Commerce Department provided a concrete measure today of the effects of the global downturn on the American economy, reporting that the nation's trade deficit widened by $2.2 billion in August to $16.77 billion.

title: Very Big Seller in a Very Small Market
description: IT'S red and yellow, nonpolluting, durable and inexpensive. In fact, the Cozy Coupe was the world's best-selling car for much of this decade, but you can't take it on the highway. Not that you'd want to: it goes only as fast as a child can walk. A young child, like 2 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EILEEN
description: COHEN-Eileen. On October 19, 1998. Adored wife of Bob, loving mother & mother-in-law to Bonni & David, Aimee, Devon and Erica, James & Cathy, Fred and Kathy, Mark, Charles and Jane, sister to Stan and loving grandmother to twenty wonderful children. She was the most loving, bravest, compassionate, unselfish, giving & forgiving person one could know. Eileen leaves a heartbroken, grieving and unconsolable army of family and friends. It was a great honor to have known her. She showed us the way. We will never see her kind again. We are so alone. Funeral at 12 noon, on Wednesday at Schwartz, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Shiva, call 516-621-2512.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Six-Star French Team

title: Military Warns Soldiers Of Failure to Hail Chief
description: Responding to a wave of grousing in the nation's military about President Clinton's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, military leaders have taken the unusual step of warning officers and enlisted personnel that they could face punishment for denouncing the Commander in Chief.

title: If You Don't Build It, They Will Go
description: The World Series moved across the country last night, but the owners of the teams playing in it acted as if they were back on Broadway. Whether by design or coincidence, George Steinbrenner and John Moores appeared to be performing a play within a play.

title: SALE OF A UNITED VIDEO BUSINESS IS TERMINATED
description: United Video Satellite Group Inc. said yesterday that the $480 million sale of its satellite television programming unit to Primestar Inc., a satellite TV service owned by a group of cable operators, had been terminated in the continuing fallout from Primestar's failed purchase of the American Sky Broadcasting Company. United Video, based in Tulsa, Okla., and controlled by Tele-Communications Inc., disclosed the termination in announcing record third-quarter net income that fell just shy of analysts' estimates. Primestar has faced numerous problems in recent months after the Justice Department challenged its bid to buy the News Corporation's A Sky B.

title: Roaming the Range In a New Niche As a Contralto
description: When Ewa Podles made her Metropolitan Opera debut in Handel's ''Rinaldo'' in 1984 and her recital debut at Alice Tully Hall four years later, she was billed as a mezzo-soprano, and impressed with her agility and her flexible timbre. That was long before the mezzo field became crowded with young stars. By the time mezzos became hot operatic commodities, Ms. Podles was back in Poland, where she worked through much of the 1990's.

title: Punishing Intent Doesn't Criminalize Thought; Need for Extra Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Talkie, Without the Walkie
description: JUST like the coach of the Jets, Giorgio Rocchi has his headset in place, and he's calling the plays at Sofia Fabulous Grill: the grilled fish formation, the pizza run. These days, Mr. Rocchi, the chef at the restaurant, on East 61st Street, is one of many who rely on this bit of high-tech support to manage his team at the grill station, the pizza oven and in the dining room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, HARRIS K.
description: SIEGEL-Harris K. Beloved son of Mary Siegel. Survived by father Alexander Siegel and sister Roberta Brown. Funeral service is today, 2 P.M., at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Letter by Defendant Calls Slain Teacher His Friend
description: In a letter read in court by a defense lawyer yesterday, Corey Arthur, the 20-year-old man on trial in the torture and killing of Jonathan M. Levin, profusely thanked Mr. Levin, his former teacher, for helping him and called him his ''true and only friend in the world.''

title: Four Drug Giants Report Profit Gains in 3d Quarter
description: Four of the world's largest drug makers reported higher profits yesterday for the third quarter, thanks largely to sales of new drugs and to direct-to-consumer advertising campaigns that bolstered sales of older products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, W. ALLEN
description: WALLIS-W. Allen. Friends and colleagues of W. Allen Wallis, former President of the University of Rochester, Dean of the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, U.S. Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, and Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, are invited to a memorial service in his honor at 2PM Friday, October 30, 1998, at the Interfaith Chapel, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY. Mr. Wallis, a Washington, D.C. resident, died Monday, October 12, in Rochester, NY, at the age of 85. He was predeceased by his wife of 59 years, Anne Armstrong Wallis, and by his sister Virginia Wallis Bowers. He is survived by two daughters, Nancy Wallis Ingling of Gambier, OH., and Mrs. Virginia Wallis Cates of Wagon Mound, NM, and Jack Cates, her husband; and three grandchildren, Barbara Ingling Wharton and her husband Andrew Wharton of Centerburg, OH, Allen Wallis Ingling of Nashville, TN and Carl Thomas Ingling of Gambier, OH. Donations in his honor may be made to the W. Allen Wallis Institute of Political Economy, University of Rochester, P.O. Box 270158, Rochester, New York 14627-0158.

title: Blood Center Ads, Meant to Be Calming, Prove Alarming
description: The newspaper advertisements were supposed to underscore assurances that anyone who had a blood transfusion in the early part of the decade need not worry about having contracted an infectious disease. But the ads, which were placed by the New York Blood Center, may have had the opposite effect, since they caused a flood of calls from frightened blood recipients.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUIT REJECTS PROPOSED BUYOUT BID
description: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc., a maker of computer chips, said yesterday that it would not accept a possible buyout offer from a group of managers because the bid of $17.50 a share was too low. A special committee from Integrated Circuit's board decided against the possible offer after conferring with its financial adviser. The offer represents a premium of nearly 24 percent over Integrated Circuit's closing price of $14.125 on Monday; that day, the management group said it might make an offer of as much as $216 million for the company. The shares fell $1.375 yesterday, to $12.75. Integrated Circuit is based in Norristown, Pa., and has sales of $160.6 million.

title: Punishing Intent Doesn't Criminalize Thought; Memorial Vigil
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGER, ERNEST A. JR.
description: RIEGER-Ernest A. Jr. On October 19, 1998. Beloved and loving husband of Susan Squier Rieger. Cherished father of Carolyn, Sally, Laurie and Chip, and grandfather of Max and Beau, Hilary and Sarah, Danielle, Eric and Peter Bruce, and Cicely. He is survived by sisters, Ruth Munson, Sally Daly and Carol Rieger, and brothers, Drs. Paul and Richard Rieger. One brother, Thomas, predeceased him. A memorial celebration of his life will be held on Friday, October 23rd, from 12:30-4:30, at Captain Bill's in Bay Shore. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: Arnold M. Auerbach, 86, a Comedy Writer
description: Arnold M. Auerbach, a comedy writer who wrote for Fred Allen, Milton Berle and Al Jolson and who contributed sketches to the successful Broadway revues ''Call Me Mister'' and ''Inside U.S.A.,'' died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 86.

title: Icon of an Innocent Age Unwrapped Again
description: Eight years ago, some time after a large chunk of lead broke off its top and tumbled to the ground, the crumbling Albert Memorial was swathed in an ignominious wrapping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, ARNOLD M.
description: AUERBACH-Arnold M. On October 19, 1998 at New York Hospital of leukemia. He is survived by his wife Justine, daughter Nina, and son Andrew. He was a prolific satirist, wrote for Broadway theater, several novels, many satiric articles for newspapers, including The New York Times, magazines and radio shows including Fred Allen's. Funeral service on Friday at 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In His Own Words: CHARLES E. SCHUMER
description: From remarks at a news conference in Washington yesterday with the president of the Planned Parenthood Action Fund:

title: A Passion for Cars -- Just Don't Make Her Drive Them
description: ALTHOUGH I've been a passionate lover of cars for a long time, I've begun to realize that I hate to drive and that I am part of a growing class of disenchanted people who hate to drive. Love cars, hate to drive them: what explains this disagreeable paradox? Somehow, the way marriage is said to finish off romance, a Platonic love of cars is compromised by having one.

title: Edward Watson Hook Jr., 74, An Expert on Infectious Diseases
description: Dr. Edward Watson Hook Jr., a national authority on infectious diseases like salmonella and influenza, died on Oct. 5 at a hotel in Gettysburg, Pa., where he had gone for a meeting. He was 74 and lived in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Florida Player Earns Women's Record
description: The women's Division I scoring record of 103 goals shared by Mia Hamm and Tiffeny Mildrett of North Carolina is history. Danielle Fotopoulos of the University of Florida reached 106 goals on Sunday with a hat trick in a 9-1 thrashing of Mississippi.

title: Slowdown Expected In German Growth
description: Germany's economic growth will slow to 2.3 percent in 1999, the country's six biggest research organizations said yesterday, from 2.7 percent this year, as shrinking economies in Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America cut demand for exports. The global economic climate ''has deteriorated considerably,'' the institutes said in the latest of their semiannual reports on the German economy, adding that the risks for the German and European economies ''have grown noticeably.'' In their spring report, they had forecast 2.7 percent growth for 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, JARVIS GEER
description: WILCOX-Jarvis Geer, of Oxford, MD, formerly of Louisiana and NY, beloved son of the late Dr. Herbert B. & Louise Geer Wilcox; loving father of George Jarvis Geer Wilcox of New York City, Benjamin Davis Williams Wilcox of Houston, TX., and Mary Haven Foster of Easton, Maryland; also survived by 3 grandchildren. Memorial service at Christ Episcopal Church, Easton, Wednesday, Oct. 21, 1998, at 5 PM. Private burial at Loudon Park Cemetery, Baltimore. Memorial donations may be made to the Talbot Hospice Foundation, 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton, MD 21601. Information: the Fellows, Helfenbein & Newnam Funeral Home, Easton, PA.

title: Big Broadway Break May Be of the Heart; 4 Unknown Writers Can't Breathe Easy
description: If you called Rob Bartlett at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Saturday during the matinee of the show he wrote and starred in, ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy,'' you got this message on his answering machine: ''Hi, it's me. I can't take your call right now because I'm not in the dressing room, I'm onstage trying to find a last bit of dignity left. Or I'm somewhere in the basement of the theater, opening a vein.''

title: Going Where Off-Road Vehicles Hardly Ever Go: Off Road
description: CRAWLING over the boulders strewn across the muddy trail up Bear Mountain, I kept peering over the hood of my Range Rover, searching among the maple trees for the hidden camera.

title: 3,000 Miles and 9 Innings Away
description: They wouldn't voice the concern, but the San Diego Padres privately wondered, ''What if we play an entire World Series and we never get Trevor into a game?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, EDITH
description: BRAND-Edith. Born in Monroe Michigan in 1892 and lived in New York City most of her life, passed away on October 20, 1998. She was the great great niece of Judah P. Benjamin, Secretary of State of the Confederacy. She is survived by daughter Barbara Brand, granddaughter Jill Gandolfi, and three great granddaughters Anandi, Liana and Jessi. Services will be private.

title: When You Can the Car, Keep the Paperwork
description: MANY charities accept cars as donations, including the National Kidney Foundation and various chapters of the Disabled American Veterans. Charity experts warn, however, that donors need to be careful of groups that have similar sounding names but not necessarily similar agendas.

title: THE CHEF
description: EVEN though I am a pastry chef, I think in terms of three-course menus. When I'm creating a dessert tasting menu, the ''appetizer'' is always light, cool and fruity like this pear. Then there's the middle sweet, maybe something vanilla- or coffee-flavored, sometimes another fruit, perhaps a tart or a napoleon. And finally, the main dessert: usually it's chocolate, as much because people love it as because it is, by its nature, a finisher. It dulls the palate for anything but a strong espresso.

title: New York, a Nice Place to Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: Saying Salinas Aided Traffickers, Swiss Seize $90 Million
description: Officials in Switzerland announced yesterday that they had seized more than $90 million from Raul Salinas de Gortari, a brother of Mexico's former President, after a police investigation found that he had filled Swiss bank accounts with money he received for protecting drug shipments into the United States.

title: Dave and Audrey Get Down to the Nuts and Bolts
description: In the summer of 1996, I left my Seattle houseboat and began a 13,000-mile odyssey around the United States, ending up in Detroit the following January for the International Auto Show. My intent was to drive deep into America's national obsession with the automobile and, as a committed environmentalist who loves and writes about cars, to try to resolve some of my own conflicted feelings. I visited places where cars are venerated, despised, built, rebuilt, armored, raced, crashed, crushed -- even buried. Among them was Spring Hill, Tenn., in the hills south of Nashville, where Saturn had become a model of modern industrial relations. I spent a day just before Christmas touring the huge complex. Then, at 5 in the evening, I began making cars.

title: Badgers' Gift at Tackle Comes in Huge Package
description: WISCONSIN

title: After Suicide, Harvard Alters Policies on Graduate Students
description: Spurred on by the recent death of a star graduate student who killed himself with cyanide, Harvard is changing some of its policies to improve support through the stressful pre-doctoral years, university officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, I. SAUL
description: JARCHO-I. Saul. Services will be held at the Old Mount Carmel Cemetery on Sunday, October 25, 1998 at 10:30 A.M.

title: Critic's Notebook; Where Every Meal Is a Fabulous Feast
description: THERE is no bad food in Italy.

title: Equities Give Up Big Gains; Dow Up and Nasdaq Down
description: Stock prices went on a wild ride yesterday, soaring for most of the session only to retreat in the last hour or so of trading and end up narrowly mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average gained ground for the fifth consecutive session, the first time since June it has rallied for that many days in succession.

title: Top Connecticut Court to Take Up Alex Kelly's Appeal
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court has decided to consider an appeal of Alex Kelly's rape conviction directly instead of waiting for it to go first through the state's Appellate Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ROBERT
description: BLOOM-Robert. Cherished husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend died as he lived on October 19 in dignity and surrounded by loved ones. His mark will last forever. The Family

title: Court Lets Stadium Vote Remain Off The Ballot
description: Brushing aside an appeal from the New York City Council, the state's highest court let stand a lower-court ruling that knocked a referendum on the future of Yankee Stadium off the Nov. 3 ballot.

title: Israel Has Kept Its Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Edmond Levy, 69, Documentary Filmmaker
description: Edmond A. Levy, an Academy Award-winning documentarian, died on Oct. 10 at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Philosopher Pope
description: The powerful encyclical issued last week by Pope John Paul II will not be the subject of earnest debate like his calls for social justice in a materialistic world. Nor is it likely to ignite religious arguments over his unbending positions on church doctrine or his stands against abortion, euthanasia and women in the priesthood. Instead, this pronouncement in the 20th year of his papacy is a missive from a religious philosopher to the world's intelligentsia. It is a plea for an end to the separation of faith and reason and an argument against the ''philosophy of nothing,'' as he calls the various forms of nihilism that have taken root in a war-weary century.

title: The Woman Who Turns Grapes to Gold
description: VERY early one day in mid-October, when the pale sun was still burning the last wisps of fog off the vines, a red van rolled to a stop at the Grace Family Vineyards, a winery near here. No one was about. Out jumped a slim woman in black slacks and an assortment of jackets meant to ward off the morning chill.

title: SPECIAL TODAY -- CARS/SECTION G
description: Are we entering a new age of distinctive car design? Herbert Muschamp believes so, and points to a group of thoroughbred models to underscore his point. Plus six designers at the top of their game, and articles about safety and consumer issues, racing and life behind the wheel.

title: VISTEON UNIT STOCK SALE NOT LIKELY BEFORE 2000
description: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander Trotman, said yesterday that Ford was unlikely to make an initial public offer of stock in its Visteon parts unit before 2000. Mr. Trotman said Ford would like to sell shares of Visteon -- the world's second-biggest auto components maker, after the General Motors Corporation's Delphi Automotive Systems -- but ''it's unlikely to happen in 1999.'' He said that an initial public offering of part of Visteon could help the unit improve its business and reduce its dependence on Ford, but that market turmoil was the main reason for holding back. Mr. Trotman also said that Ford would be closely watching an initial offer by G.M. of Delphi stock, expected in the first quarter of next year.

title: Judge Upholds Merger Of 4 Fire Departments
description: A state judge declined yesterday to block the merger of four Hudson County fire departments, but set a Nov. 20 court date for arguments on whether the plan should be put to a vote by residents, lawyers said.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHALL, HELENE
description: MULHALL-Helene. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the sister of its long time devoted member, Alvin K. Hellerstein. May her entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elva Weinman, Sisterhood

title: With Tyson Back In, Action Outside the Ring Heats Up
description: Now that the fight to get Mike Tyson his boxing license is over, the fight for his soul and his wallet has begun. The cast of characters who have been advising Tyson through the application process could change by the time Tyson returns to the ring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOURAUD SHEILA MARGUERITE
description: GOURAUD Sheila Marguerite October 21, 1994 Irma Schlesinger October 21, 1955 In loving memory: Jackson, Meg, George, Charles, Steven, Tracey.

title: Profit Rises 10% At Phillip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco concern, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 10 percent as higher cigarette prices in the United States offset a worldwide drop in demand for Marlboros, Virginia Slims and other brands.

title: Journal; Reality Bites Hollywood
description: At last there's a liar we can all root for.

title: Protesters Say the Police Created 'Havoc' at Rally
description: Organizers of a midtown rally to mourn the slaying of a gay college student in Wyoming charged yesterday that ''the police created chaos'' that led to a melee Monday night with sporadic clashes between the police and demonstrators and scores of arrests.

title: Internet Watchdogs
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Horsepower in the Look, Too
description: I WOULD like to take issue with two common complaints about car design today. The first is that cars now all look alike. Even if this were true, I don't see why it should be considered a problem. Variety and choice are very fine and democratic, but as the essayist William Hazlitt put it bluntly, the principle of universal suffrage does not apply to matters of taste. Why shouldn't ugly cars do their best to look like prettier models?

title: Punishing Intent Doesn't Criminalize Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: After Night in Jail, Many From March Are Angered at Treatment
description: Suzy Lee Korn, who acted as a marshal in the Manhattan rally to protest the killing of Matthew Shepard, said yesterday that she briefly stepped off the curb at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue to use a bullhorn to warn other marchers that if they left the sidewalk they risked arrest.

title: Five agency acquisitions are all in a single day's work in these frenzied times for Madison Avenue.
description: THE pace of transactions involving agencies specializing in advertising, public relations and other marketing communications services has accelerated again, this time with the announcement of five acquisitions. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, LILLIAN
description: SCHLANGER - Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Phyllis and Norton Kalikow, Norman and the late Sharon Schlanger, Myra and Eli Heller, and Debbie and Marvin Kansky. Cherished grandmother of Marc and Annette, Randi and Glenn, Scott and Trisha; Jill, Craig, and Darren; Andy, Jay, and David; Richard and Lisa, Steven, and Jill. Great-grandmother of Bryan, Jason, Tyler, Jamie and Noah. Loving sister of Ethel Schneider, Marty and Milton Greisman. We will always love and adore you. Services Wednesday 11AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Sports of The Times; Padres Face The Sweep Of History
description: IT is no fun thinking you might be depicted as the latter-day equivalent of the 1927 Pittsburgh Pirates, who were drubbed by the Murderers' Row of Yankees in what legend insists was something less than the minimum four games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POE, FRANCES T.
description: POE-Frances T. The Inwood House Trustees, staff and friends mourn the loss of our colleague and dear friend Frances T. Poe. Greatly loved and admired for her generosity, determination and intellect, for 40 years Frances Poe was a driving force in insuring the integrity of Inwood House and the well being of the young people we serve. Services will be held today at The Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive at 2PM. The family requests that gifts in honor of Mrs. Poe be made to Inwood House, 320 East 82 Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREATHOUSE, TIMOTHY D.
description: GREATHOUSE-Timothy D. Age 48, at his home in Manhattan on October 18, 1998 of AIDS related complications. An artist, gallery owner and graphic designer. He owned and ran art galleries (Oggi Domani and Greathouse) in the East Village during the 1980s. More recently, he worked as a commercial graphic designer in the fine arts and advertising worlds. He also spent hundreds of hours providing pro bono services to various not-for-profit organizations. He is survived by his life partner Jay L. Katz, his mother Elsie Greathouse, his brother Mark Greathouse and a close group of loving friends. A celebration of his life will be held at Feature, 76 Greene Street, 2nd floor, NYC on November 7, 1998 from 6:30 to 8:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Body Positive, 19 Fulton St., Suite 308B, NYC 10038

title: New Moves On Rushdie Exposing Iranian Rifts
description: A month after Iran's Government dissociated itself from death threats to the British author Salman Rushdie, the decision is still exposing fissures among Iran's rival centers of power.

title: Punishing Intent Doesn't Criminalize Thought; Teach the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Car-Eat-Car Would Out There
description: CONSOLIDATION and globalization have made giant auto companies even bigger, putting small car makers like Saab, Mazda and Jaguar under the wing of Detroit's Big Three. And the Big Three will soon be the Big Two, as Daimler-Benz of Germany wraps up its merger with - essentially a takeover of - the Chrysler Corporation. The resulting company, DaimlerChrysler, will be in Stuttgart, Germany, and Auburn Hills, Mich. An American, Robert J. Eaton, will remain co-chairman for three years, but it will hardly be an American enterprise any more.

title: Firefighters Who Rode Float Are Put Back on City Payroll
description: Two white firefighters who were suspended for wearing blackface as they rode on a parade float in Queens on Labor Day were put back on the payroll on Monday, three days after an administrative judge recommended that they be fired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HARRIET L.
description: SCHNEIDER-Harriet L., age 97. October 19, 1998. Beloved sister of Elsie and Franklin. Loving aunt of Sandy, Lois, Herb, David, Milton and Fran. Beloved great aunt and great great aunt. Funeral services Thursday, October 22, 10 AM, Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting Wednesday, October 21, 7-9 PM. Donations will be appreciated to B'Nai Israel of Freeport, Freeport, N.Y., or Tomorrow's Childrens Fund, Hackensack Medical Center, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Guns, Butter and TV
description: To most Americans, market news once meant hikes in hamburger prices. Now, the market means first and foremost the stock market, and viewers are following it more closely than ever.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUN MICROSYSTEMS INC., -- Palo Alto, Calif., the computer company, acquired Beduin Communications Inc., a privately held Canadian company specializing in Java products. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Rite-of-Passage Story Of an Innocent Puppet
description: Wordless but eloquent. That sums up ''Wake Baby,'' an import from Australia that is the latest intelligent, skilled entertainment to adorn the stage of the New Victory Theater.

title: S.E.C. Files Charges On Year 2000 Data
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had charged 37 brokerage firms with failing to report on their computer systems' preparedness for the year 2000, as required by S.E.C. rules.

title: For All Those Towaways, The Trucks Stop Here
description: FOR motorists in Manhattan, the impound lot at Pier 76 off the West Side Highway is the most unhappy place in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MAYNARD
description: PARKER-Maynard. Age 58, died of complications of leukemia on October 16. As reporter, editor, friend, father and husband, he was the best of the best. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M., October 22, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. In lieu of flowers please make contributions in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, New York City 10021.

title: Bound by an Uncommon Love
description: IT'S pouring, of course. The rain is coming down in sheets here at the annual picnic of the Portland, Ore., Edsel Owners Club, and all these unwavering fans of the most ill-fated car in American history are huddled under a tree. Twenty loyalists, scratching plastic forks through the greasy puddles atop their potato salad and shivering, improbably, on an August afternoon.

title: A Sound Value, With Vehicle Included
description: IN the early days of the automobile, Henry Ford heard fiscal music in the efficiency and economy of scale of the assembly line. Now the same principles are harmonizing a new tune for music-loving motorists and auto makers alike.

title: Glenn Unable to Perform Experiment Planned for Space Flight
description: For undisclosed reasons, Senator John Glenn has been dropped from one of the main age-related experiments in which he had planned to take part during his return to space next week, NASA officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Gastineau Avoids Jail With Plea Deal
description: Mark Gastineau, the former star defensive end for the Jets, has agreed to a plea deal that will get him of jail and put him into drug, alcohol and violence counseling, his lawyers said Tuesday.

title: Sunbeam Restates Results, and 'Fix' Shows Significant Warts
description: In a move that repudiates the purported turnaround of the Sunbeam Corporation, the troubled maker of home appliances said yesterday that it had restated financial results from six quarters to adjust for inflated profits and greater losses than previously reported.

title: Vongerichten's Underground Laboratory
description: WHEN Mercer Kitchen gets it right, which is much of the time, the restaurant forces you to reconsider everything you know about food and restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, HON. H. JORDAN
description: LEE-Hon. H. Jordan. Of Long Beach, New York. Died Monday, October 19. Devoted husband of the late Marion. Loving father of Sherry, Stephen, and Barry. A thoughtful, practical, wise and gentle soul, he will be missed by those he leaves behind. A memorial service will be held at Guttermans, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, 516764-9400, Wednesday, October 21, promptly at 1 P.M.

title: Father and Son, Bound by Baseball
description: Baseball has always drawn Chuck Knoblauch and his father together, the time spent in the car going to Little League and high school games, the hours of playing catch in the backyard. So, after Knoblauch slugged a game-tying three-run homer in Game 1 of the World Series, he settled on the Yankee bench and thought of his father, Ray, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

title: Hyundai Oil to Sell Stake To I.P.I.C. of Abu Dhabi
description: The International Petroleum Investment Company of the United Arab Emirates agreed yesterday to buy 50 percent of the Hyundai Oil Refinery Company of Korea for $500 million, Hyundai Oil said. Hyundai, a unit of the Hyundai Motor Company and one of five Korean refiners, will use the money to reduce its debt. ''With this investment, we hope to reduce our debt-to-equity ratio to as low as 100 percent by the end of next year,'' a Hyundai Oil spokesman, said. The ratio is now 400 percent.

title: Animal vs. Mineral: Mining Is Proposed for Snake's Habitat
description: To drivers whizzing past on Interstate 84, Sour Mountain appears as one of the stunning autumn-colored hillsides that give the Hudson Highlands its name. But those who live here also know the 1,501-foot-high ridge as the battleground between a local mining company that owns land at the foot of the mountain and an environmental group that owns 1,000 acres at the top.

title: Op-Art
Testaverde Catapults Jets Into Rarefied Air
description: It may be only for this week, and it may not even mean much in the larger scheme of things, but right now the highest-rated passer in the American Conference is the 34-year-old free agent the Jets hired almost as an afterthought this year: Vinny Testaverde.

title: D'Amato Wins Endorsement Of Gay Group
description: Ending a lengthy and caustic debate, leaders of the nation's largest gay and lesbian lobbying organization voted yesterday to endorse Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for re-election, rejecting appeals from the White House and New York gay leaders to support Mr. D'Amato's Democratic challenger this year, Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; An Englishman Softens Volvo's Sharp Edges
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

title: No Taxes Will Be Sought On Swiss Reparations
description: Holocaust survivors and their families will not be required to pay state income tax on reparations they receive from a $1.25 billion settlement with Swiss banks, under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRIN, MORRIS G.
description: ZIRIN-Morris G. Of Palm Beach, FL., May 17, 1998. Adored husband of the late Kate Zirin. Beloved father of James D. Zirin. Loving grandfather of Anne E. and David M. Esteemed father-in-law of Marlene Hess. Brother of Ida Cypin. Memorial service Friday, October 23, 12 noon, at Temple Emanuel, 5th Ave., 65 St.

title: Top Women in '96 Are Set to Compete
description: Anuta Catuna of Romania and Italy's Franca Fiacconi, the top two finishers for the women in the 1996 New York City Marathon, will compete in this year's race on Nov. 1, Allan Steinfeld, the marathon's director, announced yesterday.

title: Malhotra and Schneider Help Rangers Win First
description: For the first time this season, the Rangers got effort, enthusiasm and scoring on the same night. And for the first time, they got a victory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWINGER, FRED W. MD.
description: LOWINGER-Fred W. MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sadness the passing of Fred W. Lowinger, MD, beloved father of our dear friend and colleague Jane Falkenstein, MD, Medical Director for the Max Meltzer Geriatric Center. To Jane, her brother Leslie, the Lowinger and Falkenstein families, and all of Dr. Lowinger's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, MD, Pres & CEO Jerome S. Breslaw, MD, President, Medical Board Stephen G. Baum, MD, Chairman, Department of Medicine Sidney Stein, MD, President, Doctors Alumni Associatio

title: Microsoft Says Antitrust Case Is 'Fantastical'
description: Stinging from the Government's opening statement, a defiant Microsoft Corporation forcefully defended its chairman, William H. Gates, in Federal court today, asserting that the no-holds-barred tactics of his company are not only common in the computer industry but also good for the economy.

title: Back in Redmond, Microsoft's Profit Machine Keeps Humming
description: Demonstrating yet again the power of its franchise, the Microsoft Corporation reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings had risen 58 percent over their level a year earlier, far exceeding Wall Street estimates.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Rising Rents in Chinatown Displace Garment Makers
description: These are not the best of times for contract garment manufacturers in Manhattan. Rents are rising and the manufacturers are under other economic pressures as well, says Paul Lau, executive director of the Sportswear Apparel Association, a trade organization for the industry. About 25 have gone out of business in the last year alone, he said.

title: Hearing National Differences
description: It's hard to imagine a place where the Ensemble for Early Music sounds better than the intimate, acoustically alive St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. And this is the place where one is most likely to hear the group, because this small vocal ensemble, founded and directed by Frederick Renz, is in residence at the cathedral. On Friday night, the group, along with Grande Bande, the instrumental ensemble also directed by Mr. Renz, presented the first of its programs celebrating its 25th anniversary (repeated on Saturday and Sunday to accommodate the demand for tickets).

title: Emotional Baggage: You Are How You Pack the Car
description: STATION wagons, minivans and sport utility vehicles may hold roughly similar amounts of cargo, but everyone has a different philosophy as to how to load the luggage, tuck in the toys and slip in the sweatshirts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAREK, ADELE
description: KANAREK - Adele. American Friends of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva mourns the passing of a true Eishet Chayil, a magnificent lady who personified grace, dignity and strength. Together with her beloved husband, Dr. Irwin, Adele was a staunch supporter of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva and all worthy causes on behalf of Torah, the Jewish People, and the Land of Israel. May she continue to be a source of inspiration and blessing for Irwin and her lovely children and grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marvin S. Bienenfeld, Chairman Joel M. Schreiber, President Rabbi David Warshaw, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, IRWIN S., M.D.
description: LOWENTHAL-Irwin S., M.D. We note with sorrow the death of our friend and colleague on October 17, 1998. A devoted physician, he served his patients and his community at the highest level as a dedicated professional for almost three decades. We send our sincere condolences to his family. Lawrence Scherr, M.D., MACP Chairman, Dept. of Medicine North Shore University Hospital

title: Speedboat Champion Sets 100th Record
description: Bob Wartinger, a speedboat champion from Seattle, reached a career goal Saturday by claiming his 100th record over 28 seasons of competition. The 53-year-old Wartinger averaged 80.641 miles an hour in a 10-foot B Modified hydroplane. The time, averaged over two runs, broke the previous 79.7 m.p.h. kilometer straightaway record.

title: I.B.M. Says Profit Rose 10% But Warns of Uncertainties
description: I.B.M. reported a 10 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday because of stronger computer sales, but the company's executives warned that global economic uncertainty could lead to short-term problems in the months ahead.

title: Making Its Marque at the Top; Toyota's Lexus Offers a Lesson in Brand Development
description: Ellen Passe sat in the passenger seat of an RX 300, the new Lexus midsized sport utility vehicle, while her 2-year-old son, Alex, fiddled with the steering wheel. Outside the car, her husband, Michael, spoke with a salesman at a midtown Manhattan Lexus dealership.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a creation without a mother or father. It's more like a Frankenstein monster patched together from old legislative body parts that don't quite fit.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR CLIMBS. The dollar surged against the Japanese yen on talk that Tokyo's plan to strengthen the troubled banking system would not take effect soon. The dollar rose to 116.83 yen in New York, from 114.28 on Monday.

title: Accountants' Group Picks Chairwoman
description: Olivia F. Kirtley, the chief financial officer of the Vermont American Corporation, was named chairwoman of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the nation's largest professional organization for accountants.

title: CALENDAR
description: Food for a Cause

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG-Sylvia. Died suddenly in Newton, MA., on October 20, 1998, less than three years after the death of Sam, her beloved husband of sixty-one years. Loving mother of Peter and Eileen. Caring mother-in-law of Joe Tom and Barney. Devoted grandmother of Solana and Sabrina. Born in Russia eighty-seven years ago, Sylvia grew up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn and lived most of her life in the Bronx. Short, smart, savvy and very funny, she was a woman who kowtowed to no one, even in pre-feminist times. Her abiding interest in people and politics made her a lively companion and was probably the reason she seemed so much younger than her years. While second to none in her love a good (or bad) joke, and a good (or bad) mah jongg game, her serious side was never far away: She continued to wish for political and economic justice for all people. Her family and friends will miss her, but she would be the first to say, ''I had a good run.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSLOW, ROBERT J.
description: SUSLOW-Robert J. Age 65. On October 18, 1998. His kind heart, generous spirit and intelligent wit will be forever missed by his loving family: Howard, Judy, Ken, Steve, Susan, Brian, and his caring friends and relatives. Funeral arrangements are private. Contributions may be made in his honor to the charity of your choice.

title: HEALTHEON CANCELS INITIAL OFFERING, CITING VOLATILITY
description: The Healtheon Corporation canceled a proposed $51 million initial public offering yesterday and opted instead for a $40 million private placement. Company officials cited market volatility. Mike Long, Healtheon's chief executive, said the deal was oversubscribed, meaning demand for the shares was greater than the number available. Healtheon, which offers large health care companies a centralized system to gain access to health care information on the Internet, will reconsider a public offering when the market stabilizes, perhaps in mid-1999, Mr. Long said. Healtheon had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 7.3 million shares at $6 to $8 each.

title: Corrections
description: The Key Rates chart in Business Day on Saturday and yesterday misstated the prime rate. It is 8 percent, not 8.25 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, BELLE
description: ABRAMOWITZ-Belle. Of Deerfield Beach, Florida, formerly of the Bronx, NY. Devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Stephan and grandmother of Michael and Diane. Graveside services on Sunday at 1 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For more information contact Riverside Nassau North Funeral Chapel.

title: Classes Are Canceled After a Body Is Found
description: Classes at a Mount Holly school for special education and Head Start students were canceled yesterday after a body was discovered on school grounds, officials said.

title: 25 Stations Renew Game-Show Deals
description: King World Productions Inc. said today that it renewed ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy'' on 25 television stations, securing the broadcast of its hit shows in 36 percent of the United States for at least two more years.

title: Sides Clash as Jones Seeks to Have Her Suit Reinstated
description: Lawyers for President Clinton and Paula Corbin Jones clashed today before a panel of Federal appeals court judges over her effort to reinstate her sexual harassment lawsuit, and the judges seemed clearly sympathetic to her argument that the case was wrongly dismissed last April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTOLENGHI, PAOLO, M.D.
description: OTTOLENGHI-Paolo, M.D. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart and the Medical Staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague.
