Dr. Ottolenghi was a dedicated physician who served Cabrini Medical Center for thirty years. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Albert Ciancimino, M.D., President, Medical Staff Morton Davidson, M.D., Med. Dir. Jeffrey Frerichs, President, Cabrini Medical Center

title: Nomination for F.D.A. Post Nears Approval in Senate
description: A powerful Republican senator dropped his opposition today to President Clinton's choice to head the Food and Drug Administration, clearing the way for the Senate to approve the nomination before adjourning.

title: Thompson Names A Creative Director
description: Bill Hamilton, executive vice president and worldwide creative director on the important Merrill Lynch & Company account at J. Walter Thompson New York, has been named one of three worldwide creative directors at the parent, the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: On the Nascar Circuit, Nelson's Rules of Order Apply
description: WHEN Smokey Yunick, the legendary stock-car mechanic and owner, prepared his car for the 1968 Daytona 500, he made one of the more brazen attempts to bamboozle the Nascar inspectors. He built a Chevelle two-thirds the size of rule-book specifications -- making it lighter and therefore faster -- with all the components built proportionately to disguise the alterations.

title: Brown's 100-Yard Effort Not a Surprise to Coach Fassel
description: Just before the two-minute warning on Sunday, Gary Brown pushed his way through the right side of the Arizona Cardinals' defensive line, dragging two defenders for a 5-yard gain. It was nothing flashy, hardly memorable, but with that run, Brown passed the 100-yard mark.

title: Ludicrous! Impractical! Exorbitant! I'll Take It!
description: IT'S outrageous, Herb Chambers conceded, to pay $1 million for a McLaren F1 sports car. ''It makes no economic sense at all,'' said Mr. Chambers, who lives on a sprawling estate in Old Lyme, Conn., equipped with a helicopter and a helipad.

title: Woman Killed as Car Shifts Into Drive
description: A 62-year-old woman died after being hit by a car that was probably shifted into drive by her 3-year-old grandson as she checked the transmission fluid, the police said yesterday.

title: YTL Unit to Purchase Land in Kuala Lumpur
description: The YTL Corporation of Malaysia announced yesterday that a subsidiary, YTL Land, had entered into a sales and purchase agreement with Taiping Consolidated for the acquisition of three prime properties in Kuala Lumpur for 323 million ringgit ($85 million) cash.

title: 2 Words U.S. Race Fans Don't Hear: Formula One
description: MICHAEL SCHUMACHER, the two-time auto-racing world champion from Germany, was fourth last year in Forbes magazine's annual ranking of the world's highest-paid athletes. But for all that American fans see of him, he might as well be a Munich cabby instead of the No. 1 driver on Ferrari's legendary Formula One team. Mr. Schumacher was the only athlete -- and, yes, with their stamina and lightning-quick reflexes, race drivers are athletes -- among the Forbes Top 10 in earnings last year who did not perform primarily before American audiences. In fact, he has never driven a racing car on American soil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, JOHN W.
description: HERZ-John W., a senior partner in the New York City law firm of Wolf, Haldenstein, Adler, Freeman & Herz, died October 19. He was 83 years old. Mr. Herz, who resided in Larchmont, New York, died after a prolonged illness. He was born in New York City and received both his B.A. and his law degree from Columbia University. He practiced corporate law with his present firm for over fifty years. He was the editor of the text Business Acquisitions and a faculty member for the Practising Law Institute. In addition to his law practice, Mr. Herz was a community leader and served as President of the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, a trustee of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center, President of Camp Madison-Felicia, a trustee of the Hudson Guild, Inc., Vice President of I Care and a Trustee of the Mamaroneck School District Community Education Program. Mr. Herz also served as a U.S. Army Captain during World War II. John Herz is survived by Elise, his wife of 57 years, his three sons: Andrew, James and Bill, his three daughters-in-law and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Ethical Cultural Society of Westchester in White Plains, New York, at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, November 11, 1998. Contributions can be made on his behalf to the Strang Cancer Prevention Center in New York City or the Guidance Center of New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, WILLIAM J. JR.
description: BYRNE-William J. Jr., 68, formerly of Pelham, deceased, October 18, 1998, Pinehurst, N.C. Mr. Byrne is survived by his wife Mary F., sons William J. III, Ellicott City, MD., Thomas F., Telluride, CO., James M., Laurel, MD, Matthew F., Athens, GA and Peter G., N.Y., N.Y. Mr. Byrne graduated from Manhattan College in 1952 and Fordham Law in 1956. He retired from Pittson Co and Freeport-McMoran Co. Requiem mass will be celebrated at 11 A.M. Wednesday in Sacred Heart Church, Pinehurst, N.C. Graveside service will be celebrated at 2 P.M. on Thursday at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Sacred Heart Church, P.O. Box 1768, Pinehurst, N.C. 28370.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, HENRY
description: CANTOR-Henry, 81 years. Son of the late Samuel and Ida Cantor. Husband of the late Sylvia Pepper Cantor. Beloved father of Richard, Linda S., & Linda. Devoted grandfather of Daniel, Amanda, Andrew, & Laura. Great-grandfather of Lily. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Final Spending Bill Passes in the House
description: Facing a rebellion by conservatives, House Republican leaders won approval for a $500 billion catchall spending package by enlisting Democrats. The House voted 333 to 95 to accept the colossal package, copies of which arrived on the House floor for review by members less than four hours before the vote.

title: KING HUSSEIN JOINS TALKS ON MIDEAST AS OPTIMISM RISES
description: With King Hussein of Jordan joining President Clinton at the Middle East peace talks, optimism rose today that some kind of settlement would be reached between Israelis and Palestinians after more than 19 months of stalemate and 6 days of talking here.

title: Strike Gives Northwest a Loss; Southwest Air Profit Up 40%
description: Wounded badly by last month's pilots strike, Northwest Airlines reported a $224 million third-quarter loss yesterday. Also yesterday, Southwest Airlines, following the industry pattern, announced record earnings for the period.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; Father of Reborn Beetle Gets a Big Family at Ford
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

title: Gore Takes Role of No. 1 Campaigner
description: This is crunch time in the 1998 campaign season, and no Democrat is likely to be hammering Republicans around the country more extensively than Vice President Al Gore in the two weeks remaining before the Nov. 3 elections.

title: True to the Spirit of Mexico (if Not the Details)
description: PATRICIA THOMSON says she opened Mexicana Mama about four months ago because she felt a need in New York for authentic Mexican food. Mexicana Mama, barely a narrow aisle with no more than a dozen seats, is her first restaurant. Her previous job, as the general manager of Benny's Burritos on Greenwich Avenue, speaks more of her familiarity with California food trends and margarita consumption than it does of Mexican regional fare.

title: Where Every Day They Hit the Wall
description: AS with any crash, witnesses rushed in the moment the glass stopped flying. But these bystanders did not whip out cell phones to call for help nor did they grab bandages to stop the bleeding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, ADELE REISMAN
description: WEINER-Adele Reisman, on October 19, 1998. Beloved sister, aunt, grandmother. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM. Levayah-Garlick Funeral Home, Yonkers. Interment Riverside Cemetery, NJ.

title: Man Captured After Knife Attack Is Also Accused in a Slaying
description: An auxiliary police officer and a security guard captured a knife-wielding man who is suspected in a stabbing death last week in Manhattan after he repeatedly slashed a woman in a Chinatown mall, the police said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: CHIEF RESIGNS AND CIRCON CALLS OFF SEARCH FOR ACQUIRER
description: The Circon Corporation, a maker of minimally invasive surgery products, said yesterday that its top executive, Richard A. Auhll, had resigned and that the company would stop looking for a buyer. Circon said Mr. Auhll, chairman and chief executive, had quit without citing a reason. George Cloutier, a director, will serve as interim chief executive. John F. Blokker, another director, is the new chairman of the company, which had 1997 revenue of $160 million. Circon had been searching for a friendly buyer for two years, to avoid a proposed purchase by the United States Surgical Corporation. U.S. Surgical withdrew its offer last month. Shares of Circon, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., fell $1.375, to $8.25.

title: Summit Bancorp Expands
description: Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, has agreed to acquire privately held Madison Consulting Group, expanding its employee-benefit insurance business.

title: Antitrust Chief Warns Industry Leaders
description: As the second day of the Microsoft antitrust trial unfolded in Washington, the Government's chief antitrust official came here to tell a group of computer industry leaders that they face an unhappy choice.

title: The Unstoppable Shadow
description: It came as a surprise to most New Yorkers to find out that Donald Trump has started work on the tallest residential building in the world, an 861-foot glass behemoth at First Avenue and 48th Street. This tower, almost as tall as the observation deck of the Empire State Building, would loom hundreds of feet above neighboring buildings on Beekman Place and United Nations Plaza, and would dwarf the Secretariat building.

title: Business Travel; Recent surveys find airline fares are stabilizing -- somewhat -- as corporations trim travel budgets.
description: BUSINESS travelers can take some comfort that the typical domestic business fare rose only 3 percent in the 10 months ended August, to $458, according to the latest American Express Business Airfare Index. By contrast, comparable fares increased 16 percent in all of 1997 compared with 1996. A typical business fare generally means the lowest fare available with the least restrictions. But business fares in August, the latest month for which data were available, were 9 percent higher than in August 1997, when the comparable fare was $421.

title: For Older Drivers, a Choice Between Freedom and Safety
description: THE bridge club was worried. Elsie Emslie, its oldest member at age 87, was planning her usual drive from Florida to North Carolina. The club members, living in St. Petersburg, wondered whether she was up to making the drive alone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Oct. 2 about a day in the life of the Broadway musical ''Titanic'' misidentified an actor in the show. The part of Edgar Beane, a second-class passenger, is played by Bill Buell. Hal Davis is his understudy.

title: Staten Island Police Couple Found Dead in Suspected Murder-Suicide
description: A Staten Island couple, both veteran police officers, died yesterday in what investigators believe was a murder-suicide when a detective apparently shot his wife, a community police officer, four times and then put a bullet through his brain.

title: A Cerebral Choreographer's Seventh-Inning Stretch
description: Helgi Tomasson became the artistic director of the San Francisco Ballet almost accidentally. A leading dancer with the New York City Ballet, Mr. Tomasson sensed that by the mid-1980's it would be time to retire from the stage. An offer to direct the Royal Danish Ballet didn't pan out, so when Mr. Tomasson got a call from the San Francisco company, he signed on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, W. ALVORD
description: FINN-W. Alvord. On October 18, 1998. Rutgers University; BA; MA; ROTC Top Cadet. Assistant Dean of Men (1946-1948). Army Air Corp (1942-1946), Bronze Star. Lieutenant Colonel, Air Force Reserve. Brookhaven National Laboratory (1949-1974), Administrator of Medical Research and Hospital. Captain Engine Company, Bellport Volunteer Fire Department; Trustee, Bellport Methodist Church; Secretary, Bellport Board of Education; First Cub Scout Master in Bellport. Beloved husband of the late Virginia Marvin. Father of Chic and Bobby Finn. Grandfather of David Finn and Julia Holian. Great-grandfather of Travis Holian. Memorial contributions may be made to the Bellport Ambulance Company, 5 Cottage Place, Bellport, New York 11713.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FANNING, SR. MARY MERCEDES
description: FANNING-Sr. Mary Mercedes, a Sister of the Divine Compassion died October 19, 1998. She was 92. Sister Mary Mercedes (b. Helen M. Fanning) on April 2, 1906 in the Fordham section of the Bronx, the daughter of Patrick J. and Mary Moore Fanning. She attended Our Lady of Mercy elementary school and Evander Childs high school in the Bronx, and received certification from New York Training School for teachers in 1926. She entered the Sisters of the Divine Compassion on October 7, 1930 and pronounced perpetual vows August 15, 1938. Sister Mary Mercedes earned the Bachelor of Arts degree from Good Counsel College in 1933 and the M.A. degree from Fordham University in 1943. She continued her work in education at City College in New York and Catholic University in Washington, D.C. Sister Mary Mercedes taught for three years in the New York City public schools and, as a member of the Congregation, founded and was first principal both of St. Bernard's school in White Plains 1932-1946 and Preston High School in the Bronx 1947-1957. She was principal of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel School in Elmsford 1957-1963, and Good Counsel Academy Elementary School in White Plains 1963-1969. From 1969 to 1981 she taught English at Good Counsel Academy High School and from 1978 to 1982 she served as assistant treasurer of the High School. Sister Mary Mercedes served 38 years in various administrative roles in the New York Archdiocesan school system. Sister Helen Coldrick, President of the Sisters of the Divine Compassion said, ''Sr. Mary Mercedes' long and distinguished career in the field of education, gave fellow administrators and teachers a model of proficiency and caring concern, and students of diverse ages, a hunger for learning and most of all, happy hearts during their school years''. Sister Mary Mercedes is survived by devoted nieces, one nephew, cousins and is remembered by a multitude of friends and former students. Visitation hours Tuesday 7-9 PM, and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Good Counsel Convent, 52 North B'way, White Plains. Mass of Christian Burial will be on Thursday, 10 A.M. in the Chapel of the Divine Compassion. Interment at Mt. Calvary Cemetery, White Plains, NY. For information McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett funeral home in White Plains. Memorial donations may be made to the Divine Compassion Ministry Fund, 52 North B'way, White Plains, N.Y. 10603.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest End up Pretty Much Even
description: PACKING the family car for a weekend road trip (and inevitably forgetting something) is an American tradition that dates to the time of the Model T. Since then, the basic goal has never changed: to fit as much as possible into the back of the car. To carry more cargo and people, buyers have traded in their station wagons for minivans and sport utility vehicles, the same way their parents moved from sedans to station wagons a generation ago.

title: Treasuries Fall As Investors Turn Elsewhere
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday as investors moved some money into stocks and scouted for opportunities in corporate bonds. Many were emboldened by the Federal Reserve's reductions in interest rates, which have eased concern that the economy will enter recession.

title: A Machine of Many Parts, Every One a Real Steal
description: I TRY to lead a quiet life. I live on a nondescript block in a bland neighborhood in Queens, New York's most unassuming borough. Like one of Richard Ford's average-guy narrators, I'm not looking for trouble. I don't want to stand out. And I really, really don't want my car to stand out. So what went wrong?

title: Killing Shakes Complacency Of the Gay Rights Movement
description: For some of the younger marchers, the demonstration Monday night that paralyzed parts of midtown Manhattan was their first political rally. For some older protesters, though, the march -- to express outrage over the killing of a gay college student in Wyoming -- was a return to the angry street protests that had so often symbolized the militancy of the gay rights movement.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Spain Says It's Neutral on Pinochet; Signs Are Otherwise
description: Eager to appear neutral on a highly charged issue, the conservative Government of Spain said today that it would let the nation's courts decide whether Madrid had the right to ask London to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, for trial there.

title: Is It Opera? Pop? Gospel? Don't Ask; Just Listen
description: How often does a performer appear who has the vocal power and charisma to make you believe in a better musical future? Once in a generation? When Audra McDonald, the 28-year-old phenomenon who made her Broadway debut four years ago in a revival of ''Carousel,'' unfurls her operatic mezzo-soprano with its bright, quickening vibrato, then breaks into a triumphal cry before dipping into an ominous funk-tinged blues shout, a better musical future seems not only possible but upon us, right here, right now.

title: Slugging It Out In the Ratings
description: Who is getting more air time during the World Series? Stars of the Yankees or stars of Fox?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHLIS, JOSEPH
description: MACHLIS-Joseph. The Juilliard School notes with sadness the death of Jospeh Machlis, distinguished member of the faculty since 1977. An innovative scholar, a remarkable teacher and a trusted colleague, Joseph Machlis had an enormously positive impact on the entire music profession. His engaging smile and his incisive wit will be missed by us all. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: INSIDE
description: Salinas Funds Seized

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, DUNCAN
description: MORRISON-Duncan. Suddenly, October 18th, 1998. Former Art Director of Humpty Dumpty Magazine. Interment Arlington National Cemetery. It was a privilege to know you, Duncan.

title: Singapore Carrier May Buy Taiwan Stake
description: Singapore Airlines Ltd., Singapore's flagship carrier, said yesterday that it might buy as much as 25 percent of China Airlines, the Taiwanese national airline, in a move that would make it the Taiwan carrier's largest foreign investor. A 25 percent stake would cost about $318 million, based on recent share prices.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT OFF 2.6 PERCENT. Prices fell on doubts that the United States will donate food to Russia, dimming hopes for reduced supplies and more demand. The December contract dropped 7.75 cents, to $2.8625 a bushel.

title: Shrinking Egg Whites
description: Q. My chiffon and sponge cakes occasionally fall while still in the oven, even if I do not open the door. Why?

title: By Wide Margin, House Passes $500 Billion Budget Bill
description: Facing a conservative rebellion, House Republican leaders enlisted Democrats tonight to win approval for a $500 billion catchall spending package, an unwieldy 40-pound document of nearly 4,000 pages that virtually no one had time to read before the vote.

title: With Stock Issue Ahead, Goldman, Sachs Names 57 as Partners
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company named 57 new partners yesterday, awarding them an ownership stake in the world's most profitable private partnership with the promise of a lucrative public offering down the road.

title: Editorial Observer; N.B.A. Labor War Could Last a Long Time
description: As labor battles go, the current one between the National Basketball Association and its players is weird even by sports standards. There is a real possibility that most, if not all, of the coming season will be canceled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, REVEREND EDWIN J.
description: DUFFY-Reverend Edwin J. On October 19, 1998 at United Hospital Medical Center, Port Chester, New York. Son of the late Florence and Stephen Duffy. Brother of Miriam D. Scavullo of New York City, Rev. Stephen V. Duffy, S.J. of New York City, Sr. Helen Marie, S.S.N.D. of Towson, MD, Florence D. Doherty of Scranton, PA, Jane D. Burt of Fort Lauderdale, FL and Constance D. Corroon of Rye, NY. Also survived by 21 nieces and nephews and 48 grandnieces and nephews. Visiting hours are Wednesday from 2 to 4 P.M., and 7 to 9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye. A Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, October 22 at 10:00 A.M., at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to the United Hospital Skilled Nursing Pavilion, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573 or the National Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 366 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10001.

title: 30 Designs That Changed the Face of the Automobile
description: SCIENTISTS have theorized that biological evolution marches through time not in a smooth, straight line, but by fits and spurts. The same holds true of art. And automotive design, like all forms of art, includes specific works that changed the direction of everything that followed.

title: Out of Prison, Rapist Is Held In New Attack
description: A man who had previously been convicted of rape was arrested late Monday and charged with raping a 71-year-old woman in Hunters Point, Queens, minutes after she returned home from church on Sunday, the police said yesterday.

title: Big Board Profit Up 17%
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 17 percent and average daily trading volume soared 35 percent from the corresponding period in 1997. The Big Board said net income rose to $30 million in the quarter from $25.6 million in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $189.3 million, from $163.1 million. Average daily trading increased 35 percent, to 719 million shares, from 532.2 million. The Big Board makes most of its money from listing fees, sales of data, trading fees and regulatory fees. In the third quarter, 43 companies joined the list of stocks traded on the exchange, down from 65 new listings in the 1997 period.

title: Giant Has New Ideas for On-Line Guides
description: The Microsoft Corporation is expected to introduce today a makeover of Sidewalk, its on-line city guide, in an ambitious effort to create on-line advertising vehicles for dozens of local products and services, ranging from nannies to new refrigerators.

title: With Best Foot Forward, Padres Fall
description: The San Diego Padres had a 5-2 lead in Game 1 of the World Series on Saturday night with their ace, Kevin Brown, on the mound. They had a 3-2 lead in tonight's Game 3 with the premier closer in the National League, Trevor Hoffman, on the mound.

title: Pavarotti Withdraws From 'Tosca' Role at Met
description: Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, announced yesterday that Luciano Pavarotti had withdrawn from the three performances he was scheduled to sing as Cavaradossi in Puccini's ''Tosca,'' on Nov. 7, Nov. 12 and 16.

title: Chase Manhattan Earnings Beat Forecasts of Analysts
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank, reported better-than-expected earnings in the third quarter yesterday, even as trading revenue from emerging markets evaporated. Wells Fargo & Company, which concentrates on the domestic economy, also beat average estimates.

title: A Messy Budget Endgame
description: Few actions have brought more discredit on the 105th Congress than the frantic deal-making that surrounded the budget negotiations over the last few weeks. Pressed on by their leaders, legislators are holding their noses and approving a sprawling, $500 billion measure that includes provisions they have not even read, much less studied, from grants for the Red Cross and the Tennessee Valley Authority to special favors for truckers and the peanut industry.

title: Rights Query On Killing Of Immigrant
description: Mayor Lee Brown, Representative Sheila Jackson-Lee, four City Council members and several civil rights leaders are asking the Justice Department to determine whether the fatal shooting of a Mexican immigrant by six Houston police officers in July violated Federal civil rights laws.

title: I'll Take Manhattan (Brooklyn, Too)
description: NOW that New York is seeing renovation left and right, with a freshly minted Grand Central Terminal and the once-derelict Times Square so crowded no one goes there anymore (as Yogi Berra may or may not have said about Toots Shor's), how about the island's signature cocktail? What happened to the Manhattan? How come it has taken so long to get a face lift?

title: State to Study Student Drinking
description: In response to the drinking-related death of a Rutgers University student last week, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero announced yesterday that he would convene a panel of students, bar owners and local officials in New Brunswick to discuss drinking by university students.

title: Judge Collins Seitz Dies at 84; Refuted Segregation in Schools
description: Collins Jacques Seitz, a senior Federal appeals court judge in Delaware who as a young judge helped refute the separate-but-equal doctrine in public education, died on Friday at the Foulk Manor North retirement home in Wilmington. A lifetime resident of Wilmington, he was 84.

title: Creating Biscuits From a Garden Bounty
description: BASKETS full of end-of-season bounty from the garden left me with a delightful problem: how to make the most of it? My assistant, Sarah Carey, and I wanted to make something a little different, and first considered baking vegetable breads. But then I started to think about biscuits.

title: A Cool Rivera Turns On The Heat
description: Mariano Rivera blew into his clenched hands and then he spit. There was not a bead of sweat on his forehead or a bit of doubt in his confident eyes. Rivera knew the task. The Yankees needed one more out and he needed to get it.

title: Peering at the Series, From 1,000 Feet Up
description: TELEVISION reception above Yankee Stadium is pretty good -- Tracy Rockhold says you don't need cable up there. But he was not watching his little Sony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTWIN, PHYLLIS DUKE OF TENAFLY
description: LITTWIN-Phyllis Duke of Tenafly, NJ. Died in her sleep, Monday, October 19 unexpectedly. Wife of Dr. Stuart Littwin. Mother of Carolyn Fischer, and Charles Littwin. Grandmother of Rachel and Jack. Sister of Herbert Duke. Daughterin-law of Ruth Littwin. Member of Temple Emeth Congregation in Teaneck, NJ. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emeth, 11AM, Wednesday, October 21.

title: Tall (and Existential) in the Saddle
description: GHOST TOWN

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the nomination of James C. Hormel to be Ambassador to Luxembourg, an appointment that would have made him the first openly gay American ambassador, misidentified the home state of Trent Lott, the majority leader, who refused to allow a vote by the full Senate. Mr. Lott is from Mississippi, not Louisiana.

title: Six Hot Designers Making Cars Look Cool Again; Scandinavian Style For Wing or Wheels
description: MOST people don't think twice about telling friends they bought a Jil Sander, a Giorgio Armani or a Joseph Abboud. The very names bespeak the designs. But what about cars and trucks, which cost a lot more than suits and dresses? Who designs them?

description: So, That's What the Fork Looked Like 400 Years Ago

description: MASTERSON-Mary M. (nee McDonough) of Middletown, N.J., formerly of Irvington-on-the-Hudson, N.Y., on October 18, 1998. Wife of the late Francis D. Masterson. Mother of Claire M. Chamine. Grandmother of Courtney C. Moss and Suzanne B. Chamine. She has one great grandson. Mass of Christian Burial Wed., 10 A.M. at St. James R.C. Church, Red Bank, N.J. Committal at Mount Olivet Mausoleum, Middletown, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, GENE J.
description: FLANAGAN-Gene J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Gene J. Flanagan, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Home builders begin to see the advantages of consolidation.
description: IS a consolidation coming in the home-building business? That could be one message drawn from the announcement yesterday that the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation will buy the privately owned Lewis Homes, a leading builder in California and Nevada. The price is $409 million in cash and stock, plus the assumption of $135 million in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, DAVID
description: RAPOPORT-David. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of David Rapoport, beloved father of our dear friend and supporter, Dr. Samuel Rapoport. The generosity of the Rapoport family enables Boys Town to provide a quality academic, technological and religious education to disadvantaged Israeli youth. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec VP

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEARLMAN, STEPHEN
description: PEARLMAN-Stephen. Memorial service Sunday, October 25, 1998 12 Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Brazil's Plan On Deficits Is Still Under Construction
description: Brazilian officials ended four days of meetings with representatives of the International Monetary Fund today without living up to their public pledge to announce concrete measures to reduce Government deficits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELBER, DR. NORBERT
description: FELBER-Dr. Norbert. On October 20th, 1998, of Jericho, New York. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Michael, Adam and Susan. Dear brother of Lily Green. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at ''Guttermans'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: In percent

title: Deadline on Impeachment Is Tied to White House, Hyde Says
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that his goal of finishing the impeachment investigation of President Clinton by the end of the year was ''all dependent on whether there's reasonable cooperation from the White House.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENBERG, IRVING
description: LEVENBERG-Irving. Of Huntington, New York, suddenly on Friday, October 16th, 1998 while on holiday in Turkey. Adored husband of Thelma & the late Evelyn. Beloved father of Seth (Ellen), Merrit (Betty) & the late Warren. Much loved by his brothers Fred, George and Phil, his step children Jonathan and David Rothstein and Laura Levine. Adored by all of his grandchildren, Ivy, Scott, Sari, Erica, Jason, Michael, Justin, Alyssa, Allie, Jake, Lara, and Kaela. Loved by all his friends and respected by his many clients, he will be sorely missed.

title: Alan S. Donnahoe, 82, Ex-Chief Of a Richmond Media Company
description: Alan S. Donnahoe, a former president and chief executive of Media General, died Oct. 10 at his home in Richmond. He was 82.

title: No Bold Call to Arms Sounded
description: Germany's new government has produced a coalition agreement of unexpected blandness, an attempt to deal with the country's problems through discreet remedies that offer neither a mobilizing idea nor a program certain to stir its economy or spirits.

title: If a Car Seems Made Just for You, Here's the Reason Why
description: TWO-THIRDS of Saab car owners also have dogs and take them for a ride at least twice a week.

description: Microsoft Strongly Defends Gates's Business Tactics

Church -- discussing the Community Reinvestment Act and other programs Mr. D'Amato has overseen as chairman of the Senate Banking Committee:

title: Is Monopoly the Microsoft Boards Game?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: SANDERSON-Leo W. (Sandy) Died at age 82, October 14, 1998 at Turner Geriatric Center, Galveston, TX. He is survived by daughter Kate Burdon, son Lee Sanderson, sisters Joan Seetoo and Pearl Bauer and extended families.

description: To the Editor:

May his memory be a blessing. The funeral will be held in Springfield, Ma. on October 22. Shiva will be observed at the Stahl home, 88 Briarcliff Road, Long Meadow, Ma. and will continue in NYC at Rodeph Sholom on Monday evening October 26 from 6:30 to 8:30PM. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Clergy, Board of Trustees, Staff and Members of Congregation Rodeph Sholom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIN, PAUL.
description: ROCHLIN-Paul. On Oct. 19, 1998, devoted husband to Marjorie, superb father to Jonathan, loving brother and uncle to Miriam and Michael. He will be dearly missed. Services Thursday, Oct. 22, 11:00 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. The Rochlins will receive at home Thursday and Friday evening. Contributions in his memory to Gilda's Club.

title: Rookie Ranger Center Off to a Good Start
description: In the Rangers' dressing room at Playland Ice Casino, most players have their names printed in big, dark letters above their lockers. Not so with Manny Malhotra, the 18-year-old rookie center. Is the lack of identification a sign of insecurity for the first-round draft choice? Not really.

title: Tight Race Attracts Big National Guns to Ohio
description: It is a Congressional race that is so tightly competitive that it has lured to the Ohio Valley a cavalcade of prominent politicians from throughout the country.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPHATTER, GORE, LENA
description: McPHATTER-GORE-Lena. On October 18, 1998. Her charming, wonderful spirit will be forever missed by her loving family, friends and relatives. Memorial service November 14 at 3PM, Rutger's Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to the Lena McPhatterGore Fund established at Rutger's Presbyterian Church would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paean to the Fall Game, When Splendor Reigns
description: Those who already know about golf in the fall are probably going to be a little upset by this spilling of the beans. It's liable to cause the loss of their paradise. But in the spirit of sharing the wealth, the beauty, charm and pleasure of playing golf in the autumn must be revealed.

title: Spitball Incident Prompts Investigation of Teacher
description: A fifth-grade teacher in Brooklyn is under investigation after reports that she stood by as students threw spitballs at another 10-year-old student, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: The Agony and the Epoxy
description: NO matter what kind of tiles you buy, the excitement dies hard if they go up on the wall looking like your first set of teeth, with toothpaste smeared fatly across the front.

title: Iowa's Quiet Voters
description: Iowans have remained remarkably calm through the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. Nobody seems to want to talk about it publicly, although a soccer mom might be overheard at the supermarket complaining about five 11-year-olds discussing oral sex, semen stains and cigars on the way to the game.

title: INSIDE
description: Marrow Transplant Hope

title: As Floodwaters Head to Sea, More Texas Towns Brace for the Worst
description: When the Colorado River seeped over its banks here early today, Irene Edwards began to unplug the appliances and stuff her clothes in boxes. When it crossed the road and swallowed her lawn, she called her uncle to get over in a hurry and bring his trailer. By noon, when it crested the doorsill, she was bouncing up the street with everything she owned.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NEWS WATCH
description: APPLE's NEW OPERATING SYSTEM -- Still basking in the warm glow of the iMAC's success, Apple Computer this week released MAC OS 8.5, the new operating system for Macintosh. Among the features the company is touting: Sherlock, a ''personal search detective'' that can browse the Internet by combining several search engines (including Excite, Lycos and Alta Vista) and can browse desktop files by content as well as by name, and the ability to copy files across a network twice as fast as the previous MAC OS and about 20 percent faster than Windows NT.

title: A Collector of New York Pictures, in Words
description: WHEN out-of-town friends come to visit New York, Phillip Lopate puts down whatever book he is editing and laces up the sturdy walking shoes of a tour guide. He leads the visitors through haunted blocks of Williamsburg, from which he escaped his family's lurid quarrels, and into the art-deco towers of lower Manhattan, their lobbies gilded and soaring beyond the imagination of his old neighborhood. And he doesn't stop for nuisance necessities like food or rest.

title: Big Board Posts a 1.4% Drop In Its Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions on the New York Stock Exchange fell by 1.4 percent last month, to 4.15 billion shares, the exchange reported yesterday. On the smaller American Stock Exchange, uncovered short sales decreased by 4 percent, to 195.4 million shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARESCO, RACHEL
description: MARESCO-Rachel. On October 20, 1998. Beloved daughter to Isaac Cohen and Anna Colchamiro Cohen. Loving sister to Esther, Molly, Beatrice and Sophia, and the late Sarah Jacob and Diana. Aunt and great aunt to many. Rachel touched many through her constant dedication and commitment to the helping professions as an occupational therapist to GIs after WW II, a teacher to handicapped children in school and homebound and as a guidance counsellor. Her pursuits of culture and art spanned from modern and international folk dancing, jewelry making and creative craft to visiting museums, movies and theater. She loved animals especially her cat NIKKI. Her legacy lives on through all her loved ones. Services at Sherman's Funeral Home, Bklyn, NY, Thurs October 22, 9:45 A.M.

title: Disconnect the Dots
description: THE path from technological miracle to public nuisance is often a direct one. Witness the descent of the laser, the pure, steady light that can cut diamonds or could, in theory, carry all the world's electronic information simultaneously on a single beam.

title: 3 G.O.P. Candidates for Governor Face Trouble
description: Part of the political legend of Fob James Jr., the pugnacious Republican Governor of Alabama, is that he likes to play from behind.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some copies yesterday about the World Series referred incorrectly to the home-run performance of Scott Brosius, the Yankee third baseman. He had two home runs in Game 3, but did not hit one in Game 1. The article also misstated the number of World Series titles the Yankees would have by winning this year. It would be 24, not 25.

title: RAYTHEON TO SELL SYSTEMS UNIT FOR $160 MILLION
description: The Raytheon Company agreed yesterday to sell its Raytheon Aircraft Montek unit to Moog Inc. for $160 million. Montek, based in Salt Lake City, supplies systems for aerospace concerns. Raytheon expects the transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, to close in the fourth quarter. Raytheon, an aerospace company based in Lexington, Mass., said the unit sale was part of its plan to focus on core businesses and shed select noncore assets. This sale will follow three others. Proceeds from the four sales, expected to total $300 million, will be used to reduce debt.

title: Essay
description: There are good Kurds and bad Kurds.

title: Microsoft Uses E-Mail From Netscape to Contest Antitrust Case
description: Trying to refute a central accusation in the Government's antitrust case, the Microsoft Corporation produced a secret E-mail message today from the chairman of the Netscape Communications Corporation seeking Microsoft's cooperation, offering to stay out of its way and suggesting that Microsoft invest in Netscape.

title: Mexico Pushes Effort to Block A Texas Dump
description: With the Texas state environmental agency set to meet on Thursday to decide whether to license a proposed dump for storing out-of-state low-level nuclear waste about 20 miles from Mexico's border, a group of Mexican lawmakers has been in Austin since Saturday trying to persuade the state to relocate the proposed site.

title: Is Computer Gap Bad for Girls?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYDEN, EILEEN, NEE SHARKEY
description: HAYDEN-Eileen, nee Sharkey of County Roscommon, Ireland on October 19th. Beloved mother of Kevin, John, Terence, Eileen and widow of John. Service private. Donations may be made to Gods Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10013

title: PEOPLESOFT SHARES PLUNGE ON GROWTH WARNING
description: Peoplesoft Inc.'s shares plunged 23 percent yesterday after the No. 2 maker of business management software warned that its sales growth would plummet by half because of stronger competition. The shares fell $6, to $19.75, in trading of 37.7 million shares. The company, based in Pleasanton, Calif., posted earnings Monday in line with expectations. Peoplesoft has lost nearly $9 billion in market value, a drop of nearly 70 percent, in the last six months on concerns about slowing demand in the $14.4 billion market for business software. It expects 1999 revenue to rise 25 percent to 35 percent, compared with the 60 percent gain expected this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITSTOCK, ROBERT H.
description: WHITSTOCK-Robert H. 68, of Cortland, NY. Retired VP of The Seeing Eye, Inc. in Morristown, NJ. Died Friday, October 16, 1998 in Palisades, NY. He is survived by his wife, Mary Jane Whitstock (nee Noonan), three daughters Holly (David) Seeger, Ivy (Morrison) Bryan and Laurel (Stephan) Carfaro, two sons Robert D. and Paul C. (Lori), eight grandchildren and four sisters. Services were held on Oct 19. Memorial contributions: Hospice of Rockland County, 18 Thiells-Mt. Ivy Rd. Pomona, NY 10970 or to The Seeing Eye, Inc. PO Box 375, Morristown, NJ 07963

title: U.S. Judge Allows a Lawyer To Stay in Police Brutality Suit
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected the city's attempt to disqualify a former senior lawyer in the City Corporation Counsel's office, now in private practice, from representing a plaintiff in a police brutality suit.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conoco Raises $4.4 Billion In a Record Initial Offering
description: Institutional and small investors snapped up more than 190 million shares of Conoco yesterday, raising $4.4 billion for its parent, DuPont, in the largest initial public offering in the United States.

description: There were days, not long ago, when it looked as though United States Representative Steven R. Rothman's Congressional race in New Jersey's Ninth District might turn into a referendum on President Clinton's libido.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the House vote on the Federal budget incorrectly summarized a comment by Representative Ernest J. Istook, Republican of Oklahoma. Mr. Istook did indeed say that the President needed the support of liberals. But he did not accuse Republican leaders in Congress of caving in to the President.

title: Polygram Says Profits Rebounded in 3d Quarter
description: Polygram N.V., the world's biggest recorded-music company, said yesterday that third-quarter profits jumped 95 percent, unexpectedly rebounding from drops in the first and second quarters as it reorganized and as new music releases revived demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, JOHN W.
description: HERZ-John W., a senior partner in the New York City law firm of Wolf, Haldenstein, Adler, Freeman & Herz, died October 19. He was 83 years old. Mr. Herz, who resided in Larchmont, New York, died after a prolonged illness. He was born in New York City and received both his B.A. and his law degree from Columbia University. He practiced corporate law with his present firm for over fifty years. He was the editor of the text Business Acquisitions and a faculty member for the Practising Law Institute. In addition to his law practice, Mr. Herz was a community leader and served as President of the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, a trustee of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center, President of Camp Madison-Felicia, a trustee of the Hudson Guild, Inc., Vice President of I Care and a Trustee of the Mamaroneck School District Community Education Program. Mr. Herz also served as a U.S. Army Captain during World War II. John Herz is survived by Elise, his wife of 57 years, his three sons: Andrew, James and Bill, his three daughters-in-law and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Ethical Cultural Society of Westchester in White Plains, New York, at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, November 11, 1998. Contributions can be made on his behalf to the Strang Cancer Prevention Center in New York City or the Guidance Center of New Rochelle.

title: ROCK
description: Stammering Sounds

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSEY, RALPH
description: DORSEY-Ralph. The Board of Directors and Staff of ArtsConnection mourn the passing of Ralph Dorsey, a talented musician and educator, who brought much joy to the public school children in the City of New York. Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman Steve Tennen, Exec. Director

title: 20 Are Arrested in a Scheme To Cut Businesses' Water Bills
description: A city water-meter reader built a thriving business on the side, reducing water bills for coin laundries, bodegas and apartment houses in exchange for tens of thousands of dollars in payoffs, Federal and city investigators charged yesterday.

title: Toll's 25 cents, Sir; No Charge For the Dog
description: IMAGINE yourself as a toll taker on the Garden State Parkway. An elderly couple pulls up to the booth at Raritan and asks directions to Florida.

title: Network Defends Islanders Blackouts
description: Although Fox Sports New York has refused to carry three Islanders telecasts because they conflicted with Devils' games, the executive who runs the cable channel said yesterday that he was not punishing the team.

title: Muzzling Dissent in Serbia
description: While the West's attention is fixed on Kosovo, Slobodan Milosevic is stilling independent voices inside Serbia. On Tuesday Serbia's parliament passed a suffocating new law on the media, the latest in a series of threats and actions against dissenters there. As always, Mr. Milosevic's timing is diabolically clever. Western officials have not sufficiently criticized these attacks on Serbia's civil society, afraid to anger the leader they need to deliver a deal on Kosovo. Washington has not yet realized that these independent activists are essential to the development of a democratic Serbia, the best way to break Mr. Milosevic's power.

title: Dow Jones Says Its President Plans to Retire
description: Dow Jones & Company announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Kenneth L. Burenga, would retire at the end of the year.

title: Schumer Fires Counterattack at D'Amato on the Holocaust
description: Invoking relatives he had lost in the Holocaust, Representative Charles E. Schumer yesterday assailed Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for gathering Holocaust survivors to attack Mr. Schumer's record on Jewish issues. He also berated Mr. D'Amato for disparaging him with a Yiddish vulgarism at a meeting with Jewish leaders earlier this week.

description: Blythe Danner Quits Miller Play

title: A Low-Key Day for Pataki and Vallone
description: With less than two weeks until the election, Gov. George E. Pataki and his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, both kept their campaigning low-key yesterday.

description: SCHNITZLER-Lucille. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of the mother of our devoted member, Barbara Goldman, and mother-in-law of Trustee Mark Goldman. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: New Ink-Jet Printer Has a Darkroom Inside
description: One clear trend in electronics is to package ever more functions in a single device, turning a cellular phone, for example, into a beeper, E-mail receiver, message center, bottle opener -- and, by the way, a telephone.

description: The question is not whether people are tuning in to radio programs over the Internet -- they are, albeit not in mass numbers. The question is whether the listeners count.

title: Painters Rescued After Scaffold Tips on Bridge
description: Cecilo Spencer and Orlando Lima were putting the final touches of paint onto the steel span of the Triborough Bridge yesterday when a metal cable snapped with a startling crack, tipping their scaffold like a trapdoor and dropping them into space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHILOWITZ, STEPHEN
description: SHILOWITZ-Stephen, architect, died on October 19 in New York City. He was 69 years old. He is survived by his wife, Carole Clarke, of Malvern, Pa, his daughter Yumi Shilowitz Ross of Chicago, Ill., his son George Shilowitz of New York City and his treasured grandchildren Ian and Camryn Ross. He received his architectural training at the University of Pennsylvania, MIT and the Ecole des Arts Americains in Fountainbleu, France. A two year stay in Tokyo, Japan, working for renowned architect Antonin Raymond, was a lifelong influence on his architectural philosophy. Recipient of a Ford Foundation grant for design of a mixed-use school and a Graham Foundation Grant for a traveling exhibition on Antonin Raymond, he taught archirectural concepts at the Phelps School in Malvern, Pa. He was a committed sailor, who was working on the design of a new catboat at the time of his death. Services will be held today at 9:45AM at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Two Studies Brighten Prospects for Bone Marrow Transplants
description: Two groups of researchers say they have found ways to make bone marrow transplant operations considerably safer and to expand the pool of donors who can provide a compatible match.

title: McCarthy and the Left
description: To the Editor:

title: The Legacy of a Stage-Struck Teacher; Dusty Treasures Reveal a Golden Era for Broadway, TV and Ethel Burns (Who?)
description: Jane Klain had been searching for Ethel Burns for a year and a half before she found her last February. It was not how she wanted to find her. She found her on the obituary page.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPKIN, NATHANIEL
description: LAPKIN-Nathaniel. Died October 20, 1998. Age 91. Loving husband of Frances, beloved father of Mitchell and adored grandfather of Jason and Jordan Lapkin. He was humane, a philanthropist and a giant among men. May his soul rest in blessed peace forever. Services private.

description: There was a headline in The Times yesterday that said, ''The Holocaust as a Teaching Tool.''

description: PINKEE was born far away, in Paris, at a time when a fire burned in every grate and smoke curled black and feathery like a horse's tail from a thousand chimney pots.''

title: For Congress From New York
description: There are more members of Congress from New York City and its suburbs running uncontested this year than facing serious opposition. But an election still presents an opportunity to evaluate the incumbents. Here are our endorsements in some of the more interesting local races:

description: WOMENVOTE.ORG

title: A Stand-In Rises to A Rarity And a Soloist
description: When Wolfgang Sawallisch, the music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, announced that he had to remain in Germany recently because of the illness of his wife, finding a conductor to cover the all-Brahms program the orchestra presented in Philadelphia last week and at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was challenging.

title: Megs Jenkins, 81, an Actress Known for Her Matronly Roles
description: Megs Jenkins, a British stage, film and television actress who specialized in playing kindly, matronly characters, died on Oct. 5, said a spokeswoman for the Gordon Rodwell Funeral Service in Felixstow, Suffolk, where her funeral was held. She was 81.

title: Record Penalty Likely Against Diesel Makers
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to impose its biggest civil penalty ever in a settlement with manufacturers of heavy-duty diesel truck engines for violating clean air standards, officials said today.

title: Computer Haves and Have-Nots in the Schools
description: WHEN William Yokoyama started seventh grade, he had already been using a home computer for more than six years. He could easily use it as a word processor, to surf the Internet, draw pictures, make charts and graphics and write simple game programs.

title: Economic Scene; The timid Japanese banking bailout just might do the job.
description: THE law the Japanese Parliament recently passed to rescue broken-down banks commits several blunders. It does not require insolvent banks to close. It does not require banks to disclose losses. It does not require wobbly banks that accept taxpayer money to lend to credit-worthy borrowers -- the primary purpose of a bailout. The obvious prediction is that Japan will remain credit-starved, dragging down other economies in Asia and beyond.

title: To Aid Players, Agents Ponder Forming League
description: Fed up with unfruitful negotiations with owners and fearing a work stoppage that could last into 1999, agents for National Basketball Association players are looking into economic alternatives, including exhibition games and even creating their own league.

title: POWER HUNGRY: A special report.; U.S. Splurging on Energy After Falling Off Its Diet
description: Twenty-five years after an oil embargo proved that fuel supplies were neither reliable nor endlessly cheap, the United States has given up almost all the gains it made in conserving energy. On average, Americans have returned to consuming nearly as much energy as ever before.

title: For a Traffic Agent's Burial, Lines of Colleagues and Police
description: Wearing white caps, blue uniforms and glum faces, traffic enforcement agents lined up five deep yesterday for the funeral of Larry Siegelbaum, the traffic agent killed in an accident with a yellow cab on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTINGLY, CHARLES, JR.
description: MATTINGLY-Charles, Jr. In Wilmington, DE on October 17, 1998. Age 74. Beloved father and fatherin-law of Maris, Sandy & Louise, Joe, Jim & Amy, and Sharon. He is also survived by 8 grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held Thursday, October 29, 11:00 AM at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church, 345 Bear-Christiana Rd, Bear DE. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Jesuit Seminary & Mission Bureau, 39 East 83 Street, New York, N.Y. 10028.

title: Volunteers Answer Questions Via Internet
description: The copious information available on the Net is all well and good, as far as Steve Gordon, a New York lawyer is concerned, except that Mr. Gordon figures that people spend hours trying to find the one bit of expertise they are looking for. So he decided to put the experts in one place.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles on Oct. 4 about Plum and Lucy Sykes, young Englishwomen who are popular on the New York social scene, incorrectly described the recent career of Sarah Giles, whose earlier social life in New York has been compared to theirs. After leaving Vanity Fair magazine in 1994, Ms. Giles operated a business importing clothing from Asia, and until recently was a researcher and coordinator of a photo project for The New Yorker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, HOWARD (JIGGSY)
description: JACOBY-Howard (Jiggsy). Died October 21, 1998 in Deerfield Beach, FL. Formerly of Elmhurst, NY. Loving husband to Dorothy; beloved father of Leslie (Jacoby) and Robert Goodman, and Mark; adored Poppa of Eliana. Services today 2PM at Schwartz Bros., Forest Hills, NY. Shiva observed at the home of Mark in Bayside.

title: Thompson Shuffles Its Ford Motor Team
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had reorganized the international management team for its important Ford Motor Company account.

title: Losers, Yes, but to a Winsome Ovation
description: The Padres had a three-run lead in the seventh inning of Game 1, a three-run lead in the seventh inning of Game 3 and a 0-0 tie through five innings of Game 4. And in the end, they had nothing to show for it. No matter how hard they tried, the Yankees always had a little bit more at the finish line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, LEONARD H.
description: BARON-Leonard H. We are going to miss our life long friend. Lots of love and kisses. Norma and Danny Ross.

title: COMPANY BRIEF
description: LENOX INC., Lawrenceville, N.J., a subsidiary of Brown-Forman Corp., will discontinue operations in early 1999 at its Kirk Stieff plant in Baltimore, affecting about 75 employees.

title: DeBerg Puts Down Clipboard For Huddle
description: When Steve DeBerg's voice came over the conference call, before a question was even asked, the 44-year-old quarterback of the Atlanta Falcons quipped: ''I hope you guys got the announcement that I retired this morning. This is not part of my deal. Mop-up duty was fine.''

title: Merry-Go-Round View of Baseball Stadiums
description: When the final out is called, when the TV crews have packed up, when the last baseball die-hard has been pulled from the bleachers by the authorities, Yankee Stadium will take on the serene quiet of its natural state. And that is the way visitors will find it at the Web site of Be Here Inc. (www.behere.com), a Silicon Valley technology company that makes technology to display 360-degree images on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKEL, LENA (NEE KRIEGER)
description: SCHENKEL-Lena (nee Krieger). Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Talia Schenkel and Sandra Schenkel Braus. Loving grandmother of Jonathan and Cheryl. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Englewood, N.J. Wednesday, 11:30AM.

title: CURRENTS/CHICAGO -- GERMANY; Office Space With a Twist
description: For home-office workers who wish their desks would vanish at the end of the day (or that Happy Hour were only seconds away), the German company Interlubke may have an answer. The Duo Center is a giant revolving swizzle stick: one half can be either an entertainment center or a drinks cabinet; the other is a computer work station that can hold a zip drive, printer and phone.

title: Series Sweep Provides the Exclamation Point for the Yankees' Stunning Season
description: On the night the Yankees won the World Series with a four-game sweep of the San Diego Padres, the outfielders for both teams could almost have taken the night off. That was the kind of game Andy Pettitte and Kevin Brown pitched.

title: Seeking to Revive Case Against Hubbell, Starr Defends His Inquiry of Clinton Friend
description: The Independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr offered a broad defense today in a court hearing in the case of Webster L. Hubbell to the repeated criticism that he had overreached in his investigation of President Clinton's inner circle.

title: Three Large Oil Companies in U.S. Report Weak Results
description: The Exxon Corporation and Texaco Inc. reported double-digit drops in earnings for the third consecutive quarter yesterday, and the Amoco Corporation reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss, a reflection of the slump in oil prices that began a year ago.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT BUYING 5% STAKE IN SPYGLASS
description: Spyglass Inc. shares rose 10 percent yesterday after the General Instrument Corporation, the leading United States maker of television set-top boxes, said it agreed to buy 5 percent of the Spyglass stock. Spyglass rose $1.1875, to $12.875 in trading of 1.5 million shares, almost four times the three-month daily average. General Instrument rose 37.5 cents, to $24.625. Spyglass will receive at least $20 million in revenue over three years from General Instrument to run a development center that will concentrate on cable services and applications. Spyglass will hire about 40 to 45 people to operate it, a spokesman said.

title: Outlook for Political Dynamics: More of the Same
description: As the 105th Congress cast its final legislative vote today, it stood identified less with any signature bill than with the paralysis of American politics near century's end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, ROLF
description: WALLACH-Rolf. 89, of Sherman, CT. Loyal husband of Violet, devoted brother of Lotte Hanf, Annelise Rosenberg, and Fred Wallace, affectionate uncle of six nieces and nephews, benign and generous friend of Pixie, Ursula, Lillian, Tony and scores of others. His life was rich in unassuming heroism. Because of his foresight and clear thinking, he was able to rescue parents, siblings, aunts and uncles who were trapped in Munich on the eve of the Holocaust. Thank you, Rolf, and rest in peace. Donations in his name may be made to the New Milford Visiting Nurse Hospice, 68 Park Lane Road New Milford, Ct. 06776.

title: Totally Tiled: It's Awesome
description: TILE has always been long on service, but it's no longer short on style.

title: For Kanell, a Good Report After Surgery
description: Danny Kanell jogged gingerly along the sideline of the practice field this morning, but after 50 yards, he stopped and put his left hand to the right side of his chest.

title: Taliban Aide Casts Doubt on Giving Up bin Laden
description: A senior official of the Taliban, the militant Muslim group that controls Afghanistan, says that his Government has no intention of extraditing Osama bin Laden, the man the United States has accused of planning the bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: White House and G.O.P. Duel Over Impeachment Panel
description: The White House today accused Congressional Republicans of rigging an impeachment proceeding, and Republicans fired back that Democrats were trying to shift the focus away from President Clinton's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRIN, MORRIS G.
description: ZIRIN-Morris G. The New York Law School community pays tribute to Morris G. Zirin, lawyer and writer, graduate of the class of 1933, who died last May at the age of 94. To his son, James D. Zirin, member of the Board of Trustees at NYLS and to the rest of his family and friends, the School pauses on the eve of his memorial service to remember Morris G. Zirin, attorney, father and friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODINSKY, RAYE
description: GOODINSKY-Raye. 97, on October 20th, peacefully in her sleep. Sister of Florence Frank. Beloved aunt of David and Shoshana Bilowit, Ira Bilowit, Alice Spivak, Louise Bilowit, Toby and Paul Mitchell, Florence Frank and Eugene Frank. Loving great-aunt of William and Grela Bilowit, Michael Bilowit, Fred and Marilyn Bilowit, Anne Bilowit, Marcy Bilowit, Chet Zmijewsky, Inice and Craig Smith, Wayne Bilowit, Robin and Randy Frank, Nancy and Robert Postelnek, Jay and Melanie Cotenoff, Robert and Cindy Mitchell, Ruth and Michael Jamnik, Eileen and Howard Kessner and numerous great-grand nephews and nieces. Graveside services today, 11AM Beth-El Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Ariane-5 Success Follows Pair of Failures : Rocket Launch Keeps Europe Alive in Space
description: PARIS  Ariane-5, the new European launch rocket, went into space Wednesday, putting into orbit a symbolic payload, a dummy telecommunications satellite, and, more important, Europe's hopes of keeping its leadership in the increasingly competitive global market for commercial space launchings.

title: 'Smart Guns' Setting Off Debate: How Smart Will They Really Be?
description: The 9-millimeter semiautomatic looks like an ordinary pistol, evil and menacing to gun haters, strangely beautiful to gun fanciers. But it is no ordinary weapon; pull the trigger and nothing happens.

title: In a Straitened Brazil, Talk of Pay in Goods
description: In normal times, even before the Christmas decorations go up, Nilton Silveira knows how he will spend the extra month's salary that comes at the end of each year. There are the presents for his wife and two children. There is the tree, with tinsel glistening like rain. There is the 26-hour bus ride up to see family in Bahia, the only chance the children get to know their relatives.

description: There are two dramatic defensive maneuvers that are superficially similar but have quite different objectives. Both call for the lead of an unsupported honor, usually a king.

title: Karl E. Prindle Dies at 95; Made Cellophane Marketable
description: Karl E. Prindle, an industrial chemist who helped transform cellophane into a mass-market wrapping, then devised a way for the masses to unwrap it without breaking their fingernails, died on Oct. 13 at a hospital in Willoughby, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, DAVID NATHAN
description: MEYERSON-David Nathan. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students, of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion express our heartfelt condolences to our beloved Governor, Morton H. Meyerson and Marlene Meyerson, devoted parents of David and members of the HUC family on the untimely and tragic death of their son. As it is written in the Book of Lamentations, our ''eyes are spent with tears, our hearts are in tumult, our being melts away.'' May his memory be a comfort to all those who mourn him, his dear parents and sister, family and friends. May God comfort them together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, Pres. Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: It May Be Snail Mail, but Technology Gets It Where It's Going
description: IF there is one institution that would seem to be threatened by the information superhighway, it's the United States Postal Service. The world of E-mail, Web pages and software downloads seems to offer everything the old paper-based world of information delivers but offers it almost instantaneously. Many have been wondering whether something known colloquially as snail mail can compete.

title: 3 Cheers and a Toast For the Straw Man, Too
description: David Wells called for the Yankees to gather in a corner of the sticky, cramped clubhouse and then every Yankee took their bottles of Champagne, raised them toward the ceiling and shouted, ''This is for the Straw Man.''

title: The Rev. Edward Flannery, 86, Priest Who Fought Anti-Semitism
description: The Rev. Edward H. Flannery, a Roman Catholic priest and outspoken opponent of anti-Semitism, died on Monday at Miriam Hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 86 and lived in Georgiaville, near Providence.

title: Group Claims Responsibility For Blazes At Vail Resort
description: The Earth Liberation Front, a shadowy group that has taken responsibility for a series of arsons in the Northwest, declared in an E-mail communique today that it set the fires atop Vail mountain on Monday ''on behalf of the lynx.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFONSI, PHYLLIS
description: ALFONSI-Phyllis. The Staff of American Presort are deeply sadden by the sudden death of our dear friend and associate. She will be forever remembered with fondness and respect. Viewing October 23rd. at 9am, McHoul Funeral Home, 655 Route 82, Hopewell Junction, New York.

title: Deer Hunt Called Off After Many Are Killed
description: An annual deer hunt at the 2,000-acre Watchung Reservation has killed so many deer so fast that it will be called off a year ahead of schedule, Somerset County officials announced.

title: The Boss Loves It, And Won't Let Go
description: George Steinbrenner's team was getting ready to win another World Series championship and soar into baseball history as one of the best teams ever, but the principal owner, for once, was straining for words. In the hours before his Yankees captured Game 4, in the hours before he would break down and cry in the victorious locker room, Steinbrenner was searching for the proper way to describe this team today, this team for the ages. He settled on calling it astounding, with unbelievable as a close second.

title: Alfred Kazin Memorial
description: A memorial service for the author, critic and teacher Alfred Kazin will be held on Saturday at 7:30 P.M. at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. Among those scheduled to participate are Louis Menand, Morris Dickstein, Anne Fadiman, Leon Wieseltier, Jonathan Rosen, Daniel Bell, Sean Wilentz and Mary Beth McMahon, Mr. Kazin's last doctoral student. Mr. Kazin died on June 5 at the age of 83.

title: Intel Chief Plans to Sell One-Third of Stake
description: The chief executive of the Intel Corporation, Craig R. Barrett, disclosed plans today to sell about one-third of his stake in the company, or 700,000 shares, as the stock recovers from a slump earlier this month.

title: Fireworks At Wye As Dance Goes On
description: For all the American efforts to envelop Middle East talks in a sylvan and secluded setting at the Wye Plantation, the smoke signals issuing from behind the police barricades have spelled a steady increase in tension, frustration and brinkmanship, building up to the pillar of flame that erupted today when the Israelis angrily threatened to bail out.

title: Teachers in Miami Are to To Be Offered Edison Project Stock
description: Stock options are usually reserved for high-paid executives or employees of high-tech start-up companies. But teachers in the for-profit Edison Project school in Miami will begin receiving them under a program believed to be the first of its kind.

title: Women Want It All, and It's All on Line
description: AMERICAN women are fast closing the Web gender gap. Women 50 and older are one of the fastest-growing populations on line, and women now make up almost half of all American Internet users. Given the reams of magazine pages devoted to charting a woman's every body curve and fashion fetish, Web sites for women were merely a matter of course.

title: Conjuring Works of Art That Live Mostly in Memory
description: ''Theater of Drawing,'' an exhibition of Robert Wilson's early artwork at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design, offers evocative emanations of the director's performance events. The carefully selected items -- drawings, pages from his notebooks and sculptural objects -- conjure atmosphere and environment. On their own terms they have an artistic appeal. The display, which runs through Oct. 29, coincides with the presentation of Harvard's Excellence in Design Award to Mr. Wilson.

title: Global Distress Takes a Toll On the Results at Citigroup
description: Citigroup Inc., the world's largest financial services company, reported a 65 percent drop in third-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting the impact of trading losses in volatile global markets this summer that offset strength in its domestic consumer businesses.

title: Budget Bill Is Signed Into Law by Clinton
description: President Clinton signed a 4,000-page budget bill yesterday after the Senate passed it 65 to 29. Many Republicans complained about last-minute items that failed, in the view of some, to reflect the party's principles of prudent spending. The pork-laden bill included measures like one providing $750,000 for grasshopper research in Alaska. [Page A24.]

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL TO CUT 600 JOBS OVER 18 MONTHS
description: The Great Lakes Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 600 jobs, or about 12 percent of its work force, in the next 18 months as part of a plan to save $40 million a year. The chemical maker said it would take pretax charges totaling $100 million to $120 million for the moves. It took $40 million against third-quarter earnings, and the remainder will be taken in the fourth quarter, Great Lakes said. The company, based in West Lafayette, Ind., had 5,100 employees at the end of last year. Its chemicals are used in fire retardants, water treatment and other functions. The job cuts were disclosed after the close of trading. Great Lakes shares fell 56.25 cents, to $44.875.

description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved Keycorp's pending acquisition of McDonald & Company Investments, a financial services firm based in Cleveland. The purchase will allow the Cleveland-based Keycorp to underwrite and deal in debt and equity securities, as well as take part in other nonbanking businesses.

Funeral services will be held on Friday October 23 at 1pm at Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapels, 1170 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD. Interment will be private. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Vintage Pettitte Pitches With Heart
description: Andy Pettitte was relieved before he ever threw a pitch against the Padres tonight because his father, Tom, was released from the hospital today after undergoing double heart-bypass surgery last Thursday. So as Pettitte tried to guide the Yankees to a World Series sweep, it was comforting for him to know that his father was watching on television at home in Deer Park, Tex. He was safe.

description: No one here seems to understand why Zippy Chippy cannot win a race.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: There are two things that listening to ''Electro-Shock Blues,'' the second album by the Eels, makes one want to say when talking to E (formerly Mark Oliver Everett), the band's singer, songwriter and guitarist. The first is ''I'm sorry''; the second is ''congratulations.'' The first response is out of sympathy for the recent tragedies that inspired the album: the suicide of his sister, the diagnosis of terminal cancer for his mother, the deaths of several friends and, years earlier, the heart attack of his father, whom E discovered dead. The second response is out of admiration that E, on the verge of becoming the only surviving member of his immediate family, managed to create such a beautiful, profound and moving album out of these losses.

title: When Baby Talk Makes Good Material
description: IT was mom to mom: an actress with a 16-week-old baby, a reporter with a toddler. Is the baby sleeping well? How's she eating?

description: Repesentative Barbara B. Kennelly, who told newspaper editors yesterday that she was disappointed with the support she had received from her party during her campaign for governor, backed away from those comments today, saying that she regretted her criticism but had no regrets about entering the race.

Their marriage was most beautiful and magical. Loving father of Charles (Sheryl) and Dr. Richard (Terry). Admiring grandfather of Lance, Samantha, Lauren and Justin. Dear brother of late Ben. Loved by his many friends. Rest in peace dearest Sam. We will always love you. Services Friday, October 23 at 9:45AM The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Third-Quarter Profit Fell 16% at DuPont
description: The DuPont Company, the largest chemical company in the United States, said third-quarter profit fell 16 percent on weakening global demand and the strong dollar before charges resulted in a quarterly loss.

description: New Yorkers will have to wait until tomorrow to give their conquering heroes a formal welcome home from San Diego, but it promises to be quite a bash. For the second time in three years, the Yankees will march triumphant up lower Broadway's Canyon of Heroes beneath a torrent of ticker tape.

title: Medical Center Will Pay To Settle Billing Case
description: Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills will pay the Government $840,000 to settle charges that it overbilled Medicare during 1994 and 1995, under a settlement announced yesterday.

title: Laughs Mix With Pathos At Richard Pryor Tribute
description: A laughing group of comedians and actors who have been inspired in their work by Richard Pryor gathered on Tuesday night at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to pay tribute to him. Robin Williams brought all the loose ends together when he recalled the Mark Twain observation that sorrow is a greater source of humor than happiness.

title: If Israel Gives Up on Peace, a Son Died in Vain
description: Another terrorist attack in Israel threatens efforts to achieve peace with the Palestinians. For me, the pictures of the victims of Monday's grenade attack at the Beersheba bus station had a very personal meaning. My son Amir was killed on Jan. 22, 1995, when suicide bombers blew up two crowded buses in Beit Lid. More than 20 people died, and dozens were wounded. This latest attack makes me relive that horrible day once more.

title: Technology Shares Help Nasdaq Market Advance Sharply
description: Technology shares led the Nasdaq stock market sharply higher yesterday, while blue-chip companies saw a far more mild rise.

title: Venezuela Sets Value Of Currency Losses
description: Venezuela's defense of its currency cost investors who bet on a devaluation in recent months about 60 billion bolivars ($105 million), Armando Leon, a governor of the central bank, said yesterday. The losses resulted from companies and investors rushing to borrow bolivars at interest rates of up to 100 percent to buy dollars in late August and early September, anticipating a plunge in the currency after Russia's devaluation.
