title: Moceanu Sues, Saying Parents Squandered Her Earnings
description: Raising serious questions about the protection of young athletes who make large sums of money, 17-year-old Dominique Moceanu has filed suit seeking independence from her parents and alleging that they squandered her earnings from a career as a gold-medal-winning Olympic gymnast.

title: Seat on Big Board Is Sold
description: A New York Stock Exchange seat sold for $1.275 million, $35,000 more than the previous sale, the exchange said yesterday. Owning a seat gives the holder the right to trade stocks at the exchange and to vote at meetings of the Big Board. The previous sale of a seat was last Thursday at $1.24 million. Prices peaked in March, at $2 million. Since the sale announced yesterday, the most an investor has been willing to pay for one of the 1,366 seats is $1.15 million and the lowest price an owner is willing to accept has been $1.775 million, the exchange said. The Big Board does not disclose the names of the sellers of exchange seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, IRVING
description: COOPER-Irving. (January 21, 1901-October 18, 1998). Beloved husband of Sally Menken, Claire (died 1967). Devoted father of Sandi, Myrna, John Cammett, Howard Allen. Adored grandfather of Melani and Angelo plus stepchildren and grandchildren. We mourn our genial patriarch whose life covered the century. Private funeral.

description: MINKOWITZ-Jacob. On October 20, 1998. Beloved father of Dorothy Lewis, Martin Minkowitz and Renee Minkowitz. Father-in-law of Lionel Lewis and Carol Ziegler. Cherished grandfather of Tracey Okun, Jonathan Lewis and Stuart Minkowitz. Great-grandfather of Mark and Scott Okun. Owned and operated famous bakery of Park Slope from 1936 to 1989. Member of Congregation Young Israel Beth-El of Boro Park. Services Thursday, October 22, 1998, 11:45 AM, Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP 4.1 PERCENT. Prices increased after the third weekly drop in supplies of U.S. distillate fuel signaled an early start to the home heating season. The December contract rose 56 cents, to $14.08 a barrel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an encyclical issued by Pope John Paul II incorrectly described papal encyclicals. An encyclical is not the most authoritative form of papal statement. The most authoritative statements are those made when the Pope indicates he is speaking ex cathedra, formally declaring a doctrine to be infallibly or irreversibly part of the Catholic faith. Such ex cathedra statements can appear in encyclicals and in other papal documents as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERELS, SONDRA (NEE SHAVELSON)

Loving mother of Roseanne Serels and Dr. Scott Serels and his wife Rose. Cherished grandmother of Gillian Serels. Services 11:30AM Friday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of the Western Reserve, 300 E. 185 St, Cleveland OH 44119.

description: This time Mark McGwire had to play catchup to Sammy Sosa.

description: WWW.IVILLAGE.COM

title: Videophone Call-Ins On a Cable TV Channel
description: The Internet has made it possible to perform all sorts of tasks without leaving the house -- banking, working, even dating. Credit ZDTV, a fledgling 24-hour cable channel with programming focused on computer issues, for using the Net to make a virtual community out of yet another group: the studio audience. The network, based in San Francisco, urges viewers to call in to its programs using Internet-based videophones, which transmit not just voices, but faces.

title: TENNECO CUTS 1,000 JOBS, TRIMMING WORK FORCE BY 2%
description: Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force. Tenneco, based in Greenwich, Conn., and the third-largest United States packaging company, said it would step up cost-cutting measures, resulting in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $95 million to $105 million. The maker of Monroe auto parts and Walker mufflers also said it recorded an 11 percent drop in third-quarter earnings because of weakening demand for its replacement auto parts. Third-quarter earnings, excluding a gain, fell to $93 million, or 56 cents a diluted share, from $105 million, or 62 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected Tenneco to earn 64 cents.

title: Book Reissued in Indonesia
description: A collection of essays on racism and discrimination against the Chinese minority in Indonesia, written by the nation's most prominent literary figure, was reissued today, nearly 40 years after the book landed the author in prison for a year in 1960.

title: Computer Associates Plans L.I. Expansion
description: Computer Associates International, the fourth-largest software company in the United States, said yesterday it would add 1,000 jobs within the next year as it expands its headquarters in Islandia, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSLOW, ROBERT J.
description: SUSLOW-Robert J. The Directors, Trustees and staff of National Jewish Medical & Research Center in Denver express their sincerest condolences to the Suslow family and the many friends of Robert J. Suslow. Mr. Suslow also was a long standing member of The National Jewish Council of National Trustees. In this capacity, he was a major leader in the annual retail industry dinners in New York. Mr. Suslow's long association with and support of National Jewish did much to assist in the treatment and research of lung, allergic and immune system diseases at the center. In 1980, when Mr. Suslow received The National Jewish Humanitarian Award, the event in his honor drew more than 2,000 friends and business associates. The event established the Robert J. Suslow Fellowship in Environmental Lung Disease. A major supporter of National Jewish Medical & Research Center in Denver, other charitable organizations, and the retail and fashion industries, Mr. Suslow was liked and admired by all those with whom he interacted. Family, friends and business associates will truly miss his leadership and friendship. Robert L. Mettler, Chairman Council of National Trustees Lynn M. Taussig, M.D., President & CEO

title: Sabratha Journal; From Qaddafi, a Softer Message: Send Tourists
description: Among majestic Roman ruins set against an azure sea, Sebastian Cuisenier walked alone, a rare visitor to a site that almost anywhere else in the world would be thronged with tourists.

title: Cheaper Thinkpads Still Classy
description: AFTER spending nearly two years interviewing consumers about their computing desires and habits, I.B.M. has created a very impressive new line of notebooks designed for people who spend their own money on computers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Middle East peace talks misstated the year in which Jordan, under King Hussein, fought Israel. It was 1967, not 1973.

title: Mail Order: The More, The Merrier
description: As the holiday season approaches, postal bags are swelling to Santa-size proportions with mail-order catalogues. This week, there will be two new arrivals in the mail -- both from small downtown design stores that are new to the mail-order business.

title: Accord Set For Syria And Turkey
description: A three-week-old crisis between Turkey and Syria appears to have been at least temporarily defused by the signing of an agreement between the two nations.

title: For Fans, Never A Doubt
description: Oh sure, there were moments when Kevin Brown looked sharp and made the Yankees flail their bats in futility. And yes, there was that eighth inning, when the San Diego Padres had the bases loaded with the post-season hero Jim Leyritz at the plate, twirling his lethal bat.

title: Newell Buying Rubbermaid in $5.8 Billion Deal
description: Rubbermaid Inc., despite its well-known brand name and product lines, is finally calling it quits as an independent company. Yesterday it announced that it would merge with the Newell Company in a stock swap valued at about $5.8 billion.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The dollar rose against the mark after a German central banker, Hans Jurgen Krupp, suggested that interest rates might be lowered. The dollar rose to 1.6484 marks, from 1.6384 Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBERG, MAX, M.D.
description: MILBERG-Max, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. Max Milberg. Dr. Milberg was associated with the Department of Medicine for over 35 years. He also served as Director of Infectious Disease for many years. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Jacob Shani, M.D., President David Feldman, M.D., Pres. Elect Salvatore DeGliuomini, M.D., Secy Steven Farber, M.D., Treasurer

title: After That Night At the Airport
description: In today's popular culture, the journey between fast buck and sheer greed has a stopover called sequel. Book publishing, alas, is no different in this from the movies or television. The most recent excursion into what could become publishing's latest nostalgia black hole is a sequel to the Hollywood classic ''Casablanca.'' This time it's a novel, titled ''As Time Goes By,'' which is actually both a sequel and a prequel, with the melancholy memories from the movie the cream in the middle of the cookie.

title: Yanks Sweep Series and Assure Legacy
description: The Yankees have been a team greater than the sum of its parts all year, and when they secured their own corridor in history tonight, it was appropriate that a pitcher who had struggled in recent weeks pushed them over the finish line.

title: Holding Hands of Young Web Writers
description: I HAD my usual nightmare the other night, the one in which I am stumbling down the halls of my old high school, feeling cold, late for a biology exam, noticing that other students are staring oddly at my outfit. Catching sight of my reflection in a window, I see why. I am naked, except for a pair of men's black nylon dress socks.

title: 'Don Zimmer Ate My Homework' and Other Tales From Game 4 on Fox
description: In two instances last night, Fox's Joe Buck showed why he is a delight.

title: Classical Ballet Energized With a Jolt of Contemporary Dynamism
description: The San Francisco Ballet, truly a world-class company, opened its weeklong season at City Center on Tuesday night with a gala program -- but not any old gala program.

title: Wall Street Optimism
description: After a season of worry that sent prices plunging and sparked talk of world recession, many of the world's financial markets have rallied amid optimism that the worst will be avoided. The recoveries are a welcome sign of renewed investor confidence in the ability of central banks and national governments to prevent a severe downturn.

title: Clinton Vetoes Measure to Pay $1 Billion in Late U.N. Dues
description: After arguing for months that the United States has to pay its back dues at the United Nations to keep its credibility as a superpower, President Clinton vetoed a bill today that would have paid those dues, declaring that an unrelated anti-abortion measure left him no choice.

title: PHELPS DODGE TO CLOSE 2 COPPER MINES AND CUT 680 JOBS
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the largest United States copper producer, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 680 jobs as it closes two mines, in New Mexico and Chile, because of continued low copper prices. The Phoenix-based company will cut 500 jobs in southwestern New Mexico. It will also immediately close its underground mine in northern Chile, eliminating 180 jobs. The company will have about 7,000 mining employees after the cuts. The cuts will result in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $10 million. Shares of Phelps Dodge fell $1.125, to $56.375.

title: European Union Forecasts More Growth
description: The European Union Commission predicted continued growth yesterday for the 15-nation bloc, though it trimmed its previous forecast for 1999. The latest forecast for growth in gross domestic product in 1999 was 2.4 percent, down from the 3 percent forecast in March, the commission said.

title: Nomura May Trim Up to 2,000 Jobs
description: Japan's Nomura Securities Company plans a major job cut worldwide because of a substantial net loss for the six months ended Sept. 30, Kyodo news service quoted company sources as saying.

description: ESTRONET.COM

title: Piazza Believed to Get Big Contract Proposal
description: Nearly five months to the day when they acquired Mike Piazza, the Mets were believed to have made their first substantial contract proposal to the All-Star catcher.

title: ISRAELIS THREATEN TO ABANDON TALKS, THEN BACK DOWN
description: The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, backed down from a threat to walk out of the Middle East peace talks tonight after Palestinian and Israeli security officials met with the Director of Central Intelligence and apparently made enough progress on key issues to satisfy the Israelis.

title: Japan Banks Consider Public Financing Plan
description: Industrial Bank of Japan said yesterday that it was prepared to seek Government money, though it was undecided on the timing and amount. It became the first big Japanese bank to say it would apply.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORPORATION IN STOCK DEAL FOR FORT BEND
description: Southwest Bancorporation of Texas Inc., Houston's largest independent bank holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Fort Bend Holding Corporation for $65 million in stock to expand its presence in the rapidly growing Houston market. Fort Bend, with assets of $330 million, has six Fort Bend Federal Savings and Loan branches in the Houston area and sells mortgages through its Mitchell Mortgage Company unit. Southwest will exchange 1.45 of its shares for each Fort Bend share, valuing the transaction at $21.75 a share. The purchase price assumes the conversion of $9.9 million of Fort Bend convertible debt. Shares of Fort Bend gained $1, to $20. Southwest shares fell 56.25 cents, to $14.4375.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; The Blurry Images Of a Family History
description: A NEW book, ''The Agnelli Gardens at Villar Perosa'' (Harry N. Abrams, $75), is filled with fuzzy pictures of very beautiful gardens in the Piedmont region of Italy, virtually secret gardens that have never been opened to the public. They cover 25 acres surrounding the Agnelli family seat in the village of Villar Perosa 30 miles north of Turin.

title: Microsoft's Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCTIVITY; Scheduling Children's Time With Divorced Moms and Dads
description: GOING through a divorce five years ago, Maralyn Facey watched her lawyer set up child custody and visitation schedules with calendar sheets, a beleaguered paralegal clutching a calculator and colored pencils spilling across the office floor.

title: October's Market Value
description: It was good news for Wall Street that the Yankees got to the World Series, but stock market fans might have actually preferred to see them lose the Series. That is, of course, if you assume that the results of the World Series have anything to do with the subsequent performance of the stock market. The fact is that the stock market has tended to do better in years after the Yankees played in the Series than in years when the American League was represented by another team.

title: GRAPHICS TECHNOLOGY COMPANIES SET $67 MILLION MERGER
description: ATI Technologies Inc., the world's largest supplier of three-dimensional graphics and multimedia technology, agreed yesterday to acquire Chromatic Research Inc. for $67 million to gain Chromatic's proprietary chip technology for consumer electronic products. The Toronto-based ATI, which had 1997 sales of $602.8 million, said it was acquiring all of the stock and debt of the closely held Chromatic. Chromatic, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is developing technology to place graphics, system logic and processor blocks on a single computer chip.

title: BBDO Pulls Out Of Kellogg Review
description: BBDO Worldwide in New York said yesterday that it had withdrawn from a closely watched review by the Kellogg Company that may result in Kellogg's adding an agency to the roster of shops handling its American general-market cereal account.

title: Lincoln Artifacts Are Popular on Line
description: IMAGINE for a moment that the reputations of American Presidents were like publicly traded companies. You and your broker would be dizzy following the peaks and valleys of your Clinton stock, or you might still be kicking yourself for not shorting George Bush before the 1992 election. Maybe a revisionist biography or two could juice those shares of Warren Harding that have long been dormant in your portfolio.

title: U.S. Sees Brooklyn Link to World Terror Network
description: Several months after the bombing of the World Trade Center in February 1993, one of the suspects tried to bargain with Federal prosecutors in New York, offering inside information about the bomb plot in exchange for a lighter sentence.

title: Memos Released in Sun-Microsoft Suit
description: Documents released today in the Microsoft Corporation's second major legal front -- the lawsuit filed by its rival Sun Microsystems -- include E-mail messages and internal memos certain to embarrass both parties.

title: First 'Black' President
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAST, MARY, FORMERLY MACASSEY(NEE VANCE)
description: KEAST-Mary, formerly Macassey(nee Vance).Died peacefully October 12 Browhill Nursing Home, St.Peter Port, Guernsey, C.I. Remembered with affection by her family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGER, MIRIAM
description: KRUGER-Miriam. October 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Kruger. Loving mother of Arline Rodman and her husband Norman, and Edward Kruger and his wife Suzanne. Cherished grandmother of Linda Rodman, Barbara McGrath, Debra Rodman, Roberta Hanley, Gary Kruger, Jonathan Kruger, Douglas Kruger, Maggie Kruger, Bob Kruger, Stacey Birndorf and her mother Elaine Klein, and Allison Kruger. She will also be missed by her great-grandchildren who loved her dearly. Service Friday October 23, 10 a.m. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

title: In a First for Italy, Former Communist Is Named Premier
description: A former Communist became Italy's Prime Minister today, the first ever to do so, and he quickly appointed an eclectic Cabinet that is not solidly to the left.

title: Simply the Best
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Campaign Funds at Center of Wisconsin Race
description: Senator Mitch McConnell cannot vote in Wisconsin. A Republican, he represents Kentucky on Capitol Hill. But he may have more to say than anyone else about whether his colleague, Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat who represents this state, retains his seat next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, FLORENCE
description: MANES-Florence. Died peacefully in her sleep October 14, 1998. Beloved aunt of Barbara Joan Grubman, Jack (Leslie) Manes and Jill (Robert) Rosen; sister-inlaw Geraldine Manes. Also survived by several great-nieces and nephews. Affectionately known by all of us as ''The Mayor of 8th Street in Greenwich Village'' because of all the wonderful friends she had there. We will all miss her very much. Funeral services Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, Sunday October 25 at noon. Donations to Womens Memorial, Dept 560, Washington, DC 20042

title: Gore Warming To Appellation Of Next in Line
description: Several months ago, Vice President Al Gore cringed at the sound of someone introducing him as anything other than Vice President Al Gore. But the introductions are changing, and so is the look on Mr. Gore's face.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAHONEY, HON. J. DANIEL
description: MAHONEY-Hon. J. Daniel. October 23, 1996. Dan-You went up to Columbia Law School and set the place on fire. You were the best. Rest in peace, wonderful friend.

title: Isles to Move Offices Back to the Coliseum
description: The Islanders have decided to move their team offices back into Nassau Coliseum early next month, an official with the club said yesterday.

title: Condemned to Repeat the Joy of the Past
description: Sick of hearing about iffy job prospects and ozone depletion in the 1990's, a high school student named David (Tobey Maguire) is in love with the sugar-coated past. On his favorite old television show, Dad booms ''Honey, I'm home,'' and Mom wears a crinoline and pearls. The kids say ''Gee whiz!'' and the fire department rescues cats in trees. The teacher's desk is lined with apples, for this is a ''Father Knows Best'' clone with a vengeance. Who knew, while plotting to stay home from school and watch it in reruns, that this show's idea of family paradise would make it the great cultural madeleine of its time?

title: Team Sale Approved
description: The management committee of Major League Soccer, which started operations with 10 teams three years ago at a cost of about $5 million a team, has unanimously approved the sale of the Los Angeles Galaxy to Philip F. Anschutz, the Denver billionaire, for $26 million.

title: Boeing Results Beat Forecasts In 3d Quarter
description: The Boeing Company reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that were higher than expected, but it warned that the recession in Asia would cause it to lose more airplane orders than it had previously estimated.

title: A Guy Just Back From Hell Has One Heck of a Challenge
description: For anyone who fears that heaven is out of reach, here is some consoling news about the other place. It seems the gates of hell aren't that heavily guarded, and escape is a distinct possibility. The strained concept of ''Brimstone'' is that 113 of hell's most vile souls (some dead for centuries) have escaped and returned to earth. The man Satan chooses to haul them back is Ezekiel Stone, who landed in hell because he murdered the man who raped his wife. Stone also happened to be an ace New York City detective in the 1980's. Now he can redeem himself by bringing the evil dead back home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADOCK, ROSABELLE J.
description: SADOCK-Rosabelle J. Beautiful and devoted wife of Jules B. Sadock. Died on October 22, 1998. She is survived by her beloved husband, her son Geoffrey, her daughter Dona, her daughter-inlaw Karen and her granddaughter Katharine. The funeral is private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Truth About Preferences
description: To the Editor:

title: When Scraping the Sky Makes a City Bleed
description: HE is polite about it, but Edward C. Rubin really doesn't like to talk about himself with reporters. He will list the firms where he worked as a young architect, before he started his own firm in the Flatiron district. He will say that he and his wife, Susan, a teacher at Stuyvesant High School, have two daughters, one in high school, one in college. He will reveal that he grew up in the Bronx, that his family was in retail (some coaxing draws out the fact that his father ran a restaurant).

title: From Palestinian or Israeli, The Attitude Is Skepticism
description: In a mirrored cafe on Palestine Street in Ramallah, the Palestinian men smoking water pipes, playing cards and talking politics were deeply wary.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILOWIT, DEBBI WASSERMAN
description: BILOWIT-Debbi Wasserman February 3, 1946 - October 23, 1986 Without you the world is incomplete. You are missed by all of us.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: BOWATER TO SELL MAINE TIMBERLANDS TO J. D. IRVING
description: Bowater Inc., the largest United States newsprint maker, agreed yesterday to sell one million acres of Maine timberland for $220 million to J. D. Irving Ltd., part of the business empire of Canada's Irving family. Bowater expects to record a $100 million gain from the sale when it closes in the first quarter of next year, said Deborah Humphrey, a spokeswoman. Proceeds will be used to repay debt, to buy back shares and for other corporate purposes, she said. The sale was announced two days after Bowater, based in Greenville, S.C., said it would shut a pulp mill in British Columbia and proceed with a plan to spend $220 million to upgrade a paper mill in East Millinocket, Me. Its shares fell 81.25 cents, to $39.25.

title: A survey of teen-agers will help advertisers decipher the infinite meanings of 'whatever.'
description: YOUNG consumers have been under scrutiny from the 1940's, when Seventeen magazine popularized the term ''teen-ager,'' to the 1960's, when Paul Lynde asked ''What's the matter with kids today?'' in ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' to the 1990's, when adults learned that the word ''whatever'' could have an almost infinite number of meanings. Now a major agency is enlisting teen-agers themselves to help explain and predict their behavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENZA, CHARLES R.
description: CLEMENZA-Charles R. Beloved husband of Gena. Devoted father of Courtney and Vincent. Loving son of Clementine. Fond brother of Anthony, James and Jerry. Reposing at Bensonhurst Prospero Funeral Home, 2444 86th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:15 AM, St. Bernard's Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM Saturday and Sunday. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia Society of America.

title: Procter & Gamble Adds Assignments
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with two of its largest roster agencies by awarding them additional assignments.

title: KROLL-O'GARA TO PURCHASE LABORATORY SPECIALISTS
description: The Kroll-O'Gara Company, an international corporate security company, agreed yesterday to buy Laboratory Specialists of America Inc. for $29 million, or $5 a share, in stock. Laboratory Specialists operates a laboratory in New Orleans that tests for the use of illegal drugs. Kroll-O'Gara, with more than 1,500 people in 50 sites around the world, will add the drug-testing service to its range of corporate security products and services.

title: Ditching Rap for More Hardcore Metal
description: The pop makeover of the year belongs to Vanilla Ice, the rapper and one-album wonder of the early 1990's. As late as the summer of 1997, he was still performing his hit ''Ice, Ice Baby'' the way he did it in 1991, when he joined M. C. Hammer as a dancing, grimacing rapper packaged for MTV. In his brief heyday as a rapper for teeny-boppers, he sold millions of albums, but at the price of becoming a hip-hop punch line. Now there's a setup for a new joke: Vanilla Ice, the tormented rocker. As a pre-emptive strike, his new album is called ''Hard to Swallow'' (Republic/Universal).

title: Small Budgets, Big Successes
description: Three weeks into October and three new productions look like bona-fide hits. But unlike past seasons, this one has early winners that are neither new Broadway musicals nor expensive revivals but small-budget shows in unlikely Off-Broadway venues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRIN, MORRIS G.
description: ZIRIN-Morris G. Of Palm Beach, FL., May 17, 1998. Adored husband of the late Kate Zirin. Beloved father of James D. Zirin. Loving grandfather of Anne E. and David M. Esteemed father-in-law of Marlene Hess. Brother of Ida Cypin. Memorial service Friday, October 23, 12 noon, at Temple Emanuel, 5th Ave., 65 St.

title: A TEAM FOR ALL TIME
description: Scott Brosius imagined all year that he would make the final play to end the World Series. A vision like that can be weird, the Yankees' third baseman said. ''You're playing a game and you think to yourself, 'O.K., this is the World Series, and you're going to make the last out.' ''

title: Griffith Joyner Died After Seizure in Sleep
description: The Olympic sprint champion Florence Griffith Joyner died of suffocation a month ago after suffering a seizure while she slept, medical authorities said yesterday in southern California.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Ford Plays Midwife for Junior Jaguar
description: THE chairman of Jaguar Cars Ltd., Nicholas V. Scheele, put on a grand party this week on the eve of the British International Motor Show here. It was a beautifully choreographed affair inside a renovated factory in Castle Bromwich, a suburb a few miles up the road. Nearly 1,000 luminaries attended from the worlds of entertainment, sports and the Ford Motor Company -- Jaguar's parent since 1989. There was excellent food and fine wines.

title: Guatemala Cover-Up Charged in Killing of Bishop
description: Forensic teams from three countries have tried to unravel the mystery, but have come to radically different conclusions. Nearly six months after Juan Gerardi, a Roman Catholic bishop and outspoken human rights advocate here, was bludgeoned to death, a solution to his slaying appears further away than ever, even as the political controversy surrounding the case continues to grow.

title: Two Foreign Affairs Agencies Are Eliminated
description: Two independent foreign affairs agencies were abolished this week by a stroke of President Clinton's pen, and a third will have its independence sharply curtailed under a reorganization plan for the State Department that was championed by Republican leaders in Congress.

title: Court Ruling Puts an End to Some Marijuana Sting Operations
description: In a ruling that will limit the way police departments conduct some sting operations involving marijuana, the State Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday reversed a Monroe County Court decision that allowed people who believed they were buying marijuana to be charged with criminal solicitation.

title: Finding a Sense of Harmony With 60 Diverse Teen-Agers
description: In the spring of 1994, 60 teen-agers in and around Washington volunteered for a theater project based on their lives and conflicts. Black, white and of mixed blood, from drifters and prostitutes to prosperous preppies, they came together for a year to write and rehearse a musical production that was performed in the ornate Warner Theater, not far from the White House.

title: Office-Block Brussels / Bureaucracy Is Their Business : Eurocapital in Search of a Human Dimension
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union and other international organizations have brought wealth but not much style to the capital of Europe. The EU institutions, which occupy about 13 percent of the office space in Brussels, have grown haphazardly in response to the changing nature and the successive enlargements of the 15-nation community. It was only in 1992 that heads of government decided once and for all that Brussels would be the EU's permanent home and it is only since comparatively recently that serious thought has been given to the impact this decision will have on the city, at least from an architectural point of view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERPNER, SANDRA
description: KERPNER-Sandra. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Sandra Kerpner, beloved sister of our devoted members Mark & Jennifer Landesmann. Sincere condolences to them, her parents Peter and Ellen Landesmann, her husband Richard, daughter Naomi, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Eight Players File
description: On the day after the World Series ended, eligible players began filing for free agency. Jose Canseco of Toronto, Brian Jordan of St. Louis and Todd Stottlemyre of Texas were among the first eight players to file yesterday.

title: Brady Learns to Relax For His Best Pro Game
description: The secret has been let out: Kyle Brady was the culprit, the player who was the worst offender during last Friday's theatrical workout walkout by Coach Bill Parcells.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN WEAKENS. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen for a third day amid doubts that officials in Tokyo had done enough to strengthen the ailing banking system. The dollar rose to 117.87 yen from 117.00 on Wednesday.

title: ROUNDUP
description: L.P.G.A. SAMSUNG WORLD CHAMPIONSHP

title: Dazzling Images Delineate a World That Never Was
description: In every culture, objects of beauty bring delight. They also push ideologies, advertise interests, secure alliances and pump up reputations. So it has always been; so it is likely always to be.

title: SPARE TIMES -- ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHALL, HELENE
description: MULHALL-Helene. AMIT is deeply grieved at the untimely passing of the beloved sister of our most devoted friend, advisor and supporter, Alvin Hellerstein, and cherished sister-in-law of our most dedicated National Vice President, Mildred Hellerstein. A person of many talents, Helene Mulhall lived a varied life, and through her personal Aliyah demonstrated her love for the people and State of Israel. Heartfelt condolences to her beloved mother, brother, children and the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, DR. MARGARET MCKEE
description: ANDERSON-Dr. Margaret McKee, 90, died October 19, 1998, in Carthage, IL. Preceded in death by husband Orrin E. Anderson in 1972. She was graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1928 and from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1932. She spent most of her life in Riverdale, NY, where she practiced pediatric medicine for 32 years with offices in Manhattan and Riverdale, and was affiliated with St. Luke's Hospital, New York City. In 1971 she retired to the family home in Carthage, IL. Surviving are two daughters Laura Anderson of St. Louis, MO and Martha Lou Anderson of Carthage, IL, and a niece, Edythe McKee of Stamford, CN.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Nan Goldin

title: After Century of Baseball, How Do Yanks Stack Up?
description: Even George Steinbrenner, who likes to brag about his baseball team, was not ready to say outright that the 1998 Yankees are the best ever, even after they completed their stunning 125-victory season with a World Series sweep of the San Diego Padres on Wednesday night.

title: A 'Lion King' With Girls as Stars
description: On the low end, there's the dinky Simba key chain, and on the high end the extravagant Broadway musical. With all those ''Lion King'' products floating around, it comes as a shock to realize there hasn't been a sequel to the movie until now. The straight-to-video ''Lion King II: Simba's Pride,'' scheduled for release in stores on Tuesday, is based on an obvious but sensible and cheering idea: it's the girls' turn to be hero and villain. Simba has grown into a protective father; his daughter, Kiara, is a rambunctious teen and the movie's star. And since Simba's evil Uncle Scar was last seen about to be shredded by hyenas, the new villain is a wicked mother lion named Zira.

title: F.C.C. Offers Rules Intended to Settle Wiretapping Dispute
description: The Federal Communications Commission issued a proposed set of rules today intended to settle a dispute over high-tech wiretapping that has pitted the Federal Bureau of Investigation against the telecommunications industry and privacy advocates.

title: China Ending Protection of Insolvent Trust Companies
description: As signs of deep financial trouble in China's trust and investment companies come to light, bankers and economists say they expect the Chinese authorities to close dozens more debt-ridden financial houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVNER, VIOLA
description: YAVNER-Viola. We deeply regret the passing of our former longstanding member and active participant in our cooperative. Condolences to children Ruth Himes, Judith Yavner, Daniel Yavner and wife Mary. Three Arrow Cooperative Society Alice Appenzeller, President

title: Yanks Return After Celebrating for Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry was watching the Yankees celebrate their World Series title on Wednesday night when the telephone rang and he was suddenly verbally transported from silent Fort Lee, N.J., to rollicking San Diego. It was Derek Jeter and some of Strawberry's closest friends on the line. About 24 of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUMACK, DR. IRVING
description: RUMACK-Dr. Irving, on October 20, 1998, age 81. Beloved husband of Mildred Rumack. Devoted father of Peter and Lucy, and fatherin-law of Nina and Rod. Adoring grandfather of Julia, Amy, Charlotte and Matthew. At home Saturday and Sunday after 1:00 P.M.

title: Nomura Reports $1.7 Billion Loss In Its First Half
description: Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, reported a $1.76 billion loss for its fiscal first half yesterday and provided an emergency infusion of funds to rescue its hemorrhaging United States operation, which caused most of the losses at the parent company.

title: How Does an Ad Spell Success? A-N-S-K-Y
description: They were cast with their shirts off and that's how fame came to the ANSKY boys, five screwy characters with large letters painted on their fleshy chests who embody the passion of Yankee fans in commercials for Adidas America.

title: Issues at U.N. Again: Iraq, Nerve Gas and Weapons Inspections
description: Experts on chemical and biological weapons met here today to examine whether Iraq loaded deadly nerve gas on some of its missiles.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 8
description: Game of the Week

title: Anti-Gay Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Piazza Talks 'Productive'
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips held his first productive meeting with Mike Piazza's representatives on Wednesday in Beverly Hills, Calif., in his attempt to negotiate a contract with the feee-agent catcher. It was a productive meeting and negotiations are ongoing, Phillips said.

title: The Dance Life: How Chaos Eventually Makes Order
description: Ronald K. Brown settled into a chair at a table in the crowded restaurant, his backpack and dance satchel on the floor beside him. It was lunchtime recently at Kelley & Ping, a popular Vietnamese cafeteria-style hangout in SoHo. Mr. Brown gazed into space, then broke into a slow, easy grin. ''I think I have a handle on this now,'' he said.

title: PLUS: BOXING; Father-Son Cards
description: Call it Macho-a-Macho. Hector (Macho) Camacho Sr. will go head-to-head against his son, Hector Jr., tonight -- in a ratings war.

title: Refusing Rent Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Victorian Escapism and Denial With the Fascinating Fairies
description: It's about sex.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; How the West Was Won, Then Lost
description: LASSO THE WINDAway to the New WestBy Timothy Egan 266 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS SEEKS CONTROL OF DAVIS HAMILTON
description: Affiliated Managers Group Inc. has agreed to purchase a majority stake in Davis Hamilton Jackson & Associates Inc., a Houston money-management firm. Affiliated would not disclose the purchase price. Affiliated, a Boston holding company that purchases majority interests in midsized asset managers, plans to acquire 65 percent of Davis Hamilton, manager of about $3 billion for institutional clients. Affiliated now controls 12 firms with a total of $50 billion in managed assets.

title: Francis W. Sargent, 83, A Massachusetts Governor
description: Francis W. Sargent, the moderate Republican, defender of the environment and solver of fiscal crises who served as Governor of Massachusetts from 1969 to 1975, died today at his home in Dover, Mass. He was 83.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Switzerland's seizure of more than $90 million from Raul Salinas de Gortari, a brother of Mexico's former President, misstated the number of witnesses who said they had seen Mr. Salinas meet with drug traffickers, introduce them to Mexican officials or pick up suitcases full of cash. It was about 10 of the almost 80 witnesses located in the investigation, not all of them.

title: Saatchi Sells; Students Benefit
description: It has been a few years since Charles Saatchi has surfaced as a seller at an auction. But this week, Christie's in London announced that Mr. Saatchi, the advertising magnate who is also one of Britain's biggest contemporary art collectors, would be selling 130 works by 97 artists, together valued at $1.6 million, on Dec. 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: SALMAN-Charlotte. Loving wife of the late David. Devoted mother of New York State Supreme Court Justice Barry Salman and Arlene and Dr. Arthur Salman and Leonora. Dear sister of Alan Grant. Cherished grandmother of Karen Sbriglio, Jocelyn Khalifa, Wendy Herlands and Craig and Amy Salman. Greatgrandmother of Aleya and Zachary Khalifa, David and Daniel Sbriglio and Sara Herlands. Services on Friday 11:00 AM at ''Garlick-Riverside'', 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, New York.

title: 2 Agencies Reward Top Executives
description: Top executives at two agencies have been rewarded, in one instance with equity stakes and in the other with new duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, JOHN F.
description: DALY-John F., M.D. The faculty & staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. John F. Daly. A native of New Jersey, Dr. Daly received his A.B. Degree from Fordham University in 1932 and his M.D. Degree in 1937 from Long Island College of Medicine. He served his internship at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, NJ. From 1942 to 1946 he served in the U.S. Army Air Force where he attained the rank of Major. Dr. Daly came to NYU School of Medicine in 1946, and had a long and distinguished career as Professor and Chairman of the Department of Otolaryngology from 1949-1980. He was also Director of Otolaryngology at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was one of the founders of the field of modern Head and Neck Surgery and an outstanding physician-educator who was devoted to his patients and students. An active member of many professional societies, he served as President of the American Society for Head and Neck Surgery, The American Academy of Ophthalmology, and Otolaryngology and was Chairman of the American Medical Association's Section Council on Otolaryngology. Dr. Daly was the recipient of numerous honors and awards. In addition, he was consultant to many hospitals in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan area. To his long-time wife, Annette O'Mealia Daly and daughter, Sharon Ann Butler, and grandchildren, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Noel L. Cohen, M.D., Chairman Dept of Otolaryngology Vice Dean for Clinical Affairs Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine

title: 2 Top Internet Music Sellers Make an Agreement to Merge
description: After weeks of negotiation, CD Now and N2K, the two biggest Internet music sellers, agreed to merge yesterday afternoon.

title: On My Mind; Prisoner of Baghdad
description: Goal by goal and strength by strength, the U.N. inspection teams searching out Saddam Hussein's weapons are being diminished in purpose, effectiveness and dignity by Secretary General Kofi Annan, to the point of public insult.

title: Police Operation Cracks Car Theft-Fraud Ring
description: Forty people were arrested yesterday and accused of paying to have their own cars stolen in a scheme to collect insurance money, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHULMAN, HOWARD
description: SCHULMAN-Howard 12/24/1710/23/97. Dad, your spirit is always with me, your presence is greatly missed. Love, Jud

title: A Conservative, D'Amato Learned to Adapt
description: On a recent evening, a crowd of elegantly dressed people, many of them Democrats, gathered at the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan to honor a Brooklyn housing group founded by one of the state's most famous liberals, Senator Robert F. Kennedy. And there, seated near the front, was an unlikely guest of honor: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the three-term Republican running hard for a fourth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the effort by Paula Corbin Jones to reinstate her sexual harassment lawsuit against President Clinton misstated the name of a judge on the three-member panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit that is hearing the arguments. He is Judge C. Arlen Beam, not Arlen C. Beam.

title: Observer; What About Inferno?
description: The tattoo parlor in the next block caught fire a half-hour ago, and I dropped everything and went to watch the spectacle. We don't get a lot of spectacles in Burgville, my hometown.

title: Enter the Ingenue: 'Can You Guys Call Me Monica?'
description: In the rehearsal hall, the dialogue was sliced tart and true from the life and times of Monica S. Lewinsky, with no less than three actresses taking a crack at the ultimate ingenue's role in the inescapable national melodrama that has no copyright, perchance no ending.

title: Crime Costs Many Black Men the Vote, Study Says
description: Nationwide, 1.4 million African-American men -- 13 percent of black men -- cannot vote because of their criminal records, according to a report made public yesterday by Human Rights Watch and the Sentencing Project, two nonprofit research and advocacy groups.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: When the Sure-Footed Stumble; Swiss Banks Stagger After Several Investing Missteps
description: The global financial turmoil has jolted big banks across Europe and the United States, but few can match the woes here in Switzerland.

title: TODAY: A SEASON TO REMEMBER
description: A special section looks at the Team for All Time, at Steinbrenner the sentimentalist and at a grateful Joe Torre. And, in color: 125 victories, game by game. Section G.

title: INSIDE
description: Griffith Joyner Had Seizure

title: Finding a Jewish Perspective Even in the National Anthem
description: Having revived the American Symphony Orchestra with programs in which works and composers are linked by overarching themes, Leon Botstein showed on Monday evening that his programming approach can enliven fund-raising concerts as well.

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?; Rewarding Complainers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLER, PETER H.
description: HALLER-Peter H. Of Eastchester, formerly of Bronxville. Beloved husband of Evelyn Haller. Friends who wish may contribute to The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York 10601 or The Humane Society of your choice.

title: Bankers Trust Posts Loss of $488 Million
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation reported a quarterly loss of $488 million yesterday, considerably worse than expected, and announced a cost-cutting agenda that is likely to mean some layoffs among its 18,300 employees.

title: 125 -- THE WINNINGEST SEASON
description: The Yankees looked good in spring training -- good enough for George Steinbrenner to ask out loud whether a team had ever gone 162-0. And he turned out to be closer to the truth than anyone would have thought: a team- and American League-record 114 regular-season victories, a major league-record 125 victories over all and the third-best overall winning percentage (.714) for a World Series champion. Here is the Yankees' seven-month march into the history books, game by game.

title: Small Telephone Company Is Victim of Credit Squeeze
description: Telegroup Inc., a small international telephone carrier that was flying high just six months ago, is on the verge of running out of cash and is weighing takeover offers from at least two communications companies, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; A Stadium Imperfect In Its Glory
description: A SEASON that began with an inauspicious West Coast crash and a scary South Bronx collapse played out in seamless, spectacular style. After stumbling out of the gate, the Yankees won 125 games. After being closed for repairs, Yankee Stadium held up to a record number of fans. More than ever, team and stadium stand tall and imperfectly proud.

title: Series Not a Hit On Fox Network
description: It was a glorious run toward a 24th World Series championship for the Yankees, but the Nielsen ratings were far from sensational for Fox. In fact, the final rating was the lowest ever for a televised Series.

title: In a Suburb, Echoes of the Third Reich
description: There's a scene in ''Apt Pupil'' in which an old man, a former Nazi war criminal, literally takes his marching orders from a clean-cut high school boy. The old man moves his feet reluctantly at first, then displays a mocking, puppetlike compliance. But as he moves faster and faster, something terrible happens: long-dormant evil is rekindled and the old man begins to stomp as fiercely as he did for the Third Reich. ''Boy, be careful,'' he hisses to his teen-age taskmaster. ''You play with fire!''

title: Making It Politically Possible for the Two Leaders to Agree
description: When the Israelis finally claimed a breakthrough tonight it did not involve the concrete issues of land and security, but rather matters of acute political sensitivity -- the Palestinian charter and the seizure of Palestinian suspects wanted by Israel.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Ferdinand Marcos's Swiss Bank Legacy: Tighter Rules for Despots and Criminals
description: The case of some $500 million stashed in Swiss banks by the former dictator of the Philippines, Ferdinand Marcos, has prompted reforms that make it harder for corrupt rulers and criminals to stow assets here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICULAR, ARTHUR
description: SICULAR-Arthur. On October 22, 1998 after a vigorous life and brief illness. Beloved husband of Lilian. Loving father of David, Michael, Eve and Steven. Father-in-law of Lili. Dear grandfather of Jonathan, Sarah and Rebecca. Service Friday, 12 noon, at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY. Contributions in his memory to NARSAD, 60 Cutter Mill Road, Suite 404, Great Neck, NY 11021.

title: MGM SAYS IT WILL BUY POLYGRAM'S MOVIE LIBRARY
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $250 million in cash to the Seagram Company for most of Polygram N.V.'s library of movies, including ''The Graduate'' and ''Fargo,'' to create the world's biggest collection of films. The struggling studio's Orion Pictures unit will pay $235 million of its own cash and $15 million from the cash flow of Polygram Filmed Entertainment's movies. The transaction does not include Polygram's ITC library of TV shows and films. The purchase will increase MGM's library by more than 1,300 films to about 5,200, including more than half of all Hollywood films produced since 1948. Seagram has been trying to sell Polygram Film Entertainment since May to help offset part of the cost of its planned $10.4 billion purchase of Polygram N.V., the world's largest recorded music company, from Royal Philips Electronics N.V.

title: A Soldier's Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAY, WILLIAM
description: HAY-William. 71. A resident of Kennebunkport, ME., died in Gorham, ME. He was a lawyer, former President of Trizec Corp and Executive Vice President of Olympia & York Properties. Survived by his wife Elizabeth, daughter Sheila & son David & their families. Memorial donation to Alzheimer's Disease Research, 15825 Shady Grove Road, Suite 140, Rockville, MD 20850. Info: Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk, ME

title: Permitted by Court, 1,000 March Against Police Brutality
description: Hemmed in by a throng of police on foot and on scooters, more than 1,000 protesters marched down Broadway yesterday afternoon to speak out against police brutality.

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?; Damage to Free Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Guidelines On Airline Alliances Set
description: Congress gave the Transportation Department new authority under the budget it passed this week to delay new airline alliances that it suspects are anti-competitive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPKIN, NATHANIEL
description: LAPKIN-Nathaniel. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai-NYU Medical Center and Health System deeply mourn the passing of Nathaniel Lapkin, a generous long-time supporter and Sponsor of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, as well as a benefactor of The Mount Sinai Hospital for many years. Mr. Lapkin supported a broad range of research, educational and clinical activities, as well as assistance for indigent patients. He will be remembered most fondly, with gratitude for his far reaching philanthropy. We extend deepest sympathy to his daughter Frances, his son, Mitchell, to his grandchildren and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTENPLAN, MILTON
description: GUTTENPLAN-Milton. 83. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted father of Kenneth and Barbara, Carol Wolf and the late Howard. Cherished brother of Harold. Adored grandfather of Joshua and Adam Wolf, Elena, Marra and Ethan. A Great Neck resident for 48 years, always involved in charitable causes. Founder and active member of the Board of Trustees of the Great Neck Synagogue. Served as V.P., Public Relations for the Great Neck United Community Fund. Board member of Great Neck Adult Education, served on the Board of the Jerusalem Reclamation Project. Retired Director of Advertising and Marketing at Barney's New York. Received four Clio Awards for outstanding TV commercials. He was also President of the ''100'' Club. Served as Captain in charge of the Pentagon printing office during WW II. Funeral services today, 1PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations to Great Neck Synagogue Torah Fund or Great Neck United Comm. Fund.

title: After 31 Years at Goldman, Vice Chairman Plans to Retire
description: Roy J. Zuckerberg, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company and the longest serving partner at the private Wall Street firm, will retire next month -- potentially missing out on a chance to perhaps triple the value of his stake if the firm goes public.

title: Giving China an Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, ARNOLD M.
description: AUERBACH-Arnold M. On October 19, 1998 at New York Hospital of leukemia. He is survived by his wife Justine, daughter Nina, and son Andrew. He was a prolific satirist, wrote for Broadway theater, several novels, many satiric articles for newspapers, including The New York Times, magazines and radio shows including Fred Allen's. Funeral service on Friday at 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Friends may visit the residence from 1:30 on.

title: Anne Klein Put on Block
description: Anne Klein & Company, the struggling fashion house, is up for sale. Those approached include Arthur Levine, the owner of Kasper ASL Ltd., and Eli Tahari, head of Tahari Ltd. Anne Klein is owned by Tomio Taki and Frank Mori, who also are co-owners of Donna Karan. Mr. Tahari said he was offered an outright purchase with other investors or the possibility of a licensing deal. He said he was told Anne Klein's licensing income is about $12 million a year and losses are currently running at $20 million a year.

title: Giants Are on the Run During Their Off Week
description: For many National Football League teams, the bye week in the schedule is often a time for rethinking the basic operating strategy devised back in the halcyon days of summer training camp.

title: Foot in the North, Heart in the South
description: The city began with the river.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEER, FLORENCE FAY
description: BEER-Florence Fay. Beloved wife of Walter, mother of John and David. Memorial service Wednesday, October 28th 12 noon at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets Brooklyn Heights.

title: STRYKER TRIMS PAYMENT FOR PFIZER'S ORTHOPEDIC UNIT
description: The Stryker Corporation said yesterday that it had trimmed its purchase price for Pfizer Inc.'s Howmedica orthopedics business by about $250 million, or 13 percent, to $1.65 billion in cash. Stryker said it reduced the price from the $1.9 billion announced in August because of ''changes in the financial markets.'' It added that all other terms and conditions of the transaction were substantially the same. After the purchase, Stryker will become one of the biggest makers of devices to repair injured joints and bones. The change in the terms of the transaction was announced after the close of trading. Stryker fell 56.25 cents, to $37.5625. Pfizer rose $2.75, to $100.75.

title: Metro Business; New Offer to Big Board
description: New Jersey officials plan to sweeten their offer to the New York Stock Exchange in the hope of persuading it to move across the Hudson River to Jersey City, a state development official said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON FALLS 2.7 PERCENT. Prices slumped after a Government report showed that already-low prices had failed to attract foreign buyers as expected. The December contract fell 1.84 cents, to 67.36 cents a pound.

title: Ormonde de Kay, 74, Writer, Poet, Editor and Translator
description: Ormonde de Kay, a writer, poet and magazine editor, died on Oct. 2 at Beth Israel Hospital. Mr. de Kay, who lived in Manhattan, was 74.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A tale of executives and egos: When does the board decide it's time to tell a chief he must leave?
description: JAN LESCHLY, the chief executive of the London-based SmithKline Beecham, has never been short for words. He's more than willing to tell you about Paxil, his company's popular antidepressant, and how its sales increased 21 percent in the third quarter.

title: Gun Charges and Trouble South of the Border
description: Johnny Manuel sat in the interview room at the Centro de Readaptacion Social Para Adultas, a dusty and sun-bleached prison at the foot of the Sierra de Juarez, telling his story in the bitter monotone of a man who has seen his nightmares grow bones.

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?; Guarding Consumers?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: The Case Against Ken Starr
description: Did Kenneth Starr know that Linda Tripp had tape-recorded her phone conversations with Monica Lewinsky weeks before Jan. 12, the date when he said he first learned of the tapes? If he did, the implications would be significant.

title: Honoring Potter's Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Padres Stand Tall in Defeat, and Not Without Reason
description: It sounds strange to say a team that was just swept out of the World Series did not get embarrassed as well. But even though the San Diego Padres dropped four straight games to the Yankees, they were never made to look foolish.

title: Richard Nesson, 66, Ex-President Of Teaching Hospital in Boston
description: H. Richard Nesson, the former president of Brigham and Women's Hospital, one of the nation's leading teaching hospitals, and a pioneer in hospital management in the new era of health maintenance organizations, died Oct. 18 in Boston. He was 66.

title: BLIND TRUST: A special report.; A Hedge Fund's Stars Didn't Tell, And Savvy Financiers Didn't Ask
description: Sanford I. Weill, the co-chief executive of Citigroup, excels at sizing up risks. He has swallowed up numerous firms, including Salomon Smith Barney, to create the world's largest financial company, winning praise for shrewdly negotiating the financial pitfalls of Wall Street.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SUPERIOR TELECOM TO PURCHASE ESSEX INTERNATIONAL
description: Superior Telecom Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire its rival wire and cable maker Essex International Inc. for $936 million in cash and stock, and assume $419 million of Essex's debt. Superior, based in New York, makes cable and wire for telephone companies, distributors and other users. It had revenue of $159.6 million in the quarter ended July 31. Essex, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., makes electrical wire and cable for residential and commercial use. It had revenue of $369.6 million in its second quarter ended June 30. Superior will make a cash tender offer of $32 a share for up to 81 percent of the 22.56 million Essex shares outstanding. That is a 33.7 percent premium over Essex's Wednesday closing price of $23.18. Shares of Superior fell $3.75, to $42.25, while Essex rose $4.5625, to $27.75.

title: Just Where Did The Girls Go?
description: The young women are still nowhere to be found, but this week the movie is back. Tied up for 15 years by various financial complications, Peter Weir's acclaimed ''Picnic at Hanging Rock'' has returned to video in tape and DVD editions released Tuesday by Home Vision and Criterion.

title: Why Torre? 'He's Perfect for This City'
description: Joe Torre was eating a late dinner with his wife, Ali, on a brisk night in San Diego last Tuesday when a question that he has occasionally pondered sneaked up on him again. Torre spoke the words softly and simply across the table: why me?

title: A Little Town Goes A Little Footloose
description: That poor, tormented Reverend Moore. All that worry for so little reason, all that anguish over something so tame.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AMORY, CLEVELAND
description: AMORY-Cleveland. A memorial service for Cleveland Amory will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 111th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Thursday, November 12 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Fund for Animals.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Yvette Brackman

title: Japanese Mobile-Phone Offering Sets Record
description: The world's largest initial public offering in dollar terms got off to a soaring start today as shares of NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc., Japan's largest mobile telephone company, jumped more than 19 percent in their first day of trading.

title: TV Pact for Ivy
description: Attention college basketball junkies with satellite dishes: your Friday night fix has arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAVNER, VIOLA LEVENSON
description: YAVNER-Viola Levenson. On Wednesday October 21, 1998, of Potomac, MD, formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Louis E. Yavner. Devoted mother of Ruth Himes of Falls Church, VA; Judith Yavner of Arlington, VA and Daniel Yavner and his wife Mary of Minnetonka, MN. Loving sister of Arthur J. Levenson and his wife Marjorie of Bethesda, MD. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held on Friday October 23 at 1pm at Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapels, 1170 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD. Interment will be private. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: McKay's Goal Gives Devils the Edge on Unbeaten Flyers
description: In the moments before the start of the third period, Devils Coach Robbie Ftorek stood alone at the darkened bench. With his team still in the locker room, Ftorek paced back and forth.

title: Lawyer's Fall Rends Immigrants' Lives; Search for Help in Gaining Work Permit Leads to Deportation
description: In the tightly ordered, self-contained world of Li Yu Mei and Wei Liang Li there is little room for chaos.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Tower for Young Professionals on East Side
description: Nearing completion on East 86th Street, the 246-unit Ventura is the newest addition to the Upper East Side streetscape, and the first luxury rental designed to attract young professionals in six years along the 16-block stretch from 80th to 96th Streets.

title: When Walls Talked To You
description: Are you sorry you tossed that Bob Dylan poster? You know, the one with his face in silhouette and his hair a tangle of psychedelic spaghetti; the one that came folded up in the ''Best of'' album, which you tacked to your wall and then threw out after senior year?

title: Proposed Accounting Rule Could Crimp Future Mergers
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board has tentatively decided on new rules that might make companies think twice about future mergers and acquisitions because of their effect on the bottom line.

title: Political Briefing; Citing 'Moral Crisis,' A Call to Oust Clinton
description: Pat Robertson, the television evangelist and chairman of the Christian Coalition, says it is time for President Clinton to resign and for Congress to begin ''repairing America's moral fabric,'' and he is asking ''Christian Americans'' to send money to his politically potent organization to help it get the job done.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 240 N.B.A. Players Balk at Salary Cap
description: Karl Malone made an impassioned plea for unity. Michael Jordan and David Robinson said the greatest obstacle their fellow locked-out players may face was divisiveness.

title: For the Legislature From New York City
description: Many of New York State's legislative districts are so dominated by one party that the real elections occur in the primaries. These are our endorsements for some of the more contested races in New York City.

title: Flawed Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, JOHN W.
description: HERZ-John W. The Strang Cancer Prevention Center notes with profound sorrow the passing of its long time trustee, John W. Herz, Esq. John's wisdom and invaluable counsel have left an enduring mark at Strang. He will be remembered with affection and great respect. Julian H. Robertson, Jr., Chairman Daniel G. Miller, MD Vice Chairman Michael P. Osborne, MD President

title: German Bank Buys A Polish Stake
description: Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank A.G., Germany's second-largest bank, said yesterday that it had bought a 37 percent stake in Poland's third-largest publicly traded bank for around 1 billion marks, or $607 million.

title: Clinton, in Letter, Asks His Church for Forgiveness
description: President Clinton has sent a letter to the members of his home church in Little Rock, Ark., expressing his repentance and asking their forgiveness for his sins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSLOW, ROBERT J.
description: SUSLOW-Robert J. Age 65. On October 18, 1998. His kind heart, generous spirit and intelligent wit will be forever missed by his loving family: Howard, Judy, Ken, Steve, Susan, Brian; and his caring friends and relatives. Contributions may be made in his honor to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNBACH, MILDRED
description: FERNBACH-Mildred, on October 22nd, 1998 of Morris Plains, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Harry, devoted mother of Barry & Hrysso, Robert, Don and Renie, adored grandmother of Heather, Shira, Katie, Sharon and Naomi. Graveside services today 11AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple B'nai Or 60 Overlook Road, Morristown, New Jersey 07960.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Francis Newton Souza

title: Albert Johnson, 73, San Francisco Film Festival Program Director
description: Albert Johnson, a film critic and historian who, as program director of the San Francisco International Film Festival from 1965 to 1972, was celebrated for his pioneering tributes to Hollywood legends, died on Oct. 17 in Chicago. He was 73 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Pumpkins, Pets And a Big Party
description: The Mayor and the police may have done their best to make Central Park a less spooky place, but the Department of Parks and Recreation has other ideas, at least for tomorrow. Beginning at 11 A.M., the park will be seriously haunted, not by muggers and other miscreants, but by ghosts, goblins and monsters.

title: 2 Initiatives In New York Win Awards For Innovation
description: A New York State program that seeks innovative solutions to criminal-justice problems and a Rockland County academy for troubled foster-care children were among 10 initiatives that the Ford Foundation and Harvard University honored yesterday as the most creative and successful Government programs in the country.

title: Sears, Roebuck Earnings Are Down 1%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the largest United States department store retailer, said today that third-quarter profit declined 1 percent as sales of clothing and demand for household services were weaker than expected.

title: Shandwick Acquires Brown Powers
description: Shandwick International in New York, part of the International Public Relations P.L.C. unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired Brown Powers & Associates, a health care public relations agency in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, LEONARD H.
description: BARON-Leonard H. We are going to miss our life long friend. Lots of love and kisses. Norma and Danny Ross.

title: Home Ownership in U.S. Rises to a Record
description: The United States home ownership rate soared to a record of 66.8 percent in the third quarter of this year, driven by a strong economy, Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo said today.

title: Microsoft Disputes Netscape Meeting Account
description: A lawyer for the Microsoft Corporation today portrayed the company's competitor in the Internet software business, the Netscape Communications Corporation, as a willing and eager participant in deal-making that culminated in a June 1995 meeting at which the Government and Netscape now say that Microsoft illegally offered to divide the market.

title: Persevering Woman Helps Free Stranger In '90 Murder Case
description: Do not be deceived by Priscilla Read Chenoweth's sweet manner, the dust on her resume, the spectacles on her nose or her matronly appearance. Do not dismiss this 68-year-old widow as some kind of amateur Angela Lansbury with a law degree.

title: Both Rowland and Kennelly Pressing to Get Out the Vote
description: The two camps in the Connecticut governor's race set out today on very different paths to getting out the vote, with Democrats focusing on their traditional supporters by planning rallies featuring the Rev. Jesse Jackson, while Republicans began broadcasting television advertisements aimed across party lines.

title: Still Among The Young At Heart
description: ALL but lost in the whirl of important issues, like which Senate candidate is proving to be rougher, was a recent report on how Federal agents arrested seven middle-aged New Yorkers on burglary and racketeering charges. It put the lie to the slander that the press never prints good news.

title: City's Haitians Divided on Deporting Man Tied to Murders
description: For nearly four years, many Haitians in New York have been united in their resolve to have the United States extradite Emmanuel Constant, the former leader of a right-wing paramilitary group, so that he can face charges in Haiti that he killed and tortured thousands of people there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASWELL, DORIA A.
description: CASWELL-Doria A., 75 years old. Of West Palm Beach, Florida, died on Monday, October 19, 1998 at a local hospital. She is survived by her loving husband of over 40 years, Walter H. Caswell, Jr. of West Palm Beach, FL; son, George Y. deRandich of West Palm Beach, FL; sister, Odessa Cassuci of Aiken, SC; aunt Juliette Santangelo of Highland Beach, FL & numerous nieces and nephews. A scripture service will be held on Friday evening, October 23, 1998 (tonight) at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, 10580, (914) 967-0129. A Graveside Service will take place Saturday morning, Oct. 24, 1998 at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. Friends may call at the funeral home Friday (tonight) between the hours of 7:00-9:00PM.

title: Waldorf Fires 63 For 3-Shot Lead At Disney World
description: All things considered, it was a pleasant day for Duffy Waldorf. His family enjoyed being at Walt Disney World. And Waldorf had a great time on the golf course.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: John Knight

title: Coker Is a Natural Battler Against the Odds
description: James Coker knows all about beating long odds. It is in his genes. His great-great uncle, John Coker, was one of seven Texans who forced Gen. Santa Anna's Mexican army to surrender at San Jacinto in 1836, a decisive battle that turned the tide in Texas' fight for independence from Mexico 150 years ago.

title: Everglades and Sugar
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * J. Walter Thompson Atlanta, part of WPP Group P.L.C., was awarded duties on two accounts with combined billings estimated at $18 million: Slazenger Golf USA, Greenville, S.C., to handle its national account, which had been handled in-house, and Suburban Lodges of America Inc., Atlanta, to handle media planning and buying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, LEAH
description: EISENBERG-Leah. On October 21, 1998. Beloved wife of Herman. Loving mother of Sheryl. Adoring grandmother of Jody, Elyse and Howard. Graveside service is on Friday, 11 AM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: National News Briefs; Boston Globe Fills Vacant Columnist Jobs
description: The Boston Globe yesterday filled the two metropolitan columnists' jobs left vacant this summer when editors discovered that one columnist, Patricia Smith, had fabricated characters and quotes and that another, Mike Barnicle, had recycled stories he heard from others sometimes publishing them without checking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, LENORE
description: KRAMER-Lenore. With great sadness we mourn the death of our beloved sister-in-law for half a century. Cherished by a loving, accomplished family and many friends, she will be deeply missed as a compassionate, loving human being. Julian and Ruth Kramer

title: A Victim of Planned Obsolescence Fights Back
description: Brawn without brains can't accomplish much beyond wreaking glorious, mindless destruction. That's the message that leaks through ''Soldier,'' a high-testosterone science-fiction fantasy starring Kurt Russell as a professional fighter trained from birth to be nothing other than an efficient killing machine.

title: Direct From Cuba, El Duque's Family
description: It is one thing to be a World Series hero, to be honored with a parade and lauded by millions of strangers. It is another thing altogether to be joined by your mother and your two daughters, whom you have not seen since fleeing your native country 10 months before in a rickety boat, having no idea if you would ever see them again.

title: Leave It to a Stocky Guy to Discover a 'Cure for Gravity'
description: There are two David Dorfmans. One is a choreographer who can lift the spirit with luscious rollicking movement that somehow communicates the great pleasure that might be felt by a dancer who, like Mr. Dorfman, is stockier, older and less well-trained than the norm. The other choreographer seems to hedge his bets with words and cute humor.

title: ECLIPSE SURGICAL PLANNING TO ACQUIRE CARDIOGENESIS
description: Eclipse Surgical Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Cardiogenesis Corporation for about $86.1 million in stock, or $7.03 a share, as the maker of devices for treating heart disease seeks a technological edge in a promising market for laser surgery. Eclipse will exchange 0.8 of a share of common stock for each share of Cardiogenesis, issuing 9.8 million new shares, the equivalent of about half the current shares outstanding. Both companies are based in Sunnyvale, Calif. Shares of Cardiogenesis surged 190 percent, or $4.2188, to close at $6.4375, while Eclipse fell 15.63 cents, to close at $8.6250.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS-Elsa. October 23, 1985. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Nieces, Shirley and Lorraine; Brother, Archibald

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Edward Hopper's ''New York Movie'' '

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Renew Push in New Mexico
description: The Governor's race in New Mexico was a dead heat a month ago -- and it still is. Neither the Republican incumbent, Gov. Gary E. Johnson, nor his Democratic challenger, Martin Chavez, a former Albuquerque mayor, has been able to break clear.

title: Hindu Party in India Retreats on Using Sacred Texts in Schools
description: Religion and politics, a combustible mix here, exploded today in a furor over a proposal to make the study of sacred Hindu texts compulsory for all children in this vast country of many faiths.

title: Giving a Human (and Humorous) Face to Rearing a Boy Under Fascism
description: His look is impish. His limbs are rubber. His hair is vanishing and his face is a caricaturist's dream. So Roberto Benigni gets some of the biggest laughs in his brazen ''Life Is Beautiful'' when, impersonating a school inspector in Fascist Italy, he is asked to hold forth on why Italians are a superior race.

title: World Champs
description: Now that this New York Yankee team has certified its claim to greatness by winning the World Series, and finishing the year with an astounding 125-50 record, the debate has turned to whether this is the best Yankee team of all time or merely the team with the most victories. But for our money, the really interesting thing is that the 1998 Yankees were a team that even Yankee-haters could like.

title: A Warm Pop Delivery With Playful Sensuality
description: When Paula West made her New York cabaret debut at the Algonquin Hotel two years ago, you could sense a keen musical intelligence churning beneath her mischievously sunny exterior. But in bending over backward to be likable, the San Francisco-based singer tended to soft-pedal the juicier elements of her material, and she appeared slightly bland.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'New York Stories'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about New Jersey's plan to acquire more open land at a time when the state's existing parks are in poor repair, misstated the given name of a state assemblyman who wants more money for park maintenance and repair. He is John Wisniewski, not Joseph.

title: From Nasty To Elegant, A Company On Display
description: The San Francisco Ballet displayed the breadth of its repertory and the beauty and power of its dancers on Wednesday night at City Center. There was unfamiliar choreography on view. But the highlights were two well-known, and stylistically contrasting, works.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Peter Boynton

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUSTIG, QUEENIE
