description: LUSTIG-Queenie. October 23, 1973. 25 years. Always remembered-always loved-always in my heart. Lucy D. Lustig-Curtis

title: In Their Own Words
description: DENNIS C. VACCO

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits yesterday about on-line sales of Lincoln artifacts referred incorrectly to a Christie's auction of an 1843 daguerreotype. It did not take place on line.

title: Girls and Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Breaking Ground'

title: Mideast Talks Show Progress on Final Obstacles
description: Critical issues were resolved on Thursday at the Middle East peace talks here, and President Clinton pushed early today to try to close a deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JAMES BIGELOW
description: McINTYRE-James Bigelow. Sons of the Revolution in the state of New York notes with great sadness the death of James B. McIntyre, a life member and past president of this society. Mr. McIntyre served with devotion on our Board of Managers and held many other vital committee positions. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Henry S. Middendorf, Jr., Pres. Laurence S. Simpson, Secretary

title: Glamorous Witches Vs. the Walking Dead
description: Practical Magic

title: A Russian Adds Delicacy To a Machine Technique
description: The buzz in the music world over Arcadi Volodos was evidently audible enough to fill Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. Major management has taken up the young Russian pianist, and film cameras planted in the first tier boxes promised multimedia exposure to come. Mr. Volodos's solo recital program -- often Russian but sometimes with pieces by Schumann and Liszt -- came across as part poetry reading, part circus act. His audience coughed and shuffled during the first phase and yelled adoringly over the second.

title: You Can't Chart the Era Without a Program
description: Much as I enjoy the American theater, it has never occurred to me that the programs we clutch as we settle into our seats could be hung in a place of honor in the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JAMES B.
description: McINTYRE-James B. Age 72, on Oct. 21, 1998. Husband of Juliana S.C.; father of James, and Juliana McIntyre Sowles. Funeral Sunday, October 25 at 1:30 PM at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions to the James B. McIntyre Memorial Fund at Princeton Junior School, P.O. Box 672, Princeton, New Jersey 08524.

title: Study Suggests Monkeys Have Ability to Think
description: Animals do not have language and therefore, savants from Descartes onward have held, cannot think, because words are coin of thought. A strong hint that animals can think, but in ways that do not involve language has emerged from a study of Rosencrantz and MacDuff, two rhesus monkeys whose cognitive skills are being explored at Columbia University.

title: CENTENNIAL HEALTH CARE TO BE ACQUIRED BY WELSH CARSON
description: The Centennial Health Care Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe L.P., for $16 a share, or $190.4 million in stock, plus $100 million in debt, giving it access to the investment company's financial resources during a volatile time in the long-term health care industry. Welsh, Carson said its affiliates owned about 23 percent of the company's outstanding shares. The offer is nearly twice Centennial's closing price of $8.50 on Wednesday. Shares of Centennial, which had $304.3 million in 1997 sales, rose $5.75, to $14.25. Centennial operates 101 nursing homes and provides rehabilitation services and home health care.

title: Getting to First Base Is a Sure Way to Stay in the Yankees' Good Graces
description: Imagine the Yankees without Bernie Williams. No, not if he leaves as a free agent this winter, but if he had not made the team at all.

title: Joseph Howard Stamler, 86, Influential New Jersey Judge
description: Joseph Howard Stamler, a former Newark lawyer whose decisions had a wide impact in the seven years he was a New Jersey Superior Court judge, died on Friday at his home in Stony Creek, Conn. He was 86 and a former resident of Summit, N.J.

title: New Charges Are Sought In Disappearance
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they will ask a grand jury to file new charges against Sante and Kenneth Kimes, the mother-and-son suspects in the disappearance in July of an Upper East Side millionaire, 82-year-old Irene Silverman.

title: Lost in a Labyrinth Of Bristling Barriers: So What If It's Corn?
description: Forget about England and the groomed green hedges that line the maze at Hampton Court Palace, with its quiet bench in the center.

title: Cold War Moose On the Loose
description: The cold war produced plenty of victims, but the ending of the cold war has had its victims, too. The military-industrial complex is a shadow of its former size, the back yard bomb-shelter business has died, and Rocky and Bullwinkle have become forgotten heroes without a Boris Badenov or Natasha Fatale to pursue.

title: 3M Profit Declined 9.2% in Third Quarter
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, better known as 3M, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell by 9.2 percent amid slower economic growth, both in the United States and abroad.

title: Weekly Claims for Jobless Benefits Are Up
description: The number of Americans applying for state unemployment benefits for the first time rose for the third consecutive week, inching up by 2,000 in the latest week, the Government said today.

title: Revisionist McCarthyism
description: Beware the rehabilitation of Joseph McCarthy.

title: Men Charged in Robbery Ruse May Be Linked to Other Crimes
description: Four men who were arrested Wednesday on charges that they had posed as water utility workers to enter and rob two Brooklyn apartments were placed in the first of a long series of lineups yesterday to see if they could be linked to several dozen similar robberies in the borough over the last two months, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGLER, FREDA LEBOWITZ
description: SPIEGLER-Freda Lebowitz. On October 20, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Ellen and Larry Stein, Howard Spiegler and Jayne Cohen. Beloved grandmother of Sandy and Julie Stein, and Robert and Liz Stein and Alexandra Cohen-Spiegler. Dear Aunt and great-aunt. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to Cabrini Hospice or any other charity.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ANDERSEN CONSULTING, New York, named David Cudaback editor in chief of Outlook magazine, the firm's journal. He had been editor of Institutional Investor magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPICEHANDLER, ESTHER
description: SPICEHANDLER - Esther (nee Brafman). On October 22, 1998. She celebrated life by devoting herself to others and performing mitzvot. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral services today, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hudson River Park Wins Council Backing
description: The City Council yesterday unanimously approved changing the zoning along the Hudson River from manufacturing to parkland, opening the way for Hudson River Park, a state-city park that will extend from Battery Park City to 59th Street.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Tragedies Entwined, the Literary and the Literal
description: The French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj set his 1990 ''Romeo and Juliet'' in a police state. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where this highly theatrical and updated version of a well-known tale is retold with alternating grimness and luminous beauty, the Berlin wall still stands.

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?; Question for Court
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. Intelligence Chief Steps Up to the Plate
description: A Director of Central Intelligence, says George J. Tenet, the man who holds the job, ''should be seen and not heard -- and preferably not seen.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHRISTIAN, CLAIRE
description: CHRISTIAN-Claire. 10/23/88 We miss you. Never doubt our love. Judith, Themi and Torey

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Moynihan Backs Democratic Challenger
description: Asserting that the prestige of the state attorney general's office has declined under Dennis C. Vacco, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday endorsed the Democratic challenger, Eliot Spitzer, saying he would bring energy and high legal standards to the job.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Maxim magazine misidentified the parent company of an advertiser, Saturn autos. It is the General Motors Corporation; Mercury is a brand of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Fisher-Price Recalls Up to 10 Million Battery-Driven Vehicles
description: In one of the largest recalls in the toy industry, Fisher-Price is pulling up to 10 million battery-driven Power Wheels cars and trucks off the market for repairs because they can catch fire or fail to stop while children are riding them.

title: Lucent Profit Rises as Sales Surge Abroad
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the nation's largest maker of telephone equipment, said today that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit before charges rose a better-than-expected 48.5 percent on a strong increase in sales, particularly overseas.

title: Murder Trial Examines Drug Use By Teacher
description: Defense lawyers and prosecutors jousted for the first time yesterday over the defense's charges of drug use by Jonathan M. Levin, the popular Bronx high school teacher who prosecutors say was killed by a former student.

title: New York Moves to Challenge Diesel Settlement
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York took preliminary steps today to challenge a huge national settlement between Federal authorities and diesel truck engine manufacturers, saying it would do too little to prevent smog and acid rain in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CHARLOTTE DOROTHY
description: COHEN-Charlotte Dorothy. Devoted wife of the late Mortimer. Beloved mother of Myra, Jeffrey and Sharon. Dear sister of Claire. Cherished grandmother of Robin, Eric, Brandon and Raggi. Services today 1:30PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

title: City Council Backs Changes To Campaign Finance Rules
description: Overriding Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's veto by a 44-to-4 vote, the City Council revamped the city's campaign finance system yesterday to discourage candidates from accepting donations from corporations.

title: EATING OUT
description: Vietnamese

title: A Ray Gun That Makes Cupid Quiver
description: ''Batman'' meets ''Boogie Nights'' via Hong Kong-style kung fu in ''Orgazmo,'' Trey Parker's flat-as-a-pancake spoof of superheroes, the pornography industry and religious conservatives. In writing and directing ''Orgazmo,'' Mr. Parker, a creator of ''South Park,'' faced an insoluble problem: how do you make a boundary-shattering gross-out farce about the porn business that isn't itself pornographic? Having the actors wear silly costumes embellished with sex toys just won't do the trick.

title: National News Briefs; Suit Filed to Block Internet Smut Measure
description: Attacking an hours-old Federal statute intended to restrict children's access to pornography on the Internet, a coalition of 17 organizations filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Philadelphia to block the measure, which they say violates the free speech provisions of the First Amendment.

title: Hedge Fund Firm Denies Being in Trouble
description: Paloma Partners Management, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that runs hedge funds, acknowledged yesterday that it had been battered by the recent turmoil in the bond markets but insisted that it was still in sound financial health. The firm, which operates more than 10 funds and is said to have at least $1 billion under management, issued a statement in response to increasing speculation about its well-being.

title: Sports of The Times; These Yanks Dominated Their Time
description: THEY won the World Series with their fifth-string left fielder, for goodness' sake. They won two huge games with a pitcher who had emerged from the roiling seas. Their World Series hero was underestimated by everybody, at the beginning.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I won't say anything about us being the greatest. But there hasn't been anybody better.''

title: For This Clown Prince, Art Here, Art There, Art Everywhere
description: Sometimes, these days, it can be awfully hard to distinguish a work of art from the objects that stray into the rest of life. Artists like it that way. They have been trying to widen the boundaries of art land since the second decade of this century and began really strenuously hacking at the borders in the 1960's. The ultimate grand, inclusive, generous gesture made by the French artist Ben Vautier was the declaration that ''Everything is art,'' which rather mitigated the importance of distinctions. (On the other hand, maybe this was the ultimate cop-out.)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Einstein and the Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Why Was George Blubbering on TV?
description: WHO was that silver-haired man in the white turtleneck and blue blazer blubbering over the World Series trophy on television Wednesday night?

title: Neat Trick For Humor
description: In the Cannes prize winner ''Life Is Beautiful,'' one of Italy's biggest comic stars dares to laugh in the face of the unthinkable.

title: NAIROBI EMBASSY RECEIVED WARNING OF COMING ATTACK
description: Nine months before the attack on the American Embassy here, United States intelligence officials received a detailed warning that Islamic radicals were plotting to blow up the building, according to Kenyan and American officials.

title: Political Briefing; Illinois Race Takes Turn for the Democrat
description: Though he has been trailing in the polls for weeks, Representative Glenn Poshard has always said he would make a real contest of this year's governor's race in Illinois. And if a new poll by the Chicago Sun-Times has it right, he is as good as his word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, DOUGLAS A.
description: SMITH-Douglas A. Former Vice President of General Foods. Died on October 21, 1998. Of Waccabuc, NY. Husband of Nevann. Father of Susan W. Donaghy, Geoffrey W. and Ronald S. Smith. Grandfather of Ryan, Sean & Lauren Donaghy. Brother of Margaret Hunn and Phyllis Germinder. Reposing at Clark Assoc. Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y. Friday from 5-8 P.M. Funeral service at South Salem Presbyterian Church, Saturday, at 1 P.M. Interment private.

title: Yankees' Sweep Puts Mayor in Benevolent Mood Toward His Rivals
description: In his exuberance over the remarkable New York Yankees season that ended with a World Series championship on Wednesday night, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has momentarily set aside his many differences with various politicians -- and there are many -- to invite them all to today's Yankees parade that begins at Battery Park and ends with a reception in front of City Hall.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When bricks started falling from a building at 54th Street and Madison Avenue last year, it brought life to a halt for everyone nearby. But few had a harder time than Caviar Russe, the elegant new restaurant that was just starting to build a reputation as a luxurious place to stop for a treat.

title: 2 Arrested in Killing Of Trucker at School
description: A man whose body was found Tuesday on the grounds of a Mount Holly elementary school was killed when his effort to buy drugs went awry, the authorities said yesterday, announcing the arrests of two Pemberton men in the slaying.

title: Whitman Says She Will End Car Pool Lanes
description: Bowing to pressure from angry drivers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would end the state's experiment with car pool lanes on two heavily traveled highways in northwestern New Jersey, and that the state would not repay the millions of dollars in Federal funds used to build them.

title: Italy's Political Experiment
description: Massimo D'Alema, who heads Italy's former Communist Party, seems likely to win parliamentary confirmation as prime minister, making him the first ex-Communist to lead a major West European country. But Washington, which worked hard during the cold war to exclude Italian Communists from government, has little to worry about. Mr. D'Alema would lead a coalition that ranges further right than the last Italian Government. He is likely to continue the conservative fiscal policies that have sharply reduced Italy's budget deficits and qualified it to join Europe's new single currency.

title: Vail Fires Were Probably Arson, U.S. Agents Say
description: Federal agents in Colorado have concluded that the fires atop Vail Mountain were almost certainly arson, law-enforcement officials said today, a finding that means the case will be investigated as an act of environmental terrorism.

title: Metro Business; Sotheby's Expands In Wine Auctions
description: In a move that is likely to increase its competitiveness in the expanding wine-auction market in the United States, Sotheby's has acquired Davis & Company, a five-year-old wine-auction house based in Chicago. Sotheby's declined to give the price of the purchase, which was announced this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODEK, HENRY
description: BODEK - Henry. Emunah of America mourns the loss of Henry Bodek, beloved life-long friend and supporter of our organization in the United States and Israel. Condolences to his sisters Esther Flashberg and Peggy Kaufman and the entire family who adored ''Uncle Henry.'' May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld, National President Shirley Singer, Exec. Vice President Melanie Oelbaum, Honorary National President

title: Mistrial for a Defendant In Officer's Murder
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday for one of three defendants in the 1996 robbery and murder of a Teaneck police officer moonlighting as a Sears security guard. The jury reached an impasse after deliberating for 10 days, lawyers said.

title: To Fend Off Cabin Fever, Long Walks (at the Mall)
description: ''Welcome to Day 8 here at the Wye River Middle East Peace Conference,'' intoned James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, with just a hint of the cabin fever that everyone was beginning to suffer.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Arab militants and their links to Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the indictment of Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, who has been charged in the bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Prosecutors have not accused him of driving the truck that carried the bomb to the embassy in Kenya.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Opposite of Sex

title: Moscow Memo; Primakov's Silence Raises Worries, and the Ruble
description: Now that Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov has spent six weeks leading one of the biggest nations in the world through its worst fiscal crisis, one thing is becoming increasingly clear: nobody outside the Kremlin knows what the Prime Minister is doing.

title: Recipe: First, Take a Dinosaur Egg . . .
description: Passions for the prehistoric that remain unsated after the two ''Jurassic Park'' films are likely to be requited by the latest IMAX 3-D film, ''T-Rex: Back to the Cretaceous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROB, ELIZABETH
description: GROB-Elizabeth, on October 22, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. David. Loving mother of Charles and Anne, Susan and Lou, Emily and Mark, and Philip. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Jana, Alexandra and Brett. Loving sister of Judy. She was loving and compassionate to family and friends. Funeral services Friday, 1:30 PM, at Riverside Nassau North, Great Neck, New York.

title: DELUXE TO SELL TWO PRINTING UNITS AND CUT 3,900 JOBS
description: The Deluxe Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Social Expressions greeting card business and Paper Direct specialty printing unit to the closely held Taylor Corporation for cash. It also said it planned to cut 3,900 jobs to reduce costs. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Deluxe also said third-quarter profit rose to 58 cents a share from 55 cents a year earlier. The company said its cost-cutting plan would increase fourth-quarter profit 5 cents a share, to 65 to 71 cents. Deluxe expects earnings in 1999 and 2000 to rise 11 percent to 15 percent each year, up from previous forecasts of 5 percent to 9 percent. The moves are expected to cut $100 million from selling, general and administrative expenses by the end of 2000.

title: Strong Opinions of a Dizzy Tour Guide
description: Timothy (Speed) Levitch, the loquacious New York City tour-bus guide, sidewalk philosopher and one-man almanac of urban lore profiled in Bennett Miller's compelling documentary film ''The Cruise,'' is a man who enjoys making himself dizzy. One of his favorite activities, he confides, is to spin around under the twin towers of the World Trade Center and, when thoroughly disoriented, to look up and reel under the illusion that the buildings are toppling down on him.

title: This Mother Hubbard Is a Militant Feminist
description: The Nuyorican Poets Cafe does the best favor it possibly could to Ishmael Reed in its production of his ''Mother Hubbard.'' At the invitation of Miguel Algarin, the executive producer at the theater, Ronald L. McIntyre has written a score, and a few songs for which Mr. Reed supplied lyrics. The director, Rome Neal, and a cast so exuberant it sometimes seems downright unruly play down the convoluted plot and treat the text as 10 discrete scenes of comic cavorting. It is only on reflection afterward that you fully realize what an emotional and intellectual muddle the play is. But after you've been laughing for a good part of two hours, the reflection doesn't much matter.

title: Richter Frustrates Isles With Penalty-Shot Save
description: The game had five goals, all of them important, most of them with style. But it was the one important shot that did not cross the line that provided the best moment of a match that ended in a 3-2 Rangers victory over the Islanders last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt

title: Late Comeback Gives Dow 13.91-Point Gain for Day
description: Blue-chip stocks staged a late comeback yesterday and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to a seventh straight gain while the Nasdaq market continued a two-week advance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELAHI, CYRUS
description: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

title: A Fascination With Fairies
description: ''Victorian Fairy Painting'' at the Frick Collection evokes a world of sprites and eros, like that in Edward Robert Hughes's ''Midsummer Eve,'' above.

title: Miami Journal; Hints of Love Triangle Put New Twist on a Case
description: When City Commissioner Humberto Hernandez Jr. was convicted in state court of helping to cover up voter fraud in last November's election, many in this city saw the case as part of Miami's healing from a period of widespread corruption in local politics. Mr. Hernandez pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit bank fraud in an unrelated Federal case, insuring that he would face at least five years in prison.

title: D'Amato Says He's Sorry, but Not to Schumer
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato apologized yesterday for making a disparaging remark about Representative Jerrold L. Nadler's physical appearance, but refused to back away from his use of a Yiddish vulgarism to describe his opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: The Biggest Mercedes Shapes Up
description: THE next S-Class, the luxury flagship of Mercedes-Benz, will be 500 pounds lighter and loaded with high technology. The imposing slab-sided styling of the current car will give way to a striking, smoother design that Mercedes says will be the most aerodynamic car on the market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rally in Blue-Chip Stocks Extends to Seventh Day

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZ, ROSE
description: SELTZ-Rose. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Rose Seltz, and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Martin Kay, President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLTEL CORP., Little Rock, Ark., a telecommunications company, said it would increase its dividend by 5.2 percent, to 30.5 cents, up from 29 cents, payable Jan. 4 to shareholders of record on Dec. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPHATTER, GORE, LENA
description: McPHATTER-GORE-Lena. On October 18, 1998. Her charming, wonderful spirit will be forever missed by her loving family, friends and relatives. Memorial service November 14 at 3PM, Rutger's Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to the Lena McPhatterGore Fund established at Rutger's Presbyterian Church would be greatly appreciated.

title: Was Microsoft Bundling, or Was It Bullying?; A Gainer, Not a Loser
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Series Fallout

title: In Race for Governor, Democrat Is in Trouble
description: In the race for Florida governor, Kenneth H. MacKay is the candidate with the record as state legislator, Congressman and, most recently, Lieutenant Governor in an administration presiding over good times. He is the Democrat in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans. He is the native Floridian, and the one invariably described as nice.

title: SPARE TIMES -- FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Man in the News: David Michael Walker; A C.P.A. at Center Stage
description: Just before adjourning this week, the Senate approved a 47-year-old accountant for one of the Government's most powerful and important positions: Comptroller General of the United States, the chief auditor of all Federal programs, contracts and operations.

title: Man Charged in Attack At the Fashion Institute
description: A 31-year-old man has been charged with trying to sodomize a female student at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Chelsea on Wednesday afternoon, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Serb Dissidents Need U.S. Help; Postwar Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Sierra Club Case Study On Political Advertising

title: Op-Art; Better Than Cold Fusion
description: First we had broccoflower, a cross between broccoli and cauliflower. Now another fusion vegetable called broccolini -- broccoli crossed with Chinese kale -- has been introduced. The fusion phenomenon can be seen elsewhere, of course -- folk-rock, country-western, donkey basketball, conservative Democrats. Indeed, perhaps something primal in human nature causes us to continually try to merge things that may or may not belong together:

title: As Deal Came Together, a Snag Over Release of an American Spy
description: At 7 A.M., after a long night of bargaining ended with handshakes and, it seemed, a peace agreement, the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, met alone with President Clinton and made one last demand: As part of the deal, the United States had to free Jonathan J. Pollard, the American serving life in prison for spying for Israel in the 1980's.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Hiccups On the Horizon?; Sparkling Wine Makers Look Beyond the Year 2000
description: Champagne is to New Year's as cotton candy is to carnivals. So, with the millennium approaching, and with it the biggest New Year's Eve party in a while, makers of sparkling wine throughout Europe are happy to talk about how well they are doing these days.

title: Belgium's Biggest Utility In South Korea Accord
description: Tractebel S.A., the largest utility in Belgium, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy 75 percent of the gas distribution business of the Hanjin Engineering and Construction Company of South Korea, as part of its expansion in developing countries. Yves Crits, a Tractebel executive, would not confirm the 160 billion won ($120 million) price announced by Hanjin Group, saying the amount was still being discussed.

title: Rangers' Knuble Is Quick to Contribute
description: Mike Knuble describes himself as a late bloomer. He played high school hockey in Grand Rapids, Mich., and for Red Berenson at the University of Michigan.

title: Think Tank; No Est Known Lingua Aber Du Understande, Eh?
description: ''Que would happen if, wenn Du open your computerzo finde eine message in esta lingua? No es Englando, no est Germano, no este Espana, no est keine known lingua aber Du Understande!''

title: A Reminder
description: Standard time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set back one hour.

title: DREYER'S TO CUT JOBS AND SELL SOME OPERATIONS
description: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. said yesterday that it would cut jobs and sell some operations, taking pretax charges of $60 million and $65 million, to cut costs and return to profitability. The largest United States ice cream company, which makes Dreyer's, Edy's and Starbucks brands, also reported a third-quarter loss, its fifth in eight quarters. Dreyer's is trying to regroup from a too-ambitious expansion in Texas, as it faces the loss of an exclusive distribution agreement with Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. Dreyer's, based in Oakland, Calif., lost $5.98 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, in contrast to net income of $4.97 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier. The loss included a portion of the revamping charges.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Decline Slightly After Advancing for 7 Days

title: NEC's Elder Statesman Resigns in Scandal
description: A military-procurement scandal ended the career today of one of Japan's eminent executives, Tadahiro Sekimoto, chairman of the NEC Corporation, the world's second-largest maker of computer chips.

title: ARAFAT AND NETANYAHU IN PACT ON NEXT STEPS TOWARD PEACE; MODEST DEAL TO 'REBUILD TRUST'
description: After nine days and nights of tortuous negotiations, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel today signed a modest agreement that restores life to the Middle East peace effort and opens the way for talks on a final resolution of the 50-year-old fight over whether the Palestinians will have a state.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Habitats / York Avenue; At $566, the Rent Is Small, But the Problems Are Big
description: WHEN Phillip Lee complains to friends that his shower leaked or that his stove refused to light, he doesn't get much sympathy. Not in New York. Not when you have managed to rent a cheap apartment. Envy, yes. Sympathy, no.

title: McCarthy's Tactics In Light of Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICULAR, ARTHUR
description: SICULAR-Arthur. We mourn the great loss of our dear friend and Doctor who was always in Mel's corner, and always in our hearts. Deepest sympathy to Lilian, David, Eve, Michael, and Steven. The Sokolow Family

title: U.N. Report Faults Big Accountants in Asia Crisis
description: After putting their stamp of approval on the financial statements of Asian financial institutions that then collapsed, the world's five largest accounting firms are coming under increasing pressure to strengthen their auditing procedures in Asian and other emerging markets.

title: VW Plans Investment In Rolls and Bentley
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's biggest auto maker, said yesterday that it would invest $:500 million ($845 million) to develop and increase production of Rolls-Royce and Bentley luxury cars in the next five years.

title: New York-Bred Horses To Be in the Spotlight
description: It may not rank with historic breeding centers such as Kentucky or Florida, but New York State will produce about 1,200 thoroughbreds from its 400 horse farms this year and will offer purses of $25 million in 1,000 races next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, JOHN F., M.D.
description: DALY-John F., M.D. The faculty & staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. John F. Daly. A native of New Jersey, Dr. Daly received his A.B. Degree from Fordham University in 1932 and his M.D. Degree in 1937 from Long Island College of Medicine. He served his internship at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, NJ. From 1942 to 1946 he served in the U.S. Army Air Force where he attained the rank of Major. Dr. Daly came to NYU School of Medicine in 1946, and had a long and distinguished career as Professor and Chairman of the Department of Otolaryngology from 1949-1980. He was also Director of Otolaryngology at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was one of the founders of the field of modern Head and Neck Surgery and an outstanding physician-educator who was devoted to his patients and students. An active member of many professional societies, he served as President of the American Society for Head and Neck Surgery, The American Academy of Ophthalmology, and Otolaryngology and was Chairman of the American Medical Association's Section Council on Otolaryngology. Dr. Daly was the recipient of numerous honors and awards. In addition, he was consultant to many hospitals in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan area. To his long-time wife, Annette O'Mealia Daly and daughter, Sharon Ann Butler, and grandchildren, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Noel L. Cohen, M.D., Chairman Dept of Otolaryngology Vice Dean for Clinical Affairs Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine

title: When Verbal Resists Visual: Freud's Defense Against Art
description: At the end of the exhibition ''Sigmund Freud: Conflict and Culture'' at the Library of Congress, a slow, weak, singsongy voice can be heard: ''I started my professional activity as a neurologist . . . I discovered some new and important facts of the unconscious in psychic life . . . I had to pay heavily for this bit of good luck. . . . Resistance was strong and unrelenting . . . the struggle is not yet over.''

title: Debate Takes Harsh Turn Over Ethics
description: The first debate in the campaign for New York State Attorney General quickly turned nasty yesterday as the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, repeatedly called his Democratic challenger, Eliot L. Spitzer, a liar and a lawbreaker, while Mr. Spitzer swung back by raising questions about Mr. Vacco's ethics.

title: New Role As Umpire May Bring More Risk
description: The Middle East peace agreement gives the Central Intelligence Agency a new and potentially risky role in safeguarding security for Israel and the Palestinian Authority.

title: SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo?
description: IT took David C. Walentas 17 years to win permission from New York City to begin the residential conversion of a muscular old industrial complex on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, SCHAINMAN, PEARL C.
description: GORDON-SCHAINMAN-Pearl C. Beloved wife of Leonard Gordon and the late Mory Schainman. Loving mother of Lynn Russell. Dear sister of Martin Sandberg and his wife, Grace, and the late Norma Schnitzer. Services Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: In Debate, Dodd's Rival Says Senator Does Little for State
description: Gary A. Franks, the Republican seeking to unseat Senator Christopher J. Dodd, used their opening debate tonight to scold Connecticut's senior Senator repeatedly, accusing him of missing crucial votes and paying more attention to Hollywood than to the home crowd.

title: After All the Talk, a Hesitant Peace
description: Even in the self-congratulatory sparkle of the East Room of the White House, the words of caution rang loud and clear. If it took 19 months of blood and insult, and 9 days of extraordinary round-the-clock wrangling, just to do things that were supposed to have been done ages ago, what superhuman intervention would be required to surmount the truly formidable issues of refugees, Jerusalem, water?

title: A Philharmonic Rampant Welcomes 2 New Women
description: The New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday evening was like a restart to the season. No one would call the complete run of the Beethoven symphonies that opened matters a few weeks ago a false start, certainly, but it didn't really get the brass and percussion sections into the swing of things. Even the orchestra's recent two-week residency in Cologne, Germany, added only Tchaikovsky to the mix.

title: Florida Company Is Accused of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a Florida company of using fraudulent advertising and high-pressure tactics to sell about $6.6 million worth of unregistered securities.

title: In His Latest Ad, Schumer Uses D'Amato's Own Words Against Him
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer released a new television advertisement last night that seeks to use Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's own words against him: a 19-second clip of unedited news footage in which he repeatedly denies that he ever insulted Mr. Schumer with a Yiddish vulgarism.

title: Etcheverry Named The Top Player
description: Marco Etcheverry, the Bolivian midfielder for D.C. United who has led his team to the championship game of Major League Soccer every season in the league's three years of existence, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday in Los Angeles. Etcheverry was voted the award even though he finished eighth in the league in scoring with 39 points from 10 goals and 19 assists.

title: Off Parade Floats, the Players Themselves Become the Fans
description: Against the backdrop of a joyous victory parade, and with thousands of fans fervently screaming his name, David Wells did his best yesterday to uphold the wild-and-crazy reputation that has become his.

title: Weekend Talks Seen As Season Is Imperiled
description: Amid growing concern that the season will be in jeopardy if the labor dispute runs into December, the chief negotiators for the National Basketball Association owners and the players have tentatively set meetings for this weekend in Manhattan.

title: About New York; Giuliani Loves A Parade, If It's His Kind
description: THE gridlock reports on the car radio sounded dire yesterday morning as the city prepared to heap praise and confetti on the Yankees. The Brooklyn Bridge was closed down for a while; the Manhattan Bridge was clogged, and traffic was backed up. Forget about the sidewalks along the Canyon of Heroes where fans were packed in, including children whose hooky party was winked at by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani when he said he learned as much playing baseball as he did in school.

title: An Adoring City Turns Out To Honor Its Yankee Victors
description: In what is becoming an autumn habit, New Yorkers turned out yesterday at their rapturous loudest and paid obeisance to the conquering Yankees in a rollicking ticker-tape parade up the Canyon of Heroes along lower Broadway.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Mattel toy company's recall of Fisher-Price's Power Wheels cars and trucks misstated the resulting charge being taken against third-quarter earnings. It is $27 million, not $270 million.

title: Years of American Secrecy Has Kept a Chasm Wide
description: For 13 years, the case against the convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard has symbolized darker aspects of the normally warm relationship between the United States and Israel while also exposing fissures long dividing American and Israeli Jews.

title: 'On the Hudson's West Bank'
description: To the Editor:

description: DIBBLE-Peter Davis, 71 years, of Manhattan, died on October 8 after a long illness. He was an Editor and Writer for Women's Wear Daily for over 30 years. Although, he leaves no immediate family, he is deeply mourned by his extended family of friends. A memorial service will be held on November 21, 1998 at 11am at Grace Church, 820 Broadway, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his memory to Bread & Roses, 50 Water St, Norwalk, CT 06854.

title: Orange County Is Set Back In Efforts to Recover Losses
description: A Federal judge has dealt a serious blow to Orange County's chances of recovering further damages from Wall Street securities firms in connection with the county's 1994 bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMERFORD, MAIRE K.
description: COMERFORD-Maire K., age 53. Former Director of Nursing, New York Eye Infirmary, on October 21, 1998 of cancer. Beloved sister of Thomas, sister-in-law of Kathleen; aunt and godmother of Dr. Kathleen Comerford, aunt of Dr. Elizabeth C. Melia, grandaunt of Emily Melia; cousin of Dr. Patricia Mitchell, John Dooley, Barbara Hawkins, Jeff and Ted Comerford and Terry Oneto. The family wishes to thank the following friends for their loyalty and devotion: Lydia Rivera, Carol Cordes, Dr. Joseph Walsh, Don Lundquist and Denise Pankey. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. Remembrances may be made to St. Rose's Hospice in New York City.

title: 2 NATO Generals to Warn Milosevic of Air Raids
description: NATO ambassadors in Brussels today ordered the alliance's two top generals to Belgrade on Saturday to warn President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia again that he would face air strikes unless he ordered troops and special police units to withdraw from Kosovo Province or return to barracks by Tuesday.

title: Deal Balances Concessions For Israelis and Palestinians
description: Under the peace agreement signed today, Israel would withdraw from more territory on the West Bank and the Palestinian Authority would accept a stronger plan for preventing terrorist attacks against Israel. Here are the key gains for Israel:

title: Wrestling Insults Fuel Free Speech Case
description: Probably, very few Federal judges telephone professional wrestling lines for updates on the likes of Rowdy Roddy and Macho Man.

title: Troubled Bank Is Nationalized By Japanese
description: In the first nationalization of a Japanese bank since World War II, the Government decided today to take over the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of the nation's biggest financial institutions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Oct. 13 about placebos referred incompletely to a study on arthroscopic knee surgery. It was a pilot study, carried out on 10 patients, and results are therefore preliminary. A larger study of 180 patients is under way, with results expected in two years.

description: SALOSHIN-Edith, October 25, 1997. Dearly Beloved-remembered, never forgotten. With aching heart, Fred, Clifford, Ull

title: New, and Unknown, Voters Hold Key to a Race for Senate
description: From the observation deck of the Stratosphere Tower, 1,149 feet above the glitzy casinos on the Strip, dozens of green fingers can be seen on the outskirts of town, sticking out into the brown desert valley.

title: Grand Jury Refuses To Indict Accused Man
description: A Somerset County grand jury refused on Thursday to indict an 84-year-old Hillsborough man who a teen-age girl said had kidnapped and sexually assaulted her at gunpoint last July, the man's lawyer said. The man has been free on $50,000 bail.

description: LYONS GRAND PRIX

title: Davis Love Surges Into Tie For Lead
description: Most golfers would envy the year that Davis Love 3d has enjoyed.

title: ENDOREX IN JOINT DELIVERY VENTURE WITH ELAN
description: The Endorex Corporation established a joint venture with the Elan Corporation yesterday for the research, development and commercialization of products using Elan's Medipad delivery systems for two drugs in undisclosed fields. Endorex said the two drug delivery companies had contributed a total of $10.5 million in capital to the venture, which is initially owned 80.1 percent by Endorex and 19.9 percent by Elan. Additionally, Elan has bought Endorex preferred stock for $8.4 million, which is exchangeable for stock in the joint venture or convertible into Endorex common stock at a premium to market. Endorex said Elan had granted an exclusive worldwide license to the venture for the Medipad system for use in the delivery of specific drugs.

title: Eric Ambler, Thriller Writer Who Elevated the Genre to Literature, Is Dead at 89
description: Eric Ambler, whose name is synonymous with novels of suspense, action, adventure and intrigue in foreign lands and whose books became models for generations of other writers, died on Thursday at his home in London. He was 89.

title: For a While, The People Of the City Are United
description: Everybody knows those timeworn cliches about baseball as the quintessential American sport, the game that brings out the innocent kid in hardened urban gladiators, the field of dreams where differences of class and origin and fortune can be erased with the satisfying crack of bat meeting ball.

title: The Stadium's Grass Is Greener on the Radio
description: For baseball fans, the relationship with their home-team radio broadcasters is more than just a summer fling. You get to know them as you would neighbors or relatives, for all their charms and foibles. Baseball announcers shout at you while riding with you in the car. They laugh with you at the picnic table or at the beach. And they whisper to you from the pillow in the late innings of West Coast games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALMUD, RENEE, 70
description: TALMUD-Renee, 70, of complications following heart surgery. Loving wife of Allen. Beloved mother of Howard, Laura and John. Adored grandmother of Andrew, Holly and David. Services 10:30 AM, Sunday, Oct. 25, 1998, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Kidney Foundation.

title: Packed Subways and Trains
description: For the riders and managers of New York City's public transportation systems, it was a day of predictable, almost ritualistic crowding, delays and stress. But for many, apparently, it was a price worth paying for a ticker tape parade.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS. Prices weakened on expectations that warm, dry weather this weekend in the Midwest will lead to a bumper crop and ample supply. The December contract fell 2.5 cents, to $2.1875 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, MIMI
description: CANTOR-Mimi. We miss you very much and love you. As always, Eddie, Barry, Adam and Mary Ann

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPKIN, NATHANIEL
description: LAPKIN-Nathaniel. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai-NYU Medical Center and Health System deeply mourn the passing of Nathaniel Lapkin, a generous long-time supporter and Sponsor of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, as well as a benefactor of The Mount Sinai Hospital for many years. Mr. Lapkin supported a broad range of research, educational and clinical activities, as well as assistance for indigent patients. He will be remembered most fondly, with gratitude for his far reaching philanthropy. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife, Frances; his son, Mitchell, to his grandchildren and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: ISSUE ADVERTISEMENTS -- MAKING OF AN ISSUE (A special report.); Sierra Club Ads in Political Races Offer a Case Study of 'Issue Advocacy'
description: Last spring and summer, officials at the Sierra Club gathered for a series of confidential meetings to plot how to make the environment an issue in elections around the country. But their deliberations often had little to do with things like polluted streams or global warming. Instead, they focused on political tactics: which candidates to help and which to punish.

title: Anne Klein Said to Be for Sale, With Its Name as Biggest Draw
description: The women's sportswear maker Anne Klein & Company is up for sale, and despite the fact that the company has been losing money for several years, its lucrative product licenses and well-known brand name would make it an attractive acquisition, fashion industry analysts and executives said yesterday.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: IN SEARCH OF A CHILD
description: Adoptions have shed a cloak of secrecy, reaching a new level of openness where children are no longer kept in the dark about their origin. But the changes do not stop there: a market system has developed to bring families and children together, adoptions freely cross racial boundaries, and many adoptive and biological parents are keeping the lines of communication open.

title: Courting the Elderly Voter
description: This is a new 30-second commercial against Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, that the New York Republican Committee began running this week.

title: Editorial Observer; Mayor Giuliani Dances With New Hampshire
description: Amid the gentle smiles and the strong colors of autumn, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seemed an odd addition this week to the scenic state of New Hampshire. Trying out a new audience for his old Marlon Brando imitation and his bragging stats on New York City, The Mayor Who Tamed the Capital of the World suddenly landed in civility central, a quilted haven where people tend to raise their voices only at football games. So why was he in New Hampshire, site of the first Presidential primary, generating a New York buzz amid the soft cries of birds going south for the winter?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's time that together we occupy a place beyond ourselves, our peoples, that is worthy of them under the sun, the descendants of the children of A Abraham -- Palestinians and Israelis coming together.''

title: Tennessee Senator's Killing and Opponent's Arrest Upend Small Town
description: In rural, rugged middle Tennessee, the race for one State Senate seat has been altered by a single bullet, and the surviving candidate in District 15 will watch the outcome from behind a jail door.

title: Sports of The Times; The Business Of Baseball Never Ends
description: AFTER a morning and afternoon filled with speeches and platitudes for one of the great teams of all time, yesterday's Yankee celebration at City Hall began to wind down. Finally, the announcement came that Tony Bennett, the great singer who had performed ''America the Beautiful,'' would come back and sing a duet with Max Von Essen, who had sung the national anthem. I knew that wasn't going to happen; I'd spoken with Bennett shortly after he sang, and he was hurrying off to another engagement.

title: Chairman Resigns At Telecom Italia
description: The chairman of Telecom Italia S.p.A., Gian Mario Rossignolo, resigned yesterday, a company official said. His 10-month tenure was marred by a series of managerial gaffes. The company confirmed the resignation and said its board had named Berardino Libonati as chairman. Shares of Telecom Italia surged on the news, rising 793 lire, to 12,271 ($7.52).

title: UConn Yearns to Make Playoffs
description: Coach Skip Holtz has guided the Connecticut Huskies to a 29-21 record in five years, but they have yet to make the Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Quest for Presidential Primary Clout May Hinge on Passage of Obscure Ballot Measure
description: Less than a month ago, Gov. Pete Wilson let loose national political lightning by signing a bill moving California's Presidential primary to the front of the pack in 2000, on March 7, just after New Hampshire and Iowa. But unless voters here pass an obscure ballot measure next month, the new primary may be virtually meaningless.

description: THE DOLLAR RISES. The dollar rose against the yen after the Japanese Government took over Long-Term Credit Bank, one of the nation's biggest financial institutions. The dollar rose to 117.95 yen from 117.87 on Thursday.

description: Sometime soon the Jets are going to have to beat a nondivision opponent to keep alive their playoff dreams.

title: Mets Closing In on Deals With Piazza and Leiter
description: A one-day record of 44 players filed for free agency yesterday, but none of them was named Mike Piazza or Al Leiter. The Mets' catcher and No. 1 pitcher may never file because the Mets appear to be close to signing them.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; A Flurry of Proposals for Gas-Fired Power Plants
description: LAST April the Connecticut General Assembly voted to restructure the state's electric utilities, separating the generation of electricity from its distribution to the consumer.

description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

description: Succumbing to pressure from baseball officials, Marge Schott will step down as controlling owner of the Cincinnati Reds.

description: ASIA'S economic turmoil is having a ripple effect on the New Jersey commercial marketplace, where a number of Japanese and Korean companies are selling buildings they own.

description: The Justice Department filed suit yesterday to prevent Northwest Airlines from buying a controlling stake in Continental Airlines, saying that the deal would stymie competition and lead to higher ticket prices for millions of Americans.

description: Unlike most opera productions, Franco Zeffirelli's ''Carmen'' at the Metropolitan Opera calls for the use of a large number of horses -- seven -- distinguished not by a stage-friendly unflappability, but by a handsome friskiness to help characterize them as soldiers' steeds.

title: Alfred Van Sinderen, 74, Phone Executive
description: Alfred W. Van Sinderen, who served as the top executive of the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation for 17 years, died Oct. 12 at the Harborside Healthcare-Willows, a nursing home in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 74 years old.

description: Parallel investigations of Linda R. Tripp's recordings of her telephone conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky have moved forward in recent days with the issuance of new subpoenas and the questioning of important witnesses.

description: THE conversion of Times Square from a seedy, rundown neighborhood to a prime venue for entertainment has involved the contributions of city officials, developers, architects and other planners. Now the work is well under way, and another profession is making its presence felt: the engineers.

title: Religion Journal; An Environmental Agenda for the World's Faiths
description: The American Museum of Natural History might seem an unlikely place for a conference dealing with religious traditions. But the intersection of faith and science was the focus of a gathering there last Wednesday called ''Religion and Ecology: Discovering the Common Ground.''

description: LONG ISLAND'S surging commercial market has brought vacancy rates to their lowest levels in years and rental rates to their highest.

description: Although the San Francisco Ballet has a wide repertory, it is concentrating on novelties for its brief and welcome season, which closes tomorrow night at City Center.

description: He was drawn and pale, left bald by repeated courses of chemotherapy. He had no substantive inducements to offer the Israelis or the Palestinians.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS PLANS $285 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Applied Materials Inc., the No. 1 maker of semiconductor equipment, said yesterday that it would take charges of $285 million, or 56 cents a share, as part of a previously disclosed plan to reorganize operations. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it completed the revamping disclosed in August, which included cutting 2,000 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, and that the moves would save it $40 million a quarter. Applied is trying to cope with a slowdown in the chip-equipment market, caused by weak computer sales and the economic crisis in Asia.

title: Officials Say This Father Didn't Know Best
description: The plot was like something from ''Law and Order'' with a punch line from the show ''Kids Say the Darn edest Things.''

description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization and King Hussein of Jordan at the signing of the Middle East peace agreement at the White House yesterday, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Mr. Arafat's remarks were translated from the Arabic.

description: In suburban counties outside New York City, many legislative races are virtually decided, most in favor of incumbents. These are our endorsements for some races that are considered competitive:
