description: FRIEDLAND - Josine. Devoted wife of the late Morton. Loving mother of Melissa, Edward and Lesley. Cherished mother-in-law of Barry, Lisa and Andrew. Beloved grandmother of Gregory, Jonathan, Henry, Eric, Elliot, Ethan, Seth, Abigail and Matthew. Tireless in her efforts to help those in need, she will be deeply missed by her family and many friends. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, October 25 at 9:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. Friends may visit at Lesley's home on 72 St. Sunday 1:30-5 PM, Monday 5-8PM & Tuesday 4-8PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Another Knifepoint Attack in Central Park
description: A 33-year-old man was robbed just after sunset yesterday as he strolled through the middle of Central Park, the sixth knifepoint attack in the same general area of the park in the last month.

title: In Colorado Resort Fires, Culprits Defy Easy Labels
description: Years before someone took responsibility for burning a Colorado ski resort this week in the name of the Earth Liberation Front, the name was used by radical saboteurs who said they would strike to protect animals and wildlife habitat.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Devils May Put Terreri in Goal
description: For Chris Terreri, it marked a homecoming when the Devils traded for him this summer almost three years after dealing him away. But the homecoming has not been complete, as he has not played in the Devils' first five games. That is expected to change Saturday night when the Boston Bruins visit the Devils.

title: Several Youths Go on a Rampage, Wrecking Vehicles and Beating a Vendor
description: While most of those who lined Broadway yesterday afternoon had a good time and got home safely, at least one hot-dog vendor and five cars -- including two owned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation -- fell victim to a rowdy band of fans.

title: Stellar Play Makes a Game At a Team Event in Beijing
description: The world's smallest annual team event, with just four invited squads, is also one of the strongest. It is the Marlboro China Cup, played last week in Beijing, and the winners were four Frenchmen who have won multiple world titles: Paul Chemla, Alain Levy, Christian Mari and Frank Multon. For winning a double round-robin ahead of, in order, another European team, a North American team and a team from the host country, they collected $18,000 in prize money. In the parallel event for women's teams, China took the top prize.

title: PACIFICORP PLANS UNIT SALES AND A REFOCUSING
description: Pacificorp said yesterday that it would focus on its electricity business in the Western United States and sell its other businesses. The company will also undertake a cost-reduction program aimed at achieving annual pretax savings of $30 million from its continuing business, and will record related fourth-quarter charges. In addition, Pacificorp will begin a $750 million program to repurchase about 13 percent of its shares in the next 12 months. The company said that as part of its strategic redirection it would terminate all of its business-development efforts outside the United States and Australia.

title: Loving Him to Death
description: We know Matthew Shepard in death. Now there's at least a fleeting image of him in life. Distraught about the murder in Wyoming, Tim Kirkman, a young gay film maker, spent frantic days searching his files, convinced that Matthew was among the interviewees who didn't make it into the final version of his documentary about Jesse Helms, ''Dear Jesse,'' which Cinemax is showing in its ''Reel Life'' series in January. ''I was sick of seeing this split-rail fence everywhere,'' said Mr. Kirkman this week, as he described his ultimately successful effort to unearth his 1996 video of an unbrutalized Matthew.

title: Cornell Announces Plans to Put Greater Focus on Undergraduates
description: Joining the growing list of elite research universities that are making undergraduates more of a priority, Cornell University announced plans yesterday to transform undergraduate education -- changing everything from the way students live to the way they learn.

title: Istanbul Journal; Fearless Turks' Big Fear? Oil Tankers
description: Late on a moonless night several weeks ago, two giant oil tankers approached each other near the north end of the Bosporus.

title: James McFadden, 68, Editor and Publisher
description: James P. McFadden, an editor, publisher and prominent Roman Catholic layman, died on Oct. 17 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 68.

title: GTECH HOLDINGS IN BID FOR TRANSACTION NETWORK
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking to acquire Transaction Network Services Inc. Gtech said discussions had occurred, but no agreement has been reached and significant issues, including financing, remained unresolved. Transaction Network Services, based in Reston, Va., provides data communications services for transaction-oriented applications. It earned $5.8 million on revenue of $64.1 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. Gtech, based in West Greenwich, R.I., supplies computer on-line lottery services It had revenue of $465.8 million in the six months ended Aug.29.

title: Boston to Iowa to Boston: The Lend-Lease Lineman Plan
description: Boston University dropped football last fall, but the co-captain of the team, Travis Raitt, was unwilling to quit, too. He had another season of intercollegiate eligibility remaining, but it was just as important for him to gain his degree in business.

title: Gap Between Party Funds Grows in Races for Congress
description: Republican Party fund-raising has exceeded the Democrats' by more than $110 million in the current Congressional campaign, and, in the year that change in campaign finance faltered in Congress, unregulated donations to both parties more than doubled from the 1994 mid-term elections.

title: Officially a School Day, But Who's Counting?
description: On Thursday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani all but dared city schoolchildren to take the day off from school to attend the Yankee ticker tape parade, saying the First Son and First Daughter, Andrew and Caroline, would be on hand. Yesterday, thousands of public school students took him up on the idea.

title: Italy Tightens Rules on Lending of Art
description: VENICE  By the end of her days here, Peggy Guggenheim, with her private gondola, bevy of exotic lap dogs, bizarre signature sunglasses and earrings that doubled up as wall hangings, had become a monstre sacre and herself one of the sights of the city.

title: U.S. Revises Its Medicare-H.M.O. Stance
description: The Clinton Administration moved today to clarify the rights of hundreds of thousands of elderly Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations, and it threatened to impose fines on insurance companies that refuse to sell them coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUMACK, DR. IRVING
description: RUMACK-Dr. Irving, on October 20, 1998, age 81. Beloved husband of Mildred Rumack. Devoted father of Peter and Lucy, and fatherin-law of Nina and Rod. Adoring grandfather of Julia, Amy, Charlotte and Matthew. At home Saturday and Sunday after 1:00 P.M.

title: The President, Who Kept Them Talking, Basks in Their High Praise
description: No one but the President of the United States, even if burdened with other immense problems, could have kept Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat talking for nine days and eight nights until they reached an agreement on land, law and security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ARDEN
description: DAVIDSON-Arden. On October 22, 1998 of Forest Hills, NY. Wife of Richard, mother of Darcie and Sarah. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave., corner Metropolitan Avenue, Forest Hills, on Saturday, 6-9 P.M. Funeral service Sunday, October 25th at noon.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the Bell Atlantic Corporation's third-quarter earnings referred incorrectly to its early retirement program. The program began in 1994 as part of a labor settlement, and the costs associated with it had no connection with the merger of Bell Atlantic and the Nynex Corporation last year.

title: Q. & A.
description: Interest on A Security Deposit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, TESSIE
description: LYON-Tessie. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations expresses condolences to our distinguished colleague Avram Lyon on the loss of his beloved mother. We pray that the family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mel Salberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Barber Very Nearly Has Nowhere to Run
description: The Giants' starting running back when the season opened, Tiki Barber, may lose his status as the team's third-down back. His grip on the position grew more tenuous today when Coach Jim Fassel acknowledged that he has been preparing Greg Comella, the rookie backup fullback, for the job in case Barber continues to falter.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review in the Art Guide column of Weekend yesterday misstated the given name of the painter whose work is at the gallery M-13, 72 Greene Street, SoHo. He is Donald McLaughlin, not David.

title: Rock's Excess in Service of Introspection
description: As an electric keyboard tinkled demurely behind her during her second encore at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Thursday night, Alanis Morissette sang about wailing so hard she would crack. Paying homage to that impulse was only fair, since it made Ms. Morissette a superstar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, WILLIAM J.
description: COTTER-William J. Of Mansfield, CT. Formerly of New York City. Died Ocotber 23, 1998, after a short illness. Dearest and beloved friend of Elaine Landry. He was associated for many years with TWA in sales and marketing; also with Hilton Hotels. He was a loyal member of the TWA Seniors. Funeral services will be private. Good night, sweet prince.

title: Hedge Fund Firm Says It Covered Its Losses
description: Ellington Capital Management, the hedge fund firm in Old Greenwich, Conn., that was forced to sell many of its holdings to meet margin calls earlier this month, told its investors yesterday that the losses in its three funds, while sizable, appeared to be limited.

title: Malaysian Oil Company Seeks Big Cut in Jobs
description: Petroliam Nasional, Malaysia's state oil company, said yesterday that it would offer 4,000 workers, or 29 percent of its work force, a voluntary retirement package in November and that it expected a third to take up the offer. The offer to nonexecutive and nontechnical workers results from automation of operations that leaves the company, known as Petronas, with excess staff, a company spokesman said.

title: Streetscapes / Douglas Leigh, Sign Maker; The Man Behind Times Square's Smoke Rings
description: WHILE New York is a city of both historic buildings and historic signs, the signs have largely faded into history. But Douglas Leigh, who created many of them -- including the one that sent those Camel smoke rings wafting across Times Square -- is still very much around.

title: The Spy at the Peace Talks
description: Desperate to sweeten a peace agreement that is distasteful to his ultraright constituency, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu may have outsmarted himself: at the last minute on Friday, Israel demanded that President Clinton release Jonathan Pollard, the American naval aide who was sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for spying on behalf of Israel.

title: MATCHUPS
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Jubilant Today, but Who's Gone Tomorrow?
description: With fans chanting for him to remain with the Yankees, Bernie Williams stood on a podium at City Hall yesterday and said, ''I think I've got a chance to stay.''

title: Stricter Law On Facade Inspections
description: LAST March, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed a measure mandating sweeping changes in Local Law 10, the 1980 measure that requires periodic inspections of facades of buildings taller than six stories.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about third-quarter financial results at major airlines misstated earnings at Trans World Airlines. The company reported operating income of $23.7 million and a net loss of $923,000 before extraordinary items -- not an operating loss of $923,000.

title: Netanyahu Stakes Out Israel's Political Center
description: With the flourish of a pen at today's signing ceremony, Benjamin Netanyahu, the rightist Prime Minister of Israel, has positioned himself as a centrist and redefined the relationship between the two major political parties of his country.

title: A Schumer Counterpunch
description: This is a new 15-second commercial that the campaign of Charles E. Schumer began broadcasting on Thursday.

title: McCarthy's Tactics In Light of Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Calls Pataki Elusive, and Wants His Day on the Dais
description: Frustrated by what he called a lack of attention to his gubernatorial campaign, Peter F. Vallone said yesterday that the public should be taking his proposals more seriously and pressuring Gov. George E. Pataki to debate him.

title: At Last, I Love a Parade
description: My grandmother, a proud immigrant with a heavy accent, taught me to sing ''The Sidewalks of New York.'' But my 4-year-old mind could not comprehend the description of what folks do on those sidewalks: ''we'll trip the light fantastic.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ACX TECHNOLOGIES INC., Golden, Colo., a maker of packaging and advanced ceramics for the electronics industry, said it would dismiss about 85 employees as it revamps its flexible packaging division and takes a $2.4 million charge.

title: Reid Continues On Path to a Title
description: David Reid has been on the fast track toward greatness since he walked out of the ring at the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. Reid was the only American boxer to win a gold medal, which helped to certify him as a future professional world champion.

title: At Their Party, the Yanks Are Upstaged on the Dais
description: There they were, the heroes of the 1998 World Champion New York Yankees, depicted in their uniforms on baseball-card-style posters hung prominently across the facade of City Hall: O'Neill. Wells. Hernandez. Giuliani.

title: If It Says 'Yankees' Or 'Series,' It's Selling
description: Michael Modell was ecstatic. The co-president of Modell's Sporting Goods was on the telephone from his Seventh Avenue office crowing about sales of Yankee merchandise, while his brother, Mitchell, also a co-president, attended the downtown parade to celebrate the team's World Series championship.

title: UNITED VIDEO SELLS $31 MILLION IN GEMSTAR STOCK
description: United Video Satellite Group Inc. said yesterday that it sold $31 million of shares it held in Gemstar International Group Ltd., a company it sought to take over through a $2 billion bid earlier this year. The company, a developer of cable television program guides and a satellite TV operator, said the sale generated a pretax profit of $10.4 million, or more than 50 percent above what it paid for the shares. United Video, which is controlled by affiliate Tele-Communications Inc., dropped its bid for Gemstar in July after it offered $45 a share for the company, an independent developer of interactive TV technology.

title: Focusing on Jobs, Education and the Economy
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker and Democratic candidate for governor, by editors and reporters of The New York Times:

title: 250 People Arrested In Statewide Drug Sweep
description: In a coordinated effort to keep drug dealers from simply moving their operations, the authorities throughout the state arrested about 250 people yesterday morning in raids on suspected outdoor drug markets, State Attorney General Peter G. Verniero announced.

title: Writers as Plunderers; Why Do They Keep Giving Away Other People's Secrets?
description: Murderer. Thief. Cannibal? Oh, the writer at work! Perhaps the way authors work was most famously described in two books by Janet Malcolm: ''The Journalist and the Murderer,'' in which she compares journalists to confidence men who betray their subjects without remorse, and ''The Silent Woman,'' in which she described biographers as ''professional burglars.''

title: Rally in Equities Takes a Holiday; Dow Declines 80.85
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday, breaking a run of seven advancing sessions, the longest in 16 months.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Howard Beach, Queens; An Urban Enclave With Prow to the Sea
description: CITY? Suburb? Seaside? Howard Beach has something of each.

title: Suspect Denies Ordering Immigrant Ship Grounded
description: The man accused of masterminding the Golden Venture voyage -- an ill-fated effort to smuggle hundreds of Chinese immigrants into the United States on a crumbling freighter -- sought yesterday to take back a major part of the statement he made when he pleaded guilty in the case.

title: POSTINGS: Two-Families for Soundview; 25 Homes On 3 Blocks
description: Construction is to start in December on the first market-rate, two-family home development in the Soundview section of the Bronx in nearly 25 years.

title: After Alou Rejection, Dodgers Get Their Man
description: Davey Johnson, the best manager in baseball who has had the toughest time getting and holding jobs, added a fourth team to his re$(0$)sume$(0$) yesterday. The Los Angeles Dodgers named Johnson successor to Walter Alston, Tommy Lasorda, Bill Russell and Glenn Hoffman.

title: Sadly in Love With Love
description: We should all age as gracefully as Charles Aznavour. At 74, the legendary French-Armenian singer and songwriter, who is performing a limited engagement (through Nov. 15) at the Marquis Theater, has a voice that, if anything, has gained in strength and emotive authority over the decades. Trim and dapper in a black suit, his white hair cut short, Mr. Aznavour exudes the electricity of a veteran pugilist with the soul of a mime. That voice, combined with body language, allows him to convey the emotional core of a song with a directness and clarity that transcend language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, EMMA
description: GOLDIN-Emma. On October 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Theodore; loving mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. Service Sunday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Threats Over Pinochet Case Inflaming Tensions in Chile
description: Chilean leftist politicians who have applauded the arrest in London of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, say they are receiving anonymous death threats. A rightist political party that supports the general canceled a news conference because of a bomb threat. And an unidentified protester threw a gasoline bomb at a police car.

title: 'Only a Couple of Bad Guys'
description: On Monday, a Manhattan rally to protest brutality against homosexuals led to more than 100 arrests as demonstrators clashed with the police. But yesterday, with lower Manhattan brimming with Yankee fans, arrests were held to a minimum, and the biggest problem seemed to be a confetti fire.

title: Teach Children to Be Internet Filters
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Move Back Into Stock Funds
description: Investors bought a net $2.05 billion in stock mutual funds in the week that ended Wednesday, AMG Data Services reported yesterday.

title: A Turn Toward Peace
description: The body language in the East Room of the White House yesterday was more eloquent than the words that were uttered or the accords that were signed. For the first time since Benjamin Netanyahu became Prime Minister of Israel more than two years ago, he looked at ease with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. The distrust and stiffness between the leaders seemed to be gone, replaced by the kind of respect and partnership that can make a permanent peace possible in the Middle East.

title: POSTINGS: 14 Lofts at 140 Franklin Street, From $1.65 Million to $3.95 Million; A Renovation in TriBeCa
description: The whirr of machines can still be heard in the workshop of a manufacturer of parts for electric pumps on the sixth floor of the 1887 building at 140 Franklin Street in Tribeca. But the pumps will soon depart as part of a $10 million renovation that will turn the Romanesque Revival building at the corner of Varick Street, with its weathered yellow brick and cast-iron detail, into a 14-loft luxury condominium building by the end of next year.

title: White Woman, Black Slave in Britain
description: The patient, a slave named Luke, has died. The doctor turns to the devastated young mistress of the house and tells her he'll send the bill to Cole & Sons. ''It is a commercial loss, is it not?'' he says.

title: MORE ON THE PACT
description: C.I.A. Shuns Shadows In New Middle East Role

title: One Minimalist Color After Another
description: Bruce Brubaker's recital at Miller Theater this week was thoughtful and stimulating. Part of his project was to suggest an ancestry for the music of Philip Glass and John Adams in some of John Cage's piano pieces of the 1940's, and indeed the two he chose, ''A Room'' and ''Dream,'' did fit well beside Mr. Glass's music in particular. ''A Room'' is directly repetitive; ''Dream'' floats up and down in soft scale patterns. But minimalism, like the color orange, surely existed long before there was a name for it. Circling figuration is found in musical cultures from around the world, and if Bach or Handel were to return they would recognize familiar features in Mr. Glass's scores, which they might think to be eccentric passacaglias, rather long and lacking in variation.

title: In a Diplomatic Coup, El Duque Welcomes His Awestruck Family
description: On this day of marvels, there was a soaring plane ride with propellers chopping and stomachs quivering. There were giddy imaginings of steely skyscrapers, the Statue of Liberty and the never-before-experienced shivers of a Cuban family's first blustery October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFCOURT, ALBERT DR.
description: LEFCOURT-Albert Dr., retired optometrist, died on October 21, 1998, in Hallandale, FL. He was 87 years young and is survived by his devoted wife of 40 years, Rachael, of Hallandale, his two sons, Robert and Gerald of N.Y.C., his brother Harold, of Levittown, PA, his cherished nephew Ian Erlich of Oregon, & his adoring grandchildren, Jenny, Daniel, Jeffrey, and Karen of N.Y.C. A high school track star, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, School of Optometry, he was a Mason, violinist and lover of music and dancing. He practiced optometry for 50 years in Jersey City and briefly in West Orange, NJ before partially retiring as an optician in Hallandale, FL. Memorial contributions in his memory to National Foundation for Cancer Research, 4600 East West Hway, Bethesda, MD 20814. Service Sunday, 11 A.M., at the ''Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam

title: Down Market Weighs on Donations, Too
description: SINCE June, gifts of cash to the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York are running several million dollars below last year.

title: Don't Look Down
description: LEAVING EARTH

title: Fred O'Green, 77, Shaped Litton Into Leading Defense Contractor
description: Fred W. O'Green, who led Litton Industries in the 1970's and 1980's, first as president and then as chairman, died on Oct. 2 as a result of complications from Alzheimer's Disease at the St. John of God retirement and care center in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old and had lived in Los Angeles for more than 30 years..

title: Mindy Klein, John Rittenhouse
description: Mindy Ellen Klein, the daughter of Carole and David S. Klein of Long Branch, N.J., is to be married this morning to John Scott Rittenhouse, a son of Muriel and John E. Rittenhouse of East Northport, N.Y. Msgr. Richard A. Rusconi is to officiate at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi Nathaniel Benjamin will take part in the ceremony.

title: Kosher Food Pantry Extends Helping Hand
description: THE woman put a box of matzoh, some jars of gefilte fish and a few other items in her grocery sack.

title: A Young Life Hangs in the Balance
description: HE seems like any other 14-year-old boy in Millburn. Attending middle school. Playing with friends.

title: For Once, the Living Get the Roses at Campbell's
description: With a client list that reads like a who's who of American celebrities -- Mae West, George Gershwin, Arthur Ashe and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis among them -- it is no ordinary funeral home. So when Frank E. Campbell, a genteel, nondenominational mortuary, decided to celebrate its 100th anniversary last week, it organized an extraordinary event: an open house with white roses for the ladies and refreshments served by tuxedo-clad attendants.

title: The Rake's Progress
description: Casanova in Love By Andrew Miller. 272 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, SCHAINMAN, PEARL C.
description: GORDON-SCHAINMAN-Pearl C. Beloved wife of Leonard Gordon and the late Mory Schainman. Loving mother of Lynn Russell. Dear sister of Martin Sandberg and his wife, Grace, and the late Norma Schnitzer. Services Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: Laura Sheehan, Jared Kallen
description: Laura Ann Sheehan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah J. Sheehan of Richmond, and Jared Matthew Kallen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Roland G. Kallen of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., were married last evening in the Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington. Msgr. Lawrence Madden officiated with Dr. Arthur C. Blecher, the rabbi of Congregation Beth Chai in Washington.

title: Restoring Old Boats: Many in Number, but Which to Choose?
description: FROM a distance, the old boat swaying gently at a berth in East Creek Marina appears to have retained her seaworthiness and structural integrity. But get close to the Little Jennie and the 114-year-old wooden ketch's rotted bowsprit, cracked deck, discolored wood trim and rusted metal fittings betray her age and deterioration.

title: Gargoyles, 'Creepy and Cute'
description: ''The Monsters of Wall Street'' is not an expos'e of predatory capitalism. Rather, it's part of a Web site about Amelia Wilson's fascination with New York City gargoyles, those decorative, often grotesque human and animal figures on buildings.

title: Mellow Roll Captures Empire Classic
description: Mellow Roll rolled through the homestretch to win the $250,000 Empire Classic at Belmont Park yesterday and to lay claim to the unofficial title of king pro tem of the horses bred in New York State.

title: New Technology Turns Useless Agricultural Byproducts Into Fuel for Autos
description: The plant was opened in 1977 to refine crude oil into gasoline, but when that proved unprofitable, it was converted in 1981 to run on molasses, and then in 1987, on grain. Bankruptcy followed.

title: Oh, Those Yawning Spreads
description: True or false: The Federal Reserve's recent interest-rate cuts, and those expected forthwith, will forestall an economic recession in the United States and lower the risk that credit will dry up across the economy.

title: Raw Material
description: SILK AND INSIGHT

title: Reid Wins And Stays On Path To a Title
description: David Reid's march toward a world championship continued tonight unabated by James (Cowboy) Coker, who was supposed to teach Reid about patience and discipline before the 2,345 fans at the Mark G. Etess Arena at Trump's Taj Mahal.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS with RONALD W. BURKLE; On a Shopping Spree For Supermarket Chains
description: IN the recent wave of supermarket mergers, Ronald W. Burkle has proved to be the master deal maker. As chairman and largest shareholder of Fred Meyer, he engineered its planned $8 billion sale to Kroger last Sunday. The previous week he guided Dominick's Supermarkets, of which he was also chairman and major shareholder, into the arms of Safeway for $1.85 billion.

title: Flat Top Triumphs
description: Flat Top, ridden by Bitsy Patterson, an amateur, led the entire race and survived a claim of foul to win the $150,000 Breeders' Cup American Grand National Steeplechase at the Far Hills (N.J.) Race Meeting. The victory placed the bay gelding owned by Mrs. Henry F. Gerry of Locust Valley, N.Y., in contention for an Eclipse award as steeplechasing's horse of the year.

title: The World; Chicken Little! Shut Up!
description: MAYBE it was just a false dawn there have been plenty of those.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONENGOLD, MINNA
description: KRONENGOLD-Minna. On October 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry Kronengold. Dear mother of Susan. Services private.

title: 60 Years After Invasion, Some Revisionist History in Grovers Mill
description: On the evening of Oct. 30, 1938, Martians landed at Grovers Mill intent on invading the country, or so believed more than a million people who tuned in Orson Welles's Mercury Theater ''War Of The Worlds'' radio broadcast, adapted from the H. G. Wells book. The panic that ensued has since marked the village of Grovers Mill, now as then little more than an intersection near a barn and mill pond.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Pontiac Grand Am; Beneath All the Flash, A Firmer Foundation
description: OVER the years, General Motors has turned out a lot of memorable big cars, but this colossal company has had trouble thinking small. Remember the Corvair, the Vega, the Chevette? The Nova derivatives like the Buick Apollo, or the X-body compacts of the late 1970's? Surely you haven't forgotten the Pontiac Phoenix?

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Best? Yes, But Wait
description: AS soon as the Yankees piled together at the mound in San Diego last Wednesday night to celebrate their World Series sweep, the debate began.

title: Counter Intuitive
description: THE interview with the press secretary at the White House, Tony Larocca, was to take place, in his words, at the take-out counter at 2 P.M., ''or when it isn't too busy, whichever comes last.''

description: Too Good to Be Forgotten

title: Tracking Gertrude Treadwell's Ghost
description: WEARING a golf shirt and a large gold St. Michael medallion around his neck, David Umbria held his small tape recorder up toward a crystal chandelier at the Merchant's House Museum in Greenwich Village and called out in the dark.

title: Claudia Carson, Tom Jeziorny
description: Claudia Carson, a daughter of Marvin Carson of Manhattan and Carol Carson of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Tom Jeziorny, the son of Anna Jeziorny of New Britain, Conn., and the late Ludwig Jeziorny. The Rev. Frank Hall performed the Unitarian ceremony at Seventy Hillside, a historic house in Waterbury, Conn.

title: Too Much
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: It's Pumpkin Season Down in the Squash Patch
description: PUMPKINS are everywhere -- in fields, by entryways, stacked at garden center gates or piled by the roadside farm stand. By next Saturday, Halloween, they'll be carved with make-believe faces, products of the urge to produce the silliest, scariest, brightest faces for jack-o'-lanterns.

title: Surprise! Some Hedge Funds, It Seems, Really Do Hedge
description: The rich money may not be so dumb after all. Despite the much-publicized woes at Long-Term Capital Management and other hedge funds, investors in such investment vehicles appear to have fared far better in the recent market downturn than those who plowed their money into stocks or run-of-the-mill mutual funds, according to Van Hedge Fund Advisors International, a Nashville consulting firm that compiles an index of hedge funds.

title: Bluestone Blues: Tripped Up by Sidewalk Repair Notices
description: The roots of a 50-year-old maple tree were gradually lifting the curbside sections of bluestone sidewalk in front of Otis Pratt Pearsall's house on Willow Street in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Gay March Didn't Honor Shepard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, NORMAN
description: WILSON-Norman, died October 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Stephen Wilson and Robin Levy. Cherished grandfather to Arlynn, Adam and Sean Wilson and Josh, Corey and Kate Levy.

title: The Nuisance Of Overheard Calls; Cell Phones Are Everywhere But Good Manners May Not Be
description: The setting was bucolic when the high-powered cell phone couple went away for the weekend to a little inn in Maine.

title: The War Between the Democrats
description: As they left Washington this weekend for the election break, Congressional Republicans were either muttering that President Clinton had once again taken them to the cleaners or defending their retreat in the last-minute budget showdown. Democrats heading for the airport were laughing, joking and enjoying the opposition's discomfort.

title: At Northern Italian Restaurant Wine, Bath and Beyond
description: There's a Roman bath in the women's restroom at Bacco, a northern Italian restaurant that opened last month at 150 Spring Street (between West Broadway and Wooster Street). Bacco is Italian for Bacchus, the Greek god of wine and debauchery, and at the restaurant, there's as great an emphasis on wine as on food.

title: His Day in Court
description: Lawyer

title: After Intense Scrutiny, Suffolk Death-Penalty Jury Is Selected
description: Over the last three and a half months, nearly 1,300 prospective jurors have filed into court here and answered questions about whether they could fairly determine the guilt or innocence of a suspect in a series of murders and then possibly sentence him to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUILLARD, PEARL SCHWARTZ
description: REUILLARD - Pearl Schwartz. Died October 23, peacefully at home at age 90. Pearl was a retired teacher from Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn. She was involved in political activities all of her life, especially with The League of Women Voters. Pearl will be missed by her many nieces, nephews and friends. Funeral services Tuesday, October 27, 1:00 PM, at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' 312 Coney Island Ave, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Interment to follow at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Odd Speculation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The World; Unstacking Milosevic's Deck
description: SLOBODAN MILOSEVIC, Serbia's strongman, knows the playbook well.

title: Mysterious Art of West Mexico
description: West Mexico has been, relatively speaking, terra incognita in the cultural world. Though long known for ceramic sculptures, the present-day states of Jalisco, Colima and Nayarit are only recently coming into their own for the imposing architecture and complex society that flourished there between 200 B.C. and 800 A.D.

title: An East End Transfer Tax? Realtors Say No Way.
description: THE dead-heat contest between Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer may be the highlight of the campaign season across the rest of New York State. But in Suffolk County, farm and environmental referendum issues are generating enough heat to compete with the Senate race as the hottest topic down at the coffee shop.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on page 3 of the Travel section today, about the royal yacht Britannia, refers incorrectly to Mohandas K. Gandhi. He was never entertained aboard the ship; he died in 1948 before she was launched.

title: Gay March Didn't Honor Shepard
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Fiction; A Nice Sea for Scoundrels
description: A VIEW FROM THE MANGROVE (University of Massachusetts, $24.95) is the final part of a trilogy by the expatriate Cuban writer Antonio Benitez-Rojo in which he sets out to investigate the history and culture of the Caribbean using three different genres. Thus the short stories in this collection can be read as companion pieces to his novel ''Sea of Lentils'' and his book of essays ''The Repeating Island.'' Not surprisingly, this new volume (translated by James Maraniss) covers a wide historical range, from the 16th century to the mid-20th; some of the material is based on actual records, some has been fictionalized to resemble fact. Here Benitez-Rojo chronicles events of unremitting and often unspeakable horror -- slave trading, invasions, mutinies, rebellions, murders. His stories are dense with disaster and rich in description. The characters seem to exist only in extremis, dying in despondency and despair or in false glory. They are either mysterious and foreign to one another or brothers in suffering. Ambition motivates them all -- hypocritical priests, opportunistic scoundrels, even a few doomed romantics. In Benitez-Rojo's view, the truth is often more contradictory and confusing than fiction, and in both it is difficult to tell the defeats from the triumphs, the pious from the godless, the honorable from the unworthy. History is what is written down, an orderly procession of events leading to a specific outcome -- to a duel, to the establishment of trade, to the political division of an island. These stories persuasively present the improbable swirl of action out of which that history is confidently fabricated. Barbara Fisher

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ORBACH, MILTON N.
description: ORBACH-Milton N. Most beloved husband of Jean K., loving grandfather of Daniel Milton Viola Johnson. Also survived by sisters Ruth Vallon and Annette Epstein, cherished friend to many. Memorial service Thursday, October 29, 2:30 PM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Family will receive at home following service. In lieu of flowers, donation to a charity of your choice.

title: Sarah Rosen, Theodore Wartell
description: Sarah Rosen, the senior adviser for financial and regulatory affairs at the National Economic Council, and Theodore Ernest Wartell, a special assistant to the program associate director at the Office of Management and Budget, both at the White House, are to be married this afternoon in Washington. Judge Merrick B. Garland, of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, is to officiate at the Woman's National Democratic Club.

title: A La Carte; Thrills of Mexico in an Unassuming Spot
description: THE authentic and often exotic cuisine of Mexico cannot be found in the fancy suburban restaurants or the commercial mass appeal chains with their glitzy rum drinks, bland salsas and so-called Mexican pizza. Rather it is being cooked in tiny, decidedly unfashionable nooks like Taste of Mexico, tucked away in an alley-like extension of Oyster Bay's South Street (624-8740), facing a parking lot. This colorful little spot with sombreros, Mexican flags, a counter, cactus plants, bare Mexican tile tables and a half-Latino, half-Anglo crowd successfully recreates the rhythm, aura and spirit of Mexico.

title: Dior, Oui!
description: In Paris, nostalgia fills the air. The chestnut trees are in autumn colors, and the spectacle of fashion, which remains an intense subject of interest in the French capital, has taken an unexpected turn, to a romantic silhouette created by the designer John Galliano. This jolt to understated minimalism has created tension between the opposing tastes. The lavish look was in vivid evidence on women attending his shows for Christian Dior, held Oct. 13. There is a newly rich international clientele that wants the style that shouts the loudest. Dior's striking shawl-collar suits, left and above; its extravagant colors, top right, and sumptuous accessories (as in a belle-epoque necklace worn with a tiger-stenciled fur jacket) fully capture the aspirations of this small but potent fashion force, which is enjoying the fun of dressing up.

title: Even for Preschoolers, There's Home Schooling
description: This is the first year in the city's four-year plan to offer all families prekindergarten education. But this fall 330 preschoolers, from the Bronx to Bedford-Stuyvesant, are sitting around their kitchen tables instead, as their parents try to teach shapes, colors and the proper use of scissors.

title: Abortion Doctor in Buffalo Slain; Sniper Attack Fits Violent Pattern
description: Dr. Barnett Slepian, an obstetrician with a practice in this Buffalo suburb, returned home from synagogue Friday night with his wife, Lynn, and greeted his four sons. Then he stepped into his kitchen, where a sniper's bullet crashed through a back window and struck him in the chest, the police said.

title: Inside the District
description: THIS fall, the Yonkers Public School District is teaching 25,300 students in 29 elementary schools, four middle schools, four high schools and one continuing education school.

title: Abstract Painting, Though Not Entirely
description: IN its earlier styles, art was generally meant to represent nature. But modern art, abstraction in particular, has often professed to embody its operations. Thus, Jackson Pollock's celebrated affirmation: ''I am nature!''

title: A Glorious Adventure, Made in Brooklyn
description: I HAD no master plan when I came to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1967, nor any objective other than to make BAM a successful operation. It was far from that then.

title: PULSE: HALLOWEEN EDITION; Hot Pink Puppies
description: Going beyond silly hats and sunglasses for their pets, owners are now trotting out animals who have had their fur dyed. They have been turning to Eric Gonzalez, owner of Urban Pets on Christopher Street, New York's top -- and perhaps only -- fur colorist. The Brad Johns of the pet world, Mr. Gonzalez turns white poodles aqua, golden labs green and white cats pink. Most of his regular clientele are models, but this month he has also answered pet-dipping requests for nonworking pets. ''A woman brought her white dog in and asked me to make it look like a cow for trick-or-treating,'' he said. The process, which uses safe vegetable dyes and costs $45 to $85, works best on light-colored animals and does not wash out easily, ''though the hot pink fades to a nice cotton-candy color,'' Mr. Gonzalez said. Ruth Voorhies, a fashion-show producer, had her Maltese, Mags, dyed fuchsia for a video by Total, a female rhythm-and-blues group. Ms. Voorhies was aghast when she first saw her hot-pink puppy; now she thinks Mags should go safety orange for Halloween. ''I just hope it fades by Thanksgiving,'' said Ms. Voorhies, who goes home for the holidays and does not want to frighten her 93-year-old grandmother. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Despite Losing Lead, Rangers See a Turnaround
description: The Rangers aren't a great team. They probably won't be a good team for a while. Possibly, they might not even be a mediocre team in what is obviously a rebuilding season. But they do seem to be a competitive bunch that plays interesting games, at least after eight performances of the 1998-99 season.

title: Sparring on Abortion, Impeachment, Attendance and Integrity
description: Following are excerpts from the senatorial debate last night in Schenectady, N.Y., between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer, sponsored by WRGB-TV, Channel 6, and moderated by Liz Bishop:

Cherished Grandpa of Aaron, Joshua, Alisha and Rachel. Devoted brother of Mickey Wallburg. Loyal friend and colleague. Services Sunday, 11 AM, Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., Bronx. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your local hospice or the American Cancer Society.

title: In Final Stretch, Parties Turn Up Ad Blitz to Prod Voters
description: The campaign of 1998 entered an intense final 10-day stretch today as Democrats and Republicans turned their energies to vast telephone, mailing and advertising drives to prod millions of loyalists to the polls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, REV. MSGR. GERARD A.
description: GREEN-Rev. Msgr. Gerard A., Pastor Emeritus Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry. Lying in State Monday 2-4 and 7-8 P.M. (Evening Wake Service at 8 P.M.) at Sacred Heart Church, Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Mass of Christian Burial 10 A.M. Tuesday at Sacred Heart Church. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery.

title: Stop Me Before I Apologize Again
description: William Safire's defense of Trent Lott's use of the word ''Topsy'' rings hollow. Safire may be correct in his quotation of the meaning as it appears in the Oxford English Dictionary. However, in common usage, it is meant as a term of derision when speaking about blacks. I don't know that he is qualified to decide for blacks what words or terms they consider to be offensive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATES, ARNOLD D.
description: KATES-Arnold D. Oct. 25, 1898Sept. 17, 1986. On his 100th birthday, a man ahead of his time. Bobbi, Marc, Alex, Nat

title: Italian Experience With Few Let-Downs
description: SAY goodbye to Portugal and hello to Italy. Even though a tile sign outside the corner building at 149 Mineola Boulevard still reads Atlantis, a brand new burgundy marquis proclaims Villa Altadonna.

title: Costume Dramas
description: Teletubbies and Madeleine were gone by Oct. 1. Zorro, complete with cape, sword and mask, vanished soon afterward. It is no longer enough for parents to rush their toddlers onto waiting lists for elite nursery schools. Now they must gear up months in advance for Halloween -- or face the horror of being shut out of the hottest costumes. ''We used to put the costumes out in early October,'' said Steven Nauman, manager of Zittles, the toy department at Zitomer Pharmacy on Madison Avenue and 76th Street. ''This year, they were on the floor the second week in August -- and right away, people bought them like crazy.'' And while a sellout means big-time disappointment, he added, ''The kids are usually more flexible than the moms.'' Case in point: a tug of war that erupted between two mothers over a $40 Teletubbies costume (above). ''One mother charged over and snatched it out of the other mother's hand,'' Mr. Nauman said. ''When the shouting really escalated, we had to intervene.'' Pickings are now slim: some M&M's, plenty of Godzillas. ''If I can't find something, I might order from a catalogue,'' said Rachel Wolf, an Upper East Side mother. Mr. Nauman said: ''Whatever happened to the days when kids would put on their dad's shirt, smudge dirt on their face and go as a hobo?'' ELLEN TIEN

title: Keren Kazis, Bradley Phillips
description: Dr. Keren Amy Kazis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle W. Kazis of Rye, N.Y., was married on Oct. 17 to Bradley David Phillips, the son of Tema Megaro of Montville, N.J., and Arthur Phillips of Morris Township, N.J. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: State Offers Plan to Expand Cranberry Farms in Pinelands
description: A plan to allow New Jersey's 45 cranberry farmers to expand their operations in the Pinelands has been revived by the Whitman administration, but environmentalists say the changes don't make the new plan acceptable.

title: October 18-24; Anti-Gay Senator Blocks a Nomination
description: Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, recently compared gay people to kleptomaniacs and alcoholics. So it was no surprise when the nomination of James C. Hormel as Ambassador to Luxembourg died in the Senate because Mr. Lott refused to permit a confirmation vote.

title: My Main Man: Tarzan
description: There are masqueraders, and then there is Phil Petras, who has devoted much of his life to becoming the master archivist about, and living replica of, Tarzan, Lord of the Jungle. For decades Petras has pumped iron and collected ape-man memorabilia in obscurity, but now his moment may be here. With Disney set to release its animated Tarzan blockbuster next summer and a reissue of the first Edgar Rice Burroughs Tarzan novel selling briskly, Tarzan fever is spreading. Nowhere does it burn hotter than Hellertown, Pa., a remote, hilly coal town where a deeply tanned, muscle-bound and hopeful bachelor still lives in his father's basement, surrounded by 40,000 mementos and awaiting the call from Hollywood. Here's a look at the evolution of this self-made jungle king.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Broadway revue, an early drama about anti-Semitism and two moving love stories in very different settings enliven the offerings of film on television this week.

title: It's About Priorities
description: To the Editor:

Great grandmother of Robert D. Goldberg. Former attorney with S.E.C. Graveside service Monday, 2 PM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

Also survived by Grace and Arthur Cohen and Alvin & Dorothy Handin and a Granddaughter Katie. Private graveside services were held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Memorials may be made to the Easter Seals Society 2400 Trenton Road Levittown, PA. 19055. Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, Newton, PA.

Willy Schwenzfeier 3d of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Nicholas Brooks DuBois, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Delafield DuBois of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Breitkreuz, a United Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at St. Luke's Chapel at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Mourner Awaits a Memorial
description: Until summer 1997, it appeared as though Gowanus Playground would finally be renamed Nicholas Naquan Heyward Jr. Park in honor of a 13-year-old who was accidentally shot and killed by a Housing Police officer in September 1994. Nicholas was playing with a toy gun in the Gowanus Houses at the time.

title: Julianne James, Jeffrey Smith
description: Julianne James and Jeffrey Scott Smith were married yesterday by Msgr. Ronald J. Rozniak at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: McCarthy's Revisionists
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSER, DOROTHY M., NEE KANTER
description: GROSSER-Dorothy M., nee Kanter, of Queens Village, NY and Sherman, CT, on October 18, 1998. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, friend, loving companion, quilter, gardener. She opened her heart and her home to all of us. We will miss her terribly and love her always.

title: Hisayo Arikawa, Leonard Cronk
description: Hisayo Arikawa and Leonard Cronk are to be married today by the Rev. Charles J. Minifie at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Coyote Backlash
description: Despite the public demand to eliminate coyotes that are attacking pets in New Rochelle, an animals-rights group wants the city to stop capturing and killing the wild animals. The group is asking the city no longer to use James Dreisacker, a trapper who asphyxiated one coyote in the city and left another running loose with a leg-hold trap dangling from its leg.

title: Risky Recreation
description: What is the most risky sport or other activity you have engaged in? Why do people take risks for recreation?

title: Speaking of Crime: In Praise of Shedunits
description: MYSTERY fans who normally spend Thursday nights curled up in front of PBS may want to program their VCR's this week and head out for Douglass College in New Brunswick, where 10 writers will drop some clues about how they thicken their plots.

title: Victory In Variety
description: Q. I am a junior at the State University of New York at Buffalo. So far, I've completed internships in international business, public relations and city government. I am currently working as an intern with a political campaign, and I plan an internship in international relations or security before I graduate. How will prospective employers react to my involvement in such a wide range of apprenticeship programs? I don't want to look as though I'm ''internship hopping'' or can't commit myself to a single job.

title: Debra Gorsen, Lawrence Rose
description: Debra Michelle Gorsen, the daughter of Sharon and David Gorsen of Weston, Fla., was married last evening to Lawrence Marc Rose, the son of Sondra and Marvin H. Rose of Cedarhurst, N.Y.. Rabbi Sheldon Harr performed the ceremony at Temple Kol Ami in Plantation, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIN, FRANK SK
description: CHIN-Frank SK. Left us on October 21, 1998 after a lifelong friendship. Condolences to his family. Lee and John Hauser

title: Joan Baker and Rudolph Gaskins Jr.
description: Joan Marie Baker and Rudolph Adam Gaskins Jr. were married yesterday at the Alta Mira Hotel in Sausalito, Calif. Mayor Albert J. Boro of San Rafael, Calif., officiated.

title: Ideas & Trends; It's So Hard to Be No. 2
description: AT a meeting at an Albany hotel recently, the Democratic nominee for Lieutenant Governor was introduced as Sandra Feldman, the longtime teachers' union leader. Never mind that the candidate's name is Sandra Frankel and that the speaker was none other than the chairwoman of the Democratic Party.

title: It's . . . Yahweh Time!
description: The opening of a new synagogue in a rapidly assimilating urban environment is usually cause for celebration among Jews. But there were a few jeers in London this month when the Saatchi Synagogue made its debut.

title: INSIDE
description: Steps by the Koreas

title: Designing a Library for the Least Private President
description: SOME weeks ago an article appeared in this newspaper in which various people were asked to comment on how Presidential libraries should deal with embarrassing episodes in an administration's record. As I recall, no one suggested that the embarrassing episode should be the major focus of such institutions. But maybe that's the way to go.

title: Walk, Don't Walk, and Send Call: Crossing Guards Are Going Digital
description: THE crossing guard, as American as a Norman Rockwell illustration, has entered the information age.

title: Obnoxious Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tenants Lose Ownership Bid
description: The news hit 894 Rogers Place in late July. Residents found fliers under their doors announcing an inspection by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which owns, manages and subsidizes the rent of this 48-unit building.

title: Symphony to Perform In Cortlandt Manor
description: THE Northern Westchester Symphony, founded in 1965 as a community ensemble for ''enthusiastic amateur musicians and music students who give their best to the orchestra,'' gives its best to the audience at a free concert today at 3 P.M. in Walter Panas High School in Cortlandt Manor.

title: October 18-24; Glenn Doesn't Strut The Old Stuff
description: A recent lull in space shuttle launchings has raised quiet concerns over the safety of Senator John Glenn's flight, prompting an unusual series of dry runs meant to keep ground crews sharp and complex gear up to snuff. Safety experts agree that the winged spaceships must run regularly or become balky and their launching crews rusty.

title: 'Chief' Finds New Arena: Politics
description: Robert Comas put down his half-eaten roast beef sandwich and explained how being a team mascot prepared him for politics. It was lunchtime Tuesday in the back of Brennan & Carr, a restaurant at Nostrand Avenue and Avenue U.

title: Stricter Law On Facade Inspections
description: LAST March, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed a measure mandating sweeping changes in Local Law 10, the 1980 measure that requires periodic inspections of facades of buildings taller than six stories.

title: Landscapes of Australia and America
description: ''A FASCINATING mix of the similar and dissimilar'' is how an Australian critic sums up ''New Worlds From Old,'' an exhibition of 19th-century landscape paintings that was shown first in Australia and is now at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Indeed, the dynamic of the show is in comparisons of the development of landscape painting in Australia and America.

title: Gay March Didn't Honor Shepard
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Tacky All Right, Deliriously So
description: DON'T be fooled by the family's tacky living quarters outside Dallas: a cramped, broken-down trailer home whose chief amenities are a fridge used mostly for beer, a large television set that seldom shuts up and plastic cutlery accumulated over years of eating takeout. The slobbish Ansel Smith, his tarty second wife, Sharla, his pot-smoking son, Chris, and his 20-year-old still-virginal daughter, Dottie, haven't abandoned -- nor have they been abandoned by -- the miraculous American economic juggernaut. They are part of the system and each, in his or her own way, contributes to the national weal and woe.

title: Croton Falls Company Changes Its Name
description: NINE years ago, Cara Caldwell Watson formed a theater company and named it Wordplay. The word part stood for writing, which is how Ms. Watson once earned her living. Yes, real estate advertising copy counts as writing, Ms. Watson said. As for the play part, ''My whole life is theater,'' she added. ''The money came in from words and went out on plays. We were always nonprofit.''

title: Hamptons Realty Company Under Scrutiny
description: A DISPUTE between the surviving owners of a top real estate company in the Hamptons and the husband of a deceased principle is headed for a court showdown, and court papers provide a rare and revealing glimpse into the inner workings of a real estate partnership.

title: VW Day
description: I let out a groan when I read Posner's first sentence: ''Why would any Jew buy a BMW, Mercedes or Volkswagen?'' According to my calendar, the year is 1998, which means that World War II ended 53 years ago. No one would hope that the memory of the atrocities of the 1940's be forgotten. At the same time, it becomes increasingly tiresome when people like Posner continue to obsess on historic injustices from five decades ago.

title: Terreri Returns and Gets Little Respite in Victory
description: After Chris Terreri returned to the Devils this season, he spent his first five games on the bench. And when his first opportunity in goal came tonight, he was spending a lot of idle time on the ice.

title: Georges Was an Island Hopper
description: FOR 11 days last month, Hurricane Georges plowed across the Caribbean, killing at least 500 people and inflicting property damage estimated at more than $5 billion as it weaved through nearly a dozen countries before expiring as an early fall rainstorm over Georgia. It was a disaster -- although not for the entire region and not necessarily for the tourist industry on which the area's economy depends.

title: Where It Began, Half a Century Ago on Henry Street
description: FOR Murray Louis, landmark events are not only the most obviously important occurences. The Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance Company will celebrate a 50th anniversary, for instance, in a weeklong season that opens on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. What is being celebrated is not the start of either choreographer's career or their companies, but rather the beginning of a yeasty, highly productive residency at the Henry Street Settlement House on the Lower East Side.

title: Meeting Set on Medicare Changes
description: SHOULD Medicare be expanded to cover prescription drugs? Should premiums be set on a sliding scale based on income? Should the eligibility age be kept at 65 or raised to 67 or lowered to 63? Should beneficiaries be enrolled in managed care? Should taxes be increased to pay for the increased cost of Medicare? Should payments to medical providers be further reduced?

title: Bartok and Stravinsky: Odd Couple Reunited?
description: ''I NEVER could share his lifelong gusto for his native folklore,'' said Igor Stravinsky of Bela Bartok in 1959. And what is more, ''I couldn't help regretting it in the great musician.'' Stravinsky was seeking distance from a composer with whom, he felt, he was too often compared. On Wednesday and Friday evenings, the Hungarian pianist Andras Schiff, the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra bring their countryman and the latter's unwilling Russian counterpart back together at Carnegie Hall, setting Bartok's three piano concertos in what the performers evidently consider their proper Stravinskian context. It's about time.

title: Things That Go Pop In the Night
description: The gourmet soda bottle gets a new spin. Oop! Juice is introducing Ghoulade, a sugary, black lemon-flavored soda, in time for Halloween. It is the latest addition to the groaning shelf of boutique sodas vying for attention with bright colors, exotic flavors and gimmicks galore. Stewarts, famed for its root beer, has sodas in flavors like Key Lime Pie. And this summer, Jones Soda had a limited edition of bottle labels showing Armani models drinking the stuff. Oop! Juice, based in Rhode Island, will have 10 holiday sodas, including Turkey Slurpy, a super-sweet cranberry soda for Thanksgiving, and Gefiltefizz, a blueberry soda the color of Windex for Hanukkah. ''To stay competitive, we really have to be creative when it comes to marketing our product,'' said Jennifer Neuguth, who owns the company with her husband, David Riordan. The labels have cartoonish characters, from Shirl, a superhero, to Madcapper, a villain. Information, (800) 281-4147. KIMBERLY STEVENS

title: For Japanese Tourists, It's First Stop Las Vegas
description: WHERE have all the Japanese tourists gone? To Las Vegas.

title: Molding Our Lives in the Image of Movies
description: NEARLY 160 years ago, Alexis De Tocqueville observed that Americans lacked an appreciation for what he called the ''pleasures of mind.'' Instead, he wrote, they ''prefer books which may be easily procured, quickly read, and which require no learned researches to be understood. They ask for beauties self-proffered and easily enjoyed. . . . They require strong and rapid emotions, startling passages, truths or errors brilliant enough to rouse them up and to plunge them at once, as if by violence, into the midst of the subject.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FINANCIAL DISTRICT

title: Battery Reminder
description: Standard time resumed at 2 A.M. today; clocks should have been set back an hour.

title: Rhapsody in Black and White
description: 'If the African-American influence had not been in Gershwin's music, Gershwin would basically be part of the big blur of those guys who wrote the standards,'' says the jazz pianist and composer Herbie Hancock. ''He'd be another Jerome Kern or Cole Porter.'' That wouldn't necessarily have been a bad thing, of course. But George Gershwin's legacy of cross-culturalism seems to carry special weight with contemporary jazz artists -- particularly Hancock, who so admires Gershwin that he dedicated much of the past year to a prodigious recording project in the composer's honor. Titled ''Gershwin's World,'' the CD is epic in sweep and impact, a commanding exploration of Gershwin's place at the heart of 20th-century American music and a touchstone affirmation of Hancock as the composer's proudest heir.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Boutique Baby for the Old Grande Dame?
description: The 113-year-old St. George Hotel at 100 Henry Street, near Clark Street, was once the city's grandest and largest hotel, with more than 2,000 rooms. But some of the once-elegant eight-building complex has fallen into disrepair over the last two decades, and part of it was destroyed by fire three years ago.

description: ROGERS-Raymond J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Raymond J. Rogers, associated with The Times from 1954, until retiring in 1983.

description: European leaders welcomed Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, at a lakeside summit meeting in the Alps today and praised this week's agreement on Israeli withdrawal from additional Palestinian territory as a triumph for President Clinton.

description: CITY? Suburb? Seaside? Howard Beach has something of each.

title: October 18-24; A Little Respect For the Commander in Chief
description: By now in the Lewinsky matter, there is very little bad that has not been said about President Clinton. Already the butt of late-night television jokes and talk-radio scorn, his reputation took a new drubbing in Minnesota when Paula Jones's appeal of her dismissed sexual-harassment lawsuit rehashed some of the more sordid accusations.

title: The Hissing of a Living Legend
description: Mitchell complains that her music is played infrequently (if at all) on radio, MTV or VH1. The reason Mitchell's music is not played is simple: These outlets are there to make money. Good or bad, radio stations program music according to playlists based upon sales. MTV and VH1 are basically 24-hour commercials for artists, and they, too, are guided by consumer taste and sales. They are (supposedly) giving consumers what they want. Outside of a small fan base, there is not a lot of interest in her work.

title: Yankee Museum
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Misfortune of Hedge Funds Is Converted Into Bargains
description: THE fallout from the recent hedge-fund eruptions continues to waft into the nooks and crannies of the financial markets. One asset class caught in the downdraft is convertible bonds, which according to the Credit Suisse First Boston Convertible Securities Index, have fallen 21.5 percent since April 30.

title: Koreas Take A First Step To Work Out Formal Peace
description: The United States, China and the two Koreas, in a third round of negotiations, agreed today on a first step toward the long-range goal of permanent peace on the divided peninsula.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORDETSKY, HARVEY
description: MORDETSKY-Harvey. Birthday remembrances of a good and decent man, my best friend. Russell

title: Word for Word/www.taliban.com; Allah Is Good. Technology Is Bad. Visit Our Web Site.
description: THE Taliban hard-liners who rule most of Afghanistan are arguably the world's most vociferous enemies of modern technology. When they aren't busy enforcing the rules that prohibit females from leaving their homes unveiled or unaccompanied by a close male relative, the Taliban religious police roam neighborhoods searching for radios, TV's, VCR's, phonographs, satellite dishes or computers, which are promptly destroyed while the owners are arrested.

title: University Presses; Tabloid Philosopher
description: MAX LERNER

title: It's About Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Weighing Home Security Measures
description: MANY homeowners become complacent about home security because they feel they have nothing worth stealing. What these homeowners fail to realize is that the majority of burglars have no way of knowing what is inside a home. Most break in hoping to get lucky. Given enough time, a burglar will try to make his own luck by tearing into a house, ripping apart upholstery, breaking up cabinets and tearing pictures from the walls looking for salable items.

title: Trip-Hop Reinvents Itself to Take on the World
description: WHEN Massive Attack came on the British dance-music scene in 1991 with its debut album, ''Blue Lines,'' the group's bass-heavy beats and brooding spirit of introspection became the sonic blueprint for trip-hop. A studio-concocted blend of hip-hop, ambient techno and reggae that set the tone for fellow Bristol artists like Portishead and Tricky, trip-hop seemed ideally suited to our globally aware, culturally fragmented times. Spawned by the latest recording technologies, yet resolutely human in its message, it was steeped in the ironic film-noir paranoia of 60's spy movies and apocalyptic angst.

title: Deaths in Argentina Feed a Taste for Conspiracy
description: The brother of a former aide to President Carlos Saul Menem was found hanging from a rope early this month with a newspaper clipping about a bribery scandal involving the Government and I.B.M. stuffed in his mouth.

title: Julia Moore, Richard Burke Jr.
description: Julia Peery Moore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Moore of North Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Francis Burke Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. G. Kerry Robb performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Msgr. John F. Casey, a cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the service.

title: 'Bech at Bay'
description: BECH HAD A NEW SIDEKICK. Her monicker was Robin. Rachel "Robin" Teagarten. Twenty-six, post-Jewish, frizzy big hair, figure on the short and solid side. She interfaced for him with an IBM PS/1 his publisher had talked him into buying. She set up the defaults, rearranged the icons, programmed the style formats, accessed the ANSI character sets--Bech was a stickler for foreign accents. When he answered a letter, she typed it for him from dictation. When he took a creative leap, she deciphered his handwriting and turned it into digitized code. Neither happened very often. Bech was of the Ernest Hemingway save-your-juices school. To fill the time, he and Robin slept together. He was seventy-four, but they worked with that. Seventy-four plus twenty-six was one hundred; divided by two, that was fifty, the prime of life. The energy of youth plus the wisdom of age. A team. A duo.

A pre-concert lecture by Richard Price begins at 4.

description: DANA REEVE said the reality of her Broadway debut last Thursday first hit home a few weeks ago when workers at the Eugene O'Neill Theater were installing the marquee for ''More to Love: A Big Fat Comedy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACOMBER, JEAN
description: MACOMBER-Jean. Died on Sunday, October 18th at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Connecticut. She was 95. Daughter of Alexander Brough, Jr. and Alice Southworth Macomber Brough, sister of John A. Brough, Miss Macomber is survived by her nephew and godson John A. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of Andra Sanders and Linda Murray (Stephen). Cherished grandfather of Gordon and Cara Murray. His warmth, humor and love for his wife, children and grandchildren will be sorely missed. Services graveside Monday, 10/26/98, 2 PM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association. RiversideGordon Memorial Chapel, Hollywood, FL. 800-759-1151.

She was loved and will be missed by everyone who knew her. A Memorial Mass will be held on Wednesday, October 28, 1998 at 4:00 PM at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 E. 14 St., NY City. Robert C. Della Rocca, MD, Chairman, Medical Board Joseph P. Corcoran, President and CEO

title: Fiendish Contacts
description: Oozing flesh wounds. Cumbersome bloody stumps. Itchy facial hair. No need for such messy, unconvincing disguises. Wesley Jessen, a company that has long supplied the film industry with freaky contact lenses (remember Jack Nicholson's lupine eyes in ''Wolf''?), has a line of special-effects lenses that allow everyday masqueraders to outscare the competition on Halloween. Wild Eyes come in eight varieties, from Hypnotica, which is your basic Hitchcockian spiral, to the unnerving Red Hot, which turns eyes into flaming globes.

title: Spano Submits Budget For Capital Projects
description: YES, to a promised $5 million toward open-space acquisition, no (for now) to $25.5 million for construction at the County Penitentiary. Yes, too, to money for technology, new buses and renovation of the County Office Building.

title: INVESTING WITH: Dennis M. Bein and Harindra de Silva; PBHG Advisor Defensive Equity Fund
description: IT is hardly surprising that people scratch their heads over a mutual fund like PBHG Advisor Defensive Equity. The fact that it gets 30 percent of its returns from options summons up notions of all kinds of derivatives-fueled volatility. Yet the fund, with $51.2 million in assets, is actually a tame offering. Indeed, it has not posted a loss in 20 years.

title: Consumers Discover The Wines of Spain
description: LUNCH with an importer of Spanish wine, Jose Ramon Gude, can last until 3 A.M. At a recent impromptu lunch and wine tasting at Tempranillo, one of the largest importing concerns of Spanish wines in the New York City area, Mr. Gude, the owner and president, offered a group of customers, friends and his delivery man a selection of wines to accompany Spanish-style crab cakes and lamb.

description: Stock prices plowed ahead last week, helped by a number of better-than-expected third-quarter earnings reports and a widely held belief that the Federal Reserve Board will push interest rates even lower.

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Fiction
description: THE LOSS

title: Why the Women Are Fading Away
description: I covered Connecticut state government in the 1970's, and I can still remember how wonderful the women were. I'm not really thinking about Ella Grasso, the first woman-elected-in-her-own-right Governor -- Grasso still seemed more like a traditional pol with an extra X chromosome. The women I really admired were the state legislators, those battle-scarred survivors of charter-revision and zoning boards who waded diligently through important but utterly unglamorous issues like special education and ambulance regulation. They seemed miraculously devoid of ego. Next to them, the men looked like squalling children (albeit children who had all the real political power). I couldn't wait until the women moved up, so they could run the whole country the way they ran the subcommittee on inland wetlands.

title: After the Fall: Only the Weaver Knows for Sure
description: ''SO how's my favorite hair floozy?'' my friend Jonathan asked, tweaking a hank of the two-foot-long blond ponytail that lay across my shoulders like a particularly well-behaved ferret. The floozy shrugged, and $4,000 worth of the finest Nordic hair splayed across her back. I mean my back. But whose hair? Because what was now shedding lightly on Jonathan's velvet couch did not spring from my own head, and it was no Dynel pup.

description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Spirits
description: When the new Westside light-rail line opened in Portland, Ore., last month, the transit authority was quite proud of the Washington Park Station -- at 260 feet below ground, the deepest depot in North America. Some members of the region's Asian communities were outraged, however, because part of the tunnel ran under a cemetery -- bad luck. ''Life is out of balance there,'' says Ronault L.S. Catalani, a Javanese-American who believes buried spirits have been disturbed.

title: A Budget We Should Be Ashamed Of
description: In the 266 calendar days of the session that officially ended on Wednesday, the 105th Congress passed only four of the 13 appropriations bills that keep the Government functioning. Then, on the 267th day, we debated and passed a 4,000-page, 40-pound, nonamendable budget that gives half a trillion dollars to finance 10 Cabinet-level departments for the fiscal year that started 25 days ago.

title: Literary Fireworks
description: To the Editor:

title: Curators of Ballet, From the Classic To the Brand-New
description: IN its early days, publicists for American Ballet Theater frequently called it ''a museum of the dance.'' That remains a good phrase to describe the company, provided one realizes that great museums can encourage new art as well as preserve old.

title: In a Switch, Unions Begin Recognizing Republican Allies
description: In the 1996 campaign, organized labor's approach toward the Republican Party could best be described as all-out war, but judging from Tony Speelman's enthusiastic calls on behalf of a Long Island Republican, Representative Michael P. Forbes, labor's approach has evolved considerably.

title: BASEBALL: An Emotional Season Plays Out; A Look at the Yankees' Championship Run Through the Eyes of David Cone
description: David Cone strolled into the Yankees' clubhouse before Friday's parade and saw Darryl Strawberry talking with other teammates, less than three weeks after undergoing surgery for the removal of a cancerous tumor in his colon. Feelings that Cone has had difficulty containing in the last month welled within him again.

title: Taking a Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Turtle Watch in Costa Rica
description: WE were standing at the edge of the Pacific Ocean in northwestern Costa Rica, looking down a three-mile sweep of tropical beach along the Pacific shore. The sun was hot, the sand blindingly bright, and the waves ideal for bobbing or body surfing. But perfect as it seemed, our family wasn't here for the beach. We had come to see leatherback turtles.

title: An Unpretentious Chef Has Many Fans
description: Husbands held hands with wives and children, clutching cookbooks and waiting for hours to get a few seconds with their idol, the self-appointed ambassador to pork fat, Emeril Lagasse.

title: Paying for Dirty Diesels, Searching for Cleaner Fuel
description: The seven largest makers of heavy diesel engines, accused by the Environmental Protection Agency of cheating on emissions tests for a decade, settled the case by agreeing to pay a total of $1 billion, fix old engines as they are overhauled and design new engines that meet tighter standards. Caterpillar and Cummins Engine will pay the most in the settlement. . . . Hunting for ways to keep their ever-larger light trucks in compliance with Federal emissions and fuel economy standards, the Big Three auto makers are looking at equipping them with more efficient diesel engines and have quietly begun working with oil companies to develop a new synthetic diesel-like fuel that they hope will burn as cleanly as gasoline. . . . An obscure clause in the new Federal spending law allows truck and bus fleet operators to satisfy Government requirements that part of their fleets run on alternative energy sources by burning ''biodiesel'' fuel made with soy oil in ordinary engines, saving the cost of buying new vehicles.

title: Inner Peace, Empowerment and Host Worship
description: WHAT little I know of the human heart and the human mind I learned long ago from television. Programming back then was black-and-white, as seemed the world it purported to represent. These were the early 60's, before there was much educational television per se, and grade-school squirts like me were left to sort things out for ourselves. Commercials of that era were particularly helpful in this regard, rendering the best and worst of our mutual experience in schematic diagrams that even children could understand. Hence my ardent lifetime conviction that the brain is shaped like a tiny anvil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, JOAN
description: SOLOMON-Joan. The Board of Directors of the Tranquillity Alumni acknowledges with deepest sorrow the passing of our beloved friend and fellow Tranquillity-ite, Joan Solomon. ''Joanie'' was a hard working Board member and lifelong supporter of Camp Tranquillity. Together with her husband Joe, she worked tirelessly to the benefit of the Camp and its Campers. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Joe; children, Barbara and Nolan, Susan and Lenny; precious grandchildren, David and Alyssa; and devoted sister, Irene. Joanie's infectious smile, hearty laugh and warmth will be forever in our memories. Tranquillity Alumni, Inc.

title: Nassau Villages Fight for Zoning Rights
description: ''TAXATION without representation,'' the Mayor of Atlantic Beach calls it, knowing a trustworthy rallying cry when he hears one. But ''zoning without representation'' would be a more accurate slogan for his village's fight against the Town of Hempstead.
