description: After a hard frost in the markets, an Indian summer of corporate finance: With the Dow well back up in the 8,000's again, big deals suddenly are as ubiquitous as pumpkins.

title: Charles Schumer for Senator
description: The New York Senate race this year is one of those rare contests in which it is a pleasure to take sides. The incumbent Republican, Alfonse D'Amato, is a strong campaigner and a powerful politician who knows how to get things done. But his opponent, Representative Charles Schumer, is a more serious lawmaker with more rooted values, sounder policy positions and a deeper commitment to the common good. The chunks of pork Mr. D'Amato boasts of bringing home are no fair exchange for the damage he does with his impulsive style and devotion to special interests. New York deserves a senator who will grow in gravitas, not just in volume. The state needs a senator who hearkens to the yearnings of the average citizen rather than to the demands of contributors and his party's ideologues.

description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer met last night in their first debate, a tense and uneasy standoff in which Mr. D'Amato hammered Mr. Schumer for his attendance record in Congress, while Mr. Schumer portrayed Mr. D'Amato as an untrustworthy legislator who had embarrassed New York and repeatedly voted with Republicans against the state's interests.

title: Police Doubt Robbery Is Tied To Other Central Park Attacks
description: The police said yesterday that they saw no connection between an armed robbery on Friday night in Central Park and other robberies at knifepoint that have occurred in the same general area over the last month. But detectives had developed evidence, they said, that some of the other attacks may be the work of one or two prolific assailants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, RUSSELL CONWELL
description: NEWHOUSE - Russell Conwell. Age 91 of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, died at home Thursday. A native of Clyde, OH, Mr. Newhouse was awarded the Bachelor of Electrical Engineering and Master of Science in Electrical Engineering degrees from Ohio State University. Mr. Newhouse made notable contributions to defense electronic systems, television, radar, computers, navigation aids and air traffic control systems. Husband of the late Clara Lucile Scovell, Mr. Newhouse is survived by his wife, the former Jane Davies, his son Alan, three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Julie Flaherty, John Livingstone
description: Julie Blackburn Flaherty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Flaherty Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to John Thomas Livingstone, a son of Patricia M. Livingston of Excelsior, Minn., and the late John D. Livingston. The Rev. Joseph P. McGarry performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter Claver in West Hartford.

title: Island's Only Dairy Rises From Fire's Ashes
description: CHARLENE COSMAN stood on a milk crate on a neighbor's lawn last October and looked at the remains of her family's dairy, which had burned to the ground the night before. Many of her employees stood with her, some weeping, and it was then that she made them a promise: Help us rebuild and I'll make sure no employee loses a job because of the fire.

title: This Brand of Soccer Mom Wears Cleats
description: THIS is not about soccer moms cheering from the sidelines, piling little tykes in cleats and shinguards into the backs of minivans and admonishing them not to get mud on the upholstery. It's not about carpooling from soccer game to drum practice to tennis lessons on Saturday afternoon and then shuttling back to soccer practice on Sunday.

title: Economic Development
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano has formed a public-private partnership to keep and expand existing businesses in Westchester and attract new ones.

title: Pier Developers Look Toward Harlem
description: ON a recent Friday afternoon, a beam of sun cast a glow on Rover Green's face, as his fishing line tightened under an unseen weight in the Hudson River. Mr. Green has been fishing on the esplanade at the western edge of 125th Street for the past 20 years, arriving most days about 3 P.M., after he gets off work as a building manager, and heading home to 127th Street a few hours later.

title: Evelyn Dillon, Joseph Reed

The family requests that donations in her memory be sent to The Boys Choir of Harlem, Inc., 2005 Madison Ave., New York, N.Y. 10035, in lieu of flowers.

title: Mideast Marathon: How 9 Days of Talks Ended in 'the Long Night'
description: What participants at the Wye River Middle East conference call the Long Night -- the all-night stand from Thursday to Friday during which an agreement was finally clinched, or almost clinched -- opened with the second crisis.

title: Parcells Is Counting On the Good Jets to Make Repeat Appearance
description: Keith Byars, who has been there with the Eagles, the Dolphins and the Patriots, was trying to explain to the Jets what this winning thing is all about. Welcome to the club, Keith. Even Byars's coach, Bill Parcells, does not know what he has with this team.

title: A Thrift Shop Moves on the Upper East Side
description: To many, the two Spence-Chapin Thrift Stores are as well known on the Upper East Side as the Spence and Chapin Schools. (But there is no abiding relationship between the stores and the schools.) One shop will move tomorrow, to 1473 Third Avenue (between 83d and 84th Streets), a block from its old location on Third Avenue near 82d Street. Spence-Chapin Services' other store is at 1850 Second Avenue, near 95th Street.

title: A Survivor's Salute to a Holocaust Heroine
description: A MARTYR in Israel, where her name and her diaries are as epochal as Anne Frank's, Hannah Senesh (the phonetic spelling of Szenes) is not a household heroine in America, even though the young woman, who was obsessed with smuggling Jews and British prisoners of war out of Nazi-occupied Hungary, has been the subject of various books, a play and a film.

title: VW Day
description: Posner's essay is not about burying the past, though he would like to think so. Posner saw himself as a man of principles, reproving his friends for their failings. Along comes a hot little number, winking its headlights at him, and suddenly his principles seem old-fashioned. It is an old story indeed -- the spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.

title: On Ballots: Racing and Trash
description: How much open space, at what cost, is a big question that New Jersey voters will be asked next month. But it's not the only one.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page of Sunday Styles last week with a report about a reception to benefit the Smithsonian Institution's Archives of American Art misidentified a guest. He was Arthur A. Feder, not James R. Gaines.

Dear brother of George, Sylvia Eisen, Betty Yesner and the late Harvey, and also survived by his extended family of Robert and Steve Baum. Private graveside service. Family will be received at the home of his daughter Phyllis.

title: A California Vote Could Rewrite U.S. Electric Bills
description: AS political rallies go, it wasn't much: a knot of about 20 people standing in front of a Pacific Gas and Electric Company office in this small city about 90 miles north of Sacramento. Passers-by ignored the signs they waved, placards that supported a proposition on the California ballot on Nov. 3 intended to upend deregulation of the state's utilities and sharply cut electric rates for residential and small-commercial customers.

description: JOHN GRANDE has a lot on his mind, as usual.

title: Ideas & Trends: Giving Outrage a Face; Breaking a Taboo, Editors Turn to Images of Death
description: ONE spring afternoon in 1994, a University of Wyoming freshman was shot in the head at point-blank range and left to die. A day or two later, The Laramie Daily Boomerang shoved the event in the community's face, printing a front-page photograph of the young man's body as it lay near his dormitory. The figures of police officers partly blocked the view. But only partly.

title: The Champ

title: Dr. Doom to Bankers: There You Go Again
description: As chief economist at Salomon Brothers in the late 1970's and early '80's, Henry Kaufman was known on Wall Street as ''Dr. Doom'' for his dire predictions about government deficits and interest rates. Those forecasts, which often summoned jeers from his more optimistic peers, clearly earned more for him than notoriety. Last week, Dr. Kaufman gave $10 million to the Stern School of Business at New York University, where he is chairman of the board of overseers. Part of the money will pay for the expansion of the newly renamed Henry Kaufman Management Education Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, GEORGE S. TRUMBULL, CT.
description: SHERMAN-George S. Trumbull, CT., on October 22, 1998 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. Husband of Davette Cohen Sherman. Father of Stacey Sherman, Keith and Karen Sherman, Brett & Kim Sherman. Brother of Eileen Trager, and grandfather of Austin Louis Sherman. He fought a courageous battle for 21 years, and will be greatly missed. Services Sunday 1 P.M. from Abraham L. Green and Son, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: Sex Advice for the Clinton Age
description: I've been waiting for The Times to publish an article like Rebecca Johnson's, and hope it will foster an urgently needed national discussion on sexuality beyond the Clinton-Lewinsky debacle (Oct. 4). In this country, public -- and I suspect private -- attitudes toward sex are naive, hypocritical, misinformed and hedged round with taboos. The Government's and the news media's responses to Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky are far more disturbing than the relationship itself.

title: A REMINDER
description: Standard time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set back one hour.

title: GT: The Sport Is Skin Deep
description: LIKE the weekend jogger who plods in designer Spandex and $150 shoes, the Grand Am GT strikes an athletic pose. The front and rear fascias are even more aggressive than the SE's; there is a wide-open air dam so the Ram Air system can breathe freely; thick ribs run up and down the body-side cladding; low-profile tires clench 16-inch wheels, and the exhaust rumbles a bit through four outlets.

title: Lynne Schiffman, Robert Delise
description: Lynne Allison Schiffman, the daughter of Jill and John T. Schiffman of Hanover, N.H., was married there yesterday to Robert Michael Delise, the son of Joan M. Delise and Dr. Claudio M. Delise of Hingham, Mass. Justice Albert D. Leahy of the Claremont (N.H.) District Court officiated at the Rollins Chapel at Dartmouth College.

title: Weather Contract
description: International Business Machines has been selected by the National Weather Service to build a supercomputer to improve the agency's national weather and climate-forecasting capabilities. The supercomputer -- an IBM RS/6OOO SP -- is more than 10 times more powerful than the system used during Deep Blue's 1997 chess victory over Garry Kasparov, a grand master.

title: EVENING HOURS
description: For Research, Arts and More Benefits with a serious bent.

description: Because the Village of Freeport has been given the loan of an electric car for one month by the New York Power Authority, the public might think that the transition from gas- to electric-powered vehicles is at hand [''Freeport Test Drives Electric Car,'' Oct. 11].

description: 'Hello, James Gleick,'' said the Amazon.com Web site the other day. (Click here if you're someone else.) ''Take a peek at your brand-new music recommendations.''

title: It's Pumpkin Season in the Squash Patch
description: PUMPKINS are everywhere. In fields, by entryways, stacked at garden center gates or piled by the roadside farm stand. It's the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEE, DR. MARGARET ANDERSON
description: McKEE-Dr. Margaret Anderson, 90, died Oct 19, 1998, in Carthage, IL. Preceded in death by husband Orrin E. Anderson in 1972. She was graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1928 and from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1932. She spent most of her life in Riverdale, NY, where she practiced pediatric medicine for 32 years with offices in Manhattan and Riverdale, and was affiliated with St. Luke's Hospital, New York City. In 1971 she retired to the family home in Carthage, IL. Surviving are two daughters Laura Anderson of St. Louis, MO and Martha Lou Anderson of Carthage, IL, and a niece, Edythe McKee of Stamford, CN.

title: Arlene Silverman, Arthur Handler
description: Justice Arlene Roberta Silverman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan was married last evening to Arthur M. Handler, a lawyer. Justice Robert L. Cohen of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: The Hissing of a Living Legend
description: Neil Strauss's profile of Joni Mitchell depicts a self-absorbed individual who appears never to have grown out of a particularly narrow 1960's identity that was reprehensible even 30 years ago (Oct. 4). The true heroes of Mitchell's life are the adoptive parents of her 30-something daughter, whom she met a year and a half ago. The people who raised her daughter appear to merit barely a bump in Mitchell's autobiography. She does, however, note that her daughter ''hasn't forgotten about them.'' Nor should we. After all, they did free up the artist to give us ''Big Yellow Taxi,'' and where would we be without that?

title: Laura Jehl and Michael Cicero
description: Laura Elizabeth Jehl and Michael John Cicero were married yesterday by the Rev. Raymond F. Schmidt at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Palm Springs
description: Albert Einstein loved Palm Springs. On his retreats there in the 30's, he'd rise at dawn and stroll in his slippers through the ancient rock canyons and voluptuous palm groves of the Coachella Valley. It was, by all accounts, a happy place for him. One night, he even grabbed a violin and astonished dinner guests at El Mirador with an impromptu performance under the desert moon.

title: POSTINGS: Two-Families for Soundview; 25 Homes On 3 Blocks
description: Construction is to start in December on the first market-rate, two-family home development in the Soundview section of the Bronx in nearly 25 years.

description: WORKING WITH EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE By Daniel Goleman. 383 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $25.95.

description: THERE'S an iron law of history that decrees, given enough time and sufficient scarcity, anything from broken crockery to petrified dinosaur droppings will become a precious relic.

title: Germany's New Face: Age 22, at Threshold of Change
description: A newly elected Government and a new capital have promoted much talk of ''a new Germany,'' and here, in a very old German town, may be found the newest face of all.

description: CIRKER-Minette. 10/24/86. In loving memory of my dear Minette. Forever in my mind. Sadly missed. ''Rest my sweet darling.'' Stanley

title: Hooray for Gaultier!
description: The genius of Jean Paul Gaultier's fall couture collection was its splendid ordinariness. While others presented costumes and called it high fashion, Gaultier set his sights on the everyday. He took a trench coat and made it a ball gown. A Fair Isle sweater was reinvented entirely from feathers. The critics applauded his ingenuity, his Frenchness, his wit. Hooray for Gaultier, they chimed. France has been saved!

title: Britannia's Gangplank Lowers for the People
description: Over the years, world leaders like Nelson Mandela, Tony Blair and Mahatma Gandhi have been entertained aboard the Britannia, the luxurious vessel used by Queen Elizabeth and her family around the world. Tomorrow the 412-foot yacht, which has recently been refurbished, will be opened to the public for tours at the port of Leith, two miles from the center of Edinburgh.

title: October 18-24; The Yankees (and Baseball) Win
description: David Cone, the veteran pitcher, found himself hoarding newspapers after the New York Yankees ended their extraordinary season with a World Series sweep of the San Diego Padres. ''I'm curious to see what everyone is saying about us and how we stack up'' in history, Cone said.

title: All the Right Moves Made by Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Lifetime of Knowing What's Next
description: BEFORE I start examining their edges and undersides, let me lay my cards on the table. Harvey Lichtenstein -- who turns 70 next spring and who recently announced his retirement, effective June 30, after 31 years as head of the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- has been the most innovative and influential performing arts administrator New York has known.

description: ASIA'S economic turmoil is having a ripple effect on the New Jersey commercial marketplace, where a number of Japanese and Korean companies are selling buildings they own.

title: In a Museum, Market Artifacts and Lots of Perspective
description: RUSSIA defaults on its obligations, the Dow Jones industrial average swoons, markets around the world bounce around like yo-yos. Yet this Wall Streeter exudes calm. And why not? He takes a somewhat longer view.

description: The countdown is set to begin tomorrow morning for a space flight that will not make history or any new heroes but has everything to do with history and an aging hero, John Glenn.

description: PARENTS of the Upper West Side, beware. ''This Is Our Youth'' is back.

description: At one point during today's round, when the humidity was rising, Davis Love 3d turned to someone in the gallery and said, ''It's getting pretty warm out here.''

title: Halloween, the Best Time to Be Someone Else
description: A LARGE young man, considerably more than six feet tall and bulked up like a football defensive guard, walked into a retail establishment in the South End of Hartford a few days ago and casually inquired about getting some vampire teeth.

title: An Island in a Sea of Calm
description: ONE of the great joys of traveling to the Caribbean in winter is being able to shovel out of East Coast snow in the morning, and be on the beach that afternoon. Unfortunately, once you get there, you're likely to find hordes of people who have done exactly the same thing.

description: PAUL MARCHAND, F.M.C. By Charles W. Chesnutt. 144 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $20.

title: GOVERNMENT; To Victors Go Spoils? Sorry, Kids
description: The Toms River East world championship Little League team will probably long remember being on a float in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade next month. But memories are about all the team will get to keep, if they want to continue playing in Little League -- or in high school and college, for that matter.

title: Former Professor Makes Bid Against First-Term Congressman
description: Rush Holt, the Democratic challenger in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District race, was at a union dinner here when Beverly Dey, a Ewing Township secretary, asked why the age when she would be eligible for Social Security benefits had risen to 66 from 65. She thought that was unfair.

title: Urging People to Share and Dispel Their Old Sorrows
description: Though they have a common history, the Holocaust victims who gathered last week at Weis's restaurant on Coney Island Avenue did not know each other well. So to break the ice, they were asked to mark their birthplaces with pins on a map.

description: Dr. Rachel Katherine Levy and Andrew Stanley Lombara were married last evening by Rabbi Helene Ferris at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A headline with a brief item on the Private Sector page last Sunday about the efforts of Thomas T. Stallkamp, the president of the Chrysler Corporation, to learn to speak German misspelled the name of a German car. It is Porsche, not Porshe.

title: U.S. Seeks Redress for 1976 Doping In Olympics
description: The first time that Camille Wright laid eyes on East German swimmers, they were in a pool in Concord, Calif., preparing for a 1975 meet against the United States, a year before the 1976 Summer Olympic Games in Montreal.

title: October 18-24; Tyson Gets to Return To the Ring
description: Mike Tyson is back.

description: LEGAL BASES

title: Tokyo, Folksy and Affordable
description: TOKYO, a city infamous for its $15 cups of coffee and $200 cab rides from the airport, has been sitting on the back burner of my travel list for many years. I'd visited there on business in 1979, and the city had intrigued, baffled and stimulated me. Zen gardens, pachinko parlors, temples, gadgets, sumo matches, Hello Kitty -- Tokyo's quirky urban weirdness appealed to my New York sensibility. But vivid memories of the outrageous costs of my trip made me too anxious to think of attempting Tokyo without an expense account.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SERIFF, NATHAN S., M.D.
description: SERIFF-Nathan S., M.D. A tribute in honor of Nathan S. Seriff, M.D. will be held Thurs, Oct 29 at 5pm at Lenox Hill Hospital, the Einhorn Auditorium, 131 E. 76 St., New York City. He is much loved and greatly missed.

title: Rockefeller Gift
description: The state is acquiring 88 acres of new parkland in Mount Pleasant along the Hudson River from the Laurance S. Rockefeller Fund. The property, called Rockwood Hall, is one of the few large tracts of undeveloped space on the lower Hudson River and affords views south along the Hudson River to New York City and north to Bear Mountain.

title: Colonial-Era Human Remains Are Unearthed Near City Hall
description: City workers who were slogging through the mud of a broken water main near City Hall yesterday afternoon turned over spadesful of small bone shards and personal effects of New Yorkers who may have been laid to rest more than two centuries ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Guy Kawasaki, a Silicon Valley executive and entrepreneur, misstated some accomplishments of his new venture capital business, Garage.com. The company has obtained financing for one company, not eight, and has agreed to help find financing for seven other businesses.

title: Those Horror Movies That Haunt Us Still
description: There are no hockey masks, no rivers of blood, no terrified high school babes in midscream.

title: University Presses; Liberte, Egalite, Infidelite
description: Seductive Journey American Tourists in France From Jefferson to the Jazz Age. By Harvey Levenstein. Illustrated. 378 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $30.

title: History's View of the Finest
description: NEW Yorkers have long had an ambivalent relationship with their police: the heroism is often praised, but incidents of brutality, corruption and prejudice have been denounced. Through photographs, newspaper clippings, weapons, official logs, crime detection equipment and other artifacts, ''New York's Finest,'' an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society, explores the complex interaction between New Yorkers and the police, and how that interaction has been shaped over the years by specific events and demographic shifts.

title: Odd Job
description: A DANGEROUS PROFESSION

title: SOAPBOX; Tranquillity in the Outfield
description: IT'S Saturday in Central Park, late afternoon. The sunlight is fading and the crowds that had jammed the lawns and pathways earlier in the day have thinned. Autumn has arrived and there is a chill in the dusky air. By this time of year, football and soccer have firmly supplanted softball as the game of choice for most park-goers. But on a field on the north end of the Great Lawn, a ragtag group of middle-aged men and women, kids of all ages and other assorted relations and hangers-on, stubbornly and intensely continue to pursue our own, very personal field of dreams.

title: The View From/Old Lyme; Giving the Impressionists Their Due
description: JUST as a painting takes shape on canvas, what is arguably the most famous landscape in the most American style of painting is slowly re-emerging along the banks of the Lieutenant River in Old Lyme -- the lawn sweeping down to the water, willow and beech trees standing sentinel, explosively colorful flower gardens, barns that speak of country atmosphere.

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Nonfiction; Social Climbers With Claws
description: Katharine M. Rogers recognizes the paradox of the cat: though we may live for years with our beloved pet, we may never truly know it. Instead, we are led to imagine. Perhaps we see in its searching stare a ''preternatural knowledge,'' in its stealthy movements a tendency toward artifice, or in its antiauthoritarian disposition a rejection of bourgeois values. In The Cat and the Human Imagination: Feline Images From Bast to Garfield (University of Michigan, $29.95), Rogers examines the progression of our cultural understanding of the cat. Her insightful exploration, which begins with ancient Egypt and ends with the present day, attempts to explain why and how certain artists and thinkers --among them Tintoretto, Poe, Dickens, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Mark Twain, Baudelaire, Renoir and (of course) T. S. Eliot -- have embraced the image of the cat. Rogers charts the historical development of feline representations as the ''insignificant domestic animal'' becomes ''a treasured and mysterious companion.'' Her book catalogues not only artistic but also linguistic, folk and religious perspectives relating to cats. Threaded throughout are Rogers' arguments about why some people hate cats, why cats are ''successful rivals to dogs'' and why discussions of cats often ''slide automatically into comparisons with women.'' The book -- sheer catnip for the intellectual feline lover -- implies that whether we consider it a symbol of the home, a paragon of independence, an agent of evil or a cherished friend, the cat will remain in our cultural imaginings for centuries to come. Zoe Helena Rice

title: Sex Advice for the Clinton Age
description: Your article only further obscures the central theme of the Starr report and probable impeachment proceedings. To paraphase the crude Clinton 1992 campaign theme, ''It's the perjury, suborning perjury and obstruction of justice, stupid.'' Not the sex. To sensationalize and trivialize the issues demeans the significance of the constitutional process.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Changes in Latitude, Changes in Attitude
description: I have always considered myself a night person, so I suppose I should be happy this time of year, when we begin to get so much of it. But the day we convert to Standard Time makes me sad anyway -- even though we get an extra hour to sleep.

description: Despite rumblings that he is on the verge of defecting, the half-brother of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Barzan el-Takriti, who is an envoy in Geneva, has sidestepped the question.

description: WE were still using telephone party lines in the late 1960's when a mentally retarded woman in my small Midwestern town dialed information and asked for my mother's number.

title: Amy Kapatkin, Robert Poppenga
description: Dr. Amy S. Kapatkin, an assistant professor of surgery at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Howard Poppenga, an associate professor of toxicology at Penn's veterinary center in Kennett Square, Pa. Justice Daniel J. Maisano of State District Court in Kennett Square officiated at the Allam Farm House on the grounds of the veterinary center.

title: Will Everybody Go to Joe's?
description: ''ARE you on the list?''

title: Q&A/Ossie Davis; Involved in a Community Beyond Theater
description: OSSIE DAVIS'S parents actually named him Raiford Chatman Davis. As was the custom in the South at the time when he grew up, people tended to use initials, so his mother told the courthouse clerk in Clinch County, Ga., who was filing his birth record that his name was ''R. C. Davis.'' The clerk thought she said, ''Ossie Davis,'' and Mr. Davis's mother was not about to argue with a white person. Such was the beginning of a man who went on to become a famous playwright and actor.

title: After Another Arrest, an Isolated Taylor Draws Concern From His Friends
description: In recent months, the familiar ritual, sad if no longer much of a mystery, began to unfold again for Lawrence Taylor. He regularly refused to return telephone calls from friends. Even a call from Wellington Mara, the owner of the Giants, went unanswered. Taylor's withdrawal included virtually isolating himself inside his $1 million house in New Jersey.

title: After Harvests, Fields Gleaned For the Hungry
description: A tractor pulled up to a field at the Giamarese farm in East Brunswick and out tumbled two hay-wagons full of volunteers. Their aim was to glean the fields of string beans that were missed in the first harvest. This bounty, however, was meant for the needy, not the market. Stephanie Rybicki, far left, and Melissa Craco of Rutgers University dropped beans into a pail while Greg Myer worked in a nearby field of collard greens.

title: A Surprising Yale Gains Tie for Ivy Lead
description: Yale helped create a logjam atop the Ivy League today, routing Columbia by 37-14 and moving into a four-way tie for first place.

title: Streetscapes / Douglas Leigh, Sign Maker; The Man Behind Times Square's Smoke Rings
description: WHILE New York is a city of both historic buildings and historic signs, the signs have largely faded into history. But Douglas Leigh, who created many of them -- including the one that sent those Camel smoke rings wafting across Times Square -- is still very much around.

description: THE SHADE OF BLOSSOMS.

title: Sex Advice for the Clinton Age
description: The lesson to be learned from the Clinton-Lewinsky affair is not about the constraints of monogamy, but rather about the effect of continued gender inequity on the sexual politics of heterosexuals. If what ''post-feminism'' has taught young women is to be totally uninhibited about satisfying male sexual appetite, without feeling entitled to reciprocity, then an important lesson has been missed. If Lewinsky had made it clear from the start that she expected to receive as much pleasure as she gave, what became the basis of a national crisis might literally have ended before it began.

title: Burton Melvin Cross, 95, Governor of Maine
description: Former Gov. Burton Melvin Cross of Maine, a Republican who advocated states' rights, fiscal conservatism and local government responsibility, died on Thursday at his home in Augusta. He was 95.

title: Naomi Berlin, Michael Hoffman

Hoffman and Ronald S. Hoffman of Massapequa Park, N.Y. Rabbi Arnie Sleutelberg officiated at the Amway Grand Plaza Hotel in Grand Rapids.

title: Jana Pompadur, Timothy Kierstead

Rabbi Albert Sturmer officiated at Lyndhurst, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y. Msgr. Peter Conley took part in the ceremony.

title: 'Deals of the Century' In Flights to Asia
description: ASIA'S economic woes have hit that region's airlines particularly hard, and many are slashing fares in a desperate attempt to attract passengers. For example, the regular full coach fare between New York and Seoul, South Korea, this time of year is about $2,500 round trip, while full coach fare between Newark and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, is about $3,600. But bargain hunters can fly from New York to Seoul on Korean Air from $749, including five nights in a hotel, or between Newark and Kuala Lumpur for $739 on Malaysia Airlines, including four hotel nights.

title: Champion Yankees Won't Be Taking a Page from the Marlins
description: A year ago this week the Florida Marlins executed a double play unique in baseball history. First they won the World Series and then they planned the instant demolition of the World Series champions. Fortunately for baseball and its fans, that scenario will not occur this year.

title: Money Isn't Everything, Especially in Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: OPINION; Keeping Alive Our Aviation History
description: THANKS to a $250,000 community enhancement grant from Governor Pataki, a New Jersey-based squadron of vintage flight-ready aircraft will now be able to call Long Island home with the construction of a hangar at Republic Airport. With access to a legendary B-17 Flying Fortress and examples of Long Island aircraft like the Grumman Avenger, the American Museum for the Preservation of Historic Aircraft will create a strategic marketing alliance with the Cradle of Aviation Museum to project Long Island as an aviation destination with international appeal.

title: Tacking to Starboard With the Elite
description: During a pro-am regatta last year in the British Virgin Islands, Russell Coutts pulled up to the dock in his 30-foot race boat and waved everybody on board. Ten guests clambered onto the sloop, much to the chagrin of the regatta chairman, who was organizing crews of five.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE -- BUZZ; War Stories With a Slant
description: THE SETTING -- Tommy the Turk was late, and the organizers of the monthly nonfiction reading at the KGB Bar on East Fourth Street were worried. The former Communist meeting hall, with its dusty Soviet-era propaganda, was packed with academics, journalists, graduate students, diplomats and others.

title: BAAAD PREZ
description: ''Blood and sex in entertainment desensitize kids to sin all the time -- to get our message across, we have to compete with that,'' says the Rev. Keenan Roberts of the Abundant Life Christian Center in Arvada, Colo. This year, Roberts's ''Hell House'' -- a controversial haunted-house-style play staged at the church -- is finding a timely way to broach the subjects of lust and adultery. One scene takes place in the Oval Office, where an actor portraying the President is tempted by a beret-sporting Monica Lewinky look-alike. Fans watch the two surrender to demons and ''make out'' on the President's desk. Other scenes include a high-school shooting and a date rape. People apparently appreciate the rough viewing. In the last three years, Roberts has sold about 300 '''Hell House' kits'' -- $199 plans for putting on a show, including sound effects.

title: Editorial Observer; Losing the Corporate Crown
description: No man, the Bible says, can serve two masters. But it is silent on what happens when a company has two masters, each of whom is used to being the sole boss. The reality these days is that few things are more likely to mess up a merger -- either before or after it is completed -- than squabbles about the duties and prerogatives of the two erstwhile chiefs.

title: We Take You Live
description: Breaking News

title: When Men Get Cancer Of Breast
description: IT may never have occurred to most people, but men can get breast cancer, too. Although only 1 in 800 to 1,200 men will be told they have the disease, compared with 1 in 8 women, the disease is exactly the same as female breast cancer.

title: Scarlet Knights Are Swept by the Green Wave
description: Rutgers, which has been taking baby steps toward improving its program, looked across the field today at a team making giant steps.

title: It's Pumpkin Season in the Squash Patch
description: PUMPKINS are everywhere. In fields, by entryways, stacked at garden center gates or piled by the roadside farm stand. It's the season.

title: The Crude Face of Global Capitalism
description: I worked at Freedom House, a human rights organization, in Baku between 1995 and 1996. It was a fascinating experience. Jeffrey Goldberg aptly depicts what ''Bakintsy'' (residents of Baku) commonly refer to as ''the intrigues'' (Oct. 4). Think of Orson Welles's movie ''The Third Man,'' and you get a rough idea of how this environment operates.

title: But Is It Art?
description: Maria Morris Hambourg is correct in playing down the potential for eroticism in Julia Margaret Cameron's photograph of her maid as ''Sappho.'' However, the allusive title owes less to literature than to the iconographic tradition of Sappho, who has been a favorite subject of artists since her ''portrait'' was first published by Fulvio Orsini in 1570. Cameron's maid, with her hair pulled back, does in fact sport a remarkable ''Greek Profile,'' the principal trait by which artists and art lovers have identified presumed likenesses of the famous poet.

title: Honoring, Yes, the Jewish Athlete
description: From his apartment near Central Park, Shel Wallman puts out a publication dedicated to that reputedly rare species -- the Jewish athlete.

title: Hair Today, Gone Pretty Soon
description: Simply put, the point of Vanishing Point is to zap unwanted body hair into oblivion. There must be a lot of unwanted hair out there, because it can take three months to schedule a session at the first Vanishing Point studio, which opened in January at 4 West 16th Street in Chelsea.

title: A Long American History With Drugs and Alcohol
description: FROM a wake-up cup of coffee to an afternoon cocktail to smoking a cigarette, many people depend on chemical substances for a lift. Thus the reason for ''Altered States: Alcohol and Other Drugs in America,'' an exhibition at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport through Dec. 27, which takes a look at America's use of tobacco, alcohol and drugs from the early settlers' involvement in the tobacco and rum trade to today's drug and alcohol abuse concerns. The exhibition, arranged by the Strong Museum in Rochester, N.Y., gained critical acclaim and became a traveling exhibition on mood-altering temptations.
