description: Pour With Prosciutto

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADOCK, ROSABELLE J.
description: SADOCK-Rosabelle J. Beautiful and devoted wife of Jules B. Sadock. Died on October 22, 1998. She is survived by her beloved husband, her son Geoffrey, her daughter Dona, her daughter-inlaw Karen and her granddaughter Katharine. The funeral is private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: McNown and Defense Help U.C.L.A. Thwart an Upset Bid
description: U.C.L.A. 28, CALIFORNIA 16

title: Under Siege From Deer, Farms Lose Big
description: At a time when suburban communities are struggling over how to handle a huge deer population that is a real danger to motorists, not to mention backyard gardens, a survey by Rutgers University has found that deer are also a major threat to the state's cultivated farmland.

title: Reaching Out to New Partners and Audiences
description: A FORMER employee of Crossroads in New Brunswick recently recalled the early days of the country's foremost black theater company, now in its 21st season. Not yet the roomy, inviting showplace in the midst of a downtown cultural center, Crossroads was then making do in a walk-up in a converted sewing factory, now demolished.

title: Bronx Cheer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Gentle Hero Dies, and Mongolia's Innocence, Too
description: Who killed Zorig?

title: Debating 'Sore Losers' and Troubled Officers
description: Several state Senate committees considered legislation on Monday. The state Senate met for a voting session on Thursday. Here are some highlights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILEA, CARL
description: MILEA-Carl. The Board of Regents, Administration and staff of Long Island College Hospital (LICH) mourn the passing of Carl Milea, our benefactor and dear friend, and beloved husband of Regent Faye Milea. We are deeply grateful to Carl and his family for their generous support over the years, especially their contribution to the LICH Chapel. To Faye, the entire Milea family, and all of Carl's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Wren, Chairman of the Board of Regents Peter A. Kelly, Interim President Daniel D. Ricciardi, M.D., President, Medical Staff

title: Parasites Jolt Oystermen From Dreams of Bumper Crops
description: ED LANG had a good crop of oysters growing early in the summer last year, and was looking forward to a profitable harvest. He decided to give his adult oysters a chance to spawn and seed other beds where he had put down tons of oyster shells for baby oysters. But that turned out to be a mistake.

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Fiction
description: RADIANCE

title: Cleusa Millet Is Dead at 67; Nurtured Afro-Brazilian Faith
description: Cleusa Millet, a former nurse who became the spiritual leader of one of the most celebrated Candomble temples in Brazil, died on Oct. 15 in Salvador da Bahia. She was 67.

title: Too Many Cooks? Not Nearly Enough
description: ON a recent Sunday night at Le Cirque 2000, dinners were flying out of the kitchen like baseballs from a batting machine. In a matter of four hours, over 300 diners would be decadently fed, plied with wine, and sent home filled with black truffles and chocolate.

title: Elizabeth Bryant, Lenard Jacobson
description: Elizabeth Maria Bryant and Dr. Lenard Eduard Jacobson were married last evening at the Americas Society in Manhattan. Surrogate Lee L. Holzman of the Surrogate's Court of Bronx County officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMADA, MORRIS
description: HAMADA-Morris. We extend heartfelt condolences to Carl Hamada on the loss of his beloved brother. As Silver Founders of the Medical Center and supporters of the Jesselson Heart Center, Carl and Hilda have helped to fulfill the hospital's mission to heal the sick and ease the pain of the afflicted. May Carl and the entire family have warm and loving memories of this very special individual and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Sidney Adler, Treasure Lee Weinback, President, National Women's Division Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Fun and Spooky

title: Who's the Boss? In Mozart You Can't Always Tell
description: GOOD help is hard to find these days, snobs say, as if it were news. The complaint has been circulating the globe since the race first cooked up the division of labor. Like parent and child or mate and mate, master and servant make up one of the handful of stock pairs in the theater of human destinies. In the drama of all places and periods, their dance of dominance and deference has been a constant.

title: Step Aside Party Loyalty. Make Way for Incumbency.
description: AS Nov. 3 closes in, two statewide candidates in Connecticut are holding onto blowout-sized leads that pollsters and even the lucky campaigns had predicted for months would shrink in the fall frost. One is a Republican and one is a Democrat -- throwing into a cocked hat the many theories about Democratic disillusionment and, depending on the day, Republican rage or Republican backlash.

title: Surf's Way, Way Up For Skysurfing Champions
description: Two New Jersey men have become the first national champions of a daring sport called skysurfing, beating four other teams in a recent competition in Lake Elsinore, Calif.

title: Pinochet's Arrest Violates No Law; France Shirked Its Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Seigel, Edward McCabe
description: Emily Rose Seigel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jan K. Seigel of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married last evening to Edward Vincent McCabe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. McCabe of Point Lookout, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald Hahn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAREK, ADELE
description: KANAREK-Adele. Yeshiva University Women's Organization expresses its grief and sorrow upon the untimely demise of Adele Kanarek, a gracious long-time member of our organization and a National Vice President of Y.U.W.O. We extend our warmest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Irwin Kanarek, their children and grandchildren and all the family. Dinah Pinczower, National Chairman of the Board

title: Alcohol Crackdown
description: After a homecoming party in a private house in Mount Pleasant earlier this month, when two 17-year-old girls were treated at a hospital after drinking and passing out, the police said they would continue efforts to control the sale of alcohol to minors.

title: Widmer Wants to Talk; Giants Want to Talk; So, They Will Now Talk
description: The Giants will begin negotiations this week to extend the contract of middle linebacker Corey Widmer, who can become an unrestricted free agent at the end of the season. Similar talks may also ensue with defensive end Chad Bratzke, the team's other top player who is scheduled for unrestricted free agency.

title: Against Dodd, G.O.P. 'Bomb' Misfires
description: Just a few months ago, when Republicans relished the thought of tying their opponents to President Clinton, few targets were juicier than Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the President's golf buddy and friend of 30 years. The Monica Lewinsky matter was not the only reason the Republicans sensed the Senator's vulnerability. After the Republican romp of 1994, Mr. Dodd had been Mr. Clinton's choice to lead the Democratic National Committee, which later became enmeshed in an investigation of campaign fund-raising irregularities.

title: In the West Bank, Almost Zero Jubilation
description: Yasir Arafat has a tough crowd to please.

title: Teachers Try to Renew Interest in French
description: SO much for studying French to read Moliere and Voltaire, Balzac and Sartre or to be able to order Filets de Dorade sur Lit d'Epinards a la Sauce Moutarde in Paris with elan (sea bream with spinach and mustard sauce).

title: Crime
description: Matt Scudder has certainly calmed down since the old days. The life-scarred New York veteran of 13 city-wise crime novels by Lawrence Block shows up for action in EVERYBODY DIES (Morrow, $25) in a contented fog. Wry and ruminative by nature, the aging shamus hasn't entirely lost his edge, but still: he's happily married, he's been off the sauce for 16 years, he has his private investigator's license, he eats mushroom-and-tofu stroganoff (''with a big green salad''), and he carries an umbrella.

title: Ideas & Trends; Top of the World. (For Now.)
description: WILL it matter to consumers that William H. Gates isn't a nice guy?

title: The Women's Room
description: BIG GIRLS DON'T CRY

title: In the Region / Long Island; Striking a Good Deal in a High-Rent Office Market
description: LONG ISLAND'S surging commercial market has brought vacancy rates to their lowest levels in years and rental rates to their highest.

title: Jocelyn Burman, David Belluck
description: Jocelyn Holly Burman and David Lowell Belluck are to be married today by Rabbi Daniel Landes at the Standard Club in Chicago.

title: The View From/Purchase; Fond Flattery for Frank Sinatra: All the Imitators
description: START spreading the news: four Frank Sinatra sound-alikes are on their way not to New York, New York, but to the County Center in White Plains where, on Nov. 14, they will perform with the Dorsey Brothers Orchestra at the Westchester Arts Council annual gala.

title: Literary Fireworks
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hissing of a Living Legend
description: I'm all for us women looking our age, but why is it that you chose to capture Joni Mitchell on a ''bad hair day,'' with lighting so harsh that she's made to look older than she appears in person?

title: The World: Blueprint; Filling In Peace's Details Is the Painful Part
description: THE images were arresting. There they were, Ariel Sharon, who once sent the Israeli military to Beirut for Yasir Arafat's head, and Benjamin Netanyahu, who long avoided shaking the man's hand, sitting together in Maryland agreeing with the Palestinian leader on land and airports and prisoner releases.

title: Sports of The Times; On the Other Side of the River, Another Hailing of Champions
description: AS if to make sure we do not underrate the best-ever greatness from the good old days, the last player to hit .400 showed up here hours after the Yankees' Broadway parade Friday afternoon to honor an old pin-striped catcher who won more than a handful of World Series rings, and apparently never wanted his fiercest rivals to forget it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEEWEIS, RAY
description: SCHNEEWEIS-Ray. On October 24, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Teddy. Caring mother of Rochelle and Harold. Cherished grandmother of Scott, David, Richard, Karen, Beth and Michael. Loving greatgrandmother of Robert, Andrew, Rebecca, Taylor, Aaron, Emily, Hannah and Isaac. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: A Dual Show on Eyes and a Video-Face Mannequin in Nyack
description: A LODGER has moved into the Hopper House Art Center here. Clad in a black suit and a white shirt, this two-foot-tall personage stands in a dark corner, muttering, his face illuminated by a spotlight. Visitors may be taken aback by the spectacle, which is the work of Tony Oursler, but they will have been softened up by what precedes it, namely, paintings of larger-than-life eyes by Paul Bochner.

title: U.S. to Auction Land Near Las Vegas and Give State the Money
description: The Federal Government is preparing to auction 27,000 acres of public land near Las Vegas, Nev., estimated to be worth $500 million to $1 billion, with almost all of the proceeds to stay in Nevada instead of going to the Treasury.

title: ART REVIEWS; Personality on Both Sides of the Lens; Landscape From Four Directions
description: 'Harlem: The Vision'Amelie A. Wallace Gallery, State University at Old Westbury. Through Oct. 30. 876-3229.

title: Corrections
description: An article and chart on Oct. 11 in the quarterly Mutual Funds Report, part 2 of this section, about the hypothetical retirement portfolios of five money managers, misstated the portfolios' cumulative returns from July 7, 1993, to Sept. 30 of this year, and their total values on Sept. 30. The errors did not affect the portfolios' rankings. Corrected figures appear here.

title: Confidential Police Records Left Strewn About Ruined Jail
description: Reduced now to ruins, the old Essex County Jail remains a sinister and forbidding place. Its rotting doors, barely hanging, are open to anyone who wants to get in, or out. There are fissures in the corroded roof, providing some cells with views of the wide-open sky. Even empty, the dark, cavernous cellblocks evoke echoes of bedlam.

title: A Band After Haydn's Own Heart
description: SYMPHONY conductors are forever exhorting their troops to play like chamber musicians: to achieve immediate, intimate and constant communication by listening intently to one another and learning to react symbiotically. Only a few of the best ensembles, notably the Vienna Philharmonic and the Cleveland Orchestra, seem to have assimilated this style of performance as second nature through long decades of good, hard work.

title: A House of Mirrors: The Tale of Two Indexes
description: It's a market observation that may leave investors scratching their heads. Since August, the price-to-earnings ratio of the Dow Jones utilities average has tended to levitate above that of the Dow Jones industrials. As of Oct. 19, the P/E on the utilities was 22.20 percent, while that of the industrials was just 21.31 percent. Usually, industrials have a far higher P/E; according to Charles B. Carlson, co-manager of the Strong Dow 30 Value fund, that has been the case for the last seven and a half years.

title: The World: Pinochet in the Dock; Arresting a Dictator Is One Thing. Then It Gets Tough.
description: NOT so many years ago, it would have been impossible to find Genaro Arriagada on the side of Chile's former military dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Dog Comes in a Bar
description: BIG FISH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, TESSIE
description: LYON-Tessie. We note with great sadness the death of Tessie Lyon, mother of our Executive Director, Avram Lyon. The officers and staff of the Jewish Labor Committee extend our sincere condolences to Avi, father Daniel, sister Barbara Redmond, grandchildren and all family members. Lenore Miller, President

title: Bergen Freeholders Scolded On Records of Closed Meetings
description: Closed sessions permit county freeholder boards, city councils and other public bodies to discuss contracts, lawsuits and personnel matters in secret. But under the Open Public Meetings Act, the time and place of closed sessions, the subject, action taken and vote of each member must be recorded in ''reasonably comprehensible'' minutes and made public once matters are settled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, JERRY
description: FUCHS-Jerry. Passed away on October 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Jeanie Fuchs, father of Kevin and Brian Fuchs, brother of Larry and Alan Fuchs, son of Mary Fuchs. Chairman of Hunter Douglas, Inc., Jerry resided in Saddle River, NJ. Call 800-436-2656 x3552 for details about wake and funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Hackensack University Medical Center Foundation, 60 Second St, Hackensack, N.J. 07601.

title: Airports: A New Rate For Short-Term Parking
description: It's cheaper these days to make a quick stop at any of New York's major airports and to park long-term at La Guardia.

title: The Ritual of Dressing Up
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Defensive Reading
description: NOT long ago, in search of a book to accompany a trying journey, I took from my shelves a volume that had served me well before: ''A Sportsman's Notebook,'' by Turgenev, its pages still redolent of jungle rot, its stories evoking the hardest journey of my life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUONANNO, JOSEPH
description: BUONANNO-Joseph. On October 20, 1998, of NYC. Beloved father of Frances Moreno and Anthony Buonanno. Grandfather of Michael, Kevin and Nicholas Moreno. Brother of Ralph. Interment private. Hancock Funeral Home, Ltd., 215-332-1099.

title: AT THE CASINOS
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Chess on Sundays
description: The Chess column, formerly found in Science Times on Tuesday, now appears in this section. Today, page 51.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, LEONARD
description: ZIMMERMAN-Leonard, on October 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Florence, cherished father of Arnold and Ann and Joan and Steve. Adored grandfather of Toby, Jesse and Isabel and dearest brother and uncle of Irma and Bennett and Armin. He will be sorrowfully missed. Memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church, Somers, New York, November 8th at 1:30 PM.

title: Norwich Finds Tie to Lincoln
description: THE red silk banner was mere backdrop in 1860, just decoration welcoming a Republican vying for presidential nomination.

title: Plastics as Pop Art
description: REMEMBER the so-called throwaway plastic culture of the 60's? Well, no one threw it away, and 30 years later, pristine artifacts from that period are already turning up in exhibitions. The 160 objects on view in ''Pop Goes the Plastic: The Visual and Cultural Esthetic of a New Technology 1960-1975'' at the Katonah Museum of Art document the revolution in industrial design fostered by the coming of age of plastics.

title: Beating John Glenn to the Punch
description: Sixty-three years ago, his father made a perilous flight from Racine, Wis., to Brazil in an amphibious airplane nicknamed the ''Ugly Duckling,'' to look for wax-producing carnauba palm trees in the wilderness. To commemorate the event, Samuel C. Johnson, the 70-year-old chairman of the privately held S. C. Johnson & Son, took off on Thursday from the same town for the same destination with his sons, Curtis and Fisk. And they flew in a replica of the craft, a Sikorsky S-38, which Mr. Johnson said was once called a ''collection of airplane parts trying to fly in formation.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REISS, ROSE
description: REISS-Rose. October 26, 1997. We miss you more everyday. Your loving family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEHL, SEYMOUR
description: KOEHL-Seymour. On Friday, October 23. A resident of Kings Point, NY. Beloved husband of Ruth. Dear father and adored grandfather. Services today, 12 noon at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Vanguard's Tongue Twisters Will Walk the Plank
description: The Vanguard Group will change the names of 102 of its 109 mutual funds on Tuesday to make them less confusing to investors.

title: The Carver to the Crown Was a Sculptor
description: THERE could hardly be a more English artist-craftsman than Grinling Gibbons. Master Carver to the Crown, he invented a decorative style that dominated interiors in England during the late 17th century. His name is embedded in the consciousness of the nation. Windsor Castle, Hampton Court Palace, the grand country houses like Badminton, Burghley and Petworth and, of course, St. Paul's Cathedral all abound with his baroque cascades of fruit, flowers and foliage. ''There is no instance of a man before Gibbons who gave to wood the loose and airy lightness of flowers,'' wrote the collector and man of letters Horace Walpole in 1763.

title: MUSIC; The Latest of the Jazz Weirdos
description: FOR the last few years, there has been a rallying cry for weirdness in jazz. The critic Francis Davis, writing in the Atlantic Monthly in 1996, spoke for many fans when he decried the neotraditionalist movement in jazz not only for narrowing the definition of the music but for draining it of its eccentricity, a quality inextricable from the genius of Thelonious Monk, say, or Ornette Coleman, or Miles Davis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERSKO, SOPHIE
description: FERSKO-Sophie. On October 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Moe Fersko. Dear mother of Sari and Ronald Mainzer, Alan and Judy Fersko. Loving grandmother of Lynn and Brad Packer, Barry and Marci Mainzer, Greg and Tammi Fersko, and Scott Fersko. Greatgrandmother of Alison, Lauren, Lisa, Justin and Samuel. Funeral services Sunday, 10 AM, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, at 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Brazil Picking Governors In Votes Vital To Economy
description: Closing out elections that have held up action to rescue the country's faltering economy, Brazilian voters will elect governors in key states Sunday.

title: College Gets Go-Ahead for Holistic Degrees
description: AFTER examining the patient's tongue and taking his pulse at various points, Darlene Easton inserted several needles into the area surrounding his knee, while Joel Lafemina recorded his observations on a chart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAROSELLA, S. JOSEPH
description: CAROSELLA-S. Joseph The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of S. Joseph Carosella, associated with The Times from 1923, until retiring in 1972.

title: What's in a Name? A Lawsuit
description: Two arts organizations are in conflict in Brownstone Brooklyn. As attorneys for both groups negotiate over a lawsuit filed two weeks ago, local artists and art lovers are wondering what is going on.

title: PARTY PLANNING WITH: Bette Midler; From Queen of Trash to Queen of Clean
description: LIKE Ziegfeld making an inspection in size 6 Bottega Veneta flats, Bette Midler paraded through the workrooms of a set-construction studio on West 22d Street, stopping to glue a gold paillette on a floral backdrop already blooming in sequins. Pleased with the paint crew's progress, she wandered over to a worktable to try on a pair of white feather, angel-wing opera gloves last seen at a Victoria's Secret fashion show.

title: Pinochet's Arrest Violates No Law; Justice, Then Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Tales to Thrill and Chill the Young and Old
description: ''MURDER is the ultimate dramatic subject,'' E. J. Wagner said. ''Just look at Shakespeare and the Greeks. Few plays have survived for centuries without a good murder.''

title: Sushi and Tempura, With Lots of Decor
description: JAPANESE cooking has never gotten the attention some other Asian cuisines have. Yet it is still an occasion when a Japanese restaurant opens, as the arrival of Little Tokyo in Norwalk indicates.

title: University Presses; Duck!
description: FRIENDLY FIRE By Kathryn Chetkovich. 116 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. Paper, $15.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, RAY
description: LICHTENSTEIN - Ray. Yeshiva University Women's Organization expresses its grief and sorrow upon the passing of Ray Lichtenstein, a staunch, devoted member who held many important positions during her long tenure with Y.U.W.O. We extend our warmest sympathy to her daughters Gail Daitch and Diane Jacobs, brothers, Morris Sukenik, Rabbi Julius Sukenik and Aaron Sukenik, their children and grandchildren and all the family. Dinah Pinczower, National Chairman of the Board

title: 'On the Hudson's West Bank'
description: To the Editor:

title: Please Go Haunt Someone Else's House
description: HALLOWEEN is not my favorite festival. I don't like candy, I hate pumpkins and I think it's a bit late to be celebrating 5th-century B.C. Celtic superstitions on the edge of the 21st century A.D. What's more, the presiding spirit of Halloween, Samhain, Lord of Death, just doesn't sound like my kind of person.

title: Style; The French Connection
description: In the 1960's in Paris, a child named Jean Paul Gaultier stumbled upon his grandmother's corset and was so entranced that he begged to lace her up. By the time he dropped out of high school, Gaultier was a bona fide fashaholic who spent his days studying photographs of Yves Saint Laurent's tuxedos for women and daydreaming of designing something equally inventive. One day, he sent his fanciful sketches to the great couturiers of Paris, hoping to land a spot with Saint Laurent. Only Pierre Cardin called, and by then Cardin had given up space-age minidresses and go-go boots for umbrellas and neckties. So Gaultier quickly fled to Patou.

title: October 18-24; Suspicious Fires in Vail
description: Skiers who visit Vail, Colo., often rate it the best ski area in the nation. So the stakes seemed clear after a series of fires there that destroyed a luxury restaurant, a picnic shelter and the ski patrol headquarters on Vail Mountain -- all of the blazes erupting in linear sequence. Suspicions immediately focused on the possibility of an act of vengeance against Vail Resorts, a corporate giant resented by local residents because it has been acquiring huge parts of the local ski trade. Gov. Roy Romer called the fires ''terrorism,'' and the F.B.I. and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were called in to investigate, since the fires took place on United States Forest Service land.

title: Documenting the Life of a Musical Master
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN was a hero in my home,'' Susan Lacy said. ''I cried every day making the film. He was so emotional for me.''

title: Mary Louise Eller And James Ball
description: Mary Louise Seely Eller and James Arthur Ball were married yesterday at the Roaring Gap Church in Roaring Gap, N.C. The Rev. William J. Danaher performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERTSEN, ELEANOR C.
description: LAMBERTSEN-Eleanor C. A Memorial service for Dr. Eleanor C. Lambertsen, former Dean of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing, Senior Associate Hospital Director and Director of Nursing Services at The New York Hospital, will be held on Tuesday, November 3, 1998, at 4:30 p.m. at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, Uris Auditorium, 1300 York Avenue, at 69th St in Manhattan.

title: Smatter of Faith
description: Critics tactfully absorbed Joan Crawford as the heroine of Rachel Crowther's Broadway hit, SUSAN AND GOD (1940), about a shallow socialite who dabbles in religion. The actress once commented to me about her portrayal of the Gertrude Lawrence Broadway role: ''I got off lucky in that one. It could have been worse; the reviews weren't bad.'' Most critics felt the screen version slipped by with no noticeable damage to anyone. The cast includes Fredric March as Crawford's husband, Rita Quigley as her daughter and some very notable supporting players, like Rita Hayworth, Ruth Hussey, Rose Hobarth and Bruce Cabot--THURSDAY at 6 P.M. on TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES. Howard Thompson

title: Longfellow's House Is Closing for Repairs
description: The Longfellow House in Cambridge, Mass., will close today for a yearlong construction program designed to preserve this 240-year-old National Historic Site.

title: Word & Image; A Great, Irrelevant Wall
description: On a visit to China, my main question turned out to be a media question. Can the Internet scale the Great Wall? Can the global flow of information and images penetrate the defenses of a rigid old oligarchy? Can China run a free market economy without a free market in ideas?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: In the Big Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property / Times Square; Underpinning the Revival, Feats of Engineering
description: THE conversion of Times Square from a seedy, rundown neighborhood to a prime venue for entertainment has involved the contributions of city officials, developers, architects and other planners. Now the work is well under way, and another profession is making its presence felt: the engineers.

title: Dr. Matthews And Mr. Shatteen
description: Dr. Westina Lomax Matthews and Alan Garnet Shatteen were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Paul Smith at the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins took part in the ceremony.

title: October 18-24; Numerical Lunacy (Cont.)
description: How big is a googolplex? An article last Sunday -- one that invited readers on a wild ride through the world of really, really big numbers -- presumed to answer that question in a down-to-earth, lay-'em-end-to-end sort of way. ''Write the numeral 1 followed by a letter-sized page of zeros,'' it suggested innocently. ''Continue writing zeros until you have a stack of paper that reaches the moon.''

title: Tracey Cohen, Lee Warshaw
description: Tracey Orlean Cohen, a daughter of Kathy and Richard Cohen of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., was married last evening to Lee Gregg Warshaw, a son of Sheila and Fred Warshaw of Pomona, N.Y. Rabbi Gregory S. Marx performed the ceremony at the Blue Bell (Pa.) Country Club.

title: On Language; Enough Already! What Am I, Chopped Liver?
description: 'What red-blooded American hasn't surveyed the muck and mire of our national politics,'' writes Mark Jurkowitz of The Boston Globe, ''and said, 'Enough, already'?''

title: But Is It Art?
description: Those of us who labor as fine-art photographers celebrate the efforts of Maria Morris Hambourg and others like her who recognize and promote photography as one of the arts (Deborah Solomon, Oct. 4). However, Hambourg does a disservice to us all, herself included, in describing the photographs accompanying the article in such hyperbolic terms. To call a photograph a masterpiece, or completely perfect in its framing, and then not to be able to verbalize what ''she looks for in a photograph'' makes us all look somewhat foolish. No wonder people think their pictures are as good as work hanging on museum and gallery walls.

title: 2 Men Parachute Off Empire State
description: Two daredevils parachuted from the observation deck of the Empire State Building last night, landed feet first and then disappeared into the evening, the police said.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: University Presses; Classics Illustrated
description: Accomplished in All Departments of Art Hammatt Billings of Boston, 1818-1874. By James F. O'Gorman. Illustrated. 291 pp. Amherst: University of Massachusetts Press. $39.95.

title: In Executive Job Hunts, Experience Doesn't Pay
description: It might seem that the job market is so strong and the labor pool so dry that experience, a car and a set of opposable thumbs ought to land you a corner office. Not so fast. Exec-U-Net, an outplacement service in Norwalk, Conn., cautions that age bias remains well ensconced in the corridors of corporate America, just in time to bedevil aging boomers.

title: Soul-Satisfying Greens With Southern Italian Accent
description: STURDY greens deserve a permanent place on the menu. Not only are big bunches relatively inexpensive but they also deliver a rich concentration of vitamin A. Broccoli rape, spinach and frilly kale are in the market now, as are others, including collard greens, Swiss chard and mustard greens. You can easily substitute one for another. Just be sure the leaves on the bunches you buy show no signs of yellowing.

title: Legions Of Wings, Little Uplift
description: ''LET go, give in, and take the journey.'' That slogan, a fatuous a new-age variation of the 60's ''turn on, tune in, drop out,'' is the motto of Eddie Murphy's character, a bald-headed prophet who goes simply by the initial G. in the movie ''Holy Man.'' The soft-spoken, ever-smiling G. (is it short for God, Gabriel, Gump, Godawful?) appears one day on a Miami freeway to help two harried executives from the Good Buy Shopping Network fix a flat tire.

title: Martinique, Deja Vu, but Different
description: ''WHAT, Martinique again?'' my husband, Max, said last winter when I told him I wanted to spend a week there. He's a man who likes to vacation in capitals of civilization, not paradises of nature, who prefers sightseeing to sunbathing, touring to tarrying. Besides, we'd already been to Martinique four times in the last 15 years.

title: Report Card in Yonkers On New Schools Chief
description: THE ink had barely dried on Andre J. Hornsby's contract when the problems here began.

title: More Aviation News
description: Lots of executives come into their offices on weekends, but how many hover above them? That's what George Tanaka, Fuji Photo Film USA's new president, did last Sunday. He went for a ride on the Fuji blimp, figuring he'd get an up-close look at the airship's new artwork and talk promotional strategy with its captain, John McHugh. No problem on the 20-minute, 10-mile float from Westchester Airport to Fuji's home in Elmsford, N.Y. But headwinds that gusted up to 31 miles per hour dragged the return trip out to 35 minutes, probably creating enough turbulence to keep Mr. Tanaka from admiring the fall foliage below.

title: A Twist in the Revolution That Turned U.S. History
description: WHEN a fisherman-turned-colonel by the name of John Glover led his men against British and Hessian troops in what was then part of the town of Eastchester, his strategy and heroics became a pivotal part of the Revolutionary War.

title: Florida Keys Try To Put Georges Behind
description: Only two weeks after the evacuation of the Florida Keys -- when Hurricane Georges swept through the island chain on Sept. 25, causing $250 million in losses and cutting off access to popular tourist spots -- visitors had begun trickling back. It's too soon to know whether they'll be back in their full numbers, tourism officials say, especially since the hurricane struck during the off season. But airports, the Port of Key West, and most hotels and attractions are now fully operational, they hasten to point out, and big events like the Halloween Fantasy Fest in Key West, which began Friday, have not been affected.

title: Some Good News, Some Bad From Soft Energy Prices
description: The continuing effects of cheap oil on the economy are being thrown into sharp relief by the latest wave of earnings reports. Nearly all the big airlines posted robust earnings last week (Northwest, with its strike, and TWA, with its familiar host of problems, were the exceptions), while nearly all the big oil companies reported steeply falling profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, MIKE
description: ADLER-Mike. On October 23, 1998. Stamford, CT. Loving husband of Yetta Adler. Loving father of Judith Haber, Debra AdlerKlein, Honni Pomerantz, Stephen Adler and loving brother of Shirley Smith. Also survived by 12 grandchildren. Funeral Sunday, October 25, at 9:30 AM, Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Rd., Stamford, CT. Burial Beth El Cemetery, Stamford, CT. Memorial contributions to the Mike Adler Fund, c/o JCC, 1035 Newfield Ave., Stamford, CT 06905.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, JAMES W.
description: MAHONEY-James W. On October 22, 1998. Retired Banker and W.W. II Veteran. Beloved uncle of Robert F. Stewart, Jr. of Wilmington, DE, John E. Stewart of San Francisco, CA., James W. Stewart of Hopkinton, MA., Mary Jo Conn of Scottsdale, AZ., Anne Louise Keehan of Perth, Australia, John S. Mahoney of Knoxville, TN., and Kathleen Mahoney Simmons of Dickson, TN., Edward J. Mahoney of Niagara Falls, N.Y., and Dorothy Ann Connolly of Williamsville, NY. Devoted companion of Luis Rivera. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, October 26th, 6PM-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, Tuesday at 11 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, N.Y., N.Y. 10013.

title: Catherine Karutz, James Rogers
description: Catherine Stewart Karutz and James Richard Rogers were married last evening at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Tewell performed the ceremony.

title: Terri Sash, David Hautzig
description: Terri Madalyn Sash, a daughter of Barbara and Jerry Sash of Boynton Beach, Fla., is to be married today to David Rudomin Hautzig, the son of Esther and Walter Hautzig of New York. Rabbi Jonah Pesner is to officiate with Rabbi Michele B. Medwin, a cousin of the bride, at Studio 450, a party space in New York.

title: The Nation; Want Votes With That? Get the 'Waitress Moms.'
description: ONE of the bellwethers for next month's elections is taking milkshake orders from a late-night party of 25 in the Tastee Diner here -- all separate checks, she notes, with a sort of kindly grimace.

title: Now Help Utilities Invest in Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Caribbean Options, Pool To Trail
description: YOU can't book a room this winter at Sandy Lane, the Palladian palace on Barbados's Caribbean shore. The island's swankiest enclave is now a construction site, making way for a swankier reincarnation with more lavish guest quarters, a spa the size of a mansion and 45 holes of golf. Sandy Lane will reopen next fall with some rates topping $1,705 a night, last winter's price for an oceanfront suite.

title: Setting a Tale In the Alleys Of a Sunny Oz
description: THE film is called ''Anywhere but Here,'' but the sun-blasted alley where director Wayne Wang in a gray polo shirt and wire frame glasses is studiously contemplating an aging Mercedes could not actually be anywhere except Los Angeles. Indeed, to certain of the city's devotees, the view is as endearing in a downmarket way, as are, say, the wooden water towers that spike the Manhattan skyline to diehard New Yorkers. Among the signature features are a red bougainvillea flicking its papery blossoms over a pastel stucco wall; a glimpse of self-serve gas pumps; a neon motel sign; and, in the far distance, a haze of greenery denoting the wealthier enclaves of the city's Westside.

title: Miss Olney And Mr. Wyman
description: Diana Salisbury Olney was married yesterday to Franklin Wyman 3d at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Richard H. Downes performed the ceremony.

title: Lapointe's Second Goal Saves Islanders From Themselves
description: For the second straight game, the Islanders' fate lay on the stick of Claude Lapointe. This time, however, he did not let his team down.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING
description: A Bizarre Turn In Wisconsin Race

title: The Nation: Gay Politics and Anti-Politics; A Movement Divided Between Push and Shove
description: THOUSANDS of gay demonstrators scrapped with police officers in midtown Manhattan on Monday, protesting the violent death of a young gay man in Wyoming. The clash recalled the Stonewall uprising, the brawl between homosexuals and policemen outside a Greenwich Village bar that launched the gay rights movement in 1969. More than a few of the people gathered in front of the Plaza Hotel last week had marched in Greenwich Village 29 years before.

title: Lull in the Party for Year-2000 Stocks
description: NO one yet knows how much digital mayhem the world will face when the year 2000 arrives. Filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission suggest that repair and contingency planning projects are just now building up steam at many companies.

title: Linda Elliott, Jeffrey Joyce
description: Linda Rowland Elliott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Sutton Elliott of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey William Joyce, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William Franklyn Joyce of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Dr. William G. Nigh performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Habitats / York Avenue; At $566, the Rent Is Small, But the Problems Are Big
description: WHEN Phillip Lee complains to friends that his shower leaked or that his stove refused to light, he doesn't get much sympathy. Not in New York. Not when you have managed to rent a cheap apartment. Envy, yes. Sympathy, no.

title: Playing God in the Garden
description: Planting

title: Evaluating Home Security: Simple Ways to Stay Safe
description: MANY homeowners become complacent about home security because they think they have nothing worth stealing. What these homeowners fail to realize is that a majority of burglars have no way of knowing what is inside a home. Most break in hoping to get lucky. Given enough time, a burglar will try to make his own luck by tearing into a house, ripping apart upholstery, breaking up cabinets and tearing pictures from the walls looking for salable items.

title: University Presses; Heavy Symbolism
description: THE LAST DINOSAUR BOOK

title: SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo?
description: IT took David C. Walentas 17 years to win permission from New York City to begin the residential conversion of a muscular old industrial complex on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Stuck in the Rough
description: It is a hot and sunny Friday afternoon, the temperature just a few crucial degrees beyond comfortable. Jerry Foltz is working on his swing on the nearly deserted practice tee of the Dominion Club golf course in Glen Allen, Va., a Richmond suburb. The fair-haired Foltz, flushed and sweaty, hits ball after ball after ball, carefully studying the flight of each one. After two rounds of the Nike Dominion Open, Foltz, who led after the first 18 holes with a 65, is in a three-way tie for third place, nine under par. But he's not happy with the state of his game. ''The way I'm hitting it right now,'' the easygoing Arizonan says, ''I'm as liable to shoot 86 as I am 65. It's all I can do to pull the trigger on most tee shots without panicking.''

title: Harold Ford Jr. Storms His Father's House
description: The block party has just begun in Harbor Town. Residents stroll from their homes down to River Mist Lane for hot dogs, beer and live music. Tinsel and balloons hang from the street lamps. The whole thing looks like the set for ''The Truman Show,'' and that's no accident. Harbor Town, a planned community plunked down on an island in the Mississippi River, is an affluent enclave separated, by natural moat, from the mean streets of downtown Memphis. Anchored by a corner coffee shop, the place recalls the sort of American neighborhood that no longer exists -- right down to the bell on top of the schoolhouse.

title: The Hissing of a Living Legend
description: I found it disturbing for your writer to consistently refer to Mitchell as a mother and a grandmother of a daughter and a grandson she met only recently.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 11 about high school athletic trainers misstated the services that chiropractors can offer. They can indeed provide athletic training, but they are not licensed to practice physical therapy.

title: Some Exhibit Concern Over Museum Expansion
description: Since 1979, when the Asia Society built its elegant headquarters at 725 Park Avenue, it has wondered how to fix some not-so-elegant design quirks. For example, to air-condition one floor, all eight floors need to be cooled, which sends utility bills sky high.

title: In New York's Tight Race for Senate, Black Voters Could Be Decisive
description: Black voters are emerging as a critical factor in the final-week strategies of both candidates in the Senate race in New York, which is considered so close that it could be decided by a tiny fraction of the electorate.

title: New Growths In the East 60's
description: CIRCUS **

title: BASEBALL: The Mets Agree to Make Piazza Baseball's Richest Player; Leiter Says He Is Close to a $32 Million Deal
description: The Mets and Mike Piazza, their All-Star catcher, reached agreement yesterday on the richest contract in baseball history, a seven-year deal for $91 million.

title: Oh, Is That All?
description: Starting this month, the Securities and Exchange Commission is requiring that stock and bond prospectuses and other disclosure documents be written in plain English. To help their members master so alien a tongue, the American Bar Association and the American Society of Corporate Secretaries have sponsored workshops and distributed a plain-language handbook from the S.E.C.

title: Stonehenge Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: June Azoulay, George Kalinsky
description: June Azoulay, a psychotherapist, and George Kalinsky, a photographer, will be married this afternoon by Rabbi Martin Rozenberg at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, N.Y.

title: Festival Delves Into Halloween's Celtic Origins
description: THE holiday that comes next Saturday is known to us as Halloween but to the ancient Celts it was the eve of Samhain, a feast of the dead. On Samhain, the Celts believed, the boundary between the earthly world and the realm of the spirits was weaker than any other time of the year; on Samhain, the dead could call on the living.

title: October 18-24; In Time for Elections, A New Federal Budget
description: After a grueling labor, Congress delivered a 40-pound, 16-inch-high monster, otherwise known as the Federal budget. It ran 3,825 pages, and hardly a man or woman alive had read the whole thing before Congress passed it into law and President Clinton signed it.

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Nonfiction
description: Forgive Us Our Press Passes

title: 'A Hole in Our House'
description: HUNGER

title: Charlton Ogburn, 87, Proponent Of Earl as the 'Real' Shakespeare
description: Charlton Ogburn, a former State Department official and the author of novels and books about World War II and Shakespeare, died on Monday at his home in Beaufort, S.C. He was 87.

title: Pinochet's Arrest Violates No Law; Let Chileans Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Measure Skirts Outright Threat of Force Against Milosevic
description: The United Nations Security Council today adopted a finely tuned resolution skirting an outright threat to use force against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia if he fails to remove forces from Kosovo.

title: October 18-24; Pipeline Blast Kills 48 In Colombia
description: Even as the Colombian Government was moving toward opening peace talks to end 30 years of civil conflict, rebels of the National Liberation Army blew up an oil pipeline in northwest Antioquia province.

title: Waging the Battle of the Soliloquy
description: MANY versions of a dialogue between Samuel Beckett and an old friend have come round. It was a fine sun-drenched day, a happy day, one version goes. The friend remarked that on such a day, it felt good to be alive. Beckett famously responded: ''I wouldn't go that far.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGUE, NATALIE (NEE ROLLINS)
description: HOGUE-Natalie (nee Rollins). Formerly of Great Neck L.I. and Waterville, ME. Died peacefully October 19, 1998. Beloved wife of Paul. Cherished mother of Melanie and Norman. Loving sister and aunt. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Gunman Kills the Owner Of a Bodega in Brooklyn
description: The owner of a Brooklyn bodega was shot early yesterday morning during a failed robbery attempt, the police said, and detectives were searching for the gunman.

title: Collection's Home Is at Sea
description: When Sailors' Snug Harbor, a seamen's retirement home, moved to Sea Level, N.C., in 1970, it also moved its collection of maritime art, which dates to 1833. Now the group wants to close its North Carolina home and return to New York. The Snug Harbor Cultural Center, which moved to the grounds of the former retirement home in 1976, wants to house the art collection, but the plans have hit a snag over where to put it.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Got Themselves a Bargain
description: THIS was in mid-September, when the Mets still had a chance at a wild-card berth. Nelson Doubleday liked that possibility, and he also liked the gossip coming out of the Mets' clubhouse.

title: POSTINGS: 14 Lofts at 140 Franklin Street, From $1.65 Million to $3.95 Million; A Renovation in TriBeCa
description: The whirr of machines can still be heard in the workshop of a manufacturer of parts for electric pumps on the sixth floor of the 1887 building at 140 Franklin Street in Tribeca. But the pumps will soon depart as part of a $10 million renovation that will turn the Romanesque Revival building at the corner of Varick Street, with its weathered yellow brick and cast-iron detail, into a 14-loft luxury condominium building by the end of next year.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; A Flurry of Proposals for Gas-Fired Power Plants
description: LAST April the Connecticut General Assembly voted to restructure the state's electric utilities, separating the generation of electricity from its distribution to the consumer.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Why not be proud when you see the opportunity to get more land, to have our prisoners freed? We have been living in darkness, and this is a light that brings us back hope.''

title: William Passmore, Caroline Krass
description: Caroline Diane Krass, a lawyer, and William John Passmore, a management consultant, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. David B. Wolfe, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the National Cathedral.

title: Corrections
description: The art column on Oct. 4 about an exhibition of artifacts from one-room schoolhouses at the Scarsdale Historical Society misstated the show's closing date. It is Nov. 1, not Nov. 29.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHUGH, THOMAS
description: McHUGH-Thomas. Native of Stranamorth Barran, County Cavan, Ireland. On October 11, 1998, in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee McCarthy). Loving father of Margaret (Rich), Thomas (Deb), Kevin (Geri), Rosemary (Steven). Adored grandfather of Brian, Cathy, Roe, Sean, Liz, Tess, James and the late Felicia. Memorial contributions may be made to ''The Children of Bellevue,'' Bellevue Hospital Center, 462 1st Ave, NYC 10016.

title: Chasing a Swimming, Eating Machine
description: The muscular outboard engine on Captain David Blinken's 20-foot flats skiff gurgled and growled pleasantly as we left his slip in the harbor under the still, leaden skies of October. The boys and girls and Porsches and lattes of summer were long gone from the East End of Long Island, and this cozy, overcrowded harbor had regained its identity as a seafarer's outpost, where luxurious pleasure craft and monstrous, rusting dredgers and other ''work'' ships added equal measures of character and charm to the harborscape.

title: Andrea Amiel, Jeffrey Tepper
description: Andrea Amiel, a television producer, and Jeffrey Mark Tepper, a mergers and acquisitions specialist, were married last evening. Cantor Jill Spasser officiated at the Penn Club in Manhattan.

title: GRIM READER
description: * More than 3,000 inmates await execution in American prisons; a roster of each person is contained in ''Death Row,'' an annual compendium of the condemned. * Once aimed only at crime professionals, the $24.95 book has recently become available at mainstream bookstores and on the Web. * Featured players include Darlie Routier, one of 47 condemned women, who requested a delay of trial because dark roots were showing in her blond dye job. * The late Michael Marnell Smith asked to hold a Bible during his electrocution in 1986. That was denied; officials said it was a fire hazard. * From 1976 through 1997, 432 Americans met their death by execution -- 74 in 1997, with Texas tallying half. * ''The crimes are deplorable, but the book is actually entertaining to read,'' says Bonnie Bobit, the editor. ''It's a coffee-table book.''

title: The Plot Never Thickens
description: MY YEAR IN THE

title: VW Day
description: I didn't buy Gerald Posner's efforts to resolve his cognitive dissonance about being a Jew who owns a car manufactured by a German company intrinsically linked to the Holocaust (Lives, Oct. 4). He bought the car because his desire for snazzy wheels was stronger than his gut sense that Volkswagen had not yet paid penance for its war crimes.

title: Friendly Coaching Rivals Meet for the M.L.S. Title
description: Bruce Arena and Bob Bradley have been friends since 1982 and coached together at the University of Virginia and D.C. United in Major League Soccer. They also joined forces on the United States Olympic team. But they will be rivals Sunday afternoon, coaching against each other, when Washington and Chicago clash for this year's M.L.S. championship at the Rose Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, BELLE
description: ABRAMOWITZ-Belle. Of Deerfield Beach, Florida, formerly of the Bronx, NY. Devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Stephan and grandmother of Michael and Diane. Graveside services on Sunday at 2 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For more information contact Riverside Nassau North Funeral Chapel.

title: Catching Carnival Fever
description: CULTURES get carnivals that reflect them, and Martinique's careful, deliberate carnival, with its strains of political satire and its eruptions of beautifully lyrical vulgarity, has the island's number. Martinique is worldly on its surface, but under that sheen lies all sorts of fun.

title: Katherine White, David Stadler
description: Katherine Rose White and David Martin Stadler were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Pompeii in New York. The Rev. Ralph Bova performed the ceremony.

title: Secrecy and Stigma No Longer Clouding Adoptions
description: Yvette Weilacker sits in the kitchen of a small house in Buffalo waiting for the contractions to begin. Her baby, already named Nicholas Lee by his anxious parents, was due days ago, and he shows scant signs of being ready to be born.

title: In Election, Kazakhstan Gets a Dose Of the West
description: In the past eight weeks, Akezhan Kazhegeldin says, his press aide was attacked by masked men, a weekly close to him was firebombed and he was shot at.

title: 'Little London' Indeed
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Megan Fitzgerald, Patrick Crossman
description: Megan Kathleen Fitzgerald, the daughter of Susan Fitzgerald of New York and Michael Allen Crow of San Francisco, was married last evening to Patrick Hamilton Crossman, the son of Elizabeth Davis Crossman and Patrick Farrell Crossman of New York. The Rev. Paul B. Williams performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Women's National Republican Club in New York.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; Jodi Clement and Michael Smart
description: IN the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room on Oct. 17, 200 guests stared impatiently at the floral gazebo. Most were not surprised that the wedding couple were late, for little in the relationship of Josephine M. Clement and Michael A. Smart had happened on schedule.

title: If It's Politics and It's Local, Someone Is Paying Attention
description: When Nov. 3 dawns here in central New Jersey, the 3,500 residents of Rossmoor will have to walk or drive no farther than the clubhouse ballroom to vote. And vote they do.

title: Harvest Time in the Stonington Vineyards
description: WINE makers are born, not made, suggests Mike McAndrew, the wine maker at Stonington Vineyards, where production is currently at about 7,000 cases a year. Mr. McAndrew has been a wine retailer visiting vineyards in California and Oregon, then a cellar rat for a Litchfield winery, when he arrived in Stonington in 1987, the year the vineyard owner, Nick Smith (above left, white shirt, back to camera), a former banker and self-professed oenophile, began Stonington Vineyards.

title: Q & A
description: Learning German in Zurich

title: N.B.A. Players Have Found the Enemy
description: When a little-known agent named Stephen Woods complained recently that the National Basketball Players Association was derelict in its duties, the fears began to surface.

title: Hey, Like They're on a Mission for The U.N.
description: THIS is a tale of two news conferences on the same day last week concerning the same organization, the United Nations Population Fund.

title: Parks Here, Farms There? It's Up to Voters
description: If New Jersey voters want to approve new taxes to preserve farms and parkland, they will have plenty of chances to do so on Nov. 3.

title: Now Roasting (and Toasting) Drew Carey
description: The New York Friars Club, the 94-year-old club for entertainers, has up to now kept cameras out of its annual roasts, those insult-laced testimonials meant as a tribute to a different member each year. Considering the uproar surrounding the Whoopi Goldberg roast in 1993, in which Ted Danson donned blackface and made racial jokes that became public, maybe the secrecy has been to everyone's benefit.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Morning After
description: On the morning after being defeated by Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel's 1996 elections, the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, was asked what he thought happened. ''The Israelis lost,'' said Mr. Peres. ''The Jews won.''

title: F.Y.I.
description: Tricking the Trees

title: Q&A/Isidore Tepler; Making Strides Against Breast Cancer
description: IF 1998 is any indication, science is putting up a good fight against breast cancer.

title: University Presses; No Jail Could Hold Him
description: THE MEMOIRS OF FRAY SERVANDO TERESA DE MIER Edited by Susana Rotker. Translated by Helen Lane. 242 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30.

title: Just Like the Old Days, Except for the .com
description: IMAGINE a curtain of thick, black smoke sweeping across the Hudson River, funneling into the streets of New York and lapping against midtown's office towers. This is the famous Martian invasion of New York, as told by Orson Welles 60 years ago, Oct. 30, 1938, in his famous radio play ''The War of the Worlds.''

title: BENEFITS
description: Cooks and Celebrities

title: Road Map
description: ''There's not enough good news'' is a common complaint about the media, and especially when the subject is Newark. Yet a half-hour television documentary called ''Newark: the Road Ahead'' dispenses with urban blight and the 1967 riots within a minute and then gets to the good news. The focus is on Episcopal Community Development, which helps people buy their first home; North Star Academy, a charter school; the Teixeira bakery, which has flourished in the Ironbound district, and a performance workshop for young people at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Steve Adubato, the host, was born and reared in Newark. He tells viewers the future of the city depends on programs and people that change things a few lives at a time. As Dr. Clement Price, a history professor at Rutgers-Newark puts it, people need to appreciate ''the value of small things.'' The program will be broadcast on WNET Saturday at 12:30 P.M. and next Sunday at 6 P.M. and on NJN next Sunday at 10 A.M. and Nov. 4 at 6:30 P.M. It will also be broadcast on various cable channels in early November.

title: Russian Oil: So Much, Yet So Little
description: HIDDEN beneath the vast Russian land mass and the Arctic waters around it could lie more oil than enriches the Middle East, many experts believe. Yet despite decades of effort, the Russian oil industry has tapped only a small fraction of it.

title: Stop Me Before I Apologize Again
description: William Safire refers to Senator Trent Lott's obscure locution, ''grown like Topsy'' as a ''widely used Americanism.'' (On Language, Oct. 4). I have been an American since 1958. I am a veteran, and as a former trucker, I have traveled throughout the country. Until I saw the Senator's use of this phrase, I had never heard of it, and I have absolutely never heard any African-American use it (being one myself). Now I know why.

title: Books in Brief: University Presses Nonfiction
description: ALL-AMERICAN ANARCHIST Joseph A. Labadie and the Labor Movement. By Carlotta R. Anderson. Wayne State University, $34.95.

title: Moment of Truth: What to Tip
description: HOW much to tip is an anxiety-provoking question that follows a traveler from airport to hotel to restaurant, nationally and internationally. Do you tip a hotel-room housekeeper? How about the masseuse? The golf pro? A restaurant's captain?

title: Lives; Home to the Hills
description: No matter how you leave the hills -- army, prison, marriage, job, college -- when you move back after 20 years the whole county is watching carefully. They want to see the changes that the outside world put on you. They are curious to know if you've become bitter and lost your laughter as a victim of the land beyond the hills. They are worried that perhaps you've gotten above your raisings.

title: Getting There First: Reflections of a Collector
description: When Richard Brown Baker bought Jackson Pollock's ''Arabesque'' for $2,500 in 1955, he demonstrated a keen eye, for the painting is now worth around $15 million and is a star of a Pollock retrospective, which opens next Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

title: Bangles and Beetles
description: Wear it or try to exterminate it? People are scooping up Lucite bug bangles from the Philippines at a SoHo street vendor's table. The bracelets, which sell for $10 each on the corner of Greene and Prince Streets, feature brilliantly colored beetles with orange, blue and green carapaces and red thoraxes.

title: Opportunities Remain
description: This year has been a boon to serial refinancers, as the lowest mortgage rates in a generation have continued to entice homeowners. The Mortgage Bankers Association of America reports that refinancing activity accounted for nearly 60 percent of total mortgage applications in the most recent week.

title: Food; Small Fry
description: Columbus, Ohio, where I grew up, was once the test-market capital for the food industry. The thought was, If they like it in Columbus, they'll like it anywhere. I'm still not sure whether this was a compliment or a put-down.

title: The Etiquette of Rejecting a Draw Offer: Just Say No
description: You should not let yourself get annoyed when your opponent offers a draw that you don't want. Just refuse it -- this can be done by nothing more than making your next move -- and get on with the play. Yet there are opponents who grumble after the game that you ruffled them and that's why they lost. Still, unless you make repeated draw offers -- that's against the rules -- your adversaries are not justified in complaining.

title: October 18-24; Forget Apples; Give Teachers Stock
description: The problem is this: how to make teaching a more prestigious occupation, one that draws the best and the brightest. The Edison Project, a privately held company that runs public schools around the country, thinks it has an answer: Pay teachers like executives.

title: Yes, It Could Happen Here
description: With images of wind-sheared houses and flooded villages still fresh in the public's mind, the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management has inaugurated a campaign warning New Yorkers about the dangers of a hurricane like the one that just lashed the Caribbean.

title: IN BRIEF; Police Give Out Gun Locks, No Charge, No Questions
description: The Ocean Township police department is giving away childproof gun locks, with no questions asked.

title: A Bronx Cheer For the Coliseum
description: Re: your Oct. 4 article about the Nassau Coliseum [''Coliseum: It's Aging but Cozy''] the suggestion that it is an inviting place for someone to view hockey is both laughable and a fantasy.

title: At Play in The Conception Zone
description: By midweek -- with the World Series gone and the Super Bowl still a distant dream -- sports-crazy men will be vulnerable to painful withdrawal, so it would be nice to have something to keep their minds occupied. Like, say, being present when their wives have a baby.

title: Our Towns; Stores Dress As Santa Claus For Halloween
description: LISA HEIM has yet to buy the candy corn for trick or treaters or organize the Batman and Robin costumes her sons will wear for Halloween. Yet here she was one recent afternoon, trying on shoes at Lord & Taylor, beneath holiday wreaths, garlands and pine cones.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 25, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Affirmative Action: The Fact Gap
description: The Shape of

title: A Determined Writer Evokes His Parents' Past
description: THE playwright's fading family photographs hang virtually unnoticed on the walls of the set. In one frame, a black World War II soldier grins beneath a rakishly tilted cap. In another, a shy young woman glimmers in a gown that sweeps her toes. They are his parents, long buried, their era long gone.

title: Buckeyes Handle the Wildcats With Their B Game
description: OHIO STATE 36, NORTHWESTERN 10

title: Mayor Says Democrats Have Made Ethnic Slurs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani accused Democrats yesterday of ''a pattern'' of anti-Italian slurs, citing two recent campaign incidents and three from prior years. Joined by two fellow Italian-American Republicans, he called on voters to repudiate such tactics.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the revival of debate over American Communism referred incorrectly to Prof. Ellen Schrecker of Yeshiva University, a historian of the McCarthy period. She says she was a child of liberal parents, not a ''red diaper'' baby, weaned on the left.

title: A City That Covers Your Losses
description: MY leather-bound daily planner had been missing for so many days that it didn't even enter my mind when the unfamiliar voice on the other end of the intercom said he had dropped by to return something left on the back seat of his taxi.

title: Together, Contrarians Stand Alone
description: A LITTLE knowledge is a dangerous thing, particularly in the way that investment advisers have co-opted the term ''contrarian analysis'' without really understanding it.

title: A Great Day for Tire-Kicking, But Maybe Not for More
description: As blue laws have faded, it's become easier to buy almost anything on a Sunday. But Ward's Dealer Business, a trade magazine for automobile dealers, says Sunday is still a pretty difficult day for car-shopping. In about 60 percent of the country, the magazine says, it is impossible to buy a car that day.

title: Microsoft and I.B.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Isn't Everything, Especially in Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ROSE
description: ROSENBERG-Rose. On October 23. Beloved wife of the late Louis (founder of Superior Florist). Devoted mother of Samuel, Susan Geen and the late Charles. Cherished grandmother of Steven, Melissa, David and Sara. Adored great-grandmother of Adam. Family will receive friends at Midwood Chapels, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, today (Sunday), 11-11:30 AM. Religious services will begin at 11:30, with burial to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing.

title: Gingrich Draws Fire From the Right
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich is under fire from his conservative flank. Again.

title: THEATER; When Broadway Was Ruled by the House of Shubert
description: WHEN the Shubert Theater [named in memory of the middle brother, Sam, who had died as a result of a railway accident in 1905], opened on West 44th Street in the fall of 1913, Lee and J. J. moved into offices on the third floor. Lee had a commanding view of the street; J. J. was down the hall in the back. Lee referred to both the third and fourth floors as ''my offices'' -- a pointed reminder that in 1913 J. J. was not yet a full partner.

title: Ms. England And Mr. Blair
description: Elizabeth Jean England, a daughter of Loraine E. England of Passaic, N.J., and the late Richard G. England, was married yesterday to Wolcott Rhoades Blair, a son of Watson K. Blair of Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Josephine Cutting Blair. The Rev. E. Kyle St. Claire Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in New Hope, Pa.

title: Hazing, a Longtime N.F.L. Tradition, May Have Seen Its Last Days
description: Nothing like a lawsuit to finally scare the National Football League when it comes to the nasty subject of hazing.

title: New Chef at Colonial Inn in Chappaqua
description: JUST when we thought the kitchen of this handsome inn was getting tired, Jonathan Crean, the new chef, has come to the rescue, revitalizing the restaurant's offerings. Service, too, appears to have been overhauled.

title: Miss Dempsey, Mr. Arundel
description: Christine Diane Dempsey, a daughter of Mrs. John I. Sacks of Washington and the late John J. Dempsey 2d, was married on Friday to John Howard Arundel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Arundel of The Plains, Va. Msgr. Thomas M. Duffy performed the ceremony at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington.

title: That Market Bottom Might Be A Trap Door
description: AS almost anyone with a market memory can attest, the month of October is not usually friendly for stocks. Since 1915, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen an average 0.17 percent in the 10th month of the year, according to Birinyi & Associates. Only Septembers have been worse.

title: BOOKEND; Recognitions
description: It was at the height of his success ... With ''Randell's Folly'' selling 150,000 copies in 1940 alone ... That its author, Milo Warren, disappeared, ... Only to reappear (some said) in a remote Idaho cabin. For many years Milo Warren remained in seclusion. In time the postal worker had long conversations with him. They became friends. They grew closer. Before long, Milo Warren became her mentor. She left her job to become a writer. In 1998 her biography of Milo Warren was published.

title: Adding New Wine To Vintage Modernity
description: To mix and match 20th-century ballet classics with newer works is always a risk, but the San Francisco Ballet met the challenge at the start of the weekend. The contemporary choreography included a gem, while the company's touchstone neo-classicism was displayed in two masterpieces: ''Agon'' (1957) by George Balanchine and ''The Cage'' (1951) by Jerome Robbins.

title: Now, Another Ranking to Rankle
description: College football will officially embrace the computer age when the Bowl Championship Series ranking is released for the first time today and another prefix is added to the alphabet soup of polls and calculations already in place to determine the best team in the land.

title: God, on Our Own Terms
description: Once again, the New Age movement has come under attack this time, in reaction to an encyclical by Pope John Paul II. That's too bad, because the New Age is helping a lot of people figure out what religion -- even Christianity -- is all about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTENTHAL, MINNIE
description: MITTENTHAL-Minnie. Lived with grace and dignity for 95 years. Devoted wife of the late Phillip Mittenthal and the late Henry Brand. Treasured by daughter and son-inlaw Phyllis and Larry Bangser and their children and grandchildren, and by Larry and Estelle Mittenthal and Richard and Joyce Mittenthal and all of their children and grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be given to the charity of your choice. Services private.

title: Quiet, Affluent Town Is Stunned by Sniper Slaying of One of Its Doctors
description: With no arrests reported in Friday night's slaying of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the two doctors in the Buffalo area who publicly acknowledge performing abortions remained in seclusion today as residents of this picturesque Buffalo suburb struggled to grasp the thought of a sniper attack in their midst.

title: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and an aucton of two-year notes on Wednesday.

description: WEIL-Else. Gone from us two years, but always in our hearts. Bob and Fre

description: TROPP-Ethel Robbins. Age 96. On October 24, 1998. Devoted wife of the late James Tropp. Loving mother of Alberta T. and Lester Salkin, Yvonne D. and the late Alan R. Tropp. Cherished grandmother of Leslie and Lester Millman, Jonathan and Oleasa Salkin, Karen and Robert Veronesi, Janis Tropp, Dana Tropp, Lisa and Tim Fitzgerald. Proud great-grandmother of Arielle Salkin, A. Robert and Nicholas Veronesi, Brian Fitzgerald. Services Tuesday, October 27, 12 noon, Community Synagogue, Rye, NY. In her memory, contributions may be made to Larchmont Hadassah or Community Synagogue of Rye.

title: D'Amato and Schumer Focus on Issues in a Feisty Debate
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer laid out sharply different views on tax cuts, gun control and abortion rights yesterday, during a free-flowing, if clamorous, debate in which each Senate candidate struggled to set the agenda for the final week of his campaign.

description: To the Editor:

title: NBC to Name New President For Network Entertainment
description: NBC plans to name a new president for its entertainment division today, setting up a transition that will eventually put all the network's entertainment operations under the executive, Scott Sassa, senior NBC officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft's Trial Thesis: Big, Yes, but Not a Bully

title: Negotiators Plan To Meet Today
description: As the labor dispute between National Basketball Association owners and players moves toward its fourth month, chief negotiators on both sides have resumed talks and plan to meet today in Manhattan.

title: When Millionaires are Laid Off
description: Two months after the National Basketball Association's lockout came and his paycheck went, Kenny Anderson began contemplating the unthinkable. It had nothing to do with asking his mother in Queens for his old room back or taking a part-time security job; he figured there were only so many indignities young millionaires should have to face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, NORMAN
description: RUBIN-Norman. A wonderful husband of Sylvia. Loving father and grandfather. A special friend to all who knew him. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

description: TENENBAUM-Jonas. Age 91. Of Riverdale, NY. On October 24, 1998. Patriarch of our family. Beloved husband of the late Sydell. Cherished father of Anita and Robert Sessler and Stephen and Rosalie Tenenbaum. Adored Grandpa of Scott and Andrea Sessler, Lee and Madeline Sessler, Andrew and Roseanne Tenenbaum, Lisa and Richard Ehrlich, Karen and Danny Chilewich. Loving great-grandfather of Ryan, Jordan, Sarah, Harry and Emma. Dear friend of Penny Lobello. His warmth, humor and love for his family and friends and his dedication to his community, his religious beliefs and his synagogue are unparalleled. He will be missed by all. Services were held Sunday at Riverside Chapel, New York, NY.

title: Federal Budget: Of Pork and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Evanescent Season In a Timeless Place
description: Rarely, over a period of more than 40 years, have I enjoyed brilliant success when fishing for Cole Pond's brook trout, but I keep trying.

title: Media Talk; New Editor of Glamour Kills Politics Column
description: The Conde Nast magazine Glamour long prided itself on the fact that it was the only women's magazine that had a column about women in politics, written by contributors based in Washington. The column ''Women in Washington: What Have They Done for Us Lately?'' was one of the hallmarks of Ruth Whitney, Glamour's editor of 31 years, who was replaced in September by Bonnie Fuller, the former editor of Cosmopolitan.

title: Media Talk; Michael Eisner Waits For the Right Price
description: If Walt Disney Company shareholders are unhappy about the stock's 34.4 percent decline since May 4, probably none are less happy than the company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner.

description: SAPOUNAKIS-Paul S. October 26, 1996. In remembrance. Steven J. Fellouris Georgia Sambazis

Funeral from Meislohn-Silvie Funeral Home, 1289 Forest Ave., SI, NY on Tuesday, 10:30 AM. Service at the Unitarian Church, 11 AM. Private cremation. Friends will be received Monday, 2-4, 7-9 PM.
