description: Nowadays, the eyewear of choice among really cool people onstage is that favored not by European movie stars, but by accountants.

title: John G. Gude, 96, Agent for Journalists
description: John G. Gude, an agent who represented many prominent figures in broadcasting and publishing, died on Oct. 11 at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts after a fall at Long Hill Nursing Home in Edgartown, Mass. He was 96.

title: Esprit de Corp. Hires Toth Brand Imaging
description: Esprit de Corp., the apparel marketer in San Francisco, has named Toth Brand Imaging in New York and Concord, Mass., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house since 1994. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Eradicating Bad Dreams
description: Week by week, Vinny Testaverde -- now 4-0 as the Jets' starting quarterback -- continues to erase the memory of all the interceptions he threw earlier in his career. In yesterday's victory over Atlanta he threw two touchdowns and no interceptions. In the last three-plus seasons, he has thrown 79 touchdowns and only 45 interceptions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWELL, RICHARD B.
description: ATWELL-Richard B. The Zoning Advisory Council extends its sympathy to the family of Richard Atwell. He served the city and the zoning and planning industry with distinction. Sheldon Lobel, President

title: Is There a Case Against Mr. Starr?; Investigate Both
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: DANCE
description: Women Who Know Pain

title: Elam Goes Deep as Broncos Go 7-0
description: When Jason Elam jogged onto the field and began to line up for the kick -- the kick of the day, the kick of the year, the kick of the decade, the kick of the last two decades, in fact -- most of the Denver Broncos stood on the sideline began to make a murmur that soon escalated. Some jostled each other.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit was omitted from the special Cars section on Wednesday with an article about crash-testing. The photographs were by Timothy Wright, for The New York Times.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a real departure of the traditional role of the C.I.A. And I would hope that they stay within their role, and they would not be something -- border guards, arbitrators, enforcers of a policy.''

title: Federal Budget: Of Pork and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Comeback Year, Huston Comes Back for Victory
description: Today's victory by John Huston was done in comeback fashion, befitting his comeback season.

title: Better Living Through Sorcery; New Broom Sweeps Witches' World
description: From broom closet to book jacket comes an evolving literary definition of the thoroughly mainstream witch: a teen-age girl casting economy spells on crabby teachers, or a sleek Wiccan high priestess with a coven, a law degree and the three press agents to promote the resulting spiritual memoir.

title: Rome Journal; Where Free-Wheeling Mopeds Are Life! Or Death
description: Lifting her 4-year-old son from the seat of a blue Honda moped, Federica Frontani, 33, tenderly kissed him and warned him to play carefully at preschool.

title: Meet the New Jets, Not the Same as the Old Jets
description: In the Jets' new era, as they continue to escape from their twilight zone, they take advantage of the breaks instead of being victimized by them.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Oct. 16 about an auction of fixtures designed by Frank Gehry for Rebecca's Restaurant in Venice, Calif., which has closed, referred incorrectly to Thomas Hines's comments in the auction catalogue about Adolf Loos's American Bar in Vienna. Mr. Hines, professor of history and architecture at the University of California at Los Angeles, cited the American Bar's interior as an example of modernist design that had escaped demolition. He did not include the bar in his reference to ''the venerable company of Restaurants Departed.''

title: Glenn William Poorman, 90, An Executive at Standard Oil
description: Glenn William Poorman, the president of Esso International from 1966 until he retired in 1970, died Wednesday at his home in Crowley, La. He was 90 years old.

title: A Lucrative Industry Booms on the Side
description: As the adoption industry grows, in dollars if not in resulting adoptions, peripheral services have multiplied. Some are financial products: Adoption cancellation insurance can help adoptive parents recover expenses incurred if birth mothers change their minds; at least two companies, Fireman's Fund Insurance and Kemper Insurance Company, underwrite policies costing 10 percent to 15 percent of their face value.

title: In Their Own Words
description: ALFONSE M. D'AMATO

title: RETURNING HOME, NETANYAHU FACES THE REAL BATTLE
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, stepping off a plane from Washington today into a turbulent political arena, plunged directly into an aggressive campaign both to stay in office and to secure support for the new peace accord with the Palestinians.

title: Husky Comfort Rising From the Mist
description: Filmmakers know how versatile shadows and mist can be. Out of obscurity, viewers conjure their own images, filling in implications and meanings. The songs of Seal, who performed on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall, are the sonic equivalents of fog-shrouded landscapes and candlelit interiors. Keyboard chords billow like clouds of incense, drifting over a beat that pulsates steadily but rarely pushes. Now and then, a little hook winks into earshot: a few piano notes, a flicker of guitar. And through the atmospheric harmonies comes Seal's grainy baritone, husky or gliding or reaching for gospel peaks, as he ponders love and death or offers what comfort he can.

title: Political Briefing; Michigan Challenger Plays the Mom Card
description: What do you do in politics when your opponent is beating you 2 to 1 in the polls and 65 percent of all voters say they have an ''unfavorable'' view of you -- the election equivalent of being ''hated,'' as one pollster put it?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEER, FLORENCE FAY
description: BEER-Florence Fay. Beloved wife of Walter, mother of John and David. Memorial service Wednesday, October 28th, at 12 noon at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article on the front page of The Metro Section yesterday, about the influence of black voters on the Senate race in New York, was omitted from some copies. The complete article is reprinted today on page B6.

title: Hong Kong Confronts Foreign Phone Giants
description: Anxiety has been running high in this former British colony, which has seen its economy buckle, tourism dry up and free-market reputation tatter in the 15 months since it reverted to Chinese rule.

title: From Most Arab Neighbors, a Guarded Shrug
description: After the hoopla in the United States, there was a guarded shrug from much of the Arab world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, JAMES W.
description: MAHONEY-James W. On October 22, 1998. Retired Banker and W.W. II Veteran. Beloved uncle of Robert F. Stewart, Jr. of Wilmington, DE, John E. Stewart of San Francisco, CA., James W. Stewart of Hopkinton, MA., Mary Jo Conn of Scottsdale, AZ., Anne Louise Keehan of Perth, Australia, John S. Mahoney of Knoxville, TN., and Kathleen Mahoney Simmons of Dickson, TN., Edward J. Mahoney of Niagara Falls, N.Y., and Dorothy Ann Connolly of Williamsville, NY. Devoted companion of Luis Rivera. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, October 26th, 6PM-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, Tuesday at 11 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, N.Y., N.Y. 10013.

title: Two Are Shot Dead At Brooklyn Nightclub
description: Two men were shot dead after a dispute at a Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday, the police said.

title: Voting in Basque Region Helps Moderates, and Peace
description: Moderates outstripped separatists today in elections in the northern Basque region. The voting was closely watched for its impact on peace prospects after the Basque guerrilla group E.T.A. began a cease-fire last month.

title: Hernandezes Attend Mass
description: Two days after a joyous reunion with family members he had left in Cuba, Yankees pitcher Orlando Hernandez sat with them in the front row at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday listening as John Cardinal O'Connor praised Cuban President Fidel Castro for making it all possible.

title: Beliefs Pushed Doctor to Keep Abortion Role
description: Some of those who knew him said today that Dr. Barnett A. Slepian continued to perform abortions in the face of death threats because he had what one friend called ''a stubborn kind of courage.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CHARLOTTE DOROTHY.
description: COHEN-Charlotte Dorothy. Devoted wife of the late Mortimer. Beloved mother of Myra, Jeffrey and Sharon. Dear sister of Claire. Cherished grandmother of Robin, Eric and Brandon. Dear motherin-law of Lenny. Services were held at ''Gutterman's,'' on October 23, 1998.

title: Leverage and Folk Memory Keep I.R.A. Armed
description: The Irish Republican Army, despite this year's peace accord and efforts by Protestant and Catholic leaders to persuade it to disarm, continues to maintain a huge secret arsenal, according to Irish and British officials and other experts.

title: Randolph Carter, 90, Broadway Playwright
description: Randolph Carter, an author who wrote several plays produced on Broadway, died on Oct. 12 at St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens. He was 90.

title: Is There a Case Against Mr. Starr?; Only the Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOFF, BEATRICE
description: ABOFF-Beatrice On October 24. Huntington, NY. Born November 24, 1896, NYC. Founder, with husband Dave, Aboff's Paints in 1929. World traveler. Master baker. Loving mother of Lois Stamberg and Herb Aboff. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Interment private. Memorial to be announced.

title: I.C.M. Talent Agency Recasts Executive Ranks and Strategy
description: In crucial steps in the evolution of one of the largest and more unusual talent agencies in Hollywood, International Creative Management Inc. has announced the naming of new co-presidents and the adoption of a more forward-looking strategy after a decade of focusing on debt reduction.

title: Patents; The Commissioner quits, after focusing attention on intellectual property and making enemies.
description: BRUCE A. LEHMAN, who announced Friday that he would step down as Commissioner of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, is not a man many people feel lukewarm about. His loyalists defend him as a visionary who has served the public admirably. His critics dismiss him as an intemperate despot who does the bidding of big business.

title: Complications Arise When Greed Is Good
description: There are, from time to time, warnings posted in theater lobbies, advising that strobe lights will be used or that gunshots will be heard. But shouldn't this trend be expanded? Shouldn't there, for instance, be a sign in the Helen Hayes Theater that announces, ''Warning: Cute monks will be featured in this production''?

title: Expecting the Worst, Leisurely
description: It is safe to say that the mood of the conference sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America in Orlando, Fla., last week, was one of caution.

title: Breaking Ground for a Memorial in Oklahoma
description: Standing upon the flattened three acres where a Federal office building stood until a bomb brought it down three years ago, killing 168 people, Vice President Al Gore broke ground today on a memorial to the victims and the ordinary people who helped Oklahoma City's physical and spiritual rebuilding.

title: Higher-Speed Internet Standard Is Approved
description: Even as Microsoft battles the United States Government, it can celebrate an incremental victory in the internaional arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, DANIEL J.
description: REID-Daniel J. On October 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Carol. Father of Daniel, Brian, Carol Ann and the late Michael. Grandfather of three. Brother to Millicent and the late Edward. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: If Homer Simpson Had an Intel Brain
description: Homer Simpson, the man-child patriarch of the animated Fox sitcom ''The Simpsons,'' is to receive a much-needed brain upgrade in an unusual commercial for the Intel Corporation.

title: In New York's Tight Race, Black Voters Could Be Pivotal
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of this article from the front page of the Metro Section was omitted in some copies yesterday. The complete article follows.

title: Awkward Steps Move Reid a Step Closer
description: As David Reid and James (Cowboy) Coker waltzed into the wee hours yesterday morning at Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, it looked as if both had two left feet. But that's what happens when Fred Astaire goes toe to toe with Hopalong Cassidy. In the end it was a very dissatisfying 12-round dance for both Reid, the slick puncher from Philadelphia, and Coker, the cowpuncher from San Antonio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, BETTIE
description: KURTZ-Bettie. Of Jersey City. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Stephen. Grandmother of four. For information, ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Despite Invitations to Debate, Pataki Avoids a Commitment
description: He has said repeatedly that he wants to debate, plans to debate and hopes to debate. But just nine days before the election, Gov. George E. Pataki has yet to actually commit to a debate against his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone. Mr. Pataki has said only that their campaigns are working on the arrangements.

title: Equity Offerings Listed
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: DANCE
description: The Glow of a Journey,

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about reasons people wrinkle with age misstated the link between smoking and the loss of collagen, the molecule that makes up most of the skin. Smoking worsens collagen loss and another disease of the elderly, osteoporosis; it is not osteoporosis that affects the skin.

title: Premonitions of Terrorism
description: Since the deadly bombing of two American embassies in Africa in August, there has been a troubling accumulation of evidence that the State Department inexplicably ignored warnings of possible terrorist attacks against the installations. The latest and most disturbing account suggests that nine months before the truck bombing in Kenya, the department received a detailed description of the planned attack but did little to strengthen security at the embassy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, BERTA
description: GRAF-Berta. Beloved wife of the late Oskar. Dear mother of Rudolf and Bettina. Loving grandmother of Jeffrey and Roberta Graf, Debbie and Mark Berman. Cherished great-grandmother of Allison, Sheryl, Daniel, David, Russell and Scott. Holocaust survivor from Vienna. Her warmth, loving kindness and strength will be sorely missed. In our hearts she will live forever. Funeral services Monday, October 26, at 10:30 AM, at Beth El Synagogue, Northfield Road and North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A map caption in Science Times on Sept. 29 with an article about the search for alien life misspelled part of the name of the observatory where the project is being conducted. It is the Arecibo Ionospheric Observatory, not the Iconospheric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, KINGDON
description: LANE-Kingdon. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Father of Barry and uncle of Paul Reback. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Is There a Case Against Mr. Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEHL, SEYMOUR
description: KOEHL-Seymour. It is with deep regret that we record the passing of our esteemed member Seymour Koehl. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ruth and the entire family. Fresh Meadow Country Club Steven Howard, President Allen Kaplan, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUGLIELMELLI, SILVIO M., M.D., FACP, FACCP
description: GUGLIELMELLI-Silvio M., M.D., FACP, FACCP. Internist and cardiologist of Brooklyn, on October 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Elaine (Lawson). Dear father of Sylvia MacFarlane, Claire Krotiuk and Carla Goggin. Also survived by six grandchildren, three sisters, Adeline Bosco, Elvira and Hilda Guglielmelli and brother Dante Melli. Reposing Coffey Funeral Home, Inc., 91 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY, Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Augustine Church, Ossining, NY. Interment Green-Wood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, The Salvation Army, or Habitat for Humanity would be appreciated.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Prospectus; Some New York on-line specialists are placing their ads off line on billboards, newspapers, radio and TV.
description: IF Scott Kurnit, the founder and chief executive of the Mining Company, ever finds himself feeling insignificant or questioning his new business endeavor, he can bolster his self-esteem by catching the F train from his offices in midtown Manhattan to SoHo and there gaze upon his company's latest marketing effort: a giant mural on a building on Houston Street near Broadway touting ''miningco.com.''

title: For DeBerg, One Battle That He Lost
description: Steve DeBerg is 44 years old and trying to play in a sport where old guys are swallowed up like raw meat in a zoo. That creaking noise you heard yesterday was DeBerg's knees when he walked onto the field as the starting quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Restoring Everglades
description: To the Editor:

title: James V. Hallisey, 70, Health-Care Lawyer
description: James V. Hallisey, a lawyer specializing in health care and Surrogate's Court matters, died on Oct. 16 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, SAMUEL
description: SANDERS-Samuel. 89. Of Hallandale, FL, formerly of Woodmere, NY, passed away Friday, 10/23/98. An attorney at law in New York for many years and Army veteran of WW II. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of Andra Sanders and Linda Murray (Stephen). Cherished grandfather of Gordon and Cara Murray. His warmth, humor and love for his wife, children and grandchildren will be sorely missed. Services graveside Monday, 10/26/98, 2 PM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association. RiversideGordon Memorial Chapel, Hollywood, FL. 800-759-1151.

title: In Debate, Spitzer Invokes Killing of Abortion Doctor
description: In the second and final debate in the race for State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic challenger, accused the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, yesterday of ignoring the threat posed by radical anti-abortion protesters, thereby helping to ease the way for this weekend's slaying of an obstetrician.

title: Running His Own Race
description: The morning of the 1997 New York City Marathon, Jerod Neas jumped in a car with his parents in Princeton, N.J., drove to Staten Island and hopped out at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge for a 26.2-mile commute through the city's five boroughs.

title: Four A's Addresses Review Problems
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York is undertaking three initiatives meant to address problems that occur in the agency review process.

title: The Politics Of Peace
description: Bismarck called Napoleon III a ''Sphinx without a riddle.'' That phrase might be used today to describe Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. While the agreement reached at the Mideast peace conference last week was widely welcomed, Mr. Netanyahu spent more energy on striking attitudes than on achieving practical gains, and he has damaged his political standing in Israel in the process. This raises the question of what this enigmatic man really stands for.

title: For Congress in New Jersey
description: Here are our endorsements for some of the more competitive races in New Jersey:

title: Noel Carroll, 56, Star Runner And Fitness Devotee, Is Dead
description: Noel Carroll, a hulking half-miler who set Irish, European and world records and helped establish Villanova as a showcase for a generation of Irish track stars, died in Dublin on Friday as he had so conspicuously lived -- on his feet, apparently after suffering a heart attack during his regular noontime run.

title: Web Site Owner Says He Had No Advance Word on Slaying
description: Neal Horsley, a 54-year-old computer programmer in Carrollton, Ga., does not understand what the fuss is about. Three years ago, he established a Web site called ''The Nuremberg Files,'' a list attempting, in his words, ''to record the name of every person working in the baby slaughter business across the United States of America.'' Each name in the list is either in black type, meaning ''working''; in gray, meaning ''wounded,'' or has a line through it, meaning ''fatality.''

title: The Impact of Violent Images
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Devastated Keys, a Call to Improve
description: It was not the five inches of gray muck that covered their once-green lawn or even their water-sopped mobile home -- its floors gone, its furniture ruined -- that disheartened Bob Dagnall and Dawn Kawzinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENK, LEONORE
description: SENK-Leonore. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Laurie Katz Braun, Asst. Rabbi

title: 4 Prized Drawings, No Longer Modern, Have Left MOMA
description: As one of the founders of the Museum of Modern Art, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller was steadfast in her conviction that the institution be devoted only to new art.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEMELKA, JEAN
description: SHEMELKA-Jean. Jean, we sure miss you. Rob and Dee

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; The Bosnian Horrors, Seen Close Up
description: BLOOD AND VENGEANCEOne Family's Story of the War in BosniaBy Chuck SudeticIllustrated. 393 pages. W. W. Norton. $26.95.

title: DANCE
description: A Juliet in Need of Calories,

title: For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate
description: Chuck Schumer had just graduated from Harvard Law School, earning a passport to the kind of wealth and freedom from worry that his parents could only imagine, when he broke the news to them that he had hatched a different plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, CAROL
description: SCHWIMMER-Carol. October 23. Beloved wife of Irving. Devoted mother of Alan and Judy Schwimmer, Marjorie and Frank Goldstein. Wonderful grandmother of Kristin, Aaron, Joshua, Talia and Laura. Loving great-grandmother of Charlotte and Eli. Services at Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave, Maplewood, NJ, Monday, noon. Contributions to the American Cancer Society. We love you; you have made our lives happier, and will remain in our memories and hearts forever.

title: Helping the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Opel Leader Resigns From G.M. Europe
description: A top European executive of the General Motors Corporation resigned over the weekend, the company said, because of ''differing perceptions of the company's business strategy.''

title: Yugoslavia Assures NATO Of Pullout to Avoid Attack
description: After brandishing yet another threat of Western air power, NATO's top two generals left Belgrade today with assurances that Yugoslavia will withdraw enough of its forces from the province of Kosovo by a Tuesday deadline to avoid punitive air strikes, according to Western diplomats.

title: At 25, Kronos Quartet Hasn't Lost Its Hipness
description: It is hard, on several counts, to believe that the Kronos Quartet has been around for 25 years. For one thing, the group continues to project a reasonably persuasive image of hipness if no longer of youth. For another, that image, and with it fame, did not coalesce until a decade or so after the group's founding.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Violence Against Abortion Doctors
description: The murder of Dr. Barnett Slepian is the latest depraved assault on the small number of courageous physicians who still risk their safety to perform legal abortions in this country. Dr. Slepian was one of only three doctors who performed abortions in the Buffalo area, and harassment and threats against him by anti-abortion groups had become routine over the past decade. He persevered through courage and a belief in the right of his patients to choose whether to bear a child.

title: Accounts
description: * Bridgestone/Firestone, Nashville, part of Bridgestone Corp., to Grey Advertising, New York, to handle its national account, which had been at TBWA/Chiat/Day, Playa del Rey, Calif., part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Essay; Now the Hard Part
description: Years ago, the joke was told of the Jewish matchmaker who had the idea of matching up poor Sammy -- a nebbish and a schlumpeh -- with Princess Margaret, then the world's most eligible woman.

title: Audience Left Wondering As Radio Host Disappears
description: Extra-dimensional beings, disasters foretold and Government conspiracies are standard fare on Art Bell's late-night radio talk show. In the last two weeks, though, the host provided listeners with a mystery of his own, signing off his nationally syndicated program in the small hours of Oct. 13 by saying that a life-threatening event meant this would be his last broadcast.

title: Useful Things to Remember About Those 'Useless Fifths'
description: One of the most mysterious elements in card play is the ''useless fifth.'' It always seems safe for a defender to make one discard from a five-card suit when it is clear that neither opponent can match that length. But there are some interesting exceptions, such as the diagramed deal played at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, in Manhattan.

title: Media Talk; A Question of Control For PBS Stations
description: With so many channels competing ever more fiercely for viewers, even soft-spoken public television must find ways to make its name stand out in the crowd. But which name -- the individual station's, or PBS's?

title: Editors Delay Goal on Diversity And Add a Concern for Women
description: After six months of intensive discussions about the extent to which newsrooms fail to reflect the ethnic diversity of the country, the governing board of the American Society of Newspaper Editors agreed last week that ''the nation's newsrooms must reflect the racial diversity of American society by 2025 or sooner.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADOCK, ROSABELLE J.
description: SADOCK-Rosabelle J. Beautiful and devoted wife of Jules B. Sadock. Died on October 22, 1998. She is survived by her beloved husband, her son Geoffrey, her daughter Dona, her daughter-inlaw Karen and her granddaughter Katharine. The funeral is private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Walter Kendrick, 51, Scholar of Literature
description: Walter Kendrick, a professor of English at Fordham University who was an authority on Victorian literature, an author and a literary critic, died early yesterday in Beth Israel Hospice in Manhattan. He was 51 and lived in the West Village.

title: Media Talk; New Assignments Under Zuckerman
description: New York City's tabloids can't seem to agree on much of anything. On Thursday, The New York Post reported that Fred Drasner, the chief executive at The Daily News, was resigning as group publisher of the three magazines owned by Mort Zuckerman -- U.S. News & World Report, The Atlantic Monthly and Fast Company, a business magazine. The Post said the move represented a loss of power for Mr. Drasner.

title: Federal Budget: Of Pork and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Refrain: Who Was Harmed?
description: The Microsoft Corporation's defense in the antitrust trial that began last week boils down to one question: Where's the harm?

title: Man Killed In an Attack On Officers
description: A man entered a station house in Queens last night, stabbed a police sergeant in the back with a screwdriver, lunged at another officer with a knife and was shot dead by officers, the police said.

title: Edison Project Stock
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVSTREIH, DAVID
description: AVSTREIH-David. We wish to express our profound sadness at the death of our dear friend, David Avstreih. David was an extraordinary man whose life focused not on what he could do for himself, but on what he could do for others. When we met he was our legal advisor, but he and Esther quickly became treasured friends. In addition to being expert in his profession, David was a generous, philosophical, humorous, sensitive and honest man. It is impossible to capture the essence of our David in words, but the best approximation would be ''mensch.'' We are blessed to have known such a man and wish to extend our condolences to our dear friend Esther, their children Alice and Cecil, and Bob, and grandson Dan. We will miss David greatly. Bobbie and Mickey Meshirer

title: Compressed Data; A Few Quirks Exposed In the Microsoft Trial
description: In Microsoft's view, the Government's antitrust suit represents ''a return of the Luddites,'' the English workers who first tried to stop the advance of industrialization in 1811 by smashing new machines that were being used to manufacture socks.

title: Drug-War Casualty
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Charge Man, 31, In Central Park Attack
description: A 31-year-old man with a lengthy criminal history was arrested early yesterday and accused of trying to rob a man at knifepoint in a Central Park playground, the police said, but investigators added that they did not believe the suspect was connected to other attacks in the park in recent weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITEL, NATHAN
description: TEITEL-Nathan. Age 88. On October 25, 1998; husband of the late beloved Carol, actress. He had won distinction in every literary genre: poetry, drama and fiction. His book of poems, ''In Time of Tide'', was noted by fellow poet, William Packard, as ''terse, impassioned and utterly lyrical-something that is rare in any day and age....The severe spirits of Catullus and Herman Melville hover over these lines, ominously plain and stark and heroic.'' Mr. Packard's Appreciation ''Catullus: Roaming over many lands and waters/I come, my brother,/to give you these last rites of death/and speak to your mute dust./Atque in perpetuum/frater, ave atque vale. Service Thursday, 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Anti-Gay Speech And Religious Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Archimedes Text Turns Up, and It's for Sale
description: A millennium-old volume, defaced by mildew and scorched around the edges, will go on the auction block on Thursday, and scholars hope that expert examination of the relic will reveal nuances in the thinking of Archimedes -- the greatest mathematical genius of the ancient world.

title: Sports of The Times; Big Spending Can Make Fiscal Sense
description: THE headline writer's job is to capture the essence of the story, and such was the case for the author of yesterday's Mets press release. ''Mets sign Mike Piazza to a record seven-year $91 million contract,'' the enlarged, bold print announced, with organizational pride and unrestrained glee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, HARRY
description: RAND-Harry. Of White Plains, N.Y. On October 24, 1998. A retired executive in the office of Rockefeller Family and Associates. Retired Lt. Col. Public Relations Manager, U.S.A., for KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. He is survived by his wife, Louise Rand, two daughters Lark Shlimbaum, Susan Joyce Braun, one granddaughter and two great grandchildren. Funeral service Thursday, 11AM at Saint Bartholomews Episcopal Church, White Plains, N.Y. Interment Arlington National Cemetery. Friends may call at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, N.Y. Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: French Insurer Buys U.S. Money Manager
description: AXA Investment Managers, a fund management unit of AXA S.A. of France, Europe's biggest insurer, said today that it had agreed to take control of Barr Rosenberg Investment Management, expanding its business in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSMAN, BEN
description: WACHSMAN-Ben. At the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Mollie. Devoted father of Harvey and Kathryn, and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Ashley, Marea, Melissa, Brandt, Dara, Trevor, David, Jacqueline, Lauren and Derek and greatgrandfather of David, Jeremy and Haley. Services Tuesday 11:30 am at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza Great Neck.

title: What the Pill Cannot Do
description: To the Editor:

title: East Orange Ex-Mayor Confirmed for U.S. Post
description: The United States Senate has confirmed President Clinton's nominee, Cardell Cooper, the former Mayor of East Orange, as assistant secretary for community planning and development in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the department announced yesterday.

title: A Space Adventure Tailored to Glenn's Contemporaries
description: In the commander's chair of a space shuttle, Robert Deupree safely brings his craft home after launching a satellite into orbit. Mission completed, Mr. Deupree and his crew emerge from the shuttle Falcon to the applause and cheers of well-wishers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Anti-Gay Speech And Religious Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Daimler Holders Swap Old Shares
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that its shareholders had swapped 97 percent of their shares in the company into stock of the forthcoming DaimlerChrysler A.G., enabling the company to avoid accounting charges of 54.9 billion German marks, or $33.5 billion, as it buys the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Hardest Habit to Break: Memories of the High
description: As anyone who has tried to quit smoking knows, it is much easier to get off an addictive drug than to stay off it. That applies to virtually all addicts and all types of addictions, whether to alcohol, cocaine, heroin, nicotine or amphetamines. Long after the drug is cleared from the body, it retains a powerful hold on the mind, and despite weeks, months or sometimes even years of abstinence, cravings can linger or suddenly make a shattering comeback. The usual, devastating, consequence is relapse.

title: At Least It Fools A Moose
description: The only time Dr. Joel Berger feels silly about dressing up like a moose is when tourists catch him in the act. Otherwise, it is serious work.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Abroad at Home; The Three Clintons
description: After nine days of secret meetings on the tormenting issues of Israeli-Palestinian peace, the denouement in the East Room of the White House had its inherent fascination. But for me the most interesting aspect of the ceremony was what it said about President Clinton. Three things, really.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMM, TRUDY
description: STAMM-Trudy. On October 25, 1998 at home. She had a full and vibrant life: family, friends, the arts, travel, the joy of writing, her beloved ballet. A spirited woman. Sister of Muriel Schertz, Benjamin, Dorothy, Milton and the late Raymond and Abraham. Visitation Tuesday, 2-7 PM at Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23 St., Manhattan.

title: Anticipating the Mood: Retailers Check the Pulse
description: As the millennium rapidly approaches, fashion is in a fix, and not about mundane matters like hemlines and silhouettes. There are intimations of a worldwide recession looming, and fears that the Y2K computer glitch will disrupt communication and transportation -- not to mention make it impossible to withdraw cab fare from a bank machine in the early hours of New Year's Day 2000.

title: Bayer Takes U.S. Partner in Herbicides
description: Bayer A.G., the big German producer of drugs and chemicals, and Paradigm Genetics, a biotechnology company based in Raleigh, N.C., said today that they had agreed to collaborate in developing new herbicides.

title: Trenton Pushes for Road Opposed by E.P.A.
description: In an indication that the Whitman administration is digging in its heels on a proposed road that Federal environmental officials have said is unnecessary, state officials insisted today that they needed more time to make their case for the proposed highway link.

title: In Poll, New Yorkers See Senate Contest as Too Negative
description: New York voters are growing increasingly critical of the caustic tone of the campaign for Senate, but the daily rounds of attacks between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Charles E. Schumer have yet to sway significant numbers of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Pedone Awarded Account at Corning
description: The Corning Consumer Products CompAny in Corning, N.Y., which markets consumer cookware products like Corning Ware, Pyrex and Corelle, said yesterday that it had named Pedone & Partners in New York to handle its account, which has been handled for 15 years by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, a unit of MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: A Jew, Then an Arab, Killed in the West Bank
description: A 28-year-old Jewish security guard was shot to death by two Palestinian gunmen this afternoon, his bloody body hurled from a speeding car and left by the roadside in the rancorously divided West Bank city of Hebron.

title: Political Briefing; In Maine, Democrats Stare Into the Abyss
description: ''As Maine goes, so goes the nation,'' or so went an old political saw. But that was before Maine became one of the nation's most politically quirky states.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: Insurer Must Pay $100.5 Million in Redlining Case
description: In a milestone decision, a Richmond jury ordered the Nationwide Insurance Company yesterday to pay $100.5 million in damages to a local housing group that accused the insurer of refusing to sell homeowner policies to black residents.

title: Slain Man Had Planned To See Family in Yemen
description: For weeks, Ahmed Kaida had been on a shopping spree. Every time the Yemeni immigrant went out, it seemed, he was buying clothes for his growing boys, toys to keep them entertained, dresses for the little girl he had never set eyes on. He had bought new luggage. He had had his teeth fixed at the dentist, and he had saved as much money as he could.

title: English Ketch Sets Monohull Record
description: The newly built yacht, Mari-Cha III, a high-tech, carbon fiber ketch owned by Robert Miller of England, succeeded last Saturday in doing what it was built to do: establish a trans-Atlantic monohull record from west to east.

title: South Africa Braces Itself For Report by Truth Panel
description: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission, in a report wrapping up two years of hearings into human-rights abuses in South Africa during the apartheid era, is expected to lay overwhelming blame on the government, but also to implicate members of the liberation struggle in atrocities, according to parts of the document that have been leaked.

title: Social Phobia and Alcoholism
description: To the Editor:

title: Taylor Enters Drug Clinic In Wake of Cocaine Arrest
description: Just over one week after his second arrest in three years on crack-cocaine charges, the former Giant linebacker Lawrence Taylor checked into a drug rehabilitation clinic in New Jersey last night, his lawyer said.

title: New Actions On Pinochet Begin in Paris And Geneva
description: As his lawyers in London tried to quash a Spanish arrest warrant for Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, efforts began in Geneva and Paris to have him extradited.

title: Happiness May Grow With Aging, Study Finds
description: Aging brings predictable travails: The body starts to crumble, memory decays, old friends begin to fall ill and die. But a new study indicates the passage of years may also bestow a heightened sense of well-being, at least for the generation of Americans now well into their retirement years.

title: Kenyans Who Train At Gentle Altitudes
description: It was a recent lunchtime and John Kagwe of Kenya was eating a Philadelphia cheese steak the size of a catcher's mitt. Actually, it was a variation called a pizza steak, which included the four basic food groups: fat, grease, french fries and enough cheese to line a 26.2-mile marathon course.

title: Define 'Tapering Off': To Run or Not to Run?
description: If you are entered in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, you have been training hard and are probably planning to skip running on Friday and Saturday, making them days of complete rest. But you may be making a big mistake, according to some coaches and physiologists who have revised their approach to the final stages of marathon training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, JOHN W. KOHNSTAMM
description: HERZ-John W. Kohnstamm, Inc. mourns the loss of John W. Herz, a resident of Larchmont, NY, who died on October 19. He was a senior partner of the law firm Wolf, Haldenstein, Adler, Freeman and Herz, and counsel to this company. He was a valuable Director and with his predecessor Herbert Haldenstein, established the company pension program. He will be missed by our company which was established in 1851, and was served by the Wolf Haldenstein firm for over 80 years. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Elise, and to their three sons. Avtar Singh, Managing Director Paul Kohnstamm, Chairman Timothy L.R. Hicks, Consultant

title: Keeping a Friend Close to His Heart
description: When Hartwig Gauder won a gold medal as a racewalker for East Germany in 1980, he covered 31 miles in an Olympic-record 3 hours 49 minutes 24 seconds. In Sunday's New York City Marathon, Gauder will struggle to complete 26.2 miles in seven hours.

title: Police Increase Presence in Central Park After Robberies
description: Reacting to a recent string of robberies in Central Park, the police stepped up security in the park last night and vowed to strictly enforce a 1 A.M. curfew that has long been on the books but has mostly been ignored.

title: Tegla Loroupe's Race for Respect
description: When she arrived here seven years ago from Kenya, looking for a coach and a manager, searching for someone to take her seriously as a runner, Tegla Loroupe found that sexism traveled without a passport. The man who would become her coach joked to another runner, ''Is this your girlfriend?'' He had never trained men and women in the same group. Women can be difficult to manage, he told her. What if romance interfered with running?

title: Planting Ominous Seeds In the Minds of Children
description: ''Frontline'' returns tonight to the 1980's, when the nation was afflicted by an epidemic of accusations of child abuse. Here again are the bizarre charges, sensational headlines, anxious parents, zealous or gullible prosecutors and juries persuaded by the testimony of children led on by so-called therapists. The one new element reported on tonight is the role of Janet Reno, who, when a state attorney in Miami, won a reputation for producing a method of getting convictions in shaky cases.

title: A Spy Mystery:Why Did Clinton Deny Israeli Plea?
description: PARIS  As long as it remains publicly unclear exactly what harm he did to the United States, it will be hard to understand exactly what made Jonathan Pollard, Israel's spy in the Pentagon, such a high-stakes issue that the U.S.-brokered accord last week between Israel and the Palestinians was nearly torpedoed.

title: Haiti Paralysis Brings a Boom In Drug Trade
description: Sensing a singular opportunity in a country weakened by a paralyzed Government and an inexperienced police force, Colombian and Dominican drug traffickers have made Haiti the fastest-growing transit point for cocaine on its way to the United States, American and Haitian law enforcement officials say.

title: Hernandez Gets Parade and Offers
description: The Orlando Hernandez fairy tale becomes more compelling by the day.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEGABIOS CORP., Burlingame, Calif., agreed to acquire GeneMedicine Inc., of Woodlands, Tex., for about $38.1 million in stock, creating a biotechnology company with seven products in clinical development and partnerships with four major drug makers.

title: Anti-Gay Speech And Religious Right
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Reassigns Opel Chief To Key U.S. Post on Labor
description: The General Motors Corporation replaced the top management today at its most important European subsidiary, Adam Opel A.G., but not before provoking a bitter rebellion by German management and labor leaders.

title: Intel Cuts Some Chip Prices
description: The Intel Corporation has cut prices on some of its chips for personal computers. Intel has been cutting prices on its chips more frequently as it faces competition from rivals like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. Prices for Intel's top-performing PC chip, the 450-megahertz Pentium II, fell to $562 in October from September; its price for the 350-megahertz Pentium II fell to $213, and its 400-megahertz Pentium II price fell to $375. Advanced Micro, which tends to price its chips about 25 percent below similar Intel versions, is expected to respond with its own cuts.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Fall 5 Percent on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market fell 5 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, reported yesterday.

title: Demographic Factors Foster Change : Onshore Markets In Europe Expand
description: PARIS  In their pursuit of the coveted high net worth individuals, private banks, especially divisions of large European commercial banks, are increasingly looking in their own backyards.

title: Even the Symphonic Elite May Have a Change of Mind
description: The Montreal Symphony was on strike for the first three weeks of its season and settled last week, just in time for its annual visit to Carnegie Hall and recording sessions with the pianist Martha Argerich. The Carnegie Hall series was to have been a nicely symmetrical package, with Ms. Argerich performing both Chopin Concertos, the First on Saturday evening, the Second on Sunday afternoon. The Sunday program was to have had another attraction as well, Henri Dutilleux's ''Timbres, Espace, Mouvement.''

title: Odiorne Wilde Wins Salon's Account
description: Salon, an on-line magazine operated by Salon Internet Inc. (www.salonmagazine.com), has named Odiorne Wilde Narraway & Partners in San Francisco as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $2 million. Patrick Hurley, marketing director at Salon in San Francisco, said a two-month review of the account had also included Blazing Paradigm in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONISH, GERTRUDE
description: KRONISH-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Joan Parmet and Eleanor Goldstein. Cherished grandmother of Wendy Parmet and Michael, Eric, and Talley Goldstein. Also survived by four loving greatgrandchildren. Dear sister of Sarah Edelson. Services Wednesday 12:00 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR station. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah.

title: Daiwa Bank to Cut Employee Pay 10%
description: Daiwa Bank Ltd. will cut employees' salaries by 10 percent and focus on business in its home city of Osaka, the bank said two days after announcing the closing of its overseas branches.

title: New Families Redraw Racial Boundaries
description: Until he was 3 years old, Ryan Golden had his own understanding of race: boys were white like him, he figured, and girls, like his African-American sister, Nikki, had dark skin.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Bearing Baby With Ease

title: Three-Acre Legacy of the A-Bomb; A Pile of Radioactive Dirt Awaits Cleanup in New Jersey
description: In an industrial part of this suburban town, behind a chain link fence topped by barbed wire and a pole with a forlorn and tattered wind sock, is an unintended monument to the atomic age: a three-acre, 20-foot-high mound of radioactive dirt tightly sheathed in matte black polyethylene.

title: PHILIP SERVICES SELLING SOME PLANTS FOR $70 MILLION
description: The Philip Services Corporation, an industrial-waste and scrap-metal recycler, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its aluminum plants to Wabash Alloys L.L.C., a subsidiary of Connell Limited Partnership, for about $70 million in cash to reduce its $1.1 billion in debt. The sale includes an aluminum deoxidizing plant in Bellwood, Va., and alloys plants in Syracuse and Guelph, Ontario. Philip is based in Hamilton, Ontario. The company ran up its debt as it purchased steel and iron scrap operations and is now narrowing its focus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, MANNY
description: FINK-Manny, passed away October 25, 1998, survived by loving wife Claudette, adoring sons Henri B. and David B., broken-hearted mother Anna and caring brother David. Former Managing and Director of Oppenheimer & Co. and private entrepreneur. The sun will never shine as brightly for us again. Services Tuesday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Giuliani Stumps With D'Amato, While Bratton Backs Schumer
description: Four years after he attacked Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato as a threat to ethics in government, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned with the Senator in Republican strongholds across the city yesterday, contending that Mr. D'Amato's influence within Congress's Republican majority was vital to the city's well-being.

title: Vanishing Launching Pads
description: To the Editor:

title: AVERY DENNISON AND STEINBEIS PLAN EUROPEAN VENTURE
description: The Avery Dennison Corporation, based in Pasadena, Calif., and a unit of Steinbeis Holding G.m.b.H., of Germany, said yesterday that they would set up a joint venture to manufacture and market office products in Europe. Terms were not disclosed. Avery makes self-adhesive stamps, labels and other products. Steinbeis's subsidiary Zweckform Buero-Produkte produces labels, films and specialty paper for office use. Avery will hold a majority stake in the venture, to be called Avery Dennison Zweckform Office Products Europe G.m.b.H. and to be based in Oberlaindern, Germany.

title: Master Teachers Whose Artistry Glows in Private
description: When holding forth on almost any subject, George Bernard Shaw usually got to the truth of the matter with blunt, unsentimental brilliance.

title: Brooklyn Man Convicted of First-Degree Murder Rejects Deal, Risking Death Penalty
description: A Brooklyn man convicted of first-degree murder rejected a deal yesterday under which prosecutors would not have sought the death penalty and would have agreed to a life prison sentence for him provided he agreed to give up his right to appeal the conviction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATEMAN, DANIEL
description: STATEMAN-Daniel. 78. On October 25, of Cancer. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, the former Ruth Gladstone, sons, Ethan and Keith. A 1947 graduate of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, he owned and operated a pharmacy in Flushing. He retired as Alumni Director and Director of Special Services for the College of Pharmacy of Long Island University. On December 8, 1941 he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and was discharged 5 years later as a 1st Lt. An advocate for pharmacy, active member Temple Beth Sholom in Flushing.

title: A Computer Glitch Interrupts Trading
description: A computer glitch forced the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading for nearly an hour yesterday, setting off trading interruptions at stock and futures exchanges nationwide. It was the Big Board's first big technology problem in three years.

title: Dow Slips 20.08 in Modest Trading Highlighted by Delay
description: Stocks were mixed in relatively subdued trading yesterday, a session highlighted by a computer glitch on the New York Stock Exchange that halted trading for nearly an hour.

title: Long Talks Yield Little Progress In Lockout
description: Representatives of the National Basketball Association and its locked-out players yesterday held the longest negotiating session in their labor dispute, which has brought the cancellation of the season's first two weeks, but chief negotiators said that no progress was made.

title: D.C. Coach Is Set to Take Over
description: U.S. MEN'S NATIONAL TEAM

title: Movado Group hires an outside agency to reset the luxury face of its Concord watch.
description: A LEADING maker, distributor and retailer of watches is naming an outside agency to handle one of its top brands.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction at Lipper Analytical Services, the closed-end fund table in Money & Business on Sunday carried week-old data. A corrected table appears today, on page C25.

title: Into a 3-Month Maelstrom
description: During the last few months in Russia, no one could be blamed for asking, ''Can this nation be saved?''

title: Patterns
description: The Failure Virus

title: I.B.M. Consolidates, From 60 Down to 6
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had consolidated its worldwide interactive account at 6 agencies, down from 60. Billings were estimated at more than $40 million.

title: When Girls Make Their Mothers Sick
description: Few pregnant women escape the well-meaning chums who insist they can tell a baby's sex from various telltale signs -- like the height of the mother's belly or the foods she craves.

title: Go With the Overflow? An Opening for ESPN
description: Will Cablevision Systems' newly revealed distaste for creating ''overflow'' channels when two or more teams play games on Fox Sports New York or the MSG Network provide ESPN with the impetus to start a local cable sports channel?

title: Insurers Reviewed in Japan
description: Moody's Investors Service said today that it was reviewing its assessment of the creditworthiness of eight Japanese life insurance companies and might lower their credit ratings. Declining stock prices have probably eroded the value of their huge equity portfolios, Moody's said. The companies are Meiji Mutual Life, Dai-Ichi Mutual Life, Taiyo Mutual Life, Fukoku Mutual Life, Mitsui Mutual Life, Asahi Mutual Life, Tokyo Mutual Life and Sumitomo Life.

title: Many Donors To Pataki Do State Business
description: In his quest for another term, Gov. George E. Pataki and his fellow Republicans have mounted the most successful fund-raising operation in New York history, drawing support from thousands of donors, many of whom share a common trait: they do business with the state.

title: Anti-Gay Speech And Religious Right
description: To the Editor:

title: SERBS IN KOSOVO ARE WITHDRAWING FROM MANY POSTS
description: Only a day before a NATO deadline and under the threat of air strikes, Yugoslavia today began what appeared to be serious troop withdrawals from many positions in Kosovo. Soldiers and policemen abandoned many positions they had fortified over the last three months, and waited, with hard faces and bandoleers of ammunition, for military buses to pick them up on the roadsides.

title: Peru and Ecuador Sign Treaty To End Longstanding Conflict
description: In an emotional ceremony that officially ends a bitter conflict that spanned generations, the Presidents of Peru and Ecuador signed a peace treaty here today to open their borders and create avenues for trade and development.

title: Doctor Is Eulogized as Killer Is Sought
description: Pallbearers carried the body of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian from the Amherst Memorial Chapel in suburban Buffalo after funeral services yesterday. Dr. Slepian, an obstetrician who performed abortions, was killed in his home Friday by a sniper. He was eulogized as a kind and caring physician. Page B1.

title: Sports of The Times; The Best Intentions For a Race Never Run
description: MY Marathon Blues came earlier than usual this year.

title: Teligent Begins Foray in Telecommunications
description: Alex J. Mandl, who resigned as president of the AT&T Corporation in 1996, has kept a low profile recently. Ever since his new company, Teligent Inc., went public last fall, he has kept his head down -- quietly securing additional financing, building networks and constructing a sales force.

title: Vast Shakespearean Drama With All People as Players
description: SHAKESPEARE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, today your 80th. Birthday celebrations had always been happy days for all of us. Through your wisdom and insight, you gave us your strength. We miss you so much. Love always. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-me

title: VITAL SIGNS: PRO & CON; Putting Pig Parts Into Human Bodies
description: Should researchers be permitted to experiment with the transplanting of pig cells or organs into humans? JOHN O'NEIL

title: Casting Moon Glow Across 2 Cultures
description: Wherever good intentions may lead, it is never a pleasure to take issue with them. The Harmonia Opera Company was created in 1981, its program booklet says, ''for the purpose of promoting an artistic bond between Japan and America.'' But the company's latest production, the hourlong ''Princess Kaguya,'' at the Kaye Playhouse on Saturday evening, raised questions of principle and practice.

title: Graduate Students Aren't Robots; Exploited in the Lab
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Composer Unabashed by Cries of the Heart
description: Gerard Schwarz's advocacy of American music goes back to the start of his conducting career, in the mid-1970's, and beyond that to his trumpet-playing days. Early on, his tastes in new music were fairly omnivorous: his lamented Music of Today series mixed the difficult and the accessible, often showing that the distance between them was not so vast. In recent years, both in the concert hall and in recordings, he seems to have narrowed his focus, largely dropping harmonically thorny works from his repertory and delving more deeply into the neo-Classical and neo-Romantic repertories.

title: Learning to Put the Best Shoe Forward
description: To the list of factors that affect one's fate, add footwear.

title: So Where's the Button To Fix the Brightness?
description: A sacred tenet in the cult of celebrity holds that personality is all, even if the famous person has nothing clever to say. Maybe television should rethink that idea, which seems responsible for the failure of this dismal season. Commercially and creatively, the season that began just over a month ago is one of the worst in memory. While the badness of new shows has become a familiar story, never has the distance between the pure acting talent on screen and their mediocre material seemed so vast.

title: Ruling Puts Leniency, a Top Tool For Prosecutors, Under Scrutiny
description: Every day in courts across the country, witnesses take the stand in exchange for favorable treatment from prosecutors. Some people call them informers. Prosecutors call them essential.

title: Bure Makes His Stand And Waits for a Trade
description: Twice a day a limousine pulls up in front of Luzhniki Arena in Central Moscow dropping off Pavel Bure, kit bag and all. That he arrives in such fashion is not so much an expression of prosperity brought on in seven seasons in the National Hockey League, but more for security reasons. In an economy near collapse, people may take desperate measures against such a wealthy local.

title: Yeltsin Drops Vienna Trip; Fears About His Health Grow
description: Three days after his spokesman insisted that he had conquered bronchitis, enjoyed normal health and was wounded by rumor mongering to the contrary, President Boris N. Yeltsin called off a one-day visit to Austria today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David. October 27, 1989. Remembered with love By his family.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Panic has not yet set in, but reality has.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, GLADYS
description: MURPHY-Gladys. Age 95, in Pasadena, CA, on October 23, 1998. Widow of James A. Murphy; predeceased by parents, Charles and Jeannette Lynch, six brothers and sisters and nephew Charles E. Brown. Loving aunt, survived by Eugene and Alice Brown, Marie and Ed Flynn, Joan Sutherland, Barbara Brown and Mary Coe. Also seventeen grand-nieces and nephews and eleven great-grandnieces and nephews, as well as many loving in-laws and numerous friends from Florida to Alaska. Gladys retired from Con Edison as a customer service representative. Rosary at Flynn Memorial, 1652 Central Avenue, Yonkers, NY, 8PM, October 27. Mass of Christian burial, 10AM, October 28, 1998, St. Anthony's Church, Yonkers, NY. Interment Pinelawn National Cemetery.

title: Canada Urged To Broaden Sniper Inquiry
description: Canadian abortion rights advocates called on the Canadian Government today to bolster and broaden a task force investigating a string of sniper attacks carried out over the last four years against doctors performing abortions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, SHIRLEY
description: BLOOM-Shirley. On October 25. Beloved mother of Alan. Dear sister of Milton (Lorraine). Loving aunt to nephews and nieces.

title: West New York Police Named in More Charges
description: New charges yesterday involving police corruption in West New York accused officers of extorting payments 125 times from people they believed were illegal immigrants in return for not charging them with petty offenses.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANTA CORP., Spring House, Pa., appointed Jeffrey E. Keisling as chief information officer.

title: Death Rate on U.S. Roads Reported at a Record Low
description: The death rate on the nation's roads fell to a record low last year, the Government said today after re-calculating travel statistics. The total number of deaths changed hardly at all, but the death rate fell because of the relentless increase in traffic.

title: The Athlete's Secret to Warding Off Overuse Injuries: Good Technique
description: Overuse injuries happen to the very best of athletes. Just 16 days before this year's United States Open golf tournament Tiger Woods was forced to take a break from golf for a week to let a sore back heal. Soon after, during the United States Open semifinal tennis match, Pete Sampras was hobbled by a strained muscle in his thigh.

title: New German Parliament Ponders History, Past and Future
description: The themes of an elusive unity and a painful history were dominant today as Germany's newly elected Parliament convened for its last inaugural session in this city on the Rhine.

title: John Didcott, South African Lawyer and Judge, Dies at 67
description: John Didcott, a South African judge known for his firm support of human rights during 23 years on the bench in and after the apartheid era, died last Tuesday at his home in Durban, South Africa. He was 67.

title: Abortion and Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Ordered to Stand Trial In Killing of Pizza Deliverymen
description: A state judge found today that a suspect in the ambush and slaying of two pizza deliverymen in Franklin in April 1997 was mentally competent, and ordered him to stand trial on murder charges, beginning Feb. 22.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Mixed as Glitch Interrupts Big Board Action

title: VW Profit Surged In the 3d Quarter
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that profit in the third quarter had risen a better-than-expected 86 percent because of higher demand for its VW brand cars and continuing cost savings. VW shares surged 9.3 percent, to 123.5 marks, as the company said profit from July through September rose to 676 million marks ($916 million) from 364 million marks last year, beating an average forecast of 527 million marks.

title: On the Run Every Day, for More Than 23 Years
description: Most of the 30,000 people who will run the New York City Marathon on Sunday train daily for the 26.2-mile event. Some manage to run every day for weeks, even months. But one entrant has not missed a day of running since Gerald Ford was President and disco filled the airwaves.

title: A Scruffy Old Tavern Is Now Luxury Apartments
description: Manhattan's oldest building is a venerable Georgian chapel, its second oldest, a graceful country estate. Its third oldest building was one of the foulest grog shops within staggering distance of the East River wharves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, FRANK
description: DUNNE-Frank. Age 73. In Wilmington, N.C. on October 17, 1998. His former colleagues at White Weld and Merrill Lynch mourn his passing. He was the best. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife Didi and to his son Frank. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yale University, Yale Soccer Association, POB 208216, New Haven CT 06520 or the American Cancer Society-NYC Division, 19 W. 56 St, NY NY 10019.

title: NBC Says Time Is Right As It Picks an Executive
description: NBC officially anointed Scott Sassa yesterday as the executive who will lead the network's entertainment division, installing him as president of entertainment in place of Warren Littlefield, the longtime programming executive for the network.

title: Georgianna Kappes History Teacher, 94
description: Georgianna Morris Crowther Kappes, a longtime teacher of history in private schools, died on Oct. 17 at Greenwich Hospital. She was 94 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVALUZZI, JOHN ANTHONY
description: CAVALUZZI-John Anthony. On October 25, 1998 at age 92 after a long illness. Devoted husband of the late Elsie. Loving father of Nancy and John, M.D. and daughter-in-law Olivia. Proud grandfather of Christina and Michael. He will be terribly missed by all his nieces, nephews, other family members and many friends. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC Thursday, 4-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 9:30 AM at Saint Bernard of Clairvaux Church, 328 W. 14 St, NYC. Intombment Rose Hills Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY.

title: Metro Business; S.N.E.T. Sale Is Completed
description: SBC Communications has completed its $6.5 billion purchase of the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, allowing SBC to move into the Bell Atlantic Corporation's northeastern territory.

title: Richter Takes a Turn for the Better
description: At the center of the Rangers' four game unbeaten streak is the man who stands between the pipes.

title: Countdown Begun, Glenn and Shuttle Crew Arrive
description: With the countdown clock running and all preparations on schedule here, the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery, including Senator John Glenn, flew in today from Houston to get ready for their nine-day mission, set to begin at 2 P.M. on Thursday.

title: Two Views of Growing Up When the Faces Don't Match
description: Kirsten Albrecht and Alexis Oberdorfer are both 27-year-olds born of one black parent and one white parent, and adopted, as infants, by white parents.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day last Thursday, about Conoco's initial public offering of stock, misstated the percentage purchased by small investors. It was 25 percent, not 80.

title: Accounts
description: * Symantec Corp., Cupertino, Calif., the software products marketer, to Partners & Simons, Boston, as creative agency for corporate advertising, and Carat Freeman, Wellesley, Mass., a unit of Aegis Group P.L.C., as media agency. Billings on those assignments, which had been handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: SFS BANCORP SHARES FALL AFTER COHOES CANCELS DEAL
description: Shares in SFS Bancorp Inc. fell yesterday, the first day of trading after the privately held Cohoes Savings Bank announced late Friday that it had canceled plans to buy SFS. SFS stock fell $1.75, to $22.50. SFS, based in Schenectady, N.Y., had risen 36 percent, to $27.25, on Aug. 3 after Cohoes announced plans to acquire it and to convert itself from a mutual company to a public company. A mutual savings and loan or bank holding company is owned by its depositors. Cohoes, a savings and loan based in Cohoes, N.Y., a suburb of Albany, said Friday that it still planned to convert to public ownership.

title: Infant Homicide Found to Be Rising in U.S.
description: The number of infant homicides has increased to the point that a baby is killed practically every day in the United States, according to the largest study of the subject ever undertaken. Though it makes few conclusions about who commits these crimes and why, the study suggests how to protect babies at high risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ARTHUR
description: FELDMAN-Arthur. October 24, 1998. Husband of Sylvia nee Shenker. Father of Donald Feldman, stepfather of Ross and Gregg Graison. Also survived by grandchildren and great grandchildren. Services and interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTENTHAL, MINNIE

Treasured by daughter and son-inlaw Phyllis and Larry Bangser and their children and grandchildren, and by Larry and Estelle Mittenthal and Richard and Joyce Mittenthal and all of their children and grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be given to the charity of your choice. Services private.

title: Global Thermometer Imperiled by Dispute
description: A $40 million research program has proved that sound can be used to measure the temperature of the world's oceans and detect long-term climate change, scientists say. But the project has spent so much money meeting demands by environmental groups that its leaders expect to have to end the program a year from now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BONNIE
description: ROSEN-Bonnie. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved wife of Leonard Rosen. Devoted stepmother of Michele, Andrew and Jeffrey. Dear sister of Paul Fass. Loving grandmother of Brianna. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'' Hackensack, N.J. Tuesday, 10AM. Contributions may be made to Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 6th Ave, NY NY 10104.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Soros Making Some Changes In His Funds
description: George Soros, one of the world's most famous investors, is making several changes at his Quantum Group of mutual funds after poor investment returns in the recent months of global financial turmoil, with some funds showing declines of more than 15 percent so far this year. One fund, which Mr. Soros is proposing to close, has lost more than 30 percent of its value this year.

description: Alan Dickison went to the funeral of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian this afternoon carrying his two towheaded children, Connor, 4, and Kelsey, 2, a boy and girl whom Dr. Slepian had delivered.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing Suspects Are Isolated in New York Jail
description: Federal prison officials have cut off virtually all communications for two men being held in Manhattan in the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

Also survived by his father Nicola, his brothers Dominic and Paul, and his sisters Catherine and Isabel. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 7-9 pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont NY. Mass Thursday 10 am at St. Mary's Star of the Sea Church, City Island. Interment Pelham Cemetery, City Island, NY.

title: City Union To Be Audited By Its Parent
description: With prosecutors investigating accusations of embezzlement and kickbacks at New York City's largest municipal labor union, its Washington-based parent union announced yesterday that it would audit the books of the municipal union, District Council 37, and the council's 56 member locals.

title: Winnie R. Judd, 93, Infamous As 1930's 'Trunk Murderess'
description: Winnie Ruth Judd, who spent three decades in an Arizona state mental hospital as the notorious ''trunk murderess'' in one of the most sensational criminal cases of the 1930's, died in Phoenix on Friday. She was 93.

title: Live High, Train Low and Move Faster
description: For years, many endurance athletes have believed that exercising in thin mountain air is the best way to improve performance at sea level. But recently, a team of doctors gave a new spin to the high-altitude hypothesis and discovered that living a more sedentary life in the mountain air while training at a lower level gives athletes the greatest gains.

title: In California Coast Race, the National Scandal Ebbs as the Local Issues Flow
description: Last winter, when Lois Capps decisively won a special Congressional election to finish the term of her late husband, Walter, in this swing district on California's central coast, politicians of both parties all but wrote off her Republican opponent, Assemblyman Tom Bordonaro, as a hopeless case for this fall.

title: Material Hints Of Assistance In Jones Case
description: Kathleen E. Willey, a one-time White House volunteer who has said she was briefly groped in the Oval Office by President Clinton, may have once tried to help Paula Corbin Jones succeed in her sexual misconduct lawsuit against the President, according to court documents filed by a former Jones lawyer.

title: In Search of the Perfect Stretching Formula
description: For decades, experts have been reminding people to stretch to improve and maintain flexibility and, for the first time, the American College of Sports Medicine has issued guidelines for flexibility training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUGGIERO, JOSEPH THOMAS
description: RUGGIERO-Joseph Thomas (Rogers). Passed away Sunday, October 25, at his home in Manhattan surrounded by his family. He was 87 years old. Joe was born on February 8, 1911, in New York City. Joe was a mill worker and a proud member of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, Union Local 246, for 70 years. Joe lived nearly his whole life in Astoria and was a parishioner at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Roman Catholic Church. Joe's family and friends will miss him and will never forget how he touched their lives. Joe is survived by his wife, Mildred, and two daughters, Gloria Ruggiero and Carol Ruggiero Shabe. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and 13 great - grandchildren. Visitation Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 79pm at Joseph Farenga & Sons (Queens Chapels), 38-08 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10:30am Immaculate Conception R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations are to be made to Cabrini Hospice Center, 227 E. 19 St., NYC, 10003, in his memory.

description: House Available: Specs on Demand

description: Because of a computer malfunction at Lipper Analytical Services, the closed-end fund table in Money & Business on Sunday carried week-old data. A corrected table appears today on page C25.

title: Man Killed in Police Station Had Psychiatric Problems
description: A man who was shot to death by the police on Sunday night after walking bare-chested into a Queens station house and attacking officers with a screwdriver and a kitchen knife had a long history of psychiatric problems and had recently complained to his mother about ''the Devil,'' law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: 'Too Many Players' In a Lean Market : Shakeout Expected In Asia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  "By 2000, Asia will be the largest private banking market in the world."

title: Big Investor Wary Of Stock-Pay Moves By Bridge News
description: A leading mutual fund industry executive today sharply questioned the growing practice among United States corporations of repricing stock options granted to their executives.

title: Dow Jones Presents Three-Year Plan to Bolster Earnings
description: Less than a year after swallowing a $1 billion loss from its unsuccessful venture into financial information services, Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced a three-year financial plan yesterday that is intended to increase earnings 10 percent a year.

title: By Design; Long Hair, a la Cher
description: Think Cher. The hair story for next spring, as played out on the European runways, is long and straight, falling well below the shoulders, and most often parted in the center.

title: Voters Are Asked to Cede Power on Horse-Race Issues
description: New Jersey's voters will be asked next week to amend the State Constitution to give up a half-century of power to select the types of betting allowed on horse racing, and ultimately make it easier to introduce off-track betting and betting by telephone.

title: New Poll, New Math and That New College Try
description: There's a new poll, a new No. 1 and some new math for gridiron-ologists to digest as college football marches on to the bowl season and, presumably, an undisputed national champion. The Bowl Championship Series has released its first ranking and the U.C.L.A. Bruins are on top.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROPP, ETHEL ROBBINS
description: TROPP-Ethel Robbins. Age 96. On October 24, 1998. Devoted wife of the late James Tropp. Loving mother of Alberta T. and Lester Salkin, Yvonne D. and the late Alan R. Tropp. Cherished grandmother of Leslie and Lester Millman, Jonathan and Oleasa Salkin, Karen and Robert Veronesi, Janis Tropp, Dana Tropp, Lisa and Tim Fitzgerald.
