Funeral services 12 noon Tuesday, October 27, Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave. (Ave. V), B'klyn.

title: BOEING AND BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO BUILD FLIGHT CENTER
description: The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft maker, and Berkshire Hathaway Inc., its partner in a joint venture, said yesterday that they would build a $100 million flight-training center in Miami to instruct pilots for Latin American routes. The center will train 7,000 pilots and 3,000 flight technicians annually and will be the largest flight-training center not owned by an airline, Boeing said. Its new Boeing Enterprises is trying to capture business from airlines that hire outside companies to handle maintenance and training. The Miami center will be run by Flightsafety Boeing Training International, Boeing's joint venture with Berkshire Hathaway's Flightsafety International unit.

title: Mets' Brass Is Talking Of Dealing For Bonilla
description: Mike Piazza has signed. Al Leiter has all but signed. And now the Mets' next move may be bringing back someone they once made the highest-paid player in the game when they signed him as a free agent almost seven years ago: Bobby Bonilla.

title: Q & A / Rudolfo Bogni, UBS Executive : Staying Ahead of the Competition
description: The banking environment has changed substantially since Swiss Bank Corp. merged with Union Bank of Switzerland earlier this year to become UBS AG, the world's second-largest bank and the largest in the field of private banking. UBS reported a $700 million loss on account of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund, and its chairman resigned over the affair. Rudolfo Bogni, chief executive for private banking at UBS, spoke with Conrad de Aenlle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIOR, RICHARD D.
description: DIOR-Richard D. of Marlboro, NJ on October 26th. Beloved husband of Sandra (nee Rubin). Devoted father of Scott Dior and Rachel Rodriguez. Dear father-in-law of Jason Rodriguez. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Cedar Knolls, NJ.

title: Dizzy Gillespie's Memory Draped With Loving Care
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie was such a powerful figure as a person and as a musician that those who knew him still tread lightly around his name, and try to live up to his standards. At the Blue Note on Wednesday, a party celebrating both the club's 17th anniversary and what would have been Gillespie's 81st was filled with Gillespie and his way. The club had brought in a Gillespie tribute band led by the bassist John Lee and invited friends and band-mates of Gillespie to play.

title: Williams Puts One Foot Out the Door
description: After years of contentious contract negotiations, Bernie Williams took a possible first step away from the Yankees yesterday, becoming a free agent for the first time. Though anything could happen, the prevailing feeling in baseball circles is that Williams will sign elsewhere.

title: Switch Failure Halts Trading On New York Stock Exchange
description: A computer glitch forced the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading for nearly an hour yesterday afternoon, setting off a cascade of trading interruptions at stock and futures exchanges across the country that list products linked to the Big Board.

title: U.S. Finds Radium In South Jersey Water
description: Testing of the ground water supply used by 1.2 million people in southern New Jersey has revealed elevated levels of radium 224, a cancer-causing isotope that is difficult to detect because it dissipates quickly, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, NORMAN
description: RUBIN - Norman. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Brian C. Rappaport, President Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Panel Studying Iraq Missiles Is of 2 Minds on Nerve Gas
description: An international panel of arms experts announced today that they had accepted American scientific evidence indicating that Iraq had loaded some of its missiles with a deadly nerve gas known as VX.

title: Danone Plans to Buy Polish Cookie Maker
description: Danone S.A., Europe's third-largest food company, agreed yesterday to buy Poland's biggest cookie maker, Delicja, from Pepsico Inc. Paris-based Danone also said it would sell its German ready-meals business to the H. J. Heinz Company, the world's largest maker of ketchup. Terms of the transactions were not disclosed.

description: Dwight Stones, the stylish high jumper turned television commentator, has never been at a loss for words. Such was the case yesterday when he became one of four athletes voted into the National Track and Field Hall of Fame.

title: Five Boroughs in Four Hours: A Guide to Running 4:00.00
description: When the 29th New York City Marathon begins at 10:52 A.M. this Sunday, there will be elite athletes pushing ever closer to two hours and serious amateurs intent on breaking three hours. But there will be many more regular runners with a more modest goal: a four-hour or better marathon, a level reached by roughly a third (9,834) of last year's finishers. Here is Jere Longman's guide to running the New York course in four hours.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS SOARS. Prices rose as Hurricane Mitch headed for key Gulf of Mexico production and loading operations with winds of 170 miles an hour. The November contract rose 13.4 cents, to $2.298 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: John Daly, 86, Specialist in Head and Neck Surgery
description: John Francis Daly, an ear, nose and throat specialist who contributed to the development of modern head and neck surgery while associated with New York University Medical School and many other regional institutions, died last Wednesday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. A former resident of Tenafly, he was 86 and lived in Fort Lee.

title: At AT&T, Cost-Cutting Lifts Earnings
description: Since C. Michael Armstrong took over as chairman of the AT&T Corporation late last year, a pattern has emerged in the company's financial results: aggressive cost-cutting leads to strong earnings growth, but the company's revenue figures are tepid at best.

title: Far From Madding Beltway, Clinton Issue Intrudes
description: ''Bill Clinton brings out passion in people and that's what makes him a hard character to sit in judgment of,'' mused Representative Lindsey Graham, driving across his sun-dappled rural district far from Washington and pondering the impeachment task that awaits him after the election.

title: Travel Plans for Hamed Are Grounded
description: The already troubled show between Prince Naseem Hamed and Wayne McCullough hit another bump yesterday. Hamed remained in Sheffield, England, while his United States-based promoter, Cedric Kushner, scrambled to get him a last-minute visa so that the featherweight sensation could box in Atlantic City on Saturday night.

title: Anti-Gay Speech And Religious Right
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCIAL DEBATE DIVIDES DEMOCRATS AS ELECTIONS NEAR
description: Leading Democrats in Congress have angrily accused officials at the White House and the Democratic National Committee of hurting House and Senate campaigns by husbanding resources to erase the party's debt and help Vice President Al Gore kick off his own campaign in 2000.

title: MGM TO SELL NEW SHARES, MOSTLY TO KERKORIAN
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell 84.8 million shares for $8.25 each in an offering that would let its majority owner, Kirk Kerkorian, inject millions more dollars into the MGM. For each common share, investors would receive the right to buy 1.289 shares at a 12.6 percent discount from Friday's closing price. Mr. Kerkorian will buy at least $596.2 million of the $700 million offering just two months after he paid $389 million to raise his stake to 89.5 percent. MGM, which has not had an annual profit in 10 years, will use the new cash to expand its TV business and finance the $250 million purchase of a major film library. The company also reported a third-quarter loss of $40.3 million.

title: NATO Is Likely to Extend Deadline for Kosovo Strikes
description: NATO is almost certain to extend the Tuesday deadline for ordering air strikes against Yugoslav military and police forces, NATO and Clinton Administration officials said today as Yugoslav troops and equipment rumbled out of Kosovo.

title: At Trial, Microsoft Says Key Meeting Was a Setup
description: Opening a new line of defense in its antitrust trial, the Microsoft Corporation today portrayed a meeting that is a focal point in the Government's case as a ''setup'' orchestrated by its Internet software rival, the Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: Despite Early Expectations, Kennelly Faces Gap of Historic Dimensions
description: As Representative Barbara B. Kennelly's car headed back toward this capital city after a recent campaign event, she turned to glimpse the red maple and golden beech trees on the hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RORKE, JACQUELINE
description: RORKE-Jacqueline (nee Billingsley), 72, of Hackensack, NJ, formerly of Manhattan NY and Hollywood FL on October 25, 1998. She was the daughter of Sherman and Hazel Billingsley, owners of the Stork Club in New York City. Mrs. Rorke had attended the Spence School and graduated from Finch College, both located in New York. A former actress, Mrs. Rorke had also spent some time as a Real Estate broker. She is survived by her two sons, Alexander III of Evanston, IL, Brian of Haverhill, MA, a daughter, Hazel Rorke of Hackensack, NJ, two sisters, Barbara Mohler of Scottsdale, AZ and Shermane Billingsley of New York City. She is also survived by three grandchildren. She had been pre-deceased by her husband, Alexander, Jr. in 1963. A graveside service will be held on Tuesday, October 27 at 11:15 am at the Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. For further information contact C. C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, 201-445-0344

title: Palestinians Denounce Arafat's Forces
description: Denouncing Palestinian security chiefs as agents of the C.I.A., hundreds of youths marched through the streets of Ramallah today, protesting the killing of a teen-ager by the Palestinian police on Sunday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, WILLIAM DONALD
description: GARSON-William Donald. 71, former director of corporate communications at Forbes Magazine, died on Sunday, October 25, at the Sarah R. Neumann Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. due to complications from a stroke. A World War II Navy veteran and a graduate of Temple University, Don Garson was the son of William Roy and Anna Reilly Garson of Drexel Hill, PA. After a brief career as an actor, primarily in summer stock, he entered the newspaper advertising business with the now defunct New York Mirror, moving from there in 1963 to become head of promotion and research at The Saturday Review. In 1966 he joined Forbes Magazine as head of advertising promotion and research. He also handled public relations for both the magazine and its publisher, Malcolm Forbes. During his years at Forbes the magazine rose in prominence to become the number one publication in ad pages. He retired in 1992. Garson has been listed in Who's Who in Advertising, Who's Who in Finance and Industry and Who's Who in the World. A resident of the Edgemont area of Greenburgh, Westchester County, N.Y. since 1967, Garson was active in the Greenburgh Nature Center, serving as president of its Board of Directors in 1994 and 1995. He was also a member of the Greater Westchester Orchid Society and a past council member of the Greater Scarsdale United Way. He is survived by his wife, Mildred, of Edgemont, his son, Graham, of Littleton, CO., a brother, Robert, of West Chester, PA., two sisters, Claire Kelly of Mechanicsburg, PA. and Sister Nancy Garson, O.P. of Elkins Park, PA. and a grandson, Jeffrey. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Rd, Scarsdale, N.Y. 10583. Memorial mass to be held at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, NY on Friday, October 30 at 11am.

title: Political Briefing; In This Race, a Ticket Is Not Just a Slate
description: In 1984 when he ran for governor of North Carolina, and again in 1992 when he ran for the United States Senate, Lauch Faircloth's driving record became something of an issue after newspapers reported that he had been pulled over more than 30 times for speeding. Mr. Faircloth, a hard-right Republican, conceded he was a ''lead foot'' and, expressing regret, promised to slow down.

description: The killing of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, a gynecologist in Buffalo who performed abortions, has become a factor in at least two campaigns in New York, say political consultants and some campaign advisers.

description: They are either too young or too old is the vintage song Bill Parcells sings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MOLLIE
description: GOODMAN-Mollie. The Boards and Staff of United Jewish Appeal Federations of North America, a partnership of United Jewish Appeal, Council of Jewish Federations and United Israel Appeal, mourn the passing of Mollie Goodman, mother of Charles H. Goodman, Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency for Israel, UJA National Vice Chairman and former member of the UJA Board of Trustees, and past President of CJF. Our condolences to Charles and his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Conrad L. Giles, M.D., Pres. CJF Jay Yoskowitz, Exec. V.P., CJF Richard L. Wexler, Pres., UJA Carole A. Solomon, National Chairman UJA Bernard C. Moscovitz, Exec. V.P., UJA Bennett L. Aaron, Chairman, UIA Daniel R. Allen, Executive Vice Chairman UIA

title: Political Briefing; From Dr. King's Wife, Political Perspective
description: California voted it down. Houston voted it up. And next week Washington State votes on affirmative action.

title: Piazza, Risking Boos, Accepts Challenge With Mets
description: Acknowledging that he had become more and more comfortable as a Met last season, Mike Piazza said yesterday that he decided to remain with the team because of the challenge and potential rewards of playing in New York.

title: Home Resales Fell Last Month
description: Home resales fell in September for a second straight month, suggesting that low mortgage rates are not enough to overcome an overall slowing of the United States economy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an electoral debate between the New York State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, and his challenger, Eliot L. Spitzer, omitted a word in identifying Mr. Spitzer. He is a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, not a current one.

title: 2 Firefighters Who Rode Float in Blackface Are Dismissed
description: Two white firefighters who were suspended for wearing blackface as they rode on a parade float in Queens on Labor Day were dismissed from their jobs yesterday, Fire Department officials said.

title: Seeing Stars
description: Q. I have heard that all the stars we can see with the naked eye, except for a few faint nebulae, are part of our own galaxy. If that is so, why aren't the visible stars confined to the Milky Way band?

title: Abortion and Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Horror-Show Absurdism Brought Into the 90's
description: Closing its highly successful season at City Center, the San Francisco Ballet went out with a blast of pyrotechnics and good will on Sunday afternoon in a weekend that brought out the company's Danish connection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAHA, JOHN F.
description: BLAHA-John F. On October 26, 1998 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved Husband of Margaret W. Blaha. Father of John W. and the late Robert L. Blaha. Also survived by 7 Grandchildren and 7 Great Grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, NY on Tuesday 7-9PM and Wednesday 25 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church on Thurs. 10:45AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGETSON, ROSE C.
description: MARGETSON-Rose C. (nee Willoughby). On October 24, 1998, of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late composer, organist and founder of the Schubert Music Society, Edward H. Margetson. Mother of Barbara M. Watson and Desmond W. Margetson. Grandmother of Craig and Dr. Marc Watson and Evan and Neil Margetson. Greatgrandmother of Armand, Devyn, Adam and Vanessa Watson, Arlen and Rose Margetson. Born in Kingston, Jamaica, W.I. April 22, 1904. She came to the U.S. in 1920 as a music student and became a citizen. She studied voice and music theory with teachers, Richard Crooks, Augusta Scheiber and Edward Margetson. She maintained a life-long interest in the arts. Loved by family and friends, she was our light. A 95th birthday memorial is planned for April 1999.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Black Loyalty to Clinton Hinders G.O.P. Outreach
description: At this point in her race for the House two years ago, polls showed Anne Northup with the support of about 8 percent of her district's African-American vote. And though she squeaked out a victory, Ms. Northup, a Republican, fared so poorly in Louisville's black neighborhoods that in one precinct she received only 5 out of 600 votes.

title: Hyundai Group to Close 25 of Its Companies
description: Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest industrial group, said yesterday that it planned to shut down about 25 of its 62 companies by mid-1999 as part of its efforts to focus on its most profitable business lines. A spokesman said the company would regroup the surviving companies into five sub-sectors: automotive, chemical and heavy machinery, electronics, construction, and banking and other services.

title: Sun Microsystems Introducing A New Version of Unix Today
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to introduce a new version of its Solaris operating system on Tuesday in an effort to capitalize on delays by the Microsoft Corporation in its newest version of the Windows NT operating system.

title: Better Returns Drive Investment Demand : Private Equity Deals Entice Entrepreneurs
description: NEW YORK  Top of the shopping list for many prospective private banking clients is exposure to private equity deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, STANLEY I.
description: FISHEL-Stanley I. Age 84. On October 25, 1998. Former chairman of Fairfax Advertising Agency, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi/ Worldwide. Graduate of Columbia College 1934. World War II Lt. Commander U.S. Coast Guard. Former National President of Zeta Beta Tau. Founding director of the Fraternity's student loans and scholarships. Named Interfraternity ''Man of the Year'' by the National Interfraternity Conference. Beloved brother of James. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison ave at 81 St, Wednesday, 10am. Interment Mt. Judah Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to ZBT Foundation, Fishel Fellowship Fund, 3905 Vincennes Road, Suite 101, Indianapolis, IN 46268.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard, Ph.D., on October 26th, 1998. Beloved husband of Bernice, father of Charles, Myra (predeceased) and Phyllis, grandfather of Maraysa and Joseph Schwartz and Michelle and Sarah Nessen, and father-in-law of Antoinette Schwartz and Joshua Nessen. Services on Wednesday, October 28th, Temple Beth-El, Poughkeepsie, NY. Rest in peace.

title: Time Warner Is Sued by U.S. In Employee Benefits Case
description: The Department of Labor sued Time Warner Inc. and officials of nine corporate pension and health plans today, saying they wrongly denied health and retirement coverage to hundreds of employees.

title: MACDERMID PLANS TO PURCHASE BRITISH CHEMICALS GROUP
description: The MacDermid Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire W. Canning P.L.C. for 300 British pence a share, or $:89 million ($150 million). Canning, based in Birmingham, England, is a 223-year-old specialty chemicals company whose principal business is plating additives. It has annual revenue of about $:156 million. MacDermid, based in Waterbury, Conn., makes specialty chemicals and equipment for electronics, metal finishing and graphic arts. It had revenue of $166.9 million in the six months ended Sept. 30.

title: LEGATO TO ACQUIRE FULLTIME SOFTWARE FOR $69.4 MILLION
description: Legato Systems Inc., a maker of software to protect and store computer data, said it would acquire Fulltime Software Inc. for $69.4 million in stock to improve its customers' accessibility to data. Legato, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it would issue 1.72 million shares in exchange for all stock and options of Fulltime. Legato had 1997 sales of $81.8 million. Fulltime, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., and was known as Qualix Group Inc. before it changed its name in July, had sales of $30 million for the year ended Sept. 30. Shares of Legato fell $5.1875, to $35.125. Shares of Fulltime Software rose as much as $2.5625, to $4.5625.

title: What 'New' Role for the C.I.A.?
description: When you work for a largely secret organization, you get used to being misunderstood fairly often by the public. Normally, I accept those misperceptions as the price of doing business.

title: Old Electronic Keyboards For Neo-1970's Campiness
description: Keyboard instruments have evolved fast over the last 30 years as analog technology gave way to digital programming and precision. So fast, in fact, that instruments invented in the 1960's and 70's now sound as quaint to rock ears as sackbuts and clavichords sound next to trombones and pianos. For some musicians, it's a short step from quaintness to nostalgic revival, and analog keyboards have been turning up lately on rock albums.

title: More Than Meets the Eye
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK FALLS. Germany's currency declined because of pressure on the Bundesbank to ease interest rates after Italy cut its discount rate by 1 percentage point. The dollar rose to 1.6627 marks, from 1.6375 Friday.

title: A Career Takes Off, But the Ego Is on a Leash
description: There are those moments in a theatrical career when everything clicks, when an actor is embraced by both the public and the critics, when the awards and accolades just seem to keep coming.

title: H&R Block Plans To Make 2 Acquisitions
description: The tax preparation giant H& R Block Inc. said today it had agreed to acquire certain assets of Freed Maxick Sachs & Murphy P.C., an accounting, tax and consulting firm, and Freed Maxick ABL Services L.L.C., a lending-services firm.

title: Back Peace, U.S. Urges Arab Allies
description: Now that the Wye conference has broken the deadlock between the Israelis and the Palestinians after 19 months, the Clinton Administration is urging moderate Arab nations to recommit themselves to actively aiding the peace effort.

title: A SPECIAL SECTION -- New York City Marathon
description: Tegla Loroupe, a crowd favorite and now a world-record-holder, will try to win her third New York City Marathon when 30,000 runners hit the streets on Sunday. A preview includes a look at new training approaches and tips on running a four-hour race. Section G.

title: Asian Economic Crisis Hits Home, and Silicon Valley Is Targe
description: For several years, Mattson Technology Inc. in Fremont, Calif., embodied the Silicon Valley dream. Sales tripled from one year to the next. When the company's stock was first sold to the public in 1994, about a dozen executives became millionaires. One year the company took all employees and their families to Lake Tahoe for a Christmas vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDERONE, MARY S.
description: CALDERONE-Mary S. The faculty, students, alumni and staff of the Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health of Columbia University mourn the loss of its distinguished alumna, Mary S. Calderone, MD, MS '42. A true visionary, co-founder of SIECUS, and indefatigable leader in sexual responsibility, Dr. Calderone has left a remarkable legacy to the health of the public. To her daughter, Francesca Calderone-Steichen and the entire family, we extend our deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, MD Dean Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health Columbia University

title: After 40 Years, Pacemakers Are Smarter and Safer
description: Arne H. W. Larsson's last billion heart beats have made him a medical marvel, a pioneer in one of the great triumphs of cardiology and electronic engineering.

title: TRANS WORLD TO BUY CAMELOT MUSIC FOR $451.9 MILLION
description: Trans World Entertainment Corporation agreed yesterday to buy its rival Camelot Music Holdings Inc. for about $451.9 million in stock and assumed debt, creating the nation's largest operator of music stores found in malls. Trans World has headquarters in Albany and owns the Strawberries, Coconuts and Record Town chains. Camelot is based in North Canton, Ohio, and owns stores called Camelot, the Wall and Spec's Music. The combined company will have more than 1,000 stores in 44 states.

title: A Hole in the Insurance Umbrella; Storms Expose Thin Coverage of Puerto Rico Homeowners
description: In many ways, the capital of Puerto Rico does not look strikingly different from cities in the 50 states like Miami, Houston and parts of New York. There are plenty of modern office buildings, condominiums and fast-food places. And just as in those other cities there are lots of modest neighborhoods, away from the modern facades, with people who are just getting by.

title: INSIDE
description: $100.5 Million Bias Verdict

title: Russian Bailout Of Truck Maker
description: Russian national and regional governments said today that they would take control of Kamaz, the country's largest truck producer, in return for assuming about a third of its debts. The move is intended to rescue one of Russia's largest employers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSAMT, ALAN
description: GOLDSAMT-Alan. On October 25, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Alice, loving father of Caryn Margolis, Roberta Sands, and Jay. Cherished grandfather of Phil, Seth, Katie, Bonnie, Nate, Ben, Deborah, Riva and Jenna. ''Always in our hearts.'' Service Tuesday 1PM at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-01 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills NY 718-263-7600

title: Around the World in 26.2 Miles: The International Brigade
description: When the New York City Marathon sprouted from a modest event sequestered in Central Park to a celebration coursing through the streets, the word got out to the world.

title: Can Fassel Get Giants Up for 0-7 Redskins?
description: You're Jim Fassel and your Giants are getting ready to play the Washington Redskins. How do you convince your charges to fear an 0-7 team?

title: Still Holding a Mike and Ruffling Feathers
description: GABE PRESSMAN may not have been the first local television reporter in America, but he was close, and no one would ever dispute that in New York he was the first, and most irascible. ''All I know, I was alone out there,'' said Mr. Pressman, who is 74. ''I was the only one holding the mike.''

title: In Caste System, Women Can Marry Up
description: India's one billion Hindus still generally observe a caste system that prohibits members born into one caste from marrying into another. The system is thought to have prevailed for more than 2,000 years, long enough to have impressed a subtle genetic signature on the population, according to a team of American and Indian biologists.

title: New Political Equations in the Mideast
description: The weary Mideast bargainers of Wye Plantation will not find much rest in the weeks ahead. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, now face the fights of their political lives back home.

title: A Second Term for Mr. Pataki
description: When George Pataki delivered his first address to the State Legislature nearly four years ago, New Yorkers who had grown used to the wide-ranging agenda and verbal pyrotechnics of Mario Cuomo were startled by their new Governor's pedestrian oratory and narrow set of priorities. Now, almost four years later, we know there is another difference. Mr. Pataki promised only a few things, but he has done what he promised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEF, LILA EHRICH
description: LIEF-Lila Ehrich, 72, of Chestnut Hill, MA, formerly of New York City, died of leukemia on October 26 at her home. Her husband, Dr. Philip A. Lief of the Brigham and Women's Hospital and the Harvard Medical School, died in 1992. She is survived by her four children, William Lief of Manalapan, NJ, Louise Lief of Washington, D.C., Gerald Lief of Brookline, MA, and Varda Lief of Chestnut Hill, MA, and three grandchildren, Erica Lief, Scott Lief and Zachary LiefPaul. She was the sister of Fredric Ehrich of Marblehead, MA and the late Zara Blechman. Services at the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA on Wednesday, October 28. For information please call 617277-8300.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, JONAS
description: TENENBAUM-Jonas. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences on the loss of our member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Make Way for Moose; As Their Predators Decline and Forests Grow, Herds Head South
description: Wolves in the wild are mostly phantoms that shy away from humans as if they were poison. Pronghorn antelopes are so nervous that if one looks at them the wrong way they are off like a shot. And short of tracking down a mountain lion with dogs, it is all but impossible to see one.

title: New York's To-Do List: Fix Team, Start Another
description: Another season, another $20 million loss for Major League Soccer. The average attendance dropped by 304 from last season's 14,616, and the television ratings were less than 1 point in 12 ABC telecasts.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE FINDS MANAGER FOR MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that Drexel University in Philadelphia had agreed to manage a Philadelphia medical school, opening the way for Tenet to acquire eight affiliated hospitals for $345 million. Tenet was the winning bidder in Federal bankruptcy court last month for the assets of Allegheny Health Education and Research Foundation, but said it would not go through with the purchase unless it could find a college to manage the medical school. Drexel backed away from an earlier agreement to run the school but returned to the plan after Gov. Thomas Ridge of Pennsylvania and Mayor Ed Rendell of Philadelphia appealed to its board. Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., owns and operates 120 hospitals in 18 states, second only to Columbia/HCA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ROSE KLEINMAN
description: STERN-Rose Kleinman. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Barbara and Richard and mother-in-law of Francine and Sheldon. Cherished grandmother of Risa, Julie, Remy, and Mariel. Adored great-grandmother of Hallie. Loving sister of Vicky Zuckerman and of the late Henry and Arthur Kleinman. True friend to everyone. We will always love and adore you. Services Thursday, 12 Noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, New York City.

title: Gift Comes Back To Haunt Candidate
description: Back in 1994, after he won election as treasurer of California, Matt Fong had some campaign money left over. So he sent a $50,000 check to a conservative Orange County group, the Traditional Values Coalition, which was promoting a ballot initiative to ban same-sex marriage in California, a ban he favored.

title: Cold-War Archives And Scholars' Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B. Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, DORIS BULLARD
description: DUNCAN-Doris Bullard. Age 103, on October 26, 1998. Vassar graduate 1917. Beloved wife of the late John C. Duncan Jr. Loving mother of John C. and Bruce Duncan and the late Michael Duncan. Grandmother of nine, greatgrandmother of eight, and greatgreat-grandmother of one. Interment private. Memorial service at St. Bartholemew's, Park Avenue at 50th Street, Thursday, October 29, at 4:30 PM.

title: Bitter Rematch Reflects Changes in Orange County
description: At 63, Sam Romero has never felt more wanted.

title: Simplifying Italian Zucca
description: GO to central or northern Italy at this time of year and you're sure to be offered tortelli filled with zucca.

title: Mexico's Wanted Poster Exchanges Black Hat for White Collar
description: The halls of Mexico's Congress are adorned these days with wanted posters that show a man whom many opposition lawmakers consider to be an unrepentant white-collar outlaw.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Leiter Is Next On Mets' Rich Menu
description: Two days after signing Mike Piazza for $91 million to be the cornerstone of their offense for the next seven years, the Mets plan to announce today that they have agreed to a four-year, $32 million deal with their pitching ace, Al Leiter.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 4.5 PERCENT. Prices plummeted as talk that Brazil may devalue its currency caused a flood of selling from Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer. The December contract fell 4.95 cents, to $1.054 a pound.

title: Era of Schroder and His Generation Begins
description: Gerhard Schroder, a Social Democrat, became Germany's seventh postwar Chancellor today, the first member of his party to lead the country since unification in 1990.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE SPINNING DOOR: A special report; Regulators Find Easy Path To Gambling Industry Jobs
description: As the interim director of the Mississippi Gaming Commission, Bruce Nourse authorized the opening of the state's first casino in 1992. But a year later, as casino neon began to flicker with opportunity all along the Gulf Coast and north into the Delta, Mr. Nourse traded roles. Instead of continuing to police the casino operators, he joined them, doubling his pay to more than $100,000 and becoming a senior vice president for Casino Magic, an owner of two Mississippi casino hotels.

title: On Eve of Election, Mostly Apathy
description: Four years ago, people interviewed in this bedroom community of stucco houses, strip malls and independent-minded voters expressed deep disappointment with President Clinton and complained vehemently about declining wages, rising taxes and worsening crime.

title: THE CHEF
description: AT my grandfather's pastry shop in Nice, there was always a large selection of sweets that were called ''mamie cakes'' because they were the favorites of that French city's grandmothers, the ''mamies'' who took up teatime as a daily treat. Any cake that didn't have cream, custard or mousse was a mamie cake (it's pronounced ma-MEE, with the ''a'' as in mat).

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar dipped as nervousness slipped into markets ahead of an announcement in Brazil that could include a currency devaluation. The dollar fell to 117.75 yen, from 119.10 on Monday.

title: Abortion Clinic in Buffalo Vows To Continue Slain Doctor's Work
description: With Federal marshals posted outside and protesters waving pictures of aborted fetuses from the sidewalk, the clinic where Dr. Barnett A. Slepian performed abortions until he was slain on Friday night reopened here today and its director vowed to continue his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDLAY, DONALD RIDOUT
description: FINDLAY-Donald Ridout. A longtime resident of Palm Beach and Jupiter Island died on Tuesday, October 27th, after a short illness. He was 82. Mr Findlay was born in New York City and moved to Palm Beach in 1954. He was predeceased by his wife Joy Douglas Plummer. Mr. Findlay was survived by his wife Katherine Deere Wiman Findlay, four children, George W. Findlay of Dover, DE., Steven D. Findlay of Chevy Chase, MD., Deborah B. Findlay of Del Ray Beach, FL., Diane F. Paty of West Palm Beach, FL., stepchildren, Katherine D.G. Dunne of Stuart, FL., Patricia D. G. Ramsay of London, England, Elizabeth B.G. Marino of South Egremont, MA., and Dawson C. Glover III of Stuart, FL. Mr. Findlay is also survived by eight grandchildren and 12 step-grandchildren. Mr. Findlay was a member of Bethesda-ByThe-Sea in Palm Beach, FL. and The Christ Church Chapel on Jupiter Island, FL. A private family service will be held on Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to Wayside House, 378 Northeast 6th Avenue, Delray Beach, FL. 33483.

title: Bailed-Out Hedge Fund Cutting 18% Of Its Staff
description: Long-Term Capital Management Inc., the hedge fund that a group of banks and brokerage firms rescued last month, laid off 33 people, or about 18 percent of its 178 employees, yesterday, according to people close to the firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, BENJAMIN J.
description: WALDMAN-Benjamin J. Of New Milford, NJ. beloved husband of Annette. Devoted father of Michele Wegodsky. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Melanie. Services ''Gutterman's - Musicant, Hackensack, Wednesday 1PM.

title: New Sense Of Urgency In N.B.A. Negotiating
description: The meetings have not been billed emergency sessions, but with the National Basketball Association scheduled to announce the cancellation of more games today, negotiations between owners and players may go a long way toward settling the nearly four-month-old labor impasse and salvaging the season.

title: INSIDE THE CAMPAIGNS
description: MONEY SOURCE -- After repeatedly contending that he alone paid his campaign bills this year and in 1994, Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic candidate for New York Attorney General, acknowledged that his father had played an extensive role in financing his campaigns. Page B1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTENATI, MARYBETH FRANK
description: PETTENATI-Marybeth Frank, 37 years old. Entered into eternal rest on October 26th. Beloved wife of John J. Adored mother of Jack, Michael, and Luke. Loving daughter of William M., and Carole K. (nee Kennelly) Frank. Dear sister of Paul M. and sister-in-law Donna Rand Frank. Dear daughter-in-law of Frances M. Pettenati. The family will receive their relatives & friends Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Feeney Funeral Home Inc., 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Friday 10:45 A.M. at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood. Burial at Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah. Donations may be made to the Marybeth Frank Pettenati Memorial Fund, C/O of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, Box E 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Hamed Spars With the Bag, Then Spars With the Press
description: Maybe he ate bad peanuts on the Concorde from London this morning. Whatever it was, Prince Naseem Hamed blew into town, breezed through a 1-hour-10-minute workout, and then blew his stack, blasting a couple of reporters during an interview session before stalking out of a meeting room at Bally's Park Place Casino late this afternoon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profits at America Online Surpass Street Estimates

title: In Its Case Against Microsoft, U.S. Now Cites Note From Apple
description: After four days spent watching lawyers for the Microsoft Corporation attack its key witness, the Justice Department today introduced a host of new documents, videotaped depositions and fresh testimony to strengthen its antitrust case and undermine Microsoft's defenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLYNN, THOMAS P. JR.
description: GLYNN-Thomas P. Jr. Of Ridgewood, N.J. Formerly of Belmont, Mass. October 26. Beloved husband of Loretta A. (Mullin) Glynn. Devoted father of Thomas P. Glynn III and his wife Marylou Batt of Belmont, Mass. and Katharine H. Glynn and her husband Sam Clements of Englewood, N.J. Loving grandfather of Kate and Jenni Glynn. Services in Belmont, Mass.

title: SERBIAN PULLOUTS LEAD NATO TO LIFT THREAT OF ATTACK
description: NATO suspended its immediate threat to attack Yugoslavia today, concluding that President Slobodan Milosevic was now in ''substantial compliance'' with demands to end his attacks on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

title: Another Hasek Shutout, But Richter Joins Him
description: The game ended in a double shutout, 0-0, between Mike Richter's Rangers and Dominik Hasek's Buffalo Sabres last night at Madison Square Garden. The verdict extended the Rangers' undefeated streak to five games, but the bad news involved an injury to Aleksei Kovalev, who will miss about three weeks with a separated left shoulder.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about elections in Brazil and the country's financial problems misstated the amount of foreign reserves Brazil is losing every day. It is hundreds of millions of dollars, not hundreds of billions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENIN, SAM
description: KENIN-Sam. July 26, 1998. Professional fundraiser, union organizer, lifelong activist for Peace and Social Justice. ''The Fight Will Still Go On.''

title: Profits Up 46% At HealthSouth
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, the biggest United States operator of outpatient surgery and rehabilitation clinics, said today that third-quarter profit rose 46 percent as it worked to hold down costs while adding clinics.

title: $57.4 Million Poorer, And Still No Victory
description: When the Washington Redskins spent $57.4 million in the off season to acquire Dana Stubblefield and Dan Wilkinson, the thought was that the two tackles would solidify a defense that could lift the Redskins to the top of the standings.

title: Amgen Earnings Increase 23%
description: Amgen Inc., the world's largest biotechnology company, said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 23 percent on an increase in sales of the anemia drug Epogen, its best-selling product.

title: Woman Held in Killing Of Her Mother in 1971
description: After spending the weekend in Newark's Juvenile Detention Center because of a quirk in New Jersey's former juvenile-crime laws, a 41-year-old woman charged with murdering her mother in 1971 was moved Monday night to the women's unit in Caldwell, the authorities said.

title: Argentina Selling Stake In Mortgage Bank
description: Argentina said yesterday that it planned to sell 25 percent of its national mortgage bank for at least 312 million pesos ($312 million), seeking to raise cash amid slumping demand for emerging-markets debt.

title: The Ideal Burger Is in the Grind
description: LIKE so many other culinary pursuits, making a hamburger that approaches the Platonic ideal means starting from scratch: the juiciest, most flavorful burgers begin with meat that you grind yourself.

title: Business Travel; An international arrivals hall at Kennedy will soon be replaced by a temporary structure.
description: ONE of the landmark sights at Kennedy International Airport, the parabolic arch at the entrance of the Terminal Four arrivals hall, will soon be demolished, along with the hall. Both structures will be replaced by a temporary arrivals area that opens Nov. 15.

title: Metro Business; Hiring of Disabled Is Strong
description: The casino industry in New Jersey hires a significantly higher percentage of disabled people than does the state or other employers in Atlantic City, a survey prompted by complaints from advocates for the disabled has found.

title: Williams Has Hills To Climb
description: The sight must have distracted motorists along Interstate 20 in suburban Dallas last summer. Every day, a young man wearing shoes with platforms on the balls of his feet would repeatedly sprint up a concrete overpass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the Quantum Group. It is a family of hedge funds, not mutual funds.

title: Anti-Abortion Speech Deserves to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAGUE MEETINGS
description: Cleveland has a team. It begins play next season and becomes the National Football League's 31st franchise.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Fifth Ave. Tower to Shift To Multilevel Retailing
description: Despite its good location on Fifth Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, the retail spaces in the building at 666 Fifth Avenue were not very inviting to shoppers. The storefronts were set back from the building's perimeter, behind columns and under overhangs.

title: A Governor Finds Himself In a Struggle for Survival
description: By most ordinary reckoning, Parris N. Glendening should be a shoo-in as he seeks re-election as Governor of Maryland.

title: A Phone Fee Quirk Benefits New Providers
description: As new local phone companies have taken on old communications giants, some of the upstarts have come to rely on a quirk of negotiation and technology that has grown into a cash cow. It goes by the name of reciprocal compensation.

title: A Self-Taught Chef Is Lord of the Manor
description: GREAT cooks usually start at the bottom, and they start very young, learning classic kitchen techniques honed over centuries.

title: Fans Will Have to Pay More to See Piazza
description: After bestowing a seven-year, $91 million contract on catcher Mike Piazza, the Mets will soon reveal how much their ticket prices will increase to help pay for the deal.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you own the politicians, regulators, judges or whoever you need to do what you need to do, you totally control your environment. It's always best to have these people on your side, so why not hire these people?''

title: I.B.M. Sets Yet Another Big Buyback Of Its Shares
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional $3.5 billion worth of common shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, MORRIS
description: HORN-Morris, known as ''Mr. Local 627'' for founding the Provision Salesmen and Distributors Union, which he headed for over 50 years, died October 26th, two months shy of his 97th birthday. He is survived by his wife of over 72 years Yetta, daughters Muriel Sokol and Roslyn Bank (Alex), son Howard (Lois), five grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. The Marc Ballroom on Union Square is named for a grandchild who predeceased him. Services today at ''Sinai Chapel'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, at 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, VINCENT
description: CAMERON-Vincent. On October 24th, 1998 of Hackensack, New Jersey. Brother of Norma Bombasset. He worked as a printer for the N.Y. Times. Kohler Funeral Home, Wood-Ridge, New Jersey.

title: The Doctor in the Bulletproof Vest
description: On Saturday morning I was in the family room getting ready to go to work. As usual, my wife reminded me to wear my bulletproof vest, and once again my 7-year-old son wanted an explanation. As I began to tell him that the vest was ''part of Daddy's work uniform,'' the television news was reporting the murder of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the gynecologist in Buffalo who performed abortions.

title: Giving Memory Its Due In an Age of License
description: In the moral universe, especially the one that postdates the Holocaust, remembering is almost always enlisted on the side of good, and forgetting on the side of bad. But in a symposium that ended today titled ''The Claims of Memory,'' held at Boston University over the last few days to celebrate Elie Wiesel's 70th birthday, it was memory's difficult skirmishes -- battles where it has clashed with artistic freedom, morality, fact, writing and sanity -- that were evoked.

title: Spitzer Concedes That His Father Has Helped to Pay for Campaigns
description: For months, Eliot L. Spitzer's political rivals in the race for state attorney general have attacked him by raising one essential question: who has paid for his campaigns?

title: KVAERNER TO SELL TRAFALGAR HOUSE, A U.S. HOME BUILDER
description: The British-Norwegian engineering group Kvaerner P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its United States home-building business, Trafalgar House Property Inc., to two buyers for $150 million. Trafalgar, based in McLean, Va., builds single-family detached homes, town houses and condominiums in four Eastern states and has a large land development project known as South Riding in Virginia. A United States construction company, which Kvaerner declined to identify, agreed to buy the bulk of the home-building business. The 6,000-plot South Riding development is being bought by a consortium led by Gregory Cox, South Riding's president.

title: G.O.P. Begins Ad Campaign Citing Scandal
description: In a sudden strategy reversal in the last week of the campaign season, the Republican Party tonight opened a $10 million nationwide television advertising blitz that uses President Clinton's sex scandal as a theme, both directly and with winking innuendo.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: William Irwin, 91, Pianist and Conductor
description: William C. K. Irwin, a pianist and conductor, died on Friday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan. He was 91 and had lived for many years on Staten Island.

title: Arts and Humanities Awards Announced
description: The White House has announced this year's winners of the National Humanities Medal and the National Medal of Arts. The recipients of the medals are selected by the President from lists of nominees presented by the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Endowment for the Arts, respectively.

title: The Irrepressible Bernstein in Retrospect, Fondly
description: From his famous 1943 debut at the age of 25, when he filled in for Bruno Walter as conductor of the New York Philharmonic, to his death in 1990, Leonard Bernstein was rarely offstage, whether as conductor or composer, teacher or showman. Tonight's partly autobiographical and altogether affectionate ''American Masters'' tribute brings out the qualities that endeared him to generations of collaborators, students and audiences.

title: Gay Church Sues TV Station For Rejecting an Infomercial
description: The nation's largest gay and lesbian church filed suit today against a Chicago television station, accusing the station of breaking its agreement to broadcast an infomercial produced by the church because the station considered the advertisement too controversial.

title: Wolfe Turns 'The Bonfire' Upside Down
description: A MAN IN FULL

title: Corrections
description: The ''Revisions'' column on Oct. 19, about ways of characterizing the film ''Beloved,'' misstated the relationship between two characters. Sethe and her lover, Paul D., are unrelated; he is not her brother-in-law.

title: Tax Revenues Exceed City's Budget Projections by $368 Million in Quarter
description: Tax revenues in the city exceeded budget projections by $368 million in the first three months of the fiscal year, but the recent gyrations on Wall Street could crimp the flow, the City Comptroller's office reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MOLLIE
description: GOODMAN-Mollie. The Israel Education Fund mourn the passing of Mollie Goodman, mother of Charles H. Goodman, Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Jewish Agency for Israel, UJA National Vice Chairman and former member of the UJA Board of Trustees, and past President of CJF. Our condolences to Charles and his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jane F. Sherman, Chairman, Israel Education Fund Avrum Burg, Chairman, JAFI Executive Yitzchak Shavit, Vice President, Israel Education Fund

title: When It Comes to Yogurt, Save the Calories and Fat
description: IF you ever doubted that people who shop in natural-foods stores are different from people who shop in conventional supermarkets, take a look at their yogurt-buying habits. While most Americans have decided they would rather have a little bit of fat in their yogurt, as well as in their cookies and potato chips, people who shop in markets where they can buy organic and additive-free foods still want fat-free.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL -- The Pieces of Perfection; Broncos' Many Strengths Bring Talk of an Undefeated Season
description: There is an aura enveloping the Denver Broncos, an invincibility, a feeling that this Bronco season could be as special as last year's. Maybe even more so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, NATHAN A.
description: GREENBERG-Nathan A. Beloved husband of Muriel. Loving father of Claire, Susan, Carol, Leslie. Cherished grandfather of Robin, Steven, David, Suzanne, Andrew, Kori & Perri. Services on Thursday, October 29, 1PM BernheimApter-Goldsticker, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, NJ. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the national changeover to digital television misstated the number of stations that will begin digital broadcasts on Sunday in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Washington. It is four stations per city, not one.

title: A Little High-Profile Help For D'Amato and Schumer
description: Turning to his protege for help at a critical juncture in his re-election campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato barnstormed across the state with Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday, seeking to take advantage of the Governor's high ratings in the polls and of his large campaign war chest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKEN, MILTON
description: DICKEN-Milton. The Zigmont family mourns the loss of Milton Dicken who passed away October 27, 1998 and offers their deepest, heartfelt condolences to the family, both here and in Israel.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS POSTPONE VOTE ON RATIFYING NEW PEACE ACCORD
description: Under pressure from his right flank, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has postponed ratification of the new Israeli-Palestinian accord by his Cabinet until Palestinians show a plan to fight terrorism to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFENOWITZ, MILTON
description: SAFENOWITZ-Milton, 70, a founding principal of Getty Petroleum Corp, and a member of Getty's Board of Directors died from complications of ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease) on October 27th, 1998. Milton had devoted 35 years of his efforts, good judgment and dedication to the Company serving as Executive Vice President of Getty until his retirement in 1990. He is survived by his wife Marilyn, his three children: Ellen and her husband Gary, his son Howard and his wife Lynn and his daughter Susan and her husband Alan. He is also survived by his grandchildren, Jordan, Bailey, Amanda, Jeffrey, Rachel, Ryan and Samantha, as well as his brother Aaron and wife Carole, and his sister-in-law Libby and husband Jackie. Services are on Wednesday, October 28, at 10 AM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York, 516921-5757. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the Greater New York Chapter of the ALS Association, 40 Wall Street, New York, New York 10005. The Board of Directors, the Officers and everyone at Getty, express their sorrow on Milton's passing and extend deepest condolences to his family. Getty Petroleum Marketing, Inc Getty Realty Corp Leo Liebowitz Chairman & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAN, SARA
description: LEVITAN-Sara. On October 27th, 1998. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Services Wednesday, 10:45 AM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAHA, JOHN F.
description: BLAHA-John F. On October 26, 1998 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved Husband of Margaret W. Blaha. Father of John W. and the late Robert L. Blaha. Also survived by seven grandchildren and 7 great grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway & Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, NY on Tuesday 7-9PM & Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church on Thursday 10:45AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: D'Amato Admits He Missed Votes During '80 Senate Race
description: For the last 27 days, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has hammered at a single theme, attacking his challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer, for skipping votes in Congress to tend to his Senate campaign. ''You haven't been there to vote,'' Mr. D'Amato scolded Mr. Schumer in a debate on Saturday. ''Chuck Schumer always puts politics over people.''

title: Bonds Gain Amid Big Sale of Corporate Debt
description: Bond prices rose for a second day as the Associates Corporation of North America sold $4.8 billion of debt in the second-largest corporate sale ever, a sign that the concerns that have gripped financial markets are ebbing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNETT, JOHN W.
description: BURNETT-John W. Fort Worth, Texas, passed away Oct. 26, 1998 in Ft. Worth. Services 11 A.M., Oct. 29, 1998 at Greenwood Chapel. Memorials to the Becky Childress Scholarship Fund, PO Box 1947, Ozona, Texas 76943. He resided in NYC for nearly 40 years. Greenwood F.H., 3100 White Settlement Road, Fort Worth, TX. 76107.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK -- Modern Art: A School or a Journey?; Defining a Term Depends on What You're Looking for and At
description: What does modern mean? Is it purely historical, as in ancient, medieval and modern (the latter frequently seen as beginning with the Renaissance)? Is it uppercase, an umbrella term covering all art from van Gogh to, say Frank Stella and Robert Ryman (afer which post-modern takes over)? Or is it a lowercase valedictory applied temporarily to things that are deemed new and irrefutably contemporary -- that is, a designation that is outgrown, rather like being a freshman in high school? Furthermore, is it possible for a museum of modern art to accumulate a collection and still remain involved with modern art as it evolves?

title: Not Just Leaving the Light On; Motel 6 Is Still a Cheap Sleep, but With New Strategies
description: Motel 6, a stubbornly utilitarian chain for most of its 36 years, has been making some fancy moves lately.

title: Just Blunt, or a Bully? Canada Divided on Leader
description: Even for a tough political competitor like Jean Chretien, question period in the House of Commons can be a grind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKENSTEIN, ROSLYN
description: BECKENSTEIN - Roslyn. Very dearly beloved wife of Fred, devoted mother of Alan Dodge Beck and Deborah Lisansky Beck, Robert Edward Beck and Ann Edwards Beck and Shelley Beck. Cherished grandmother of Julie, Emily, Lauren and Matthew. Dear sister of David Dodge and the late Surella Dodge. Funeral services Thursday 12:00 noon at I.J. Morris 46 Greenwich St. Hempstead. Donations to: Comprehensive Community Hospice of Parker Jewish Institute, 5 Dakota Drive Suite 104 Lake Success, NY 11042.

title: Anti-Bias Effort Roils City Where Gay Man Died
description: When Matthew Shepard died in a hospital here two weeks ago, this prairie city was a fleeting focus of national concern over antigay violence. A Web site created by the Poudre Valley Hospital for Mr. Shepard, the 21-year-old college student who was beaten in Wyoming, drew 15,000 E-mail messages for his family and 815,000 hits from around the world.

title: At Parade, Immigrants Bask in El Duque's Glory
description: It was a day for pride, more than for politics, when Orlando (El Duque) Hernandez, the Yankee pitcher, paraded down Bergenline Avenue here today, in the heart of Cuban and Hispanic New Jersey.

title: Patrols Up in Central Park, Dangerous or Not
description: Crime sprees, real or imagined, in Central Park have always given New York City officials fits.

title: In Computers, Fast, Faster And Fastest
description: The Energy Department will take delivery on Wednesday of what the Government says is the world's fastest computer, capable of a peak performance of 3.88 trillion calculations, or teraflops, a second.

title: For the Adventurous, Paradise in Hell's Kitchen
description: WALKING home from the greengrocer along Ninth Avenue, I pass from a sliver of Korea to outposts of Pakistan, Thailand, Senegal and Puerto Rico in six blocks.

title: The Pop Life; Feeling the Beat Of No Drummer
description: ''Did you see the drummer's hair?'' the rock group Pavement once asked in a song, sarcastically referring to the obscurity of rock-band drummers. But after Keith Moon of the Who died in 1978, the band never regained its creative footing. And when John Bonham, Led Zeppelin's drummer, died in 1980, that band broke up, and it has refused to reunite under the name Led Zeppelin.

title: Clinton and Lott Wrangle Over Social Security
description: President Clinton and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, traded accusations of demagoguery and bad faith today in a partisan pre-election skirmish over Social Security.

title: Pinochet's Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Keyes Martin, East Hanover, N.J., was named as the first agency to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at $2.5 million: Nuova Linnea, Easton, Pa., to introduce the marketer of natural botanical products in the United States, and Schering-Plough, Kenilworth, N.J., to develop a motivational direct marketing program aimed at the drug maker's sales force.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON TO ADD BAGGAGE TRACTOR MAKER
description: Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc., a maker of Army trucks and aircraft ground servicing equipment, agreed to buy the closely held TUG Manufacturing Corporation for an undisclosed amount to expand its airline services business. Stewart & Stevenson, with annual revenue of $1.1 billion, plans to combine its airline equipment unit with TUG, the country's top maker of baggage tractors and mobile belt loaders. TUG, based in Kennesaw, Ga., expects 1998 revenue of about $50 million. The Houston-based Stewart & Stevenson plans to form a wholly owned subsidiary called S&S/TUG. Don Chapman, the owner and chief executive of TUG, will serve as the unit's president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDZIMER, HARRIET ''BUDDY''
description: GOLDZIMER-Harriet ''Buddy''. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Harriet ''Buddy'' Goldzimer, our esteemed colleague. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Executive Director

title: A Political Brawl In Historic Boston
description: They love a good political fight in Boston, always have. But on Monday night, things got a bit out of hand.

title: The Darkest Chambers of a Nation's Soul
description: Advertisements for the controversy magnet that is ''American History X'' seem to be selling Edward Norton's buff physique, savage scowl and swastika tattoo in equal measure. So they reflect the film's bold but reckless synthesis of visual enticement and rhetorical fever. Presented in the ersatz poetic idiom of videos and commercials, this is an inflated yet gut-slugging film that dares to address America's neo-Nazi culture with brutal candor. Its toughest images stick even when its lurid self-aggrandizing spins out of control.

title: Elephants and Dogs and Budgies, Oh My!
description: When the Big Apple Circus reaches its finale, those most deserving of a salute are nowhere to be seen. In this year's production of the intimate circus, which has pitched its star-ceilinged tent in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center through Jan. 10, it's the animals that should be taking the bows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, VERA B.
description: FRANKEL-Vera B. On Saturday, October 24, 1998, beloved wife of Lester R. Frankel; beloved mother of Martin (and Jean) Frankel of Greenwich, Conn. and Judith (and Evan) Novenstein of Potomac, MD, grandmother of Steven and Jill Novenstein and Jennifer and Margaux Frankel. Also survived by a sister Louise (and Harold) Applebaum. Services were held at Congregation Har Shalom in Potomac, MD. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to United Jewish Appeal Federation.

title: Runner Opened a Door and Keeps It Open
description: As he crossed the finish line as the 1996 Olympic marathon champion in Atlanta, Josia Thugwane of South Africa found his life undergoing the same tumultuous change as his country's political system.

title: Giuliani to Aid G.O.P. In California and Florida
description: In the final days before the 1998 elections, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is in demand nationally and will be campaigning over the next three days for Republican candidates in California and Florida, his office announced yesterday.

title: Dhaka Journal; Defiant Author, Dying Mother and Wrath of Islam
description: The writer Taslima Nasrin returned home to Bangladesh last month to be at the side of her dying mother. But while the older woman lies bedridden -- cancer amok in her liver and colon -- her daughter has been forced into hiding by religious firebrands who chant ''Death to the apostate!'' and have put a $5,000 price on her head.

title: A Determined Milbury Leaves the Bench to Pursue Palffy
description: While their coach was in Vienna seeking to get their leading scorer to rejoin the team, the Islanders barely got enough scoring to beat the Los Angeles Kings, 1-0, at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: DANA TO BUY 2 BUSINESSES FOR $430 MILLION
description: The Dana Corporation, the big automotive supplier based in Toledo, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $430 million for two engine-bearing businesses from the Federal-Mogul Corporation, the large auto parts maker based in Southfield, Mich. Federal-Mogul, which will receive an additional $13 million from the collection of receivables, said proceeds would pay down debt. It acquired the two operations, which have annual sales of around $450 million, when it bought the British auto component maker T & N P.L.C. in March. As a condition of the T & N acquisition, Federal-Mogul entered into a consent order with the Federal Trade Commission to divest itself of T & N's global engine-bearing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEEGER, ALICIA
description: SEEGER-Alicia, at age 76, loved by all who knew her, beloved wife for fifty-six years of Louis, mother of Carol Risher (John), Joshua (Judith), and Julie Sano (John); devoted grandmother of Adam & Jeanine Seeger, Mark and Conrad Risher, & Sam Sano; loving sister of Bill Krasilovsky & Alfred Krass. Alicia was administrator of Sh'ma Magazine for twenty-two years, and, for the last six years, until now, administrator of the National Association for Poetry Therapy (NAPT). Funeral Wednesday, October 28, 1:00 PM, at Community Synagogue, Sands Point, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to NAPT Foundation, P.O. Box 963, Arvada, CO. 80001.

title: Hitachi and Toshiba Post 6-Month Losses
description: The Toshiba Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. today reported losses for the six months ended Sept. 30, illustrating how even Japan's vaunted high-technology companies are vulnerable to its deep economic malaise.

title: Separating Boys and Girls
description: ''All boys, all day'' is how Rich Cronin, president of Fox Family Channels, described the new cable channel his company plans to start next year. On cue, a dozen slightly awestruck third-grade boys from East Harlem trotted into the midtown Manhattan hotel room where Mr. Cronin was making his announcement yesterday.

title: Vallone Enjoys the Rare Sight Of a Hearty Campaign Rally
description: Speaking to what has been a rare sight in this year's political campaigns -- a large live audience -- Peter F. Vallone exhorted several hundred union members and low-income New Yorkers yesterday to go to the polls next week, telling them that Gov. George E. Pataki ''may have a lot of money, he may have a lot of power, but he doesn't have you, he doesn't have your votes.''

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; The 'New News'
description: The question raised in the full-page ad from the Anti-Defamation League in Sunday's Times was plaintive: ''Is there no moral responsibility at NBC News anymore?'' What prompted the ad -- an open letter to NBC's president, Bob Wright -- was Louis Farrakhan's appearance on ''Meet the Press'' the previous Sunday. Under the cover of the flimsiest of news pegs -- the otherwise unremarked third anniversary of the Million Man March -- Mr. Farrakhan had been invited on air to give his opinion of ''the President's moral behavior and his possible impeachment.''

title: Nonagenarian Proudly Walks the Marathon
description: FOR a while it seemed as if Sam Gadless, the old guy who looks like Albert Einstein with his flying white hair, might not make this year's New York City Marathon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHEINER, SONNY
description: SCHEINER-Sonny. February 28, 1936-October 28, 1997. You're in my mind, heart and soul every day. I miss you, I love you, Tami

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 20 about the negotiations over the $500 billion budget bill referred incorrectly to the type of legislation that is required to originate in the House. The Constitution mandates that bills raising revenue originate there; it has become custom that spending bills also originate there.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: TO GO; Thai to Buy (or Cook Yourself)
description: THE little space at 179 Prince Street in SoHo has housed a couple of noteworthy restaurants, including Katana, which closed after the chef returned to Japan, and Bop, whose owner, Brad Kelley, moved it to the Bowery. Now, Mr. Kelley, who also owns Kin Khao, a popular Thai restaurant, and Kelley & Ping, an Asian market and cafe, has turned 179 Prince Street into KIN KHAO MARKET , specializing in Thai-style takeout and groceries.

title: At Cape Canaveral, Reliving the Grand Highs of '62
description: If he could see the place this week, Juan Ponce de Leon might wish he had taken a closer look when he passed this way in 1513 in his quest for the Fountain of Youth. There must be something here invigorating the likes of John Glenn and T. J. O'Malley.

title: Brazil's President Pledges Budget Cuts in Early Austerity Step
description: Bracing his nation for a package of austerity measures that are generally seen as a first step to restoring Brazil's standing in world markets, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso pledged tonight to cut $7 billion in spending from the deficit-ridden Federal budget next year.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Profit at Northern Telecom Up 52%
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., a top seller of phone equipment in North America, said today that its third-quarter operating profit rose by 52 percent, better than expected.

title: DENAMERICA CANCELS ACQUISITION BY TECH ELECTRO
description: The DenAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled its acquisition by Tech Electro Industries for $67.5 million in cash and stock. Tech Electro, an electronics concern, offered in July to buy Den America, which owns and franchises Black-Eyed Pea restaurants and is a franchisee of Denny's restaurants. DenAmerica, of Scottsdale, Ariz., said it had executed its option to cancel the merger agreement because certain financing contingencies were not met by the Oct. 24 deadline. Tech Electro, based in New York, said it had met the requirements and was surprised by the cancellation. Shares of DenAmerica closed unchanged at $1.625. Tech Electro fell 18.75 cents, to $1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, STANLEY I.
description: FISHEL-Stanley I. Age 84. On October 25, 1998. Former chairman of Fairfax Advertising Agency, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi/ Worldwide. Graduate of Columbia College 1934. World War II Lt. Commander U.S. Coast Guard. Former National President of Zeta Beta Tau. Founding director of the Fraternity's student loans and scholarships. Named Interfraternity ''Man of the Year'' by the National Interfraternity Conference. Beloved brother of James. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison ave at 81 St, Wednesday, 10am. Interment Mt. Judah Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to ZBT Foundation, Fishel Fellowship Fund, 3905 Vincennes Road, Suite 101, Indianapolis, IN 46268.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: B. F. GOODRICH CO., Richfield, Ohio, the aerospace industry supplier, said its performance materials unit planned a $5 million capacity expansion at its plant in Antwerp, Belgium.

title: Africa Falls Prey to H.I.V.
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, CAROL
description: SCHWIMMER-Carol. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the sudden passing of Carol Schwimmer, beloved mother of our friend and colleague Dr. Alan M. Schwimmer, D.D.S., Chief of the Division of Dental Medicine. To Dr. Schwimmer, his sister, Marjorie Goldstein, Carol Schwimmer's grandchildren Kristin, Aaron, Joshua, Talia and Laura, her great grandchildren Charlotte and Eli and all who loved her we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO, Beth Israel Medical Center Moses Nussbaum, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Surgery BIMC

title: Too Old for MOMA?
description: Modern philosophy is said to have begun with Descartes, since he tried to derive his image of the world by analyzing the structure of the self. It would still be correct to call Descartes a modern philosopher, even though he died in 1650.

title: Norwich Union Buys Business From Hartford
description: Norwich Union P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire London and Edinburgh, a general insurance company, from Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. for $:315 million ($524.2 million).

title: Nets Agree to Remain At the Meadowlands
description: Ending months of speculation that the team might abandon the Meadowlands Sports Complex for a new arena in Newark or pack up for a return to Nassau County on Long Island, the Nets agreed yesterday to keep playing in Continental Arena through the next decade.

title: RACING: NOTEBOOK
description: BREEDERS' CUP

title: Executive Returns to DDB Needham Office
description: The Los Angeles office of DDB Needham Worldwide said yesterday that Mark Monteiro had rejoined the agency to oversee daily creative output as executive creative director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, GERALDINE SPRECKELS
description: FULLER-Geraldine Spreckels, 79, a homemaker passed away on October 25, 1998, at her residence in Palm Beach, Florida. Private services will be held. Memorial prayers will be announced at a later date. Memorials may be made to the Four Arts, Four Arts Plaza, Palm Beach, FL 33480. Mrs. Andrew P. was born Geraldine Anne Spreckels on October 15, 1919, daughter of John D. Spreckels, III and Syida Wirt, in San Francisco, CA. She was the only child of Syida Wirt Spreckels and John D. Spreckels, III. In 1946, she married Andrew Powhattan Fuller of Ft. Worth, who died in 1994. During their life together. Mr. and Mrs. Fuller resided in Ft. Worth as well as New York City, NY, Southampton, and Palm Beach. Mrs. Fuller was noted for her passion for modern art. Her taste and discernment in assembling a collection of paintings earned her the respect of other collectors, as well as that of scholars in the field. Survivor is a daughter, Gillian Fuller of Beverly Hills, CA.

title: Future of U.S. Program Is in the Hands of Arena
description: Bruce Arena was named yesterday as coach of the United States national team and technical director of the United States Soccer Federation, a vital position for the development of soccer coaches and players.

title: Music Industry Loses a Bid To Stop Internet Recording
description: A Federal judge has refused the recording industry's request to halt production of a hand-held device that can record and play back digital music found, often illegally, on the Internet.

title: 'Amsterdam' by Ian McEwan Wins Booker Prize
description: Ian McEwan, the British writer whose novels explore the ways that seemingly ordinary people can veer frighteningly out of control, was tonight awarded the Booker Prize, Britain's most prestigious literary award, for his latest work, ''Amsterdam.''

title: Yugoslav Forces on the Move From Positions in Kosovo
description: Under the gaze of American spy planes overhead and international monitors prowling the back roads in armored cars, filing reports by satellite telephone, Yugoslav forces continued to move out of the battered province of Kosovo today.

title: The Pride of Texas on a Bun
description: IN Texas, the long, winding road that leads to the ultimate hamburger ends in Amarillo, at a place called Arnold Burgers. There, in the state where beef is king and the hamburger its most perfect culinary expression, Arnold's delivers the goods in spectacular fashion.

title: CISCO AND HEWLETT-PACKARD PLAN JOINT PRODUCTS
description: Cisco Systems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that they planned to jointly develop products that will combine voice and data communications on the Internet, using their existing partnership to enter a lucrative new market. Hewlett-Packard, the No. 3 computer maker, and Cisco, the No. 1 computer-networking company, already share technology that lets corporations set up their computer networks to handle voice and data. The first new product from the partnership is expected to ship in the first quarter of 1999. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., and Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, said they would have additional new products to combine voice and data traffic seamlessly between phone networks and the Internet by the second half of next year.

title: Coutts Dominates Bermuda Regatta
description: Russell Coutts, the New Zealand America's Cup skipper, dominated the Gold Cup regatta in Bermuda last week as the eight-day match-race series ended with a one-on-one final. Coutts defeated Murray Jones, also of New Zealand, by 3-1 last Sunday in the final match for his fifth victory in the 50-year-old event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLMAN, ZACHARY
description: WELLMAN-Zachary, of Albany, New York. At rest October 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Celia (Farber) Wellman, son of Henry and Fromma Wellman of NYC.
