Father of Jennifer (Wellman) Golden of Queens, NY and Eric Wellman of Long Island, NY. Brother of Elisabeth (Wellman) Vazquez of NYC. Services at The Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Ave., Albany, NY, Thur. at 10am.

title: Yanks in Squeeze Play Over Williams's Salary
description: While the Yankees began their efforts to retain their World Series hero, Scott Brosius, at a bargain price, Bernie Williams yesterday added an ingredient to his agent's argument that he should receive a bigger contract than the Mets just gave Mike Piazza.

title: G.O.P. Leaders In Congress Oppose Letting Pollard Go Free
description: Republican Congressional leaders called on President Clinton today not to release Jonathan Pollard, the convicted spy, saying he still represented a threat to national security.

title: ALLMERICA FINANCIAL BIDS FOR REST OF CITIZENS CORP.
description: The Allmerica Financial Corporation, the insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that it had offered to pay $29 a share, or about $171 million, to buy the 17.5 percent of the Citizens Corporation that it did not already own. Both companies are based in Worcester, Mass. Shares of Citizens, a property and casualty insurer, closed at $29.50, up $1.9375. Allmerica, whose stock rose $3 a share, to $47.9375, also said it planned to repurchase as much as $200 million worth of its own shares.

title: A Baby's Avoidable Death
description: The New York State Department of Health has concluded its investigation into the death of Shannell Coppage, a six-week-old girl who died of malnutrition because her young mother, Tatiana Cheeks, had failed to breast-feed her adequately. The investigation suggests that the hospital where Ms. Cheeks sought help blundered badly.

title: S.E.C. and Firm Settle Municipal Bond Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement today in a civil case against O'Brien Partners Inc., which it accused of breaching its fiduciary duty to municipal bond clients by not informing them of commissions it received from brokers who invested revenues from the municipal issues.

title: Citibank teams with Sony to market a credit card for the consumer who wants to be easily amused.
description: CITIBANK, one of the nation's largest issuers of credit cards, has teamed up with Sony, the giant electronics and entertainment company, to introduce a co-branded card they are promoting with an extensive national multimedia campaign.

title: Fistfight Breaks Out On Flight to La Guardia
description: A fistfight broke out between two passengers on a U S Airways flight yesterday, apparently after one passenger struck his child and the second passenger intervened.

title: New Space Venture Turns Back the Years
description: As John Glenn prepares to return to space tomorrow at age 77, he has said he hopes to show the world that the lives of older people need not be dictated by the calendar. The astronaut is not the only one coming back to the site of his 1962 space flight, when he became the first American to orbit the planet.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Covering John Glenn
description: Anyone wondering about the extent of interest in 77-year-old John Glenn's return to space, almost four decades after he became the first American to orbit the earth, could get an idea from this week's television listings.

title: European Investors Don't Flee Stocks
description: A fresh crop of European stock owners, the result of Government privatizations of industry and a general trend toward equity investment, has been battered by recent global market turmoil. Yet experts say it has survived to bear fruit another day.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: YANKEES

title: After Signing Rights Pact, China Begins a Crackdown
description: Only weeks after signing a global covenant calling for freedom of speech and assembly, China has taken new steps to suppress political organizations and debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHGRUND, HERBERT B
description: FISCHGRUND-Herbert B, age 84. Adored and beloved husband of Cis, devoted and loving father of Terry, Tom and Jeff, cherished grandfather of Casey, Beth, Ted and Sam, admired father-in-law of Deurward, Lynne and Geovanni. He was a kind, gentle, and noble spirit whose passion for family, work and giving ruled his life and enriched ours. Services Thursday 11:30am at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cancer Support Team, 32 Rye Ridge Plaza, Rye Brook, NY 10573 or Westchester Jewish Community Services, 845 North Broadway, Suite 2, White Plains, NY 10603-2427.

title: Internet Research Firm Sells Stake to Nielsen
description: Another consolidation in the Internet research field occurred yesterday as Nielsen Media Research in New York acquired what was described as a significant equity stake in Net Ratings Inc., an audience research company in Milpitas, Calif., and combined the two companies' audience-measurement systems for the Internet. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, REBECCA
description: FISCHER-Rebecca. Age 96 on October 27, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Albert. Beloved mother of Eleanor. Interment private.

title: Starwood Ends An Equity Swap
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. said today that it had terminated a financing arrangement with affiliates of Merrill Lynch & Company, Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and what was the Nationsbank Corporation before it merged with BankAmerica. The termination involved a repurchase of about eight million Starwood shares for $255 million.

title: Police in West New York Face Additional Charges
description: More charges were announced yesterday in a Federal investigation into corruption in the West New York Police Department.

title: Temptation; For Purists, Green Tea Ice Cream With an Asian Aura
description: IN the small world of green tea ice cream, there is little variety. In most New York restaurants where it is served -- unless it is made in-house -- you will usually find one of just two kinds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSES, JULIAN MORTON
description: MOSES-Julian Morton. October 28, 1911-October 16, 1997. JULIAN, My Dear and True and Only Friend, today is your Birthday. But you are with me and in my heart and in my prayers all day every day. I Love You and I Thank You for more than half a century of happiness. Buon compleanno! Iot'a! CHRIS

title: Microsoft Deal For Banc One
description: The Microsoft Corporation has signed a five-year, $90 million agreement with the First USA unit of the Banc One Corporation that is being described as the largest such deal involving Internet advertising.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: The House Built on White Zinfandel
description: EVERY prominent winemaker has one creation of which he or she is particularly proud. Robert Mondavi has his Reserve Cabernet, Francis Ford Coppola his Rubicon. And Bob Trinchero has white zinfandel, America's most popular style of wine.

title: About New York; Mr. Earth Day Has New Goal: Star of Hope
description: WHEN John Glenn returns to space tomorrow he will behold a humbling view of Earth that few have savored. John McConnell can appreciate the old astronaut's perspective, and he doesn't even have to leave his apartment in Ridgewood, Queens. In a corner of his kitchen is a flag emblazoned with the Big Blue Marble. Next to it lies the instrument panel that guides him through his favorite space: cyberspace.

title: Nigerian to Direct Next Documenta
description: The artistic director of the next Documenta exhibition in Kassel, Germany, will be Okwui Enwezor, a Nigerian critic and independent curator who lives in New York. The announcement was made on Monday at a news conference at the Fridericianum Museum, a graceful 18th-century former palace that is the heart of the sprawling Documenta show, which traditionally occupies several exhibition buildings and the grounds of the park that holds them. The exhibition is held every five or six years in Kassel, an industrial town 188 miles northwest of Berlin.

title: Anti-Abortion Speech Deserves to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: Low-Key Manner Helped Vallone, Until Now
description: Another Columbus Day had rolled around, and with it, the annual Peter Vallone Columbus Day Breakfast.

title: Earnings Climb At Tobacco Giant
description: British American Tobacco P.L.C., the world's No. 2 cigarette company, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 31 percent and said it had yet to face the ''full force'' of emerging-markets problems. Investors, discouraged by that warning, pushed the shares down.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Suddenly Dreadlocks

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Is Said to Admit Killing a Teacher
description: A former girlfriend of Corey Arthur, the young man accused of torturing and fatally shooting his former high school English teacher, testified yesterday that Mr. Arthur confessed the killing to her.

title: Pataki Retaining 2-1 Lead Over Vallone, a Survey Shows
description: Gov. George E. Pataki continues to hold a 2-to-1 lead over his Democratic challenger, Peter F. Vallone, but voters are paying scant attention to the race as Election Day draws near, according to a statewide New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Stigma of Dr. Do-Little Fades From Grenada U.
description: Seen from the campus here, the Caribbean Sea appears so serene and breathtakingly beautiful that it may be hard to remember that just 15 years ago this month the United States fought a sort of war to save St. George's University.

title: In a More Relaxed, Easygoing Mood
description: IT is August, and David Ruggerio has just opened the new restaurant he has named for himself. The hostess, teetering on very high heels, looks nervous when two parties arrive simultaneously. She looks at me and asks, hopefully, if we would like to wait in the bar until our entire group has assembled. I decline, and for a moment she seems uncertain how she should handle the situation.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar
description: Taiwan Chefs in Queens

title: Chinese Investment Trust Defaults on Bond Payment, Stirring Fear
description: In a move that could intensify fears of a debt crisis in China, the country's second-largest investment-trust company has failed to make a bond payment, a bank official said today. It was the first time a Chinese company has defaulted on an international bond since the Chinese Communist authorities came to power in 1949.

title: Columbia/HCA Profits Are Flat
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest operator of hospitals, said today that third-quarter profit was little changed, as patient admissions declined at centers it put up for sale. The performance failed to meet analyst expectations.

title: Spies for Peace
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's role in instituting and monitoring the new Middle East peace agreement has touched off a useful debate about whether the agency's activities in the region will corrupt its analytical work. But consideration of this matter should not labor under the naive belief that the agency is somehow entering unexplored territory. The C.I.A. has long mixed action and analysis, often with disastrous results.

title: America Online Earnings Set Record in First Quarter
description: America Online Inc. reported record first-quarter profit and revenue yesterday, surpassing Wall Street estimates, on strong growth in membership, advertising and electronic commerce.

title: VINTAGE PETROLEUM ACQUIRING PROPERTIES IN EAST TEXAS
description: Vintage Petroleum Inc., an oil and gas company, agreed yesterday to acquire several producing properties in East Texas for $49.7 million from an undisclosed seller. Vintage, based in Tulsa, Okla., said it would operate a substantial portion of the properties, which have current net daily production of 1,100 barrels of condensate and natural gas liquids and 3,800 million cubic feet of gas, or a total of 1,733 barrels of oil equivalent. The purchase, expected to close early next month, includes five key onshore fields and some smaller fields.

title: Microsoft Places a Large Bet On Tiny Smart Cards System
description: The Microsoft Corporation introduced a tiny computer-operating system for smart cards yesterday as well as support for the system from 20 hardware makers.

title: Cox, Other Older Pros Go All Out For Jets
description: Through his career as a pro football head coach, Bill Parcells has had a special affinity for older players who have lost their allure with their employers. Year after year, he has plucked them from bad situations, revived them and their careers and utilized their leadership to build his teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELS, BERNARD
description: FELS-Bernard. Born December 25, 1912, died October 26, 1998, joined his wife of 53 years. Survived by his brother David, sisterin-law Helen, sister Hilda, brotherin-law Lou, son Charles Livingstone Fels, daughter Susan Casella, her husband John, grandchildren Lauren, Michael, John, Stephanie, Elizabeth and Robert. A horseman, former jockey and racehorse trainer. Services today 1 PM at Schwartz Bros., 11403 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Donations to National Museum of Racing, 191 Union Avenue, Saratoga Springs, NY 12866-3566 or The Heart Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKIN, LANGDON G.
description: RANKIN-Langdon G., 90. Of Essex, CT. died October 26, 1998. Husband of Frances Jones Rankin. Father of Mrs. Joan Rankin Davis and Mrs. Judith Rankin Codella. Brother of Mrs. George M. Knowles and Mrs. Roy Byrne. Headmaster Emeritus of East Woods School. Memorial Service at St. Johns Church, Essex, Conn. on Friday at 2 P.M. If desired contributions in his memory may be made to East Woods School, Oyster Bay, New York 11771.

title: Arts Abroad; First, van Gogh's Millet, Then van Gogh's van Gogh
description: At first sight, the new show at the Musee d'Orsay suggests a bizarre attempt to resuscitate a neglected 19th-century French painter by exhibiting him alongside a rather more famous name. In truth, the idea of uniting Jean-Francois Millet and van Gogh is far more interesting. Since the Dutchman looked to the Frenchman as a role model, Millet's life and work serve as a mirror that reveals much about van Gogh.

title: $25 AND UNDER; Italian and Unusual, From the Antipasto to the Dessert
description: ANTIPASTO selections are the buffets of Italian restaurants, and for that reason are generally to be avoided. You already know what you'll get: cold cuts, cheese that's been sitting in the refrigerator, vegetables grilled yesterday.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY TO EXPAND PLANT CAPACITY
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation, a specialty steel company, said yesterday that it would invest $113.6 million to expand its Pennsylvania melt shop and add finishing capacity at its Talley Metals Inc. plant in South Carolina to reduce costs. Carpenter, which had sales of $1.18 billion in the fiscal year ended June 30, said expanding operations at its headquarters in Reading, Pa., and in Hartsville, S.C., would reduce its need to buy melting and finishing services from outside sources. Carpenter is grappling with ways to cut costs as aerospace companies are scaling back inventory and in the aftermath of the General Motors strike, which hurt earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNES, EVELYN SABIN
description: MANNES-Evelyn Sabin, October 27, 1998. Wife of the late Leopold. Mother of Elena Mannes. Sister of the late Robert Sabin. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHFELD, JANET RUBNER
description: HIRSCHFELD-Janet Rubner. Age 56. Beloved wife and best friend of Jimmy. Treasured mother of Jennie and Julie. Dear sister of Judy, Robert and Paul. Adored and remembered by all who knew her. Memorial service Noon Friday, October 30th, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Janet Hirschfeld Memorial Fund, c/o Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 CPW, N.Y., N.Y. 10023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, EDWIN FLYNN
description: SCHNEIDER-Edwin Flynn. 77, of Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL. On October 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Regina Caldwell. Loving & wise father of Regina Schneider de Ojea of Madrid, Spain; Edwin C. Schneider of Armonk, NY; Kathleen Schneider Pratt of Chestnut Hill, PA; and Michael Gerard Schneider of Lower Gwynedd, PA. Proud grandfather of Jeannita, Andres, Bettina Tara, Gable, Galen, Chuck, Tory, Caroline, Alexander and Graham. Graduated Princeton University Class of 1944 in Electrical Engineering. President and CEO of Ettco Wire and Cable Corp., founded 1907, a leading manufacturer of wire and cable in Brooklyn, New York. Mr. Schneider served as a member of the Advisory Committee of Chase Manhattan Bank, Borough of Queens. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Lost Tree Club and the Meadow Brook Club. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Thursday, 6-9 PM. Funeral mass Friday 9:45 AM, St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Brookville. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Brain Tumor Center, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, 3 West Gates, 3400 Spruce St., Philadelphia, PA, 19104 or to Princeton University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, TILLIE
description: BREGMAN-Tillie. On October 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Bruce and the late Jack. Sister of Tessie Glickman. Visitation Wednesday 7-9 PM. Services 11 AM Thursday, Schwartz Bros Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ.

title: T. Rowe Price Bank Plan
description: T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., the 10-largest mutual fund company in the United States, wants to open a Federal savings bank so that it can offer CD's to its customers. T. Rowe Price said it applied this month to the United States Office of Thrift Supervision for approval to offer bank deposit-type products, like CD's. The company said it expected to get approval from Federal regulators to begin selling CD's next year. The plan was reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Verner Panton, 72, Is Dead; Dane Designed Stacking Chair
description: Verner Panton, the Danish industrial designer and architect known for his radical molded-plastic chairs, Op Art-inspired textiles and lighting, died at his home in Copenhagen on Sept. 5. He was 72.

title: WACHOVIA IN STOCK DEAL FOR INTERSTATE/JOHNSON LANE
description: The Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Interstate/Johnson Lane Inc., a brokerage firm based in Charlotte, N.C., for $230 million in stock as the bank builds its financial services business. The purchase values Interstate/Johnson Lane at about $32 a share, below yesterday's closing price of $37. Wachovia, the bank holding company based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has also set aside $23 million in stock to entice the brokerage firm's employees to stay with the company after the merger, which is expected to be completed in the first half of 1999. The purchase will give Wachovia 63 brokerage offices in the Carolinas, Georgia and Virginia.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Voila! French Steak

title: AIDS Is Slashing Population Of Africa, U.N. Survey Finds
description: AIDS is cutting the life expectancy in many African countries and will effectively reduce their populations within the next 10 to 15 years, according to a report to be released on Wednesday by the population division of the United Nations.

title: Teacher Admits to Abuse Of Foster Children
description: A special-education teacher faces up to 15 years in prison after he admitted molesting four foster children who lived with him from 1985 to 1997.

title: Satellite Will Carry Entire Tourney
description: College basketball fans with satellite dishes will be able to watch every game of March Madness next year under an agreement announced yesterday by CBS, the National Collegiate Athletic Association and DirecTV, the satellite program distributor.

title: INSIDE
description: Beijing Represses Debate

title: Unit of AXA Makes Offer for Belgian Bank
description: Europe's biggest insurer, AXA S.A., said yesterday that its Royale Belge S.A. unit wanted to buy the Belgian bank Anhyp N.V. for less than its last market value, a price some investors and analysts say is too low.

title: With Taxes Up, Nassau Searches for Someone to Blame
description: An unexpected increase in school property taxes that is costing many homeowners in Nassau County an estimated $100 more this year is causing a lot of finger pointing among Republicans, Democrats and local school board officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUCHINCLOSS, HUGH, MD
description: AUCHINCLOSS-Hugh, MD of Westwood, MA and Manchester, MA, formerly of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, died on October 25, 1998 at the age of 83. His death resulted from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Dr. Auchincloss was born in New York City, the son of Dr. Hugh Auchincloss and Frances C. (Newlands) Auchincloss. He attended Groton School, graduated from Yale in 1938 and from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. After service in the Navy during World War II, he finished his residency and joined the faculty at Columbia as Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at Columbia. He was also Attending Surgeon at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, NJ for 39 years prior to his retirement in 1992. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Katharine Lawrence (Bundy) Auchincloss, three daughters, Katharine A. Corbin of Phoenix, AZ, Margaret A. Strachan of London, Elizabeth L. Auchincloss, MD of New Rochelle, NY, his son, Hugh Auchincloss, Jr, MD of Newton, MA, two sisters, Maria A. Look of West Tisbury, MA and Barbara A. Thacher of New Canaan, CT, eleven grandchildren and one great grandson. Services and interment at Mount Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Valley Hospital, N. Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. For information, The J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, MA.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Looking for Backlash In Clinton Scandal
description: Republican candidates have been trying for some time to capitalize on the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. Only yesterday, the party kicked off a $10 million national advertising campaign that focuses on the issue.

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Fear the Moose
description: To the Editor:

title: J. Reese Phifer, 82, Founder Of Aluminum Screen Empire
description: J. Reese Phifer, who turned a tiny aluminum screen factory into a business that dominates its worldwide market, died on Sunday at DCH Regional Medical Center in Tuscaloosa. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth. Journalist, former senior editor TIME magazine and violinist in chamber music groups in New York City and Pawling, N.Y. On October 22, 1998 at home in Greenwich Village. Devoted wife of the late John K. Hutchens. Beloved mother of Brigid Gollogly and Kevin and Duncan Brine. Cherished mother-in-law of Gene Gollogly, Madeline Brine and Julia Brine. Loving and involved grandmother ''Uma'', of Lila, Mumu, Jamie and Colette Gollogly, Alexis and Lindsay Brine and Kyle and Alden Brine. memorial service on Thursday, November 19, at 6 P.M., at New York University Fales Library of the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library and Study Center, 3rd Floor, 70 Washington Square So.

title: Sports of The Times; Hardly The Boys Next Door
description: PRO basketball players seem puzzled over the public's failure to embrace their ''struggle'' against National Basketball Association owners. They seem to ask, ''Where's the outpouring of sympathy for fellow workers?''

title: The Soft-Money Dodge in 1998
description: It took nearly 75 years for the United States to enact laws protecting elections from the corrupting influence of campaign contributions. But it has taken only four years to eviscerate those reforms. The wanton fund-raising this year by both parties, especially the Republicans, has returned the nation to the system prevailing at the turn of the last century, when businesses and special interests bankrolled Presidential and Congressional campaigns. This cannot be what Americans want.

title: Turn Off Your Phones
description: To the Editor:

title: Should the U.S. Release Spy for Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and State Assail City in Closing of Queens Nursing Home
description: The state and Federal agencies that monitor nursing homes say that the city provided inadequate care for the 282 residents of a nursing home in the Rockaways when it suddenly evacuated and closed the complex last month, after a storm that city officials say had created hazardous conditions.

title: Shift at American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it named Alfred Kelly Jr. president of its consumer cards group, replacing Phillip Riese, who is leaving to become chief executive of Optimark Technologies. The New York-based American Express said Mr. Kelly, 40, would start his new job on Saturday. He will be responsible for the United States consumer credit cards business, as well as customer service and risk management support for all domestic cards.

title: Sports of The Times; New American Coach Tried Football First
description: BRUCE ARENA wanted to play quarterback, just like his brothers, Paul and Mike. The problem was, when he reached the ninth grade, he was not able to see over his linemen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLSTEIN, BRUCE A.
description: HOLSTEIN-Bruce A., died on October 26, 1998 at the Daughters of Israel. Dear son of the late Sol and Gladys Holstein. Loving husband of Marilyn, (nee Halperin). Devoted father of Holly. Beloved brother of Frank Holstein and Marilyn Blum. Funeral services were held Tuesday, October 27, 1998 at Goldstein Funeral Chapel, 2015 Woodbridge Ave., Edison, NJ. Donations may be made to Center for Hospice Care, 3 High St., Glenridge, NJ 07028.

title: Pupils Using Vouchers Had Better Scores, Study Finds
description: Low-income public school pupils who transferred to religious or private schools under a privately financed voucher program championed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani showed a slight increase in standardized test scores compared with pupils who did not transfer last year, according to the results of a preliminary study.

title: By the Book; Spider Cookies and Other Scary Treats
description: STUMPED for Halloween ideas? Being clever comes easily with the help of ''Halloween Treats: Recipes and Crafts for the Whole Family'' by Donata Maggipinto (Chronicle Books, $14.95). In less than 100 pages, this colorful book covers everything from pumpkin-seed candies for children to make, to pumpkin-based menus and centerpieces for grown-up autumn dinner parties.

title: Shares Open With a Rally But Finish With a Slump
description: Stock prices slumped after a strong opening yesterday, but traders said profit taking rather than a shift in sentiment was most likely the cause.

title: Re-elect Carl McCall Comptroller
description: New York voters have traditionally elected governors and state comptrollers from different parties. That may be an accident of history, or an instinctive feeling that the comptroller ought to be a watchdog over the state's fiscal health who is not politically beholden to the chief executive. This year, at least, we believe the precedent is worth following. We have endorsed the re-election of the Republican Governor, George Pataki, and now recommend that Carl McCall, a Democrat, be re-elected Comptroller.

title: A Comedown for NBC
description: In the wake of the changes at the top of NBC's programming department, the network suffered through one of its worst ratings weeks in recent years last week, finishing last among viewers, and third among viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the network's main target group.

title: Anti-Abortion Speech Deserves to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, RHODA
description: ALTMAN-Rhoda. Beloved daughter of Gus Blau. Beloved wife of Hank. Beloved mother of Red and Steve. She will be greatly missed by all of those who had the pleasure of knowing and loving her. Services private. Groman Mortuary, California.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Trying to Test How False The Positives Might Be
description: Is the bear market over? Or is the recent rise in stock prices just a seductive rally intended to suck investors in before the market slides once more?

title: Plotting Into the Night
description: CBS is quietly putting the pieces in place for its new late-night show with Craig Kilborn. The network has selected Billy Kimball, a comedy writer and producer, to be the executive producer of the show, which will replace Tom Snyder's talk show as the 12:35 companion to David Letterman's ''Late Show'' early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAROLINO, SHELLEY ANN
description: FAROLINO-Shelley Ann of Dobbs Ferry, NY, formerly of Orchard Park, NY. Beloved wife of Philip and mother of Griffin, loving daughter of Richard and Anna, cherished sister of Shane and Stacey. Service to be held at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry at 5PM on Thursday, October 29. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NYC, NY 10021.

title: NATIONAL CITY PLANS BUYBACK OF UP TO $2.7 BILLION
description: The National City Corporation said yesterday that it would repurchase as many as 30 million shares of its common stock, or 9 percent of the shares outstanding, because it expects an increase in earnings growth next year. National City, which is based in Cleveland, is the 13th-largest United States bank. It said it would spend as much as $2.7 billion in the buyback. Shares will be repurchased on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions, and will be held by the bank for reissue for dividend reinvestments, stock option plans and general corporate purposes. The shares fell $2 yesterday, to $62.8125, as most bank stocks declined.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Quesadillas, Salsas and More From a Queens Kitchen

title: 'Star Wars' World With a Sense of Humor
description: A LONG time ago, in a galaxy far, far away, there was a movie that was so resonant it became a universe. After a big cultural bang, it grew and grew and grew to include sequels, novels, comic books and galaxies of T-shirts, lunch boxes, towels, blankets and toys. And miraculously, even the little bits of plastic had soul. A Darth Vader action figure or plastic X-Wing fighter was more than the sum of its mass-produced parts. It was a relic of the film, a speck of the original magic. It was a way of connecting to the ''Star Wars'' universe.

title: A Horrid Little Girl As Murder Suspect
description: Little girls, especially those inclined to kill people, should learn to keep their footwear clean. It was, after all, a pair of bloodstained Mary Janes that got Rhoda, the piano-playing, angel-faced murderess, into such trouble in ''The Bad Seed,'' the popular 1950's melodrama by Maxwell Anderson. Now Lizzie Gael, the 9-year-old in Hilary Bell's ''Wolf Lullaby'' at the Atlantic Theater Company, is arousing suspicions by wearing a pair of sneakers spattered in red. What is a mother to do?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBROW, IRVING
description: OBROW-Irving. The musicians and Board of Directors of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra express great sorrow at the loss of our friend and former board member whose wisdom, kindness, and unfailing support helped to sustain our music-making for many years. We will remember him with affection, gratitude and respect. We extend our condolences to his wife Lucille and daughters Patricia White and Joanne Bailey. Orpheus Chamber Orchestra

title: State Control Is Proposed For an H.M.O. In New Jersey
description: In a move that highlighted regulatory questions with health maintenance organizations, New Jersey officials have moved to take over the operation of H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey, after it appeared to be sliding into insolvency and was having problems paying its health care providers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about documents released in the Paula Jones case misattributed an assertion about the case. It was Mr. Clinton's lawyers, not Judge Susan Webber Wright of Federal District Court in Little Rock, who called Ms. Jones's accusation about ''distinguishing characteristics'' on President Clinton's genitals ''baseless and scurrilous.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Straight-Ticket Voting Losing Ease in Illinois
description: It was an old hard-nosed politician, Paddy Bauler, who crowed defiantly, and accurately, in 1955, ''Chicago ain't ready for reform.''

title: Kodak Will Sponsor Events at the Garden
description: Eastman Kodak, the world's largest photography company, said that it would be the lead sponsor for several events at Madison Square Garden to promote its brand in the New York City market.

title: Met Buys Its First Painting by Jasper Johns
description: In a move to strengthen its holdings of postwar works, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has bought ''White Flag,'' its first painting by Jasper Johns, the museum announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, WILLIAM J.
description: O'MALLEY-William J. Esteemed member of the St. Clare's Hospital Board of Trustees, passed away October 26, 1998. A revered member of the theatrical community, Bill used his talents to create the Helen Hayes Gala for the benefit of St. Clare's. We greatly appreciate those many years of service spent on our behalf. A cherished and respected friend, he was the distinguished recipient of many awards and honors. He will be greatly missed by the St. Clare's family, and our hearts are with his wife, Connie. Viewing at John J. Barrett & Son, 424 West 51st Street on Thursday, October 29th, from 2-5PM and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Paul The Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street on Friday, October 30 at 10 A.M.

title: Workbook Is Powerful, Methodical
description: QUICKEN FINANCIAL PLANNER

title: Hispanic Civic Leaders Assail Vacco Over Remarks
description: Editors of a weekly newspaper say State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco told them early this week that it was hard to prove the effectiveness of the death penalty because researchers do not ''stand outside a bodega'' and ask ''the bandito'' if capital punishment deterred him from crime.

title: Sniper Attacks on Doctors Create Climate of Fear in Canada
description: For many Canadian doctors who perform abortions, it has become a grim mid-autumn ritual. They pull their drapes at night and wear bulletproof vests to the office. They are told to drive different cars and change the spots they park in from day to day. Some even schedule their vacations for the first two weeks of November.

title: Utensils Get Cute
description: ''GODJETS'' is what the architectural historian Reyner Banham called the household gadgets that Americans love so well as to almost worship. All those blenders, mixers, grinders and other appliances serve as gods -- mechanical lares and penates of the American home.

title: Richard Dior, 51, Mixer for 'Apollo 13'
description: Richard Dior, a recording engineer whose work on the film ''Apollo 13'' won an Academy Award for sound, died on Monday at his home in Marlboro, N.J. He was 51.

title: Clinic in Buffalo Resumes Abortions
description: This city's last remaining abortion clinic resumed performing the procedure this morning, five days after its primary doctor was killed by a sniper.

title: Allmerica Sued Over Citizens Bid
description: Shareholders of the Citizens Corporation have sued to block the Allmerica Financial Corporation's $171 million offer for the 16.8 percent of the insurance and financial services company it does not already own, saying they are not getting enough for their shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHEL, RONALD J.
description: KUHEL-Ronald J. In San Francisco, October 25th, 1998. Beloved companion of Seth Ira Chodosh; loved brother of Gerald Kuhel and Suzanne Igler; also survived by six nieces & nephews and one greatnephew. A Requiem Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at 2:00PM Saturday, October 31, 1998 at the Church of the Advent of Christ the King, 261 Fell Street, San Francisco. Memorials to the AIDS Emergency Fund or Hospice by the Bay preferred. Memorial in New York to be announced.

title: Let No Bad Chip Tear Asunder
description: FOR nearly 20 years, Steve Mann has pursued the dream of developing a networked computer that would slip onto the human body as easily as a layer of clothing.

title: Let's Make Adoption a Non-Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Mac OS Is Better Than Ever
description: HOW unfortunate that 95 out of 100 personal computer buyers might not care that Mac OS 8.5, Apple Computer's new operating system software for Macintosh computers, is easier to use, more elegant, more innovative and more reliable than Windows 98.

title: GAP PLANS 3-FOR-2 STOCK SPLIT AND BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: Gap Inc. said yesterday that it planned to split its stock 3 for 2, and buy back as many as 30 million shares, after its stock soared 56 percent the last year on strong earnings gains. The moves were announced after its stock closed up 75 cents, to $55.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The split, in the form of a half-share dividend for each share, will be distributed Nov. 30 to holders as of Nov. 11. Gap, the nation's third-largest clothing retailer, last split its stock, also on a 3-for-2 basis, in December. The new buyback plan represents about 7.77 percent of Gap's shares outstanding before the split, the company said.

title: Essay; That Wagging Finger
description: That 800-pound gorilla beckoning to you to join him in the voting booth is The Impeachment Issue.

title: Peace Accord Leaves Israeli Labor Party in a Tough Spot Over Whether to Topple Netanyahu
description: As the conservative Likud Government takes up the mantle of peace, Labor, Israel's historically dovish party, finds itself with a conundrum.

title: Australian Concern to Use Foxtel Option
description: Publishing & Broadcasting Ltd. said today that it will exercise its option to take a 25 percent stake in Australia's largest pay-television company Foxtel.

title: O'Meara and Duval Vie for Top Honor
description: It is a two-man race that has come down to the season's final official event.

title: Justice, at Long Last
description: This summer I wrote two columns about a man named Jeffrey Blake, who was serving a term of 36 years to life in prison for the murder of two men in the East New York section of Brooklyn in 1990.

title: 31 Picassos Sold at Paris Auction
description: One of Picasso's ''Weeping Woman'' portraits, perhaps the last still outside museum collections, was bought by the Zurich gallery Apedoros for $7.1 million as the auction of the estate of the artist's former mistress, Dora Maar, began here on Tuesday night. Although their relationship ended in 1945, Ms. Maar held on to all of Picasso's gifts to her until her death last year.

title: Tapping Cyberbrains For Financial Advice
description: DESPITE recent stock market fluctuations -- or maybe because of them -- investments remain hot cocktail chatter as boomers fret about how to swing a comfy retirement. The money has to go somewhere, and under the mattress won't do.

title: South Africa Truth Commission May Withhold Its Report
description: Facing two court challenges, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission today was on the verge of withholding its final report, which was due to be released at noon today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption yesterday with an article about former government officials who join the casino industry misidentified the former job of Bruce Nourse, now a senior vice president for Casino Magic, which owns two Mississippi casino hotels. Previously he was interim director of the Mississippi Gaming Commission, not a Federal regulator.

title: A New Vantage Point to Watch the Empire State Go Up
description: The itinerant Skyscraper Museum is homeless no longer. The museum disappeared from 44 Wall Street last December, when the building was sold. This month, the museum reopened at its temporary home at 14-16 Wall Street (Nassau Street) with 100 photographs of the construction of New York's most famous skyscraper. The Empire State Building, the world's tallest from 1931 to 1971, was designed, engineered and built in only 20 months.

title: Ziff-Davis to Buy Sky TV
description: Ziff-Davis Inc., the publisher of computer trade magazines, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sky Television, an in-flight programming, video production and broadcasting company based in Dallas. The price was not disclosed. Northwest Airlines, U S Airways Group and other companies use Sky Television to produce independent monthly technology programs for their in-flight television networks. Shares of Ziff-Davis rose 56.25 cents, to $7.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Guadalajara Beckons, Architects Follow
description: FORGET Bilbao. The future of architectural pilgrimage may be in Guadalajara, Mexico.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Brazil Plans $80 Billion In Cuts and Tax Increases

title: Medical Lobbyists Fight Auto Insurance Proposal
description: Proposed regulations to help cut automobile insurance premiums 15 percent by cracking down on fraudulent medical claims are being criticized by medical lobbyists who say the regulations would result in some patients being denied necessary coverage.

title: Competition And Laughter As Dancer Meets Diva
description: Cecilia Bartoli does not dance onstage with Angel Corella every night, but she did on Tuesday when American Ballet Theater opened its new season. Mr. Corella did not break into song. But it was a perfect match: young Italian mezzo-soprano superstar (Bartoli) meets young Spanish ballet virtuoso (Corella) and both knock out audience at chock-full-of-chuckles gala.

title: Where the Kitchen Is Also the Classroom
description: WHILE the teacher settled his class down for a discussion of ''The Iliad,'' a 14-year-old student, Magnus Elhardt, chuckled at a classmate's wisecrack. The moment was typical of a high school literature class, except the teacher was 150 miles away, the classmate was 3,000 miles away, and Magnus, a home-schooled student in Thousand Oaks, Calif., was sitting in front of a computer in his family's kitchen. His mother, Maria, was ironing a shirt a few feet away.

title: Boy Scout Handbook Adds A Page About the Internet
description: For the first time, ''The Boy Scout Handbook,'' that trusty life guide used by almost 100 million boys throughout the century, will include a page on the Internet.

title: Lawrence Doyce Hancock, 85, Entrepreneur and Philanthropist
description: Lawrence Doyce Hancock, a philanthropist who parlayed his L. D. Hancock Company into Hancock Fabrics, one of the nation's largest retail fabric chains, died on Oct. 5 at the North Mississippi Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 85.

title: IN THE CAMPAIGNS
description: END OF THE LINE -- In Chicago, the city where reform has seemed only five minutes nearer than the end of time, change has indeed made its mark. This Election Day will be the first in more than a century that Illinois voters will have to cast votes for each candidate separately, rather than endorse an entire party slate with a single swipe. Page A26.

title: Report Ties Union Official to the Gambino Crime Family
description: When he was the underboss and No. 2 power in the Gambino crime family in the early 1990's, Salvatore Gravano decided that his bodyguard and chauffeur lacked a killer's instincts and was unfit to become a Mafia soldier.

title: Women on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Whipping Up Martinis and Home Glamour
description: BLENDERS whirred all day in the Rowe Furniture showroom at the International Home Furnishings Market, which opened here on Oct. 15 and ran through last Friday. Behind an antique bar, young assistants in white jackets whipped up fresh fruit smoothies for the buyers shopping Rowe's line of mid-priced furniture. Come 5 P.M., however, a glowing neon olive in an oversize cocktail glass signaled that Rowe was shaking up martinis.

title: Economic Scene; A few-billion-dollar fix that won't ultimately cure Brazil.
description: THE austerity plan spelled out yesterday by Brazil will not solve its financial crisis. Nor will a $30 billion to $35 billion bailout package, including several billion from American taxpayers, that the International Monetary Fund is expected to offer to sustain Brazil's commitment to a fixed exchange rate to the dollar.

title: Despite a Truce, Kosovo Albanians Dig New Graves and Vow Revenge
description: Hoping that NATO's demand that the Yugoslav Government reduce its forces in Kosovo Province would help keep their village safe, the family returned after three months of hiding.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Where the Politics Is Not Academic

title: Youth Held in Drawing Of Swastikas at City Hall
description: A Manhattan teen-ager was charged yesterday with drawing six swastikas on the front doors of City Hall, the police said.

title: China Expert On Missiles Is Arrested On Return
description: A top Chinese missile scientist who has lived in the United States since 1989 is in prison here awaiting trial on a charge of revealing state secrets, say colleagues at Stanford University, where he was a research associate.

title: Luxury in Recession Land; The Hermes of the World Find New Ways to Prosper In Japan's Weak Economy
description: Perhaps nothing epitomizes the Wonderland-like quality of the Japanese recession like the giant orange Hermes box in the heart of Ginza, Tokyo's most exclusive shopping district.

title: Bell Atlantic Chief Moves To Rothschild
description: Raymond W. Smith, the chairman of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said yesterday that he would become chairman of Rothschild North America Inc., the North American holding company for the Rothschild Group, in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, RABBI SEYMOUR
description: SUMNER-Rabbi Seymour. Touro College mourns the untimely passing of Rabbi Seymour Sumner, devoted and beloved father of Reva and father-in-law of our Executive Board member, Martin Oliner. Rabbi Sumner was one of the first recipients of Ordination from Yeshiva Chaim Berlin and a pioneer builder of Torah Studies in the United States. He was distinguished by his Talmudic acuity and beloved for his humane qualities. Dr. Bernard Lander President Touro College Dr. Mark Hasten Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Iran Closes 'University' Run Covertly By the Bahais
description: One day late last month, Iranian security officials fanned out across their country and raided some 500 homes and several office buildings owned or rented by members of the Bahai faith, confiscating material and arresting dozens of people.

title: Lawsuit Against a Spammer Is Filed Under a Oregon Law
description: In what is believed to be the first lawsuit brought by a state against a spammer, Jason Heckel of Salem, Ore., has been sued on charges of violating Washington's law against misleading commercial E-mail. Mr. Heckel, 24, has admitted sending between 100,000 and one million pieces of E-mail per week to solicit interest in a get-rich-quick scheme, said Paula Selis, senior counsel in the consumer protection division of the State Attorney General's office. A trial date has been set for March 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MARION THOMPSON
description: GREENE-Marion Thompson. Of Manhattan. On October 28, 1998 in her 100th year. Survived by three nephews and several grand and great-grand-nieces and nephews. Funeral services private.

title: A Campaign Tradition With More Impact on Reporters Than on Voters
description: Back in the summer of 1982, few people gave Mario M. Cuomo, then the Lieutenant Governor of New York, a real shot at winning the Democratic primary for governor. By almost any measure -- financial backing, name recognition -- he stacked up miserably against the front-runner, Edward I. Koch, the seemingly indomitable Mayor of New York City.

title: Space Aging
description: It is hard to recapture, so long after the event, what a galvanizing effect John Glenn's first ride into orbit had on an apprehensive nation. In the years before that triumph, Americans had been plunged into self-doubt by the Soviet Union's success in orbiting an unmanned Sputnik satellite and then two Russian cosmonauts while a succession of American rockets exploded or misfired. Then, on Feb. 20, 1962, the freckle-faced, square-jawed Marine flier got America back in the space race with the nation's first manned orbital flight. A delirious public honored him with a tumultuous ticker-tape parade and canonized him as a genuine American hero whose exploits owed much to his unswerving patriotism, his enduring marriage, his deep roots in Presbyterianism and small-town America.

title: Prayer Vigil Set for Eve Of Election
description: When the election campaigns draw to a close on Monday and the final volley of charges has been made and the last round of television advertisements shown, the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church, wants voters to turn to prayer -- and to keep at it all night.

title: Injury Leaves Big Hole for Rangers
description: Aleksei Kovalev's injury and Mike Keenan's unhappiness are coincidental. But could both combine to affect the future of Pavel Bure?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, ROBERT RUBEN
description: PERLMAN-Robert Ruben, 72. On October 26th, 1998. Gifted senior researcher with National Physics Institute of Hebrew University. Author, inventor. Loving brother of Dorothea Sasson, Herbert Perlman and Ruth Klebaner.

title: Elliott Carter at 90: Young Music for a Young Audience
description: Ninetieth-birthday concerts, when they happen at all, are usually retrospectives. Speculum Musicae's evening of Elliott Carter at the Miller Theater on Tuesday night was, on the other hand, a showcase for the new and the recent. Only the eminent Double Concerto (1961) and a brief song written 60 years ago looked very far into the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, EVA (LEVINE GHEN)
description: FINKELSTEIN - Eva (Levine Ghen). Died October 27, 1998. Survived by her son Edward, daughter Timmy, daughter-in-law Myra, five grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Graveside service Friday 10:30 A.M. at Mt. Eden Cemetery, 20 Commerce St, Valhalla.

title: Starr Has Hired Ex-Federal Agents in Investigation of Clinton
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, has employed a team of outside investigators, all of them former Federal agents, to supplement his staff in the course of his four-year investigation of President Clinton.

title: League Approves Sale of Franchise
description: In a unanimous vote yesterday, the National Basketball Association's board of governors approved the sale of the Nets to a consortium of northern New Jersey businessmen led by the philanthropist Ray Chambers.

title: City to Tear Down Queens Nursing Home for Parkland
description: Neponsit Health Care Center, a nursing home in the Rockaways from which residents were removed swiftly in the night last month after the city deemed its buildings unsafe, will be demolished and replaced by a park on its six-acre beachfront property, city officials said yesterday.

title: Talk of Drug Link Angers Loved Ones of 3 Slain Men
description: People do not usually die here, 24 floors up.

title: Japan Bank Appointment
description: Japan appointed Takashi Anzai, an executive director of the central bank, to be the new president of Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. today as it carried out its first nationalization of a lender. Japan took control of the bank under a 60 trillion yen ($509 billion) industry bailout package that went into effect last Friday. With 24 trillion yen in assets, Long-Term Credit is Japan's 10th-largest lender. The Government said Mr. Anzai, 57, who will resign from his post at the Bank of Japan, was in the best position to carry out the takeover under measures he had helped form.

title: Amazon Says Sales Soared As Quarterly Loss Narrowed
description: Amazon.com Inc., the leading on-line bookseller, yesterday reported a quadrupling of sales and a narrower-than-expected third-quarter loss.

title: Accounts
description: * Tear Drop Golf Co., Morton Grove, Ill., to Young & Rubicam Chicago, to handle a creative project for its Armour Golf brand. Space Time Media, Chicago, will handle media services. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Augusto Pinochet's Escape Route
description: England's High Court yesterday quashed the arrest order of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, ruling that as a former head of state he is immune from prosecution in English courts. The decision is a mistake. If the evidence holds up, General Pinochet should be turned over to the Spanish judge who issued a warrant for his arrest on charges of genocide, terrorism and torture. His military coup in Chile in 1973 led to the killings of at least 2,000 people. Though Mr. Pinochet may soon be free to return home, the court decision does not have standing outside Britain. It does not save him, or other accused international criminals, from arrest or prosecution in other nations.

title: Mastercard joins the growing crowd that believes what sells here will sell there, too.
description: THEODORE LEVITT may or may not pay for anything with a Mastercard, but he can certainly use the company to prove his theories of global marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAKOVER, ABRAHAM
description: MAKOVER-Abraham. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of David and Sharon. Brother of Morris. Devoted grandfather of Jeremy, Daniel, Judah, Ilana, Avishag, Netta, Hillel, and Mishael. Services and Interment Thursday, 2 PM. New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Mets Seal the Leiter Deal And Look to Free Agents
description: As expected, the Mets announced yesterday that they had officially come to terms with their ace left-hander, Al Leiter, on a four-year, $32 million contract. The deal, with an accompanying news conference with Leiter, came two days after the Mets announced a seven-year, $91 million agreement with the All-Star catcher Mike Piazza.

title: 'Fatal Error' on Entrance Test Turns Out to Be Not So Bad
description: There is no good time to receive a ''fatal error'' message on your computer screen, but 400 business school applicants found out last week that some times are more unnerving than others.

title: Sports of The Times; Sympathetic (Snicker!) To the Cause
description: THE tinkle of bells on the sidewalk in front of a midtown hotel yesterday afternoon appeared to be hurrying the season. But it was not quite the familiar sound ringing from soldiers of the Salvation Army seeking alms during Yuletide. There was indeed a handful of people, not wearing red but black -- black caps and black-and-white shirts -- and standing beside cardboard boxes designed for contributions.

title: TORSTAR OF CANADA BIDS TO ACQUIRE SUN MEDIA
description: The Torstar Corporation, which owns Canada's biggest newspaper, The Toronto Star, offered yesterday to buy the Sun Media Corporation for $748 million (Canadian), or $486 million (United States), in cash and stock, as it seeks a platform to counter a challenge from the publisher Conrad Black's new national daily. Sun Media publishes The Toronto Sun. Combined, the two companies would have 26 percent of the average weekly circulation of daily newspapers in Canada. Mr. Black, through Hollinger Inc. and Southam Inc., now has a 42 percent share that will expand if his new paper, The National Post, gains readers; the paper started publishing Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B. Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: Muscling In on Martha Stewart
description: ARMED with little more than a sheaf of recipes, a glue gun, some dried flowers and a puritanical zeal for modern home-keeping, Martha Stewart has built a multimedia empire worth $200 million, by one conservative estimate. Thus, it comes as no surprise that pretenders are cropping up thicker than sprouts on a Chia Pet.

title: BRAZIL INTRODUCES $80 BILLION PLAN FOR ECONOMIC ILLS
description: The Brazilian Government introduced a three-year, $80 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases today in an effort to restore the country's flagging credibility in world markets and prepare the way for a rescue program led by the International Monetary Fund.

title: 'I Was Busy Reading My Playbook, and . . .'
description: Malcolm Thomas was brought to the Giants last month to be the team's practice-squad running back, a thankless job that is pro football's version of the Hollywood stuntman.

title: Women on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Chelsea: Virtually Wild
description: IT'S been a long time since moose have been bagged below 14th Street. And this is probably the first time a zebra has been spotted in Chelsea. Nevertheless, an afternoon's shopping excursion in these neighborhoods and others can turn into a veritable safari. Gentle hunters can furnish a cabin (or an apartment) with trophies that are exotic, yes, though none of the hides here ever roamed the savanna. But don't think that fake means inexpensive. A well-financed expedition is required to take home some of these trophies.

title: America Online Adds 40 Retailers
description: America Online, the world's largest on-line service, said yesterday that it had added 40 new retailing partners, including Toys ''R'' Us Inc., to the shopping section of its on-line services, bringing the total to 11O.

title: New CBS Head Is Known For Focus on Bottom Line
description: Aggressive is the word most often used to describe Mel Karmazin, the new chief executive officer of the CBS Corporation, and it is an epithet as often as it is a compliment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Five years without Halloween birthday cupcakes, just painful thoughts of what a wonderful, if absurdly youthful, 53 year old you would have been. Miss you now and always. Vick

title: Scholars and Historians Assail Impeachment Inquiry on Clinton
description: Hundreds of constitutional scholars and historians, and the man who presided over the Watergate impeachment proceedings, today criticized the inquiry into President Clinton, as House Democrats and Republicans became entangled in a request for more documents.

title: Play 'What If,' But Plan To Skip Tour
description: MICROSOFT MONEY FINANCIAL SUITE 99

title: A Debate Over What Encyclical Allows
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Game Shifted To MSG Saturday
description: Cablevision Systems said yesterday it would carry Saturday night's Devils-Florida hockey game, reversing its decision last week not to show it on Fox Sports New York because it conflicted with the Islanders-Philadelphia game. But New Jersey's game won't be carried on FSNY, the Devils' TV home. Instead, it will be on the MSG Network.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Political Briefing; Libertarians Taking A Crack at Mormons
description: As in most other states, the Libertarian Party of Utah finds itself almost perpetually short of members and in an uphill fight.

title: CENTURA BANKS TO BUY FIRST COASTAL FOR $117 MILLION
description: Centura Banks Inc. said yesterday that it would buy First Coastal Bankshares Inc. for $117 million in stock. Centura, based in Rocky Mount, N.C., said it would pay the equivalent of $23.50 a share for First Coastal, a 21 percent premium to yesterday's closing price of $19.50. First Coastal, based in Virginia Beach, Va., has $578 million in assets and 17 offices. Centura has assets of $7.8 billion and 210 offices, including nine in the area where First Coastal operates. Its shares fell 37.5 cents, to $69.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, CATHERINE P. (NEE CARLIN)
description: LEAHY-Catherine P. (nee Carlin) on Wednesday, October 28, 1998 of Sag Harbor, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of William F. Leahy. Dear mother of William C. and Michael J. Leahy. Loving grandmother of William G., Lorraine Winsor, Michael J. Jr., and Crista. Also survived by six great grandchildren. The family will receive friends Friday 2-4:30 and 79:30PM at Cecere Funeral Homes, 356 Westbury Ave., Carle Place, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 11AM at Queen of the Most Holy Rosary R.C. Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Interment following at Sacred Hearts Cemetery, Southampton, NY. The family suggests donations to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486 or The American Cancer Society.

title: Entrepreneurs; On-Line Businesses Tap Home-Schooling Market
description: THE technology of home schooling has provided business opportunities on several levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, EDWIN FLYNN
description: SCHNEIDER-Edwin Flynn. 77, of Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL. On October 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Regina Caldwell. Loving & wise father of Regina Schneider de Ojea of Madrid, Spain; Edwin C. Schneider of Armonk, NY; Kathleen Schneider Pratt of Chestnut Hill, PA; and Michael Gerard Schneider of Lower Gwynedd, PA. Proud grandfather of Jeannita, Andres, Bettina Tara, Gable, Galen, Chuck, Tory, Caroline, Alexander and Graham. Graduated Princeton University Class of 1944 in Electrical Engineering. President and CEO of Ettco Wire and Cable Corp., founded 1907, a leading manufacturer of wire and cable in Brooklyn, New York. Mr. Schneider served as a member of the Advisory Committee of Chase Manhattan Bank, Borough of Queens. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Lost Tree Club and the Meadow Brook Club. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Thursday, 6-9 PM. Funeral mass Friday 9:45 AM, St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Brookville. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Brain Tumor Center, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, 3 West Gates, 3400 Spruce St., Philadelphia, PA, 19104 or to Princeton University.

title: Electronic Combination Lock Designed to Keep Out Hackers
description: The agency that helped create the world's biggest bombs has now helped create its smallest combination lock, a bit of technology aimed at preventing attacks by computer hackers.

title: Asian Woman's Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Steve Martin's Career Skips Down Another New Path
description: Steve Martin, the actor, comedian and screenwriter, began his fourth career -- or was it his fifth? -- with an essay about a birdbath. He had read a newspaper article about the discovery at a house on Fifth Avenue of a fountain that may have been sculptured by Michelangelo, and he conjectured that he had a birdbath by Raphael in his own backyard in California, the Martin Birdbath ''as some scholars are now calling it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFER, BERTHA S.
description: LAUFER-Bertha S., 88. Beloved wife of Charles, mother of Matthew and the late Paul. Loving aunt. Inspiring teacher at Walton. Burial services Sunday, 11:30AM.

title: The Republican Ad That Revisited the White House Scandal
description: This is a new commercial the Republican National Committee began broadcasting this week.

title: In a Shaky District for Incumbents, Both Parties Focus Energy
description: Voters in the Fifth Congressional District are not ones to send their Representative back to Washington automatically. In the last 13 elections, they have fired their Representative four times, most recently two years ago when Gary A. Franks, a Republican, lost to James H. Maloney, a Democrat.

title: Evelyn Sabin, 90, Student of Graham
description: Evelyn Sabin, who performed with Martha Graham's first dance company in the mid-1920's, died on Tuesday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 90 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fierce Opponents Go Down to the Wire
description: Here in the hills of eastern Kentucky, where Loretta Lynn grew up as a coal miner's daughter, the politicians are talking this fall about ''a turnout election.'' You hear the same phrase in Louisville and Paducah, and in Wisconsin, New York and North Carolina -- everywhere there is a close race for state or Federal office.

title: Moceanu Gets Adult Status In Dispute Over Her Money
description: Like Bernie Williams of the Yankees, the Olympic gymnast Dominique Moceanu has been declared a free agent.

title: The C.I.A.'s Little-Known Resume
description: Much ado is being made of the Central Intelligence Agency's prominent role in negotiating the recent Israeli-Palestinian accord and its prospective part in carrying out the agreement. Both critics and defenders of the C.I.A. have expressed concern that this is a significant departure from -- and an expansion of -- the agency's traditional activities and mission.

title: Gleeful Democrats Assail Ads By G.O.P. on Clinton Scandal
description: A parade of prominent Democrats today pounced gleefully on what they called a Republican blunder in waging a last-minute, multimillion-dollar advertising offensive that exploits President Clinton's sex scandal.

title: A Restyoration at Saks
description: What customers want, customers sometimes get. Saks Fifth Avenue closed its home furnishings department in 1990. Customers grumbled that they needed to buy gifts; now furnishings are back. This month, Frank McIntosh Home (late of Henri Bendel) opens at 14 stores, including the flagship in Manhattan. Above, a handblown Italian bowl ($45), salad servers ($125) and frames ($55 to $75).

title: Netanyahu Risked Enough Politically for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Mirage Resorts And Publicis Part
description: Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco and Mirage Resorts Inc. in Las Vegas, Nev., said yesterday that after a decade they had mutually parted ways. As a result, the Mirage account, with billings estimated at $10 million, was placed in review.

title: PCS Antenna Can Avoid Thick Skulls
description: PCS cellular telephone transmissions would be much clearer if not for one thing: the cellular telephone user's cranium.

title: Stepping Lively From Past To Future
description: Murray Louis surely glanced back with pleasure and looked forward with confidence as he planned the two-week season of Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance, which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: GOODRICH WINS CONTRACT FOR BOEING REPLACEMENT PARTS
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that its Aerospace Aerostructures unit won a contract worth a potential $400 million to supply the Boeing Company with replacement parts for planes no longer being made. Boeing will buy components from Goodrich for the next six years for out-of-production models including the 707, 727 and DC-10. Goodrich said it would invest $30 million to build a parts plant in Arkadelphia, Ark., which is expected to begin operations in the fourth quarter and employ 200 to 300 workers in the next three to five years. Goodrich has previously supplied Boeing with other parts.

title: Clinton Foe Is Doubtful Of Senate
description: The humorlessness of Representative Bob Barr, the scowling conservative who started the drive to impeach President Clinton, was celebrated by hometown supporters tonight in a political roast, and Mr. Barr agreed that they had a point.

title: A Debate Over What Encyclical Allows
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Tests Stacked Against It, eBook Passes
description: WHEN I was 7 years old, my father took me to the public library. While I browsed the familiar collection of picture books, he disappeared down another aisle and reappeared carrying something that looked entirely different from the usual see-the-pretty-seashells fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINE, RUTH
description: BRINE-Ruth. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Brine, beloved mother of Kevin Brine, a generous supporter and cherished friend of the Jewish community. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Brine family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Birdhouse Gourds
description: Q. When are birdhouse gourds ready for harvest? Must they age or dry out after harvesting? How does one make a real birdhouse from the birdhouse gourd?

title: Turkish Bank in Talks To Buy Gasoline Retailer
description: Turkiye Garanti Bankasi A.S., Turkey's fifth-largest bank, and its parent, Dogus Holding, said yesterday that they were in talks to acquire the state-run gasoline retailer Petrol Ofisi for about $1 billion after the winner of a tender dropped out.

title: Cone Granted Week to Weigh Yankees' Offer
description: David Cone's affiliation with the Yankees could have ended yesterday. But the pitcher, apparently intent on working out an agreement that would keep him in pinstripes, agreed to wait an additional week before deciding whether to accept a $5.5 million deal for the 1999 season.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged In Beating Death of Baby
description: A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with beating his girlfriend's 20-month-old daughter to death, the police said .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWSKY, PAUL B.
description: BERKOWSKY-Paul B. On Octboer 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Sheala, devoted father of Kevin and Pamela. Founding Vice President of The League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers and invaluable and historical figure in the history of the Off-Broadway theatre movement. Friend, mentor and teacher. Our heartfelt condolences to his family, our eternal gratitude for his lasting contribution to the theatre industry. The League of Off-Broadway Theatres and Producers Barry Grove, President

title: Lacroix's Sketches for Christofle
description: Like many fashion designers, Christian Lacroix has added a new sideline to his empire beyond the runway: china for Christofle. Six porcelain plates feature Mr. Lacroix's sketches of his favorite cities: Arles, France, his hometown; Paris; Rome; Seville, Spain; London, and New York, which he calls ''a colossal Tower of Babel.'' Paris is $55; other plates come in pairs ($110). Teacup and saucer, $135. Through Christofle, 680 Madison Avenue; (800) 799-6886. RIMA SUQI

title: Treasuries Off As Stability Aids Markets
description: Bond prices fell for the first time in three days as signs of stability in world financial markets decreased the demand for Treasuries, and the Government announced plans to sell $38 billion of notes and bonds next week.

title: Let's Make Adoption a Non-Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: TENET AWARDS OWENS & MINOR $2 BILLION CONTRACT
description: Owens & Minor Inc. said yesterday that it signed an eight-year, $2 billion contract with the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the No. 2 United States hospital operator, to supply its medical and surgical products. Owens & Minor, which is based in Richmond, said that under terms of the contract, it would be sole provider. The contract, which had been held by the McKesson Corporation, will save Tenet about $20 million a year, Tenet said.

title: UConn Is Coaches' Unanimous Preseason Choice to Capture Big East Title
description: It's that time of year in New York. Fashion designers parade their new spring lines down the runway for review and college athletic conferences give the news media a look at their starting lineups for the coming basketball season.

title: Isadora Duncan Danced Here
description: When Madam C. J. Walker, left, lived at Villa Lewaro, Isadora Duncan danced on the lawn and Langston Hughes wrote on the walls. Through Nov. 29, the 34-room landmark mansion will be open to the public, as a show house benefiting the United Negro College Fund.

title: Eliot Spitzer for Attorney General
description: The race for New York State attorney general this year involves two flawed candidates, and the temptation is to skip an endorsement for either the incumbent Republican, Dennis Vacco, or his Democratic opponent, Eliot Spitzer. Mr. Spitzer has misled the public about how his father's wealth was used to support about $9 million in loans that financed his campaigns in 1994 and 1998. His conduct may not be illegal, but it was clearly designed to circumvent laws that would have limited his father's direct contributions to the campaign. In normal circumstances, Mr. Spitzer's evasions would have made it impossible to endorse him for the state's top legal position.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a United Nations report on the impact of AIDS on the population of several countries misstated the number of affected countries that are sub-Saharan. It is 29; 34 is the total number of countries in the report.

title: I Don't Know Who You Are, but You're Toast
description: DANIEL SHIFFMAN, a lanky 25-year-old who is a self-proclaimed computer geek, was never an athletic powerhouse. At the small private high school he attended in his native Baltimore, he was often ''well down near the bottom of gym class,'' he recalled with a chuckle.

title: Art and a Will
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 44 Stock Promoters Accused by S.E.C. Of Internet Fraud
description: Delivering a blunt reminder to investors that the World Wide Web can be treacherous, Federal regulators said yesterday that they had accused 44 stock promoters of fraudulently recommending more than 235 small companies on the Internet.

title: Digital Cameras Harness Chip Technology to Do the Job of Film
description: ONCE considered an engineering folly in a world of film and video cameras, digital still cameras have become a booming industry in the last decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHGRUND, HERBERT B.
description: FISCHGRUND-Herbert B. The partners of the former firm of Fields, Fischgrund & Aerenson CPA's mourn the passing of our very much loved partner and friend. Herb was the consummate professional in every respect. He epitomized the highest principles of integrity, ethical and moral standards, serving as a wise and trusted advisor and mentor to his clients, friends, employees and partners. Our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Cis, his children Terry, Tom and Jeff and their families. He will remain forever in our hearts and thoughts. Louis W. and Esther Fields Robert A. and Marjorie Aerenson Daniel and Geraldine Soba Fred and Barbara Bornstein Leonard and Lois Lichter

title: Governor's Race Lacks Fire, Hurting Democrat
description: In the vast megalopolis known here as Chicagoland, which stretches 50 miles from the high-rises along Lake Michigan to suburban cul-de-sacs, it has often been difficult to get voters interested in the political action in the Illinois Statehouse.

title: $70 Billion Surplus As U.S. Closes Books On 1998 Fiscal Year
description: The Federal Government officially closed the books today on the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, saying it ran a $70 billion surplus, the first time since 1969 that Washington spent less than it took in.

title: Steinbrenner Will Donate $200,000 for Hurricane Relief Effort
description: Still jubilant after his baseball team won the World Series last week, George M. Steinbrenner 3d announced yesterday that he would donate $200,000 from the Yankee Foundation to hurricane relief efforts in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIN, AUNG, FRANCIS
description: TIN-AUNG-Francis. October 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Odette. Devoted father of Danielle and Isabelle. Services Saturday, 2PM at CCUN Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza, NYC.

title: Pataki Defies Expectations And Becomes Quiet Force
description: It was the most indelible image of the 1994 gubernatorial campaign: a newspaper photograph of George E. Pataki being led, literally by the hand, through a crowded fund-raising dinner by his political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUORUM HEALTH GROUP INC., Brentwood, Tenn., an owner of acute-care hospitals, will buy back as much as another 5 million shares, or 6.6 percent of its 75.7 million shares outstanding.

title: Skipped Votes by D'Amato End the Issue, Schumer Says
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer denounced Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato today for running a ''cynical campaign on what we now see clearly is a phony issue'' after Mr. D'Amato acknowledged that he had skipped hundreds of votes as a local official when he first ran for the Senate in 1980.

title: A Debate Over What Encyclical Allows
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK
description: AQUEDUCT

title: City to Allow More Time For Absentee Ballots
description: City elections officials said yesterday that they would allow 10 extra days after the Nov. 3 election for the return of ballots from members of the military and overseas citizens to resolve a Federal complaint charging that delays in delivering absentee ballots had violated the law.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR STRENGTHENS. The dollar rose after Brazil announced an austerity package viewed as critical to helping stabilize Latin America and other emerging markets. The dollar cost 1.6542 marks, up from 1.6519 Tuesday.

title: Tropicana Raising Prices
description: Pepsico Inc.'s Tropicana juice division, the world's largest juice maker, said today that it would raise the wholesale prices of its orange juices an average 10 percent next month because of the reduced Florida crop. The retail price could increase from 30 cents to 40 cents for 64-ounce cartons of Tropicana Pure Premium, the company said. The Agriculture Department forecast earlier this month that the Florida orange crop would decrease 22 percent, or 4.9 billion pounds, this season. With domestic consumption of orange juice on the rise, the smaller crop has sent orange juice futures up about 20 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, ADDY
description: WALD-Addy. Professor of English at Jersey City State College and writer. Died peacefully on October 27, 1998 at age 82 in her Manhattan home. She was the wife of the late Dr. Arthur H.
