Wald, the loving mother of Leslie Blankfein and mother-in-law of Dr. Robert J. Blankfein (of Manhattan) and beloved grandmother of David H. Tabachnick (a Ph.D candidate at the University of Virginia). Addy, a survivor of the Nazi Holocaust immigrated to the United Sates at age 18. She then completed both her undergraduate degree and graduate training in English literature at Columbia University. Addy will be terribly missed by her immediate family, her friends, her colleagues and her students. She will be remembered for her inner strength, her moral and political conviction as well as her constant attention to the human condition. Services on Friday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Simms and Taylor Nominated
description: Quarterback Phil Simms and linebacker Lawrence Taylor, heroes from the Giants' two Super Bowl championship teams, were among the 76 nominees named yesterday for the Pro Football Hall of Fame's class of 1999.

title: Arthur Merritt, 96, Renaissance Music Expert
description: Arthur Tillman Merritt, a specialist in Renaissance music who was a professor at Harvard University and director of the university's music department for many years, died on Sunday in Bedford, Mass. He was 96.

title: No-Frills Look at Retirement
description: PLAN RETIREMENT QUICK AND EASY

title: Op-Art; CELESTIAL BODIES AND THEIR AGES IN YEARS
Two Patakis: In 4 Years, Governor Has Pushed Issues Both Conservative and Moderate
description: When asked to assess George E. Pataki's record as Governor, Tom Carroll, president of the conservative group Change-NY, asked: ''Which one? The Pataki of the first two years or the Pataki of the second two years?''

title: Both Home and School on the Range
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Witches On Line: Nothing Nearly As Spooky as You Might Imagine
description: IT'S perfectly reasonable that you'd be able to work magic over the Internet,'' said Kristin Spence, a former editor at Wired magazine. ''It's just another tool. Instead of a cauldron, you're using a keyboard.''

title: On the Express Track to Venerability
description: FOR New York City subways, the next stop is history.

title: Dancer's Hesitant Pas de Deux With Cuba
description: AFTER 24 years with the New York City Ballet, the last 14 as a principal dancer, Lourdes Lopez knows how to move her lithe body gracefully. She understands harmony and movement, pacing and breathing. Yet here she is, painfully stretching her calves, puffing like a novice, sweat beads dampening her taut chest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNES, EVELYN
description: MANNES-Evelyn. The administration and faculty of Mannes College of Music mourn the passing of Mrs. Leopold Mannes, who served on the Board of Trustees from 1979 to 1989 as the widow of a distinguished former President of the College, the son of the founding family. We extend our deepest sympathies to her daughter, Elena. Joel Lester, Dean Robert J. Morgado, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Group Fights Attack Ads With Its Own
description: After long deploring political commercials that hit below the belt, a good-government group decided this fall to fight back, and not by Marquess of Queensberry rules.

title: Songs Spread Wings to Fly Beyond Mere Words
description: Mary Margaret O'Hara began her performance at St. Ann's Church in Brooklyn Heights with the song ''Body's in Trouble,'' and unsuspecting audience members might have thought she was narrating her own predicament.

title: English Court Rules Pinochet Should Be Free
description: England's High Court ruled today in favor of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's claim that he is immune from arrest here and extradition to Spain on charges of murder, kidnapping and torture. But the justices ordered him detained pending an appeal, expected next week.

title: Executive Changes
description: HERSHEY FOODS CORP., Hershey, Pa., named Michael Pasquale head of its candy and pasta businesses, making him the probable successor to the current chief executive, Kenneth Wolfe. Mr. Pasquale, who headed Hershey's North American chocolate business, was also nominated to the company's board. Also promoted was Raymond Brace, to senior vice president for operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAYKIN, SIDNEY R.
description: CHAYKIN-Sidney R. On October 28, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Blanche. Beloved father of Carol, and dear brother of Mildred Rakofsky, Irving, and the late Jean Solomon. Services Friday 11:30 a.m. at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: A Debate Over What Encyclical Allows
description: To the Editor:

title: Wide Aisles for More Bargains
description: ABC Carpet and Home -- the improved outlet store. ABC has been selling off-price rugs at its Bronx warehouse for five years, but now the company has expanded the space and filled it with bed linens, furniture and accessories. As of today, bargain hunters can view ABC's merchandise, available for 20 percent to 70 percent off downtown prices. The warehouse's wide aisles are a welcome change from the crowded, attic-like environment at the main store at 888 Broadway, which inspires a ''Whoops, watch your elbow'' style of shopping.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Liechtenstein Trust Share Buyback Offered
description: The Liechtenstein Foundation, the majority owner of Liechtenstein Global Trust A.G., offered yesterday to buy all the bank's certificates, valuing the listed portion at 1.187 billion Swiss francs ($882 million).

title: Wireless Alliance Prepares to Oppose Microsoft
description: Cementing an alliance intended to block the Microsoft Corporation from dominating new consumer communications markets, Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it had completed an investment in a European joint venture that is developing an operating system for a future generation of digital wireless phones.

title: Political Briefing; Senator Dumped For Mrs. Clinton
description: Last summer, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a possible Democratic Presidential aspirant in 2000, asked to speak to a big A.F.L.-C.I.O. rally in neighboring Iowa, home of the first Presidential caucuses. Labor leaders said no: he was out of tune on changing Social Security.

title: Corrections
description: A brief review in the In Performance column on Monday about the Robert Wood Dance New York company at the Joyce SoHo on Saturday misidentified the soloist in the dance ''Episode.'' He was Ricky Lizalde, not Christopher Bonomo.

title: Crafts, Interiors, Rare Prints
description: Crafts and Interiors

title: North Korea to Let U.S. Group Visit Suspicious New Complex
description: North Korea has agreed to allow a Clinton Administration delegation to visit there next month to discuss American concerns about the construction of a vast underground complex that is widely thought to house a nuclear weapons program, the State Department said today.

title: James Goldman, 71, a Creator Of 'Lion in Winter' and 'Follies'
description: James Goldman, who wrote the Broadway play ''The Lion in Winter'' and the book for the Stephen Sondheim musical ''Follies,'' died yesterday. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Suit by Officers Accuses Police Of Harassment
description: Two police officers filed a suit against the Police Department yesterday charging that they had been subjected to years of anti-gay harassment, including cruel taunts and humiliating assaults, at the 23d Precinct station house on the Upper East Side.

title: Expert Says Teacher's Blood Was on Defendant's Clothes
description: The trial of the former student accused of killing Jonathan M. Levin turned to the intricacies of scientific evidence yesterday as a forensic expert testified that DNA evidence linked the student to the knife used in the attack and showed that his clothes had been stained with his former teacher's blood.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Philanthropy

title: A New York Comeback After a Scary Detour
description: After she finished 10th in the 1996 Olympic marathon, Anne Marie Lauck and her husband, Jim, took a Christmas season vacation to Hawaii. It was a chance to relax and celebrate, to pop the cork on a successful season. But, in one horrific moment, her career nearly ended just as it had reached its peak.

title: Women on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, FRANCIS X.
description: LARKIN-Francis X. Of Montclair, New Jersey, and Point Pleasant, NJ, on October 26,1998. Husband of Patricia (Kenney). Father of Francis X. Larkin Jr of Boise, ID, Mary Patricia Caputo of Bristol, CT., Ann Therese Smith of Lawrenceville, NJ and Elizabeth Ann Larkin of NYC. Brother of Edward Larkin of Nashua, NH, and the late Michael Larkin. Also survived by 5 granddaughters. Funeral from the Frank Halpin's Brookdale Funeral Home, 1284 Broad St., Bloomfield NJ on Friday at 9:00 AM. A funeral mass will be offered at Mt. Carmel Church, Montclair, NJ at 10:00 AM. Interment Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Montclair, NJ. Visiting hours Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Mt. Carmel Restoration Fund, 94 Pine Street, Montclair, NJ 07042 in his memory.

title: Sides in N.B.A. Talk It Over, Then Call a Timeout
description: Yesterday was the 120th day of the National Basketball Association lockout and it was unlike any other, with a large group of owners and players going face to face for 90 minutes, with the league deleting two more weeks from the 1998-99 schedule and with both sides negotiating late into the night in the hope that a deal can be reached before more damage is done to the season.

title: Women Playing To Fill N.B.A. Void
description: The American Basketball League is trying to capitalize on the misfortunes of the National Basketball Association.

title: Glenn Draws Huge Crowd To View His Latest Flight
description: The machines, the weather and John Glenn himself were ''go'' today for launching as countdown preparations progressed smoothly toward the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 2 P.M. on Thursday, on the most eagerly awaited space mission in years.

title: GOLF: Golf Course At the Center Of a Community; Developer's Dual Initiative Revives Atlanta Neighborhood
description: The neighborhood housing project was so violent, it was nicknamed Little Vietnam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, HERMAN W.
description: RAPPAPORT-Herman W. October 28, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Roby Gluckman and her husband Thomas. Cherished grandfather of Mya, Andrew, Even and Kelly, and great grandfather of Ian and Zane. Loving brother of Ann Lipton and Poppy Rappaport. Service on Thursday, October 29, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. He was a generous benefactor to all who needed his help.

title: Momentum Awards For Work on Internet
description: Several Internet-related companies and executives were honored for leadership and innovation at the 1998 Momentum Awards ceremony.

title: New Yorker Cartoons to Go on Line
description: PICTURE a cartoon: a woman opens a door labeled ''computer room'' only to find shelves of loose-leaf binders and a surprised group of men in lab coats shuffling papers. ''We're updating the database,'' the caption reads.

title: NEWS WATCH; Internet Service For Orthodox Jews
description: Many Orthodox Jews are concerned that much Internet material is not appropriate for the home. Now Jews can subscribe to Koshernet (www.thekosher.net), an Internet service provider that filters out Web sites that might be objectionable. Koshernet has contracts with three companies that scan the Web for material judged to be inappropriate for Orthodox Jews. Rabbis and educators also advise Koshernet, which provides links for those who want to use the Internet for religious purposes, like learning from holy texts.

title: Church Debate Over Voter Guides
description: As the Christian Coalition prepares to distribute 45 million voter guides in churches this Sunday -- its most ambitious election-year effort ever -- it is hitting more resistance than ever before from liberal advocacy groups and even from conservative and moderate ministers who contend that the guides are biased in favor of Republican candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEALE, MARY CECELIA
description: NEALE-Mary Cecelia. Born to Eternal Life, Oct. 28, 1998. Beloved sister of Teresa Misklow and the late J. Hamilton Neale, F. Brent Neale, and Catherine Brent Neale Hill. Devoted aunt of Richard Hill, Mary Lucille Hill-Monaco, Patricia and James Neale, Mary Burke and Phillip Misklow. Visitation 6-9 PM Friday October 30, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Church of the Holy Family, 315 47 St., 10:30 AM, Saturday, October 31. Interment is at 1 P.M., Monday, November 2nd, at the New Cathedral Cemetery, Baltimore, Maryland.

title: Asea Brown Executive To Head Kvaerner
description: Kvaerner A.S.A., Europe's largest shipbuilder, named Kjell Almskog, a rising star at Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., as chief executive yesterday with a goal to revive flagging earnings and sell unprofitable units.

title: Business Optimism Lags
description: Business activity in the New York City region slowed this month and the outlook for the next six months dimmed, a survey of services and manufacturing executives showed.

title: Vacco's Ticket For a 2d Term: Jail a Scalper
description: JERRY NAHAY always figured that he, like many of his fellow ticket scalpers, might one day play a role in the re-election campaign of a New York State attorney general. But it never occurred to him that he could be the first to go to prison in the process.

title: Strike Is Authorized By Jersey City Teachers
description: The 2,500 teachers in New Jersey's second largest school district voted yesterday to authorize a strike, the union said.

title: Herlitz to Cut 500 Jobs In Move to Cut Costs
description: Herlitz A.G., a German office-equipment supplier, said yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 500 jobs in a reorganization aimed at reducing costs, adding that sales in the first nine months of this year fell 1.2 percent, compared with the previous year. Within the next six months, 250 employees will lose their jobs in a reorganization of subsidiaries in Berlin and Peitz.

title: Profits Are Off 45% at Mobil
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 45 percent because of low crude-oil prices, decreased production and less profit from making and selling fuel, especially in Asia.

title: New Projection Television Promises Lighter Viewing
description: Samsung Electronics America Inc. says it can make the decision to buy a television less weighty -- by more than 40 pounds.

title: Getting There Is Half the Battle; Learning How To Pick Fights In Cyberspace
description: IT was a humbling sight: a silvery cloud of hover jets descending upon my fortress cluster of laser towers, armament factories and rocket launchers to reduce it all to smoldering rumble. It had taken just more than an hour for someone who called himself Hefty Lefty to vanquish me at Total Annihilation, a computer strategy game at which I had long considered myself a resourceful player.

title: Clinton Cites 'Inner Changes' Since Scandal
description: President Clinton asserted today that he had undergone ''inner changes'' as a result of the Monica Lewinsky scandal and said Tuesday's elections should not be a referendum on his personal behavior but on his conduct in office.

title: Race for 3d Pits Golisano Against McCaughey Ross
description: Although nothing in politics is certain, least of all predictions, polls suggest that George E. Pataki will most likely win the race for Governor next Tuesday, and that Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic nominee, will finish a distant second.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAPHAEL, AARON
description: RAPHAEL-Aaron. Dear Aaron, On your birthday, we love and miss you every day. Love, Lillian, the kids and grandkids

title: Lectures on Preservation, A Landscape Exhibition
description: Behind Closed Doors

title: New Orleans Chosen For Super Bowl in 2002
description: Super Bowl XXXVI on Jan. 27, 2002, will be played in the Superdome in New Orleans. The National Football League owners chose that city yesterday over the other finalist, San Diego, but said that San Diego would be favored to be the host in 2004.

title: INSIDE
description: N.B.A. Cancels More Games

title: A Debate Over What Encyclical Allows
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick! Name a Top Israeli Filmmaker; Nation's Cinema Is a Well-Kept Secret
description: The dark-haired man in the slate-gray turtleneck sounded as if he were trying to explain the dynamics of the Middle East peace process, which was nearing a crescendo as he spoke on Friday.

title: Arena Picks Team For Australia Match
description: One day after being named coach of the United States team, Bruce Arena made his first selection of players for the national team an all-Major League Soccer squad. Not only that, but nine of the 22 players selected for the match against Australia in San Jose, Calif., on Nov. 6 are on the team for the first time.

title: Maris, West to Lead Campaign on Smoking
description: The Partnership for a Healthy Mississippi in Jackson, a nonprofit organization working to reduce tobacco use by teen-agers, said yesterday that it had named Maris, West & Baker in Jackson to lead a multi-agency marketing team to introduce an anti-smoking campaign. Billings for a two-year effort were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Chile Applauds Court Ruling on Pinochet
description: The Chilean Government applauded the ruling today by the High Court in London that this country's former dictator, the retired Gen. Augusto Pinochet, is protected by diplomatic immunity. But Chilean human rights activists promised to press on with their efforts to force him to stand trial in Spain or some other European country on genocide charges.

title: Antidotes For Crashes
description: Q. Does anti-crash software really help?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Tell me who's going to show up at the polls next Tuesday, and I'll tell you who's going to win.''

title: Devils Can't Finish a Play, and Boos Remind Them of It
description: The familiar malady failing to finish their chances -- returned to haunt the Devils again tonight. After scoring three goals in each of their last two games, victories over Philadelphia and Boston, the Devils shot 40 blanks against the Los Angeles Kings tonight and suffered a 4-0 loss.

title: The Mansions You've Been Looking For
description: Double staircases. Coffered ceilings. A crystal chandelier (a gift from Winston Churchill). The mansion is near Palm Beach, and it's for sale.

title: A Mouse That Could
description: Black & Decker's new Mouse ($59.99) may look like a computer mouse, but that's where the similarities end. The Mouse is a small sander and polisher that is versatile, thanks to its ironlike shape.

title: McColl Secures Control Over BankAmerica
description: The former management of the Nationsbank Corporation today solidified its control over the BankAmerica Corporation, the biggest bank in the United States, extending the term of the chief executive who led the merger of the two companies.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Gestures That Grow

title: Artistry in the Garden: A Study in Cabbages and Kale
description: THERE'S a proud green serpent of vegetables undulating over the grass at Wave Hill, the public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, known for its imagination and unusual plants.

title: First American Settles Charges
description: A First American Financial Corporation unit agreed today to settle accusations by the Federal Trade Commission that it did not give consumers a fair chance to dispute inaccurate credit reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBACH, RUTH
description: STERNBACH-Ruth, on October 26, 1998 in Norwalk, CT, a resident of Westport, CT and Delray, FL, survived by her husband, Louis Sternbach, her sister, Patricia Brown of Cleveland, OH, two nieces and a nephew. Private services from Abraham L. Green & Son, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions to a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RABBI LAWRENCE WILLIAM
description: SCHWARTZ - Rabbi Lawrence William. Of White Plains, NY. On October 28, 1998. Rabbi Emeritus Congregation Kol Ami, (The Jewish Community Center), White Plains, NY. Survived by his son, Lawrence William Schwartz, Jr. Pre-deceased by his daughter, June Schwartz Lichtenstein. Funeral service Friday 1 PM, at Congregation Kol Ami (Jewish Community Center), Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Japan Looks at Issuing Certificates to Spur Consumer Spending
description: A senior adviser to Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi said in an interview today that the Government was highly likely to adopt a plan to issue gift certificates in an effort to spur consumer spending.

title: Jets' Johnson Is Ready For Chiefs' Challenge
description: As he landed on a touchdown catch Sunday against the Atlanta Falcons, Keyshawn Johnson, the Jets' flamboyant receiver, bruised the big toe on his right foot. The next day, Coach Bill Parcells saw Johnson limping ever so slightly.

title: Post-Office Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR UP 2.8 PERCENT. Prices rose as concern ebbed that Brazilian growers would flood the market. The March contract rose 0.21 cent, to 7.76 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MIMI F.
description: AUSTIN-Mimi F. On October 28, 1998. Much loved mother of Diane Gidding and Rob Austin, sister of Stephen Fields, devoted grandmother of Zack Gidding and Robin Snow, dear sister-in-law of Suzanne, loving mother-in-law of Diane Austin and Josh Gidding. Fiercely loyal and devoted to her family, friends and the causes she so deeply believed in. Service Friday 12 noon at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 2 Studies Dash Hope of Reducing Complex Regimen of AIDS Drugs
description: Two new studies have undercut scientists' hopes that people infected with H.I.V. could avoid a lifelong regimen of taking a drug ''cocktail'' of 20 to 30 pills a day, a regimen that can cost $15,000 a year and cause a variety of side effects.

title: Arafat Gets a Scripted Welcome Back Home in Gaza
description: Cheered by throngs of schoolchildren but ignored by most Gazans who went about their daily routines, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, returned here today to promote his accord with Israel to a wary public.

title: R.L. White, 82; Headed Union In Post Offices
description: Robert L. White, a former mailman who was president of the National Alliance of Postal and Federal Employees, one of the country's oldest independent, black-led labor unions, died on Sunday at Washington Hospital Center. He was 82 and lived in Washington.

title: Sports of The Times; A Familiar Idol Talks About His 'Idol in Life'
description: HE usually walks with a cane now, but rather than be on his feet for too long, he'll sit in a wheelchair. Ted Williams is 80 years old, somewhat affected by the stroke he had in 1994, but he still glows as a baseball idol.

title: People
description: * Ted S. Barton was named to the vacant post of executive vice president and executive creative director at Publicis & Hal Riney, Chicago, part of Publicis S.A. He had been senior partner and creative director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C.

title: An Analysis With Attitude
description: T. ROWE PRICE RETIREMENT PLANNING ANALYZER

title: Women on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Make Adoption a Non-Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Describes Microsoft Fight To Secure Ally
description: Firsthand testimony from a senior executive at America Online and new documents introduced in court today provided an extraordinarily detailed portrait of the Microsoft Corporation's campaign to thwart a planned partnership between the nation's largest on-line service and the Netscape Communications Corporation, Microsoft's rival in the Internet software market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, JANET (NEE OPPERMAN)
description: FITZGERALD-Janet (nee Opperman) of Queens, NY formerly of Toledo, Ohio. A Senior Business Analyst with Nautica Enterprises, Inc., died Oct. 25, 1998. Survived by her husband, John T. Fitzgerald; father, Willis H. Opperman; daughter, Kelly Martin; sister, Judith A. Scoville; and brother, Daniel W. Opperman. Visiting on Thursday, 7-9PM and Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM at the Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home, Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River. New York. Funeral service to be held Saturday, 10:30AM, at the funeral home. Burial will be at Cemetery of the Ascension, Munsey, NY. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society, Breast Cancer Programs, 19 West 56 Street, NY, New York 10019 or Alzheimer's Association of NY, 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 610, New York, NY 10017, Attn: Lynne Raymond.

title: 18 Are Arrested in 1997 Miami Ballot Fraud
description: Florida officials arrested 18 people today and were seeking 3 others in a case of widespread ballot fraud that tainted last November's citywide election here.

title: Man Is Cleared In Murder Case After 8 Years
description: Jeffrey Blake went to prison for murder in 1991 on the weight of one man's word. Today, after spending more than a quarter of his life behind bars, Mr. Blake will go free, because, officials now concede, that man's word was a lie.

title: Technically Secure Pianist Stokes His Fire Carefully
description: Part of the gold medalist's spoils at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition is a recital at Carnegie Hall. Usually, this part of the prize is also a pianist's New York debut, but Jon Nakamatsu, the Californian who won the Cliburn in 1997, gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall in 1995, when he won the American National Chopin Competition. He returned to play his Carnegie Hall concert on Monday evening.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Homey Touches

title: Catering Hall Planned in Landmark Midtown Bank
description: ''I'd better stop going around looking at beautiful buildings,'' Arrigo Cipriani said yesterday, his smile one part bashful, two parts gleeful as he contemplated the next New York City landmark over which his family would preside as hosts.

title: Political Briefing; With $4 Million, Why Go for More?
description: The other night when Senator John McCain of Arizona debated the four challengers who are trying to unseat him on Nov. 3, only 40 people showed up to listen, which was as good a measure as any of the excitement this race has stirred.

title: Head of CBS Quits in Move Seen as Early
description: Michael H. Jordan, the chairman and chief executive of CBS, who led the transformation of the Westinghouse Corporation from an industrial and broadcasting conglomerate into a pure media entity retitled the CBS Corporation, announced his resignation yesterday. Mel Karmazin, the president, was appointed the new top CBS executive.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: INSIDE

title: The Dow Breaks Its Fall As Most Averages Advance
description: Stock prices resumed their advance yesterday in a relatively subdued session as investors appraised Brazil's fiscal package and awaited key Government reports on United States wage growth and output.

title: Netanyahu Risked Enough Politically for Peace; Missing From Wye
description: To the Editor:

title: A Culinary Fantasy Life
description: Once upon a time, in an empire now long gone, Marcus Gabius Apicius spent his last denarius on a feast. Realizing he had neither the desire nor the discipline to economize in his dining, he committed suicide. But before he did, this epicure of the first century A.D. wrote the oldest known cookbook, ''De Re Coquinaria.'' It was still selling about 900 years later. Which certainly made it a backlist champion. So what Apicius started, no one in book publishing will put asunder. Along with serious religious texts, there's hardly a genre as popular as the cookbook, and a celebrated one sells for years and years and years. In hardcover.

title: Safranbolu Journal; The Alarming Scarf and Other Turkish Worries
description: Festive banners fluttered from lampposts and windows as a troupe of young folk dancers prepared to mount a makeshift stage here on Saturday morning. Like tens of millions of Turks across the country this week, they were joining in celebrations of their country's 75th birthday.

title: NATO Errs in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 20 about the opening of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Center for Latin American Art, a wing of the San Antonio Museum of Art, misstated the origin and opening year of an exhibition of Mexican art at the museum. The show, called ''Mexico: Splendors of 30 Centuries,'' was organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, not by the San Antonio museum, and opened at the Met in 1990, not in San Antonio in 1986. It then traveled to San Antonio and other cities.

title: Funk & Wagnall's Available On the Internet, and It Is Free
description: A long time ago, there was something known as the print version of the Funk & Wagnall's encyclopedia, a 29-volume set that sold door-to-door for thousands of dollars. Here is how much things have changed: the encyclopedia now takes up zero shelf space and is free.

title: Lord Sainsbury Is Dead at 96; Built a British Grocery Empire
description: Lord Sainsbury of Drury Lane, who revolutionized the retail food industry in Britain, transforming his family's grocery business into the country's first modern, self-service supermarket empire and forever changing the shopping habits of the average Briton, died on Oct. 21. He was 96.

title: DEXTER PLANS TENDER OFFER FOR LIFE TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Dexter Corporation said yesterday that it would make a tender offer for the 48 percent of Life Technologies Inc. it did not already own, after the maker of chemicals for biological research rejected Dexter's $420 million bid. The cash offer of $37 a share will be made directly to Life Technologies shareholders. Dexter, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., said the price was 19 percent more than Life Technologies' closing share price prior to its original offer on July 7. Life Technologies, based in Rockville, Md., makes cell nutrients and other compounds used in biotechnology; it had 1997 sales of about $331 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Long Inquiry on Abuse in the Housing Department Is Completed
description: Almost 10 years after Congress found the Federal housing agency under President Ronald Reagan to be replete with waste, fraud and abuse, two independent counsels have concluded their investigation, which led to the convictions of 16 people.

title: Trying to Rescue the Old West From the Dustbin
description: INCIDENT AT TWENTY-MILE

title: Johnson: Big Unit, Now a Free Agent, Has a Short List
description: The second Randy Johnson sweepstakes in three months began yesterday. Houston won the first; who will win the second? Try the Yankees, Anaheim, Texas, Houston, San Diego, Los Angeles or Arizona.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL TO CUT ITS BUSINESS BY 30%
description: The United Companies Financial Corporation, a home mortgage and home equity lender that put itself up for sale in July, said yesterday it had failed to find a buyer and would shrink its business by 30 percent to cut costs. The company, based in Baton Rouge, La., said its board approved a plan to dismiss 1,070 employees, or more than 30 percent of its staff, and close all businesses that could not be sold except the unit that lends directly to borrowers. The plan will cost between $4 million and $6 million. The company also reported that third-quarter income from continuing operations fell 3 percent, to $25.8 million, from $26.7 million in the period a year earlier.

title: How to Button Your Lip And Win Travel Expenses
description: The American Contract Bridge League does not spend its resources on giving cash prizes for tournament performance, but once a year it is, rather unevenly, generous to some winners. Most of those who qualify for the national final of three North American Pair Championships have their expenses paid to the site of the playoffs. Three years ago the New York qualifiers had the pleasure of winning a trip all the way to Philadelphia, but this year they earned a much more valuable award. In March they will travel at the league's expense to Vancouver, B.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, ISABELL (NEE PENDLETON)
description: SCHIFF-Isabell (nee Pendleton). Loving wife of Samuel for 57 years, died October 16, 1998 at age 87. She is survived by her husband.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Statement of Taste

title: Brooklyn Killer Takes Deal for Life in Prison
description: A Brooklyn man convicted of murder accepted a deal yesterday under which prosecutors dropped their pursuit of the death penalty and agreed to life in prison for him in return for his pledge not to appeal his conviction.

title: A Veteran Candidate Runs Once More, With Feeling
description: Sitting behind a bare desk in a busy campaign headquarters in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Luigi R. Marano, a veteran of generations of Republican campaigns in Brooklyn, discussed his return this year to electoral politics.

title: Anheuser-Busch Earnings Grow
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's largest brewer, said today that third-quarter earnings rose 3.8 percent, helped by retailers' stocking up in advance of the company's first price increases in two years for most of its beers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTROLL, LENA (GANS)
description: CASTROLL-Lena (Gans), 88 years, of Concordia, Monroe Township, NJ, Oct. 28, 1998. Wife of Harry E. Mother of William G. and Alan. Sister of Edythe Scherer Hecht. Grandmother of Beth, Scott, Joanna, Tracy and Lauren. For information contact M. David DeMarco Funeral Home, Monroe Township, N.J., 732-521-0555.

title: BORDEN CHEMICALS STAKE SOLD TO MINNEAPOLIS INVESTORS
description: A group of Minneapolis investors said yesterday that it acquired a 5.1 percent stake in Borden Chemicals and Plastics L.P. and would ''actively explore alternatives'' to increase the company's shareholder value. The investors bought 1.88 million of Borden's outstanding limited partnership units and may acquire more units, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Borden, which had $737 million in 1997 from sales of chemicals used in adhesives, fuel additives and plastics, posted a loss each quarter this year. The units of the company, which is managed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, fell 63 percent in the last year. Borden units rose 56.25 cents, to $3.625, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: IT GROUP ACQUIRING FLUOR DANIEL GTI FOR $69 MILLION
description: IT Group agreed yesterday to buy Fluor Daniel GTI Inc. for $69 million in cash, or $8.25 a share, to add the company's environmental services expertise to IT's range of engineering and construction services. IT Group, based in Pittsburgh, said that Fluor Daniel GTI's engineering consulting business would add about 20 cents a share to its earnings. Fluor Daniel GTI, based in Norwood, Mass., is 52 percent owned by the Fluor Corporation, which will receive $36.3 million from the sale of its stake to IT. As part of the arrangement, Fluor's principal subsidiary, Fluor Daniel, agreed to contract with IT for environmental services.

title: PLUS: BOXING; No Jet Lag For Hamed
description: Prince Naseem Hamed believes that a change in time zones over a short period will not have any bearing on his performance in his featherweight title bout against Wayne McCullough on Saturday night in Atlantic City.

title: A Writer's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Make Adoption a Non-Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: In Their Own Words
description: ALFONSE M. D'AMATO

title: Slow Cosmetic Sales Hurt Revlon Profits
description: Revlon Inc. reported a 62 percent decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday, hurt by retailer inventory reductions, product delays and softness in international demand for the company's cosmetics.

title: Women on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventive Use of Tamoxifen Is Allowed
description: The Government approved use of the drug tamoxifen today to help prevent or delay the development of breast cancer in healthy women who have a very high risk of getting the disease.

title: McCann Unit Buys Agencies in 3 Countries
description: McCann Relationship Marketing in New York said yesterday that it had acquired agencies in Australia, Japan and Spain with estimated combined billings of $60 million. Financial terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed.

title: Spaniard Is Counting on a Dash to the Finish Line
description: If there is one runner whom others fear in the final hills of Sunday's New York City Marathon, it is Abel Anton of Spain. He runs more like the miler that he once was than the marathoner that he is. He stalks patiently, sitting on an opponent's shoulder, waiting to unleash his ferocious kick. And then he goes with cold detachment. A man who once slaughtered pigs for a living cannot afford to be sentimental about his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, MOE
description: VOGEL-Moe. On October 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Howard and Laurence. Dear brother of Sarah Kurlanzik. Adoring grandfather of Peter Andrew, Michael Scott and Carsten Dyhr. Great-grandfather of Edward Arthur Kenney Vogel and Charles Taft Vogel Kenney. Devoted father-in-law of Judith and Anna Lise. Cherished uncle of Naomi Leeds and Alan Steinberg. Moe was a unique, caring person who loved and was loved by his wife of more than 65 years, his sons and their wives, his grandsons and their wives, and his great-grandsons. Moe started working at eight, had his own business before age 21, supported his parents, raised his siblings, and assisted in raising a close niece and nephew. He was a successful businessman and an even more extraordinary person who always was active, engaged with life and upbeat. Moe will be missed by all who knew him. Service Friday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 29 discussed the release of 60,000 secret documents on the killing of President John F. Kennedy. Their declassification occurred over a period, leading up to the final report of a citizens' commission created by Congress six years ago to dispel lingering suspicions that the truth had been hidden.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 14.

title: In Liberty We Trust: An Ethos Evolves
description: THE STORY OF AMERICAN FREEDOM

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES IN STOCK DEAL FOR CRC HOLDINGS
description: Jackpot Enterprises Inc., an operator of slot machines and casinos, signed a letter of intent yesterday to buy the closely held casino company CRC Holdings Inc. for about $71.3 million in stock. Jackpot said it expected to buy CRC, which operates as Carnival Resorts and Casinos, for about 6.485 million of its shares. Shares of Jackpot, based in Las Vegas, Nev., rose 12.5 cents, to $11. CRC, based in Miami, owns a 60 percent interest in the Casino Rouge riverboat casino in Baton Rouge, La., operates the Casino Rama north of Toronto and is developing the Grand Bay Resort on Lake Las Vegas in Henderson, Nev.

title: Southwest Air to Try Its Continental Wings
description: Southwest Airlines, the granddaddy of no-frills, discount carriers, has made its name flying short hops between secondary airports. But on Thanksgiving Day, the airline plans to offer its first nonstop, transcontinental service -- for $99 one way.

title: Metro Business; 20 Fired at Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation, the seventh-largest bank in the nation, fired 20 people on its New York emerging markets desk, a bank official said yesterday.

title: Glenn's Space Ride: For Young and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Sentence in Prom Case

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON FALLS 1.6 PERCENT. Prices fell on persistent concern that overseas demand will stay weak in the months ahead. The December contract fell 1.06 cents, to 67.12 cents a pound, the lowest closing price since May 21.

title: Army Pullback in East Timor Disputed by Leaked Reports
description: Opponents of Indonesia's control over the disputed territory of East Timor said today that documents leaked from the Indonesian Ministry of Defense show that the army is not drawing down its forces in the territory as the Government has reported.

title: On One Man's Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, BLANCHE
description: SMALL-Blanche. Died peacefully October 28, in New Haven. Formerly of New York City, Mount Vernon, N.Y. and San Rafael, CA. She was born April 24, 1899. Survived by her four children, Peter, Roger, Claire Javna and Nina Salamon, ten grandchildren and ten great grandchildren.

title: Re-elect Senator Dodd
description: Connecticut's Senate race has been a one-sided affair. Senator Christopher Dodd's opponent, Gary Franks, is a former Republican Congressman who has campaigned hard but not always wisely. Mr. Franks has misquoted Mr. Dodd and gone over the top with his rhetoric more than once. It is hardly likely that many voters will agree with his contention that Mr. Dodd set a bad example for children when he called President Clinton an ''idiot.''

title: District May Be a Barometer, Thanks to a Tight Race and Early Results
description: One of the first clues next Tuesday night about the trend in this year's elections will be the early returns from the Congressional race here in southeastern Indiana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLSON, DOROTHY
description: NICHOLSON-Dorothy, age 93. On October 28th, 1998. Survived by her nieces and nephews, Diane Keenan, Jane Sumereau, Thomas and Paul Nicholson. Funeral mass at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue at 72 Street, today, October 30, 9:30 AM.

title: Patient at Nursing Home Is Missing, City Concedes
description: New York City hospital officials conceded last night that they did not know the whereabouts or condition of a 71-year-old woman who was among 282 patients evacuated suddenly from a city-run nursing home in Queens several weeks ago.

title: Family Fare; It's Slime Time In Queens
description: Snakes and slime. Spiders and skeletons. Goop and gore. All are elements of a scary, not to say messy, Halloween. But as many children know, they are also typical ingredients in a popular television series for young viewers, one whose host is a mad scientist who realizes that education can be just as much fun as getting grossed out.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: A Century's Worth of Efforts To Capture a City's Essence
description: If daily life in New York seems more, well, intense than elsewhere, it's not only because of the city's inimitable pizazz. It's also due to the multitude of artists on hand to record it. At least that's the impression you get from ''Eight Million Stories: 20th-Century New York Life in Prints and Photographs from the New York Public Library,'' a show whose cumbersome title belies its lively content.

title: Clinton Praises Launching And Gains of Space Program
description: Hitching a rhetorical ride on John Glenn's inspiring voyage into space, President Clinton today bid the 77-year-old Senator a safe journey and extolled the earthbound benefits of America's space program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, FRIEDA. (NEE EDELSTEIN).
description: SHERMAN-Frieda. (nee Edelstein). Of Yorktown Heights, New York, and Boynton Beach, Florida. Died on October 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Sherman, and Bill Siegfried. Dear aunt to Barbara Poret, Bonnie & Michael Lieberman, Ali & Philip Edelstein. Loving great-aunt to Howard, Jay, Liz, Ellen, Hilary, Marcy and Kate. Great-great-aunt to Rebecca, Jackie & Max. Dear step-mother to Sue and Bill Treuman, Irma and Steve Sherman. Cherished grandmother to Jody, Danny, Kirsten and Betsy. Her abundant love and generosity towards her family will be sorely missed. A Graveside service at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Queens, today at 11 A.M.

title: Deutsche Bank Says Losses Are Worse Than Expected
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's biggest bank, said today that huge trading losses in the securities of emerging markets, primarily Russia, had virtually obliterated its third-quarter profit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trading Losses Deplete Profit at Deutsche Bank

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: Diner's Journal
description: When fish is fresh, whole and grilled by a chef who knows what he is doing, there is nothing better in the world. That thought went through my head as I sat eating pompano at the new restaurant called City Hall.

title: Inside Art; Uncovering A Master's Hand
description: There is nothing auction houses like to crow about more than discoveries. And this week it was Christie's turn, with its announcement that the portrait ''St. Rufina'' was not by Murillo, as it had been catalogued, but by Velazquez, the master who epitomized the Golden Age in Spanish painting.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: H. C. Westermann

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKACH, MICHAEL
description: BOOKACH-Michael. Of Atlantic City, N.J. on October 29, 1998. (Formerly of Haworth, N.J.) Beloved brother of Ann Kensicki. Devoted father of Bruce & Dennis. Loving grandfather of Deborah, Jessica and Kimberly. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J. Sunday, 11:30AM. Michael was a WWII veteran and flew over 50 missions for the U.S. Armed Forces (Army Air Corp). May he rest in peace.

title: National News Briefs; Salsa Suspected as Source Of Illness for 313 People
description: Mendocino County public health officials said this week that freshly made salsa was the likely source of an outbreak of a bacterial disease that struck 313 residents last month here in Northern California.

title: Teams Play Waiting Game on Free Agents
description: Talk is cheap, so general managers continued calling representatives of free agents yesterday, a week before they are allowed to begin negotiating for players' services.

title: Adoption's 'Free Market'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits yesterday about the New Yorker cartoon archive misidentified the Web site founded by Bob Mankoff of the magazine. It is Cartoonbank.com, not Cartoon.com.

title: Stocks Gain On Stronger Profit Reports
description: Blue-chip stocks paced a brisk advance yesterday in which the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 123.06 points, its best gain in two weeks, to a level closer to its record peak of mid-July than to its low of late August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, VICTOR
description: SEIDMAN-Victor. Loving husband of Alice and devoted uncle. Services were held in Delray Beach, Florida.

title: The Hills Are Alive (or Just Lively) for Runners Who Prefer Soft Trails to Punishing Pavement
description: It's an overcast, dreary day at Van Cortlandt Park in the North Bronx, but I'm inspired by a sense of adventure and nostalgia as I prepare to tackle the running trails that I feared in my youth. As I limber up at the start of the 2.5-mile course used every fall by thousands of high school cross-country racers, I gaze at the woods in the distance. The trees hide the notorious hills that tore at my legs in the early 60's while my coach implored me to run faster with the command, ''C'mon, Bloom, blossom!''

title: State Senator Won't Press Charges Against Mayor
description: State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr. said yesterday that he would not press charges against his political nemesis, Mayor Anthony Russo of Hoboken, even though Mr. Kenny claimed earlier this month that the Mayor tried to run him down in a sports utility vehicle.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: He May Fall, But Vallone Is Going Down Fighting
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic nominee for governor, had 11 events -- some public, some private, some with the press -- on his itinerary yesterday. He started with a 7:45 A.M. subway stop on the Upper East Side, went downtown for a fund-raiser with Chinese-American leaders, visited centers for the elderly in Brooklyn and attended a Democratic dinner in White Plains and a reception in Queens.

title: An Effort to Turn the Tables on the Trust Issue
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the D'Amato campaign began broadcasting yesterday.

title: Miami's Burrell Wins College Award
description: The former University of Miami first baseman Pat Burrell won the Golden Spikes Award, given annually by Baseball America to the nation's top college baseball player.

title: In Classrooms, History Lesson Brings Cheers
description: It was the first taste of a voyage to space for dozens of students at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where two fifth-grade classes and a first-grade class gathered in front of a television to watch John Glenn blast into space for the second time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORKEN, GARY
description: DWORKEN-Gary of Commack, NY on October 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Roberta, Jay and Debbie. Devoted grandfather of Samantha, Seth & Zachary. Funeral service Friday, at 12:15 at I.J. Morris in Dix Hills, burial is at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn at 1 P.M.

title: Secretariat's Stamp
description: Secretariat, the 1973 Triple Crown champion and twice Horse of the Year, was elected along with 14 other figures from the 1970's to be honored with a commemorative stamp, the Postal Service announced yesterday.

title: Editorial Observer; The Secret Space Race Behind John Glenn
description: As John Glenn enjoys his second rendezvous with the cosmos, the country is awash with nostalgia about the great space race with the Soviet Union, one of the most memorable competitions of the cold war. If only the actual rivalry more closely resembled the myths about it.

title: Sun Media Board Rejects Torstar
description: The board of the Sun Media Corporation today rejected an offer by the Torstar Corporation to buy the publisher of seven Canadian daily papers for $16.50 (Canadian) a share, saying it was ''opportunistic'' and did not reflect Sun's true value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIS, MORDECAI
description: DANCIS-Mordecai. Born Dec. 11, 1911 in Bayonne, NJ, died October 26, 1998, Palm Beach County, FL. Successful New York lawyer who devoted his best years to politics within the Democratic Party; first as leader of Great Neck where he resided for some 40 years, then as leader of the Township of North Hempstead. He is survived by two sisters Natalie Goldberg & Ranana Benjamin, brother Joseph Dancis, twin daughters Amy Laborde and Barbara Gholz and four grandchildren Eugene & Abigail Gholz and Linda and Pascal Laborde. A Memorial Service will be held Monday, November 9 at 4:30PM at North Shore Towers, Building Two, 270 Grand Central Parkway, Floral Park, New York.

title: Antiques; An Uncelebrity As Folk Art Fan
description: It's clear that American folk art has come into its own when it can attract collectors as diverse as Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman, Woody Allen, Ronald Lauder and David Teiger.

title: Is the C.I.A.'s Mideast Role New?
description: To the Editor:

title: All Eyes in Big East on UConn Sophomore
description: For the first time in the 17-year history of Big East women's basketball, a sophomore was named the preseason player of the year today. She hardly seemed thrilled by the honor, and neither did her coach.

title: Bank's Head Raises Stake
description: C. Donald Carr, the chairman of Civic Bancorp, raised his stake in the company to 19.5 percent from 15.7 percent of common shares outstanding. Mr. Carr bought 141,100 common shares between Oct. 7 and Oct. 27, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He bought the stock at an average price of $12.98 a share. Civic Bancorp, based in Oakland, Calif., is parent of the Civic Bank of Commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, HANNAH K.
description: SEGAL-Hannah K. On October 28, 1998. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Abraham I., Beth S. and Dr. Benjamin Goldberg, Sandra L. and Irwin Duftler. Adored grandmother of Michael, Murray and Debbie, Brian and Sharon, Ilene, Gerald & Karen, Kenny, Gregg and Jeffrey. Cherished great grandmother of Ashley, Dustin, Rachel D., Rachel G., Joshua, Aliza & Mendy. Services today 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: Investors Cautiously Returned To Equity Funds in September
description: Mutual fund investors tiptoed back into equities in September, apparently encouraged as the stock market became less volatile and equities regained some of the ground they had lost in July and August.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Hong Kong Journal; For Fearfully Rich, a New Fad: A Fierce Gurkha
description: When tycoons step out of their Rolls-Royces here these days, they are often quickly surrounded by a phalanx of compact but fierce-looking bodyguards. These are Gurkhas, and while they come from the uplands of Nepal, they are deeply embedded in Hong Kong's history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, NAOMI
description: COOPER-Naomi. Beloved wife of Emanuel. Devoted mother of Daniel, Ethan and Mark. Dear sister of Bernard Bendel. Adored grandmother of Michael, Naama, Amiel and Avital. Service Friday 9:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COLE, CHARLES J.
description: COLE-Charles J. 4/5/23 -10/30/92 Not a day goes by without a Charlie-ism. You are always in our hearts and minds. We love and miss you greatly. Your Family

title: 36 Years Later, Glenn Lifts Off for His Space Encore
description: John Glenn, an astronaut again at 77, returned to orbit today in the space shuttle Discovery for a rendezvous with the memory of a time when exploits of early astronauts held the world in thrall and for a long-awaited encore, this time as the oldest traveler in outer space.

title: From Sea to Shining Sea, the TV Campaign Is All Attack Ads, All the Time
description: While television viewers in Atlanta were learning on Wednesday afternoon that Michael Coles, the Democratic Senate candidate in Georgia, ''doesn't deserve a single vote,'' those in Los Angeles were told that Matt Fong, the Republican Senate candidate in California, ''is wrong on the issues that matter.''

title: Whitman Tells Her Party She Will Not Seek the Presidency
description: Traveling through the state that will hold the first Presidential primary in the year 2000, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey told a group of New Hampshire Republicans today that she had no intention of seeking her party's nomination for President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUBEN, BERNARD
description: REUBEN-Bernard. Of White Plains, N.Y. on October 12, 1998. Husband of Carla Reuben, father of Berne Reuben & Carla ReubenCarbone. Father-in-law of Walter Reuben-Carbone and Janet Coleman. Brother of Marion Kern and the late Sylvia Newman. Grandfather of Sage Reuben-Carbone, Danielle and Melissa Reuben. Funeral service Sunday, November 1, 11 AM, at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADDELL, JEANETTE CONNOLLY.
description: WADDELL-Jeanette Connolly. Died November 28. A resident of Manhattan, Mrs. Waddell was a business woman who was active in many Catholic charities. She is survived by her sister, Frances McGorry of Wilmington, N.C., and by five nieces and nephews. Memorial mass is Saturday at 2PM at St. John the Martyr Catholic Church, 72nd St and 2nd Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave., NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGIBBON, BRIDGET (BRIDIE),
description: FITZGIBBON-Bridget (Bridie), 70. Loving daughter of the late Thomas and Mary (Flanagan) Fitzgibbon. A life long resident of Astoria. Graduate of Fordham University and a retiree of the Exxon Corp. Survived by cousins and friends. Visiting on Friday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. at Morisco Funeral Home, 30-12 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, NY. A funeral mass will be offered at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church of Astoria on Saturday 9:30 AM. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations will be appreciated if provided to Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 23-25 Newtown Ave, Astoria, NY 11102 or Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 29 discussed the release of 60,000 secret documents on the killing of President John F. Kennedy. Their declassification occurred over a period, leading up to the final report of a citizens' commission created by Congress six years ago to dispel lingering suspicions that the truth had been hidden.

title: What Did You Expect? Mr. Manners?
description: GEORGE JESSEL, a name not likely to ring many Gen-X bells, was an old-time vaudevillian who performed at so many banquets and fund-raisers that he became known as ''Toastmaster General of the United States.'' He enjoyed a special niche with older, conservative Jews.

title: Jets Defender Scores From the Corner
description: Otis Smith has never been defensive about his defense -- not even when the right cornerback was burned for nine touchdown passes last year, the most given up by a Jets defender.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLAM, DOROTHY SCOTT.
description: GILLAM-Dorothy Scott. Age 88. At home October 26, 1998. Native of Jonesville, SC. Wife of the late Ernest Gillam, mother of Scott Gillam and Gail M. Gerhart, grandmother of Leslie and Nathaniel, Timothy and Jonathan. Memorial service Saturday, November 21 Christ Chapel, Riverside Church. Contributions may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of NY, 107 E. 70 Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBROW, D. IRVING.
description: OBROW-D. Irving. Of Little Silver, NJ. Died on October 26, at the age of 81. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Lucille, his daughters Joanne Bailey and Patti White, and five grandchildren, Jennie, Peter, Edward, Timothy and Trevor. Irving Obrow was a graduate of the Columbia University School of Business and had a long and distinguished career in corporate finance. In the early 1940's, he worked on The Manhattan Project and subsequently went to International Playtex Corp, VP Finance, and to Glen Alden Corp, VP and CEO. In 1978, he joined Johnston Industries in association with his longtime friend, Paul Johnston, succeeding him as President and CEO in 1985. He was a director of Plains Resources and Jupiter Industries. Throughout his career, his depth of understanding and professionalism drew the trust and respect of his colleagues. He had a great love of classical music, and served on the Board of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Inc., 490 Riverside Dr, New York, NY 10027. A memorial service will be held on November 4 in NJ. For details, please contact the family.

title: Heat Damage Is Found in Wires of Swissair Video System
description: Investigators looking into the crash last month of Swissair Flight 111 off the coast of Nova Scotia have found ''heat damage'' in wires from the plane's in-flight entertainment system, prompting the airline to disconnect the system on all of its jumbo jets, Swissair officials said today.

title: Budget Backsliding
description: For several years, we and other deficit hawks have traveled the country warning that mounting deficits were undermining the economy and jeopardizing the well-being of future generations. Until recently, we were optimistic that great progress had been made. Last year a Democratic President and Republican-led Congress reached a bipartisan plan to balance the budget. This year the Government actually took in more than it spent for the first time since 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. 2/1/25-10/30/89. Always in our hearts. Our everlasting love. Sylvia, Susan, Gwen

title: MITSUBISHI TO REORGANIZE ITS UNITED STATES OPERATIONS
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would close its United States holding company and exit several businesses as part of a revamping to focus on digital television and computer hardware and software. The holding company, Mitsubishi Electric America, will be closed and an Americas Corporate Office will be opened as part of Mitsubishi Electronics America Inc., the largest of Mitsubishi's United States subsidiaries. The company, which is based in Tokyo, will close the audio-visual division of Mitsubishi Consumer Electronics America and open a new digital consumer electronics company. The cellular telephone operations will be streamlined by shutting the Astronet Corporation and the cellular mobile telephone unit.

title: Unpretentious Mirror For the Metropolis
description: New York is too nearly infinite to have a center, too hot-and-cold to locate its putative heart. But if one place can claim a measure of overall symbolism for the metropolis, it is City Hall and its adjoining park. City Hall itself is both grace note and anomaly, surrounded by Park Row, which once housed the legendary newspapers of James Gordon Bennett, Horace Greeley, Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst, and now plays host to hipper media like J & R Music/Computer World; by that majestic cathedral-skyscraper, the Woolworth Building, with its beige and taupe terra cotta cladding; by the muscular Municipal Building, a McKim, Mead & White wedding cake of Stalinist-architecture bulk, abutting the on-ramp to the Brooklyn Bridge; by Ellen's Coffee Shop, a New York institution run by an ex-Miss Subways, its walls covered with other Miss Subways winners, and by the masses of civil service workers on lunch break, shoppers frequenting bargain-discount outlets and criminals paroled by the nearby jail, all strolling up Chambers Street.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 9
description: Game of the Week

title: Hedge Fund Uses Its Line of Credit
description: Long-Term Capital Management L.P., the ailing hedge fund taken over by 14 lenders last month, last week borrowed $500 million from the line of credit provided by the Chase Manhattan Corporation and other banks, as the firm tries to trade itself out of losses.

title: Japan Details Cost Of a Bank Failure
description: Japan said yesterday that it would pay about 3.4 trillion yen ($29.1 billion) to clean up Hokkaido Takushoku Bank. The bank collapsed last November with debts exceeding assets by almost 1 trillion yen -- Japan's largest failure before Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan was declared insolvent last week.

title: Wages Turn Hot for Workers, With Gain of 1.2%
description: Despite signs that the labor market has cooled a bit since spring, the pay of workers is rising faster than it has in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, FREDERICK W.
description: GILL-Frederick W. Of Bronxville, NY on October 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Lillian Winter Gill, dear uncle of John N. Gill II, Patricia H. Nash, Michael A. Steinmetz and Carole A. Anderson. Memorial service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, November 7 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Some Oil Countries to Maintain Limits
description: Some major oil-exporting nations agreed yesterday to extend production cuts agreed to in June that have helped prop up falling oil prices. They also agreed that no deeper cuts should be made.

title: Concerns Over Slow Growth Lift Treasuries
description: Bond prices rose for the third time in four days yesterday as expectations for slower economic growth, together with declines in Brazil's stock market, kept demand alive for Treasury securities.

title: Global Motorsport Says It Is in Sale Talks
description: Global Motorsport Group Inc., the top independent parts distributor for Harley-Davidson motorcycles, said it was in negotiations to sell the company, though it would not name possible buyers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITCH, STANLEY L.
description: LEFKOWITCH-Stanley L. Born May 18, 1917. Died New York City October 28, 1998. Husband of the late, beloved Clarice. Son of Henry and Sylvia. Survived by loving children Jay Lefkowitch, M.D., Shelley White, Amy Niles, Judith Abbott, Gregory Abbott, Dennis Abbott; sons and daughters-in-law Jeffrey Block and Barbara Abbott, David White and J. Herbert Niles, M.D.; grandchildren Mark, Lesley, Asa, Sam, Hannah; great grandchild Nathaniel. A graduate of City College of New York, he succeeded his father, Henry, as owner of Metro Music Company, 3rd Street and 2nd Avenue in New York City, which in its day was the largest publisher of Jewish music worldwide. A versatile musician, he played clarinet and saxophone and several other instruments, was an arranger and knew what it was to be a ''side man'' and orchestra contractor during and after World War II. For most of the past two decades, until his retirement at age 80 last year, he brought his considerable musical expertise, particularly in classical music, to the Sam Ash Corporation in Paramus, N.J. He derived great pleasure from volunteering at the Allen Pavilion of ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after retirement. He adored playing tennis and played tournaments throughout Westchester County. He loved travelling with his wife, Clarice, and shared her abundant enthusiasm for the symphony, the theatre and ballet. Fascinated with all things mechanical and technical, he also painted in oils and acrylic and designed covers for many of Metro Music's sheet music publications. A gentle and loving man with a wonderfully wry wit, he will always be carried in our hearts. Memorial service on Sunday, November 1 at 12 noon, The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St., New York City (212-362-6600).

title: Women and Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; Director Rebuts Bias Complaints
description: Edward Zwick was startled the other morning to pick up The New York Times and read the headline ''U.S. Sees a Brooklyn Connection to International Terror Network.'' Mr. Zwick, director of ''The Siege,'' about a state of emergency in New York after a murderous campaign by Brooklyn-based terrorists, said: ''It was this strange reaction. What was described was upsetting and difficult. But there is some secret thrill in having gotten it right.''

title: Cemeteries Are Historical, Not Solely Grave
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the cancellation of a trip by President Boris N. Yeltsin because of health problems referred incorrectly to a statement by his spokesman, Dmitri Yakushkin. Mr. Yakushkin said he had been asked by the President to answer reporters' questions about Mr. Yeltsin's health; he did not say Mr. Yeltsin intended to meet journalists soon to discuss it.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'New Photography 14'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFFER, PHILIP
description: SHAFFER-Philip. On October 28, 1998. Loving husband of Mary for 65 years. Devoted father of Eleanor and Dr. Robert L. Schain and Joel Shaffer. Proud grandfather of Bonnie and Joseph Miskiewicz, Andrea Tannenbaum, Scott and Alyssa Shaffer, Lauren and Dr. Jay Rahman, ecstatic great grandfather and ''Papa Phil'' to Hayley Miskiewicz, Lindsey Tannenbaum, Adam Tannenbaum, Tara Miskiewicz, Sean Miskiewicz, brother of Aaron Shaffer, Sol Shaffer and Frank Shaffer of Montreal, Canada. ''We celebrate your life, Daddy, until we meet again.''

title: Running Interference Against the Elements
description: Those who will produce the New York City Marathon on Sunday hope, as usual, for great racing and moving human interest stories.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joseph Marioni

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JAMES
description: GOLDMAN-James. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the loss of our colleague and fellow Council member James Goldman. We have no doubt that his work will live forever. Our deepest sympathies to his family. He will be missed. Peter Stone, President The Dramatists Guild

title: A Sunlit Window on Mental Illness
description: Oprah Winfrey has played a big part in the emergence of our tell-all culture, not with a lurid approach, but with a truth-will-set-you-free attitude. From revelations of her own sexually abused girlhood to the stream of guests who work toward emotional health by confessing their problems on television, ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' has become a favorite site for talking cures.

title: Dad Was Out for Blood; Now the Son's a Regular Drip
description: Amid all the religious trappings and walking dead of ''John Carpenter's Vampires,'' the real miracle is how its cast was able to keep a collective straight face.

title: Union Chiefs Clash on Whether Council Director Should Quit
description: In a meeting called by union leaders to voice their unhappiness with audits ordered on Monday, the leaders of several locals in District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City public employees, clashed yesterday over whether Stanley Hill, the council's executive director, should resign.

title: ECLIPSYS IN STOCK DEAL FOR TRANSITION SYSTEMS
description: The Eclipsys Corporation, a health care information company, agreed yesterday to buy Transition Systems Inc. for about $270 million in stock to broaden its offering of software and services to doctors and hospitals. Each Transition Systems common share will be converted into 0.525 of an Eclipsys common share, a 58 percent premium to Transition's closing price Wednesday of $8.625. Eclipsys, which is based in Delray Beach, Fla., and went public in August, has grown primarily through the acquisition of three other health care information companies for $229.7 million. Shares of Transition, which is based in Boston, rose $1.75, to $10.375, while those of Eclipsys fell $2.75, to $23.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, WILLIAM J.
description: O'MALLEY-William J. Esteemed member of the St. Clare's Hospital Board of Trustees, passed away October 26, 1998. A revered member of the theatrical community, Bill used his talents to create the Helen Hayes Gala for the benefit of St. Clare's. We greatly appreciate those many years of service spent on our behalf. A cherished and respected friend, he was the distinguished recipient of many awards and honors. He will be greatly missed by the St. Clare's family, and our hearts are with his wife, Connie. Viewing at John J. Barrett & Son, 424 West 51st Street on Thursday, October 29th, from 2-5PM and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Paul The Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street on Friday, October 30 at 10 A.M.

title: Tamoxifen Approved In Cancer Prevention
description: Tamoxifen, used for 20 years to treat breast cancer, can now be used to prevent the cancer's onset in women who have the greatest risk of developing it, the F.D.A. said. The agency offered doctors a computer disk to help them decide who is most likely to benefit from the new use.

title: Devils Make Isles Miss Palffy Even More
description: The second period of tonight's game between the Islanders and Devils was delayed when hundreds of fans littered the Nassau Coliseum ice with squeezable foam ''stress pucks.''

title: G.O.P.'s Hopes Dim for Filibuster-Proof Senate Margin
description: With the midterm elections five days away, Republicans are tempering expectations that they can expand their majority to 60 seats in the Senate.

title: Israeli Jeep Blocks a Bomber From School Bus Carrying 40
description: A jeep carrying Israeli soldiers intercepted a Palestinian suicide bomber as he was about to ram a car packed with explosives into a school bus carrying children from this Jewish settlement today. The jeep absorbed the explosion, which killed one soldier and wounded three others; the bomber also died.

title: Supermarket Takeover Bid
description: The supermarket chain Oshawa Group Ltd. has adopted a shareholder rights plan and established an independent committee to consider an unsolicited takeover offer by the Empire Company of $1.36 billion (Canadian). On Monday, Empire offered $70 for each of the 600,000 shares held by the Wolfe family of Toronto and $35 for each of Oshawa's Class A shares. Empire, based Nova Scotia, owns Sobeys, the dominant supermarket chain in the Atlantic provinces. Oshawa, in Toronto, has struggled to compete with the industry leader, Loblaw Companies.

title: Pretoria's Words: 'Extrajudicial Killing'
description: Following are excerpts from the final report issued by South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission today:

title: In Graveyards, History Lives
description: Time flies. Remember you must die.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEXMARK INTERNATIONAL GROUP, Lexington, Ky., a maker of computer printers, will buy back up to $200 million of its Class A common stock.

title: Venus Williams Eager for Debut
description: Weary from a four-tournament stint on the European indoor circuit that began with an $800,000 title at the women's inaugural Grand Slam Cup in Munich, Germany, Venus Williams is resting a sore left knee but is already plotting a strategy for her debut in the year-ending Chase Championships next month at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cheese Courses
description: The practice of finishing a meal with a few bites of cheese has re-emerged in recent years. Some restaurants flourish the classic French platter, others roll out a spectacular cart, while a few offer a modest but enticing selection. Here are a dozen restaurants that offer a cheese course. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Beware of the Survivor With a Grudge and a Gun
description: He's got a gun!

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: It's All About Life, and Winning, Too; Mike Jarvis, St. John's New Coach, Embraces His Latest Basketball Mission
description: The stocky, bald, bearded man recently poked his head into the doorway of the small gym in the basement of Alumni Hall on the St. John's University campus. For a few minutes he watched several members of the basketball team working out in an array of gym-rat garb with a conditioning coach.

title: Investigator Says Bullet Was in a Murder Suspect's Pack
description: A police investigator testified yesterday that she found a .22-caliber bullet -- the same type of bullet used to kill Jonathan M. Levin -- in the front pocket of a knapsack belonging to a former student accused of killing Mr. Levin, a popular Bronx high school teacher.

title: Glenn's Space Ride: For Young and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Beck

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: I.M.F.'s Bearer Of Bad Tidings; Organization's No. 2 Gets To Tell Needy Nations What They Don't Want to Hear
description: Brazil is the bailout of the month, and Stanley Fischer, the closest thing the world economy has to a battlefield medic, is a blur of cell-phone calls and urgent E-mails.

title: Credit-Taking Classic: D'Amato on Hospitals
description: It sounds like Santa Claus ticking off last year's gift list as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato goes hopping around the hustings.

title: Unpredictable Murder Trial of a Wealthy Lawyer Mesmerizes Delaware and Beyond
description: It had been a riveting story from the start: A wealthy and well-connected lawyer who was charged with killing his girlfriend, who happened to work for the Governor of Delaware.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLOSS, MAX.
description: SCHLOSS-Max. 10 Heshvan 5749. The years do not diminish the wonderful memories of your life with us. We remember you with great fondness, love and admiration. Johanna, Stan, Henrietta & Famil

title: Daimler-Benz Profit Fails to Meet Estimates
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. reported third-quarter profit of 1.27 billion German marks ($770 million) yesterday as savings at aerospace and truck divisions offset rail-car losses and higher costs at its Mercedes car unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLYDE, WILLIAM HILL
description: CLYDE-William Hill died peacefully in San Francisco on October 26, 1998 at 90 years of age. He is survived by his loving wife, Marie, and many dear relatives, among them the Thomas Mason Clydes of Boston, Massachusetts, Mollie Clyde Wilson of Big Bear Lake, California, Mrs. George H. Clyde of Santa Barbara, California, the Motley family of Brooklyn, New York, Charles M. Mac Cracken of Memphis, Tennessee, Mrs. Stuart Billings of Washington, D.C., as well as his devoted caregiver through several years of illness, Steven S. Ramn. He was married for more than fifty years to Shirley Myrick Clyde who died in 1985. He attended The Choate School and Williams College (Phi Beta Kappa) and held memberships in The University Clubs in San Francisco & New York. He held various positions in the aircraft industry and flew proudly for a number of years as a Continental Airlines Captain. At the decedent's request no memorial service will be held. Donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital Foundation, 900 Hyde Street, San Francisco, California 94109, or MidPeninsula Hospice Services, 1199 Bush Street, San Francisco, California 94109.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUBICEK, BEATRICE COLE.
description: ROUBICEK-Beatrice Cole. Former model, actress and playwright died in her sleep Monday in Needham, MA. Mrs. Roubicek was 88 years old. Born in Winthrop, MA to British parents Mrs. Roubicek grew up in NYC and was educated at private schools in NY and Europe. She was married to the late Joseph Roubicek, originally of Prague. She is survived by her daughter, Karen Roubicek of Newton, MA and two granddaughters, Erica and Jordana. A private family service will be held.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; In a Test, the Crashed Car Calls 911
description: WHEN Mick Buffum dozed off behind the wheel at about 2:30 A.M. on April 4, his 1994 Chevrolet Cavalier drifted off the right side of the road, ran up a cable used to brace a utility pole and flipped onto its right side. Mr. Buffum, stunned and confused, unbuckled his seat belt and promptly fell down into the passenger side of the car. He could not figure out how to get out.
