title: The Heart of a City
description: City Hall, a petit-palais that harkens back to the early 19th century, is perhaps Manhattan's oldest structure still functioning as originally intended. Dwarfed by skyscrapers, it has served as a command post for a venerable lineage of mayors, and its neo classical facade (below) has seen a tumult of political protests as well as salutes to heroes. An aficionado muses on its place in the dynamics of New York.

title: Ex-Hotel Owner With Former Ties to Mobsters Disappears
description: Edward J. Halloran, whose business empire collapsed after he was accused of working with the Mafia to fix concrete prices on multimillion-dollar projects in Manhattan, vanished two months ago while on a visit to the city, the authorities disclosed yesterday.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Fairy Tale With Hints Of Mozart
description: Two years ago, an American musicologist, David Buch, found a score of the 18th-century opera ''The Philosopher's Stone'' in a German library; it had been returned there from Russia with other World War II plunder. After studying the score, he declared that Mozart had composed some of the music. Although experts are still divided, much of the evidence supports Mr. Buch's conclusion. Tonight in Boston the opera will receive its first modern performance and audience members can decide for themselves.

title: NBC May Face Boycott by Players After Lockout
description: When a reporter from the NBC affiliate in Las Vegas, Nev., asked Chuck Person if he could have a few minutes last week, the San Antonio Spurs guard shook his head and declined. Several other National Basketball Association players soon followed his lead. Walking away they muttered, ''We're not going to do NBC.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Abelardo Morell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, ROSE
description: GLICK-Rose. On October 28, 1998. In Miami Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Rubin Glick. Devoted mother of Carl Glick and Rita Moskowitz. Adored grandmother of Marianne Rohrlich, Susan Glick and Cary Moskowitz. Great-grandmother of Justin and Monica Rohrlich. Service Sunday, 11:15 a.m., Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: DuPont in $1.9 Billion Deal To Buy Hoechst Paint Unit
description: The DuPont Company, the biggest United States chemical company, agreed today to buy the paint maker Herberts from Hoechst A.G. for 3.13 billion German marks, or $1.9 billion, making DuPont the world's biggest maker of auto paints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BARBARA CHILDS.
description: LAWRENCE - Barbara Childs. Died peacefully at her home, South Pole Farm in Norfolk, Connecticut on October 23, 1998 at the age of 86. She was the widow of James F. Lawrence and was predeceased by two children, Peter F. Lawrence & Jane Lawrence Mali. She is survived by four children: Barbara L. Garside, J. Vinton Lawrence, Suzannah L. Wood all of Norfolk; and Starling R. Lawrence of New York City and 13 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at The Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk at noon Saturday, November 21. Please omit flowers., Contributions in her memory may be made to the Norfolk library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPKIN, NATHANIEL
description: LAPKIN-Nathaniel. The Board of Visitors, the Dean, and the Faculty of Pace University School of Law express our deepest sympathy to the family of Nathaniel Lapkin. His commitment to promoting excellence at the Law School will not be forgotten through the establishment of The Henry H. Korn Fund for Criminal Justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, DOROTHY FELDMAN,
description: MASON-Dorothy Feldman, age 94, in Fairfield, Connecticut, on October 24th, 1998, adored wife of Marcus Mason, treasured mother of Joan Blumenfeld & companion, Samuel Flaks, of Westport, Dr. Richard and Roberta Wedeen of Teaneck, N.J., beloved sister of Mildred Waldbaum of St. Louis, MO., cherished grandmother, great grandmother and aunt. Memorial service Sun., November 1, at 10:00 AM at Abraham L. Green & Son, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions to the Alzheimer's Assoc., Jewish Home of Fairfield, or a charity of one's choice.

title: Cuba Charges 4 in Attacks
description: Four Central Americans held in Cuba have been charged in a bombing campaign that began last year, the Cuban Government announced today. It contended that a Cuban exile had recruited the suspects. The Interior Ministry said in Havana that a Salvadoran and three Guatemalans were intercepted trying to smuggle explosives into the island. All four, the note maintained, were deployed by Luis Posada Carriles, an exile whom the Communist Government of Fidel Castro regards as its most relentless enemy.

title: Hamed Is Ahead In Verbal Sparring
description: If the fists fly as furiously tomorrow night as the words did yesterday in Atlantic City, then the 12-round featherweight bout between Prince Naseem Hamed and Wayne McCullough will be a slugfest. It will also be one-sided, because McCullough is no verbal match for Hamed.

title: Out of Politics, but Not Out of Opinions
description: DO you want to take my pulse?'' Hugh L. Carey, the former Governor, inquired on the other end of the phone.

title: Whitney Reorganizes and Expands Its Staff
description: Maxwell L. Anderson, the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, is starting to make his mark. Yesterday, he called employees to a 9:45 meeting and announced changes in the museum's curatorial and management organizations that will add more rigor to programming decisions, decentralize decision making and require hiring two curators and three senior administrators.

title: S.E.C. Names Top Mutual Fund Official
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named Paul F. Roye as director of the agency's division of investment management today.

title: In a New Tactic, D'Amato Points To a 1980 Inquiry Into Schumer
description: With five days left to go until the election, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato steered his campaign in a new direction yesterday, releasing a television advertisement that invokes a 1980 investigation into Representative Charles E. Schumer in an effort to portray the Democratic challenger as dishonest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, SHIRLEY ECKER.
description: BOSKEY-Shirley Ecker. Age 80 on October 13, 1998. Survived by husband Bennett Boskey, her brother Allan B. Ecker of New York City, her sister Laura Ecker Ludwig of New York City, her nieces Lisa Ludwig Kahn of San Francisco, Amy Ludwig of Chicago, and Sarah Rice Ecker Cooper of Houston, and her nephew Andrew Ludwig of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to and would be welcomed by Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic of Metropolitan Washington, 5225 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20015, a significant charitable activity for the benefit of vision-disadvantaged individuals and one of Mrs. Boskey's abiding interests.

title: 2 Little-Known Rivals in Fierce Fight for Attorney General
description: It is just below the Senate race in its intensity, bursting with bitter invective and sharply contrasting political views, but the campaign to become New York State Attorney General is being fought by two men almost unknown to the public.

title: FORD SAYS IT WILL TEMPORARILY CLOSE 3 ASSEMBLY PLANTS
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would temporarily shut three assembly plants beginning Monday, to prevent inventories from building up. Ford, which is based in Dearborn, Mich., said it would shut down for three weeks its Kansas City, Mo., assembly plant, which builds the Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique small cars. A plant in Cuautitlan, Mexico, that builds the same models will be idled for one week. Ford's Lorain, Ohio, assembly plant will also temporarily suspend production. That plant, where Econoline vans are made, will be idled for one week because of a shortage of V-8 engines.

title: South African Panel's Report Arrives in Swirl of Bitterness
description: Far from being the salve for South Africa's wounds that some had hoped it would be, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's final report on this country's brutal past was released today in the bitter atmosphere of court challenges and political bickering.

title: Is the C.I.A.'s Mideast Role New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pharmacia Reports 19% Increase in Profits
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that its third-quarter profits rose 19 percent as it introduced new drugs, including Detrol for incontinence, and increased sales of older products, like Rogaine, the baldness treatment.

title: In Eighth Day, Microsoft Trial Slows Its Pace
description: In its eighth day, the Microsoft antitrust trial shifted into a slower gear as a senior executive of America Online was led through a painstaking cross-examination in which he was asked to define technical acronyms and parse the fine print of contract terms. By the end of the day, the Microsoft Corporation's defense team had made a few points and scored one clear victory -- it had dragged the cross-examination out so long that the Government did not have time to show videotaped testimony from the company's chairman William H. Gates.

title: Casinos Widen Rivers To Increase Business
description: The rivers that run through this state, with their mystical and ominous might, have inspired great legends, served as literary metaphors and stirred the creative will of many who laid eyes on them. But for the people who inhabit the landscape around the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers, the ability to imagine these swift waters as anything other than what they actually are is being pushed to new limits.

title: Man Cleared in 2 Murders Gets Freedom, and Apology
description: After eight years behind bars for a double-murder conviction based entirely on what prosecutors now concede was fabricated testimony, a Brooklyn man was exonerated and freed yesterday by a judge who apologized to him for ''the entire judicial system.'' The judge also expressed shock that he himself had been ''fooled'' by the witness.

title: Maybe Mozart in a Magical Tale's Modern Premiere
description: There is something a little worrying in the idea that operatic music by Mozart has been lying around in various European libraries without anyone taking the trouble to study it properly, let alone perform it. Yet this is the conclusion that must be drawn if ''The Philosopher's Stone,'' which is to have its first modern performance tonight in Boston, with another on Sunday, really does contain numbers by Wolfgang Amadeus alongside music by other composers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCARDLE, ANDREW J.
description: McARDLE-Andrew J. Suddenly on Oct. 28, 1998. Former music director of the Diocese of Brooklyn. Currently residing in FL., formerly of Woodhaven, Queens. Beloved son of the late Andrew & Winifred. Dear brother of Margaret Pafundi, Edward T. McArdle and Winifred Greeley. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Reposing at George Werst Funeral Home, Cooper Ave. at 72nd Street, Glendale. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10AM, at St. Pancras R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. No visiting hours Saturday, October 31, 1998.

title: Filtration Systems Set For Contaminated Wells
description: In response to residents who say their water supply may be contaminated with carcinogens, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ordered state environmental officials yesterday to work with United Water Toms River to install carbon filtration systems on two wells that were polluted by chemicals from the Reich Farm Superfund site.

title: No Decision Yet On Androstenedione
description: The baseball commissioner and the Players Association agree that it is premature to say what, if anything, they will do about androstenedione, the testosterone-producing pill that Mark McGwire has acknowledged taking.

title: McDougal Says Employers Knew of Purchases
description: Defending herself against charges of stealing more than $150,000 from the conductor Zubin Mehta, Susan H. McDougal testified today that she had made credit card purchases and cashed checks with the knowledge of Mr. Mehta and his wife, Nancy.

title: U.S. Ex-Sergeant Linked To bin Laden Conspiracy
description: Federal prosecutors have filed secret charges against a former sergeant in the United States Army who is suspected of switching sides in the war against terrorism and joining the global campaign to attack Americans mounted by the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden.

title: Political Briefing; Aiming the Big Guns At Drug Initiatives
description: With polls indicating that ballot initiatives to legalize marijuana for medical use might pass next Tuesday in some states, Barry R. McCaffrey, the retired Army general who is White House director of drug control policy, figured it was time to throw more troops into the fight. So he enlisted three former Presidents -- George Bush, Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford -- and asked them to write a ''Dear Fellow Citizen'' letter that would point out why the initiatives should be defeated.

title: Political Briefing; New Poll Results Shed New Light on Races
description: With only four days to go until Election Day, pollsters are abroad everywhere, taking the nation's political pulse one last time. Here are the latest readings on six of the most important fall races, three for the Senate and three for Governor.

title: Nerve Damage to Brain Linked To Heavy Use of Ecstasy Drug
description: The illicit drug ecstasy may cause long-lasting nerve cell damage in the brains of heavy users, according to a report published yesterday by scientists at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Re-elect Governor Rowland
description: The similarities between the recent careers of Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut and Gov. George Pataki of New York are striking. Both men appear to have read the same playbook on how to succeed as a Republican in a Northeastern Democratic state. Mr. Rowland, like Mr. Pataki, started out as a tough budget-cutter who was indifferent to education issues and overly harsh in his plans for welfare reform. But during the last two years, with the help of a reviving economy, Mr. Rowland has become a friend to the environment, a champion of the public schools and a cheerleader for the central cities who says his goal is to make the Republican Party more ''inclusive.'' On the matter of campaign finance, Governor Rowland has made a turnabout and signed a strong law that will virtually ban unregulated ''soft'' money in future Connecticut campaigns.

title: Out of an Irish Frying Pan Into the Spanish Civil War
description: Is there a trend here? ''Talk of Angels'' is the third and weakest movie to be released this year in which the central character is a beautiful, charming, clever, wise young governess who becomes romantically entangled with someone in her employer's family. As for the angels in the title, the question of what these celestial beings might have to do with the movie at hand is best left unasked. It might have something to do with the fact that ''angel'' has become a Hollywood buzzword for high-minded schmaltz and phony nobility.

title: On My Mind; More Mideast Myths
description: The three major products of the Mideast are Arab oil, Israeli technology and political myths cooked up by both sides -- some entirely homemade, others a compote of foreign and domestic ingredients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, SAMUEL M.
description: FRIED-Samuel M. On October 28, in his 88th year. Beloved husband of Geraldine Fried. Dear father of Madeleine (Dr. Edward) Grossman and Dr. Richard (Dr. Jane) Fried. Loving grandfather of Jill, Lewis, Peter, Joanna, Adam and Jessica, and great-grandfather of Lauren, Steven, Jonathan and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Lillian Kleinberg and the late Pauline Platt. Services are today, 1:15, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AT&T Plans Internet Sales
description: The AT&T Corporation said today that it planned to sell At Home Corporation's high-speed Internet access separately from At Home's on-line information services. The move would let customers access the Internet through At Home via cable lines and pay other companies like America Online Inc. for information. AT&T's chief executive, C. Michael Armstrong, said that the plan would be similar to agreements America Online had to sell its content to customers of other Internet access providers.

title: On Stage and Off; 'Footloose' Shows Vigor
description: All along, ''Footloose'' bore the signs of a potential ''Carrie''-size disaster. First the tryout run in Washington was a critical bust, and when the show got to New York, the set didn't fit into the theater. Dancers were injured, an actor was replaced and even the poster design -- a giant pink F -- seemed ominous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLER, YETTA NEE WEISFOGEL.
description: STILLER-Yetta nee Weisfogel. October 28, 1998. Widow of Jesse. Loving mother of Dr. Matthew and Dr. Walter. Beloved sister of Irene, Florence, Dr. Esther and Dr. Jerry. Interment at Riverside Cemetery in Rochelle Park, N.J.

title: For the Bereft in Chile, a Cause for Tears: Pinochet Could Slip Spain's Grasp
description: Thirteen days ago they thrilled to the news that Gen. Augusto Pinochet had been arrested in London on a Spanish warrant accusing him of committing genocide during his 17-year rule of Chile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, DANIEL
description: FITZPATRICK-Daniel. March 13, 1938-October 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Aileen, father of seven: Dara, Danny, Sinead, Terence, Aileen, Susan and Cormac. Grandfather of Russell. Only brother of Edward Fitzpatrick. Mass of Christian burial at St. Andrew Avellino in Queens.

title: Defying Space With a Riot of Transforming Shapes
description: Unexpected magic happened several minutes into ''Kaleidoscope Suite,'' presented by Murray Louis and Nikolais Dance on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. The curtain had risen on a stage filled with sleek bodies, in silhouetted profile in intensely orange air, not quite human in crested helmets. As they moved slowly through the dance, their right legs were suddenly revealed to end in large, thin disks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GETTINGER, ANNA J.
description: GETTINGER-Anna J. 10/29/67 31 years. Dear and wonderful mother we think of you, love you and miss you every day. Martin and Gloria

title: JOB CUTS AT SUN HEALTHCARE WILL TOTAL MORE THAN 1,600
description: Sun Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it cut 500 jobs in the third quarter and planned to cut 1,100 more by the end of the year, following a drop in demand for its therapy services. Sun, the third largest United States nursing home operator, said the positions were eliminated through attrition and layoffs. The affected jobs account for about 29 percent of the full-time therapists in Sun's contract-therapy unit, which provides occupational, speech and physical therapy services to skilled nursing operations and nursing homes. Shares of Sun Healthcare, based in Albuquerque, N.M., rose 18.75 cents, to $5.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENKOE, GEORGE
description: BENKOE-George, 81. Died on October 27, 1998 in Queens, New York. Survived by son Jeffrey, granddaughter Talia, dear friend Eunice Dombroff, niece Eva Gardos, and cousin Kati Gabor. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion in Jerusalem.

title: Archimedes Text Sold for $2 Million
description: A scorched and moldy volume of thousand-year-old pages -- the oldest surviving copy of important mathematical works of Archimedes -- was sold at auction yesterday for $2 million, double the expected price.

title: ADULT BRAIN CELLS SAID TO REPRODUCE
description: Through a rare glimpse inside the human brain, a team of American and Swedish scientists reported yesterday that they had discovered the generation of brain cells in adult humans for the first time, opening an important area of investigation into possible new treatments for such debilitating neurological disorders as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and stroke.

title: Not Showing This Week: Gates's Taped Testimony
description: Two blocks away, on Capitol Hill, it would have been called a filibuster. At the Federal courthouse, however, it was simply a defensive strategy.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Autumn Leaflets Of a Labor Protest

title: People
description: * Jim Hunn was named to the new position of partner and chief creative officer at Earle Palmer Brown Washington, Bethesda, Md. He had been vice president and creative director at Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Co.

title: Glenn's Space Ride: For Young and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Crimson Rallies, So Does Its Quarterback
description: The Crimson has evened its record at 3-3 after an 0-3 start, and quarterback Rich Linden has emerged from a seasonlong funk.

title: PROFIT RECOVERY TO MAKE ITS 11TH ACQUISITION SINCE 1997
description: Profit Recovery Group International Inc., an auditing firm, agreed yesterday to buy Robert Beck & Associates for about $46.5 million in cash and stock to get a larger share of the market for auditing retail and grocery stores. Profit Recovery said it would pay $26.1 million in cash and 644,000 shares of its common stock to buy the closely held Robert Beck. Profit Recovery, which helps clients identify and recover overpayment of taxes and other bills, had 1997 sales of $112.3 million. Robert Beck, based in Ringwood, Ill., had 1997 revenue of $13.6 million. This would be Profit Recovery's 11th acquisition since January 1997. Its shares fell 50 cents, to $31.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ELEANOR
description: GOLD-Eleanor. On October 29, 1998. Loving mother of Allen Bachrach and Norma Goldhagen. Dear grandmother of Benjamin Goldhagen, Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, Ethel Goldhagen Bogursky and Mayer Goldhagen. Greatgrandmother of Eli and Thomas. Service Friday, 1PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. & Amsterdam

title: After the Fuss, the Launching Does Look Magical
description: During the weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's voyage into space, the former astronaut Scott Carpenter described one benefit of the flight. As he told MSNBC, ''The nation gets to revisit a time of imagination and hope and magic.'' That sounds more like a description of a Disney film than rocket science, yet it succinctly captures the gilded tone of the television coverage up to and including yesterday's high-profile launching. The networks and all-news channels quickly found their common theme: the return of an American hero. And after 10 months of wallowing in the Lewinsky sex scandal, you could almost feel their relief as they leaped on this wholesome story.

title: Expansion of Homeless Center Hours Is Urged
description: Two court-appointed lawyers chosen to help remedy New York City's practice of allowing homeless families seeking shelter to sleep overnight on the floor of a Bronx intake center, recommended yesterday that the city expand the hours for handling requests for shelter.

title: A Defendant Rejects Plea, Then Jumps To His Death
description: After casting a last glance at his mother, a teen-ager accused of selling crack cocaine jumped out the window of a packed Manhattan courtroom yesterday and fell 16 stories to his death after a judge offered to give him a three- to six-year prison sentence if he agreed to plead guilty in the case, officials and witnesses said.

title: Spending Growth Rate For On-Line Ads Slows
description: The increase in spending for on-line advertising during the second quarter of 1998 moderated somewhat from recent explosive gains, according to a report from the Internet Advertising Bureau in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TETELMAN, CATHERINE (FERRARA).
description: TETELMAN-Catherine (Ferrara). Of Pleasantville, NY on October 27, 1998. Beloved wife for 54 years of Charles. Adored mother of Marcia (Tommy Dietz), Ronald (Annmarie), and Mary Kay Arena (Joseph). Devoted grandmother of four. Loved and remembered by all who knew her as a friend and teacher.

title: Metro Business; Manischewitz Is Sold To Food Company
description: RAB Holdings Inc., a specialty foods company, acquired the Kosher foods maker B. Manischewitz & Company of Jersey City, N.J., in May for about $124.7 million in cash, debt and fees, according to a regulatory document recently filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sept. 29 discussed the release of 60,000 secret documents on the killing of President John F. Kennedy. Their declassification occurred over a period, leading up to the final report of a citizens' commission created by Congress six years ago to dispel lingering suspicions that the truth had been hidden.

title: Ted Hughes, 68, a Symbolic Poet And Sylvia Plath's Husband, Dies
description: Ted Hughes, the British poet who was known as much for his doomed marriage to the American poet Sylvia Plath as for his powerful, evocative poetry, replete with symbolism and bursting with dark images of the Devonshire countryside in which he lived, died Wednesday, his publisher said. He was 68.

title: WITH MARKETS WEAK, AGCO PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,400 JOBS
description: The farm equipment maker Agco Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 1,400 jobs and take a fourth-quarter charge of $35 million to $40 million in the face of continued weakness in world agricultural markets. Agco, based in Duluth, Ga., earned $17.9 million, or 30 cents a diluted share, on sales of $665.7 million in the three months ended Sept. 30. In last year's third quarter, which included a one-time charge, Agco earned $47.3 million, or 75 cents a share, on revenue of $759.5 million. The job cuts represent 12 percent of Agco's work force and will be concentrated in its manufacturing operations in Europe, North America and South America.

title: A Quirky Ballet Plus a Witty Shostakovich
description: ''Disposition,'' a quirky ballet that John Selya has set to witty music by Dmitri Shostakovich, is the fifth work that Mr. Selya has choreographed for American Ballet Theater.

title: IN THE CAMPAIGNS
description: POLL SHOWS UNCERTAINTY -- While the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows Republicans are viewed as more ethical and Democrats as better able to handle critical issues, Tuesday's elections hinge on which party brings out voters. Page A30.

title: Woman Gets 15 Years in Death of Newborn at Prom
description: With a stern declaration that the law must protect all lives, a New Jersey judge today imposed a 15-year prison sentence on the young woman who had admitted killing her newborn son at her senior prom in 1997.

title: Observer; Winnie Was an Amateur
description: It being Halloween, let us salute Winnie Judd, trunk murderess. She died the other day in Phoenix, age 93. The Times obituary laid her out in grand style, with a full account of her 15 minutes of grisly fame back in long-ago 1931.

title: Kanell Has a Virus, but Fassel Sees It as a Benefit
description: Danny Kanell's sweatshirt was wrinkled and his T-shirt was twisted as it hung over his belt. The baseball cap on his head was askew. His complexion would have had to rally to be pallid.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Diana Thater

title: Barkley Is Ready to Win Jarvis's Heart
description: When the St. John's players were introduced to a sparse crowd at Alumni Hall last night for the team's first public scrimmage, Erick Barkley received just a smattering of applause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIOR, RICHARD
description: DIOR-Richard. Rachel Desario, Constance Marks and Adriana Trigiani mourn the loss of the great sound engineer. Richard Dior made our movies sing. We will never forget him. We extend our sincerest condolences to Sandra, Scott and Rachel.

title: 7 Families Homeless After Three-Alarm Fire
description: Seven families were left homeless last night when a three-alarm fire tore through an apartment house on the Upper West Side, officials said.

title: PARKER IS BUYING SUPERIOR ENERGY FOR $145 MILLION
description: The Parker Drilling Company agreed yesterday to acquire the oil-field services company Superior Energy Services Inc. for $145 million in stock, plus assumed debt of about $25 million. Parker, based in Tulsa, Okla., is a drilling contractor to the offshore and onshore energy industry. Superior, based in Harvey, La., provides tool rentals, well-plugging and other products and services to oil companies operating in the Gulf of Mexico. Under the agreement, Parker will exchange nine-tenths of a share for each Superior share and plans to issue about 26 million new shares to Superior shareholders. Shares of Parker fell 62.5 cents, to $4.875. Shares of Superior fell 31.25 cents, to $3.9375.

title: A Countdown to a Very Big Party With V.I.P.'s Galore
description: John Glenn's private campaign to fly into space again became a public celebration today, generating cheers of joy and relief at the Kennedy Space Center here, mobbed viewing areas and raucous beach barbecues.

title: Apartment Rents Going Up in Converted Downtown Buildings
description: With initial leases expiring for apartments in the first wave of office buildings that were converted into rental housing in Manhattan's financial district, landlords are raising rents and most tenants are taking the increases in stride, residential brokers said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about multi-player on-line games misstated the location of Cavedog Entertainment. It is in Bothell, Wash., not in California.

title: Is the C.I.A.'s Mideast Role New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Plunging Deeper, Abandoning All Hope
description: Something looked familiar about the first big scene in ''The Dante Project: Inferno.'' The cheesy but sort of amusing scenery that was intended to convey otherworldliness. The dozen or so actors in skimpy costumes (basically flesh-colored underwear), skimpy because that's just what people wear in this faraway place. Weird props. Stylized violence. Of course! This could be a 1968 ''Star Trek'' episode.

title: Glenn's Space Ride: For Young and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: $1 Million Is Found in Carjacked Van
description: The police arrested a New Jersey man in the carjacking theft of a van in Queens on Wednesday, but were left with a mystery when officers found $1 million in cash in a suitcase in the back of the van.

title: Schumer Returns Fire on Missed Votes
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Schumer campaign began broadcasting yesterday.

title: Impossible Dreams Of Gods and Heroes
description: If you don't know the work of the Bolognese painter Donato Creti (1671-1749), you're in rather good company. Although he didn't lack for success and recognition in his own day, Creti's reputation faded after his death. His polished, ultra-refined paintings, devoted to the concept of ideal beauty, weren't rediscovered until the 1930's. At that time his masterpiece, a cycle of works commissioned by a patron, Marcantonio Collina Sbaraglia, was found in storage and in 1935 appeared in a show of 18th-century Bolognese art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MIMI F.
description: AUSTIN-Mimi F. On October 28, 1998. Much loved mother of Diane Gidding and Rob Austin, sister of Stephen Fields, devoted grandmother of Zack Gidding and Robin Snow, dear sister-in-law of Suzanne, loving mother-in-law of Diane Austin and Josh Gidding. Fiercely loyal and devoted to her family, friends and the causes she so deeply believed in. Service Friday 12 noon at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At CBS, news of a new chairman and a strong earnings report quickly lifts share prices.
description: FIXING the CBS Corporation will not be easy. But investors in the company that owns the storied television network appear to have faith that Mel Karmazin, the newly chosen chairman and chief executive, has the ability to do it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Will Barnet

title: A Nostalgic Celebration in Glenn's Town
description: At this place, John Glenn was first airborne, on a crazy, wooden bridge over the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad tracks. It is a blind, one-lane bridge, so steeply arched that a driver cannot see whether a car is coming from the other direction. The Lindbergh-obsessed young man known as Bud Glenn loved to drive fast over the bridge in the 1930's, whistling as he drove.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: PACIFIC BELL CLASSIC

title: Reform in Brazil
description: Because Brazil is the largest economy in Latin America, its success or failure will always be important to its hemispheric neighbors. But seldom has its fate seemed as significant as now, when the world fears that the financial crisis that began in Asia will spread to the Americas.

title: How Even Pollock's Failures Enhance His Triumphs
description: A thought occurred to me while I was standing before the earliest drip paintings in the Jackson Pollock show that opens Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art: they are now closer in time to the reign of Queen Victoria or to the production of the Model T than to us.

title: Off-Duty Officers Suspected of Brawling in Bar
description: The Police Department is investigating whether several off-duty police officers took part in a brawl last Friday night at a bar on the Upper East Side that sent an off-duty police lieutenant and another patron to the hospital, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions yesterday with an article about the race for governor in Illinois were reversed in some copies, and the pictures were credited incorrectly. The upper picture showed George Ryan, the Illinois Secretary of State who is the Republican candidate for governor; the lower one showed Glenn Poshard, the Democratic candidate. The pictures were from The Chicago Tribune, not The State-Journal Register in Springfield.

title: Is the C.I.A.'s Mideast Role New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Diversity Onstage, Passion's a Mother Tongue
description: For a place as wildly diverse as New York, the city's major commercial theater can often seem considerably less so. Sure, ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' is an Irish play, and ''Art'' is French. The list, and the world, seem pretty much to end right there.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a Chinese company that defaulted on a bond payment misstated its place of incorporation in some editions. The Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation is incorporated in China, not in Hong Kong.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Sue Williams

title: SARA LEE IS BUYING MONSAVON FROM PROCTER & GAMBLE
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Monsavon, a French maker of soaps, from the Procter & Gamble Company for an undisclosed amount as part of a push to expand its product lines through acquisitions. Monsavon, which makes mostly bar soaps, has about $45 million in annual revenue, a Sara Lee spokesman said. The transaction is to be completed within a few days. Separately, Sara Lee said it planned to split its stock 2 for 1, increase its quarterly dividend 9 percent and repurchase as many as 40 million shares with cash generated from a worldwide cost-cutting campaign.

title: G.O.P Given Ethics Edge in Poll, but Democrats Rate Higher on 3 Issues
description: As Republicans and Democrats compete for advantage in the dash toward Election Day, Americans view Republicans as more ethical but say Democrats can better tackle the pivotal issues of education, health care and the future of Medicare and Social Security, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. And nearly 7 out of 10 said the drama that has dominated the news throughout the year -- the White House sex scandal -- would not affect how they voted in Congressional races.

title: Behind the Men Atop the G.O.P.: A Tough Woman
description: When Zenia Mucha had 10 minutes to spare before Gov. George E. Pataki arrived in the Orange County village of Chester for a campaign stop the other day, she did what any confident manager of an incumbent who is some 30 points ahead in the polls would do: She went antiquing. And then she did something only a very powerful campaign manager would do: She continued shopping, even after she knew her boss had arrived. Quickly, she bought a copper lamp for $65 and two occasional tables for $95, then hurried over to the bar where the Governor was shaking hands to show him her treasures.

title: AS EARNINGS FALL, COOPER CAMERON WILL CUT MORE JOBS
description: The Cooper Cameron Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell 5.3 percent and that it would cut more jobs and take additional charges to pay for an expanded revamping, as low oil and natural gas prices reduce demand for its equipment. Cooper Cameron, a Houston-based oil-field services and equipment company, said it would cut about 1,000 jobs, an increase from the 500 it announced last month. The jobs represent 10 percent of its work force. It will also take charges in the fourth and first quarters totaling $17 million. Shares of Cooper Cameron fell 68.75 cents, to $33.1875.

title: Yada Yada as a Way Of Getting Another Life
description: As a lonely, newly divorced New Yorker in ''Living Out Loud,'' Holly Hunter does lots of talking out loud -- and talking to herself, too. She plays Judith Nelson, a woman who pours out her heart while trying to get her life back on track. Judith's way of achieving instant intimacy with strangers is one of the more literary conceits in this, the first feature directed by the screenwriter Richard LaGravenese (''The Fisher King,'' ''The Bridges of Madison County,'' ''The Mirror Has Two Faces''). The filmmaker has borrowed from Chekhov the soul-baring introspection that can be so ineffable on the page or stage yet becomes so damply sensitive and dramatically vague on screen.

title: Questioning Treaties Isn't Country's Option
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar declined on concern that Brazil's plan to trim its deficit will indirectly lead to slower United States growth. The dollar cost 116.93 Japanese yen, down from 117.82 yen Wednesday.

title: Chicago Will Lose a Storied Bastion of Double-Checked Facts
description: The City News Bureau, a fixture in American journalism that trained Mike Royko, Kurt Vonnegut, Seymour M. Hersh and legions of other gritty reporters here, will close after more than 100 years as Chicago's legendary news-gathering operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JOSEPH
description: SCHWARTZ-Joseph. The leadership of EMUNAH of America mourns the loss of Joseph Schwartz, beloved father of our Honorary National President, Sondra H. Fisch. Joseph's devotion to EMUNAH's children in Israel was exemplary and continues in the dedicated work of his wife, Florence, and daughters, Sondra, Susan Black, Andrea Sanders and Barbara Segall whom we feel so close to. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld, National President

title: Dodd's Voting Record Draws Attack From Franks in Debate
description: Taking a page from the bitter senatorial battle in New York, Gary A. Franks, a Republican, harshly criticized today the voting record of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, saying the Democrat had missed 1,000 votes while in Congress.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Liftoff of Discovery with a crew of six astronaut heroes and one American legend.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, JAMES A.,
description: MYERS-James A., 89. Of Long Valley, NJ, died on Wednesday, October 28, 1998 at Hackettstown Community Hospital. He is survived by his beloved wife, Marie (nee Morel), beloved stepsons, Raymond Ferrante of NYC and Louis Ferrante of Hazlett, NJ. Mr. Myers was a Senior Partner with the stock market firm of Stillman Maynard & Co. in NYC. The Funeral Service will be Saturday, October 31, 1998 at 9:00 A.M. at The William J. Leber Funeral Home. Visiting will be on Friday, October 30, 1998 from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. at The William J. Leber Funeral Home, 15 Furnace Road in Chester, NJ. The interment will be Saturday, October 31, 1998 at Valhalla Burial Park-Ocean View in Staten Island, New York.

title: New Hospital for Pinochet
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet was moved from a downtown clinic to a hospital in a secluded area of North London for security reasons today.

title: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: Man in the News -- John Herschel Glenn Jr.; To the Stars, Again
description: Two weeks before the launching, John Glenn settled into a chair for an interview, one of many in the buildup to his return to space. He had been in training for the Discovery flight long enough to adopt the mien of an astronaut, forsaking senatorial togs for gray slacks and a polo shirt with the crew insignia.

title: Brazilian Economic Plan Encounters Some Naysayers
description: The Government's $23.5 billion austerity package intended to reduce the budget deficit next year, crucial for securing International Monetary Fund credit and restoring Brazil's fiscal credibility, moved to Congress here today, where reaction foreshadowed bitter political wrangling to come.

title: Yeltsin Ready to Pick Constitutional Panel
description: As President Boris N. Yeltsin prepares to fly on Friday to a Black Sea resort on an extended sick leave, a Kremlin spokesman said today that the President would soon name a panel of legal experts to review changes to the Russian Constitution, including creating a post for a vice president and successor.

title: Sports of The Times; Marathon Man Finds His Path
description: HE is not on a nostalgia trip, but sometimes his feet just take him in that direction. Suddenly Alberto Salazar is at the south end of Central Park, and there is a right turn just before Columbus Circle. There was an autumn afternoon in 1982 when Salazar made a right turn on the dirt, and annihilated a brave Mexican runner who had been with him for nearly 26 miles.

title: Home Video; Finding Treats Beyond the Hits
description: As video schedules go, November's isn't particularly well endowed. But beneath a few hits -- ''The Horse Whisperer'' (Nov. 10), ''Armageddon'' (Nov. 17), ''Dr. Dolittle'' (Nov. 24) -- lies an engaging assortment.

title: New Video Releases
description: Les Miserables

title: You Don't Need Every Vote
description: In the heat of political campaigns, even the experts often forget a simple rule: you don't have to appeal to everyone to win. It's a waste of resources. What you need to do is secure your base -- make sure core supporters turn out to vote -- and appeal to swing voters, those who often split their tickets, picking and choosing between Republicans and Democrats.

title: At Toys 'R' Us, the holiday rush is more important than ever.
description: THE advertising that promotes Toys ''R'' Us Inc. for the holiday shopping season is always crucial for the company, the nation's largest toy retailer, which rings up 50 percent of its annual business in the weeks leading up to Christmas. This year, though, as Toys ''R'' Us battles a sales slump, the stakes confronting the chain are as high as the orbit of John Glenn, who is featured along with models of his Discovery and Friendship 7 spacecraft in a new Action Pack set of Hot Wheels toys from Mattel.

title: Glenn's Space Ride: For Young and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Broken Hands to Keep Running Back Sidelined
description: St. Louis running back Amp Lee will not play against Atlanta on Sunday because he has broken bones in both hands, the Rams said yesterday.

title: The Inner Ballerina: Three Dancers Approach Larger-Than-Life Roles
description: Antony Tudor's ''Gala Performance,'' which he created in London in 1938, portrays three highly competitive star ballerinas from Moscow, Milan and Paris as they prepare for and perform in a glittering gala. Though essentially a stylized period piece, the ballet continues to be surprisingly popular and this year is part of American Ballet Theater's fall season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUSTER, RITA
description: SHUSTER-Rita. Loving and devoted wife, ''world's best Mom'', step-mother, sister, aunt, 2nd Mom. Loved and adored by countless friends. Accomplished pianist, supporter of AIDS research and volunteer at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. Always with us. Services at Sherman's Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. Donations to Chamber Music Associates, c/o Evelyn Gilbert, 114 E. 84 St, NY, NY 10028.

title: Singapore Output Falls; Further Drop Likely
description: Singapore, one of Asia's most resilient economies, has succumbed to the region's economic turmoil. Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said today that the city-state's economy contracted in the third quarter by an estimated 1.5 percent. It was the first quarter of reduced output recorded in Singapore since the mid-1980's.

title: Updating the Music of Spanish Monarchs
description: Wednesday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall was given by Jordi Savall and his big band: the players on viols, guitar, percussion, assorted wind instruments and keyboards of his group Hesperion XX together with the six singers of his La Capella Reial de Catalunya. And they kicked up quite a storm.

title: F.C.C. Fines Brittan for Phone Slamming
description: Federal regulators, as part of a crackdown on companies that illegally switch consumers' long-distance phone service, fined the Brittan Communications International Corporation $1.12 million for the practice, known as slamming.

title: Singh's 63 Lowest Score At Atlanta's East Lake
description: This has been the best year of Vijay Singh's career, and today he played one of the best rounds of his life. Shooting a brilliant seven-under-par 63 on a challenging East Lake Golf Club course where only nine players broke par, Singh soared to a three-stroke lead over Billy Mayfair after the first round of the Tour Championship.

title: Is the C.I.A.'s Mideast Role New?
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Gains Are Noted in N.B.A. Talks
description: National Basketball Association owners and players took a respite from negotiations yesterday after some narrowing of their positions on revenue distribution in a late-night bargaining session.

title: Democrats Kick Off Counterattack Ads
description: Insisting they can capitalize on the Republicans' campaign blitz, Democratic leaders unveiled rebuttal commercials to Republicans' criticism of President Clinton's moral behavior.

title: A Maverick, Of the Violin and Generally
description: Probably the first thing to know about the English violinist Nigel Kennedy is that having returned to the classical concert stage after a five-year self-imposed exile, during which he worked almost exclusively on rock projects, he is no longer using his first name. In the tradition of Madonna, Prince (in his pre-glyph days) and the British pianist Solomon, he is now listed on concert programs and recordings simply as Kennedy. At the end of his program note for a recent Elgar recording, he added: ''P.S. I've changed my name because I never liked the name Nigel. Cheers!''

title: Chairmen of the Board (and the Inlay)
description: A little wood marquetry goes a long way. This is substantiated by the intricate surfaces -- some fabulous, some merely busy -- that greet the visitor to ''Masterpieces in Wood: Folk Art Marquetry From the Hirschhorn Foundation'' at the Museum of American Folk Art. While uneven, this exhibition still manages to be informative and punctuated regularly with visual thrills of the first rank.

title: GTECH ENDS TALKS TO TAKE OVER TRANSACTION NETWORK
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, the on-line lottery operator, said yesterday that it had ended talks to buy Transaction Network Services Inc., the transmitter of data between merchants and credit card companies, because of financing difficulties. Gtech, based in West Greenwich, R.I., said that while the high cost of financing prevented an acquisition, it hoped to negotiate strategic partnerships with Transaction Network to branch out beyond its main lottery-products business. Transaction Network, based in Reston, Va., purchased the AT&T Corporation's credit card transactions unit in September for $64 million in cash, giving it about 70 percent of the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, LAURENCE A.
description: WEINSTEIN-Laurence A. The Board and Staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the passing of our friend and esteemed Board member, Laurence A. Weinstein, on October 27, 1998. His was a genuine commitment to preserving and teaching the rich Yiddish culture of East European Jewry. Through his support of the Max and Frieda Weinstein Archive of Sound Recordings at YIVO, Laurence Weinstein helped preserve rare field recordings of the Y.L. Cahan Folklore Club, interviews with refugees in German D.P. camps, cultural events and music, much of it in Yiddish. This sound archive is at the heart of the current Yiddish cultural renaissance. YIVO sends our deepest condolences to his family. May his memory be for a blessing. Koved zayn ondenk! Bruce Slovin, Chairman YIVO Institute for Jewish Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITCH, STANLEY L.
description: LEFKOWITCH-Stanley L. Born May 18, 1917. Died New York City October 28, 1998. Husband of the late, beloved Clarice. Son of Henry and Sylvia. Survived by loving children Jay Lefkowitch, M.D., Shelley White, Amy Niles, Judith Abbott, Gregory Abbott, Dennis Abbott; sons and daughters-in-law Jeffrey Block and Barbara Abbott, David White and J. Herbert Niles, M.D.; grandchildren Mark, Lesley, Asa, Sam, Hannah; great grandchild Nathaniel. A graduate of City College of New York, he succeeded his father, Henry, as owner of Metro Music Company, 3rd Street and 2nd Avenue in New York City, which in its day was the largest publisher of Jewish music worldwide. A versatile musician, he played clarinet and saxophone and several other instruments, was an arranger and knew what it was to be a ''side man'' and orchestra contractor during and after World War II. For most of the past two decades, until his retirement at age 80 last year, he brought his considerable musical expertise, particularly in classical music, to the Sam Ash Corporation in Paramus, N.J. He derived great pleasure from volunteering at the Allen Pavilion of ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after retirement. He adored playing tennis and played tournaments throughout Westchester County. He loved travelling with his wife, Clarice, and shared her abundant enthusiasm for the symphony, the theatre and ballet. Fascinated with all things mechanical and technical, he also painted in oils and acrylic and designed covers for many of Metro Music's sheet music publications. A gentle and loving man with a wonderfully wry wit, he will always be carried in our hearts. Memorial service on Sunday, November 1 at 12 noon, The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St., New York City (212-362-6600).

title: 42d St. Revival May Alter Face Of Theater Row
description: Hoping to tap the resurgent energy of Times Square for Off Broadway as well as Broadway, a development that would include as many as 11 smaller legitimate theaters as well as about 250 new apartments is being planned for the heart of West 42d Street's tenement-line Theater Row, west of Ninth Avenue.

title: FUJI PHOTO MAY ENTER U.S. INSTANT-FILM MARKET
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company, the world's second-largest photography company, said yesterday that it was considering selling instant film and cameras in the United States, challenging the home-market domination of the troubled Polaroid Corporation. Fuji is introducing a new instant photo system in Europe, called Instax, and may bring it to the United States, the world's largest photo market. Polaroid is the only seller of instant photographic products in the United States, where its patents forced the Eastman Kodak Company out of the business in 1986. Those patents have expired for Polaroid, and Polariod stock is down 44 percent this year.

title: Dora Maar's Picassos:A Trek Through Classicism and Caricature
description: PARIS  As visitors streamed into the Maison de la Chimie to view the Picasso memorabilia that sold this week for 205 million francs, some must have wondered whether the Paris School master had not played a phenomenal prank on society.

title: Middle Ground Is Good Ground, 2 Candidates in California Find
description: When this election year began in California, the big political questions were whether the Republican nominee for governor, State Attorney General Dan Lungren, a staunch foe of abortion, was too conservative to appeal to swing voters in this diverse and giant state and whether Senator Barbara Boxer was too liberal to do the same.

title: Biggest Shareholders Act To Protect BMW Stakes
description: The Quandt family, the largest shareholder in BMW, Germany's second-largest auto maker, said yesterday that it had moved most of its 45.6 percent stake into holding companies to protect against takeover attempts.

title: Trial Is Testing Louisiana's Sodomy Law
description: Jim Wiltberger, an accountant and political activist, remembered what it was like to be a gay man traveling outside the French Quarter into the more conservative and unwelcoming parishes of Louisiana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHE, ROBERT
description: ROHE-Robert. Of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of Bedford, New York, died on October 27, 1998. Survived by wife Dorothy Riordan Rohe. Father of Cheryll Herrmann, Robert, Jr., and Allen Rohe. Stepfather of Catherine Olson, Dorothy Hughes, Elizabeth Karlsson and Daniel Riordan. Grandfather to Meghan, Patrick, Marykate, Maggie, Whitney, Lukas, Morgan and Brigid, Caroline and Elizabeth. Brother of August and the late Charles Rohe, Jr. Son of the late Charles and Adele Uihlein Rohe. Great-grandson of Henry Uihlein. Founder and President of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Co., Milwaukee, WI. Graduate of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. Member of Sigma Phi Epsilon Fraternity. Served as a survival instructor in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, Sunday, November 1st from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, November 2 at 10 AM. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society and the Phoenix Zoo.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the CD-ROM ''Star Wars: Behind the Magic'' misstated the title of the coming ''Star Wars'' film. It will be ''Star Wars, Episode One: The Phantom Menace,'' not ''Shadows of the Empire.''

title: Undecided May Decide The Senatorial Race
description: They are fed up with the negative tone of the campaign. When attack ads appear on television, they turn them off. They feel deprived of any real debate on the issues, and some are even prepared to use their votes to push other political agendas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKIN, LANGDON G.
description: RANKIN-Langdon G. The Board of Trustees of East Woods School mourns the passing of our former Headmaster, Langdon Rankin. His leadership was invaluable to the life of the school.

title: IVANHOE TO ADD TO ITS CAMBRIDGE SHOPPING HOLDING
description: Ivanhoe Inc. said yesterday that it planned to make an offer to buy up to an additional 15 million shares of the Canadian shopping center owner Cambridge Shopping Centers Ltd. for $187.5 million (Canadian), or $121.5 million (United States). The move would raise the closely held Ivanhoe's stake in Cambridge to 42.5 million shares, or 54 percent, from 27.3 million shares, or 35 percent. Cambridge shares were up 10 cents, to $10.60 (Canadian); for the year to day, Cambridge shares are down 26 percent. The Toronto-based company owns, has stakes in or manages 93 properties with 35 million square feet of space. The Montreal-based Ivanhoe controls $2.6 billion (Canadian) of properties in Canada and the United States.

title: Deidre S. Murphy, 47, a Newspaper Editor
description: Deidre S. Murphy, assistant managing editor for news at The Star-Ledger of Newark, died on Thursday at St. Mary Hospital in Hoboken. She was 47.

title: About New York; At 100, Still Teaching, Learning and Joking
description: ABRAHAM GOLDSTEIN scanned the gathering at Baruch College and wondered what he, a contract law professor, should discuss. Anticipatory breach? Economic duress? Estoppel? Oh, that reminded him. . . .

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH SURPRISINGLY SOLID IN THIRD QUARTER
description: Despite months of financial turmoil and heightened anxiety about contagion from the rest of the world, America's economy is holding up far better than most experts expected.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Ali A. Mohamed, a former United States Army sergeant suspected of involvement in Osama bin Laden's global war against Americans, referred incorrectly in some editions to his military assignment. Mr. Mohamed served as a supply sergeant and assistant instructor on the staff of the John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center in Fort Bragg, N.C. He was not a member of the Special Forces.

title: Offense Gets to Play The Bully, for a Change
description: The Jets finally appear to have the weapons that could allow them to win games on sheer muscle, so that they will not have to place a top-heavy reliance on special teams or turnovers.

title: Singh Stumbles but Holds First as Woods Topples to Last
description: The dour expressions, the clubs slammed to the ground in frustration and the double-bogeys said it all. The season-ending Tour Championship has become a grind, a grueling test at the East Lake Golf Club on a course that is as demanding as it is picturesque.

title: Candidates Are Neck, Neck and Neck in Governor's Race
description: Norman Degeest poked his head into the Main Street Cafe this morning to catch a glimpse of Norm Coleman, the Republican candidate for governor, giving the breakfast crowd a peppy plug for his campaign.

title: A Ticking Bomb on the Web
description: Avner Cohen has made a career of pushing the frontiers of public discourse. Israeli-born but largely American-educated, he has spent the last decade shining light on what has long been a fiercely hidden subject: how Israel became an unacknowledged nuclear power in the 1960's.

title: Man Arrested in Robbery After Pausing for Drinks
description: A Waretown man who was arrested Thursday afternoon and charged with robbing a bank in Stafford Township was caught because he stopped for a couple of drinks instead of fleeing, the police said yesterday.

title: With Big Lead, McCall's Top Concern Is Getting Voters to Polls
description: Striding confidently from one campaign stop to another, H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller, would appear to be on a simple mission: rousing enough voters to the polls to assure a handy dispatch of Bruce A. Blakeman, the majority leader of the Nassau County Legislature, who was chosen by Republican leaders to mount a long-shot challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOICHET, GOLDIE
description: SCHOICHET-Goldie. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Mother of Gary and Toby; grandmother of David and Anna, each of whom was her favorite. Services Sunday 9:30 A.M. at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Middle Way House, P.O. Box 95, Bloomington, Indiana 47402.

title: Glenn Reports Back to Earth, 'It's Been a Great Ride So Far'
description: On his second day in orbit, 77-year-old John Glenn was feeling fine, eating well and working hard today, and so were all the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery.

title: Op-Art; Something in the Air
Niedermayer Accepts Offer And Is Set to Join the Devils
description: The Devils became a better team offensively last night when Scott Niedermayer, their attacking defenseman, agreed to a contract after missing the first three weeks of the National Hockey League season.

title: Wilhelm Karmann Jr., 83; Ran German Car Body Maker
description: Wilhelm Karmann Jr., whose coach-building company produced the classic Volkswagen Karmann Ghia and other cars, died on Sunday at his home in Osnabruck, Germany. He was 83.

title: House Race Centers on a Fiery Incumbent
description: Former Gov. Cecil D. Andrus says that if Representative Helen Chenoweth were to come across a brush fire, her instinct would be to douse it with a pail of gasoline.

title: 4 Abortion Clinics Receive Anthrax Threat
description: Letters claiming to contain the deadly virus anthrax were sent to four abortion clinics in three states today, sending dozens of people to the hospital and causing the evacuation of a clinic in Indianapolis.

title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Tobacco Buying Majority of Torii
description: Japan Tobacco Inc. said yesterday that it was buying a majority stake in the Torii Pharmaceutical Company in a friendly takeover.

title: Razing of Nursing Home Is Delayed by Judge
description: The Legal Aid Society and the law firm Kaye, Scholer, Feirman, Hays & Handler yesterday enjoined the city from demolishing the Neponsit Health Care Center, pending a public hearing on Wednesday over the future of the Queens nursing home.

title: The Opinion Game: We're All Players; Look at the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl Stricken With Rare Form of Encephalitis
description: A Bronx teen-ager has contracted a rare and often fatal disease, Eastern equine encephalitis, the first such case reported in New York City and only the third time a person in New York State has been afflicted with the virus, health officials said yesterday.

title: Bloodcurdling Capitalism; Theme Parks Raise the Dead to Lift the Bottom Line
description: Strange things are going on at Universal Studios Florida. Roving bands of chain saw-brandishing hoodlums pursue fleeing customers through darkened streets. Zombies and demons lunge from every nook and cranny. Shrieks and foul odors emerge from haunted houses. Basically, in the words of one Universal employee, the theme park wants ''to try to make you scream until there's no sound left.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, LOUIS
description: DANIEL-Louis. The staff of The House of Burgundy is greatly saddened by the death of Louis Daniel, who was revered by all who knew him as a warm and gentle man. He will be sorely missed by the wine and restaurant community. We remember Louis with great affection, and I personally have lost a treasured friend. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Margaret. Robert F. Fairchild, President

title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Congress in Connecticut
description: Here are our endorsements for some competitive Congressional races in Connecticut.

title: Judge Cites Possible Improper Leaks by Starr Office
description: A Federal judge has ruled that 24 news accounts about the investigation of President Clinton appear on their face to show that prosecutors in the office of Kenneth W. Starr repeatedly and knowingly violated Federal rules by leaking grand jury testimony or other secret information, according to documents released today.

title: Polls Find Several Races To Be Too Close to Call
description: As Election Day draws closer, many Senate and governors' races are drawing closer, too. Going into the final weekend of campaigning, no more than half a dozen points separate Democratic and Republican candidates in at least half a dozen Senate races and a dozen governors' races, a spread that sometimes can be closed in a last-minute rush of advertising and stumping.

title: Court Reverses a Recall Order for Chrysler Cars
description: The Chrysler Corporation won a significant victory over Government safety regulators today as a Federal appeals court overturned a 1996 order that the company recall about 91,000 cars to improve their rear seat belts.

title: Japan's Old Values Are No Less Worthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Woman Leaves Hospital
description: Sang Lan, the 17-year-old Chinese gymnast who fractured her neck in a freakish fall at the Nassau Coliseum three months ago at the Goodwill Games, was discharged yesterday after 13 weeks of rehabilitation at the Mount Sinai-New York University Medical Center. Her therapy will continue at the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine while she and her mother live at a friend's apartment in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, PAULINE
description: KLEINMAN-Pauline. On October 29, 1998 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Much loved mother of Harriet (Lewis) Dickman, Carole Leinwand (David) and Suzanne Cavalier (Mayer). Adored Grandma to Ronie (Robert), Alyse (Richard), Andrea (Jeffrey), Laurie (Phillip), Janet (Andrew), Keir Kandace and the late James. Precious great-grandmother of eight. A wise and savvy lady to the end. We will miss her. Services on Sunday, 1:30PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Thursday with an obituary of Lord Sainsbury of Drury Lane was published in error. It showed his son Lord Sainsbury of Preston Candover.

title: C.I.A. Said to Reject Bomb Suspect's Bid to be Spy
description: A former sergeant in the United States Army who is now being held in connection with the terrorist campaign of Osama bin Laden was rejected in the 1980's when he offered himself to the C.I.A. as a spy, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, JOHN C.
description: McLAUGHLIN-John C. Of Massapequa Park on October 29, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Mildred. Devoted father of John Jr. and Mary Ellen Biederman. Dear brother of Helen Lemon. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Reposing at the Massapequa Funeral Home Inc., 1050 Park Blvd. (at Clark) Massapequa Park, on Saturday and Sunday 2-4:30 and 79:30 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45 AM Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Massapequa Park. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens.

title: Executive in H.M.O. Deal Is Apparent Suicide
description: Two days after New Jersey officials moved to take control of the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, the president of the company that had bought its medical centers was found dead at his home, apparently a suicide, the authorities said.

title: Wealthy Nations Back Plan To Speed Help to the Weak
description: The leading industrial nations today endorsed President Clinton's proposal to help protect vulnerable but essentially healthy nations from the currency and stock market upheavals that have battered nations from Asia to Latin America in the last year.

title: Wife of Eagles Executive Charged in Accident
description: The wife of an executive for the Philadelphia Eagles football team turned herself in to the New Jersey State Police yesterday and was charged in the hit-and-run accident that caused the death of a man who was driving home from an Eagles game earlier this month.

title: Oxford Cuts Costs and Its Losses, but No Profits Are Expected Soon
description: By reducing costs and shedding troubled businesses, Oxford Health Plans appears to be reducing the losses that have plagued it over the last year. The managed care company said yesterday that it had lost $47 million, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, on revenue of $1.2 billion.

title: Security Council Outlines New Strategy on Iraq Arms
description: The Security Council outlined today how it might proceed with a comprehensive review of Iraq's relations with the United Nations, if and when the Government of President Saddam Hussein allows arms inspections to resume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, ROSE
description: GLICK-Rose. On October 28, 1998. In Miami Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Rubin Glick. Devoted mother of Carl Glick and Rita Moskowitz. Adored grandmother of Marianne Rohrlich, Susan Glick and Cary Moskowitz. Great-grandmother of Justin and Monica Rohrlich. Service Sunday, 11:15 a.m., Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Tuesday about Volkswagen A.G.'s third-quarter profit of 676 million marks misstated the dollar equivalent. It is $406 million, not $916 million.

title: U.N. and World Bank Unite To Wage War on Malaria
description: Three major United Nations agencies and the World Bank said today that they were joining forces in a coordinated campaign against malaria, a leading killer of the world's poorest people.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Small Schools With Big Hearts; In a Hotbed of Football, Passion for the Game Still Burns
description: Up and down Interstate 79, along an 80-mile stretch of western Pennsylvania from Pittsburgh to Meadville, the rhythm of small-college football is found in the beat of outsized hearts -- not in the cheers for outsized talents. It is a region once considered a cradle of stoic coal miners, hard-nosed steelworkers and a who's who of native sons that became football heroes. Hall of Famers like Joe Namath and Tony Dorsett.

title: Reforming World Markets
description: The world's leading industrial nations have sketched out a plan to revamp the international financial system and improve the handling of economic crises. It looks promising, but will be difficult to carry out.

title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gambling Proponents Bet $85 Million on Election
description: Facing vital ballot initiatives and continuing to fight for increased acceptability across the country, the gambling industry and its supporters this year have contributed about $85 million to influence next week's election.

title: Bar Owner Loses License For Serving Driver
description: The owner of a Warren County bar was fined $50,000 and ordered to sell his liquor license after pleading no contest to charges of selling alcohol to a drunken driver who killed three people and himself in an automobile accident in 1995, officials announced yesterday.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: NEW AMERICAN CONSENSUS
description: The truths that modern Americans seem to hold self-evident are mostly those that indulge the self. Nicholas Lemann writes about government of, by and for the comfortable, and Fareed Zakaria examines the United States' hollow hegemony. An Election Day report, in the Times Magazine.

title: CENDANT UNIT DRAWING THE INTEREST OF 5 SUITORS
description: The Cendant Corporation's software unit has drawn the interest of at least five companies, and an agreement with a purchaser could be reached by the end of the year, Henry Silverman, Cendant's chairman, said yesterday. The prospective buyers of Cendant Software include international companies that would not have problems financing the purchase, Mr. Silverman said during Cendant's shareholders meeting. The sale may be closed in the first quarter of next year. That would allow Cendant to benefit from software sales during the fourth-quarter holiday shopping season, Mr. Silverman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAMMEN, WILLIAM J., SR.
description: MAMMEN-William J., Sr. Age 84, of Mt. Laurel, NJ (formerly of Massapequa, NY) on October 29, 1998. Cherished husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Carrington). Beloved father of the late William J., Jr.; Elizabeth Sheehan of Manhattan; Thomas C. of Clarksville, NY; Robert P. of Wynants Kill, NY; Julia Lund of Marlton, NJ and Ellen T. of Manhattan. Adored grandfather of seven. Reposing after 2 PM Sunday, November 1, 1998, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (exit 28N SS Pkwy), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, Maria Regina R.C. Church, Seaford. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. Family will receive friends on Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: A New Rowland Preaches Flexible, 'Fun' Republicanism
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican, was elected on a promise to eliminate the state income tax, and didn't do it. He tried to slash the state budget, but retreated after protests from priests, pupils and park rangers.

title: The Opinion Game: We're All Players
description: To the Editor:

title: An Eye for Patterns In the Social Fabric; Patriarch of Sociology Sees His Insights Become Just What Everyone Knows
description: The Bloomington airport had the feel of a dinky Greyhound bus station in 1978 when Robert K. Merton arrived to deliver a lecture at Indiana University. So Tom Gieryn, who had studied the sociology of science with Mr. Merton, could wait outside while his guest stepped off the plane. As they stood catching up by the chain link fence, they could hear the puddle jumper Mr. Merton had flown in on groan to life.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KORN, JACK
description: KORN-Jack, 6/18/10-10/31/94. Forever remembered and loved by his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, FAY
description: LEVINSON-Fay. Colel Chabad-Lubavitch extends heartfelt condolences to pillars of our organization and our genuine friends, Steven and Bede Levinson and the entire family on the passing of their beloved mother, Fay Levinson. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sholom Duchman, Director Colel Chabad

title: British Airways Seeking Phased-In Link With American
description: After repeated delays by European and United States regulators, British Airways said yesterday that it would now settle for its proposed alliance with American Airlines to be phased in over five years.

title: Candidates Scrutinized During Tenure
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's decision to dredge up an 18-year-old investigation of Representative Charles E. Schumer to attack the credibility of his Democratic challenger seemed like a risky move in the waning days of their Senate race. It drew a swift response: Mr. Schumer's aides called Mr. D'Amato ''the most investigated Senator in New York history.''

title: Amoco Deal Advances
description: The board of the Amoco Corporation approved its $60 billion acquisition by the British Petroleum Company today. The agreement that would create BP Amoco P.L.C. is ''fair and in the best interests of Amoco and shareholders,'' said an Amoco proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The transaction is still subject to approval by shareholders of both companies and by United States and European regulators.

title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer Broadens Criticism Of Vacco 'Bodega' Remark
description: Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic candidate for attorney general, continued yesterday to assail the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, over what Mr. Spitzer and some Hispanic leaders have called an anti-Hispanic slur.

title: Sports of The Times; Player's View From Across The Pond
description: EVERYONE has a different view of the National Basketball Association lockout. From Rod Sellers's vantage point -- a breathtaking view from a four-bedroom home overlooking the Mediterranean Sea -- the lockout is a world away.

title: MATCHUPS
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HELEN
description: KATZ-Helen. Passed away October 29, 1998. Of Delray Beach, FL. Loving wife of the late William, adored mother of Marlene (Marvin) Padover, George (Evelyn) Katz and Adele Katz. Cherished grandmother of Roger, Craig, Kenneth, Mitchell, Richard and Douglas. Most cherished greatgrandmother of her beautiful ten. Beloved sister of Ted Barrett and Selma Goldman. Services Sunday November 1, 1998, 11:30 AM at Gutterman's Inc., 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Quirk Or Omen? Merely 2-7 After Byes
description: Jim Fassel, who can recite every possible statistic pertaining to the Giants, is well aware of their record in games following the bye week since it began in 1990.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: USINOR BID FOR J & L SPECIALTY STEEL IS ACCEPTED
description: Usinor S.A., Europe's fourth-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that J & L Specialty Steel Inc., the third-largest United States maker of flat-rolled stainless steel, had accepted its $113 million offer to buy the 46.5 percent of J & L it did not already own. Usinor will pay $6.25 a share for the 18.03 million outstanding J & L shares. The J & L board's approval, which was unanimous, means the company will become a wholly owned unit of Usinor by Nov. 5. When the move was first announced last month, J & L said approval of the offer would not result in plant closings or job losses. J & L shares rose $6.125 in New York.

title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?
description: To the Editor:

title: That Druidical Feeling
description: To a child who grew up, as so many of us did, trick-or-treating in small towns or quiet suburbs, where the sense of freedom was offset mainly by the early darkness and the chill of the season and the heavy odds that it was a school night, a modern Halloween feels very strange. Costumed children troop about, if they troop at all, in the late afternoon or early evening with their liberty sharply curtailed, ransoming their innocence door to door, making cautious sorties under the eyes of watchful adults. Meanwhile, what license the kids have lost the adults dispense among themselves, turning the evening, with some historical justification, into another New Year's Eve.

title: ENRON TO PURCHASE STAKES IN COGEN POWER PLANTS
description: The Enron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire interests in three power plants in New Jersey from the privately held Cogen Technologies for $1.1 billion plus assumed debt of $350 million. The three plants burn natural gas to provide power and steam under contract to users in New Jersey and New York City. Enron, the Houston-based natural gas and electricity company with assets of $28 billion, will make the acquisition through its Enron Capital and Trade Resources unit. Under the agreement, Enron will sell up to $130 million in stock to a specially created entity in which it will retain a 50 percent interest. It will also use borrowings to help pay for the deal.

title: The Opinion Game: We're All Players; Rush to Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLEN, BETTY
description: GALLEN-Betty, died peacefully at her home Friday, October 30, 1998. Beloved wife of Herbert for 61 years, loving mother of Joan Megibow and Nancy Scheriff, dear sister of Doris Konner, devoted grandmother to Terri and Andrew Megibow, Michael, Adam and Todd Runyon, Tracy and Megan Scheriff, adoring great-grandmother to Melissa and James Megibow, Jordan and Abigail Runyon.
